column2: Benjamin Disraeli, Earl of Beaconsfield," a biography by Cecil Roth, will be published by Philosophical Library on Aug. 22. The story considers the cultural background that shaped the man -- the nature of Disraeli's heritage in molding his career and policies. The author is a British biographer and historian.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Greater freedom to purchase raw materials in dollar markets was granted today to British importers.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet continued yesterday his tour of city firehouses and visited nine engine companies, including three that have been recommended for elimination by consultants to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 5 (UP) -The Ivy League's eligibility committee ruled six weeks ago that fourteen members of Brown University's football team were ineligible for the 1952 season because they received unreported financial aid from outside the university, it was reported today.
An eighteen-hour attempt to settle a ten-week strike by 600 armored car drivers and guards failed yesterday after it appeared that settlement might be forthcoming.

With a 150 per cent increase in imports of Uruguayan wool tops, the Secretary of the Treasury can no longer ignore the demand of American wool combers to impose a countervailing duty justified by Uruguayan subsidies, according to Ames Stevens, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Jack Reilly, co-manager of Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, yesterday requested Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, to reverse the decision against Graham in Monday night's fight with Joey Giardello of Philadelphia at the Eastern Parkway Arena.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Two explosions shattered the dye plant of Zinsser Co., chemical manufacturer, here today. One man was killed and another was injured in the explosions and three persons were injured in rescue work.

I read with great interest your editorial entitled "Criminal Insanity," published on July 30. Your comments on the case of Bayard P. Peakes are very much to the point with some exceptions which, I think, should be borne in mind.
More beef will be available for the consuming public in the months just ahead -- and the prices will be lower.

Mrs. Bella V. Dodd, attorney and former member of the national committee of the Communist party of the United States, was received back into the Roman Catholic Church last April 8, she announced yesterday.

Steeped in the lore of Viennese music, Robert Stolz, composer-conductor, has been approached by the Theatre Guild to write the tunes for a song-and-dance treatment of the Guild's justly celebrated "Reunion in Vienna."

MONCAY, Indo-China, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Communist China is moving tens of thousands of civilians into the interior of Kwangtung Province from the border of French-held areas in extreme northeastern Indo-China. Simultaneously, the Chinese have halted all traffic on the international river bridge from their city of Tonghing into Moncay.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech to the Veterans of Foreign Wars tonight follows:
HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 5 -- The disappearance in mid-Atlantic of 18-year-old Patsy Ann Partridge was declared a suicide today when the Holland-America liner Veendam docked here.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, Aug. 6 -- W. Stuart Symington of St. Louis, one-time Truman Administration trouble-shooter, captured the Democratic nomination for Senator early today in the Missouri primary by a sizable margin over President Truman's personal choice, J. E. (Buck) Taylor, the State Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Governor Driscoll of New Jersey has been asked to cooperate with the Department of Agriculture in a drive to clear up a serious epidemic among hogs.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Sir Jack Drummond, as scientific adviser to the Ministry of Food during the war, persuaded Britons that their wartime austerity diet was good for them. He had the faculty of putting across in simple words scientific data not easily understandable to the layman.

A reporter for this newspaper, Meyer Berger, found some stories this week in northern Saskatchewan. One had to do with the first uranium rush in history. One young prospector, John Oliver of Kirkland Lake, Ont., expressed what was probably current sentiment among white men, Indians, the eminent and the obscure, who are filing claims above the northern shore of Lake Athabaska.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The United Nations Commission on Free German Elections quietly abandoned today its six-months efforts to obtain the cooperation of the Soviet Control Commission in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -Northern Natural Gas Company, Omaha, Neb., asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to furnish natural gas as a raw material source for a proposed $25,000,000 fertilizer plant near La Platte, Neb.

ATLANTA, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Two men carrying a small fortune in $100 bills and tentatively identified as Cincinnati gambling figures were killed today when their light plane stalled and crashed in flames at the small Fulton County Airport near Atlanta.

PUSAN, Korea, Aug. 5 -- South Korea held its first Presidential election by popular ballot today in a quiet and orderly parade to the polls. President Syngman Rhee apparently was running up a vast plurality as this country's leader for another four years, but when the polls closed there were predictions that he might find himself faced with a political personality who could grow into a strong rival.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 5 -- Charles F. Horne, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, today called the roar of aircraft flying over residential sections "one of the gravest problems facing the aviation industry."
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -- About 100 hogs are in quarantine...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -Representative Patrick J. Hillings, Republican of California, accused Deputy Attorney General A. Devitt Vanech today of entering the United States Senate race in Connecticut as an "excuse" to get out of the Justice Department.

TEHERAN, Aug. 5 -- Fifty-four Deputies out of the eighty-two now in the Iranian Chamber of Deputies have signed a resolution demanding that the peasants of Iran, who are among the most unjustly treated in the world, receive a 15 per cent increase in their share of the crop.

London treated New York yesterday to a ride twice around the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Hundreds of local citizens -- fifty-six at a time -- climbed aboard the two decks of a red bus, whose No. 11 route usually ends at London's Liverpool Street, and went from Eighth to Ninth Avenue along Forty-first street, turned south to Fortieth Street, east back to Eighth Avenue and north to the starting point.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 5 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois will open his formal campaign for the Presidency in New York Aug. 27. His office announced today that he would address the national convention of the American Legion at Madison Square Garden that day in his first major speech in the East since winning the Democratic Presidential nomination in Chicago.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- Boston, Providence, R. I., and Hartford, Conn., appeared today to have borne the brunt of a series of severe electrical storms that visited drought-stricken New England. Although reports from various parts of the region were that forest fires had been somewhat retarded, the accompanying rain apparently did little more than lay the dust.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Aug. 5 (UP) -- The defending champion, Ross Collins, Arkansas A. M. athletic director, moved into the quarter-finals of the national left-handed golfers championship tournament today by scoring two victories on the Shawnee Country Club course.
ATLANTA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A deep South Negro Democrat and longtime leader of his people, A. T. Walden, urged support of the Democratic ticket today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A partial quarantine on the Chicago hog market today retarded trading and caused prices to fall 50 cents to $1.00 a hundred pounds.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,333, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified eighty-nine battle casualties in a new Korean war list. It included nineteen killed, sixty-three wounded and seven injured in accidents. No casualties were reported from New Jersey or Connecticut.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 5 --Two indictments against former Police Commissioner Harry B. Gourley and Detective John Colligan, which were returned in connection with the Passaic County Grand Jury's investigation into gambling here in 1949, were nolle prossed today by County Judge Louis V. Hinchliffe.

DEAL, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Janet Kern of Englewood scored 39, 40 -79 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's three-day Jersey Shore tournament at the Deal Golf Club.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 5 -- India will be represented at the forthcoming talks on the Kashmir dispute in Geneva by N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar, Minister of Defense, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today in the Upper House of the Indian Parliament.

Once again the New York Stock Exchange has reissued its popular booklet, "Investment Facts" -- of which 2,500,000 copies have been circulated since 1949 -- and once again it has created a picture of the ideal hypothetical stock. This is a composite of the 305 Stock Exchange issues that have paid dividends steadily twenty or more years, some as long as 105 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Ross L. Malone of Roswell, N. M., has been chosen as Deputy Attorney General to succeed A. Devitt Vanech. His appointment may be announced tomorrow by James P. McGranery, the Attorney General.

The third annual outdoor square dance in behalf of the Berkshire Industrial Farm in Canaan, N. Y., will be held next Friday night on the campus of the school. Committees have been formed in the Albany district, Columbia County, and throughout the Berkshires to assist the event.

It may seem a bit odd to refer to 4,200,000 tons of rice as one of the fundamental factors touching world peace and stability. The ordinary citizen has enough to worry about from day to day -- the Korean war and the Iron Curtain, unrest in Egypt and chaos in Iran, high taxes and Presidential politics -- without thinking too much about the deficit in the world's rice supply.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The Western Electric Company announced today the reorganization of its manufacturing division into eastern and western operating areas, effective Sept, 1, and the reassignment of several company officers and executives.

More than 600 state leaders of the Liberal party endorsed the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket last night at a meeting in the Statler Hotel. They also approved a resolution urging Averell Harriman, unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, to run as a candidate for the United States Senate in opposition to Senator Irving M. Ives, incumbent Republican.

Investment in all kinds of advertising reached a record of $6,496,500,000 in the United States in 1951. This was 14 per cent more than the amount spent the year before and the trend in expenditures is continuing upward in 1952 at a rate of about 9 per cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- A reactionary trend developed today in both grains and soybeans on the Board of Trade. Profit-taking by longs was heavy, with many taking advantage of the bullish crop figures contained in the Galvin Bennett August report on corn and oats to unload.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The new Wage Stabilization Board officially took over the nation's wage machinery today as Roger L. Putnam, Director of Economic Stabilization, lashed out anew at Congress for stripping the panel of its disputes authority.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 6 -- The United Nations and Communist staff officers yesterday completed revision of the draft armistice terms for the Korean war and adjourned after a forty-four-minute session, leaving the truce talks at a standstill for the first time this year and the roadside tent village of Panmunjom deserted except for patrolling guards.
The newest and largest mechanical banana-loading terminal in the world capable of handling 8,000 stems an hour, was previewed yesterday by officials of the United Fruit Company.

URANIUM CITY, Sask., Aug. 5 -- The second wave of prospectors expected to enter uranium mines claims in this wilderness tent city, north of the Fifty-ninth Parallel bogged down in heavy rain today. The uranium rush started at 8 o'clock yesterday, when the uranium fields in the Beaverlodge area around Lake Athabaska were thrown open for public claiming.

Two men kidnapped and brutally beat Mrs. Alice Assante, 18 years old, a bookkeeper for the French American Hat Company, at 2:10 P. M. yesterday as she was returning from a bank at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street to the company's office, 20 West Fifty-seventh Street.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP) -About 500 Mississippians, most of them States' rights Democrats, voted today in an informal convention to support Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Presidential race.

CAIRO, Aug. 5 -- The Egyptian Cabinet issued a decree tonight placing former King Farouk's property in state custody. Ahmed Khashaba, former Foreign Minister, and Hussein Fahmy, former Finance Minister, were appointed custodians.

New York Communist party school taught selected students from Southern colleges that the only true revolution called for "violent forceful action on the part of the oppressed class aimed at the ruling class," a witness testified yesterday at the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court.

The good ladies from the Big Blue River Valley who stormed into President Truman's Kansas City hotel to protest construction of a dam that would flood their homes were not cranks trying to block the march of progress. On the contrary, they were making a very serious point which deserves nation-wide attention -- a point which the President himself has perhaps insufficiently considered.

TOKYO, July 9 (By Airmail) -- A minimum house at minimum cost, the dream of many young American couples, was also the desire of the young Japanese architect, Makoto Masuzawa, when it came to building a home for himself, his wife and their 3-year-old son.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 -- Fourteen California Communist party leaders on trial in United States District Court for six months, were found guilty today of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

The parents of Eileen Fahey, 18 years old, who was shot dead in the office of the American Pyhsical Society at Columbia University on July 14 by Bayard P. Peakes, 29-year-old pseuo-physicist and former Air Force veteran, applied in Surrogate's Court yesterday for letters of administration on her estate.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 5 -- The racing fleet of the New York Yacht Club made the second squadron run of its annual cruise today, traveling twenty and a half miles from Block Island.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Benjamin C. Haviland, teacher-coach at Deerfield Academy, was killed late this morning when he fell from a window ledge and landed on his head on the steps of the main academy building in the center of the campus. Mr. Haviland was 44 years old.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 -- A modern Ambrose lightship to replace the one at the mouth of New York harbor since 1926 has been built and launched at the Coast Guard yard here.

A relief from the nervous chatter of quiz shows and the frantic heroics of mystery movies is to be found in two new programs that have turned up on the video dial. Both are soothing and tasteful musical offerings, which recognize that there is a place for a new form of television: restful television.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Railroad Retirement Board said today it could not pay any greater benefits without an increase in revenues, and the railroads agreed but said they could not afford to pay any more.

Demolition of the Third Avenue Elevated structure lies in the distant future, awaiting the Second Avenue Subway. Meanwhile surface traffic and pedestrians face unusual hazards, as pointed out by the Lexington-First Avenue Association. These will be somewhat alleviated with the widening of Third Avenue for a few blocks in the midtown area, but the cure will be far from complete.

The Seattle Municipal Light and Power System, Seattle, Washington, borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of revenue bonds maturing from 1970 to 1987 at an interest cost of 2.823 per cent. The bond issue was bought by Halsey, Stuart Co. at a bid of 97.809 for 2 3/4s.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- David L. Behncke was served today with notice to show cause why he should not be held in contempt of court for refusal to recognize order issued by Judge Walter C. Lindley of the United State Court of Appeals, removing him as president of the Air Line Pilots' Association, A. F. L.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bobby Cain gained his first victory since June 27 tonight as he pitched the St. Louis Browns to a 5-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Bobby Young drove in four of the Brown's runs with a pair of bases-loaded singles.
French-Canadian chefs in Adirondacks lumbers camps where he worked as a boy first interested him in cooking, Frank Cogan said yesterday in discussing what he cooks and how he feels about cooking.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- A subtle semi-itted look in well tailored suits is prophetic element in Jacques Heim's collection. Short, sleek, youthful jackets make no particular effort to cinch the waistline or hold the midriff. Buttoned tabs cross at the throat under a black Persian Peter Pan collar on a suit of brown shadow plaid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -"Serious irregularities" have been discovered in the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau, House investigators said today.
Contract talks between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., opened yesterday and the union asked for a wage package of "20 to 30 cents."

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 5 Senator Richard M. Nixon of California. Republican Vice Presidential nominee, will give the keynote speech at a special Republican state convention here Sept. 4 and 5 to nominate a candidate for the United States Senate to succeed the late Senator Brien MacMahon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman returned to Washington from his home in Independence this afternoon and said the Democrats would win the election in November.

A plea to Americans to help rehabilitate Japanese industry was made yesterday by Shige Kawata, president of the Nippon Steel Tube Company, at a luncheon in his honor at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Aug. 5 (AP) A group of Gold Coast farmers who contend that they produce 25,000 tons of cocoa annually have served notice that they will only sell their cocoa direct during the coming year.

A chic blonde wandered into the marble hall of the New York Public Library yesterday and approached the big, semi-circular counter marked "Inquiry Desk," which faces the Fifth Avenue entrance. In an embarrassed whisper she asked the librarian, "Where do they keep the books?"

WEST POINT, Aug. 5 -- Two companies of West Point third classmen (sophomores) marched through rugged, hilly country seven miles west of the United States Military Academy in the broiling sun this afternoon to meet a mock invader of North America.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 5 (UP) -- Mrs. Dorothy W. Bernie, 43 years old, the widow of the band leader, Ben Bernie, charged criminal libel today to Billy Rose, the New York producer.
Edith Cary, George Freydberg, Albert D. Levin, Robert Myles Jr., Chandler Robbins, in 60 Sutton Place South--Herbert Charles Co, agents.

A traffic directional project, designed to rid part of the crowded West Side pier route of unwanted travel, was put into effect yesterday at West Fifty-fifth Street and Twelfth Avenue. The new regulation will affect southbound waterfront travel as far as Forty-fourth Street.
GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ben White, the man who's won more Hambletonians than any other driver, confessed today he was stumped on the outcome of tomorrow's trotting classic.

_a_ four-story apartment house accommodating forty-eight families at 43-17 Bowne Street in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the estate of Hymen Harper to an investing client of the Advance Realty Company, co-broker with Samuel Halperin in the transaction.

An aeronautical-structures laboratory to act as a clearinghouse for research information on high-velocity aircraft and to train urgently needed technicians for industry will be established this fall at Columbia University's School of Engineering, Dean John R. Dunning announced yesterday.

Four hours and fifty-nine minutes after they squared off at the Polo Grounds before 43,373 spectators, the National League's largest after-dark crowd of the season, the Giants at 1:31 this morning were established as 7-6 victors in fifteen innings over the Dodgers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (UP) -- The Reds, playing their first game under Manager Rogers Hornsby, defeated the Cubs, 4 -- 0, tonight as left-hander Ken Raffensberger pitched his second consecutive shutout and his fourth of the season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The State Department has drafted a plan to provide for a system of appeals for persons denied passports to travel abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug: 5 -- Frank Costello, the gambler, made a second try today to escape prison pending his appeal to the Supreme Court. He filed a second petition with the clerk of the high court, asking to be allowed to continue on bail until his appeal is actually filed with the tribunal.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The King Ranch's Armagh galloped to a handy victory in the Black Toney Purse at Monmouth Park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Ellis G. Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, today was reported ready to submit his resignation to President Truman tomorrow. Mr. Arnall would not comment on the reports, but said he planned to talk to the President "about a lot of things."

The feasibility of the transfer of the transit police to the city Police Department was discussed yesterday at a conference between the commissioners of the Board of Transportation and top-ranking officials of the Police Department.
Two former bookmakers testified yesterday, at the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen, about alleged monthly payments of $1,000 and $500 for "police protection."

Deliberations of the 125-man wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., ended abruptly yesterday with the dockworkers voting to seek a pay increase of 50 cents an hour in wage review negotiations that will open tomorrow morning.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 5 -Temperatures were running just under fever heat at the Montauk Yacht Club today. For yesterday Russ McGrotty, one of the active angling members of the club, brought in the first giant tuna of the season, and topped the event by hooking and boating a second one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -The Screen Writers Guild today announced that it would strike against the Alliance of Television Film Producers and that S. W. G. writers and members of the Authors League of America would not work for producer members of the Alliance after 12:01 A. M. on Monday.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 5 -Only thirty-seven boats of a fleet of seventy-eight starters were able to make the finish line today in the second day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Race Week. A southerly wind that blew up to 25 and 30 miles an hour caused seven craft to capsize, disabled numerous others and snapped the mast of one of the Star boats.
LIMA, Peru, Aug 5 (UP) -- President Manuel Odria swore in a new Cabinet today to succeed the one that resigned Saturday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 5 -- Areas throughout the world where threats of Soviet aggression are present were placed under the microscope today by the foreign policy heads of the three Englishspeaking nations in the Pacific preliminary to the drafting of common defense measures to cope with such situations.
Attendance at the thirty-fourth annual convention of the American Legion, opening in New York Aug. 24, will exceed 115,000, Legion officials estimated yesterday.

Despite widespread interest in the new cotton tweeds, the camel's hair colored flannels, the homespun tweeds and the new synthetic fabric blends, velvet remains a perennial favorite in the schoolgirl's wardrobe. This was indicated in the back-to-school fashion show held at Russeks yesterday afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- The life story of Joe Louis, former world heavyweight champion, will be brought to the screen next year by Federated Films, an independent producing company now in the process of formation. Louis made the announcement today in Chicago, where he began his climb to fistic fame eighteen years ago last July 4 by scoring a quick knockout victory in his first professional fight against Jack Kracken.

VANCOUVER, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) -- A record-breaking 115,788,073 bushels of grain were shipped from British Colombia ports in the 1951-52 crop year. More than half of it went to Great Britain, Japan and India.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The rally in the stock markets that began after the economic debate last week continued when the stock exchange reopened today after the August bank holiday. Sentiment was further assisted by a favorable interpretation of the gold and dollar reserve figure announced on Saturday.

The twelve-family apartment house on a plot 42 by 100 feet at 707 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Bernard Goldshore from Sam Marfeld. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The Asian-Arab bloc moved again today to try to force a United Nations debate on the trouble in Tunisia between the country's nationalists and the French administrators.

MADRID, Aug. 5 -- The Spanish Government's investment policy of financing its own industry is retarding and hampering the development of free enterprise the Banco Urquijo, which is one of the largest financial institutions in Spain, said in an economic report made available today.

The Board of Transportation's efficiency in operating municipal bus and subway lines was vigorously defended yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as he caustically suggested that criticisms made on Monday by Rudolph Halley, President of the Council, should be submitted in writing.

A British geographer who is one of the world's leading authorities on the utilization of land suggested here yesterday that the United States might be one of the world's most underdeveloped countries. Our foreign aid funds might well be spent in the Mississippi Valley rather than in the Amazon, he said.

LURS, France, Aug. 5 -- Sir Jack Drummond, 61, Britain's noted World War II food planner, his pretty brunette wife and their 11-year-old daughter were brutally slain early today in the foothills of the French Alps where they were vacationing.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Fred M. Alger Jr. took the lead in returns early today in Michigan's Republican primary election for the right to oppose the Democratic incumbent, G. Mennen Williams, for Governor in November.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Under the impetus of the expanded program of the Technical Assistance Administration, more than 2,500 fellowships and scholarships have been awarded this year by the United Nations and its affiliated agencies, according to a survey released today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Zygmunt Fabisiak, the Polish Consul General in Chicago, announced today that he had resigned rather than obey orders to return to Poland and had asked the United States for asylum.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Brady resolved two contests on nominating petitions in favor of the regular Republican organization candidates yesterday when he ruled against Richard Neville and William J. Bianchi, insurgents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Truman led a distinguished group of Government officials and others at the Washington opening of a new production of "Porgy and Bess" at the National Theatre tonight. The President went backstage and shook hands with members of the cast at the conclusion of the performance.

Contrary to the general downward trend of the textile industry, M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., turned in substantially large sales for the three-month and six-month periods ended on June 30 over the corresponding periods of a year ago, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

Asserting that the State Education Commissioner was trying to saddle the city with $120,000 more in taxes to support upstate schools, Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, charged yesterday that the administration was doing nothing to protect the city's interests.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Communist MIG-15 jets swept southward almost to the Thirty-eighth Parallel in Korea yesterday and United States Sabre jets blasted four of them out of the skies in five clashes. Six other swept-wing Red jets were damaged, one by a comparatively slow United States F-84 Thunderjet, the Fifth Air Force reported.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Wayne Ryan, backed by Gov. Edward F. Arn, held to a narrow lead tonight over the incumbent, Fred Hall, in the Republican lieutenant governorship race as returns rolled in from the Kansas primary election.
DENVER, Aug. 5 (AP) -- United States District Judge William Lee Knous today approved the sale of rails and other equipment of Colorado's historic "Galloping Goose" line -- the Rio Grande Southern.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., said yesterday its organizational drive in nonunion shops would be spurred instead of halted by an anti-trust suit filed Monday by forty nonunion manufacturers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- It is true what they say about Bobby Shantz. If the undersized southpaw of the Athletics is not a king-sized pitcher -- the best in all baseball -- better not say that to any of the 35,673 fans who saw Bobby beat the Red Sox, 5 -- 3, at Shibe Park tonight and become the first major league hurler to score twenty victories.

Seven hundred miles is a long way to come to see a Broadway show. And seven hundred miles is a long way to come to school. But the forty students who are here this week for both reasons came neither for entertainment nor book learning.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- Five under par for two rounds, Tommy Goodwill of Westchester County and the Bahamas, led the qualifiers in the Metropolitan district's trials for the United States amateur golf championship today with a 36-hole score of 137.

Today's new film is "Affairs of a Model," a Swedish-made romantic drama, featuring Alf Kjellin, Maj-Britt Nilsson, Marianne Lofgren and Stig Jarrel, at the Rialto. Gustaf Molander directed from a screen play by Rune Lindstrom. The Swedish Film Productions offering is being released by Union Film Distributors.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- San Francisco Bay ports set a peacetime record for foreign trade last year, the Board of State Harbor Commissioners announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The British Government is putting the finishing touches on a new proposal to set up a planning body for a Middle East command. Within the next few days the plan will be referred to the United States, France, Turkey, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand.

TORONTO, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Union put up a token fight today as the discord-ridden Red Cross conference approved the revised statutes of the International Committee of the Red Cross by a vote of 70 to 17.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Premier Antoine Pinay is having some interruptions of his holiday cure in Aix-les-Bains. In addition to the visits of officials reporting on negotiations with the United States on offshore contracts, with the Bey of Tunis on the proposed
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Del Rice's long fly with the bases loaded in the twelfth inning scored Solly Hemus to give the sizzling Cardinals a 4 to 3 victory over the Pirates.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Sam Mele and Jim Rivera hit home runs tonight as Saul Rogovin won his tenth game of the year, 6 to 3, over the Indians to give the White Sox a split of a twilight-night double-header before 40,909 fans.

There is a bear clad in forester's hat and blue jeans that merits particular attention these days. His name is Smokey and he looks solemnly down from placards in the subways and elsewhere against the background of a raging forest fire.

READING, Pa., Aug. 5 -- Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, made his annual inspection of the 107th fighter unit of the New York Air National Guard at General Spaatz field here today. A dress parade was held by the 1,700 officers and men of the unit.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower set forth tonight a ten-point program for Americans that, he said, would "win a just and lasting peace" and build at home "a prosperity not based on war."

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 5 -Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Mrs. Harry Nevil Jr. of Hudson River, who tied for qualifying honors yesterday, both advanced to the second round of the Westchester and Fairfield golf championship lat the Woodway Country Club course today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 5 -- A delegation of seven Danish officers from all three service branches, the defense staff and the Defense Ministry left by plane for France today where they will confer on the technical aspects of building up Danish airfields to the standards of Supreme Allied Headquarters.

David S. Meister, through his 1022 Sixth Avenue Corporation, has resold the five-story building at 1020-1022 Avenue of the Americas to clients of Harry Goidel, attorney. The property, on a plot 46.8 feet at the northeast cornerI of Thirty-eighth Street, contains seven stores on the ground floor.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Rene Pleven, the French Minister of Defense, indicated today that the French would seek at the next meeting of the North Atlantic Council a way to finance defense construction on a long-term basis instead of year by year. He said that the present

The drastic cuts in both defense and mutual security funds voted by Congress despite warnings from our top-ranking leaders, including President Truman and General Eisenhower, have now produced their inevitable results. As predicted, they have caused serious difficulties in both our own rearmament program and that of our allies, leading to an all-around stretch-out which delays the attainment of our own defense goals and those of NATO.

Sugar prices jogged downward again yesterday. A 10,000-ton cargo of Cubas sold here on a 5.95-cents-a-pound basis for clearance tomorrow, down 5 points from the last spot price, and the futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange followed the trend.

In a news dispatch dated July 28, Camille M. Cianfarra, the special correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Madrid, outlined some of the difficulties in the present Spanish-United States negotiations for air and naval bases. The present writer has had no detailed connection with the purely military aspects of the United States-Spanish relations, but has some firsthand knowledge of the economic aspects.

HONG KONG, Aug. 5 -- Unemployed workers, intellectuals, former Nationalist military men and vagrants are scheduled to be registered in Communist China and assigned to jobs through a network of labor placement committees to help achieve "centralized allocation of the labor force" under a policy of "full employment."

The extensive drought which is now afflicting a large portion of the eastern half of the United States, varying reports on "flying saucer," as well as rainmakers in the West, together with the proposed rain-making which is to be undertaken in near-by Connecticut, might give us pause for a small amount of meditation on the possibility that our sins, mostly against Nature, may have overtaken us.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Luck, which was eluding Casey Stengel so persistently recently in the West, rode with the Ol' Perfessor for the second successive night tonight when his Yankees outslickered Bucky Harris' Senators, 3 to 2, in a game that had to be called at the end of seven innings because of rain.
Two security issues of the Pennsylvania Electric Company are scheduled for reoffering after being awarded to banking groups yesterday.

Many "fair-trading" manufacturers face loss of business if they fail to recognize that retailers' increasing expenses are frequently not compensated for by producer-fixed margins, according to a warning in the current bulletin of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The building with thirty-six apartments and six stores at 874 East 167th Street, at Intervale Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Boden Holding Corporation to the Estates Security Company. The property is assessed at $115,000. Seeger Co. were the brokers.

The stock market faltered again yesterday but losses were limited. The session followed closely the pattern set on Monday with prices easing after a steady opening, then going to a better level in the final hour. This left the price structure again in neutral territory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) -- Vice Admiral William M. Callaghan reported today that the Military Sea Transportation Service had hauled more than 34,000,000 tons of cargo to the Far East since the start of the Korean war.
The people of the drought areas in New England and the South looked skyward for a sign of rain yesterday without avail, The Associated Press reported.

Billy O'Connell, an 11-year-old redhead who thinks summer in New York is "not so hot because it's just too hot" got an official invitation from the state of Maine yesterday to come and cool off for a week on its rockbound coast -- and bring his whole family, all expenses paid.

ROME, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- The whole Italian railroad network was tied up last midnight by a twenty-four-hour strike declared by the Communist - dominated railroad workers union. Coming as it did, at the height of the holiday and tourist season, the strike caused great annoyance to hundreds of thousands of Italian and foreign travelers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Civilian employment in the Executive Branch of the Federal Government increased by 112,999 in the fiscal year 1952, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures reported today. The total at the end of the year, June 30, was 2,596,690.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- On the basis of two famous political beliefs the events of this second week after the adjournment of the Democratic National Convention are very encouraging to supporters of Governor Stevenson for President and Senator Sparkman for Vice President.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Two Californians and one player from Virginia today entered the semi-final round of the Eastern grass court junior girls' tennis championships. Heavy rains interrupted the remainder of the program at the Nassau Country Club.

In its edition of July 27 THE NEW YORK TIMES, reporting on King Farouk's abdication, carried a dispatch from Reuters News Agency that since 1939 six other kings, among them King Peter II of Yugoslavia, had abdicated their thrones.

MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Bob McMillen of Occidental College, who gave the United States a surprise second place in the Olympic 1,500-meter run, won that event today in a post-Olympic track and field meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 30:
TOKYO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Far East Air Forces disclosed today that B-29 Superforts, bombing by radar last night, had blasted the Communists' biggest gold mine in North Korea.
LENOX Mass., Aug. 6 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, which made its first European trip last spring, will make its first transcontinental tour next spring.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 -- The contract bridge team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee, all of New York, with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, was declared winner of the Masters Team of Four Championship in a sixty-four-board final match here early this morning.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- The twenty - seventh Hambletonian, scheduled for Good Time Park today was postponed until tomorrow because of rain. It was the second straight year that the famed harness racing classic for 3-year-old trotters was balked by the weather.

I Edgewater, N. J., sold yesterday $1,267.000 of sewer bonds due from 1953 to 1982 to Boland Saffin 1 o . ' r C. and assocmtcs at a bid ofi 100.535 for 2N;s, The bonds were/ reoffered at prices to yield 1.10 to[ ,2.55 per cent.

The radio stations and newspapers of four cities in upstate New York and Canada have signed an agreement whereby in time of attack their complete plants and all their personnel will automatically become part of the civil defense organization of Niagara Falls, N. Y.

Four members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L. -- one of them a union vice president -- were arrested yesterday while demonstrating in the organizing drive among nonunion cloak and suit manufacturers.

It was indeed with pleasure, initially, that I read your brief editorial "Prisons in the Sun" in your July 28 issue. Certainly a public concern for the 180,000 inmates of federal and state prisons is to be encouraged, for they are public charges -- to be made worse criminals or better citizens, as the public and their representatives choose.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Great Lakes iron ore carriers have hit their stride again after the crippling steel strike, the Lake Carriers Association said today.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Eight men were killed and an undetermined number wounded in an accident aboard the United States carrier Boxer, the Navy reported early today.

The market in vegetable oils on the New York Produce Exchange was active yesterday as traders attempted to appraise the effects of the drought and possible Government moves to control prices. The general picture was confused, but cottonseed oil rose 14 to 20 points on 368 lots and soybean oil advanced 10 to 15 points on twenty-five lots.

TORONTO, Aug. 6 -- Over Soviet opposition, a compromise resolution for an impartial investigation of Communist charges of germ warfare against the United States was adopted today at the International Red Cross Conference. The vote was 69 to 12.
OXFORD, England, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- A world conference of the Quaker Society of Friends, which ended here today, issued an appeal for peace in Korea through India's good offices.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- It began to be obvious to London observers this week that the ambitious plans made in Lisbon last February for increasing Western Europe's military strength this year could not be fulfilled and were quietly being revised by the action of individual countries in the North Atlantic alliance.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 6 -- Striking warehousemen resumed their picket lines today outside the Army-leased Claremont Terminal after a two-day truce. The strikers, who comprise a segment of Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., voted last night to resume the strike after a three-and-a-half-hour conference with international union officials yesterday in New York failed to settle any grievances.

Details of plans to realign production facilities in the big carpet manufacturing plant of Alexander Smith, Inc., at Yonkers, were announced by the company yesterday after two years of development of a broad program to strengthen its operations.

Formal wage review negotiations between employers and the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., will open today, with the union seeking a 24 per cent hourly wage increase. The meeting will be held at 11 A. M. in the offices of the New York Shipping Association, which represents the majority of the stevedoring concerns on the North Atlantic Coast, at 80 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles Brannan said today that the Department of Agriculture has "not taken under consideration" the question of lifting the embargo on Canadian livestock.

MANILA, Aug. 6 -- Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay sent more troops and armor into Jolo Island yesterday and flew there from Manila himself to look into new phases of the Government's campaign against the Moro outlaws.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 6 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, Europe, conferred for several hours today with Gen. Lauris Norstad, his Air Commander for Central Europe, and with United States Army Secretary, Frank Pace Jr., reviewing the United States Army's new responsibility as the "executive agent" for the three American armed services in Europe.

CAIRO, April 6 (UP) -- Informed sources said today that Farouk stood little if any chance of reclaiming any sizable amount of the fabulous wealth he left behind when he sailed into exile with former Queen Narriman and their infant son, Egypt's new King, Fuad II.
DENVER, Aug. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he was going to keep the Democrats guessing about a month regarding his campaign itinerary.

The New York State Building Service Minimum Wage Board, established last April by State Industrial Commissioner Edward F. Corsi to draft recommendations for the industry's 200,000 workers in the state, held its fourth and final hearings here yesterday.

Two armed bandits used a "honk-when-you're-ready" method at noon yesterday to steal a $5,000 payroll from the Carlin Brothers Corporation, makers of women's handbag's, at 345 Eldert Street, Brooklyn. The men entered the ground-floor offices at 11:30 A. M., told the receptionist they were "frame salesmen" and were shown into an inner room, where Max Carlin, one of the owners, and a dozen women employes were at work.
DUBLIN, Aug. 6 -- France won the second international jumping competition at the Dublin Horse Show today.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Aug. 6 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield of Columbus, Ohio, the Olympic champion, won the 800-meter race in 1:48 in a post-Olympic track and field meet tonight. Whitfield's time was the best in the world this year.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The automobile industry has made heavy commitments for steel that will cost it considerably more than the additional $5.20 a ton authorized in the settlement of the recent steel strike.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads (A. A. R.) today estimated the net income of Class I carriers during June at $49,000,000, compared with $52,000,000 in the 1951 month.

An investigation by the Department of Justice into alleged cartel arrangements by international oil companies is scheduled to get under way in Washington on Sept. 3. Several oil companies here were served yesterday with subpoenas returnable on that date before a grand jury in the criminal division of a United States District Court in Washington.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Bill Kings' Sweet Sioux won today's Star Class race in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual regatta being held off Timber Point. Sweet Sioux defeated Charley Dominy's Independence by a half boat length.
James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, has been dropped as a participant in a weekly television symposium, "Starring the Editors," he said yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 6 -- Pakistan will receive approximately $14,000,000 in United States aid for the 1952 fiscal year. India is slated for $45,000,000.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- The Communists made new charges today of violations on the neutral zone around Panmunjom, where the conferences for an armistice in Korea are in abeyance until next week, and asserted that the Americans had declined to make proper investigation of the incidents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A year will be required to offset the effects of the fifty-five-day steel strike on the defense production program, Dr. John R. Steelman, acting head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, has advised President Truman in a monthly report, parts of which were kept secret.

SARATOGA, SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, horse trainer, polo player and one-time ace of the over-the-jumps riders, said this morning that he expected Ogden Phipps' Great Captain to go well in today's top race at the Saratoga Association's old horse park.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- In an apostolic constitution decreed today, Pope Pius XII brought up to date and strengthened the institutions that the Roman Catholic Church has established in the last fifty years for the spiritual care of emigrants.

What is described as a new and highly accurate method of using atomic energy to detect and measure impurities in foods, pharmaceuticals, metals and other materials has been developed by scientists of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation at the Oak Ridge, Tenn., National Laboratory.

Peck Peck deserves a rousing cheer for its fresh approach to college fashions. Far from following the routine formula of middy silhouettes and blond tones, its presentation yesterday at the concern's general offices. 260 Fourth Avenue, was enlivened with such attractive ideas as plaid polo coats and tweed shoes.

The National Wage Stabilization Board in Washington approved yesterday an increased ceiling of 45 per cent in commission rates for drivers of 4,978 fleet-owned taxicabs here. The present ceiling is 44 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Danny Thomas will be making "The Singing Fool" for Warner Brothers about this time next summer, according to Michael Curtiz, who is directing Mr. Thomas in the studio's new Technicolor version of "The Jazz Singer."
A 19-year-old youth stabbed a husband and wife when they refused to let him see their daughter and then killed two men who tried to block his escape in the Bronx early yesterday morning.

William G. Christy, director of the city's Smoke Control Bureau, announced yesterday that its marine division would soon increase its activity in curbing smoke violations on the waterfront and in New York harbor. A patrol launch previously lent by the Department of Marine and Aviation only one day a week will be made available to the bureau more often, Mr. Christy said.

GREENWICH, Conn, Aug 6 -- Rene Coudert, representing Indian Harbor Yacht Club, held a 2 1/2-point lead over Gale Lorenzen of Stamford Y. C., after the fourth event in the Law Cup series in Luder -- 16S was completed today off Indian Harbor.

Ensign Theresa McLaughlin, a 22-year-old Navy nurse from Burlington, Mass., served yesterday as the "victim" for four of her sister nurses, who learned how to propel her to shore aboard a stretcher in the pool of the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens.

A former Communist testified yesterday that at a training school here where he was sent to become "a professional revolutionary" four of the fifteen defendants at the Communist conspiracy trial were teachers.
Earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for the first half of 1952, estimated at $84,000,000, were the highest for any similar period in the history of the company.

Development of a fiber with special properties that might meet a number of important industrial and defense needs was announced by the Carborundum Company at a special showing yesterday in Niagara Falls.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 6 -- A proposal for a 2 per cent tax on all land and real estate -- expected to yield 10,000,000,000 rials ($330,000,000 at the official rate of exchange) to the Iranian treasury -- was understood to have been presented to the Cabinet tonight by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

Wartime dispatches from England seldom mentioned Sir Jack Drummond, the British nutrition expert who was killed Tuesday in France. A check of our files showed only four news stories that named the man who was scientific adviser to Lord Woolton's Ministry of Food from 1940 to 1946.

Plans are already under way for the annual luncheon of the American Women's Voluntary Service, Inc., to be held on Oct. 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, honorary president of the organization, and Mrs. Robert L. Gerry Jr., a new member of the board of directors, will be co-chairmen of the luncheon. Mrs. C. Ruxton Love is national president of the association.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 6 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, predicted today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois would be elected President in November by "one of the largest majorities any man ever had."

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 6 -- The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offering of $40,000,000 of first mortgage pipeline bonds due in 1972. it was announced today by Gardiner Symonds, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Security Agency today announced thirty-four grants totaling $523,993 to aid cancer control studies and demonstrations in sixteen states, the District of Columbia and Israel.

A flood of orders both for nearby and fourth-quarter delivery has forced many cotton textile manufacturers to withdraw from the market temporarily, it was learned yesterday. The major activity has been in sheets and pillowcases, Worth Street houses reported, but substantial business was written early in the week for unfinished print cloths.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 6 -- Octavio (One Punch) Rubert, the Houston Buffs' unpredictable Cuban hurler, lost a unanimous one-round decision to the dugout water cooler (metal) and was lost to the Texas League baseball season today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Cleveland's Early Wynn today registered his thirteenth victory of the season as the Indians downed the White Sox, 7 -- 1, in the rubber contest of a three-game series before 10,502.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- Pravda and Izvestia today conceded that the fifteenth Olympic Games had ended in a dead heat between Russia and the United States instead of in a Soviet victory in the unofficial team point scoring, as earlier accounts had reported.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Gabe Paul, general manager of the Reds, said tonight that Outfielder Wally Westlake had been sold to the Indians for cash and two players yet to be named. The amount of cash was not disclosed.
PARIS, Aug. 6 -- Balenciaga introduces a semi-fitted silhouette to jackets and slender street frocks and continues the middy as well as hip cuffs and sashes indicating a mock low waistline.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Apparently they haven't yet run out of miraculous achievements under the lee of Coogan's Bluff, and while it isn't at all certain whether they will have one this fall to match last October's proportions, they have a pretty fair-sized one coming up.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 6 -- Howard A. Kaiser's 45-foot sloop Matinee from Stamford, Conn., won Division I honors in the American Yacht Club's annual cruise, a five-day sail, which ended today without a race.

The Board of Transportation dismissed yesterday Michael Murphy, 46 years old, a B. M. T. motorman whose Culver line train rolled back and struck a Fourth Avenue train under Nassau and Fulton Streets in the evening rush hour on July 16, causing injuries to a hundred passengers and damage to twelve cars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Reports came from responsible quarters at the Capitol today that threats had been made against Senator John J. Williams, the Delaware Republican whose one-man investigations into alleged income tax irregularities and favoritism to racketeers and others have started or augmented Congressional inquiries into Internal Revenue Bureau scandals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, declared today that the loyalty pledge for which he fought so hard at the Democratic National Convention should be enforced by party rules rather than Federal law.
Plans for increased sales and promotion of home sewing machines built around imported German "heads" were announced yesterday by representatives of the Pfaff Sewing Machine Corporation.

The forty-four-hour week for the 55,000 city employes now working longer hours will become effective Oct. 1, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday. The change, which originally was scheduled to become effective "by Jan. 1, 1953" will affect policemen, firemen, sanitation workers and other employes now working up to forty-eight hours a week.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Between thundershowers that delayed play for an hour, the second round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield's twenty-seventh annual golf championship was completed over the Woodway Country Club course today.

The difficult bridge between the Spanish and the Portuguese in Latin America has been successfully crossed by the publishers of the news magazine Vision with the launching in Rio de Janeiro this week of a Portuguese counterpart called Visao.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Larry S. MacPhail's General Staff kept his unbeaten Monmouth Park record intact as he splashed to an easy victory at 6 -- 5 in today's renewal of the $15,000 Salvator Mile. He scored by three lengths, with the favored Senator Joe quitting suddenly in the stretch and just outlasting the fast-charging Joey Boy.

The nation's gasoline stocks dropped 2,042,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend supplies amounted to 116,243,000 barrels, compared with 118,285,000 a week earlier and 129,027,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 114,310 today, an increase of 642 since last week.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- United States Sabre jets shot down six MIG's yesterday in the third straight day of aerial combat, the Fifth Air Force announced today.

Sales of the Borden Company for the first six months this year increased about 7 per cent to $374,495,075 from $354,026,887 in the 1951 period, but earnings declined about 15 per cent, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A suggestion that if food prices got out of hand a special session of Congress might be necessary to strengthen the economic controls law was advanced to President Truman today by Ellis Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 6 -- The South Carolina State Democratic Convention decided overwhelmingly today to support the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois. But it also told party members they could vote Republican without losing party standing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Department stripped a fast-driving chauffeur for the Saudi Arabian Embassy of his diplomatic immunity today and left him to the mercy of traffic officers.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Turk Lown replaced Paul Minner after two runs had scored in the first inning and went on to pitch the Cubs to a 5-to-3 victory over the Reds today.

The stock market snapped out of the rut of the preceding two sessions yesterday and, although trading proceeded on a highly selective basis, prices made some substantial gains. Despite the rise of 0.28 point in the composite rate, in terms of THE NEW YORK TIMES index, trading was spotty.

Rudolph Halley as President of the City Council and a member of the Board of Estimate is enlivening the summer scene with some critical comments on city policy as to its transit system. Nowhere has Mr. Halley spoken a truer word than when he says, of the transit problem, that "what is necessary is leadership."

Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan will congratulate at 10:15 A. M. today the police who cleared up three major cases over the last week-end. The officials will meet the honor men at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Navy recommended today that the Office of Defense Mobilization cease giving preference in the award of Government ship contracts to New York and other "distress areas" of high unemployment.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 6 -- National political interest will center on this state tomorrow when Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, at 83, one of the most colorful and powerful legislative figures on the Washington scene, requests the voters in a Democratic primary to renominate him for a seventh successive Senatorial term.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today the naming of a New York-to-Los Angeles skyway for the late Will Rogers. The route, forty miles wide and 2,500 miles long, crosses his home state of Oklahoma, and his hometown, Claremore.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The Grant Park Symphony Orchestra rehearsal in the park bandshell was disrupted today when a gunman fired a volley of shots at a couple seated in the grass, killing the girl and wounding her companion, and then ended his own life.

A weary band of ball players waged an unsuccessful battle against the elements yesterday trying to renew the Giant-Dodger interborough rivalry at the Polo Grounds after the 4-hour-59-minute battle the Giants had won in fifteen innings the previous night.
With polio cases reaching a high level in various parts of the country, an appeal was issued here yesterday for trained nurses and physical therapists to help fight the illness.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals took both games of a twi-night double-header from the Pirates tonight, exploding for five runs in the tenth inning to win the opener, 7 -- 2, and then edging the cellar dwellers, 3 -- 2, in the second.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Government's systematic drive to cripple the American Communist movement by jailing its top leaders has resulted in thirty-one convictions, with thirty-four other Red leaders still awaiting final court action.

Formation of a trading concern to operate between Mexico, Japan and the United States was announced yesterday by Harold L. Bache, senior partner of Bache Co. It is to be known as Dai Ichi Mexicana, S. A., will use the trade name of "Daimex" and will be represented in Japan by Dai Ichi Bussan Kaisha, Ltd., a leading Japanese trading company in which Bache Co. have a substantial interest.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- An assault on the West German Government's attempts to solve the Saar question and an indictment of the Schuman plan for a coal-steel merger as a "supercartel" marked the return tonight of Dr. Kurt Schumacher, chief of the Social Democratic party, to active political debate.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Nine Hungarian Olympic athletes have refused to return to their Communist-ruled homeland and have taken refuge in Western legations at Helsinki, Finland, the Stockholm newspaper Dagens Nyheter reported tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 -- Specialists in rabies treatment are experimenting with a new serum that may make it possible to reduce the number of painful vaccine injections now administered to persons believed to be infected.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- General buying interest developed in grains as a result of the stress placed upon the crop damage in Southern and Southeastern states and prices were sharply higher. Washington talked of adding to states in the disaster area and of the relief necessary and thus public interest in the markets was aroused.

Felix Bocchicchio, manager of Jersey Joe Walcott, apparently has ruled out New York City as the site of the heavyweight champion's defense against Rocky Marciano tentatively scheduled for mid-September.
Plans for two major low-rent apartment projects in the New York City Housing Authority's long-range program were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

HONOLULU, Aug. 6 -- The foreign policy heads of Australia, New Zealand and the United States ended tonight a three-day organizational meeting of the Pacific Council by establishing a pattern for mutual defense against aggression in the Pacific.

Ever have a bolt of lightning seek you out? A scary thing it is, William J. Kennedy, chief meteorologist of the United States Weather Observatory atop Bear Mountain, testified yesterday. A bolt too heavy for the lightning rods hit the peak of the observatory's tower at 8:30 A. M., jumped into the room where Mr. Kennedy was reading instruments and grounded in his teletype, telephone and recording instruments.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 6 -- Lower taxation and higher social service benefits are features of the "incentive" budget introduced by Sir Arthur Fadden, the Australian Federal Treasurer, in the House of Representatives tonight.
Irving Maidman, real estate operator and investor, has sold the Harris Theatre property at 226 West Forty-second Street and 223-229 West Forty-first Street which he acquired about a year ago.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, could not go. Neither could Dr. Grayson Kirk, acting head of the university in the general's absence. For a while in April it looked as though the university would not be represented on the summer training cruise of the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps, which weighs anchor this Sunday.

TOPEKA, Karl., Aug. 6 -- Lieut. Gov. Fred Hall, 36-year-old Dodge City lawyer won a hot Republican primary battle yesterday for nomination to a second term but his victory left Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's home state in a political tizzy today.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- Maimed and crippled survivors of the world's first atomic bomb explosion marked the seventh anniversary of the historic blast today by leveling protests against the United States for treating them as guinea pigs instead of helping to heal them.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 6 -- To supply some of the elements frequently missing in college education the University of Illinois is inaugurating this fall a curriculum in "Family and Community Life." Open to both men and women, it will be offered as a "minor" in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

Doremus Co., financial advertising concern, circulated in Wall Street yesterday an analysis it has made of the recent Brookings Institution national census of shareholders, treating it as a marketing study.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 6 -- President Truman and the big city political bosses in Missouri took a walloping in the state's bitter Democratic primary from an apparently rising tide of independent voters.

The time has come again for the college girl to select her back-to-school wardrobe. Throughout this month fashion shows are being presented in which the college girl will find clothes for every occasion on every type of campus. The teen-age and career girl also benefits, in many cases finding something that will be just right for her particular wardrobe.

JULIUS CAESAR suffered from epilepsy. So, it seems, did Alexander the Great, Peter the Great and Alfred the Great. So did Byron, Mohammed, Maupassant and Flaubert. So did Dostoevsky, Pascal, Paganini and certain relatives of Queen Victoria. Epilepsy is no respecter of thrones, titles -- or ideal marital happiness. Just what happens when the disease strikes in an average home is the subject of Virginia Evans' unusual and absorbing novel, "The Lovely Season."*

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Members of the London and provincial stock exchanges are being asked to approve an increase in stock brokers' commissions to meet the rising cost of transactions, John B. Braithwaite, chairman of the Council of the London Stock Exchange announced today.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- The Yankees' four-game winning streak came to grief early this morning as Bucky Harris' Senators turned on their arch tormentors and flattened out the Bombers, 6 to 4, in a battle that, delayed twenty minutes at the start by rain and interrupted forty-three minutes in the fourth, dragged past midnight.
Nixon A. Brewer has been appointed general manager of the Allegheny - Industrial Electrical Company, Pittsburgh.

The Canadian dollar soared to a new peak in terms of its American counterpart yesterday, rising to a premium of 4 7/32 cents, highest since mid-November, 1933. The market opened strong, at a premium of around 4 to 4 1/6-cents and quickly climbed to its new high which was reached at midday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged seven New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles concerns today with concealing the fact that the "heads" of sewing machines they assemble and distribute were made in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, has accepted an invitation from President Truman to attend a Cabinet luncheon meeting at the White House Tuesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Truman has been asked to designate Kentucky and Tennessee as disaster areas because of drought. He is expected to issue a proclamation to that effect tomorrow. This action would be taken at the request of the Governors of those states and upon recommendation of the Department of Agriculture.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- The maintenance of Saranac Lake at its present level for the remainder of the summer season appeared likely today after a public hearing by the State Public Works Department for boat and camp owners in the vicinity.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Aug. 6 (UP) -- Frank Costello, the gambler, testified for one hour today before the special blue ribbon grand jury investigating gambling and corruption in Saratoga County only two days before he was scheduled to go to prison.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HONG KONG, Aug. 6 -- "Labor hero" Li Yung Lu, whose famous locomotive, Number 1913 once held three iron horse records in China, has come a cropper. Communist China's Casey Jones and Hsi Neng An, chief of the locomotive engineering section in the Peiping office of the Tientsin railway administration, have been expelled from the Chinese Communist party.

LURS, France, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The French Press Agency tonight said police had picked up a suspect in the triple murder of a British diet expert, Sir Jack Drummond, his wife and their 11-year-old child, Elizabeth.

Because of the loss of passengers and of operating revenue, the Long Island Rail Road has petitioned the Public Service Commission to permit it to discontinue a shuttle service from the Country Life Press station in Garden City to Mitchel Field, it was brought out in testimony yesterday at a hearing in the commission's offices at 233 Broadway.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 6 -- Passengers aboard the Israeli ship Negbah en route to the Hazamir World Assembly of Jewish Choirs have "rioted" in protest against overcrowding in stuffy dormitories, the ship's purser reported on arrival in Haifa yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 6 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin today nominated three justices of the Puerto Rican Supreme Court. He sent to the Insular Senate for confirmation the names of Jaime Sifre, Benjamin Ortiz and Pedro Perez Pimentel.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Rain, inexperience and skilled opponents combined to make today a miserable day for a group of West Point cadets out in the field defending the Bear Mountain area from an "invader."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States and Bolivia will resume talks tomorrow on a contract for United States purchase of Bolivian tin.

A $1,300,000 municipal bond issue, convertible into a corporate equity under a special agreement, was announced yesterday by the underwriters. The arrangement, between the city of Florence, Ala., and the Stylon Corporation of Boston, is believed to mark the first municipal bond financing in which such a conversion privilege was provided.
Negotiations between the New York Central Railroad and four railroad brotherhoods collapsed suddenly yesterday, raising anew the possibility of a strike on the road's lines east of Buffalo.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The stock markets remained cheerful today. British government securities continued to rise steadily, gaining up to seven shillings sixpence ($1.05).

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Tam o'Shanter course was in excellent shape today, probably more than can be said of the nerves of eighty top professionals who tomorrow start competition in the richest tourney in golf history, the $90,000 "world championship."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange quieted down somewhat yesterday, and closed 2 to 16 points net higher than on Tuesday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Argentine-bred Tio Ciro finished two lengths ahead of his stablemate, Cuore, to win the $29,300 Meadowland Handicap over the grass course at Washington Park today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 6 -- Father Cyril Francis Borg, priest of the Carmelite Order, in charge of the Church of the Sacred Heart at Abadan, center of the Iranian Oil Industry, has been expelled from that city. He has come here to the residence of the Apostolic delegate to Iran.

In the Aug. 1 edition of THE TIMES Lewis F. Manly eloquently urges that we save American lives in Korea by immediately yielding on the prisoner-repatriation issue and returning to the Communists prisoners who would rather not go home. Mr. Manly states that our reluctance to return these prisoners is based on a "new principle" for which we should not sacrifice American boys.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Government today granted ceiling price increases to the aluminum industry, estimated to increase the cost of primary aluminum products about $62,500,000 annually.
ATLANTA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Government spokesmen said today no farmer would be put out of business or forced to sacrifice productive livestock because of widespread drought.

The city is expected to act within the next few weeks on some of the proposals made by the Mayor's Joint Committee on Port Industry, it became known yesterday. The proposals for port improvement have been in process of preparation and study for more than two years and members of the private shipping industry have recently expressed concern over the city's failure to take action.

Weary after a twenty-four-hour flight from Helsinki but aglow with the pride of accomplishment and the memories of a thoroughly enjoyable experience, the first two contingents of returning United States Olympic athletes landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- An Army scientist has succeeded in producing fiery objects that look just like some of those seen shooting through the night skies.

MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 6 -- You had to like fishing in order to spend eight or ten hours offshore today, especially in view of the fact that the school tuna seemed to have scattered over a wider stretch and the catches were well below par.
The price of zinc was cut 1 1/2 cents yesterday to a new price of 13 1/2 cents a pound, East St. Louis basis. This was a delayed effect of the fifty-five-day steel strike.

Your July 30 editorial on the British trade problem was correct in emphasizing the difference between short and long term economic planning. The editorial, however, did not offer proper justification for its preference for "the existing type of [trade] controls" over a policy of devaluation.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,333, for the twenty-fours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korean time:

PUSAN, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- Late returns compiled this morning on South Korea's first Presidential election by popular vote showed that President Syngman Rhee had received an overwhelming mandate to continue in office for another four years.

With an air of injured innocence the Soviets have protested against the suspension of all Soviet Embassy publications in this country, decreed by the American Government in retaliation for the restrictions placed on the circulation of a State Department publication in Soviet Russia. The Soviets base their protest on two arguments which must make even the Communists smile.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 6 -- Denmark will probably build a sistership to the oil tanker Apsheron, which it has delivered to the Soviet Union over United States protests, but whether the new vessel will actually be handed over to the Soviet when completed, one or two years hence, will depend on the world situation at that time.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- Belgium and the Netherlands each will send an army corps to participate with the British Army of the Rhine on maneuvers next month, Gen. Sir John Harding said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Two tiny islands--one is called Alpha and the other has no name, just a number--have become the center of a new flare-up of border trouble between Greece and Bulgaria. And the Greeks have warned that this is not just another border incident but could mean serious trouble.

David M. Keiser and John A. Nichols have been elected chairman and president of the Cuban-American Sugar Company, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Keiser has been a director since 1928. Mr. Nichols joined the company in 1948 as vice president.

A mass meeting to protest new electric rates will be held this afternoon as the result of the discovery within the last few days by the largest commercial users of power here that their bills will soar up to 40 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A bases-loaded single by Bob Nieman in the twelfth inning enabled Satch Paige to score a 1-0 victory over the Tigers tonight as he made his second starting appearance of the season for the Browns.

OLORON - SAINTE - MARIE, France, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Max Cosyns, a Belgian physicist, who once plunged into the sea in a bathy-sphere with Prof. Auguste Piccard, started an expedition under the surface of the earth today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Department indicated today that the United States would offer a counter-proposal to a reported British recommendation for a limited Middle East defense organization.

CAIRO, Aug. 6 -- Sir Ralph Stevenson, British Ambassador, had another in his current series of meetings with Egyptian Premier Aly Maher today. These talks have been described as bearing on matters of mutual interest, including defense.

A man who said he had "walked out" of the Kings Park State Hospital in 1950 while there as a mental patient was arraigned yesterday in the Queens Felony Court in Ridgewood on a charge of having raped an 8-year-old girl in Rockaway Beach, Queens.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Union boycotting of Westchester road repairing jobs merely because of union displeasure with the county's general labor policy was held to be illegal today by Supreme Court Justice Samuel W. Eager.

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 6 (AP) American track and field stars captured a majority of events today as some of the world's best athletes, en route home from olympic competition in Helsinki, performed in an exhibition sports show before 35,000 German fans.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Pravda revealed today that a widespread shake-up had taken place in the officialdom of the Communist party of Lithuania. The disclosure came in the course of animated discussion in the official Moscow press of big and little internal problems in the Soviet Union.

In his brief sand moving address to the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Los Angeles, General Eisenhower kept away from politics and yet set the tone for his political campaign. He spoke of an America that he and every other G. I. had been fighting for in the recent war, the America that "each of us carried in his heart."
DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Democratic Gov. G. Mennen Williams will fight it out with his Republican Secretary of State, Fred M. Alger Jr., for Michigan's Governorship in this fall's elections.
