The Citizens Traffic Safety Board, which was organized at the end of last month to make a frontal attack on the traffic accident problem, reported yesterday that in the ten-year period ended last Dec. 31 more than a million motor vehicle accidents had occurred in this city.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 6 -- When Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said the other day that the Presidential campaign should be "serious but not solemn," he was expressing an old personal bias against political stuffiness.

The exchange of compliments by which a family of five New York O'Connells are to have a free vacation near Bath, with expenses paid by the State of Maine, deserves, indeed requires, examination. Mrs. William E. O'Connell of Queens, a mother and letter-writer extraordinary, had the happy inspiration during July heat to sit down and pen a few words to a Portland newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Negotiations for a new soft coal wage agreement are now going on in comparative secrecy between two men, John L. Lewis and Harry M. Moses, and they could wind up in a week or two, or drag through a long strike this fall.

The story of an alleged "accommodation arrest" that had been stricken from the record was reintroduced yesterday through a new witness in the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen charged with having protected Harry Gross' gambling operations for graft.

Outside of the television studios there is no rocket travel to the moon these days. To get there, according to Dr. Werther von Braun, German rocket engineer, a 7,000-ton rocket with a sixtyfoot base and as tall as the Times Tower in Times Square Would have to be built.

Some time in the Nineteen Forties average Northern Hemisphere temperatures began to decline for the first time in many decades, Dr. Hans Wilson Ahlmann, world-famed climatologist and diplomat, reported here yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 6 -- Harold H. Purviance, general manager of the General Tire and Rubber Company in Israel, announced today that his factory, now in commercial production, would next week begin selling tires to the Israeli public and would export 500 tires to the United States.

The public offering of $9,500,000 of 3 3/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of Pennsylvania Electric Company is being made today by a banking group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. Priced at 100.47 and accrued interest, the bonds will yield 3.55 per cent to the Aug. 1, 1982 maturity.

During the July 4 week-end an accident occurred on the New Jersey Turnpike wherein three cars were stopped on account of a minor accident and plowed into later by a twenty-ton truck. I believe the accident could have been avoided if somebody in the party had placed a red flare on the road or had gone back to flag the truck with a searchlight.
Alexander H. Cohen and Joseph Kipness will be associated in the production here in October of "Be Your Age," a comedy by Reginald Denham and Mary Orr, in which Conrad Nagel will star.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Truman, the canny campaigner, gave a group of young political students a brief lesson in how to attract feminine interest today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Bob Satterfield of Chicago, a 7-2 underdog, tonight defeated Harold Johnson of Philadelphia in their ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The United States in its fourth protest over the kidnapping of Dr. Walter Linse, an anti-Communist leader, on the streets West Brelin July 8, has charged that he is being held by forces under Soviet control. The note, made public today, added to accusations made against the Russians by indicating he was in a Soviet-controlled jail.

One reads with wry amusement the statement in THE TIMES of Aug. 4 by sixteen prominent Republicans charging the Democrats with insincerity in their stand on civil rights and declaring that a Republican victory "would hasten the enactment of a compulsory civil rights program."

Details of a proposed merger of five branches of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent American Federation of Labor body exercising jurisdiction over entertainer unions, were explained yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting attended by 503 persons at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
A former bookmaker yesterday named Edward Cugell, one of thirty-four suspended policemen on departmental trial, as a member of a plainclothes foursome to whom he paid $100 a month graft.
Abraham Straus, Ohrbach's and Bond's Fifth Avenue made their bow to the college girl yesterday with showings of campus fashions.

PARIS -- Aug. 7 -- The names of the nine members of the high authority that will direct the six-nation coal and steel pool that is known as the Schuman plan were announced today. The authority, which includes two Frenchmen, two Germans, two Belgians and one member each from Italy, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, will hold its inaugural meeting in Luxembourg, its temporary headquarters, Sunday and will begin its first working session the following day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A program to indemnify farmers for slaughtering hogs to stamp out an outbreak of vesicular exanthema in fifteen states was put into effect today by the Agriculture Department. States that join in the program must put up 50 per cent of the cost.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 -- The Government appealed today to the Indonesian populace to protect foreign lives and property and assist the police and the army in curbing the recent wave of kidnappings and murders of Dutch citizens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Representatives of a group of tramp ship owners, the Maritime Board and ten steamship companies met here today and tentatively agreed to begin hearings Sept. 8 on a demand by the tramp ship operators that some Government-owned freighters running under charter to private companies be withdrawn from service.

This country has taken from Europe the distinction of being the world center of research in the field of powder metallurgy, Dr. Henry H. Hausner, manager of atomic energy engineering of the atomic energy division of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., asserted yesterday.

THE latest reports from the salmon rivers of the Canadian maritime provinces indicate that low water conditions have, with few exceptions, cut very seriously into the sport. However, with the arrival of rain, the fishing should be even better than normal.

A Federal court ruling here that a change made in a regulation of the Office of Price Stabilization after it allegedly was violated does not remove the basis for an injunctive action brought against a defendant was described by the agency yesterday as an important advance in the Government's efforts to enforce maintenance of price ceilings.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Umpire Bill McGowan today was suspended indefinitely by President Will Harridge of the American League for an incident involving sports writers in the Tigers-Browns game at Sportsman's Park last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- "The question in this race," said Jack Cooper, the steeple-chasing secretary, "is whether Oedipus is his old self. He had a cough at Belmont, and he had to be shot full of penicilin. He always improves at Saratoga, and if he's right, maybe he'll lead all the way -- despite the 162 pounds.

The forty-nine-family apartment house at 3013 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Valen Properties, Inc., Louis Lipman, principal, to the Tildale Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages of $255,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The speed with which the steel industry has managed to step up its output since the end of the fifty-five day strike of its workers has "exceeded all expectations," Henry H. Fowler, head of the Defense Production Administration and of the National Production Authority, told a news conference today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- The Screen Writers Guild will propose an assessment of 1 per cent on the salaries of its members working in motion-picture studios to finance the organization strike, effective Monday, against the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

The prosecution in the Communist conspiracy trial was directed lyesterday by Federal Judge EdIward J. Dimock to produce in icourt a 125-page summary of aI witness' Communist party activities that the former Communist had put on file with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Grain and soybean futures failed to retain early advances today and on the Board of Trade closed mostly lower. Heavy selling was done by longs, offsetting continued buying by the public.

ALBANY, Aug, 7 -- Another step in the long-range state-sponsored program to eliminate all grade crossings from the electrified part of the Montauk division of the Long Island Rail Road was taken today with the receipt of a $1,107,248 bid for construction work in Massapequa.
CAIRO, Aug. 7 -- Egypt's new strong man, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, bid today for United States military aid and hinted that if he did not get it from the West he might have to seek it from the East.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Cardinals combined Mike Clark's tight relief hurling and some lusty slugging tonight to take a 7-to-4 decision from the Reds. Clark relieved Harry Brecheen in the third inning after the Reds had scored four runs and held them scoreless the rest of the way.

The letter of Justice I. Montefiore Levy of Aug. 5, which was titled "To Combat Delinquency," calls attention to a problem that he believes will be partially solved by amending the State Education Law "to make it easier for 15-year-olds and 16-year-olds who do not profit by an educational school program" to obtain regular employment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- President Truman said today that he was considering Senator John J. Sparkman's request for the publication of a secret Government report on international oil cartels.

In its largest troop movement since World War II, the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division will leave New York in a convoy of fifty buses just after midnight tomorrow for the annual two-week tour of duty at Camp Drum, Watertown, N. Y.

The theatrical paraphernalia of Robert H. Burnside, former manager of the old Hippodrome, will be moved this week from his former house in Ridgewood, N. J., to the storage annex of the New York Public Library, a library spokesman said yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 7 -- The Iranian Chamber of Deputies voted today a full pardon to the assassin of Premier Ali Razmara, who was murdered in March a year ago, and elected the famous Islamic political mullah, Ayatollah Kashani, now regarded as the second most powerful man in the state, as President of the Chamber of Deputies.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 7 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic candidate for President, has completed the nucleus of a personal campaign staff that is distinguished by its youth, its legal training and its almost total lack of experience in Presidential politics.

Meeting in an atmosphere of cordial friendship and complete mutual trust, the ANZUS Powers -- Australia, New Zealand and the United States -have now established the first nucleus of a collective security system in the Pacific and have reaffirmed the need for expanding this system to include other nations -- when the time is ripe for this step.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Each of the three performances given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at this third Thursday evening concert of the Berkshire Festival was distinguished.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company said today that "still lingering steel shortages" would force a closing next week of eighteen of its nineteen assembly plants across the nation. The company explained, however, that it was hopeful it could .resume and maintain -n{-terrupted iproduction around the eighteenth Of AugustJ'
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 7 -- The Government has ordered export controls on live cattle to make sure that opening of the United States border does not cause a meat shortage here.

Gene Hairston of New York and Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu signed yesterday to meet in a ten-round middleweight fight at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 27. The bout heads the opening card of the fall boxing season at the Garden.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Premier Antoine Pinay decided today to revise the French national budget for 1952 to finance what he called essential French defense production that was "menaced by the insufficiency of off-shore orders." He referred to orders placed by the United States in France for weapons for French forces paid for by dollar aid.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Three hundred combat veterans of the Regular Army completed their three-day defeat of the cadets of the United States Military Academy in the annual Summer war games here today.

William L. Pfeiffer, state chairman of the Republican party, announced yesterday that the State Republican Committee would meet on Aug. 26 at the Hotel Ten Eyck in Albany to nominate a candidate for the United States Senate and to choose the forty-five Republican Presidential electors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- E. Reesman Fryer, assistant administrator for the Near East and Africa Development Service, said today that the recent criticism by several eminent geographers that the Point Four program was trying to do too much too fast was based on false assumption and lack of knowledge.
OMAHA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha today announced purchase of 51 per cent of the Permian Basin Pipeline Company, for $102,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 -- Japan and Indonesia tonight entered into a $100,000,000 trade pact in a brief and colorful ceremony in which both countries hailed the agreement as a major step leading to the restoration of normal relations between the two nations. The agreement culminates two months of negotiations here.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, Aug. 7 -- The negotiations on German compensation for Nazi anti-Semitic acts which started twenty weeks ago between West Germany and delegations of Israel and world Jewish organizations are entering what may be their final stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- For guidance in making his decisions and pronouncements concerning a fair employment practices law, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, is studying the text and explanatory report of a bill that already has reached the Senate calendar for floor action.

The Department of Justice has started an anti-trust suit against a number of Hollywood motion picture producers for the express purpose of forcing them to make their films available to television. In our opinion it is a suit born of fuzzy bureaucratic thinking that clearly flouts economic reality.
A television set that was literally too hot to handle was the subject of a proceeding yesterday in Bronx Magistrates' Court.

The Army has enlisted Tin Pan Alley to help turn out a piece of equipment it feels is missing from its morale arsenal. It wants an all-Army song to fit "the new Army" and with as much popular appeal as the time - honored "Marine Hymn" or "Anchors Aweigh."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Parliament today endorsed the new rapprochement with Jammu and Kashmir State worked out by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and representatives of the State Government.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Paced by Del Ennis' grand-slam homer, the Phillies beat the Braves, 10 -- 2, tonight after Robin Roberts had pitched his seventeenth victory by taming the Tribe, 2 -- 1, with a three-hit performance in the twilight opener of a double-header.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- A group of conservatives from about forty states, dissatisfied with the national Republican and Democratic tickets, talked today of forming a third party. About 100 attended a day-long conference, which will resume tomorrow.
HONOLULU, Aug. 7 -- Following is the text of the communique issued here by the Pacific Council on the conclusion of its first confrence:

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 7 -- The executive secretary to the Mayor of Mount Vernon and two investigators for the Office of Price Stabilization were arrested last night by Nassau County police on a charge of trying to extort $4,000 from a man who had allegedly sold his car at a price in excess of the O. P. S. ceiling.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 7 -- A flare-up for the first time of what appeared to be Communist terriorist activity was reported today from the British colony of Sarawak in North Borneo.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- The middy and the sashed hips of the Twenties are themes running through Maggy Rouff's collection. The spirit of the Chanel epoch pervades entire ensembles, such as a straight black velvet coat with scarf collar tipped in mink tails and worn over a real middy frock of black satin.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The recall of Abdul Fattah Amr, Egyptian Ambassador to London since 1945, which has been reported from Cairo, has drawn universal expressions of regret here. The Ambassador was described as a regrettable casualty of the recent military coup in Egypt.

Shipping industry officials and representatives of the National Shipping Authority are attempting to set up a system of compensation for liquidation work in the removal of 523 Government-owned vessels from active service.

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A three-day-old qualifying record tumbled today as Chuck Thompson drove the Detroit-owned Miss Pepsi nine miles at an average speed of 103.746 miles an hour to qualify for Saturday's Gold Cup race.

The second consecutive new high for the year was reached yesterday by the stock market in an extension of the creeping advance. Further demand for the railroad issues was the main prop for the list. Gains ranged from fractions to more than a point in a variety of stocks with firmness most pronounced, aside from the carriers, in the motors, metals and airlines.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 7 -Charley Dominy's Independence assumed a commanding lead in the Corry trophy series for star boats in conjunction with the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's thirty-seventh annual regatta. Although Independence was second today to Harold Halsted's Chuckle, she needs only a fourth place in each of the next two races of the series to clinch the 1952 championship.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 7 -- The Yanqui and the Senorita," a colorful pageant-play with a cast of 250, plus thirty-six horses, presented tonight in the natural amphitheatre of the Santa Barbara County Bowl before 3,500 persons, proved to be the drama highlight of the "Old Spanish Days Fiesta."
Three railroad brotherhoods authorized yesterday a strike to begin Monday at noon on all lines of the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo.

Like a political convention after a long, hard fight, the continent's markets are moving to make unanimous the decision of the New York Stock Exchange to close on Saturdays throughout the year. Yesterday the board of managers of the New York Produce Exchange made the move.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,335, covering the twenty-four hours ending at 6 A. M. today:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The United States and Britain have been forced to lower their sights on plans for a regional defense alliance in the Middle East.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- At the request of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, the French Government agreed today to postpone the French-German talks on a settlement of the Saar problem, which were to have been resumed tomorrow.

VIENNA, Aug. 7 (AP) -- United States Olympic track stars won all seven events tonight in the closing of a two-day international carnival. The night's outstanding performance was accounted for by William P. Miller of Phoenix, Ariz., who hurled the javelin 242 feet 7 5/8 inches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 2 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:
The famous Capt. John Smith, Virginian, reported in 1614 on the spot now called Ipswich, near the northern shore of what is now Cape Ann, in the actual Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission examiner held today that two subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., should supply natural gas to four utility companies serving communities in Pennsylvania and New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (UP) -- A gunman who killed a girl and wounded her male companion yesterday in Grant Park was identified today as a former mental patient who left a veterans' hospital at Gulfport, Miss., only three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Administration predictions that consumers would pay sharply higher prices in the fall for canned goods because of the drought and higher costs for tinplate for cans were condemned as "scare talk" by canners here today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Mrs. George J. Brady of Scarsdale sprang the biggest surprise of the Womens' Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship when she defeated the defending champion, Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, 2 and 1, to reach the final over the Woodway Country Club course today.

ISLIP, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Plans to convert MacArthur Airport into a major air cargo terminal and 139 acres of surrounding land into a center for light industry were announced here today in a statement by Islip Town Supervisor Vern L. Furman and Robert E. Outman, president of Airport Industries, Inc., of New York.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 7 -- Dillard B. Lasseter, head of the Farmers Home Administration, told officials of the agency from fourteen states at the emergency drought relief conference here today to give drought-ravaged farmers "the benefit of the doubt" when they applied for Government disaster funds.

A campaign to stimulate recruitment of 300,000 additional "skywatchers" to man the 19,400 aircraft spotting posts along this country's northern and seacoast boundaries and in certain inland areas was announced yesterday by the Advertising Council, Inc., of 25 West Forty-fifth Street.

The Times Square-Grand Central subway shuttle was an atrocity from the beginning and has had no substantial improvement in a third of a century. Now, with the disclosure in our news columns this morning that $3,800,000 is being sought in the 1953 capital budget to rebuild the shuttle, harassed riders have reason to hope that something finally will be done about it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Price officials said today an order is due to be issued next Tuesday granting anthracite producers a ceiling price increase of 75 cents a ton on smaller sizes of anthracite used chiefly by industrial concerns.

The National Broadcasting Company presented yesterday the results of a study of actual sales to radio network listeners as compared with non-listeners which indicated increased sales for a variety of products by from 11 to 111 per cent among radio listeners as against nonlisteners.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- The Fifty-third National Encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, which lists a membership of 1,200,000, adopted today a resolution denouncing the United Nations Educational, scientific and Cultural Organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Two former high officials of the Justice Department were named today as central figures in a new phase of a House Judiciary subcommitttee's investigation of the department.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Foreign bonds provided the main feature of Stock Exchange dealings today with German issues fluctuating sharply in view of reports of the terms agreed at the debt conference. On further consideration of the reported terms much of the early losses was recovered.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- It was one stride backward and one forward for the Yankees today as they wound up their tour by splitting a double-header with Bucky Harris' exasperating Senators.

Reflecting the continued low level of business in the textile industry, sales and earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America for the three and six months ended on June 30 declined sharply below the corresponding periods last year, according to the mid-year report issued yesterday by Harold Blancke, president.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- "The Happy Marriage," a satire on psychiatry which opened here tonight at the Duke of York's Theatre, went down fairly well with the London newspaper critics, although almost unanimously they decided it was rather unsubstantial.

The Kips Bay Boys' Club, 301 East Fifty-second Street, has introduced a new program to its members. We call it Camp Ski-Hi. It is an attempt to bring to those members who cannot attend our summer camp some of the experiences enjoyed at a true camp. To boys aged 6 and 7 it means being on their own for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The suit by Paul Robeson, singer, to have the State Department revalidate his passport was ordered thrown out of court today.
DENVER, Aug. 7 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower repudiated today appeals to religious or racial prejudice whether designed to help or hurt his candidacy.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Connie Miller and Paul Gavin of the Nassau Country Club scored 80 -- 13 -- 67 to triumph in the Long Island Golf Association's mixed foursomes championship at the Piping Rock Club today. The winning pair finished three strokes ahead.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

A syndicate headed by Louis Fixell has purchased the two buildings at 2273-2279 Broadway and 252-254 West Eighty-second Street, containing five stores and thirty eight apartments, from William F. Berghold and Edward J. McGratty, as trustees. Pearce, Mayer Greer and Millard S. Bondy were co-brokers in the transaction.
May I call attention to the extraordinary importance of a sentence tucked away at the end of a dispatch from Iran published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 1.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The Tuxedo Park Association, governing body of this private community of fine homes, is yielding its civic functions this month to an incorporated village, now in the process of organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- During the week ended Aug. 6, member bank reserves decreased $149,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- A 672-page book that is probably unique in its origins and contents, "The Sterling Area -- An American Analysis," is being published here tomorrow by the United States Aid Mission in London.
Subway riders do, at times, board the wrong train and wind up miles from their destinations. However, early yesterday fifty riders boarded the right train but reached the wrong place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce and President Truman want the Olympic marathon champ from Communist Czechoslovakia and his javelin-hurling wife to get a look at the United States -- and to let the United States see them.
A continuing high level of industrial activity in Toronto during July has been marked by new plant development and expansion of existing facilities by British, Canadian and United States concerns.

It may seem mean to spoil the fun for those now being intrigued by thoughts of visitors from space scouting the upper atmosphere over our national capital. Or to interfere with the dreams of those among our tax-burdened citizens who may be anticipating that these visitors will atomize the Administration and all its works.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- From tho eminence of its position in British public life The Time of London passed judgment tonight on the constitutional issue raised in Parliament last week between left-wing Laborite Aneurin Bevan and the leader of his party, Clement Attlee.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- Strikes over the high cost of living that threaten to develop into riots have gripped the southern Brazilian State of Rio Grande do Sul and cut off rail traffic to Argentina, it was reported here today.

The return to active service of two familiar pre-war liners after seven years of idleness was nearer yesterday. The Maritime Administration took possession in California of the 18,O00-gross-ton Monterey, paying the Oceanic Steamship Company of San Francisco $3,098,000, and her sister ship, the Mariposa, was turned over to the Matson Navigation Company.

Pork cuts rose as much as 6 cents a pound this week, reflecting higher wholesale price ceilings and a tighter supply caused by livestock market quarantines to halt the spread of a virus hog disease. Loin pork cuts, which show a cumulative advance in the last two weeks of 10 cents a pound, have hit the highest level since August, 1950, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Demands submitted yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., which include a 50-cent hourly pay increase, were described by employing stevedores as "entirely unreasonable" as wage review negotiations opened.

Until about 9 P. M. last night, Leo Durocher was so happy he found himself at a loss for words. He said so, in front of 36,694 cheering fans assembled at the Polo Grounds for the nocturnal part of a day-night program that was also a celebration, of "Durocher Night."

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Far East Naval Headquarters revealed details today concerning the roaring fire and explosions Wednesday aboard the aircraft carrier Boxer off Korea. Nine lives were lost in the disaster, the exact cause of which has not yet been determined.
A spokesman for the Zim Israel Navigation Company here denied yesterday charges by a travel agency that one of it passenger ships was "unfit to carry American passengers."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Cecil B. de Mille today officially confirmed a long-standing rumor that his next film undertaking will be "The Ten Commandments" and that Paramount will sponsor the project. The new picture, to be photographed in Technicolor, will deal with the early life of Moses and will bear no resemblance, other than its title identification, to the religious drama produced by the veteran director in 1923.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The Greek Army announced today the withdrawal of an invading Bulgarian patrol from a tiny, muddy island in the river that forms a part of the Greek-Bulgarian border after the island had been sprayed for more than an hour by Greek mortars and machine guns.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- Carl A. Latva, 49-year-old Finnish-born textile worker who spent 50 cents to join the Communist party in 1934, stood today in the shadow of a deportation order as result of his efforts to become a United States citizen.

Dollar sales and tonnage of the National Dairy Products Corporation in the six months ended on June 30 totaled $560,525,686, a record high for a first-half period. This represents an increase of $25,495,498 over the $535,030,188 volume transacted in the corresponding half of 1951.

Development of a "fabulous new solid fuel" for jet-assisted take-offs, guided missiles and supersonic flight launching was reported to the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday by Carlton B. Waller, president of the Unexcelled Chemical Company.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Gordon Goldsberry's double, scoring Jim Dyck, gave the Browns a 5-to-4 victory over the Tigers tonight -- their second straight twelve-inning, one-run triumph. Hal White, who had lost last night, also suffered this defeat, each time in a relief role.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman today charged a large part of the American voting population with "laziness and indifference" in failing to register and vote in national elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Department of Defense identified 191 battle casualties in Korea today. A new list reported twenty-three killed, 158 wounded, one missing and nine injured. No casualties were reported from New Jersey or Connecticut. Those from New York were:

HONOLULU, Aug. 7 -- The foreign policy heads of Australia, New Zealand and the United States, who last night completed the outline of a tripartite security structure against Communist aggression in the Pacific, had today a closeup view of the token effects of an aggressors actions of almost eleven years ago.

There was standing room only in Flatbush Magistrates' Court yesterday when the case of Biruta Sneiders, the Latvian nightingale now practicing her controversial scales in Brooklyn, came up again. But there was no singing and little recitative as the case was postponed for another two and a half weeks.

Nervousness over the pending publication today of the first crop estimate of the season by the Government caused an erratic cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices for active months were 16 to 41 points net higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman said today that the primary purpose of the visit of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois to Washington next Tuesday would be to participate in a discussion at which everything necessary for a Democratic party success in November would be reviewed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Lew Worsham and Pete Cooper, a couple of club pros in tournament golf's low income bracket, shot 7-under-par 65's today to pace the first round of the $90,000 "world championship of golf."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Government officials said today that basic dollars-and-cents retail ceiling prices on new passenger automobiles would be wiped out in an order to be issued in the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Truman told his news conference today that he had "under consideration" proposals for calling a special session of Congress to strengthen the Economic Controls Law. Asked when such a session might be called, the President emphasized that the matter was just being considered and that it would be necessary to wait and see if such a move was necessary.

William Conklin, said by the police to have a criminal record dating to 1898, when he was arrested in the investigation of mailbox theft, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo in Felony Court for a hearing Wednesday on charges of forgery and grand larceny.

The delightful Mrs. Beeton -- the Fannie Farmer of Great Britain -- is being introduced formally to Americans next week when Crown Publishers brings out her "English Cookery" for the first time in this country. Up to now there has been no organized sale and distribution of this British classic, which has grown into a complete housekeeping handbook of almost 700 pages.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- The Army said today nearly 15,000 of the 50,000 applications received for mustering-out pay had been returned to veterans for more information.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau shook up the Red Sox after three straight defeats and the new line-up batted out an 8 -- 4 decision over the Athletics today in the second game of a double-header. Philadelphia won the opener, 7 -- 5, on two homers by Gus Zernial.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 7 -- Ireland's Ambassador John J. Hearne sad here tonight that the unity of Ireland "is not impossible in the near future." and would be achieved "without civil war." Declaring that union of the Republic of Ireland, and the British counties "is in any event inevitable," he added: "We want unity, but we also want peace."

TORONTO, Aug. 7 -- The eighteenth International Red Cross conference ended its plenary sessions today with a pledge that the Red Cross would continue in its traditional humanitarian role in the world, despite the injection of political issues here, which had caused fear that the entire movement was jeopardized.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Tennessee and 'Kentucky were designated disaster areas because of drought by President Truman today. He announced that $3,000,000 of emergency funds would be allocated to aid farmers in those hard-hit states.

Fresh-looking motifs, delineated in pleasant colorings, distinguish the new collection of thirty wallpapers designed by Harry Paulson for F. Schumacher Co. Now available through decorators at the concern's showroom at 60 West Fortieth Street, the papers are expected to be in stores by the first of the month.

Enforcement of the new fur labeling law, which goes into effect tomorrow, will be materially aided by the Better Business Bureau of New York, Inc., and the Master Furriers Guild. Both of the organizations pledged yesterday that they would take an active part to obtain adherence to the new regulations enacted to eliminate unfair trade practices and deceptive merchandising and advertising of fur coats.

Mayor Impellitteri publicly commended yesterday twenty-three members of the Police Department who took part in rounding up over the last week-end suspects charged with crimes of violence in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Maynard H. Smith, a 41-year-old World War II hero accused of faking the rescue of a woman in a suicide hoax, surrendered to the police today and was released under $300 bond.

Despite the Cassandras who contended that "Dial 'M' for Murder" would not reach Broadway because of film complications, there's an excellent chance of the new London hit being done here with Maurice Evans in it.

The triumphant homecoming parade of United States Olympians continued yesterday with the arrival at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, of the third of five chartered planeloads of American athletes from Helsinki.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Friday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator McKeller was trailing Representative Gore by almost 50,000 votes on the basis of returns early today from 1,781 of the state's 2,300 precincts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Public Health Service reported today that there were 2,290 new cases of infantile paralysis last week, the highest weekly total so far this year.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Bill Kuntz Jr., who has been playing golf at the Bonnie Briar Country Club for more than fifteen years and Mike Volpe, who played the course for the first time, shared the lead today in the qualifying round of the Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 1.8 per cent above that of the comparable 1951 week, according to reports received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations. Shipments were up 8.2 per cent and orders rose 18.4 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The 1952 electoral vote will be different from 1948 in sixteen states where the 1950 census necessitated a reapportionment of House seats due to changes in populations.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- Izvestia and Pravda today predicted that American efforts to create a Pacific defense system parallel to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would fail, primarily because of growing contradictions between the United States and Britain and because of the opposition of the Southeast Asian countries.

Capital Products, Inc., has leased the one-story building at 36-25 First Street in Long Island City, Queens, and will use it for the fabrication of metal Queens Industrials and Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., were co-brokers in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The recent illness of the Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, and the realities of military politics have created renewed indecision in the top levels of the service.

There seems nothing mystical about the number 114,310. It's not like 3 or 7 or those larger, strange quantities evenly divisible only by themselves and 1. It might be last year's dollar income for a top executive, or the number of words in a long novel, or the population of some up-and-coming Midwest city, or the count of books in a college library.

Their faces covered by black hoods, a dozen employes of the Department of Sanitation picketed a department pier at Twenty-first Street and the East River yesterday morning in protest against the city's failure to give sanitation workers a five-day, forty-hour week.

The New York County Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars, has urged Parks Commissioner Robert Moses to prevent the New York Peace Institute from holding a rally Aug. 20 in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. The veterans, in a letter to Mr. Moses last Tuesday, charged the institute was a "Communist front."

An informal character study of Joseph Stalin by Budu Svanidze will be published Sept. 5 by Putnam, entitled "My Uncle, Joseph Stalin." The author, a Georgian, is doubly related to Stalin as his cousin and as his nephew by marriage. The book, translated by Waverly Root, is based on the author's meetings, visits and associations with Stalin over the years.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Through open ocean and up Buzzards Bay, the New York Yacht Club fleet came here today from Newport. It was thirty-two miles, the longest run of the cruise, and forty-seven sailing craft raced for the Alumni Association of the United States Navy Challenge Cups.

Mayor Impellitteri and other city officials, with none too kind references to newspapers and other critics of City Hall, praised the administration's record of achievement yesterday and pledged continued service to the people of New York.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 8 -- United Nations fighters shot down yesterday four of the enemy's Soviet-designed MIG jets and damaged five others in air battles over Korea while the negotiations for an armistice stayed in adjournment until next week, deadlocked over the exchange of war prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 2 totaled 732,920 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 125,649 cars or 20.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 80,468 cars or 9.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 104,510 cars or 12.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Despite the complexities and conflicting concepts of value in modern baseball, there still remain two irrefutable symbols of achievement -- the .300 hitter and the twenty-game winner. These are the select few who play in the all-star games and are compared with the greats of yesteryear.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Noel Brown, an unseeded former professional from Los Angeles, and seven seeded players today gained the quarter-finals of the twenty-sixth Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Plans were started yesterday by the city's largest commercial users of electric power to organize an all-out attack on new rates of the Consolidated Edison Company that went into effect Monday by order of the Public Service Commission.

PUSAN, Korea, Aug. 7 -- The United Nations Commission for the Reunification and Rehabilitation of Korea disclosed today that it had posted a watch to see that there was no attempt at post-election retribution against any of the losing candidates in South Korea's first popular election for President and Vice President.

Operations of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first six months of this year resulted in a net loss of $3,902,125, according to the report released by W. P. Marshall, president, for publication today. The loss is after a $198,120 non-recurring credit from adjustment of prior year's provision for depreciation of cable system plant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Wage Stabilization Board has a new inflation problem in its lap, that of permitting reductions in the number of working hours in a week without loss of take-home pay for the workers involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- A Federal Communications Commission examiner rejected on constitutional grounds today a proposed Western Union Telegraph Company regulation aimed at choking off the flow of illegal racing news.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UP) -- Americans earned money at the record rate of $264,000,000,000 a year in the first half of 1952, the Government reported today.
BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- East Germany has embarked on an extensive program to indoctrinate and train its youth as the backlog for a proposed new army. This was reflected today in a number of reports.
OLIVER GOLDSMITH could very well have had Gene Leone in mind when he penned:
CANNES, France, Aug. 7 (UP) -- An annual series of "Artistic Evenings" was planned today to raise money for continuing an art foundation left by the late Henry Clews, American millionaire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The desire for a change in party power in Washington is accurately listed by the Republicans as one of their two principal assets in the Presidential campaign, the other being the special qualifications of General Eisenhower to achieve a durable peace.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 7 -- United States naval officers at Supreme Allied Headquarters were taking a joshing today from their Army and Air Force colleagues over their newly acquired "surrender cards."
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -The Government of Argentina announced today that it will buy any amount of raw cotton offered it by Argentine producers from the present 1951-52 crop.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Andrei A. Gromyko rode in medieval splendor today to present his credentials to the Queen, and even a reluctant horse could not spoil the show.
Paul Bland and his mambo band hit Broadway by surprise yesterday.

TRENTON, Aug 7 (AP) -- The New Jersey Civil Defense division today reported the Red Cross had refused to accept its offer to help collect blood for American troops in Korea. Thomas Dignan, deputy Civil Defense Director, said his division several months ago had offered to help the Red Cross by getting blood donations from the state's 200,000 civil defense volunteers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Friday, Aug. 8 -- Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, 88-year-old veteran lawmaker and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, was defeated in his bid for a seventh successive term on the basis of nearly complete returns tabulated early today from yesterday's nominating primaries.

YONKERS, Aug. 7 -- Accused of the daylight payroll hold-up of representatives of the International Flouncing Company, Inc., here yesterday, two young men were held for the Westchester County Grand Jury by Judge Martin Fay in City Court today.

The fact that Dr. Syngman Rhee has polled a vote of about four to one over his combined opposition in the Korean election is no surprise. It has been often pointed out that he is not only the one man in Korea whose name is known to all but is also a unique symbol in the minds of the Korean people.

The Board of Transportation has asked for $3,800,000 to install a moving platform designed to carry 15,000 passengers an hour to replace the thirty-four-year-old subway shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Terminal. That amount has been earmarked for inclusion in the 1953 capital budget, now before the City Planning Commission.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- Conservative Prime Minister Sidney Holland presented to Parliament today a budget in which social services made up nearly half the expenditures.

Censorship by controversy again has arisen in television. James A. Wechsler, the editor of The New York Post, has been dropped from the excellent program called "Starring the Editors" (9:30 Wednesday on Du Mont) under thoroughly disheartening circumstances.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Tenth in the first heat, Sharp Note went on to win the next two and capture the twenty-seventh Hambletonian before 15,000 spectators today at Good Time Park. It was the first time in five years that more than two heats were necessary to decide the famed classic for 3-year-old trotters.
Volume sagged in New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Only in cocoa and in cotton-seed oil, in which 187 and 809 lots were traded, respectively, was the turnover appreciable.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- A serious slump in coal production in West Germany, resulting partly from the indifference of some mine managements to the gravity of the production problem, has forced the United States to withhold temporarily some of the funds it allocated to help increase production and to ask the Germans for an inquiry into the reasons for the falling output.

Indications that the seasonal expansion of business credit may already be under way are contained in the combined statement of New York City member banks issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. According to the data, covering the week ended on Wednesday, business loans rose $63,000,000 to register the first increase since June 25.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- Maximum penalties of five years in prison and $10,000 fines were imposed by Federal District Judge William C. Mathes today on four-teen California Communists convicted Tuesday of conspiring to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
Prince Gholam Reza Pahlavi, brother of the Shah of Iran, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Albert Arnold Gore has been one of the most active and aggressive members of the House of Representatives since he came to Congress in 1939.

A prospective employe by any other name still has the same qualifications, the New York State Commission Against Discrimination has ruled in ordering an employment agency to remove a question concerning name changes from its application form.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Jim Ferrier, the unorthodox swinger and master putter, took a two-stroke lead over Lew Worsham at the thirty-six-hole mark of the $90,000 "world golf championship" at Tam O'Shanter today with a second round of 66 for a 134, ten under par.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve reported today that earnings of its member banks improved in the first half of 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 8 -- The delicate question of the British movement of Gurkha troops from Nepal through India to Malaya has reached a position that is awkward for both the Nehru Government and Britain, but especially to the latter.

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 8 -- A former German field marshal, serving a life prison term on war-crimes charges, was revealed today to have been elected president of the Stahlhelm, one of West Germany's most powerful veterans' organizations.
The off-again, on-again strike set by three railroad brotherhoods against all lines of the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo was off again yesterday.

Dr. Harold Lenz of Queens College said yesterday that the college's administrative committee had turned down his request for a hearing on his transfer from dean of students to a teaching position. Last month Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, told Dr. Lenz that he could appeal the transfer.
Sugar, rubber and zinc scored moderate gains in yesterday's futures trading. Other commodities were lower or mixed. Volume was generally light.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 8 -- The Communist party's refusal to surrender illicit arms and its insistence upon the right to foster armed rebellion against the Government was aired today in the Council of States, the upper house of the Indian Parliament, where a Preventive Detention Bill is being debated.

The targets set by the North Atlantic Council in Lisbon last February were adjudged reasonable and attainable by the top Ministers of the Allied Governments. They were fixed after a careful survey of the economic and military capabilities of the countries involved and represented a reduction of the original goals, with the object of easing the strain for the member states and focusing interest and effort on the 1952 schedule.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 8 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois passed over the professional politicians tonight and backed a political amateur for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 197 additional casualties of the Korean war. The list included nineteen dead, 160 wounded, thirteen injured and five missing. None were listed from Connecticut. Those from New York and New Jersey were:
Three Democratic Senators and their wives were among the 1,650 passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday aboard the superliner United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Newspaper executives today felt their wdy at the Government's request through a test of proposed substitute material for newsprint.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The bacon-loving Britons were mildly inspired by the news today that Government food scientists at Cambridge have been driving herds of hogs through the beams of a portable X-ray machine to get the internal profile of the ideal "long, lean hog."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- J. H. Carmichael, president of Capital Airlines, has informed his employes that merger negotiations with United Air Lines have failed, but that "in all probability there will be further exploratory conversations between Capital and other carriers."

In a bid to stimulate increased demand for Canadian-styled quality clothing and footwear in this country, leading concerns of Canada's garment industry, in cooperation with the Canadian Government, will begin a special exhibit next Tuesday in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Attorney General McGranery said today that he had ordered a grand jury investigation of alleged bribes and other irregularities in the 1946 sale of the St. Johns River Shipyard at Jacksonville, Fla.

We have now seen the nomination for President of two men of extraordinary world-awareness. They are both strong supporters of the United Nations. Both have called for universal enforceable disarmament administered by the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (UP) -- A postal inspectors' report that thirty-eight Chicago post office supervisors paid up to $500 for their promotions will be turned over to a Federal grand jury, United States Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Quarantine restrictions imposed because of the swine disease known as vesicular exanthema were lifted today from the states of Ohio, Arizona, Georgia and Wyoming.

Nine persons are under consideration for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator to oppose the Republican incumbent, Irving M. Ives, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, said yesterday.

Nine men were named in Paris yesterday to constitute the High Authority of the coal and steel pool known as the Schuman Plan. The nine consisted of two Frenchman, two Germans, two Belgians, one Italian, one Dutchman and a representative of Luxembourg. They will meet for the first time tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Chinese Embassy announced today that Brig. Gen. Peter T. K. Pee, named by Senator Wayne Morse in his "China lobby" charges, was being replaced as military attache.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 -- Undaunted by a downpour that lasted all day, Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich won the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's twenty-seventh annual championship by defeating Mrs. George J. Brady of Scarsdale, 10 and 9, in the scheduled thirty-six-hole final at the Woodway Country Club today.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output, at a subnormal 42,383 units this week, will continue at low levels next week but should begin to mount during the week commencing Aug. 18, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Judged strictly from the qualifying times, the forty-fifth Gold Cup speed-boat classic tomorrow shapes up as a two-boat battle between Miss Pepsi of Detroit and the pride of Seattle, the Slo-mo-Shun V.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Iran's proposal to enter into negotiations for a settlement of claims arising out of the nationalization of the British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's property in Iran aroused no enthusiasm in London today.

THOSE anglers headed for eastern Connecticut and Rhode Island in search of striped bass should have plenty of activity, for reports received late yesterday indicated that large schools of bass were moving along the Rhode Island shore, with concertrations in the Narragansett area.

The Texas Company and its subsidiaries estimated net earnings for the first half of 1952 at $83,044,760 after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday by W. S. S. Rodgers, chairman. The profit is equal to $3.02 a share and compares with $86,507,142 or $3.14 a share earned in the initial six months last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Dr. Lyle E. Hagmann, Rutgers University entomologist, said today that Dr. C. Howard Curran, chief curator of insects and spiders at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, misjudged distance when he said mosquitos could fly more than sixty miles from their birthplace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today notified the state of Kansas that its intrastate railroad freight rates on about a dozen heavy commodities should be raised by 8 per cent.
