There aren't enough Republicans to elect him President without the help of the independents and Democrats who want a change in the National Administration.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- Max Surkont tonight achieved his first victory over the Giants. The 30-year-old right-hander limited the National League champions to four hits to give the sixth-place Braves a 2-0 victory before 4,151 fans at Braves Field.

The stock market followed yesterday the pattern of the two preceding sessions, price increases being almost identical in most cases, volume at a similar pace and the difference between the stocks to advance or decline in like proportion.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell tonight earned his third triumph as against twelve defeats in pitching the Reds to an 8-5 victory over the Cardinals. Cliff Chambers was the losing pitcher.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission will meet Tuesday to hear the Western Powers present new details on their proposals for limiting the armed forces and armaments of the powers.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- The Pennsylvania department of the American Legion demanded today that the Communist party be outlawed in the United States.

Unless there are unexpected developments over the week-end, contracts will be signed on Monday for presentation of "My Darlin' Aida," Charles Friedman's version of the Verdi opera, beginning on Oct. 27 at the Winter Garden.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UP) -- The Republicans began to move into their new national campaign headquarters today and, in the confusion, the bigwigs managed to lock themselves out.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Mass deportations of "enemies of the people" started again in Hungary last month according to a rural policeman who recently fled the Communist country and has arrived in West Germany.

Robert R. Coles, the conservative curator of the Hayden Planetarium, predicted here yesterday that flying saucers would be reported in great numbers this week-end and early next week if the weather was good.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 9 -- American Sabre jets knocked down three more of the enemy's Russian-designed MIG-15's in dogfights over Korea yesterday. They brought the total score in five successive days of air combat to eighteen Chinese jet fighters destroyed and nineteen damaged.

ROOSEVELT, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Pioneer programs in diagnosing and treating victims of cerebral palsy, developed during the last three years under the auspices of the Nassau County Cerebral Palsy Association, went into full-scale operation here this week at the association's new $500,000 diagnostic and treatment center.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- The fifty-third national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today elected the following unopposed nominees for officers for the coming year:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Karl A. Latva, Finnish-born textile worker who paid 90 cents to the Communist party in 1934 after he unwittingly joined the party, will not be deported if he is as innocent as he seems to be, Attorney General James P. McGranery said at a news conference today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue said today it would allow newspaper men to examine the records of any tax settlement case when its propriety had been publicly questioned.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki told the Japanese Cabinet Friday the Government intends to settle the case of two British sailors amicably and as soon as possible.
A housewife testified yesterday that she joined the Communist party after conferring with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and that she held various party positions in Washington for six years.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The Coronation plans for June 2, 1953, call for a broadcast by the newly crowned Queen Elizabeth that night.
ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, the state's Public Works Superintendent, announced today that the historic Executive Chamber in the State Capitol would be completely refurbished this fall.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Chris Campanell, sergeant-at-arms for the Essex County courts, placed a shot one foot two inches from the pin to win the New Jersey section of The World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one contest today at the Forest Hill Field Club.

Joseph and Rose Rizzo have purchased the three-story building at 481 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, containing a store and three apartments, from the V. R. Service, Inc., of which Vincent J. Striano is president. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
Plans to study the possibility of using potato starch in the manufacture of paper have been revived by the Potato Industry Council of Maine, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 8 -- The Iranian Government released today the text of a note to the British Government demanding that the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, whose properties here were nationalized in March, 1951, pay Iran tens of millions of pounds sterling, alleging that these were sums due to Iran from the oil company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The cotton crop in the Southern states, where drought is prevalent, will be short more than a million bales compared with last year, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The international conference on Germany's pre-war foreign debts, which total $2,668,200,000, came to a successful conclusion today, marking another major step in the economic resurgence of West Germany.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Oleta O'Connor Yates, state organizational secretary of the Communist party, was sentenced today to eleven concurrent one-year prison terms for criminal contempt of court. She had refused in eleven instances to answer questions during her recent trial for violation of the Smith Act.

OGDEN, Utah. Aug. 8 (AP) -- Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah, bulled and punched Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati for ten rounds tonight and received the decision from the referee and sole judge, Jack Dempsey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The remodeling of the Department of Justice under Attorney General James P. McGranery proceeded today when President Truman filled three key positions with interim nominees who had been designated by Mr. McGranery.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Although week-end considerations restricted business, prices on the stock markets again moved slightly higher today. German bonds continued to attract most attention although the oil shares came into the picture following the news that Iran had made tentative proposals to renew discussions over the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute.
HAVANA, Aug. 8 (UP) -- A Cuban press bloc representing the nation's major publishers reiterated today its intention to block entry into Cuba of publications in Spanish printed abroad.

The Army and the Air Force are about to go heavily into advertising for recruits. Officials of the two departments as well as members of Congress responsible for their appropriations have been convinced through representations made by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association that the $1,000,000 expenditure contemplated will effect an ultimate saving to the taxpayers because the cost of a voluntary enlistment is basically below that of drafting a man.

NEWARK, Aug. 8 -- The sale of its low-rent Chellis Austin Apartments here on Raymond Boulevard was announced today by the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The purchaser is a syndicate headed by Jack Finkelstein of 6 East Forty-fifth Street, New York.

Negotiations between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., on a wage review reached an impasse yesterday and the union suspended the talks "independently," subject to a forty-eight-hour recall. The talks had been going on for seventy-six days.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president and studio production chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, today charged the Truman Administration with political "pressure" tactics in the recent filing of an antitrust suit against major movie companies that have refused to sell 16-mm. film prints of feature pictures to television and other interests operating in competition against established theatres.

Salami, one of the most popular of the cold cuts that so often provide a short cut to summer meal preparation, certainly needs no introduction. It has been used since early Greek and Roman times. In fact, its name is thought to derive from Salamis, the Greek city on the east coast of Cyprus in the Aegean Gulf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The State Department announced today that the Czechoslovak Government had officially reported the escape of John Hvasta, a naturalized United States citizen imprisoned by the Communist authorities in Prague almost four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A major shake-up in high Senate posts is certain in January, no matter which party has control. If the Republicans win control all committee chairmanships will pass from Democratic hands. If the Democrats stay in control, death, defeat and retirement have already made certain a big reshuffling of important posts.

DENVER, Aug. 8 -- John Foster Dulles of New York asserted today that Gem Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, alone could check the drift toward global war and that his Democratic opponent, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, lacked the experience, stature and demonstrated ability to make the decisions required to save our nation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Post Office Department has recommended that it be allowed to use non-scheduled airlines for the delivery of air mail when necessary.

CAIRO, Aug. 8 -- Former Premier Mustafa Naahas, the Wafdist leader, announced today that his party, Egypt's largest, was getting ready to resume the struggle to drive the British from the Nile Valley.

VIENNA, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Eight directors of Austria's biggest nationalized bank, the Creditanstalt Bankverein, were arrested by Austrian police today and charged with illegal foreign currency transactions.

TORONTO, Aug. 8 -- In its final action today, the International Red Cross Conference appealed to the Bolivian Government to restore to the Bolivian Red Cross $80,000 in funds and supplies, including relief sent from other countries such as the United States, said to have been seized by the regime of Victor Paz Estenssoro.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Bob Kuntz of Bonnie Briar eliminated J. Henry Attas of Dellwood, defending champion, by 2 up in the quarter-final round of the Westchester Amateur golf championship today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- In preparation for the forthcoming test of Britain's first atomic weapon the Admiralty demarcated today a forbidden zone of 23,500 square nautical miles off the northwest coast of Australia.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 -- Vice President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez will continue as Acting President without any new formality so long as President Laureano Gomez is unable to return to office because of his health or until the end of the Presidential term, Aug. 7, 1954, if President Gomez resigns.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has sought to increase by $2,500,000 its charges for electricity sold to the city, a move that would raise the city's 'bill 15 per cent, it was disclosed ysterday by Commissioner Dominick F. Paduano of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

When a youngster listens to a story about a child in another land whose name sounds strange but whose life and thoughts are very much like his own, that child has made a first step toward international understanding.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Charley Dominy's Independence all but clinched the Corry Trophy, emblematic of Star boat supremacy on the Great South Bay, with a second-place finish behind Bill King's Sweet Sue today. Independence needs only a ninth place in tomorrow's final race to be assured of the Great South Bay Race Week championship for Stars, and the Corry Trophy.

A Bronx housewife appealed yesterday for the return of her husband's Valentines Day gift to her that flew out a window and disappeared a little more than a week ago. The gift is easily identifiable by its rather limited vocabulary of "hello, tootsie, pretty boy, pretty baby."

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Asymmetry in line and detail runs through the Patou collection. Pin checks are so small that black and color -sapphire, red, ginger or oxford -- produce the effect of a shot fabric, especially when blurred by mohair surface.
Resident buyers have joined suppliers of both cotton and rayon textiles in advising wholesale buyers that the price basis for the fabrics is a firm one.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 8 -- Edgar Burton, Toronto layman, was elected president of the Fourth World Convention of the Churches of Christ (Disciples of Christ) at its meeting here. He succeeds the Rev. Ennis of Melbourne.

The Criminal Courts Building, from which only one prisoner had escaped since its opening in 1941, was the scene yesterday of a second successful break when a theft suspect slipped down a steel-barred inner stairway and walked out of crowded Felony Court.

A vacant plot of 20,000 square feet on the easterly side of Thirty-sixth Street, 200 feet south of Forty-eighth Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Michael Contracting Company for improvement with a one-story factory.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- There are 101 ways -- or perhaps 202 ways -- to lose a horse race. One way is for a horse to make a tardy departure from the gate. That's what George D. Widener's Battlefield, the 6-to-5 favorite did today in the six-furlong sprint that had top billing on Saratoga's program.

Nonunion garment shops that had been resisting an organizing drive by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., gave up the fight yesterday and asked the union to negotiate a contract with them.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Basil Brewer, publisher of The New Bedford Standard-Times, said today that he knew "nothing whatsoever" about any move to organize former clubs for Senator Robert A. Taft for President to support Representative John F. Kennedy, who is running for the United States Senate against Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.

A plan to free sixty miles of city streets of parked vehicles during peak rush hours, principally on major mid-Manhattan crosstown arteries, was outlined yesterday by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. The idea, if adopted, would speed up traffic by 10 per cent on these thoroughfares, Mr. Wiley said.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 8 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, today told 428 graduates at Bryant College that the leaders of Soviet Russia had spurned all American efforts toward peace, "have taken the aggressive in numerous parts of the world and have openly proclaimed that it is a life-and-death struggle between them and us."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The breaking of the drought in New England and the South, along with rains in western and southwestern portions of the Corn Belt and a promise of moisture over most of the Belt during the next several days, weakened grain futures today.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Solicitor, a speedy 4-year-old colt, raced in front all the way at Roosevelt Raceway tonight to win the $6,000 Southampton Pace.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- The Chautauqua Opera Association, which has produced seven American operas in its twenty-three-year history, added two more to its roster this evening.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Little Murry Dickson singled home the winning run in the tenth inning tonight as the Pirates captured a 1-0 decision from the Cubs. Bob Rush gave only five hits to Pittsburgh.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 8 -- Pressure on Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington to commute death sentences of Utah and Truman Wilson to life imprisonment is mounting. The brothers, who lived at Camas, Wash., were found guilty in June, 1950, at Vancouver, Wash., of kidnapping and murdering Jo Ann Dewey, 18, of Portland.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Bulgaria sent a protest to the United Nations today accusing Greece of responsibility for the trouble over the island of Gamma.

Having established himself as the nominal dictator of Iran. Premier Mossadegh has formally submitted to the British Government another offer to negotiate a settlement of the oil dispute which brought him to power and his country to bankruptcy and mob rule.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir, chairman of the Department of Child Study at Vassal College, said yesterday at the closing session of the Vassar Summer Institute that peace in the family did not mean an absence of conflicts or problems.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 8 -- A. T. Costarino and Michael Sarro, unattached, posted 37, 33 -- 70 near the close of the qualifying round today to tie Joseph Murphy and James Oleska of Shore View, 36-34, for the medal in the eighteenth annual Arthur Mann invitation best-ball tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club.

DUBLIN, Aug. 8 -- The United States finished second to the British team in the jumping competition for the Nation's Cup at the Dublin horse show tonight. The British had sixteen faults, the United States twenty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Truman directed the Civil Service Commission today to devise a plan that would merge all the existing programs for hiring or dismissing Government employes on considerations of loyalty, security and competence.

The Moore - McCormack liner Uruguay struck a submerged object 230 miles from New York yesterday morning, disabling one of her two propellers. The collision caused an "excessive vibration'' and induced the line to divert the ship to Newport News, Va., for replacement of the damaged blade.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, is expected to arrive here next Saturday with Mrs. Fisher on board the Cunard liner Media. They will remain in this country five weeks as guests in Boxford, Mass., of Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Eighty-three city residents died in June and July as a result of the excessive heat, the Department of Health reported yesterday. This compares with no fatalities in the similar period last year and five in 1950.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Production plans of the Soviet Union's two biggest Republics were fulfilled by 103 per cent or over for the second quarter of this year, according to an announcement by their statistical boards. The figures given were:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 8 -- Representative Albert A. Gore, a 44-year-old lawyer and former country school teacher, registered a thumping victory in yesterday's Democratic nominating primary over Senator Kenneth D. McKellar, 83-year-old veteran Tennessee lawmaker, on the basis of almost complete returns tabulated today.
Bus service between Queens and Rockaway Beach will be halted over the week-end because of a dispute between the Triboro Coach Company and Local 100, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
A "ham" radio station is alleviating homesickness for aviation trainees who come from abroad to the Aeronautical Center of the Civil Aeronautics Administration at Oklahoma City.

The only book issued today is "Your Opportunity to Help Yourself, to Help Others," which is being offered in two editions, $3.95 paper and $4.95 cloth. Edited and published by Theodore S. Jones, P. O. Box 41, 73 Adams Street, Milton 87, Mass., the book contains references to awards, competitions, scholarships, loans and unusual opportunities to Americans and Canadians for use in this country and abroad.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, and closing prices for active months were 23 to 61 points net lower than on Thursday.

On this day one hundred and twenty-one years ago there was great excitement in Albany and Schenectady. For on Aug. 9, 1831, the first locomotive on a New York State railway made its first run on a road constructed between the two cities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Wilson Co., third largest United States meating packer, omitted the quarterly dividend on its common stock normally declared at this time. It was the first time since 1945 that a quarterly payment was omitted. Directors took no action on the recommendation of management because of unsatisfactory earnings in the domestic meat-packing business in recent months, the company said.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, still shrewd political leader of the republic he helped found four years ago, sees no hope of peace for Korea in his coming second four-year term as President.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The United States took two singles matches in straight sets from Canada today as the final round of the North American zone Davis Cup tennis started.

The old score between Greece and Bulgaria has been aggravated since Bulgaria became an instrument of Soviet policy. Bulgaria supported the Communists in the Greek civil war, and since then numerous border industries have served to keep suspicion and ill feeling alive.

The cruel stupidity of Senator McCarran's pride and joy -- the Internal Security Act of 1950 -- is well illustrated by the story of Karl Latva. A Finnish immigrant who came to this country as a boy in 1913, Mr. Latva settled down in a New Hampshire mill town, married an American girl and had two sons, bath of whom served honorably in the Navy during the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Justice reported today an investigation had established that about 100 Canadians who entered the United States and settled in the Detroit area had obtained immigration visas through fraud.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, which has jurisdiction over price and other controls, declared decisively today against the calling by President Truman of a special session of the adjourned Eighty-second Congress to tighten economic curbs.
Joseph C. Murphy has joined United States Fabrics, Inc., to merchandise the men's and women's fabrics division.

The United States Olympic basketball team, which defeated Russia for the championship in the international games at Helsinki, arrived at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, yesterday. Also on board the fourth Pan American charter flight from Helsinki, which landed at 2:30 P. M., were the soccer team and administrative officials.

CAIRO, Aug. 8 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib said tonight it might become necessary to proclaim a dictatorship unless Egypt's political parties cleaned up the country's political life for themselves.

HONG KONG, Aug. 8 -- Communist China's large-scale military training and development program, which was launched in December, 1950, with the avowed objective of creating a "modern army, navy and air force," is still continuing on the mainland as a top priority build-up to which all other domestic considerations are being subordinated.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- Preacher Roe, ignoring a sore right side, pitched two shut-out innings in relief tonight and Andy Pafco belted a three-run homer off Curt Simmons to give the Dodgers a 6-3 victory over the Phils in ten innings.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 -- The Ministry of Foreign Trade advised Argentine tire manufacturers they will be unable to import rubber and other materials for the production of tires until next June, it was learned here today. Argentina has been importing an average of 1,800 tons of rubber a month, mostly from Singapore.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Building Inspector Jack Blumfield reported today that nearly $250,000 in building permits had been issued here in July, making Spring Valley the fastest growing village in Rockland County. But he had a problem concerning "skyscrapers."

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug 8 -- Ophir Hall, a forbidding granite mansion to whose empty turrets cling tatters of ivy and whose broad, stone-balustraded terraces and formal gardens are half hidden in a weedy jungle, is stirring with new life today.

General of the Army Omar N. Bradley and other former commanders of the First Army will be present here Monday for ceremonies marking the unit's thirty-fourth anniversary, Army spokesmen announced yesterday.

DENVER, Aug. 8 -- There was something of a flurry around Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters this morning with the belated publication of the fact that one of the Republican Presidential nominee's off-the-record visitors yesterday was Davis Merwin, a cousin of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

Plans to merge The First National Bank Trust Company of Floral Park with The Franklin National Bank of Franklin Square to create a combined Long Island institution with resources of about $140,000,000, were announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Mark-Ye-Well, winner of $128,395 this season while substituting for the ailing Hill Gail, Kentucky Derby victor, will race eight other 3-year-olds in the forty-second running of the American Derby at Washington Park tomorrow.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- It has been remarked here that, if the French were unable to increase their land forces substantially next year, the only way to provide the increased security planned by the North Atlantic Council would be to reinforce the American and British troops on this continent.

NEUROSIS, like charity, is a word that covers a multitude of sins -- especially in the literal trade Every other non- historical novel that a reviewer opens these days is sure to have some kind of neurosis as its main- spring, and the ghost of Dr. Freud is just as sure to appear in the first chapter, ready to act as both stage manager and raisonneur.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Monroe Boston Strause of San Diego, Calif., patented this week a new original and ornamental design for a meringue pie. He has the right for fourteen years to exclude all others from making, using or selling meringue pies having the same appearance as his.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

Two of the thirty-four policemen standing departmental trial on graft charges were told by Third Deputy Police Commissioner James A. Delehanty yesterday that they would be cited to the Supreme Court for contempt, This followed their refusal to take the witness stand when directed to do so by the Commissioner, a former surrogate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The retail food price index dropped 0.6 per cent from July 15 to July 28 as the result of a 4 per cent decline in fruit and vegetable prices.
The following is a round-up of hints on housekeeping that may be of use to homemakers:

Loomis J. Grossman, New York operator, has purchased the three-story department store building at 301-05 West Main Street in Durham, N. C., from the Durham Real Estate and Insurance Company of North Carolina and Kenneth T. Barnaby of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- An attempt to recover manganese in quantity from vast deposits of low-grade ores in the Cuyuna range in Minnesota will be partially underwritten by the Government, Jess Larson, head of the Defense Materails Procurement Agency, announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The White Sox tonight twice came from behind to sweep a twilight-night double-header from Detroit, 4 -- 3 and 2 -- 1, to hand the cellar-dwelling Tigers their seventy-first and seventy-second defeats. The games were witnessed by 20,648.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Monroe Boston Strause of San Diego, Calif., patented this week a new original and ornamental design for a meringue pie. He has the right for fourteen years to exclude all others from making, using or selling meringue pies having the same appearance as his.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

Two of the thirty-four policemen standing departmental trial on graft charges were told by Third Deputy Police Commissioner James A. Delehanty yesterday that they would be cited to the Supreme Court for contempt, This followed their refusal to take the witness stand when directed to do so by the Commissioner, a former surrogate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The retail food price index dropped 0.6 per cent from July 15 to July 28 as the result of a 4 per cent decline in fruit and vegetable prices.

The cultural store of this country will be enriched immeasurably when the plan for the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy moves from the drawing board and becomes a reality. The design for the establishment of such a project at Westport, Conn., began to take shape in earnest last summer when Gov. John Davis Lodge signed a bill authorizing the festival, which is to be privately endowed.
Two examples of houses "designed from the inside out" will go on view tomorrow as the model homes in a new development, Morton Village, in Plainview, L. I.
Two armed men held up the Crest Sportswear Company at 96 Throop Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday and escaped with $2,486.

Reflecting the tight money situation now prevailing, rates to brokers on call loans against securities are being raised to 2 3/4 per cent, it was learned yesterday. The rise from the 2 1/2 per cent level is the first change in the call loan rate since January of this year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A wildcat strike by foundry workers shut down production in the McCormick Works of the International Harvester Company today. Between 100 and 200 members of the left-wing Farm Equipment-United Electrical Workers Union walked out.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8 -- Delegates representing the women of eighteen American nations concluded the eighth annual conference of the Inter-American Commission of Women with the signature here tonight of a "final act" formally endorsing resolutions that call on their governments to see that full poilitical and economic equality really was granted to all women of the hemisphere.
A matter of 2 1/2 per cent stands between the world heavyweight champion, Jersey Joe Walcott, and a September title defense against Rocky Marciano, probably in Philadelphia.

Joseph Kleinman has purchased the two five-story buildings at 2112-2118 Second Avenue, containing four stores and twenty-seven apartments, from the Orma Realty Corporation, of which John DiGrigurio is president. Maurice DiMiceli was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The National Negro Opera Company will convert Washington's ball park. Griffith Stadium, into an outdoor opera house next Friday and present a cast of fifty singers, dancers and actors in Gounod's "Faust."
A timely remedy for declining sales and consumption of butter may be found in a new butter making process introduced by a Midwest dairyman, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, today attacked as irresponsible and defeatist European reports that have been dismally forecasting that North Atlantic Treaty rearmament would fall short of the goals set for this year.

Perverse weather, which has been raising havoc with the Giants most of this season, crossed the Harlem River yesterday to give the Yankees a touch of it as rain washed out the homecoming of the Bombers at the Stadium.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,336, for twenty-four hour period ended 6 A. M. Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Arrangements for speeding hay shipments into drought-stricken Kentucky and Tennessee to feed livestock were completed today. The Federal Government asked the railroads for a 50 per cent cut in freight rates on the emergency shipments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- John D. Hickerson. Assistant Secretary of State, today told the International Geographical Union that the modern science of geography could contribute much "to that stability and progress which a future of peace and justice demands."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Trailing by eight runs after two innings, the Indians hammered away at the Browns' pitchers until they tied the score in the ninth on Larry Doby's three-run homer and won in the twelfth, 10 -- 9, on Rookie Bill Glynn's home run.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Hog supplies again were scanty today smallest for a Friday since May 25, 1951, but with order buyers still out of the trading market was not more than steady to 25 cents higher. The Department of Agriculture said a quarantine at the hog yards which has prevented outgoing shipments since Tuesday will be lifted in time for Monday's trading. The Department's reports on trading today:
Four and a half million citizens are already enlisted in a national campaign to get out the vote this fall, the American Heritage Foundation reported yesterday.

RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer scored a final-round 40, 38 -- 78 over the rainsoaked Rumson Country Club course today to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's three-day Jersey Shore tournament by eight strokes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Iraq called on the United Nations General Assembly today to hold a full debate on French rule in Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Department of Defense issued today specific instances of how the steel strike had retarded arms production during July and said that the full impact of the stoppage would be felt this month and next.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The King's Cup, generally considered the yachting premier of America and which was presented to the New York Yacht Club by the late King George V of England, to be held forever by it and sailed for annually, was won by John H. Matthews' international twelve-meter sloop, Vim, in Buzzards Bay today.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 8 -- A three-hour conference at City Hall, where Jersey City officials were attempting to mediate the warehousemen's strike at the Army-leased Claremont Terminal, broke up late this afternoon without progress.
ATHENS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Greece recovered her calm today in the wake of her brief clash with border guards of Communist Bulgaria in the dispute over the tiny island of Gamma in the Evros River.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- Bishop Otto Dibelius, titular head of the German Protestant churches, who hitherto has remained neutral in East German-West German controversies, charged the Soviet Zone Government today with having hindered church operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- President Truman walked through a thunder shower at Washington Airport tonight to grasp Secretary of State Dean Acheson by the hand and congratulate him on the success of his mission to Honolulu to set up Pacific defense machinery.

The backlog of patent applications awaiting action by the Patent Office, United States Department of Commerce, at the end of the fiscal year was the lowest in six years. For the first time since 1946 there were fewer than 100,000 applications awaiting action. The year-end total was 98,138, or 13,000 less than a year ago.
BOCCHERINI: String Quartet in D major, Op. 6, No. 1; HAYDN: String Quartet in E flat, Op. 64, No. 6; Quartetto Italiano (London). Two fine works played and recorded superbly.

WE knew it was hot that morning when we started out on a five-day pack trip into Arches National Monument. But we did not know that it was the beginning of the hottest spell on record, or that early July is not usually considered a time for dudes to be riding the southeastern Utah desert.

Confusion caused by the "Buy American" amendment in the 1953 Appropriations Act has brought about virtual suspension of purchases of cotton and wool textiles by the Armed Services. The Quartermaster Corps, principal purchaser of clothing and equippage, has requested clarification by the Munitions Board of the restrictions imposed by the amendment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- Public health teams, with aerosol bombs and mobile sprayers, traversed California's Central Valley this week fighting the Culex Tarsalis mosquito in a renewed effort to stamp out encephalitis, or sleeping sickness.

TRENTON, Aug. 9 -- Archibald S. Alexander, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, charged today that the Republicans were "hoping" to deceive the voters on civil rights through their platform and other declarations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Arthur Bliss Lane, former Ambassador to Poland, tonight denounced the 1940 massacre of at least 4,100 Polish officers in Katyn Forest, near Smolensk, Russia, "when this area was controlled by the Soviet Russian authorities," as among the "most outstanding genocide crimes."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- The Army announced two years ago that it planned to build a heavy tank for the first time in the nation's history. Today the production rate is still under wraps.

JENNY LINSKY, the shy little black cat of Cat Club fame, here makes her sixth appearance, this time with a serious personal problem. Always generous and thoughtful, Jenny impulsively took two homeless wanderers, Checkers and Edward, home to Captain Tinker, who adopted them without question.

Spanish designers will make a marked contribution to the fashion field this year, David I. Nemerov, chairman of the board of directors of Russeks, predicted yesterday as he arrived at the International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, after a seven-week tour of European fashion centers.

A convoy of sixty buses began leaving New York last night with 1,700 officers and men of the Seventy-seventh Infantry (Statue of Liberty) Division, Organized Reserve Corps, for their annual summer training at Camp Drum, near Watertown.

SOMEONE has said that Harold Lamb looks like a British Army officer, and he does. Not Colonel Blimp though, but a Gary Cooper-Lawrence of Arabia officer, straight, gray-haired and slim. He has a pleasant manner, is easy to talk to and expresses his opinions moderately but firmly.

A CAREER as an X-ray technician had been Bea Perry's ambition all through high school, and she was fully prepared for the year of hard work which lay ahead of her when she enrolled in the course in radiography at Beechwood General Hospital.

INDIANAPOLIS -- Airplane noise, like Mark Twain's weather, is something that everyone talks about but nobody does much to change. Last week the twelve-man Aviation Development Advisory Committee to the Civil Aeronautics Administration went into the problem in considerable detail.

THE annual field day at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station is scheduled for Aug. 20, at the experimental farm in Mount Carmel. Field plots where experimental work is carried out will be open to the public at 10 A. M., and throughout the day.

THERE is so much talk about corruption in all phases of our society that it is difficult to appraise what has been happening. We need some perspective. We must separate symptoms from ultimate causes. Political corruption, crime, immorality, athletic scandals, the current disorders of our society, cannot be diagnosed as independent, isolated phenomena.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 9 -- Nearly all workers in the heavily industrialized areas of south and southeast Belgium began a twenty-four-hour strike this morning in protest against the two-year conscription law. The stoppage was almost complete in metal plants and coal mines.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Impatient of the Government's appeals for wage restraint, the national committee of the Amalgamated Engineering Union decided today to call for a rank-and-file poll to choose between strike action and a ban on overtime and piece work.

Two patrolmen who broke up a dice game on the West Side yesterday and made two arrests were forced to take shelter with the prisoners in a locked patrol car when an angry crowd of 200 persons surged about the vehicle. They radioed for help and five other patrol cars raced to the scene and dispersed the crowd.

ALTHOUGH it is presented in the form of a "thumbnail" historical survey of photography, the purpose of the exhibition "Then (1839) and Now (1952)," which opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art, is primarily to demonstrate the vital but little appreciated fact that there is a world of difference between imitating the work of someone else and being influenced by that work.

CHARLOTTETOWN, P. E .I. -- Prince Edward Island, the smallest of Canada's ten provinces, has long been overlooked as a vacation possibility by motorists from the States. Each year, however, more and more visitors have been discovering the tiny Garden Province, which has much to offer both scenically and recreationally.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) -- George Crowe, whose big bat terrorized pitchers in the American Association last year, was optioned today by the Braves to league-leading Milwaukee. On twenty-four-hour recall, the first baseman is due to join the Brewers tomorrow at Charleston, W. Va.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns reported the option of left-hander Frank (Stubby) Overmire to Toronto of the International League tonight.

HONOLULU, Aug. 9 -- The problems of the vast Pacific basin, containing a half-dozen civilizations and a great majority of the world's two-billion-plus population, are seldom emphasized to the extent that they were this week at the meeting of three foreign ministers intent on erecting a security set-up in the Pacific.

Although steel production is rapidly approaching its pre-strike level, clouds gathering on the labor horizon are tempering the improvement. Crop damage caused by drought in many of the states is also proving a disquieting factor in financial markets.

DUBLIN, Aug. 9 -- A proposal probably will be made to the equestrian committee of the Olympic Council that the horse events of the 1956 Olympic Games be held in Dublin and not in Melbourne. Most European countries strongly favor this move on the ground that the horses would suffer from the long voyage to Australia.

MARY BRECKINRIDGE came from a family of fighters. A report of her grandfather's bravery in the Confederate Army at the Battle of Shiloh went: "After they fit and fit again, up came John C. Breckinridge and asks the privilege of the field for an hour.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N. J., Aug. 9 -- The people of this and neighboring communities celebrated Big Sea Day today. A beauty contest was held, and 100,000 persons, defying threatening weather, lined the streets to watch a parade.

The business a manufacturer does tomorrow depends on the planning he does today. With this broad statement as a premise, a detailed planning guide to help manufacturers, distributors and retailers decide new sales and merchandising objectives has been prepared by National Sales Executives, Inc., an organization of 20,000 sales leaders who direct the activities of some 2,000,000 salesmen.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (UP) -- A large thirty-five feet deep hole suddenly opened up in the middle of a city street today, engulfing automobiles and shaking houses with a noise that sounded "like an earthquake."

THE strident call of the white peacock, the muffled roar of the lonely lion and the distant jangle of the cash register ringing up one more box of popcorn bit into the hush as the conductor lifted his baton. The curtains parted and the caged animals and the exotic birds sank drowsing into the shadows as the shirt-sleeved audience settled back for a performance by the Cincinnati Zoo Opera Company.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 9 -- Canada's 5-0 victory over the Mexican Davis Cup team -- the first time the Canadians have beaten the Mexicans -- has left a bitter taste among this country's fans. But it may serve one good purpose in the development of the game here.

IN recent years A. E. Van Vogt has abandoned the short story to write ponderous novels whose action ranges over inter-galactic vastnesses and whose protagonists are invariably routine and unattractive supermen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Army engineers have blueprints ready for quick and relatively cheap construction of new Army camps in case of all-out mobilization, a spokesman said today.

TAMPA, Fla. -- The Tampa International Airport has been dressed up by the completion of an $850,000 pastel-colored terminal building that will enable it to handle large crowds of travelers in the manner to which they are accustomed.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Gordon Guiberson's Arroz, under the expert handling of Willie Shoemaker, came from far back to capture the $10,000 added La Jolla Handicap today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9 (UP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover received the award "Engineer of the Century" from the Northwest Engineering Centennial tonight and urged the country to stimulate scientific experiment as a means of cutting down inflation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Public Health Service estimated today that about 500,000 persons are exposed annually to the danger of being bitten by rabid dogs and that about 40,000 persons have to take the costly and sometimes hazardous Pasteur anti-rabies treatment.

A substantial minority of women office workers in New York have suffered losses of real income as the result of the post-Korea inflationary price rises, data released yesterday by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics show.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Fred Marsh dropped Pinch-Hitter Luke Easter's fly in short center field with two out in the ninth inning and two runs scored to enable the Indians to beat the Browns, 7 -- 5, tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- The formal inauguration of the Schuman Plan to merge Western Europe's coal and steel will take place at Luxembourg tomorrow. The High Authority which is to administer the plan will begin on Monday to tackle the task of applying a project that has been under almost constant negotiation for two years and is considered the greatest single step yet taken toward the union of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- It now appears that Alger Hiss and "McCarthyism," and all the harshness they have separately and disparately symbolized in American life, may figure prominently in the national campaign this fall.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 9 -Maj. Elizabeth Guild has a reputation in the Air Force for being a good listener. In fact she's made quite a useful racket of a racket.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Peter J. McGuire, the father of Labor Day, was praised today for his "fighting spirit" by Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin as a monument was dedicated in Mr. McGuire's memory in Arlington Cemetery in near-by Pennsauken Township.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug., 9 -- A fleet of seventy-nine, representing fourteen classes, got in one of the best races of the Yacht Racing Association season today during the Stamford Y. C. sixty-second annual regatta. A fresh easterly of 15 and 18 knots carried the big craft thirteen and one half miles and the smaller ones six, traveling windward, leeward and windward.

THROUGH John Hersey's monumental novel, "The Wall," Americans of all faiths learned about the battle of the Warsaw ghetto in 1943, when a few thousand poorly armed desperate Jews defied the Wehrmacht for many weeks.
THERE may be critics who will find flaws in this unusual novel, even as learned astronomers find black spots in the shining sun, but this reviewer must confess herself bewitched by "The Landsmen."

STATION WPIX renewed its television franchise with Madison Square Garden last week and will televise ninety-three sports events from there during the fall and winter season beginning Oct. 26. It will pay the Garden about $250,000 for the privilege.

It is hard for import traders dealing in Chinese-style goods to gain much sympathy from Customs officials, who now have strict orders not to admit anything that might benefit Communist China.

ONE of the joys of gardening for novice or expert is the discovery of the unusual in flower or leaf. The tendency in nature toward variation in color, form or substance is followed up by the patient plant breeder in order, eventually, to give the world a new type of rose or new variety of lily.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 9 -- John Roreck and Don Cherry of the Garden City Country Club eliminated one of the co-medalist teams, Joseph Murphy and Jimmy Oleska, Shoreview, and then advanced to the semi-final round of the eighteenth annual Arthur Man invitation golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Beck Hanover, a 4-year-old gelding by Nibble Hanover owned by Charlotte Sheppard and Archie Mudge of Hanover, Pa., and handled by Johnny Simpson, scored a half-length victory over Emerson Hanover in the Greater Orlando trotting feature for $3,500 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Mark-Ye-Well, Calumet Farm's 3-year-old sensation, today walked off with the forty-second running of the American Derby at Washington Park and earned a purse of $103,325.
SARVEPALLI RADHAKRISHNAN holds a unique place in modern philosophy. Although a Hindu, he has been sufficiently impressed by the West's achievement to study not merely our work but our thought.

New progress in the movement to obtain relief from double taxation on international trade and foreign investments was reported last week by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Office of Education announced today that 100 British teachers would arrive in New York Monday and Tuesday to exchange positions with 100 American teachers for the next school year.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 9 (AP) -- First-seeded Julia Sampson of San Marino, Calif., rallied today to defeat unseeded Linda Mitchell of San Diego, Calif., 8 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, for the Eastern grass court junior girls' championship at the Nassau Country Club.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (UP) -- A 28-year-old Navy veteran who "died" for fifteen minutes last year was home from the hospital today, apparently reliving his teen-age years.
TRENTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Word has come from Denver that New Jersey Republicans will carry the hall on civil rights for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -The Government revealed today -as John L. Lewis, United Mine Workers president, framed new contract demands on the soft coal industry -- that mine employment was at the lowest point in thirteen years.

The Citizens Traffic Safety Board, organized July 30 to combat traffic accidents and traffic congestion in the city, announced yesterday that its drive to raise $250,000 for a three-year program had started to attract aid from small business men.
PARIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- France took a 21-to-12 lead over Japan today after the first day's competition in a two-day post Olympics swimming meet.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 9 -- A campaign has begun throughout Middlesex County to recruit 15,000 women to serve on an auxiliary for the Middlesex County Polio Hospital wing being built in North Brunswick.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- From the Gulf of Mexico to the forests of Maine during the past two months pastures have dried up and corn, cotton, tobacco and other crops have withered in the fields as clouds refused to release their rain and a pitiless sun beat down.

Cesium teletherapy, a cheaper and safer method now being developed for cancer treatment, will be a real advance in medicine, Dean W. C. Davison of the Duke University Medical School predicts. Duke is one of some thirty Southern universities which will sponsor a $100,000 research project in the Atomic Energy Commission's Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies to perfect cesium teletherapy in the treatment of cancer.

BOTH the admirers and the detractors of the current blood-bosoms-and-brandy school of fictional private detectives trace such capers back to Dashiell Hammett; and Mr. Hammett is alternately praised for re-creating the detective story or damned for destroying it.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell said today that his surprise selection as chairman of the Democratic National Committee left him in a "state of shock."

AFTER fifty-eight years of activity as a national organization, the Society of Philatelic Americans, with 4,500 members, will hold an annual convention this week in New York for the first time. The Hotel Astor will be the scene from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday and noon to 6 P. M. on Sunday.

NEWYORT, R. I. Aug. 9 -- House guests have started arriving for tennis week, which will see leading national and foreign net stars appearing in the Casino's thirty-third annual invitation tournament. OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 9 -Many records were established at Monmouth Park today as the forty-nine-day meeting came to a close. WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A former fellow prisoner of John Hvasta, the young American reported to have escaped from a Czechoslovak prison last January, said today that in the first months of servitude the Hillside, N. J., man believed the United States Government would be able to obtain his freedom.

THE publishers' new catalogues are now on their way to booksellers and the ad agencies are preparing their campaigns on the fall books. NEW kitchen equipment arriving in the stores during the late summer and early fall will be confined to small pieces for the most part. The steel shortage resulting from the long strike is limiting the manufacture of large appliances; available stocks of certain items were cleaned out some weeks ago.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 9 -- On the last squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise today from Buzzards Bay, forty sailing craft had their finest racing. It was twenty-four miles down the long bay, through Quicks Hole, separating Pasque and Nashawena Islands of the Elizabeth string, then through Vineyard Sound to West Chop on the jaw of Vineyard Haven.

HANOI, Indo-China, Aug. 9 -- (AP) -- A young woman who is a French Army captain, doctor and helicopter pilot is rolling up quite a record in the war against the Communist-led Vietminh in northern Indo-China.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Statistics compiled by the Massachu setts State Planning Board show that industrial activity in Massachusetts in June was 4 per cent below a year ago. Factory employment for that month was 6.2 per cent below June, 1951. Because of the steel strike the July figures and probably the August figures will be worse comparatively than were the figures for June.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 -- Steel operations snapped back in the Cleveland-Lorain area this week from about 36 per cent capacity to 94 per cent, and 100 per cent or better operations are generally expected next week. However, for lack of steel, the American Steel and Wire Company will close certain departments next week, idling about 4,000 workers.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- America's Olympic athletes, led by Charley Moore and their mile relay team, whirled through a slashing rain today to better two world records and capture fifteen of nineteen events in the British track and field games in White City Stadium.
ALAMOSA, Col. -- These are the days when most of Colorado's clear air is made hideous by the tom-toms of tourism. But not in the San Luis Valley.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of Thomas A. Edison's invention of the phonograph will be commemorated Tuesday by an outdoor concert of early recordings. The concert will be held from noon to 2 P. M. at Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library at Forty-second street and Fifth Avenue.

THIS summer tens of thousands of persons will be driving to Mount Rushmore in South Dakota to gaze in awesome wonder at the gigantic heads of Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt which Gutzon Borglum carved out of a mountain peak, a mile in the sky.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 8 -- Idle tonnage lately has become noticeable in the principal Scandinavian ports such as Cophenhagen, Oslo and Goeteborg. The reason is falling freight rates which make it uneconomical for the owners to operate, particularly coal burning ships.

WHEN Brigham Young encouraged the building of this mountain - desert town in the late Eighteen Sixties, the pioneering Mormons could not have foreseen that a town dedicated to spreading the Gospel among the Piute Indians would one day become the hub of Hollywood's production of outdoor films.

Some persons are considered employed, even though they are out of work, by the Department of Commerce in its compilation of total employment of the nation. This was indicated in its report of a slight decrease in the working force in the month ended July 12, despite a nation-wide steel strike at the time.
Nearly two-thirds of America's breadwinners have taken steps to provide themselves and their families with weekly indemnity benefits should injury or illness prevent them temporarily...

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9 -- Midshipmen from fifty-two colleges and universities, along with faculty members from six of them, have begun arriving here to join ships making the third and last 1952 summer training cruise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Truman today signed an Executive Order turning over to the State Department the task of liquidating the Displaced Persons Commission.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Buba Church received credit for his fourth victory of the season tonight as the Reds rallied to rout the Cardinals, 12 to 3. Rain delayed the game for one hour and ten minutes at the end of the fifth inning.

VERIFIABLE evidence on China is hard to come by, but from all the indications it is already possible to make some generalizations about the nature and durability of the Communist regime. It may be ventured that failing a third world war, which will deflect the course of every country, the Communist regime is not likely to be any more lasting than those that preceded it since the monarchy fell in 1911.

A SUCCESS story that has made automotive history will be unfolded on the fiftieth anniversary of the Ford Motor Company, founded in 1903 by Henry Ford. Arrangements are under way to celebrate a half century of existence next year.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,337 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Sunday, Korean time.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- World trade climbed to a record height in 1951 despite the steady decline of commerce between the Communist powers and the rest of the nations.
BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- Rising tax rates, impelled by increased costs of operation and higher municipal salaries, are vexing reform city governments here and in Cambridge.

NOT long ago one of the suave young men around Chancellor Adenauer remarked that General Guderian, the author of "Panzer Leader,'' should be put in jail. He had not read the book. His remark reflected both the propensity of the Germans for putting people in jail without due process of law and the distaste felt for both Guderian and his book by the present regime in Germany.

THESE valuable studies dealing with deviate behavior in childhood emphasize the use of arts in the diagnosis and treatment of problem children. Edited by the chief of the Children's Psychiatric Division at Bellevue, the volume contains much that was originally published in separate papers and has long been out of print.

IN order to lure recalcitrant members of the early-to-bed set to theatre box offices, managements of most Broadway attractions have agreed to raise their curtains at 7 P. M. on Monday evenings, beginning on Sept. 8. Although there were few dissenters when the managers, in solemn conclave, decided on the early curtain time, the experiment is being regarded by some of the producers with a "let's wait and see" attitude.
LONDON'S interest in dance, which permits this city to have a year-round dance season, is taken for granted by the Londoner. An overseas observer is no less than overwhelmed by it.

THIS third novel by Wilbur Daniel Steele is considerably less entertaining than his first, "That Girl From Memphis," and more contrived than his second, "Diamond Wedding." It is definitely inferior to the short stories which made him, during the Twenties and Thirties, one of the most celebrated American tellers of tales.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Charley Dominy's Independence of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club won the Corry Trophy, emblematic of Great South Bay star boat supremacy, with points to spare, finishing second in today's finale behind Jack Danes' Pursuit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Defense department identified today 160 more casualties of the Korean war, including 30 killed in action, 105 wounded, 17 injured and 8 missing in action. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

There is no balm, no healing unguent, quite like rain after deep drought. Not the slashing rain of a thunder shower but slow, steady rain that falls from a sunless sky, rain that starts before dawn and continues for hours, with only an occasional let-up. Rain that washes the leaves and soaks down under the dust and cools and refreshes the earth and all things thereon.

IN his position as president of the National Concert and Artists Corporation, Marks Levine hears a lot about the state of music throughout the country. But this summer he decided to get out and see for himself what was happening.

IT'S harvest time in the herb garden. Flavor and fragrance reach the point of greatest intensity and foliage is likely to be fullest just before blossoms appear. And that brief period, which many herbs have now attained, is the best time to gather herbs for drying.

Top style news for the fall are costumes combining fabrics of two unrelated textures in dress and jacket. It may be that the little topper is of tweed, while the dress is of sheer wool or flannel. Again the fashion team may be composed of a nubby poodle cloth and a wool jersey.

IT is a strange impatience we exhibit when we remark of a writer that he has nothing new to say. Yet it is one of the commonest complaints of criticism. Most frequently, I think, you will find that accusation leveled against poets, though novelists are sometimes belabored in the same manner.

News comes from Niagara Falls, N. Y., of the development of a fiber which can stand a temperature of 2,300 degrees F., does not soften under 3,000 degrees F., and consists of aluminum oxide and silicon carbon. In gas turbines and jet engines materials are needed that can withstand intense heat.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 9 -- settlement of the Saar question in Germany's favor is the key to better relations between West Germany and France, according to Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany.

Education's stake in the 1952 Presidential campaign is represented by the controversial issue of Federal aid to schools and colleges. The problem, arising out of the strained financial position of the country's educational institutions, is widely acknowledged, but the solution is subject to various shadings of opinion, both among educators and within the political parties.

EASTVIEW, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- A bitter fight to the finish is brewing against commercialization here of the Saw Mill River Valley, an area of broad fields, lush woods, sprawling estates and secluded homes thirty miles from Manhatton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Turning on the light, the television set, the refrigerator, the toaster and the waffle iron cost the average American householder a penny more last year. But the typical electric bill is still about the lowest it has ever been.

AMONG the cimicifugas, or bugbanes, there are two species that can be used to good advantage in the perennial garden when a plant of considerable height is desired. The native Cimicifuga racemosa, commonly known as black snakeroot or black cohosh, is one.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Planned expenditures for industrial expansion in the Chicago area announced during July rose to a new monthly high mark for the year, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The total for the month was $32,237,000. The figure was more than double the $13,826,000 announced in the previous July.

PAUL SMITHS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- In the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's-in-the-Wilderness today at noon, Miss Emily Elliott Seaman, daughter of Mrs. Howard Lobdell Seaman of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Seaman, was married to William Scholl Nagle, son of Mrs. Walter Nagle of Havertown, Pa., and the late Mr. Nagle.

Which is the greater menace -- that all Government workers are unjustly accused of the corruption and communism of a few; or that a few corrupt and communistic Government workers were able to sell out China to communism?

August is usually the dog-day month in a Presidential campaign -- a stretch of dead air between the tumult of the July conventions and the tooting of the "Victory Specials" getting under way around Labor Day.

AN impressively successful integration of thoughtful science fiction with an expertly constructed espionage melodrama is the achievement of this first novel. The science fiction element of Cyril Kornbluth's story is a projection of America as it could be not too many years from right now.

MUSKEGON, Mich. -- A visit to western Michigan's summer vacation country quickly becomes an exciting journey of discovery; there's so much more here than one expected. For one thing, scenery. Michigan's great timberlands were cut over long ago, but the green woods seem to crowd closer on the horizon, and every little town has its majestic oaks and elms lining the side streets and forming a cool arch overhead.

Bloomingdale Brothers, a leading Manhattan department store, will build a branch on a seven-acre site in Stamford, Conn., designed to serve the 75,000 residents of that city and the 200,000 of the trading area surrounding it.

DALLAS, Aug. 9 -- Non-farm employment may set a new all-time record in Texas this month if the present rate of hiring continues, Texas Employment Commission officials said this week. Employment in Texas during June, excluding farm workers, reached 2,598,400, the commission reported.

IN this wise and sensitive young novel the author of the much-loved "Roommates" follows the lives of happy-go-lucky Debbie and subtle, sophisticated Rachelle. Debbie is older now and responsible enough to take a summer job as a waitress in a Cape Cod restaurant.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 -- With full military honors normally accorded only to a President who dies in office, the body of Ssnora Eva Peron was taken today on the first part of a triangular route to her final resting place. The body of the Senora, who died a fortnight ago, was taken to the National Congress Building, where it will lie in state another twenty-four hours.

Dick Gernert and Dom DiMaggio clipped Johnny Sain for tenth-inning home runs to give the Red Sox a 3-1 victory over the Yankees before 34,277 spectators at the Stadium yesterday. Four-baggers accounted for all the Boston runs, Faye Throneberry having connected against Vic Raschi in the third.

OMITTING cancer, diseases in which emotional tension plays a leading role now kill more people than any other cause, besides making more people ill. Psychosomatic medicine has become an important field, therefore, although still shamefully neglected in the education of physicians, new and old.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- There must be something in the very association with the Dodgers which has a deleterious aftermath where the Giants are concerned. At least, Leo Durocher was convinced of this tonight. For his Giants suffered another jolt to their pennant hopes at Braves Field today as the left-handed Warren Spahn baffled the champions, 2 to 0, the doleful tally with which Max Surkont blanked them last night.

THE small fruits which may be grown in any home garden reach their harvest peak in midsummer when blueberries, raspberries and blackberries ripen. There may even be a few everbearing strawberries to pick. All of these fruits as well as rhubarb, currants, gooseberries and grapes are permanent crops.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 -- The United States won the North American zone Davis Cup tennis championship today when Vic Seixas and Herb Flam defeated the Canadian doubles team of Brendan Macken and Lorne Main, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

OGDEN, Utah, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Utah's farmboy heavyweight, Rex Layne, now holding decisions over the former champion, Ezzard Charles, and the titleholder. Jersey Joe Walcott, demanded a shot at the crown today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 9 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois declared today that the Democratic Administration had been "a little careless" about appropriations.

The letter of Robert W. Damino published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES expresses astonishment at "the apathy of the public toward medical research." The relatively low expenditure of the Government for the support of medical research is indeed pitiful, particularly in this rich country, where $221,000,000 is being spent in one year on chewing gum and over one billion dollars on television sets.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Lew Worsham, 1947 United States open golf champion, posted a 5-under-par 67 today for a pace-setting 203 at the fifty-four-hole mark of the $90,000 "World" tourney.

I should like to comment on Sam Boal's excellent article, "New Departures in Old Dublin" (July 27). During my brief stay in that great city of the old sod about a month ago, it seemed to me that the Irish did not consider their great problem so much "to get the British out" as to get rid of English (not the people, but the very language. * * *

Nearly 150 chess players from twenty-five nations assembled yesterday for a preliminary session of the biennial tournament for the team championship sponsored by the International Chess Federation at the Kauppakorkeakoulu Auditorium, according to a report from Helsinki.

THE pursers at M.-G.-M., theatre owners in several key cities throughout the country and the august entrepreneurs of the Radio City Music Hall are laving their hands in glee over the record public response to "Ivanhoe."

Volume in department stores failed to pick up from the sluggish levels of the previous week, and trade observers estimated the decline from 1951 at about 11 percent. There was considerable rain during the week and this, coupled with continued excessive warmth, was said to have kept customers from buying.

UNTIL recently the humorist was one of many human tinkers who, dissatisfied with his species, was forever attempting to improve the product. The right to vote is one of the most precious rights of citizenship for free men. Yet it is one of the privileges and responsibilities too little exercised in our country. The percentage of eligible voters who go to the polls has been falling rather than rising, a fact that should shame and stir us to action.

Your editorial on the inequities of the passport situation, printed on July 31, must receive the approbation of scores of citizens who have had difficulties with the Passport Bureau. It is generally assumed that the refusal of passports is the principal wrong in question. The refusal of passports is, for the reason your editorial indicates, a very great evil, and a violation of fundamental rights, as the court decision indicates.

HONOLULU -- The hottest attraction in all the Hawaiian Islands today is the erupting of the Kilauea crater on the island of Hawaii. Since the eruption began, just in time for the arrival of summer tourists, more than 100,000 people have come to witness this spectacular sight.

A further step in the making of an all-over Pacific security policy was taken during the past week in the top-level conference in Honolulu among Australia, New Zealand and the United States. The mechanical object in this conference was simple. Its purpose was to set into motion the implementation of the tripartite ANZUS defense pact.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 -- The theory and practice of "military pressure" ruled the stage in Korea this week as the United Nations sought -- on at least so the Communists charged -- to apply a powerful lever to the lagging armistice conversations at Panmunjom, again in recess and seemingly as tightly deadlocked as ever over the question of prisoner exchange.

I wish to register a forcible protest against the gratuitous judgment made by James Reston (a man whom I have always admired professionally) in his statement in THE TIMES of July 27. In his article comparing Gov. Adlai Stevenson to General Eisenhower, Mr. Reston wrote: "He [Stevenson] is not regarded as a good administrator out here * * *."
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 9 -- The horse show piazza of the Casino was the gathering spot of the summer colony this afternoon for a fashion show held for the benefit of the Newport Hospital.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 9 -Bob Faris, 31-year-old pilot from Wichita, Kan., flew 1,400 miles from Wichita to Montpelier today in just half a minute under 12 hours to set a new nonstop distance record for very light planes.

THE British have always, and with good reason, been proud of their recording technicians. British shellac disks have been synonomous with quality ever since the introduction of the electrical process, a generation ago.

SINCE the announcement of the development of Krilium by the Monsanto Chemical Company at the December, 1951, meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, newspapers and magazines have been filled with advertisements for an array of new products known as "soil conditioners.''

THE relative importance of Hollywood and New York as program production centers for television again is in the news. The latest flurry of interest was occasioned by the optimistic predictions of Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet that thanks to the cooperation of city officials, New York would retain its position of commanding importance in TV.

Retailers in the wholesale market here last week were extremely optimistic about business during the third quarter, McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office, reported. Many reorders were received for fur-trimmed and untrimmed coats in misses and junior sizes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, deeply concerned with developments in the Middle East, especially in Iran, is expected to call meetings early next week to discuss the situation there.

Like vitamins, tablets for colds and the newer injections for various ills, a new product has appeared on the American horizon that has created as great a stir as those older remedies. It's chlorophyll.

THE entire action of Margaret H. Freydberg's novel takes place on the day after the heroine's wedding. Miss Freydberg's project is an interesting one. She endeavors to analyze the girl's state of mind both in relation to her husband and to her family.

ROME, Aug. 8 -- Seven thousand workmen at Ansaldo shipyard, in Sestri Ponente, near Genoa, are feverishly at work outfitting the new Italian 27,500-ton liner Andrea Doria. She is due to be turned over to her owners, the Italia Shipping Line, at the end of November, and is scheduled to sail for New York on her maiden voyage Dec. 14.

This was the situation in Korea last week: Truce negotiations -- stalemated. Military activity -- increasingly sharp. The pattern has been emerging more and more clearly for several weeks. As the impasse at Panmunjom has deepened, the U. N. has sought to step up military pressure in an effort to break it.

ONE of the beguiling perversities of this world is that you can fly to South America from the Explorers Club in West Seventy-second Street in hours, then spend months pushing 300 miles into country never before honored by the presence of a white man.

WELLS were once an accepted part of all dooryards. Although comparatively few homes rely on wells nowadays, a wellhead pool can be most appropriate. It is somewhat rare, but a good solution to the problem of a pool in many gardens.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- An official account of the chief characteristics of the so-called nerve or "madness" group of gases derived from organic phosphorous and fluorine compounds was published in the British Medical Journal this week at the request of the Chemical Defense Advisory Board.

AS of press time -- with no knowing what the ensuring hours may have brought forth -- the newest jobs Robert Moses has are chairman of Mayor Impellitteri's special six-man committee to investigate the fire hazard in New York's old tenements and chairman of the Mayor's committee on Staten Island transit.
