Now, as a Dubliner born and bred and but a few years estranged, I must point out a few errors to your scribe, although I concede that he has every right to his opinion about the place.

EXCEPT in the peripheral matters of our national pastime, "Baseball Complete" isn't complete. There are chapters on temperament, myths, managers, umpires, handicapped players, versatile ones. The gimmick is doubtlessly amusing.

The last leg of an air tour of the United States for 111 aviation students from fifteen foreign nations ended last night at the Astor Hotel, where the youths assembled after visiting different sections of the country.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -About 20,000,000 Indian peasants are suffering acute distress because of crop failures in Madras, Bengal, Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan States, according to reports reaching here.

A surprisingly large number of children -- perhaps 7,000,000 of the nation's 26,000,000 grade school pupils -- have difficulty learning to read, according to William Kottmeyer, director of the St. Louis Public School Reading Clinic. This does not mean that these youngsters are not as intelligent as those who can read well, the educator points out.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 9 -- William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York, who is nearing the end of his second year as Ambassador to Mexico, is probably the most controversial figure to represent the United States here since Henry Lane Wilson was intriguing against President Madero forty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -The pattern of a foreign-vs.-domestic policy battle was outlined sharply today for the fall Presidential campaign.
Thefts of single packages, in the mass, take an even greater toll of truckers and shippers than the hijacking aggregate of truck cargoes, according to figures released yesterday.

A 22-year-old housewife and a man companion were stabbed by the woman's husband while the two sat in the balcony of the New Amsterdam Theatre, 214 West Forty-second Street, Friday night, the police reported yesterday in Felony Court.
Marcus B. Harrelson, 26 years old, died at 3:30 A. M. yesterday of a shot fired by one of two youths who had rung the door bell of his apartment at 127 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, at 11 P. M. Friday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Bob Kuntz of Bonnie Briar, who eliminated the defending champion, J. Henry Attas, yesterday, became Attas' successor today by winning the Westchester amateur golf title.

Hoboken industrial interests questioned yesterday a charge made earlier in the week by the National Association of Manufacturers to the effect that Government control since World War I of a number of local piers had cost each person in that city $360.

VISITING Manhattan for the opening of his latest directorial stint, "Sudden Fear," at Loew's State, David Miller was equally enthusiastic over plans for his first independent production, which he intends to activate late this year in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A Republican move to squeeze Senator Blair Moody of Michigan off the key Senate Banking Committee in the event a special session of Congress is called, came to light today.

EVER since communism was established in Russia some Western democrats have had a somewhat uneasy feeling that communism, unlike racist and other forms of totalitarianism, is a kind of democracy gone wrong, that it has roots in common with ours, that it is a democratic heresy rather than a totally different set of beliefs.

The decline in world trade is reflected in a report of Customs receipts in the Port of New York released here yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port. The statistics show that receipts during the first six months of this year were nearly $15,000,000 less than in the last six months of 1951.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UP) -- Representative Frank L. Chelf selected today a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to boss his subcommittee's investigation of the Department of Justice. He said hearings on a code of ethics for Government attorneys would be the subcommittee's next move.

THE ingredients that go to make a best seller today are combined in this massive novel: digestible religion, a sweeping sense of history, clear parallels between the ancient and modern world, and a moderately strong dash of sex.

UP at a summer play school being conducted on Manhattan's West Side a group of youngsters last month kept very busy building a "jeep" out of plywood pieces. A bicycle wheel made the steering gear; two tin cans -- painted red -- were fastened strategically to simulate headlights; a real automobile horn made satisfyingly loud noises when pushed.

PARIS. IT is probably no exaggeration to say that the future of Europe depends on the success of nine men in controlling, in the next few months, a piece of real estate no bigger than metropolitan New York. This real estate is the Ruhr Valley, the heart of Germany's industrial might.

OPENING leads against slam bids are a subject (or perhaps an art) all to themselves. Not only do they present unique problems, but they are subject to subdivision, leads against trump slams being different from leads against no-trump slams.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company gave its 30,000 workers a 10-cent hourly pay increase tonight, subject to approval by the Wage Stabilization Board.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 9 -The Democratic nominee for the Presidency, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, believes there can be a substantial reduction in the annual cost of rearmament by July 1, 1954.

President Truman is expected to act in the near future on recommendations by the Tariff Commission which are said to favor increased protection for American watchmakers against their Swiss competitors. If he accepts the Commission's proposals, as The Washington Post points out, "he will have to eat many of his fine words" dealing with the general subject of restriction of trade practices.

In addressing the opening session of the current assembly of the International Geographical Union on Friday, Assistant Secretary of State Hickerson observed that the geographers and their field of study could make a substantial contribution to world stability, progress and peace. He noted geography's concern with factors that affect industrial development, use and conservation of resources and relations between geographic boundaries and ethnic groupings.

FACED with the problem of giving advice on how to keep vegetables garden fresh when they are destined to travel farther than the home kitchen after being picked. I turned to the genial friend of my childhood, Phillip Batt of Piermont, N. Y. Erstwhile grocer and butcher, Mr. Batt has grown everything from artichokes to sweet potatoes in his own garden.

DRESSED up with Technicolor, "The Jazz Singer," which, twenty-five years ago, demonstrated to a skeptical public that motion picture actors could be heard as well as seen, once again is taking cinematic form under the sponsorship of Warner Brothers.

MEN have looked up into the heavens ever since there were men -- and wondered. In the past two weeks their wonderment about the wide blue yonder has been increased by the reports of mysterious objects "sighted" over Washington. What lies above the fluffy clouds overhead? How high is the sky? Is the air all of one piece?

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 --Brazil has dropped motion pictures from the list of "essential" imports for which import licenses will be granted. United States newsreels ceased coming in here seven months ago, and this new move, if unchanged, will mean the complete disappearance of United States films from Brazilian screens.
A new champion will be crowned in the eighth annual tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association which gets under way at the Apawamis Club tomorrow. Competition will end on Friday.

An undertaker's fire extinguisher, a grocer's soda pop cooler, a chemistry teacher's hot water heating system and a housewife's water jug are helping provide University of Chicago scientists with samples of "middle-aged" water, badly needed for nuclear research.

THE other day Rogers Hornsby, in a brief, outspoken inaugural address that could be used in a lot of places as a model of simplicity, told the players he was about to manage for the Reds what he expected of them, what they were to expect of him.

Not a single space ship has been built, yet the rocketeers or astronauts are already resenting their confinement to the solar system. They are worrying about the survival of the human race if the sun should be blotted out and life with it. Accordingly, one of them, Dr. L. R. Sheppard, recently examined the possibilities of colonizing other stellar systems.
DENVER, Aug. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower urged higher old-age assistance payments and expanded Social Security coverage today for every worker in America.

TOURISTS heading for the Southwest can now ride from St. Louis to the heart of Texas in dome cars. Coaches of this popular type were recently added to the consist of the Missouri Pacific's streamlined Texas Eagles, which link San Antonio, Austin, Dallas and Fort Worth.
CHRISTMAS COVE, Me., Aug. 9 (AP) -- A freckle-faced lad from the crowded pavements of the world's biggest city got his first taste of Maine tonight -- and he liked it.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Hugh Gaitskell, who was Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Labor Government, warned today of the danger of reducing Britain's defense commitment without consultation with Britain's Allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
THE present emphasis on texture in design of decorative fabrics, carpets, wallpapers and pottery has reached tile.

THE "best of the year" collections of science fiction shorts as annually assembled by Messrs. Bleiler and Dikty have served as models of taste and keen awareness of trends in the field. However, by their own or any other standards this latest Bleiler - Dikty anthology is a most inferior product.

IT is impossible for anyone living in the midst of a cultural period to say with certainty why it is languishing in its produce and general vitality. This is especially true of the theatre, where we tend to compare our usually vapid present with "Chekhov's" period, or "Ibsen's," or our own previous decades, much to our disadvantage, forgetting that the giants usually stood alone in their time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -Three tax service career men, all lawyers, and the oldest of them 44 years old, were named Assistant Commissioners of Internal Revenue in a reorganization of the service's headquarters here today. They will be sworn in Monday for duties substantially like those they were performing under the old set-up.

John Boone, 31 years old, of 4 St. Paul's Place, the Bronx, was stabbed and beaten to death at 1:45 P. M. yesterday in a street brawl at 170th Street and Brook Avenue, the Bronx. Two hours later, Forest Dennis, 31, of 1222 Brook Avenue, was shot and critically wounded by Patrolman Richard Austin, who, with Sgt. Isidore Winter, had been combing the area for participants in the brawl.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Aug. 9 (AP) -Harry E. P. Meislahn of Albany today sailed his Sunbeam II to the second straight championship of the twelfth district, International Star Class Yacht Racing Association.

ABBY FITCH-MARTIN died in 1937, mourned by Whitesboro neighbors as a God-fearing woman. Actually, the sadistic old hypocrite had spent decades crippling the lives of the members of her household. Last of a Puritan clan that for 200 years and eight prosperous generations had intermarried, the race proud spinster claimed sole right to the Fitch-Martin name and fortune.

Balanced against the discouraging news that last week poliomyelitis reached a national high incidence record for this time of year is the fact that the incidence here in New York, though above that of corresponding periods in 1950 and 1951, is far below the incidence of the 1949 peak epidemic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Truman today named Vernon D. Northrop, a veteran in Federal Government service, to be Under Secretary of the Interior.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Aug. 9 -- A major historical mystery with roots in antiquity is being examined with scholarly zeal these summer days in a book-lined study in this quiet Fairfield County town.

They do this in no derogation of his standing as one of radio's most popular news commentators but in recognition of the fact that his scripts are, for the most part, polished literary gems.

THE statue of the title was a gift from a flighty former resident of the "guest house" of Sainte Marie des Anges, conducted by French nuns in Gloucestershire. This curious thirteenth-century carving purported to be that of an obscure saint, Hugo Castellat:

Courses in psychology should be offered by every high school in the country to help American teen-agers become emotionally mature and responsible citizens, according to a report on a workshop sponsored by the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation of Teachers College, Columbia University.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -King Tribhubana of Nepal, who, until a year and a half ago, had been a lifelong virtual prisoner in his palace, has taken over full governing powers in his strategic buffer state in the Himalayas between India and Communist-dominated Tibet.

TAKE seventy-five accordions, all playing fortissimo in a different key. Add a generous assortment of Hammond organs, pianos, electrically amplified Hawaiian guitars, slap-bass violins, gongs, tom-toms, cymbals, castanets and tambourines.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Rookies Jim Waugh and Brandy Davis, fresh from the minors, teamed today to help the Pirates gain a 4-3 victory over the Cubs.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Baltimore Sunpapers came out tonight for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican candidate for President.

THE "shirtsleeve" in the title apparently has several connotations -- informality, a down-to-earth non-technical approach to economics, and a willingness of its author to do battle with all who may differ with his own opinions.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 11 -- United Nations and Communist truce delegates met for thirty-five minutes today, and then called off the conferences for another week when neither side had a new proposal to offer on an exchange of Korean war prisoners.

The Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, returned to his pulpit yesterday after a six-week exchange preaching assignment in England.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- The concluding concerts of the 1952 Berkshire Music Festival this afternoon and last night had rare impressiveness. This afternoon's program was devoted to the Berlioz Requiem, "The Grand Mass for the Dead," which, interpreted as it was by Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, assisted by the Berkshire Festival Chorus and Andrew McKinley tenor, had an overwhelming effect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged its affiliates today to invite foreign workers in this country on Government-sponsored trips to visit C. I. O. unions and "see how we live."

SEATTLE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The heart beat of a small but maddened whale thrashing about with two harpoons in its flanks has been recorded on an electrocardiogram. The recording made from a beluga (white) whale was similar to those made from elephants and humans but more nearly resembled that of an elephant.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Usually reliable sources said today that Jordan's ailing King Talal would abdicate within the next forty-eight hours.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- The Berlin-Brandenburg synod of the German Evangelical Church urged the East German Government today to ease its restrictions on church activities and at the same time asked the great powers to abandon their armament race.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1.338, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Migratory birds have been indicted by British scientists on a charge of carrying hoof-and-mouth disease from the European Continent to this country.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- A rousing musical performance with an American accent was given here tonight in Europe's newest concert hall by the 115 members of the United States Army Field Band, now on its first European tour.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the nation's leading money winner, and Julius Boros, the 1952 National open champion, tied at 276 -- 12 under par -- today in the $90,000 "World" golf championship at Tam O'Shanter and will enter the richest play-off in links history tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Sweden will not place before the United Nations the matter of the destruction of two Swedish planes in the Baltic Sea last June 16, Foreign Minister Oesten Unden declared today.
Real etate sales by the Board of Transportation in the last five and one-half years have enriched the city treasury by $6,479,200.
SEATTLE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Wild Bill Cantrell, badly burned when the Such Crust IV exploded during yesterday's running of the Gold Cup speed-boat race, is recovering at a local hospital.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Fanny Blankers-Koen of the Netherlands, once the fastest woman in the world, closed her sports career in defeat today as United States athletes dominated the track-and-field meet.
VIENNA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Austrian Government will maintain Nazi amnesty laws despite the United States' protests, Interior Secretary Ferdinand Graf said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 10 -- Israel and the United States have reached an agreement by which American investors in Israel may get guarantees from the United States Government of currency convertibility and protection against losses from expropriation or confiscation.
PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- France today completed a 41-29 victory over Japan in a post-Olympics swim meet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- World War II veterans who bought Government life insurance received protection at bargain prices, Veterans Administration officials said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- A survey of the pattern of prolonged non-occupational illness among industrial employes and its effect on the national economy is being conducted by the Research Council for Economic Security.
The New York Puerto Rican Scholarship Fund, Inc., an agency of the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs, announced yesterday ten scholarship awards for 1952-53.

MANILA, Monday, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of Defense Ramon Magsaysay returned to Manila last night and reported to President Elpidio Quirino that he had directed the full strength of the Sulu task force, including planes, artillery and 2,000 men and a naval contingent, against the Moro outlaw chieftain Hadji Kamlon on Jolo Island.

SOMERSET, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Treasure hunters sifting through the debris-littered mountain farm where Samuel Jackson King lived and died said today their search for cash, bonds and bank books was about completed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley warned today that in seeking world peace this nation had no other choice than to build and maintain "military power commensurate with our world responsibility."

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- Chuchi Ohashi, who was Japan's Vice Foreign Minister until five months before Pearl Harbor, denounced the late President Roosevelt today as a "war criminal" who had lured Japan into the Pacific war. The criticism appeared in the issue of the Japanese magazine Hanashi (Story) that came out today.

When General Motors, in 1948, introduced for the first time in a wage contract with the U. A. W. the concept of an annual wage increment geared to the "normal" increase in the nation's productivity the innovation aroused a good deal of discussion, and some controversy, among experts in industrial management and labor relations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 -- Brazil is facing a money crisis more serious than most persons here seem to realize. With no solution yet in sight, it threatens to affect the whole daily life of the country because the Brazilian economy is heavily dependent on imports of petroleum products and wheat, for which hard currency is necessary.

Cotton prices in the domestic market showed considerable strength last week, but lost a good portion of their gains in the final trading session on Friday. At their best levels of the week active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 88 to 147 points.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- It has surprised many observers that at the very height of the holiday season the stock markets last week have experienced satisfactory expansion in business and a very fair advance in security values.

In what was described as one of the largest realty transactions in recent years in the Chicago area, a New York syndicate headed by Louis J. Glickman has obtained control of the well-known State-Madison Building at the northwest corner of State and Madison Streets there.

Advertising, promotion, research and planning departments of National Broadcasting Company's radio and television networks will hereafter be combined, Ruddick C. Lawrence, director of promotion, planning and development, announced yesterday.

The passion of history is not discriminatory. In its course it gives everyone the opportunity to express himself politically, through his own works or through his own party. As a student of human beings and their motivations, may I say that life teaches us the necessity of being realistic, of accepting what can be had within the limits of reality.

With the Volunteers for Taft as its nucleus, an organization called the Americans for Republican Action has been formed to counter "left wing" influences in the Democratic party, according to William J. Goodwin, who headed the Volunteers for Taft.
A bid by nonunion employers in the garment industry to settle their difficulties with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., was rejected yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Periodically something of ominous portent threatens the auto industry, but the industry usually comes through -- and with profit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic nominee for Vice President, declared today that the controversial civil rights issue could be "worked out by reasonable men" if divorced from politics.

Strikes in New York State in the first half of 1952 resulted in a loss of 1,840,000 man-days of work affecting 116,000 workers, according to a report yesterday from Merlyn S. Pitzele, chairman of the New York State Board of Mediation.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Cubs turned back the Pirates' new strikeout threat, Ronnie Necciai, 9 -- 5, in the first game of a double-header today, then went on to edge the Bucs in the second game, 4 -- 3.

The United States, seeking to regain the championship won by Yugoslavia in 1950, started off inauspiciously by losing to the Netherlands yesterday in the first round of the International Chess Federation Congress, according to a report from Helsinki.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 10 -- Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, Australian Davis Cup aces, stroked their way into the final of the men's doubles today in the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
Three passengers from Bermuda were injured slightly late yesterday afternoon when they were "thrown about"

Al Capp, who in a leisure moment spawned the Schmoo, is now fathering fifteen minutes of hilarious TV. His new quarter-hour show, presented locally at 12:15 P. M. on Sundays over WNBT, is a witty, impish and satirical package that is one of the really pleasant surprises of the television season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Trade activities on the Board of Trade broadened last week, with a particularly active trade in oats futures, purchases of that grain exceeding the volume of business in both wheat and corn, although purchases of the latter were also heavy.
Forty-seven TV stations in forty-four cities are expected to carry "live" the new C. B. S. program, "Pick the Winner," to be launched on Thursday at 9 P. M. over the Columbia and Du Mont networks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The White Sox regained fifth place in the American League today by sweeping a double-header from the Tigers, 3 -- 1 and 5 -- 4, before 20,757 fans. The Athletics fell to sixth by splitting with the Senators.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Frank Strazza, pro at Round Hill, and Sydney Danis had a net best-ball of 31, 32 -- 63, seven below par, at Briar Hall Country Club today to win a benefit pro-and-member golf tourney by two shots.
There is a serious question of doubt whether "Austria is and of right ought to be a free and independent state," as your editorial of Aug. 2 insists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Nunnally Johnson, who wrote the screen play and is producing "My Cousin Rachel" for Twentieth Century-Fox, has been handed another slight but mystifying case of murder to prepare for filming. This is "Black Widow," a novelette written by Patrick Quentin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Small business is continuing to slip behind big business in rate of sales, profits and plant investment, President Truman was told today.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A consolidated net loss of $6,032,837 for the six months ending last June 30 was reported today by Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. Total sales for the same period were $155,746,200.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Aug. 10 -- On the basis of data submitted by seventeen countries in replies to a questionnaire, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has just issued a comprehensive analysis of average prices paid to farmers in Europe during the post-war period. The publication, the first of its kind, is now being circulated to governments.

Travelers arriving in a new land with a strange tongue and unfamiliar customs received valuable aid in the first half of this year from the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society. A semi-annual report covering the period from Jan. 1 to June 30, just issued, shows that of 4,964 Jews arriving in the United States in that interval 2,190 were released to HIAS by United States immigration officials.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 10 -- Australia has invited the United States to use the giant naval and air bases on Manus Island, Richard G. Casey, Minister for External Affairs, said today.

Here in New York we take exceptional pride and pleasure this week in joining the celebration of the anniversary of the organization of the First Army. This is "First Army Week," beginning with the actual anniversary yesterday, and it is a good time to express our satisfaction with the historic command that has its headquarters here.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 10 -- The reduction in the bank rate last week, followed by downward adjustment in interest on Treasury paper, ushers in a period of lower interest standard caused by natural factors and not by an artificial cheap money policy.

The next administration must give real consideration to the needs of American shipping and not be guilty of the neglect that has marked the past and stymied the nation's maritime aspirations, Representative John J. Allen Jr. asserted prior to his departure yesterday aboard the San Angelo Victory of the Prudential Steamship Corporation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Freddie Marsh's first home run of the season, good for three fourth-inning runs, provided the winning margin today as the Browns defeated the Indians, 6 -- 3, to further frustrate the Tribe's attempt to overhaul the front-running Yankees.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 10 -- President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois are having a little trouble in getting together on the direction and opening of the Democratic Presidential campaign.
Robert A. McLaughlin has been appointed director of sales for the fiber glass division of Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.

Roman Catholics must not confuse the externals of religion with true humility of soul, the Rev. Thomas C. Donnellan warned yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presded in the sanctuary.

Bishop Herbert Welch, "elder statesman" of the Methodist Church, who will celebrate his ninetieth birthday in November, was the guest preacher yesterday at the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street. He spoke on "The Meaning of Life."

Those who read to learn rather than to reinforce prejudices will enjoy two books recently published by the Tax Institute, Inc., of Princeton. They are "Taxation and Business Concentration"* and "Economic Effects of Section 102" and both are symposia of the views of professors and of practicing tax consultants.

Little sisters of the back-to-college girls receive a share of the limelight at this time of year with their own pretty little back-to-school fashions. Today Patterns of The Times presents three such patterns, with variations of each, all by Advance.

The State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had completed fifteen grade-crossing eliminations last year at a cost of $10,602,000, with the Old Southern - Rosedale project in Queens ranking as most important in the metropolitan area.

ZURICH, Aug. 10 -- Coming at a moment when Switzerland was so disappointed at the unyielding attitude of British authorities during negotiations to amend the Anglo-Swiss trade agreement, news that the Bank of England would now provide British companies with dollars to buy raw materials in the dollar area for resale against sterling in European Payments Union countries caused great surprise here.

Negotiations for a new agreement covering the 22,000 members of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., will open this morning in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn. The union's present contract expires on Sept. 30.

HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Most speed-boat regattas run along on even keel, but today's regional and New York State championships for the stock outboards and hydroplanes had out-of-the-ordinary occurrences while the title races were being contested.

TEN MILE RIVER, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Rough and tumble election year politics replaced handicrafts and hiking today as 500 followers of Dan Beard began campaigning for the next President of the United States. Two and a half million more Scouts will follow suit throughout the nation next month.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 10 -- The New York Yacht Club fleet, with some seventy-five units, including the sailing and motor craft, lay over in the harbor here today, as the wet fog blew in from the east and the south over this island of Martha's Vineyard.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 22 (By Airmail) -- The profits of South African gold mining companies have fallen sharply, but it is possible that, for the time being at least, the rise in working costs has been checked.

United States exports to Latin America this year probably will fall below those of 1951, but the reduction is likely to be less than expected, according to an analysis released over the week-end by the National Foreign Trade Council.

The three-story, eight-family house at 149 West Tenth Street, between Greenwich Avenue and Waverly Place in Greenwich Village, has been sold by the Accountants Foundation, Inc., to an investing client of William Alfred White, broker, with James Felt Co., realty concern, acting for the sellers.
Four new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

For more than forty years the key to good reading at the New York Public Library and its branches was a beige card of oblong shape with spaces to note the dates of books taken and returned. It had its advantages as an indicator of the number of books taken but was cumbersome to handle, easily lost, and when filled required replacement.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Allied fighter-bombers scorched Chinese Communist troops on bitterly contested "Siberia Hill" in western Korea yesterday in day-long waves after United Nations troops had been driven off the knob three times in twenty-four hours.

The reply of the Port of New York Authority to suggestions of Hoboken officials in connection with the proposal of the bi-state agency to erect modern terminals on the site of that city's piers will be discussed tomorrow at a meeting in the offices of Mayor Fred M. De Sapio of Hoboken.

Employers in New York State will pay lower average unemployment insurance tax rates next year. The lower rates will average about 1.5 per cent as compared with the 2.32 per cent average paid this year.

Nine floors of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were turned into a virtual fortress yesterday as more than $10,000,000 worth of jewelry was put on display for a five-day exhibition open only to the jewelry trade.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 10 -- A lapse of memory enabled a Rumanian Olympic sharpshooter to make a long-planned break for freedom and outwit Communist agents dogging his every step.
ATLANTA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Parts of the South had week-end rain, but the drought in the region still was reluctant to take its leave.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 10 -- Since the establishment of the state of Israel, the country's only major port of Haifa has become one of the most inefficient in the world. Most officials had maintained that nothing could be done about it without a big expenditure for new equipment and expansion.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Statesmen and strategists in Washington and London are faced this week with a dilemma: Should they help the Iranian Premier, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, out of his troubles or let him drown in them?

GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Seventeen - year - old Morris Whitney of Clearwater, Fla., successfully defended his national junior Snipe championship today by winning one race on Green Lake and placing second in the third and final event.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- Emphasizing Russia's role as a world naval power house whose "flag flies on every sea," the Soviet press said today that no effort was being spared to equip the Soviet Navy with the best and most powerful weapons of all categories.

The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind plans to construct a three-story residence hall for blind working men at Forty-sixth Street and Newton Road, Long Island City, Queens, Percival S. Howe, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Senators beat Bobby Shantz of the Athletics, 4 to 2, today but lost the second game of the double-header, 4 to 2, to Rookie Harry Byrd as the Philadelphians pounded Frank Shea for ten hits.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- East Germany's Communists this month are pressing a program designed to revolutionize the agriculture of that region in a way that will minimize peasant resistance.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 10 -- The 30,000-ton liner Uruguay, which went into drydock at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company late last night for emergency repairs, should be able to continue her voyage about 7 P. M. today.

The American Heritage Foundation, a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization, reported yesterday that substantial progress was being made in its national campaign to get out a big vote on Nov. 4. The drive is being held in cooperation with the Advertising Council.

Richard Neville, president of the East Side Republican Club at 230 East Thirty-sixth Street, has been directed to show cause in Supreme Court today why he should not be restrained permanently from distributing a publication called The Republican and from saying in the paper's masthead that the publication has been authorized by the club.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 10 -- Former President Herbert Hoover presumably spent his seventy-eighth birthday fishing on Oregon's McKenzie River.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The month-long drought is over today in all except one of the five New England states chiefly affected. The drought still persists in Maine, where light showers today eased the forest fire danger, but brought little or no relief to farmlands.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- The National Commander of the Disabled American Veterans praised today the prompt care of wounded Americans in Korea by Army medical men.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 10 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh presented to the Chamber of Deputies today, in his capacity as Minister of National Defense, a bill for the extension of the period of martial law in Iran and ran into a rebellion by Deputies from his own National Front.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Brookings Institution reported today that the average death rate in the United States had been cut nearly in half in the past fifty years -- from 17.2 per 1,000 persons in 1900 to 9.6 in 1950 -- and that individuals of all ages in the nation had enjoyed increasingly good health in that period.

Genuinely Christian Americans have an obligation to "provide moral leadership, economic assistance and political direction for the underdeveloped countries where communism is making the greatest inroads," the Rev. Dr. Gayle J. Lathrop declared yesterday morning.

Burton Crane's article under the title "U. S. Renews Talks Over Buying of Tin" in your July 27 issue refers to the renewed accusation by the United States Senate Preparedness subcommittee of the existence of a tin-producers' cartel.
Small dwellings in various parts of Long Island formed the bulk of realty trading reported by brokers in that area over the week-end.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Britain today lifted restrictions on the movement of cattle, clamped down last November as a hoof-and-mouth epidemic spread through the country.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Averell Harriman, who was the choice of the New York Democratic organization for the Presidential nomination, told officials of the State Committee and county chairmen from the metropolitan area today that his successful opponent for the nomination, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, "is a great man and will make a great President."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is quietly combing the voluminous files of the defunct Senate Crime Committee for possible new leads on the criminal activities of underworld characters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Monday, Aug. 11 -- The first major strike by creative talent in the television industry was scheduled to get under way early today, following his breakdown in negotiations thirteen days ago between the screen Writers Guild and the Alliance of Television Film Producers over a royalty payment formula demanded by the union.

The first contingent of international exchange teachers will arrive in New York today and tomorrow. This is a group of about a hundred from Great Britain. Before the school year opens there will be others coming, it is hoped, from Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, New Zealand and Norway.

The Canadian dollar soared to a new high premium in terms of its American counterpart when it sold at a 4 7/32 cent, last Wednesday. This was the highest since November 1933, when it touched 4 9/16 cent, for the record.
A dinner dance will be given on the St. Regis Roof the evening of Nov. 20 under the auspices of the Big Brothers, to raise funds with which to carry on the organization's work among young boys.

This newspaper has consistently favored and praised our nation's participation in and support of international health programs. We believe that it is good business to support the World Health Organization and to provide health services under the Point Four program.

For the second time in three days rain reached out yesterday to disrupt matters a little further in the American League flag race by washing out the second game of the Yankee-Red Sox series at the Stadium, an encounter which, with its heavy advance sale, was expected to draw all of 60,000 fans.

GALLUP, N. M., Aug. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the American Indians today that they never had received full justice from the white man who conquered their lands, but that he looked forward to the day when there would be no differences among Americans because of color.

Since he left the musical. "Kiss Me, Kate," in June, 1950, while it was still flourishing, Alfred Drake hasn't acted on Broadway. Despite lucrative offers, nothing could induce him to be associated with a musical again as far as acting was concerned.

CHATHAM, N. Y., Aug. 1O -- From a small office on the main street of this Columbia County village, Arthur S. Hopkins, an expert on forestry activities, directs forest fire protection in an area that embraces New York State and New England.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10 -- The Rocky Point Sailing Club, in its debut as a sponsor of a Long Island Sound Y. R. A. championship regatta, drew the season's worst weather today. Rain poured and the wind was shifty and light, and only forty-one starters appeared.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration approved tax benefits today for 244 defense plant expansion projects to cost a total of $151,128,470.

A post-war trend to decentralize manufacturing throughout the metropolitan area was reported yesterday by the Regional Plan Association in making public the results of a twelve-month study of 2,658 new plants built in the area between 1946 and 1951.

Preaching yesterday at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, the Rev. Dr. J. Chapman Bradley said that "many people have become so accustomed to having 'Uncle Softie' make bread out of stones, that now it is difficult to think of providing bread for themselves any other way."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The private electric industry made public a study of its post-war expansion program today with a statement that it shows "we have more than met our responsibility to furnish power where needed and as it is needed."
Heavy rain fell intermittently in the city and suburbs yesterday, flooding cellars in sections of Queens and causing a tie-up on the Long Island Rail Road's Port Washington branch.

The Progressive party said yesterday that the National Broadcasting Company had granted national network time for televising and broadcasting the acceptance speeches of Vincent Hallinan, its Presidential nominee, and Mrs. Charlotta A. Bass, the Vice Presidential nominee.

At the dedication of the $6,000,000 Rockaway pollution - control plant Mayor Impellitteri and Commissioner Robert Moses made some remarks on municipal policy that deserve thoughtful attention. The plant is part of the sewage-purification program, to cost something over $200,000,000, which is rapidly nearing the halfway mark of completion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee reported today that an easier cotton supply situation is indicated for the 1952-53 season which began Aug. 1.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- The 1,700 officers and men of New York's Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, Organized Reserve Corps, arrived here at noon today and began drawing equipment for the two weeks of intensive field training that will begin tomorrow.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10 -- The Rocky Point Sailing Club, in its debut as a sponsor of a Long Island Sound Y. R. A. championship regatta, drew the season's worst weather today. Rain poured and the wind was shifty and light, and only forty-one starters appeared.
Heavy rain fell intermittently in the city and suburbs yesterday, flooding cellars in sections of Queens and causing a tie-up on the Long Island Rail Road's Port Washington branch.

The Progressive party said yesterday that the National Broadcasting Company had granted national network time for televising and broadcasting the acceptance speeches of Vincent Hallinan, its Presidential nominee, and Mrs. Charlotta A. Bass, the Vice Presidential nominee.

At the dedication of the $6,000,000 Rockaway pollution - control plant Mayor Impellitteri and Commissioner Robert Moses made some remarks on municipal policy that deserve thoughtful attention. The plant is part of the sewage-purification program, to cost something over $200,000,000, which is rapidly nearing the halfway mark of completion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee reported today that an easier cotton supply situation is indicated for the 1952-53 season which began Aug. 1.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- The 1,700 officers and men of New York's Seventy-seventh Infantry Division, Organized Reserve Corps, arrived here at noon today and began drawing equipment for the two weeks of intensive field training that will begin tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Frank Hiller pitched the Reds to an even split in a double-header today as he hurled a five-hit, 4-2 victory after the Cardinals had rallied with three runs in the ninth inning to win the opener, 3 -- 2.

" This Was Publishing," by Donald Sheehan, a member of Columbia University's History Department, has been scheduled for publication in the fall by the Indiana University Press. Based on Mr. Sheehan's research in the files of such publishing houses as Henry Holt, Charles Scribner, Dodd, Mead and Harper's, the volume presents an inside story of the book publishing industry from the Civil War to 1914.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 10 (UP) -- They all laughed when little Marcelino Romany got up at the Republican National Convention, but he is getting the last laugh now.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The attention of the market last week centered on the rise in gold and hard currencies, making the first time since the Pinay experiment began that market has displayed the symptoms of doubt over success of the Government's policiees.

LUXEMBOURG, Aug. 10 -- Europe's unique and ambitious venture in practical unity -- the Schuman plan for merging the coal and steel industries of six nations into a single market -- was formally launched as a going enterprise here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Aug. 10 -- In an attempt to work out a practical legal basis for establishing responsibility for support of indigent families after their natural protectors have emigrated, a seven-member panel of jurists appointed by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, will meet Aug. 18 in Geneva.
ALBANY, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Water fluoridation has caused a 47 per cent drop in tooth decay among Neuwburgh children, the State Health Commissioner said today.

" Hollow blocks," playthings known and enjoyed by thousands of youngsters lucky enough to attend well-equipped nursery schools, may become equally well known to their parents soon as a new version of the toy, inexpensive enough for home use, went on the retail market this week.

Someone remembered the other day that the "Flatiron" Building, at the intersection of Broadway and Fifth Avenue, on Twenty-third Street, is celebrating its fiftieth birthday this year. The twenty-one-story building was completed in 1902 from plans by D. H. Burnham Co. and was regarded as an advance in the structural system used to erect "the skyscraper" because its exterior walls and its floors were supported at each story by the steel frame.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Substantial gains were registered in most deliveries of grains on the Board of Trade last week, with soybeans also moving up in response to unfavorable crop reports and low seasonal estimates.

CAIRO, Aug. 10 -- In a blunt statement to the independent newspaper Al Ahram, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Commander in Chief of the Egyptian armed forces, took the nation's political parties severely to task today for their conduct since the change of regime.

About a year ago, in a debate in the British House of Commons on the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute, the then Prime Minister Attlee partly excused his weak policy by saying: "It took a long time to get people in the United States to realize the importance of the Middle East."
All of the city's 579 air raid warning sirens will sound simultaneously on Tuesday night, Sept. 30, in the first city-wide civil defense exercise since April 3.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A squad of United States Olympic track and field champions easily defeated German competitors in a post-Helsinki exhibition today, but failed to register any outstanding performances.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- With a reactionary tendency in hog prices and irregular moves in oils, the general tendency on the Board of Trade was downward. Compared to the closing prices of a week ago hogs were off as much as $1.25 per hundred at around $23.25.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Except for the strictly legal, eight-a-day jousts with the mutuels at the running-horse track and the harness-horse track, there's not supposed to be any gambling here. The roulette wheels aren't spinning, the dice aren't rolling and the blackjack dealers aren't dealing -- either from the top or from the bottom.

ATLANTA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Southern Negro voters apparently will continue their new loyalty to the Democratic party in November despite some dissatisfaction over the civil rights plank and Senator John J. Sparkman's nomination for the Vice Presidency.
The prerogative of teen-agers to whistle at pretty girls ran afoul of the law in Forest Hills, Queens, last night.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 10 -- Despite the continuance of a heavy unfavorable trade balance, Mexico's gold and dollar reserves have climbed steadily during the first six months of 1952, largely on the strength of record tourist traffic.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 11 (UP) -- A pilot killed yesterday in an unexplained crash of an F-94 all-weather jet fighter was identified today as Capt. Hobart R. Gay Jr., 28, of 95 Harvard Avenue, Rockville Centre, L. I., and son of a former commander of the First Cavalry Division in Korea.

Having recently been on a visit to the United States, which was, as always, interesting and stimulating and full of friendliness, may I draw attention to one unhappy memory. As you know, visitors are required on leaving to provide themselves with an income-tax clearance from the Internal Revenue authorities.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The seventy-first annual Newport invitation tennis tournament opened today, with five seeded Americans and two foreign favorites getting by early opposition after play was delayed until noon because of wet grass.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 -- Carl G. LoDolce of Rochester, a sergeant with the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, won his fight today to prevent his extradition to Italy to stand trial for the wartime murder and robbery of Maj. William V. Holohan of New York, his superior officer. No further action in the case was expected.

Globe-trotting Harry Lassen, 71 years old, and his wife, 64, of Los Gatos, Calif., arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from London yesterday on the next to the last stop of their four-month trip around the world by air.

The Swedish American liner Gripsholm arrived here yesterday from Goteborg, a day ahead of schedule, with 915 passengers. Her skipper sported a gold watch he had received for his role in rescuing forty-five passengers last month from the burning Norwegian freighter Black Gull.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 -- Army Secretary Frank C. Pace Jr. is scheduled to arrive in Belgrade tomorrow for a visit that will close with a conference with Premier Marshal Tito in Bled Wednesday evening.

The grand larceny case involving ownership of a miniature French poodle was settled yesterday in Felony Court when a theft charge against Miss Peggy Yancie, 24 years old, a model of 15 East Forty-eighth Street, was withdrawn.
The police racked up a two-out-of-three score in the early hours yesterday in the campaign against hotel robbers.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- Edward Cronjager, prize-winning photographer who headed a special Technicolor camera crew from Twentieth Century-Fox International to photograph ceremonies of the funeral of the late Eva Peron, said today that $200,000 worth of United States equipment had been flown down here within the space of seventy-two hours at the request of the Argentine Government.

Rayon and acetate textiles have only a narrow range in which to move upward before the reimposition of price control, the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., pointed out yesterday. The industry, according to the federation, will find itself subject to Office of Price Stabilization ceilings if prices rise only a few more cents a yard on representative fabrics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Julius Boros, the United States open champion, blasting brilliantly out of four sand traps, rallied for a 2-stroke victory today over Cary Middlecoff in a play-off for golf's richest prize, the $25,000 first money in the "World championship" tourney. Boros carded a 4-under-par 68 to Middlecoff's 70.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,339 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Tuesday. Korea time:

The downward trend in shipping activity, described in recent months as world-wide, apparently halted temporarily in July, at least as far as the Port of New York is concerned. In that thirty-one-day period, customs receipts here reached $22,537,174, the highest figure for any month since March and $1,681,021 more than was collected in July, 1951.

The First Army observed its thirty-fourth anniversary yesterday afternoon at a retreat parade on Governors Island at which General of the Army Omar N. Bradley and a squad of generals and admirals paid tribute to the organization and five of its members who were decorated for heroism in Korea.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The Westchester C. C. team of Mickey Homa and Bill Murray captured the Westchester County pro-amateur golf championship today at the Willows C. C. with a best-ball effort of 32, 33 -- 65.

Swedish players, repeating their sweep of the opening round against Brazil, yesterday defeated Norway, 4 -- 0, in the second round of the biennial team championship tournament of the International Chess Federation, according to a report from Helsinki.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Grain futures came in for considerable selling pressure today, better weather conditions in drought areas causing some selling while the outlook for possible record yields of small grains in western Canada restricted buying of wheat especially.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Telford Taylor, Small Defense Plants Administrator, posted his resignation notice today but agreed to stay on until President Truman named a successor.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 11 -- In a suit filed here today in United States District Court, the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad asked that Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City and others be ordered to pay the $51,012 it cost the railroad to defend the 20-cent fare between Jersey City-Hoboken and New York.

The New York Security Dealers Association has protested to the Securities and Exchange Commission about a proposed rule that would require a broker or dealer to give actual notice before a transaction with any partner, officer, director or employe of another broker or dealer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Government has sold more than $1,000,000,000 worth of savings bonds since new and higher interest rates were put into effect three months ago, Treasury officials said today.

New accessories for one room that may need refurbishing, the bathroom, are now available. Many of them are made of plastic, which is not only durable but colorful. New shower curtains range in design style from contemporary geometric prints to those more traditional in feeling.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Sidney S. McMath will seek a third-term Democratic nomination tomorrow in a run-off primary election that holds national political interest because of background developments involving President Truman.

A well-known author of children's books and members of the division of home-missions of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America are cooperating in a new project using drama to increase youngsters' understanding of the problems of migrant children.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports climbed to a peak $2,100,000,000 during the first six months of 1952. They were pushed ahead, the Bureau of Statistics reported today, by a marked expansion in shipments to the United Kingdom, Latin America and most European markets.

King Faisal II of Iraq, with his royal entourage including Emir Regent Abdul Illah, will arrive here at 11 A. M. today aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary for an informal visit to the United States until Sept. 10. This will be the 17-year-old monarch's first visit to this country.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- In an interim statement of domestic policy the National Executive Committee of the British Labor party proposed today that there should be "a periodic review" of Britain's rearmament program, which from its beginning has been a source of acute controversy in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug 11 -- Representatives of organized labor told the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation today that means must be found to overcome the economic barriers to the kind of health services workers require for themselves and their families.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- United Nations planes smashed a sprawling Communist chemical plant on a North Korean mountainside yesterday. The target was north of Namsok, which is about thirty miles northwest of the battered port of Wonson, on Korea's northeast coast. Smoke billowed from fire and explosions in twenty-nine buildings and a power station.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 -- The fourth congress of the World Organization for Early Childhood Education opened here today on a note of hope that international conflict is not inevitable if children can be properly taught early enough.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 30 to 57 points yesterday, with a moderate volume of business.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 11 -- More than 600 Naval Reserve midshipmen left here today aboard a heavy cruiser and four destroyers for a three-week training cruise through the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Army today asked the Selective Service System to send 47,000 recruits to training camps in October. The new draft call was 17,000 men higher than the September total, although it was not so high as had been officially predicted.

A collection of old, hand made Pueblo Indian pottery with irregular shapes and markings -- decorative accessories to give a pleasing contrast to modern furniture -- is now on display at Kagan-Dreyfuss, 123 East Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- At least 3,750 C. I. O. United Packinghouse Workers walked off their jobs at four Armour Co. plants today, in protest against working without a contract. The walkouts were not authorized by the international union.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -- A dozen persons, including a newspaper man, have been arrested for indecorously marking the death of Senora Eva Peron, the General Confederation of Labor disclosed tonight.

Major crimes in every category have shown a sharp increase in the first six months of this year, as compared with a like period in 1951, official figures obtained yesterday from the Police Department disclosed. Only the misdemeanors show a decrease.
GRINDSTONE LAKE, Wis., Aug. 11 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, replied today to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's suggestion that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower repudiate the Senator.

Two prominent motion-picture players, Charles Boyer and Joan Crawford, may depict the leading roles in "Kind Sir," the romantic comedy by Norman Krasna, which recently was added to the production schedule of Joshua Logan, producer, director and author.

For the delightful 150-year-old poem on Boston baked beans revived here today, we thank Herbert L. Matthews. This editorial writer for THE NEW YORK TIMES, who formerly reported from many parts of the world, recently happened on what he calls "this nostalgic and expert ode."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Downey Rice, special counsel, and George Martin, staff consultant to the Senate Preparedness investigating subcommittee, have received dismissal notices, effective Sept. 1.

A provisional committee to oppose the recent increase in the commercial rates of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was formed yesterday at a meeting in the offices of the Real Estate Board of New York, 12 East Forty-first Street.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- The question of amending New York State's Unemployment Insurance Law to liberalize the present twenty-week eligibility requirement is being studied by the Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment Insurance, Assemblyman Ray S. Ashberry, Republican of Tompkins County and the committee vice chairman, disclosed today.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- British Overseas Airways today inaugurated the first commercial jet flight by record-breaking Comet jetliners to Pakistan, India, and Ceylon, confident of clipping thirteen hours off the usual flying time.

HONG KONG, Aug. 11 -- Five new economic ministries have been set up by the Peiping Government in a Cabinet reorganization that is viewed here as a forerunner of a tighter nation-wide development plan geared to Communist China's present national defense program.
DALLAS, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Temperatures rose to 100 degrees in Texas today for the fifty-fourth day this summer. It was the tenth consecutive day that it has been 100 or above in this city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's recent statement on Social Security conflicts with his previous views and with the Republican record in Congress.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Southeastern Conference suspended the University of Kentucky from basketball competition today for one year and ruled two Kentucky football players ineligible because of professionalism.

The body of Edward Quirk McEvoy, who was reported missing after he had started to cross the St. Lawrence River on skis on Feb. 23, 1951, has been found, according to word received yesterday by his father, Edward McEvoy of 2715 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx.
Twelve football games to be played by service teams of the armed forces will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System network on each Saturday afternoon from Sept. 20 through Dec. 6.

An important result of the two recent national political conventions has been a growing conviction on the part of both the press and the public that the procedures for nominating candidates for President and Vice President of the United States must be improved so as to permit a larger participation in them by the rank-and-file membership of the two parties.
Among the excellent TIMES items covering the recent Olympic Games in Helsinki was one in the Aug. 1 issue that invites comment.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Government movie censors today approved the American flim "Viva Zapata" for showing in Mexico, reversing an earlier press announcement that the picture had been banned for "altering the historic truth."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 11 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh won a complete victory in the Senate today. That body at last adopted a bill giving him full dictatorial powers for six months to deal with the present crisis.

J. Raymond Jones, the generally acknowledged Democratic "boss" of Harlem, declared yesterday that the nomination of Averell Harriman for the United States Senate would erase completely the fears aroused among Negroes by the nomination of Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama for Vice President.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 -- The Knesset (Parliament) voted the World Zionist Organization an official status today as "the representative organization of all the Jewish people which shall continue to work for the development and the colonizatiton of the country."

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- German bonds, initially buoyant on further consideration of the debt settlement terms, closed at, or below, Friday's prices on the stock market here today. Only dollar clause stocks such as Potash and Munich 6's withstood the losses of late profit taking sales and improved.

The $1,300,000 bond issue by Florence, Ala., for the erection of a manufacturing plant will be offered today by Gearhart Otis, Inc., and associates. The 5 per cent first mortgage industrial development revenue bonds mature serially Sept. 1, 1954-77 at par, and are redeemable on any interest payment date at 105 per cent plus accrued interest.

The information department of the Austrian Consulate General, 31 East Sixty-ninth Street, clarified yesterday a United Press dispatch from Vienna, published last Saturday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, which reported the arrest of eight directors of Austria's largest nationalized bank, the Creditanstalt Bankverein, on charges of illegal currency transactions.

An immediate practical outcome of the recent ANZUS conference in Honolulu is the invitation to United States naval and air forces to again use the Manus Island base. This important position, north of New Guinea, was developed during the war and reached a high peak of operational value.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Union labor officials said today that a flood of foreign timepieces was creating dangerous unemployment in the United States watch and clock industry. They urged President Truman to help erect tariff barriers that will protect American watchmakers.

R. J. Lascelles, secretary and treasurer of the Pullman Company, has been elected vice president and controller, effective Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Carroll H. Harding, president. Mr. Lascelles succeeds C. H. Westbrook, who will continue as a director and a member of the executive committee. H. J. Jostock was elected secretary and treasurer to succeed Mr. Lascelles.
KOBE, Japan, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Lawyers for two British sailors being held here said today they would appeal the touchy international case to a higher court. It appeared to be a move to gain time.

One of the fifteen defendants at the Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court urged the establishment of a Communist-taught school in Washington in 1949, a Government witness testified yesterday. The defendants, secondary Communist party leaders, are charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau said today tax claims of $1,423,427 against Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Lowe of Orlando, Fla., either were grossly excessive or unfounded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that crop production this year would be the third largest in the nation's history despite losses from a severe July drought in a broad Southern and Eastern area.
The two largest unions in the maritime field, representing nearly 70,000 unlicensed American seamen, sat down here yesterday with employing steamship operators to discuss working conditions.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Taxpayers and community organizations split sharply here tonight at a public hearing on whether rezoning should be permitted to allow the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation to build a multi-million-dollar new headquarters on the site of the old 286-acre James Butler estate.

The difference between success and failure of many businesses has been the amount of progress made in keeping up to date on what the public desires rather than resting on what management believes the public wants.

DENVER, Aug. 11 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he would not campaign for the Presidency as if he were "a messiah" who alone could bring peace to the world, but that he felt that "the Republicans generally can do a better job than the Democrats" in organizing foreign and domestic programs that faced the facts.

THE big fish picture is still dark, primarily because the wind and weather discouraged most of the anglers over the week-end. A few hazarded the deep water between gusts and brought in some school tuna.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Rena Ellen Mooney, widow of Tom Mooney, who was convicted of murder in the 1916 San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing, died here today at her home. Her age was 74. She suffered a heart attack while ironing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Two members of Congress who urged President Truman today to call a special session of Congress to tighten price controls reported that they "got nothing definite" from him about his intentions.

Sales of the J. C. Penney Company, nation-wide department store chain, rose $5,809,258 to $444,448,145 in the six months ended on June 30 from the $438,638,887 volume transacted in the corresponding half year of 1951.

Re William J. Mackay's letter appearing Aug. 7 urging that all automobiles be required to carry flares for emergency signal use at night, I wonder if the average motorist realizes what an admirable safety device he has in his directional signal lights in case of emergency.
Eddie Compo, 133 1/4, New Haven, Conn., scored a split ten-round decision over Teddy (Red Top) Davis, 130 1/2 Hartford, Conn., at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Harry Gross was so short of cash in the summer of 1950 -- about one month before his arrest brought his empire of gambling and graft crashing down -- that he borrowed $4,500 from a clerk in his "figure room," according to surprise testimony yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen.

While production is the most pressing problem of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the day is approaching when it will be matched by that of sales and distribution, according to Dr. John F. Thompson, board chairman.

The negotiations for a military and economic accord with France Spain are running into difficulties. A few weeks ago Generalissimo France claimed that Washington's refusal to treat Spain on a par with other Western European nations was the reason for the failure to reach an understanding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Shipment of 7,600,000 bushels of wheat to Argentina during the next three months has been authorized by United States officials to relieve a shortage caused by crop failures in the South American republic. Argentina normally is an exporter of wheat.

Government potato crop estimates, due after the close, resulted in unsettled trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Expecting official figures higher than their own, longs took their profits in the morning, with trade houses picking up the offerings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Ever since President Truman failed to induce the writers of the anti-filibuster plank in the Democratic platform for 1952 to demand that Senate Rule 22 be modified to help achieve this objective the political approach to the legislation principally obstructed by the rule has continued to be of the sham battle variety.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- The thirteen member companies of the Alliance of Television Film Producers continued to make films today and a number of writers remained on the job in the first day of the strike called by the Screen Writers Guild and the Authors League of America. Picket lines did not appear.

Two diesel units are scheduled for delivery to the Rutland Railway System in Vermont tomorrow, with two more coming on Thursday, it was announced by the railroad in Rutland yesterday. The four 1,600-horsepower Alco-G. E. diesel-electric locomotives will bring the line's diesel equipment to a total of sixteen units.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- In contrast with 1951, which marked an expansion of intra-European trade, the first three months of 1952 reflected a reduction in the momentum of this traffic, as reported in the quarterly Direction of European Trade, published today by the United Nations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, alarmed over recent steep increases in prices, called on President Truman today to "take whatever steps the facts make necessary" to check the rise in the cost of living.

The return of the United States Olympic team was officially completed yesterday with the arrival of the bulk of the men's and women's track and field teams and accompanying officials. The sixty-eight-person party arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from London aboard, a chartered KLM Royal Dutch Airline's plane.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- This military center will be dedicated in honor of the late Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum at a ceremony to be held on Aug. 22, First Army headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Athletics jammed three of their six hits off Randy Gumpert and Don Johnson into the sixth inning to produce the winning run as they defeated Washington, 2 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Senators won the opener, 6 -- 5.

An ultimatum from nonunion garment manufacturers was sent yesterday to David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., demanding that he set a date for a negotiations meeting by tomorrow noon.

Chalk up a belated Olympic victory for a Rumanian pistol shot. Panait Calcai has told the story of how he escaped from two Communist guards just before he was slated to go back to Rumania after the close of the Olympic Games in Helsinki. The account reads like the script of an Alfred Hitchcock movie.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 t)--A New York physician who lost $8,500 and the cost of a trip to 1Vexico in an ancient swindle got a final word of consolation today. The Tax Court of the United States said the physician, Dr. Curtis H. Muncie, a practitioner in New York for more than forty years, could deduct the $8,500 on his income tax returns as a loss to theft.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to disturb railroad rates on export and import traffic moving through south Florida ports.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 11 -- Jordan's Parliament removed King Talal today and proclaimed his son, Crown Prince Hussein, 17, his successor.

NEWARK, Aug. 11 -- Word was received today that the National Production Authority in Washington had approved a $5,500,000 materials allotment for construction on the Sacred Heart Cathedral here. This means that the edifice, started more than fifty years ago, should be completed by the autumn of 1953, when the archdiocese will celebrate its 100th anniversary, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark said.

A colorfully dressed and slightly wide-eyed group of 111 aviation students from fifteen nations assembled on the steps of City Hall yesterday to receive an official welcome from Mayor Impellitteri. The visitors, mostly teen-agers, have toured the country July 28 as guests of the Civil Air Patrol.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Running over a heavy, rough and tiring racing strip that was drying slowly in the sun, Greentree Stable's Tom Fool weakened in the final strides and was nailed at the finish by E. P. Bixer's Count Flame in the mile-and-a-furlong contest for 3-year-olds that headed Saratoga's program today.

THE rivalry between Russia and the United States for top scoring honors in the Olympics had every one so steamed up at Helsinki that no one thought to shed a tear for another great power going along day after day without a single gold medal to its name.

A three and one-half hour lunacy hearing was held in the prison ward of the Bellevue Hospital psychiatric division yesterday for Bayard P. Peakes, admitted slayer of Eileen Fahey, 18-year-old typist, in a building at Columbia University on July 14.
Two teen-age hoodlums were arrested yesterday and charged with the cold-blooded slaying in Brooklyn of 26-year-old Marcus B. Harrelson.

The Texas Company denied yesterday that it was a party to any international oil cartel or any illegal price-fixing of any kind, or any monopoly. This statement was made by W. S. S. Rodgers, chairman, and J. Sayles Leach, president, who said also that they did not believe other oil companies were involved in any such cartel.

Prices are turning upward in the cigar industry, but the increases so far are only at the wholesale level and it is unlikely, because of the competitive situation, that the public will have to pay more within the near future.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- United States Tax Court held today protection money cannot be deducted from income tax, even if the payments are made in a semi-official arrangement with a city.

Beta is home again. The black and white cat that wandered into Roosevelt Hospital Saturday and gave birth to five kittens in the emergency ward was claimed by her owners yesterday. Now Beta and her five are resting comfortably in a box beneath the chopping table in the kitchen of the Cozy Corner Restaurant, 924 Ninth Avenue.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Hank Edwards blasted Rookie Cal Hogue off the mound with a bases-loaded single in the first inning and the Reds went on easily to defeat the Pirates, 10 to 4, tonight.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Bloomington Pantagraph, partly owned by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, said in an editorial today that it wished it could endorse him for the Presidency "without reservation," but that his party was a "great handicap."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- The Dodgers made it four out of five here tonight as they bounced back from a first-game, 7-2 defeat to beat the Phils, 9 -- 5, and extend their first-place lead over the Giants to nine games.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 11 -- Fanny Blankers-Koen, Holland's "flying housewife," said today that she does not want to retire from competition until she has conquered the hurdles, which threw her in the Olympic Games and again here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- John M. Allison, Assistant Secretary of State for the Far East, today described the fighting in Indo-China as the key to future developments in that area of the world.

GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The administrative tribunal of the United Nations ruled today that Secretary General Trygve Lie could not terminate the appointment of a member of the United Nations staff without reason.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- Plenary negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war were in adjournment again today after a futile thirty-five-minute session of the delegations yesterday. The brief meeting at Panmunjom gave no evidence that any compromise solution was in the making to end the long deadlock over an exchange of prisoners.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William W. Wickham's White Skies, the only thoroughbred to hold a victory over the Calumet Farm's Real Delight, scored the most important triumph of his career today when he raced to a convincing victory in the $10,000 added Pageant Handicap as Atlantic City opened a forty-eight-day race meeting.

The ten-day strike of longshoremen that was prompted by an intra-union dispute and has interfered with the overseas shipment of defense materials at the Army-leased Claremont Terminal in Jersey City appeared last night to be near an end.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 11 -- The mystery of "radio stars" may be solved with the help of enormous new radio telescopes under construction or recently built.

President Truman recently elevated Allium sativum, alias garlic, to unprecedented international importance. In a 2,000-word state paper about the bulbous herb he rejected a proposed anti-garlic tariff increase, thereby scoring a march on the Italian Communists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Highway construction procedures to reduce accident potential and traffic congestion 20 per cent were outlined today as a National Good Roads Association was formed here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, will get a thorough briefing on the international situation and defense problems when he visits the White House tomorrow.
