BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- By way of celebrating the anniversary eve of the start of their spectacular dash to the 1951 National League pennant, the Giants practically read themselves out of the 1952 party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Reorganization of the Internal Revenue Bureau will result in a tax collection agency of "top efficiency, unquestioned integrity and maximum operating efficiency," John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, promised today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Miss Vivien Kellems opened her campaign for election as United States Senator tonight by charging that Connecticut's convention system "makes it comparatively easy for a few rich men, sitting in swivel chairs in New York City, to dictate to corrupt political bosses" in this state.
Blond and brown tones vied with a gray and black for top honors in the college fashion show at B. Altman's yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois will fly to Washington tomorrow for a campaign strategy meeting with President Truman and his Cabinet.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 11 -- A compound known as SR-406, which kills fungi that cause such conditions as mildew, crop diseases, athlete's foot, diaper rash and a host of tropical diseases, has been developed at Rutgers University in cooperation with the Esso Laboratories of the Standard Oil Development Company of Linden.

Pleas of not guilty were entered yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court by five men accused of conspiracy to defraud the Government in the preparation of technical manuals used by military trainees. Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo released them in bail for trial Sept. 8.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 11 -- While public doubt about the methods and pace of rearmament in the North Atlantic Treaty nations continued to be voiced on both sides of the Atlantic, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, spoke out sharply today to warn that the threat of a Communist attack had in no way decreased.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in its semi-annual statement issued yesterday by P. W. Litchfield, chairman of the board, reported an increase of $24,191,014 in net sales to a record $568,833,355 for the first half of 1952, but a decline of 25 per cent in earnings.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 10 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee explained today that it was a case of "I thought he did it, he thought I would do it" in the failure of Tennessee to switch its vote to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois at the Democratic National Convention.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The centenarian Haj Mohammed el-Mokri, who has been Grand Vizier of Morocco for forty years, paid a formal call today on Premier Antoine Pinay.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- With hog receipts the fewest for a Monday in four months, prices were steady to 50 cents a hundred pounds higher today. Cattle were steady to 25 cents higher and sheep steady to 50 cents up. Department of Agriculture reports for the day:

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Czechoslovak refugee said today he escaped from a Communist prison Jan. 2 with John Hvasta. The refugee said he believed Mr. Hvasta still was alive and hiding in some Slovakian village.

Museum officials and educators from nineteen nations will meet at the Brooklyn Museum this fall for a seminar arranged by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to review the role of the museum in education.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The Cubs celebrated their return to Wrigley Field after a three-week absence by battering three pitchers for thirteen hits and a 10 -- 2 victory over the Cardinals today.
The Soviet Government has recently raised the Iron Curtain slightly by permitting the export of eleven major provincial newspapers to private persons abroad.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 11 -- In an all-Australia final at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today, Ken McGregor defeated Frank Sedgman after they had halted American rivals in semifinal matches of the Eastern grass court championships.

Early gains on the stock market were shaded yesterday when selling among the rails changed the general direction of prices. Sales in the carriers were tied up, especially with issues of the petroleum companies in which mutual interests exist.

The realignment of the traffic pattern of the Manhattan Bridge to bar Manhattan-bound passenger cars at all times from the upper two-lane south deck will go into effect tomorrow, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Louis B. Mayer, who resigned last August as studio head of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, has been chosen by the Screen Producers Guild to be the second recipient of its Milestone Award for historic contributions to the development of American motion pictures.

Another one of Allie Reynolds' superlative mound performances and some devastating stick work by Mickey Mantle combined last night to bring the Yankees one of those smashing triumphs that Casey Stengel seems able to pull out of his bag of tricks whenever his Bombers need victory most.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The engagement of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Miss Clarissa Churchill, a niece of the Prime Minister, was announced today. The marriage is to take place shortly.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Workmen hastily propped up the foundations of twenty-eight houses and apartments today to try to save them from a runaway underground creek that already had swallowed a truck, a car and three front porches.

A year ago today a dread phenomenon made itself felt in a small corner of the United States. The citizens of this community found themselves jumping at slight noises, tossing in their beds at night and generally behaving like rabbits being pursued slowly but inexorably by an irate farmer.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Margaret Truman crossed the Soviet zone to Berlin today and figuratively knocked at the city's "little iron curtain," but did not go through it.

The Brookings Institution has performed the useful task of collecting, summarizing and interpreting the vital statistics of the last fifty years. That the death rate for the country as a whole should in that period have been reduced by about 45 per cent will be gratifying news to the public, yet no news at all to life-insurance actuaries,
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today added all of New Hampshire and parts of Oklahoma and Illinois to the drought disaster loan area.

ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (UP) -- The head of a dissident Georgia Republican faction that had opposed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today abandoned a rebellion against the regular Republican slate of Presidential electors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Kenneth R. Iverson, president of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs, which administers United States Point Four technical assistance programs in other American republics in cooperation with those countries, said today that recent criticism of the programs by international geographers were based on fallacies.

The movement toward the unification of Europe took its first step from theory into practice on Monday when that Continent's first international High Authority established itself as a going enterprise and began work to make the Schuman Plan for a European Coal and Steel Community a living, functioning reality.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (UP) -- Brendan Macken of Montreal became the first Canadian in twenty-one years to beat an American in Davis Cup tennis play today when he smashed out a 2-hour 20-minute victory over Bob Perry of San Leandro, Calif., in the fifth and final match of the North American tie, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 13, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- For the second year in a row Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century won the medal in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship with a 5 over par 39, 39 -- 78 over the Apawamis Club course today. Mrs. Untermeyer, who thus retains the Kay Byrne memorial candelabra that goes to the medalist, was the only player in the field of forty-nine able to break 80.

A new work by Bernard DeVoto, which will complete his trilogy on America's westward expansion, has been scheduled for Oct. 23 publication by Houghton Mifflin. "The Course of Empire," although appearing last, is chronologically the first volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hvasta came here today to appeal, in their words, to all the free world to help them discover whether their son John is dead or alive and lost in the silences of Communist Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Herman Hickman, football's rotund and jovial personality, resigned today as head coach of the Yale University team to enter private business. The 300-pound mentor, who gained national fame for his weight, eloquence and humor, as well as his feats on the gridiron, probably will turn his talents to television broadcasting.

Manufacturers must control their channels of distribution to help prevent "unfair" merchandising practices, William B. Ogush, senior vice president of the Gruen Watch Company, Cincinnati, said yesterday at a special panel at the annual convention and trade show sponsored by the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 11 -- The Sarawak police have seized seven men in connection with the outbreak of Communist terrorism in the British colony in northwest Borneo on Aug. 6, according to reports from Kuching, the capital, tonight.
CAIRO, Aug. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Mohamed Naguib, Commander in Chief of the Egyptian armed forces, announced today that elections for a new Egyptian Parliament would be held next February.

The sound of hammering -- even when it penetrated the rugged consciousness of Central Park's chess players -- was a welcome noise yesterday. It signaled the approaching completion of a handsome brick shelter into which they will retire next fall.

Parkways, according to Commissioner Moses, were designed to afford good roads, beautiful views and leisurely, pleasurable motor trips. Parkways, according to many of the people who use them, are the shortest and quickest unobstructed routes to most destinations and are ideal places to dispose of unwanted garbage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,500,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Aug. 14 and to mature on Nov. 13 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 11 -- Several thousand Pennsylvania Railroad passengers traveling between New York, Philadelphia, Washington and New Brunswick were delayed from eight minutes to an hour early this morning after a passenger train stalled at the east end of the Hackensack River drawbridge, in Secaucus.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Heeled over against a lively and steady south-southwest breeze in Nantucket Sound, the New York Yacht Club fleet competed today in the organization's ninety-eighth annual regatta and for the Astor Cup which became fogbound last year.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- Harvey J. Scott, Superintendent of Police in the Department of Public Safety for the last thirteen years, was dismissed today as a result of a brawl in an East End restaurant last Saturday night.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States carrier Boxer steamed into this Japanese naval base today with a dozen fire-ruined planes and a deckload of heroes. Nine dead and scores of injured had already been evacuated by air.
A "prosperous luncheonette" in the domestic terminal at La Guardia Airport has been ordered closed to make way for a nursery, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.

Foreign governments' restrictions on the dollar earnings of exporters continue generally severe with a few outstanding exceptions, according to a study released yesterday by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade.

KALIMPONG, India, Aug. 11 -- The Tibetan and Chinese Communist Governments have reached an agreement under which Tibet is to have permanent representatives in Peiping to deal with matters affecting Tibet's internal autonomy and Chinese-Tibetan trade, according to reports reaching here from Lhasa.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Stunned members of India's upper house heard P. Sundarayya, a Communist, openly threaten to shoot landlords and black marketeers after public trials if the Communists gained power.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, completed a nation-wide survey today which, he said, shows that the drought will cause no widespread increase in prices.

The stock market took its worst beating yesterday in more than three months in terms of price recession. Despite the battering that the list encountered, the volume failed to enlarge on the decline. Brokers considered that the price structure had not been materially impaired and that the retreat stemmed from purely technical considerations.

Declaring that it was not in the "public interest to endanger the economy of the United States by destroying the theatres, which are the heartbeat of every American community," Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, yesterday decried the Department of Justice's recent suit to compel film companies to sell their 16-millimeter pictures to television.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- A solution of one of the world's greatest archaeological enigmas -- the mystery of the Mayan hieroglyphics -was claimed today on behalf of a young Soviet scientist and research specialist in the field of Mayan culture.
The price of zinc was a subject for considerable discussion and no small amount of confusion in the trade yesterday.

A group of seventy obviously excited British school teachers arrived here yesterday to exchange positions with an equal number of American teachers during the 1952-53 academic year. The second and last contingent from England, their interests ran all the way from hobnobbing with cowboys and Indians to finding American husbands.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, said yesterday that he would go to Springfield, Ill., tomorrow to submit detailed proposals to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for campaign speeches in New York State by the Democratic candidate for President and by other national leaders of the party.
WAVERLY, Ohio, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Pike County citizens got a jolt today when they learned that three of their towns were marked for atomic age destruction.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 12 (AP) -- West Virginia's "ice-pick surgery" project was marked concluded today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor has decided to wage one big campaign for altering the Taft-Hartley Law, rather than the piecemeal job that has been done up to now.

While an estimated 410,000 street and highway accident cases will be reported to the Motor Vehicle Bureau this year, statistics indicate that about 95 per cent of the 4,219,863 registered vehicles in service in the state are insured.

Two more registration statements under the Quinby plan for savings through purchases of common stocks have become effective with the Securities and Exchange Commission. They are Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and General Motors Corporation.

KEYSTONE, S. D., Aug. 12 -- A first-day issue of commemorative stamps yesterday marked the silver anniversary of the carving of four giant stone. Presidential portraits on Mount Rushmore. Five thousand persons watched the ceremony at the foot of the mountain.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen, a slim southpaw Army sergeant from Fort Sill, Okla., and Sid Schwartz, burly right-hander from Brooklyn, supplied the surprises today as singles competition in the seventy-first annual Newport invitation tennis tourney progressed to the round of sixteen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The chemical industry has "firm plans" to complete more than two-thirds of the expansion requested by the Government to meet defense and civilian needs, the Defense Production Administration reported today.

The top echelon of the advertising profession needs considerable training; according to Bayard F. Pope Jr., a vice president at Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, and author of a series articles called Strategy of Handling Accounts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate s Southern Democrats are marshaling already to meet an expected effort to force a fight on the intermixed closure rule-civil rights issue when the new Congress assembles in January.

Two teen-agers were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony i Court on a charge of homicide arising from the slaying l[St Fl-iday Of Marcus B. Harrelson, 26 years old, in his apartment at 127 Remsen Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The family milk bill will go higher in the month ahead, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Alan Gregg, vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation of New York City, today told a panel of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation that the whole report of the commission should be "suffused" with the idea that medical care should be accepted as one of four main essentials of the family budget.

It was recently reported in Topics of The Times that United States cigarette consumption rose to a record 421 billions during the 1951-52 marketing year, again emphasizing the tremendous extent of this habit. Commencing as it now does among high school boys and girls who try smoking to keep social pace with other classmates, few find themselves able to break the craving for nicotine when greater emotional maturity is reached five or ten years later.
CAIRO, Aug. 12 -- The Egyptian press published today the details of the draft land reform legislation drawn up by Army Headquarters and passed on to the Government for action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the selection of a 6,500-acre site in Pike County, Ohio, for a $1,200,000,000 plant to produce uranium 235, the fissionable isotope of uranium, a chief component of the atomic bomb.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Steve Tell, a trotter, and Gene Jester, a pacer, won the big events of the Grand Circuit meeting today but the big thrill was the season's first two-minute mile, registered by Yankee Hanover.

A surprisingly varied number of sources have inspired the new collection of wallpapers introduced by Katzenbach Warren, 575 Madison Avenue, and available from that showroom through decorators. The subject matter of these patterns ranges from a somewhat exotic design of the feet of the Indian god Krishna, to a depiction of delicately wrought-iron porch chairs, and also includes more conventional pictures of objects like daisy chains, kitchen molds, wood pigeons and zinnias.

No one can argue with the justice of the premise that a public utility is entitled to a fair return on its investment. It is the responsibility of the regulatory body, the state Public Service Commission, to see that Consolidated Edison receives rates that will assure such an income.

The disabled children at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center have not been able to get out and go swimming all sum mer, so yesterday a small beach was opened there for the children.

MANILA, Wednesday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Filipino Mohammedan bandits, flashing swords and screaming for Christian blood, cut down three soldiers and wounded six yesterday as Philippine military units tightened their trap on the notorious robber chief, Datu Kamlon.

NOW that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has officially recognized increased waterfowl production, wildfowlers may reasonably expect at least a minor relaxation in the waterfowl regulations for this fall.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- A former union leader who had been expelled by the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., was ordered reinstated today by Circuit Judge Arthur Webster.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -Court action hag turned back to the Federal Power Commission for further consideration a proposal of the New York State Power Authority for St. Lawrence River power development.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Following is the timetable by which the Government has poured approximately $6,000,000,000 into construction costs alone for its five major atomic energy plants:
A chic, sophisticated group of college fashions was presented to the press yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel by Saks Fifth Avenue.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Aug. 12 -- The open season has started for Congressional prospectors digging for absentee votes among the dark hills of Korea. And the Eighth Army is ready for an invasion that should bring at least sixteen members of Congress to this peninsula within a month.

I agree fully with everything expressed in your editorial in the Aug. 10 issue, headed "Getting Out the Vote." The efforts on the part of the organizations mentioned to induce voters to register and vote are to be highly commended. But what strikes me as too absurd for words is the necessity for such efforts.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Stuart Miller, a 24-year-old right-hander from North Hampton, Mass., broke into the major leagues today by pitching the Cardinals to a 1-0 victory over the Cubs.

Anybody who tries to analyze New York City's crime statistics immediately finds himself standing in quicksand. Two major reforms in methods of reporting crime have been made within the Police Department since the fall of 1950. Commissioner Murphy reported that total felony complaints in 1950 rose 34.8 per cent over 1949.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- East Germany today completed the first stage in a complete reorganization of its internal administration designed to bring all political units, down to the village level, under tighter central control.

Good propose can be served by a meeting now in progress in Washington sponsored jointly by the Aircraft Industries Association, the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Air Transport Association. It brings together some fifty educational leaders from twenty-two cities for a ten-day conference to keep teaching thought abreast of the increasingly important impact of civilian and military aviation on community living.

In a further effort to ease the dangers and crushing burdens of the present armament race the three principal Western Powers yesterday proposed to take the whole disarmament problem temporarily out of the hands of the deadlocked United Nations Disarmament Commission, which they sponsored, and to submit it to a conference of the five Great Powers, to be supplemented later by regional conferences of the other nations involved.

The New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau intends to find out why there has been a two-year delay in fetching the legislative spirits of ammonia that were supposed to revive the drooping legitimate theatre here.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the country's third largest steel company, suffered a 39 per cent decline in its earnings for the first half of this year, reflecting the effect of the fifty-three-day nation-wide steel strike that ended July 24.

TEHERAN, Iran. Aug. 12 -Premier Mohammed Mossadegh astounded his National Front group of Deputies today by sending to them for consideration a decree that he intends to issue taking 20 per cent from the powerfully entrenched Iranian landlords' share of the harvests and giving it to the poverty-stricken Iranian peasants.

The United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, George F. Kennan, believes that recent Western comment on the Kremlin's virulent domestic "Hate America" campaign has placed Moscow on the defensive, leading the Soviet Government to offer lame and insubstantial denials, it became known yesterday.

May I be permitted to make a few remarks on your editorial comment published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 5, devoted to the generous grant of $2,900,000 made by the Ford Foundation to refugees and of which I, as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, have been made sole trustee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- All-rail shipment of iron ore from the northern ranges is under way in considerable volume, a survey disclosed today. Hundreds of heavily laden cars a day are moving south and east to help build up winter stockpiles of ore for the steel mills.

A 16-year-old boy brought into Magistrate's court yesterday as a wayward minor hysterically attacked his mother there. After court attendants subdued the youth, he was manacled and sent to the Bellevue Hospital psychiatric ward in an ambulance.

MANCHESTER Mass., Aug. 12 (UP) -- Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mrs. Thelma Long of Australia scored first-round victories today at the opening of the Essex County Club's twenty-fifth annual women's invitation tennis tournament.

Ownership of the Clinton Gardens apartment development at Robson Place and Clinton Street in Hempstead, L. I., has been conveyed through the sale of common stock by Clinton Terrace Inc., represented by Dreyer Traub, attorneys, to a client of Giller Stein, attorneys.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The suspension of a University of Kentucky football player has been appealed.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 -- The Mexican Government has started a campaign against the illegal flow of migrant labor across the Rio Grande that, according to officials, had drastically reduced the number of "wetbacks" entering the United States in the past fortnight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines defended the United States tonight against criticisms that it was by-passing the United Nations in the conduct of its foreign policy.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Army officials here changed their policy today on the use of Army bands at civilian events after a protest by Local 734, American Federation of Musicians.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 12 -- A strike of 280 employes of the C. F. Mueller Company, manufacturer of macaroni and spaghetti products, closed the plant at 9:30 o'clock this morning. The walk-out protested the temporary suspension of three employes.
Two issues of common stock totaling more than $8,350,000 will be offered for sale today by investment bankers.
An issue of $30,000,000 of bonds was sold at public bidding yesterday by the Los Angeles, Calif., School District. The winning bid was submitted by a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co.

A summer day camp program for young residents at Bell Park Gardens, a forty-acre veterans' cooperative housing project in Bayside, Queens, was observed first-hand yesterday by a group of interested mothers from the Queens area.

ELLENSBURG, Wash., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Turbulent air thwarted efforts by a helicopter pilot today to snatch Alan Robert Grant, 19-year-old University of Washington student, from mountainous country north of here.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Harrison Dillard, winner of four Olympic gold medals in 1948 and 1952, said today he was sure that the Russian athletes who competed in the Olympic games would take home a new and favorable opinion of the Americans.

Plans to promote two popular projects -- world peace and another holiday -- were announced yesterday by the National Citizens Committee for U. N. Day. Choosing Oct. 24, the seventh anniversary of the United Nations, as the day for the observance, leaders of the program hope to set up a "tradition" in record time.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Yale University announced today the appointment of Jordan Olivar, former mentor of Villanova and Loyola of Los Angeles, as acting head coach of football for the 1952 season. The announcement was made yesterday of Herman Hickman's resignation at Yale to accept a lucrative television and public relations post with the General Cigar Company.

Net sales of the Procter Gamble Company and its subsidiaries declined to $818,084,833 in the fiscal year ended on June 30, from $860,687,707 in the preceding fiscal year, which resulted in a drop of $9,564,474 in earnings, the annual report showed yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 12 -- Hopes of a settlement of a three-week-old strike of pier warehousemen at the Army Corps of Engineers depot at the Claremont Terminal here faded today when officials of Marine Warehousemen's Local 1,478, International Longshoremen's Association, failed to attend a conference at the office of Acting Mayor Donald Spence.

Federal taxes will be reduced every year for the next four years, Beardsley Ruml, tax economist and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, predicted yesterday at a panel meeting that was part of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- "Jollyanna," a substantially reworked version of "Flahooley," which ran briefly on Broadway last season, had its premiere here last night to mixed but generally favorable reviews.

ALBUQUERQUE, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Murder charges late today were filed against Cruz Simbola, 52 years old, in the fatal beating of Gerald Nailor, 36 Indian artist whose murals decorate the Interior Building in Washington.

DENVER, Aug. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, charged today that President Truman's Administration "is determined to nail down through its handpicked successors every detail of the doctrines and policies that have brought us to the present situation of bewilderment, indecision and fear for the future."

Members of the jewelry and jewel-bearing industries as well as export-import traders here and abroad awaited anxiously yesterday the decision of President Truman on Tariff Commission recommendations for restricting imports of watch and watch movements.

The initial step in the planned construction of the first new medical school in this city in fifty-three years was taken yesterday when architectural and engineering contracts were signed for the $10,000,000 College of Medicine sponsored by Yeshiva University.

The widely-publicized drought is not the only factor affecting food prices and supplies, according to the American Institute of Food Distribution. Many food markets, it pointed out yesterday, were so unprofitably low last spring that some growers and many packers, planned materially smaller acre-age.

Third-seeded Barry Murtha of Bayside, L. I., paced the favorites into the quarter-finals of the junior division competition yesterday as the Metropolitan Junior and Boys Tennis championships began at the Hispano Club, Queens.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Rain pitter-pattered onto Saratoga today after having sluiced onto the area all through the night. The Saratoga Association's old racing oval was deep in slop. Jockeys on slow horses took a mud-in-the-face beating. But a horse named Tocoli thought the conditions were just ducky.

PERT AMBOY, N. J., Aug. 12 -.1V.ddlesex Cou'nty .oSecutor [Alex'Eber opened todaytiis invesI,tigation' o'f a $,082 slortae :in the ti9e-49 .muds of te ty Tax Collector's Office,- , Fou/.)-'county detectives examined, records of city land. sales,' trying to determine. the method by Which the funds were removed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Trading in grain and soybeans on the Board of Trade today was dominated largely by the Government's August crop figures, these being regarded as bullish on the coarse grains and beans, while the wheat figures were considered rather bearish. Both corn and oats showed substantial gains for a time, with the oats market withstanding heavy profit-taking. However, there was a rather strong undertone.

" Sam Clemens of Hannibal," by the late Dixon Wecter, a biography of "the real-life Tom Sawyer," will be published Aug. 28 by Houghton Mifflin. The story begins with Sam's forebears in Virginia and of their move to Missouri and ends with his earliest literary efforts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, announced today the appointment of Under Secretary David K. E. Bruce to be United States deputy on the council set up by the United States, Australia and New Zealand. He also announced the selection of Washington as the regular meeting place of the council between conferences of the three foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Small Defense Plants Corporation announced today that small business was entitled to roughly one-third of the expansion planned in three electronics fields under goals set up by the Defense Production Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The State Department has called on the Soviet Union again for a reply to proposals for an abbreviated Austrian treaty made by the United States, Britain and France last March 13.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- At the invitation of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, representatives of Governments from all over the world are scheduled to meet in Geneva from Aug. 16 to Sept. 6, to sign the first universal copyright convention.

The death of James A. Brown, the change-booth attendant at the Pennsylvania Avenue subway station, after a hold-up on July 26 has justly induced the Board of Transportation to have a closer examination of safety in the subways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Mutual Security Agency officials reported today a prolonged spurt of interest on the part of United States companies in the possibility of foreign investment in countries where they can be insured by their own Government against loss by expropriation or blocked exchange.
As reported by Drew Middleton recently, the Kremlin "Hate America" propaganda seems to make little impression on the great mass of people in the Soviet Union.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Plans to launch a new Movietime, U. S. A., campaign of tours this fall by Hollywood personalities to help stimulate box-office attendance throughout the country are being discussed by executives of the Council of Motion Picture Organizations at a series of meetings here this week.

A man suspected as a narcotics seller escaped out of a window from two United States deputy marshals after a fight in which fifteen shots were fired in his apartment at 462 East 144th Street, the Bronx, the police reported.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Trading in German bonds again was the most active feature on the London stock markets today. In other sections business generally contracted, although the undertones were firm and price movements narrow.

Rehabilitation, rather than punitive measures, is the keystone to the drug-addiction problem among teen-agers. Miss Dorris Clarke, chief probation officer of the City Magistrates' Courts, declared yesterday in a talk to New York University's sixth Institute on Problems of Narcotic Control, held at the university's Washington Square center.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- New York State's continuing search for crime and political corruption has cost the taxpayers $861,437.06 so far and the end is not in sight.

BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- A United States Army sign-painter burned the midnight oil last night preparing a sign redesignating the mecca of about 7,000 Americans in this city as "Truman Hall" before the President's daughter, Margaret, could find out that some changes had been made.
The United States chess team was beaten by Finland, 21/2 -- 1 1/2, yesterday in the third round of the international team championship tournament, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday 12 to 27 points net higher than on Monday.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 12 -- The Democratic State Central Committee at a meeting here tonight set Sept. 5 and 6 as the dates for a special state convention to nominate a candidate to serve the final four years of the Senate term of Senator Brien McMahon, who died last month.

A revised discount plan granting a 25 per cent reduction in nighttime rates to most of its network radio advertisers was overwhelmingly approved yesterday in Chicago by a radio committee representing 120 affiliated stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The works and voices of persons of many places and times were brought together yesterday for a music lovers' tribute to the late Thomas A. Edison. The occasion, which was observed in a cool corner of Manhattan's Bryant Park, was the seventy-fifth anniversary of the day when the Wizard of Menlo Park jotted down the ideas that led to his patenting, a few months later, the first method for artistically recording and reproducing sound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that Alberto Moravia, an Italian novelist, had been told he could appeal to the Attorney General for admittance to the United States.

VERBANIA, Italy, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ontonio Morando, District Attorney, said today only high level authorities could decide whether Italy would drop a case against two Americans accused of slaying Major William Holohan, their commanding officer, in war-time Italy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -Henry W. Grunewald, the "silent witness" of the House tax scandals investigation, has been ordered to appear before two grand juries checking Internal Revenue Bureau affairs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A New York marine was convicted today of driving about the Capital with lemons painted on his car. In Washington, that's a crime.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Western Big Three proposed today Big Five talks and regional conferences aimed at limiting the military strength of the nations and eliminating atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The automobile industry may be able to start 1953 at a production rate of 5,000,000 cars a year, National Production Authority officials said today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Will Clement Attlee, leader of the British Labor party, be a man or a mouse when he goes to Morecombe next month to confront his rivals at the party's annual convention? Political commentators searching for an answer to that question have begun to see signs that the former Prime Minister, whose mild demeanor is sometimes deceptive, is getting tougher with rebellious elements in the party.

The Colonial Sand and Stone Company, with which the Smoke Control Bureau has had "a lot of trouble," received yesterday a summons for causing dense smoke. Before getting the summons, the sand company had been served with a number of violation notices calling upon it to notify the bureau of steps taken to abate smoke nuisance, William G. Christy, director of the bureau, said.

Wally Cox, the Milquetoast wired for sound, is using his priceless monologues as the nucleus of a half-hour situation comedy called "Mr. Peepers" (9:30 P. M. Wednesday over N. B. C. television). While the program is above the average of summer video shows, it still is a far cry from good farce and overextends Mr. Cox's unique if rather limited talents.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Representatives of the six nations linked in the European army plan were unable to agree today on the common standard of two years of compulsory military training that was described yesterday by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, as a minimum.

Bayard P. Peakes should be committed to the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, it was recommended yesterday in a psychiatric report that noted that the 29-year-old would-be scientist was aware he had killed Eileen Fahey "but has no general understanding of what he has done or that the act was wrong."
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- All the top favorites won their first round matches with ease in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association tournament at the Apawamis Club today.

The Rockland Hospital Guild, Inc., which consists of parents, relatives and friends of mental patients, protests the usage of such words as lunatic, insane and maniac, especially when used by public officials. They should realize that thousands of mentally ill are harmless and not violent.

Cpl. Kenneth Bergsohn, a Marine of 385 Grand Street, who got married last Saturday, accidentally gave a bellboy a $100 bill as a tip yesterday afternoon as he hurriedly left the Statler Hotel, where he spent part of a brief honeymoon, to catch a train back to camp at Cherry point, N. C.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- The Mutual Security Agency has decided to withdraw its action freezing counterpart funds for the modernization of German coal mines on the promise of the West German Government and coal operators to make a greater effort to increase coal production.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that a decision had been reached last Thursday to add 1,600 policemen to the force between October and next June, bringing the department up to its authorized budget strength.

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Residents of Shanks Village, the temporary housing project converted from military barracks six years ago to accommodate veterans' families and college students under the G. I. bill of rights, learned today that they must vacate their apartments by July 1, 1953.

PARSIPPANY, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Archibald S. Alexander of Bernardsville, N. J., former Under Secretary of the Army and Democratic nominee for the United State Senate, attacked tonight as "mistaken" those political leaders who characterized American foreign policy as "a policy of containment."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Jim Dyck's two home runs, one in the eighth and other in the eleventh, gave the Browns a 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox today. They were his twelfth and thirteenth homers of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The capital got its first look at Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as the Democratic nominee today and found an affable individual with a quick smile and an adequate stock of quips to lighten the tensions of a crowded schedule.

NORTH TARRYTOYN, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation won a complete victory tonight on its application for a rezoning of the Mount Pleasant part of the old James Butler estate, which the company now can convert into a $12,500,000 to $17,000,000 headquarters.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 12 -- Hundreds of stars in the heavens are hissing at us. Astronomers are not yet certain just what these peculiar, noisy stars look like. Only one or two have been seen through telescopes.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Town Court Judge Julius H. Groher of New Canaan will preside at the trial here on Monday of the Westport Woman's Club on charges of fraud and illegal operation of a lottery.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A total of fifty-five yearlings went under the hammer tonight as the thirty-eighth annual Saratoga yearling sales got under way at the Fasig-Tipton sales paddock.

TOKYO, Wednesdays Aug. 13 (AP) -- A scandal of missing national treasure -- including Empress Nagako's diamond-studded crown -- shook Japan today with overtones of corruption involving wartime Japanese and United States occupation officials.

The new Holland-America liner Maasdam, sister of the economy liner Ryndam, is now en route to New York by way of Montreal on her initial Atlantic crossing. The ship left Rotterdam Monday and called at Le Havre and Southampton yesterday. She is due here Aug. 27.

The sea trials of the new air-conditioned transport U. S. N. S. Geiger, scheduled for next week, will be held under the direction of Harry W. Pierce, recently named executive vice president of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation in Camden, the yard announced yesterday.
Business executive are optimistic on the business trend for the remainder of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Americans fighting in Korea may start drawing their new $45 a month combat bonus this month, but veterans will not receive retroactive payments for at least another month, Defense Secretary Robert A. Lovett said today.
May I congratulate you on your splendid editorial "Death on the Highway," dealing with a vital problem.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednesday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Judge Francis Cherry early today turned back Gov. Sidney S. McMath's bid, backed by President Truman, for a third term as Arkansas' Governor.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Billy Hitchcock singled in Gus Zernial with the winning run tonight to give the Athletics' right-handed Carl Scheib a thirteen-inning 4-3 victory over the Red Sox. Clyde Vollmer belted a two-run homer in the eighth to put the Red Sox into a 3-3 deadlock.

PELHAM, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Charles Jacob, retired piano manufacturer and one of the oldest members of the New York Athletic Club, was drowned while swimming in Long Island Sound this afternoon. He would have been 95 years old next Sunday. He lived at 85-15 Britton Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- Commenting on the Korean situation today, Pravda said there was a growing will among the North Korean people to achieve a final and full victory "over the American aggressors.''

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Navy tonight placed the full blame for the mid-Atlantic collision of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson and the aircraft carrier Wasp -- a disaster that cost 176 lives in April -- squarely upon the Hobson's commanding officer. The skipper, Lieut. Comdr. William J. Tierney, went down with his ship.

Last night was to have been a big baseball night here, with the Dodgers and Giants ready to swing away at each other at Ebbets Field and the Yankees set to entertain the Senators at the Stadium. But rain washed out both contests.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 2 quotes Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, as saying that "any civil rights plank is academic without a promise to change the Senate rules." Conceivably the content of Senate Rule XXII makes any promise to change the closure procedure of the Senate equally academic.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -Guy Gabrielson, former Republican National Chairman, was accused in Superior Court today of illegally acquiring between $75,000 and $100,000 in stocks from a wealthy widow.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is planning to make a major campaign issue of the scandals uncovered in the Bureau of Internal Revenue by a House Ways and Means subcommittee and has asked for specific information on the more flagrant cases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois discussed campaign strategy at the White House today in what both Democratic leaders described as a "very satisfactory" meeting.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The wedding of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Miss Clarissa Churchill will take place at Caxton Hall, Westminster, on Thursday morning. It will be a civil ceremony because the Church of England generally does not permit a church wedding for a divorced person, even if, as in Mr. Eden's case, he was the offended partner when his previous marriage was dissolved.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Elton M. Evans, 48 years old, controller of the John B. Stetson Company, Philadelphia hat manufacturer, was found hanging early today from a joist in the cellar of his home here. Dr. Frank M. Goldys, acting medical examiner of Danbury, said Mr. Evans had committed suicide.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Federal judge dismissed today a $5,500,000 suit against a chain of theatres and eleven motion picture companies accused of violating the Sherman - Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson asserted today that the mysterious disappearance of a United States citizen reported to have escaped from a Czechoslovak prison emphasized the "outrageous consequences" of the failure of the Communist satellite Governments to respect their treaties.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- A test will be made in Supreme Court here of the legality of adding fluoride to public water supplies to retard tooth deterioration. The Peekskill Water Commission said today it had been served with a complaint in an injunction suit brought by Charles E. Winslow, an elderly Peekskill attorney.
SPRINGFIELD, Aug. 12 -- Governor Stevenson said tonight that the 1952 Democratic Presidential campaign may be opened on Labor Day both by himself and President Truman.

The history of England, the coming coronation of Queen Elizabeth and the fabulous glitter of Cartier's jewels were all woven into the Chanda collection of fall millinery shown yesterday at Chanda's West Fifty-seventh Street salon. The result was sparkling, highly imaginative and thoroughly delightful.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12 -- The Nassau Civil Defense organization, continuing its search for a satisfactory air raid warning system, put a powerful special siren through some preliminary tests here today and found that it was not a howling success.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Prices for some British goods and services are beginning to be stabilized and can be expected to remain steady for several months, the Treasury stated today.

Mrs. H. F. Dobbin, a 14-stroke handicap player, of the Hempstead Golf Club, produced the best shot ever made by a woman in the World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one tournament yesterday in the nineteenth annual event at the Bayside Links.

Federal mediator held separate sessions yesterday with officials of the New York Central System and with officers of three railroad unions in the second day of their effort to mediate a dispute that is threatening to cause a strike on the railroad's lines east of Buffalo.

" THE end of life is not happiness, only wisdom," the Golinskers used to say. They knew from bitter experience how small was their chance for happiness in Golinsk, a miserable little village in the Russian Pale some forty miles from Minsk. In 1885, when everything seemed to happen at once in Golinsk, there were only sixty families there, of which nineteen were Jewish.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 12 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's choice as his successor, Lieut. Gov. Sherwood Dixon, was picked today as the Democratic nominee for Governor of Illinois by a close vote of the Democratic State Central Committee.

Frank McGuire resigned as head basketball coach of St. John's University in Brooklyn yesterday to take a similar position at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. McGuire, who will be 38 years old in November, was released from a five-year contract that had three years to go.

Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, commanding general of the Strategic Air Command, United States Air Force, received the "Airman of the Year" trophy last night as "the man who did the most last year for peaceful aviation."

DURING an Olympic year lawn tennis is pretty much in eclipse, as is every other sport not on the program of the games with the exception of baseball, which defies competition from any source, including Presidential nominating conventions.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 (UP) -- Five election commissioners described as supporters of Representative F. Edward Hebert were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiring to violate the Federal election laws in the 1950 Democratic Congressional primary.
Those delicate-tasting shellfish that look like infant lobsters -- the fresh-water crawfish -- are back in town.

King Faisal II of Iraq, a personable and self-possessed young man of 17, arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary for a month's visit that will take him to many parts of the United States. He had the air of well-being that might be expected of a monarch whose country, in striking contrast to adjoining Iran, had recently acquired oil revenues that are expected to reach $165,000,000 a year by 1955.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Wildcat strikes spread through eight Armour Company packing plants today as the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O. , negotiated for a new contract in Chicago. About 10,000 workers were idle.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -Hard-fighting United States Marines early today beat off a new Chinese attack on "Bunker Hill," a ridge position near the armistice conference site at Panmunjom, which for the last three days has been the scene of some of the sharpest local encounters of the Korean war.

Maine potatoes dropped the 25-cent trading limit yesterday on the New York Mercantile. Exchange as operators assessed the state-by- state breakdown of the Department of Agriculture crop estimate. This showed the Maine potato crop down about 4,000,000 bushels from the figure of a month easier, leaving a net estimated crop of 53,040,000 bushels.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 12 -- Two fully trained United States Marine Air Squadrons will be assigned for duty with the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean early this fall it was announced from Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe today.

Pending the outcome of negotiations with British Actors Equity, with the deadline fixed for Dec. 31, the American Actors Equity yesterday took a decisive step, to the vast relief of Broadway producers, by suspending the application of a recently adopted and drastic policy restricting the employment of alien performers.
H. W. Fairfax Advertising Agency, Inc, in 15-17 E 49th St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co brokers.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Fred Annon, Rye Wood club professional, posted a 5-under-par 31, 35 -- 66 to lead a field of eighty-five in the fifty-four-hole Westchester County Golf Association open championship at the Willows Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Three new aides picked by Attorney General James P. McGranery were sworn in today.
GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Twenty - eight fresh - water sailors from all parts of the nation today were named as qualifiers in races to determine the National Snipe championship on Green Lake.

CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dozing passengers on a Dixie Greyhound bus speeding through the pre-dawn darkness suddenly found themselves trapped in the bus near here today with water swirling about them.

Recent reports of drought damage to crops in New England, the South and the Mountain States have aroused understandable fear about the prospects for food and other farm-product supplies in the year ahead. Serious reductions in crop production this year would tend to raise food prices, thus increasing the cost of living and giving another impetus to inflationary trends.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 -- None of the T-41 Walker Bulldog light tanks, built at the Cadillac tank plant here, has met Army requirements.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Amateur gladiolus growers eclipsed the professionals today as the annual Eastern International Gladiolus Show opened in the West End Armory. Some 5,000 braved a driving downpour to be on hand for the start of this two-day event.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 12 -- The Economic Committee of the Belgian Cabinet is studying a dollar bonus proposal intended to alleviate Belgium's chronic dollar shortage.

Demolition of the Randall Memorial Church, a copy of St. Paul's in London, is under way at the Sailors Snug Harbor, the home of retired mariners and a landmark on the north shore of Staten Island. Workmen were busy yesterday salvaging the windows and the big organ.
GENEVA, Aug. 12 -- Nature seems to be conspiring with world economic forces against Europe this summer.

Add number four to the list of casualties in the top command of price stabilization since the President issued his emergency proclamation some six months after Korea. Unless he should decide to reconsider his decision between now and Sept. 1, Ellis G. Arnall will go the way of Alan Valentine, Eric Johnston and Michael DiSalle.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- A bill granting the World Zionist Organization a special status was withdrawn from the Knesset (parliament) today by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion. The action was taken because the House voted yesterday to accord the Zionist group the status of "representative organization of all Jewish people" instead of that of "authorized agency," as the Israeli Government had proposed.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 12 -- A five-hour conference between representatives of the Port of New York Authority and officials of this municipality settled one major point at issue and left three others still to be discussed at another session, set for next Tuesday, on the sub-leasing of Federally-controlled piers by the Port Authority.

There are few appeals whose urgency is as self-evident -- as the continued call by the Red Cross for blood donations. By radio, newspaper, television and poster the organization is constantly trying to drive home the single simple fact that a steady flow of blood into the bloodbanks across the nation must be maintained so that men wounded on the battlefields of Korea will not have to die for want of plasma or whole blood.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears intercepted two of Chuck Ortmann's passes to set up two touchdowns in the third quarter and a 14-9 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a charity exhibition football game tonight.

The production of steel in the first seven months of this year fell to 46,637,256 net tons, a drop of 14,351,224 tons from the corresponding period a year ago as a result of the prolonged steel strike.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A spokesman for the British Overseas Airways Corporation said today that the company planned to operate jet airliners across the Atlantic within two years.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Andy Stanfield of Jersey City won both the 100 and 200-meter dashes today as a team of United States Olympic stars easily captured an international track meet, mostly against Swiss opposition.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,340, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday Korea time:

SEDALIA, Mo., Aug. 12 (UP) -- Charles D. (Casey) Stengel, manager of the Yankees, and Dr. Forrest C. (Phog) Allen, famed University of Kansas and Olympic basketball coach, entered Missouri's Sports Hall of Fame today.

Earlier in the summer the prophets of doom came up with a winner. Taking note of a wet spring, as well as certain handiwork on the part of near-by mankind, they said this would be a fine year for mosquitos. They were right, as the prophets of doom invariably are right when it comes to mosquitos.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The upset of the defending champion, Barbara Bruning of Whippoorwill, and a close victory for Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, the medalist, marked play in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club today.

The largest block of life insurance policy funds invested in the first six months of this year went into bonds of leading United States corporations. During this period a total of $2,422,000,000 was channeled into the financing of business and industry, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Selective Service officials said today they might have to call middle-aged physicians and dentists to fill medical quotas sometime after October.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- United States Marines -- proudly flying a bullet-tattered flag given them by a Korean orphanage -- smashed a third Chinese Communist assault on "Bunker" hill last night with blazing gunfire.

Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation for the first half of this year increased to $8,600,319, or $2.49 a share on common stock from $6,307,992, or $1.77 in the corresponding six months last year. Sales rose to $323,691,593 from $185,220,572.

An automatic pistol, described as a 6.35 millimeter was identified late yesterday as the weapon with which Patrolman James J. McGillion of the District Attorney's squad was fatally shot in Harlem at 4 A. M. on Tuesday, it was announced last night.
The Keystone Mariner, first of the largest and fastest class of dry cargo ships in the world, left for her sea trials last night.
Separates were endorsed for all hours of the day in the presentation of college fashions at McCreery's yesterday.

The heaving tides of unrest that sweep through large parts of the post-war world are producing, in addition to the growing unity among the free nations and the specific unification movement in Europe, at least one more constructive development, and that is the spreading wave of what is generally characterized as land reform.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13 -- Army Secretary Frank Pace Jr. said tonight, after conferring with Marshal Tito, that the latter had taken the initiative in informing him of the decision, announced last night, to dispatch a military mission to Greece. The Secretary added that a general conversation ensued on the problems of cooperation between Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia, but that the discussions remained within the limits set by Marshal Tito.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that the bureau would make public the applications of organizations asking for tax-free status. He added that the agency had not yet decided how far it could go in disclosing tax compromise settlements.

The assignment of the weathered and worn British cable laying and repairing ship John W. Mackay is to find and fix faults in the 47,000 miles of undersea cable owned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A Government manpower directive issued today declared that the country was wasting needed skills and abilities because of an indiscriminate rejection of older workers.

A program for the preparation and distribution of engineering and technical data on the uses of lead was announced yesterday by the National Lead Burning Association after a meeting of the executive board at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Williams College has added a hotel manager to its staff as part of an anti-inflation campaign to serve students with high-quality food at low prices.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- An attempt by the Westchester Citizens Transportation Committee to acquire control of the Yonkers Railroad Company was in effect blocked today by the refusal of the Public Service Commission to approve a proposed exchange of certain properties of the two companies. The commission held the proposed move not in the public interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The notice to Southern Democratic Senators that, very early in the sessions of the next Congress, a bipartisan effort will be made to change the Senate rules in the interest of facilitating passage of "civil rights" legislation was accompanied by reports that this will take the form of a challenge of the historical concept that the Senate is a continuous body.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 13 -- Militiamen recruited under Belgium's twenty-four-month military service law will be sent "on furlough" after they have served twenty-one months, the Belgian Cabinet decided today.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- After being held up a day by rain, Maureen Connolly, 17-year-old national and Wimbledon titleholder, started in the star-studded Essex County Club women's invitation tournament today by defeating Mrs. Helen Pedersen Rihbany of Boston, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, will launch the Democratic party's real campaign on Labor Day, Sept. 1, with major speeches in two politically important cities.

VIENNA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The music-festival city of Salzburg was reported tonight to be planning an appeal to President Truman against United States Army plans to build a tank training ground on the outskirts. The President was named an honorary citizen of Mozart's birthplace last year.

Without uranium 235 an atomic bomb could not have been devised. But uranium 235 constitutes only 0.7 per cent of all the natural uranium in the world. Moreover, uranium 235 is intimately mixed with the more plentiful uranium 238. A chemist cannot tell one from the other, but a physicist can, by weighing them.

Another rise in the price of sheets was announced yesterday by several leading manufacturers. The increase was expected in view of the strong market in cotton after last week's crop report, and the fact that some mills with nationally advertised lines had sold their production through September.
Meal-trade distress with price ceilings and a record day in potatoes on the New York Mercantile Exchange dominated the commodity market news yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug 13 -- Dr. Rajendra Prasad, the President of India, has taken the lead in his Government's economy drive by turning back to the treasury each month 40 per cent of his salary, which is the equivalent of $2,100. He retains after taxes only $735, his secretary said today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 13 -- The World Assembly of Jewish Choirs, comprised of choral groups from nine countries, sang tonight at the wine festival in Zichronyaakov, a village of vinyards and gardens on the spur of the Carmel Range. The festival was attended by 40,000 persons.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 13 -- Fascist youths belonging to the Sumka celebrated tonight the end of martial law in Teheran by smashing a Tudeh Communist party reading room and destroying books in a kiosk selling Communist literature. The Communists turned up too late to protect their reading room and began to shout:
YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- A young man named Cuff coughed up an allegedly stolen $425 diamond ring here today while gasping for breath under police questioning about a jewelry theft.

MOSCOW, Aug. 13 -- Charges in the United States that a "hate America" campaign was being conducted in the Soviet Union evidently have engaged the closest attention on the part of Soviet specialists in foreign affairs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Rogers Hornsby returned to Wrigley Field today for the first time since 1933 as a National League player or manager and his Reds marked the occasion by crushing the Cubs in the first game of a double-header, 11 -- 3.
WETZLAR, Germany, Aug. 13 -- The Leitz concern here, which makes Leica cameras, announced today it would no longer deliver supplies to its former branch in New York, Leitz, Inc.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP) -- A world pacing record was tied, and Hit Song, second to Sharp Note in the Hambletonian last week, avenged that defeat in the Review 3-year-old trot to headline Grand Circuit races at the Illinois State Fair today.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Most sections of the London stock market registered improvement today under the influence of British Government securities which gained up to ten shillings ($1.40).

DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Joe Dobson of the White Sox, 35-year-old right-hander who specializes in whipping the Tigers, did it again tonight for the fifth time this season. He allowed only four hits in the 7-to-1 victory, one of the blows a homer by Johnny Groth on Dobson's first pitch of the game.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 13 -- Under a master development program devised by Solomon Trone, a United States engineer, the Israel Government is preparing to invest $615,000,000 of the reparations funds to be paid by West Germany, $181,000,000 obtained from other countries and 825,000,000 in local currency over a ten-year period.

THE first thing a fellow should do on returning to the store is to look around and take stock. He quickly discovers that an astonishing amount of business has been done while he has been gadding about somewhere else. Hence this is in the nature of an inventory sale in order to catch up on what has happened in the interval.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- A major reorganization of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau to simplify administrative procedures and provide stricter enforcement of driver license suspensions and fraudulent applications was announced today by Commissioner James R. MacDuff.
A child can't keep a secret -- or so they say.

Rather than the Internal Security Act -- Senator McCarran's pride and joy -- being "cruel stupidity," as you say, it is, and has been, in my opinion, an absolute necessity. In the first place, what happened under that law to Karl Latva would never have occurred if he had not waited all these years to take out his citizenship papers.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- The Public Service Commission ordered today a public hearing on Aug. 26 on a proposal by the Long Island Water Corporation for a 50 per cent increase in rates for fire-protection service to thirty-one Nassau Country villages and districts. The hearings will be held at 233 Broadway, New York, at 10 A. M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- The Jaffe Agency is in the process of completing a "package" deal for the filming of "Hermiston," a transplanted adaptation of the Robert Louis Stevenson story, "Weir of Hermiston."

CAIRO, Aug. 13 -- Egyptian troops were called out today to put down demonstrations near Alexandria by 6,000 textile workers who had sought to buttress their demands for higher wages and better treatment by setting fire to the cotton mills and damaging the machinery.

William Shinkman of Split Rock, a 54-year-old investment broker, came within 11 inches of the cup yesterday in the seventh and final day of the nineteenth annual World-Telegram and Sun's hole-in-one tournament at the Bayside links.

TOKYO, Aug. 13 -- Japanese Government circles said today that the agreement under which the United States is to lend Japan eighteen small warships and fifty coastal defense vessels for a minimum of five years probably would be signed here within a week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave final approval today to distribution by the American Power and Light Company of its holdings in the Washington Water Power Company, Spokane, Wash.

Arthur W. Wallander, New York City Director of Civil Defense, received from the Civil Defense Research Associates a plaque extolling him for his work in civil defense, at a brief ceremony yesterday in his office at 425 Avenue of Americas.
Communists have attempted to infiltrate the Boy Scouts of America but have been refused membership or weeded out, Dr. Arthur A. Schuck, Chief Scout 'Executive declared here yesterday.

The season for fresh lima beans, now at its height, will continue well into October with the bulk of the shipments coming from Long Island and New Jersey. We are reminded of this by the local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing, which adds that those who like the sweet, tender bean probably need no further urging to include it on the shopping list.

GENEVA, Aug. 13 -- The North Atlantic community's new machinery for translating plans for military objectives into economically realizable programs has shown a tendency to break down before the Presidential elections in the United States and this has given the pessimists something about which to crow.

PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 13 (UP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley said today before leaving for Springfield, Ill., that he would not comment on a labor-backed move to return him to the United States Senate seat he gave up four years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Sam Jethroe slammed two home runs to lead the Braves to a 9-to-3 victory over the Phils in the second game of a twi-night double-header tonight, after Karl Drews had pitched a five-hitter to give the Phils a 3-to-0 triumph in the opener.
New life returned to the railroad issues yesterday, this force being responsible for giving some life to the stock market, which otherwise was dull and inactive.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 13 -- Jewish doctors from eighteen countries attending the World Congress of Jewish Physicians in Jerusalem heard today an appeal from the medical authorities here for help in the task of organizing Israel's national health and medical services.
The Appellate Division in a special session yesterday, after more than two hours of argument, reserved decisions in three contests over nominating petitions in next Tuesday's primary election.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 13 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina has signed a petition to place an independent slate of Presidential Electors pledged to the Republican nominee, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, on the state ballot for the November election.

On record sales of $234,499,146 for the nine months ended June 30, Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., had a 53 per cent increase in earnings over the prior years period, although its taxes were almost doubled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations opened a three-day series of political meetings today but deferred the main business -- the question of endorsing a candidate -- until tomorrow.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Freddie Annon, the club professional at Rye Wood, captured the thirtieth Westchester County Open golf championship today at the Willows Country Club with a 54-hole score of 210.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended. Aug. 6:

LICQ-ATHERAY, France, Aug. 13 -- A French cave explorer suffering from "cavern disease" -- acute depression caused by his having spent five days in the world's deepest known pot-hole -- fell 130 feet while being hauled to the surface today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- The United Nations truce delegation charged yesterday that the Communists endangered the lives of prisoners they had taken in the Korean war by withholding information regarding new camps to which many captives were recently moved.

A city-wide grand jury investigation into prostitution, which has been going on since February, was disclosed yesterday when a married couple, who maintained a lavishly furnished apartment at 17 East Sixty-seventh Street, were held in $100,000 bail as material witnesses.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate its third request since March, 1951, for a 15-cent fare. The company, whose buses carry about 100,000 passengers daily, asked also that its franchise payment of 5 per cent of gross annual revenue be reduced to one-half of 1 per cent.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Danny Nardico, trailing on points, registered a technical knockout tonight over Lalu Sabotin in the fifth of their scheduled ten-round bout.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Food and Drug Administration decided today to permit the continued distribution of chloromycetin. It ruled, however, that labeling regulations must be changed to warn physicians against using the drug "indiscriminately or for minor infections."

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- A startling upheaval in soybean future prices sparked a general recovery in all grains on the Board of Trade today after early setbacks. Heavy short covering in beans coupled with fairly general commission buying resulted in an extremely strong market, which naturally affected grains.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -- Brazilian Federal troops were in control of the southern town Rio Grande do Sul today and all of the State of Rio Grande do Sul was reported orderly, though tense, after rioting yesterday that cost three lives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Young Progressives of America clubs were organized in thirteen Brooklyn high schools by Communists, according to testimony made public today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

George Nicoll, 44 years old, of 1209 East Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of forgery and grand larceny in the writing of worthless checks. He will have a hearing tomorrow in the same court.
GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Sailors from Florida, New York and Indiana were the leaders after two of the five events in the national snipe championship were completed on Green Lake today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Selection of an unorthodox political newcomer as Arkansas' Democratic nominee for Governor developed today into a smashing defeat for one of President Truman's favorite disciples.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The United States and Australia equally divided quarter-final positions in the Newport invitation tennis tournament today as four star players of each nation scored fourth-round triumphs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Several automobile makers are manning radical changes in their 1953 models in the belief that an expected increase in production next year will result in an out-and-out buyers' market, officials said today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 13 -- The military advisers to the West German Government believe that eighteen months of military service will be sufficient to train the young Germans who will form the twelve divisions to be contributed by West Germany to the projected European army.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 10 to 26 points net higher than on Tuesday.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Aug. 13 (UP) -- The police arrested a former finance company manager today and charged him with defrauding the firm of thousands of dollars in a "good Samaritan" effort to help a family unable to repay its loan.

WITH CANADIAN TROOPS, in Korea, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Edward Murray Dalziel McNaughton said today he did not "like the idea of changing my name," but would wait until next year before deciding whether to do so to collect a $250,000 fortune.

The Canadian dollar reached its highest point in eighteen years yesterday. Trading at $1.0434 in foreign exchange markets here, for a time it took one United States dollar plus a premium of 4-11/32c to buy one Canadian dollar.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 114,685 today, an increase of 375 since last week.

With the United States and Russian teams idle yesterday, West Germany swept a fourth-round match with the Saar and took the lead in the tournament for the international team chess championship, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.
ABERDEEN, Scotland, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Eleven Britons arrived home by yacht today to tell of a strange adventure with Russians who held them up near a group of top-secret islands in the Gulf of Finland.

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to Russia and now chairman of the American Committee for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia, has been selected by President Truman to succeed Dr. Raymond B. Allen as director of the Psychological Strategy Board.

A suspect was arrested on Tuesday in the investigation by the police into the murder of a young wife in Queens and the attempted rape of two adolescent girls in Nassau County less than three weeks ago.

The thing that is rarer than the poetical night in June is that day which is the last before the start of vacation. In fact, it is rare in two senses, the poetical and the actual, the latter rarity being so because the day comes but once a year. In this sense it is far too rare, and no one would object at all if it became commonplace, like blue Monday.

The Park Department's school and neighborhood playground program has been stymied by the Board of Estimate, although construction funds were authorized in the 1952 capital budget, Park Commissioner Robert Moses has reported to Mayor Impellitteri.

New versions of two popular types of wallpaper, "flocked" and plastic-coated, are now available in the Alma Barr wallpaper collection at the Davis Wallpaper Company, 193 Madison Avenue, among other stores.

The trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders in Federal Court for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government was adjourned for twenty-four hours yesterday when one of the defendants reported he was ill and unable to appear.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, gave little comfort today to prospective efforts by avowed liberals to invalidate the Senate's present soft rule on filibusters simply by declaring it out of date.

DENVER, Aug. 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the foreign policy he would institute as President would hold out the hope of obtaining by peaceful means freedom for the peoples now behind the Iron Curtain in both Europe and Asia.
