ARVIDA, Que., Aug. 13 -- Some sixty miles from this Saguenay region center -- the aluminum capital of Canada -- one of the largest hydroelectric projects in North America since the second World War will be opened in a day or so.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Informed quarters here expect that within a few days the British Government will give some indication of a general willingness to reopen negotiations with Iran on the future of the Iranian oil industry.

Reform movements in American history have been slow in starting and long in gaining the momentum necessary to effect their consummation. The tardiness in accepting needed change has too often been used as an argument aimed at defeating reform measures.

The visit which Secretary of the Army Frank Pace is paying to Marshal Tito in Yugoslavia is a reminder of how long and how successfully that strange bedfellow of ours is carrying on without Stalin and the Russians. To be sure, he has only been able to do so with aid from us and, to a lesser degree, from the British and French.

BACK in 1946 zoophiles all over America were reveling in an unusual, back-to-fundamentals diary called "Driftwood Valley," which described the day-by-day routine of a pair of young naturalists in the wilds of British Columbia. Mr. and Mrs. John Stanwell-Fletcher were the couple involved, and Theodora Stanwell-Fletcher was the free-wheeling, and altogether captivating, narrator.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- A 3-year-old filly that was claimed for $5,000 at Belmont Park last October was the front-running winner of $5,875 in the twenty-eighth running of Saratoga's Test Stakes today.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- One of Madeleine Vramant's most enchanting ideas in her new collection is bracelets of sparkling embroidery on the long, tight, pushed-up sleeves of wool jersey middy frocks. Though the bracelets are equally spaced, the glitter of rhinestones on black jersey, cut steel on elephant gray or of gold beads on pine green is concentrated about the elbow since the sleeves are pushed up.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 13 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields of the Larchmont Yacht Club won both races today as the Long Island Sound district trials of the Men's National Sailing championship started at the Riverside Yacht Club.

The city's effort to jail two suspended policemen for their refusal to take the witness stand in the departmental mass trial ran into a snag yesterday because Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor J. Herwitz had neglected to hand 50-cent witness fees to the pair when he had subpoenaed them.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, urged today continuance of truce talks in Korea while "keeping on the heat" to show Communist forces this nation's military strength.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Today's prices of livestock reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Ellis G. Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, stood today on his predictions that there would be a steady and sharp upswing in consumer living costs in the fall.

RAHWAY, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Raleigh Road, a block-long residential street here, had all the aspects today of a deserted village as families moved away temporarily to escape an outbreak of polio. There have been four cases on the street in less than a month, two of them fatal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Department of Agriculture announced new United States standards today for Florida grapefruit, effective on Sept. 14.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Ace Destroyer, a 21-to-1 shot, surprised 17,630 spectators at Washington Park today by galloping to an impressive victory in the $24,000 Prairie State Stakes for 2-year-olds.

The five-story loft building at 626 Tenth Avenue has been sold by Apex Appliances, Inc., to the Rosenberg Foundation. At the same time, the present tenant, Apex Refrigerator Sales Corpration, of which Jules Harris is president, signed a lease for the entire property for ten years with a ten-year renewal option.

The Treasury has just released figures on the progress of its savings bond program during the three-month period which ended July 31 last. This period is of more than ordinary interest, since it comprises the three months immediately following the liberalization of terms on the assortment of securities that goes to make up the so-called savings bond "basket."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Indians rallied to split a double-header with the Browns tonight and held second place, 2 1/2 games behind the Yanks.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,341, for the twenty-four hours to 6.A M., Thursday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- A family of burglars that broke in its younger members as apprentice thieves by giving them "on-the-job training" was charged today with stealing $100,000 in household goods from suburban homes.

With the arrest of three investigators of the State Temporary Rent Commission for an alleged $800 shakedown attempt, a twofold inquiry was begun yesterday to determine to what extent such extortions may have been practiced in the commission's Manhattan offices.

The two-story building with a railroad siding at 23-23 Borden Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by S. Posner Sons to the Saxon Paper Products Corporation, which will use it for warehousing and metropolitan distribution. Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., and H. Clayton Smith Co. were the brokers. The structure, containing about 54,000 square feet of space, originally was erected by H. J. Heinz Co.

The men's clothing industry operated at 70 per cent of capacity in the first six months of 1952, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America reported yesterday. The rate of operation dropped from 86 per cent in the corresponding 1951 period and from 87 per cent in 1950.

Electric power production for the week ended Aug. 9 rose to 7,495,322,000 kilowatt-hours from 7,404,913,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Aug. 11, 1951 was 7,069,890,000.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- A study of case records and releases of mental patients to learn "whether there is any way in which our laws or procedures can be improved to provide additional precautions against the release of dangerous or violent persons" will be undertaken by the State Mental Hygiene Council, it was announced today.

The General Electric Company offered wage increases, and improved insurance benefits to about 200,000 of its employes yesterday, but a chilly reaction was given to the proposal by the two major unions negotiating with the company.
Two of the East's leading players and a Southern campaigner were admitted as substitutes yesterday to the field for the national amateur golf tournament. The tournament opens next Monday at Seattle.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. Charles Leichner, Willow Brook, was the low gross winner during the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at North Hempstead today with a 39, 42 -- 81.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Truman reopened the acrimonious controversy over shipping subsidies today. He directed the Department of Commerce to furnish him, by Oct. 15, a study determining the effect of the complete elimination of tax benefits for Government-subsidized ships and the amount of additional subsidy considered necessary to offset the loss.

After meeting yesterday with representatives of the New York Central System and of four railroad unions, Francis A. O'Neill, chairman of the National Mediation Board, said that he was pleased with the progress being made in settling the dispute that had threatened to tie up the railroad's lines east of Buffalo.

A 17-year-old stable boy whose one ambition in life was to join the Marines convinced recruiting officials that he would make a good leatherneck, the United States Marine Corps Headquarters reported yesterday.

Employes of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, led by Dorman D. Israel, executive vice president, will give blood today to a Red Cross mobile unit in the company's plant at 111 Eighth Avenue.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 13 (UP) -- Representative John T. Wood, Republican foe of the United Nations, and his fellow incumbent Congressman won renomination today in the Idaho primary election.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- A secret United States military intelligence report predicted seven years ago that Russia would try to "dominate" Korea and advocated strong steps to avert Communist control of China.

Mortgage financing totaling to $3,500,100 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for the third section of the "213" Deepdale Gardens cooperative apartment project under construction on Marathon Parkway in Little Neck, Queens. The apartments will house 1,396 families. They are being built by Samuel Praver and Efram Kahn Associates.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The conference of unions representing Britain's engineering and shipbuilding workers unanimously endorsed today the compromise decision, taken yesterday by its executive council, to postpone consideration of strike action for four weeks pending another attempt to negotiate a wage rise.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- The advisability of filing suit in Supreme Court to upset the rezoning of the James Butler estate in Eastview will be studied at a meeting here Friday night of the Pocantico Hills Citizens Committee, Julius L. Leitzer, chairman, said today.
BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Southpaw Mel Parnell pitched a three-hitter and Clyde Vollmer drove in three runs today as the Red Sox shut out the Athletics, 4 -- 0.
Frank Kenna, Republican leader of Queens County, appealed yesterday to all Queens Republicans to vote in Tuesday's primary election as a "preview" for the national election on Nov. 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The world must feed its increasing population from land that is now in use because there are "no longer empty areas worth developing," Dr. George B. Cressey, Maxwell Professor of Geography at Syracuse University, told the International Geographic Union here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The State Department announced today that forty-four "escapees" from the Soviet Union and its satellites in Eastern Europe would arrive in New York Saturday and try to build a new life in the United States.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government has officially asked for the extradition of Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, who was seized by the Mexican Federal Police last Saturday. General Mow had been detained incomunicado until the press was allowed to talk with him this afternoon.

The United States furnished nearly $220,000,000 for thirty-one iron and steel projects in Marshall Plan countries in the four years since the plan was started in 1948, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It said the total cost of the thirty-one projects originally was estimated at $864,000,000.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 13 -- Leonard Schmitt, an attorney who is seeking to win Wisconsin's Republican Senatorial nomination from Senator Joseph McCarthy, finished a twenty-five-hour political talkathon tonight, still in good voice.

MADRID, Aug. 13 -- The Falangist press and some newspapers such as Madrid, which generally display a strong anti-United States attitude, hinted today at the possibility that negotiations between the United States and Spain for economic and military agreements might be broken off if the Spanish terms were not met.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Aug. 13 (UP) -- A World War II hero of the Russian army who fled from Communist rule flew here today with his American bride under strict protective guard from Frankfort, Germany.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Martin A. (Skip) Purcell of Indian Harbor, completed a remarkable sailing performance off Larchmont Yacht Club today to annex the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 13 -- A three-week wildcat strike of longshoremen and warehousemen at Claremont Terminal neared settlement tonight after a two-hour demonstration of 300 pier workers at City Hall.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was at work today preparing the speech he will make in Detroit at noon on Labor Day after putting the finishing touches on an address set for tomorrow at Governor's Day of the Illinois State Fair.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission is awaiting suggestions from utilities before adopting a thirty-one-point safety code for natural gas pipe lines in New York State. A commission spokesman said yesterday he could not say when the board would put the new code into effect.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- With Prince Aly Khan among the onlookers at the jam-packed Saratoga Sales Paddock tonight, twenty thoroughbred yearlings sent here by the Aga Khan were sold for $173,500, an average of $8,675.

The one-story repair shop on a plot about 40 by 78 feet at 542-544 Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Agnes Pulda to Leonard Mele. The Moratto Realty Company was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Defense Materials Procurement Agency reported today that it approved 436 expansion projects during the year ended June 30 to increase the supply of metals and minerals.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday that he would stick to his policy of immediately filling vacancies in key city agencies, including the Police Department and other departments, "where I know it would be suicide to attempt false economy."

THE waters off Peru continue to maintain their status as the "big fish" capital of the world, having provided the two largest fish ever taken on rod and reel over a three-month period, which accounts for the increasing popularity of Cabo Blanco with the big-game angling brotherhood.

Various purpose bonds totaling $15,987,000 were sold here yesterday by the State of Delaware. The National City Bank of New York and associates submitted the high bid of 100.872 for the issue maturing from 1953 to 1972.

An increase last week of 1,005,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 117,248,000 barrels, compared with 116,243,000 a week earlier and 127,750,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The Air Force announced today that it had ordered the eight-jet Boeing B-52 heavy bomber into full-scale production and had abandoned all plans to order any Convair B-60s.

Today's new film is "Les Miserables," Twentieth Century-Fox's remake of the Victor Hugo novel, with Michael Rennie, Debra Paget, Robert Newton and Edmund Gwenn, at the Rivoli. Lewis Milestone directed and Fred Kohlmar produced from a script by Richard Murphy.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Britain's trade deficit with countries not in the sterling bloc except for the dollar area was markedly reduced in the first six months of this year, according to figures published today by the Board of Trade.

Diesel locomotives not only are replacing steam-driven locomotives but are eliminating the need for electrified railroad lines, particularly through tunnels. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, operator of the first electrified railroad in the country, recently stated that eight electric locomotives which operated over an electrified line through the heart of Baltimore are awaiting a bidder.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The French-German talks on the problem of the Saar were resumed here today and after a conversation lasting two and one-half hours they were discontinued until Friday, Aug. 29.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Well-informed and responsible officials today gave this account of what happened and did not happen in the Truman-Stevenson conferences at the White House yesterday:

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday as a new site for the New York School of Printing a tract of land within the block bounded by Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 -- For the first time in twenty-eight years the American Federation of Labor appears certain to endorse a Presidential candidate. The way for this unusual step was cleared here today when the administrative committee of Labor's League for Political Education, political arm of the federation, decisively rejected a proposal that the A. F. L. stand by its long-time tradition of no Presidential endorsement.
WICK, Scotland, Aug. 13 (UP) -- The 18,000-ton Norwegian whaling ship Thorshovdi and the 11,600-ton Swedish passenger ship Anna Salen collided in heavy fog off the northeastern tip of Scotland today.

A shift in the traffic pattern and new signal timing will go into effect tonight at the southern end of the intricate Grand Army Plaza intersections in Brooklyn, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Dr. Anthony J. J. Rourke of New York, president of the American Hospital Association, predicted today at an open hearing of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the nation that medical teaching service as it was now known would disappear if prepayment plans continued to divest teaching hospitals of clinical cases.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, challenged Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate, on the Illinois Governor's home grounds today to repudiate "Trumanism."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- John J. Muccio, United States Ambassador to Korea, has been chosen by President Truman to succeed. Francis B. Sayre as United States Representative on the United. Nations Trusteeship Council.

The drive to get out the vote this November is gaining considerable momentum, according to the American Heritage Foundation. Already forty states in which a committee representing radio and television stations have joined the drive.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 13 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh decreed today the establishment of rural democracy in Iran. He ordered landlords to turn over to the peasants 20 per cent of their return from their lands to be divided equally between the rural development and cooperative organization created by the decree and the individual peasants working on the land.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- Representative John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, today urged that a special session of Congress be called to stiffen price controls. He warned that inflation was now the nation's No. 1 domestic problem.

Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson refused yesterday in Washington to continue Frank Costello's bail pending appeal and United States Attorney Myles J. Lane said the 61-year-old gambler would have to surrender at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow to begin his eighteen-month contempt sentence.

Handicrafts of Hawaii may lend an exotic island note to homes in the United States when a project now in the planning stage gets under way. The project will result in a central distribution shop in Honolulu in which will be displayed craft products from all of the islands so that both importers and tourists can find a complete selection of the best Hawaiian designs in one spot.

Shortly after midnight, following more than six hours of frenzied struggling, the Dodgers and the Giants this morning completed the day-and-night renewal of their interborough rivalry at Ebbets Field exactly where they had rejoined battle at 1:30 P. M. yesterday.

Punch Opera's final presentation of the season, Wolf-Ferrari's "Doctor Cupid," was given last night at the Metropolitan-Duane Church Auditorium. The organization had re-introduced the work last year. It had not been heard in this city since the Metropolitan season of 1913-14, at which time Arturo Toscanini conducted the premiere.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for July showed an aggregate gain of 8.8 per cent over July, 1951, figure, according to a compilation covering forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. It was the fourth successive monthly gain.

Your internationally known and highly respected publication has reached me in various parts of the world in recent years. The community problems of New York and other cities are not nearly as great as the problems facing many large cities abroad. We are still way above par.
The 20,000 passengers who use the Triboro Bus lines between Woodside, Queens, and Rockaway Beach on sunny week-ends will find the bus service resumed this week-end.

GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- President Truman's refusal to accede to requests of United States watch manufacturers for more protection against competition from Swiss watchmakers was believed here to have strengthened the influence of the United States, not only in Switzerland, but throughout Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations condemned by resolution today the latest price increase put into effect by the Canadian newsprint industry.

Aug. 15 is a big day on the calendar in several Asian states. It is independence day for Korea and for Pakistan and it is the actual anniversary of India's independence, although India celebrates the establishment of the republic at a different season. Today, therefore, it is appropriate to consider the large political changes that have taken place in recent years in what was once the "colonial" world.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Nellie Fox' two-run triple in the tenth inning and Marvin Grissom's three-hit pitching helped the White Sox to a 2-0 victory over the Tigers today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Public Health Service said today 2,648 new cases of polio were reported in this country last week, a 15 per cent increase over the previous week.
SOUTHSEA, England, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- British shipyards, struggling against growing German and Japanese competition, faced tonight a possible slump in production.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Firing a 38, 40 -- 78, 6 over par, Vincent Fitzgerald of Oakland took the senior championship and the Hotchkiss trophy by a one-stroke margin in the twenty-fifth annual Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 14 -- Oliver Kisich, 53 years old, of San Francisco, denied today that he was implicated in the alleged embezzlement of $25,000,000 in Chinese Nationalist funds by Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Automobile manufacturers, confident that they will be allowed to make more passenger cars next year, asked the National Production Authority today to grant them a production quota of at least 1,500,000 units for the opening quarter of 1953.

Today's new film is "Son of Ali Baba," a Universal-International period adventure in Technicolor, with Tony Curtis, Piper Laurie, Susan Cabot and William Reynolds, at the Palace. Kurt Newmann directed and Leonard Goldstein produced from a story and screen play by Gerald Drayson Adams.
Shipbuilding in this country's privately owned yards last month again set a peacetime high with 2,082,750 deadweight tons of shipping under construction or contract.
Communist-front student organizations may have existed surreptitiously at some city high schools, but apparently they met with no success, it has learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that United States exports declined from a record high of $1,466,200,000 in May to $1,162,300,000 in June. At the same time, imports rose.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 ((AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from President Truman to Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, and Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, both Democrats, announcing his rejection of Federal Tariff Commission recommendations for an increase in the tariff on imported watches:

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. P. F. Cassidy of Metuchen and her daughter, Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, posted an 84 today to win a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-daughter tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club.

Record companies in America that offer for sale disks containing music originating in the Soviet Union will face legal proceedings unless they have previously obtained permission for their release from the Leeds Music Corporation, it was learned yesterday.
LINCOLN, Ill., Aug. 14 (UP) -- Nearly 600 persons faced possible fines and jail sentences here today in a contempt of court case that could grow into a major legal battle on the issue of free speech.

The seasonal upturn in business borrowings from New York banks gathered new strength last week, advancing $47,000,000 after a gain of $63,000,000 in the previous week. The rise cut the decline in such borrowings since the first of the year to $411,000,000 against an increase of $623,000,000 in the similar period in 1951.

Aaron G. Bass, a jewelry salesman of 1 Christopher Street, was in the Criminal Courts Building bright and early yesterday ready to be a complainant against a youth who had stolen his 1950 Buick on July 30.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- The United Nations Balkans subcommission said today that the world organization must continue its "vigilance" in the Balkans.

On several fronts in the last few days there have been indications that not everybody is looking at television. Some of the motion picture houses have reported major upturns in business and on Monday evening a crowd of 51,000 showed up at Yankee Stadium for a baseball game that wasn't televised.
SEATTLE, Aug. 14 -- The United States team assumed a slight lead in a new international links series launched today at the Seattle Golf Club course.

With a big assist from Al Corwin, Sal Maglie made a triumphant return to the mound yesterday as the Giants edged the Dodgers, 4 -- 3, before 16,592 spectators and 5,000 Knothole Gang youngsters at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Following is the text of the Executive Board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations' statement today backing the Democratic party's Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Two of the nation's top steel producers signed contracts with the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., today, formally ending the 1952 strike and a third said it had reached agreement with the union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the Regents of the University of the State of New York to build two non-commercial educational television stations. It also authorized six commercial stations elsewhere.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Lois Hallager of Scarsdale Golf Club toured the Knollwood Country Club course in 44, 41 -- 85 today to win low gross honors by two shots in a Westchester-Fair-field Golf Association one-day competition.

MANILA, Aug. 14 -- The mobilization of manpower and equipment to fight the dangerous infestation of locusts began today on the basis of a national emergency decreed by Vice President Fernando Lopez who is also Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The leadership of the Congress of Industrial Organizations recommended today that its members, believed to number about 4,000,000, vote for the Democratic nominees for President and Vice President to insure the "unfaltering continuation of the best traditions and ideals of the New Deal and the Fair Deal."
An impartial arbitrator upheld yesterday the dismissal of a newspaper linotypist whose typographical error echoed the Communist party line.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14 -- The American Federation of Labor, recently at odds with the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, gave notice today that it was ready to resume an active role in the affairs of the world labor group.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, the defending champion, toured the Milburn Country Club course in 5-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the $15,000 Kansas City open golf tournament.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Phillip Scott scored an easy two-length victory tonight over Voltoman in the Calverton Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. Navy Hal was third.
Nedick's, Inc., has sold its office and factory property at 44-58 West 143d Street and will move to New Jersey where it will build a new plant on a tract of about four acres on Route 4 in Englewood.

TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- State institution authorities made known today that thirty hardened inmates of the State Prison, many of whom had participated in recent riots, engaged in intermittent hunger strikes last week.

HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- An outline for the establishment of three types of "autonomous regions" has been adopted by the Peiping Government as a blueprint for governing the basic concentrations of the 40,000,000 persons classified in China as belonging to the "non-Han" national minorities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- American corporations raised $2,900,000,000 through the sale of securities in April, May and June -- more than in any three-month period since 1929 -- the Government reported today.

WAVERLY, Ohio, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Engineers and speculators descended on Pike County in full force today in the wake of the Government's announcement that it would build a huge atomic installation in the hills hereabout.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The free nations supplied Russia and Communist China with about 82,000 tons of natural rubber in the first half of 1952, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The ides of August are upon us once more and with them the official sneezing time for hay fever sufferers. The Department of Health, which has been at work since June to curb the growth of the demon ragweed, has already sprayed some 2,100 acres of untenanted city real estate with a chemical weed killer, and will continue its efforts with the aid of other city departments up until Labor Day.

The Aug. 5 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES carried the news of deportations from Bratislava. A few days later the issue of Aug. 9 stated "mass deportations of the 'enemies of the people' started again in Hungary." The tragedy of thousands of families is concealed behind this news.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 -- Following is the text of a speech by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, at the Illinois State Fair today:

Desperately in need of a Lift, the Yankee pitching staff got one yesterday at the Stadium. On the heels of Wednesday's superb ten-inning relief job by Tom Gorman, Johnny Schmitz came along with a route-going, six-hit, 7-2 victory over the Senators.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission issued a three-way complaint today against the General Foods Corporation, charging violations of the anti-trust laws.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Running over a squishy course that earlier in the proceedings had been doused by one of Saratoga's patent - applied - for storms, James F. McHugh's 5-year-old gelding Jam today won the North American Steeplechase in a finish that had the crowd of 14,563 bouncing with excitement.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Miss Clarissa Churchill were married today at Caxton Hall, Westminster, while thousands of Londoners waited outside to cheer them.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 14 (UP) -- Judge Francis A. Cherry, who defeated the candidate backed by President Truman for the Democratic nomination for Governor, today announced support for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for President.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- In a program designed to familiarize residents of various countries with the customs and methods of their neighbors, some 800 workers are participating in tours arranged for this summer and fall under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Shipments of the Sperry Corporation for the first six months this year increased 66 per cent to $178,574,684 from $107,601,253 a year ago, reflecting a rise of 132 per cent in Government business and a 12 per cent gain in commercial business, H. F. Vickers, president, reported in the mid-year report mailed to stockholders today.

The Citizens Union gave its endorsement yesterday to two candidates for the Democratic nomination for the Assembly in the primary next Tuesday, both of whom are opposing the party organization choices. In two other Democratic Assembly contests, the Citizens Union said that insurgents were to be "preferred" over the organization candidates.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 15 -- Kim Il Sung, North Korean Premier and Commander in Chief, has told Parliament that North Korea would be prepared to sign an armistice in the two-year-old war as a drawn battle, the Pyongyang radio said today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The Presidential election of forty-four years ago had its problems about the powers of the President, corruption and foreign policy, Volumes V and VI of "The Letters of Theodore Roosevelt," published here today, reveal.
BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Effective relief pitching today enabled the Red Sox to sweep a double-header by beating the Athletics, 4 -- 2, after a 5-4 victory in thirteen innings.

The stock market adhered to a thin line of operation yesterday, making slight progress in one of the laziest sessions of the summer. The moderate momentum that the list was able to generate was spread over a wide variety of issues, with only the railroads making general progress as a group.
If you are collecting money, there's no point in examining your change every night in the hope of finding that 1913 Liberty Head nickel, or any other valuable coin, for that matter.
Your interest in the plight of the people of Kansas and your strong editorial on the proposed dam come at an apt time.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 14 -- An uneasy truce settled today over the Claremont Terminal as rank and file members of Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., withdrew picket lines and allowed 460 nonstriking longshoremen and warehousemen to return to their jobs, ending a three-week wildcat strike.

While gross revenues of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., reached new high of $194,000,000 for the twelve months ended June 30, net income of the utility dropped to cents a share on the outstanding common stock from $1.25 a share the preceding twelve months.

The rugged life of a logging camp as viewed and experienced by a woman is the subject of a book that Crowell has scheduled for Sept. 15 publication entitled "The Lady and the Lumberjack." The author is Oliver Barber, a former schoolteacher, who went to a Coos Bay, Oregon, logging camp with her husband.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of the home club and Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich will meet in the thirty-six-hole final for the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship over the Apawamis Club course tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Marvin E. Coyle, retired executive vice president and director of the General Motors Corporation, has been selected to receive the annual Cardinal Newman Award.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman described as "tragic" today a situation in which old pieces of furniture purchased by the early Presidents for the White House have been scattered from one end of the country to the other.

Population increases in the United States, coupled with more coordinated merchandising efforts, point to a "terrific" sales potential for dairy products, according to E. L. Homan, director of dairy merchandising for the Kroger Company, food chain.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,342 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- Benjamin Fine of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a dozen other writers, including Carey McWilliams and Paul Blanshard, were accused of "prejudiced and unjustifiable attacks" upon the people of Pasadena, in the tenth report of the California State Senate Committee on Education, released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- World production of natural rubber fell to 127,500 tons in June, the lowest monthly output in more than two years, the Department of Commerce said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The favored Los Angeles Rams, champions of the National Football League, will oppose one of the best-balanced collegiate squads ever assembled in the nineteenth annual All-Star football game at Soldier Field tomorrow night.

The American cargo ship Newberry Victory, which ran aground on a rocky reef in the outer harbor of Casablanca last January and has remained incapacitated, has been sold to the Prudential Steamship Company and will be towed to New York later this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14__During the week ended Aug. 13, member bank reserves decreased $124,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Faisal II, King of Iraq, stood on a platform high up on the side of a giant "cat cracker" yesterday and looked out over a refinery that handles more oil than the entire output of his country, which ranks tenth in world production.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, today appealed to the states to halt the "tidal drift" of power to Washington, attacked what he called the Republican "doctrine of change for the sake of change," and struck at the Republican party in general and former President Herbert Hoover in particular.
New advice is available to those for whom mildew prevention is one of the problems attendant on closing the summer house for the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Two world projects considered by geographers fundamental to the United Sates Point Four programs of aid to underdeveloped areas, a world land-use map and a world atlas of disease, were the subject of special sessions today at the Congress of the International Geographical Union.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14 -- Dr. James S. Moroka, president of the African National Congress and leader of the non-white campaign of defiance against "unjust laws," was arrested today at Thabanchu while attending his patients.

Consolidated net earnings of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation for the first half of 1952 totaled $14,524,014, as compared with $13,757,973 in the like 1951 period, and continued good results for the remainder of the year are expected, Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic chairman, said today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson would address the New York Democratic Convention Aug. 28 and would tour Upstate New York in mid-October.
Teen-agers played a major role in the increase in crimes in this city noted in the first six months of this year as compared with the last six months of 1951.

ESKILSTUNA, Sweden, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Mal Whitfield, the Olympic champion from Columbus, Ohio, won the 800-meter run in an international track and field meet tonight with a clocking a full second faster than his Olympic record.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 14 -- The Bakhtar Emruz, the principal press organ of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's National Front, and which is believed to mirror his views better than any other publication, urged him today to follow up yesterday's agrarian reform decrees by breaking up the large estates and distributing the land to the peasants.

Representatives of borough civic groups toured East Bronx for nearly three hours yesterday to emphasize their organizations' demands for cleaner streets and stricter parking regulations. On lots on Trinity Avenue near 165th Street and on Tinton Avenue near 166th Street they found heaps of refuse and junk.
Vegetarians excepted, this is a grim week for the food shopper.

The story about the banker with the kindly eye -- the glass one -- has been brought up to date by the Mosler Safe Company. It is supplying bullet-proof glass so that the eye of a teller will have a clear, as well as kindly, view through its new automatic drive-in window for banks.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, top-ranked United States player battled three hours today before eliminating Australia's Mervyn Rose in the quarter-finals of the Newport invitation tennis tournament.

For the second time since the opening of the tournament for the team championship of the International Chess Federation, the quartet representing the United States swept all four boards and gained a 4-0 victory over Switzerland yesterday, according to a report from Helsinki.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 14 -- A young financier whose exploits have been causing a sensation in the Rio de Janeiro business world has shocked the city by disappearing from business with an announcement in the press that he would make good all debts eventually.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman said today that plans to brief both the Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees on the international situation and to supply, thereafter continuing information to them, were formulated a week or ten days ago and that both nominees were informed of these plans.

A tract of about 50,000 square feet fronting 250 feet on the west side of Route 25 in Newark, N. J., has been purchased by the Heat and Power Engineering Company of Newark in an expansion move. The land was acquired from the Atlas Oil Company in a transaction negotiated by Flusser for Factories as broker.
Nine ships under Rear Admiral John M. Will, commander of the Atlantic Area of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service have received new duty orders.

Next Tuesday, at the peak of the summer vacation season, New York City will have a primary election in which, despite all well-meant appeals to the contrary, voters will as usual stay away from the polls in droves. This is a pity, and the situation requires analysis and correction.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Ned Garver, who last season became the first twenty-game winner for a last-place major league club in twenty-eight years, was traded today by the Browns to the Tigers for Outfielder Vic Wertz in an eight-player waiver deal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- All grain and soybean futures scored substantial gains in the early trade today, but in all pits profit-taking caused substantial reactions. Soybeans set new highs for the season for all deliveries before reacting. Corn was up as much as 2 5/8 cents early, the September being relatively strong on rumors that the Commodity Credit Corporation was to curtail shipments of this grain to terminal markets.
Technical considerations seemed to rule the market in cottonseed oil yesterday and it showed independent strength, despite the decline in soybeans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- General Eisenhower will hold a regional meeting with about 140 party aspirants and leaders from seven States in Kansas City next Thursday, Arthur E. Summerfield, chairman of the Republican Na tional Committee, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The rejection by General Eisenhower of the President's invitation to be "briefed on the foreign situation" by the Cabinet and Lieut. Gen. W. Bedell Smith, the Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is based on reasons that undoubtedly will be strongly approved by a large section of the voting population.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A very Brundage formally took over the presidency of the International Olympic Committee tonight with a pledge to keep the Olympic Games out of politics and business.

ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the County Transportation Company, Inc., to raise fares on its Westchester County routes by $21,400 a year. The increase may go into effect on three days' notice after formal filing.

RAHWAY, N. J., Aug. 14 -- In an effort to eradicate a possible cause of infantile paralysis, which has caused three deaths here in the last month, the city will be sprayed with insecticide, Mayor James G. Egolf announced today.

Eight thousand noisy children swarmed into Yankee Stadium yesterday as guests of the management. One group of seventeen wore white sweatshirts with "Lords Highway" lettered across in blue. At their head was a deeply tanned, sharp-featured man wearing a similar sweatshirt, a blue baseball cap and patched khaki pants.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Steadiest demand on the stock markets here today was for South African gold mining shares, British Government securities and German bonds. Elsewhere business was quiet with a firm undertone prevailing.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Phillies took the odd game of a three-game series today as they defeated the Braves, 5 -- 3.
GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 14 (AP) -- One victory and one sixth place finish today gave Ted Wells of Wichita, Kan., a slim lead in the national snipe championships. The final race will be held tomorrow.

LICQ-ATHEREY, France, Aug. 14 -- An underground explorer, Marcel Loubens, died tonight 1,000 feet down in the Pyrenees, just before rescuers had hoped to bring him out. His back was broken yesterday in a fall down a fissure, one of the world's deepest.

After four days of talks with Federal mediators who have been trying to avert a strike on New York Central lines east of Buffalo, leaders of the railroad brotherhoods that have threatened to call the walkout were pessimistic yesterday.

As a very ordinary British subject, proud and privileged to be classified as a permanent alien resident, in good employment, and thoroughly enjoying the wonderful living conditions in this great country as compared to Great Britain, I feel that I must take certain exceptions to the letter of Malcolm Muggeridge which appeared in your powerful newspaper, on Aug. 12.

There was sharp disagreement among exhibitors at the American National Retail Jewelers show on the amount of business booked. The five-day convention and exhibit at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel ended yesterday. A number of companies said business was satisfactory and slightly better than last year, but few would say the activity was very good.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 14 -- Matyas Rakosi, Hungary's Communist boss, became Premier of this Soviet-orbit nation today. A sudden shift of jobs made the behind-the-scenes leader the legal director of the country.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Major R. W. Schroeder was 67 years old today, and from throughout the United States his friends and flying comrades gathered at Chicago airport to celebrate the anniversary.

SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Stanwood W. Sparrow of South Bend, Ind., 64 years old, a vice president of the Studebaker Corporation, was injured fatally today in an automobile accident on Route 20. He died in Harrington Memorial Hospital.

Two suspended policemen, threatened with jail for their refusal to answer questions in the departmental graft trial, won another delay yesterday as the legal contest ping-ponged between the Criminal Courts Building and Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Ken Raffensberger, the Red's 35-year-old southpaw, beat the Cubs, 4 -- 1, today for the twenty-fourth time in his career.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Air Force presented the Distinguished Flying Cross today to Roscoe Turner, veteran speed pilot, for his contributions to the advancement of flying. Mr. Turner, president of an Indianapolis Aeronautical Company, is the first civilian in 20 years to receive the decoration.

A 43-year-old Queens handyman, held in the City Prison for shooting his estranged girl friend, confessed yesterday that he had used the same weapon to kill Patrolman James J. McGillion early Tuesday, the prosecutor's office announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- Trueman T. Rembusch, Indiana theatre owner, told a meeting of Hollywood studio heads today that the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax was taking away $300,000,000 annually from theatre receipts and that the sum represented the difference between failure and survival for 6,000 of the nation's smaller theatres.

Back from a sojourn in Europe, Margaret Webster disclosed yesterday that she had tied up a Parisian hit, an all-male play called "Sur la Terre Comme au Ciel" ("On Earth as It Is in Heaven"), for Broadway presentation. The date depends on when Victor Francen, who is starred in the French production, will be free to come over.

Frank Costello will surrender at 10:30 A. M. today to United States Marshal William Carroll to begin his eighteen-month contempt sentence. While the 61year-old gambler remains behind bars for the second time since 1915, his counsel will press the United States Supreme Court to review his conviction.

Colonial Williamsburg's streets were shining as brightly as eighteenth-century candlepower and torchlight could make them shine when Norborne Berkeley, Baron de Botetourt, arrived just after sundown on an October day in 1768 to assume his post as the first Royal Governor of Virginia to enjoy the full rank, and all perquisites, on Virginia soil.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt of near-by Hyde Park was "in dutch" with her neighbors in this city today.

Laden with animal crackers and toy airplanes and stuffed animals they had made themselves, twelve blind people visited the children's ward at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Madison Avenue and 124tl Street, yesterday.

DENVER, Aug. 14 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, today turned down an invitation to lunch with President Truman and members of his Cabinet next Tuesday and be briefed on the world situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Defense Production Administrator Henry H. Fowler said today he is "considering" letting the automobile industry buy foreign and conversion steel to help meet its goal of 1,150,000 cars the last three months of this year.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 14 -- An objectionable reference to Mohammedanism in a Hindi-language newspaper, Amrita Patrika, of Allahabad has caused Moslem demonstrations in the important near-by industrial city of Kanpur (formerly Cawnpore) in which more than 200 persons have been arrested and many injured in two days.

David Alan Exler, the 17-year-old racetrack groom who went to great lengths to enlist in the Marine Corps, was sworn in at 11 A. M. yesterday after having taken the wrong subway train, a mistake that delayed the ceremony an hour and a half.

Carl Norgauer of Yonkers and George Mandel of Astoria, seeded first and second, respectively, gained the semi-final round of boys' competition yesterday in the Metropolitan junior and boys' tennis championships at the Hispano Club, Queens.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The famed old Grand Union Hotel, fashionable nineteenth-century rendezvous of horse-race followers, will close at the end of this month and is scheduled to be torn down, Mayor Addison Mallery said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced proposed changes today in its Regulation "A," under which certain offerings of securities not exceeding $300,000 in any one year may be made without complying with the registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933.

CAIRO, Aug. 14 -- The military police today surrounded the pro-Wafdist newspaper Al Misri. For four hours nobody was allowed to leave or enter the premises. An army spokesman said that the newspaper recently had been publishing untrue and tendentious reports,, including one this morning to the effect that the Government was contemplating the mass dismissal of superfluous civil servants.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Federal restrictions on building materials and credit are blamed for a building decline of almost 10 per cent from last year's figures in the first six months of 1952 in Nassau County. According to a survey report filed here today by the County Planning Commission, building permits were 45 per cent below the peak period in 1950.

THOSE willing to put their trust in the weather man, who has been exhibiting an un-cooperative spirit over a few week-ends, have a rather broad field of opportunity on salt water for the next couple of days.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Though the new feeling for suppleness runs through Manguin's collection, it is most attractively expressed in chiffon dinner gowns. Bodices in one layer of chiffon over a strapless foundation have long tight sleeves and a high plain neckline calling for a bib necklace in a chain mail of rhinestones.

Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, chief political adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, said yesterday that the Republican Presidential nominee would "write his own platform." The Governor left the impression that the general might take a tack in the campaign at some variance with the popularly accepted meaning of the document approved at the party's national convention.

In the death of Adolph Alexander Weinman our country has lost one of the last of a school of master sculptors whose fabulous achievements over the past half century or more have left a heritage in bronze and stone unequaled since the Italian Renaissance.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 14 -- Speaking on the fifth anniversary of Pakistan's independence, Prime Minister Khwaja Nazimuddin pledged today that Pakistan would never rest until she had liberated Kashmir, the control of which she disputes with India.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Two home runs by Ralph Kiner, his twenty-third and twenty-fourth of the season, each with a man on base, gave the Pirates a 5 -- 3 victory in ten innings over the Cardinals tonight. Murry Dickson went all the way for the Pirates to defeat Joe Presko.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Treasury reported today that it has been able to borrow only five-sixths of the money it needs despite the highest interest rate the Government has offered in twenty years.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and steady yesterday, with closing prices 18 to 29 points net higher than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the telegrams exchanged by President Truman and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Government wound up its marathon hearing against the Communist party today by contending it had proved conclusively that the party should have to register as an agent of Moscow.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Anita Kanter of Santa Monica, Calif., the national junior champion, upset defending titlist Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., 6 -- 0, 3 -- 6, 10 -- 8, in a surprising second round match today in the Essex County's Women's Invitation Tennis tournament.

JUST before the second Battle of Bull Run was fought, Amos Alonzo Stagg was born in West Orange, N. J. That's a staggering long time ago. But that same Amos Alonzo Stagg, still spry and hearty, will celebrate his ninetieth birthday tomorrow. Truly can it be said that the Grand Old Man is one of the most remarkable persons the world of sports has produced.

A hot bread has its place in hot summer, contradictory as that may sound. It varies an otherwise cold meal. Its temperature pleasantly contrasts with that of salad, icy soup or cold cut. In warm, as in cold, weather, its delicious odor stimulates the appetite.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today opened sales of American wheat and flour under the 1952-53 international agreement quotas and announced maximum prices that can be charged participating countries.

American cotton manufacturers who will attend the International Cotton Textile Conference in England next month will urge competitors in foreign countries to work for elimination of trade restrictions.

With the 1952 harvests approaching completion, the Communist drive to eliminate kulaks and to expand the area of collectivized agriculture seems to be speeding up in satellite Eastern Europe, particularly in Czechoslovakia and Rumania.

A "topping-out" ceremony yesterday marked completion of the concrete and steel framework of the twelve-story Carnegie Endowment International Center, First Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The building is designed to bring together educational organizations active in world affairs.

For almost half a century Israel Cohen was one of the anonymous people who helped prepare and edit the news for the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES. As picture editor he worked behind the scenes, selecting and editing the photographs that appeared in this newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Meteorologists here are beginning to wonder why hurricanes, due about this time, have not appeared. On the average, two big Atlantic storms would have come and gone by now, but this year there has not been a trace of one.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 14 -- Two of post-war Germany's top Jewish leaders were convicted and sent to prison today by a German court on charges' of misappropriating hundreds of thousands of Deutsche marks belonging to Jewish victims of nazism.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- United States Marines turned back today a fifth Chinese Communist attempt to recapture strategic "Bunker Hill" on the western front in Korea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- Approximately fifty delegates, representing 1,800 men and women blinded in military service, registered here today for the opening session of the seventh annual convention of the Blinded Veterans Association.

MADRID, Aug. 14 -- The Spanish press today assailed with unusual violence THE NEW YORK TIMES, calling it a mouthpiece of United States political circles who have been opposing for years collaboration between Washington and Madrid.

Lady Baden-Powell, a leader of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts and the widow of Lord Robert S. Baden-Powell, originator of the Boy Scout movement, won one of the 100 prizes awarded by The Christophers of 18 East Forty-eighth Street, it was announced ystrday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Truman, in rejecting today a recommendation of the Federal Tariff Commission that the duty be increased on Swiss and other imported watches and watch movements, declared that any new restrictive action on imports into this country must be clearly justified "if we wish to avoid a serious loss of confidence in our leadership" in the world.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- New York City's Forty-second (Rainbow) Division celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary today with training drills as usual.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 15 -- President Syngman Rhee was inaugurated today for his second term before tens of thousands of his countrymen, who gathered in the midsummer heat before the bomb-wrecked Capitol here. They stood patiently while the aged Chief Executive told them they were fighting for "the world's cause of freedom" as well as their own.

Cleverly presented against gay background sketches expressing this shop's belief that the gowns should conform to the spirit of their settings, the Rosette Pennington Brides Shop of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street exhibited a sex-tette of fall wedding gowns and bridesmaids' frocks yesterday at this address.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The International Harvester Company said today that if it got Wage Stabilization Board approval it would raise wages of 50,000 employes this month because of increased productivity.

With the appointment of Admiral Alan G. Kirk as director of the Psychological Strategy Board that key governmental agency receives its third chief in the, roughly, eighteen months of its existence. The first director, Gordon Gray, had to receive temporary leave from his post as president of the University of North Carolina to accept the position and devoted his time primarily to the initial organizational work required.
Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee for President, and his running mate, Senator John J. Sparkman, received two endorsements yesterday.

One of the many features of a free press which totalitarian dictators dislike is the fact that uncensored newspapers report many events which dictators would rather were not known. A case in point is the Soviet "Hate America" campaign, which has reached new heights of virulence these past few months and news of which has reached the free world despite Moscow censorship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The United Mine Workers welfare and retirement fund paid out $126,338,269 in benefits in the fiscal year that ended on June 30 -- almost as much as was paid in.
Construction of the $85,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, delayed for more than a year by a dispute with the city over adequate street connections, will start in mid-September.

The Daniel Houlihan Corporation sold the fifty-six-family apartment house at 104-06 Elliott Place, the Bronx, built by the company in 1924, to Ray Hetterman, who resold the property to Berkowitz Rosenberg. The buyers paid cash above mortgages totaling $165,000. Bernard I. Sandford and Max Kleinman were the brokers.

An old holding in the downtown area has passed to new ownership through the sale of the two five-story buildings at 176-178 Greenwich Street, southwest corner of Dey Street, by the Bankers Trust Company, as trustee of the estate of Baylor S. Hilton, to Frank Gordon and Barney Sedran, who own the adjoining four-story garage. Title was taken in the name of the Cortlandt and Dey Associates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, indicated today that there might be a need for revamping the command structure of United States forces in Europe to conserve manpower. Mrs. Rosenberg returned several days ago from an extensive tour of armed forces installations there.

LICQ-ATHEREY, France, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Four stranded explorers buried the body of a dead comrade, Marcel Loubens, tonight under a pile of stones in the Pierre St. Martin cave 1,153 feet beneath the Pyrenees, and threw away unnecessary gear to save themselves.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Former President Herbert Hoover and Governor Dewey will be honorary pall-bearers tomorrow at the funeral of Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, former Commanding General of the New York National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department announced today that the Soviet Union had rejected Western Big Three proposals for an abbreviated treaty restoring Austria to full freedom and independence. The Soviet Government has proposed instead, the department stated, a resumption of talks on "the entire Austrian treaty question based upon a return to the punitive spirit of 1945."

MACON, Ga., Aug. 15 (UP) -- A Georgia sheriff, his deputy son and a Georgia state patrolman were indicted Wednesday by a Federal grand jury for jailing and beating a Negro man and a Negro woman in violation of their constitutional rights.

Hippocrates, the father of modern-day medicine, would have been appalled at the paucity of men who now have the opportunity to follow his code. The medical students of this country are few in comparison with the urgent need for them. Doctors are scarce, and if our society is to be a healthy one we must do everything in our power to enlarge our present facilities for a medical education.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture came up with good news today for farmers battling the pink bollworm, one of cotton's worst enemies.

Agencies with transportation, luggage and other accounts were cheered yesterday by reports of the increasing volume of European travel and predictions that it would continue high during the year. Travel Items, trade newspaper of the industry, released a study of passports issued for Europe this year, indicating they would reach a total of 370,000. This would compare with the 299,665 issued in the record Holy Year of 1950.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- For today at least, citizens of the United States can bask in the warmth of another people's heartfelt gratitude for a wise and kindly act.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- A charge that a group of conspirators were attempting to destroy the nineteen-year-old Air Line Pilots' Association was made today by David L. Behncke in an answer to a contempt citation filed before the United States Court of Appeals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Amos Alonzo Stagg made a promise when he was a young man that he would "work with young people the rest of my life."
ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern reported today that state financial aid to local units of government has increased nearly $30,000,000 a year for the last ten years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department challenged the North Korean Communists today to put before the truce conference at Panmunjom any "specific proposals" they might have for ending the Korean war.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to homemakers:

Police Comissioner George P. Monaghan assured an American Labor party delegation yesterday that its organization in the Nineteenth Congressional District, at 82 Second Avenue, would have adequate protection at all subsequent street meetings.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Kenneth McClave and Mrs. T. U. Lyman of Maplewood retained their metropolitan father-and-daughter golf championship today at the Forest Hill F. C., scoring 40, 440 -- 80 for a one-stroke margin over J. K. and Alberta Moeltner of the Knoll C. C.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields of the Larchmont Yacht Club acquired the Commodore Clifford A. Hipkins Trophy, symbolic of the newly-established men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, as the Sound's final eliminations, for the first Men's National Sailing Championships, were completed today at the Riverside Yacht Club.

In THE TIMES of Aug. 11 it is reported that Bishop Herbert Welch, in a sermon at the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, compared the sense of destiny of the Jews to the sense of destiny which inspired the German and Japanese types of nationalism. According to Bishop Welch, "all three were wrong in shutting others out."

The Public Service Commission yesterday extended until Oct. 1 the date before which objectors to the recent increase in the commercial rates of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York must file petitions if they wish a rehearing of the case.

William M. North, secretary of the National Gypsum Company, has been named general manager of the ordnance plant at Parsons, Kan., owned by the Government and operated by National Gypsum. Colon Brown, now general manager, will supervise four of the company's subsidiaries, with headquarters at the Buffalo executive offices.

In the heat of the political conventions some of us may have overlooked the appointment by Governor Dewey of Arthur H. Schwartz to the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (covering Manhattan and the Bronx) to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the great jurist Bernard L. Shientag.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- The American President Lines has increased its fleet of vessels more than 100 per cent, its corporate net worth by nearly 50 per cent and its net current assets by 65 per cent in the last five years, according to a report to directors here today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru seized the occasion of India's fifth anniversary of her independence today to strike another verbal blow at this country's Communist party. Speaking from the ramparts of the immense Red fort of Mogul Emperor Shah Jahan, he was heard by more than 100,000 persons, according to newspaper estimates.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 15 -- The American Federation of Labor, breaking its tradition of no interference in the affairs of its autonomous affiliates, began today to clean "strangers" with unsavory reputations out of the federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The Progressive party reported today that it had received campaign contributions of $32,084 so far this year, including $2,500 from a "V. Hallinan, San Francisco."
HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Doubts on the outcome of the proposed port rehabilitation program for Hoboken developed today after the city's Chamber of Commerce rejected the plan.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Julia Sampson of San Marino, Calif., moved into the semi-finals of the Middle Atlantic girls' grass court tennis championship today by defeating Mary Slaughter of Charlottesville, Va., 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Mr. Avery Brundage, first non-European to be president of the International Olympic Committee, expressed the true sportsman's simple faith in the speech he made at Lausanne on Thursday in taking his new office. "The whole world," he said, "is sick -- socially, economically and politically.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Judge John Morgan Davis of Common Pleas Court late today blocked a proposed work stoppage by 10,500 operating employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, at least until after next Wednesday.

Sales in the furniture and home furnishings industry now promise to equal or better last year, following the substantial pick-up in the last ninety days after a lagging first quarter, it was reported yesterday in Chicago by Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -A bridging of the gap existing between regular motion-picture and television film production is planned by Richard Carlson, actor and magazine writer; Ivan Thors, scenarist-producer, and Curt Siodmak, writer-director, who have pooled their talents to form an independent producing company called A Men Productions.
GREEN LAKE, Wis., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ted Wells, 45-year-old skipper from Wichita, Kan., sailed his Good News to his third national snipe championship today on Green Lake.

Minot Frazier Jelke 3d, 22-year-old heir to an oleomargarine fortune, was one of three persons arrested yesterday in a series of early morning vice raids in the latest phase of a seven-month investigation into prostitution.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, today explored labor and farm issues, two vital fields in the Presidential campaign, and mapped plans for a stumping tour of California.

Stephen Gottlieb of New York, seeded fourth, upset Joe Jacinto of East Rockaway, L. I., seeded second, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, in the junior division semi-finals of the Metropolitan Junior and Boys' tennis championships yesterday at the Hispano Club, Queens.

DENVER, Aug. 15 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, declared today that the Republicans were not going to write off the labor vote in 1952. He said that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was trying to rearrange his itinerary so he could appear in person before the American Federation of Labor convention in New York beginning on Sept. 15.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington mystery man who had refused to testify before the House Ways and Means subcommittee in the tax scandals investigation, faces prosecution in Brooklyn for failing to appear yesterday before a Federal grand jury.

The North Atlantic defense program, already handicapped by a "stretch-out" that involves all participating nations, including the United States, has suffered two further blows. One is the refusal of the members of the projected European Defense Community to assume the same military burdens as the United States and Britain, as expressed by their failure to adopt a uniform two-year service term for their armed forces.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Ray Boone's single, followed by Harry Simpson's triple, enabled the Indians to defeat the Browns, 7 -- 6, in twelve innings tonight and cut the Yankees' lead to two games.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- In Nina Ricci's new collection her black taffeta stoles with long tight sleeves are as attractive as practical for transforming a short halter or strapless frock into afternoon gear. Just long enough to knot over the bust, they look like an off-shoulder fichu, and one would never guess that the sleeves are not on the dress.
TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- Japan has asked for freedom today, the seventh anniversary of her defeat in World War II, for 821 war criminals imprisoned here under the authority of the five Allied powers.

Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol granted yesterday a motion to transfer to the Appellate Division a petition for the reinstatement of Deputy Fire Chief Nathan perlman, who was dismissed from the department last April for alleged participating in a shakedown racket.

The stock market went through a routine session yesterday, with transactions small and prices slightly lower at the close. It was a typical Friday performance for the summer months, only a few issues moving out of a fractional range.
SEATTLE, Aug. 15 -- The United States won the first of the new international series for the Americas Cup by defeating teams from Canada and Mexico at the Seattle Golf Club today.

The grand award for the best exhibit at the convention of the Society of Philatelic Americans at the Astor Hotel was won yesterday by Ewald van Elkan of 527 West 110th Street for his display of the "Postal History of Great Britain 1840-1870."

PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 15 (UP) -- One wildcat strike ended, but another started today, and work at the $1,000,000,000 atomic energy project near here was almost at a standstill. An official estimated 2,000 of the 18,000 manual laborers were on the job.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Cancellations of surcharges now collected by truckers as a means of offsetting the effect of the new weight-distance tax on motor carriers was ordered today by the Public Service Commission. The commission held the levy should be treated like all other operating taxes, and not as a separate and distinct charge.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Newsprint rationing in Britain will be eased after Aug. 24, the Ministry of Materials announced today. Low-priced daily newspapers will be allowed to increase their size to an average of eight pages a day with no over-all tonnage restrictions. They now have six pages.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The president of Antioch College today said his school was "going to continue to preserve our liberal tradition" but termed accusations that it was Communist-dominated "laughable."

Gambler's luck ran out on Frank Costello yesterday. He entered the Federal Court House in Foley Square just after 10 o'clock in the morning well-tailored, neatly shod and scrupulously manicured. By 5 o'clock he was just another prisoner in the Federal Detention House in West Street, one of hundreds in gray cotton denim, blue chambray shirt, heavy prison shoes.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 15 (UP) -- The defending champions, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor of Australia, were seeded first today among the foreign entries in the Seventy-first annual National Doubles starting on Monday at the Longwood Cricket Club.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The discovery this week of the remains of an Iguanodon, or prehistoric bird-footed dinosaur, at the little village of Ockley in Sussex, twenty-five miles southwest of London, has caused a stir among the paleontologists at the Natural History Museum.

The Giants and Braves struggled to a stand-off in their twilight night double-header at the Polo Grounds last night. The home side, recovering from the shock of a 4-3 setback in the first game, rebounded behind Max Lanier's 5-hit pitching and gained the split with a 3-1 triumph in the second.

" What People Wore," written and illustrated by Douglas Gorsline, will be published Sept. 5 by Viking. It is a pictorial encyclopedia comprising more than 1,800 drawings and fifty pages of text that depict American dress from frontiersman to flappers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Prices moved in a restricted range on the Board of Trade today, with the market showing little initiative either way. Soybeans were reactionary at times and this caused a little selling of grains, but not sufficiently to cause much change in quotations. Commission buying appeared broad enough to absorb the moderate amount of selling, and there was little evidence of hedge pressure in any grain.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 15 -- Twelve hundred women, representing twenty - three nations, have been busy in Copenhagen this week, attending the Soroptimist International Association's international convention. The convention opened Monday under the patronage of Queen Ingrid of Denmark. The convention of this group, which is a welfare organization of women, was called to consider the problems of the handicapped child, juvenile delinquency, and the illegitimate child.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Philip B. Perlman, who fought some of the Government's most important cases before the Supreme Court in the last five years, stepped down today from his job as Solicitor General.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,343, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday:

Two incoming stage attractions have delayed their Broadway openings. "In Any Language," the new comedy by Edmund Beloin and Henry Garson, starring Uta Hagen, will make its local debut at the Cort Theatre on Oct. 14, instead of Oct. 8.

Shortly before the news of the American Federation of Labor's eventual break with its long-time tradition of no Presidential endorsement, A. F. L. President William Green wrote under the heading "We Are Not Neutral": "It always comes as a shock to me to hear the name of Samuel Gompers invoked in support of the hollow argument that labor should stand neutral and aloof from political issues and contests."
Looking ahead to the opening Sept. 1 of the season for oysters, growers in this area expect a crop somewhat smaller than in 1951.
The City and County of Denver, Colo., awarded $4,000,000 of off-street parking revenue bonds dated Aug, 1, 1952, and due Feb. 1, 1956 to Aug. 1, 1982 to A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and associates.

Twenty thousand Chinese intellectuals who have sought refuge in Hong Kong are being wooed by the Communists to bring their skills back to their homeland, an American back from the British colony declared yesterday. He asserted that they should be aided by the Allies as they are a tremendous resource against communism in Asia.
HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Three women and a man were killed in a three-car crash at 4 o'clock this afternoon on the Hutchinson River Parkway about three miles from the Connecticut line.
CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A New York girl tourist was killed last night and two friends were hurt when their car ran off the road at a curve four miles north of here.

The election of Vice Admiral Leslie C. Stevens. U. S. N., retired, to succeed Admiral Alan G. Kirk as chairman of the American Committee for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia, Inc., was announced yesterday. Admiral Stevens will take over his duties with the committee when Admiral Kirk, former Ambassador to Russia, moves into a new assignment as director of the Psychological Strategy Board in Washington, probably next month.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 15 -- The seven-week job of assembling a new Cabinet following the June 25 elections was near completion today. L. A. Donker, parliamentary leader of the Labor party and the third man chosen by Queen Juliana to solve the jigsaw puzzle of Dutch coalition politics, reported to her that all but the last few pieces had been fitted together.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, primed his state and city leaders for the political campaign with an attack today on some of the statements made three to four years ago by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President.

Two representatives of the Methodist Church, Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of the Philadelphia Methodist Area, and Ralph G. Luff, president of the Ocean City Tabernacle Association, Ocean City, N. J., will visit Heidelberg, Germany, soon to confer with Army chaplains and officers on occupation problems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The 55-cent steak dinner that officers and civilians may buy at many military messes apparently is on the way out.
