A plot on the west side of Queens Street, 100 feet south of Jackson Avenue, in the Bridge Plaza section of Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Bernard J. Ferguson to M. W. Weiss who plans to improve it with a one-story factory and office building. The property now contains a three-story frame building which will be demolished. Queens Industrials was the broker in the sale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A raindrenched crowd of 88,316 tonight watched the Los Angeles Rams, champions of professional football, explode for 10 points in the fourth period to defeat the College All-Stars, 10 -- 7, in Soldier Field.

Delegates from 575 associations in the United States that are affiliated with the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will attend the nineteenth convention of the federation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, starting at 9 A. M. Wednesday and ending Friday evening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Considering that there is no more danger of a tin can shortage that could jeopardize this season's pack of perishable foods, the National Production Authority lifted restrictions today on the uses to which tinplate might be put.

With two successive Tariff Commission recommendations for import curbs turned down within a month by President Truman, importers and industrial users of dried figs are now increasingly hopeful of like action on recommended curbs for this product.

The Delaware Supreme Court recently voided a management option plan that permitted executives to buy stock "not later than six months after termination of employment." It held that the provision negated the management claim that the plan was intended to keep skilled executives on the payroll and therefore the compensation to the corporation for granting the option promised to be inadequate.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Demand for Japanese dollar clause stocks, stimulated by heavy buying of the comparable New York stocks and favorable reports of debt settlement estimates, was the feature of stock market trading here today. In other sections a firm tendency prevailed although end-of-the-week profit-taking gave a ragged appearance to the closing prices.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest domestic copper producer, and its consolidated subsidiaries had a consolidated net income before depletion of $40,710,113 in the first six months this year, a decline of 19 per cent or $9,603,688 from the $50,313,801 a year ago.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- E. W. Edwards and Son's department store here will be discontinued on Dec. 31.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 15 -- A plea for loyalty to the church, to the exclusion of allegiance to national ideologies, "race" or East-West lines marked the service in Lund's eleventh century cathedral tonight at the opening of the third World Conference on Faith and Order.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- The text of the Soviet note rejecting the Western Powers' latest proposals on Austria, as published today by Tass, official Soviet news agency:

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- The thirty-first national convention of the Disabled American Veterans today elected Floyd L. Ming of Bakersfield, Calif., as National Commander for 1952-53, as its five-day conference ended. He succeeds Ewing W. Mays, Little Rock, Ark.

A sense of duty and a downright liking for work have kept a dozen Junior Red Cross members on the job at the New York center of the Red Cross regional blood program, 70 West Fortieth Street. Normally, only adult volunteers work at the center, but this summer the Red Cross appealed to its teen-age members to volunteer their services.

JACKSON, N. H., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Charlotte Cook, 13-year-old Windham Center (Conn.) vacationist, who was lost for two nights in the woods of White Mountain National Park, was found today on East Branch Trail near the summer home of Maxwell Foster, Ipswich (Mass.) lawyer, to which she had been headed when she lost her way. The girl had suffered no serious injuries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Phil Cavarretta received a vote of confidence today in the form of a contract to manage the Cubs through 1953. The signing of the one-year contract was announced by Wid Matthews, Cub personnel director.

Jute, like other fibers, appears destined to enjoy a fairly strong market for the rest of the year. Burlap buyers therefore will find that prices of this material, used mainly for bags and carpet backing, will remain stable in the months ahead.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Arnold Reigger of Seattle, outshot 258 others today to win first-day preliminary honors at the fifty-third grand American invitation handicap trapshoot tournament here.

Minus signs outnumbered plus marks in commodity futures markets yesterday. After sharp rises and falls on the Cocoa Exchange most of the day, cocoa prices declined 61 to 42 points under aggressive trade selling near the close. Volume was 209 lots.

The $12,000,000 judgment against Harrison Williams awarded to trustees of a corporation once dominated by the 78-year-old utility executive was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals in a 2-to-1 decision. The court also directed that the suit be dismissed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Maker, who has reached the ripe old racing age of 9, was at his frisky best at Saratoga today and won the seven-furlong American Legion Handicap for the second successive year.

Bias is a many-edged weapon that hurts people who for some reason, often beyond their control, are not members of the majority. In New York State the state Anti-Discrimination Law discourages religious and racial bias in hiring, but there seems to be little reduction in the bias toward hiring people over 40 for jobs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Moscow's verdict on Pennsylvania is that Wall Street runs both political parties in the state, the Philadelphia police are "open to bribes" and the city's water has a peculiar taste.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Army's rules permit professional athletes to play for money in their own field of sports if it does not interfere with their military duties.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- A magnificent exhibition of iron play and putting in the afternoon round carried Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis to a 5-and-4 victory over Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich in the thirty-six hole final of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, Australian ace, and Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., blasted their way into the semifinals of the Newport invitation tennis tournament today.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 15 (UP) -- Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism announced today that the University of Puerto Rico planned to open a graduate school of journalism next year.

MANY anglers seem to be convinced that giant tuna are approaching the scarcity phase of the cycle in the waters ranging from New Jersey's Mud Hole to Casco Bay, Maine, although the big horse mackerel seem to be as plentiful as ever in Nova Scotia waters.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Millions of crickets swarmed into Chicago's South Side today, invading the city as far north as the Loop. Householders stamped, swept and beat at the insects in an effort to keep them out of their homes

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- "Coercive and excessive" picketing of the Howard Johnson restaurant on Tarrytown Road near the County Center here was enjoined today by Supreme Court Justice Samuel W. Eager, but the court said two pickets might walk in front of the place if no misrepresentations or threats were made to employes and customers.

The cases of the thirty-four suspended policemen now on departmental trial on charges of accepting graft to protect the gambling empire of Harry Gross were recessed yesterday until Sept. 3 by Third Deputy Commissioner James A. Delehanty.

The tourist business is terrible this year, Charlie Bretney says, and he is a man who should know. Mr. Bretney is 76 years old. Except for a few years during the war he has been selling sightseeing trips at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street since 1939.

A quarterly dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Oct 1, has been authorized by directors of the Illinois Central Railroad. The carrier distributed 75 cents a share in previous quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Central of Pennsylvania asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to permit it to abandon operation of its 223-mile line in Pennsylvania under a sublease from the Central of New Jersey, and so save about $250,000 in Pennsylvania state taxes, the Central of New Jersey to resume operation of the lines.

WHEN this nine-finger sonata in derringdo was first announced by its publisher it was labeled "Appointment With Venus." To this reviewer, the label was more descriptive than the one eventually chosen. "Island Rescue,"* after all, could serve as a title for almost any adventure involving the British Navy, a lovely exile and a War Office man with a few forged passports.

A messenger employed since Jan. 7 in a Western Union telegraph office at 203 West Fifty-second Street finiished his duties at 6 o'clock last night and then whiled away two hours in the front of the store.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Federal Judge Roy Shelbourne ruled today that any manufacturer is free to use the Ballard and Ballard Company patent for oven-ready biscuits.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commandant in Berlin, decided today to have his troops take target practice at 2:30 A. M. in an effort to quiet the storm that has been raging in the city's press -- both East and West -- this week.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today an attempt by State Senator William J. Bianchi (Republican and American Labor party) to have the name of Dr. Charles Muzzicato removed from the ballot as Republican candidate for the State Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board opened the way today for half a million workers in the steel fabricating industry to get quick Government approval for a 16-cent wage rise such as workers in the basic steel industry had received.
Soviet railroad lines are carrying more freight than ever before and their technical condition has been substantially improved, recent Soviet press comment indicates.

The Police Department Property Clerk, Frank Leuci, gave an engagement ring yesterday to another man's wife who had never had the ring before. But since the husband had found the ring in the first place, everybody was happy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A tour of the Far East by the president-elect of the United States, between his election in November and his inauguration in January, was advocated today as a means of building good neighbor relations between the United States and Southeast Asia.

Just as Jerome Kessler was quite amused by a previous letter addressed to you regarding the possession of lethal weapons by private citizens, I am sure that the quarter-million members of the National Rifle Association and many others would be very amused by the letter of Mr. Kessler.

The thirty-fifth season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band ended last night with a concert in Central Park under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman. It was the fiftieth program of the season and the 1,996th of the Guggenheim Memorial series.

The TV-Radio Workshop established last year by the Ford Foundation with a grant of $1,200,000 has been authorized by the foundation to spend additional money in the production of a new television series entitled "Omnibus."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, acting chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that a series of television debates between Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was "a very interesting idea."

The Dodgers tangled with Robin Roberts at Ebbets Field again last night and the Phils' ace right-hander came out ahead as usual. The Phils gave Robin his nineteenth triumph and eighth straight by an 8-3 score. It also was the ninth time in his career he has won in Brooklyn with only one loss.

Steel shortages may prevent many small ship-repair plants in the New York area from completing the jobs already under way, and virtually all such yards are avoiding future commitments. They are unwilling to purchase available but high-priced Japanese steel or to resort to a spreading black market in the metal.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Crafty Admiral, a challenger from the East, heads a list of twelve probable starters in the $45.900 Whirlaway Handicap at Washington Park tomorrow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 -- Yugoslavia has approached the United States for permission to purchase wheat with part of the funds that will be granted in aid during the fiscal year 1952-53.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The sound that every mother waits for when she holds an infant over her shoulder and pats it on the back can now be produced at will. Patent 2,606,399 was issued this week to Muriel V. Graham of Kent, Wash., for a new doll to join the sleeping, crying and wetting varieties that little girls already know. This one burps.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- All of the foreign threats were eliminated today as Maureen Connolly, the 17-year-old National and Wimbledon champion, led the way into the semi-finals of the Essex Country Club's invitation singles tennis tourney.
A sharp break in the apparent deadlock in the mediation talks aimed at averting a strike on the New York Central Railroad lines east of Buffalo was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Price controllers said today an order detailing ceiling price increases for various types of steel, based on a boost of $5.20 a ton for carbon steel, will be made public Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Roy F. Priest of Bountiful, Utah, who has had long training in political work, was named director of the women's division of the Republican National Committee by Arthur E. Summerfield, chairman, today. She succeeds Mrs. Gilford Mayes, who has returned to her home in Kellogg, Idaho.
The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday, 17 to 33 points net higher, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in moderate volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz, although battered for fourteen hits, went the distance tonight for his twenty-first victory of the season as the Athletics pounded out sixteen hits for an 11-7 victory over the Senators.

Faced with the first major outbreak of typhoid fever in this area in six years, the city Health Department traced the source yesterday to a 45-year-old cook in a Far Rockaway, Queens, day camp for 325 children.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15 (UP) -- Jerry Barber of Pasadena, Calif., and Dave Douglas from Newark, Del., both fired 67's, 5 under par, today to tie the defending champion, Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, for the lead at the halfway mark in the $15,000 Kansas City Open golf tournament.

The reduction of Russia's lead in the international team chess championship tournament marked the play yesterday in the fifth round of matches in Group C, in which the Soviet and United States players are rivals, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- The Socialist Reich party, the largest and most powerful of the forty-four Neo-Nazi groups in West Germany, is torn by violent internal struggle and neither it nor any other Fascist organization is expected to play an important role in next year's general election.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The world's sterling-area countries, hungry for dollars, may soon be able to get more of them through more generous loans from the International Monetary Fund.

MADRID, Aug. 15 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, who for several months has been deploring the "tolerance" of the Spanish Government toward Protestants, asked Generalissimo Francisco Franco today to define in clear terms what was the juridical position of non-Catholic sects in Spain, where Roman Catholicism is the officially recognized state religion.
EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Medalist Tommy Jacobs caught Scotty Fraser on the eighteenth hole today to tie for the lead in the national Junior Chamber of Commerce golf tournament.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 15 -- On top of the other financial scandals that have plagued Brazilians recently has come official confirmation that there are counterfeit Brazilian war bonds in circulation almost indistinguishable from genuine ones.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Four race track officials are expected to testify against legalization of off-track betting when the joint legislative commission to study horse racing opens hearings at Saratoga Springs next Thursday and Friday.

The Soviet Empire further tightened its grip on its European satellites when Matyas Rakosi, a Soviet citizen, Colonel General in the Soviet Army and Communist boss of Hungary since the war, took over the office of Premier of that country to wield official as well as actual power over it.

There may be a tendency in some quarters to take the Communist propaganda line at its face value and believe that the real and only reason for the accelerated bombing attacks in North Korea is the desire to put pressure on the stalled negotiation at Panmunjom. Obviously the Communists want the world to think this and thus, by inference at least, condemn the bombing as a calculated move against peace.

In a report made for the Inter-American Press Association, just issued, it is stated that "there is no more arbitrary and politically capricious censorship exercised anywhere in the Western Hemisphere today" than in Colombia. These are strong words, but they are applied to a truly distressing state of affairs.

The necessarily brief reports of the interview which I gave to the press on Aug. 5 in New York have been widely but quite erroneously interpreted as a criticism of the Point Four program and its administration. What I tried to say in short, I have said at greater length and fully supported by facts and figures in my book "Land for Tomorrow," recently published by the American Geographical Society and the Indiana University Press.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug, 15 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, who gained note as a cataloguer of female foibles, acknowledged today that her re-entry into politics -- from which she had "retired" in 1946 -- was a bit of feminine mind-changing. And, she vouchsafed, she might change her mind again.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The recent steel strike has cost the auto industry an estimated 544,000 units of production. Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department said today that the United States Embassy in Guatemala was watching closely the case of the three Pan American World Airways officials who were prohibited by Guatemalan authorities from boarding a plane for Miami.
PETERBOROUGH, N. H., Aug. 15 -- The State of New Hampshire paid tribute here today to Mrs. Edward MacDowell, 94-year-old widow of America's first internationally famous composer.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Good Time stepped the last half mile in 59 seconds tonight at the Roosevelt Raceway to defeat Solicitor by a half length in 2:03 2/5 in a $6,000 free-for-all pace. Prince Jay was third in the six-horse field.

CAIRO, Aug. 15 -- A special military trabunal sitting in the mill town of Kafr el-Dawar, just south of Alexandria, resumed today the trial of persons accused of inciting 6,000 workers to riot and arson early Wednesday.
HAWAII NATIONAL PARK, Aug. 15 -- Pele, the Hawaiians' goddess of volcanoes, has come back to her traditional home in Kilauea crater to give the island of Hawaii an economic shot in the arm.

In this city of skyscrapers it's the easiest thing in the world to look down from high places. But, says the Proper Bostonian, New Yorkers show a surprising lack of interest in the prospects below that looking down reveals.
WALLA WALLA, Wash, Aug. 15 -- Turman Wilson, 26 years old, and his brother, Utah, 22, scheduled to be hanged today in Washington State Prison here, have at least 120 days more to live.

LONDON, Aug 15 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation's network of five major television stations was completed today with the successful opening of transmission from Wenvoe, near Cardiff, for viewers in South Wales and southwest England.

King Faisal II of Iraq will fly to Washington this morning for a luncheon with President Truman. The two heads of state, one 17 years old and the other 68, are expected to touch on such subjects of mutual interest as photography and the stability of the Middle East.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- That illusive first victory of the year at Fenway Park was still eluding the Yankees tonight as they bowed to Lou Boudreau's Red Sox in the opener of a four-game series, 3 to 2, before a roaring crowd of 33,418.

The Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday that it would open hearings on Sept. 8 in Washington to receive evidence on the policy of chartering out Government-owned, war-built ships. The shipping agency held its annual review on chartering earlier in the summer and found tentatively that conditions justified continuing the policy.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 16 -- The Chinese Communist authorities told the North Koreans today that close cooperation between the two nations could "smash the schemes of the American aggressors" in the Korean war as well as the deadlock in the armistice negotiations.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- The Soviet Union demonstrated today that North Korea continues to enjoy its fullest support and aid against what Pravda called "the instigators of a new war -- the American imperialists."
ATLANTA, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Mississippi's delegation to the Democratic National Convention refused today to bind itself to support the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket, reviving the fading Southern rebellion.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- The United States said today that it would give no pledges not to use atomic, chemical and bacteriological weapons against an aggressor until strict international control had become a reality.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A physician today gave a youth critically ill of polio a drug that had been flown from Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Laurance Hoes, president of the James Monroe Memorial Foundation and great grandson of President James Monroe, said today that President Truman had been in error in his statement yesterday that there was no Monroe china in the White House.

The liner United States may be the holder of the speed record for both the east and west crossings of the Atlantic but her "smoke performance" in her home port is "not at all satisfactory," in the opinion of the city's Smoke Control Bureau.
In the future as Vonnegut envisages it, the machines have completed their triumph.
Hugh J. Devore will start his third year as coach of New York University's varsity football team when the Violets report for preseason practice at Lake Sebago, N. Y., on Aug. 31.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 17 -- Fiercely fighting Chinese Communist infantry lost more than 3,700 killed and wounded, a substantial part of one division of Peiping's "Volunteer" army in Korea, in a week's struggle to recapture the ridges east of the truce conference site at Panmunjom, the United States marines estimated yesterday.

FOUR 1-centavo blue postal tax stamps have been issued by Colombia in tribute to the activities of the National Medical Academy in Bogota. The respective designs are portraits of four Colombian physicians who were associated with the institution: Jose Maria Lombana-Barreneche, Pompilio Martinez, Nicolas Osorio and Ezequiel Uricoechea.

ANYBODY writing or editing a book about San Francisco is in trouble, not because material is lacking but because there is too much. The Spanish priests and soldiers, the Yankee trappers, the Russians, the Forty-Niners, the vigilance committees, the arrival of the railroad, corruption, sin, earthquake and fire, fog and the trade wind, the spirit of speculation and the joy of living -- all belong in a book dealing with San Francisco.

Controversies over rural school reorganization, which seeks to eliminate the traditional one-room schoolhouse in favor of the larger consolidated community school, have cropped up in many parts of the country over the past forty years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- John L. Lewis proclaimed today a ten-day memorial stoppage of coal production by members of the United Mine Workers beginning next Saturday, Aug. 23.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- As one of the sixteen Republicans who issued a statement Aug. 3 contending that enactment of civil rights legislation would be accelerated by Presidential and Congressional victories for their party, Representative Jacob K. Javits of New York offered new defense of that declaration today in the light of Democratic attack.

SLOATSBURG -- Throughout the summer the difficulty of negotiating traffic jams on the lower section of Route 17, the principal artery for week-end travel to and from the Catskills, is a constant problem for city motorists.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 16 -- For the first time since the Democrats and Republicans picked their 1952 Presidential candidates attention was focused this week on the farm vote. This is somewhat unusual, because both major parties have vied for the farm vote on a year-round basis for a score or more years, and the general approach of recent Presidential candidates has been fairly well known at an early stage.

THE acceptance of oneself is the essence of the moral problem and the epitome of a whole outlook upon life. That I feed the hungry, that I forgive an insult, that I love my enemy in the name of Christ -- all these are undoubtedly great virtues.

A HALF-MILE from the mainland, on a 342-acre tract of land completely surrounded by the green waters of Biscayne Bay, a 71-year-old inventor-sportsman is having a lot of fun. For more than a quarter of a century, Gar Wood has been hailed as the speed boat king, and always identified with boats.

In his address at Springfield on Thursday Governor Stevenson belittled the issue of the need for a change in Administration. He called it a doctrine of change for its own sake and applied it exclusively to the Republicans, going on to say, of the period of long Republican tenure after 1860, "Evidently 'change' is a sound principle only when the Republicans are out and the Democrats in."

HONG KONG, Aug. 16 -- An American traveler has reported the opening of advance engineering offices above Lanchow for the construction of the projected northwest Chinese railway that is scheduled to lead into Sinkiang Province and be linked eventually with the Soviet Union's Turkestan-Siberian railway in central Asia.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- An "exploding star" or nova has just been reported sighted behind the Iron Curtain. It is in the constellation Scorpion visible low in the south at evening.

Walk the fields now and you walk with the mints, particularly with the bergamots, those shaggy-headed friends of the bees. There is wild bergamot, there is Oswego tea, and there is bee balm, all of them bergamots; and though the names are often used interchangeably, they actually denote slight variations within the family.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- At least twenty-nine women have set their sights on seats in the next Congress. The big field is a cause of satisfaction to the women's divisions of the Republican and Democratic national committees.

THEODORE ROOSEVELT was the first modern President of the United States -- the first, that is, to face the problems of the modern state. He was also a forerunner of the "liberal internationalist" wing of the contemporary Republican party, and the most influential founder of the tradition to which the G. O. P. returns again and again in its efforts to reach the American electorate.

JERUSALEM -- A capsule report on a tour of Israel requires two adjectives and a noun -- stimulating, disturbing, and hope. Of eight countries visited on this tour, only in Israel did one find a strong feeling of hope for a future that must certainly be better than the present.

FOR his third venture into the field of historical fiction Noel Gerson offers the clientele something fresh in frontier settings, the free state of Franklin that was eventually to come into the Union under the name of Tennessee.

IT was forty years ago this month that the first "feature-length" foreign movie was shown in the United States. "Queen Elizabeth" was its title; it was made in France with Sarah Bernhardt as its star and, when Adolph Zukor flashed it upon America, it was an unprecedented and sensational thing.

The split-level dwelling ma' become the' best-selling house in the New York area, according to Lee Schoenfield, Long Island home builder, whose current project is Brewster Aianor, a colony of 350 such dwellings on Hicksville Road in Massapequa.
An official veil of secrecy was drawn yesterday over Frank Costello's first day in prison in thirty-seven years.

Every day nearly 15,000,000 persons visit the 50,000 pharmacies in the United States. Some make leisurely visits just to chat and for minor purchases entirely unrelated to medical care. To them the soda fountain of today's drug store has replaced the cracker barrel of yesterday's general store.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- In France the next few months will be a period for revision of budgets, of ideas, of policies. The experiment of Premier Antoine Pinay with financial stabilization as its object will meet its real test. The aspirations of Rene Pleven, Minister of Finance, to build up an armament industry with United States aid will have to be adjusted to the realities of Washington policy and North Atlantic Treaty planning.

THEY undoubtedly should have been talking learnedly about boxing because they were sitting in ringside seats, awaiting the start of the Marciano-Matthews fight a few weeks ago. But being baseball men, Frank Frisch and Ben Chapman naturally discussed baseball. Frisch is a petunia fancier from New Rochelle and Chapman probably is growing cigars or something in Tampa.

DENVER, Aug. 16 -- Campaign headquarters for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today that he would deliver his first major campaign address over radio and television from Philadelphia's Convention Hall on the night of Sept. 4.

BECAUSE baseball attendance is down at Yankee Stadium, the New York Yankees attempted to test the paying public in the absence of video last Monday night by banning the telecast of their game with the Boston Red Sox.

In his article "Colorado's Publicity-shy San Luis Valley," published last Sunday, Marshall Sprague writes: "The north is pure cowboy, with Saguache at the center. Saguache has a street named Sauerkraut Avenue. It is one of the world's most famous towns in juridical circles, for it was here that a certain Alfred Packer was sentenced to quite a few years in prison for having eaten five men."

Exterminators of pests can learn something from Howard Young, Robert L. Strecker and Prof. John T. Emlen Jr., all of the University of Wisconsin's zoological department. The three have found out that the city mouse is a home-lover and therefore not given to wandering.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Department Defense identified today 197 more casualties of the Korean war, including 41 killed in action, 130 wounded, 6 injured in accidents and 20 missing. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

ESSENTIALLY Hammond Innes is a first-rate reporter at large, adroitly bending the art of fiction to his use. Such novels as "The Blue Ice," "Air Bridge" and "Campbell's Kingdom'' are well-documented and emotionally convincing reports on various parts of the earth where interesting things are going on, cast in the form of melodrama and interpreted in terms of soundly (if not subtly) developed characters.

A PLAYER of duplicate bridge must think of some aspects of the game that do not concern a rubber-bridge player. For example, the fact that the trick-score at no-trump contracts is 10 points higher than it is at major-suit contracts.

Yogi Berra's three-run homer in the sixth inning yesterday enabled the Yankees to defeat the Red Sox, 5 -- 4, for the New Yorkers' first victory at Boston this season. The Dodgers stretched their lead over the idle Giants to eight games as Billy Loes blanked the Phillies, 15 -- 0. Rain cut each game to six innings. The Indians beat the White Sox, 4 -- 3, on Dale Mitchell's circuit clout.

SCRUYLERVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- A week-long celebration beginning tomorrow will mark the 175th anniversary of the Battle of Saratoga, fought on the site of the village, eleven miles east of Saratoga Springs.

ALTHOUGH the 1952 parade of state fairs began last month -- North Dakota opened its annual exposition July 28, Montana's closed yesterday and Illinois' ends today at Springfield -- the season does not actually get into full swing until this week.
The two-year row between commercial bankers and savings bankers over the latter's attempts to establish additional branch offices in this state may be reaching a settlement. Maybe.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- With the aid of a three-run homer by Yogi Berra, his twenty-fourth of the year, and the timely intervention of rain, the Yankees today achieved their first triumph of the season at Fenway Park to the disappointment of 28,635 fans.

The cry of "witch-hunt" is rising again, and this time through the leading columns of the dramatic section of your Sunday paper, as witness a pair of articles by Arthur Miller and James Thurber, respectively.

TAKEN together, these three books will help children discover for themselves the how, when, where and why of many commonplace mysteries of life around them. In "See For Yourself." Nancy Larrick speaks directly to young children as she describes in simple non-technical terms easy experiments they can do at home.

The source of atomic energy is the element uranium. The composition of uranium as found in the earth is 99.3 per cent U-238 atoms (238 times as heavy as hydrogen, the lightest element) and .7 per cent U-235 atoms. There are two principal methods for converting uranium into an explosive substance.

Persistent reports that Soviet Russia is planning to open a passenger-cargo service between Odessa and the Far East with old German ships acquired as war reparations or raised from the bottom of the Baltic received credence last week when an authoritative source announced the arrival at Singapore July 5 of the liner Russ.

THE fifth annual American Dance Festival, as usual the most important modern dance event of the summer season, will be held in the handsome Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College at New London from Thursday evening of this week through next Sunday afternoon.
A penetrating inquiry under Federal auspices into rackets and other illegal operations in the waterfront industry has been going on quietly for six months.

I should like to congratulate you on the excellent editorial "Crisis in the Middle East" of Aug. 11. I was particularly struck by the comment, "There are things that we Americans, especially, can do * * * economic, Point Four, technical and military aid, education and propaganda * * * advice, example and encouragement for the right men and policies * * * anti-Communist containment policy * * * understanding, patience, patience and more patience."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Republican leaders of the Senate and the House of Representatives gave today their estimates of the accomplishments of the Eighty-second Congress, which adjourned July 7.

THE growing interest in tree peonies is manifest in the increasing number of fall catalogues which list examples of this magnificent plant. Anyone who is fond of peonies should include at least one or two Japanese tree peonies, if only to extend the season.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A 19-year-old Negro brought a 100,000 damage suit today against four Lynchburg policemen he accused of violating his civil rights.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 (UP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson wrote The Oregon Journal today that he had "no commitments to anyone about anything -- including President Truman" and left it to his record as to whether he could "clean up the mess in Washington."
ARAM SALISIAN remarked the other day during an interview in his Armenian restaurant, the Golden Horn, that "eggplant is endless." Dishes in which it may appear did, indeed, seem so.
A new 28,000-ton passenger liner will bear the name Arcadia when she is launched next year thanks to the courtesy of a small Thames River tugboat that gave up the name and took another.

I CAN'T understand why, at a time when the factual activities of spies are in the daily headlines possibly more often than ever before, the fictional spy-suspense melodrama is in the doldrums. Before and during the last war, the spy story reached its highest point of literary development; now it is all but nonexistent.

The Middle East is a broad semicircular belt of land that connects the continental masses of Asia, Europe, and Africa. At the southwest end of the belt lies Egypt. At the northeast end lies Iran. Over a thousand miles of desert, sea and mountain separate the two countries.

CAIRO, Aug. 16 -- These are anxious times for the political parties in Egypt, particularly for the Wafd, the largest of them all. The parties have been warned in no uncertain terms, first by the army, then by the Government, that if they are not promptly purged of corrupt and unworthy elements and recast in an entirely new mold they must disappear.

Concerning the stimulating article by Albion Ross about the Egyptian student, "A Power in Egyptian Politics" (Aug. 3): While it shows how well informed Mr. Ross is about the structure of Egyptian society, it was disappointing in its analyses.* * *

PARENTS in cities and the kind of suburbs where open fields are only an invitation to the builders of housing developments are liable to find their nerves somewhat strained as the children's vacation time draws toward its close.

I am glad to note your observation (Calendar, Aug. 3) of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Thomas A. Edison's invention of the phonograph, but the date Aug. 12 is not the date of the patent. The patent was executed Dec. 15, 1877, applied for Dec. 24, 1877, and granted Feb. 13, 1878.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The world welterweight champion, Kid Gavilan of Havana, opened a South American tour tonight by gaining a ten-round decision over Mario Diaz of Buenos Aires in a non-title bout. Gavilan weighed 150 1/2 and Diaz 157 1/2 pounds.

IT is a generally accepted fact that travel is good for us -- and good fun as well. But if a popular poll were conducted on the joys of traveling the answers would be as many as the travelers. In fact, such pleasures must be left to speak for themselves and this, after a journey right round the world, I will try to do.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Gamblers and racketeers were major targets in an income-tax drive that won commendations for the Internal Revenue Bureau today from Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder.

John Foster Dulles, chief foreign policy adviser to the Republican party, accused the Truman Administration yesterday of wrecking the principle of bipartisan foreign policy and expressed doubt that two - party unity could be maintained under any Democratic Administration.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN has given the rights for the American premiere of his opera, "Billy Budd," to the Music School of Indiana University in Bloomington, Ind. The students there will present the all-male work in a single performance on Dec. 5. It will be under the supervision of the team that has been responsible for the school's other major productions, Ernst Hoffman, conductor, and Hans Busch, stage director.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 -- John Thomas Hill, 49 years old, described as one of the nation's ten most wanted fugitives, was arrested early today in a rooming house in suburban Hamtramck, Mich. He was seized by Detroit agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers, hampered by a soggy turf and a slippery ball, fought to a 0-0 tie tonight in a pre-season exhibition football game before 11,489 fans.

VIENNA, ON the surface Vienna exhibits an almost somnolent placidity in this summer of 1952. The city is seemingly interested in its most successful opera season since the war, as well as a new and doubtful specific for rejuvenation -- the consumption of nine-day fertilized eggs.

THE ever-increasing number of youngsters who cannot remember when they took their first airplane trip because they were too young to remember anything at the time is only another sign that commercial aviation has come of age.
Arthur Miller's analysis for the dearth of top-flight Broadway playwriting brings to mind the views of the late Arthur Hopkins, who was also much concerned with the problem.

Mrs. Rose V. Russell, legislative representative of the Teachers Union, charged yesterday that recent testimony before the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee that Communist-front student organizations had existed in thirteen Brooklyn high schools constituted "interference in our schools by a Federal agency."
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Jockey Oliver Eric Guerin got some mud in his face, but he nevertheless had a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon at the Saratoga Association's old horse park today.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 16 -- A leapfrog, whistle-stop campaign by airplane and train shaped up today for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, who said he would carry his quest for the Presidency "into every part of the nation."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 11 -- Figures on the occupational structure of Israel's population, published this week in the Statistical Bulletin of the Central Bureau of Statistics and Economic Research, showed that the percentage of the population engaged in public and other services, including the liberal professions, and in trade and finance was higher in Israel than in any other country in the world.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 16 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman, told the Republican State Convention here today that the party's candidates in the state would have the aid of a hard-hitting campaign by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Presidential nominee.
THE music of Tchaikovsky, perversely enough, seems to produce most gratifying results when conductors do not follow too literally the composer's instructions as to how it should be played.

DALLAS, Aug. 16 -- Drought and parching winds continued to wither farm and ranch prospects in the Southwest this week. Farmer's Home Administration field representatives meeting in Dallas during the week told of ruined corn crops and withered cotton and a Rio Grande Valley citrus industry that hasn't had enough moisture to recover from 1949 freeze damage.

BOITO'S "Mefistofele," which has not been played in San Francisco since 1923, will be the major novelty of the San Francisco Opera season, which opens on Sept. 16. The title role will be sung by Nicola Rossi-Lemeni, who made a hit in San Francisco last year as Boris Godunoff.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The official Laborite Daily Herald administered an editorial rebuke today to the unofficial Anglican weekly Church Times for criticizing the Conservative Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's remarriage after divorce while remaining in high Government office. The Herald said:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Julia Sampson of San Marino, Calif., and Mary Ann Eilenberger of San Diego, seeded first and second respectively, breezed through their semi-final matches in the Middle Atlantic Girls Grass Court tennis tournament today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Opposition to a purely Continental strategy of defense advocated by French military men is growing, and powerful voices are being raised for a review of the purely military arrangements for the defense of Western Europe against possible Russian aggression.

In it, as in them, we are taken into the future and shown an America ruled by a tiny oligarchy, and here too there is a revolt that fails.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York came out strongly today in favor of Averell Harriman for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York.

Arthur Miller's article on why our theatre today is dead is a significant social document. If it points up the fears of writers to take up challenging themes bravely and forthrightly it also reflects the same situation in other walks of life.

Federal mediators last night called in representatives of the New York Central Railroad and of four railroad brotherhoods and presented them with a package proposal aimed at a settlement of their labor dispute and the unions' plans to strike.

TECUMSEH, behaving like a New England farmer beholding the recent rains, last week hailed the announcement that Stanley Young's "Mr. Pickwick" would open at the Plymouth on Sept. 17, thereby ending the local play drought.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 16 -- Iran's Supreme Economic Council met tonight to put final touches on a tax bill that, according to reports, may take as much as 10 per cent of the value of very large landholdings and 1 to 10 per cent of the value of landed estates, buildings and real estate investments in general.

MAYBE it is true that the novel, of all literary forms, is the one most peculiarly suited to the presentation of live characters. Certainly it is still the novel's special and mysterious grace that it can come all alive with people, showing a quick vitality unlike that of any other form, as if the projection of people were its own singular, predestined and proper business, at which it naturally and unselfconsciously excels.

With good weather and visibility, with sun, blue skies and next to no wind, a spectator throng of thousands will stretch along a 130-mile arena this morning to see one of the zaniest manifestations of speed boating ever devised. This will be the Hudson River outboard marathon, starting from Albany at 8 A. M. and with the winner finishing off Dyckman Street probably between 11:30 and noon.

What has apparently become a cliche among derogations of the American hot dog crops up once again in Martin Gansberg's article "Hot Dog Centennial" (July 27). Mr. Gansberg quotes an unnamed German manufacturer as describing the American product as "pale and wrinkled."

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 16 -- Most of Nassau County's 152,000 enrolled Republicans, 39,395 Democrats, 850 Liberals and 411 American Labor party members will ignore it, but Tuesday's primary balloting nevertheless will cost the county about $60,000.

The Department of Meteorology of New York University's College of Engineering has been redesignated the Department of Meteorology and Oceanography, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Thorndike Saville, dean of the college.

The volume of physical-damage, or collision, insurance written on a "contingent commission" basis on automobiles financed by banks, finance companies, loan companies and self-financed automobile dealers has mushroomed since the end of World War II.

JERRY LAWRENCE and Bob Lee are two script writers who do a day's work. Their regular assignment is to put words to music for "The Railroad Hour," but in addition they also write for "The Halls of Ivy" and "The Hallmark Playhouse" on radio and for "The Unexpected" on television.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Moonrush, California's biggest money-winning gelding, put on a driving finish to capture the tenth running of the $10,000 added San Diego Handicap today.

The United Nations International School in Parkway Village, Queens -- an unusual experiment in education for children from twenty lands -- has been saved from possible extinction. The school will reopen on Sept. 4 with an increased registration; meanwhile, a militant board of directors is striving to improve the institution's financial situation.
An 8-year-old lad from Stamford, Conn., was convinced yesterday that the Brooklyn Dodgers' manager was clairvoyant.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- East Germany is to build a "People's Army" equipped with the latest planes, tanks and other weapons, largely furnished by the Soviet Union, Frar Dahlem, a leading German Communist, said today.

CAIRO, Aug. 16 -- The special military tribunal set up to try the instigators of Wednesday's demonstration by 6.000 textile workers continued to take evidence at the mill town of Kafr El Dawar near Alexandria today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Republican National Headquarters announced today that General Eisenhower's Philadelphia speech would be aimed primarily at the country's youth.

WENDOVER, Utah, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A. T. (Goldie) Gardner, 61, a British racing driver, was injured today when his super powered stock car crashed into a mileage marker on the Salt Flats at more than 150 miles an hour.

LILLIAN DE LA TORRE knows her way about in the eighteenth century, and like the people of that age she takes a great delight in mulling over the scandalous problems which agitated it. A few years ago she cut her teeth on the relatively minor mystery of Elizabeth Canning, and in the present skillful volume she tackles one of the most celebrated of all causes celebres.

THE status of frequency modulation radio, for which such high hopes were held, constitutes one of the more difficult problems of the moment. The high-fidelity medium has fallen upon unhappy days which, to say the least, means it faces an uphill struggle in the future.

NEWARK, Aug. 16 -- John Dodds, 62 years old, of 43 Hillside Place, night watchman at the Mosque Theatre Building, 1020 Broad Street, was beaten fatally early this morning when he apparently surprised burglars attempting to break open the box office in the theatre lobby.

EACH year gardeners search hopefully among nursery lists for perennials that will "grow in sun or shade" or, more rarely encountered, those "recommended for shade." This is a good time to consider the possibilities of perennials that will flower in shade, with a view toward a better garden next year.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Last summer the British lost their biggest and most profitable investment abroad when Iran nationalized the properties of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company. With the investment they also surrendered a foothold in the strategic Middle East.

President Truman's action under the Hull Trade Agreements legislation in the case of American watchmakers and the accompanying statement in support of his position are in the best tradition of American trade diplomacy.

WITH an issue of six long-play Decca disks, Wilhelm Kempff has completed his recordings of the thirty-two Beethoven Piano Sonatas. His is the first integral version of modern times; the only other pianist who achieved a comparable feat was Artur Schnabel, and the majority of his interpretations were available only on imported H. M. V. Beethoven Society sets.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, today assailed labor unions, industrial groups and professional organizations whose "failure to mature" was a "definite threat to the total democratic system."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: The summer has brought a vigorous invasion of crabgrass, even in turf which was thick in spring. Before fall rehabilitation of lawns can be started, this weed grass must be eliminated. Spray with liquid or apply the powder form of either potassium cyanate or phenyl mercuric acetate. Plantain and other weeds are destroyed by a 2, A-D, spray.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The sale of forty-six horses in training brought $51,900 today an average price of $1,128.

TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- The latest pattern of air warfare in Korea continued its development this week as U. N. planes roared north of the thirty-eighth parallel to strike a new series of blows against the enemy's supply bases and "marginal" strategic targets.
DES MOINES, Aug. 16 -- Members of the Wacs now serving overseas "don't want to come home," Col. Mary A. Hallaren of Washington, director of the Women's Army Corps, said here Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United States has indicated Japan that it will promptly set up machinery for consideration of applications to free Japanese war criminals.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The blond American secretary of a Chinese general was freed today after eight days of imprisonment while her boss was transferred to prison pending extradition proceedings on charges of embezzling $25,000,000.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The nation's best shotgun marksmen will finish tuning up tomorrow for the championship competition that starts Monday in the fifty-third Grand American trapshoot.
SOME people can travel round the world and see nothing to speak about. Some can take a single walk in a forest and come out with stories to fill a book about its wonders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Veterans Administration official estimated today that of those entitled to $200,000,000 in 1952 dividends on National Service Life Insurance only half would draw out their share before the year end.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 16 -- A general reorganization in the command of the North Atlantic Treaty air power in western Europe is being considered by senior Allied military commanders in Supreme Headquarters here, in its major subordinate commands and in Washington.

Re "Was Yalta a Calamity?" (Aug. 3): Without rejecting Chester Wilmot's appraisal entirely, I would be inclined to agree with Professor Commager that circumstances inevitably played a large part in the decisions taken, but, inexplicably, Professor Commager makes one, possibly two, very untenable statements in rebuttal.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The defending champion Revonoc, sailed by Larry Conover and Al Echerdt of Larchmont, N. Y., was disqualified in today's heat of the international One-Ten sailing class championship on Gull Lake.

Customs officials here face a packed schedule tomorrow with nearly 6,000 passengers from eleven liners due to debark on New York piers between 8 A. M. and 5 P. M. They will not be required, however, to inspect an additional 732 military personnel aboard two troop ships from Europe and South America.

With Dr. James A. Van Allen as its leader, the State University of Iowa will send an expedition to Greenland late this month to study the intensity of cosmic rays near the geomagnetic north pole. Rockets are to be sent nearly fifty miles into the earth's upper atmosphere.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Undefeated in a major primary contest in thirty-five years, top leaders of the Westchester County Republican organization will face a stiff battle in Tuesday's primary election when Ralph A. Gamble of Larchmont, veteran Representative, will be opposed for renomination by Edwin B. Dooley, Mayor of Mamaroneck.

THE bounty of midsummer gardens will crowd show tables at the Mill Plain School in Fairfield, Conn., on Tuesday and Wednesday. Sponsored by the Fairfield County Horticultural Society in cooperation with twenty Connecticut garden clubs, this annual exhibit ushers in the "state fair" season of suburban flower shows.

President Truman's order to two of his executive departments for a study of shipping tax benefits and their relation to maritime subsidies is a presage of hard times for the merchant marine, industry leaders said last week.

The United States has notified the Philippines that because of the lack of any budget provision there will be no official American representation in the big international fair that is to open in the Philippines early next year. This situation is lamentable to say the least. This is the first exposition of this sort to be held in Southeast Asia.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 16 -- The University of Illinois' Big Ten champion football squad has lost six players through scholastic ineligibility, it was disclosed today with the release of the Illini invitation gridiron list of fifty-eight, smallest in several years.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- "It was too much like old times to be funny," Corp. Bernard Gotfryd reflected today following his "capture" last night by security elements of the 307th Infantry Regiment, a unit of the Seventy-seventh Division.

THIS commentary on James Joyce's "Ulysses" was published for the first time in 1930. Long out of print, stolen from college libraries, and all but unavailable, it is now republished in what the author claims to be an expanded and revised edition.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Larger crowds than ever before are being attracted this summer to Bandelier National Monument, one of the most accessible of the Southwest's Indian cliff dwelling and pueblo sites. On one Sunday not long ago 12,150 visitors came to the area near Los Alamos and just thirty-six miles northwest of Santa Fe.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug 16 -- A statement of principles pledging a "clean and vigorous campaign on the issues" and looking toward "an active progressive administration under Adlai Stevenson" was issued here today by Democratic candidates for Congress from New Jersey.

With the eight countries in Group C, including Russia and the United States, taking a rest, West Germany, playing a 2-2 tie with Argentina yesterday, maintained the lead over the South Americans in Group A of the International Chess Federation championship tournament, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.

ADJECTIVES attach themselves easily to Masaichi Nagata, the dynamic little boss of the Daiei Studios which gave the world the multiple prize winner "Rashomon." His associates describe him as shrewd, brilliant, a man with a steel trap mind.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral made a brilliant Midwestern debut and increased his chances for the year's handicap horse honors today when he carried top weight of 126 pounds to a three-length triumph over a muddy track in the $44,300 Whirlaway Handicap at Washington Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- United Nations diplomats are predicting the election of Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, as the next president of the General Assembly
DETROIT, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks came in from the bull pen to halt a ninth-inning St. Louis rally today as the Tigers defeated the Browns, 5 to 2, before 5,098 fans at Briggs Stadium.

A CLOSER integration of division activities and the desire to see a more equitable distribution of emphasis on photography's varied applications marked the 1952 convention of the Photographic Society of America, which closed a five-day meeting here yesterday.

IF Charles Patrick Fitzgerald's analysis is correct (and only the passage of time is likely to prove him wrong), the current triumph of the Chinese Communists is the inevitable climax of a process started a century ago by the West when it began to exert pressure on the Manchu emperors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Navy sought today to forestall a rash of flying saucer reports by announcing that it plans to launch a series of cross-country balloon flights next week.
TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The National Democratic Club of New Jersey announced today that Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, would be a guest at its $50-a-plate dinner on Aug. 27.

The National League for Nursing, 2 Park Avenue, has named Miss Marion W. Sheahan director of its division of nursing services, and Miss Julia M. Miller, director of its division of nursing education. The league recently was organized to replace the Association of Collegiate Schools of Nursing, National League of Nursing Education and National Organization for Public Health Nursing.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- The Republican eagle and the Democratic rooster will be absent from Ohio's Presidential ballot this year for the first time in probably fifty years.
Contracts totaling $472,376 for building the superstructure of Cargo Terminal Building 140 in Port Newark were awarded last week by the commissioners of the Port of New York Authority.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- There are no contests in the primary election in Rockland County next Tuesday. The county has a strong Republican voting record in Presidential years and it appears that the five incumbent Republican officeholders will be re-elected.

GATHERED together here are twenty essays, some polemical, some scholarly, some speculative, written over the last few years by a group of critics and scholars associated with the University of Chicago. Although the essays are sometimes elusive in doctrine, their style is heavily weighted with the omniscient learning, the nervous scrupulosity and the somewhat dire moral intent of neo-scholasticism.

JOSEPH LANE, who played so important a role in the settling of the Oregon Territory, is the subject of Victoria Case's latest novel. A crusader and patriot with a strict code of honor, Jo Lane's self-sacrifice and gallant political stands returned only to plague and ruin him.

GARDENS have suffered almost as much as people this summer, if queries and complaints are to be believed. Although it has been necessary to declare certain states disaster areas from the standpoint of farm crops, home grounds have never quite reached that stage.

THE Warner Brothers publicity department certainly must have been laughing up its sleeve last March when it announced that "Jim McLain," first in a group of pictures to be produced by John Wayne and Robert Fellows, would deal with the adventures of a Texas cattle buyer (that would be Mr. Wayne) who follows a trail of excitement to Honolulu.

READERS from two camps will be drawn to Mr. Calitri's novel. The devotees of the mystery thriller will find suspense, violence and plenty of such familiars as the cynical reporter, the crooked politician and detective squad heavies. Those who thrill to the performance of a subtler kind of detective, the psychiatrist tracking motive to its psychological lair, will likewise find God's plenty.

There was shock and dismay last week when official New York City police figures for the first six months of this year were made public. Compiled at the behest of THE NEW YORK TIMES, the figures showed an increase over the first six months of 1951 in every category of major crime, ranging from 11 per cent to nearly 50 per cent.

Voters throughout New York State will resolve thirty-nine contests for nominations when they get to the polls on Tuesday, Primary Day, to ballot for candidates for the House of Representatives, the State Senate and Assembly, and a scattering of judicial posts.

The announcement last week that the Stratos Division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation at Bay Shore, L. I., is making the little machine that will air condition the cockpit of the French jet fighter Le Mystere brings to full cycle one of the least known thrillers of World War II.

SMITHTOWN BRANCH, L. I., Aug 16 -- The Mystery Stable's black gelding, Sporting Chance, won the working hunter championship today at the thirty-seventh annual Smithtown Horse Show. The events were run off in the rain for the most part and by the time a third of the afternoon program had been completed the show rings were heavy with mud.

A leprosy research and training center is to be established within a year in India under American and British Protestant mission auspices, Dr. Eugene R. Kellersberger, general secretary of American Leprosy Missions, 156 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., the 1942 winner here, gained the final round of the Essex County women's invitation singles tennis tournament by defeating the national junior champion, Anita Kanter of Santa Monica, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2, today before rain halted the competition.

Fifteen national trade associations representing retailers and wholesalers in fair-trade industries have accepted membership on the new advisory council set up by the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade. Maurice Mermey, director of the bureau, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today listed twelve members of the ninety-six-member Senate and sixty-nine of the 435-member House of Representatives who had voted "right" from the C. I. O. viewpoint on all of the issues it considered most important in the Eighty-second Congress.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 16 -- Miss Abbe Law, an 8-year-old Peter - At - Law trotting mare, owned and driven by Jimmy Cruise, scored a one-length victory 2:07 4-5 over Hadley Hanover in the Utica junior free-for-all trotting feature for $4,500 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

CETRA-SORIA, which in March, 1949, brought out an abridged version of "La Forza del Destino" as its first long-play release, announces that the complete opera will be released at the end of this month The "Forza del Destino" recording, made from the same masters as the 1949 release, features Maria Caniglia, Ebe Stignani, Galliano Masini and Carlo Tagliabue, with the late Gino Marinuzzi conducting.

Apparel buyers seeking fall merchandise in the New York market in the next few weeks will find it difficult to obtain quick deliveries of the wanted items in women's coats and suits. Manufacturers are running behind on deliveries, mainly because of delays in production of fabrics.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 16 -- The Democratic State Convention filled out today a slate of state candidates to run with Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Grosse Points and John Conolly of Detroit, nominee for Lieutenant Governor, who were designated in the state primary.

ALL ages will be playing in the sand piles on Thursday when Virginia Beach, Va., holds its Sand Festival, celebrating a reclamation effort that has added ten blocks of beach to the old shorefront, which has been washing away. The town will be en fete, with competing bands, parades and the arrival of Miss Virginia Beach of Union, N. J., by heliocopter.

Communist influence is widespread in the schools of nearly all countries in the South Pacific area, according to Dr. Walter Crosby Eells, former adviser on higher education with SCAP in Japan, who has spent the last year traveling in the Orient. His report on conditions in Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Thailand and Burma has been published by The Educational Record, quarterly journal of the American Council on Education.
Taking advantage of Luigi Dallapiccola's presence in this country, the N. B. C. Symphony had the Italian composer on its program yesterday as piano soloist.

HONOLULU, Aug. 16 -- From a wartime Woman's Army Corps barracks at Fort Ruger on a Honolulu hilltop, a staff of sixty-one members is administering a strategic area of the Pacific that is drawing increasingly more attention in the light of the area's developing security pattern.

Sales in department stores for the country as a whole were 2 per cent above 1951 in the week ended Aug. 9, on the basis of Federal Reserve Board figures. In the preceding week a decrease of the same extent had been recorded. In the latest week there were seven increases and three decreases, with two districts unchanged. Atlanta had the largest increase, 11 per cent, and New York the largest decrease, 9 per cent.

New officers of the Society of Philatelic Americans were installed yesterday at the final business session of the society's convention at the Astor Hotel. Tampa, Fla., was chosen for the 1953 meeting.

THERE is an art of expressing absurdities with such an earnest solemnity that they then pass for plausible discourse. An excellent example of this was provided by Arthur Miller's article, "Many Writers: Few Plays," in THE Times for Aug. 10.

The most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and the first personage of England after the members of the royal family, said upon his arrival here yesterday that those who undertook to judge Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, should be sure that they judged him fairly.

EACH fall thousands of American hunters move into Canada for their deer, bear, moose, elk, and caribou hunting, but, under the present ban on the importation of game animals from Canada, these men will be seeking their big game nearer home, which will place something of a burden on many states.

TWENTY-FOUR persons were named fellows, fifty-eight associates, two honorary fellows and two honorary members, at last night's annual honors banquet of the Photographic Society of America at the Hotel New Yorker.

NORTH AMERICANS who are accustomed to thinking of Mexican architecture in terms of either modern borrowed from Northern European sources or baroque curves and gold leaf will be interested in the home pictured here. It represents a new kind of contemporary design native to Mexico.

A COMPOST pile is one of nature's mills. There, seemingly inert material is transferred into valuable substances. When added to the soil, these increase its fertility, correct and maintain certain balances and improve the physical structure.

SEATTLE, Aug. 16 -- Over the Seattle Golf Club course, where the newest international series ended yesterday, the fifty-second amateur championship of the United States Golf Association will start on Monday.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 16 -- The rumored sale of the fifty- seven-room J. P. Morgan mansion here to the Russian delegation to the United Nations or to nuns of the Roman Catholic Order of St. John the Baptist in the Bronx fell flat today.
After reading George D. Griffin's romantic reply to Howard Taubman's article, "Musicians' Troubles,' I was immediately moved to write.

IT is not surprising that Americans have been alarmed by the latest Soviet hate campaign directed at the United States. There is now an extravagance and viciousness of propaganda which exceeds anything ever before experienced in time of peace, with the possible exception of Hitler's pre-war denunciations of the Bolsheviks.

OUT here at Antioch College a rare Shakespearean festival has been in progress since early July. Put on by the Antioch Area Theatre, the festival has been parading England's Kings through the 300 years that are covered by the Bard's so-called chronicle plays, said plays, by the way, having had a 350-year popularity rating equal to that of Typhoid Annie.

BUFFALO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Howard Hibbert of Miami, Fla., drove the Nitrogen through choppy waters and rain today to win both heats for the Class F service run-about national championship in the Buffalo Launch Club regatta.

Since the end of World War II there have been numerous programs to improve understanding between nations through the exchange of students, scholars and teachers. Among the most significant of the international projects are the teacher exchanges between the United States and other countries, the largest of these being with Great Britain.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,344, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:
There are two types of money collectors. There is the popular variety, an undiscriminating lot whose fascination turns toward the latest bankbook entry, and then there are the numismatists.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 -- Ohio, which always takes its politics seriously, is expected to establish a new high this November in total votes cast. Early registration figures point heavily in that direction.
I wish to express my gratitude for the inspiring Arthur Miller column in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday. It brings back some of the hopes for the lost dignity of playwriting.

The third generation of the Bell family is now helping direct the destinies of General Mills, the world's largest milling company. The rangy 45-year-old president of the company, now holding down the chief executive job for a little more than two months, is not only following in the footsteps of his father and grandfather, but is adhering to principles of the business followed by the Bell family since pre-Revolutionary War days.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Old guard Louisiana Republicans defeated an Eisenhower leader's bid for control of the State Central Committee today but the rival factions united to name a state campaign manager.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Floridian, relatively unknown among the country's top shooters, took the lead today in the sixty-seventh national pistol championships.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Australia's terrific one-two tennis punch of Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor today swept into the final round of the Newport invitation tournament, scoring straight set victories over two of America's top-ranked stars.

A comparison between the broadcast of North Korean Kim Il Sung in which he spoke of a truce without victory and the more truculent tone of the Peiping radio when it urged the North Koreans to fight on might suggest that the Chinese Communists and the North Koreans were not seeing eye to eye.

You refer in the Aug. 12 report of the engagement of Anthony Eden to Winston Churchill's niece to the dropping of the "Spencer" from the surname "Spencer-Churchill," allegedly so that the present Prime Minister of the United Kingdom could get a higher place in his school's alphabetical lists.

Stores that were delaying confirmation of orders rushed them in last week as prices tightened in various wholesale markets here, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Price increases on cotton goods resulted in stores placing orders through the end of the year, and the firming of prices of rayon and other synthetics at the mill and converter levels stabilized market prices.

Top Police Department officers were among 1,000 mourners who crowded the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes at 472 West 142d Street yesterday morning for the funeral of Patrolman James McGillion. The patrolman was shot early Tuesday while interceding in a street corner quarrel in Harlem.

HERE'S the way it happens. One rainy night, on a downtown street corner, this big-time lawyer, Frank Hobart, is blasted right out of this world. Nobody sees it happen except the snotty little kid who sells papers near by, and he can't tell who holds the heater.

Herbert Weisberger, 34 years old, of 5360 Broadway, manager of the men's department of the Macy's store at Flatbush Avenue and Tilden Street, Brooklyn, admitted yesterday systematic thefts from his own department.
The action by President Truman in rejecting Tariff Commission recommendations for an increase in duties on watches and watch movements imports was hailed last week by importers and exporters.
MISSOULA, Mont. -- Both as a welcome relief from sultry summer highways and as a spectacular side trip, Montana's Lewis and Clark Cavern is being discovered by increasing numbers of vacationists.

A HISTORICAL adventure story, "Gateway to Fortune" tells how the Panama route was sold to Congress and the American people in preference to the Nicaragua route; how a revolution was then promoted with the support of Teddy Roosevelt and the Navy to detach the neck of the isthmus from Colombia; and how the canal was built in spite of the hell and high water of the tropics and the murderous activities of Yellow Jack.

Large polished diamonds of more than a carat are bringing better prices on the western European market than they are in the United States. Companies may find it advantageous to sell the diamonds of more than three carats with slight flaws abroad instead of in the domestic market, according to Alexander E. Arnstein, senior partner in Arnstein Brothers Co., diamond dealer.

WITH H. R. 5767, the new McGuire Fair Trade Law, now on the books, as Mr. Poore reported in these columns two weeks ago, the booksellers can breathe a collective and possibly consumptive sigh of relief. No more price-cutting; at least, not by that name.

Thunder, lightning, rain and the biggest shutout victory ever achieved by the Dodgers made for a long, damp, dark and uncomfortable afternoon at Ebbets Field yesterday. The Dodgers, who jumped to an eight-length lead over the idle Giants, did not mind, but the Phillies had to absorb a most embarrassing 15-0 drubbing by Billy Loes, the young right- hander, who is making a career out of blanking the erstwhile Whiz Kids.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Faisal II, the 17-year-old King of Iraq, arrived at noon today on the second leg of a month's tour of the United States, the purpose of which is to provide fun and education for him.

YOUNGSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Peter Kingsmill of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, piloted Bill Gooderham's Buzzy to victory in both of today's races for the Alarm Trophy. He ended the day at the head of the standings with a perfect score of 28 points.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 -- Dale Mitchell smashed a home run in the eighth inning today to mar Billy Pierce's six-hit pitching and give the Indians a 4-3 victory over the White Sox. Pierce had retired thirteen straight batters before Mitchell walloped his fifth homer of the year over the right field fence.
EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Tommy Jacobs, 17-year-old golfer from Montebello, Calif., won the National Junior Chamber of Commerce tournament today with a 2-over-par 290.

Earle A. Newman, commenting on "Nye Bevan's One Rule -- 'Fight'." (July 13), warned us that there were two things which "should be well considered:" (1) Bevan is essentially anti-Christian; (2) Bevan is a Marxist. * * *

THE Royal Institute of International Affairs (Chatham House, as everybody calls it from the name of its London headquarters) is performing a notable service to students of Latin America. These two little books on Chile and Uruguay are the first in a projected series.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 16 -- The police reported here today the arrest of a drunken hit-and-run motorist after he had left the scene of an accident that had resulted in the death of a Massachusetts man and his sister-in-law.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Little Solly Hemus hammered two homers to supply the margin of victory as the Cardinals defeated the Reds, 3 to 1, tonight. Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell and Harry (The Cat) Brecheen combined their pitching efforts to scatter eight Reds' hits effectively.
Samuel Chapman, 56-year-old millionaire dress distributor, was arrested last night on charges of procuring women for men and for possession of indecent pictures.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- The new world record chalked up by international trade in 1951 -- a total of $76 billion worth, according to United Nations calculators -- looks almost as good as some of those brought back from Helsinki by our athletes. Unfortunately it calls for a good deal less congratulation than a new Olympic mark. Meters and seconds are unequivocal standards of measurement. Dollars are not.

ACCORDING to a Broadway columnist, those who are really hip refer to a thoroughgoing square as a "cubist." Despite the adoption of this word, however, it is doubtful that the hipsters will dig the new exhibition of "Cubist and Futurist Art" at the Museum of Modern Art.

More than one hundred young people from 17 to 23 years old attended the 1952 Encampment for Citizenship, sponsored by the American Ethical Union, and held at the Fieldston School in Riverdale, New York City. The participants, selected on the basis of leadership ability, came from thirty states, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Denmark and Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- United Nations cost-of-living statistics for the non-Communist world indicate that the United States has held the line against rising prices better than any other major power.
