MILWAUKEE, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An intercepted lateral pass and a 22-yard sprint by Eddie Price gave the New York Giants a 7-0 victory over Green Bay tonight in a National Football League exhibition game at Marquette Stadium.

ELEVEN years ago Igor Sikorsky, a world renowned designer and builder of military and commercial aircraft of conventional types, invited representatives of the newspapers, magazines and newsreels to his plant in Bedfora, Conn., to see and photograph his newest flying machine -- a helicopter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Americans made more money on a national average in 1951 than ever before. Earnings averaged $1,584 for every man, woman and child in the United States, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Judging from September's schedule of events, the unbenched show is gaining in popularity among exhibitors. Several all-breed events listed hereabouts next month call for this type of show and unbenched events may furnish at least part of the answer for the meeting of increased costs and increased competition from other sports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Representative Herbert C. Bonner, Democrat of North Carolina and chairman of a House of Representatives watchdog subcommittee, said today that the present system of buying billions of dollars worth of military supplies was inefficient and wasteful.
Lightning struck in at least four places in the city and suburban area yesterday in the course of intermittent showers that played hob with many carefully planned weekends.

The latest Soviet note on the question of an Austrian state treaty comes as a disappointing sequel to the continued efforts this last year by the United States, Great Britain and France to obtain final agreement on such a treaty and the end of foreign occupation of Austria.

FOR many years now Connecticut's summer colonies bordering Long Island Sound have provided havens for art's more innocuous and conservative manifestations. But, recently, something of the gilt-edged liveliness of Fifty-seventh Street and even of the disquiet of Greenwich Village has invaded these placid towns.

THE United States Coast and Geodetic Survey is John Floherty's subject. In simple language he tells how the men of this vital, but little known, agency operate on land, at sea and in the air, and explains how their findings affect the lives of us all. Here are exciting stories of undersea surveys off the Aleutians, of night expeditions along icy mountain peaks, of perilous surveying trips in Idaho canyons.
Two significant facts about Yalta were not mentioned either by Chester Wilmot or Henry S. Commager ("Was Yalta a Calamity?" -- Aug. 3).
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Windswept seas and a rip-snorting thundersquall enlivened the regatta of the Beach Point Yacht Club today on Long Island Sound.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 16 -- The Government issued orders tonight banning further exports of cereals, including corn, because of severe losses already caused by the drought that is continuing throughout the country.

IF speech-writing ghosts cared to speak in their own right, they would no doubt reflect a degree of bitterness over the cavalier way they have been treated in recent months. They must have winced when Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, ungrateful for the opportunity of reading scripts
Having trouble finding a secretary? So is everybody else. Here's the situation:
The purchase of $30,000,000 of new equipment was announced yesterday by officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- Philipp Auerbach, former head of the restitutions office in Bavaria, who was convicted Thursday of irregularities in office, died in Munich today. His wife attributed his death to an overdose of sleeping pills.

EXCITEMENT over the effects of the drought died down last week, but official views were still sharply divided. Ellis G. Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, stuck to his stand that the fall would see a sharp upswing in living costs.

ALBANY, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A process which gives this country a degree of self-sufficiency in producing high quality natural rubber was announced today by the United States Department of Agriculture.

In 1944 a study of the effect of sodium fluoride on drinking water was begun in Newburgh and Kingston, N. Y. Kingston was to drink fluoridated and Newburgh ordinary water for ten years. Though we shall have to wait until 1954 or 1955 for the final verdict, the Health Department of the state has reported on the interim results.
The Department of Parks Marionette Theatre will present sixteen performances of "Jack and the Beanstalk" at fourteen Manhattan park playgrounds beginning tomorrow.

WHEN Hans told his father he was not going back to Sweden, but staying on alone in America, he surprised even himself. He was giving voice to a dream that had grown during the three years that the two had worked together in the wheat fields. Later, by a lucky accident an empty freight car carries the 15-year-old boy straight to a job at Andreas Eleborg's grain elevator.

THE equivalent of hundreds of miles of highway experience will be provided this fall by simulated "behind the wheel" lessons in the driver-training courses for New York youngsters. To cope with the lack of suitable areas in this city for outdoor instruction, a series of twenty-two motion pictures has been made to teach students proper motoring skills.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 16 -- Christos Megaloginnis, a 26-year-old Greek seaman, sat in the brig of the Greek Steamship Company's ship Nea Hellas today, unhappily looking forward to a third enforced trip back to his native land.
The dark aspect of a rainy city of refuge seemed uncommonly bright yesterday to forty-four men, women and children who had fled from Czechoslovakia past the Iron Curtain to liberty.

Shoe production for the first seven months of 1952 was estimated at 289,709,000 pairs, an increase of 1.9 per cent over the 284,341,000 made in the same period last year, William Sheskey, economist for the National Shoe Manufacturers Association reported in a quarterly survey. Military production declined, thereby increasing the percentage of civilian output.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill of New York and Newport gave a ball tonight at Bois Dore, their summer home here, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Hope Hill.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 16 -- Ed (Porky) Oliver, the popular round man from Lemont, Ill., shot a five-under-par 67 for a fifty- four-hole total of 204 to take the lead at the three-quarter mark in the $15,000 Kansas City open golf tournament today.

PINKS are wonderful garden flowers, but in this brisk age they seem to have been pushed aside. Yet they and their country cousin (sweet william), and the more aristocratic carnation still rank, in my opinion, among the best flowers for the garden. All are members of the dianthus clan.

TEHERAN, Aug. 16 -- The Tudeh Communist party, which now stands openly as the possible successor to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh if he should tumble from his political tightrope, is the largest single political organization in the country and the least secret -- so-called secret -- organization that probably ever existed.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 16 -- The Timber Point Club here, which for fifteen years was the headquarters of the Suffolk County Republican Club, will soon change hands under a ten-year lease to be signed during the coming week.

INTERVIEWERS have an infinite capacity for surprise. No one ever seems to turn out as he is expected -- authors least of all. Thomas B. Costain, author of "The Black Rose," "The Moneyman" and most recently "The Silver Chalice," proves no exception. Just what we had expected of this untypical historical novelist who is a popular (his books sell by the million) as he is respected (librarians call him God-sent) is hard to say.

ANTHROPOLOGISTS, professional and amateur, need have no qualms when "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" is unveiled at the Rivoli Theatre on Sept. 18, according to Twentieth Century-Fox. The transcriber of Ernest Hemingway's famous short story labored, it seems, under the ethnological supervision of no less an authority than Capt. Hassoldt Davis, a man whose camera and pen already have proved his efficiency in the field.

THESE are thirty-four stories or sketches about Don Camillo the priest and his adversary, Peppone the Communist Mayor, laid in a small village near Milan in the valley of the Po. "The Little World of Don Camillo" is the title of an earlier book by Mr. Guareschi, and in the preface to the stories he bounds the "Little World" and explains that the happenings to follow grew in its atmosphere.

Despite the drought over a large part of the cotton belt, prospects are that this year's crop will exceed the demand. The recent forecast by the Department of Agriculture of a yield of 14,735,000 bales would exceed the expected consumption by domestic mills and exports in the present season.

"When Sirius parches head and knees, and the body is dried up by reason of the heat, then sit in the shade and drink." This advice given by Hesiod about 800 B. C. has been very generally, followed in Western lands -- evidence of the enduring influence of Greek thought.

SALEM, N. H., Aug. 16 (UP) -- Anthony DeSpirito, the 17-year-old apprentice who leads the nation's jockeys in 1952 triumphs, rode four more winners today at Rockingham Park to increase his victory total to 189 as Bobby Ussery, another apprentice, guided Hiram Jr. to victory in the White Mountain Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- On March 8, 1950, at Norfolk, Va., twenty-four Navy Hellcat fighters and twenty-four Helldiver Scout bombers were swung abroad the French carrier Dixmude, French insignia glistened on the rudders of the shiny blue aircraft.

Restrictive or nonexistent provisions for absentee voting will deprive most members of the armed forces from thirty states of the privilege of voting in the general election on Nov. 4 and will effectively disfranchise thousands of civilians whose circumstances will require them to be away from home on Election Day.
Higher taxes and industrial dislocation caused by the recent steel strike are becoming more pronounced in corporate earnings. As a result, financial markets last week moved in a more cautious manner.
Final steps in Free China's land reform program, due to take effect in the coming year, will put most Government-owned enterprises of Formosa into private hands.
HARTFORD, Aug. 16 -- The choice of a successor to the late Senator Brien McMahon has been narrowed down by the two major parties in Connecticut to six candidates, three in each party.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (UP) -- In a long, drawn-out game delayed an hour and 13 minutes by rain, the Senators crushed the Athletics, 10 -- 3, today.

THE little black calf had an itch in his mind and a joy in his legs and even a morning of mischief about the farm did not ease him. Breaking out of his hedge, he wiled Old Neddy, the shaggy gray donkey, away from his questing for thistles and off they went into the great free world.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 16 (UP) -- John Kurth of Columbus, Wis., and Jim Rasmussen of Waukesha, Wis., today made off with most of the honors in the second day of the preliminaries, prior to the opening of the fifty-fourth Grand American invitational trapshoot tournament.

THE likable young heroine of this novel will be attractive to older girls because she shows good sense in facing new situations. Moving from a loved Ohio farm to a busy household in New York City, where everyone is hurried and absorbed in his own job, she at first feels lost and resentful.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 16 -- The placid Saturday morning life of Englewood, Teaneck and Tenafly was disrupted at 10:20 A. M. today by a power failure in a cable leading from the Fort Lee substation of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

BRIGANTINE, N. J., Aug. 16 (AP) -- John Laporte Given Jr., who says he is an heir to the Heinz pickle fortune, left this shore resort island today rather than face a year in jail. Mr. Given was ordered by Magistrate Robert Peacock last night either to leave Brigantine or go to jail on a disorderly conduct charge brought by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Born, the defendant's neighbors.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 16 -- Greek Ship, the Brookmeade Stable's 5-year-old star who had been racing in poor luck this year, finally reached the winner's circle this afternoon. Competing in the $26,853 Ocean City Handicap, a mile and a sixteenth test on grass, the son of Heliopolis pounded home a half-length winner over the Carolyn K. Stable's Hi Billee.

In an effort to correct a situation which finds 4-year-olds deprived of the rich stakes available to 3-year-olds, two stakes were added this year for the former age group at Roosevelt Raceway. The first is to be held next Friday when the $10,000 Massapequa Pace is staged over the Nassau County strip.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Vito (Babe) Parilli, brilliant quarterback from the University of Kentucky, today was named in a ballot of more than 100 sports writers as the most valuable collegiate player in the All-Stars' 10-7 football defeat by the Los Angeles Rams last night.
The quadrennial hour of the Convinceable Middle has struck once more. Victory will come to that political party which is best able to attract the votes of those who care for neither.

Block by block, the street scene in this city gave up some of its most intimate secrets yesterday. Of the 2,433,465 dwelling units in the city, 111,589 have no private baths and 112,117 have no running water or are so dilapidated as to be unfit for human habitation.

JEROME, Ariz. -- Clinging tenaciously to the steep side of Cleopatria Mountain at the 5,435-foot level, this is a ghost town in the making. Once one of the richest copper veins in the world sustained Jerome, but the ore has run out and the days when 15,000 people filled the streets and 4,000 miners spent their pay checks in wild flings are only a memory.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 16 -- Engineering careers in American industry, offering youths an opportunity to rise to the top ranks of the profession and to major executive posts in leading corporations, have been opened up on an equal basis for Negro college graduates.

BACH: Fifteen Three-Part Inventions; Lukas Foss, pianist (Decca). Careful, neat and well-equalized performances of Bach's little clavier pieces that should provide a model for the legion of young (and old) pianists who are at this moment working on them.

The decision of the Atomic Energy Commission to build in Ohio at a cost of $1,200,000,000 a plant which is to produce uranium 235 indicates that our stock pile of atomic weapons is not what it should be. We thought that there must be hundreds of bombs. Perhaps there are.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- Motherwell upset the Hearts team by 1 -- 0 and Hibernian lost a surprise 1-0 decision to Celtic in Scottish soccer today.

SOUTH MARCH, Ont., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Maj. Desmond Burke of Toronto today won the Governor-General's gold medal at the eighty-fourth annual Dominion of Canada Rifle Association prize shoot at the Connaught ranges.

DENVER, Aug. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, as Republican Presidential nominee, has been finding out in recent weeks that political campaigns, like military expeditions, require an immense amount of time-consuming detailed planning and what military men call logistical support.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The Dorothea Carlile Chime in the tower of Smith College Hall will ring out more harmoniously when the college opens its seventy-eighth session Sept. 22.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- President Truman acceded today to a request by the United States Tariff Commission and raised the duty on imported dried figs to 4 1/2 cents a pound from the present rate of 2 1/2 cents. The new rate will become effective on Aug. 29.
LYNTON, England, Aug. 16 -- Eleven persons were killed and thirty-five missing today in violent flash floods that spread terror and destruction through Southwest England.

Professor Commager, in "Was Yalta a Calamity?" (Aug. 3), omits important facts that throw an entirely different light on his interpretation. First, he does not tell us that several high level military leaders, including General Groves and Admiral Leahy, advised our conferees to avoid deals to bring Russia into the Far Eastern war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The difficulties faced by the United States Government when it attempts to rescue Americans trapped behind the Iron Curtain are dramatically illustrated by the case of John Hvasta, the young naturalized U. S. citizen who -- according to a Czech Government announcement last week -- "escaped" from a Czech prison in January.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 16 -- The third World Conference on Faith and Order got under way here today with two plenary sessions, in the course of which officers to guide the two weeks of deliberations were elected and committees formed. The 1954 assembly was scheduled for Evanston, Ill.
The marine sessions of the National Safety Congress and Exposition will begin in Chicago on Oct. 21.

With Good Time's expected appearance in the $25,000 Yonkers Derby Thursday night listed as the top attraction at the summer meeting, harness racing returns to Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. The meeting lasts through Aug. 30, competing with Roosevelt Raceway for twelve nights.
EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 16 -- Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., won the women's Canadian open golf championship today by defeating Mary Gay of Kitchener, Ont., 9 and 8, in the final.

ONE very important thing seems to have been definitely established by the results of the Berkshire Festival and the coordinated activities of the Berkshire School of Music which ended their 1952 season last week.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UP) -- A pair of doubles by Ralph Kiner, each driving home a run, gave the Pirates and Howie Pollet a 2-1 victory over the Cubs today before 12,356 at Wrigley Field.
VANCOUVER, Aug. 16 -- A member of the royal family "will in all likelihood open British Empire and Commonwealth games here in 1954," The Vancouver Province said in a sports page article today.

MICHAEL DONOVAN, better known by his pen name Frank O'Connor, is Ireland's foremost living story-teller. During the last twenty years two novels and five collections of his short stories have appeared in this country, but despite these books and the occasional appearance of his stories in The New Yorker, his work is still not so well known here as it deserves to be, and will be.

RARELY in a generation does one man leave his mark on the lives of an entire profession. Yet, at least in New York City, such has been the almost unprecedented story of Judge Harold Medina. The New York bar is large. But over a period of more than thirty years Harold Medina taught thousands of students at Columbia Law School in New York City. Many thousands more attended his bar exam cram courses.

The national headquarters staff of the American Legion will arrive here today from Indianapolis to prepare for the Legion's annual convention, which will open on Sunday and continue through Thursday, Aug. 28. The staff's headquarters here will be at the Statler Hotel.

IN his first new novel in three years, Arthur Meeker has returned to seventeenth-century France, the scene of his earlier success, "The Ivory Mischief." It is a warm, lovingly wrought tale of a young French duke and his incredible adventure, taken, as Mr. Meeker affirms, from French history -- which so often is likely to be stranger than mere fiction.

How does it feel to be president of the world's largest store? Wheelock H. Bingham, who just took over the job, says it feels great, but he wants the opportunity to feel his way around, get a solid footing and then apply the talents which a retailing enterprise like Macy's New York needs to maintain its pre-eminent position.
GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- The prospects for European refugees in Communist-held Shanghai have taken a turn for the worse.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Plans were made today, in the midst of the $15,000 Kansas City open golf tournament, to scatter the ashes of Milburn Country Club's founder and professional over the course.

Although cases of illness among children and personnel of the Hi-Li Day Camp at Far Rockaway, Queens, increased yesterday to thirty-eight, the number of verified typhoid fever patients remained at fifteen, the city health department reported yesterday.

This is the issue in the 1952 Presidential election as the Republicans are trying to develop it: (1) The Truman policies and practices are wrong; (2) Stevenson is the "captive" of Truman and thus will continue the Truman policies; (3) therefore it's time for a change to the Republicans.

RAWDON, Que. -- The Laurentian Mountain area, whose summertime appeal need take no back seat for its famous winter sports attractions, has much to offer the moderate-income tourist who has time and inclination to do a little exploring.

The weather, which has dealt the Giants many a foul blow this season, crossed them up again yesterday. A series of heavy showers led Horace Stoneham to call off his team's scheduled game with the Braves just before noon, so there was no action at the Polo Grounds.

The enrollment in colleges in the fall of 1952 will be slightly lower than last September, the American Council on Education predicts. However, engineering and the physical science schools are expected to show increases of 20 per cent.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 -- The Economic Planning Committee in Manchuria, Red China's leading industrial area, said today that the production plan set there for the first half in 1952 had been exceeded by 4.8 per cent.

A new volume on Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be added to the bookshelf when Macmillan issues "Champion Campaigner -Franklin D. Roosevelt," by Harold F. Gosnell. The author presents a study of how Mr. Roosevelt won elections, influenced future politicians, defeated the opposition and became the idol of millions of Americans. The book will be published on Oct. 29.

In your letters column of Aug. 6 Jack Farnsworth criticizes careless farming methods as being largely responsible for agricultural problems ranging from drought disaster to land abandonment. There seems to be a regrettable tendency among many to overemphasize the importance of soil conservation and farm management faults as a disruptive factor in the historical development of our national food and fiber producing industry.

For the first three of the six months he has been in this country, Kumer Simgh said the other day, everything tasted flat. Then the registrar in the Indian Consulate General's office became more used to the food and now does not mind it much.
About 17,000 miles of private microwave radio relay systems are in use or have been ordered by industrial companies, Federal Telephone and Radio Corporation reported over the week-end.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's state of fatigue has alarmed Teheran. The Premier has issued a broadcast statement requesting that the people not seek interviews with him but take problems to the Ministries concerned or if necessary to his assistants.
All the leaders gained yesterday in the semi-final round of the International Chess Federation championship tournament according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.

BUFFALO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Joe Taggart of Kent, Ohio, steered his sleek Wildcatter to victory today in the national championship for seven-liter hydroplanes in the Buffalo Launch Club regatta on the Niagara River.

Annual deficits which have marked operations of the Federal Government for most of the last twenty years have now spread to state governments, where they represent "an augury of dangerous fiscal instability," according to a study to be issued today by the Tax Foundation, a private nonprofit research organization.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- More than 150,000 Roman Catholics from both East and West Germany are due to converge on Berlin this week for the seventy-fifth congress of the Roman Catholic Church in Germany.

SONORA, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Brent Bradberry, 13 years old, confidently came out of the wilderness today, proud of the Boy Scout training that enabled him to survive seven days lost and alone in California's rugged High Sierra.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador., Aug. 17 -- Exportation of sulphur has started from the Tixan mines of the Ecuadorian Mining Company, it has been reported from official sources in Quito, according to the newspaper Telegrafo here. Sulphur from these mines is already supplying local needs.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 17 -- Eighty-three racing craft had about the best sailing sessions of the summer on Long Island Sound today.

Your editorial on "Crime in New York" in THE TIMES of Aug. 13 is most informative in pointing out that in the strange interlude between the La Guardia and the Impellitteri administrations the New York City statistics with respect to crime were so misleading that the other cities of this country would not accept them.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) -The United Rubber Workers Union, C. I. O., struck at the B. F. Goodrich Company tonight after failing to reach agreement on a new contract.

W. R. Grace Co., international trading concern with offices in San Francisco, has offered to buy the common stock of the Foster Kleiser Company, largest outdoor advertising organization on the Pacific Coast, according to a joint announcement by L. H. O'Dell, vice president of the Grace concern, and George W. Kleiser, chairman of the board Of the advertising company.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -- Unreasoning "nationalism," which is earnestly encouraged by the Communists for their own ends, is holding up Brazil's economic development, blocking her way out of her increasingly serious dollar crises and impeding all forms of cooperation with the United States.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -The seventh anniversary of Indonesia's proclamation of independence was marked by restraint today. Jakarta's streets were festively decorated, but the city generally was quiet and undemonstrative.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (UP) Bob Feller and Mike Garcia helped the pennant hopes of the Indians today by recovering from slumps to whip the White Sox in a doubleheader, 6 -- 2 and 2 -- 1, before 45,560.
The American Smelting and Refining Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $16,731,237 in the first six months this year, according to the midyear report issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The country's national banks ended 1951 healthy and growing, the United States Controller's office reported today.

Avery Brundage, newly-elected president of the International Olympic Committee returned from the 1952 games yesterday with continued criticism of the point system of scoring the Olympic results by nations.

Railroad union officials turned down yesterday a "package" proposal made by Federal mediators who are seeking to avert a strike on the New York Central Railroad lines east of Buffalo. Company officials had accepted the compromise offer.

We wonder if the traffic experts who recently told a seminar at Northwestern University that "a high-grade moron" is likely to be a better automobile driver than "smarter people" actually thought through what they were saying. The theory as expressed was that a person of 10 or 12 years mental age was not likely to be distracted while driving and therefore paid close attention to operating his car.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- Margo Jones, director of the Dallas Repertory Theatre, has been in San Francisco looking over sites for a similar project here.
ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Mississippi and Louisana Democrats will meet this week to decide whether to back Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for the Presidenty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer said today that American industrial production "is now limited only by our ability to use."

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -A teen-ager and a small boy suffered fatal injuries when their automobile skidded on a rainswept road and collided with another car yesterday at Meadowbrook, ten miles south of here. Two other young persons were injured severely.

ZURICH, Aug. 17 -- Two events of momentous importance for Switzerland occurring the same day last week evoked expressions of unstinted tribute to the sagacity and generosity of the United States Government from all competent Swiss authorities and those engaged in international trade and finance.

The Norwegian cargo ship Black Gull, which burned off Long Island last month with the loss of four lives, took to sea in tow early yesterday for the final trip of her brief and ignominious career. Reduced to a hulk and sold by insurance underwriters who did not consider her worth repairing, she is bound for Baltimore to be broken up for scrap.

The impasse between the League of New York Theatres and Actors Equity over one aspect of a new basic agreement will be discussed by the former's negotiating committee at a special meeting this morning of the league's board. Pending ratification by both groups, details are said to have been agreed upon with the exception of a provision affecting payment to union members in recording the albums of shows.

Last Thursday President Truman released his decision, and the reasons therefor, in the case of the recommendations of the Tariff Commission that increased protection be accorded the American watchmaking industry. The answer was a decisive "No." And unless there were important aspects of the case that were left uncovered the argument in support of the White House finding would seem to have been incontestably sound.

" The 'New York hustle' is not necessarily a sign of a master race," the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of King's University, Halifax, N. S., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church. West Sixty-ninth Street, near Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The personal papers of General of the Army H. H. (Hap) Arnold, aviation pioneer and Air Force chief in World War II, have been donated to the Library of Congress by his widow, Mrs. Eleanor P. Arnold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Premier Chou En-lai's visit to Moscow appears to have caught the State Department by surprise. No responsible official would speculate as to its meaning pending receipt of advices from the United States Embassy in Moscow.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Stu Miller, the Cardinals' newest pitching find, won his second straight game today by downing the Reds, 2 -- 1. He was deprived of his second shut-out when Solly Hemus made a double error in the ninth inning to let in the Reds' run.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Prices for lard futures on the Chicago Board of Trade held in a moderate range, and for the week showed only moderate price changes. Although receipts of hogs at Western points were small compared with last year, prices had a sharp decline at the stock yards, with a partial recovery.

TWO burglary suspects, ordered to drive in their automobile to a police station, fled from a police radio car for two miles through the Bronx early yesterday morning. Then they abandoned their automobile and ran up and down embankments and across railroad tracks. One suspect was wounded and captured, and the other escaped.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott, world heavyweight champion, will defend his title in a fifteen-round bout against Rocky Marciano Tuesday, Sept. 23, in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium, co-promoter Herman Taylor said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration expects the nation's airlines to be carrying 40,000,000 passengers a year by 1960, almost twice as many as in the boom year of 1951.
Harness racing returns to Yonkers Raceway tnight. The leading attraction of the twelve-night meeting will be the $25,000 Yonkers Pacing Derby on Thursday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 17 -- The last obstacle to getting a full line of books, magazines and newspapers from the United States into Israeli bookshops and newsstands was overcome today by an agreement setting an exchange rate for the import of books at $1.40 for 1.

John L. Lewis has called a memorial work stoppage of the United Mine Workers to begin next Saturday. Five working days will be affected. He is thus within the legal limits of his contract and there is no reason to suppose that the suspension of production will not take place. The estimated loss in volume will be about 9,000,000 tons.

The letter by Wilbur A. Steger, relative to Britain's imports, exports and devaluation of the pound, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 7, stated: "Only devaluation will do this [cut British imports] and give a direct spur to British exports. Devaluation by raising the price of imports and lowering the price of exports is the economist's first answer to the problem of cutting imports and raising exports."

SINGAPORE, Aug. 17 -- Authorities of the British Colony of Sarawak in North Borneo carried out today their first deportations of Chinese Communists resulting from the flare-up of Communist terrorism there recently. Five Chinese were flown to Singapore for transfer to a ship that will take them back to Communist China.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., the 17-year-old United States and Wimbledon tennis champion, today reaffirmed her role as queen by defeating Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, to win the twenty-fifth annual Essex tournament championship.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- Seventy-nine more African passive-resisters were arrested today in Johannesburg and Capetown for having deliberately broken Jim Crow laws.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 17 -- "The scientific world must now focus its research efforts on constitutional diseases which are non-infectious. They are today's greatest medical challenge," Dr. Clarence C. Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, said here during the two-day meeting of the twenty-third annual meeting of that institution.

A plan to reorganize the Long Island Rail Road under public ownership and take it out of bankruptcy will be filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Brooklyn Federal Court by the Long Island Transit Authority.

The Rev. Dr. J. J. Mends-Cole, Moderator of the Presbytery of Western Africa, Liberia, and a member of the Liberian National Legislature, spoke yesterday on "The Desires of a Christian" at the Rendall Memorial Church (Presbyterian), 61 West 137th Street.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- British Actors Equity Association has received a letter from United States Equity confirming its readiness to resume negotiations on a new agreement covering rights of British and United States actors to appear in each other's country.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Aug. 17 -- Unable to agree after seven hours and twenty minutes of deliberation last night in the Federal Court action brought here against two Cody business men charged with conspiracy to defraud the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the jury of ten men and two women was discharged.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 17 -- A fast-moving Presidential campaign tied in with Congressional contests for the benefit of all Democratic candidates was outlined today by Democratic strategists who concluded a two-day meeting with Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the party's Presidential nominee.

The plan for reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road to be filed in Federal Court today seems to be an unavoidable and perhaps logical sequel in the procession of events since the tragic wrecks of 1950. The plan is advanced after long study by George E. Roosevelt, chairman, and Tracy S. Voorhees, member, of the Long Island Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- When the huge new YB-52 goes on its test flights a jet "chase plane" tags along to keep track of things the bomber's crewmen cannot see for themselves.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Robin, Too, sailed by Bob Mann of San Diego, Calif., and his daughter, Mary, today won the 1952 championship of the international 110 class sailing boats on Gull Lake.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Chinese Government and military leaders headed by Premier and Foreign Minister Chou En-lai arrived in Moscow by plane today for high-level conversations designed to implement and broaden Soviet-Chinese relations, now governed by the Treaty of Alliance and Friendship of 1950.

Christ was incarnated not to judge or condemn the human race but to save it by "paying our debt to His Father" and to spread the gospel or "good news" of God's forgiveness by speaking "with a human voice" to ears so deafened by sin they could no longer "hear the voice of God," the Rev. John M. Crotty of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass there yesterday.

With an increasing number of five-minute weather programs on television, today's viewer is not likely to reap that rich, full-flavored satisfaction from his handsome, mahogany console unless he knows something about meteorology.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Air Force promised today to increase its fighting strength by nearly 50 per cent -- from eighty operating wings to 143 -- with an increase in personnel of only 14 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The stock markets in the past week have continued to advance in the face of the restraining influence of business holidays. Turnover is holding up surprisingly well and showing further expansion in several directions. Mild favorable influence was exerted by July overseas trade figures which show the second half of the year has started with a trend justifying official forecasts for the balance of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Americans for Democratic Action endorsed the 1952 Democratic ticket today in a statement calling on independent voters to support the nominees, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Four members of Congress took by air today on a two-week tour to see for themselves how the military services buy and store supplies.

After easiness in the early dealings, cotton prices last week turned firmer and ended with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 18 to 57 points from a week earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (UP) -- A seven-run uprising in the eighth inning enabled the Athletics to gain a 12-5 victory in the second game of a double-header today after Bob Porterfield had pitched the Senators to a 7-2 triumph in the opener.

Practical as well as decorative are some of the objects in a large collection of items made in the Victorian Era and now on view at Bamberger's, in Newark. Imported from Europe, they are comparatively inexpensive.

The contrast of a strong Canadian dollar which for the last several weeks has been edging forward to new high premiums in terms of its American counterpart, while British sterling shows a tendency to softness after attempts to rally and hold its gain, was again evolved out of the business in the foreign exchange market last week.

Alger B. Chapman, former president of the State Tax Commission, and Mrs. Walter Scott McNab, vice president of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs, have been designated as co-managers of the Republican state campaign, William L. Pfeiffer, chairman of the Republican state committee, announced yesterday.

The grocery store handling nothing but food is beginning to go the way of the dodo, or the drug store that once handled only drugs. Rack after rack in the modern supermarket offers such items as clothing, appliances, hardware and other goods. This trend is now spreading to the jobbers.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 17 -Two men were killed and three persons were injured, one critically, in three automobile accidents in northern Westchester and southern Putnam counties in a heavy rainstorm last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner's twenty-sixth home run, the first he has hit in Wrigley Field this season, gave the Pirates a 5-2 victory over the Cubs today and an even break in a double-header before 26,635.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17 (UP) -- Jack Burke Jr of Houston and the defending champion, Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, finished in a tie in the $15,000 Kansas City Open golf tourney today, with 72-hole totals of 276, twelve under par.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Another milestone in the protracted and acrimonious controversy over public education in this otherwise sedate residential city was reached last week with the publication of the findings in an exhaustive eighteen-month study of its school system.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet sector has mobilized a huge band of informers to catch anyone selling fruit, vegetables and other foods to West Berliners.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The average city family outspent its 1950 income by more than $400, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners opened their National Football League exhibition schedule with a 35-0 victory over the Washington Redskins today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Twentieth, or "lame duck," Amendment to the Constitution, which changed the starting and ending times of the terms of office of the President, Vice President and members of Congress, has been operative for eighteen and a half years, but has not yet been put to perhaps its most vital test of full effectiveness for national benefit.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- British research experts working to develop better and cheaper industrial and consumer goods have received 350,000 ($1,000,000) worth of scientific equipment from the United States, the Mutual Security Agency mission here disclosed today.

SEATTLE, Aug. 17 -- In the cool Northwest the 200 contestants schedule to take part in the fifty-second United States Golf Association amateur championship this week ended their practice sessions today.

Trustworthy sources insist that the Play Series, sponsored by the American National Theatre and Academy, a non-profit group holding a charter from Congress, will be discontinued. In lieu of a series, a substitute plan will be considered at a meeting early next month of ANTA's Greater New York Chapter to finance one outstanding presentation a season and let it go at that.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- An official statement from the office of Premier Antoine Pinay, which said that France would meet all her defense commitments for 1952, ended with the declaration that the French Government was concerned lest the forces of the "Atlantic Nations" be insufficient "to assure the security of Europe" in 1953.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- The long-awaited comeback test of Eddie Lopat today turned out to be a highly gratifying performance for the Yankees.

Under sponsorship of the productivity and technical assistance program of the Mutual Security Agency, two teams of French industrialists will arrive in New York today to study the American fats and oils industry.

In their admiration of the cultural institutions of foreign countries many Americans are apt to overlook the treasure houses to be found at home. While most American tourists vacationing abroad this summer undoubtedly visited the famous museums and cathedrals overseas, how many appreciate the worth of similar places in their own country?

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug 17 -- Trumpets of peace sounded over Scotland's capital today when, in a ceremony marked by medieval pageantry, the Duke of Edinburgh officially opened the sixth International Festival of Music and Drama in the presence of diplomats from thirty-eight nations and a cosmopolitan gathering of festival pilgrims.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17 (UP) -- Frank Sedgman today retained the Newport Casino singles crown by conquering his Australian countryman, Ken McGregor, in a four-set struggle lasting 2 hours 20 minutes. The score was 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 12 -- 14, 6 -- 3.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 17 (AP) -Theologians, representing the world's Christian churches, were warned tonight that the movement for a united Christendom was in danger unless they took more effective steps toward their common goal.

An explosive incident between Manager Leo Durocher and Umpire Augie Donatelli enlivened yesterday's proceedings at the Polo Grounds, where, before 22,918 onlookers, the Giants split a double-header with the Braves.

The vice investigation being conducted by the staff of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan resulted yesterday in the arraignment in Week-End Court of Samuel Chapman, 56-year-old president-treasurer of the dress distributing company incorporated under his name, of 530 Seventh Avenue, on charges of procuring women for prostitution and of possession of obscene art.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The State Department released today a study of the tactics by which Communist Governments are capturing youth and chaining churches to the state in their drive to kill all religion.
DENVILLE, N. J., Aug. 17 -- A multiple crash near here on Route 6 early this morning involving six cars, caused injuries to three persons and the arrest of two others on charges of drunken driving.
DENVER, Aug. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is planning a quick airplane tour of ten to twelve cities in seven Southern states starting Sept. 2.

A prediction that next week's annual convention of the American Legion might break all attendance records was made yesterday as fifty members of the organization's national headquarters staff arrived from Indianapolis.

A patrolman off duty and out of uniform was wounded superficially by a police sergeant last night in a Greenwich Village case of mistaken identity. The wounded man, William Hayes, 31 years old, of 33-40 Ninety-seventh Street, Corona, Queens, attached to the West 135th Street station, was taken to it. Vincent's Hospital in a patrol car by the sergeant who had shot him, Harold Riker of the Fourth Precinct.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Something new in trombones reached the concert stage here today when Davis Shuman performed as soloist at the world premiere presentation of Tibor Serly's Concerto for Trombone and Chamber Orchestra.

CAIRO, Aug. 17 -- The Egyptian Cabinet approved tonight the budgetary estimate for 1952-53 Revenues and expenditures were described as balanced at 206,000,000 Egyptian ($588,571,480) without an increase in the national debt or a decrease in the general reserves of state.

Steps toward stimulating dollar exports from countries aided by the United States were urged over the week-end by F. J. Emmerich, chairman of the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade. He urged basic action to bring many foreign governments to allow their exporters to retain some part of the dollars earned by their sales in this country.

When a man entered her bedroom at 1:30 A. M. yesterday, Mrs. Cecelia Donovan of 1071 Eightieth Street, Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, thought it was her husband. But when his voice betrayed him she picked up a shoe and chased him down to the street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -Anthony Valente, president of the United Textile Workers, A. F. L., said today that more 50,000 "voluntarily have voted" to leave the C. I. O. and join his union since May. He lashed back at the C. I. O. and its Textile Workers Union for accusing the A. F. L. union of raids.

The Times Square area will be the chief target of a city-wide mock atom bomb attack to be held Sept. 30 at 7:45 P. M. The theoretical attack on the five boroughs, which will last fifteen minutes, will bring into action the full resources of civil defense organization. Although the "main incidents" will be staged in the heart of Manhattan, "less serious incidents" will be simulated in the other boroughs.

American ships engaged in foreign commerce, both privately-owned and Government - owned, continued last month to reflect the current downward trend in overseas trade. As of Aug. 1, the United States fleet had shrunk to 1,491 vessels, a new low for the year, and had expanded the nation's reserve or "moth ball" fleet to 1,854 ships.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Vic Wertz hit a two-run homer to beat Detroit, 4 to 2, in the first game of a double-header today and Ned Garver scattered nine hits to defeat St. Louis, 4 to 2, in the second game before 27,479 fans. Both were involved in the recent eight-player waiver deal between the two clubs.

HONOLULU, Aug. 17 -- Problems ranging from those caused by the destruction of cocoanut trees by the rhinoceros beetle to those posed by what High Commissioner Elbert D. Thomas calls a "baling wire economy" are confronting the Interior Department in administering the Trust Territory of Pacific Islands under an agreement between the United States and the United Nations.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 17 (UP) -Three trapshooters posted perfect scores today in final preliminaries of the fifty-third Grand American invitational handicap tournament.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Edna Goldfarb, 45 years old, of 1860 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was killed and seven other persons were injured today in the head-on collision of two automobiles on Route 20, about two miles west of this Madison County resort village.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, Aug. 17 -- The negotiations on compensation for Nazi anti-Semitic acts have moved a step nearer completion with the formulation of recommendations for an agreement with world Jewish organizations, which the West German delegation has submitted to Bonn for approval.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 17 -- The western region of the Radio Writers Guild today called illegal the strike begun last Monday by the Screen Writers Guild and the Authors League of America against the Alliance of Television Film Producers. The Radio Writers Guild announced that its membership would not support the action.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 17 (UP) -- A lacy shawl around her shoulders, Mme. Chiang Kaishek, wife of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, rested in a darkened room in Franklin Hospital here today, awaiting the decision of three specialists.

Sometimes it is hard to vizualize what the development of the United States might have been without foreign investment. Until the closing decade of the last century we had mighty little money for the things we wanted to do. But Britain and Holland, aided by the mechanization of industry, were stripping the treasure from the East and spending it in this country, largely for railroad securities.

It is not what the world does to us but what goes on in our inner selves that makes us what we are, the Rev. D. Julius Mark, senior Rabbi at Temple Emanu-El, told the congregation at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday morning.

LAKE TAHOE, Nev., Aug. 17 -- Two of Henry J. Kaiser's racing speedboats were discovered today to be sabotaged in what the industrialist called "a murderous attempt" on his life. The sabotage was found 30 minutes before Mr. Kaiser was to have piloted one of the boats in the Lake Tahoe Gold Cup Race.
Formation of a committee of seventeen to study a city manager plan for New York was announced yesterday by Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union.

Congregation Shaaray Tefila, the largest synagogue in Far Rockaway, Queens, was robbed early yesterday by two or more burglars who "borrowed" the caretaker's tools to "break open a safe containing at least 92,000 in charity contributions and silver medalions.

Residents of Western Germany will have an opportunity to examine esthetic qualities of walls in American homes when a just-completed exhibit arrives in that country next month. The exhibit, which is a cross-section of contemporary wallpapers designed and made in the United States, is under the auspices of the Traveling Exhibit Service of the Smithsonian Institution and was selected and arranged by Tom Lee of Tom Lee. Ltd., of New York.

MADRID, Aug. 17 -- Resentment over what Spanish officials regard as Washington's inimical attitude toward the Franco regime was said today to have delayed action on a request by United States woolgrowers for the services of 405 Basques needed to relieve a serious shortage of sheepherders.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (UP) -Superior Judge John Swift of Boston, Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, said today that the Communist party should be outlawed in the United States.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- Figures for July, just published by the European Payments Union give the positions of the different member countries and give a view of the principal factors in the present situation of the European nations in respect to balance of payments. Three main facts become apparent through these figures.

German-flag passenger ships will return to the North Atlantic in two years or less, but not on a scale approaching pre-World War II days, Willy Max Rademacher, a member of the West German Parliament, said yesterday.

Donald A. Kepler has been appointed general purchasing agent for the General Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio. Chester J. Zabik has been named purchasing agent for rubber and tire fabrics and Emil F. Schnedarek has been appointed purchasing agent for engineering projects and services.

Instead of one winner as in most former years, yesterday's Hudson River outboard motor boat marathon from Albany to New York brought to fame and some little fortune six winners. In speed boating circles the solons have a habit of changing rules every so often and yesterday's thrilling and dangerous 130-mile downstream dash was typical.

Two dispatches to this newspaper from Hong Kong, recently published, have a vital meaning in relation to the future of China. The first told of the creation of somewhat "autonomous" areas for the sake of non-Han populations. On the face of it this is a gesture toward the protection of minorities.

In a dispatch dated July 6 from Lisbon, Camille Cianfarra reported that the Portuguese are undertaking colonization schemes in Angola and Mozambique; that the United States was giving financial aid for this purpose; that thousands of European families were to be established in areas suitable for white colonization; that this was to relieve overpopulation in Portugal.
TAYLOR, Wis., Aug. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. Helge Hjornevik, who saw five of her eight children stricken with poliomyelitis last week, one fatally, feared today that another of the children had the disease.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Grain futures business on the Board of Trade was lighter in volume than the previous week, but larger than a year ago. Average daily purchases of grain and soybean futures were 51,000,000 bushels, compared with 62,000,000 bushels the previous week and 34,000,000 bushels a year ago.

The public probably does not care whether a shirt is classified as a sport or dress garment, but producers and retailers find it important in their planning. Considerable confusion is evident in the matter, at least at the retail level.

DURING the war years, when the Dodgers were training at Bear Mountain, the skipper of the Brooks was Leo Durocher and the boss man was Branch Rickey. The Mahatma whisked up to the Inn one evening for an important conference with his manager. He waited and waited and waited. No Durocher. Leo the Lip had a room at Jack Martin's hostelry that he rarely used.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 17 -- According to De Telegraaf, Holland's credit quota in the European Payments Union will be exhausted by November. The limit is $355,000,000. By the end of July the quota used had reached $275,000,000 and a further monthly increase by some $30,000,000 is expected.

Work on the proposed Second Avenue subway, tentatively scheduled to begin in the fall, may be indefinitely postponed because of a warning from Controller Lazarus Joseph against substantial additions to the city's "staggering" gross funded debt of $3,352,877,062, the largest in its history.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- More than 2,000 pharmacists, educators and students from the United States and eighteen foreign countries met here today for the opening of the 100th anniversary convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian and American hockey authorities tonight banned exhibition tours of Europe by their teams. They are willing to send representatives to world championships overseas but want expense guarantees.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 17 (UP) -- Texans continued to sizzle and bake today as the worst heat wave in many years entered its third week.

The use of Bible quotations by political candidates has been "prompted more by a desire to catch votes than to voice convictions," the Rev. Arthur E. Oudemool, minister of the First Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Kingston, N. Y., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Acts of discourtesy are responsible for at least 25,000 deaths annually in the United States, according to a report made yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council, listing the more common of the fatal breaches of etiquette.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Three story purchases were reported by different studios this week-end.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 18 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,345 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Fourth-Seeded Stephen Gottlieb of New York and First-Seeded Carl Norgauer of Yonkers, the defending champion, yesterday won the singles titles of the Metropolitan junior and boys' tennis championships at the Hispano Club, Queens.
Nine new films, including importations from England and France, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
SEOUL, Monday, Aug. 18 (AP) -Chinese infantrymen recaptured yesterday an outpost on the east-central front that has changed hands three times in four days of hot fighting.
Knits are back in the news. Be it knit trim, knit accessories, or whole knit garments, knits are a very important part of the fall fashion picture.

Two newly reported cases of typhoid fever yesterday brought to seventeen the total among children and employes who had been at the Hi-Li Day Camp in Far Rockaway, Queens, where a cook was found last week to be a carrier of that disease.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 18 -- Communist liaison officers handed a new protest to the United Nations Command's delegates yesterday, charging that Allied planes Saturday "repeatedly" flew over the neutral area at Panmunjom, where the negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war are scheduled to resume tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The United States produced at a rate of $343,000,000,000 a year in April, May and June, a 1 per cent increase over the previous three months, the Department of Commerce reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 17 -- The week-end's discussions of the State Economic Council in Bled, Slovenia, indicated that the current drought had struck at staggering blow to the Yugoslav national economy.

OKINAWA, Aug. 16 -- Because of preparations taken at the vital United States military installation on this island south of Japan to meet the storm, Army authorities were able tonight to summarize the results of a thirty-six-hour typhoon with this score: No lives lost and property damage held to thousands of dollars instead of millions.

Production of newsprint in Canada, including Newfoundland, in July amounted to 485,539 tons and shipments to 483,250 tons, it was reported over the week-end by the Newsprint Service Bureau. Output in the United States was 94,192 tons and shipments were 94,933 tons, making a total North American production of 579,731 tons and shipments of 578,183 tons.

In the light of the fact that the Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment Insurance is currently considering amending New York State's Unemployment Insurance Law in order to liberalize the twenty-week eligibility requirement it would appear that another modification of this law would be in order at this time.

Twenty-four hours brought quite a difference at Ebbets Field yesterday and it was not only in the weather. The previous afternoon the Dodgers rammed fifteen hits and amassed as many, runs against the Phillies in the rain. This time the sun shone brightly but not the Brooks, who bowed, 2 -- 1, to Karl Drews and his four-hit pitching.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Veterans Administration figures there were 19,288,000 living veterans of all wars and peacetime military service of the United States June 30.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 18 -- Hundreds of laborers, soldiers, firemen and policemen went to work yesterday to clear away the muck and debris left behind Saturday by a deadly flash flood.
The cotton futures market on the New York Stock Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 4 points lower to 10 points higher than Friday's close.

An eighteen-story and penthouse office building is planned for the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth, Street where a plot about 122 by 130 feet has been leased by Milton A. Kimmelman, real estate investors, from the Oceanic Investing Corporation for ninety-nine years.

" STRANGE how the thought of stopping novel-writing seems to me like dying!" wrote Hugh Walpole in 1919. He was only 34 years old but already the author of many successful books. When he died in l941, killed by diabetes and the nervous strain of the London blitz, he had written more than fifty. No novelist of his generation had a greater facility for storytelling

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -Mrs. Julius Petty of Stuttgart, Ark., wrapped up the majority of the honors today as the fifty-third Grand American trapshoot opened, taking two major championships, each in a shoot-off.
An issue of $5,640,000 of new common stock of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., was placed on the market yesterday by an underwriting syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman has been considering for some time what to do when he leaves the White House in January.

BELGRADE, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia has introduced a new system of foreign trade by remote control, ditching the system borrowed from the Soviet Union, of directing foreign trade through centralized government departments.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The Westport Woman's Club, accused of fraud and the illegal operation of a lottery last month, won a partial victory in Town Court today.

THE problem of those shooters who have been shopping around for a light-weight, big bore, rifle that would prove generally adequate for both Eastern and Western big game seems to have been solved by the new Winchester .308.

Careful shopping and small but steady purchasing featured the opening yesterday of the summer New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels. Some buyers were surprised to see a considerable quantity of Czechoslovak glass giftware offered by a few exhibitors although giftware imports from that Iron Curtain country have been almost nil for many months.
DYERVILLE, Calif., Aug. 18 (UP) -- Bernard Baruch, here to receive birthday honors, said today he had tried to devote his eighty-two years to helping the common man.

ANOKA, Minn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A young doctor treating tubercular mental patients with a new drug said today that the drug had unexpectedly improved long-standing mental disorders of a reasonably good percentage of the patients.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- Although Great Lakes vessel operators are giving top priority to ore, coal is moving in greater volume than it was at this time a year ago, the Ore and Coal Exchange reported here.

LICQ-ATHEREY, France, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Four rescued cave explorers promised the wife of their dead companion tonight that no one would explore the cavern near here, in which he lost his life, until his body had been brought to the surface.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 -- The managerial axe dropped on the neck of Duke Snider today when Charley Dressen decided to bench the Dodgers' center fielder, beginning with tomorrow's twilight-night double-header with the Reds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The State Department accused the Soviet Union today of seeking to punish Austria as "a vanquished nation" and of missing the whole point of a Western proposal to give Austria an "abbreviated" treaty.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Prospects for a record spring wheat crop in Canada with an official estimate of 632,000,000 bushels, announced over the week-end by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, was too much for the bulls in wheat today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. l8 -- The recent shutdown in the steel industry was "badly mishandled from the very first day," Senator Sparkman said in a copyrighted interview published today by the U. S. News World Report, a weekly news magazine.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The most consistent demand on the London stock market today was for British Government securities whose best gains were 7s 6d ($1.05). Elsewhere the end of bookkeeping influences restricted business and price losses outnumbered gains.
Has deficiteering -- once a device to be countenanced only in sovereign Governments, and there only in time of war -- now become a national habit?

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 -- President Truman, in a message read to the centennial convention of the International Typographical Union here today, promised to continue his efforts "in office and out to have the unjust features of the Taft-Hartley Act stricken from the statute books."

Marjorie Capo, mezzo-soprano, flew in the face of the city's musical conventions last night by giving a recital in the middle of the summer. She sang at Carnegie Recital Hall, where she made her local debut last November.

There are many Americans who will recognize that the Nationalist Government of China has acted with unusual wisdom in naming Hollington Tong as its Ambassador to Japan. Mr. Tong, American-educated, is known to every American newspaper man who served in Free China during the war, and he has been an unofficial Ambassador of his country and his Government for a large number of years.

With the closing of the doors at Sherry's for the last time a colorful page in a chapter of New York history comes to an end. First opened when the Brooklyn Bridge was nearing completion and when the Centennial was still fresh in mind, Sherry's, along with Delmonico's, was for many years the hub whence stemmed all things gastronomic.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Aug. 18 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama forecast today "the South will be proud to stand behind Gov. Adlai Stevenson" of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, in November's election.

Rapid changes are being made in the world's steel map. World output in 1951 was 230,512,000 tons, with Soviet Russia and her satellites responsible for 19.7 per cent. According to United Nations estimates, the 1953 figure will be 266,453,000 tons, with the Iron Curtain countries supplying 20.7 per cent.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 19 -- The Korean armistice delegations met for an hour in their-roadside tent at Panmunjom today, then took another week's recess, with, no indication that any progress was in store on the long deadlocked issue of an exchange of prisoners.

Abolition of the Post Office directory service has been a real source of hardship to foreign correspondents. Very often persons in foreign countries don't realize the difference between a street and avenue; again, others forget to mention "East" or "West," with the result that their mail is sent back without the directory service being consulted.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- There were memories of Man o'War at old Saratoga today, for Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's brown colt Bradley, by Bimelech from the Man o'War mare Our Colors, won the fortieth running of the Sanford Stakes for 2-year-olds.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Manager Leo Durocher led his Giants into town tonight to discover his leadership of the club temporarily ended.

American pharmaceutical products have a potential $10,000,000-a-year market in Japan, Korea and Formosa, Taisuke Nakamura, president of the Nakamura Taki Company, Ltd., of Tokyo, said yesterday. He and his managing director, Katsuo Tojo, are concluding a flying visit to the Bloomfield, N. J., plant of the Schering Corporation, which they represent in Japan.

Three hundred delegates from ninety-five schools and departments of journalism across the country will gather on Monday at Columbia University for the second annual convention of the Association for Education in Journalism.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, and his wife today greeted 200 persons at the reception for them by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Sherrill at Seabury House, conference center of the church.

A new work by Norman Cousins, described as "a definition of hope for man in the atomic age," will be published on Nov. 10 by Macmillan under the title "Who Speaks for Man?" Combining a commentary on our time and a personal odyssey, the volume includes accounts of two visits to the Far East, of a democratization survey in post-war Germany, and of other travels.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 18 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, referring in a conciliatory vein today to Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, the Egyptian "strong man," said that Israel had no quarrel with the Cairo Government and that cooperation with Israel would help Egypt .to overcome her political and social problems and raise her international status.

The commitment of Bayard P. Peakes, 29-year-old slayer of Miss Eileen Fahey at Columbia University, to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane was ordered yesterday by General Sessions Judge Edward J. McCullen.

The polls will be open in New York City today from 3 P. M. to 10 P. M., and outside New York City from noon to 9 P. M., for the fall primary election. Registered voters who are enrolled in a party -- Democratic, Republican, Liberal or American Labor -- are eligible to vote.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. Aug. 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, will make a farm speech Sept. 6 at the National Plowing Matches at Kasson, Minn., on the same day that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, will appear before the same group.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won low gross honors in a Class A Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament, with 40, 41 -- 81 at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Troops of the Forty-second and Seventy-seventh Infantry Divisions started their second week of summer training today after enjoying week-end leaves in Canada and at St. Lawrence River resorts.

Underwriting installment buying is becoming big business. It is called consumer credit insurance. It costs less than industrial life insurance, with the same rate for all ages up to 65. And no medical examination is required.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 134 casualties of the Korean war. The list included fifteen killed, 108 wounded, seven injured and four missing. The following casualties were listed for New York (none from New Jersey and Connecticut):
Design details reminiscent of the American past as well as of the European present appear in a new collection of Drexel furniture, now on view in one of the five new model rooms at McCreery's.

Hour by hour and then minute by minute, accountants at the Bowery Savings Bank's offices tallied each deposit yesterday, awaiting the moment when deposits would reach the billion dollar mark for the first time in savings bank history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Fred M. Saigh Jr., owner of the St. Louis Cardinal Baseball Club, accused Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, today of playing politics by suggesting there were tax irregularities in connection with the purchase of the club by Mr. Saigh and the late Robert E. Hannegan of St. Louis.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The Soviet Union and China opened diplomatic negotiations designed to broaden military and economic collaboration of these two great powers today.

We hope that the dispute between the railroad Brotherhoods and the New York Central lines east of Buffalo, which will be the subject of conferences today in Washington, will yield to adjustment without a strike.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Pershing Hanover won the Ithaca Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in 2:07 3-5, finishing a length and a half ahead of McElwyn Hanover. Dutchess of Brookville was third. The winner, an entry with Star Mite, was a 3-4 favorite.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The national stockpile of critical and strategic materials was valued at $3,565,390,655 at the end of June, the Munitions Board announced today. In addition, materials worth $1,918,964,446 were under contract for delivery to the stockpile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Government said today that more than half the nation's 500,000 grocery stores would be required to post dollars-and-cents ceilings on a wide range of market basket items by Oct. 1. New York City is included.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18 -- A slim, six-foot, 18-year-old golfer, Ira Gruber of Pottstown, Pa., a sophomore at Duke University, eliminated the defending titleholder, Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., in the opening round of the United States amateur golf championship today.

A vivid and detailed account of the operations of a Soviet-controlled uranium mine in western Czechoslovakia and the story of the fantastic escape of seven of its political prisoners were given here yesterday by Ivan Pluhar, who led the flight to freedom last September and arrived here Saturday to continue his law studies.

The present wave of crimes occurring in New York is generally credited by those who should know as the result of having too few foot patrolmen on the streets. A possible solution to this immediate problem might be the utilization of some 19,000 citizens who have been enrolled as auxiliary policemen, but who up to the present time have been ignored.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Robert Brown, president of the Rhode Island Republican Club, which is co-sponsor of a party clambake, at which Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois has been invited to speak, said today that he believed 'prejudices Dirksen has created would hurt the candidates here."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 -- The Indians today announced a deal with the Pirates, bringing Relief Hurler Ted Wilks and Infielder George Strickland to Cleveland in return for Infielder Johnny Berardino and a "sizable bundle" of cash.

The dispatch from our Rio de Janeiro correspondent, Sam Pope Brewer, describing the harmful effects of Brazilian nationalism points to an evil that corrodes the whole of Latin America. The Brazilians are holding back on measures of economic and military cooperation with the United States for purely nationalistic reasons.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Many of the nation's leading industries are concerned about the serious shortage of engineers in the United States today but at least one concern has found a "stretchout" solution to this problem.

The Panamanian-flag cruise liner Silverstar, bound in from a ten-day cruise to Havana and Nassau by way of Miami, was heading for New York last night at reduced speed and is not expected to dock until 5 P. M. today because of boiler trouble at sea.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UP) -- A pinch home run by Manager Phil Cavarretta in the ninth inning enabled the Cubs to beat the Pirates, 4 -- 3, today.

Eight evangelists who held a Sunday evening meeting at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street were found guilty yesterday of disorderly conduct. Magistrate Paul Balsam in Mid-Manhattan Magistrate's Court then adjourned the case for sentence on Aug. 28.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, Prime Minister of the State of Jammu and Kashmir, appears to be having trouble persuading Yuvraj Karan Singh, the youthful heir apparent of the exiled Maharajah of the State, to become the territory's first Governor when the monarchy is formally abolished.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Members of the American Pharmaceutical Association were urged today to organize local units of the association to "bring the health message to the American people." The suggestion came from Dr. Don E. Francke of Ann Arbor, Mich., president of the association, at the opening session of its centennial convention in the Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 18 -- Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, announced today that the new headquarters for the Allied Land Forces, Southeastern Europe, would be situated in Smyrna (Izmir) in Turkey.
As a New York County grand jury opened hearings in the vice inquiry, a 39-year-old motion picture extra was held in $25,000 bail yesterday on charges of living off the earnings of a prostitute.

ATHENS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A quarreling, bickering Greek Parliament opened debate today on a wide field of economic, political and military subjects that was expected to end in a dangerously close vote of confidence for this country's coalition Government.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,346 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korea time:

Heavy rains in Maine over the week-end crumpled the potato futures market on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Reports to trade houses indicated that the downpour had come in the nick of time.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- Negotiations aimed at improving trade between Eastern and Western Europe that had been proposed for the second week in September will not be held, Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the United Nations' Economic Commission for Europe, said today.

The advertising, sales and fair trade policies of the whisky business are getting a going-over this week. At West Point's Thayer Hotel Tubie Resnik, executive vice president and general sales manager of Calvert Distillers Corporation, told 150 representatives of its distributors from twelve Eastern states that despite the bid last year to crash the mass market by straight whiskies, the ten best selling brands were blends.

Lorette, the wool and Orlon "miracle fabric" developed by Milliken, was one of two major attractions in the style shows of fashions made from McCall patterns shown at Macy's yesterday. The other attraction was the appearance of the ten O'Neil sisters from Boston, modeling clothes their mother had made of Lorette.
Scrap metal is not being hoarded and some ingot makers actually are declining to purchase scrap, Henry Klingenstein of the Keystone Metal Company, Pittsburgh, asserted yesterday.

National headquarters of the American Legion, moved temporarily from Indianapolis, opened yesterday at the Statler Hotel, which at once began to buzz with pre-convention activity. The convention will begin next Sunday and will continue through Thursday, Aug. 28.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has its sights trained on a pair of prospective comedies, but it will be some months before either reaches the shooting stage.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Communist guerrillas poured high velocity fire early today into a United States Army courier train wounding an American captain and a civilian newsreel camera man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Prince Abdullah Faisal of Saudi Arabia, called at the White House today to thank President Truman for the invitation under which he has traveled from the Atlantic Coast to the Pacific and back again. He arrived in the United States on July 14.

Firm prices and low inventories at the retail level brought excellent business for seventy exhibitors of linens and domestics in a combined showing in the Commodore Hotel.
