The showing, arranged by Allied Linens and Domestics Association, Inc., has been attended by several hundred store buyers since its opening on Sunday.

A seven-day strike notice, involving 34,000 workers in eight shipyards in four states, was served on the Bethlehem Steel Company last night by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The United States Army defeated the Marines and hit the bullseye in the national pistol team shoot today, sweeping the three championships and breaking a world record.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18 -- The National Chamber of Commerce said today it is confident Mexico can maintain her present exchange rate despite her unfavorable trade balance. But the figures on which the Chamber based its optimistic statement did not agree with those from other sources.

Seventeen contests for Democratic or Republican nominations are to be decided at primary elections in this city today. At the same time voters in the rest of the state will settle twenty-two similar contests, likewise involving Democratic or Republican nominations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -The Marine Corps said today that a rider on the current military appropriation bill would slow up promotions, but no officers would be demoted.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -Jersey Joe Walcott, heavyweight champion, and Rocky Marciano will sign contracts Wednesday in the office of Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. of Philadelphia for their fifteen-round title bout at Municipal Stadium Sept. 23.

CAIRO, Aug. 18 -- The special military tribunal set up to try instigators of last Wednesday's cotton mill riots in Kafr el-Dawar near Alexandria, sentenced one of the defendants to death by hanging today for treason and complicity in the murder of soldiers sent to put down the demonstrations.

LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The sabotage of two racing speedboats owned by Henry J. Kaiser, industrialist, was dismissed as the work of "an anti-social crank" today, despite the millionaire's insistence that someone tried to murder him.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 18 -- The recent decree permiting exportation of some thirteen items, formerly on the prohibited list, has caused discussion in business and official circles and the press as to its ultimate effect on the economy of the country.

One of the pleasantest aspects of a vacation, in anticipation, is the time it will offer, presumably, to catch up on one's reading. The harried urbanite who can seldom manage to read more than the headlines while clutching a subway strap or balancing on a bus looks forward to some lazy days far from the madding crowd and possibly, also, far from television sets.

Co. Directors of Carman Co. took no action yesterday on a dividend on the common stock. The previous payment was 10 cents on March 1, Last year disbursements were I0 cents each in March and September and 20 cents in December.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 18 -- Authorities at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, here affirmed today that protests in the Communist press against the North Atlantic Treaty war exercise called "Mainbrace," to be held in Scandinavia, will have no effect on their plans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Truman today declassified a report by the Federal Trade Commission on international oil cartels -- kept secret for many months -- and authorized its publication.

Queens Borough President James A. Lundy disclosed yesterday that he had been personally going down into Queens sewers to see how well they had been built, and he announced especial dissatisfaction with a $185,679 project in Laurelton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Spokesmen for seventeen railroad unions have told the eastern and western railroads that their "patience is exhausted" in their union shop dispute and that they will insist on a settlement on terms recommended by an emergency board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- State Department officials watched closely all reports on the conference that began today in Moscow between Soviet leaders and a delegation of top Chinese Communist officials. They said they found no evidence of anything extraordinary, however, about the meeting.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 18 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh ordered district and local officials today to form within fifteen days village councils under his rural reform decree and proceed to force landlords to return 20 per cent of their share of the harvest to be divided equally between the peasants and the councils.
Red Cross officials announced yesterday that a three-day drive for blood donations would begin this morning at the Army post at Fort Monmouth, N.J. A minimum of 900 pints is expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Publicly reported cash dividend payments amounted to $542,000,000 in July, or $7,000,000 more than the $535,000,000 disbursed in July, 1951, the Office of Business Economics, a unit of the Department of Commerce, reported today.

The New York Rangers, lacking on defense during the 1951-52 campaign, took measures to correct that shortcoming yesterday by acquiring Leo Reise, hardhitting performer from the champion Detroit Red Wings. In exchange, the Detroiters obtained Wingman Reggie Sinclair, the professional rights to John Morrison and an undisclosed sum in cash.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The Chicago Board of Trade will extend its trading hours by thirty minutes beginning next week. It will open at 9:30 A. M. Eastern Standard Time, as usual, and will close at 1:45 P. M., Eastern Standard Time on Mondays through Fridays.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense announced today it has authorized New Jersey Natural Gas Company, Asbury Park, to extend natural gas service to 5,000 new house-heating customers within the next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had been catching draft-dodgers at the rate of 5,000 a year since the new Selective Service Law was enacted four years ago.

DENVER, Aug. 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic nominee for President, got the thanks of Republicans today for helping them to establish one of their main campaign arguments -- that there was "a mess" in Washington that required cleaning up.
The Champion Paper and Fibre Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $2,384,167 in the quarter ended on June 30, against $2,549,830 earned in the similar three months last year.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Surmounting a number of hazards including the singular notion that Fenway Park is no place in which to win a ball game, the Yankees, behind the steady hurling of Vic Raschi, today scored their third straight victory here, where previously they had dropped their first five encounters.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 18 -- A walkout of seventy employes, including unskilled and semi-skilled workers, at the Wood Newspaper Machinery Manufacturing Corporation here today, halted production after nearly 200 skilled employes refused to cross a picket line.

The responsibilities and burdens assumed by subsidized shipping operators are greatly overestimated, according to a critical study of the subject made public yesterday by the Association of American Ship Owners, 90 Broad Street.

The recent heat wave, aside from adding to discomfort generally, brought a sell-out of General Electric room air conditioners, it was reported in Louisville by Harold B. Donley, general manager of the company's room cooler department.

Record sales of room air conditioners lifted net sales of the Fedders-Quigan Corporation in the second quarter of this year to $13,722,714, highest in the company's history, topping the $9,896,063 volume for the 1951 quarter by 39 per cent, Salvatore Giordano, president, reported yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- While the Australian defenders, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, sat out the first round with a bye, the men's division of the National Doubles Tennis tournament went through the opening paces with only a minor upset today at Longwood.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Defense Department reported today that its obligations for the fiscal year that ended June 30 totaled $61,900,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The National Production Authority today authorized builders of approved industrial projects to use up to 500 tons of "conversion steel" in the last quarter of this year and a like amount in the first quarter of 1953.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- American enterprise, plus native palates, is shifting the appetites of the Congo from corn to wheat -- packaged flour, that is.
A "sightless" television set, designed to receive only the sound of television programs, has been developed for blind persons, the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind announced yesterday.

On the eve of the last round in the preliminaries for the International Chess Federation team championship, four countries including Russia and the United States, are certain of places in the final round-robin, according to a report yesterday from Helsinki, Finland.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Members of Local 489 of the Textile Workers, C. I. O., voted today to end their twelve-week strike and acept the Mohawk Carpet Company's latest wage offer.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- Each spring, summer and fall a harness race meeting is opened at Yonkers Raceway, the old Empire City course which in 1950 was converted into a half-mile track for standard-breds. Tonight 22,524 fans turned out for the start of the twelve-night summer meet and poured $1,172,026 into the mutuels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The Screen Writers Guild retorted today to the western region of the Radio Writers Guild, which yesterday revealed that its members had voted not to support the strike called last Monday by the screen writers and the Authors League of America against the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

While volume still carried a minus mark, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores improved last week. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its "flash report" yesterday, reported sales last week were 6 per cent below a year ago, against a drop of 13 per cent for the week ended Aug. 9.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Bay Head Yacht Club of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association today held first place as the three-day Mid-Atlantic Sears sailing championship semi-final races opened in Fishers Island Sound.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- A prominent British Socialist, Ernest Davies, acknowledged today that the "full advantages" that the community was led to expect from the nationalization of industries in Britain "have not yet in every case, been fully realized."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A new concerted Communist propaganda line directed against the United Nations and tailored for world-wide consumption has been built on the United Nations' use in the Korean war of napalm, the jellied-gasoline weapon.

The nation's shipbuilding industry will have this month one of it busiest periods since World War II with the delivery of five vessels. Officials said yesterday that it was a peacetime mark that had not been approached in many years.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 18 -- The question of how to deal with teachers who are former members of the Communist party is threatening to split the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L. which opened its thirty-fifth national convention here today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Arthur Cohen and Lloyd Wadkins of Glen Oaks clipped seven strokes from par with a sizzling 31, 34 -- 65 to win the Long Island Golf Association amateur-pro championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 18 -- Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach has started the arrangements required by Allied law to dispose of his huge steel and coal holdings, now in the hands of trustees appointed by the Allies.

The Shwab Rubber Company, of which Willy Schwab is president, has purchased the seven-story, garage-type building at 2341- 2347 Twelfth Avenue. southeast corner of 134th Street, from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and will occupy it in an expansion and consolidation move.
LUND, Sweden, Aug. 18 -- With a heavy accent on persecution, the position of the Christian church behind the Iron Curtain and in the Near East was aired today by delegates from the areas concerned.
HONOLULU, Aug. 18 -- Monopoly and price support are terms not confined to the mainland United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The story of the long-drawn-out negotiations between the West and the Soviet Union to write a treaty with Austria will probably be put before the United Nations General Assembly in the fall.

Prices were marked down drastically yesterday on the stock market. Despite the absence of any heavy selling, quotations melted all along the line with losses in individual issues ranging from 1 to 4 points. It was the worst shaking suffered by the share list since mid-April in terms of the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index, which shrank 2.47 points.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- B. F. Goodrich Company plants in nine cities were hit by a strike of the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., today while negotiations for a new contract went into the eleventh week.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug 18 -- The Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship went to Clarence Doser today for the third time. In the twenty-third annual event, over the Fenway Golf Club's tricky 6,485-yard, par-71 course, the Scarsdale procarded 36, 35 -- 71 this morning and 37, 36 -- 73 after lunch for a 36-hole tally of 144.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- If delinquency is to be decreased, communities throughout the state must use their schools in prevention and in treatment, Dr. Herbert A. Bloch, director of a special survey on delinquency being sponsored by the New York State Youth Commission, declared today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Congressional investigators asserted today that prosecution of an alleged fraud case was blocked for the past eight years in the Department of Justice.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A typhoon, weakened by its twelve-hour eastward sweep across the mountainous Korean peninsula, whirled out into the Sea of Japan today. It was expected to build up new strength on its ocean course toward the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.

The Pennsylvania Railroad condemned yesterday the reorganization plan of the Long Island Transit Authority for the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, calling it "not a plan for reorganization, but a plan for confiscation."
TOKYO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The bull is running berserk in Japan's lively post-war stock market.
MADRID, Aug. 18 -- Spain's leading women's fashion houses made a bid today for a share of United States and Canadian trade with the opening of a three-day "fashion festival."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- What was merely as plain as a pikestaff after the two Presidential candidates had been nominated is now as plain as day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Some of the leading Democratic campaign strategists are backing a policy that would keep President Truman relatively in the background on television and turn the full focus on the Presidential candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

A "refrigerette on wheels," a small portable appliance designed to supplement the standard kitchen refrigerator, may also be a boon to the one-room dweller. The electrically operated Wonderbar, as it is called, has been finished in mahogany, blond or white plastic and has been styled to resemble a piece of modern furniture so that it fits into the decor of any room.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18 -- An effort to defeat officers of the Federation of Post Office Clerks, A. F. L., was taking form today as the twenty-seventh biennial convention of the federation opened here.

For the first time in his long and distinguished theatrical career, Thomas Mitchell will be undertaking a musical comedy role. The actor-author has signed contracts to sing and dance in "Hazel Flagg." This is the musical adaptation by Ben Hecht of his movie.

Each national convention of the major parties is different from the ones that preceded it, but there is one odd and correctible thing that all have in common. They are all held in the wretched, debilitating heat of July. Ever since I first became interested in political developments I have wondered what there is about July that makes it a sacrosanct and immovable date for national political conventions.

ALL summer baseball men have kept saying in their smug, opinionated fashion, "Ol' Case is gonna win his fourth pennant easier than any of the others in spite of the fact that he has the worst team of his Yankee career." It certainly looked for the longest while as if Casey Stengel would make these self-styled experts look as if they knew what they were talking about.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 18 -- Agricultural experts from some fifty nations outside the Iron Curtain began pooling their technical knowledge today at the opening of the Sixth International Grassland Congress on the campus of Pennsylvania State College.

An appeal against a decision of the regional Wage Stabilization Board, which cut almost in half a 15-cents-an-hour increase requested for 20,000 hourly employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation in Farmingdale, L. I., will be filed in Washington by both the company and five local unions involved.

The crushed body of a teen-age boy was found on the express tracks of the Lexington Avenue I. R. T. Subway near 103d Street late last night shortly after two unidentified youths had robbed a newsstand dealer and had fled up the tracks.

Plans for re-facing the 140-year-old City Hall to save it from gradually wearing away and for erecting a $14,400,000 consolidated courthouse for the City and Municipal Courts in Manhattan marked the opening of City Planning Commission hearings yesterday on capital budget requests.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 (UP) -Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, Tenn., the defending champion, shot a six-under-par 66 today to defeat Jack Burke Jr. of Houston, Tex., by six strokes in a play-off for the $15,000 Kansas City open golf championship.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 18 -- Mississippi's State Democratic Convention voted overwhelmingly today to pledge its eight Presidential electors this November to support the national party's candidates, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama.

Eight young Americans with ideas on what makes their country great were on a rapid-fire tour of New York yesterday. Winners in an essay contest held by General Mills, they stopped here on their way to Boston and Detroit from flying visits to Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas and Washintgon.
GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- Work has started on a pilot project for resettling European migrants in Australia, the implications of which are considered large by migration experts here.

Joseph J. Colahan has been named manager of the carpet division of Goodall Fabrics, Inc., replacing Frank E. Steimle, who is to retire, effective Oct. 1. Andrew V. Crean will continue as assistant manager.
Potato futures again broke the 25-cent limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange as margin calls forced liquidation by overextended longs. Volume for the day set a new high of 998 carloads.

The cry seemed to come from nowhere. There had been silence, the stillness of expectancy among the stream-threaded hills embedding the Festival town of Salzburg, its cathedral and the wooden benches of the auditorium in front of it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- A Federal judge, weary from arguing with a landlord for six months, tried to settle a case today by offering to pay the landlord's hot water bill himself "just to get rid of this matter."

CAIRO, Aug. 19 -- Abdul Rahman Azzam, secretary general of the Arab League, conferred with the Egyptian Premier, Aly Maher, here today about implementing the Arab security pact which comes into force Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee accused the Congress of Industrial Organizations today of attempting with "bunk" and half-truths to "confuse the preponderant majority of Negroes who are not accepting the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket."
The subject of smoking in public transportation carriers, as commented upon in a letter to the editor appearing in your issue of Aug. 13, is worthy of more extensive treatment and publicity.

LYNMOUTH, England, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- Harold Macmillan, Minister of Housing and Local Government, trudged ankle deep through mud and climbed over giant boulder today to see how the British Government could aid this seaside resort town, wrecked by last week-end's flash flood.

I have seen your recent editorial concerning the pending anti-trust suit brought by the United States against some of the leading producers and distributors of sixteen-millimeter motion picture films.

The B. F. Goodrich Company onnounced yesterday arrangements for the sale of $20,000,000 promissory notes, the redemption of its outstanding preferred stock and a drop of $1,270,411 in its half-year earnings.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Apart from continued demand for German and Japanese bonds, the London stock market was virtually featureless today and without significant price changes. The German Dawes and Young loans finished one and a half points higher, while some non-Reich issues did still better.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Prospects of a peaceful settlement of the dispute between the New York Central system and four operating unions appeared improved today after a meeting sponsored by the National Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Truman accepted today an invitation to receive in person the International Brotherhood Award of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at a luncheon here Nov. 11. The acceptance was announced after a visit at the White House this morning by Albert M. Greenfield of Philadelphia, a conference representative.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 19 -- Two court stenographers after more than two years of work delivered today the almost interminable transcription of the longest court case in Rhode Island history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Bernard C. Schoenfeld, playwright and Hollywood screen writer, told the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he became a Communist in 1945 in "shock" from the death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Grand jury action by Friday was predicted yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Anthony J. Leibler in the vice case involving Minot Frazier Jelke 3d and two others. At a morning session yesterday the panel heard testimony by two witnesses, one who identified herself as a prostitute and the second as her sweetheart who lived off her earnings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Connie Marrero scattered twelve hits for his tenth victory of the season and drove in the winning run with a single tonight as the Senators edged the Browns, 2 -- 1.

Sales of Food Fair Stores, Inc., now are at the highest in the company's history and a volume approaching $300,000,000 is expected for the fiscal year ending next May 2, Samuel Friedland, chairman, told shareholders yesterday.

HONG KONG, Aug. 19 -- Regulations for the establishment of the projected All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce have been released by Peiping. This body, which parallels the All-China Federation of Trade Unions, is organized to fit all types of urban economic enterprises into a tighter mold for purposes of more efficient government planning and control.

Representative Ralph A. Gamble of Larchmont won renomination in the Republican primary yesterday in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, located in Westchester County, defeating a strong bid by Mayor Edwin B. Dooley of Mamaroneck.

Overcrowding in city hospitals has become so "desperate" that these institutions are "getting tough" and refusing admission to some patients who would have been admitted formerly, Hospitals Commissioner Marcus D. Kogel said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United States Justice Department officials today made a second arrest in an alleged Canadian visa fraud and said the sister of one of the Dominion's top officials was involved.
MOSCOW, Aug 19 -- A word picture of one of the greatest natural disasters of recent times -- the Ashkhabad earthquake of Oct. 6, 1948 -- was published today by the Soviet literary journal Znamya.

Israel's Prime Minister, David Ben-Gurion, made a courageous and heartening gesture on Monday when he pleaded for "peace" between Egypt and Israel. This was followed up yesterday by another olive branch, from Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett, offered to all the Arab states.

William G. Christy, director of the city's Smoke Control Bureau, who criticized last week the new superliner United States for emitting excessive smoke, visited the vessel yesterday and came away satisfied that her operators were taking measures to control the problem.

Mary Grissom, a 34-year-old right-hander who is making good with the White Sox after previous failures with the Giants and Tigers, last night put a temporary crimp in the Yankees' hopes of breaking away from the uncomfortably close pursuit of the Indians on their final long home stand of the season.

DENVER, Aug. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower reasserted his personal control of Republican campaign strategy and policy direction today by establishing his own four-member committee in Washington to coordinate activities of the regular National Committee.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 19 -- The Swedish Foreign Office began today an investigation of Miss Margaret Truman's right to have three armed American bodyguards in Sweden.

TRENTON, Aug. 19 -- An indictment charging Prosecutor Walter G. Winne with neglecting to stamp out gambling in Bergen County was quashed today by Superior Court Judge Richard J. Hughes, who said it was "uncertain and failed to charge a corrupt motive." An appeal is likely.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 19 -Gov. Robert F. Kennon said tonight he would ask the Democratic State Central Committee meeting tomorrow to condemn parts of the national Democratic platform and to approve formally the Louisiana delegation's refusal to sign the "loyalty" pledge.

Weakness in sales in the textile field and less profitable defense business were chiefly responsible for the $4,932,690 drop in half-year earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company. In addition, the company announced after its board meeting yesterday the appointment of three vice presidents and a first vice president.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force reported today a new low major accident rate of twenty-nine for every 100,000 hours flown during the first six months of 1952.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Truman revised today his budget estimates for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1953, and predicted a Treasury deficit of $10,300,000,000 instead of the $14,400,000,000 he foresaw when he sent his fiscal message to Congress last January.

James F. Reilly of the League of New York Theatres denied here yesterday that the next move in efforts to liberalize regulations controlling the construction and operation of legitimate theatres was up to the owners' group.

Your editorial "Blood for Life" makes mention of the media used by the Red Cross in its appeals for blood donations. It seems to me that radio, newspapers and television, in this case, are not as effective as a direct-mail campaign might be.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 19 (UP) -- A Portland newspaper editor said today that Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, had deliberately misinterpreted a statement by Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois when he asserted that the Democratic Presidential nominee had admitted there was a "mess" in Washington.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The old "Snellen chart," a placard lined with random letters of the alphabet in graduated sizes, used for years to test the vision of millions of children, is on its way out of the nation's schoolrooms, officials of the American Optometric Association reported today. A new chart, using Arabic numerals each with the same total area of blackness, has been officially adopted by the association.

MINOCQUA, Wis., Aug. 19 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, flew today to this northern Wisconsin summer resort for a brief holiday after a mix-up resulted in the cancellation of a speaking date.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 19 -- Resuming a security measure of World War II, the Coast Guard soon will station a guard ship outside the Virginia capes to challenge all vessels entering Chesapeake Bay, the service announced today. The cutter Tahoma will go on duty about Aug. 25.

In 1932 the Consolidated Edison Company filed new rate schedules to increase its revenues by about $11,000,000 per annum. With the approval of Mayor La Guardia, the undersigned, then Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, refused to enter into contracts with the Consolidated Edison Company or its subsidiaries, except on the basis of lower rate schedules.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Two long-hitting young players, Diana Bourne of Siwanoy and Dorothy Lowenstein of Fenway, playing alternate shots, took a two-stroke lead with a 43, 39 -- 82 in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fourteenth annual thirty-six hole Scotch foursome tournament at the Old Oaks Country Club today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- If Yale can uncover some men who can throw the ball, the Eli football team probably will have a wide-open passing attack during the coming season.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The Westport Woman's Club was convicted today of violating the state's anti-lottery law in the operation of a "fish bowl" booth at its recent charity fair. Judge Julius H. Groher of New Canaan fined the club $100 but remitted $90.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 19 -- The sixth International Grassland Congress heard today that accomplishments of grassland farming clearly proved the world was far from the limit of its production and population potential.

The slump in prices on the stock market was halted yesterday and, while the reversal of form proved to be slight, the composite rate managed to return to the higher side. The rails again set the course, and moderate improvement in this division enabled the list to establish a firmer price structure.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 19 -- William C. Horley, 50-year-old former vice president of the First Bank and Trust Company of Perth Amboy, today was sentenced to state prison for ten to fourteen years by Judge Ralph J. Smalley in Superior Court here for embezzling $459,689 in bank funds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie issued today the draft of a convention on the political rights of women, in conformity with a directive to him from the United Nations Economic and Social Council to formulate the wording of the measure.

An issue of $5,180,000 of new common stock of the Pacific Finance Corporation, automobile sales financing enterprise, will be offered to investors today by an investment banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Hornblower Weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Export-Import Bank, the Government's foreign lending agency, extended new credits amounting to $413,300,000 in the first six months of 1952, the agency reported to Congress today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 19 -- Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, said today the main subject of the Kashmir demilitarization talks opening at Geneva Aug. 25 would be that of the number of troops to remain on either side of the cease fire line in the state.
OSLO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Norway's Elizabeth X, with Finn Ferner at the helm, defeated Llanoria, America's Olympic six-meter yachting champion, today in the opening race of the International Gold Cup.

State Senator William J. Bianchi, who defied the Manhattan Republican organization two years ago by accepting American Labor party endorsement after promising not to do so, was defeated in his bid for renomination in yesterday's Republican primary by Dr. Charles J. Muzzicato, a former State Senator.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- Negotiations for an armistice in Korea were in adjournment again today after an hour's angry meeting at Panmunjom yesterday that reached a new high in recrimina tion on the part of the Communist delegation.

A billion dollars is a figure we mention rather casually nowadays. But when it is a billion saved perhaps we should take some note of it. The Bowery Savings Bank, with its four offices in Manhattan, was a scene of some excitement Monday, when deposits passed the $1,000,000,000 mark for the first time in savings bank history.
The parched skeletons of Quonset huts that once were fairly cozy Bronx apartments presented yesterday a foretaste of what is to come for the city's eight temporary emergency housing developments.
An attractive, 31-year-old New Jersey housewife dashed up the gangplank of the Italian liner Vulcania yesterday just as longshoremen prepared to lower it.

JOHNNY NEUN delights in telling the story of his adventures as manager of the Cincinnati Reds, an ill-fated episode in his life that's lost its tragic overtones and merely become funny. At least Johnny now makes it sound funny.

The value of new drafts drawn on Brazilian importers fell sharply last month although aggregate value of the drafts drawn on importers in other Latin-American countries rose moderately, according to the monthly export credit data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Marine Maj. William E. Barber, who will receive the Medal of Honor from President Truman tomorrow, said today "one bullet wound doesn't stop a man."

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The French Government does not expect the negotiations with West Germany over the final status of the Saar materially to change the economic union between France and the Saar, Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, said today.

The fifty-two-family apartment house at 2070-72 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Edward Schoenfield and Frances Sapin to Morris Friedman, operator, who resold it to the Square Realty Corporation, Hyman Katz, president. The property is assessed at $165,000.

Customers of Long Island banks may be able to draw against their check deposits more promptly under a newly established check collection system. The arrangement, now being operated on an experimental basis by the Manufacturers Trust Company, cuts collection time to two days among participating banks in Nassau, western Suffolk and Queens Counties.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The steady blows against North Korean targets by Allied air power brought a cry of protest from the North Korean radio today. It broadcast an appeal to "the peoples of the world" to halt the bombings and called them "barbaric."

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 19 -- An independent slate of eight electors pledged to support the candidacy of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, was named today at an organizational meeting of Mississippi Democrats-for-Eisenhower.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The Seventy-seventh Division, Organized Reserve, moved out on a tactical bivouac today to defend itself from an "aggressor" force moving down from the north.

ALBERTVILLE, Ala., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman said today that both he and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson believed that people should go to church on Sunday rather than listen to political speeches.

ATHENS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Deputy Premier Sophocles Venizelos said today the Greek coalition Government, shaken by deep cuts in United States dollar aid, probably would ask for new elections even if it should win a vote of confidence in Parliament this week.

MANILA, Aug. 19 -- Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, United States Ambassador, said today that the United States was in a much better position now to defend the Philippines than it was in 1941 at the outbreak of the Pacific war.

Negotiations for a chess match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Paul Keres, the Estonian player who holds the title of Soviet national champion, were started yesterday in Helsinki, where the principals head their respective international teams, it was reported from the Finnish capital.

Seven members of two Bronx youth gangs known as the Dragons and the Rockets were arrested yesterday after an armed clash Monday evening between the two groups in which three persons suffered minor gunshot wounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- President Truman has accepted an invitation to address a rally of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in Pittsburgh the week of Oct. 6, an official of the International Union of Electrical Workers reported today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- The measure providing for a six months' increase in the period of compulsory military service was approved on first reading in the Knesset (Parliament) tonight by 70 votes to 11.

With the cotton trade divided on the question of year-round Saturday closings for the New York Cotton Exchange, much interest is attached to the meeting on Aug. 28 of the board of governors to consider the matter.

The number and dollar volume of distress transfers of Manhattan real estate declined in July, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. There were two foreclosures on liens of $54,601 and two surrenders in lieu of foreclosures on $26,043.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned barely steady yesterday and closed 16 to 39 points net lower on the active months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to permit the Illinois Central Railroad Company to market $62,000,000 of its consolidated mortgage thirty-year bonds, Series E, without calling for competitive bids.

SEATTLE, Aug. 19 -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, one of the game's leading competitors, successfully passed his first test today in the fifty-second United States amateur championship on the Seattle Golf Club course.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 19 -- The Iranian Army, which had been withdrawn from Teheran after the clashes of July 21, rolled back into the city tonight and halted rioting by Communists and Nationalists in the center of the city.
TOKYO, Wednesday Aug. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,347, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

My purpose is to suggest that we cease to think of rent control as something "temporary" and occasioned by an "emergency" and think rather of state control of rents -- at least of residential rents -- as in the same category as public control of railroad rates, of gas and electric rates and of telephone rates.

A vacant industrial plot of about 7,800 square feet at the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by William Gottfried to the Pax Trading Company which plans to improve it with two one-story buildings for showroom and warehouse occupancy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Sang Ryup Park, Korean journalist held in the United State detention barracks here for more than ten months under orders of deportation, was released today by order of Federal District Judge Louis E. Goodman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Heavy liquidation by holders featured the trade in grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade today. Recent extremely bearish estimates of small grain crops in Western Canada, especially of spring wheat, dampened any aggressive bullish enthusiasm, and, with but little outside buying, the liquidating pressure has been cumulative.

New York City's population of about 8,000,000 will suddenly increase by 100,000 or so this week-end as the American Legion comes to town to begin its annual convention on Sunday. It will be the Legion's fourth visit here, the last having been five years ago.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will arrive here by air Sunday to address the American Legion convention at Madison Square Garden the next day, and will set up his eastern campaign headquarters at the Commodore Hotel.
A revolutionary note in labor relations -- in so far as the theatre is concerned -- has been struck by the local stagehands union.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Fauna Preservation Society in London has become seriously concerned about its heaviest responsibility, African elephants. They are again being killed for their ivory by white hunters taking advantage of the new cheap elephant licenses and operating under the guise of trophy-hunting sportsmen.

The tax-exemption feature of the Long Island Transit Authority's plan for rehabilitation of the bankrupt railroad came under attack yesterday in Suffolk County. An exemption from future state and local taxes during the period of proposed operation by the Authority, pending possible return of the road to private ownership, is contained in the law establishing the transit authority.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug, 19 -- A thirteen-state alarm was sent out today for a 58-year-old woman who has been told that she is dying of cancer and has not more than eight weeks to live. The woman has been passing worthless checks, at least one of which was used to buy drugs to help relieve her pain.

Free rides for shoppers have encouraged Wichita (Kan.) stores to remain open on Thursday nights. The transit company offers the free rides downtown, but collects fare for the ride home. In commenting on the scheme, the American Society of Planning Officials reports that the free rides are paying off by encouraging uniformity in late closing hours among downtown stores.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 19 -- The Americans for Democratic Action, the national political organization dedicated to carrying out the program of the New Deal, asserted today that the Republicans had wrested control of the Eighty-second Congress from the Democratic majority during the Congress' second session, Which started Jan. 8 and was adjourned July 7.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Gus Zernial singled in the ninth inning with two out and men on first and second to give the Athletics a 4-to-3 victory over the Tigers in the first game of a twinight twin bill tonight. Harry Byrd, the winning pitcher, limited the Tigers to six safeties and contributed two hits, a single and double, to the Philadelphia attack.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Aug. 20 -- Representative W. Sterling Cole of Bath won his fight for the Republican nomination in New York's new Thirty-seventh Congressional District early today, rolling up one of his heaviest majorities in recent years to defeat Representative Edwin A. Hall of Binghamton.
Negotiations between hard-coal producers and John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers began here yesterday, with the industry telling employes they would have to dig more coal if they wanted more pay.

Following is the list of candidates nominated by the voters of the several parties in yesterday's primary for public offices to be filled at the November election. Where more than one names appears for a single office, the result was still in doubt.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- A golden age of healing is opening to medicine due largely to the many new drugs now being turned out in quantity, Dr. R. Q. Richards, president-elect of the American Pharmaceutical Association, said today.
that a plan be worked out whereby the new Secretary of Defense could get a thorough initiation in the ways of the Pentagon before he had to assume responsibility for the vast military establishment.

The Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of Schrafft's restaurants, has leased the street floor in the two-story business building at 1237 Avenue of the Americas, the southwest corner of West Forty-ninth Street, for a bakery and candy shop and a restaurant with a seating capacity for sixty-eight persons.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Robin Roberts became the first National League pitcher to win twenty games this season as he hurled the Phillies to a 10-3 victory over the last-place Pirates.

The five-story dwelling at 14 East Sixty-fifth Street, converted to apartment use, has been sold by Mrs. Jeanne Murdock Brown to Cesare Barbieri. The Payson McL. Merrill Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $89,000.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 -- Investigation of the International Typographical Union's program for establishing and operating newspapers in cities where union printers or union mailers go on strike or where there is only one paper was requested in a resolution submitted to the union's centennial convention here.

Jesse H. Jones, former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said yesterday that the result of the coming Presidential election was still "a toss-up." He described both major party tickets as "excellent" but declined to say which he intended to support.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Support for the Conservative Government's campaign against a general increase in wages in Britain was given today by the leadership of the Trades Union Congress, the country's one big labor association, which represents nearly 8,000,000 workers.
OTTAWA, Aug. 19 -- No case of foot and mouth disease has been uncovered in Canada since May 4 when the last infected herd was slaughtered and the country today was declaimed free of the disease.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Displaced Persons Commission issued an urgent plea today for new legislation -- including revision of the immigration system -- to cope with the twin problems of refugees and European overpopulation.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Rudy Etchen, red-haired, 29-year-old Sun Valley, Idaho, crackshot who won the North American clay target championship as a professional a year ago, did it again today as an amateur at the fifty-third Grand American Trapshoot.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Vic Ghezzi, Inwood pro, played four-under-par golf with a 32, 36 -- 68 despite a disastrous 6 on the last hole to take a one-stroke lead in the fifty-four-hole Long Island Golf Association open championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

The Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, executive director of the Brooklyn division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, has informed the State Department that he will apply again for a passport to visit Japan. His application last spring was turned down.
BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- A 60-year-old naturalized American appeared in West Berlin today with a tale of seven years of confinement in East German concentration camps.
Pittsburgh, Pa., announced yesterday that it will take bids Sept. 16 on issues of $4,900,000 of bonds dated Oct. 1, 1952, and due Oct. 1, 1953 to 1972.

At a press preview of their fall collection yesterday, company officials announced that the Tall Apparel Shop would occupy a building at 20 West Thirty-eighth Street shortly after Labor Day, and in so expanding, will offer twenty different types of women's wearing apparel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Government warned today that many new industrial and commercial construction projects might have to be deferred until next year because of the fifty-five-day steel strike.

GENEVA, Aug. 19 -- If anyone wants to go into the business of coining his own money a decision of the Swiss Federal Court published today would seem to make it a bit easier to do so legally -- provided the money is made of pure gold.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -About twenty striking dock workers employed here by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad have agreed to go back to work and let mediators settle a dispute over union representation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, said today that he was hoping for a healthy outbreak of tertiary flap.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Robert Ramspeck, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, denied today that the 2,600,000 Federal employes would vote as a bloc for the Administration.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 19 -- Four New York institutions will receive substantial sums from the residuary estate, estimated at $10,000,000, of Mrs. Emily Coddington Williams, widow of W. H. Williams, railroad executive of New York and Newport, whose will was filed here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- With an eye toward discovering and encouraging new creative talent for the movie industry, the Screen Producers Guild today announced that it has established an award to be presented annually for the best films made by college students in this country. The prize will be known as the Screen Producers Guild Intercollegiate Film Award.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 19 -- The United States, British and French Governments are making a concerted effort to bring about a rapprochement between Yugoslavia and Italy. Relations between the two countries have deteriorated to a point of open animosity in recent months over the question of Trieste.

MADRID, Aug. 19 -- Spain's first "fashion festival" continued today with the showing to United States and Canadian buyers of the fall and winter collection from Pedro Rodriguez of Madrid and El Dique Flotante and Santa Eulalia of Barcelona.

JAN DE HARTOG'S new novel, "The Distant Shore,"* is as engrossingly exciting an account of action at sea as Nicholas Monsarrat's "The Cruel Sea" and, as a novel about believable and interesting human beings, it is much better. These words of enthusiastic praise are not written lightly. There were moments while I read "The Distant Shore" when I wondered if Mr. de Hartog was going to put across several of his rather tricky psychological themes.
Recent letters from readers have posed a variety of culinary questions. Some of these, such as one on the use of yogurt in cooking, are presented today together with the answers.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Vern Benson and Red Schoendienst whacked two-run homers tonight as the Cardinals gained their fourth straight victory, beating the Braves in the opener of a three-game series, 7 to 5.

The French soaps and detergents productivity team, a nine-man group that has just arrived in this country to make production studies for the French fats and oils industry, had its first look at American production know-how yesterday. The group toured the plant and laboratory of the West Disinfecting Company, Long Island City, Queens.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Measures to bridge the gap in the French budget, caused by the refusal of the United States to place the orders France had hoped to get for the production of military equipment, will be submitted to the French Cabinet tomorrow.
LE HAVRE, France, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The French Line announced today it was postponing the maiden voyage of its new liner Antilles, originally set for Oct. 3.

Madison Square Garden, which seats 18,000 spectators at a boxing show or music concert, will seat only 17,000 to hear the two Presidential candidates, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, at the American Legion convention next week.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Eight years ago this month the original U. S. S. Harder disappeared on Pacific patrol after having piled up what the Navy has called one of the most enviable records in submarine history.
A man who gave his ninetysixth pint of blood to the Red Cross yesterday said, "It doesn't do you any harm if you don't overdo it."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Former Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, co-author of the Miller-Tydings Act, told a sales meeting of distributors of Calvert Distillers Corporation at the Thayer Hotel here today that the recent McGuire Fair Trade Act merely permitted the forty-five states that have fair trade laws to enforce them effectively.
Manufacture of alloy steel gained sharply in 1951, increasing more than the consumption of alloying elements, it was reported yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- They patched up the crippled Sal Maglie in the clubhouse at Wrigley Field today and the Barber went out on the hill to blank the Cubs, 5 to 0, and set the pattern for a twin triumph by the Giants.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., 42-year-old Borough President of Manhattan who has been under consideration for almost a year as a Democratic candidate for United States Senator, announced his candidacy for the office formally last night.
MONTAUK, L. I., Aug. 19 -- The weather has been as near perfect as any off-shore angler could ask for the past two days, but the fish have not been cooperating.

In a still precarious economic situation in most of Western Europe, which has already led to a slow-down in its defense programs, the continued economic recovery of Western Germany presents a notable exception that is matched only, on a smaller scale, by that of Belgium.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Anne Quast, 14-year-old of Everett, Wash., turned in the big upset of the first round of the National Junior Girls' Golf championships today when she eliminated the tournament favorite, Berridge (Berri) Long of Huntington, W. Va., 3 and 2.

Robert W. Williams and Albert W. Gatov, members of the Federal Maritime Board, and A. J. Williams, board secretary, returned here yesterday aboard the superliner United States after what has been described as an unprecedented subsidy inquiry mission.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- King Faisal II of Iraq had a glimpse today of American industrial power and was thrilled by a ninety-mile-an-hour spin around the Ford Motor Company's test track at suburban Dearborn.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., assailed yesterday a group of nonunion cloak manufacturers as "an underworld association."

The Florists' Telegraph Delivery Association has adopted a new emblem for its flowers-by-wire advertising and sales. It is a popeyed infant Mercury with winged cap and heels, decently clad in a diaper and carrying, of all things, a bouquet of flowers. His name is Speedy:
ROME, Aug. 19 -- Defense Minister Randolfo Pacciardi told Army Secretary Frank Pace Jr. today that Italy had no intention of scaling down her rearmament effort this year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Ogden Phipps' Busanda, a 5-year-old mare who seemed to have lost all interest in horse racing, regained same at old Saratoga today -- with an assist from Ted Atkinson -- and won first money of $7,675 in the $11,300 Diana Handicap.

Sales and operating revenues of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana and its subsidiaries were $766,718,420 in the first half of this year, compared with $733,172,254 in the 1951 period, but net income declined $13,254,726, according to the mid-year report issued yesterday.

Seminars, educational programs and a tightening of financial and administrative procedures among local unions of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., were recommended in a report made public yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the waterfront labor organization.

I read with much interest your column Topics of The Times for Aug. 8. I was fascinated by your account of the voyage made by Capt. John Smith in 1614 to Agawama, now Ipswich, Mass. I was also saddened by the changes that may occur to Ipswich in the near future -- made in the guise of progress.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Diplomatic quarters expressed the belief today that in the course of the discussions between Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China and Soviet Government leaders, who would include Premier Stalin and Deputy Premier Vyacheslav M. Molotov, detailed plans would be drafted regarding a policy on Japan.

" Pick the Winner," a series of streamlined political debates as compared to some of the meandering oratory in Chicago last month, is being presented each Thursday from 9 to 9:30 P. M. over Channels 2 and 5.

Herbert Quintana, 19 years old, of 215 West Twenty-third Street, was arraigned yesterday in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood, charged with attempting to rob a little church in South Jamaica that had been rifled by burglars no fewer than nine times since last March 23.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A Senate subcommittee said today that the Federal Government should emulate private industry in making greater and more effective use of incentive pay for its employes.

Harvey Matusow, a former Communist who recently has been cooperating with the Government in exposing Communist infiltration, yesterday answered Dr. Douglas McGregor, president of Antioch College, Ohio, who was quoted by The Associated Press last Friday as having said an alleged charge by Mr. Matusow that "500 Antioch students supported the Communist party line" was "utterly false."

Between now and Oct. 1, according to an announcement from the Office of Price Stabilization, more than half the nation's 500,000 grocers will be displaying the ceiling prices for many of their staple items. The 300 or so items listed will represent commodities accounting for about 40 per cent of all grocery sales.

A decline in demand for home furnishings, including electrical appliances, will occur in the next eight to ten years, Theodore H. Silbert, president of the Standard Factors Corporation, predicted yesterday. He said the shrinking market would develop because of the recent decline in marriages and a perceptible easing off in construction of new homes.

Some new room settings, planned for those who will be living in college dorms, might be of interest also to others who live in small quarters. On view at Lord Taylor, the settings were arranged to display a new collection of Craig cotton bedspreads of the type known as a "throw."

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- In spite of the recent prison riots, New Jersey has one of the best correctional systems in the country, Roberts J. Wright, one of the nation's leading authorities on penology, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Paul G. Hoffman, the first administrator of the Marshall Plan, denounced today as "fantastically false" accusations made by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, against that program and against General of the Army George C. Marshall.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (UP) -- President Truman said today that those who indulged in "character assassination" were violating the spirit on which this nation was founded.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Carol Durand of Kansas City failed to qualify her mount for the jump-off today in the Queen Elizabeth II Cup event, premier prize of the international horse show at London's White City Stadium.

A series of mishaps on the Long Island Rail Road last evening delayed forty-five trains and caused considerable inconvenience to passengers. It started at 4:30 P. M. when a train bound for Pennsylvania Station from the Rockaways developed electrical trouble while approaching the Woodside Station in Queens.

FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Edward H. Brooks, commanding general of the Second Army, announced today that he had approved the court martial sentence imposed on Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow for letting his dairy fall into Communist hands.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, today accused the Administration of "dragging its feet" for four years in the matter of international oil cartels.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 -- Rogers Hornsby's Reds gained their first home victory over the Dodgers this season when they took the second game of a twin bill, 5 -- 3, after Preacher Roe had shut them out, 3 -- 0, in the twilight contest.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 19 -- Attempts by private groups to suppress textbooks and control school study programs in the name of fighting communism must be opposed as a serious danger to the nation, the thirty-fifth national convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., was warned here today.

Heavy reorder business has clogged production lines of New York manufacturers of knitted sweaters. Producers here revealed that since the beginning of the month, the volume of orders had been unusually heavy and deliveries that retailers wanted before Labor Day or by Sept. 15 would be considerably delayed.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Frank Sedgman and his giant blond team-mate, Ken McGregor, made a brief but convincing bow in the second round of the seventy-first national doubles tennis championships today and gave every indication they would carry the crown back to Australia for the fourth successive year.

HOBOKEN, N J., Aug. 19 -Port of New York Authority representatives and Hoboken city officials seemed in complete agreement this afternoon after a two-hour conference in which final obstacles blocking a sublease of the city's Federally-owned piers to the authority were eliminated.

Mayor Impellitteri gave the long-vacant Traffic Commissioner's post yesterday to T. T. Wiley, who has been Acting Commissioner since July 1, 1951. The Mayor said that "the fact that I am appointing him shows that I have faith in him."

The ABC Steel Equipment Company, Inc., of this city, was accused yesterday by the National Production Authority of illegal use of 58,792 pounds of aluminum and twenty-five tons of steel in excess of permitted amounts. The alleged violations occurred during the first three quarters of 1951.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -Bernard Baruch celebrated his eighty-second birthday in the heart of a redwood forest in Humboldt County, north of here, today.

Those who are in any way responsible owe an apology to members of the armed services and their families if, absent from home, they are deprived of their vote Nov. 4 because they have answered the call to the colors.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- A slow infield roller by Sammy White with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today enabled the Red Sox to beat the second-place Indians, 6 -- 5, before 11,238 fans at Fenway Park.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- It is assumed in diplomatic circles here that the British Cabinet at its special meeting tomorrow will consider a reply to the recent Iranian Government note proposing negotiations on claims and counter-claims arising from the nationalization of the former British oil properties in Iran.

Because of mounting operating costs that no longer make steamship passenger services profitable, the United Fruit Line will terminate its liner cruise sailings out of the Port of New York, the old-time shipping concern announced yesterday.

Those arranging the American Legion's thirty-fourth annual national convention in New York next week are taking no chances on empty seats for the addresses of the two major Presidential candidates in Madison Square Garden next Monday and Wednesday afternoons.

Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol authorized yesterday the jailing of Patrolmen John F. Sullivan and Charles Goubeaud for refusing to answer questions at the departmental trial in which they and thirty-two other suspended policemen are charged with having protected the bookmaking operations of Harry Gross for graft.

The mysterious Henry W. Grunewald of Washington Was threatened yesterday with arrest and a forced appearance in Brooklyn Federal Court unless he voluntarily appeared Tuesday to explain why he failed to respond to a grand jury summons.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 20 -- The Hamburg State Opera Company may not be the greatest opera company in the world -- and it probably wouldn't claim to be so -- but it has at least proved to the Edinburgh Festival audiences that there is still tremendous life in the old dogs of opera.

The New York All-Stars turned back the United States All-Stars, 5 -- 4, in eleven innings in the seventh annual Hearst sandlot baseball game at the Polo Grounds last night before 14,652. It was New York's second victory in the series which started in 1946.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Thirty members of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division (Oklahoma National Guard) were drowned Monday when a flash flood swept them from a sandbar in the middle of a South Korean river, the Eighth Army reported today.

CHICAGO, Thursday, Aug. 21 -- A walkout of 25,000 members of the Farm Equipment Workers Council of the United Electrical Workers Union, independent, in ten plants of the International Harvester Company went into effect at 12:01 A. M. today, Chicago time, as attempts to form a new contract failed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 13:

The Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, which appears to be open, probably will be decided at a series of conferences next Thursday in which Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, nominee for President, is expected to be a participant.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 20 -- The first International Congress on Humanism and Ethical Culture opens here tomorrow with some 200 persons from ten countries attending.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, is expected to arrive at La Guardia Airport at 9 o'clock Sunday evening on a chartered United Airlines plane. He is scheduled to address the national convention of the American Legion in Madison Square Garden Monday at 3:15 P. M.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,348, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korea time:

SYRACUSE, Aug. 20 -- Business and industrial corporations have started a campaign to influence the nation's public schools, Harold Hanover, a spokesman for the New York State Federation of Labor, asserted here tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- Great Britain's national health plan was described today as a "great piece of legislation," by M. J. Tristram, president of the British Pharmaceutical Society.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address in Boise today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President:

Today's new film is "The Quiet Man," a romantic comedy in Technicolor, filmed in Ireland and directed by John Ford, at the Capitol. John Wayne, Maureen O'Hara, Barry Fitzgerald, Ward Bond and Victor McLaglen are featured.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Livingston W. Houston, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute of Troy, N. Y., presented tonight four honorary degrees in civil engineering to leaders in that field at a meeting in the Museum of Science and Industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Maj. William E. Barber, 32-year-old Marine of West Liberty, Ky., received the Medal of Honor today from President Truman in a White House ceremony.

A banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., will place on the market today a new issue of $19,000,000 of preferred stock of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation. The offering consists of 190,000 shares of $100 par value 5.5 per cent cumulative dividend stock priced at $100 a share.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 20 -- Lousiana's Democratic State Central Committee voted overwhelmingly today to pledge its ten Presidential electors to support the candidacy of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Truman again has placed the weight of the White House behind the United Nations' refusal to repatriate by force those North Koreans and Chinese Communists who have said they would resist being returned to their homelands.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 20 -- The whole town turned out this afternoon in a great show of Northern hospitality to two visiting Little Baseball League teams from the South -- then rooted a neighboring team from Hackensack to a 1-0 victory over the Frederick (Md.) All Stars, one of the guest outfits.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 21 -- Communist liaison officers at Panmunjom told the United Nations yesterday that the Allied Command had taken insufficient measures to curb violations of the neutrality of the area set aside for the Korean truce conferences.

Aggregate short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange hardly changed between July 15 and Aug. 15, dropping from 1,750,711 to 1,728,913 shares. Both figures exclude short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers. These rose from 69,959 to 79,847 shares.

HAMPTON BEACH, N. H., Aug. 20 -- Richard M. Nixon, Republican candidate for Vice President, asserted today that the time had come for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to choose between President Truman and the American people for support in the 1952 campaign.

TORONTO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Dick Savitt and Art Larsen, the two United States favorites to fight it out for the Canadian tennis championship, advanced to the quarter-final round today, but not without some anxious moments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 20 -- The Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, Walter Moreira Sales, arrived today on an unheralded visit and went immediately into consultation with Government figures connected with finance.

New York is a wonderful place. You can see almost anything if you know where to look. For instance, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon experts were X-raying a Peruvian condor at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals at 350 Lafayette Street.

The import regulation, C. P. R. 31, of the Office of Price Stabilization applies to importers and resellers of tin, including those who deal in the metal, its ore, concentrates, powder, scrap and alloy, James G. Lyons, regional director of the price agency, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A White House spokesman said today there was "not one word of truth" to reports that Secret Service bodyguards for Margaret Truman touched, pushed or otherwise molested Swedish citizens during the visit of the President's daughter to Stockholm.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday and 13 to 28 points net lower than on Tuesday.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Foreign bonds were again the most active sections of the London stock market today. Elsewhere price movements were narrow and insignificant.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- Delegates to the sixth International Grassland Congress joined thousands of Pennsylvania farmers today at a grassland field day sponsored by the agricultural extension service and the agricultural experiment station of Pennsylvania State College.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- This was the second successive afternoon during which the biggest chunk of the cash in a stakes race at Saratoga went to a horse owned by Ogden Phipps and trained by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons. Yesterday Busanda won the Diana Handicap, and today the 2-year- old filly Flirtatious made a runaway of the Spinaway.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 20 -- Martial law was reimposed today in Teheran and its environs in view of the impossibility of maintaining law and order without it. Brigadier Kazem Sheibani, director of the police, resigned and was replaced by Brigadier Aziz Kamal, former military governor of Abadan, and Brigadier Rezza Azimi was appointed military governor of Teheran.

An interesting contrast between the mass-produced and the designer-made Japanese ceramics is offered by two groups of objects now on view at the Fan Company, 225 Fifth Avenue. The ceramics are available through decorators there.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Official experts on Soviet affairs expect the long overdue meeting of the Communist party Congress in Moscow to set off a massive propaganda campaign.

The probability that Politburo member Georgi M. Malenkov will be Premier Stalin's successor when the latter dies or retires was sharply increased yesterday with the Moscow announcement that Mr. Malenkov will take Premier Stalin's former role as reporter for the Central Committee when the nineteenth Communist party Congress convenes in October.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The general outlines of the new production plan call for an increase in the gross industrial production of 70 per cent, compared with the 1950 figures.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- The protection of the succession in the leadership of the Soviet Union from internecine strife probably is the mainspring of the momentous changes in the organization of the topmost levels of the Communist party announced today.

ALTHOUGH many Americans normally combine upland game and waterfowl shooting with their big game hunting in Canada, there are many who go to the Dominion only for the bird shooting, and the seasons have now been announced in Ontario and New Brunswick.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Lefty Harvey Haddix pitched a five-hitter tonight in his major league debut as the Cardinals surged to their fifth straight victory, trouncing the Braves, 9 to 2, in a game called because of rain after seven and one-hail innings.

SUFFOLK AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Aug. 20 -- A show of extraordinarily precise flying of jet fighter planes was put on today by a team of four veteran pilots known as the Skyblazers, who flew their F-84 Thunderjets with skill that astounded the Air Force personnel here. The display was a preview of the demonstration the Skyblazers will give at the Air Force Association's annual meeting in Detroit over the Labor Day week-end.

A four-story building at 1881 Broadway, near Sixty-second Street, will be opened today as another branch of the Automobile Club of New York. The structure has been completely remodeled and has 21,000 square feet of floor space, William J. Gottlieb, president, said yesterday.

IT USED to be a mighty exclusive club in the old days and membership qualifications were so difficult that few could gain admittance. But a horde of strong-arm guys swept past the doorman a year ago and entered the rolls of the fashionable 20-Game Club, the ultra-select group of pitchers who have won twenty games or more in a season.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The defending champions, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor of Australia, and six of the other seven victorious seeded teams, moved into the quarter-finals of the men's national doubles tennis tournament today with straight-set victories at Longwood.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Okinawa-based Superforts smashed at two new Communist targets in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang last night with more than 350 tons of bombs. Civilians were warned in advance to leave the area.

The Soviet Union's fifth Five-Year Plan, announced in Moscow yesterday, sets production targets that, if realized by 1955 as planned, will give the Soviet Union a level of military economic potential more than twice as great as at the beginning of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Stephen A. Mitchell of Illinois took over today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and promptly made gestures of the strongest deference to President Truman as still "head of the Democratic party."

DOVER, Del., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Delaware Republicans today nominated candidates for state-wide office on a ticket headed by Senator John J. Williams, who seeks reelection, and Representative J. Caleb Boggs for Governor.
A 40-year-old man and a cane were more than a match for two hold-up men yesterday.

Pan American World Airways will begin operating Douglas DC-6B planes on its round-the-world and "Asia Express" routes on Sept. 1. The new service, scheduled for three flights a week, will cut five and a half hours from the current six and one-half days for the global run.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Second Baseman Connie Ryan smashed his twelfth homer, stole two bases and walked three times to pace the Phillies to a 3-1 victory over the cellar-dwelling Pirates today.

PADUCAH, Ky., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Union and management officials at the atomic energy plant here reached agreement today on a plan aimed at blocking any further unauthorized walkouts at the $1,000,000,000 installation.

Hard-coal producers complained yesterday that John L. Lewis' plan for a ten-day memorial stoppage of work by members of the United Mine Workers in honor of miners killed in accidents was a violation of the anthracite contract.
CAIRO, Aug. 20 -- A special committee to study the Egyptian Army's proposals for limited land ownership completed its labors today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 20 -- Marshal Tito informed a group of Turkish newspaper men today that his country was prepared to negotiate political, economic and military understandings with Turkey.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., notified the Todd Shipbuilding Company yesterday that it planned to call a walkout of 5,000 workers in the company's Brooklyn and Hoboken yards "any time after seven days from today."

A lot of candy is consumed in this country every year. In fact, last year each person spent $10.72, believed to be a record high, to satisfy the sweet tooth. Retail sales of candy and confectionery products in 1951 reached about $1,620,000,000.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Aug. 20 -- In an effort to comply with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's "clean up or else" order, pig farmers of this community today sponsored a "space deodorization" test, sup posed to remove the bouquet of well-slopped pigs and leave in its place sweet and clean air.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Truman issued an executive order today authorizing the Internal Revenue Bureau to open for public inspection tax cases where the Government had accepted compromises for less than the original amount demanded.

Casey Stengel's master plan for a home-stand drive by the Yankees to a fourth straight American League pennant is rapidly foundering on the rocks of faulty execution. Looking very bad in the process, the Bombers lost again to the White Sox yesterday. The reversal, witnessed by 14,456 fans at the Stadium, was suffered by a humiliating 12-3 count.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Righthander Carl Scheib batted in two runs and scored another on Ferris Fain's fourth hit of the game as the Athletics rallied for three runs in the eighth inning tonight to nose out the Tigers, 4 to 3. Two of the Detroit tallies came in the same inning on Walt Dropo's twentieth homer of the season with one on base.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Acting in his capacity of Secretary of the Central Committee of the All-Union Communist party, Premier Stalin announced today a call for a general party congress Oct. 5, at which Georgi M. Malenkov, Deputy Premier, will deliver the chief report.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP) -- America's marksmen fired almost until dusk today as class championships were decided at the fifty-third Grand American trapshoot. The 200-target, 16-yard event, which attracted 910 shooters, was a tune-up for tomorrow's preliminary handicap, one of the week's outstanding events over the 100-target route.

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company increased mill prices of its carpets yesterday, and many trade elements are convinced that the first industry-wide price increase in seventeen months will occur within two weeks. Other major mills are expected to increase their prices beginning today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Roy F. Priest, new Assistant Chairman of the Republican National Committee and head of its Women's division, took over her post today with the prediction that the votes of millions of women would assure victory for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in November.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, one-armed, one-legged Social Democratic leader, died in his bed tonight of a circulatory ailment. He was 56 years of age.
The Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation opened its 1952 appeal yesterday with a goal of $433,480 in public contributions to combat infantile paralysis in the Eastern states.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- James Blattman of Riverside, Conn., and Rocky Point appeared to hold a safe lead today in the Lightning Class of the fourth annual junior Manhasset Bay regatta after the second race of the three-day series.

Operations of Merck Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists at Rahway, N. J., during the first half of this year resulted in a net income of $5,115,395 after all charges, including $8,500,000 provision for taxes, according to the mid-year statement to be mailed to stockholders today.
