WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Air Force today released details of the conversation between a fighter pilot and an airport control tower just before the pilot crashed while chasing an unidentified aerial object. The incident occurred Jan. 7, 1948, near Godman Air Force Base, Fort Knox, Ky.

Raymond Russell Davioni, an unemployed press agent arrested last Friday with Minot Frazier Jelke 3d on procuring charges, was taken from City Prison yesterday to the District Attorney's office for questioning.

AT SEA ABOARD THE TROOPSHIP GEIGER, Aug. 20 -- A $20,000,000 luxury troopship came to life at 7:07 A. M. today when three tugs gently nosed the 17,000-ton Geiger into the Delaware River off the New York Ship-building Company's ways in Camden, N. J.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- Fred Wampler sank an 8-foot putt at the final hole for a birdie 4 and a tie at 210 with Shelly Mayfield of Rockaway Hunting Club in the 54-hole Long Island Golf Association open championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Rain prevented the resumption of hostilities today between the Giants and the Cubs at Wrigley Field and forced the clubs into another twin bill tomorrow, when the leaderless Durocher troupe will make its last appearance of the season here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- James A. Mullally, a lawyer in the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice, was suspended by Attorney General James P. McGranery today "pending an investigation of outside activities." He has been in the department for nine years.

STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Martin A. (Skip) Purcell, 17-year-old Indian Harbor Yacht Club skipper from Greenwich, recent winner of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship, led the Middle Atlantic District qualifiers for the Sears Cup national junior title series today.
China and Iran were accused yesterday of abetting opium addiction in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumption for, the period of June 29 to Aug. 2 averaged 28,858 bales for each working day. This compared with an average 32,003 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 34,798 for the June period this year.

The Swedish passenger vessel Anna Salen, delayed on her current voyage from Helsinki, Finland, by a collision off the northern tip of Scotland, has canceled her scheduled call here and will debark all her passengers at Halifax, N. S., on Tuesday.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- British experts on Soviet affairs today interpreted Moscow's decision to call the long overdue nineteenth party congress not as heralding any major change in Soviet policy but as a return to the normal pre-war practice of the Soviet Communist party.

What's the matter? Why such consternation merely because "hundreds of stars in the heavens are hissing at us"? News stories have recently reported "steady hisses" emitted by stars and picked up here by microwave radio and the tone of these stories has been fairly apprehensive, as if we should duck or something. Why?

The new draft statute of the Communist party of the Soviet Union published in Moscow yesterday formalizes and makes legal the tight control of that organization by Premier Stalin and his colleagues. They also tighten up party discipline and alter significantly the key organizational bodies at the head of the party power hierarchy.

Ten thousand persons attended a "Peace Under the Stars" rally and concert held last night in the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island by the New York Peace Institute. Fifty policemen also were present as a result of protests that had been made against the use of the stadium for the gathering. There was no picketing, however, and the program was not interrupted.

Twelve Massachusetts housing authorities announced yesterday plans for borrowing $30,818,000 on state guaranteed bonds. Bids for the bond issues will be received at the State Housing Board, Boston, on Sept. 4. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1 and will come due each Oct. 1 from 1953 to 1992.

HARTSELLE, Ala., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman tore the "no politics" label off his homecoming visit today and opened his Vice Presidential campaign with a rags-to-riches description of two decades under Democratic rule.
Might I ask the kind indulgence of your newspaper in printing the following, as clarifying the human side of the impending "Shanks Ouster."

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today told a demonstrative crowd of 19,000 Idaho citizens that the "great task" before Americans was to take a "middle road" toward peace and prosperity, preserving "social gains" but stopping the encroachments of Government control that he said would lead to tyranny.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 -- Billy Loes put the Dodgers back on the right track today as he went all the way for a 6-3 victory over the Reds at Crosley Field. The victory increased the Brooks' lead over the idle Giants to seven games.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 20 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will make a speech in Grand Rapids on the morning of Labor Day, party officials announced tonight.
VICTORIA, B. C., Aug. 20 -- Victoria banks have started discounting larger American silver coins at about 7 per cent on the dollar.

I wish to take exception to the reiterated accusation by some circles in this country that our foreign policy has been in gross error in its overemphasis on strengthening Western Europe to the supposed neglect of the Far East.

NAHA, Okinawa, Aug. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Robert S. Beightler, commander of the Ryukyus defense chain in the Western Pacific, made a personal visit to the Ryukyuan Legislature today to issue a warning that the Communists had seized a foothold in the islands and posed a real danger to their security.

MINOCQUA, Wis., Aug. 20 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said today he felt "very comfortable" about his prospects of winning the Presidency against Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee. The Democratic candidate set forth major points of his campaign as follows:

With the completion of the preliminary contests in the biennial team championship of the International Chess Federation, drawings were made last night for the balance of the meeting, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.

New York streets, if properly organized, can still handle a lot more traffic, T. T. Wiley, Acting Traffic Commissioner for the last fourteen months, said yesterday. Mr. Wiley, who will become Commissioner tomorrow, said his "greatest need right now" was engineers.

That brown paper bag that people were kicking all around the supermarket last Friday and Saturday contained $4,305. Next time, people will probably look before they kick. But if they do, they won't find Mrs. Julia Zold's $4,105. She decided yesterday to put it in a bank.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Still sporting New York license plates, a No. 11 bus that had just logged 12,000 miles in the United States and Canada, went back on its regular run past Trafalgar Square and Westminster Abbey today.

The first collection of fashions to be created and made in America by the Italian designer Fabiani was presented at a gala dinner showing last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The collection is exclusive for Russeks.

Recent criticism of the educational programs of private schools as a threat to democratic unity is indicative of further opposition to the extension of educational facilities under religious auspices, the Most Rev. Patrick J. McCormick, rector of Catholic University, Washington, declared yesterday.

Voting in Tuesday's fall primary was deplorably meager, as expected, and the results are of interest chiefly for what they show as to the strength of insurgency against regular party leadership, both Democratic and Republican.
The Aug. 15 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES publishes a picture of a pile of litter in the Bronx with headline "Littered Bronx Streets Assailed; Civic Groups Demand City Action."

MUOTATHAL, Switzerland, Aug. 20 -- Rescue workers today floated nearly one mile into famous "Hell Hole" cavern in an attempt to rescue a Swiss professor and three Swiss Boy Scouts who have been trapped for six days by rising water several hundred feet underground.

AROLSEN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- Officials of seven nations gathered in this town near Kassel today to dedicate a new three-story red brick building as the documents center of the International Tracing Service.
A pink-nosed redhead from Yorkville pulled a twelve-ounce catfish out of Central Park Lake yesterday, proving herself the scourge of competition as well as of the metropolitan fish population.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged five sets of competing corporations with operating under illegally interlocking directorates. Those named are:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 115,373 today, an increase of 688 since last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Government and private investments abroad returned $1,992,000,000 in interest and dividends last year, an increase of almost $250,000,000 from 1950.

Five big castings have arrived at the plant of the Aluminum Company of America at Lafayette, Ind., on the last leg of a trip from Dusseldorf, Germany, for use in a 13,200-ton extrusion press, believed to be the largest under construction in the country.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- Pope Pius has reminded German Roman Catholics that "as long as any believers exist, even if in chains, materialism cannot speak of victory" and urged them to feel and remain united across the political barriers that now divide their country.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Australia had a deficit of 576,000,000 Australian pounds ($1,296,000,000) -- the biggest in the dominion's history -- in her balance of payments during 1951-52, according to official figures issued today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Ralph Budd, board chairman of the Chicago Transit Authority, confirmed today that the authority had reached an agreement to buy the Chicago Motor Coach Company and had employed five financial firms to market a $20,000,000 bond issue to pay for the bus company and for other improvements.

Being a purely sociable and fraternal organization of people who collect coins, medals and the like, the American Numismatic Association closed its five-day convention here yesterday with only one project in view: It will try to persuade the Government to issue a 25-cent coin to commemorate the Pine Tree Shilling of 1652.
SEATTLE, Aug. 20 -- Favorites tumbled during two rounds of the United States amateur championship today at the Seattle Golf Club as the field was reduced to sixteen.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 20 -- A Swiss executive who once won a medal for helping the United States during the war with Japan today took the oath of United States citizenship on a hospital bed where he is suffering, from a heart attack.

Arthur Krock's able discussion Aug. 14 of the continuous organic character of the United States Senate as established with the Republic, that is to say beginning with its first session and by the Constitution, is directed to present political issues concerning civil rights.

General Eisenhower fired the opening gun in his campaign for the White House last night when in a frankly political but also statesmanlike speech he repudiated the extremists of both left and right and proclaimed his own philosophy and policy to be that of the Middle Road.

The stock market made a piece-meal recovery yesterday with the help of the railroad and television shares. The best increases were not maintained through to the close, for prices wavered on a lack of support in the afternoon. It was a continuation of the drab sessions of last week.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 20 -- A cache of the long-sought records of Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, who was dismissed last year as deputy chief of the Chinese Nationalist Air Force and sued for an accounting of $25,000,000 in procurement funds, was discovered yesterday in the basement of a house in Great Neck where Mme.

Wage review negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association, acting in behalf of employing stevedores, will be resumed at 11 A. M. Monday. The joint talks began Aug. 8 when the union presented a series of proposals. Management requested an opportunity to study the demands, and no further sessions have been held.
BOSTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The Indians scored ten runs in the third inning today to swamp the Red Sox, 18 -- 8, and even the three-game series.

Although I was born in Paris and brought up with European standards, I feel that I am 100 per cent American, and am proud of being so. I have had all my schooling here, including attendance at Columbia University. But the one subject which is never brought up in our schools is etiquette -- social conduct -- how to behave one's self with others, and social obligations toward our fellow-citizens.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- If this country had adequate probation and parole services, there would be less chance that tragedies like the recent slaying by Bayard Peakes of an office girl at Columbia University would occur, Will C. Turnbladh, one of the nation's leading authorities on probation and parole, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The educational section of a new G. I. Bill of Rights for Korean veterans went into effect today, but a legal snag may force some former service men to pay their own school bills at the start.

The civilian and military personnel of Fort Monmouth, N. J., consistent contributors to the blood program, donated 384 pints Tuesday, the first day of a three-day drive in which 900 pints had been pledged, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Swedish Foreign Minister, Oesten Unden, said tonight ha had the greatest sympathy with Margaret Truman's desire to avoid press photographers sometimes. He also deplored what he called "personal tactlessnessses" Which marred "an objective discussion" of her Stockholm visit. He did not define what he meant by "personal tactlessnesses."
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- President Truman is considering a world tour after he retires from the White House January, Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies declared today.
College graduates entering the Sept. 30 Marine Corps Officer Candidate class will have an opportunity to become aviators, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Warren A. Leitner, Procurement Officer.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- A committee of the House of Commons, considering a problem that has arisen many times with the Voice of America, recommended today that the British Government's grants for radio broadcasting to overseas countries should be made on a five-year basis, so that there could be some long-term continuity in the service.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Claims for $1,424,067 in taxes and penalties have been brought by the Federal Government against Henry M. Garsson.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott, the world heavyweight champion, and Challenger Rocky Marciano formally signed contracts today for their fifteen-round title bout at Municipal Stadium. Sept. 23.

ALPINE, N. J., Aug. 20 -- Alberta Moeltner of The Knoll scored a second straight 44, 43 -- 87 today and won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's thirty-six-hole junior girls' championship at the Aldecress Golf Club.

The Fire Department served official notice yesterday that it wished to retain at least six of the forty-nine fire-fighting companies recommended for elimination by consultants hired by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

Wholesale food prices pushed ahead to another new high for 1952 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Dun Bradstreet food index. The index now stands at $6.69, the highest since Nov. 27 last year, and compares with $6.66 for the preceding week and $6.93 in the comparable week of 1951.

LIVINGSTON, N. J., Aug. 20 -- A "Congress of Municipalities" in the West Essex County area to meet community problems created by the post-war building boom was proposed today by Mayor Vernon H. Wisdom of this township. He announced that he was inviting all elected officials in the eleven municipalities in the area to participate.

New York, locale of many unusual sights, has now had the novel experience of observing employers picketing a union. Members of the newly formed Independent Association of Women's Apparel Manufacturers, a group of nonunion jobbers, has picketed briefly the offices of a local union of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union with placards demanding "recognition" of their association and opposing the alleged "monopoly" of contractual relations between the union and four specialized employers' associations.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Aug. 20 -- The Jaclyn Stable of Dr. Leon Levy, executive vice president of the Atlantic City course, furnished the winner of the featured Merry Widow purse today when Bobs Alibi raced the mile and a sixteenth on turf in near-track-record time.

State Senator Harold I. Panken disputed yesterday the accuracy of an unofficial tally of Democratic primary votes that showed him beaten for renomination by 171 votes in the Twenty-first Senate District by Julius A. Archibald. Mr. Panken asserted he had won by 239 votes.

Out of the bubbling activity and record volume of the potato futures market on the New York Mercantile Exchange a new pattern has emerged. The last three days have seen heavy liquidation and numerous margin calls, but fresh buying interest appears to have been entering the market at the lower levels.

State Senator Harold I. Panken disputed yesterday the accuracy of an unofficial tally of Democratic primary votes that showed him beaten for renomination by 171 votes in the Twenty-first Senate District by Julius A. Archibald. Mr. Panken asserted he had won by 239 votes.

Mayor Impellitteri rejected yesterday a proposal by the newly formed Citizens Traffic Safety Board that city executives concerned with traffic matters be named as an advisory committee to cooperate with the civic organization.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (UP) -- The delegates headed today for a showdown with the union's Independents, a minority party, over its Unitypo program.

DEAL, England, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The American wartime Liberty ship Western Farmer broke in two and sank tonight in the storm-lashed Strait of Dover, twenty miles east of Deal, three hours after crashing with the Norwegian tanker Bjor Gholm.
Resort and spring fashions created especially for Cohama Fabrics by leading European courturiers were shown to the press at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. It was Cohama's second annual collection.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- United States authorities here have asked the State Department for a final ruling on the citizenship of Charles A. Noble, naturalized American who reappeared in West Berlin yesterday after seven years of detention in the Soviet zone of Germany.

A decline last week of 969,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 115,979,000 barrels, compared with 116,930,000 a week earlier and 126,286,000 a year ago.
ATHENS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Greek newspapers today quoted United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy as saying that Greece should hold a general election soon to stabilize the nation's economy.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- Disturbed by reports that the defense goals set for 1952 by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council might not be attained, permanent representatives of the council reviewed the outlook at a meeting today and were reported to have agreed that these goads would be approximately reached by the end of this year.

GENEVA, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A sharp increase in poliomyelitis in northwest Europe and in the United States was reported today by the weekly health bulletin of the United Nations World Health Organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Buying demand generally was sluggish in grain and soybean trading today. Prices were depressed sharply at times, the Canadian grain statistical situation apparently being too bearish to permit any great amount of buying. Canadian crops are maturing rapidly and will soon be out of frost danger.

The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries increased sales of goods and services in the first six months this year to $450,029,790 from $413,130,888 in the corresponding period a year ago, but earnings declined.

Those with a penchant for fish usually have a favorite sauce to serve with it. "Down East" in Maine, the ubiquitous boiled salt cod customarily is accompanied by a drawn butter sauce made with butter, flour and hot water, flavored with lemon juice, salt and pepper and topped with sliced, hard-cooked eggs and sometimes bits of fried, diced salt pork.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Five proposed plant expansions for the production of new, antibiotic drugs were approved today for Federal tax assistance by the Defense Production Administration.
CAMP DRUM N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The city of Watertown fell to "Aggressorland" forces today after the Seventy-seventh Division had earlier emerged victorious from an engagement with other "invaders."
OSLO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Llanoria, America's Olympic champion, made a daring run over wind-swept waters today to win the second race of the International six-meter Gold Cup yacht competition.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Premier Stalin and Chou En-lai, Communist China's Premier, opened discussions tonight on the general question of Soviet-Chinese relations, with particular reference to the problems of economy, defense and international commitments.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 -- The convention of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., urged today the enactment of the Murray-Dingell-Rhodes Bill as a modification of the Taft-Hartley Act.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 20 -- A typically strong-worded letter by Long Island State Park Commissioner Robert Moses was mailed here today to Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, protesting Air Force plans to extend a Republic Aviation Corporation jet plane runway at Farmingdale to within 500 feet of Southern State Parkway.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday its 126th consecutive quarterly dividend at the rate of $2.25 a share for payment Oct. 15. Approximating $80,000,000, the dividend will go to more than 1,100,000 shareowners in 19,000 cities and towns.

The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries increased sales of goods and services in the first six months this year to $450,029,790 from $413,130,888 in the corresponding period a year ago, but earnings declined.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Buying demand generally was sluggish in grain and soybean trading today. Prices were depressed sharply at times, the Canadian grain statistical situation apparently being too bearish to permit any great amount of buying. Canadian crops are maturing rapidly and will soon be out of frost danger.

A. S. Lipsett, whose letter, "Labor's Role in Politics," appeared in your esteemed paper on Aug. 16, leads off by stating that one can hardly take exception to the sentiments recently expressed by A. F. L. President William Green to the effect that "we (organized labor) are not neutral" and that the old Gompersian credo of electing friends and defeating enemies by no means implies neutrality but is rather a call to action.
MINOCQUA, Wis., Aug. 21 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, hung a tentative "me-too" tag today on his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that he had subpoenaed the books of a Queens contractor and ordered him to appear immediately to answer questions about the allegedly improper building of sewers in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -The Public Health Service said today that the number of new poliomyelitis cases reported had risen 17 per cent last week but cautiously predicted that this year's outbreak was approaching its peak.

Donald R. Wilson, national commander of the American Legion, arrived here yesterday for the Legion's thirty-fourth annual convention and asserted that the delegates would demand a more vigorous foreign policy and a military victory in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Senate investigators reported today that the Air Force had disciplined three officers and penalized a Chicago company after investigating alleged favoritism in procurement.

Now that Bernard Gimbel, president of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, and Howard Cullman, a gentleman with more than a passing interest in the state of Broadway's health, have begun to blow upon the still-warm ashes of a number of proposals to revive the theatre in New York we may expect another rash of diagnoses and suggested treatments from all sides.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Aug. 16 were 2 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This was the second consecutive week in which sales rose 2 per cent. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

GROUNDS, Md., Aug. 21 -- A new version of the Army jeep was unveiled in a mud bath this afternoon. Prettified externally, packing more horsepower under its hood and more cushion in its driver's and passengers' seats, the reformed jeep passed a press demonstration with flying jounces.

Reversible coats featured a college and career fashion show held last night at Namm - Loeser's, Brooklyn. One was a gray tweed fleece for daytime wear, reversing to black velvet for evening. Another was a three-quarter cocoa fleece for town wear, reversing to a checked fleece for the country.

Three new fills will open at first-run theatres this morning. "What Price Glory," Twentieth Century-Fox's Technicolor remake of the Maxwell Anderson-Laurence Stallings play, with James Cagney, Corinne Calvert, Dan Dailey and William Demarest, is at the Roxy.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that more than 95 per cent of its affiliated radio stations had approved the network's revised discount structure for advertisers. Effective Monday, nighttime rates will be reduced 25 per cent and daytime rates increased about 5 per cent.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 21 -- For the first time in its thirty-six-year history the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., voted overwhelmingly here today not to defend any teacher proved to be a Communist party member.

Beardsley Ruml, whose appointment as chairman of the finance committee of the Democratic National Committee was announced on Wednesday by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, nominee for President, promised yesterday a fund-raising campaign that would be "cheerful, efficient, convenient and successful."

Complete control of Union Pacific Stages and Interstate Transit Lines, bus lines operating between Chicago, Los Angeles and Portland, Ore., under the name of Overland Greyhound, will be acquired by the Greyhound Corporation on Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The American Civil Liberties Committee asked Mayor Martin H. Kennelly today to lift a police censorship ban on a documentary film, "Latuko," which was barred on the ground of "nudity and cruelty to animals."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 16 totaled 805,704 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Mrs. Raymond Russell Davioni, a singer known professionally as Gloria Sinclair, was committed late yesterday afternoon in $10,000 bail as a material witness in the vice inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The two most prominent Democrats in the nation were quick today to see and exploit the fact that, in his Boise speech, General Eisenhower repeated in broad terms criticisms of the New Deal-Fair Deal ideologies that were made by Wendell L. Willkie and Thomas E. Dewey in their unsuccessful campaigns for the Presidency.

The Advertising Federation of America announced yesterday that for the sixth year its high school essay contest, which has brought many young men and women into advertising, has been approved by the National Association of Secondary School Principals.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 22 -- United Nations warplanes in more than 100 sorties yesterday knocked out a big North Korean cement plant at Osu, just southeast of Sariwon, about thirty-five miles north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused Academy Knitted Fabrics Corporation of New York today of failing to reveal to purchasers that the brushed rayon fabrics it manufactures and sells were highly flammable.

MADRID, Aug. 21 -- American buyers have made their final purchases at the "Fashion Festival of Spain," this country's first organized entrance into the international fashion world. Summing up of the shows indicated, according to Spaniards, that the venture was a success.

Martin's will offer hints on good grooming for teen-agers, along with a presentation of its latest fall fashions, at a show to be held at the Brooklyn store tomorrow at 11 A. M. The steps recommended for good grooming, which were demonstrated at a press preview yesterday, included neatness of dress, good posture, a becoming and trim coif and use of discreet make-up.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Improvement in British Government securities, which gained up to 12s 6d ($1.75) spread a cheerful tone to most other sections of the stock market here today. Volume of business however remained fairly small.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Red Sox beat the Indians, 4 to 1, today to take the series, two games to one. It was the first series in a month to be lost by second-place Cleveland, which remained one behind the league-leading Yankees.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 -- The curious process of arriving at the final results of Mexico's July 6 elections now is in full swing. The proceedings have advanced sufficiently to confirm the clean sweep of the Presidency, the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate garnered by the ruling Party of Revolutionary Institutions.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 21 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh struck hard today at his fellow members of the Iranian wealthy class, who have considered themselves above the law, by decreeing the creation of commissions throughout the country to collect the immense arrears of unpaid back taxes of the rich for the last ten years.
ISLE ROYALE, Mich, Aug. 21 -- Wildlife Service officers gave up in disgust today and pronounced four timber wolves as howling failures at answering the call of the wild.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Britain's steel industry, taken over by the former Labor Government, as a going concern, is continuing to make money under public ownership.

The stock market remained in a vacuum yesterday both price-wise and in volume. In a further contraction of business that reduced transactions to 800,000 shares, against 960,000 on Wednesday, prices idled along through most of the session although on balance the list tipped to the higher side.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer tonight lowered the boom on Mario Lanza by formally notifying the National Broadcasting Company that the tenor was in default of his contract for failing to report for work in "The Student Prince" and therefore could not do his weekly radio show over the network tomorrow night.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers, C. I. O., has been voted a $15,000 per year salary increase by the union's international executive board. Mr. Murray's salary as head of the union has been $25,000 a year since 1948. He receives no salary as president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The antics of a young television clown named Ernie Kovacs have undergone a change since he was first seen here last summer. At that time Mr. Kovacs was piped in from Philadelphia by the National Broadcasting Company as a summer replacement.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday two bills already passed by the City Council creating an independent Department of Air Pollution Control and defining its duties and powers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Production lines of eight International Harvester Company plants in three states were halted today as 23,800 members of the United Electrical Workers' Farm Equipment Council (independent) went out on strike.

Further protests are being made to the New York Cotton Exchange against the proposal for Saturday closing throughout the year. Yesterday the Greenwood Cotton Exchange, which deals only in spot cotton, sent a telegram to the New York Cotton Exchange urging that it remain open for trading in futures on Saturdays in September, October, November and December.

Insurance costs on 3,500,000 private passenger cars and commercial automobiles in this state will go up on Monday. The liability rate increase, the seventh to be given to the insurance companies since World War II, was announced yesterday by the State Insurance Department.
That was an inopportune question that Boris Brysman asked the motorcycle patrolman: "What would you do with a fellow who got six or seven tickets and didn't answer them?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Mutual Security Agency charged today that price discrimination practiced on a world-wide scale by international oil companies had increased by more than $50,000,000 the cost to American taxpayers of oil bought for other countries under the foreign aid program.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- The 3-cent-an-hour pay rise for approximately 1,000,000 automobile workers will bring to 26 cents an hour the total cost of living allowance provided automatically under the escalator contract initiated by General Motors in May, 1948.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Air Force lost several million dollars and more than a year trying to develop an advance radar fire control system for guns on B-47 atomic bombers.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- E. G. Beckey, 45-year-old engineer of Rock Falls, Ill., today won the championship but little of the money in the preliminary handicap at the fifty-third Grand American trapshoot.

Operations of the Torrington Company and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30, showed a net income of $3,870,185, equal to $2.37 a share, according to the report released yesterday by Lester J. Ross, president.

After an incomprehensible delay for which no explanation was ever offered the important post of Traffic Commissioner has been filled by Mayor Impellitteri. T. T. Wiley, Acting Commissioner for over a year, has been appointed, just as so many interested in the subject had been urging.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower charged today that "really terrible blunders" led to the Korean war but he agreed that, once the Communists had invaded South Korea, the United States had no acceptable alternative but to resist promptly with American troops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today that he would try to persuade Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, to campaign for a compulsory fair employment law.

STORRS, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Ways in which young children can learn to understand more clearly the wise use of money and materials were discussed this week by elementary teachers during a workshop on family financial security education at the University of Connecticut. The workshop, which began Aug. 4, ended today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- Under the provisions for increased production in the fifth Five-Year Plan, which will end in 1955, heavy industry in the Soviet Union was pointed today toward the greatest quantitative expansion in the history of Russia.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The Fifth American Dance Festival, sponsored by Connecticut College, opened here tonight. A capacity audience attended the first of four evening performances, which highlighted the modern dance season.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 18 to 30 points net higher on active months than on Wednesday.

Purchasing activity on popular price dresses, lagging behind other types of women's apparel, is due for a revival immediately after Labor Day. Manufacturers have been disappointed in the slowness of re-orders, they said yesterday, but feel certain that their product soon will be in as strong a demand as it was during the early summer.

Two pork cuts that fit particularly well into the small family's week-end menu plans are the smoked daisy and the smoked picnic ham. Both might be described as miniature hams with a rich, smoky flavor similar to that of the larger cut, and both are of a size more easily managed in the household of three or four.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -Bob Cain pitched a five-hitter as the Browns defeated Washington, 8 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Senators had won the first game, 3 -- 2, on Frank Shea's five-hitter.

Consolidated net earnings of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and all subsidiaries, including Wesco Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc., amounted to $962,493, equal to 35 cents a share on 2,769,485 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the report yesterday covering the twenty-six weeks to June 28.

TORONTO, Aug. 21 -- The Canadian National Exhibition will be opened tomorrow by Governor General Vincent Massey and promises to be even better than all its predecessors, its organizers say. Attendance is expected to reach 3,000,000.
Blood donors at Fort Monmouth, N. J., contributed more than 1,000 pints of blood to the American Red Cross in a three-day drive ended yesterday.

The urgent need for political, economic and military unification of Western Europe as the only means to assure its survival is again emphasized by three major developments now taking place in Moscow. There is inclination in official quarters, both here and abroad, to discount these developments as "routine" and unlikely to produce any great changes in Soviet policies.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- One of the problems being studied by officials of the North Atlantic Council in connection with the 1953 program, soon to be discussed, is the extent to which Western Europe can produce the arms for its own forces and thus become less dependent on United States production.

YONKERS, Aug. 21 -- Whether it was the muddy track or the blazing thirty-second final quarter that was responsible, the fact remains that Good Time, the wealthiest and generally acknowledged best pacer in the land, could do no better than third place in the $25,000 Yonkers Pacing Derby tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

The creation of a permanent Transit Advisory Commission of three city officials with the rank of Commissioner, or its equivalent, was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate on motion of Mayor Impellitteri.

TORONTO, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Tiny Felicissimo Ampon of the Philippines played one of his greatest games today to eliminate top-seeded Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., 6 -- 3, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the quarter-finals of the Canadian Lawn Tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- During the week ended Aug. 20, member bank reserves increased $131,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The steer, mare and pony seen walking in Thirty-fourth Street just west of Eighth Avenue yesterday noon had, as it happens, no connection with next week's American Legion convention. They and their young companions had come to New York to publicize the 107th annual Dutchess County Fair, which opens a five-day stand next Tuesday at Rhinebeck.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 14 -- The Soviet Union is attempting to regain the position of influence in the religious affairs of Jerusalem once enjoyed by Czarist Russia. It is doing this by reinforcing the staff of the Russian Orthodox Church, by backing the Russian Palestine Society's claim to extensive property here, by generous use of funds and by devious efforts to gain control of the Greek Orthodox Church throughout Palestine.

MAYWOOD, N. J., Aug. 21 -- A three-truck accident closed U. S. Route 17, one of northern New Jersey's busiest highways, for six hours today, cut off electric power in three communities and spread a 5,000-gallon coating of oil over a one block section of the highway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The American Zionist Council made public today a letter from its chairman, Louis Lipsky, to Secretary of State Dean Acheson urging a grant of $49,900,000 in military assistance to Israel.

Reporting on operations for the six months ended on June 30, the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced yesterday a net profit of $2,349,238 after a $271,700 tax credit, while $5,111,079 was earned in the 1951 period after deducting $12,029,700 for tax charges.

S. B. Cousins has been named president of the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company with headquarters in Omaha, effective on Sept. 1. it was announced yesterday. Mr. Cousins has resigned as vice president and general manager and a director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, effective that date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a new rise in the consumers' price index to another high record today. Many wage increases, including 3 cents an hour for more than 1,000,000 automobile workers, will follow. The trend has been steadily upward since last February.

Representatives of forty civic and trade associations and business concerns met at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday to help organize a new city-wide committee to fight the higher rates just imposed upon the city's largest commercial users of Consolidated Edison electric power.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Hammered into submission by the potent bat of Hank Sauer in the curtain-raiser, the Giants rallied at Wrigley Field today to split a twin bill with the Cubs and maintain their position, seven games behind the idle Dodgers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt said today that horse racing throughout the country would be ruined if off-track betting were legalized. He is president of the Thoroughbred Racing Association.

Stockholders of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation will meet at Saltville, Va., on Sept. 30 to vote on the company's merger with E. R. Squibb Sons. Squibb shareholders will meet for the purpose on the same date here. Stockholders of record on Sept. 2 will be eligible to vote at the meetings.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 21 (UP) -- Blazing around the Elks Country Club course in 6-under-par 66's, Dr. Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, Tenn., and Ted Kroll, New Hartford, N. Y., tied for the eighteen-hole lead today in the third annual $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf championship.
New techniques for obtaining chlorophyll from alfalfa have been developed by the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company of Minneapolis, a processor of farm crops, it was disclosed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Influenced by another big advance in soybean futures, grain prices rallied sharply following a lower trend in early trading today. Commission buying broadened on the dips and selling pressure diminished, making it easier to rally the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- A Justice Department attorney under suspension for "outside activities" resigned today, and Congressional investigators prepared to aim their fire at another "responsible official."

New light on the military situation in the Orient, as reflected by the views of competent observers in two countries, reveals anxiety in some quarters about the well-organized Communist strength in Japan, but indicates increasing stability in Burma.
Keen competition marked play in the first round of the finals in the team title tournament of the International Chess Federation, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland, yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- United States military authorities and Japanese police today said they had arrested some American service men and seventy-three Japanese, Chinese and Korean nationals in connection with what they called a $3,000,000-a-year black market ring that feeds dollars to the Communists.
MARIETTA, Ohio, Aug. 21 -- George White, former Governor of Ohio, celebrated his 80th birthday here today.

It was impossible at all times to withhold a full measure of admiration and respect for Kurt Schumacher, the German Social Democratic leader, who died on Wednesday. His indomitable courage, his high ideals, his years of suffering and struggle in the causes of anti-nazism and anti-communism, his devotion to the working-class movement, his intense patriotism -- these are all qualities that cannot be denied or minimized.

The Argentine luxury liner Rio Tunuyan, one of three sister ships maintaining bimonthly cruise service between New York and Buenos Aires, will be renamed the Evita today in honor of the late Evita Peron, wife of the Argentine President. The vessel is now at the Latin-American port and is scheduled to depart for New York next Friday.

EVERYONE suddenly has started to feel awfully sorry for Jersey Joe Walcott. The poor, old guy has just signed his death warrant, so to speak, by agreeing to place his head on the guillotine in Philadelphia on Sept. 23. Then the chopper will descend, the chopper being Rocky Marciano. If this doesn't finish off Jersey Joe as a person, it will finish him off as the heavyweight champion of the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Public Advisory Board for Mutual Security today selected Daniel W. Bell to be its acting chairman during the forthcoming study of United States foreign trade policies it will undertake at the direction of President Truman.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- "Affairs of State" was well received tonight at its London premiere at the Cambridge Theatre under the auspices of Emile Littler and Tom Arnold. After seven curtain calls the audience was still applauding vigorously when the house pianist lowered the boom by playing "God Save the Queen."

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Pravda said today the Soviet Communist party would go into its ninteenth All-Union Congress Oct. 5 "firmly rallied around its Central Committee and around the great leader and teacher of all progressive humanity, Comrade Stalin."

CAIRO, Aug. 21 -- The special military tribunal that was to try the instigators of the cotton mill riots of Aug. 13 concluded its hearings today at the mill town of Kafr el Dawar near Alexandria. The prosecutor demanded the death penalty for twenty-seven of the twenty-nine accused.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Three judges of the United States Court of Appeals held David L. Behncke in contempt of court today because he refused to relinquish his post and powers as president of the embattled Air Line Pilots' Association.

The Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester, declared yesterday that criticism of private schools as a "threat to democratic unity" constituted "a veiled attempt on the part of secularists to gain control of the educational system in this country."
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 21 -- Dr. Julian Huxley, the British biologist, offered "evolutionary humanism" tonight as a new world religion.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. Ned D. Cherry and Ned Jr., of Maplewood displaced Mrs. J. B. Balding and Bob Balding of Creek as the Metropolitan Golf Association's mother-son champions today at the Maplewood Country Club.

humorous novel y Clyde Brion Davis, author of "The Anointed" and "The Great American Novel," will be ,published on Sept. 17 by Lippincott. "Thud!bury," the book's title, is also the name of the protagonist, a man of influence, whose story is told by hi friend and admirer, the editor of the town's newspaper.

Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, accepted yesterday an invitation from Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, to be chairman of the Democratic State Convention Thursday evening. The convention, to be held in the Commodore Hotel, will nominate a candidate for United States Senator.

BELMAR, N. J., Aug. 21 -- School tuna that scale seventy-five pounds or more are just about as plentiful off the New Jersey coast as fresh run salmon in the Musconetcong River, although there may be those (especially contestants in the New Jersey tuna derby) who consider a seventy-five-pounder in the "giant" class.

Coats and suits of richly textured fabrics for fall were previewed yesterday in Ohrbach's Gray Room. Thick, nubby woolens; tightly curled poodle fabrics, tweeds as soft as cashmere, long-haired zibelines and elegant cross dyes in subtle colors shared interest.

AT SEA ABOARD THE TROOPS GEIGER, Aug. 21 -- Army transports free of cold germs were envisioned as an early likelihood today when air conditioning experts aboard this $20,000,000 luxury Army transport disclosed that it was the first ship ever to be equipped with a cold germ killer known as triethylene glycol vapor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Government today assigned slightly larger shares of metal to the four largest auto producers and cut allowances to seven smaller companies.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. William Spencer and Paul Kelly, both from Sleepy Hollow, captured low gross laurels today in the annual mixed scotch foursomes tournament conducted by the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.
The first round of negotiations between hard coal producers and the United Mine Workers ended yesterday and the parties agreed to resume talks next Tuesday in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

The treatment of the older worker by private industry is wicked, particularly the ruthless cold shoulder given the older worker seeking work for which he is qualified. Business men roundly condemn socialism, but work for it in their attitude toward the older worker.

WESTERLY, R. I., Aug. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Eliiott R. Thorpe, United States Army, retired, today confirmed that he removed himself from the race for United States Representative from Rhode Island's Second Congressional District because he has been under investigation by the Army's Counter-Intelligence Corps.

The arrest last night of four 18-year-old boys on Sullivan Law charges spurred an investigation into the manner in which they allegedly obtained several items of ordnance from a Coast Guard station and a well-guarded military installation in the Rockaways in Queens.

VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The concept of telling a customer exactly what he is buying is gaining among retailers. This is the view of Ephraim Freedman, director of the Macy Bureau of Standards, expressed on the eve of the bureau's completion of twenty-five years as a going concern and an important unit of the big New York department store.
Prices of most commodity futures on the local exchanges moved lower yesterday. Hides, rubber, tin, zinc and coffee futures ended the day with net losses, while lead and sugar futures held firm.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Dr. J. Quintin Griffiths Jr. today told the American Pharmaceutical Association of an improved drug that is more effective than its predecessor in strengthening weak blood vessels.

Biggest news to come out of the collection of French millinery imports and adaptations, shown yesterday to the press by Gladys Belle at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street, is that the little hat again is the undisputed favorite. Added to this is emphasis on the turban, the use on many sides of scarf drapes, and the continuing favor of the profile slant and back movement.

PENANG, Malaya, Aug. 21 -- Gen. Sir. Gerald Templer, the High Commissioner for Malaya, threatened today to banish seventy-nine natives from their village "forever" unless they ceased aiding Communist terrorists.

SEDALIA, Mo., Aug. 21 (AP) -- A tornado raged through the Missouri State Fair Grounds early this morning and in less than five minutes killed one man, injured seventeen others and caused extensive property damage.

WELDON, N. C., Aug. 21 (UP) -A clerk of the New York State Supreme Court, his wife and their two children were killed today when their automobile was in a head-on collision with a large truck four miles south of here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- There will be no endorsement for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, when Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, goes into Wisconsin to speak during the national campaign.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane, owner of Brookmeade Stable, had reason to be elated today. One of her pet horses, the 7-year-old His Boots, won the fifty-third running of the Beverwyck Steelpechase. He made an eight-length score in the role of $11.40 third choice.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Age prevailed over youth today in the most exciting contest the five-division national doubles championships of the United States Lawn Tennis Association has produced to date.

Beef and pork price rises have been halted, temporarily at least, but veal and lamb costs took an upward turn this week. Butter advanced slightly. Chickens -- fryers and roasters -- and eggs continued their climb. Good news this week-end is confined to fresh produce and fish, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The Westchester Country Club team of Mario Del Guerico, Fred W. Mayer, Tommy Goodwin and the home professional, Mickey Homa, won the ninth Jack Hoffhine Memorial golf tournament over the West course today with a total score of 289.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 21 (AP) -Unitsd Nations Gourmand coriqz 1,349, for the tenty-four hours 6 A. Air., Friday, Korea time:

Progress is reported by a syndicate of American showmen eager to make it possible for Robert Morley to arrive here in his substantial London hit, "The Little Hut," under the auspices of John C. Wilson. Word just received is that the star has accepted the syndicate's offer to purchase his 20 per cent slice of the Andre Roussin-Nancy Mitford comedy.
BALLATER, Scotland, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- A bouquet of white roses and gladioli were wired to Princess Margaret by an unidentified admirer in Danville, Ill., on her twenty-second birthday today.

A committee of five nationally prominent American Federation of Labor leaders, in a report to William Green, federation president, has condemned as "biased and dangerous" the report of the state board of inquiry that investigated the long dock strike here last fall.

Advancing seasonally for the third successive week, business borrowing from banks rose $34,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The increase cut the decline in such credits since the first of this year to $377,000,000, against an expansion of $670,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug 21 (AP) -- Wilmer Mizell, rookie left-hander of the Cardinals, pitched the high-flying Redbirds to their sixth straight victory and his seventh in a row tonight in a 3-2 duel with Southpaw Warren Spahn of the Braves.

Your berating of the Perons in your editorial regarding the inflationary spiral in Argentina is undoubtedly warranted. It does, however, bring to mind certain criticisms of the present American Administration made by you in connection with the rising cost of living in this country.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 -- The administration forces of the International Typographical Union won a decisive victory here tonight on a roll-call vote that ordered continuation of the union's "Unitypo, Inc.," which operates newspapers in cities where union printers or union mailers strike.

An attendant at the Willowbrook State School for Mental Defectives on Staten Island, who formerly had been an inmate of the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, was held without bail yesterday on a charge of having beaten two boy patients with a broom handle.

Who among us can keep reading day after day the little news items from South Africa without a feeling of dismay? There is something degrading to humanity about these stories of Negroes being arrested -- thirty, fifty, a hundred at a time -- fined, jailed and now flogged.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- About 80,000 Roman Catholics, most of them from the Soviet zone of Germany, assembled in West Berlin today to hear messages of encouragement from leading clerics, including Pope Pius XII.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Jean Monnet, president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community (Schuman plan) entered into discussions with British officials today on the functions and aims of the British delegation to the High Authority, which probably will be appoitned next month.
The National Production Authority will apply the principle of the steel fist and the velvet glove in a determined effort to see to it that vital steel goes where it can do the most goods.

Representative Robert W. Kean of New Jersey, ranking Republican member of the House Ways and Means subcommittee that earlier this year investigated the scandals in the Bureau of Internal Revenue, has been subpoenaed to appear on Sept. 4 before the additional Brooklyn Federal grand jury inquiring into income tax delinquencies among former Government officials.
GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- There are anywhere from 2,000,000 to 7,000,000 afflicted by leprosy in the world, the World Health Organization reported today.

WITH U. S. 45TH DIVISION, in Korea, Friday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Army was pressing a search today for the bodies of eighteen missing infantrymen who are feared to have been drowned Monday in a flash flood while fording a South Korean stream.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 21 -The Brazilian Government is intensifying its efforts to get high grade immigrants as part of a general program for developing the country's vast possibilities. Hugh S. Gibson, a former United States Ambassador here, has just begun talks as the director of the Provisional Intergovernmental Committee on Migration from Europe to see how that body can help.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Knights of Columbus Supreme Council condemned the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today for following "a course contrary to natural law and the deeply religious disposition of the founders of our nation."

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The crime increase in New York as reported recently by official police figures was called "a fictitious or paper increase" today by Dr. Paul Tappan, one of the country's leading authorities on crime and delinquency.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- Rain today washed the Dodgers and the Pirates into a twilight-night double bill tomorrow night and the Brooks' new Cuban flash, Edmundo Amoros, may see his first major league action then.

Casey Stengel's hoped-for "cushion" with which he aims to make the travels of his Yankees a bit easier next month was practically ripped right out from under the Ol' Perfessor at the Stadium yesterday by his arch tormentor, Paul Richards.
FORT DIX, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Military authorities at Fort Dix and near-by McGuire Air Force base are cooperating with state agencies to prevent taverns in the area from serving liquor to G. I. minors.

DOVER, England, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Thirty-seven United States seamen were landed safely on the coast today after a losing six-hour battle to save their 7-239-ton Liberty ship Western Farmer, which fell apart after a collision in the stormy English Channel.

ALLAN NUNN MAY, the brilliant young atomic physicist who betrayed his country and the civilized world to Russian agents, wrote in his official confession: "The whole affair was extremely painful to me and I only embarked on it because I felt this was a contribution 'I could make to the safety of mankind. I certainly did not do it for money."

ROME, Aug. 21 -- An important step for the solution of the Trieste problem, which has embittered Italo-Yugoslav relations since the conclusion of the Italian peace treaty in 1947, is believed to have been taken on Monday when the United States Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker; British charge d'affaires, George Peregrine Young, and the French charge d'affaires, Pierre Sebilleau, called separately on Foreign Under Secretary Paolo Emilio Taviani and had long conversations with him.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the question and answer exchange between Midwestern Republican leaders and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the party's nominee, at a conference here today:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Truman named today a Safety Board of Review under the new Coal Mine Safety Law and appointed Alex U. Miller of Vincennes, Ind., as the public member.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Former Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, one of Japan's top twenty-five war criminals, died today at Keio University Hospital. He was 86 years old.

SEATTLE, Aug. 21 -- A Canadian threat developed today in the United States amateur golf title tourney as Bill Mawhinney of Vancouver, B. C., gained the semi-final round of the championship at the Seattle Golf Club.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- New York City's Army Reserve force units -- the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division of the Organized Reserve Corps and the Forty-second Infantry Division of the New York National Guard -- trudged in from the field today at the close of two weeks of intensive field training at this 107,000-acre military reservation.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Charles Schall of St. Louis today set a world record at the forty-fourth tournament of the National Association of Angling and Casting Clubs for combination distance casts in four events.

A Jersey City man was killed by the police early yesterday and two of his companions were arrested for attempted grand larceny when the police surprised the three tinkering with automobiles in Macdougal Alley, near Eighth Street.
YORK, England, Aug. 21 (AP) -Jack S. Gerber's filly, Bebe Grande, led all the way today to win the six-furlong Gimcrack Stakes, one of the classic races for 2-year-olds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Federal Treasury collected a record $64,970,000,000 in taxes last year but still ran $4,000,000,000 deeper into the red because of mounting expenses.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- The wasted body of Dr. Kurt Schumacher was carried today through driving rain to the Social Democratic party's headquarters where it lies in state among tributes from friends and enemies, the greatest of which is the common assumption that with his death victory for the Government coalition is assured in next year's election.
The 2,152 infants born at St. Vincent's Hospital in 1951 set a new annual record for deliveries there during the last twenty years, the hospital announced yesterday.

A large gray horse van moved up a sidewalk at the Bronx Zoo about 11:30 A. M. yesterday and backed up toward the entrance of the antelope house. Something like the end of a piece of garden hose flapped out of a barred window of the van.
To the article by Walter Sullivan, "German Reds Push Collective Farms," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 11, I would like to add some remarks.

Passenger car owners of New York State got the bad news yesterday that their annual bill for automobile liability insurance is going up again, the seventh increase since the Second World War ended. One estimate puts the increase in premium costs at $40,000,000 for a year's coverage, on top of the present bill of somewhat under $250,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Truman made it clear today that so far as he was concerned the Democratic Presidential campaign must be based on the record of the Roosevelt-Truman Administrations. That is the only thing the party has to run on, he said.

BIRMINGHAM, Aug. 21 -- Senator John J. Sparkman today left the question of whether there was a "mess in Washington" to be decided by the two men who spoke out on that subject yesterday and today -- Governor Adlai E. Stevenson and President Truman.

A minor dispute over the true location of the source of the Orinoco River in Venezuela was renewed yesterday by Maj. Franz Antonio Risquez of the Venezuelan Army, who last year ventured up the turbulent stream and plotted its origin forty miles east of a previously reported point.

Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, last night accused the Republican party of "disgracing" itself by putting Herbert Hoover, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois on the program of the Republican national convention in Chicago.
A busy, successful dentist who has devoted a share of his time for the last twenty-five years to work in the dental clinics of the Community Service Society was honored yesterday for his efforts.

KALIMPONG, India, Aug. 20 -- Resentment against the loss of their ancient freedom to the Chinese Communists smoulders angrily beneath the surface of the present apparent subservience of Tibet to Red occupation. It waits an opportune moment to burst into flame, as it has always eventally done in previous Chinese attempts to subjugate the Himalayan Lamaist state.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Western railroads have rejected an emergency board report recommending a union-shop agreement with seventeen nonoperating unions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- International Minerals and Chemical Corporation reported today its sales for the year ended June 30 increased 28 per cent and profit was 2 per cent over a year ago.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Charles A. Noble, naturalized American who recently reached this city after seven years of imprisonment in East Germany, said tonight that his brother, Heinz Spanknoebel, who was active in the German-American Bund, died in a neighboring Soviet zone cell in 1947.

Encouraged by certain modifications in Marshal Tito's policies since his break with Stalin, the United States, Britain and France have embarked on a new effort to promote a direct settlement between Yugoslavia and Italy of the troublesome issue of Trieste. Such a settlement would not only remove the chief point of friction between these countries which now find themselves in the same boat fighting off Soviet domination.

Two bids are expected to be made for the big issue of Illinois Central Railroad bonds to be offered at sealed bidding next Wednesday in pursuance of an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission disapproving sale of the bonds by private negotiation.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Aug. 22 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest producer, has developed a four point program designed to avert a repetition of the recent eight-week strike which the company describes as a "labor-management" disaster.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- South African gold mining shares attracted most of the interest in the stock market here today. Firmness in quiet conditions characterized most of the other sections.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 22 -- An indictment of the Administration's farm policy and of Federal intervention in agriculture was made here today by Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, former chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers.

A vacant plot of about 15,000 square feet at 411-17 Elizabeth Avenue in Newark, N. J., has been purchased by Lynn Motors of Irvington from Jack Goldman. The property adjoins the garage recently acquired by the purchaser. Marks Realty Company and Fred Mitchell were the brokers.

Homemakers with a taste for travel can take a pleasant armchair journey to far-flung spots simply by looking through the new collection of papers offered by Wall Trends, 509 Madison Avenue, through decorators.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 22 -- The General Tire and Rubber Company announced today the formation of a Government-approved "mother hen" holding company to help smaller concerns get war orders.

Michael Bartell, Socialist Workers party candidate for United States Senator from New York, declared last night that what he called the reactionary role being played in the world by the United States was illustrated by the caliber of the Democratic and Republican candidates for the Presidency. He spoke at the opening meeting of his party at Adelphi Hall, 74 Fifth Avenue.

ROME, Aug. 22 -- The problem of Trieste has leaped into the headlines of all the Italian newspapers following the revelation that secret conversations on this subject had occurred last Monday between United States, British and French diplomatic representatives on the one hand and Foreign Under Secretary Paolo Emilio Taviani on the other.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, tonight described Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, and the regular Republican leadership as "two loud speakers" with "exactly opposite messages." Mr. Mitchell said it was about time the Republicans made up their minds.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 -- Candidly admitting their legislative impotence, the Radical party Deputies in the Argentine Congress late last night announced their intention to withdraw completely from that body. Since their proposal will undoubtedly be accepted by the national committee of the party, the. Argentine Legislature will become an undisguised one party affair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- For the second time this week, the Interstate Commerce Commission today turned down a railroad request for permission to sell bonds without complying with the rule set up by the I. C. C. in 1944, requiring competitive bidding on new securities, unless specifically exempted.

An order for the "forthwith" incarceration of two suspended patrolmen for refusing to obey subpoenas directing them to testify at the departmental trials of thirty-four policemen accused of having protected Harry Gross, bookmaker, was signed last night by Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol.

The Assistant Attorney General has purported to answer your excellent editorial attacking the Government's anti-trust suit aimed at forcing motion picture producers to distribute their sixteen-millimeter feature prints to television.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- New curbs on racketeering, gambling, tax frauds, the peddling of narcotics and other offenses against Federal law have been effected since the Senate's investigation last year into interstate crime, Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said today.

Eight brawny American seamen, who will represent this country Wednesday in the first international lifeboat race since 1939, hauled lustily but vainly at their oars yesterday on a practice run in the Hudson River from 112th Street to Eighty-ninth Street.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- State Senator William S. Hults, chairman of a joint legislative committee seeking a method to eliminate monetary losses from accidents involving uninsured motor vehicles, said today that he "leaned" toward a state fund from which unsatisfied judgments could be paid.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 23 -- The Communists protested today against United Nations bombing of North Korean towns and villages, and called upon "people throughout the world to stop this outrage."

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Aug. 22 (UP) --The Coos Bay, crippled in a pre-dawn crash at sea, was taken in tow today by two tugs while the other vessel involved, the Swedish motorship Stratus, made. port here under her own power.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday 15 to 29 points lower than on Thursday.

A new Protestant Episcopal religious order for women, to be known as the Community of the Holy Spirit, will be started at the cathedral of St. John the Divine at 10 A. M. Wednesday. Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Diocese will preside at the profession of two novices, who with two sisters to be transferred that day from the Sisterhood of St. John the Divine, Toronto, will comprise the new community.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Pan American World Airways said today it had received a "thinly veiled threat" that the month-old strike against the company in Guatemala would be spread to other Latin-American countries where it has bases.

KALIMPONG, India, Aug. 22 -- Communist troops edged closer to the Indian frontier this week when an estimated total of 500 Red soldiers with carpenters and masons moved from Yatung to Champithang, Tibet, four miles below an important trade route across the Himalayan pass of Natu, where the

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 22 -- Proposals to legalize off-the-track betting on horse races came under fire today from representatives of both the clergy and racing associations at the close of a two-day hearing held by the joint legislative committee to study horse racing.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, Premier of Rumania and Secretary General of its Workers (Communist) party wrote in Pravda today: "The rout of Right-Wing opportunists, deviationists and conciliators was the most important factor in the strengthening of the party (in Rumania) and a heavy blow to enemies of the people's democracy."

CLAREMONT, N. H., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The retiring president of the New Hampshire Medical Society is urging the reinstatement of Dr. Hermann N. Sander, who was dropped from membership after he was charged with murder in the death of an incurable cancer patient. Dr. Sander was acquitted in a trial by a Hillsborough County Superior Court jury in March, 1950.
The following is the text of the draft directives for the Fifth Five Year Plan of the Soviet Union, as translated from a Russian language broadcast by the Moscow radio:

Senator Estes Kefauver said yesterday that associates of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, had suggested to him that he might be appointed Attorney General in the event of Governor Stevenson's election, but that he had replied he was not interested in any Cabinet post.

A delay in possible action on grand jury indictments against Minot Frazier Jelke 3d and a second man on charges of procuring was announced yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Anthony J. Leibler, who said the vice case would not be completed before early next week.

CAIRO, Aug. 22 -- The Public Prosecutor General was reported today to have taken personal charge of the investigation resulting from the discovery Wednesday of a Communist cell in Faraskour in the northern Egyptian province of Dakahlieh.

Condemnation of "a current type of propaganda for the one type school" as contrary to "American principles of freedom and liberty" was voiced yesterday by the closing session of the convention of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae.

Steps to increase the sale of carbonated wines appear to have the greatest possibilities of offsetting unsatisfactory conditions in the wine industry, according to Martin Lefcort, president of the Eastern Wine Corporation, producers of Chateau Martin wines.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Afghanistan's Ambassador to Russia, Sultan Ahmed Khan, had a talk today with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

THE ghost of Dr. Sigmund Freud (as noted two weeks ago in this same space) still haunts the novelist's study as persistently as the: Old Man of the Sea. On occasion he is a willing, though chilling, collaborator as he probes the caverns of the psyche with an accommodating flashlight. Far too often (since ghosts are unreliable guides) he takes charge of the tour entirely, and the amateur speleologist will follow at his peril.

The taxpayer building containing two stores at 123-125 West Park Avenue in Long Beach, L. I., was sold by the Rutis Realty Corporation to Joseph L. Steinfeld, who resold it to Aaron Blum, real estate operator. Seeger Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Emanuel Goldberg for the buyer and Benjamin Gelosky for the seller.

The 100th flag of the City of New York to be sent to men serving in the armed forces overseas was returned yesterday. A Marine Corps master sergeant, Joseph A. Stich of 136-31 Sixtieth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, custodian of the blue, white and orange flag for the last five months, returned the standard to Mayor Impellitteri in a ceremony in front of City Hall, and the flag was raised over the building.
Our relief for the settlement of the steel strike should not blind us to its political character and those responsible. The truth about the catastrophic effects of the steel strike is emerging.

Trading continued within a confined area on the stock market yesterday with price shifts insignificant and little change in the pace of business. Only the oil issues were able to show alterations well in excess of the average, but dealings in these stocks proved meager.

Performing in a manner that could indicate they finally mean business, Cleveland's long-vacillating Indians thrashed the Yankees in a rip-roaring battle at the Stadium yesterday, 6 to 4, before a gathering of 33,880, and stormed into first place in the American League.

Recent letters to THE TIMES have suggested that the law should not permit the sale of firearms to ordinary citizens, that the citizen in good standing would be the last person in his community to require the use of firearms, at least for self-protection, and that the age of civilization is upon us.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Soybean futures prices declined today on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of a report from Washington that the Government was about to clamp down on the market in bean meal mixtures. Beans, as much as 2 cents a bushel higher at the pit opening, closed with declines ranging from 3/4 to 1 3/4 cents.
The semi-annual report of the Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company issued yesterday shows its net profit for the six months ended on June 30 declined to $591,321, from $1,588,032 a year ago.

Young gardeners put down rakes and sprinklers yesterday to hear how Br'er Mud Turtle gave Br'er Fox a well-deserved dunking. Surrounded by cornstalks and flowers growing tall on the grounds of the New York Plant and Flower Guild, thirty children listened to Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers tell an Uncle Remus story.

The American Federation of Labor is to be commended for adopting a vigorous policy in seeking to drive out shady elements that prey on organized labor. By compelling one of its international affiliates (that is, those with branches in Canada) to revoke a local union charter it had issued under questionable circumstances the Federation has abandoned its former alibi for avoiding action in such cases.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall, Australia's 17-year-old "Whiz Kids," today won a grueling 2-hour 23-minute four-set battle with Herbie Flam and Frank Guernsey to join Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, their defending countrymen, in tomorrow's semi-finals of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national doubles championships.

TORONTO, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Cliff Lumsden, 21-year-old Toronto salesman, today won the Canadian National Exhibition $9,500 ten-mile swim after the numbing waters of Lake Ontario forced the two leading contenders to withdraw.

I know of nothing more baffling or more infuriating than the state of mind, all too familiar in these United States, which produces thinking such as that expressed by Frederick C. Kroecker in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES. As an enrolled Republican I would go much further than President Truman and censure not only the "nonvoter" but also those proud possessors of the badge "independent."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Jim Lucius of Northfield, Minn., and Al Chandler of Los Angeles reached final of the P. G. A. National caddie golf championship today and will meet tomorrow for the title.

MINOCQUA, Wis., Aug. 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, charged in effect today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York had dictated the establishment of a campaign headquarters in New York for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
