BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Aug. 22 --California's second major earthquake in thirty-two days rocked this San Joaquin Valley city of 35,000 this afternoon, leaving hardly a building in the downtown area undamaged but causing only a surprisingly small number of casualties.

Beginning Monday morning, 27,000 rush-hour passengers from Queens and Long Island will find IND subway E trains using their own new southbound lower-level platform at Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Gross honors in the Women's Cross County Golf Association's family tournament were won today by Louis and Mrs. D. Cohen of the Glen Oaks Golf Club. They carded an alternate shot 40, 39 -- 79 at the Hempstead Golf Club.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Charlie Conerly's passes and Eddie Price's ground gains carried the New York Giants from behind in the second half tonight to a 24-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers. The National Football League teams' exhibition was watched by 13,000 persons.

In 1955 the Soviet Union will produce only about half as much in industrial goods as the United States did last year, if the goals set forth in the fifth Five-Year Plan are attained, analysis of the text of the directives for this plan shows. If allowance is made for

For at least two generations of affectionate observers of the American scene in its more picturesque social aspects announcement that the last of the famous hotels on Saratoga's Broadway is bound for the scrap heap puts a full stop to an era.

Jose Ferrer, who was concurrently represented on Broadway last season by four offerings, one of them the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama, "The Shrike," will take an eighteen-month holiday from the New York stage because he fears audiences may become "tired of my face."

The Government has leased 32,500 square feet of space in the forty-six-story office building at 295 Madison Avenue, the northwest corner of East Forty-first Street, for a field offiec of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, which is moving from 512 Fifth Avenue, at East Forty-third Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Hank Sauer's thirty-fourth home run wasn't enough for the Cubs today and two defensive lapses gave the Braves four unearned runs and a 4-3 victory.

A meeting of the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy was held in the longhouse on the Onondaga Indian Reservation near Syracuse on Aug. 16. It was called to receive suggestions from tribal leaders on the best method of giving legislators and the public the reasons, legal and otherwise, why Indian self-government should continue.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 22 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., was ordered today by the organization's thirty-fifth national convention to speed action for the integration of two racially segregated locals in Washington.

The action of the additional Federal grand jury in Brooklyn in subpoenaing Representative Robert W. Kean of New Jersey, ranking Republican member of the House Ways and Means subcommittee that investigated the scandals in the Bureau of Internal Revenue, was taken despite the objections of the United States Attorney's office.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The United States Department of Agriculture was requested today to declare an "extraordinary national emergency" to hasten eradication of vesicular exanthema, swine disease, which has spread to fourteen states.

TORONTO, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., beat townsman Ed Moylan, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6, and Kurt Neilsen, Danish champion, won, 6 -- 0, 1 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 10 -- 8, 7 -- 5, over the Philippine champion, Felicissimo Ampon, today in the semi-finals of the Canadian lawn tennis championships.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 22 -- The qualifying round for the New Jersey amateur four-ball best-ball championship resulted in a three-way tie for the medal over the Nos. 3 and 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club course today.

The City Council voted 20 to 2 on July 2 to set up a separate and independent city Department of Air Pollution Control, and now the Board of Estimate has endorsed the idea by 10 to 6, with only City Council President Halley actively in opposition. If Mayor Impellitteri signs the legislation as expected smoke control will be somewhat less a stepchild and be recognized for the importance it deserves in city government.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- The Communist-dominated All-India Peace Council is planning to send the largest delegation to the Asian and Pacific peace conference to be held in Peiping next month. The conference, jointly sponsored by Communist China and the Soviet Union, is expected to be attended by representatives from all the Far East nations.
Benjamin S. Graffman has been appointed buyer of major appliance for Lit Brothers, Philadelphia.

GENEVA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An international convention to assure adequate quarters and living conditions for merchant sailors at sea will come into force next January after having been pigeon-holed nearly seven years.

One of the most appalling consequences of two world wars and the rise of fascist and Communist dictatorships has been the vast displacement of populations which has precipitated the greatest migration movement in history, both voluntary and compulsory.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- The Yugopress news agency reported tonight that an understanding had finally been reached between the Yugoslav Government and the Governments of the United States, Britain and France for continuation of the three-power economic assistance during the fiscal year 1952-53.

It may seem strange, in August, to think about winter in Korea, but this is the time to look ahead. Winter will be a time of further suffering, and our efforts to alleviate it must start now. Our own abundance lays a burden upon us. We must share it with those who are homeless and hungry and cold.

A collection of five favorite stories by James Bendrodt, Australian writer, sportsman and sports promoter, entitled "Of Men, Dogs and Horses," will be published on Sept. 10 by Greenberg. Two of the stories appeared in True magazine in this country and both won awards as the best story of the year in that publication.

Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, said here yesterday that draft-age fathers would not be called until next summer. By then, he added, "we are going to have to take somebody or else decrease the size of the armed forces."

ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- India's perennial grain-shortage problem is being tackled from new angle, according to Supuran Singh of the Indian Ministry of Food and Agriculture, a visitor the Cornell University Summer Session in the Department of Institution Management, College Home Economics.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The contribution that social psychologists can make to the program administered by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization for the furtherance of world peace was discussed here this week at Unesco headquarters by fifteen distinguished psychologists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The railroad industry and the Department of Defense collided head-on today over the question of highway-hauling of explosives. In opposing briefs filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, the military authorities said the highway movement was required by the defense program, and the railroads accused the department of showing an "irresponsible attitude'' toward public safety.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 22 -- The Israeli income tax rate was reduced and a 25 per cent capital gains tax introduced by action of the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Gus Zernial hit a grand slam homer and a three-run single to help Bobby Shantz chalk up-his twenty-second victory of the season as the Athletics whipped the Browns, 9 -- 0 in the second game of a twi-night bill tonight.

Why people eat the foods they do, how important a part emotion plays in attitudes toward specific foods -- in fact, the whole field of psychological and sociological factors affecting food patterns -- has yet to be fully explored. One step in this direction is the recently published "Twixt the Cup and the Lip" by Margaret Cussler and Mary L. de Give (Twayne Publishers, 262 pp., $3.95).

A Park Department request for a 1953 capital budget allocation of $21,699,802, with emphasis on the construction or completion of sixty-six new playgrounds, was heard yesterday by the City Planning Commission at a public hearing in the Municipal Building.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 -- The International Typographical Union, in the closing hours of its five-day centennial convention this afternoon, adopted two resolutions directed against the Taft-Hartley Act. The delegates also adopted a resolution asking the State Department to take steps against further increase in the price of Canadian-produced newsprint.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 22 -- Two British agricultural experts told the sixth International Grassland Congress today that the food production capacity of the world s farmlands could and must be doubled through application of technical knowledge to meet the requirements of growing populations.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Instead of racing in tomorrow's $25,000 added Saratoga Handicap, in which he is an entrant, Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins' 7year-old Three Rings ran today in a $5,000 added number. He won with no great difficulty.

A typhoon of major intensity has lately swept over Okinawa. Then came the official report. No lives lost; damage only in the thousands, not millions. This will be more than good news to any of the men who rode out the typhoon there in the last year of the war and saw what a cyclonic storm can do to a battle fleet. It will seem like a miracle.

GENEVA, Aug. 22 -- Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, and N. N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar, Defense Minister of India arrived in Geneva this afternoon to meet on Monday with Dr. Frank Graham, United Nations mediator for Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, said today that he and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the party's Presidential candidate, would support Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for re-election if the Wisconsin Republicans nominated him.

A movement to draft Averell Harriman for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator was proposed yesterday by Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, at a luncheon conference with Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, in the Biltmore Hotel.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- This 107,000-acre military reservation, where Reserve and National Guard troops have been trained since 1908, was formally dedicated as Camp Drum today in honor of a distinguished soldier who helped write the state's military history.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- Pittsburgh fans finally witnessed a Pirate victory over the Dodgers and the 21,845 at fog-bound Forbes Field tonight were noisily happy when Gus Bell lined a single to right in the ninth of the second game, for a 3-2 Buccaneer triumph.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 22 -- Deputy Premier Bagher Kazemi has announced officially that the Mossadegh Government will proceed tomorrow to perform the virtual miracle of paying the army, the police and civil officials on time. This will be the first full pay period since Premier Mohammed Mossadegh took over dictatorial powers for six months.

Mayor Impellitteri added his indignation yesterday to that of residents in Laurelton, Queens, as he inspected sections of a recently built sewer system where some pipes had been omitted, others had been "caulked" with newspapers and rags and pavements had been rebuilt too weakly to withstand normal traffic.
SEATTLE, Aug. 22 -- Two players from the State of Washington gained the final of the United States amateur championship at the Seattle Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Government today authorized manufacturers to supplement their scarce steel supplies in the next few months by acquiring used steel free from the National Production Authority's limitations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- plea to people in the entertainment industry to get on the Stevenson-Sparkman band wagon was made today by the newly organized Hollywood for Stevenson-Sparkman Committee in Paid advertisements published in the trade papers Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter.

A few thousand of the largest commercial and industrial users of electric power here received heavy increases in their monthly bills in the new permanent rate structure that became effective by order of the Public Service Commission last Aug. 4. The increases ranged up to $5,000 a month.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The White Sox ran their winning streak to four games as they supported Joe Dobson's four-hit pitching against the Red Sox today with two-run outbursts in the third and fifth innings for a 4-1 victory.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 22 -- The third World Conference on Faith and Order finished its seventh day of deliberations here unappreciably nearer the agreement on church unity which the conferees sought to achieve than they were at the outset.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Aided by Willard Marshall's two-run homer in the fifth inning, the Reds came from behind to defeat the Phillies, 3 -- 2. tonight.

May a New York housewife ask whether the present dangers to women and children in our city are not the result over a long period of time of tendency to "hope for the best," and a belief that human beings are naturally good?
The following is a list of new products for the homemaker that have recently appeared in the stores:

Greater support from philanthropic sections of the public, rather than rate increases for hospital service, is the answer to financial problems of the French Hospital, according to the annual report of that institution, issued yesterday.

HONOLULU, Aug. 22 -- A heavy demand for homes among Hawaii's half-million residents and a depletion of mortgage loan capital in the territory -- followed by appeals to the mainland for aid in home construction -- have developed into one of the most controversial issues in the islands.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur H. Schwartz signed an injunction yesterday temporarily restraining the Supreme Lodge of the Knights of Pythias and Earl Genzberger, its Supreme Chancellor, from suspending the charter of the Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias of the State of New York.

Leather prices have been rising steadily this month with increases of 1/2 to 1 cent a pound reported this week. There was active trading in the spot hide market, but tanners were reluctant to place orders and push prices higher.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- The Century Country Club team of Peter Cooper and Mrs. Richard Kops had a best-ball score of 32, 32 -- 64 at Knollwood Country Club today to win the season's third pro-woman tournament staged by the Westchester P. G. A., seven under par with their blended cards, they led the field of sixty-eight pairs by two strokes.
The state Congress of Industrial Organizations, representing 1,000,000 members, served notice yesterday on the state Democratic party that it would not rubber-stamp any candidate for Senator.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Men and machines sprayed California's Central Valley today with a "fog" of mosquito-killing insecticide in a concentrated effort to wipe out the carriers of sleeping sickness which had caused thirty-one deaths in less than two months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Army, which is still experimenting with its own variety of body armor for its troops, today decided to purchase 25,000 of the Navy-developed armored jackets used successfully by the Marine Corps in Korea. It will ship them to the Far East immediately, it was announced by the Department of Defense.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique,1,350, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korea time:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (UP) -- About 475,000 coal miners began a payless ten-day "memorial holiday" tonight as John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, paved the way for a possible strike next month.
WILBURTON, Okla., Aug. 22 -- A Boy Scout camp supervisor brought a second sackful of antique gold rings out of the once notorious "robbers cave" country today, arousing stories of bandit treasure.

The Museum of Modern Art has purchased the five-story vacant dwelling at 31 West Fifty-third Street from the 3153 Corporation, of which A. Augstein is president. The house, on a plot about 21 by 100 feet, is separated by three buildings from the property which the museum owns at 9-19 and 21 West Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The International Harvester Company, struck yesterday by 23,800 members of the Farm Equipment Council of the United Electrical Workers, an independent union, sought a court order today against the strikers in Louisville, Ky. Harvester also is considering court action against strikers in East Moline, Ill.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 22 -- The military authorities of Belgium are working out a plan to maintain at scheduled strength the three active divisions the country was called on to keep at the disposal of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1952 under the Lisbon agreement.

" Tinkerbell" was saved once again this week by more than 150 children when they affirmed with enthusiasm their belief in fairies at a marionette performance of an adaptation of J. M. Barrie's immortal "Peter Pan."

IN addition to the $10,025,106 in Federal Aid Wildlife funds which will go to the forty-eight states for the restoration and development of wildlife resources, an additional $2,508,527 will be apportioned for fishery resoration projects.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- United States sales abroad dropped off sharply in the second quarter of this year except for shipments of military supplies, the Department of Commerce reported today. At the same time the nation was buying more foreign goods.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- United States diplomacy is now making a quiet but firm effort to achieve settlement of the troublesome Trieste question by inducing the Yugoslav and Italian Governments to negotiate an accord terminating the currently unsatisfactory structure of the Free Territory.

A "higher degree of intimacy" among passengers on the Long Island Rail Road, if the line is permitted to put into service twenty new cars of a type now contemplated, was forecast yesterday by Public Service Commissioner Paul E. Lockwood.

The American Red Cross Blood Donor Program announced yesterday that on Thursday 801 pints of blood were collected in this area for the fighting forces in Korea. Fort Monmouth, N. J., donated 282 pints, making a three-day total of 1,014.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Because of increased traffic and fatalities on Westchester parkways county officials are starting a detailed study of bottlenecks, too narrow pavements, dangerous curves and a lack of center islands.

Robert Byrne of the Manhattan Club of New York made chess history yesterday by winning his adjourned first-round game from Erich Eliskases of Argentina in seventy-four moves and defeating David Bronstein of Russia in the second round in a queen's gambit lasting forty-one moves in the International Chess Federation team tourney, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 22 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's Weekly one-day tournament over the Baltusrol Country Club course today resulted in a tie for top honors between Mrs. William Hockenjos of the home club and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair. Mrs. Cudone, the association's medal play champion, had nines of 37 and 45, while Mrs. Hockenjos was steady with 42, 40 -- 82.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Sir Cecil Weir, a prominent Scottish business man and former chairman of the Dollar Exports Board, was appointed today as chief of the permanent British delegation to the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community (Schuman plan organization).

One of the nation's leading independent operating public utility properties, the Washington Water Power Company, reported yesterday a net income, after all taxes, expenses and other charges, of $3,892,041 for the twelve months ended on June 30, 1952.

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- Maurice Thorez Jr., son of the secretary general of the French Communist party who now is in Russia, surrendered here today to the French police. The latter had been looking for him since May 31, three days after Communist riots against the role of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic forces.

Formation of the American Liberation Center, headed by Robert A. Vogeler, American business man who was imprisoned by the Hungarian Government for seventeen months, was announced yesterday. The purpose of the center will be to help liberate "all peoples enslaved by Communist tyranny," including, Mr. Vogeler said, an estimated 5,000 American citizens now detained in Soviet-dominated countries.
A major narcotics ring with international connections was smashed yesterday by Federal narcotics agents with the arraignment of three of the reputed leaders in Brooklyn Federal Court.

DENVER, Aug. 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that he would never campaign for or give blanket endorsement to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, but that he would back any Republican against any Democrat for election to the Senate this year.

ATHENS, Aug. 22 -- Greece's Parliament, acting little more than forty-eight hours after United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy suggested a new Government might help the nation, voted confidence in Premier Nicholas Plastiras' coalition Cabinet tonight, 127-118.

The Federal Government filed three civil suits in the United States District Court here yesterday to recover more than $67,000,000 from four big American oil companies and six subsidiaries. It accused them of overcharging the Economic Cooperation Administration
A last-minute hitch prevented the announcement yesterday of a master contract between metropolitan trucking operators and locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.
SACRAMIENTO, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- An insurance loss of more than $4,000,000 was inflicted by earthquakes in southern California last month.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company sounded a possible retreat today in its twenty-one-month fight for permission to erect a power plant on pretty Cove Island here. If the city fathers of near-by Norwalk prove more receptive, the company announced, it will set up its plant there, on another island.
GREENE, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Rochester couple, Helmut and Mrs. Wolf, shared the honors today in the opening competition of the three-day New York State archery championship.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 -- A babyfaced rookie with the mastery of a true pitching artisan tonight sent the Giants tottering seven and a half lengths behind the league-leading Dodgers and only 3 percentage points ahead of the third place Cardinals in the National League standing.

Thomas A. Bradshaw, vice president and general counsel of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, will become president and chief executive officer to succeed M. Albert Linton, elected to the new office of board chairman.

Newspaper linage in July was 1.6 per cent below the same month last year, but for the year including July was up 0.2 per cent, according to Media Records' report yesterday. The total linage for July and for the year to date was 175,446,937 and 1,404,654,996 respectively.

TORONTO, Aug. 22 -- Canadian achievement is being emphasized at the Seventy-third Canadian National Exhibition, which was opened this afternoon by the first Canadian-born Governor General of Canada, Vincent Massey.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., shot a three-under-par 69 today to lead by a stroke at the half-way point of the Fort Wayne open golf tournament.
Retail credit collections, while improved over recent months, continue to lag behind the corresponding period a year ago.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The Dudley-Maslow-Bales Company appeared tonight at Palmer Auditorium of Connecticut College at the second performance of the American Dance Festival. It presented two premieres in a program that also included two dances from the company's repertory.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 22 -- Equal increases in compensation for all service-connected disability cases were asked today by the Military Order of the Purple Heart in its annual convention here. The resolution was introduced by the Illinois delegation.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Orval E. Voorhees of Grand Island, Neb., 44, won trapshooting's biggest prize today -- the Grand American Handicap.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- There was gratification today among British business men at the news from Washington that the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce had called on the Government to make a closer study of the advantages a. well as the disadvantage of trade between Western Europe and the Soviet bloc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- State Department officials made plain today that the United States stands firmly behind statements about the Greek election system made by Ambassador Peurifoy.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 22 -- The Twenty-eighth Long Island open golf championship tournament ended in par-shattering performances today as Fred Wampler, assistant professional at Fresh Meadow, defeated Shelly Mayfield, Rockaway Hunting Club pro, at the North Hempstead Country Club.

It's good to know that American books, magazines and newspapers will now go to Israel in greater numbers and kinds than ever before. Under an agreement just completed with the United States, Israel has reduced her rate of exchange so that American publications may be sold there at a 28 per cent reduction.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- Soviet-American negotiations for a new United States Embassy building to replace the Mokhovaya Street quarters that will be vacated at the year's end were understood today to be near a successful completion.

Domestic sugar and potato futures trading here yesterday was described as "violent." Potatoes, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, again set a record day's volume, with 1,460 contracts, ending with three deliveries down the limit.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 22 -- Field Marshal Sir William Slim, Chief of the British Imperial General Staff, suggested here today that the Western Allies revise their current policy of seeking to stamp out communism as a standard evil throughout the world and turn their efforts instead to spliting the Communist-run areas from Moscow's control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- An electric worm-digger that a fisherman can attach to his car is among the inventions patented this week. It is an "electrocultural device" designed by Wilbur C. Fenton of Strawberry Point, Iowa, that actually shocks the bait to the surface.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 22 (AP) -- German fans stormed theatres all over the West German Republic tonight to see a Fox movie about Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, "The Desert Fox." Kept out of Germany for ten months by United States Government pressure, the film had a simultaneous premiere in West Germany's largest cities.
I read with interest your account of the speech on civil rights delivered by Congressman A. Clayton Powell on Aug. 3.

Members of the American Legion attending its national convention here tomorrow through next Thursday will be welcomed with their families at houses of worship in the city during their stay. Many churches and synogogues will be open daily for prayers and meditation.

AT SEA ABOARD THE TROOPSHIP GEIGER, Aug. 22 -- A taut ship and a happy crew headed home today to the New York Ship-building yards at Camden, N. J., after cutting a 1.032-mile swath through Atlantic waters during a rigorous three-day examination before this $20,000,000 G. I. dreamboat joins the Military Sea Transportation Service.

Twenty-four local housing authorities have borrowed $93,658,000 through notes for the temporary financing of projects bearing the contractual backing of the Public Housing Administration. The notes, which will come due variously on Dec. 19, 1952, and on Feb. 20 and March 13, 1953, were sold at discounts ranging from 1 per cent to 1.13 per cent.

One more letter was added yesterday to the controversy over whether the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., should be allowed to extend one of its runways in the vicinity of Southern State Parkway. This one was written by Mundy I. Peale, president of the company, to Robert Moses, Long Island State Park Commissioner.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Greasy Neale, Jerry Neri and Curley Lambeau were the chief prospects today as the Washington Redskins searched for a new football coach for the seventh time in their history.

KENNETH DAVIS, who extolled Kansan simplicities in his fine biography of Eisenhower, "Soldier of Democracy," goes fashionably complex in his elaborate third novel, "Morning in Kansas." The "morning" of the title refers not only to the awakening of young (and, it must be admitted, tedious) Earle Borden from a nightmarish adolescence but also to the emergence of America from the drift and doubt of the Great Depression.

An over-all program calling for economic aid to Israel, the furtherance of Hebrew language and education in this country, and the establishment of a national commission on Israel and the Middle East "aimed at the reactivation of Zionist membership in the area of public opinion," was set forth last night by Rabbi Irving Miller, newly elected president of the Zionist Organization of America.

TRIESTE -- The Yugoslav Air Transport officials take your passport before you board their DC-3 at Athens, and don't give it back until you are safely through customs, currency and security controls inside Yugoslavia, in our case in Belgrade.

A STRAIGHTFORWARD novel, "Headland," relies only on the usual insights and normal autobiographical material of the novelist. It concerns Ethan Greenleaf, a New Englander with a name carrying echoes of ancestors, lately back home with his wife, his kids, and his job after several years in the Pacific.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- Al Chandler, 16-year-old Los Angeles high school junior, today won the 1952 national caddie golf championship with a runaway 8-and-6 victory over Jim Lucius of Northfield, Minn.

INSTEAD of considering television simply as an accomplished fact, Frank Denman writes of it as the latest in a long series of devices for the communication of ideas, beginning with the cave man's drawings.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- One Saturday night in July the writer dropped by the stage door of the Spa Theatre in Saratoga Springs to invite Miss Ilka Chase to bend a relaxing elbow after her evening stint. There being not too wide a choice of evening entertainment in Saratoga this season, I had an idea; I asked Miss Chase if she had ever been inside the Grand Union Hotel. She said she had not.

THE Museum of Modern Art is taking advantage of a large summer attendance to do what other city art museums might profitably imitate: it is showing work from its permanent collection in special exhibitions.
Many years back in the present century there was a popular song entitled "How Ya Gonna Keep 'em Down on the Farm After They've Seen Paree." The late "Papa" Sam Rudofker found he couldn't.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Far West, its population booming, is siphoning political power away from the eastern and border states.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 23 -- The Chief of Staff of the Iranian Army at the time of the overthrow in July of the Short-lived Premiership of Ahmad Ghavam following rioting in Iran, the military governor of Teheran at that time and thirteen other generals of the Iranian Army were dismissed from active service today.

Lagging deliveries in the wholesale market here last week, firming prices and heavy ordering of popular items have necessitated careful planning for supplies in September and October and for Christmas, according to Independent Retailers Syndicate, Inc., resident buying office.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- Soviet Russia's leaders plainly indicated this week that the course of Soviet policy -- both domestic and foreign -- is firmly fixed and that, barring unexpected events, no major changes should be anticipated in the foreseeable future.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Two officers and an enlisted man from the United States military mission to the Soviet zone of Germany were arrested Aug. 15 on a charge of spying, and Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet commander in Germany, has asked for their recall, it was announced today.

" WARWHOOP" presents two novelettes of Indian fighting. The first -- "Behold the Brown-faced Men" -- is of Sioux warfare in Nebraska and was disappointing to this reviewer. But the second, "Missouri Moon," is a vivid tour de force indeed.
AN almost paradoxical trend in wallpaper and fabric design is the fact that contemporary designers are turning more and more to the past for inspiration.

YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- A daring drive by Bob Ryan brought Colonel Dan home in front in the Class B pace that headed tonight's harness racing card at Yonkers Raceway. The cheers of most of the 24,005 fans were for the owner-driver, for the 11-year-old bay gelding and for the night's only successful favorite.

Old trees, firmly and deeply rooted, are difficult to transplant under the best of conditions, but Dr. Saul Penner, medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals' City Home for Dependents, would rather tackle a giant redwood any day than attempt to move a single inmate from the City Home to new and improved quarters.
LAST year -- on June 24, 1951. to be precise -- this column carried a "talk" with the Irish writer, Frank O'Connor. Only, to be precise for the second and last time, it wasn't a "talk.

A "co-op" plan whereby journalism students may earn their expenses by working for newspapers, radio-TV stations, advertising departments, and in other allied fields, is being inaugurated by the University of Georgia's Henry W. Grady School of Journalism. Under the plan an interested newspaper or other journalistic organization can select two students to attend the school during alternate quarters.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- "If he doesn't win this one," said Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt to a friend early this afternoon, "I'm not only going to be disappointed -- I'm going to be very surprised."

Rats seem to have a built-in urge to learn even when they have no hope of profiting by their knowledge. This is the finding of two University of Wisconsin psychologists, Robert W. Leary and Prof. Harry F. Harlow.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- France, said Edouard Herriot today, is like a cat -- she always falls on her feet. He was interviewed at Vittel, where he is spending his vacation.
THERE was a time when after 1 A. M. a radio produced little more than static, but the night air fairly abounds today with eager broadcasters vying for the insomniac's attention.

GROVE CITY, Pa., Aug. 23 (UP) -- Three men today outwitted and captured a 22-year-old soldier who had refused to return to his post because he wanted to go to Bible school, and ended his three-week armed holdout in his home here.

Mrs. Elizabeth S. Ives, Gov. Adlai Stevenson's sister, who will serve as First Lady if the Democratic Presidential nominee is elected, has accepted an invitation to greet the 1,500 delegates to the thirty-second annual convention of the American Legion Auxiliary on Wednesday, Mrs. Euga Campbell, president of the auxiliary, said yesterday.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- The Communists at Panmunjom began digging in today for a long stay at the tiny roadside village that for ten months has been the site of the deadlocked negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

THE strength, shortcomings and potentials of the Photographic Society of America were revealed more pointedly at its 1952 convention held here recently than at any of its previous meetings. The technical division, the best organized and most purposeful of the seven divisions, set an example for the society that unfortunately continues to be overlooked.

Some geographers say that the world is drying up, and to prove it point to the deserts of Central Asia, which were once lands of milk and honey. The engineering magazine Power takes direct issue with such gloomy predictions in an "editorial report" on the water supply of the United States.

When steel and other materials in short supply again are available in ample quantities, a real road-building program may be expected throughout the country. Funds already are available and increasing steadily through record tax collections on the sale of gasoline.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, largest of the four railway operating brotherhoods, endorsed today the Democratic ticket of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman for President and Vice President.
Increases in registry, insurance and special fees for international mail will become effective Sept. 1, Acting Postmaster George M. Bragalini announced yesterday.
LAST week seemed to be Arlene Francis week on television. At least it started out that way with Miss Francis giving three varied performances on three successive evenings.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 23 -- The Military Order of the Purple Heart, holding a four-day annual convention here, today decided to change the organization's name to the Wounded Combat Veterans.
CHIPLEY, Fla., Aug. 23 (UP) -- A posse of twenty - five officers tracked down and killed a suspected Negro rapist today after six hours of pursuit in a Florida saw-grass swamp.

It is to be hoped that the address which the distinguished astronomer, Dr. Otto Struve of the University of California, delivered a few days ago at the Western Amateur Astronomers Convention, will be widely published for the benefit of the innocents who are convinced that flying saucers are space ships from other worlds; for Dr. Struve combed the universe for evidence of intelligent beings.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The position of the Joint Legislative Committee seeking to protect insured motorists against losses incurred by financially irresponsible drivers appeared today to be veering sharply away from a compulsory insurance law.

WILLIAM TINSLEY, sponsor of Thomas Hardy's first three published novels, once remarked that in "Under the Greenwood Tree," second of the trio. "I felt sure I had got hold of the best little prose idyll I had ever read."

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 23 -- Minister of Agriculture Khalil Teleghani gave a hint today that Iran saw a chance of getting some unexpected United States dollars, in a letter to Premier Mohamed Mossadegh on reviving a program to spur mechanized agriculture.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 23 -- Chet Sanok and Steve Berrien of Upper Montclair, former title winners, led the way into the semi-final round of the New Jersey Golf Association's amateur best-ball championship today at the Montclair Golf Club.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Willard Marshall broke a 2-2 tie with an eighth-inning drive into the right-field bleachers today to give the Reds a 3-2 victory over the Phils.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- President Truman has accepted tentatively an invitation to address the first session of the seventh annual National Conference on Citizenship which open here Sept. 17, the nation's first Citizenship Day.
According to the United States Treasury, gold is worth $35 an ounce, buy or sell.

The Veterans Administration has just released the amazing figure of 19,288,000 as the number of living Americans who are veterans of the armed services of this country. Over one-fourth of all our male children and men have shared the not-too-pleasantly homogeneous experiences of military or naval life.

Minot Frazier Jelke 3d, 22-year-old heir to an oleomargarine fortune, yesterday reclaimed his 1951 Cadillac automobile, which was seized last Saturday after his arrest on a vice charge. At that time the police said they had found a loaded revolver in the glove compartment.

ST. THOMAS -- People hereabouts are still talking of the three-day carnival put on in 1912 for the arrival of a Danish dignitary, complete with twenty-four-gun salute, arrival of "King Carnival" on a flower-decked float and a general profusion of merrymaking and holiday spirit.

Dwight D. Eisenhower last week was learning the truth of the old political adage that if you see only a dilemma, you are oversimplifying things. During the week he came flush up against what he and his advisers had known from the start would be a thorny problem: What to do about Republicans whose views are directly opposite to his own -- specifically what about Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin.
VIENNA, Aug 23 -- The Soviet satellites in eastern Europe are reaping even leaner crops than last year, according to early reports, and the harvesting is far behind schedule.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- Acting President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez and Jorge Leyva, Minister of Public Works, inaugurated today the reconstructed Dique Canal connecting the Atlantic port of Cartagena with the Magdalena River port of Calamar, sixty miles from the river mouth.

The man who for two years guarded Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President of Columbia University will be on hand tonight to resume a former responsibility and renew an old acquaintance when the general returns to his residence on the university campus.

GANGTOK, Sikkim, Aug. 21 -- The tiny kingdom of Sikkim, an Indian protectorate pointing like an arrowhead into Communist-held Tibet, is scheduled to become a constitutional state in another six months.
DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 23 -- The Puttencove Kennels' standard pooddle, Champion Blakeen Bali Ha'i was named best in show late today in the annual all-breed fixture of the Newtown Kennel Club.
A number of secretaries -- male and female, young and not quite so young, employed and unemployed -- came forward last week to speak their piece on why there is a shortage of secretaries.

THE film version of Margaret Irwin's novel "Young Bess," which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is preparing for an October production start, will represent somewhat of a departure from the customary Hollywood approach to historical drama.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today they expected the new multi-million dollar hoof-and-mouth disease laboratory on Plum Island in Long Island Sound to "attract some of the best scientific talent in the world."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee takes the secrecy wraps off the long-awaited international oil cartel report Monday morning and some repercussive fireworks are expected.

IN this year 1952 of mounting global stress, when to the general historian it seems that the Republic and what it stands for in the world lives from day to day in mortal peril, one might think that the American people would have little time for local history, regional, state, city or town.
BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Britain France and the United States today told the Russians that the Soviet Union, not the Western powers, was preventing resumption full East-West German trade.

A plan to draw India's youth out of politics, unite them under one democratic banner and channel their energies into a self-financed rural-aid program was described here last week by a young Indian teacher on his way back to Bombay after a six-week seminar at Harvard University.

EVERY time a motion picture story conference decides on another lurid Biblical romance, a primordial saga or a Genghis Khan special, one result is a little extra flicker of prosperity for a group of Italian villages in the Apennine Valley.

SPRINGFIELD. GEN. DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois have finished the training-camp period. They have appointed their managers, flexed their muscles and predicted the inevitable victory. And now this week they are going, appropriately enough, to Madison Square Garden for their first appearance in the big arena.

One day, just after Germany's defeat in World War II, a one-armed shell of a man showed up at British Occupation headquarters in Hanover. His name was Kurt Schumacher. A veteran of World War I in which he had lost his right arm, Schumacher had won a doctorate at the University of Munster and then taken up Socialist politics in Germany's Weimar Republic.

The shipping industry is concerned over the large number of suspended jail sentences meted out to petty thieves apprehended in the current drive to cut down waterfront pilferage in the Port of New York, it became known yesterday.

Professors representing forty-four colleges and universities from Vermont to California are staying in Seattle, Wash., for their summer vacation. Instead of relaxing, however, the educators are working in the research laboratories and in design and engineering project groups at the Boeing Airplane Company.
Cleveland's hold on first place in the American League flag race apparently was only on a short-term loan.

CHARLES POORE, vriting .in "In and Out of Books." quotes Beerbohm as stating: "Of all the countless folk * * * on this planet, not one * * * in history or legend, is known as having died of laughter."

MADRID -- To get a quick look at North Africa at no increase in price, we took the Trans World Airlines plane that ducks down from Rome to Tunis, crosses the top of Africa to Algiers and then cuts north across the Mediterranean for the second time in the same flight to Madrid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The seams of the classrooms of the nation's schools will bulge next month more than ever.

The Russian Communist party is the state. Although there are Government bureaus presided over by Ministers the men who control the party actually control the Government. The political history of Russia since the Communist Revolution of October, 1917, has been a history of concentration of power in an ever-smaller circle. In the center of this circle sits J. V. Stalin.

UTICA, N. Y., April 23 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, met with upstate Democratic leaders here this evening and reaffirmed his position that he would not be available for the Democratic Senatorial nomination from New York.

When the great gold rush was on in Alaska in 1897-98, the thousands who struggled to get there were forced to climb, heavily laden, up the steep ascent of the Chilkoot Pass. Many were buried under tons of snow in a great avalanche in April, '98. No one knows how many were trapped.
The nation's $23,000,000,000 electric power and light industry, owned by hundreds of thousands of private investors, is not in the market for a headstone.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP) -- The quake-battered Bakersfield community swept up the rubble today and counted damage estimated tentatively at $20,000,000 from yesterday's sharp shock. Two lives were lost and thirty-two persons injured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Hal Newhouser spotted the Senators three runs in the first inning and pitched shutout hall the rest of the way today as the Tigers came from behind to win, 6 -- 3.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 -- Mississippi's voters, in a Democratic primary election on Tuesday, will determine whether to give a seventeenth consecutive term to Representative John E. Rankin and whether to approve a proposal for legislative action that could lead to a county-option legalization of liquor sales in this dry state.

WITH the approach of the fall merchandising period, conditions in the wholesale markets are coming in for a greater degree of attention. Deliveries are lagging in many lines by ten days to four weeks.

In another few days the speedboat world will know whether the English 31-foot jet-propelled craft Crusader has been "souped up" enough to beat the world straightaway one-mile speed record of 178 miles an hour, set last month by Stan Sayres at Seattle in his Slomo-shun IV.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Recent developments in Egypt and Iran have highlighted the issue of land reform. In Egypt the Government has taken steps to give peasants a larger share of the land, while in Iran it has moved to give them a larger share of the harvest.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 -- Former Premier Mustafa Nahas, leader of the Wafd, Egypt's largest political party, told a mass gathering of his followers at Alexandria tonight that violence had been done to the Egyptian Constitution three times since 1938, the last time being in March of this year with the dissolution of the Wafd-dominated Chamber of Deputies.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The sailing weather was ideal today for ninety-four skippers in eight regular sailboat classes as Huguenot Yacht Club staged its fifty-eighth annual regatta on Long Island Sound. Winds blew most of the afternoon at eight to ten knots from the northwest, then increased to over twenty for picture book finishes.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- The Far East Air Forces, in a summary yesterday, claimed a record of victories during August over the enemy's MIG fighters in Korea, with fifty-seven of the Soviet-designed jets destroyed, probably destroyed or damaged.

TO the public Arnold Toynbee is known above all as the author of "A Study of History." Less known is the fact that his incomparable industry has produced the twenty-one volumes of the Survey of International Affairs which cover in a detailed way, year by year, world history from 1920 to the end of 1938.

SERACUSE, Aug. 23 -- After a long and sometimes bitter debate, the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. T. on Thursday voted overwhelmingly not to defend teachers who have been proved to be Communist party members. The action took place here at the federation's thirty-fifth annual convention.

THIS odd, compelling, uneven novel has been chosen by the Literary Guild for September. As such it ranks as the most unusual choice since another major club made "Darkness at Noon" and "Junior Miss" a dual selection back in the late Nineteen Thirties.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, bolted the Republican party tonight in an address broadcast nationally over the Mutual Broadcasting System. He asserted that "the time has come to organize another party."
New fuel was added last week to the growing resistance movement against mandatory retirement ages in pension plans by the announcement that the cost of living had risen to a new record high.

Twenty-six tugs, representing nearly all the towing concerns whose vessels ply New York Harbor, will churn the Waters of the Hudson Wednesday afternoon in the first official tugboat races ever held here.

THIS has been a fine festival season for the Wagnerians. Bayreuth continues to nourish the Wieland Wagher renaissance, and now Munich, for the first time since the war, had added the full Ring to its festival repertoire.

In "New Departures in Old Dublin" (July 27), Sam Boal expounds the rather contradictory theory that the church itself imposes a serious stumbling block in the way of marriage for the poor. First, Mr. Boal quotes a Dublin bartending bachelor, "Sure it costs you a mint of money to get married.

An absence of any stimulating development in foreign affairs, coupled with something of a lull in favorable news from the industrial field, had an adverse effect on financial markets last week. Traders kept to the sidelines as stock prices sagged in dull trading and sporadic labor disturbances continued. Meanwhile, the escalator clause in labor contracts moved wages slightly higher for millions of workers as the cost-of-living index advanced.

FACED with the loss of their farm home in the Maine woods, Mrs. Welden and her teen-age son, Tom, must locate the old boundary line of their thousand - acre spruce lot, claimed by an unscrupulous timber owner.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- But for defense program restrictions the auto industry might now be Witnessing an all-out fight for industry leadership.

THE anomaly that is Berlin divided has become even more of an anomaly with the widening of the gap between the two parts of Germany. Since the end of the war seven years ago Berlin has been an island 100 miles inside Soviet-controlled East Germany.

AROUND about this time, when mothers in homes all over the land are casting an appraising eye over their youngsters' wardrobes with thoughts of the back-to-classes movement just ahead, at least one parent attached to most up-and-coming schools must now take himself (or herself, more likely) firmly in hand and do some serious thinking.

SOUTHAMPTON -- "Chief Thunderbird is in charge of publicity for the pow-wow," said the first Indian I encountered on the Shinnecock Indian Reservation here, and after directing me to the chief's wigwam (a neat little cottage), he drove off in a Buick convertible.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., one of four large producers of Middle East oil confronted with Federal suits to recover $67,000,000 in alleged overcharges to Marshall Plan countries, declared itself "blameless" of the charges yesterday.

A cool snap brought lovely weather yesterday, although it came uncomfortably close to breaking the "cold" record for the date and caused lots of sleepers to fumble shiveringly in the dawn hours for an extra cover.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Navy revealed today it had developed a smaller, faster camera for use in new high speed jet photo planes not yet delivered to the fleet.

THIS probably is the Year of the Big Traffic Jam. More Americans than ever before are on the highways, week-ending and vacationing. Close to 40,000,000 workers now get paid vacations. About 45,000,000 families own automobiles. More than 80 per cent of all vacationers travel by car.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Canadians, area residents, tourists and newlyweds turned out today for the first joint civil defense drill of the United States and Canada.

THE very air at the Yankee Stadium was brittle with tension yesterday. The vast crowd buzzed excitedly as the Indians and the Yankees squared off for their final New York meeting with the pennant itself teetering in the balance. Even before the gladiators stepped out in the arena for their do-or-die battle they were strangely subdued and quiet, the weight of their responsibilities driving the natural playfulness and buoyancy out of them.

THIS much-needed material, compiled by the distinguished editor-in-chief of the Junior Literary Guild, is organized into three sections: writing for the 6 to 8 year olds, the 9 to 11 year-olds and the 12 to 16 year olds, the last section of which comprises nearly half of the entire work.

THIS is Patrick O'Brian's first work to be published in this country, a rare and beautiful novel, deceptively modest in tone, never faltering in the unobtrusive skill of its poetry and dramatic dimensions. O'Brian writes of the farmland of North Wales, and of the rough, parochial people in that remote valley-world, with intense knowledge and feeling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- United States customs agents today reported gains toward checking smugglers specializing in such diversified items as hot tamales, cattle and platinum. They even told of a stool-pigeon parrot.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- After a twelve-month survey, the members of the Water Pollution Research Board here have issued a report on the state of the Thames River and they have come to some pungent conclusions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The new President of the United States, when he takes office Jan. 20, will not start his tenure with a clean Congressional slate, even if he tries to.

Senator William Benton, Connecticut Democrat, returned yesterday from a two-week foreign aid mission to Europe. He renewed his attacks on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, calling him a man who used "fraudulent and deceitful tactics."

THOMAS SCHERMAN and the Little Orchestra Society, who must be numbered among the best friends of contemporary music, have recorded for Decca three works of Stravinsky and Hindemith.

Russia's players yesterday defeated the strong Argentine quartet by 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 in the third round of the tournament sponsored by the International Chess Federation at Helsinki, according to a report from Finland.

A broad investigation into the multi - million - dollar Southeast Queens sewer project, part of which has been declared to be of improper construction, was indicated yesterday as James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, began questioning a contractor and city employes involved in the case.
BONN, Aug. 23 -- Changes of the greatest importance are pending behind the blank monolithic facade which Communist Russia presents to the world.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The World Council of Churches decided today that its main task in the future would be to proclaim the essential unity of the different Christian churches throughout the world.

MILAN, Italy, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The orchestra and chorus of the La Scala Opera Company here has threatened to go on strike unless the director reinstates the choirmaster. He was dismissed for permitting his group to make recordings for an American concern.

A Federal mediator was attempting last night to avert a threatened walkout of 30,000 shipyard workers in eight Atlantic Coast plants operated by the Bethlehem Steel Company. The strike has been set for midnight tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 -- The Giants' pennant hopes suffered another jolt today as the Cardinals pounded out their eighth straight victory and passed the Polo Grounders in the pursuit of the Dodgers.

TRENTON, Aug. 23 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will make his first appearance before New Jersey voters as the Democratic Presidential candidate next Wednesday afternoon. He will be the guest of honor at a Democratic state organization rally and $50 supper at Jumping Brook Country Club near Asbury Park.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 23 -- A fleet of twenty-three started tonight in the fourteenth annual overnight Huntington Yacht Club race to Stratford Shoals for the August Hecksher Memorial Trophy. W. T. Snaigh's Figaro, the defending champion from Cedar Point, topped the list.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Despite internal hassles occasioned by the normal stress of a Presidential campaign, and despite the furious speculation inspired in this city by the Bolshevik party pronouncements of implicit importance to Soviet world relationships, the United States Government is quietly persisting in its efforts to build a long-range foreign policy.

IT is desirable, as perhaps inevitable, that the rash of Congressional investigations of recent years should provide grist for the moral mill. Everybody's against sin, but nobody ostracizes all sinners; and so ethical discussion always involves opposing impulses.

The country's chemical companies were urged yesterday by the Manufacturing Chemists Association to start a drive to get more students into the field in an effort to cope with the long-range shortage of trained manpower.

The battleship Mississippi, which carries some of the Navy's newest and most secret equipment, arrived in New York harbor yesterday for two days of liberty for her crew of 1,300. She is tied up at Buoy C. North River, off Eightieth Street, and will not be open to visiting by the public.

A civilian committee to advise the Coast Guard on port security matters through its Captain of the Port was formally organized last week, it was announced by Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, Commander of the Third Coast Guard District.

DENVER, Aug. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower plans important conferences soon with the top Republican leadership in Congress, upon whom he will have to depend to guide his program into law if he is elected President.

Pamela learns as the animal learns. Luckily for Pamela, her Grandfather Paget, a breeder of fine riding horses, guided the 9-year-old.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 -- The Soviet Union proposed tonight that a four-power conference be held not later than October on a German peace treaty, an all-German government and withdrawal of the occupation forces, and it agreed to discuss at the conference the Western proposals regarding arrangements for all-German elections.

The trend toward the buying of retail outlets by major shoe manufacturers has caused small and medium size producers to worry about finding stores to sell their shoes. While the situation now is far from critical, the smaller manufacturers are afraid that should more companies buy up outlets they may find themselves with no way of getting the product to the consumer.

ERIK Satie (1866-1925) was a French composer whose influence far transcended his music. He was the spiritual father of "Les Six," in Paris in the Twenties, and in recent years his cause has been taken up by the avant-garde group.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Perennials, annuals and even vegetables can be choked by weeds, which grow so rapidly after a rain. Some hand work is usually necessary to clean weeds out of perennial clumps and along the edges of beds and borders. Hoe or cultivate between plants to remove weeds and, if necessary, rake them off to add to the mounting compost pile.

To be a legendary figure and very much alive, which Sir Max Beerbohm is today on his eightieth birthday, is a rare experience. "The incomparable Max" was so much a part of the world of Oscar Wilde, J. M. Whistler, Aubrey Beardsley, George Bernard Shaw and others of the Gay Nineties that it is sometimes hard (but always pleasant) to remember that he is still with us.

Safety equipment protecting motorists would save thousands of lives in highway accidents, according to the Cornell Committee for Transportation Safety Research. It presented data yesterday indicating vehicles could be built that would be materially safer in case of accident.

The readiness of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in America "to join with the labor movement and other groups in a continuing effort to aid the poverty-stricken peoples of the world" is emphasized in its annual Labor Sunday message to be read in churches on Aug. 31 or Sept. 7.

WHEN the Civil War broke out in 1936 Spanish literature was at the height of one of the greatest periods it has ever known. AUGUST 15 was Marian MacDowell Day at Peterborough, N. H. Statesmen, artists, townspeople and visitors from places far and near gathered there to pay tribute to the 94-year-old widow of Edward MacDowell who, by the power of faith and her own indefatigable energy and acumen, has developed to its present status the MacDowell Colony which stands today unique and unparalleled as a center for creative work in the arts.
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,351, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

WHILE the Republican party lists a number of campaign issues at its disposal this year, ranging from the foreign policy of the Administration to corruption in high places, the infiltration of subversives into Government, and the need for a change, the chances are that the Democrats will do a considerable amount of pointing with pride.

HONG KONG, Aug. 23 -- With Communist China preparing to raise a "high tide of construction" alongside its military "modernization" program, Premier-Foreign Minister Chou En-lai landed in Moscow early this week at the head of the most important delegation sent there by the Peiping government since the signing of the Sino-Soviet treaty of friendship, alliance and mutual aid.

The Bronx was described yesterday as a "traffic captive" of Westchester motorists who park their cars in the borough's streets. Thousands leave their locked vehicles from 8 A. M. to about 4 P. M. in areas where local travel is dense and utilize public transit lines to other parts of the city.

A NEW book by Ely Culbertson, introducing his method of point-count valuation, has just been published ("Culbertson Point-Count Bidding"). Mr. Culbertson's method, which employs the 4-3-2-1 count for high cards but differs in many respects from other point counts, was described in this column some weeks ago.

A WIDOWER for the second time in his life, President Juan Domingo Peron of Argentina is at a turning point of his enigmatic career. He has lost a political partner as remarkable for her beauty, energy and fanaticism as for her absolute vindictiveness.

THE 1952-53 music season will not develop real momentum until October, but the so-called "fringe" month of September will hold many more events than last September. One of the leading factors will be the early opening of the fall season of the New York City Opera.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Two defense attorneys in the conspiracy trial of eleven Communist party leaders were released from Federal prisons today after serving terms for contempt of court.

IT was suggested, recently, and not by a commercial fisherman, that the sports anglers put their house in order before charging the market fishermen with being the only violators of sound fishery conservation.

HONG KONG, Aug. 23 -- With Communist China preparing to raise a "high tide of construction" alongside its military "modernization" program, Premier-Foreign Minister Chou En-lai landed in Moscow early this week at the head of the most important delegation sent there by the Peiping government since the signing of the Sino-Soviet treaty of friendship, alliance and mutual aid.

The Bronx was described yesterday as a "traffic captive" of Westchester motorists who park their cars in the borough's streets. Thousands leave their locked vehicles from 8 A. M. to about 4 P. M. in areas where local travel is dense and utilize public transit lines to other parts of the city.
Construction contract bids for Sound View Houses, a $15,000,00 low-rent project to be built by the City Housing Authority in the Bronx, were opened last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The National Science Foundation announced today its second graduate fellowship program of awards for scientific study. The award will cover the academic year 1953-54.

The high contracting parties will cooperate with each other in all important international questions * * * in the event of one of the contracting parties being attacked by Japan or any state allied with her * * * [the other] will immediately render military or other aid with all means at its disposal.

PARIS. THE United States has made notable progress in strengthening Western Europe, in stimulating a somewhat vague and ill-defined impulse for European nations to unite among themselves for political freedom and military security.

SUCH unanimity as greeted David Lean's new picture, "The Sound Barrier," is rare among the London critics. Not all went so far as the man who roundly declared it "one of the greatest films ever made," but an analysis of the reviews would suggest that even such a verdict would not rend in dispute a debating session of the Critics' Circle.

BUILDING a lawn from scratch may seem like a formidable task. Actually, like any other operation, it's not so difficult if approached step by step. And, after all, new lawns have to be made only once.

Passengers who choose a winter Atlantic crossing on the United States liner America will have their way smoothed through and around the seasonal storms by a Sailor's sailor -- a man with a wide reputation among his shipmaster colleagues as a weather prophet.

Dr. William B. McElroy's annual round-up of fireflies, on which this department has presented information, came to an end in the first week of August. Dr. McElroy is the Johns Hopkins Professor of Biology who pays Baltimore children 25 cents a hundred for fireflies that he needs for his researches.

While demonstrating that "Corruption Runs Far Deeper Than Politics" (Aug. 10), Marshall Clinard has neglected to mention the importance of the political remedy for corruption. The exposure of corruption in a political party makes it necessary that that party be turned out of office by the voting public.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Governor John Davis Lodge removed himself "unequivocally" tonight as a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Connecticut to succeed the late Senator Brien McMahon.
The interesting debate between Messrs. Henry Steele Commager and Chester Wilmot ("Was Yalta a Calamity?" -- Aug. 3), raises weighty issues of contemporary world history.

A new drive against the chief remaining road block of cases responsible for the four-year delay in jury trial of personal injury cases in Supreme Court in Manhattan has been under way quietly this summer and will be formally stepped up in the fall.

THIS world of free expression, this drift of sensations, passions and ideas, perpetually kindled and fading in the light of consciousness, I call the Realm of Spirit. It is only for the sake of this free life that material competence and knowledge of fact are worth attaining. Facts for a living creature are only instruments; his play-life is his true life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A letter to an editor by one Presidential candidate, statements by the other candidate to leaders of his party in the Midwest and to reporters in Denver, and a White House press conference generated forces this week that blew away the flimsy curtain of "harmony" behind which the two major parties are bitterly divided.

THOSE who had hoped that the American National Theatre and Academy would follow the path suggested by Robert Whitehead, director of the recent season's play series, whereby a permanent acting company would be formed to present an annual program of plays, were bitterly disappointed last week.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Clem Labine today did his first pitching for the Dodgers in almost a month. The effort gained his eighth victory for Labine when the Dodgers rallied in the eighth inning to beat the Pirates, 3 -- 2.

Frank Sedgman of Australia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., will defend their titles in the seventy-first annual national lawn tennis championships starting Friday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The tournament will continue daily through Sept. 7, with play in men's and women's singles and mixed doubles.

One of the most satisfying fairy-tale plots is that one about the peasant lad who slays the dragon and wins the princess. For all its royal trappings, this story of the poor boy who succeeds where knights and princes have failed is essentially democratic in spirit, and has validity as a parable, even today.

THE graduates who received their diplomas in June were the first to complete a full four-year course at the High School of Performing Arts. This unique school was founded in 1948 at the instigation of Dr. Franklin J. Keller, the progress principal of the Metropolitan Vocational High School, of which it is a branch.

NEW YORK'S enterprising city radio station, WNYC, has scheduled eight masterpieces of the world's dramatic literature for broadcasting on consecutive evenings at 8:30 o'clock beginning tonight. The series was originally produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation and the casts include leading English stage and radio actors.

The "thin veneer" that is Chinese communism ( Aug. 10 ) is undoubtedly true when looked upon in the light of past history. * * * Nevertheless, Nathaniel Peffer's claim that communism and China are no more miscible than oil and water is a falsehood.

AMATEUR photographers and gardeners are eligible to compete in a contest sponsored by the Associated Bulb Growers of Holland, Inc., which offers the equivalent of about $75,000 in paid-vacation and merchandise awards for winning pictures.

THE Pan American Union's Philatelic Division, which had its twelfth birthday a few months ago, set a new high monthly sales record during July, and the boom has been continuing through August without the customary summertime recession.

NOW hard at work on Canadian soil directing "I Confess," his latest production for Warner release, Alfred Hitchcock took time out last week to discuss the venture prior to the convergence of his stars, Montgomery Clift and Anne Baxter, a supporting cast including Karl Malden,. O. E. Hasse, Dolly Haas and Roger Dann, and a technical crew of fifty on the bilingual stronghold of Quebec.

There is no immediate relation between the present trouble in Iran and the fact that a new translation of the "Rubaiyat" of Omar Khayyam, based on a recently discovered manuscript of the year 1207, has just been published in London. Omar was chiefly concerned with wine, while the trouble in Iran largely derives from oil.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Two groups to promote grasslands education in the Latin-American countries and Europe were organized today.

The publication in this newspaper yesterday of the text of the directives for the Soviet Fifth Five Year Plan, covering 1951-55, made generally available in this country a most important Soviet economic document. Containing almost no absolute figures and confining itself almost entirely to percentages for which no explicit base is presented, this document is a splendid example of the lengths to which Soviet leaders go in their paranoid quest for secrecy.

Stephen A. Mitchell, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will speak at a meeting of the New York State Democratic Committee at the Biltmore Hotel Thursday at 4 P. M., Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, announced yesterday.

" IF he had died at the age of 25, he would have been the greatest poet in the German language" -- this cruel witticism of Vienna cafe conversation overshadowed the greater part of Hugo von Hofmannsthal's life.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Economic Stabilizer Roger L. Putnam suggested today that housewives help bring down record high food prices by boycotting scarce items.

TWO weeks ago we were discussing the revival of the pulp masterpieces of Dashiell Hammett; this week it's the turn of the only man, with the possible exception of Chandler, whose long-buried pulp stories are revived in book form as regularly (and as deservedly) as Hammett's: Cornell Woolrich.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, declared tonight Republicans would wreck the Social Security system, weaken farm price supports and ban low rent public housing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Labor Department reported today that a new division had been set up to supervise payments of unemployment compensation to jobless veterans who left the service on or after June 26, 1950. The administration of the program will be carried out by state agencies.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23 -- Brazil will not devalue her currency nor does she seek a loan abroad to provide foreign exchange to pay debts to foreign exporters, Minister of Finance Horacio Lafer declared today at a press conference. Rumors abroad of financial chaos in Brazil have been spread by Brazil's enemies, he said, asserting the country was financially sound and able to cope with the present situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) -- Communist Czechoslovakia has failed to answer an American request for a conference with a United States Army private who is reported to be in Czechoslovakia, it was disclosed today.

THE art committee of Easthampton's Guild Hall deserves greatest credit for having brought together a collection of French Impressionists and Post-Impressionists that by the highest standards is interesting and enjoyable.

The improvement in the health of this nation's people in the last fifty years as reported in the recent study of the Brookings Institution is certainly one of the great national achievements of the period.

THE usual rush to get out of town by plane, train, bus and even bicycle will mark the year's last long weekend which will extend through Labor Day, a week from tomorrow. Vacationists will begin to leave the city Thursday or earlier, and reservations are already heavy on trains and planes.

DESPITE spring freezes and rains and summer drought, produce stalls over the country are laden with fall fruits and shipments are increasing daily. Bartlett pears and grapes of all varieties are in liberal supply for home use.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- Diplomats here believed today that there had been little or no appreciable narrowing of the substantial differences that divide the East and West over the question of how to approach a solution to the impasse on Germany.

TROY, Aug. 24 -- Dave (Davey) Banks, a former professional basketball player and coach, and Alfred Elfred, an assistant horse trainer known at race tracks as Freddie Fields, were killed early today in an automobile accident near here.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- The outlook for steel demand, prices and controls is now remarkably similar to that following the 1946 steel strike, according to observers here. The parallel suggests the likelihood of trends which steel producers and consumers might be well advised to watch.
One of the important if prosaic news stories in this section of THE TIMES last week was the annual report of the Controller of the Currency, Mr. Preston Delano.

The Willis Avenue Bridge, closed to traffic for sixteen months, will reopen Friday for northbound tarffic across the Harlem River. Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen said yesterday that the reopening was planned, even though work would not be completed, because of the importance of the bridge as a traffic artery between Manhattan and the Bronx.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Civic receptions at Denver, and Jersey City will have to wait because the prospective guests of honor, Olympic Games victors, are stranded at the airport here.

As one intimately concerned for some years, not only as a minister but in other public positions, with the efforts to combat religious and other bigotry and intolerance in our country, I was deeply impressed, on a motor journey across many of our states, with the essential goodwill of our American people.

Bob Mathias, 21-year-old two-time winner of the Olympic decathlon from Tulare, Calif., returned to the United States yesterday and reiterated that he did not intend to enter a third Olympic decathlon.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 24 -- The motion picture made from Alan Paton's best-selling novel about the race problem in South Africa, "Cry, the Beloved Country," won the 1952 David O. Selznick Silver Laurel award for English films today.

In an effort to keep city streets clear during tomorrow's huge American Legion parade, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan appealed yesterday to motorists not to bring their cars into Manhattan unless absolutely necessary.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- It snowed up here today -- on a bright, warm August Sunday. The crystals gleamed in dazzling sunlight that seemed to respect their extraordinary timing and melted them very slowly. Meanwhile, sixty-five boys and girls from 6 to 12 years old tested the snow with sleighs and toboggans and throwing arms and found it not wanting in any particular.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Volume of trade in grain and soybean futures decreased sharply last week from the week before, but the pit trade was substantially larger than a year ago. Average daily purchases were approximately 44,000,000 bushels, against 50,000,000 bushels the week before and 34,000,000 bushels a year ago.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 25 -- The Chinese Reds' Peiping radio in a long commentary today on the negotiations for an armistice in Korea called United Nations military pressure "a farce" and again demanded that the crucial issue of an exchange of war prisoners be settled by the return to the Communist command of all Chinese and North Korean captives.
