CAIRO, Aug. 24 -- Premier Aly Maher said tonight that his Government did not contemplate formal negotiations with Britain until some of Egypt's economic, social and constitutional problems had been solved. He thought this would take three months -- one month to straighten out the economic tangle and two months to improve the organs of local government and prepare for new elections.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 24 -- The Iranian Government will launch a radio education program intended to teach every Iranian peasant who is capable of it to read and write. The program, to begin Sept. 6, will use specialized American radio equipment.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 24 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, made it clear today he intended to stick by his opposition to state ownership of offshore oil lands "regardless of the possible effect on electoral votes."
ROXBURY, N. Y., Aug. 24 -The Congregation of the Jay Gould Memorial Reform Church started a week's celebration today of its 150th anniversary.

The 800-family garden apartment center at 2700 and 2800 Bronx Park East, in the Bronx, formerly known as the Workers Colony, has been acquired by a syndicate headed by Milton Spitz from Chobol and Navone, who had held it two years.

With a strike deadline set for any time after midnight tonight, a Federal mediator sought at a late hour last night to effect an agreement between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O. Barring a satisfactory conclusion of negotiations, union leaders have warned that 30,000 employes in the company's eight Atlantic Coast plants will cease work.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Although the holiday season is waning, this is no explanation of the continued firmness and increasing confidence in the stock markets. While there are reasons in some instances advancing security values, this position as a whole is favorable influenced by the strength being played by gilt-edged stocks.

In one of the largest commercial leasing transactions negotiated recently in the Grand Central zone, the Horn and Hardart Company, operators of the Automat chain of restaurants and retail shops, has taken for a long term ground-floor space amounting to 20,000 square feet at 80 East Forty-second Street, in the Airlines Terminal Building.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 24 -James T. Sherwin of Columbia University, playing in defense of the title he won at Syracuse a year ago, today defeated Allan Kaufman, New York, in the first round of the New York State Chess Association championship at Cazenovia Seminary.
I am a bitter opponent of censorship, but I am equally in opposition to supplying a potential enemy with information of military value.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- West German Government sources, although acknowledging that the Soviet Union's notes on a four-power meeting on Germany contained one slight concession on the proposed election commission, are confident that the Bundestag will not be diverted by the Moscow proposals from ratifying the Bonn peace contract and the European Defense Community treaty this fall.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, arrived here last night by chartered plane from Denver to deliver a major foreign policy speech before the national convention of the American Legion in Madison Square Garden this afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Aug. 24 -- Lana Turner's next picture for Metro will be "One More Time," a comedy drama fresh from the typewriter of Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon. Filming on the story in which Miss Turner will appear as a Korean war widow is slated to begin in October with George Cukor as the director.

MUOTATHAL, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- Four exhausted and mud-smeared Swiss cave explorers found their way out of Hell Hole cavern tonight. They had been trapped since Aug. 15 by an underground flood in the cave, situated near here.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 24 (AP) -Representative Clark Thompson held a shaky lead today over T. W. Buckshot Lane, Wharton County sheriff, in the only unsettled Congressional race of Texas' second Democratic primary election.
Organization of the American Society of Appraisers as a Delaware membership corporation to operate on a national basis was announced here yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -Vincent Hallinan, millionaire San Francisco lawyer, opened his Progressive party campaign for the Presidency at a "peace" rally in the Civic Auditorium tonight.

Auxiliary Bishop James H. Griffiths, Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate, characterized schism yesterday as the "principal objective of the manipulations of church affairs in Czechoslovakia today." He made his reference in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- United States Superforts blasted away at three Red planes attacking out of the darkness during a bombing raid near the Manchurian border Saturday night. Crewmen of the B-29's said one of the Communist aircraft exploded in a burst of orange flame.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Robert Russell, one-time acrobatic burglar, who two decades ago told the police that he planned to give away free bread in Harlem with the proceeds he received in selling his loot, was back in jail again today.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A favorite literary form for well-known British authors this summer has been letters to the editor complaining of what the income-tax law does to their earnings.

TORONTO, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., unfolded some of the best tennis of his career today to blast Kurt Neilsen of Denmark in straight sets, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, to win the men's singles title at the Canadian lawn tennis championships.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 -- The superheated Cardinals had their temperature lowered and their eight-game winning streak shattered by the Dodgers today before the largest single-game crowd at Sportsman's Park in fifteen years.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 24 (AP) -The Iraq Petroleum Company announced today completion of a new 12-inch pipeline which will carry oil from the newly expanding Mosul oil fields to a big pumping station from which it will be piped to the Mediterranean oil port of Banias in Syria.

KALIMPONG, India, Aug. 24 -One of the last real "forbidden" lands outside the Iron Curtain, the independent kingdom of Bhutan, between Tibet and the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal, is regarded by experts in border affairs as the weakest link in the chain of buffers against communism that India is erecting along her northern frontier.

VANCOUVER, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The projected $400,000,000 Alaska aluminum plant will have no adverse effect upon the $550,000,000 plant now in the construction stage at Kitimat, B. C., a spokesman for the aluminum Company of Canada said here yesterday.

The concern of Christians for social righteousness has grown in part out of the meaning of the word Catholic, the Rev. Stanley A. H. Eley, prebendary of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 24 -- Gov. Allan Shivers said today that he would go on the radio in the next few days to ask for an expression of the will of the Texas electorate on the candidate he should support for President.

KEANSBURG, N. J., Aug. 24 -- Two shore-based sailors were rescued this morning from the waters of Lower New York Bay, where they had been clinging for more than ten hours to their overturned canoe. They were taken to the Army Hospital at Fort Monmouth and treated for exhaustion and exposure.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 24 (UP) -- Jim Turnesa, Professional Golfers Association champion, and Jimmy Clark tied for first place today in the fourth round of the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- The successful results that several European countries have achieved in the last two years by following the line of policy variously described as "orthodox" and "liberal" are being endangered by a number of recent developments.

NORWICH, N. Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, one of four Republican Senators whose defeat is urged by Col. Robert R. McCormick, said today he had no comment "at this time" on the Chicago Tribune publisher's remarks.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Net profits of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company in the second quarter were $1,465,831, equal to 44 cents a common share. Half of the steel strike fell in the second quarter.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 24 -- A surprise victory was scored today when the top award in the Great Barrington Dog Show went to the brown miniature poodle Ch. Diablotin Forever Amber, bred and owned by Irene Morse's Diablotin Kennels.

Texas Gas Transmission Corporation has completed the borrowing of $37,000,000 from fourteen institutional investors on mortgage bonds bearing 4 per cent interest, W. T. Stevenson, president of the company, announced yesterday. Of the total, $13,000,000 had been issued to the lending institutions last February.

The consumer price-index (sometimes loosely referred to as the cost-of-living index) reached what appeared, in temporary retrospect, to have been its post-Korean peak in December, 1951, and January, 1952, at 189.1 (1935-1939=100). Two months later, however, it had begun to turn upward again, and it is now revealed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics that in July it reached a new high for all time at 190.8.
I have read with great interest and unqualified approval the letter of Dr. Paul B. Sears, chairman, Yale University Conservation Program, which was published in your issue of Aug. 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- State Department officials found "nothing new" today in the latest note from Moscow on German unity, and predicted that the United States, Britain and France, to whom it was directed, could not accept it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The Phillies, shut out, 3 -- 0, by Warren Hacker in the first game of a double header, roared back with a sixteen-hit attack to defeat the Cubs in the second game, 14 to 4, before 33,820 fans today.

Thirty truck horses enjoyed a brief liberty in East Harlem early yesterday, after a small fire in the basement of their stable at 1417 Park Avenue, near 105th Street, had led to their release from their stalls. Most of the horses were corraled without trouble, but four led the police a chase before they were caught.

CAIRO, Aug. 24 -- Egypt's Premier, Aly Maher, said after tonight's three-hour Cabinet meeting that a committee had been set up under Dr. Mahmoud Tewfik Hifnawi, regional director of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, to give urgent study to the Egyptian Army's proposals for the reclamation and rehabilitation of Egypt's vast deserts.

New York City has an interesting international problem within its own borders which has been waiting for solution upon the return of Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations. In Jamaica, Queens, on a tract of forty acres, is a community in which citizens of perhaps fifty countries live, -- Parkway Village, with its 685 garden apartments.

The feverish activity that prevailed in the foreign exchange market for some time seemed to have subsided during the past week when price movements were confined to a narrow range and business transacted was on a moderate scale.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- Germany's seventy-fifth Catholic Congress ended today when assembled priests, nuns and laymen from the two parts of this divided country filled Berlin's Olympic Stadium to overflowing for the closing ceremony.

The nation's sulphur users -- the makers of paper, fertilizer, chemicals, steel, rubber, explosives, paints, insecticides and many other items used by everyone -- are no longer worried over the supply, as they were not very many months ago.
The city's public assistance caseload again showed a decline in the last month, decreasing 2,316 persons from June to July, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

The American people should stop acting as though they were living in peacetime, Mrs. Rae Ashton of Vernal, Utah, who will assume the presidency of the American Legion Auxiliary this week, declared yesterday.

Religious congregations in the United States had a total of 88,673,005 members at the end of 1951, Dr. Benson Y. Landis, editor of the Yearbook of American Churches, published annually by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., announced yesterday.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved irregularly last week, tending to decline. At the close of trading on Friday active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 27 to 56 points, with the 1952 contracts registering loss of 44 to 49 points while the more distant deliveries declined 27 to 51. Gains of 18 to 57 points had been recorded at the close of trading the week before.

I have just voted in my party primary. My ballot was No. 7. I voted after 6 P. M. There are more than 800 voters eligible in my district and I am registered in the dominant party. There was the name only of the incumbent for each office, plus the write-in space.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 24 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh issued a decree today under his full powers for a housing construction project on government land.
Frederick Becker and Harvey H. Eich have been appointed assistant vice presidents of the Manufacturers Trust Company, according to Horace C. Flanigan, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -Earl Rapp's bases-loaded single off Early Wynn with none out in the sixteenth inning scored Jerry Snyder from third base to give the Senators a 9-8 victory over Cleveland today. The defeat dropped the Indians two games behind the league-leading New York Yankees.

Whatever the pros and cons of "American Inventory," the educational television series, no one can accuse it of being in a rut. Of all the programs on the air, it probably comes closest to having a different format each week, which, incidentally, ties in with the show's purpose -- trying to find the best methods of presenting information for adult education.

The thirty-fourth national convention of the American Legion will open at 9 A. M. today in Madison Square Garden for a four-day session at which the speakers will include Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic nominee.

Federal contracts awarded to New York manufacturers between Dec. 26, 1951, and July 16, 1952, amounted to $1,027,233,000, according to a report to Mayor Impellitteri by Walter T. Shirley, the city's Commissioner of Commerce. The report, made public yesterday, cited the United States Department of Labor as authority for the total.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Aug. 24 -- The sum of $60,000,000 arrived here this afternoon and set off "the battle of combat pay." Probably for the rest of the Korean war United States regimental commanders will be digging in angrily behind telephones, wielding needle-point pencils as they evolve the proper tactics to conquer Paper Hill.

I should like to take issue with reader Kenneth Umbreit's appeal for permanent control of residential rents. He states that rent control should be permanent in the same manner that we have public control of utilities. He bases the need for this control on the fact that housing is affected with a public interest.

After an hour-long conference with Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils at Gracie Mansion yesterday, Mayor Impellitteri said there might be "a need for criminal investigation" by the Queens District Attorney into the construction of Laurelton sewers.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -The Samoset Canoe Club of Roxbury, Mass., paddled to a national championship victory on the Schuylkill River today.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- An eight-run fifth inning highlighted a 12-to-1 Red Sox victory in the second game of a double-header today after Boston had scored a ten-inning, 2-to-1 triumph over the Browns before 26,789 fans at Fenway Park.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet reply yesterday to the United States proposal on Germany, as broadcast from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The Small Defense Plants Administration today announced small-business shares in three industrial expansion goals set by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, today called on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, to divulge immediately to the Joint Chiefs of Staff his reported plan for ending the Korean war successfully.

Parkways built twenty and thirty years ago now are so outmoded in basic design and so dangerously overloaded with this summer's heavy traffic that some swift and effective improvement is essential. An improvement bringing an immediate reduction in fatal accidents would be the construction of center barriers to prevent cars from crossing into wrong lanes and colliding head-on with those of drivers who are innocent of violating any rule of highway safety or common courtesy.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- Exports of metropolitan France dropped in July to the lowest level in two years. According to official customs figures the July total was 63,000,000.000 francs, against an averge of about 75,000,000,000 a month in 1951. One must go back to September, 1950, for a lower figure than that of July.

In the recent Democratic National Convention the New-Fair Dealers (sometimes called "liberals") had a choice between a party split and the abandonment of their policies. In effect they chose the latter course by the extent of their compromise (a pleasanter word) in both platform and candidates. Unity, however, still seems at best doubtful, for though state organizations are not bolting the evidence of revolt by individuals is considerable.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 24 -Five persons were killed and four others were injured in traffic accidents here early today.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 24 -Dances by sixteen students from Doris Humphrey's class in repertory at a Saturday matinee, two premiere dance performances by Jose Limon and company last night and dances featuring the Dudley-Maslow-Bales company, Pearl Lang and company and guest artists this afternoon completed the 1952 American Dance Festival at Connecticut College here.

The city's Boy Scouts did their good deed en masse yesterday, contributing 5,000 articles of clothing and equipment for Italian youths in exchange for an inspection tour of the Italian liner Saturnia.
There was more brass in Lewisohn Stadium yesterday than at any time in its thirty-five-year history.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24 -- The keynote of the sixth congress of the Yugoslav Communist party, which is scheduled to convene in Zagreb, Croatia, Oct. 19, will be intensification of the struggle against the bourgeois ideology of the West and Soviet ideas of bureaucratic government in the East.
Today's program for the conventions of the American Legion and affiliated organizations follows:

A reach, a lunge and a dive, each in the outfield, tell the story of yesterday's Stadium struggle between the Yankees and Tigers. The first play saved two runs for the Tigers, the second cost the Yankees two and the third gave Casey Stengel's league leaders three runs, a 4-2 victory and a two-game lead over the Indians.

Traces of Braque, Picasso and Matisse may, surprisingly enough, be discerned in several of the designs decorating a collection of ceramics included in a special exhibit arranged by the Asahi Press and shown at the Takashimaya store in this city.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Aug. 24 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe for the last two and one-half months, has begun to show a radical change in his approach to the task confronting him, according to some of his closest associates.

Celanese Corporation of America and Coltejer, largest cotton textile company in Colombia, have jointly established a new viscose rayon producing company in Colombia, it was announced over the week-end by Harold Blancke, president of Celanese.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (UP) -The Braves took advantage of six Pirate errors to score four unearned runs, two of them in the tenth inning, and win the finale of a double-header, 5--3, after losing the opener, 4--3, before a crowd of 12,349 today.

The six-story apartment house at 3501-9 Broadway, northwest corner of West 143d Street in the lower Washington Heights section, has been sold by the Maple Management Corporation (Roosevelt and Charles Gabriel) to Joyalan Realty, Inc., through Schimmer, Kerner and Feder, brokers.
Highly satisfactory field tests of an all-electronic color television system have been going on for months in New York and other areas, with results now described as "superb."
Joseph Freeman has been appointed general manager and director of research of L. L. Manufacturing Company, Upland, Chester, Pa. He was formerly with Metlab Company of Philadelphia.

Federal, state and city officials were warned yesterday by employing stevedores that a crippling waterfront strike, similar to the one that paralyzed port operations here for twenty-five days last fall, was imminent.

Typical Spanish and Moorish motifs, tempered in color and design to suit a modern interior, keynote a new collection of hand-loomed wool rugs made in Alpujara, in southern Spain. The rugs may be seen by appointment and are available through decorators from the Lorton Studios, 21 East Sixty-second Street.

BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 24 -- The carrier Ticonderoga, known by the men who served on her in World War II as the "Queen of the Fleet," is in the world's largest drydock at the Naval Shipyard Annex here, undergoing a $50,000,000 modernization.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 -Australia's three-year hold on the United States Lawn Tennis Association's national doubles crown was broken partially today.

A history of England between the years 1841 and 1851, the early part of Queen Victoria's reign, entitled "The Age of Paradox," will be published in the fall by Rinehart. The author is John W. Dodds of Stanford University, brother of Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here yesterday:

The business woman, coming home from vacation, is offered new fall fashions for returning to her social activities or her office by Patterns of The Times today. These styles are fashion-right on the speaker's platform, at a dinner engagement or at business.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Four of the ninety competing teams tied for top honors with net best-ball cards of 66, five below par, in the Hampshire Country Club's third pro-member tournament today.

This year there have been two wonderful books on industries. The first was "Glass" by Harlan Logan, devoted to the history and development of that material. The second, just published, is "Flour for Man's Bread"* by John Storck and Walter Dorwin Teague.

With banners proclaiming "Hungary's liberation is the road to liberation for all" and "Free Americans for Free Hungary," enough Hungarians and Hungarian-Americans to form a parade five blocks long yesterday honored St. Stephen, the Hungarian king whose day, Aug. 20, has been a national holiday since 1092.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -The Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., representing 300,000 workers in the telephone industry, today demanded broad changes in company-financed pension plans to provide a minimum $100 a month retirement benefit, exclusive of Social Security.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee reported today that a construction "fiasco" promised to increase the cost of United States air bases in North Africa by at least $120,000,000.

A call for a return to the fourfold unity of place, purpose, experience and action that characterized the evangelical victory of the early church of Jesus Christ was voiced by the Rev. Dr. W. H. Rogers yesterday morning. He spoke on "The Essentials of Spiritual Victory" at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.
HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, West German Socialist leader, who died last Wednesday, was lowered into his grave today without a Christian service and without a spoken word.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Agnew Fisher's Spree led home Jim Sheldon's Abisi today in an eleven-boat Luders-sixteen race which highlighted the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's championship series regatta for the Indian Harbor and Riverside fleets. Bantam, owned by Don McClave and Roger Seymour, was third, ahead of Nancy and Tony Hogan's My Stars.

Robert A. Merritt, 32-year-old figure familiar in night clubs around town, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in the investigation into vice conditions in the city, particularly in cafe society circles.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Aug. 24 -William Fisher Jr. of Leewood and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches carded a 34, 35 -- 69 to win the Leewood Country Club's third annual miexd scotch foursomes member-guest tournament by two strokes today.

When Mme. Margarita Gallo-Muller first came to this country in 1948 on a fellowship to the United Nations, it was American breakfasts to which she found it most difficult to become accustomed. At home in Chile, the morning meal was simply coffee and toast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP)--Professional and scientific men called in the draft are receiving only half the normal basic infantry training in order to take full advantage of their special skills, the Army said today.

In your editorial "Recovery in Germany" you give high praise to the Germans for their "striking recovery" under a "liberal system of free enterprise." You speak of her pulling herself "out of the collapse of her own making by hard work under an efficient and productive system."

INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., Aug. 24 (AP) -- A C-47 Army transport plane crashed and burned attempting to land here at Muir Field today but all six aboard -- including Gen. Leon W. Johnson, commanding general of the Continental Air Command, and three other generals -- escaped without serious injury, a Pennsylvania National Guard spokesman said.
HONOLULU, Aug. 24 -- If present wage-and-work negotiations in Hawaii's sugar industry succeed, this island territory is hopeful of at least nine or ten months of labor peace.

First there was wind, then there was none and finally there was aplenty yesterday on Long Island Sound for the fifteenth anniversary regatta of the Bayside Yacht Club in which 109 sailing craft spread their wings of various sizes.

Enamored of "The Circus of Dr. Lao," Burgess Meredith was in earnest when he recently said that he expected to act this season in the Gwyn Conger-Nathaniel Benchley dramatization of Charles Finney's novel. The American National Theatre and Academy was to have offered it last season after the March tryout in Palm Beach, where Mr. Meredith appeared in it.

Unlike the "klieg light" society in which it finds itself, the church must discover a sense of the silence of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday in his final sermon at Riverside Church. He has served as guest preacher there this month.

Mayor Impellitteri's Administration may have to choose between a 5-cent fare rise on the municipal transit lines and the imposition of heavy new special taxes to meet the city's minimum expenses for the fiscal year starting next July 1, it was indicated yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 -- A four-engined British cargo plane, laden with West Berlin manufactures, crashed today a mile and a half outside the city in the Soviet zone of Germany. The flight engineer was killed but the pilot and navigator returned to the city uninjured.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 24 -Following the conclusion of the men's national amateur at Seattle yesterday, the golfing spotlight will be turned here during the next six days as the United States Golf Association's women's amateur championship begins tomorrow at the Waverley Country Club.

WEST ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 24 -- America's best-known husband-and-wife team of speedboat daredevils, Mr. and Mrs. C. Mulford Scull of Ventnor, N. J., had a gala afternoon today, winning two feature events in a new outboard-inboard regatta under the auspices of the Yacht Club of Pleasantville.

New methods of handling administrative work in connection with the extensive purchasing operations of the New York Quarter-master Procurement Agency have helped to simplify and improve the mechanics of procurement, according to Brig. Gen. R. P. Hollis, commanding officer of the agency.

With the Russian players drawing a bye in the fourth round, four matches were staged in the international team chess championship at Helsinki yesterday. However, the five-hour session failed to produce a decision, according to a report from Finland.

As a Colombian citizen, independently deriving my livelihood from a farm in New York State, I think I have the right to scan some of the concepts on Colombian affairs set forth in your editorial of Aug. 16.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 24 -Reggie Pearman of New York ran 500 meters in 1:01.1 in a track meet sponsored by the Buffalo Fire Fighters Association today, surpassing the listed world record of 1:02.

MADRID, Aug. 24 -- The Spanish Government indicated through the press today that a fundamental objective of its foreign policy was to improve relations with the United States and that it desired to reach a reasonable compromise on United States aid.
CAIRO, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -Egypt's new regime today lifted a corner of the curtain that shrouded the private life of former King Farouk.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Dominating factor in the grain futures trade last week was the bearish Canadian situation, with a record wheat crop in prospect in the Dominion and a large carryover of old barley and oats as well as wheat. Partially offsetting the bearish statistics however has been evidence of demand for cash wheat in this country from both millers and warehouse interests active enough to cause price improvement.

One's first, instinctive reaction to the Soviet note proposing a four-power conference on Germany is that it contains nothing new and therefore will have to be rejected out of hand. Certainly, we all appear to be going around in circles, getting nowhere.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Carl Scheib held the White Sox to four hits for a 5-1 victory in the second game today as the Athletics split a double-header and retained fourth place. Chicago won the opener, 11 -- 7, behind a fifteen-hit attack.

TORONTO, Aug. 24 -- All summer long the problem of what to do about the United States dollar has been plaguing Canadians. If they accepted their neighbor's money at par they realized that they would lose 2 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent. But if they suggested that the United States dollar was worth only ninety-seven or less Canadian cents they might lose a friend and a customer.

Organized labor as a pressure group is apparently determined to maximize its influence in the 1952 election. The C. I. O.'s executive board has already endorsed Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic party's Presidential nominee. The A. F. L., more cautious before departing from its established policy of withholding endorsement from Presidential candidates, has invited both Governor Stevenson and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee for President, to address its convention next month.

This week, in Geneva, there will take place a conference at a high diplomatic level that can affect the well-being of more than a third of a billion persons. Those persons are the simple folk of India and Pakistan, whose interests have been injured by the continuing clash between the two Governments over the disposition of Kashmir.
Capturing six of the eleven events, the New York A. C. scored 115 points to take the James H. Hughes Memorial Trophy in the metropolitan championship rowing regatta on the Harlem yesterday.
Four new films, including importations from France and Russia, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The American Legion's Forty and Eight fun-making organization shared an amusing afternoon yesterday with 600,000 New Yorkers as the society staged its traditional high-jinks parade down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-sixth to Thirty-second Street.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 -- The Giants lost a couple of fly balls in the sun today at Crosley Field. They lost a two-run, ninth-inning double-play ball that went through Dave Williams' legs. They split a double-header where they might have won two games.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -The Government has clarified its policy in regard to the nationalization of foreign companies operating in India. T. T. Krishnamachari, the Central Government's Minister for Commerce and Industry, said in Calcutta last week that there was no ambiguity in the nationalization policy.

Concerned over the lag of private investment in Israel, several hundred Zionist leaders here yesterday adopted an economic program, with special emphasis on private initiative, designed to help build up the state's industrial and agricultural enterprises.

New York in August is not for New Yorkers -- who are mostly somewhere else, even if it's only for the week-end. Especially is this true along Fifth Avenue in the midtown shopping region, and more especially after nightfall, when the lights are on.

NOVELISTS, like the rest of us, are human and fallible. Naturally, then, some of their novels are bound to disappoint readers who admired their better works. Less well-written, less interesting and less significant, they are the inevitable consequence of mere mortals writing and living in an imperfect world. And often they have characteristic minor virtues that endear them to readers who cherish their authors' major books.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 24 -Mr. and Mrs. Dave Kelly of New Canaan, Conn., showed entries from Leon Hamdon's Wee-3 Stables of New Rochelle to such excellent advantage today that two of the horses captured championship ribbons at the Long Island Chapter Professional Horsemen's Association show.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 -- Benelux relations continue strained. Combined action by Belgian industries, farmers and trade unions, supported by the Belgian Government, is directed against growing Dutch exports to Belgium which in August contributed to the first Belgian deficit with the European Payments Union.
TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 25 (AP) -Eight Army tactical summary 155, for Sunday's activities:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A long-secret report purporting to show how seven major companies control the production and distribution of most of the world's oil, outside of Russia and the countries behind the Iron Curtain, was made public today by the Senate Small Business Committee's subcommittee on monopoly.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 24 -- Humanists and ethical culture leaders from ten countries, meeting in their first international congress, have found that their three days of discussion so far have produced more questions than answers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, reported today that on the basis of studies in his department's field offices throughout the nation there would be no major rises in consumer goods prices this year as a result of the increased cost of steel.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 21 -- This country, center of the stormiest post-war controversies over faked masterpieces, is finally taking a calm and comprehensive look at what art forgery is all about.

Haiti, Nicaragua and Panama rate the highest of all Latin-American countries for credits and collections among United States exporters, according to a survey conducted by the Foreign Credit Interchance Bureau. The survey, covering the first six months of 1952, showed the three top countries which enjoyed identical ratings were followed closely by Mexico, the Dominican Republic and Cuba.

Tibet may be on the "Roof of the World" and about as far from New York as either of the poles, but it has considerable importance in the Asiatic picture. Robert Trumbull's dispatch from Darjeeling in today's TIMES throws some interesting light on this obscure country.

The Schwegmann super market in New Orleans is selling approximately 2,000 separate items at prices well below legal minimums set under the Louisiana "fair trade" laws. A spokesman for John Schwegmann Jr., its president, said the large Southern retail organization would continue this cut price policy despite both Federal and State legal prohibitions.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Shelly Mayfield, home club pro, posted a course-record 32, 31 -- 63, seven strokes under par, to figure in the first five prizes in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Tommy Collins, Boston's featherweight title contender, chased Glen Flanagan of St. Paul almost every minute of the way while pounding out a unanimous decision in their fifteen-round elimination boxing bout tonight at the Boston Garden.
Taxpayers don't like to pay taxes.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 26 -- Nature took a hand yesterday to complicate still further the United Nations' problems at Panmunjom, where Allied and Communist delegations have battled for almost a year over an armistice in the Korean war.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 -- A prediction that air freight, which now constitutes 6 to 8 per cent of American Airlines' total business, will increase to 33 per cent of the company's activities in ten years was made today by C. R. Smith, president of the airline.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- The letter-writing battle over the proposed extension of a jet plane runway to within 500 feet of Southern State Parkway at Farmingdale went into its third week today with a letter from Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, to Mundy I. Peale, president of Republic Aviation Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, denied today that the report of the Federal Trade Commission on an alleged international oil cartel was made public at this time, after having been kept secret for more than a year, for political reasons.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Plans for merging the New Rochelle Trust Company and the Huguenot Trust Company here were announced today. Ralph T. Tyner Jr., president of New Rochelle Trust, and Clayton E. Bixby, president of Huguenot Trust, said directors had approved the proposal and it would become effective Nov. 28 if two-thirds of the stockholders agreed on Nov. 26.

A dividend of 12 1/2 cents payable Sept. 15 has been declared by Chicago Yellow Cab Company. The company paid 25 cents in previous quarters. Higher expenses brought about by an increase of the taxicab license fee in Chicago from $5 to $40, increased limits of personal injury insurance and a fare rate insufficient to meet rising costs were cited as among the reasons for the dividend reduction.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:

An "outraged" Federal grand jury returned thirty-four indictments yesterday charging sixty-five persons, mostly manufacturers of jewelry, with being part of a $500,000,000-a-year gold smuggling racket.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Sachio Kamo, the Japanese champion, was forced to three sets before defeating Joan Merciadis, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, in the opening round of the Maidstone Club invitation singles tournament today.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn has a strength of 350 to 375 votes among delegates of the Democratic state convention that will choose a candidate for United States Senator on Thursday night, Cashmore supporters Said yesterday.

JACKSON, Mich., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The death in prison of Heywood Patterson, one of the South's famed "Scottsboro boys," of cancer Friday night was announced today by southern Michigan prison authorities.

In their traditional flag-and-flower-decked opening session, 1,500 delegates of the American Legion Auxiliary heard their retiring president, Mrs. E. A. Campbell of Homer, La., call yesterday for an increased effort in behalf of Universal Military Training, national defense measures, price control and uprooting of communism in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, posed a question today as to the effect of Saturday night's bolting of the Republican party by Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, on "such Senators" as Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois.
The recent steel strike in the United States posed a rather serious problem for Brazil's steel magnates, but they are moving swiftly to overcome it.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 25 -- On the beautiful turf of the Nassau Country Club, one of the most attractive of all lawn tennis tournaments was revived today and competition was renewed for one of the oldest and most prized trophies in the game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The United Nations has received no word from its visiting mission in West Africa concerning incidents along the border between the Gold Coast and French Togoland, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Trusteeship Division said tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- A 5-year-old horse from New Zealand made a sensational American debut at Saratoga today. Classowa, ridden by Conn McCreary, ran like Stymie in the stretch, made up something like ten lengths on the last quarter of a mile and won by a nose.

What is delinquency? Two hundred and fifty experts in the field met last week at the annual St. Lawrence University Institute on Delinquency and Crime to discuss this question and find out what they could do to help both the public and the offender meet the problems created by delinquency. They agreed that delinquency is an abstract, but that delinquents are not -- they are individuals and often troubled ones who need help.

It was encouraging to read in the columns of your newspaper that the American Heritage Foundation and other civic-minded organizations are conducting a campaign to get out the vote. I believe that this drive can achieve a greater measure of success if these organizations would also campaign for a liberalization of the election laws in regard to minority parties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Henry L. Straus' stretch-driving Pilaster came from last place in the six-horse field to post a length victory in the Union Veteran Purse over the mile-and-a-furlong turf course at Atlantic City today.

President Truman has made no definite plans for the period after he leaves the White House in January, his press secretary, Joseph Short, said yesterday in Washington, according to The Associated Press.

Aug. 15 marked the last night of this season's series of concerts by the Guggenheim Memorial Foundation and Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman. In appreciation of their yearly gift of good music, pleasant summer evenings and pleasurable memories they deserve our heartfelt thanks and an invitation to return again next year.

A continued lag in most types of building construction is blamed for the decline in new building work in New York City during the first seven months of this year. Preliminary figures released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor showed that the $181,000,000 total in New York up to the end of July was 21 per cent below the corresponding period last year.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Aug. 25 -- An advance type jet fighter that seeks out its targets by radar shot down a B-17 bomber into the Gulf of Mexico by mistake today.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 25 -- A new face was painted on this Down East seaport's business district today in a voluntary stint prefacing an economic rehabilitation effort. Men, women and children -- more than 400 residents and visitors -- scraped, brushed and painted fifty buildings on the main street of the nation's easternmost city.

BRISTOL, Va., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bill Bell, 18-year-old rookie right-hander, registered his third no-hit, no-run game of the season tonight as he pitched Bristol's Twins to a 4-0 seven-inning triumph over Bluefield in the Class D Appalachian League.

An addition to this week's new films is "The Devil Makes Three," a Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer drama made in Germany and starring Gene Kelly and Pier Angeli, due on Friday at the Globe. Andrew Marton directed and Richard Goldstone produced from a screen play by Jerry Davis, based on a story by Lawrence Bachman.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sammy Urzetta hit the rain-drenched trail to the Canadian amateur golf championship today in impressive fashion, knocking three strokes off par for thirteen holes of the rugged Capilano Golf and Country Club layout.

Time has done a little more than add frost to Legionnaires' temples since they came to New York on their first conventions. They move now like men whose tendons have lost some of the early tightness, and a majority carry more weight than they could have squeeezed into trenches in 1917.

Two thousand persons attended a pontifical mass yesterday at the St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church, First Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, in connection with the thirty-first triennial convention of the First Catholic Slovak Union of the United States and Canada.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Official returns sent today to the Secretary of State at Albany show that there is a tie between State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, Republican, and Otto Kolinger, Rockland County cattle farmer of Monsey, who received four votes for the Democratic nomination for State Senator in the primary last Tuesday.

BONAVISTA, Nfld., Aug. 25 (UP) -- An unidentified freighter, after having burst into flames forty miles northeast of here, split in half and sank tonight, leaving no clue to her registry or the fate of her crew.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 26 -- The United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, said yesterday that crimes by United States troops here since Japan was restored to independence have been "remarkably low" in number. He told the Japan Federation of Bar Associations that its recent demand for tighter discipline might have been motivated by a desire for publicity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan for the distribution of additional assets of the Philadelphia Company.

NEWARK, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Tonatiuh Gutierrez, an unheralded Mexico City high school boy, swam the fastest heat today to qualify for the 1,500-meter free-style as the National Amateur Athletic Union senior outdoor swimming championships opened a four-day stand at the Hayes Park pool.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech to the American Legion in New York today, implying that the United States should seek not merely to contain the Soviet Union but to liberate its satellites, startled many observers here who suggested it would reinforce the fears in some quarters that the United States when better armed might seek a showdown with Moscow.
Herbert Kabat has been appointed general sales manager of Olympic Radio and Television, Inc., Long Island City.

William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, told the Public Service Commission yesterday that the arrangement William H. Draper Jr., his predecessor in the post, had made with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to finance the purchase of new locomotives and passenger cars "is a very good deal."

Rubber, cocoa and vegetable oils showed wide movements yesterday but most other commodities moved little or were mixed. Potatoes on the New York Mercantile Exchange had a market in which 636 carloads were traded but closed unchanged to 7 points lower.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The possibility of foul play was mentioned today by the police investigating the death of a young New York woman earlier believed to be a traffic accident victim.

DARJEELING, India, Aug. 25 -- The Chinese Communists now occupying Tibet plan to move 200,000 troops into the realm of the "living Buddha" to dominate India's Himalayan borders. In the long-range plan of the Reds, Communist infiltration into Afghanistan, the independent Himalayan kingdom of Nepal and the Indian-protected states of Bhutan and Sikkim is to be followed by penetration of India herself.
ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, promised tonight that he would wage a "gloves off" campaign for re-election to the Senate seat he has held for the last six years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- The Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council today called on the House Committee on Un-American Activities to "initiate legislation at once" to ban the importation and showing in this country of movies made abroad by persons identified as holding "membership or loyalty to the Communist party."

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Harry G. Shulman, president of the Baker Brush Company at 83 Grand Street, New York, was crushed to death under his new automobile last night in the driveway of a friend's home at 29 Brook Manor, New Castle. He was 55 years old and lived at 330 Douglas Road.

Fear of a port-wide wildcat dock strike, similar to the work stoppage that crippled shipping here for twenty-five days last fall, grew yesterday as wage review negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and employing stevedores continued with "no progress" reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Truman appointed Ellis O. Briggs, Ambassador to Czechoslovakia for the last three years, to be Ambassador to Korea.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation offered its 75,800 employes wage increases averaging 10 cents on hour today but met an immediate rebuff from the union representing the majority of the workers.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Growing optimism among small investors over Great Britain's economic situation led to a demand for British Government securities today. It advanced some undated issues 1 7s 6d ($3.85).
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Coach Eddie Erdelatz today started practice sessions for the first Navy football team completely of his own making.
DALLAS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Two races in Saturday's Democratic run-off in Texas were still too close to showy a certain victor in tabulations today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 25 -- One race was concluded today for the Sears Bowl, emblematic of the national junior sailing championship. That was in but a flicker of air. A second was attempted but a flat calm set in to stop it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- India expects within the next five years to make up at least 25 per cent of her annual 4,000,000-ton deficiency in food grains by means of improved methods of agriculture and wider use of arable land, Kashinath Damle, Joint Secretary of the Ministry of Food and Agriculture, told a news conference here today.

Four youths were arrested between 10 and 11:30 o'clock last night at Columbus Avenue and 108th Street as the police dispersed what they said were two gangs who had sworn to fight it out over of an insult to a 15-year-old girl at Broadway and 134th Street on Sunday.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Expansion of European trade by including Latin America in the European Payments Union was suggested today in the second annual report of the managing board of the Union.

Official inquiry will in due course determine responsibility for shoddy work in constructing a two-mile stretch of the Laurelton storm and sanitary sewer in Queens costing $185,000. But to some who have followed the various scandals of New York City government, and the surveys of city shortcomings, the most puzzling question that instantly arises and long persists is, Where were the inspectors who were supposed to see that the taxpayers were getting their money's worth?

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 -- Twenty-five United States business and community leaders, composing the planning commission for the annual Israel bond-issue campaign, which opens next month, arrived today by plant for a two-week study tour of Israel.

Production of men's shirts in June increased 15 per cent over the output for the corresponding 1951 month, bearing out the reversal of the industry trend started in May, the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers announced yesterday.

Any device that enables the Mayor and the Board of Estimate to determine policy as to public transportation more nearly on the basis of facts and less on the basis of politics is welcome. Creation of a permanent Transit Advisory Commission may prove to be a move in that direction. Only time will tell.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Gran Hamner's tenth inning home run today enabled the Phillies to score a 6-3 victory over the Cubs. A homer by Roy Smalley had forced the game into overtime.

CAIRO, Aug. 25 -- In its present stage, the Egyptian Army program for reclaiming 3,000,000 acres of arid desert with the help of United States Point Four dollars is concerned chiefly with a plan to see whether perennial grass for grazing or forage will grow on experimental plots in a Libyan desert coastal strip west of Alexandria.
CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- James T. Sherwin of New York City, the state champion, was a winner again today in the annual title tournament at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- President Truman today accepted an invitation to speak in Philadelphia Sept. 16 during the annual convention of the American Hospital Association.

Federal mediators seeking to avert a still threatening strike on the New York Central lines east of Buffalo will resume their efforts today. Mediation talks with union and company representatives, which moved to Washington last week, will begin again here.

WESTPORT, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The action of Congress last spring in eliminating an $800,000 appropriation for assistance to the states in combating stream pollution was attacked today by Earl Devendorf, director of the Bureau of Environmental Sanitation in the State Health Department, as the Interstate Commission on the Lake Champlain Basin convened for a two-day meeting.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25 -- W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, has arrived in Teheran accompanied by four experts in petroleum questions and will study the problem of giving assistance to the Iranian oil industry, according to a statement today by Abbas Parkhideh, chief of the sales commission of the Iranian National Oil Company.
Dwellings dominated the real estate trading in Long Island areas in transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Truman, by his failure to act forcefully on the alleged presence of Communists in the Government, created "McCarthyism," as applied to the tactics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, asserted in an interview today.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 25 -- The Third World Conference on Faith and Order today discussed the 12,000 word reports drafted by its five subcommittees on how to attain unity among Christian churches on doctrine, worship and communion.

On your editorial page of Aug. 19 I read a note in which the writer, commenting on certain recent manifestations of nationalism in Brazil, refers to these phenomena, generalizing them as "an evil that corrodes the whole of Latin America."

The Grand Council, Royal and Select Masters of New York, one of the York Rite bodies of Freemasonry, elected Howard L. Adams of Utica, N. Y., as Grand Master yesterday at the closing session of the organization's two-day assembly in the Commodore Hotel. He succeeds James G. Purdy of White Plains.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 25 -- Indonesian tin ore production reached a post-war record last month with 3,394 long tons, or 430 tons more than the June figure and almost 750 higher than the average for the first six months, according to statistics released today by the international tin study group.

Evidence is accumulating -- more rapidly than one would like to see -- that it will be a good thing when school gets under way again. For the first blush of summer vacation's freedom has long since worn off and the days now are filled with long periods of inaction, punctuated by the plaintive cry, "What can I do now?"

A 45-year-old auditor plunged to his death from the seventieth floor of the Empire State Building at 11:50 A. M. yesterday. He was Harry Lefker, who lived at the Shelburne Hotel, Lexington Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street, and had his own auditing concern, Harry Lefker Co., 165 Broadway.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Two British oil companies that have been accused in the United States of being members of an international oil cartel denied tonight that there was any such cartel or that they were guilty of monopolistic practices.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 25 -- The largest international naval command in history, extending across the Atlantic Ocean and from the North Pole to the Tropic of Cancer, prepared today to launch its first great naval maneuver.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- The International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union of North America, at the opening of its five-day thirty-fifth convention here, was urged today to retain its fifty-year policy of including strike-avoiding arbitration clauses in its labor contracts with publishers.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- British Government quarters seemed to be surprised today by the news that a major American oil executive, W. Alton Jones, was in Iran to look at the Abadan refineries; British oil men were not surprised.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- John L. Lewis is renewing his push for a spread-the-work plan in current negotiations for a new soft coal wage agreement between the United Mine Workers, which he heads, and the operators.

A dispatch from Jerusalem in these columns recently told of increased Soviet diplomatic and propaganda activity on the religious front there. The Russian Palestine Society has been recreated in Moscow and, backed by the Soviet Government, is laying claim to extensive properties in the Jerusalem area. Every effort is being made to fan pro-Soviet sympathy among Christian clergymen of different denominations in Israel.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Top-seeded Julie Sampson launched a strong bid for the United States girls' lawn tennis singles championship today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 25 -- While Nationalist Parliament members sat in Pretoria today as the High Court of Parliament to review the Appeal Court's invalidation of the Voters Law, which restricted the colored (mixed blood) franchise, leaders of all political groups in Natal Province except the Nationalists, who hold only three of sixteen seats there, conferred at Pietermaritzburg on how to maintain a "democratic" South Africa and defeat the Nationalists in the coming elections.

The secrecy with which W. Alton (Pete) Jones, president of Cities Service Company, has operated in Iran in discussions of that country's oil problems follows closely the pattern set for many years in his operation of vast oil and gas empire, both in this country and Canada.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Residents of Norwalk appear to be no more eager to have an electrical generating plant in their vicinity than are the citizens of Stamford, which has fought for twenty-one months to prevent the Connecticut Light and Power Company from building a plant on Cove Island there.
Savings deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks rose $105,000,000 in July, almost doubling the increase in that month last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Public Housing Administration announced today that seventy-nine local housing authorities in twenty-three states would call for sealed bids on $170,719,000 in bonds to be opened at 3 P. M., Tuesday, Sept. 23. The bonds will be formally advertised by each local authority on Tuesday, Sept. 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government approved today a schedule of dollar-and-cents ceiling prices on cottonseed feed products. Officials said the new ceilings would mean an average increase of about $2 a ton for the country as a whole.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Favorable weather all through the Canadian grain belt, with domestic crop conditions good except for the continued heat wave in the Southwest, discouraged holders of wheat and coarse grains today on the Board of Trade.

Michael Todd's extravaganza, "A Night in Venice," will remain at the Marine Stadium at Jones Beach a while longer than originally planned. Instead of closing on Aug. 31, the Johann Strauss musical will play its final performance on Saturday night, Sept. 6.

Virgil Trucks, righthanded pitcher of the Tigers, became the third hurler in major league history to toss two no-hitters in a single season when he held the Yankees hitless at the Stadium yesterday as the Detroit club defeated the world champions, 1 to 0.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- Europe, particularly France and West Germany, is swarming with sharp-dealing commission agents seeking through a variety of tricks to profit from the United States $1,000,000,000 offshore military purchasing program.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, told the American Legion's national convention at Madison Square Garden yesterday that the United States must use its influence and power to help the Communist-controlled nations of Eastern Europe and Asia throw off the yoke of Russian tyranny.
The sole item on the American Legion's convention schedule today is the annual Legion parade, facts about which follow:...

Patterned glass bases for table lamps, three unusual designs in floor lamps by Gino Sarfatti, and a traverse fixture for a ceiling light are included in a collection of lamps introduced today by Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street. The lamps are availabel through decorators.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today that eligible veterans would be admitted to its hospitals hereafter on the basis of nine new priority groups.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Former President Herbert Hoover escaped injury early today when the mountain lodge in which he was a week-end guest burned to the ground.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 -- With little or no festival fanfare, the New York City Ballet tiptoed into the Scottish capital yesterday and emerged tonight on the stage of the Empire Theatre here to dance before an audience composed mainly of partisans of the Sadler's Wells Ballet family.

The only hope for a peaceful and better world lies in mass communication through the printed and spoken, word, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University declared yesterday as delegates gathered here from the nation's ninety-five accredited journalism schools for their annual convention.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens formally asked Mayor Impellitteri yesterday to suspend city collection of millions of dollars in sewer assessment bills still to be levied on thousands of residents of Laurelton and neighboring areas, pending further investigation of construction.

Dr. Arthur Pound, former New York State Historian, has come up with a novel solution to the city's problem of illegal parking. He believes that if a policeman went up to a car parked in violation of regulations and let the air out of the tires, there would be few second offenders.
OTTAWA, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Federal Resources experts said today there will be many complications in the development of a huge Alaska aluminum plant by the Aluminum Company of America.
TRENTON, Aug. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will discuss campaign issues and strategy with New Jersey Republican leaders at his New York headquarters on Thursday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 25 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., conferred with Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson today and declared him "perhaps the most independent candidate" ever to run for President.
Following is the text of yesterday's address by General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, before the American Legion National Convention as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Concerning the report that W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, is in Iran discussing the oil situation, Burl S. Watson, executive vice president of Cities Service, issued yesterday the following statement, about the presence of the Jones group in Iran:

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- India notified Britain and Nepal today that the rights for the British army to use depots in India for processing Gurkha recruits must be discontinued "at an early date." Britain has been using Gurkha troops from Nepal in her forces for the last 137 years.
Your recent editorial describing the wonderful work carried on by the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society -- known more familiarly as Hias -- brings back a nostalgic feeling.

An investment banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. and including Lehman Brothers will place on the market today $6,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible subordinate debentures of Beaunit Mills, Inc., rayon tire yarn manufacturer.

Virgil Trucks, 33-year-old right-hander of Detroit's last-place Tigers, moved himself among the ultra select of the pitching craft at the Stadium yesterday when he blazed a no-hitter against the Yankees as the Bengals tripped the Bombers in the second and last game of their series, 1 to 0.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 25 (AP) -- An American judicial ban on repatriating eastern European children born during the Nazi occupation and adopted by German couples was extended today to include Yugoslavia.

Memorials can be of all shapes, kinds and sizes. They may be cast of iron, carved from wood, hewn from rock. They may be expressed in money for good causes, in scholarships; they may be found between the covers of a book or in the notes of a song. They need be none of these.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- In the controversy between the states and the Federal Government over property rights in the mineral and other products of the submerged lands between low-water mark and three miles out into the oceans the Executive and Congress have taken flatly opposing positions, with the Supreme Court in between but much closer to the contention of the Executive.
The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, major interurban utility serving New York City and New Jersey, reported yesterday that it had cut its losses sharply in the first seven months of this year.

The richest chocolate cake this department ever has tasted is the proud creation of Mme. Colette Hebert. Her product, however, is a cake in name only. It is a confection in which the flavor of chocolate is almost as intense as if it had been distilled into a perfume.

RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 25 -- The problem of providing adequate medical and hospital care for the rural people of the South, including tenant farmers, Negroes and indigents, was discussed here today at an all-day regional meeting of the President's commission on the health needs of the nation.

Southern and other paper manufacturers, particularly in the kraft field, are starting a campaign for one of their more important byproducts, tall oil. It comes from the skimming off the top of paper caldrons and contains resins and fatty acids valuable in a number of other industries, including plastics, linoleum, soap, adhesives and paint.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was light, and the marker closed barely steady, 11 points higher to 2 points lower.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Two natives of this British West African colony were killed and fifty were seriously injured by French border patrols when they tried to cross into neighboring French Togoland to present independence petitions to a United Nations mission, reports reaching here said today.

Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime director of the Office of Strategic Services, defended this country's intervention in Korea in an address last night, but said he resented any attempt to label the Korea combat a police action.

United States chess players are exerting strenuous efforts to remain near the top among the nine contending rivals in the final championship section of the international team tournament, a report from Helsinki, Finland, indicated yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Mariette Laframboise of Montreal, the defending Canadian junior women's singles tennis champion, gained the 1952 final today by defeating Carol Wolf of Buffalo, N. Y., the top-seeded foreign entry, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.
The American Legion convention heard two conflicting views yesterday on the conduct of the nation's foreign policy. To one it gave an ovation, while to the other it listened in relative silence.

A young designer with definite promise made his bow yesterday at Jay Thorpe with a custom collection of fall millinery. His name is Martin Belasco. His hats had a chic and easy youthful wearability that seem destined to win him speedy popularity.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 25 -- The fifty-seven room Morgan mansion on Morgan (East) Island in Long Island Sound, which the Russian delegation to the United Nations has long sought to buy, will become a residence for the Sisters of St. John the Baptist, a Roman Catholic order, according to negotiations finally worked out in New York today.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 25 -- In a drizzling rain at 9 A. M. today the inhabitant of the "sealed lips" village of Permatang Tinggi in the province of Wellesley in Northwest Malaya were moved from their homes to detention camps.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- An increasing tendency to "smear" Government employes, to ascribe dishonesty and inefficiency to all Federal workers, was regretted and denounced as the American Federation of Government Employes, A. F. L., opened its thirteenth biennial convention here today.

In a very quiet way there is a campaign in operation at the moment to limit the use of automobile horns to necessary occasions. Surprisingly enough, the campaign, which is limited to New York City at the present, is being sparked by the taxi drivers. Each cab in the city carries a banner in blue and white bearing the admonition, "Quiet, Please! Think Before You Honk."

Mediation efforts in the dispute between workers in East Coast shipyards and the Bethlehem Steel Company continued this morning after the midnight deadline for a strike passed, but a spokesman for the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., refused to confirm or deny whether the strike was in progress or not.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Halloween plans are in the making early at headquarters of the American Friends Service Committee here, but they are in strong contrast to the schemes for mischief so largely associated with the night.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Aug. 25 -- All but one of the twenty persons aboard a big Public Service bus miraculously escaped with their lives at 7:10 A. M. here today when the vehicle plunged thirty-five feet off the bridge carrying River Road over the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad, and finally landed upside down on the tracks.
TORONTO, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press) -- A broad picture of the natural resources of Pakistan will unfold in Toronto in the next four years.

The stock market again went through the motions of operating yesterday without bringing forth any concrete results. With trading lagging well under the 1,000,000 share mark for the fifth consecutive session, prices leaned to the lower side, but by fractional margins.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The great horse mackerel marathon, known more formally as the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, will begin to churn the waters from Watch Hill to Nebraska Shoals tomorrow. The bits of herring and mossbunker chum should enrich most of Long Island Sound by Wednesday.

In quest of information to guide its public relations program and its Washington campaigns on the capital-gains tax and margin requirements, the New York Stock Exchange has prepared a questionnaire to be filled by all its members for each stock transaction of Sept. 10 and 17.

VIENNA, Aug. 25 -- Dr. Josef Joham, managing director of the Austrian Creditanstalt, Austria's largest nationalized financial institution, departed for Switzerland a fortnight after the arrest of five directors of the bank on a charge of illegal exchange transactions.

CWM BUGAIL was an odd place for an Oxford don to settle, a remote valley in the mountains of North Wales. But Joseph Aubrey Pugh was an odd don, a sound scholar but an ineffectual teacher who had come into a little money and wanted to live the simple life among simple people. Pentref village consisted of only twenty-one houses, a schoolhouse, a chapel and the sub-post office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 193 battle casualties in Korea, including 46 killed, 122 wounded, 18 missing and 7 injured. The following were from New York (none from New Jersey and Connecticut):
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 25 -- The invitation grass court junior tennis tournament started today at the Piping Rock Club and play reached the semi-final round.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 25 (UP) -- Jimmy Clark defeated Jim Turnesa, Professional Golfers Association champion, by one stroke today in the play-off match of the $15,000 Fort Wayne open golf tournament.

A jaunty unit clad in black and green and known as the "Reilly Raiders" marched off with the top honors at the American Legion's annual drum and bugle corps contest last night in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- Although they lost to the Reds tonight, 3 -- 0, the Giants regained second place in the National League, two percentage points ahead of the twice-beaten Cardinals and ten and one-half games behind the first-place Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The members of a Brink's armored truck crew reported today that $65,000 had "mysteriously" disappeared from their locked and parked truck while they had been out to lunch. A few hours later, the police picked up two former Brink's employes for questioning.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- A tie resulted for top honors in a Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Vernon Hills Country Club course today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Ridgefield, former United States Representative from Fairfield County, has moved into the lead for the Republican nomination for United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Brien McMahon.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company, manufacturer of air and gas compressors, rock drills, oil and gas engine pumps, pneumatic tools, air conditioning and refrigeration machinery, general mining and other machinery, had a net profit of $9,876,697 in the first half of this year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Minot Frazier Jelke 3d, 22-year-old heir to an oleomargarine fortune, was indicted yesterday with Raymond Russell Davioni, a jobless press agent, as a result of a grand jury investigation into a lucrative vice set-up here.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 25 -- Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta began the defense of her title in the women's national amateur golf championship by winning the medal in the qualifying test today with a 76 at the Waverley Country Club.

Acting to meet a pay-off on the unexchanged portion of its Sept. 1 certificates of indebtedness amounting to about $225,000,000; to obtain funds for cash redemptions of tax savings notes, and for the usual heavy month-end expenses, the United States Treasury yesterday issued a call on tax and loan accounts for more than $1,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The reshuffled Indians scored four runs in the ninth inning tonight for a 7-2 victory over the Senators to climb to within one game of the league-leading Yankees.

Complaints that clotted refuse had made an eyesore of the southeast end of the Fifty-ninth Street lake in Central Park brought orders for a prompt clean-up yesterday from William H. Latham, director of maintenance and operations of the Department of Parks.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25 -- The United States Air Force spread its magic carpet today to help fly 9,000 stranded Moslem pilgrims to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, the principal target of a critical Senate report on the air base "fiasco" in French Morocco, replied today that what had happened there was not unusual for large rush military construction jobs.

New York City has borrowed $50,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due Oct. 27 at 1 1/2 per cent interest, City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold to twenty-three banks and trust companies here by allotment as follows:

An editorial asserting that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was "running like a dry creek" in his campaign for the Presidency appeared yesterday in many of the nineteen newspapers of the Scripps-Howard chain, which had declared before the conventions that he was the man best qualified for the office.

Typical of the confusion about tin is the report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 2 quoting a speaker in the British House of Commons to the effect that Britain had realized a profit of $53,000,000 from the Truman-Churchill deal wherein Britain purchased 20,000 long tons of tin from the Singapore market to trade for American steel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Mario Lanza today renewed his work strike against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and the studio countered with an announcement that it was "contemplating" filing suit against the tenor for "substantial damages caused by production delays" to "The Student Prince."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 -- A combined afternoon and night crowd of 52,262 at Sportsman's Park saw the league-leading Dodgers beat the recently red-hot Cardinals twice today, 3 -- 1 in daylight and 9 -- 5 under the lights.

THE most heart-warming baseball development in recent years is the institution of the practice of staging an Old-Timers' Day as the fabled heroes of the past don uniforms once again to thrill young and old alike. The newer generation is seeing them for the first time, perhaps, and the graybeards find memories jostled pleasantly by seeing treasured favorites once again.

In his address to the American Legion yesterday on the peril which is facing our country in today's troubled world General Eisenhower delivered a message of calmness, confidence and leadership. Though much less outspoken in delivery than in the released script this speech was more reminiscent of the real "Ike" than any he has delivered in some time; it offered a broad program behind which Americans can unite.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Aug. 25 (AP) -- William Loeb, publisher of The Manchester Union Leader, today joined Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, in calling for creation of a new "American party."

Plans for improving the city's traffic facilities were in the limelight at yesterday's hearing by the City Planning Commission on requests by the five borough presidents for money for new and pending projects contained in the 1953 capital budget.

Directors of the American Foreign Power Company declared yesterday the first dividend that has been issued on the new common stock since reorganization of the utility holding company last February. Subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission, 10 cents a share in cash ad one share of common stock for each 100 shares of common stock held will be paid by the company.
