RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Gaining two first places and a second today in the national junior championship for the Sears Bowl, Martin (Skip) Purcell and the Indian Harbor crew from Greenwich, Conn., sailed into the point lead. They represent Long Island Sound.

XAVANTINA, Brazil, Aug. 25 -A handful of determined Brazilians, working to push back the jungle frontier and develop the country's interior, are pushing an automobile road into the heart of little known Mato Grosso jungle at the rate of half a mile a day. Already they have reached a point forty miles past Xavantina in a region made famous by the unsolved disappearance of the British explorer, Col. Percy Fawcett, in 1925.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Four members of a St. Louis Federal grand jury that investigated tax fraud cases last year testified before a House Judiciary subcommittee today that the jury had been misguided by Department of Justice attorneys into making a report that one juror described as "a whitewash of previous handling of tax cases" by officials of the department.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 -- Newspaper publishers and newspaper pressmen have a mutual interest that makes strikes unwise and the publishers hope that the pressmen will renew their arbitration agreement, Charles F. McCahill, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told the convention of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union of North America, A. F. L., here today.

We hope that John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, may prove to be wrong in his warning to federal, state and city officials that a repetition of last year's crippling waterfront strike is imminent.

Jackson and Clay Counties, Mo., sold yesterday $16,000,000 of bonds at an interest cost of 3.3732 per cent to finance construction of the Paseo Bridge over the Missouri River from Kansas City to North Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued orders today requiring Local No. 2 of the Printing Pressmen's Union and twelve New York daily newspapers to cease discriminating against non-union employes and to pay back wages to those who had suffered such discrimination since 1948.

Harold Gruber, president of Mannequin Fashions Inc; Maj. William J. Spahr, U. S. Army; Martin P. Collin, Herman F. Bremer, Floyd E. Lamb, Robert W. Gensch, Dr. Charles Sandler and Mrs. Gertrude Weisbrod, in Equitable Life Assurance Society's Fordham Hill Apartments at University Heights.

WESTPORT, N. Y., Aug. 26 -E. O. Stanley, chairman of the United States section of the Joint International Commission for the Development of Water Resources With Canada, endorsed unequivocally today the proposal to improve the Chambly Canal and Richelieu River in Quebec to a depth of twelve feet.

The stock market yesterday drew further into its shell. Price changes again were within narrow limits, with volume restricted and little attention accorded the key issues. Main emphasis of the session was on an array of unrelated specialties which had no conclusive effect on the general price structure.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 26 -- Delegates from six countries voted today to establish an International Union of Humanist and Ethical Associations with its seat in New York to provide "a third way out of the present crisis of civilization" apart from religion and totalitarianism.

HONOLULU, Aug 26 -- Although the Hawaiian islanders have adopted a proposed state constitution by a margin of three to one and both major political parties call for Hawaiian statehood in their platforms, opposition to immediate addition of the forty-ninth star to the American flag has not disappeared among territorial residents.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 26 -- The leader of the Nazi-like Iranian National Socialist or Sumka party, Davoud Monchi Zadeh, has been arrested and the headquarters of his party have been taken over by the police.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- James C. Penney, the Missouri farm boy who rose to become head of a nation-wide chain of 1.630 department stores, said today that a $225,000 gift of an endowed herd of Guernsey cattle would be made to the University of Missouri this autumn instead of by will as originally planned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -Standard Oil Company of California protested today that it should not be required to produce what it said may be "millions" of documents for a Federal grand jury preparing to scrutinize global oil trade "arrangements."

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday announced the indefinite suspension of Joey Maxim, light-heavyweight champion, and his manager, Jack Kearns, for failure to go through with a contracted London fight.

Federal narcotics agents disclosed yesterday that they had made an "important" arrest in the apprehension Monday night of a 53-year-old ex-convict from Cleveland, carrying a small, zippered bag containing 100 ounces of heroin.
HAVANA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- United States ownership of sugar mills in Cuba is declining.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican Vice Presidential candidate said today that Gov. Adali E. Stevenson's position on coastal oil lands gave voters "a clear cut issue between the two Presidential candidates."
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug 26 (UP) -- The Republicans of Texas, for the first time in the state's history, put fifteen Democratic candidates, including Gov. Allan Shivers, on their November ballot today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -Communist and Allied negotiators met again today at Panmunjom to discuss an armistice in the Korean war and then adjourned immediately without recording any progress. It was the fifth time that the talks had been put into a week's recess when neither side had anything new to say on the deadlocked issue of prisoner exchange.

A program for strengthening the financial structure of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation was disclosed yesterday when the Henry J. Kaiser Company, a holding organization owned by Mr. Kaiser, his family and associates, announced in Oakland, Calif., the consummation of loans under a long-term $22,000,000 loan agreement executed last month with a group of banks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- F. Leland Howard, assistant director of the Mint, said today that the Mint initiated the investigations that led to a New York grand jury's indictment of sixty-five persons on charges of engaging in a gold smuggling racket.
SEOUL, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Night-flying Allied attack-bombers struck twice at Communist supply depots last night as the skies over North Korea cleared for the first time in four days.

Deputy Health Commissioner Dr. Samuel Front, in commenting to the press on the occasion of the recent typhoid fever outbreak in Long Island, questioned the value of periodic health examinations of food handlers. He is alleged to have "described the system as totally inadequate, saying that a person found perfectly well might develop an illness soon after a physical examination."

Bird watchers are, of course, a dedicated race and one set apart from the prosaic remainder of mankind. With their field-glasses, pocket manuals, notebooks and enthusiasm, they are to be highly envied. Not everyone has the delicate emotional balance needed for bird watching, however, and for these others there must be a different set of avocations.

One of the eight children of a South American fisherman arrived in New York yesterday for a year's schooling in the United States. Eighteen-year-old Dominico Quandt had never before been off his home island of Aruba, twenty miles off the coast of Venezuela, had never seen a train or ridden in an airplane.

THE most vibrant figure in professional football is George Preston Marshall, the heap big chief of the Washington Redskins. The Magnificent Marshall crackles with ideas like a magneto giving off sparks. He is a master showman and has made many superlatively fine contributions to the sport in matters of both policy and rules.

Official indifference to housing conditions of extreme squalor was charged by City Council President Rudolph Halley in a thirty-three-page report on substandard dwellings he submitted yesterday to the City Council at its regular meeting.

A proposed law that would make parents liable to $25 fine for wilful destruction of city property by their children under 16 years of age was passed yesterday by the City Council after an hour of heated debate. The vote was 13 to 8.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 26 -Plans of the Long Island Lighting Company to build a $25,000,000 electricity-generating station of 160,000 kilowatts capacity in the Town of Hempstead were disclosed here today.

Broadway's celebrated Empire Theatre, which has been purveying entertainment since 1893, and an adjacent building at the southeast corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street will be torn down next June to make way for a large office building, it became known yesterday.

State Senator Harold I. Panken, who was beaten for the Democratic renomination in the primary Aug. 19 by Julius A. Archibald; obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Arthur A. Schwartz an order directing Mr. Archibald and the Board of Elections to show cause why there should not be a recount of the ballots. The order is returnable on Thursday.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 26 -- David (Skippy) Browning, the slender perfectionist from the University of Texas, today completed an unparalleled sweep of American and global springboard diving honors by recapturing the national title in his specialty.
TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick told Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, today that only minor "detail work" costing about $1,160,640 was needed to bring two controversial North African air bases up to standard.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 26 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, will invade the eastern political arena tomorrow to state some of his basic beliefs on civil liberties and patriotism before the American Legion's National convention.

BURLINGHAM, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Two glasses of orange juice sipped between games by two tennis stars, William Talbert and Hamilton Richardson, caused more gallery chatter than all the tough and beautiful shots in their exhibition game at Camp Nyda today.

" MY main job in life has been to catch spies. During the last war I was personally responsible for the execution of seven spies and for long terms of imprisonment for a great many more." If these two sentences arouse your immediate interest you may be sure that you won't want to miss "Spy-Catcher,"* by Oreste Pinto.

The American Legion finally "captured" a vital sector of Times Square at 9:35 o'clock last night when north and south bound vehicular traffic was barred by the police from Broadway between Fortieth and Forty-sixth Street on one side of the square.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- Senator Irving M. Ives was renominated unanimously as the Republican candidate to succeed himself at a meeting of the Republican State Committee here this afternoon. He immediately promised to wage a hard-hitting campaign to "expose the falseness" of Democratic promises and policies.

Mediation sessions aimed at averting a strike by three railroad brotherhoods on New York Central Railroad lines east of Buffalo were resumed here yesterday, and one union spokesman reported "no progress."

An investment banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and Coggeshall Hicks will place on the market today 160,000 shares of $25 par value $1.30 cumulative dividend preferred stock of Peninsular Telephone Company, Florida utility, at $26 a share.
OTTAWA, Aug. 26 -- Canada had a credit balance of $164,400,000 on her foreign trade during the first six months of this year, according to figures released today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -Senate Preparedness Subcommittee investigators, checking into possible waste at the Army's Claremont Terminal in Jersey City, found indications that night shift workers had received warning when they should appear busy, a Capitol source, who asked that his name not be used, disclosed today.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- British Government securities continued their advance on the stock exchange today. Although gains were smaller than yesterday rises of up to $1.92 1/2 were made. Gilt-edge securities took industrials along with them.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 -- The road was cleared tonight for oil prospecting in Israel with the adoption by the Knesset (Parliament) of the petroleum bill. This measure permits the Government to issue permits and licenses for exploration and thirty-year leases for production, which are renewable for twenty years.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 26 -Donald McNeill of Searingtown, L. I., former national champion, and Kurt Nielsen of Denmark were eliminated from the invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club today as play reached the quarter-finals.
Christmas is 119 days off, but manufacturers and retailers are concerned about the possibility of scarcities of some popular toys.
It will be hard for the advertising man to avoid education this winter. Two more series of courses were announced yesterday in which veterans of the profession will tell the neophytes how it's done.

MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Julius Boros, United States open champion, shot a pair of sparkling rounds and led the United States pro golfers to a 7 1/2-to-1 1/2 lead over Canada today in the opening day's matches of the Hopkins International Trophy competition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -Jose Ferrer has been signed to play the tragic hero, Pacote, in Barnaby Conrad's novel, "Matador," which John Huston will film next spring in Seville. The actor now is starring in Huston's "Moulin Rouge," a biography of Henri Toulouse-Lautrec, in the final stages of production in London.

The black market premium on gold, now about $2 an ounce, is so slight that smuggling from this country has been virtually discontinued, bullion dealers and refiners said yesterday. The traffic reached a peak in 1950 but reports that it hit an annual level of $500,000,000 appear exaggerated, these traders said.

John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, went into the lead over Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, in the contest for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator yesterday, when it was learned that Edward J. Flynn, Bronx leader and National Committeeman, had made a tentative decision to support Mr. Cashmore, a personal friend.

A two-story one-family dwelling on a five-acre tract on Woodhull Street in Huntington, L. I., has been sold by Jerome Wolk to Milton Gottsegen, who plans to use the property as a nursing home. The City Title Insurance Company insured title.

The question has often been raised "How long a period does temporary cover?" In the matter of housing in New York City, Quonset huts and barrack-type buildings put up to house veterans and their families for a temporary period until suitable housing had been built have now been in existence six years, with the final date of demolition set for July 1, 1954.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, secretary of the Communist party's Central Committee, said today that all Communists must step up their efforts to improve the Communist party by struggling to protect it against the "shortcomings and unhealthy phenomena occurring in the work of party organizations." Writing in a special edition of Pravda, Mr. Khrushchev said:

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee announced tonight the departure of one woman and twenty-four men tubercular patients as immigrants to Sweden, and praised the Swedish Government for a "warm-hearted and humanitarian actor."

The United States Steel Corporation, issuing its quarterly financial statement a month later than usual because of the recent steel strike, reported yesterday that its net income for the strike-affected second quarter was $22,218,922, equal to 61 cents a common sharer, compared with $43,534,212, or $1.43 a share, for the preceding three months and $58,133,716, or $1.99 a share, in the second quarter of 1951.

Merchant ships of 1,000 gross tons or more under construction or on order in the principal shipbuilding countries of the world for the quarter ended July 1 showed an increase of more than 100,000 gross tons over the previous quarrel, according to a quarterly report issued yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

The Twentieth Century Fund, an agency devoted to research and education on economic questions established in 1919 by Edward A. Filene, plans to widen its field to include the political and social forces that affect American life, its annual report announced yesterday.

The trend toward "fashion" in the home-furnishings field, which was noted at the recent Chicago furniture market, also may be observed in the field of decorating fabrics in the inexpensive to the moderate price brackets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that it must stop all promotion to lieutenant and possibly demote a "substantial number" of officers of this rank to comply with a rider to the defense appropriation bill.

Henry W. Grunewald of Washington made his long delayed appearance yesterday before the additional Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating alleged income tax frauds among former high ranking officials of the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Operations of the Hilton Hotels Corporation for the first six months of this year resulted in higher gross revenue and net earnings than a year ago, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported yesterday. Gross was aided somewhat by inclusion of receipts from hotels not owned last year, while the final net was increased through a profit received from the sale of property.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- A single by Dee Fondy enabled the Cubs to score a 3 -- 2 victory over the Phillies in the thirteenth inning today. Hank Sauer had sent the game into overtime with a two-run double in the ninth.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- The second stage of the Sovietization of East Germany is well under way. It is expected that within the next month the Communist Government there will begin repressive action against both the Roman Catholic and Evangelical churches in preparation for an announcement of "a new status" for the country at the Soviet Communist party congress in Moscow in October.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The main event today at the Saratoga Association's race track didn't provide much to write home about. In the Wilson Mile run were six 3-year-olds that haven't been anywhere in particular -- and apparently aren't going anywhere.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Transcontinental freight railroads are tentatively proposing new rates for class-rated traffic between Eastern areas and Pacific Coast terminals, it was reported today.

DOVER, Del., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Delaware Democratic state convention adopted today a platform pledging the enactment of fair employment practice laws "with effective enforcement provisions" and calling for repeal of state laws that "permit the arbitrary exclusion of members of minority groups from places of public gathering and entertainment."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -The Veterans Administration said today it had ordered 2,800 beds eliminated in its own hospitals and was giving up 400 V. A. beds in other Federal institutions because of a $40,000,000 budget cut ordered by Congress.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox set off five-run scoring bursts in the third and seventh innings tonight while overwhelming the Tigers, 11 -- 3.

Former Representative Hamilton Fish said yesterday that he was considering running for United States Senator as the candidate of the American party, proposed by Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune.
Lester J. Hyland has been appointed sales manager of the industrial rubber division of Thermoid Company, Trenton. Robert Gentles has been named manager of the western division.

James A. Wechsler, managing editor of The New York Post, who was dropped from the panel of the "Starring the Editors" television program three weeks ago, has been reinstated and will appear on the show tonight over WABD from 9:30 to 10.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- A comprehensive engineering study of methods of modernizing the Westchester parkways was advocated this afternoon by the County Board of Supervisors' committee on parkways, highways and thruways. It voted unanimously to ask the County Executive and Budget Director to provide sufficient funds in the 1953 budget for the analysis.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 26 -- President Miguel Aleman has granted amnesty to 128 persons held as political prisoners on various charges arising out of the July 6 national election.

Delay by city officials in obtaining sites for new schools was charged yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the Board of Education's committee on building and sites, and John P. Riley, coordinator of school construction for the board.

The problem of trade with the Soviet bloc has again come to the fore. Two reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES dealt with it. As former chief of the United States Army's Economic Intelligence in Austria and military member of the Vienna East-West Trade Committee, and, therefore, speaking perhaps not entirely without some authority on this subject, permit me to comment on the two news items.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Added thousands of Moslem pilgrims surged into this Middle East crossroads today, swamping the United States Air Force "Hadji Airlift" to the approaches of Holy Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia.

" Thomas Carlyle," by Julian Symons, a biography of the nineteenth-century essayist and historian, will be published Sept. 18 by Oxford University Press. Mr. Symons, who is also the author of several detective stories, discusses Carlyle's major works, explaining their importance for readers of today.

John Hays Hammond Jr. has sold the five-story ten-family apartment house at 47 East Eightieth Street to Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Faber Jr. The new owners plan to occupy a portion of the building land to hold the property for investment. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers in the transaction.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 -- Hackensack, N. J., scored a 13-7 victory tonight over Montreal in the opening round of the sixth annual Little League world series.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26 -Representative Thomas G. Abernethy tonight ended the thirty-two-year Congressional career of his "close friend," Representative John E. Rankin, long an advocate of white supremacy.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26 -- Pat Lesser, 19-year-old Seattle girl, added to her prestige today when she defeated Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., member of the Curtis Cup team, in the opening round of the women's National amateur golf championship.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- James T. Sherwin, the defending champion, lost today to Harold M. Phillips of New York City, president of the United States Chess Federation, in the third round of the annual New York State chess championship tournament. The result created a two-way tie for first place with Phillips and Max Pavey of Brooklyn.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, Aug. 26 -- A new type fountain pen that can be filled without immersing the point in ink was announced today by the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company.

Indications are that the board of governors of the New York Cotton Exchange, when they meet tomorrow to consider all-year closings on Saturdays, will give some consideration to the protests being made by the various trade associations.

BONAVISTA, Nfld., Aug. 26 (UP) -- A group of ten to twenty seamen, forced to abandon their burning ship fifty miles at sea, reached a rocky island off the north shore of Bonavista Bay today after a harrowing ride through rough seas in an open dory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Chapman announced today that duck hunters will have ten additional shooting days this fall.

The Ithaca Marine and Industrial Company has purchased the three-story mercantile building at 261 Conover Street, corner of Beard Street, in Brooklyn from William Cloonan. After extensive alterations have been completed, the building will be occupied by the buyer for marine repair work.
VANCOUVER, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Defending champion Walt McElroy of Vancouver today bowed out of the Canadian Amateur golf tournament.

The daily task of raking debris from the surface of the Fifty-ninth Street lake in Central Park lasted from 8 A. M. to late afternoon yesterday. There was an extraordinary amount of refuse and no one could say why, but park attendants wheeled it away without comment.

Careful attention to detail characterized the custom collection of fall millinery shown yesterday by Milgrim at 6 West Fifty-seventh Street. Certain to find favor with those who appreciate such fine custom details as deft draping and beadwork, the presentation revolved around profile, back movement and attractive cap silhouettes. Particularly interesting were the little feather caps with their original handling of plumage.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- Twenty top leaders of the growing passive resistance campaign against the Government's apartheid, or racial segregation, laws faced a court here today on charges of encouraging communism while 2,000 supporters outside the building roared, booed and chanted the national anthem.

The use of a new celestial-navigation "astronomy class trainer" was described yesterday by the Navy's Special Devices Center at Port Washington, L. I. The device is termed an adaption of the Spitz Planetarium.

An elaborate system of traffic and communications control, in use for the first time, halted marching divisions of the Legion parade at intervals of seven or eight minutes yesterday to permit vehicular traffic to cross Fifth Avenue at designated points.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- A report on some 25,000,000-year-old fossil ape bones, published this week in the proceedings of the Zoological Society by Prof. Wilfred Le Gros Clark, chief anatomist at Oxford University, tends to show that man has not descended from living apes or creatures like them.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Two former team-mates overpowered the Athletics tonight when Barney McCosky delivered a pinch two-run triple in the eleventh inning and Lou Brissie hurled two and two-thirds innings of shut-out ball as the Indians topped the Athletics, 6 -- 3.

The Yankees may still appear to be finding the clubs from the American League's nether regions a trifle difficult to handle. But last night, to the delight of 26,550 onlookers, who were beginning to fear the worst, all that changed within a few minutes.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Many in Britain were startled this morning when they read the reports of Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech to the American Legion yesterday.

Better reporting and more adequate interpretation of news were called for yesterday by practitioners and educators in journalism at the convention of the Association for Education in Journalism, being held at Columbia University.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens suspended a sewer inspector and an engineering supervisor without pay yesterday pending preparation and trial of charges "for incompetency and for misconduct in the prosecution of your duties" to check work on a $185,679 segment of the Laurelton sewer network.

An eight-man lifeboat crew from the Holland-America liner Noordam nosed out a crew from the Royal Netherlands Line freighter Ilos in an elimination race yesterday in the Hudson River for the right to represent The Netherlands in the international lifeboat race.
INWOOD, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift and Arthur Cohen of Glen Oaks topped a field of fifty-nine teams for low gross honors today with a 36, 38 -- 74 over the Inwood Country Club course.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- After a day's reflection, British diplomatic and oil experts were inclined today to take an optimistic view of the presence in Iran of W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service pany.
With a hearty invitation to "come aboard," Capt. Ote Lewis welcomed us yesterday into the log cabin on wheels that the State of Maine has sent here for the American Legion convention.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 -Stephen G. Crean Jr., 44 years old, manager of the Greenwich Country Club and permittee for the club's liquor license, was bound over today for trial next month in Superior Court at Bridgeport on three liquor violation charges. The four-hour trial was heard by Judge J. Gerard Tobin of the Greenwich Town Court.

On record sales of $42,672,045, Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., had a net income of $2,381,679, in the fiscal year ended last June, the annual report disclosed yesterday. This was the second highest net in its history and compared with $3,118,810 earned in the previous fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The acute memory of Maj. Robert V. Murray, Washington's chief of police, led today to the solution of the theft of $65,000 from a Brink's armored truck sixteen hours after the event.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 -- The Giants unleashed one of their most savage offensives of the campaign tonight as they swamped the Pirates, 14 -- 7, before 14,011 onlookers at Forbes Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The State Department viewed with considerable gratification today the early reaction to the airlift of Moslem pilgrims to Mecca. The Air Force undertook the operation at State Department request, on recommendation of Harold B. Minor, United States Ambassador to Lebanon.

In his speech to the American Legion Convention General Eisenhower again emphasized what has been emphasized before and is implicit in our whole foreign policy -- namely, that we shall not abandon the peoples enslaved by Communist imperialism, and that we cannot rest in good conscience or security until their hope for ultimate liberation is realized.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 -- The State Guard will be deactivated and its officers and warrant officers transferred to the State Reserve list on Sept. 27, when Federal authorization for its existence expires. Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A suit for an accounting and payment of more than $2,500,000 was filed today by Mrs. Millicent V. Hearst against the executors of the estate of her husband, William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, who died last year.

President Truman has finally announced his acceptance of the resignation of Ellis Arnall as Price Stabilizer, which has been in his hands for some weeks. Mr. Arnall will be succeeded on Sept. 1, the White House revealed, by Tighe E. Woods, the present rent controller.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 26 (AP)--The Chamber of Commerce here said today that the Mexican Government was worried about a flood of dollars returning from the United States.

Quick thinking by Pennsylvania Station officials at 5:38 P. M. yesterday cleared up a situation in incoming Tunnel 4, where fire had started in the contact shoe of a Long Island Rail Road train from Port Washington. The Pennsylvania Railroad used one of its own locomotives, operating on an overhead power wire, to get the stalled train out. It was under Park Avenue at Thirty-third Street.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's personal foreign policy was considerably clarified by his speech yesterday to the American Legion. Since that may represent the diplomatic intentions of the United States in the case of a Republican victory even more than the G. O. P. platform, the governments of Europe are keenly interested.

W. Alton Jones, the American oil executive who mysteriously and sensationally showed up in Teheran a few days ago, is fishing in very troubled waters. It may be taken for granted that he knows this as well as anybody and is more or less literally trying to pour oil on the heaving waters of the Persian Gulf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A loan of $25,000,000 to the Republic of Colombia was approved today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for improvement and extension of the nation's railway system.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26 -- Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, in a speech here today, inferentially challenged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for advocating foreign policy changes that Mr. Harriman said spread fear of war in Europe.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP) -Warren Spahn pitched five-hit ball tonight to give the Braves a 2-0 victory over the Reds.

The seismographs did not record it, but the world shrank again yesterday when a British jet bomber established a new speed record and flashed across the Atlantic and back again in ten hours of the same single day and in exactly seven hours and fifty-nine minutes actual flying time.

Inventories of New York City department stores on July 31 were 16 per cent lower than on the corresponding day last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Prices of most commodity futures on the local exchanges were irregular yesterday in comparatively light trading.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 26 -The Iranian public is being given to understand that the presence in the country of W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Oil Company, may lead to the final defeat of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in its conflict with the Iranian Government, and that Mr. Jones is primarily interested in having his American concern take over operation of the nationalized industry and distribute and sell its production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -The Defense Department today identified 312 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 27 dead, 267 wounded, 14 missing in action and 4 injured in combat area accidents. The following casualties were reported for New York and New Jersey (none for Connecticut):

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -The Government announced today that it would lift its two-year-old construction ban on bowling alleys, swimming pools, theatres and other amusement and recreation building next April 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The National Labor-Management Manpower Policy Committee reported today that "the volume of all occupational injuries rose in both 1950 and 1951, reaching a total in 1951, 12 per cent higher than that in 1949."

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A bristling John L. Lewis took over the United Mine Workers contract negotiations with the hard-coal industry today by rejecting an appeal by the operators that the nation's 475,000 hard and soft coal miners call off their ten-day "memorial" holiday.

A second criminal information was returned yesterday in Special Sessions against Erica Steel, 28 years old, of 52 West Fifty-eighth Street. The latest charge alleged that she had operated her apartment as "a house of ill fame" and a "public nuisance."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- If Eddie Stanky isn't singing the St. Louis Blues tonight it must be because he doesn't want to sing anything -for which he can't be blamed.
With a moderate volume of business, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 18 to 34 points net higher than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The White House suggested today the possibility that President Truman's journey to Milwaukee for a Labor Day speech might be broadened into a "whistle-stop" tour.

It is impossible to treat an ailment correctly unless that ailment is properly diagnosed and accurately named. New York City is presently suffering from hardening of the traffic arteries. This is a very serious state of affairs, as any alert business man will attest; one that is gradually proving lethal to many firms which depend on ability to move their goods freely for the success of their efforts.
The country's salesmen want a permanent increase in commission rates to cover increased expenses. They do not want "a one-shot bonus payment confined to the current year."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 26 -- The national doubles champions, Doris Hart and Shirley Fry, lost but one game of their doubles match at the Maidstone invitation tournament as they eliminated Mrs. Austin Pardue and Mrs. J. B. Maguire, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama today challenged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, to "clarify" their stand on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

An unofficial strike of several thousand workers in eight Atlantic Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was settled shortly before midnight yesterday, according to an announcement made by the company. The strike, if it had continued, threatened to involve 32,000 workers.

I am afraid your editorial of Aug. 17 does not give a complete picture of the problem of fluorides added to the drinking water. There seems no reason to doubt that small quantities of fluorides ingested during the period of calcification of the teeth, that is to say, during the first eight years of life, may reduce the incidence of dental caries.

John Foster Dulles predicted yesterday after an eighty-minute conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the Commodore Hotel that the Republican candidate for President would soon present a new foreign policy designed to cope effectively with Soviet aggression.

While the Russians were checking the champion team of Yugoslavia, the United States chess team moved into first place by picking up 2 1/2 points yesterday in its match with West Germany in the sixth round of the international team tournament at Helsinki, according to Finnish dispatches.
PANAMA CITY, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Two weary fliers who twice cheated death were scooped out of the stormy Gulf of Mexico by a Coast Guard minesweeper today and brought here for hospitalization.
The following booklet, of interest to parents, was published recently :

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 26 -- The opening day of the tenth United States Atlantic tuna tournament was a grand one for golfers, aquaplaners and bluefishermen, but the concentrated (and we mean concentrated) efforts of some 300 tuna fishing contestants failed to land anything more exciting than a pair of sharks on the scales, and there is no point score for sharks.

Mayor Impeilitteri directed the city's Division of Labor Relations yesterday to assign an observer to wage review negotiating sessions between the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and the New York Shipping Association, representing employing stevedores.

Living habits among the old and loyal following of "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" may have to be revised in some cases this season. No longer is the trio seen at 7 P. M. five evenings each week, as it had been since its local debut in January, 1949.

Two adventuresome young Irishmen, early four months out of their home port of Galway, tied up yesterday at the City Island Yacht Basin in the Bronx. With four other youths who left the boat at Puerto Rico, they had sailed the ocean in a forty-five-foot ketch.

Delegates representing nearly 20,000 women veterans of three wars swung down Fifth Avenue yesterday, matched the male Legionnaires pace for pace and didn't even pause for window-shopping along the famous shopping street, however great the temptation might have been.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- The Communist party Central Committee ordered all party units today to initiate a broad general discussion, including negative as well as positive comments, on the proposed changes in the party rules that will be submitted to the nineteenth Party congress Oct. 5 by Nikita S. Khrushchev, a member of the Politburo.

Economic conditions in Great Britain are improving and that country's economy is much sounder than at any time this year, Lewis W. Douglas, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, said yesterday.

The furniture industry appears to be headed for a minor boom when the active fall selling season begins next week. Department and furniture stores reported yesterday that their traditional August sales had succeeded beyond expectations.

CAIRO, Aug. 26 -- Premier Aly Maher announced tonight that a committee soon would be formed to amend the electoral law and adopt it more suitably to the special conditions prevailing in Egypt, where a large part of the electorate is illiterate.

Both the content and the tone of Nikita S. Khrushchev's statement in yesterday's Pravda confirm last week's indications that a tightening up of Communist party discipline is a major objective of the newly announced changes in party rules.

The lead tenor in a prison quartet led the bass and baritone to freedom last September, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation has arranged for a return engagement at the Kentucky State Reformatory in La Grange.
The American Legion flooded Fifth Avenue with a tide of sound and color yesterday as it staged its annual convention parade -- a tide that flowed unbroken for nine hours and thirty-nine minutes.

An industrial building at 50 Bleecker Street in Paterson, N. J., formerly occupied by the Alaska Chemical Corporation, has been leased by Popular Merchandise, Inc., a mail order concern, for a warehouse and distribution center for northern New Jersey. J. I. Kislak, Inc., and the Alexander Summer Company were the brokers.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 26 -- A British Canberra twinjet bomber flew today from the Royal Air Force field at Aldergrove, Northern Ireland, to Gander, Nfld., and back in 7 hours 59 minutes flying time.

In the remote future when American Legion ranks thin down to the thin blue line it may be recalled that the transition from the whoop-de-doo to the conservative in Legion parades began with the march up Fifth Avenue in 1952.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Tighe E. Woods, present rent control chief, was named by President Truman today to be Director of the Office of Price Stabilization. He succeeds Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, who resigned effective Monday to resume his law practice in Atlanta.

Forty-four parcels of real estate acquired by the city through "in rem" foreclosures in the Rockaway section of Queens were sold at auction yesterday for $92,100. This brought the totals to 130 parcels and $571,675 at the close of the second day.

New York Mercantile Exchange potato prices rose sharply yesterday on a flood of new buying orders, many of which were reportedly from Maine. November delivery rose 24 points. Every delivery from December to April advanced the daily trading limit of 25 points. Volume was 787 carloads.

John L. Lewis is nothing if not ingenious, as a dispatch to this paper by Joseph A. Loftus from Washington bears out. Hemmed in by a "soft" coal market and depressed prices, by large stockpiles and substantial nonunion production, Mr. Lewis is reported sounding out the coal industry on a spread-the-work plan.

The Yankees were still doing a bit of stumbling at the Stadium yesterday when suddenly they came upon the startling discovery that their adversaries, the lowly Browns, could do that sort of thing infinitely better.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Saminy Urzetta's power and putting carried the East Rochester, N. Y., golfer to a 3 and 2 victory over Jack Ellis of Vancouver today in the third round of the Canadian amateur golf tournament.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 27 (AP) -Leading churchmen from forty countries challenged the world's divided churches today to act on unity "here and now" or see their movement toward a united Christendom perish.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 27 -- This blue water contest was saved from what threatened to be a tuna-less tournament by the skill, persistence, and, it must be admitted, luck of Lindley Eberstadt of the New York A. C. anglers, who boated a 734-pound tuna, shortly before noon.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27 -- A corps of 80,000 commissioned and non-commissioned officers and a force of 40,000 technical specialists will form the core of the new West German Army, according to present planning.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27 -- Vampire bats, ugly-looking carriers of cattle paralysis, are threatening the Mexican livestock industry on the eve of the reopening of the border for cattle shipments to markets in the United states.

DENVER, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The American Legion's junior baseball "little world series" opens Monday and the way this town is buzzing you would think the Yankees and Indians were heading here to play for the American League pennant.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 27 -Max Pavey of Brooklyn, former chess champion of Scotland, is making a strong bid to regain the New York State title he held three years ago in the current tournament at the Junior College here. He gained his fourth consecutive victory today, defeating Harold M. Phillips of New York in the fourth round.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- Negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war again were in adjournment today after a thirty-three-minute session at Panmunjom yesterday during which, the United States Eighth Army announced, the Communist delegates "offered nothing new or constructive" in answer to the "irrevocable" decision of the United Nations that no war prisoner would be forced to return to his former masters against his own wishes.

While sharing your disappointment with General Eisenhower's "* * * failure to state unequivocally that he will not support the candidacy of Joseph R. McCarthy * * *," I disagree with your view that the best way to get legislation passed is to have a single authority in Congress based on a likeness of party affiliation of the President and majorities in both houses of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 20, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 27 -- The National Student Associatio congress, representing 700,000 college students in this country, today reversed a 1951 stand with a resolution rejecting universal military training.

NEWARK, Aug. 27 -- Safety Director John B. Keenan took time out from a firemen's convention in Boston today to dictate over the telephone a public reply to a letter from Margaret Ann O'Brian. Margaret, whose letter had no return address, had written:

A union of Sanitation Department employes threatened yesterday a strike "sometime before the week-end" and then postponed the walkout until late next week to give a special fact-finding committee a chance to settle the dispute.

Women furthering the plans for the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery to be held on Oct. 8 in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel met yesterday at a luncheon given by Mrs. Douglass B. Simonson in the Starlight Roof to discuss arrangements for the forthcoming event.

A smokestack watcher has been stationed in the yard of the Board of Transportation's power plant at East Seventy-fourth Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in an effort to keep at a minimum the smoke emissions from the half-century-old plant.

The United States and Yugoslavia chess teams changed places yesterday in the standing of the countries competing in the championship tournament of the International Chess Federation at Helsinki, according to news reports from Finland.

The first of a series of "Interval Concerts," being held between the summer and winter music seasons, was presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening by N. J. Seaman. The all-Bach program was played by Leon Rudin, violinist; Mildred Hunt Wummer, flutist; George Koutzen, 'cellist, and Claude Jean Chiasson, harpsichordist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The whole of the northern approach to the United States now lies under the protective screen of radar, though some sections of the screen will not be in operation for a few months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Four Chicago pitchers held Washington to four hits tonight as the White Sox defeated the Senators, 4 -- 1. Harry Dorish, who allowed three hits in six and two-thirds innings, was credited with the victory, his sixth.

" The Quiet Man," which starts a second week today at the Capitol, played to a "record attendance" over the week-end, when 34,081 persons saw the John Ford romantic comedy, it was announced by the management.

APPLETON, Wis., Aug. 27 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin today accused former Senator Millard Tydings, Democrat of Maryland, and Joseph Davies, former United States Ambassador to Russia, of sending money into Wisconsin to back Mr. McCarthy's critics in the Sept. 9 Senatorial primary election.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 27 -Some 200 volumes on the history of Jews in America were presented to the Society of Friends of Touro Synagogue, historic shrine, at its fifth annual meeting here tonight.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wife of the Republican candidate for President, and Mrs. Elizabeth Ives, sister of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Presidential choice of the Democratic party, made what scarcely could be called speeches at the national convention of the American Legion Auxiliary yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Diplomatic sources said here tonight that the United States and British envoys in Teheran had recommended today to Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Premier of Iran, a compromise plan to restore vital oil production in that country.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Braves scored five runs in the tenth inning tonight to defeat the Reds, 12 -- 7.
The Illinois Central Railroad sold yesterday at competitive bidding $62,000,000 of thirty-year consolidated mortgage bonds at an interest cost of 4.03 per cent to the road.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 27 (UP) -- A single by Julio Landa, which errors stretched into a home run, gave Norwalk, Conn., a 3-2 victory over San Diego, Calif., in the extra-inning seventh tonight and put the Nutmeg State boys in the final of the Little League world series.

A new Protestant Episcopal teaching order for women was formed yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Known as the Community of the Holy Spirit, the religious order will operate St. Hilda's primary school at 621 West 113th Street.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The line-up for the contest between the Bevanites and the right-wing at the forthcoming convention of the British Labor party was announced today in the convention agenda.

The projected $85,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel advanced a step closer to reality yesterday when the Port of New York Authority awarded the first contract for construction work on the artery.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., in its fiscal year ended with last June, increased net sales to $436,934,549, largest in its history, from the previous year's volume of $433,074,249, William J. Murray Jr., board chairman, reported in the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday.
Resellers were assured yesterday of getting the mark-ups or charges above cost that they were getting for the goods they sold before the Korean war started in June, 1950.

The immediate ouster or resignation of Carmine G. DeSapio as leader of Tammany Hall was demanded yesterday by Bert Stand, Democratic leader of the Fourth Assembly District South and former secretary of Tammany.

GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- The West German Government submitted to the United Nations Commission on War Prisoners today fifty volumes of evidence relating to nearly 1,500,000 German soldiers not known to have been killed during World War II whose whereabouts were unknown.
The state committee of the Liberal party held the first session of a two-day meeting last night in the Statler Hotel and adopted the party's platform for the 1952 election campaign.

Senator Homer Capehart, Republican of Indiana, returned yesterday from a six-week tour of Europe convinced that the United States was spending far too much money abroad but that our military units were doing an excellent job.

An increase last week of 414,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 116,393,000 barrels, compared with 115,979,000 a week earlier and 125,590,000 a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 27 -The Indian Government appears to be perturbed at what is described by official sources as the "complete inactivity" of the Secretary General of the United Nations in regard to the implementation of the resolution on South Africa adopted by the General Assembly last January.

Governor Stevenson's courageous speech to the American Legion underlined some fundamental principle. It is odd to have to refer to such a speech as "courageous"; for it ought not to require courage to restate the very essence of American democracy before any audience of Americans, especially an audience of war veterans.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed 4 to 36 points net higher on active months than on Tuesday. The advance was led by old October.

Though General Eisenhower's September journey into the South is to be swift it is to be wide. His airplane tour will take him into eight states, a fact which alone signalizes the importance of the South in the campaign debate. There have been other Presidential candidates who have crossed the Potomac in search of electoral votes in the South's recent history, but General Eisenhower's September sweep is unprecedented.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Truman, hailing another Labor Day and the advances made by the working people of America, said in a statement today that the holiday next Monday was a day to look ahead, "to plan where we are going."
The trend toward self-service types of operation in the variety store field is gaining headway.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox ran their winning streak to five games today as they pounded Dave Madison for a five-run third inning while Lefty Mel Parnell blanked the Tigers, 5 -- 0, on a six-hitter for his eleventh victory.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 26 -Martin (Skip) Purcell, 17-year-old senior at Andover Academy today won the national junior sailing championship and the Sears Bowl, a silver fruit dish that goes with it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Jacob A. Malik, the voice of the Soviet Union at the United Nations for four years, will leave his post within a couple of weeks and will be replaced by Deputy Foreign Minister Valerian A. Zorin, the man who supervised the Communist coup in Czechoslovakia in 1948.

BUFFALO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Five changes in the United States Constitution that would strengthen the Government's handling of foreign policy were proposed today by Dr. William Y. Elliott of Harvard University.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -The Screen Actors Guild today lined up with the motion-picture industry in contesting the anti-trust action filed last month by the Department of Justice to force the release of movies for television showing to a nonpaying audience.

Analysis of the first-half earnings reports of the major steel companies points up one of the principal effects of the general steel strike in June and July -- the precipitous and unanimous drop in net profits in this year's period compared with the first six months of 1951.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Observers in London surmised tonight that Britain had offered fairly substantial concessions to Iran today in renewed effort to settle the dispute between the two countries over the Iranian oil industry that was British-owned until nationalized last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- The late Lammot du Pont of Wilmington, Del., chairman of the board of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., left an estate estimated at $75,000,000 in personal property and $325,000 in real estate, before deductions for Federal and other taxes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 116.252 today, an increase of 879 since last week.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 27 -- The State Legislature convened today in special session in this Nebraska capital.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ayatollah Kashani, Iranian religious leader and president of the Chamber of Dputies took off in a United States Air Force plane for Jidda today. He was one of 3,000 fellow Moslems being airlifted by the United States to the approaches of holy Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27 (UP) -Arthur Bliss Lane, former Ambassador to Poland, tonight praised Senator Joseph McCarthy as a "patriotic, hard-hitting ex-marine" who points out "treason and subversive activities in government, no matter how much they may hurt."

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 27 -- The Connecticut Republican party leaders appeared to be moving tonight to support Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich over Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Ridgefield for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of Senator Brien McMahon.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 27 -Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., and Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., all of whom are seeded in the draw for the national championship starting Friday at Forest Hills, gained the semi-final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

PORTLAND, Aug. 27 -- The defeat of the defending champion, Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, and some spectacular golf by one of the game's youngest stars marked the third round of the women's United States amateur championship today.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Small business companies have increased their share of prime Government contracts for defense work from 12.4 per cent of total national awards in the March quarter to 18.4 per cent at present, a House Small Business Committee division hearing revealed here today.
New York theatregoers will witness Bette Davis singing and dancing in "Two's Company" at the Alvin Theatre on Dec. 4. Contracts for the local booking were signed yesterday.

Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent of schools since 1934, was re-elected to his fourth six-year term yesterday by the Board of Education. The vote by the eight members present was unanimous.

Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., were seeded first among the American entrants and Frank Sedgman of Australia, defending champion, led the foreign contingent as the drawing for the national tennis championships was completed yesterday.

After having occupied the five-story and penthouse dwelling at 26 East Seventy-third Street for more than thirty years, Mr. and Mrs. George Doubleday have sold it to Ben Golde, treasurer of Grayson-Robinson Stores, for occupancy. The house is on a lot 21 by 79 feet between Madison and Fifth Avenues and was sold for cash in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company.

NEPTUNE, N. J., Aug. 27 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, asserting that the Republican party was "split wide open on foreign policy," described its platform tonight as "a bushel of eels," and said it looked as if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would be compelled to "stand" on the Democratic platform.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Office of Price Stabilization announced today that manufacturers who process steel, aluminum, and copper would be permitted to pass through, at each stage of fabrication, the increases in ceiling prices recently authorized for these metals.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 27 -- A United States tennis group defeated a squad representing Great Britain in the annual informal international clubs match today at the Cedarhurst Hunting Club. The score was 29-19 for the singles and doubles play. A point was given for each set won.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, acting Director of Defense Mobilization, ordered the Department of Defense today to spread the Government shipbuilding program as widely as practicable rather than to make areas of heavy unemployment the primary basis of selection.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -The reputation of Government workers for honesty, loyalty and efficiency was defended today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
YONKERS, Aug. 27 -- John Acropolis, aggressive Westchester County labor leader and former Colgate University basketball star, was found shot dead this afternoon in his apartment on Warburton Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -Army Reserve officers and warrant officers now on active duty will be offered Army Reserve commissions of indefinite length immediately, the Department of Defense said today.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Although the stock markets were less vigorous than yesterday prices continued to rise in most of the principal sections.

The theme of deeper and more widespread interpretation of the worlds news, as a means of bringing about greater international understanding, continued yesterday to dominate the convention of the Association for Education in Journalism here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- James McInnes Henderson was named today as Director of Rent Stabilization, succeeding Tighe E. Woods, who was designated yesterday as Director of Price Stabilization, following Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, who has resigned.

Two hundred top engineers from Free World nations were welcomed to the city yesterday. They took part in the first session of a four-day seminar at the Roosevelt Hotel that is serving as a "warm-up" for the convocation marking the centennial of the American Society of Civil Engineers, to be held in Chicago Sept. 3 to 13.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Joseph Fisher of Winged Foot and his 16-year-old son, James, won the twenty-third annual Westchester father-and-son golf championship at the Hampshire Country Club today.

Workers at the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Brooklyn plant, where British battleships found shelter in both World Wars, watched yesterday the unveiling of a plaque commemorating an early battle against the same navy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP) -The Athletics, who seem to play better baseball with an early handicap, spotted Mike Garcia a four-run edge in the first inning today and then rallied for a 6-to-5 victory over the Indians. The winners scored five runs in the fifth, the deciding tally crossing the plate on an error.

AS a public health nurse I was very much disturbed to read in your paper the report that Commissioner Kogel will put the three proposed hospitals for tuberculosis patients "on the shelf." He himself admits that there are over 2,000 tuberculosis patients in New York City who should be hospitalized, but for whom no beds are available.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Grain futures showed a firm undertone on the Board of Trade today, but the markets were devoid of special initiative on either side, and trading was about the dullest in a long time.
Imported fabrics were a feature of a showing of yard goods yesterday at McCutcheon's. Whether they were cotton or fine silks and laces, all the fabrics had dressmaker touches.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission today turned down a Soviet demand for "immediate" debate on the prohibition of bacteriological weapons.

The headlines called it a Magic Carpet and to thousands of the stranded pilgrims it must have seemed just that. The pilgrims, many of whom came from distant lands and financed their long and arduous journey with the meager savings of a lifetime, were all devout Moslems en route to the holy city of Mecca.
Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, refused yesterday to honor his promise to turn over copies of his income tax returns to District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -Secretary of the Treasury Snyder announced today that the Treasury will again follow this fall a banking procedure aimed at keeping lending reserves high.

BUFFALO, Aug. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, foreign policy adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, said here today that the general's liberation policy for Communist "captive" peoples does not mean violent revolution but peaceful revolution using such "quiet" methods as passive resistance, non-cooperation, discontent, slowdowns and industrial sabotage.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The board of directors of the International Printing Pressmen's Union announced today it had obtained $560,484.50 from the estate of the late George L. Berry, its former president.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 27 -- The United States won a partial victory in its first case before the International Court of Justice today when the tribunal backed the right of Americans to import goods to French Morocco on the same footing as Frenchmen.
TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,355, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) Two Air Force pilots, who made the first helicopter flight across the North Atlantic and set a new distance record, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today from Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff.

Although Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, declined yesterday to express a choice for the New York Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, who will be named at a state convention tonight, leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations clung to the hope that Mr. Stevenson might use his influence to persuade Averell Harriman to reconsider his decision not to accept the nomination.

Recently in THE TIMES there appeared a column concerning the recent heat wave. It is interesting to note that the use of room air-conditioning has become so prevalent that, as the article states, it has brought a boom to the air-conditioning industry and new troubles to landlords.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson bitterly criticized yesterday those who use "patriotism" as a club for attacking other Americans and those who for political or personal reasons attack the patriotism of faithful public servants.

SEVERAL week ago, along with several hundred other critics and newspaper men, I received a present from Life magazine. It consisted of a set of galley proofs of some material that Life was going to publish in the issue which would appear on Thursday, Aug. 28. Ordinarily a book reviewer is not concerned with what material magazines publish.

Retail jewelry sales have improved considerably in the last few months, according to William Wagner, executive secretary of the National Jewelers Association, formerly the National Association of Credit Jewelers. He said jewelers throughout the country believed the next four months would be better than the corresponding 1951 period.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Bloomington Pantagraph said editorially today that Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, had made a "direct misstatement of fact" when he said The Pantagraph had been "unable" to endorse Adlai E. Stevenson for re-election as Governor of Illinois.

The campaign for the American Legion's highest office narrowed yesterday to two major contenders and it appeared certain that for the fourth straight year the Legion would elect a World War II veteran as its national commander.

Richard J. Gray, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department .of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday after a visit with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the Commodore Hotel that he intended to vote the Republican ticket this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Only a few days before Governor Stevenson was hailed for his "independence" by Walter Reuther, head of the United Auto Workers, at Springfield, the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of which the auto union is a large sector, issued a list. This appeared in The C. I. O. News and consisted of a tabulation of "right" and "wrong" votes on major issues by all the members of the Eighty-second United States Congress.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- The second choice was the right choice in the seventy-second running of the Alabama Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at the Saratoga track today.

The new Holland-America Line passenger vessel Maasdam, a gay medium-sized "economy" liner designed to attract a new class of transatlantic trade, docked in Hoboken early yesterday after a taste of the port's traditional hospitality.

A flavor that is pleasing and piquant is, of course, the first requirement for tidbits to accompany cocktails. If the savory foods also have something about them exotic enough to provoke conversation, so much the better.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The Dodgers' five-game winning streak ended at Wrigley Field today. Three pitchers, including Joe Landrum, the starter and loser, were lambasted for fifteen hits as the Cubs romped to a 10-5 triumph behind Bob Rush, who had trouble only in the first and ninth innings.
Two payrolls amounting to a total of more than $5,500 were stolen yesterday in separate daylight hold-ups in the midtown area.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Scores of residents and employes of industrial plants along the Arthur Kill waterfront in Elizabeth and a section 0f near-by Linden were affected today by a mysterious smog.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- Both the supranational and the Atlantic character of the new economic entity, the European Coal and Steel Community growing out of the Schuman plan, seemed to acquire new emphasis from conferences held here today between Jean Monnet, president of the community's High Authority, and William H. Draper Jr., special United States representative in Europe.

ONCE upon a time a steady customer at the ball parks knew every player by sight, at this stage in the season and could blandly ignore the clarion call of the vendors, "Yuh can't tell a player without a scorecard." Nowadays he had better buy one. There are too many strangers cluttering up the premises.

VIENNA, Aug. 27 -- Western and soviet occupation authorities have agreed on a common attitude toward the Nazi amnesty laws and the watering down of compensation for victims of nazism approved by the Austrian Parliament.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 27 -- A swindle involving an estimated $475,000 was charged here, today to Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, 48 years old, secretary-treasurer of Ideal Insulators, Inc., a building supplies concern in Roslyn, L. I.

WASSENAAR, the Netherlands, Aug. 27 -- Five months of negotiations culminated today in the virtual completion of the draft agreements under which West Germany will pay $822,000,000, basically in goods, to Israel and world Jewish oranizations in compensation for Nazi antisemitic acts. The Bonn Republic also will improve its machinery for individual restitution.

Overseas until recently, I have read many criticisms of Senator McCarthy. Most of them charge him with smearing and with irresponsible attacks. None of them that I could find ever indicated specifically where McCarthy had lied.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Today's prices of livestock rported by tile Department of Agriculture tollow: HiSGS

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 27 -- Nationalist party members of Parliament, sitting as the "High Court of Parliament," handed down a ruling today setting aside the Appeal Court's invalidation of the Voters Act that removed colored (mixed blood) voters from the common electoral roll.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Waste oil from the ships around the British coasts now clogs and probably kills between 100,000 and 500,000 sea birds each year, according to the first nation-wide survey of the situation conducted here by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and the British section of the International Committee for Bird Preservation.
" The only way a voter can hide this coming election day -- is in the voters' booth."

Thomas J. Mirabile of Brooklyn, chairman of the Buildings Committee of the City Council, introduced yesterday seven bills designed to provide a "modern, integrated" code covering flat-slab concrete construction work as part of the city's building laws.

CAIRO, Aug. 27 -- Premier Aly Maher's difficulties with the Army junta that was responsible for the July 23 coup and the subsequent banishment of King Farouk has become so acute in the last few days that the newspaper Al Misri this morning already had picked his successor in the person of Dr. Abdel Razzak Ahmed el Sanhoury, president of the Council of State, Egypt's highest judicial body.

A legal move in General Sessions for the release of Patricia Ward, a material witness in the vice inquiry, took an unscheduled turn yesterday when opposing counsel engaged in a wordy squabble that brought them close to blows.

The stock market took on a new look yesterday after having stumbled around for more than a week and came up with the best rally since Aug. 7. In terms of price advances, the recovery was not too impressive. To many observers, however, it indicated that a chain of wishy-washy sessions had been broken.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Rev. Leopold L. S. Braun, who said he had been the last Roman Catholic priest in the Soviet Union, declared today that before he left in 1945 he was told that word to "exterminate" him had come down from Premier Stalin, himself.

The American Legion, for the third year in a row, demanded yesterday the dismissal of Secretary of State Dean Acheson, and for the first time it urged the United States to warn the enemy in Korea that we would end the peace talks unless a speedy truce were arranged.

We believe that by any standard chosen New York City is inadequately policed. The crime figures for the first half of 1952 recently released show that over 300 felonies, and as many more misdemeanors, are committed every day. Some, but certainly not all, of these crimes could be prevented by better policing.

Saks-Fifth Avenue's presentation of fall and winter shoes at the Park Lane Hotel yesterday was one of many contrasts. In each category, completely closed styles contrasted with those that exposed all the toes and sometimes the heel and instep, while under-stated colors and fabrics or leathers gave way to those of brilliant tones and novelty medias.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Representatives of the B. F. Goodrich Company and the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., announced tonight an agreement to end a strike of 16,000 rubber workers in nine cities.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27 -- Alexander Rankovic, a member of the Yugoslav Communist Politburo and Minister of the Interior, announced last night that the sixth party congress, which is scheduled to convene Oct. 19 in Zagreb, Croatia, would vote resolutions decentralizing the party machinery and granting greater independence to local organizations.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 -- Bill Connelly made his debut as a Giant starting pitcher on Forbes Field today with results that were highly gratifying to Manager Leo Durocher.

Directors of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., voted yesterday to reduce the dividend with the declaration of a quarterly 40-cent payment to common stockholders on Oct. 1. In the two previous quarters shareholders had received 50 cents each, prior to which 60 cents quarterly was disbursed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Thirteen Arab and Asian members of the United Nations today agreed to ask the General Assembly to air charges that French rule in Morocco violated human rights and created a threat to peace.

An agreement between the Todd Shipyards Corporation and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., was reached at 2 o'clock this morning, according to a spokesman for the union. The new contract is subject to ratification of the union membership.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Republican National Committee will purchase network time for fifteen or twenty television and radio appearances by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Presidential nominee, and Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Vice-Presidential candidate.

ATHENS, Aug. 27 -- Further curtailment in Army expenditure and a lessening of the period of service in the Greek Army from three years to two have become "imperative'' because of reduction in United States aid, Defense Minister George Mavros said today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's Government received an overwhelming endorsement from the Knesset (Parliament) today for its agreement with the United States for the purchase of arms and for its negotiations with Washington for military aid within the framework of the Mutual Security Act.

Fresh from reading the courageous editorial headed "McCarthy as a Symbol," I congratulate you as a great newspaper editor who is also an exponent of clear, independent thought. Deeply I realize what a trial of fortitude it must have been to write such an article, but as the days pass I am sure the writer will experience the inner peace of one who has spoken forcible right words in good season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A Senate investigating subcommittee charged today that the Radio Writers Guild, whose members produce some 90 per cent of the scripts broadcast by radio networks, had permitted a minority band of pro-Communists to control the organization for the last nine years.

The Associates Investment Company of South Bend, Ind., announced yesterday plans for the public offering of $30,000,000 of new ten-year debentures of the company. The issue, which has just been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be underwritten by a syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -United States domestic airlines have carried more than 2,000,000 passengers in a single month for the first time in history, the Air Transport Association said today in a report showing record gains in air traffic thus far in 1952.

They could not stop the flow of blood streaming from a cut over Gene Hairston's right eye, so Carl (Bobo) Olson, Honolulu middleweight, was credited with a knock-out victory in the sixth round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

The clean, airy and uncluttered contemporary manner of decoration is demonstrated in the furnishings of a six-room model house opened to the public this week. The house, constructed by Post Homes, is located off Horace Harding Boulevard, at 232d Street, Bayside, Queens.

WEIRTON, W. Va., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Weirton Steel Company said it learned today that its continued production during the nation-wide fifty-five-day steel strike kept vital phases of the United States defense program going and prevented loss of much of the 1952 food crop.

NEWARK, Aug. 27 -- In a smashing farewell to major competition, Bowen Stassforth tonight bettered all the American long-course records for the 220-yard breast-stroke in winning a classic duel with Jerry Holan at the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor swimming championships.
Following is the text of the address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic candidate for President, at the American Legion national convention as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Phillies pulled within four-and-one-half games of the third-place Cardinals tonight by toppling the skidding Redbirds to their fifth straight defeat, 7 to 2, and ending Southpaw Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell's seven-game winning streak.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- The United States accused the Soviet authorities in East Germany today of dodging a charge that Dr. Walter Linse, a kidnapped West Berliner, was being held by Soviet zone authorities. That was the fifth United States protest since the incident occurred July 8.

An eight-man Norwegian lifeboat crew, stroking in perfect unison through a mild Hudson River chop, won yesterday the feature lifeboat race of the first International Maritime Races to be held since before World War II, beating the second-place United States entry by three lengths.
