I have been interested in the exchange of opinions, in recent numbers of THE TIMES, on the reasons for the failure of so many voters to exercise the suffrage; also on President Truman's views, as quoted.

Unqualified persons have been appointed to key city positions "with distressing frequency" and without any effort by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to safeguard the merit system against such invasions, the Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The National Education Association today reminded the American people of the values of the public school system and warned that academic freedom in that system must be maintained to "withstand the menace of communism."

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Navy planes -- including fliers from the newly repaired carrier Boxer -- hurled heavy attacks at Communist power plants in northeast Korea Wednesday while Air Force Superforts and light bombers followed at night with three hammer blows in the west.

Deeply I realize what a trial of fortitude it must have been to write such an article, but as the days pass I am sure the writer will experience the inner peace of one who has spoken forcible right words in good season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating housing construction programs of the armed services reported today that the Air Force would save $87,498,000 by correcting errors in its original estimates of requirements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- For the third consecutive week, department store sales in the United States were 2 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts during the week ended Aug. 23 follow, in terms of percentages from the like periods of 1951:

John Cashmore, who is 57 years old and who has been Borough President of Brooklyn for the last twelve years, is a veteran campaigner with a distinguished record in public life. His designation by the Democratic party as its Senatorial candidate is regarded by many political observers as a reward for work well done.
General Sessions Judge Edward J. McCullen yesterday granted J. Roland Sala, former city magistrate, permission to interview Patricia Ward, 19-year-old material witness in the vice case.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 28 (UP) -- A tropical storm twisted across the Atlantic 600 miles east of Miami today, blowing toward a high pressure area that might shape it into the year's first full-grown hurricane. Heavy rain squalls and winds of fifty to seventy-five miles an hours were reported over a 200-mile area.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 28 -- The match that drew the attention of most of the 4,000 spectators at the Waverley Country Club today was the women's United States amateur golf championship quarter-final that Mrs. Jacqueline Pung of Honolulu won by 2 up.

Resolutions on freedom of the press and progress made by the press in cutting down racial bias were adopted yesterday at the closing session of the convention of the Association for Education in Journalism. The convention, at Columbia University, was attended by 180 journalists and educators.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, advised politicians of thirty-three nations today to seek a solution of the world's troubles in the teachings of Frank N. D. Buchman, founder of the Moral Rearmament movement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Following is the text of the report by Ambassador William H. Draper Jr. to President Truman on political, military and economic developments in Europe in the past six months:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The State Department was informed today that the airlift for Moslem pilgrims to Mecca has been extended for at least another day. It was originally scheduled to stop this morning at local time.
The first American jet planes to be used in combat, Lockheed F-80 Shooting Stars, have flown 37 per cent of all fighter sorties in Korea as of July 31, the Air Force said yesterday.

In a decision likely to set a new pattern of procedure in Federal courts the United States Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the three-year contempt sentence of Gus Hall, convicted Communist leader, who fled to Mexico to avoid a prison term for conspiracy.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- A report on the three and a half hour conversation yesterday between the Iranian Premier and the British and United States representatives in Teheran was received at the Foreign Office today and was being studied.

Lewis K. Gough, a 44-year-old former commander in the Navy, was unanimously elected yesterday as national commander of the American Legion for 1952-53. He promptly pledged himself to lead the organization in the defense of the United States and her institutions.
CAIRO, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Premier Aly Maher and Gen. Mohammed Naguib, chief of the armed forces, declared tonight that there were no differences between them.

Sports shirt sales will not take business from the dress shirt field but will expand the unit volume and bring a larger share of the consumer dollar to the industry, Seymour J. Phillips, president of Phillips-Jones Corporation, manufacturer of Van Heusen shirts, says in a letter to be sent to the trade over the week-end.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Technicolor will be used on all but ten of the thirty-six pictures that Universal-International today announced for production during the fiscal year beginning Nov. 1. Coincidentally, Milton Rackmil, new president of the company and also president of Decca Records, which recently acquired majority stock control of U.-I., declared that no changes will be made in the operations of the studio.
TOWSON, Md., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The police said today they were certain now the death of Mrs. G. Edward Grammer in an apparent automobile accident Aug. 20 was not an accident but murder.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The United States called upon the United Nations Security Council today to recommend the admission of Japan to membership in the world organization.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower promised yesterday that he would "really start swinging" soon after Labor Day and that he would then wage a vigorous, fighting campaign right up to the election on Nov. 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue revealed today that John (Jack) Guzik -- former treasurer of the notorious Capone gang -- had settled a back income tax claim of more than $890,000 for $100,000 in 1942.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Two huge murals -- startling patterns in color -- have been designed for the United Nations by Fernand Leger, French modern painter and are being put up with a considerable dash of secrecy in the new General Assembly building.
A battalion medical officer home on leave from duty with the Seventh Infantry Division in Korea urged yesterday that as many persons as possible give blood to the Red Cross.

A rise of $69,000,000 in bank loans to business last week brought the advance since the seasonal upturn began four weeks ago to $213,000,000, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The latest expansion in loans from New York City banks cut the net reduction in such borrowings since the first of this year to $308,000,000, against a gain of $663,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

Katherine Brand has sold the former Brand homestead, comprising twenty-eight acres, on Bloomingdale Avenue in Hicksville, L. I., to the Twelfth Construction Corporation which plans to improve it with 130 one-family houses. Louis E. Bernstein, attorney and vice president of the purchasing group, said the houses will have two to four bedrooms and attached garages and will be priced from $10,990 to $12,990.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Although pounded for twelve hits and a half-dozen runs, Robin Roberts got heavy batting support from his Phillie team-mates as he defeated the Cardinals tonight, 10 to 6. It was Roberts twenty-first victory.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 29 -- The Communists protested yesterday against a new series of incidents in South Korean stockades in which Chinese and North Korean war prisoners were killed and wounded this month. The Communists demanded full information from the United Nations armistice delegation at Panmunjom.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn was nominated last night as the Democratic candidate for United States Senator this fall.

The New York State central school district composed of Seneca Falls, Fayette and Tyre, Seneca County, sold yesterday $1,700,000 of bonds, due from Nov. 1, 1952 to 1980, to a banking syndicate headed by Marine Trust Company of Western New York.

THE fastest game in major league history was the 51 minutes required by the Giants in achieving a 6-to-1 victory over the Phillies on Sept. 28, 1919. The American League record is 55 minutes. When did you last see a game played in less than an hour? Or two hours? You're tipping off your age if you ever admit witnessing one of those rarities.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Much British research into the new transistor tube devised by the Bell Telephone Company about four years ago has been made possible here by an original method of extracting the rare element germanium used in the tube's construction.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Mrs. Clare Booth Luce of Ridgefield, former United States Representative from Fairfield County who is seeking the Republican nomination for United States Senator, today accused Gov. John Davis Lodge of lending indirect support to the candidacy of Prescott S. Bush by his avowal of neutrality.

NEWARK, Aug. 28 -- Repeating their victories of last year, Ford Konno and Dick Cleveland of Ohio State and Michigan's Burwell (Bumpy) Jones tonight bagged the last three titles at stake in the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor swimming championships.
I have read with great interest the letter entitled "Smoking Habits Queried," which appeared in the columns of THE TIMES on Aug. 13, written by Joan Ferdinand and Peter Leavens.

An assertion that "the satisfaction of the greatest number of desires within our social and ethical structure" is the goal of management was made yesterday by L. E. Briggs, treasurer of the Ford Motor Company.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 28 -- Indications here are that the Kashmir situation may deteriorate into warfare if efforts in Geneva by Dr. Frank P. Graham, United Nations mediator, and expected subsequent United Nations Security Council consideration do not result in a quick plebiscite.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Advisory Committee to the United States Displaced Persons Commission expressed alarm to President Truman today over the fact that the Displaced Persons Act would end Sunday while millions overseas "still remain unsettled, homeless, hopeless."

The National Broadcasting Company will televise a church service from the Old North Church in Boston to be conducted by the Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher. Archbishop of Canterbury, on Sunday, Sept. 7, from 11 A. M. to 12 noon.

All lovers of fine tweeds will delight in the collection shown yesterday to the press by Peck Peck at their executive offices at 260 Fourth Avenue. Decidedly international in flavor, they were loomed in Scotland by some of the most famous mills of that country and fashioned in exclusive designs by both French couturiers and American designers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 23 totaled 834,120 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

It is a fair assumption that no Police Commissioner of New York City ever felt that he had enough policemen. Back in 1931, when there was a peak force of 19,315, Commissioner Mulrooney complained that he needed more. The city was smaller by 1,000,000 of population then, and the strength of the police force today is smaller by over 1,000 men than it was in 1931.

Dick Button, twice an Olympic figure skating champion, turned professional yesterday. The 22-year-old Harvard Law student signed a contract for $150,000 for limited appearances with the "Ice Capades of 1953," and he will make his salaried debut at Madison Square Garden on the night of Sept. 11.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- The cost of operating this installation has been cut $75,000 in the last three months, Col. Louis M Merrick, base commander, estimated today. The savings have been effected through "closer supervision" and by the adoption of money-saving suggestions from civilian and military personnel.

Seventy small-fry choristers, whose voices rang true and clear despite their lack of formal musical instruction, filled the auditorium of Public School 196 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday with lilting song. Enthusiastic approval came from a youthful audience of 400 who stamped, cheered and cried "Wow!" "We Want More!"

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., national champion in 1950, and Gardner Mulloy of Miami, Fla., member of the Davis Cup team, reached the final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

Mayor Impellitteri authorized Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens yesterday to hold up the levying of assessments on twenty Laurelton sewer contracts totaling $1,431,000 pending completion of investigations.

In a report to President Truman based on a survey of the European situation Ambassador Draper, special American representative abroad, has raised again and in a particularly forceful manner a fundamental problem which hangs like a dark cloud over the whole North Atlantic community and which must in the end determine both its military security and its political and economic stability.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 28 -- While the national junior sailing championship was clinched yesterday by Martin (Skip) Purcell of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of near-by Greenwich and a representative of Long Island Sound, he was out again today for the eighth race to complete the series.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Nassau County District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta is cutting short his vacation to start work tomorrow on the case of Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, a Roslyn business executive who is accused by the police of swindling a bank of $475,000 by forging applications for home improvement loans on behalf of fictitious clients.

" To Jerusalem," a diary by the late Count Folke Bernadotte, will be issued by British Book Centre on Sept. 16. It is a day-to-day journal of negotiations, difficulties and dangers up to the time of his assassination. The book's closing chapter was written by Gen. Aage Lundstrom, who was Count Bernadotte's chief of staff and an eyewitness of his murder.
Morale in our armed forces depends to a large extent on civilian support, Admiral Oscar C. Badger, retired, chairman of the New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund, said yesterday.
ROME, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Regular jet transportation service in the United States is "still some five to six years away." H. Mansfield Horner, president of United Aircraft Corporation, predicted today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 28 -- A study of the personality development of a group of sons of alcoholic fathers to discover the effects on the boys of their parents' maladjustments has just been completed by a graduate student of the Smith College School for Social Work here.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- The combined sixth annual meeting of the Air Force Association and an aviation display presented by the Aero Club of Michigan began here today. More than 2,000 veterans of World Wars I and II and the fighting in Korea, flying in from all parts of the country, are attending.

The power of prayer -- something that can unite and strengthen the freedom-loving countries of the world -- has again been brought into the news. A secluded, simple, non-denominational prayer room for the United Nations, to be set up in its East Midtown headquarters, is coming closer to being the reality of which its proponents have dreamed.

One hundred fifty thousand youngsters in this city will take their places in kindergarten and first-grade classes when the bell sounds for the first day of school on Sept. 8. Mothers of these beginners can start making some necessary preparations now to pave the way for this important occasion, Florence S. Beaumont, assistant superintendent of the elementary school division, declared yesterday.

Smoked hams and small-sized turkeys topped the week-end list of best buys for Labor Day picnickers or home diners, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. Legs of lamb, beef rib roast and pork loin roast also were included among the big markets' week-end specials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Industrial production bounced back this month to the level prevailing before the crippling steel strike, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The general business outlook of the American Car and Foundry Company was termed "good" by John E. Rovensky, chairman, at the annual meeting yesterday, although stockholders were cautioned "to keep your fingers crossed."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today there is no basis for market reports that the Government has contracted to buy Argentine wool.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- In a communication unique even among hundreds sent to the United Nations by members of non-self-governing races, Bigiraneza, an aged former African chief in Ruanda-Urundi, has threatened suicide if his faith in the integrity of the Trusteeship Council is not vindicated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The sworn deposition of a Federal judge that the Department of Justice had obstructed a grand jury investigation of income tax cases in St. Louis and that Ellis N. Slack, a Justice Department attorney, had instigated a report that has been described as a "whitewash" of the handling of the cases, was read to a House Judiciary subcommittee today.

The recovery effort was furthered yesterday by the stock market led by rails, rubbers, chemicals and an array of unrelated individual issues. The steels found little comfort either in price appreciation or volume although some of the motors leaned to the higher side.

A request by the Board of Transportation for a 1953 capital budget allocation of $423,584,875 was defended yesterday by Col. Sidney H. Bingham, board chairman, at a hearing before the City Planning Commission.

Net profit of Glidden Company for the nine months ended on July 31 amounted to $4,139,619, according to the report released yesterday by Dwight P. Joyce, president. This represents a decline of 30 per cent below the $5,840,220 cleared in the comparable period of 1951.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- The forty-eighth annual meeting of the American Political Science Association, attended by 800 university, Government and research experts, closed today.
The Federal mediator who for three weeks has been seeking to avert a strike on the New York Central suspended talks with union and company officials yesterday because he had "reached an impasse."

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Little activity on the buying side for grains and soybeans was in evidence today on the Board of Trade. With weather conditions in the spring wheat country favorable, and no export demand to help, there was free selling of wheat.

Gov. Adlai Stevenson charmed more than 1,000 persons at a luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with a confident speech compounded of anecdotes and expressions of his basic political theory.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Singles by Hank Edwards, Grady Hatton and Roy McMillan, the last with two out, gave the Reds a 5-4 eleven-inning victory over the Braves today.

Effectiveness of the Small Defense Plants Administration can be substantially increased by greater regional autonomy, according to Casper H. Citron, director of Region II of the Administration. Decentralization of authority, he pointed out yesterday at a meeting of the Select Small Business Committee Hearing in the Vanderbilt Hotel, will go a long way in bringing thousands of smaller companies into the defense program.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Mrs. Philip Conway of Siwanoy recorded 38, 41 -- 79 to take the one-day contest staged by the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today at Greenwich Country Club. This was her third such triumph of the season.

Rates for automobile liability insurance, which already have been sharply increased in many states, will go still higher unless the public changes its present attitude of "stick the insurance company," a leading insurance executive said yesterday.

The Delaware Lackawanna and Western Railroad filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday a petition seeking approval of the election of two directors to the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad commencing with the latter's annual meeting in May, 1953.

In an atmosphere of high hopes and accord, the Kings County Republican judicial convention met yesterday in the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building and nominated its three candidates for the State Supreme Court for the Second Judicial District.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- During the week ended Aug. 27, member bank reserves decreased $470,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 28 -- Former Nationalist judges who were kept on the bench in China to dispense "revolutionary justice" in the first phase of Mao Tse-tung's, "People's Democratic Dictatorship" are now facing a purge of their own ranks.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- On the last Thursday of the Saratoga meeting last year Ogden Phipps' Busanda led from shortly after the start in the Saratoga Cup race, Lone Eagle finished second, and immediately after the contest Sunny Fitzsimmons, trainer of the winner, headed happily down Route 9W for his home in Sheepshead Bay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Housewives of the nation will get a chance to tell the country's new Director of Price Stabilization what they think of price controls.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Sam Urzetta and Billy Campbell led the way into the semi-finals of the Canadian amateur golf tournament at the Capilano course today.
The Liberal party, hoping in vain that Averell Harriman would be the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, named Dr. George S. Counts last night as a temporary Stand-in candidate.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has issued a revised edition of its guide for retailers titled "The Retail Advertising Budget." Copies have been mailed to the newspaper members of the association whose advertising department will make them available to stores.

Versatile bar cookies deliciously solve either the picnic or party fare dessert problem. They can be cut into large bars or squares and individually wrapped for the Labor Day picnic hamper or for the school lunch kit.

The combined men's and women's national tennis championships start today on the turf of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, with Frank Sedgman of Australia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., as the defending titleholders.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The speech made in Buffalo yesterday by John Foster Dulles, Gen. Dwight. D. Eisenhower's foreign policy adviser, increased the disquietude caused in Europe by the general's own speech to the American Legion Monday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 28 -- An Iranian Government spokesman, Mohammed Aliabadi, stated at a press conference today that W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, a United States oil concern, who arrived this week in Iran with a group of experts, had asked to come to Iran and that it had been agreed that he would visit the Abadan oil installations.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Murray Vernon Jr. of Greenwich, 20-year-old Yale junior, shot a 1-under-par 32, 38 -- 70 to capture the medal over a field of sixty-two starters during the qualifying round as the twenty-eighth annual Westchester County Golf Association junior championships began at the Hampshire Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, rejected today a counter-blast from the oil industry that monopoly charges made against it "have given the Kremlin a fine talking point."

Crowell-Collier Publishing Company announced that its board of directors voted yesterday to omit payment of a dividend on the common stock due at this time. The company publishes Woman's Home Companion and Colliers Weekly.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 28 -- Monongahela, Pa., unleashed a nine-hit attack against two Hackensack, N. J., pitchers tonight to score a 10-1 victory in the semi-finals of the Little League world series.

The board of governors of the New York Cotton Exchange at a meeting here yesterday voted to close the Exchange all year round on Saturdays. The Exchange also announced that as soon as the bylaws can be changed, probably in two weeks, trading hours will be from 10:30 A. M. to 3:30 P. M. for the five-day week.

The Federal Maritime Board informed American Export Lines yesterday that thirty days would be granted the company after redetermination of the sales price of the liners Independence and Constitution during which the line could accept or reject the ships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, released today details of a September campaign tour that will take him into sixteen states.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser of the Tigers spoiled the Indians' bid to gain on the leading Yankees tonight, pitching an eight-hit 4-1 victory before 53,988 fans, largest crowd of the year here. But the Indians won the first game of the twilight opener, 9 to 3.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Development of Britain's Mark III Comet jet airliner, now in the early stages of design, will be speeded up "if firm orders are placed," a spokesman for the De Havilland Aircraft Company said today.

The United States team of Samuel Reshevsky, Robert Byrne, Arthur B. Bisguier and George Koltanowski drew all four games against Hungary yesterday in the eighth round of the International Chess Federation tournament at Helsinki, according to reports from Finland.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug 28 -- The AMVETS, an organization of World War II and Korea veterans, opened its eighth national convention here this afternoon without the traditional pranks.

In a speech to New Jersey Democrats on Wednesday Governor Stevenson made the following remark: "I am not in the delicate position of another candidate for high office, who faces the ticklish problem of whether to swallow his principles and endorse all the candidates running on the same ticket with him."
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 7 to 36 points net lower than on Wednesday.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- The Civil Service Employes Association urged today that Governor Dewey and Senators Irving M. Ives and Herbert H. Lehman act to prevent further lay-offs in the State Division of Unemployment Insurance. More than 100 workers in the division have been laid off already, with the number expected to reach 300 by Sept. 1.

Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, pictured himself yesterday as a politically minded individual who believed strongly in party discipline and regularity and who subscribed to the doctrine that the fruits of victory should go to the party workers laboring in the vineyards, with the rewards to bear a direct relationship to the efforts extended.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Although held to a draw by Jack W. Collins in the fifth round today, Max Pavey of Brooklyn retained the lead in the annual tournament for the New York State chess championship at the junior college here.

Representatives of union workers in major shipyards of this area predicted yesterday two years of peaceful labor management relations as a result of a new agreement reached between the Todd Shipyards Corporation and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 28 -- Gov. John S. Battle of Virginia and the Democratic State Central Committee, a seventy-eight-member party political steering group, announced today their support for the candidacy of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic nominee for President.

Due to expanding sales, the vacuum cleaner division of Lewyt Corporation will go on two forty-hour shifts a week beginning next Tuesday. In announcing the change yesterday from the current single forty-eight-hour shift, Alex Lewyt, president, said his company is taking the step to meet requests from distributors for larger allocations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow was assigned to the Army's Historical Office today -- one month after he was convicted by a court-martial of writing secret information in his personal diary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Government announced today it is considering establishing a mill and purchasing facilities in Arizona to handle crysotile asbestos from independent producers in that state.
In your admirable article appearing in THE TIMES of Aug. 25 in regard to Governor Stevenson's stand on the submerged oil lands you say:

A taxicab driver was held on a charge of petit - larceny in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday morning after, according to the police, he stole $26 from a passenger who looked like a drunken American Legionnaire but who turned out to be a policeman in disguise.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Delegates to the Republican judicial convention for the Tenth Judicial District, comprising Queens, Nassau and Suffolk, today nominated candidates from Nassau and Suffolk for Supreme Court Justice vacancies for the first time since the district's creation in 1948.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 28 -- John Hyatt 21-year-old captain of the Fordham University football team, was admitted as a patient to the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Institute at the Medical Center here late last night for treatment. Mr. Hyatt, who is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hyatt of 210 Seaview Avenue is suffering from the bulbo-spinal type of infantile paralysis.
Following are the texts of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's speeches last night before the state committee of the Liberal party and the Democratic State Convention, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The oil and gas properties of the Graham-Paige Corporation, a closed - end investment company, showed additional progress in the first six months of this year, according to a report yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer, chairman, and John J. Bergen, president.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Devil Makes Three," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama made in Germany and starring Gene Kelly and Pier Angeli, is at the Globe. Andrew Marton directed and Richard Goldstone produced from a screen play by Jerry Davis, based on a story by Lawrence Bachman. Richard Robot, Richard Egan, Claus Clausen, Wilfred Seyferth, Margot Hielscher and Annie Rosar are among the supporting players.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 (AP) -- J. J. McCarthy's Ginger Boots scored by a nose in the Shaughnessy Purse today for his first victory in nine starts this year. The Jamestown gelding beat Jack L. McKnight's Oriole in the last stride of the mile-and-a-furlong race.

LUND, Sweden, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The world's divided churches have failed in their efforts to map a blueprint for a united Christendom, their representatives declared today at the conclusion of a two-week conference.

In the opinion of the American Legion, this country's merchant marine is unbalanced, too small in numbers, over-age and of insufficient speed to support the country's peacetime needs, and consequently is ill-equipped to fulfill its mission as a ready military auxiliary reserve.

In contrast to yesterday's generally confident and reassuring statements by Secretary Pace about the building up of our armed forces is the sharply critical report of the Senate Armed Services Preparedness subcommittee on the aircraft production program. The Senate's defense watchdog group brought in a blistering indictment of planning and administration.
The American Legion ended its thirty-fourth national convention here yesterday with another attack on the Truman Administration's conduct of the Korean war.
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,356, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- John J. Humm of the home club played alternate shots with Mrs. Caryl Sayre of The Creek to win low gross honors in a Long Island Golf Association mixed scotch-foursome tournament with a 4-over-par 39, 37 -- 76 over the Rockville course today.

The General Electric Company's offer of a 7 1/2 to 13-cents-an-hour increase retroactive to Aug. 15 if it was accepted by the International Union of Electrical Radio and Machine Workers Union, C. I. O., by Aug. 31, was turned down yesterday by the union.

Roger M. Dailey has been named secretary-treasurer and a director of the Murray Corporation of America, effective on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday. C. David Widman, who has been vice president, secretary and treasurer, will continue as a vice president until the end of the year at which time he will retire.

Virtually no progress has been made in the last three weeks toward settlement of the Japanese overseas debt, negotiations toward which are still proceeding in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. Unimpeachable but bashful sources say that agreement has run into the barrier of British insistence that the "dollar option" contained in some sterling bond indentures be honored.

The split in the ranks of the powerful Democratic party in Brooklyn, which was brought into the open on Wednesday night at the organization's judicial convention, is expected to result in a major shift in leadership.

The five-story dwelling with brick facade and basement at 55 East Eighty-second Street has been sold by George Garfield to Dr. Sidney W. Gross, surgeon, who plans to occupy the entire building as a residence and offices. Mrs. C. T. Messing of the Madison Realty Company was the broker.

Waived out of the National League, Ewell Blackwell yesterday was dealt by the Reds to the Yankees. The lean right-hander, often called "The Whip," is to report in time for tonight's game against the Senators at the Stadium.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, called last night on General Dwight D. Eisenhower, his Republican opponent, to shake off his "middle-of-the-gutter" counselors. He said he did not "envy the general having to listen to all the conflicting advice about how to treat the slanderers of his dear friend and senior officer, Gen. [George C.] Marshall."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating the preparedness program sounded its second urgent call today for the immediate appointment of a full-time "czar" in the Department of Defense with initiative and authority to pull aircraft production out of a slump that endangered national safety.

RHINEBECK, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who has a dairy farm at near-by Pawling, spent three hours today at the Dutchess County Fair here inspecting dairy herds, visiting Grange exhibits and watching the harness races. The visit continued a custom of his for many years.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- Pravda, the newspaper, complained today of unsatisfactory conditions in the motion-picture industry and called for more and better films. The Communist party organ said a dearth of scenarios had retarded the industry and caused "prolonged idleness or part time work in almost all studios."
COLOMBO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Ceylon Government imposed new restrictions today on goods from hard currency areas.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 28 -- Mozafar Baghai, chief of the Workers party, one of the three parties making up Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's National Front, issued in his party organ today orders to his partisans to attack the Communists tomorrow and drive them away from memorial services at the graves of those killed in the July 21 rioting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey denied today that national headquarters of the Selective Service ever had exerted "improper" influence over local draft boards, as charged in an American Legion resolution. He added he would "welcome" any inquiry by Congress into the charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The State Department has never undertaken to pass on the anti-trust aspects of foreign operations by United States oil companies, a spokesman said today. It has never had, and does not now have, authority to make any such judgments, he added.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Truman refused today to consider an American Legion demand for the dismissal of Secretary of State Dean Acheson. Secretary Acheson was the best man in the United States for the position, Mr. Truman asserted.

Vincent Hallinan, San Francisco atttorney, was nominated for President of the United States by the American Labor Party convention here last night. This action placed the Progressive party's standard bearer on the ballot in New York State.

The lone tennis court at their camp in the Catskill foothills held all the magic of the center court during the finals of a championship tournament for the eighty diabetic children who looked on the other day. They watched two of America's top tennis stars demonstrate that diabetes, with proper medical care and supervision, need be no deterrent to leading a full life.
Traffic experts warned yesterday that the three-day Labor Day holiday week-end might bring the heaviest highway congestion of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Truman was advised today that there was a "real danger of a deep and perhaps disastrous fissure between the economies of Europe and America" and that the United States should greatly increase its imports from that area and other parts of the world.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- U. Tzedenbal, Premier of the Mongolian People's Republic, arrived in Moscow by plane late Thursday to join the important diplomatic discussions already underway in the Soviet capital between Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China and Soviet Government representatives.

Technical considerations, including the desire of operators to limit their commitments before the long Labor Day week-end, ruled most commodity futures markets yesterday. The more active markets had pronounced moves in both directions in the course of the day.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 -- The convention of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union of North America approved "in principle" today a committee recommendation for a five-year continuation of arbitration agreements with the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Printing Industry of America.

Nine evangelists, convicted of disorderly conduct on Aug. 18 because of their actions at a religious meeting on July 13 at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, received suspended sentences yesterday from Magistrate Paul Balsam in Mid-Manhattan Court.
GENEVA, Aug. 28 -- Six Swiss Alpinists left Geneva by air today on the first lap of a journey that they expect to end on the top of Mount Everest.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- Convinced that the public of the Allied democratic nations is entitled to all information concerning the defenses of the North Atlantic coalition that is not actually harmful to security, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway has requested the proper Atlantic alliance authorities to consider the advisability of publishing more complete facts on the condition of the forces under his command.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Aug. 28 -- Mrs. Henrietta C. Sargent of near-by Rancocas, who is 105 years old today, was the guest of honor tonight at her second birthday party in two days. Five generations of her family attended both celebrations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The principal national figures among Texas Democratic officeholders have opened an urgent campaign to hold the state for the Democratic ticket, despite Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's opposition to state control of the offshore oil lands.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Dodgers today evened their series with the Cubs by beating them, 9 -- 6, before a Ladies Day crowd of 40,311 at Wrigley Field.

TRENTON, Aug. 28 -- The State Public Utility Commission today authorized the Pennslyvania Railroad and the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines to increase South Jersey intrastate commutation fares to conform to comparable interstate rates approved or pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- Behind a salvo of sixteen hits that swamped the Pirates, 14 -- 7, the Giants took their season's farewell of Forbes Field today with a clean sweep of the three-game series that marked their last invasion of the West.

CAIRO, Aug. 28 -- Osman Moharram, former Minister of Public Works and a prominent member of the Wafd, Egypt's largest political party, has been accused by a purge committee of corruption in connection with the construction of the new Alexandria sewerage system.

The hatchet finally was buried by the League of New York Theatres and the Scenic Artists Union at a parley of both groups yesterday morning. Thus ended a long and bitter controversy over the use of foreign scenery that originated last March with the ill-fated London importation of "Women of Twilight."

YONKERS, Aug. 28 -- Detectives established through a secret witness today that John Acropolis, Westchester County union leader, was murdered in his Warburton Avenue apartment here at 2:30 A. M. Tuesday.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 28 -- General of the Army George C. Marshall, preparing to leave Santa Barbara after a two-month visit, was touched by tributes from both Presidential candidates, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- Dissolution today of the Japanese Diet (Parliament) and announcement of a general election Oct. 1 by Premier Shigeru Yoshida came as a surprise in political circles. Mr. Yoshida previously had indicated he meant to serve out his full term despite considerable pressure both within and outside the governmental Liberal party for a new deal after completion of the task of restoring Japanese sovereignty.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug 28 (AP) -- The Athletics scored four runs in the eighth inning, three on a bases-loaded double by Cass Michaels, to win the first game today of a scheduled double-header against the Red Sox, 6 -- 4. The second game was postponed because of wet grounds.

NOWADAYS, when night settles on Hannibal, Mo. (as this reviewer can testify, after a midsummer visit), much of the old magic returns, with its candlepower intact. Forgotten are the postcards at the air-conditioned Becky Thatcher house, the Famous Fence (with its fresh coat of whitewash), the Tom and Huck Motel just around the corner, the long, dampish tour of the Mark Twain cave.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A number of prominent opponents of the Government, including the manager of the huge Patino tin mines, were arrested at dawn today after what police described as an abortive "terrorist plot designed to eliminate the chief Government leaders."

What a pleasure to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 25, and from the pen of an influential Latin American, J. Texier de Unda, that "Americans have always received a most deferential and friendly treatment in many Latin-American countries like Venezuela and are well liked for their straightforwardness and frankness."
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Delaware Supreme Court today reaffirmed its decision of July 17 that stock options may not be granted to employes of California Eastern Airways, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union assailed the Army today for ordering a loyalty check that caused Brig. Gen. Elliot R. Thorpe to withdraw as a Republican candidate for Congress in Rhode Island.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 28 -- By what has been described as "sheer persistence and angling skill with a shamrock and a horseshoe on each boat" the New York A. C. anglers walked off with the tenth United States Atlantic tuna tournament laurels today, giving them the second leg on the two major trophies of the contest.

LONDON, .Aug. 28, -- The stock markets today maintained the steady rise of the past week and achieved some expansion in trading volume, especially in the market for British Government Securities. These gained as much as seven shillings sixpence ($1.05).

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 28 -- The disclosure that publicly owned documents and valuable paintings had been on loan by the Louisiana State Museum to individuals, including a former governor, brought a call from the District Attorney today for a report of the audit of the museum, as he prepared to submit the matter to the Orleans parish (county) grand jury.

Five teen-agers won fall fashions in a public drawing held yesterday at Saks Thirty-fourth Street. To the winners went a full pyramid coat of tan and blue check wool, a coordinated group of black and white plaid corduroy separates, a bright red corduroy coverall and a red corduroy jumper with matching hat.

OTTAWA, Aug. 28 -- More than a hundred members representing the free parliaments of thirty self-governing countries within the British Commonwealth have begun to gather in Canada for the third meeting since World War II of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.
With fanfare as loud as the acclamation of a queen, Mrs. Rae Ashton of Vernal, Utah, was installed yesterday as national president of the American Legion Auxiliary.

We have appealed to Secretary Trygve Lie of the United Nations, Secretary of State Dean Acheson and to John Foster Dulles to intervene to prevent the consummation of the agreement -- reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 14 -- between the Governments of the United States and Japan whereby the former will lend-lease to the latter for five years "eighteen small warships and fifty coastal defense vessels."

Shipping concerns engaged in wage review negotiations with the International Longshoremen's Association notified the American Federation of Labor union yesterday that it would not meet again to discuss new terms with the worker committee until non-wage fringe demands were dropped.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Allied land and carrier-based fighter-bombers teamed today to blast military targets in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. Civilians were forewarned to flee. There was no immediate announcement of results, but the blow apparently was a major strike.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association with a two-under-women's par 39, 36 -- 75 over the Rock Spring course today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- Disaster from the skies in the form of rain and locusts has left millions of Indians in acute distress and engaged tens of thousands of relief workers this week over wide areas covering much of the northern half of the country.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Justice Minister C. R. Swart, chairman of the Judicial Committee of the High Court of Parliament, was on hand as Presiding Justice J. E. De Villiers of the Cape Supreme Court said in his opinion invalidating the High Court of Parliament:
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,357 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A.M. Saturday, Korea time:

Coffee enjoyed a strong tone yesterday. Brazilian prices were reported firm, with Parana beans rising steadily and now within a cent of the Santos price. A good volume of business in green coffee was reported. Colombians widened their premium over Santos to 4 cents, apparently in anticipation of German purchases on Sept. 15 of 70,000 bags.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Thirty-five yachts, one more than last year, started in the Vineyard race of Stamford Yacht Club, which began at 6 o'clock tonight from the flashing white bell buoy off here.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 8 to 22 points net higher on active months than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice heard a long and complicated story today from Department of Justice files of how "one of its best cases" was tossed around in the department and in the courts for eight years until it became so "enfeebled with age" that it was dismissed.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- The 205-foot United States Navy tug Sarsi struck a mine and sank within twenty minutes off the east coast of North Korea at midnight Wednesday, the Navy announced here today. Two crew members were killed and three are missing.

MARGERY ALLINGHAM, as her American publisher informs us, divides her working time between D'Arcy House (her home in Essex) and a flat in London. D'Arcy House is half Tudor, half Georgian -- a description, by the way, that might also be applied to Miss Allingham's excellent and artful prose style. Orchards and formal gardens surround it, and the salt sweet breath of the Channel is evident, not too far to the east.

The first prickly pears of the season are here from the Southwest, an arrival that probably only those of Mexican or Italian background will greet with enthusiasm. For though this fruit of the cactus has a sweetly succulent taste, its popularity here never has been great enough to warrant annual shipments of more than eighteen or twenty carloads.
New York business men, while grateful for any pay dirt in the "deadest week of the year," mined no bonanza in the American Legion convention just ended, a sampling of opinion yesterday showed.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Skee Riegel of Tulsa, Okla., and Art Wall Jr. of Homesdale, Pa., fired 5-under-par 66's today to take the lead in the opening round of the first $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.
Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, flew back to Illinois yesterday after a triumphal fifty-hour initial campaign visit to New York and New Jersey.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Athletics drew a bead on third place tonight as they swept a twilight - night double - header from the Red Sox, 6 -- 1 and 7 -- 5.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Award of Mexican concession to exploit one of the world's largest volcanic sulphur deposit was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Several inventions patented this week are designed to protect the person. One is the pocket burglar alarm that Allan J. Conolly of Stillwater, Minn., has invented particularly to foil the removal of wallets and billfolds from hip pockets.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A late Fifth Air Force report said that United States F-86 Sabres shot down one enemy MIG jet fighter and damaged two others north of Pyongyang during yesterday's attacks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The United States Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals today ordered fourteen convicted California Communists released on $20,000 bail each.
Henry R. Michel has been appointed director of purchases for Celanese Corporation of America.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 29 -- A British judge ordered a retrial in an Ipoh court today of a pretty 24-year-old Chinese woman when two Asian assessors found her not guilty of Communist terrorist activity.

Six Brooklyn anglers, ranging from 8 to 14 years old, received bonds, bicycles and a fishing kit yesterday for their piscatorial prowess in a six-week fishing contest that drew 132 entrants to Prospect Park Lake.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Several hundred post entries flooded the thirteenth annual Fairfield County Junior Hunt Club show today to bring the list for the two-day event well above 600.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Winning from Frank Anderson of Toronto, leading Canadian expert, Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn tonight drew away from the field of twenty-six competing in the annual championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 29 (UP) -- An Atlantic hurricane packing 85-mile-an-hour winds veered sharply tonight from a course that had aimed it at Florida and the Weather Bureau said its main force might miss the United States shoreline.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Moslem prayers of gratitude sounded through Lebanese mosques today for the United States airlift that had flown 3,763 stranded pilgrims in seventy-five flights to Saudi Arabia to worship at Mecca, the birthplace of Mohammed.
CAIRO, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Premier Aly Maher announced today that the infant King Ahmed Fuad II would be educated in Egypt so that he would grow up among his people.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 29 -- An 1,800-mile accident-marked flight from far out in the Atlantic Ocean ended here tonight in tears for an Air Force sergeant and his wife.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -- An eight-month civic battle over the dissemination in the Los Angeles public schools of information about the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) culminated today in a partial ban on the subject.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Closing with a rush, Freddy Hawk, 6-year-old gelding owned by Parker Mitchell of Perryman, Md., won the Ticonderoga Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:02 1/5.

Charles K. Freeman, director, is planning to make his bow as a Broadway producer this season with "Forever Young," an adaptation by Gilbert Seldes of an Italian comedy by Cesare Meano called "La Nascita di Salome" (The Birth of Salome).

With the decision of cotton exchanges to close on Saturdays throughout the year, the nation's brokerage business now is on a five-day basis. Previously, other major commodity exchanges and the securities markets had voted to close on Saturdays.
The only book published today is "Ma and Me," a collection of twenty short stories by William Ornstein. Its publisher is the Story Book Press of Dallas, Tex.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 29 -- A Baptist church deacon complained today that jury members here were served "alcoholic beverages" at meal time?

A second slate of candidates for Supreme Court Justice from the Second Judiciary District was nominated by Democratic Convention delegates in Brooklyn last night, thus precipitating a potential court fight with a feuding faction that had named its own slate on Wednesday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 29 -- William H. Abel, president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, which lost $475,000 by a recently uncovered swindle, shot himself in the basement workshop of his home at 1:30 P. M. today, an hour and a half before he was scheduled to appear in the prosecutor's office.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Arnold Lipman, 19-year-old Elmwood player, retained the Westchester County Golf Association's junior championship today over the 6,310-yard Hampshire Country Club course. Four down going into the thirteenth, the Yale junior beat Murray Vernon Jr. of Greenwich, an Eli team-mate, 1 up, on the twentieth.

SPRINGFIELD. Ill., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The America First party launched a court fight aimed at entering General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as the party's candidate for President in the Illinois November election.

PARIS, Aug. 29 -- Rarely has an official United States document received so much attention from the French press, or such commendation from European officials here, as were accorded today to the report on the first six months of the Mutual Security Agency, just made to President Truman by William H. Draper Jr., Special United States Representative in Europe.

Five animals identified as red-faced apes from Malaya escaped their cages in the Trefflich Bird and Animal Company at 228 Fulton Street about 9 o'clock yesterday morning. It was not until afternoon that the apes were captured by eleven policemen whom bystanders described as red-faced.

Anyone planning a visit to the Stadium today to see the Yankees engage the Senators is advised to arrive early. For this is the day of the sixth annual Old-Timers Day and ceremonies will get under way promptly at 1:30 P. M., with a three-inning ball game to follow introductions and presentations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Import duties on crude petroleum, topped crude petroleum and fuel oil derived from petroleum were reduced 50 per cent by a trade agreement with Venezuela, and announced at the State Department today.

These are the words of a medical officer, Lieut. Harold Schwartz, who has just returned from duty in Korea. "It has been discouraging and amazing to me to hear about the difficulties the Red Cross has had in obtaining blood. If you had watched the boys actually being saved from certain death right before your eyes you wouldn't hesitate a minute to give blood.
Russia, by defeating West Germany by 3 1/2 -- 1/2 in the eighth round, kept the lead yesterday in the International Chess Federation team championship at Helsinki, according to a report from Finland.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Luke Easter crashed his twenty-third homer of the season, off Virgil Trucks, as the second-place Indians whipped the Tigers, 4 -- 2, today. It was Easter's eighth homer in the last eighteen games and accounted for two runs.

Acting District Attorney Joseph A. Sarafite announced yesterday that a 44-year-old mother of three children had been indicted on grand larceny charges as a result of complaints that she had mulcted 167 persons, all Puerto Ricans, of $40,000 for apartments promised but never provided.

There is double satisfaction in the Board of Education's unanimous re-election of Dr. Jacob Greenberg to his fourth six-year term as an associate superintendent of schools. First, it is an election Dr. Greenberg richly merits. Second, it assures the city of six more years of outstanding educational performance.

UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The Rev. Robert Collins of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church of near-by Rome told the Empire State Association of the Deaf in its biennial convention here today that as soon as he was more proficient in the sign-language he would say mass in that language.

The authorized strength of New York City's police force has become a paper figure of wishful thinking. Actual strength when the books close tomorrow on August retirements will be 18,225; manpower will then be 1,622 short of authorized quota.
Frank Sedgman began the defense of his title yesterday as the national amateur championships started on the turf of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee, headed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, has prepared a campaign pamphlet listing foreign policy as the main issue in the 1952 elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union gave a blanket rejection today to the West's latest proposals on arms reduction -- Big Five and regional conferences aimed at progres sive disarmament. Jacob A. Malik, deputy Foreign Minister and chief Soviet delegate, used some of his favorite epithets to describe the Western powers' suggestions -- "absurd" and "hypocritical" were two.
Labor Day holiday travelers set out yesterday on a final vacation fling with prospects of moderately good weather and dangerously congested traffic.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- A young New Zealand doctor, his family and two crew members have completed a storm-tossed, 6,750-mile voyage from New Zealand to Peru in a forty-eight-foot ketch.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Senator Sparkman sidestepped here today whether he would use his influence to end Senate filibustering. He called the question an "iffy" one. He said he would "meet issues as they come up" if he is elected Vice President and becomes presiding officer of the Senate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The Cubs are the masters of the Dodgers at Wrigley Field if not in Brooklyn. They knocked out Preacher Roe today in a three-run seventh inning to win, 4 -- 1, behind Warren Hacker's four-hit pitching.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- Pravda in a two-column front page editorial today bitterly attacked Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, comparing him with Adolf Hitler and charging him with a plan to make war against the Soviet Union and conquer most of Europe and Asia.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 29 -- The two-month-old Dutch Cabinet crisis appeared on the verge of solution tonight. An announcement by Queen Juliana's secretariat that Willem Drees, the caretaker Premier, had been designated to form a new Government, was taken as corroboration that a list of Ministers had been agreed upon and would be announced soon.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 29 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson said today he had no intention of creating an open fight with his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

I'd like to take issue with Herbert Bayard Swope, who in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES published Aug. 25 criticized the Atomic Energy Commission for publicizing the site of the future gaseous diffusion separation plant in Pike County, Ohio, and for a similar announcement many months ago about the hydrogen bomb plant now building on the Savannah River in South Carolina.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Government today announced signing of a contract for purchase of copper and molybdenum from the San Manuel Copper Corporation of New York at a guaranteed price.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Mario Lanza was prevented from doing his weekly radio show tonight over the National Broadcasting Company network because of his controversy with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The film company, which controls the singer's contract, notified N. B. C. that Mr. Lanza was in default of the agreement and could not sing on the air because of his failure to report for work in a movie, "The Student Prince."

These are the days of abundance of crops. Indeed, to speak frankly, these are the days of superabundance. Front this point it seems unreal that those few small seeds which were placed in the garden in April and May should have produced what is out there now.

Anna Buswell has sold the four-story building containing two stores and six apartments at 5624 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, to Irving Manings. The City Title Insurance Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet.

BERLN, Aug. 29 -- This city's uneasy peace of recent weeks came to an abrupt end today with several small-scale but ominous outbreaks of violence both Communist and non-Communist -- in the Western sectors.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British Government's plan for a federation of Northern and Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland does not require the consent of the Negro population, Henry Hopkinson, Minister of State for Colonial Affairs, declared today after he had returned from a one-month tour of the three Central African territories.

The major political parties have completed their nominations for United States Senator. Irving M. Ives will run on the Republican ticket for re-election to the seat which he has held since 1947. John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn since 1940, will be his Democratic opponent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (UP) -- An Air Force lieutenant colonel and three civilians were charged today with conspiring to defraud the Government in the sale of equipment to Army and Air Force post exchanges in the Chicago region.

The Government bitterly opposed yesterday a defense motion at the Communist conspiracy trial to strike out testimony of Thomas A. Younglove of St. Louis, former Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover man in the party. Federal Judge Edward V. Dimock said he would give the prosecution additional time to argue the motion.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- A playground on wheels is Detroit's answer to the recreation needs of youngsters living in the crowded slum zone bounded by the Detroit River on the south and the Grand Boulevard loop on the north.
THE season-opener for the Eastern gunner is the rail, that flitting inhabitant of the tidal wild rice flats, and these birds become legal game on Monday in both New Jersey and Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Wright Morrow, the Democratic National Committeeman from Texas, told his committee colleagues today that it was touch and go whether that State's Democratic Convention would repudiate the party's Presidential ticket.

A wildcat strike of 120 drivers employed by the Bee Line, Inc., halted bus service last night in Freeport and Hempstead, L. I. Officials of Local 252, Transport Workers of America, C. I. O., terming the strike "a spontaneous walkout," said it was caused by the company's refusal to meet union demands for additional service.

TOKYO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Finance Minister Hayato Ikeda said today the Government would permit Aluminum, Ltd., of Canada to buy into the Japan Light Metals Company, subject to adjustment of minor points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- An indignation meeting of State Department employes who were veterans of the armed forces expressed "strong resentment" today at what they took to be implications of disloyalty directed at them by the American Legion convention in New York this week.
Bernard F. Fox, engineer in charge of field personnel in the Queens Bureau of Sewer Construction, was suspended yesterday without pay by Borough President James A. Lundy.

Leaders of the Liberal party continued yesterday in their reluctance to endorse John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, whom the Democratic State Convention nominated for United States Senator late Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today he will head the United States delegation to the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Mexico City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The American Veterans Committee today accused the American Legion of "nationalistic blindness" and "complete intellectual bankruptcy" for "attacking" the United Nations.

Since the inception of the Coast Guard port security program two years ago 500,000 seamen, longshoremen and other port area workers have been screened to protect against the infiltration of subversives in American shipping and on vital marine terminals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The conference committee of eastern railroads and seventeen nonoperating unions agreed on a union shop today.

ROME, Aug. 29 -- Drilling for oil is to be begun shortly in Sicily by two American companies -- Gulf Oil Corporation and MacMillan Petroleum of California. Both have been prospecting in Sicily for years and have pooled their holdings and formed a joint corporation, the Mediterranean Oil Company.
The first issue of a brand new daily, still unnamed as this paper went to press, is scheduled to make its appearance in New York today.
A number of visiting preachers will be heard in their last sermons of the summer season tomorrow at Protestant churches. Others will be heard who have made preaching engagements for tomorrow only.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Ginseppe Pella, Italian Minister of the Treasury, said today his country's recovery and rearmament programs could not be permitted to endanger the stability of the Italian lira. He made the comment after two days of conferences with United States defense and foreign relations officials.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Reports from many parts of Britain show that older houses are deteriorating at an alarming rate because private landlords frequently cannot afford to carry out normal repairs with costs so high and controlled rentals so low.

The stock market continued to plod ahead yesterday but still without the benefit of any increase in volume. The fresh rise carried prices to the best levels of the recovery movement with the rafts, automotives and aircrafts setting the pace and with the usual assistance from an array of specialties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board announced today that Congressionally imposed budget cuts would force it to curtail its information and advisory services in almost 100 cities by Oct. 1.

Your recent editorial on "The Need for Change" seemed to this reader, at least, unfair by the high standard that we have become accustomed to in the editorials as well as the news offered us in America's greatest newspaper.

The Willis Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River was reopened yesterday after ceremonies marking the completion of reconstruction of its Bronx and Manhattan approaches. The span, which serves northbound traffic, had been closed since April, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Prices of farm products remained unchanged between mid-July and mid-August, a period in which some crops were damaged by a severe drought, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 30 -- Allied warplanes yesterday blasted Pyongyang, capital of Communist North Korea, in the heaviest attack of the two-year-old Korean War.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A petition by the Illinois Central Railroad for a flat 45 per cent increase in its intrastate suburban passenger fares in the Chicago area was made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau made public three tax cases today in which it had settled almost $140,000 in claims for $15,600.
The following is a round-up of new products which may be of use to homeowners:

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Aug. 29 -- This township has given the Delaware Valley Dairy Company, Inc., just twenty-one days to bottle up its milk-curdling delivery noises. If the noise persists, six families of bleary-eyed, sleepless neighbors of the company will be turned loose to vent their legal ire on the bottle rattlers.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 29 -- Arthur Larsen needed only thirty-six minutes today to capture the invitation grass court tournament final at the Nassau Country Club.

VIENNA, Aug. 29 -- The Soviet Union's case against Austria when the latter brings her demand for a state treaty before the United Nations was believed to have been foreshadowed in the Allied Council today when Lieut. Gen. Vadim P. Sviridov, Soviet High Commissioner, read a twenty-page tirade against the "reactionary" Austrian Government.

The City of New York obtained $951,085 in the auction of 237 parcels in the Rockaway section of Queens during a four-day sale held in the Far Rockaway High School. Obtained through "in rem" foreclosure proceedings, the properties were offered through William M. Ellard director of the Bureau of Real Estate.

YONKERS, Aug. 29 -- Union wrangles centering on John Acropolis in the last ten years were scrutinized today for clues to the reasons for his murder at 2:30 A. M. last Tuesday in his apartment at 1080 Warburton Avenue. Mr. Acropolis was president of the Westchester County Federation of Labor and Local 456 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.

Shipping men now engaged in wage-review negotiations with the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., will meet Tuesday to consider new demands presented Thursday by the dock union, it was announced yesterday.

The Bridgeport Brass Company yesterday announced the effectiveness of a payroll savings plan for employes whereby the company's workers will be enabled to acquire common stock of the company at the market price. The stock to be acquired by employes will not be new shares but will be bought in the secondary market.

Switzerland's industries are ready to help fill her part of the dollar gap, complained of yesterday by Ambassador William H. Draper Jr. in his report to President Truman. Paul O. Althouse, visiting owner of the largest and oldest Swiss advertising agency, said at the Advertising Club here yesterday that not only the watch and parts makers were anxious to increase their shipments as provided for in President Truman's recent action.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 29 -- Gar Wood, industrialist and speedboat expert, filed suit in circuit court here today to nullify a movie contract entered into with Paul R. Thoma, New York producer and director, for a film entitled "Time to Move," a story of Mr. Wood's life that was being shot on Fishers Island, where he resides.

The apartment building housing ninety-six families and occupying a plot 100 by 120 feet at 545 West End Avenue has been sold by the Clinton Trust Company, as trustee, to All Deals, Inc., for investment. It is assessed at $890,000 and was sold subject to a mortgage of $645,000.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Last year's winner fell at the second of the sixteen jumps, the favorite faded in the drive to the wire after having had trouble at several hedges, and the 9-1 outsider in the betting -- and the lightweight in the six-horse line-up -- led 'em home in the $11,300 Saratoga Steeplechase today.

Their pennant hopes dimmed, the Giants returned yesterday from the West prepared for a last-ditch stand that must be even more spectacular than last year's if they are to win the National League flag.

All the pretenses the Soviets have been making in their diplomatic notes and propaganda that they desire a unified, democratic and peaceful Germany are knocked into a cocked hat by their intensified drive to complete the sovietization of what they ironically call the "German Democratic Republic."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Ken Carpenter plunged for one touchdown and caught a pass for another tonight as the Cleveland Browns beat the Chicago Bears, 14 -- 7, in an exhibition between National Football League teams.

GENEVA, Aug. 29 -- High-level talks between India and Pakistan and the United Nations mediator for the Kashmir dispute, Dr. Frank Graham, designed to seek agreement on preconditions for a plebiscite to settle Kashmir's future allegiance, have reached their first critical point, but are going more or less "according to plan."

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Jacqueline Pung, 29-year-old Honolulu department store clerk, and 21-year-old Shirley McFedters of Long Beach, Calif., gained the final of the Women's United States amateur golf championship at the Waverley Country Club today.

If the average youngster seems sometimes maddeningly resistant to his parents' efforts to mold him somewhat nearer an adult's heart's desire, it's not because he doesn't realize pretty well what his parents want of him. This is revealed in a study involving almost a thousand Minnesota school children, aged 6 to 14.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) -- A group of Pennsylvania State College faculty members and residents have decided today to "try to find the facts" behind the dismissal of Wendell Scott MacRae, the college's publication production manager.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic nominee for Vice President, accepted here today the Vice Presidential nomination of the Liberal party, described by its leaders as the "New Deal party of New York State." Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had earlier accepted Liberal party nomination.

Miss Patricia Ward, 19-year-old vice inquiry witness who has been the subject of a three-day legal dispute, was paroled yesterday in the custody of her mother. At the prosecutor's request, however, Miss Ward will remain under twenty-four-hour police guard.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- A good week on the Stock Exchange ended today with British Government securities and industrial shares wavering slightly under week-end profit taking but with the underlying firmness of markets unimpaired. During the week undated and long term gilt-edge issues have risen a further two pounds sterling ($5.60) or so and most industrial leaders have gained about 2 1/2 per cent.

The long Labor Day week-end is at hand, and to many it represents the last week-end of summer. All over the country people will be getting into automobiles and heading for some favorite vacation spot. The highways, coming and going, will be choked. People will become impatient, will cut corners, take chances and run foolish risks.

Jim Busby, a .206 hitter, looped a two-run homer in the ninth inning to give Walt Masterson and the Senators a 3-2 victory over Vic Raschi and the Yankees last night at the Stadium. The visitors had tied the score in the eighth when Gil Coan, sporting a .212 average, hammered a round-trip-per.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 29 -- The International Printing Pressmen voted today in favor of a reduction in their thirty-seven-hour work week and an increase in wages, both changes unspecified.

The area bounded by Amsterdam Avenue, Central Park West, West 100th Street and West Ninety-seventh Street was sold yesterday by the city at public auction to a private construction group for development as a middle-income housing development under Title I of the National Housing Act of 1949.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP ) -- The Defense Department identified today 223 casualties of the Korean war, including 36 killed, 175 wounded, 2 injured in accidents and 10 missing. The following were from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:
The lack of nurses has become a national crisis. This has come about as the result of several factors.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Aug. 29 -- German industrialists expect to begin relatively soon the manufacture of light arms and other military equipment for the forces of the Atlantic alliance with the full approval of the United States and British Governments.

The Hilton Marwell Company, a food packaging concern, has purchased the four-story mill-type building at 580 Grove Street in Jersey City, N. J., from N. Davel, Inc. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Gerdes Montgomery for the seller and I. Klein for the buyer.

The program for the next several months of the Office of Price Stabilization stresses six major steps, which must be considered in relation to the suspension just announced of price controls in "soft market" areas on goods that are selling below ceiling levels, according to James G. Lyons, regional director.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 29 -- The American Federation of Labor's United Automobile Workers Union charged today that "a smear campaign" by leaders of the United Automobile Workers Union, C. I. O., in New York had prompted the investigation by an A. F. L. executive council committee into alleged labor racketeering in the A. F. L. union.
Three patrolmen won the personal congratulations of Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan in Police Headquarters yesterday morning for police action last week-end.
VANCOUVER, B. C., 29 (AP) -- Billy Campbell and Larry Bouchey fought off a couple of serious challengers today to win their thirty-six-hole semi-final matches in the Canadian amateur golf tournament.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Norwalk, Conn., scored two runs in the sixth and last inning of the Little League world series final today to edge Monongahela, Pa., 4 -- 3. A crowd of 8,400 jammed the original Little League stadium to see Norwalk gain a second straight title for Connecticut.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Nottinghamshire cricketers, stopped since June 27 when they last won a championship tournament match, gained their second success of the season today, beating Gloucestershire by 130 runs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Wheat buying support broadened today on the evidence that export business is expanding, cash interests taking considerable wheat out of the pit in removing hedges. Principal sales for export were four cargoes of hard winter wheat to Italy, but there was also a sale of 16,000 tons of red winter wheat to Spain.

An industry-wide agreement between 5,000 employers and the teamsters union representing 35,000 employes in the general trucking industry was announced yesterday. It provides for wage increases of 15 and 23 cents an hour and for elimination of wage differentials.
