Farish A. Jenkins has sold his waterfront property at 560 Davenport Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y., comprising four acres and a dwelling with twelve rooms and five baths, to Vahe J. Tinghir, consulting engineer with Corbett, Tinghir Co. The Thomas P. Sutton Corporation was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Federal control of civilian goods output may be ended next year, Henry H. Fowler, head of both the Defense Production Administration and the National Production Authority, said today.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- Private detectives disguised as orderlies and kitchen attendants have been working at Boston City Hospital for months, trying to halt a series of thefts ranging from milk and copper plumbing to microscopes and furniture.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- Two thousand persons attending the sixth annual convention of the Air Force Association were assured by Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg today that, while the Air Force "as now devised, lacks depth in reserve strengths," it is not a shoe-string Air Force and its composition is based on "a painstaking analysis of modern war."

A Coast Guard Board of Inquiry met yesterday at 80 Lafayette Street to begin hearings on the sinking of the American Liberty ship Western Farmer, lost after breaking in two in a collision with the Norwegian tanker Bjorgholm in the Strait of Dover on Aug. 21.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 29 -- The Supreme Court of Cape Province unanimously declared unconstitutional today the setting up of the High Court of Parliament by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Fredna Pavlich was legally disarmed in her private war against the Southern Pacific Railroad today when a Superior Court judge issued a permanent injunction to keep her from throwing rocks at railroad workmen.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- William A. Purtell of West Hartford, former president of the Connecticut Manufacturers Association, was appointed today by Gov. John Lodge as United States Senator for four months to fill the interim unexpired term of the late Senator Brien McMahon, a Democrat.

Estimated net profit of the Bathurst Power and Paper Company, Ltd., for the six months ended June 30 amounted to $1,028,383, equal to 86 cents a class B share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $1,518,313 or $2.21 a share for the corresponding six months a year earlier.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29 -- Two United States-sponsored information programs, designed to give the Argentine public straight-forward news and a knowledge of United States cultural life, have been forced off the Argentine radio networks.

The United States reached what might be called a draw in its case against France over the rights of American nationals in Morocco. The World Court partly upheld the validity of a treaty between President Andrew Jackson and the Sultan of Morocco that goes back to 1836.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 26, to 111.9 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products declined 1.2 per cent as lower prices were reported for fresh fruits and vegetables, livestock, raw cotton and wheat. Increases in some fresh fruits and vegetables, eggs, corn, oats and calves were not sufficient to offset these declines.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, was quoted yesterday by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chairman of his campaign advisory committee, as favoring a curb on Senate filibusters, which have been used in the past to block Congressional action on civil rights legislation.

Mayor Impellitteri appointed yesterday a three-man committee to negotiate with the Consolidated Edison Company of New York for a new contract for supplying power to city subway lines. The present agreement expires Sept. 30.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Discussions on the joint United States-British effort to get a settlement of the oil dispute between Britain and Iran continued today between representatives of the Washington and London Governments.
The Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., said yesterday it had broken the back of organized resistance to its unionizing drive.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Aug. 29 -- A large and heavily laden tractor-trailer tore into two similar vehicles here today and brushed a passenger automobile. But, though gasoline-fed flames shot high above Route 25 and heated a cargo of canned tomatoes and beans so that they exploded and shot into the air, nobody was injured.

We cannot allow the present stalemate in Korea to continue -- our best forces are tied down there and bled white, fighting an impossible fight for the liberty of 500,000,000 Chinese and Koreans, while leaving our own country ill protected. As General Van Fleet recently said repeatedly, our Asian friends should be permitted to "build and use" their own armies in their fight for peace and freedom, specifically mentioning the Nationalist Chinese on Formosa.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 29 -- Communists put on a virtual religious revival meeting today with Moslem Mullah Ayatollah Khorasani deploring the National Front Workers party's declared intention to crack open Communists' heads if the Tudeh (Communists) came near the graves of the "martyrs" of the riots of July 21.

A group of business men and educators, visiting this country to study its economic ways, was told yesterday by an official of Remington Rand, Inc., that an important key to the productivity and prosperity of the United States was deep respect for the dignity of the human being.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 29 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, declared today that he did not know "whether it is still possible to prevent World War III."

Scott Radio Laboratories, Inc., will increase list prices on many of its television receivers 10 to 15 per cent, John S. Meck, president, disclosed yesterday. The action follows decontrol of television receivers and many other home furnishings prices by the Office of Price Stabilization on Thursday.

Your first-page Washington item on the American family going $400 into "the red" in 1950 fits in with an article in a current Washington weekly. The latter shows that the average American factory worker, white-collar employe and professional man went even further into "trouble" in 1951 than the year before.
The Interstate Sanitation Commission authorized yesterday an order for a six-year program in Westchester County to improve four sewage-treatment plants and bring them up to commission standards.

It's harvest time in the Bronx and a hundred farmers are bringing in the sheaves -- and the tomatoes and the corn and assorted garden vegetables. Montefiore Hospital's "tenant farmers" -- neighbors who have for ten years worked the half-block graden spot next to the hospital on Gun Hill Road -- report that the crops are running a little undersize this year. Like typical farmers, they blame the weather.

A Park Department contractor's saw accomplished yesterday without ceremony what British troops had done five times between 1766 and 1775 -- brought down the Liberty Pole in City Hall Park, just west of the building.
ALBANY, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Fred J. Munder of Huntington, L. I., as Suffolk County judge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- President Truman probably will set the pattern for whatever "whistle-stop" speaking he will do in this campaign during his train trip to and from Milwaukee next week. During the trip, which begins early Monday and ends Tuesday night, the President probably will make at least eight speeches, including the major Labor Day address in Milwaukee at 10:30 P. M., Eastern daylight time.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The United Nations General Assembly was asked today to consider making an appeal to the Western powers and the Soviet Union to agree quickly on a treaty restoring full sovereignty to Austria.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Stolen postal money orders, worth as much as a quarter of a million dollars if they had been cashed at top value, were recovered here today because two young men went broke at Reno's gambling tables.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- About 4,000,000 young Americans will be able to vote for the first time in November, not counting those in the armed forces.

A NEW type of photographic instruction book that enables the beginner to teach himself photography with almost the equivalent of classroom instruction will be published on Sept. 9. The book is "How to Develop, Print and Enlarge Your Own Pictures" (New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company, Inc. $3.75), the collaborative effort of Jack O. Flynn, a photographer, and Albert J. Rosenberg and Alan Kellock, McGraw-Hill specialists in preparing filmstrips for teaching purposes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The most vital, in a global sense, of all the world's natural resources is oil, which has lubricated the march of twentieth-century science and civilization throughout the world.

The price of men's clothing next spring will be virtually unchanged from present levels, manufacturers said last week. While some items may rise slightly, others will ease a bit to keep the over-all picture about the same.

Undaunted by the presence of Yankee greats of a half century, Casey Stengel's Bombers of the present brought about a fitting climax to Old Timers Day at the Stadium yesterday as they up and swatted the Senators, 6 to 4, to the roar of 41,558. The victory increased the Yanks' league lead over the second-place Indians to two games.

Borough President James A. Lundy has asked the city administration for $65,000 to buy equipment and materials to expand his physical check-ups on Queens sewer construction. In the meantime, his office will scrutinize every sewer contract let during the preceding borough regimes in 1950 and 1951.

IN the mid-Nineteen Forties this latest play of Eugene O'Neill's was tried out on the road by the Theatre Guild but never brought to New York. "Casting difficulties" were spoken of, which is generally a theatrical euphemism for loss of interest in a property.

Two craters on the moon have been named "Messier" and "W. H. Pickering," after distinguished astronomers. H. H. Ninninger in Sky and Telescope presents evidence which leads him to conclude that some projectile passed through a mountainous ridge on the opposite sides of which the two so-called centers lie.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 -- John Timken's yawl Kitty Hawk, largest one in the fleet, rounded Vineyard Lightship this afternoon first of the craft in the Stamford Yacht Club's race of 234 nautical miles out around that beacon and back.

SAN FRANCISCO -- When my husband and I set out to drive from Boston to the Pacific Coast only a few weeks after our arrival on holiday in the United States from our home in the British West Indies, we faced this transcontinental jaunt with some trepidation.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Charges that the large tin-mining companies had given the Government's opponents more than $750,000 to back this week's alleged "terrorist plot" were published today by the Director General of the Police, Maj. Victor Valdes.

One of two fleeing men was shot and killed and the other captured by a transit policeman early yesterday morning after the pair had allegedly mugged another man on the steps of the Fourteenth Street station of the IND subway at Eighth Avenue.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- A huge British four jet, delta-winged bomber made its maiden flight today. It flew for thirty-six minutes over the Woodford Cheshire airfield of its makers, A. V. Roe Co.

There are blushes in Madison Avenue. The big rough men of the advertising profession are learning that the third oldest agency in the youngest profession is not among them. It is in Sweden. Furthermore, it was founded and brought to eminence by a woman.

Eight working men and women have won $2,500 scholarships granted annually by the evening division of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science, it was announced yesterday by Dean Thomas Clark Pollock.

ONE of the interesting and perhaps significant developments in the Presidential campaign is the fact that business at long last is getting the ear of both candidates. Spokesmen for important business groups, including the American Retail Federation and the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, have already met with or plan to meet Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 30 -- Die Transvaler official Nationalist party newspaper at Johannesburg, called today for abolition of the present South African Constitution and proclamation of a republic as the quickest and best way to end the country's bitter constitutional crisis.

HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Steve Hromjak of Cleveland, fast-pedaling United States Army sergeant and 1952 Olympian, gained a 3-point lead for the senior men's title at the halfway mark of the two-day national amateur bicycle racing championships.

More important, by far, than any other month of the speed boat season, September with its virtually five racing week-ends, counting the Labor Day Silver Cup fixture at Detroit tomorrow, is having a crescendo of top bracket events.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn, leading with a score of 6 -- 1 in the annual title tournament of the New York State Chess Association, encountered the defending champion, James T. Sherwin of Columbia University, in the eighth round today.

Few buyers were in the wholesale market here last week but the firming of some of the lines brought many reorders and confirmations of pending orders, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Many buyers are expected after Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Capitol police picked up for questioning today three youths and said they admitted "trying a key" in the locked door to the office of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Educators won a notable victory last April when the Federal Communications Commission set aside for non-commercial educational use 242 of a projected total of 2,000-odd television channels. However, they must act fast now to follow up their advantage. Unless the educators show substantial progress toward utilization of the facilities by next June 3, the F. C. C. may make the channels available to commercial applicants.

In southern New Jersey is a 10,000-acre vegetable farm -- largest in the world. Seabrook Farms is its name. If the farm is singled out here it is not because it is so large but because it is scientifically managed. One of its buildings has a sign that reads "Climatology Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University."

SINGAPORE "society," long famous for its conventionality and formality, was rudely shaken not long ago by what one wag described as shirtsleeve diplomacy. Malcolm MacDonald, Britain's friendly and informal Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, appeared at a public concert in this tropical city's sultry Victoria Hall dressed handsomely and comfortably in black dinner trousers, a black cummerbund, white dress shirt and black tie, but no dinner jacket.

HARTFORD -- A little more than a year ago, John Shepard Jr., a wealthy young tobacco grower who lives in South Windsor, a town some ten miles northeast of this city, became concerned over the gradually decreasing use of cigars by American and foreign smokers.

THE old saying that "Rhineland is wineland" is something for us wine-loving Americans to remember. For in our enthusiasm for the French vine and its products we often forget that Germany makes white wines that are, some experts claim, the greatest white wines in the world.

Germans and Japanese will for the first time confer on equal terms with other delegates to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development when its seventh annual meeting gets under way in Mexico City, Tuesday. Fifty-three countries will be represented at the meeting, which will be under the chairmanship of Horacio Lafer, Finance Minister of Brazil and chairman of the bank's board of governors.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Jones Beach State Park will remain open during the fall and winter, although a number of its summer activities will close soon after Labor Day, the Long Island State Park Commission announced today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- A general party discussion of the new Five-Year Plan and proposed changes in the Communist party statutes preparatory to the nineteenth party congress Oct. 5 has been instituted by lower party organizations, the newspaper Pravda reported today.

A survey of port facilities here and methods of achieving full utilization of them by co-cordinating various transportation interests were recommended last week by the Transportation Group of New York, an association of men in shipping, air transport, railroading and allied transport fields.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 30 -- The names of eighteen outstanding secondary school graduates selected to share $16,700 in Princeton University regional scholarships in the next academic year were announced today by Minor C. Morgan, secretary of the university committee on scholarships.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- The exchange of correspondence this week between the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, and the Federation of Japanese Bar Associations brought out in public a trend that is new here since the San Francisco peace treaty -- a trend that appears to indicate a growing anti-foreigner feeling in Japan.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, suggested tonight that the Communists might be about to try medium bombing tactics for the first time in Korea. He said this could change the whole character of the Korean air war.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, today received confidential reports from the Central Intelligence Agency on the international situation. These were the first to reach him since he was briefed in Washington almost three weeks ago at a meeting with President Truman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce charged tonight that some Republican party leaders in Connecticut were "making a desperate try to steal" the party's nomination for United States Senator for Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich, banking partner in New York of Averell Harriman and Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense.

This is entitled "The Return of the Native, or Kiss the Foreign Troops Good-by." Although it has less realism than "Snow White" it is always capable of exciting interest and yearning.

About a fortnight ago the newspapers published accounts of a case of icthyosiform erythrodermia which was cured by hypnosis and which is called in plain language "fishskin disease." There are about twenty forms. In all the skin is dry, rough and scaly. The particular case that excited the press recently is described by Dr. A. A. Mason in the British Medical Journal, which comments on it editorially.

IT is amusing to speculate on how Rudyard Kipling would have liked the pictures in this new edition of his "Just So Stories," done by Nicolas (Mordvinoff), illustrator of "The Two Reds" and the 1951 Caldecott Award winner "Finders Keepers."

With the four-week meeting at Saratoga Springs having been completed yesterday, the running horses return to Long Island tomorrow to start on the last third of New York's 197-day racing campaign. Aqueduct, base of the Queens County Jockey Club, is the spot where the horses -- and the horse-players -- will be operating for the next two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Elections held by the National Labor Relations Board are bringing out a heavy vote, but unions are losing more than 32 per cent of the representation tests. The rate of union losses has grown in the last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- State taxes netted the state governments a record $9,838,000,000 last year, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 25 -- Fifty farm families around Hoogeveen, in the northeastern part of the Netherlands, are in the process of picking up their roots and moving to found a new community in Brazil. The way this project was organized points up some of the main elements of Western Europe's emigration problem.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 -- West Coast shipping interests scored what they considered a significant point this week in marshalling sentiment against freight rate practices regarded as unduly favoring the railroads.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- After simmering in the cauldrons of litigation and legislation for fourteen years, the fight between the states and the Federal Government ever which owns and controls the lands under our marginal coastal waters has now boiled over in the heat of the 1952 political campaign.

IN connection with the recent item in "In and Out of Books" of New Directions' project for presenting authors recording their own works, I would like to point out that the American Foundation for the Blind in the normal course of producing Talking Books has been recording famous authors for eighteen years.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- Legislation enabling James M. Curley, Mayor of Boston four times, to draw a pension of $12,000 a year from the city was passed in the closing days of the Massachusetts legislative session, it became known today.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 30 -- Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner and Commander in Chief in Malaya, continued today his program of tough new measures in the Malayan anti-Communist campaign by ordering a new kind of security cordon around a city of 36,000 inhabitants.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP) -- An F-89 twin-jet Scorpion lost a wing above 51,000 spectators at the International Aviation Exposition today and crashed near the grandstand, killing its pilot, a Korean war jet ace, and his radar observer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The United Mine Workers Union, which is unaffiliated, gave its endorsement today to thirty-three Democrats and thirteen Republicans seeking re-election to the House of Representatives from coal mining districts, and to nine Democrats and one Republican for the Senate.

Certainly it is true that corruption can be remedied only by the substitution of ethical for material and social for selfish objectives in the life of each individual.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 30 -- The port city of Charleston caught the full force of the season's first tropical hurricane as it raged along the South Carolina coast tonight, causing at least one death.

THE late Dixon Wecter, had he lived to finish the job, would undoubtedly have produced the definitive biography of Mark Twain. The present fragment, which takes the humorist only to the age of 18, renders obsolete all previous accounts of his formative years.

" Thoughts As We Turn Away from Chicago," by R. L. Duffus (July 27) was excellent. I think most of us who listened and watched the convention hubbub were becoming a bit cynical about U. S. politics and politicians and how they operate.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The script in the forty-eighth running of the Hopeful Stakes at Saratoga today called for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's unbeaten Native Dancer, with a 1-to-4 tote board listing, to win for the sixth time, collect $51,450 of the gross of $62,650 and run his earnings past the $100,000 mark.
Outgoing Labor Day week-end traffic appeared to have passed its peak by noon yesterday. By evening the flow of cars out of New York was no heavier than on any quiet Saturday.

SIX United States documentary tax stamps, added to the current series of these revenue items, introduce in their design a portrait of Lyman Judson Gage, who was President McKinley's Secretary of the Treasury in 1897-1901 and continued to hold the portfolio under Theodore Roosevelt into 1902, after McKinley's assassination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accused President Truman today of planning a Labor Day speech in Milwaukee as an occasion to campaign against him. The charge was leveled by the Wisconsin Republican, one of the Administration's sharpest critics, in a statement released by his aides here.

IN Korea a few years ago Elwin Meader was served a dish of raspberries by a family with whom he was dining. Having tasted a few, he pocketed the remainder and brought them back to Durham, N. H. Korean raspberry bushes and several generations of hybrids are now growing and bearing fruit on the Horticultural Farm of the University of New Hampshire, where Mr. Meader is carrying on experiments in plant breeding.

YONKERS, Aug. 30 -- Traffic was tied up for an hour in Getty Square as a crowd of mourners and curious persons, estimated to number 5,000, gathered this morning for the funeral of John Acropolis, slain labor leader.
Signs of the fall fund drive of the New York Association for the Blind are beginning to crop up in the city.

Repeatedly during the past week the spotlight has swung to one aspect or another of our national defense and its problems. The American Legion Convention was a focal point, but there were other occasions as well. It was a time in which a varied group of official and unofficial leaders felt obliged to speak about how we are to equip ourselves to be and to remain free.

A CAMERA that fits in the palm of the hand, weighs less than twelve ounces and is designed for the beginner who has no photographic knowledge, was introduced here last week by Bolsey Corporation of America. The camera is the Bolsey Model A and costs $39.75 equipped with 44mm f/4.5 coated lens.

WHEN intelligence arrived that a certain region of the Bronx was stirring because its inhabitants considered the name of their newly established telephone exchange -- TUlip -- a sissy one, the time seemed ripe to learn how and why New York exchanges are christened.

The Young Communist League of the Soviet Union is experiencing the most rapid membership increase in its history, Komsomolskaya Pravda, its official organ, has revealed. In one month recently the league added 1,000,000 members. Since last January, the total increase has exceeded 2,000,000 youths between 15 and 26 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The White House and State Department learned with disappointment late today of Premier Mossadegh's summary rejection of the proposals put forward by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill to solve the oil dispute in Iran, which has lasted for more than a year.

FROM a theatre stage with its three walls and an invisible fourth, to a Hollywood stage as vast as a warehouse with no boundaries at all, is not, as one might think, just an aeroplane trip away. It is a heady journey during which the entire storehouse of one's theatre craft has to be re-examined.

THE tried-and-true ingredients of today's love stories are not missing in this novel by Louise Eskrigge Crump. The setting is the lush Mississippi Delta country at the turn of the century. The heroine is young, pretty, rebellious, and she is fighting against odds.

The goldenrod is early September's flower, the golden spray that lines fence rows and meadows, yellow as the late summer sun itself. Even its foliage is dusty green, late summer green, rather than the pristine green of June when the leaf-world was new and shining; and its flowers are autumn-generous, fulfillment in multiple, as becomes the season.

TIME continuing its inevitable march, take note this morning of some figures concerning a musical named "South Pacific." For on Tuesday the fabulous brain child of the Messrs. Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Joshua Logan will be giving its 1,400th performance at the Majestic.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- A truce of uncertain duration between Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., and the dissident leaders of Ford Local 600 was foreshadowed here this week.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Phillies swept a double-header from the Braves tonight, winning the first game, 4 -- 2, and beating the clock and five pitchers, 8 -- 6, in the finale.

RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 30 -- The economic mission from the West German Government that had been negotiating for a new commercial arrangement with Brazil left for home today without concluding an agreement, but Brazilian sources say a satisfactory settlement has been reached. No details have been released.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- John L. Lewis, United Mine Workers' president, today put out a Labor Day message telling other labor organizations they all had better unite or eventually they would be destroyed. It was the latest move by Mr. Lewis to persuade trade unions to unite in order to accomplish their joint aims.

Nowadays all the young people go out for their own amusement to shows, dances, clubs, etc. It was quite different years ago if you were brought up in a Scotch-Presbyterian household. All the going-out we did was on Monday night to the "Band of Hope," and the boys to the Boys' Brigade, all dressed up in their white belts and hats.

IT is a standing joke in the Middle West that every Corn Belt college president hopes to retire after long and constructive service to write a life of Lincoln. As a matter of fact very few retired college presidents write such biographies, but the supply of new Lincoln books does seem endless.

In his stimulating article, "The Air Around Us" (Aug. 10) Waldemar Kaempffert says: "Besides these three zones there is a fourth important layer -- a thin ozone strip in the stratosphere at a height of twenty-five to forty miles.

BERLIN, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- Last night was marked by a spate of new protests growing out of the increased East-West friction in Berlin. Three Soviet communications were reported last night by A. D. N., official East German news agency, and Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commandant in Berlin made one representation to the Russians.

The city's department stores failed to benefit materially from the American Legion convention visitors, although there was additional store traffic. Trade observers estimated volume at even to about 5 per cent under the 1951 week.

THE mood in the South since the Second World War, and even before to some extent, has been one of disenchantment with the national Democratic party of its ancient loyalties. Party affiliations are deeply held there, nearly as deeply as religious convictions, and this slow estrangement has been one of the most curious movements of our time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration today outlined the six steps a veteran must follow to obtain a G.I. loan for a home, farm or business.
CASCAIS, Portugal, Aug. 30 -- The Portuguese yacht, Faneca, today won the fourth of the five races for the world Star Class sailing championship in a close finish with the Italian boat, Elettra.

A YOUNG French economist, Etienne Mantoux, who died in World War II, wrote a spirited rejoinder to John Maynard Keynes' murderous assault on the Versailles settlement, "The Economic Consequences of the Peace." Mantoux's book now appears for the first time in the United States.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 30 -- With fingers crossed against another crippling steamship strike or similar labor difficulties, Alaskans are looking forward next season to what is expected to be their greatest building boom.

Eight courses in horticulture, botany and nature study will be offered, beginning next month, at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. The subjects will range from flower arranging to home landscaping.

The Department of Parks will close seventeen outdoor swimming pools at the end of business tomorrow. Twelve will be reopened Sept. 8 as play centers, with facilities for paddle tennis, shuffleboard, basketball, table tennis and group games.

In a smoke-filled hotel room on the West Side yesterday four men huddled intently over a card table, penciling away at sheets of paper covered with strange grids, cabalistic symbols and puzzling groups of letters.
Dorothy Barclay, Parent and Child editor, is on vacation. Mr. D'Amico, today's guest columnist, is director of the Department of Education and the People's Art Center of the Museum of Modern Art.

SINCE their conclusion is that socialism's influence upon American life is currently negligible, these two large volumes must be regarded as a post-mortem report. Of utopian socialism, whether secular or religious, the contributors find scarcely a trace today, and Daniel Bell, who learnedly discusses Marxian socialism, emphasizes the recent decline of all the Marxist parties, Communist, Socialist and splinter.

CREATING a garden of American vegetables in a strange country is an exciting though sometimes rather baffling experience. On the other hand, it is the easiest way I know to acquire a wholly undeserved reputation locally for being a good gardener.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh rejected tonight a joint proposal by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill for settlement of the Iranian oil problem, presented this afternoon by United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson and British Charge d'Affaires George Middleton, but he summoned Parliament to discuss it.

LONDON RECORDS has earned the thanks of Debussy lovers with its newly issued recording of Pelleas et Melisande, made by a distinguished cast of soloists with the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, under the direction of Ernest Ansermet.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Cardinals snapped their six-game losing streak by unleashing their heavy artillery tonight to score a 12-2 victory over the last-place Pirates.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Richland, Inc., the operator of radio station WMAN in Mansfield, Ohio, has sued The Mansfield News-Journal for $1,282,749 on charges of civil monopoly.
SUMMER holidays seem to be over so far as the garden clubs are concerned. Flower shows are the order of the month for September, with vegetables and fruits given their share of attention.

A STUDY of the message for our time to be found in Kierkegaard, Dostoevsky, Nietzsche and Kafka, this small book has a depth of insight and a comprehensiveness of treatment considerably beyond what its modesty of tone and size indicates.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 30 -- India's concern wick the conduct and intentions of her northern neighbor, Communist China, has been sharpened by the announcement of forthcoming discussions in Peiping between officials of the Mao Tse-tung Government and delegations from Tibet.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- This nation of shopkeepers had a big smile on its face this week and was rubbing its hands in anticipation of a good spell of new business.

TWO projects for the "House of Tomorrow" are now on view at the Museum of Modern Art -- one of them a brilliantly engineered bubble which may well predict the shape of things to come, the other a strange sculptural conception which can best be described as "a womb with a view." The first is Buckminster Fuller's Geodesic Dome House, the other Frederick Kiesler's Endless House.

PRETTY soon now the foliage of the hackberry tree will turn a soft yellow. Then the green fruits will ripen to a dark purple, to remain on the branches all winter long. These off-season characteristics are only two of the reasons for planting hackberry on the home grounds.

SIDNEY BECHET, who can probably be elected Mayor of Antibes by acclamation any time he chooses to run, is, of course, along with Louis Armstrong, one of the truly stupendous personalities in the world of jazz; and Muggsy Spanier, during those brief years when he was at his peak, was one of that world's fines cornetists.

They rolled back the years to the dawn of the century at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees observed their golden anniversary Old Timers Day. The crowd of 41,558 seemed mightily pleased to see Joe DiMaggio once again in uniform along with other stars of recent vintage, all of them still lively enough to take part in a spirited two-inning ball game.
SPRINGFIELD Ill., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address recorded by Governor Stevenson for broadcast in September to the men and women in the armed forces overseas: ...

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Duane Pillette pitched a two-hit victory as the Browns defeated the Tigers tonight, 2 to 1. Clint Courtney, with a double in the fourth inning and another two-bagger in the eighth, drove in both St. Louis runs.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Pointing out that Florida's highways have not kept pace with the tremendous increase in tourist traffic, the New York engineering firm of Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Hall Macdonald has approved the feasibility of construction and operation of a 350-mile limited access turnpike from Jacksonville to Miami with a westward branch of 128 miles to Clearwater.

Few developments occurred in the final week of August to change the prevailing lethargy in financial markets. True, there were several optimistic views expressed by Government officials about the nation's economy, but they failed to have any stimulating effect.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Government today handed the public its first atomic-age blueprint -- a design for building a home, office or factory to withstand the blast of an atomic explosion.

SO far as teen-age girls are concerned, Sue Barton is the most famous nurse, next to Florence Nightingale. They have loyally followed her fictional career ever since her first experiences as student nurse, and marriage and motherhood have, apparently, only enhanced her appeal.

Although the Dodgers collected ten hits against Sal Maglie last night at Ebbets Field the one they needed most did not materialize and the Giants scored a 4-3 victory over the Brooks. Maglie, rapped hard in the early rounds, finished strongly and gained his fifth triumph of the season over the league-leaders.

SINCE nothing of much immediate consequence has been going on in the Broadway theatre for three months, the vicissitudes of "Wish You Were Here" have been exhaustively publicized. During the three weeks of previews before the official opening on June 25, every move and decision Joshua Logan made in the staging was instantly telegraphed around the country, along with General Eisenhower's political thoughts at the moment and Governor Stevenson's appealing entreaties for a little privacy.

THE most colorful crop in the early fall garden, and perhaps the most rewarding for display, is the ornamental gourds that hang among the rich foliage of their vines. The pleasure in harvesting them can be made long lasting if a few simple rules for processing the crop are followed.

Exhibitors, officials and spectators who still are uncertain whether they prefer the benched or un-benched show will have chances to decide today and tomorrow as important all-breed events of both types are scheduled at near-by points.

Darwin was convinced that man was the descendant of an Old World anthropoid. But between these anthropoids and man yawned a wide gap. When Pithecanthropus erectus, the ape-man, was discovered in Java, in 1891, the anthropologists heaved a sigh of relief; for this was surely the "missing link."

MECCA, Ind. -- This is not the important Mecca right now. The important one is in Saudi Arabia, and Moslems from all over the world are pouring into it this week in the great annual pilgrimage of their faith. But no non-Moslem is permitted to join them in the holy city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A House of Representatives committee today charged widspread irregularities, including bribery and favoritism, in the administration of the huge veterans' housing program.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Fifty women knitters are digging out forgotten oddments of yarn and turning them into colorful mittens, sweaters, socks and scarves for Korean war orphans as the result of an appeal by Mr. and Mrs. William Sneidre, proprietors of a local yarn shop.

Russia clinched the team championship of the International Chess Federation yesterday after defeating Sweden by 2 1/2 -- 1/2 in the ninth and final round at Helsinki, according to a report from Finland. With one game adjourned, the additional points gave Russia a total of 20 1/3 --10 1/2.

The College All-Stars will meet the New York Knickerbockers in the second half of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, Oct. 25. The Rochester Royals, Western Division champions of the National Basketball Association, and the Boston Celtics will be foes in the opener.

For years after the 1917 Communist upheaval in Russia we were fed by the so-called "experts" on a diet of non-survival of that regime. On Page 2 of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 14, 1920, we find a Washington dispatch quoting the American Ambassador to Russia, the late Mr. Francis, that within "six months" the Bolshevist Government would be a thing of the past.

THE reaction of eastern wildfowlers to the 1952 waterfowl regulations is, as expected, that of an individual who is "grateful for small favors." Despite the reported abundance of waterfowl, the average shooter hoped for but did not expect a corresponding increase in bag limits.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 30 -- A sudden line squall which hit Bellport Bay at 4:26 P. M. today raised general havoc with the 140 assorted sailing craft assembled here for the annual Labor Day week-end regatta. The squall blew in from the east, hitting with force of from 35 to 40 miles per hour and caused ten craft to turn over and split sails on at least a score more.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Three horses just shipped from New York monopolized the spotlight in the sixth running of the $17,350 Mermaid Handicap today and they did it in a convincing fashion. First under the wire was J. C. Brady's Landmark who beat the Companas Stable's Versify by threee-quarters of a length. In the third spot was John H. Clark's Quiz Song a neck behind the runner-up.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- The second Berlin Cultural Festival, the primary effort of the Western powers to display their artistic vitality, will open here tomorrow with a lavish program of operas, ballet, stage shows and exhibitions that will last throughout September.

Concerning Martin Van Buren, whom Mary B. Aker in "Mr. Precedent" (Aug. 17) named as the first President to be born under the American flag: Van Buren was also the first member of an ethnic minority to be honored with the Presidency.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. L, Aug. 30 -- Residents of Nassau County who complain of low-flying aircraft over their homes were advised today that in a majority of cases the offending planes did not belong to the Air Force and were not based on this field.

" TALKING of constitutional melancholy," he observed, "A man so afflicted, Sir, must divert distressing thoughts, and not combat with them." Boswell "May not we think them down, Sir?" Johnson. "No, Sir. To attempt to think them down is madness.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Speed boat daredevils who usually meet head-on with wild and rugged racing conditions and raging, rough Detroit River seas found ideal water this afternoon in front of the Detroit Yacht Club in the curtain-raiser of a three-day regatta that will culminate Monday in the Silver Cup feature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Displaced Persons Commission reluctantly brought to an end today one of the strangest migrations in history. It qquietly closed America's door on thousands of victims of Nazi and Russian oppression who had hoped to find asylum in this country.
Social Security will have greater meaning for many persons tomorrow. Their old age and survivor insurance benefits will be increased.

Regarding Edward A. Mosien's article, "It's Armor Again" (Aug. 3), "bulletproof" vests were on display in shop windows in Folkstone, England, in 1918, but I don't know of a single purchase of one by American foot soldiers who saw them because they were already overburdened with equipment which they had to carry on their backs.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Bonds and money amounting to $200,000 were put up in Federal Court today as bail pending appeal for ten of the fourteen Communist leaders convicted of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

A DRAMATIC first novel, "The Gathering Darkness," begins in 1929, with recognition details like Hupmobiles, speak-easies and the game of Monopoly, and ends in the midst of World War II. Like a good many other fantasy-minded families, the McPeeks were in the bull market far beyond the limits of prudence.

ALTHOUGH it is as obvious a bad simile, love not only makes the world go 'round but it also is the inspiration and basic ingredient of more movies than a harried viewer would care to criticize. And, in the recent past at least two major productions were unveiled which not only utilized that ingredient but also illustrated Goethe's sweeping observation that "we are shaped and fashioned by what we love."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A demand that Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark resign immediately as a result of disclosures made this week before a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice, was made today by Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa.

A wildcat bus strike by 120 drivers for the Bee Line, Inc., continued yesterday to halt service between Freeport and Wantagh, L. I., and Jones Beach, but had little effect on the size of the crowd at the beach.

RECENT additions to the title lists of 16 millimeter distributors serving the constantly increasing needs of non-theatrical audiences range in scope from a praise-laden film biography of that artistic giant of the Italian Renaissance, Michelangelo, to an incisive analysis of United States foreign policy.

The Supreme Court of Cape Province in South Africa has again struck a blow for good government and against the short-sighted extremism of Prime Minister Malan and his Nationalist regime. It has held that the Government action that set up the Parliament as the supreme court is unconstitutional.

So heavy was the rate of vivax infection -- the type of malaria that relapses -- during the summer and fall of 1950 in Korea that thousands of United States veterans were hospitalized in this country late in 1951 after they had returned on rotation and had discontinued use of chloroquine, otherwise known as "aralen."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: This is a good time to take stock of the flower garden, making note of failures as a guide for next year's planting. Substitutes, either another variety or flowers, should be found for annuals that have been slow to flower, a poor height or subject to disease. The basis for adding perennials should be the filling in of any slack periods of bloom.
A survey yesterday by The Associated Press of ten universities famous for their football teams showed that the expectations generally are for increased attendance this year.

TRENTON, Sunday, Aug. 31 -- Efforts to head off a strike of truck drivers continued early today as mid-Jersey trucking associations and Local 469 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., went into their tenth hour of talks about a new contract with state and Federal mediators.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Fulvous, a daughter of Dixiana's famous Spy Song, today charged to a half-length victory in the $70,725 Princess Pat Stakes at Washington Park, setting a new record for the event.

The American Association of Rehabilitation Therapists will hold its third annual clinical conference Tuesday through Friday at the Statler Hotel. At the dinner Thursday night Dr. George G. Deaver, medical director of children's service, New York University-Bellevue Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, will speak.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A heavy rainstorm tonight washed out the game between the Red Sox and the Athletics in the bottom half of the fourth inning with the Red Sox ahead, 6 -- 0.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 30 -- As the city waited in darkness tonight for the hurricane to strike, high winds whistled through the deserted streets. Huge waves piled up over the shore embankments.

In a Presidential election year, flying coat-tails are at a premium. A Presidential candidate capable of building a commanding lead in a state can carry weak local candidates into office with him. Conversely, a strong local candidate can give the party's national standard bearer a decisive lift in a doubtful state.

THE personality of the series-detective --what the Crime Club indicates by its magnifying-glass symbol of "favorite sleuth" -- used to be the principal stock-in-trade of mystery writers. But in the past five or ten years they've come to put more and more stress on the story itself, with no formal detective at all or one created only for that single story.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Wind, or rather the lack of it, was the major factor in today's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta, conducted by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club. After a twenty-minute postponement the race chairman, Julian U. Roosevelt, sent 124 sloops in thirteen classes on shortened courses.

The recently disclosed targets for industrial production in the U. S. S. R. for 1955 are being compared in the press with actual production of the United States and Western Europe. The usual inference is that the planned output of principal industrial goods in the U. S. S. R. will be much smaller than the present production of the United States.

IT would appear that the local independent television stations are embarking on what might be called a trend in "bloc programming." WOR-TV started it all with its "Broadway TV Theatre," which offers the same dramatic production each weekday night, and then expanded the idea to include "TV Dinner Date," which presents the same variety show on five consecutive evenings -- the baseball schedule permitting.

ALTHOUGH "Star Man's Son: 2250 A. D." is not science fiction in the strict sense (no space suits or other alluring gadgets) it ought to interest any young reader who has cast a speculative eye upon the future. As a picture of America approximately two centuries after an atomic war it is grim and thought-provoking even if on second thought it isn't wholly convincing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- The White Sox knocked out Bob Feller in a seven-run third inning capped by Pitcher Harold ("Skinny") Brown's three-run homer and went on to an 11-6 victory over the rally-minded Indians tonight.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 30 -- A letter that "explained a lot of things" was left by William H. Abel, president of a Mineola bank that was allegedly swindled of $475,000 by one of his business associates, before he attempted suicide yesterday afternoon, District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta disclosed today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES cannot be commended highly enough for the important public service performed with its editorial on "Rice and Peace" in the Aug. 6 issue. The editorial directed the attention of the American people to the appalling world-wide rice shortage, estimated in recent reports of the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations to amount to more than four million long tons.

The Maritime Administration expressed satisfaction yesterday over last week's sea trials of the Keystone Mariner, the first of a fleet of thirty-five fast new cargo vessels now building in this country.

Without more adequate financing of medical education, low-cost health insurance programs cannot guarantee sound medical service, Dean Willard C. Rappleye of the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons declared yesterday.

Kenneth McGregor withdrew from the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday when leading by two sets in his opening match with Calvin D. MacCracken of Tenafly, N. J. The champion of Australia, a favorite to reach the final round, found it impossible to continue because of a pulled stomach muscle.

A new form of food distribution is spreading westward like a prairie fire. Streamlined roadside diners costing in excess of $100,000 have as little relationship to their "dog wagon" predecessors as modern television receivers have to crystal sets of the early Twenties.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 30 -- Gov. Allan Shivers gave the best possible description of the status of politics in Texas when he said early this week that the state is "on the doubtful list," indicating that there is no assurance right now that it will take its traditional place in the Democratic column in November.

A year ago this week this was the situation in the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute: The effort of Presidential mediator W. Averell Harriman to negotiate a settlement had just fallen through. Iran's Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, having nationalized the once British-owned oil industry, was on the point of expelling the last few British technicians from Iran.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 30 -The women's United States amateur golf championship trophy was being packed tonight for a long trip to the Hawaiian Islands in the custody of Mrs. Jacqueline Pung.

ABOARD the Maasdam en Route to New York -- The ship was bucking some pretty dirty weather between Nova Scotia and Newfoundland on her maiden voyage from Rotterdam to New York via Montreal, when a fellow passenger caught the spirit and purpose of Holland-America Line's new Maasdam, and of her sister-ship, the year-old Ryndam, in a slightly used phrase.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Roy Smalley's two-run single capped a four-run outburst in the fifth inning that enabled the Cubs to score a 5-3 victory over the Reds today. The triumph was the Cubs' fourth in the last five games.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 -- The feeling hero seems to be growing that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin will prove a tough but not necessarily unbeatable candidate in the Sept. 9 primaries. In the minds of many political prognosticators, the Senator holds the edge for re-election but in the absence of any accurate pre-election polling this cannot be stated with certainty.

WHETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 30 -- Skee Riegel of Tulsa, Okla., carded a 4-under-par 67 in the second round for a 133 total to set the pace at the halfway mark in the 72-hole $15,000 Insurance City Open golf tournament.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 30 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh issued the following declaration to the Iranian nation tonight:

HERE are two additions to Dodd, Mead's Famous Biographies for Young People Series which will serve well to answer questions for school book reports and to introduce younger teen-agers to writers on both sides of the Atlantic.

Voted the outstanding soldiers of the First Infantry Division, now stationed in Germany, five non-commissioned officers arrived here yesterday for a visit. They were greeted at Governors Island by Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army Commander.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 30 -- In a move ascribed to "ever-increasing production costs," The Salt Lake Telegram was sold today to The Deseret News and its publication was discontinued. It was announced simultaneously that the Sunday editions of The Deseret News would he dropped.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, paid tribute today to the nation's letter carriers as "not only messengers of business and industry, but also messengers of all the human emotions."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Athletics' Bobby Shantz, leading pitcher in the American League, said he had received three threatening notes warning him not to appear on the field when the A's play in Boston next week-end.

The State Department will be urged tomorrow to place Americans of Slavic origin in key posts that deal with Russian satellite countries. "Not one" such person holds a position of importance in those fields, according to a committee of the Federated Russian Orthodox Clubs, which will make the recommendation to the Government.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 30 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, rejected today "the notion that a third world war is inevitable" and warned that "a change to a rampaging reactionary Republican domestic policy" might brew disaster at home and abroad.

An emergency regulation, established shortly after the start of the Korean War, that permitted the employment of a small number of alien ship officers on American-flag ships has been revoked by the Coast Guard.

It looks like a long voyage home for the Norwegian cargo-passenger ship Thor I. Almost fourteen years ago the trim and new little motorship cleared her home port of Sandefjord, Norway, to head out to the United States west coast to enter freight service to the fabled islands of the South Pacific.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made a "Labor Day pledge" yesterday, promising to consult labor on his campaign and if elected, to be fair to labor and its friends, without "coercing" it "with laws."
TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,358 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Sunday, Korea time:

Creation of a corps of women to check parking violations and issue summonses was suggested yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association. The plan would confine the women's duties to spotting overtime offenders, particularly in parking-meter spaces.

CARMEL, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Ginger Robinson of Great Neck, L. I., with her 8-year-old chestnut roan Gypsy Fiddle, won the Major Candy Memorial Trophy at the twentieth horse show sponsored by the Gypsy Trail Club today.
Forty-one men, comprising the smallest Columbia football squad since the early Nineteen Thirties, will assemble at the Lions' pre-season football headquarters in Lakeside, Conn. Thursday.

THE music of Madrid has always been the hurdy-gurdy, the flamenco guitar and the castanet, but a few weeks ago as I walked down a small side street in the old quarter I was stopped by a new sound. From the open doorway of an ancient bistro burst the sad and solemn chorus of "The Whiffenpoof Song."

More than fifteen years have passed since clauses requiring the payment of certain bonds in gold have ceased to have effect in the United States, but elsewhere the concept of "gold security" has a way of coming back to life when all but counted out.

WE still live in a state, too many of us, in which any portentous-looking move in Moscow sends shivers down the spine. The latest thing to worry alarmists is the convening, a whole decade behind its proper date, of the Nineteenth Congress of the Soviet Communist party.

SENTIMENT dripped all over the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees reached back into the past and paid honor to their first manager, the venerable Clark Griffith, and to the stars of their star-studded history. Old-Timers' Day this year was in the nature of a fiftieth anniversary party. It was a delightful occasion, as usual, and none delighted in it more than the old-timers themselves.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30 -- Col. Milos Stanatovic, head of the Yugoslav military administration that governs Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, issued today twenty more decrees integrating the territory with Yugoslavia.

FOR years prior to the war, the British had been developing their justly faced secret counter-espionage service with persistence, meticulousness and imagination. When war broke out, their foresight paid off -- both for themselves and for their allies.

IT was a Montmartre-by-night bemused with champagne, reeking with patchouli, rocked in the crazy arms of the old Red Mill, which the pathetically deformed Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, six decades ago, immortalized in the acids of his lithographs, the irony of his oil.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 30 (UP) -- Larry Bouchey, a week-end player from Inglewood, Calif., today parlayed a referee's decision into his first major crown when he won the Canadian amateur golf championship with a 1-up, thirty-seven-hole victory over Bill Campbell of Huntingdon, W. Va.

I have read with interest and considerable amusement the article entitled "New Departures in Old Dublin" (July 27). In criticism may I congratulate the writer on getting his photos accurate and about 10 per cent of his facts.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Several thousand residents of the New York metropolitan area attended the opening today of the Westchester County Fair at Indian Point Park on the bank of the Hudson River near here. The eight-day event is under the sponsorship of the Westchester Horticultural and Agricultural Association, of which Emanuel D. Kelmans, owner of the amusement park, is president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The great Republican-Democratic debate on foreign policy has come down now, in its national sense, not so much to questions of principle as to questions of method and management.

The growing trend in medical practice of emphasizing restoration of the patient's functional ability as well as the treatment of his disease was greatly in evidence here in New York last week at the thirtieth annual meeting of the American Congress of Physical Medicine.

THE 1952 international bridge championship is to be decided in New York City, according to present plans. Play is scheduled to begin on Oct. 27. In this match, the American champion team of four plays the European champion.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Top-Seeded Julie Sampson, 18, of San Marino, Calif., entered the final of the thirty-fifth annual girls' national tennis championship today by beating another Californian, Linda Mitchell of San Diego, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

TWO of television's most competent musical personalities returned to the air last week in their respective programs, aided and abetted by quietly informal production work that was refreshingly impressive.
Frank Miller, first 'cellist of the N. B. C. Summer Symphony, performed as guest conductor of that organization yesterday afternoon at the Belasco Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The committee estimated that 10 to 15 per cent of current real estate costs in the Washington area, particularly in the low and middle price fields, were a "direct result" of failure by loan guaranty officials to set reasonable values on homes bought by veterans with Government backing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 211 casualties of the Korean war, including 30 killed, 177 wounded, 1 injured in an accident and 3 missing. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

" IN Japan, a two-century-old home is not obsolete," said Japanese-American sculptor Isamu Noguchi, not looking down as he slipped out of mud-encrusted leather shoes into waiting straw slippers and entered the 200-year-old farmhouse in which he lives.

THE axiom -- "some bombers always get through" -- has, in the past, epitomized the reason for the existence of the big bombers. Armed with A-bombs these giants of the air could fly far above terrain barriers and broad seas to strike an enemy's industries, cities and communications.

FILM makers, stars, critics, devotees of film art in general -- in short, "le tout cinema" -- are gathering here for the three-week rendezvous known as the Venice Festival of Cinematic Art, this year marking its twentieth anniversary.

BERLIN, Aug. 30 -- Jakob Kaiser, Minister of All-German Affairs in the Bonn Government, urged today that prospective refugees from East Germany stay home rather than imperil West Berlin by swamping its economy.

MR. COE'S latest thriller centers about a heroine who is anything but sympathetic. Vivian Worley is a designing, ambitious woman who desires power and does not mind the lives she ruins in getting it. Her father is a third-generation tycoon, who is willing enough to rest on his grandfather's laurels.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- In a speech at the opening of the agricultural fair in the war-damaged Normandy city of Caen, Premier Antoine Pinay today redefined his policy as firmly against inflation, against devaluation of the currency and against increasing prices or taxation.

THE shape of things to come in the air is being shown this week at Farnborough, England, where the Society of British Aircraft Constructors is holding its annual display. Among the planes to be flown at the international exhibition is a transport that may be used in regular service over the North Pole.

The "glamour" jobs for secretaries, typists and clerks -- those in radio and television -- are not so glamorous as they seem. A warning to this effect came last week from the personnel director of one of the big networks, in commenting on articles in THE NEW YORK TIMES giving views of employers and workers on difficulties in getting workers, or, conversely, trouble in finding jobs.

SINCE the appearance in 1941 of Walter Farley's first book, "The Black Stallion," readers have been clamoring for more and more of his thrilling horse tales. His fifth and latest book is certain to run nose to nose in popularity with its predecessors.
TORONTO, Aug. 30 -- Bob Richards, the pole-vaulting parson from Laverne, Calif., cleared 15 feet 1/8 inch at the Canadian National Exhibition track and field meet today.

GEORGE LONDON and Cesare Siepi will be the Borises in the revival of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" that the Metropolitan Opera is presenting next spring. It is expected there will be six performances of the production, which will be linguistically and musically new, for the opera is being freshly translated into English by John Gutman and the Metropolitan plans to utilize the composer's original orchestration with some revisions by Karol Rathaus.

A FLAKE of paint or a sliver of broken glass may solve the mystery of a hit and run highway accident, according to a report by the Traffic Institute of Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill. The application of scientific methods of deduction in motor crashes, it is pointed out, often turns up hidden information that traps a guilty fugitive driver.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Parker R. Whiting's Thunderation from Fort Wayne, Ind., with Clint Hodgins in the sulky, scored an upset victory in 2:07 3/5 in the $11,050 Lynbrook 4-year-old trotting stake at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

IN his "Literary Letter From Italy" of Aug. 10, Paolo Milano states that Vitaliano Brancato "has just published an impressive book-length essay, "Ritorno alla Censura" ("Return to Censorship")." The book, published early this year by Laterza, actually contains the text of a play which was barred by the authorities from being performed on the stage, and an introduction dealing with the question of public censorship.

The international oil trade is one of the most complex operations in the business world. It involves tremendous sums of capital for exploration and development in far corners of the world. It involves the building of pipelines, and tanker fleets, and huge refineries.

GEORGE K. ARTHUR, who will be remembered with Karl Dane as a top comedy team of the silent screen era, has not deserted the movies. Last week Mr. Arthur came forth with the information that he has been quietly active in the commercial short subject field for the past seven months, both here and abroad, with some tangible encouragement to show for his efforts.

SINCE these matters were last touched upon, three books, all of them about the sea, have passed their first birthdays on the best-seller list, for a combined sale of 1,638,000 copies in about a dozen different languages, including Icelandic and Serbo-Croatian. "Thank God for the sea!" publishers are mumbling to themselves these days.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 30 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic nominee for Vice President, met head-on today the charges of Republican critics who, with the benefit of what he called "20-20 hindsight," blame the Administration for the collapse of Nationalist China and the fruitless Korean armistice talks.

The international oil industry is facing its toughest fight. With foreign operations closely tied to domestic, the outcome of the grand jury investigation by the Department of Justice scheduled to start next Wednesday will have an influence on the entire industry throughout the free world. The investigation stems from a report by the Federal Trade Commission alleging that five American companies and two foreign concerns are operating a giant cartel to control prices and production.

The week before Labor Day the campaign headquarters of Presidential candidates are usually a scene of "orderly confusion" attendant upon breaking up camp. Aides are working over itineraries. Writers are putting the finishing touches on speeches. The candidates divide their time between last minute strategy huddles with their staffs and a stream of callers bringing free advice on how to win in a walk.

THREAT of a major jurisdictional struggle for control of writers working in television faded last Wednesday with the announcement that 80 per cent of the voting membership of the Radio Writers Guild had cast ballots to support the combined strike by the Screen Writers Guild and the Authors League of America against the Alliance of Television Film Producers, representing the major producers of television shows on the West Coast.

YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Mitchell Hanover, owned and driven by Hank Lowden, came on in the stretch to gain a length victory over the favorite, Direct Vic, in the Grattan Bars pace for a $3,500 purse on the closing program at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

The dispute as to which of the rival slates of Democratic candidates for Supreme Court Justice in the Second Judicial District is entitled to nomination will have to be settled by the courts, it seemed certain yesterday.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Aug. 29. -- More than eighty men-of-war of the United States Fleet maneuvered in mid-Atlantic today en route to Scotland and Exercise Mainbrace, the Atlantic Alliance naval maneuver to be held in the North Sea in September.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 30 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan warned Britain tonight that the shrinking empire would find its "grave" in Africa unless British policies in support of racial equality changed.

With a new nine-story building now under way, St. Luke's Hospital requires a further expansion program to make it a complete general hospital, Edwin S. S. Sunderland, president, declares in his annual report for 1951. The hospital cannot afford to stand still, he says, in a plea for friends to make "the greatest goodwill offerings within their power."

The recessional trend of the last eighteen months was reversed during August as industrial orders rose sharply and production made a substantial increase after a slow summer, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its monthly survey, issued for publication today.

FATHER PERRIN, her Dominican friend, first sent Simone Weil to Gustave Thibon, the scholarly French farmer who edited this volume. Mlle. Weil, Father Perrin wrote M. Thibon, was "a graduate in philosophy and a militant supporter of the extreme left."

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Diplomatic sources here interpreted Premier Mossadegh's reply to the Truman-Churchill offer as decidedly less than a definite rejection. The Premier's summoning of Parliament as the final arbiter was seen as a move giving him and his supporters more time to think it over.

Italian velveteen, which has gained a firm hold in the American fabric market in the last four years, will enjoy even greater popularity in 1953, it was predicted last week by James L. Richter of the Amity Silk Company. He said the cloth had a fashion life of at least another six to seven years and was building up a large volume in sales for home sewing.

THERE is increasing evidence that American composers are turning in the direction of opera as they never have done before. It is high time that they did so. Our attitude toward opera, or let us say the attitude of our upper musical circles toward this form, has been rather stuffy and supercilious.

THY are feeding antibiotics to pigs and poultry now, not to cure them of some dread disease but to make them grow faster, to produce more meat in less time. It works, and almost everybody stands to benefit: the consumers because it already is increasing the supply of meat and poultry: farmers because they can bring their birds and beasts to market in less time and with less feed.

PERHAPS because their refulgent color so often submerges their forcefulness, many of Georges Rouault's paintings seem to wear themselves out, the first ardent impact too soon dissipated. Not so in most of his graphic work, most certainly not in the magnificent series "Miserere et Guerre," unquestionably among his greatest achievements.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Army's sixty-third football season got under way today with a squad of fifty reporting for practice to Earl Blaik, the head coach.

Veterans who served with the Tenth Armored Division in World War II began gathering yesterday at the Park Sheraton Hotel, where the division association opened its first annual convention. The convention, which has attracted veterans from as far away as Alaska, will end tonight with a dinner dance.

" LEFT home on the 21st of August, 1902. Everybody away from home, so the departure was comparatively easy. Arrived Weymouth in the evening; found excellent rooms. Sept. 1, obtained small part as guard with 'Mary Queen of Scots'."

A new course in military history will be introduced this fall at Princeton University and will be open to students in the Reserve Officers Training Corps programs and others. The course, developed by the university History Department, will trace the main developments in the science of war from the French Revolution to the present, paying special attention to the relationship of the military to society.

European affiliates of American machinery manufacturers are operating in the most favorable business climate since World War II, according to Hobart C. Ramsey, president of the Worthington Corporation. Conditions throughout Europe, he said last week on his return from a six weeks' tour of Worthington branches and affiliates abroad, show a degree of stability that will tend to insure the continuing steady increase in plant expansion and sales.

The New York City Opera Company will present eighteen operas, the most it has yet mounted in any season, during its fall term of six and one-half weeks opening Sept. 18 at the New York City Center, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Rosenstock, general director.

BALI, the small island of the Indonesian Archipelago to the east of Java, is of legendary fame for its brilliantly stylized dances, and above all for the glittering music of the gamelan, the Balinese orchestra of bronze gongs, gong-chimes, metallophones, drums and cymbals.

A new study of students now enrolled at teachers' colleges of the State University of New York indicates that as a group they are equal in scholastic aptitude to students in the nation's four-year colleges.

Not so in most of his graphic work, most certainly not in the magnificent series "Miserere et Guerre," unquestionably among his greatest achievements.
