In 1941 Justice William O. Douglas in a famous patent case declared that an invention must be the result of "a flash of genius and not merely the result of the skill of the calling." Patent lawyers were outraged. The law stated only that an invention must be new and useful in order to be patentable.
Marking National Sight-Saving Month, beginning today, Mason H. Bigelow, president of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, listed the following rules for safeguarding sight:

So long as his lads keep winning, Casey Stengel doesn't care a dangling participle what the Indians do and Casey, who can dangle a participle like no one else in the business, had his Yankees on the right track yesterday at the Stadium.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Teachers is to be commended for its decision to recommend that its members favor by referendum vote an amendment to the union's constitution which would abolish local union charters that permit segregation of white and Negro teachers into separate local unions.
VIENNA, Aug. 31 -- The Communist regimes of the "people's democracies" have launched on Moscow's orders a final drive to break the power of the trade unions.

Three policemen in the West Twentieth Street station required first aid yesterday after a prisoner allegedly lashed out with his fists at everyone in sight. The prisoner was one of two Board of Transportation employes being booked on charges of slashing a Jersey City man so severely that his wounds required forty-seven stitches.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The National Committee of Americans of Polish Descent today opposed United States' encouragement of revolutions behind the Iron Curtain unless such encouragement was backed with material aid.

Gratitude for progress in improving working conditions and grief for fellow working men enslaved behind the Iron Curtain should be felt by American workers on Labor Day, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared in a sermon at solemn mass there yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug 31 -- Minister of Finance Antonio Alvarez Restrepo, referring to fears that a change may be made in dollar value of the Colombian peso, asserted today that the current rate of 2.50 to the dollar will not be altered.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Nearly half of the new applications for divorce now being filed in one Ohio county are by couples who previously had been "talked out" of divorce by well-meaning advisers untrained in handling complex personal problems, according to Ralph Bridgman, supervisor of marriage counsellors in the Domestic Relations Court of Toledo.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Jack Collins of Brooklyn today won the New York State Chess Association championship. Collins defeated James T. Sherwin of Columbia, last year's victor at Syracuse, in the eighth round and drew with Allan Kaufman of New York in the final round.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in August fell below the previous month every other month since July, 1949, and it was the dullest August since that of 1948. The million-share mark was reached on only eight occasions. The day with the largest turnover, 1,187,610 shares, was Aug. 7, and the smallest volume day was Aug. 21, when 795,600 shares were traded.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Browsing around a country fair on a drizzly Sunday can be fun. Crowds don't jostle you and you can concentrate on the displays, prepared with loving care.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Browns completed their sweep of a two-game series with the last-place Tigers today, gaining a 7-4 verdict for Bobby Cain, who thus became the club's first ten-game winner this season.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Rains sweeping across the entire Korean front Sunday bogged down the ground fighting and virtually halted the heavy Allied air blows of the past few days.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Some 800 or 900 speakers and delegates have prepared their notes for the 114th annual session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, which will open with fine academic flourish at Queens University, Belfast, on Wednesday, 100 years after the association first met in that city.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- The official who was removed nearly two months ago because of his prosecution of alleged Communist agitators in the Brazilian armed forces has won his fight for vindication. A court order restores him to duty.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The police posted today a twenty-four-hour guard at the hospital bedside of a 32-year-old woman held in connection with the death by gas yesterday of her ill father, 72.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Pit trade activity on the Board of Trade was less active than the previous week, but was much broader than a year ago, Soy beans took leadership of the market this week in regard to total transactions, running up a total of 55,540,000 bushels, compared with 23,061,000 a year ago.

It will be of interest to Claudette Sorel, whose letter suggested that a course in etiquette be taught in our public schools and colleges, to know that outside the City or State of New York such things as social etiquette are taught. For instance, in Kentucky, the state whose inhabitants are often referred to as "hillbillies," both girls and boys are given courses covering just the items she mentions and many more.

Queens' flood bowl in Glen Oaks should pass away into history by the end of this month as part of a flood relief program that Borough President James A. Lundy has been pressing despite some handicaps forced by the need to divert personnel to investigate defective sewers.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 31 -- Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra announced his Cabinet today before his inauguration as President of Ecuador. The list follows:...
Three new films have been scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week, all with Friday openings. The offerings follow:...

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 31 -Premier Mossadegh summoned the Iranian Chamber of Deputies to meet Sept. 10 and the Senate to convene Sept. 13 to consider the United States-British offer to settle the Iranian oil problem that was presented yesterday.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York will provide visiting nurse service to a limited number of members upon their discharge as hospital patients, Louise H. Pink, chairman of Blue Cross Plan's board of directors, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Twentieth Century-Fox intends to make a motion picture out of a portion of Eric Sevareid's book "Not So Wild a Dream," wherein the correspondent wrote of his experiences and observations in the second World War.

ZURICH, Aug. 31 -- An agreement between the Allies and Switzerland was signed at Berne on Friday to amend the Washington Accord of May 25, 1946. This permits its termination by payment to the Allies of 121,500,000 Swiss francs in a lump sum to settle in full all Allied claims respecting property of "Germans in Germany" blocked in Switzerland since 1945.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- To the stirring music of Beethoven's Eighth Symphony, Berlin's second Cultural Festival opened today as a host of performers converged on the city from all parts of the Western world.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- The upper classmen of the Corps of Cadets have returned to the Military Academy to start the new academic year after summer training trips and maneuvers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- George Meany, secretary of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight that most of the leaders of the labor organization would support Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson "if the election were held tomorrow."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Constitution party, proclaiming itself as opposed to "international conspirators who have derided and defied our Constitution for more than a decade," set out today on a campaign to win Electoral College votes for General of the Army Douglas MacArthur for President and Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, for Vice President.

Lambda Chi Alpha, Greek letter fraternity, opened its twenty-third annual assembly yesterday with a church service conducted by Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, retired Navy chaplain. The service was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the four-day assembly is meeting.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Phillies' relief star, Jim Konstanty, made his first start since June 6, 1951, a winning one today as he blanked the Braves, 4 -- 0, with three hits and knocked in the winning run in the finale to gain a split of the double-header.

A plot of about 16,000 square feet of land on Borden Avenue, 100 feet east of Fifth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Lunkenheimer Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, to Herbert S. Baudesson, builder, for improvement.
The national tennis championships got into full swing yesterday at Forest Hills and despite the threatening weather 5,000 spectators turned out and a complete program of play was carried through.

Russia's chess players, who won the world team championship on Saturday, completed their ninth-round match with Sweden yesterday, according to a report from Helsinki, Finland. Winning by the score of 3 -- 1, the Russians finished their tournament schedule with a total of 21 -- 11.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,359, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, left today by air for Los Angeles. He will represent the top Democratic command on the Pacific coast while Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Presidential nominee, and President Truman concentrate their quest for labor votes in the Midwest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A code of ethical standards for the profession of psychology has been drafted. One of the aims is to protect the public from "charlatans." Representing a frank, honest

In a recent editorial, "The Reds and the Nazis," you pointed out one more similarity between the Soviet regime and Hitler's National Socialism. In making such comparisons between these two systems we are reminded once again that their characteristics are similar not only because they are both totalitarian despotisms but also because of a deep ideological kinship arising from the fact that their beliefs stem from the same source.

HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Steve Hromjak of Cleveland, a 22-year-old United States Army sergeant and 1952 Olympian, pedaled his way to the twenty-fourth annual national amateur senior men's bicycle racing championship today.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 31 -- The bill that opened the way for former Mayor James M. Curley of Boston to obtain a $12,000 annual pension was defended today by the legislator who filed it, State Representative Thomas F. Reilly of Boston, a Democrat.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week were a bit firmer, but held within a relatively narrow trading range. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 27 to 48 points higher than a week earlier.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- While it would be an exaggeration to describe the further substantial advance in the stock markets here last week as a boom, the upward movement has exceeded anything which has occurred for many months.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Bill King's Sweet Sue of the home fleet captured the Star class honors today in the annual Labor Day weekend regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club, defeating Pat O'Gorman's Wahini of the Larchmont Y. C. John Titterington's Wendy of the Sheepshead Bay fleet placed third to tie for the series lead with Harold Halsted's Chuckle.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Aug. 31 -- Catholics may vote with a clear conscience for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, even though he is divorced, The La Cross Catholic Register declared Friday in an editorial.

Moslems attended annual Day of Sacrifice services in many countries yesterday, in thanksgiving for the substitution by Abraham of a ram as his sacrifice to God, in place of his son. The occasion is known as the Feast of Idel-adha.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, can perform a variety of farm chores -- and frequently does -- his farm tenant said today.

AFTER a while it gets to be just about the same as being hit repeatedly on the noggin by a blunt instrument. The victim gets numb and nonresistant. So there won't even be a bleat of protest in this corner at the latest mockery the big leagues are making of their own rule which expressly prohibits trades after the June 15 deadline. The way that rule has been circumvented borders on the scandalous.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 -- For the third time in eleven years, De Coursey Fales' staysail-rigged schooner Nina, now 24 years old, won the Stamford Yacht Club's annual race, the season's finale on blue water, out around the Vineyard's Lightship and back.

CAIRO, Aug. 31 -- There are indications of a desire on the part of Britain and Egypt to sweeten the atmosphere affecting the relations between the two countries in anticipation of the negotiations that Premier Aly Maher said yesterday would begin in October.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 -- More than 2,500,000 Indians who had been branded as potential criminals from birth and were kept under lifelong surveillance whether they ever had committed a crime or not were released today from this bondage, imposed on their ancestors by the former British rulers of this nation in retaliation for opposition to foreign control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, today praised organized labor for its opposition to "forces which would undermine our basic economic, social and political liberties."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- In a statement directed at North-South antipathies in the Democratic party, Arthur E. Summerfield, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was "inextricably tied to the apron strings" of the Truman Administration.

The United Press reported that a Moscow magazine is in a pet because some Russian parents, in an effort to be original, have named their children "Detector," "Radiola" or "Electrification." Some extreme deviationists have gone so far as to christen their children "Harry" and "Eleanor."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Toronto Sailing and Canoe Club today beat off a strong bid by the Samoset Canoe Club of Boston to win the Sir Thomas Lipton Trophy in the President's Cup regatta canoe races.

One of the high spots of the fall and spring seasons in the professional life of a New York fashion editor is the reviewing of a Bergdorf Goodman custom-order collection. It stands for elegance and perfection in good taste. For some years, one of the leading contributors to these outstanding fashions has been designer Leslie Morris.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. l -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, today presented an Oak Leaf cluster to the Distinguished Service Medal to Maj. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner for suppressing Communist prisoner of war violence on Koje Island, Korea.

The Aqueduct racing strip has a new, bouncy cushion, and the Aqueduct management is sincere in the hope that New York's horse players were able to put a new, fluffy cushion on their bankrolls during the past four weeks while the running horses were absent from Long Island.

EAGLEVILLE, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The bodies of Joseph Floyd (Arky) Vaughan, former National League baseball star, and a companion, Bill Wimer, who were drowned late yesterday, were recovered early today from Lost Lake.

Five thousand letter carriers from all sections off the country came into New York yesterday to take part in the thirty-eighth biennial convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers, which will open today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Al Rosen drove in three runs and Larry Doby smashed a 425-foot, two-run homer as the Indians defeated the White-Sox, 6-3, today to keep two games behind the first-place Yankees.
Flotations of new securities in August were the smallest since February. They were little changed in total from the offerings in July, but sharply higher than a year ago.

Coal trucks still rumble through the streets of city and suburb, but one notes, over the years, that they are being elbowed aside by fleets of tank trucks carrying liquid fuel to business establishments and homes. Some day it is possible that service cars carrying experts on atomic heating plants will be nudging tank trucks out of the way.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that world meat production, while increasing, was failing to keep pace with population increases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Senator James H. Duff, Republican of Pennsylvania, said tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would reveal the "secrets" behind corruption in the Democratic Administration in a hard-hitting campaign for the Presidency.

The New York Daily News announced yesterday in an editorial that it would continue to support Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee for President, despite the proposal of Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, for the formation of a new national political party, The American party. The ownerships of The Daily News and The Chicago Tribune are affiliated.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Athletics split a double-header with the Red Sox today to win four contests of the five-game series and remain in contention for the American League pennant. The A's trail the Yankees by seven games, with nine games still scheduled with the world champions.

" Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's account of the problems and hopes of peoples whose countries are now coming of age will be issued early next year by Harper. Originally scheduled for October publication, "The Awakening" combines her experiences in the Middle East, India and Pakistan with her analysis of the tremendous social and economic difficulties facing those nations.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 -- Leonard F. Schmitt, 50-year-old attorney, who is seeking the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Wisconsin, is a stubborn fighter for his principles.
CASCAIS, Portugal, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Merope, the Olympic champion Star Class yacht, won the world championship today by finishing third in the final race.

Construction of a seamen's club in Casablanca, French Morocco, is a step closer to realization, thanks to a land donation by the local government, E. A. Roberts, president of the United Defense Fund, reported yesterday.

Adjustments seem to be overdue in the relationship between income after taxes, the people's savings and the volume of retail trade, according to a study just completed by Franklin R. Uhlig, attached to the staff of the New York Stock Exchange house of Laird, Bissell Meeds.

Bonds called for payment in August before their dates of maturity dropped below the total of the preceding month but were the largest for any August since 1950. The total of $40,908,000 compared with $68,013,000 in July and $20,954,000 in August, 1951.

ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Spain beat Italy, 7 -- 3, today in Europe's first international American baseball game. The three-and-a-half hour contest was marked by twenty-one errors, including thirteen by Italy.

HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- At least nine private factories in Chungking, West China's leading economic center, have been reorganized as joint "public-private" companies in a move that has strengthened the Peiping Government's control over the heavy industry nucleus developed there under the Nationalists during the Japanese war.
KASSON - DODGE CENTER, Minn., Aug. 31 -- A boom town, born of politics and plowing, is growing up on the peaceful southeastern Minnesota countryside.

Overcast skies and occasional showers kept Labor Day week-end travel to a minimum yesterday. Traffic on city streets and suburban highways was slight, with no tie-ups reported on any of the major arteries.

Absence of any sizable activity on the part of commercials or dealers imposed upon the foreign exchange market last week its dullest trading period of the year. In turn, fluctuations in rates were extremely narrow.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- An unemployed truck driver who was charged with attempted suicide after being snatched from certain death in Niagara Fails insisted today that he fell into the turbulent stream while trying to wash his face.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 -- James P. Shields, Grand Chief Engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, today urged members of his powerful railroad union to elect a President "who will protect labor only as labor's protection means like protection to every segment of the American public."

The four-year term of President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador "went into history" yesterday. That hackneyed phrase has real meaning in this case, for Galo Plaza made Latin-American history, not only in a big way, but in the best possible way. He gave Ecuador -- a country previously notorious for its constant revolutions, brief tenures of office and autocratic military governments -- a completely democratic and civilian rule for four uninterrupted years.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- Because of the decline in air power in the United States during the last five years, this country cannot now guarantee itself against aggression, Arthur F. Kelley of Los Angeles, a vice president of Western Airlines, said in an address today before the Air Force Association, which is holding its sixth annual convention.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 1 -- The United States Navy today sent its greatest carrier raid of the war to within a few miles of Soviet Siberia and Manchuria.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- The season's first hurricane blew itself out today after causing widsespread minor damage in South Carolina ports and inland towns. Two persons, possibly three, were reported killed.

IN the summer of 1929 John McPeek allowed his wife to persuade him, against his better judgment, to cash in on his stock market speculations. And then John watched the market continue its fabulous ascent and was filled with a sense of frustrated greed. Finally he could not stand it longer and invested all the money he had on margin -- just in time to lose it all in the big crash.

There can be to compromise between Christianity and communism, the Rev. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared yesterday.
Every now and then something happens to New York that produces in old residents a feeling that they are strangers in their own metropolis. Yesterday was such a day.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 31 -- Dutch authorities expect that in 1953 the "monetary miracle" will end for a while as by then the peak of defense expenditures will adversely affect the balance of payments.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The Chemical Products Committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation has just published a report on the prospects for supplying Europe with sulphur. The report warns the European governments against the tendency toward slackening the production of this raw material and against dropping the drives for salvaging of sulphur.
Belgian semi-finished steel is being bought by western Germany at the rate of 1,250,000 tons annually, now that most trading barriers between the two countries have been removed by the Schuman Plan.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Kirsten Flagstad, Wagnerian soprano, returned to the opera stage today in a tiny neo-Elizabethan theatre in a pleasant private garden of northwest London. She appeared at the opening of the second season at the Mermaid Theatre, offering the drama and music of the seventeenth century.
The Coast Guard has permanently extinguished Navesink Light, the powerful beacon south of Sandy Hook that since Revolutionary days has guided mariners safely into New York Harbor.

While taxi-drivers sport the slogan "Think before you honk," the taxi-drivers are the most prolific honkers, as anyone who drives a car any length of time will agree. One can indict the taxi-driver with all the driving sins in the book. In spite of the fact that the police tell us that they are curbed, thirty years of private driving convinces me otherwise.

The Rev. Dr. Norris L. Tibbetts of the staff of Riverside Church warned in his sermon yesterday that "our country runs serious risks in its international relations because we seem to wish to dominate through power rather than to develop more abundant life in other lands through our own great resources.

A British minister, preaching yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), at Fifty-sixth Street, described Christian duty as "ultimately a matter of spirit rather than of calculation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Senate veterans said today that the appointment of William A. Purtell as a Republican Senator from Connecticut might lessen the chances of a special session of Congress this year.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 -- Six teen-age boys played hide and seek with the Jersey City police in the meadows adjoining Newark Bay today, shortly after they had escaped from the Hudson County Parental School in Bayonne.

ATHENS, Aug. 31 -- The North Atlantic Council in Paris will discuss the alliance's relationships with Yugoslavia at one of its next meetings, probably within a fortnight. The subject has not yet been placed on the agenda but it is understood that preparations have been made to do so and that the representatives of Greece and Turkey in the council are conferring on a report of their Governments' views toward Belgrade.
Members of the Brooklyn Dodgers who were team mates of Arky Vaughan took the news of his death as a deep personal loss.

Seldom in human history has a simple abbreviation served to express more tragic meaning than that inherent in D followed by P. It stands for displaced person. It has been spoken with pity, with scorn, with indifference. It means waiting in one of Europe's camps for something called a quota.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Favorable weather in the principal grain areas of this country and Canada exerted a bearish influence on the cereal markets at times last week. Brilliant crop prospects in western Canada were a difficult hurdle for the bulls, but wheat buying appeared to broaden automatically on moderate setbacks, prices holding in a narrow range.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Aug. 31 -- In a unanimous move today, 1,200 members of Local 469, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., voted to strike against 115 employers in five central New Jersey counties. The strike is called for midnight tonight, although tomorrow is nominally a holiday and the effect of any stoppage would not be felt until Tuesday.

More than 150 securities dealers of Philadelphia and New York have been invited by the Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation to attend a demonstration of the company's pay-as-you-see television system in New York on Thursday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 -- A proposal to revamp the Republican State Central Committee setup in Connecticut to favor small towns over cities will be brought before the special state convention of the party here Thursday and Friday.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The United States Air Force maintains in England 30,000 men, supported by powerful anti - aircraft ground forces and Army Engineers, accompanied by some 8,000 wives and children, and deployed among thirty airfields, supply depots and other installations.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The British were acting today as if they did not quite hear Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh when he said yesterday that his Government could not agree to the joint British and United States proposals for settling the British-Iranian oil dispute.

" Your Hit Parade," the animated juke box, resumed its musical mania over Channel 4 on Saturday evening at 10:30 under conditions that were not auspicious. LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- The influential Sunday Observer said today the two United States Presidential candidates maintained an "extraordinarily high level" in their addresses to the American Legion.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Aug. 31 -- Scratch one chipmunk from the list of Labor Day week-end fatalities. It was a close squeak. The chipmunk has no name, but since he's the head of a family, let's call him Father. The time was this morning and the scene a swimming pool in Oakleigh Court. Father's family (wife and son) live in a modest hole in the lawn of J. P. Oakley, whose house is near the pool.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- The Soviet press published statistics today revealing that the Soviet coal industry in the first eight months of this year produced 1,500,000 tons above the plan's quota. This output is 8.1 per cent above last year's volume, which indicates that 1952 production should run about 308,193,000 tons.

Nassau County officials were asked last night to help 220 striking drivers and maintenance men in Local 252 of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., prove to the Bee Line, Inc., and its two struck subsidiary lines on Long Island, that present bus schedules were causing a high rate of accidents.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, and Mrs. Eisenhower were guests of Cardinal Spellman at a luncheon yesterday at his residence at Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
CLINTON, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Some delegates to the annual conference of the State Young Adults Civil Council changed their minds today after hearing a discussion of the 1952 campaign issues.

The idea of Labor Day was first suggested in 1882 by Peter J. McGuire, founder of the Carpenters' Union and associated with Samuel Gompers in forming the American Federation of Labor. In 1894 President Cleveland signed an Act of Congress making the first Monday in September an annual legal holiday.

An operating deficit of $32,000,000 on the municipal transit lines for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1953, has been predicted by the Board of Transportation in a memorandum submitted to Mayor Impellitteri's financial advisers.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Labor union leaders representing some 2,500,000 engineering and shipyard workers decided today to recommend the stoppage of all overtime and piece work in the industry, because of employers' rejection of a demand for a general wage rise of 2 ($5.60) a week.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Aug. 31 -- The state of the defenses of Western Europe will be tested this month when about 400,000 soldiers and airmen and more than 2,000 aircraft of the Atlantic pact powers will take part in a series of maneuvers.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 1 -- The official Peiping radio charged today that the "Americans are plotting to expand the scale of murdering peaceful residents" of North Korea. The charge was based on the Allied air forces' recent report that the list of seventy-eight Korean cities and towns whose inhabitants had been warned to evacuate would be changed as necessity arose.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 31 (AP) --Vice Chancellor Franz Bluecher opened Frankfurt's big fall fair today with a plea for freer European trade. He told some of Europe's leading manufacturers that customs barriers on the Continent should be knocked down with the aim of creating an International Customs Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Air Force said today that the recent incidence of "stay-down" fliers had not hurt recruitment of aviation cadets although it still needed more trainees than it was getting.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Although the steel strike ended more than a month ago its effects are still being felt by steel users and steel producers. A number of manufacturing companies which were able to keep their plants running during and immediately after the strike are now sending out urgent pleas for steel to prevent plant shutdowns.

TOWSON, Md., Aug. 31 -- Maryland police officials announced late today that the quiet, soft-spoken husband of a New York Sunday school teacher, mother of three daughters, would be charged with the "perfect murder" of his wife.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff apparently have struck a snag in trying to agree on the relative size of the armed forces and the money needed for them.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Automobile makers are talking about an end to materials controls before the second quarter of next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Federal, State and local taxes of $412 in the fiscal year 1951 were borne by every man, woman and child in the United States and the average total will be even more in the 1952 fiscal year which ended June 30, the bureau of the Census reported today.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 31 (UP) -- Skee Riegel of Tulsa, Okla., matched par 71 today in the third round of the $15,000 Insurance City open golf tournament and saw his four-stroke leadership over the field cut in half.

A residence on plot 60 by 112 feet at the southeast side of Fairview Avenue, 181 feet south of Altamont Avenue, Tarrytown, N. Y., was sold by Arvid Asklof to Ben Bailey, Jr., who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

SPRINGFIELD, ILL., Aug. 31 -- The campaign headquarters of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, is a study in informality. There is somewhat of a homey touch about the operation, and talk of how families are faring vies with political talk.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Although threatening skies and storm warnings limited the fleet, a group of eight yachts, led by the twelve-meter Nyala from City Island, skippered by Gerald W. Ford, started today in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's twenty-eighth annual Stratford Shoal race at 4:15 P. M.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 31 -- Riding the crest of a wave of unusual prosperity, the Territory of Alaska also is suffering from an enlarged case of all the inflation ills currently plaguing the Continental United States.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is expected back tomorrow or Tuesday after a six weeks' vacation in Switzerland. He races many major diplomatic and political problems, such as the Saar negotiations with France, the latest Soviet note on the German situation, and the final drive for ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community treaty.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Murry Dickson and Ralph Kiner combined to beat Stu Miller and the Cardinals today as the Pirates won a 4-2 battle that was stopped for forty-eight minutes during the fifth inning because of rain.

YONKERS, Aug. 31 -- The investigation of the murder of John Acropolis, Westchester labor leader, continued without interruption today as holiday days off were canceled for detective members of the Yonkers Police Department.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 31 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson will formally open his campaign for the Presidency tomorrow in Michigan. In his Labor Day addresses the Democratic candidate will give his views on labor relations, including the Taft-Hartley Act, and on United States foreign policy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The supply of beef is larger now than it has been at any time in the last seven years, and it is increasing every week. Furthermore, prices of most cuts are lower than they were last year.
ROME, Aug. 31 -- Pinocchio the puppet has just helped defeat the Communist party.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The number of false loans allegedly engineered by Mrs. Lillian Robinson in swindling the Central National Bank of Mineola of an estimated $475,000 was placed today at 900 by Harold Spitzer, assistant district attorney.

Robert Alda, who created the role of Sky Masterson in the musical hit, "Guys and Dolls," will leave the production within four weeks. As previously announced, Mr. Alda will star in and co-produce "Herald Square," a new musical, for which Ben Segal will be the co-sponsor.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Pinch-hitters provided the pay-off punch in both games today as the Cubs and Reds divided a double-header. The Cubs won the opener, 4 -- 2, but dropped the second contest, 6 -- 5.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- A surprise marked the sixth annual competition of the Rockland County Kennel Club today when a relatively untried campaigner captured best-in-show honors. The winner was the lemon and white English setter, Sir Argyle of Flower Valley, owned by Harry Gantz of Harrison and shown by Ruth Williams of Scarsdale.

MADRID, Aug. 31 -- Spanish newspaper publishers have asked the Government to reform the present law controlling the press and especially to abolish preventive censorship except in cases of national emergency.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Jerry Harrison, 18-year-old Ohio State University sophomore from Denver who barely missed qualifying for the Olympic Games, today won the national Amateur Athletic Union tower diving title at the Olympic Pool.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- Speed-boat records, already pushed to incredible highs this season, may soar to still faster marks in Labor Day's regatta on the Detroit River for the Silver Cup, reserved for the three most powerful racing classes of all.

In Uruguay, where meat is abundant and inexpensive, the hostess counts on each guest to eat at least five pounds of barbecued beef, veal or pork at a dinner. When Senora Roberto Cosio first came to this country with her husband, who is now in the office of the Consulate General of Uruguay here, her biggest culinary problem was reconciling herself to our more modest servings of meat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that three college students had "sweated enough" under police questioning, and he would not prosecute them on charges of trying to break into his office yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31 -- Brazil's bankrupt financial wizard, former Lieut. Luis Felipe de Albuquerque Jr., has created a new problem for authorities through the reluctance of creditors to act against him.

BERLIN, Aug 31. -- In a dramatic effort to capture the imagination of Germans of both the Eastern and Western parts of the divided country the Communist-led government of East Berlin has begun building a showpiece street.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 31 -- Popular election of the President and revision of the Taft-Hartley Act were demanded in resolutions adopted today by the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS), an organization that also includes Korea veterans.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 1 -- President Truman left Union Station at 12:30 A. M. today for the first of a series of speeches on behalf of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 31 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, will fly to Maine Tuesday for a four-day, 1,000-mile whistle-stop trip that Republican state and national leaders hope will pile up an overwhelming majority for the party in the Sept. 8 state election.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 1 -Archibald S. Alexander, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New Jersey, today, called for a revision of the Taft-Hartley Law in a Labor Day speech at the monument of Peter J. McGuire, father of the holiday, at near-by Arlington Cemetery in Pennsauken.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (UP) -Dutch Leonard's wild pitch with the bases filled and one out in the eleventh inning enabled Gus Bell to score the winning run as the Pirates downed the Cubs, 5 -- 4, in the second game of a twin bill today. The Pirates lost the opener, 6 -- 0, before a crowd of 13,031.

The sum of $3,546,500, or almost 70 per cent of the $5,087,855 appropriated by Congress for the civil works functions of the Army Corps of Engineers in New York and New Jersey in the next fiscal year, will go into the improvement and maintenance of waterways in the New York port district.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- G. Edward Grammer, 35-year-old New York office manager, will be arraigned tomorrow on a charge of murdering his 33-year-old wife.

MOST of us feel that the portentous changes, which are transforming life in the twentieth century, are a menace to psychological and emotional stability. Just keeping up with them is a nervous strain and thinking about them too solemnly can lead to profound depression and the psychiatrist's couch. But we inheritors of Western civilization have only seen an alarming acceleration of trends already present in our society for many years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The United States lifted its quarantine against shipments of livestock from Mexico today. This ban was imposed in December, 1946, because of the prevalence of foot-and-mouth disease in that country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Officials of the Naval Medical Center expressed surprise tonight at President Truman's premature statement of regret.
FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 1 -- When Britain's latest aircraft for peace and war went on public display here today the delta wing emerged as the shape of things to come.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -Austin Motor Company announced imediate reductions of more than 10 per cent in the home market prices of its luxury Sheerline and Princess models today.

DARLINGTON, S. C., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Fonty Flock of Decatur, Ga., timing his pit stops to the caution flag, smartly piloted his 1952 Oldsmobile to victory and $9,500 prize money before 30,000 today in the $25,750 Southern 500 stock car race.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Sept. 1 -- Full-scale picketing of at least 115 central New Jersey shipping concerns is scheduled to start at midnight in the second day of a five-county strike by 1,200 members of Local 469, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's call for junking the Taft-Hartley labor law today placed the nation's four leading active political figures in four seemingly different positions on the controversial issue.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 1 -- Two hundred scientists from thirteen nations met here today to open the Third International Congress on Astronautics and discuss man's next great adventure, the conquest of space.
Play in the national amateur lawn tennis championships at Forest Hills was called off yesterday as a result of the violent rainstorm.
Both President Truman and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, were cut off the air yesterday before they had quite finished political addresses.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 1 -- President Truman's Labor Day tour of southern Michigan four years ago was the model for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign kickoff today, and by reason of the President's success an omen of good fortune for Michigan Democrats.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) -Promoter Herman Taylor put more than $1,000,000 worth of tickets on sale today for the Jersey Joe Walcott-Rocky Marciano fight, and said he "hopes" to sell 'em all.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The House Judiciary subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice will enter on Wednesday what may be the final phase of its inquiry and the one that may produce its outstanding result.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 1 -- Miss Lois Curtis, 32 years old, heard a warrant read at her Norwalk Hospital bed today, charging her with murder. The state accused the former woman athlete with responsibility for the death of her father, John W. Curtis, 73, on Saturday.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- A Marine sergeant destined for a second tour in Korea headed glumly back to camp today after spending a seventy-two-hour pass on a 900-mile trip and hundreds of telephone calls searching for his sweetheart.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral defied the mud and put on the power on the clubhouse turn today to smash home a two-length victor in the twenty-fifth running of the Washington Park Handicap and earn $119,900 in the richest handicap race in history.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable made it three straight in the $28,875 Atlantic City Turf Handicap when Greek Ship, carrying top weight of 122 pounds, established a course record for the mile and three-sixteenths in the infield today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 -- President Truman tonight vigorously attacked the Republican campaign theme that the time had come for a change in the National Administration. Instead, he pleaded for a stronger Democratic majority in Congress and for the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, whom he said he believed was the best-qualified Presidential candidate ever nominated by the Democratic party.

Preparations for youngsters to respond to the sounding of the school bell soon will be under way and one of the major preliminaries will be buying their fall wardrobe. Available now in all the stores is an unlimited selection for all age groups and for every occasion.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 (UP) -- Chuck Stevenson of Fresno, Calif., took advantage of a rival's tire trouble today to win the 100-mile American Automobile Association national championship big car race at the Du Quoin State Fair.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- A child who comes through an operation with the least emotional upset is likely to have a home background of love, trust and security that enables him to trust physicians and nurses to treat him fairly, according to a study report in the latest issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and head of the United Steelworkers of America, called upon industry today to join labor in an effort to obtain a guaranteed annual wage for workers.

BLOWING ROCK, N. C., Sept. 1 (UP) -- Ellis G. Arnall, retiring price stabilizer, said today living costs could "shoot sky-high between now and January" unless a special session of Congress was called to strengthen the controls law.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 1 -- How different kinds of organizations ranging from neighborhood groups to international societies can help families help themselves in time of "permanent emergency" has been one of the principal questions occupying specialists gathered for the annual conference of the National Council on Family Relations, now meeting at Rutgers University here.

The twelve-story apartment house at 490 West End Avenue, accommodating sixty-three families, has been sold by Elgin Equities, Inc., of which Julius B. Kahan is president, to the 490 West End Corporation. Goodman Mabel were attorneys for the seller and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 1 -- Willem Drees of the Labor party assumed leadership today of his third and the Netherlands' fifth post-war Cabinet. The decree by Queen Juliana announcing the names of her new ministers marked the formal end of the crisis which had persisted since the June 25 elections.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said today that the Indo-Chinese civil war could end in "a matter of weeks" if the Bao Dai Government had wide popular support.

Governor Stevenson was in the home town of the late Senator Arthur Vandenberg yesterday. He paid a fine tribute to Vandenberg's enlightened thinking and to his contribution to bipartisanship in sound foreign policy. He indicated, moreover, that the basis for bipartisanship still existed when he observed that General Eisenhower was in full accord with those parts of our policy that represent the best interests of the nation and of the free world.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Comedian Bob Hope wise-cracked his way into the hearts of an English vaudeville audience tonight in his first appearance at the Palladium, London's biggest music hall, but he had to work hard to do it.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The National Radio Show, which has just opened here, means a great deal to Britain's $250,000,000 radio industry, which has been fighting a losing battle against sales resistance at home because of the two-thirds purchase tax on radio and TV sets and installment-buying restrictions.
Business and industry are in good shape now and should continue their present activity well into 1953, according to the September letter of the National City Bank of New York.
Labor leaders exhorted their followers in Labor Day talks yesterday to make the most of their opportunity in November to elect a "liberal" Congress.

More persons are running away from home this year than in the last several years. This year is expected to show a 10 per cent increase in runaways over 1951, according to Richard C. Raymond, acting general director of the National Travelers Aid Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -The Athletics overcame two home runs by Ken Wood to beat Washington, 9 -- 8, in the first game of a double-header today, but Gil Coan's homer and triple were too much to overcome in the second game and the Senators won, 4 -- 2.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 -- President Truman said tonight that he had been "falsely informed" that Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, had died. He expressed the hope that Mr. Hull would recover to live many more happy years.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -The Housatonic River rail shooters are not nearly as enthusiastic as the wildfowlers, and in our wandering through two popular wild rice flats this morning we encountered only one other opening-day devotee. He was not happy over the situation.

The average price of real estate bonds made a fractional gain in August to mark the tenth consecutive month of an upward trend, according to Amott, Baker Co. Based on an index of forty bonds, the August advance was 0.1 per cent to bring the gain to date for the year at 5.5 per cent.
MARGATE, England, Sept. 1 -The Trades Union Congress, representing 8,020,079 workers, assembled here today for its eightyfourth congress in a truculent mood.

There has been some preliminary discussion in Philadelphia of the possibility of sending the Liberty Bell for exhibition at the international exposition that will open in the Philippines early next year. The idea is a good one if it can be worked out. Such a gesture on the part of the City of Brotherly Love would be deeply appreciated by the Filipinos and widely understood in its proper significance throughout the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 (UP) -The Rural Electrification Administration said today that 223,000 farm families will receive their first electric service and 55,000 will have telephone for the first time under R. E. A. loans approved in the fiscal year which ended June 30.

TUNIS, Tunisia Sept. 1 (AP) -Representatives from nearly every walk of life in Tunisia today advised Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, the Bey of Tunis, to reject Paris-proposed reforms for this troubled French protectorate.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -The Indian Government thinks Pakistan "may be secretly preparing for another tribal invasion of Kashmir while publicly professing helplessness in preventing it," official sources here said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie reported today that "premature optimism" concerning the capabilities of the United Nations was being replaced by a "more realistic" public appraisal of the world organization's power.

The intricate maneuvering of the great political parties and their wooing of widely divergent interest groups is puzzling not merely to the foreign observer, but I have found that study of John C. Calhoun's theories regarding the concurrent as opposed to the numerical majority casts considerable light on the scene.

A transit operating deficit that rises in successive years from $1,206,043 (1949-50) to $3,067,520 (1950-51) to $24,773,883 (1951-52) can hardly be viewed with satisfaction, even if the annual financial report is accompanied by a downward revision of dire estimates of loss for the current year.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 1 (AP) -- A ball of fire described as having an appearance half as large as the full moon zipped across southwestern skies last night. It excited comment from eastern New Mexico to the California coast.

PORT NORRIS, N. J., Sept. 1 -- The oyster season opened officially here today as the fleet sailed off to start an operation that by next April will put $3,000,000 worth of oysters on the docks of near-by Bivalve

LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Len Muncer, Glamorgan all-rounder, today became the fourth player in first-class English cricket to complete the 1,000-run 100-wicket double this season, with a quick 37 against Worcestershire.

The one-story building and adjoining land at 1318 Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn, have been leased by the F. C. A. Service Company of Camden, N. J., from Richard Zieinsky in a transaction negotiated by Morice Haymes as broker. After alterations have been completed the lessee will occupy the property as an office, shop and parking space for its trucks used in the servicing of television sets in the Brooklyn area.

Examinations for licensed merchant marine officers who desire commissions in the Coast Guard will be held Feb. 23-25 in fifteen major cities, Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Third District, announced here yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (UP) -- An unearned run in the sixth inning gave the Reds a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals in the second game of a double-header today after a pair of first-inning homers powered St. Louis to a 6-0 triumph.

Our hurricanes originate in the West Indian doldrums, an ocean area near the Equator, where calms and light variable winds abound. The cause of the hurricanes is not known exactly. There are two theories:
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers will return to work tomorrow, ending a ten-day memorial holiday that cut the nation's coal stocks by more than 10,000,000 tons.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The National Urban League was told today that one of its most challenging problems was increasing and improving Negro housing.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- The Giants' pitching soared and sagged by turns on this gloomy afternoon and they had to be content with a split of their double-header with the Braves.

CASTEL GONDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Spanish team and the Italian squad it beat in yesterday's first international baseball contest in Italy were received in a special audience by Pope Pius XII today. The teams were accompanied by their managers and high officials of both countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Barbara Stark, 15-year-old Berkeley miss, bettered the American women's 200-meter backstroke record today when she was timed in 2:46.7 in the final day of the Far Western championships.

The Joseph Katz Company, Baltimore and New York agency, threw into high gear yesterday the organization it has been quietly assembling since spring for the Democratic National Committee and the Stevenson campaign. It arranged for the half hour television speech by Governor Stevenson from Detroit on the Columbia Broadcasting System at noon and for the half hour of radio for President Truman's Milwaukee speech last night.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Playing in heavy rain and strong winds that uprooted several small trees along the course, Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., captured the first $15,000 Insurance City Open golf tournament today, with a 72-hole total of 273, eleven under par.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The first of the auto industry's 1953 model automobiles are scheduled to appear this month.
The relatively scant Soviet railroad network in Siberia and Central Asia will be substantially strengthened by new rail construction provided for in the fifth Five-Year Plan.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1 (UP) -Supporters of Nationalist presidential candidate Carlos Ibanez were ordered yesterday to be ready to "act in the streets" if he found it necessary to seize the presidency by force.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Due Date scored his second straight victory at Roosevelt raceway and his fourth in nine outings this season as Henry Myott drove the sturdy 4-year-old to a two-length triumph over Royal King in the Amsterdam Pace tonight.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 -- Furnace yards and Lake Erie docks were holding 25,904,369 tons of ore when the nation-wide strike shut down steel plants in June and this cushion will provide ample insurance against an early freeze on the Great Lakes, Lake Superior Iron Ore Association officials predicted today.

Central Park's Fifty-ninth Street lake mirrors the tall towers of Central Park South. If these waters also reflect the habits of New Yorkers, the residents of this city ought to be ashamed of themselves. The once-beautiful lake has been choked with trash -- candy wrappers, beer cans, food containers, discarded papers and waterlogged slices of bread, originally intended to entice birds, but which now only attract rats.

The Federated Department Stores Inc., reported for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 2 a net income of $14,537,891 after taxes, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $4.08 a share on the common stock. This compares with $16,943,612, or $4.71 a common share in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 4, 1951.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 1 -- Statehood is not a matter of argument in Alaska. Alaskans no longer line up politically as pro-statehood or anti-statehood, but are either for immediate statehood or in favor of statehood at some unspecified time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 1 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer obviously made a good investment when it purchased "Mexican Village," a collection of eleven short stories about life in Hidalgo, a town in the State of Nuevo Leon.
Prizes in the international team chess championship, which was held in Helsinki from Aug. 10 through Sunday, were distributed yesterday, according to a report from Finland.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- John Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, arrived here today to head the United States delegation to the annual meeting of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund.

The texts of the speech by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and of the remarks by Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, together with a letter attributed to Kenneth T. Anderson, Democratic National Committeeman from Kansas, follow as heard by the convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers:
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 2 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,360, for the twenty-four hour's to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:
Following is the text of President Truman's speech last night before a Labor Day rally in Milwaukee as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

I was much interested in your editorial entitled "Trade, Not Aid," which was provoked by the report issued by Ambassador Draper, Special United States Representative in Europe. You find yourself in complete accord with Mr. Draper's great concern over the persistence of the "dollar gap" and with his formula for dealing with it.

De luxe sleeper-plane service between New York and Los Angeles, patterned on trans-Altantic sleeper flights, will be started the night of Sept. 10 by Trans World Airlines with its new fleet of larger and faster Lockheed Super Constellations.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 1 (UP) -- George Hammond of Colorado Springs drove through blinding fog and light snow today to beat the two favored contenders in the thirtieth annual Pikes Peak auto race and set the second best time ever recorded in the event.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- An all-morning rain here not only washed out today's double-header between the Dodgers and Phils but brought on schedule complications that could bring Warren Giles, National League president, into the picture.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 1 -- William H. Abel, president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, who attempted suicide last Friday while Nassau County authorities were investigating an alleged $475,000 swindle of the institution by one of his business associates, was still in critical condition at Nassau Hospital today but members of the family were allowed to visit him briefly.
Anguished concession owners and melancholy Labor Day visitors at mountain, lake and seaside resorts lived through dark, storm-whipped rains yesterday in the last throes of summer.

James E. Reardon, former plainclothes policeman and admitted associate in Harry Gross' $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking combine, will be sentenced at 10 A. M. today in Kings County Court on a charge of perjury in the first degree.

THIS might seem slightly out of season. Excuse it, please. However, the hockey people recently got around to adding six more immortals to their Hall of Fame, a refrigerated version of baseball's Cooperstown. Four of them are strangers of sorts to this reporter. The fifth is the well-known figure of Bill Cook, the Ranger coach. But the sixth is the chap who always has fascinated this department more than any other, Nels Stewart.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Sept. 1 (UP) -- The politically powerful Long family, which suffered its worst defeat last February at the hands of Gov. Robert F. Kennon, has a good Chance of winning tomorrow in a Democratic Congressional run-off election.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida opened his campaign for the Oct. 1 general election today when he called on the Japanese to lay a "spiritual and material" basis for national rearmament and to collaborate with the United States, Britain and the United Nations.

Your editorial of Aug. 19 based on a dispatch from your Rio de Janeiro correspondent, Sam Pope Brewer, brings to my mind another editorial written by you many months ago which referred to anti-American feeling in countries south of the Rio Grande. Your comment at the time was that "a generation ago there was often good reason for it, but that it should still exist in spite of our good neighbor policy is baffling."

The lost and found advertisements suggest that one of the articles most frequently lost or mislaid by men is the briefcase. Scarcely a week passes that three or four black or brown briefcases are not reported lost by owners who, the wording of the advertisements indicates, will be seriously handicapped in their enterprises until the missing articles are returned.

The important assignment of staging the sketches for the new Charles Sherman revue, "Two's Company," in which Bette Davis will be starred, has fallen to Jules Dassin, Broadway and Hollywood writer-director. James Russo and Michael Ellis, producers of the musical, reached an agreement with Mr. Dassin over the week-end.

Despite the rain of the open-the-sluice-gates variety in the morning, and on-and-off, wind-whipped downpours during the afternoon, a crowd of 30,609 persons checked in at the Aqueduct track yesterday for the metropolitan area's first running-horse program since the move to Saratoga Springs a month ago.

John Holmes, vice president of Celanese Corporation of America, textile division, has been special assistant to K. C. Loughlin, vice president and general sales manager of the division. J. C. Cook has been named sales manager for knitted fabrics in the division.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -Sharp Note, winner of the 1952 Hambletonian, trotted the two fastest miles of the year for 3-year-olds in winning the Grand Circuit $24,703 Horseman Futurity today.

A tightened control of building in fast-growing Queens is being prepared under the direction of Borough President James A. Lundy, along with a parallel reorganization of borough administration and procedures growing out of the widening sewer investigation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The United States will support discussion of the Korean question at the 1952 session of the General Assembly, whether an armistice has been concluded by that time or not, Ernest A. Gross, deputy United States representative to the United Nations, said tonight.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Steve Wittman, 48-year-old airplane designer from Oshkosh, Wis., zipped around a 37 1/2-mile, six-pylon course, averaging 197.29 miles per hour today to win the sixth annual $20,000 Continental Motors Trophy Race.

Preliminary estimates of aggregate taxes collected by all arms of government in the fiscal year of 1952 approach $86,500,000,000, according to the National Industrial Conference Board. The figure is $16,000,000,000 or 22 per cent more than in 1951, which in turn saw 25 per cent more collected than in the year preceding the outbreak of the Korean war.

Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night may stay the United States mailmen from the swift completion of their appointed rounds, but yesterday's rain disrupted plans of the National Association of Letter Carriers for a parade up Fifth Avenue.
Electric Bond and Share Company yesterday reported net earnings of $5,561,938, equal to $1.06 a share, for the twelve months ended June 30.

CHAPLIN, Conn., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Constitution party lost its national chairman and co-chairman today because, the former said, some of its members had made statements that sounded anti-Semitic. The resignations of Mrs. Suzanne Silvercruys Stevenson as chairman and Percy L. Greaves Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., as co-chairman were announced by Mrs. Stevenson at her home here.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (UP) -- The Browns and a couple of rainstorms put a serious crimp in the Indians' bid for the American League pennant today as seventh-place St. Louis captured the five-inning second game of a double-header, 2 -- 1, after the Tribe had romped to a 9-3 verdict in the opener.

A new boat house for the Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park will be ready next summer, according to the Department of Parks, which announced yesterday that a gift of $250,000 by Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Loeb of 910 Fifth Avenue would make the improvement possible.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- Thousands of holidaying Detroiters flocked to Wayne Major Airport today to view the fifth annual International Aviation Exposition sponsored over the Labor Day week-end by the Aero Club of Michigan.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., Sept. 1 -- The Police Conference of the State of New York will hold its annual conference at Lido Beach Hotel from tomorrow through Friday. Senator Irving M. Ives will speak at the Friday morning session. State Controller J. Raymond McGovern will be heard at a dinner tomorrow night.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- The Navy followed up its massive bombing raids at Siberia's doorstep with smashing blows by air and sea yesterday at the big Korean port of Chongjin.

Either industry should base wages on family needs or the Government should provide family allowances under the Social Security program, it was suggested here yesterday at the eighth annual Labor Day mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Michael John Nevin has sold the three-family building at 104-36 104th Street in Ozone Park, Queens, to Michael Lapolla. The Liberty Realty Company was the broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 1 -Angry housewives, taking up a strike their husbands had dropped, have paralyzed one of Brazil's railroad systems in the state of Minas Geraes, according to reports received from that area.

VINTON, Iowa, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan asserted today that "a basic conflict in the philosophy of the farm price support program is the crux of the political campaign this year, the same as it was four years ago."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, asserted in a Labor Day speech today that the Republicans had no real desire to change the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Relations Act, but wanted to retain it to "sabotage union organization."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is primed for a two-fisted attack on "the mess in Washington," particularly corruption in the Bureau of Internal Revenue, during a two-day invasion of the South, which starts today, according to Arthur H. Vandenberg, the Republican Presidential candidate's executive assistant.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 -- District Attorney George M. Fanelli of Westchester County questioned three persons today in connection with the murder of John Acropolis, Westchester labor leader, but refused to identify them beyond saying they had been acquainted with Mr. Acropolis' movements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -The Agriculture Department predicted today that meat supplies for the remainder of the year would be about the same as they were a year ago and that prices would make no marked change from present figures.
Baccara, the restaurant Frank Di Lello has just opened at 203 East Forty-fifth Street, offers the superb cuisine and meticulous service of the Old World in a setting that is handsomely modern.

ATHENS, Sept. 1 -- Mose Pijade, chairman of the presidium of the Yugoslav National Assembly and leader of a group of fourteen members of the Assembly on a visit to Greece, told the press tonight that "the best possible impression of Greece and her people" had been gained during the ten-day tour.

Roger Crafts has been elected personnel director of the American Mutual Liability Insurance Company, with Miss Marion D. Russell as his assistant, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles E. Hodges, president. Mr. Crafts succeeds Ralph H. Wales, vice president, who has served as personnel director since 1936 and is now retiring.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- Speed boats and their pilots have been noted traditionally for their dare-devil-try, but today Old Mother Nature gave them a bad licking in the middle of the annual Silver Cup regatta. A Detroit river that had been reasonably tranquil suddenly was churned into raging waves by a thunder and lightning squall that pelted the fleet with rain and with winds up to near-gale force.

BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 1 -- The fleet of 140 which sailed Saturday in the first day's racing of the three-day Bellport Bay Yacht Club invitation regatta dwindled to seventy starters today. Fifty craft finished as another day of rough sailing marked the final races.

The latest experiment in trying to reform and reclaim the criminal tribes of India will be watched with interest and sympathy by all who ever had anything to do with India -- and not the least by the former British civil servants. There is a long and depressing history of efforts and experiments made by Britons and foreign missionaries, with Indian cooperation, to reform these hereditary criminals or at least to restrain their professional propensities.

LONDON, Sept 1 -- There were reports here today that W. Alton Jones, Cities Service head, who has been taking a look at the idle Iranian oil industry, might come to London on his way back to the United States.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and his Government would welcome a more specific definition of just what the joint Churchill-Truman offer to settle the Iranian oil question means.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Prof. Eric W. Marchand of Rochester University won his adjourned ninth-round game from Charles R. Heising of Cincinnati after sixty-two moves in the annual tournament for the state chess title held in the Cazenovia Junior College gymnasium today to gain custody of the Paul Morgan Trophy.

Leaders of organized crime who are lying low because of recent investigations and prosecutions are ready to break out in a new rash of racketeering throughout the nation, the Commission on Organized Crime of the American Bar Association warned yesterday.
Following a day of uncertainty and considerable disappointment as rain washed out yesterday afternoon's double-header at the Stadium the Yankees finally were able to turn something to good account.

HARRISON, N. J., Sept. 1 -Fifty-one Pennsylvania Railroad passenger trains, including the crack Congressional Limited and two sections of the Senator, were delayed by a power wire failure here today for periods from five minutes to two hours and nineteen minutes.

Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address in Cadillac Square, Detroit, yesterday that formally opened his campaign for President, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, and his speeches at Grand Rapids, Hamtramck and Flint, as carried by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Psychologists should offer their services free to families, individuals and administrative groups in exchange for the chance to test theories or build new ones about human relationships, Dr. J. McV. Hunt, president of the American Psychological Association, said today.

VIENNA, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Staff Capt. Emil Zatopek, Czechoslovakia's track star and winner of three Olympic gold medals, was inferentially warned today to stop acting like a "prima donna" and pay more attention to "defense of the people's democracy."

NEW HOPE, Pa., Sept. 1 -- For summer visitors who prefer contemporary designs to the antiques usually available in this town that sometimes seems primarily designed for shopping, a new note has been added. It is a small salesroom in the Delaware Bookshop and is devoted to the work of Japanese artisans.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 1 -- William J. MacDonald, United States Weather Bureau observer at Swan Island, was in Gorgas Hospital here today with an undefined malady after a 1,400-mile rescue flight by the Air Force. His condition has shown improvement since his arrival.
Labor Day week-enders and other summer vacationists were whip-lashed homeward yesterday by cat-o'-ninetails rain created by gusts that hit the metropolis at forty-five to seventy miles an hour.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The London stock market lost some of its recent buoyancy today and for the first time in several weeks closed on a dull note.

PAWLING, N. Y., Sept. 1 -Champion Ditton Priors' Rudraigme, Kerry blue terrier owned by Mrs. Charles R. Fleishman of North Hollywood, Calif., was named best in show at the tenth annual fixture of the Mid-Hudson Kennel Club held on the estate of Mrs. John K. Branch on Quaker Hill today.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept. 1 -- The enormous organizational difficulties that confront the next Secretary of Defense are well illustrated by the sheer size, the great power and the tremendous complexity of this naval task force.

Bus transportation for an estimated 30,000 riders on the Bee Lines, Inc., and two of its subsidiaries on Long Island will still be missing this morning as a strike of 220 drivers and maintenance workers on the three lines goes into its fifth day.

Belittlement of fears when real danger impends is a public disservice. The Secretary of Commerce, by using statistics of the Short period when the angle spread is not wide, serves the party in power when an election is impending but soft pedals the larger, more serious consequences which may eventuate not many moons away.

TORONTO, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- A crowd of 25,000 today jammed the Canadian National Exhibition grandstand and saw Rev. Bob Richards, the Olympic pole vault champion, push himself to record heights for the second time in three days.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois told the working people and the foreign minority groups of this key electoral state today that he would work for their interests -- including repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and the liberation of the Communist-dominated nations of Eastern Europe.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Miguel Aleman pledged anew today Mexico's determination "to defend the continent against any outside aggression" and promised faithful fulfillment of the nation's obligations under the United Nations Charter and the Inter-American Treaty of Mutual Assistance.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 2 -- The Communists protested again yesterday against "barbarous" treatment of their prisoners in United Nations camps in South Korea and demanded an accounting from the Allied armistice delegation at Panmunjom.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 1 (AP) -Grantor won the $25,000-added Del Mar Handicap today.
MIAMI, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A very dangerous tropical hurricane, with winds up to 135 miles an hour, lashed the Atlantic into mountainous seas today about 1,000 miles east-southeast of Miami.

Premier Stalin was the chief architect of the Communist revolution in China and Mao Tse-tung, Peiping chief, was successful because he applied the Russian leader's theoretical concepts, according to a major Pravda article published since the recent arrival in Moscow of Chou En-lai, Communist China's Premier.

LAURENCE HARBOR, N. J., Sept. 2 (UP) -- A 20-year-old telephone operator whose long-distance romance with a Marine sergeant has been badly snarled said today she hoped the Marines would make an exception and give her sweetheart another leave before he is shipped to Korea.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered a local of the Teamsters union, A. F. L., to reinmburse thirty-one employes for the $25 initiation fees and dues for seven months each was required to pay under a union shop agreement that was illegally extended to a new plant.
Gales and rain that ruined the Labor Day week-end for vacationers also saved lives that might otherwise have been lost on this most dangerous of holidays.

A reliable source felt certain yesterday that the Fulton would receive George Axelrod's's new comedy, "The Seven Year Itch," around Nov. 20. However, Louis Lotito, president of City Playhouses, who is in charge of the Fulton, reported that terms hadn't been discussed yet with the producers, Courtney Burr and Elliott Nugent. The house is available, though.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 2 -- It may be a couple of decades before man is able to venture into outer space, but the legal mind is already at work on problems of law east of the sun and west of the moon.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 2 -- President Truman today bitterly indicted the Republican party for what he termed a resort to "gutter politics" in foreign policy and a willingness to risk atomic war in Europe in a delusive effort to win votes.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

James E. Reardon, former plain-clothes policeman and admitted associate of Harry Gross, bookmaker, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to a term of two and a half to five years in Sing Sing Prison on conviction last July of perjury in the first degree.

BOSTON, Sept 2 -- Gov. Paul A. Dever rejected today the demand of Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican candidate for Governor, for a special session of the Massachusetts Legislature to repeal the so-called "Curley" pension law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- A new antidote to combat the effects of nerve gas poisons that might be employed against the United States in a chemical warfare attack was described today at the seventeenth annual Assembly of the Internationla College of Surgeons.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Angered at the umpires and the Browns, the Indians lodged a protest with the American League today over yesterday's second game with the Brownies.

WHEN Robert Burns wrote "A chield's amang you takin' notes" he put in a nutshell the source of much literary inspiration. It is the child observing his elders, storing away memories and impressions, who often grows up to be a writer spinning stories out of his own experience like a spider its thread out of his own body.

Tribute to the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, now celebrating its fifty-third anniversary as a free nonsectarian center for needy tuberculous patients, has been paid by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

It is a well-known fact that the main reason for the decline of public confidence in politicians in particular, and politics in general, is the cynical disregard by most politicians of the public interest.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Mrs. Lillian B.
