Robinson, 48-year-old business executive arrested last Thursday on a charge of swindling $475,000 from the Central National Bank of Mineola through forged loan applications, was brought back into First District Court here today for her bail to be increased from $10,000 to $40,000.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept, 2 -- The vexing problem of military organization, relatively simple at sea, tremendously difficult at policy-making levels ashore, is certain to be one of the continuing headaches of the new Administration next January.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Only small fractions of the working class in Paris go to church, according to a fragmentary survey recently conducted by Roman Catholic priests in scattered parishes in the French capital and suburbs.

NEWARK, Sept. 2 -- Martin J. McHugh of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service called a conference for tomorrow at 10 A. M. between officials of Local 478, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., and truck operators in Essex and Union Counties, in the first Federal move to settle the two-day-old strike of 2,300 truck drivers in this area.
There is much with which we can agree and some with which we must disagree in Governor Stevenson's labor program presented in Detroit on Labor Day.

A new record for a month's loadings in the fifty-one-year history of the Pittsburgh Steamship Fleet was established last month, said D. C. Potts, president of this United States Steel Company division.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., Sept. 2 (UP) -- A World War II veteran was excused from serving a prison term for taking part in Ku Klux Klan activity today because he became shell-shocked in the Pacific.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 2 (UP) -- While Governor Stevenson devised his plans for the impending Western campaign trip today, one of his chief antagonists, Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, came to town to continue his attacks on him.
ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Summer business boomed at New York's vacation resorts, the State Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Ernst Heinkel, who stopped building German bombers and jet fighters with the defeat of the Nazis, gave high praise today to Britain's latest aircraft on display at the Farnborough air show.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 -- George Edward S. Grammer, office and personnel manager for the Molybdenum Climax Company at 500 Fifth Avenue in New York City, was held without bail in Central Police Court here today in connection with the "perfect murder" of his wife, Mrs. Dorothy May Grammer, mother of his three children, on Aug. 20.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 2 -- A new hopeful feeling about the International Monetary Fund is evident among delegates gathered here for the annual meetings of the fund and its sister organization, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 2 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois began concentrating today on the series of speeches he will make on his Western trip starting Friday.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has printed two editorials on the speeches of the major candidates for President before the American Legion. It was pointed out that General Eisenhower had-withheld any comment on the attitudes and philosophy of Senator McCarthy. Governor Stevenson was applauded for his forthrightness in meeting the problems posed by this issue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Library of Congress is about to open a special exhibit for the most popular book ever printed -- the Bible.

VIENNA, Sept. 2 -- Both Maurice Schumann, French Secretary of State and Foreign Affairs, who is in Vienna for a three-day visit, and Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, agreed today that the recent Russian answer to the notes of the Western powers left room for a resumption of negotiations for an Austrian treaty.

Net sales of the International Harvester Company set a new high in the nine months ended with July but earnings fell $9,954,000 from the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday.
Separates from Macy's newly added Little Shop of Duets were featured yesterday when the store opened a new section on the second floor where all the "little shops" are now in one large room.

Forty-one days ago the steel strike was settled -- and only now has the industry gotten its production back to theoretical capacity. Still, the comeback was a little faster than usual after a major strike. Operations this week are scheduled at 100 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Capt. John W. Anderson, master of the superliner United States, disclosed here yesterday on the arrival of his ship that he had veered eight miles off course Sunday in an attempt to avoid any false rumors that he was seeking to race the Cunrad liner Queen Elizabeth to New. York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Staging pickets invaded the Federal Building and disrupted a hearing of the House Un-American Activities Committee today while witnesses testified that their union was ridden with Communists.

Central Park means many things to the many people who use it. It affords a scenic patch of greenery to those who live and work in towers of stone and steel. They can find all sorts of recreational opportunities there -- rowing on the lake, carrousel rides and visits to the zoo for the youngsters, summertime concerts on the Mall.

Women active in behalf of the Youth Consultation Service have been holding luncheon meetings recently in the Garden of the Ambassador to further the sale of tickets for the Nov. 13 performance of "Dial 'M' for Murder," a new melodrama with Maurice Evans at the Plymouth Theatre.

MIAMI, Sept. 2 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower struck hard today on the issue of corruption in Washington and scored an impressive personal triumph on the first campaign invasion of the deep South by any Republican Presidential nominee.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 2 -- New allocations of Thailand rice to the hungry Asian countries are being delayed here because of the international and domestic difficulties involved.

Net profits of member banks in the Second Federal Reserve district in the first half of the year were $106,300,000, a gain of $9,900,000, or 10.3 per cent, from that of the corresponding period in 1951, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

While conceding to John Foster Dulles his sincerity and his concern, which most of us share, for the captive peoples of Eastern Europe, it is this writer's opinion that his announced plan for rolling back Soviet power is dangerously inopportune and might well render tragic disservice to the very people for whom he pleads.

BANFF, Alta., Sept. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas said today the United States faces an inevitable shortage of petroleum unless more reserves are found and there is an improvement in production recovery.

In all his thirty-one years on the city police force, Patrolman Frederick Bauer never had to use his service revolver until yesterday, when he shot and captured two men who tried to mug him in a building at 1864 Seventh Avenue, near 113th Street.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Most of the nation's coal miners ended their 1952 memorial holiday today, returning to work after a ten-day mourning period for victims of mine tragedies.

Thousands of wide-eyed, somewhat apprehensive youngsters will be taken by their parents today, tomorrow or Friday to be registered for the first time in the city's public elementary schools, which will open for the fall term on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett said today that a first look at military budget estimates for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 indicated there might be somewhat less armed forces spending than this year.

A strike by 2,000 workers in thirteen ship repair yards in Brooklyn and Staten Island appeared imminent yesterday when yard operators and representatives of five American Federation of Labor unions broke off negotiations after a futile meeting at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 2 -- Kazem Hassibi, a member of the Iranian Oil Commission, who drafted the oil nationalization laws as deputy to the Finance Minister last year, announced today that the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company owed Iran $1,000,000,000.

The merging of the arts and crafts appears to be increasing in importance in contemporary home furnishings. An example is apparent in the designing of young William Christopher, who divides his working day, half for painting and half of making furniture. Both activities go on under the same roof.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Comparing the Republican party with "a cross-eyed old man, trying to look both ways at once," Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic candidate for Vice President, declared tonight that the Republican farm platform was belled by its members' voting records in Congress.
Frank Sedgman was put to his first real test in defense of his title in the national tennis championships yesterday as play was resumed at Forest Hills following Monday's rain storm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A new psychological service in vocational counseling will be started shortly by the Veterans Administration, Vice Admiral Joel T. Boone (retired), Chief Medical Director of the Veterans Administration, announced today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Putting on a fine stretch drive that brought him home first by a half-length, Hedgewood Fingo, 4-year-old bay owned by M. Penuel and E. P. Holloway of Frankford, Del., won the Tonawanda, the classified pacing feature, before 12,866 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Two taverns and three hotels in midtown Manhattan were robbed of about $7,385 between 3:45 and 6 A. M. yesterday. Seven armed men carried out the robberies.

A minimum of 15,000 pints of blood must be collected this month to meet both the military and civilian needs, Dr. William M. Markel, administrator of the New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program, announced yesterday. August yielded only 9,342 pints, the lowest total in the last twelve months, he explained.

The Yankees closed their last major home stand of the year on a resounding note at the Stadium yesterday as they blanked Lou Boudreau's Red Sox in both ends of the day-and-night program for a clean sweep of the three-game series.

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- The Canadian Government is preparing to referee an international battle royal over $500,000,000 in contracts that will go into the St. Lawrence seaway power and development project.

ALTHOUGH surfcasters exhibit less interest in contests than the rest of the angling brotherhood, with the possible exception of fly fishermen, few of them are averse to accepting rewards that are the result of their fishing skill and luck, which may account for the popularity of the Martha's Vineyard Striped Bass Derby.

Both the Census Bureau and the National Industrial Conference Board have come forward within the past few days with illuminating data on the burden of taxation borne by the American people. Their estimates differ somewhat. The Census Bureau puts the per capita tax load last year at $412; the Conference Board estimates it at $557.

A new class of chemicals, found to inhibit a chemical known to produce high blood pressure in animals, has been synthesized here at the laboratories of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research by Dr. D. W. Woolley and Dr. Elliott N. Shaw.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe, made a fervent and specific appeal here today for the ratification of the European Defense Communists Treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies.

It is a misguided man who does not place a day on the river near the top of his personal list of simple pleasures. This pleasure can be derived from the combination of any day with any river, for the changing seasons change only the outward signs of the pleasure and not the fact of the pleasure itself.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Channing H. Tobias, director of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, found fault today with the civil rights planks of the Democratic and Republican party platforms, contending that both conventions had ignored the impact of racial discrimination at home upon United States leadership of the free nations.
Henry Morgan, who has been in and out of radio and television in recent years, returned to radio on Monday and is being heard over station WJZ, Mondays through Fridays, from 6 to 6:14 P. M.

After a two-week recess granted to give defense lawyers more time to prepare their cases, the departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen accused of taking bookmaking graft from Harry Gross will be resumed at 10 A. M. today in the Criminal Court Building.

A profile of Hong Kong, the British Colony on China's southern coast, by Christopher Rand, a foreign correspondent, will be published on Sept. 22 by Knopf. It will be entitled "Hong Kong, the Island Between." Mr. Rand, who spent seven years in China, gives a personal impression of the crossroads city that has become the main news-gathering point for the Occident about Communist China.

One of four men being questioned early today in the Central Park police station about an alleged robbery in the park was shot and wounded by two detectives when, the police said, he fled from the police building, which is on the Eighty-sixth Street Transverse Road.

For twelve years the paving around a manhole in the Rock-aways sank repeatedly. It was when engineers for Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens found out why last March that the current Queens sewer investigations got under way, and are now expanded to a point, where, Mr. Lundy said yesterday, "let's say ten" cases and at least three contractors are involved.

A fifteen-day workhouse sentence and a $634 fine were imposed yesterday in Traffic Court on a New Jersey driver who admitted ignoring thirty-three traffic law violations. Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh handed out the penalties to Richard Sawicki, 24 years old, of 141 Paterson Street, New Brunswick, a physical therapy student under the G. I. Bill of Rights and a part-time waiter.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Al Femminelli and Doug Abrams of Old Oaks posted a seven-under-par 33, 31 -- 64 at the Hampshire Country Club today to win best-ball honors in the weekly pro-amateur one-day tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association.
The Incres liner Nassau will arrive here at 9:30 A. M. today to end a series of thirty-six, six and seven-day cruises between Nassau and New York on which she carried a total of 12,000 passengers.

MAYNARD, Mass., Sept. 2 -- Mysterious assailants, who fired nearly a dozen shots, twice attacked the home of Park F. Stone, editor of The Maynard Enterprise, a weekly newspaper, last night and early this morning. Neither Mr. Stone nor his wife was injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A multilateral agreement by the United States and eleven other countries to tighten controls on transshipment of strategic commodities was announced by the Department of Commerce today.

The British Trades Union Congress, which is holding its annual conference this week, has no exact American equivalent. It has been compared to the Security Council, but with 187 members all possessed of the veto power in their own field. The T. U. C. is a representative and advisory body of all the unions.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 2 (UP) -- Much of the nation's B-36 atomic bomber fleet was threatened by fire today as workmen rushed to mop up high octane gasoline that flooded Carswell Air Force Base here after a sudden 100-mile-an-hour windstorm destroyed or damaged about thirty of the huge bombers.

A spreading convinction that Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, could have been drafted as the Democratic candidate for United States Senator except for the refusal of Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn to step aside is proving a major obstacle to obtaining the Liberal party's endorsement of Mr. Cashmore.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Drivers and maintenance men of Bee Line, Inc., and its two subsidiary lines ended their four-day wildcat strike here this afternoon in time to handle homeward-bound commuter traffic.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Prices rose on the stock markets today. The improvement was ascribed partly to the renewed warning against excessive wage demands by the Trades Union Congress and partly to belief that figures for the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves would show a rise during August.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with active months up 26 to 59 points net.

The retirement age for women office employes of the Prudential Insurance Company has been extended to 65 years from 60 years, the company announced yesterday. This brings them up to the same retirement basis as male employes. While the normal retirement age has been set at 65, women still may retire at 60 if they elect.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Japan's application for membership in the United Nations was placed before the Security Council today in the face of indications from the Soviet Union that it would veto Tokyo's bid.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- To maintain its independence from the Council of Europe, the Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community, or Schuman plan, will meet in quarters outside the council's building when it convenes in Strasbourg Sept. 10, according to word received from Strasbourg today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 2 -- Some of the obstacles on India's hard road to prosperity and democracy are exemplified in the difficulties encountered in the capital here by the chief of an obscure tribe in the State of Madhya Pradesh, in central India, who was elected to the Central Parliament.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's speech here today:

I have read with great interest your able correspondent Robert Trumbull's stories of Aug. 26 and 31 about the danger of Communist Chinese infiltration into India through the bordering states of Tibet, Nepal, Bhutan and Sikkim. In your editorial comment of Aug. 26 you have opined that Prime Minister Nehru should "do his best to help the patriotic Tibetans who are bravely making life miserable for their Chinese conquerors."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Theron Lamar Caudle, who was dismissed by President Truman last November from his post as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Tax Division of the Department of Justice, spent five hours in executive session today with the House Judiciary subcommittee that is investigating the Justice Department.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas arrived here today from Saigon on a new stage of his extensive Far Eastern tour and declared he had found over-all conditions in Southeast Asia on "the plus side." He added, however, there was still "a long way to go" in establishing stability in this area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Mike Fornieles, 20-year-old Cuban right-hander pitching his first major league game, held the Athletics to one hit as the Senators scored a 5-0 victory in the second game of a double-header after winning the first game, 3 -- 2, in ten innings.

Net earnings of National Airlines, Inc., in the year ended June 30, amounted to $2,048,300, or $2.05 a share, compared with $2,589,073 in the previous year, the company reported yesterday. The latest earnings, G. T. Baker, president, explained to stockholders, were achieved despite a $1,022,240 decline in airmail compensation and a 24 per cent rise in operating expenses.

Under a bold ride by Conn McCreary, Arnold Skjeveland's Flaunt captured the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Rated as next to the outsider in the wagering in the field of six, Flaunt staged a stretch run that thrilled the crowd of 16,950 as he beat C. V. Whitney's Cold Command by a neck in the seven-furlong event.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Big Ten football coaches look to one of their most hotly contested title races in recent years this season with perhaps as many as five teams in the thick of it.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 2 -- Countries receiving refugees do not sufficiently concern themselves with the adaptation of the immigrants to their new circumstances, according to a report to the World Federation for Mental Health, which ended its annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The creation of a Board of Passport Appeals, to advise the Secretary of State on refusals of passports to United States citizens, was announced at the State Department today.

Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road, polled recently on what kind of new cars they would like to ride in, voted for the coaches with the most seats, but the line announced yesterday that it was modifying the commuters' choice.

There is no logical economic reason why controls on shoes should not be lifted under the suspension order issued last Friday by the Office of Price Stabilization, the National Shoe Manufacturers Association said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- Red Star, organ of the Soviet armed forces, charged today that the "threat of widening American aggression in Asia and the Pacific ocean region" has increased and that the United States is planning the creation of an "international Asiatic army."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 2 -- Vice Admiral J. H. Cassady, commander of the United States Sixth Fleet, in the Mediterranean, is scheduled to arrive on Sept. 11 with a squadron composed of the giant aircraft carrier Coral Sea, the heavy cruiser Salem and four destroyers for a four-day visit in Yugoslav waters.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman criticized local officials yesterday as having created "economic ghettos" in this city through geographic concentration of subsidized housing, and set forth his own ideas on "unstratified" housing development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. (UP) -- Former Senator Millard E. Tydings berated Maryland's Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin again today for accepting a $7,000 cash gift at a recent testimonial dinner and demanded that the Governor list all donors and their business backgrounds.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The United States Amy rifle team scored 943 points out of 1,000 to win the National Trophy team championship in today's final matches of the National Highpower rifle competition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Government today refused to permit an increase in the 10 cents a thousand cubic feet ceiling price of natural gas sold at the Woodlawn field in Harrison County, Tex.

The South saw something new yesterday, a Republican candidate for the Presidency in the campaign season. General Eisenhower's break with tradition in making his trip into Georgia, Florida, Alabama and Arkansas is a wholesome development on the American political scene.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Delegates to the twenty-second annual convention of the Oil Workers International Union, C.I.O., endorsed today a policy of seeking wage increases based on increased annual productivity in the industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- Mario Lanza apparently twisted the tail of Leo the Lion once too often. Tonight, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, roaring like its famous trademark, announced the "abandonment" of plans to film "The Student Prince" and attributed the decision to "the persistent failure of Mario Lanza to report for the start of filming."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board will begin an inquiry tomorrow designed to settle the future of nonscheduled airlines and end the wrangling between these concerns and scheduled air carriers.
Apropos of school opening next Monday, we had a talk yesterday with Kevin Howard, acting director of the school lunch program in New York City.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Members of the National Council on Family Relations closed their annual conference today basically divided in opinion on what the organization's future policy should be. One faction wishes the association to expand greatly in membership and scope and move, when necessary, as an action group on public matters influencing family life.
Futures markets in cocoa, potatoes and wool acted up yesterday, all breaking on new developments peculiarly their own. Sugar, also with significant news, spent the day digesting it.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Informed of news reports that the Iranian Government would welcome a clearer definition of the British and United States proposals for a settlement of the British-Iranian oil dispute, official quarters remarked here today that the proposals had been left deliberately vague.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 2 -- The Belgian Government is being strongly attacked for its decision to grant clemency to wartime Nazi collaborators. Socialist members of both chambers have asked for the immediate recall of Parliament from its summer recess and patriotic associations demanded today the resignation of the Minister of Justice, Joseph Pholien.

The weekly digest of trends by the retail division of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association augurs well for coming retail advertising in newspapers and other media.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The White Sox, in a bid for the first division, swept a double-header from the last-place Tigers today, taking the opener, 6 -- 5 on Rocco Krsnich's two-run triple in the ninth, and the nightcap, 7 -- 4 with a twelve-hit blast off Billy Hoeft.

District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens said yesterday that he had reopened the case of Louis Hoffner, now in Clinton Prison, Dannemora, N. Y., where he has served nearly twelve years of a life sentence for murder. Hoffner was convicted of killing Peter Trifon, a bartender, in an attempted hold-up of a Jamaica tavern Aug. 8, 1940.

Dollar sales volume of major New York and Brooklyn department stores last month was down 13 per cent from the level of the month last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. August thereby continued the streak of monthly volume declines that has prevailed for department store sales throughout this year.
UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, recalled some United Nations history for the benefit of the Security Council today, but left out two pertinent facts.

Obviously displeased by the long delay of the City Council in adopting a local law to limit incineration of refuse and garbage to daylight hours, the Board of Smoke Control has moved to accomplish the same end by departmental regulation.

Rehabilitation of the severely handicapped patient is like any other form of education in that it must prepare him to study problems and obstacles as they arise, it was emphasized here yesterday at the opening of the third annual convention of the American Association of Rehabilitation Therapists.

The delicate business of pulling a cumbersome electric cable across the Narrows between Brooklyn and Staten Island began yesterday afternoon. The pipe-type cable, a mile and a third long, is the first and the longest of its type in this area and is believed by Consolidated Edison Company engineers to be the longest such cable in the world. Therein lies the rub.

Since returning from the Helsinki Olympic games I have been deluged with questions as to why the Olympics are not held in New York City. When the games were held on American soil St. Louis was honored in 1904 and Los Angeles in 1932.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 3 -- The controlled Peiping radio called today for the indictment as a war criminal of Maj. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, former commander of the United Nations prisoner-of-war stockades in South Korea, who was in charge during the bloody rioting early this summer.

One hundred scientists and scholars began a four-day conference last night on the bases of communication and thought, symbols and values. The conference, under the auspices of the Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life, is being held at the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street.

A $5,000 trophy made by four handicapped patients at the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled will be presented by President Truman tomorrow in Washington to Niles S. Josefson of Franklin Park, Ill., cited by the President's Committee for the Employment of the Handicapped for the "most outstanding contribution in the field of employment of the handicapped" in 1952.

Plans for a city-wide atomic air raid test on the night of Tuesday, Sept. 30, will receive close study this morning in the civil defense headquarters of Director Arthur W. Wallander, at 425 Avenue of the Americas, it was announced yesterday.

Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation announced an amended plan yesterday for the liquidation of its assets. The company is a registered holding company with its chief asset, other than current assets, consisting of all stock of the North Penn Gas Company.
Eugene E. Morton has been elected president of the Hilo Varnish Corporation, succeeding Carl J. Schumann, who has resigned as president and director, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Large export sales of wheat to Spain and Italy caused more active buying today on the Board of Trade, and the market continued the upturn that started last Friday. The strength in wheat stimulated more active buying of corn, oats and rye.
COUDERSPORT, Pa., Sept. 2 -- A 35-year-old airport operator was charged today with the fatal shooting of a Harvard University student and seriously wounding the son of Grover Cleveland Bergdoll.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 -- Authorities in the State of Minas Geraes said today that the railroad strike that had tied up the state's rail system since Saturday had been terminated.
Following are the prepared texts of the addresses by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday afternoon at Atlanta, Ga., and last night at Jacksonville and Miami, Fla., as carried by The Associated Press:
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 2 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois is moving slowly but steadily to the Left in his campaign for the Presidency.

Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation announced an amended plan yesterday for the liquidation of its assets. The company is a registered holding company with its chief asset, other than current assets, consisting of all stock of the North Penn Gas Company.

Margaret Truman returned home yesterday from a two-month tour of Europe anxious to resume her musical career, but at the same time reiterating her desire to aid Gov. Adlai Stevenson in his campaign for the Presidency, if invited to do so.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 2 -- The British trade unions gave the Western policy of rearming to resist aggression a smashing vote of confidence today. By majorities well in excess of two-thirds, the Trades Union Congress, in votes taken according to the actual membership strength of constituent unions, rejected three resolutions critical of Britain's participation in the Western defense program and supported the T. U. C. General Council in favoring massive rearmament.

Because of the heavy financial load put on the city's expense budget by the costs of operating large capital projects, the city should not commit itself to any new hospital construction beyond that provided for in the 1952 capital budget, Mayor Impellitteri was told yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame in a report.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- What the Dodgers needed tonight was another rainstorm. Instead, they ran into a storm of home runs, triples and other hits and dropped both ends of a twilight-night double-header to the Phils, 8 -- 2 and 9 -- 3, before 28,582.
Joseph F. Haskell, with National Distillers Products Corporation since 1946, has been named director of the industrial relations department.
Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is not going to break her rule against making speeches, and if she should become First Lady, she will play the role as White House "homebody" and "policeman for Ike."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The Pirates exercised options to recall eleven farm system players today, but none will report to the club until next season under present plans.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 2 -- Federal Judge Harold R. Medina of New York tonight said that "every one seems to be looking for security."

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, touchdown-starved for two periods, registered a 33-to-17 victory over the New York Giants tonight on the clutch passing of Quarterback Bobby Layne and Halfback Doak Walker in a National Football League exhibition before 36,853 fans.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 -- The fifty-two contestants for the Miss America 1953 title made their debut here today before 150,000 cheering spectators who lined the three-mile line of march on the boardwalk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin today praised Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's Labor Day speech in Detroit as "the most promising approach to the problem of a fair labor law since the Taft-Hartley Act was passed in 1947."

YONKERS, Sept. 2 -- A reward of $25,000 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons who murdered John Acropolis, Westchester County union leader, on Aug. 26, was posted here today by Local 456 of the Teamsters Union, of which Mr. Acropolis, was president.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 2 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican candidate for Vice President, started his swing through Maine today by asserting that between now and Election Day he and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower would wage "the most intensive campaign in the history of American politics."
A new device developed by the International Business Machines Corporation will automatically verify the accuracy of key punches on the cards used in accounting machines, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Southern Senators are appealing to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to disavow an expected effort by the all-out civil rights forces to harden the Senate's anti-filibuster rule without opportunity for debate when the new Congress opens.

The firm wool market in Australia has given wool fabric manufacturers a green light on establishing firm prices for the spring 1953 women's wear lines. The price basis was set despite declines in domestic spots and futures. Several leading producers, it was learned yesterday, are showing spring lines prior to the formal Sept. 15 opening date.

The National Association of Letter Carriers, meeting here at its thirty-eighth biennial convention, adopted a resolution yesterday advocating that all future loyalty proceedings against Civil Service employes be conducted in the open "as provided in the Constitution."
PARKERSBURG, W, Va., Sept. 2 -- President Truman revived an old American word today when he taunted the "Republican snollygosters."
LONDON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- The season for English first-class cricket ended today, almost unnoticed in the flurry of excitement accompanying the opening games of the soccer campaign.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Police resignations upstate and on Long Island are increasing so fast each year that many municipalities are hard pressed to keep their departments up to proper strength, according to reports to be presented here this week at the Police Conference of the State of New York.
Romance, which knows no age limits, was in the air yesterday as 900 aged persons from twelve day centers went on a boat ride and had a day of square dancing and making new friends.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- While Premier Chou En-lai's political-economic-military mission continued negotiating with the Russians in Moscow, the Peiping People's Daily, the leading Chinese Communist organ, directed attention yesterday to Red China's great expectations as an ally of the Soviet Union.

The appointment of Alexander P. Chopin, who recently resigned his post as Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation, as director of public relations of the New York Shipping Association was announced yesterday by John V. Lyon, association chairman.

The election to be held in Japan on Oct. 1 will be the first national election since Japan regained her sovereignty under the peace treaty. In that election the Japanese people will have their first real opportunity to register their reaction to the occupation regime and its reforms, to test the new democracy which that regime introduced, and to determine the future course of their nation.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Police resignations upstate and on Long Island are increasing so fast each year that many municipalities are hard pressed to keep their departments up to proper strength, according to reports to be presented here this week at the Police Conference of the State of New York.
Romance, which knows no age limits, was in the air yesterday as 900 aged persons from twelve day centers went on a boat ride and had a day of square dancing and making new friends.

HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- While Premier Chou En-lai's political-economic-military mission continued negotiating with the Russians in Moscow, the Peiping People's Daily, the leading Chinese Communist organ, directed attention yesterday to Red China's great expectations as an ally of the Soviet Union.

The appointment of Alexander P. Chopin, who recently resigned his post as Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation, as director of public relations of the New York Shipping Association was announced yesterday by John V. Lyon, association chairman.

The election to be held in Japan on Oct. 1 will be the first national election since Japan regained her sovereignty under the peace treaty. In that election the Japanese people will have their first real opportunity to register their reaction to the occupation regime and its reforms, to test the new democracy which that regime introduced, and to determine the future course of their nation.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Maurice Thorez, leader of the French Communist party, who has been in the Soviet Union for almost two years recuperating from a paralytic stroke he suffered here, will return to Paris soon, probably before the end of the year, his followers were told today.
MONROVIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A modern-day ark has arrived in Liberia with Bibles to spread Christianity and bulldozers to develop the country.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The appointment of Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, as keynote speaker of the special Democratic state convention opening here Friday night was announced today by John M. Bailey, State Democratic Chairman.

STORRS, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The seventy foreign frogs that arrived in the United States by air yesterday were all croaking contentedly today in aquariums of the zoology department of the University of Connecticut here.
The Marine Corps has sent out invitations for the first large purchase of wool cloth to be made under the 1953 Defense Act appropriations, it was learned yesterday.

The Appellate Division heard arguments yesterday on an appeal from a decision by Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol that two police defendants were guilty of contempt. They had refused to testify as prosecution witnesses at the current departmental trial of thirty-four suspended policemen accused of taking bookmaking bribes from Harry Gross.

Hospitals, particularly those caring for mental patients, have changed a lot in recent years, it was declared here yesterday at the third annual convention of the American Association of Rehabilitation Therapists at the Statler Hotel.
FLINT, Mich., Sept. 3 -- A Flint shoe merchant said today that he wanted to see that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson got a new pair of shoes.

Detailed plans for the Sept. 30 city-wide atomic air raid test were drawn yesterday as Arthur W. Wallander, City Civil Defense Director, met with seventy-five representatives of city departments and officials from Westchester and Nassau Counties and New Jersey.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 3 -- The Democratic Town and City Committee announced today it had adopted a resolution opposing plans of the Connecticut Light and Power Company to build a $15,000,000 power plant on Manresa Island here.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,362 for Wednesday's operations:
Losing all the early gains, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 21 to 27 points net lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today postponed for one week the start of an investigation into international monopoly charges against twenty-one major oil companies and six individuals.

How to increase the effectiveness of their advertising as a selling tool is a problem of nightmarish proportions for most advertisers. Yesterday the head of an ad agency and the president of a hair cream and shampoo manufaccturing concern shed some light on the problem.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic nominee, is almost a 2-to-1 favorite with bettors here to win the United States Presidential election, according to the head of a well-known bookmaking firm that has placed a few hundred bets so far.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 3 -United States Ambassador George C. McGhee and Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat, of Louisiana, swam from Europe to Asia today.

BANFF, Alberta, Sept. 3 (AP) -A decision by the United States Federal Power Commission on West Coast Transmission Company's ap!plication for a natural gas pipeline from Alberta's Peace River area to Pacific Northwest States is ex Continued on Page 40, Column

LEO ERNEST DUROCHER, a miracle worker who apparently lost his license to practice, signed yesterday for Horace Stoneham for one more term as the Little Shepherd of Coogan's Bluff. This obviously is a desperation move on Horace's part. A year ago the owner of the Giants gave his skipper another contract late in July and the Giants immediately began to win, culminating their efforts with The Miracle.

BANFF, Alberta Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Federal Mines Minister George Prudham said today Canadians not only are "paddling their own national canoe, but have attached a jet-propelled outboard motor."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The first annual community service awards established by the Women's Division of the State Fair were Presented tonight to seven women's organizations judged outstanding for their programs of "civic usefulness" during the last year.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 3 -- The 114th annual session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science was formally opened in Queens University here tonight with a moral discourse on "The Ethical Dilemma of Science" by the new president, Prof. Archibald V. Hill, a physiologist.

The confusion usually attending school opening may be heightened further today in Parkway Village, Queens, where the United Nations International School will commence its sixth year with its largest enrollment.

The fall and winter fashions in Bergdorf Goodman's custom-made collection were shown yesterday afternoon at the concern's Fifth Avenue establishment. Two silhouettes predominated. The slim was in town suits and some daytime and late-afternoon sheath dresses.
The list of persons whose financial records were subpoenaed yesterday by the New York State Crime Commission follows:

As an American citizen residing in Parkway Village I was extremely gratified that your editorial of Aug. 25 "Unique Parkway Village" focused attention on the importance of that international community as living proof that people of more than fifty countries, of various races, creeds and cultures can live together in perfect harmony in the finest spirit and aspiration of the United Nations.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The School Board decided by a 5-to-3 vote after four hours' debate last night to admit some Negro boys to Polytechnic Institute, the first wedge in Baltimore's policy of public school segregation.

Under a newly revised production scheduled, "Be Your Age," the domestic comedy by Reginald Denham and Mary Orr, starring Conrad Nagel, will arrive in New York during the week of Dec. 15 at a theatre to be disclosed later. The attraction had been due here on Oct. 30.

The body of John J. Conway, an assistant vice president and manager of the Queens Plaza branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, was found hanging yesterday from a rope attached to the rafters of a garage in the back of his home at 92-53 217th Street, Queens Village, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- William A. Purtell, the newly appointed Republican Senator from Connecticut, declared today that he would neither need nor seek the aid of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin in his campaign to defeat Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut.
LONDON, Sept. 3 - London's celebrated Sadlers Wells Ballet added to its repertoire tonight a new production in three acts that eventually will be seen in New York.

Attendance was good at the Allied Shoe Products and Style Show, which opened yesterday for a three - day run at the Belmont Plaza Hotel. Many exhibitors had expected the Labor Day week-end to cut the number of buyers. The opening of the forty-first semiannual Leather Show today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel is expected to bring many more people to the shoe show.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Premier Antoine Pinay emphasized a point today in his battle against rising prices when he demonstrated that the French housewife was losing her traditional thriftiness.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 3 -Dracma, the Italian trotter, was the victim of bad racing luck tonight and wound up eighth in the field of eight in a Class C mile trot at Roosevelt Raceway. Guisseppe Nogara's 8-year-old bay mare, prepping for next Thursday's $50,000 two-mile Roosevelt Trot, was the 6-to-5 favorite in the race won by Pat Lee, owned by Robert Neuman of Shafter, Calif.

The Presidential elections which take place today in Chile rate as one of the most important events of the year in Latin America. Among other things, we will know soon whether Chile can continue to rank in the list of democratic nations -- a status which it has deserved under the well-meaning but weak regime of President Gonzalez Videla.

The Red Cross Blood Bank received the small sum of 120 pints of blood on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. The officials said they had expected this slump, however, in view of the holiday and the fact that no blood units were on the road and only two of the centers were open.

In another effort to save Iran from national suicide Secretary Acheson has issued an unprecedented public appeal not only to Premier Mossadegh but more particularly to the Iranian Parliament and public to reconsider and reverse the Premier's brusque rejection of the joint proposals made by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill for settlement of the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Col. E. R. Heiberg, Professor of Mathematics at the United States Military Academy at West Point, told a gathering of engineers today:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Millard Tydings, former Democratic Senator of Maryland, called Senator McCarthy a liar today and was accused himself of misleading the Senate and the American people.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh reversed himself on his previously announced policy of jailing multiple parking violators when two of them came before hint yesterday in Traffic Court and escaped with fines.

Sales this year of wine produced in California will be 25 per cent larger than they were last year, Franz W. Sichel, president of Fromm Sichel, Inc., a large distributing house, predicted here yesterday. About 85 per cent of all the domestic wine consumed in this country is made in California.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The three graying but youthful college professors, crouched on the United Nations conference room floor, were shooting craps. What's more they were playing with loaded dice.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America disclosed today that it might be able to start construction of its $400,000,000 smelting plant in Alaska next summer or late next spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, gave the impression today that he was eager to enter the lists in support of the national foreign policy, which seems certain to come under the increased fire of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, and of John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser.
Permit me a few observations on your very interesting editorial of Aug. 30 entitled "The Choice for Senator."

BOSTON, Sept. 3 -- Joe Black, the Dodgers' ace relief pitcher, had almost his "finest hour" tonight as the Dodgers squeaked out a 6-5 triumph over the Braves, who now have lost fourteen games to the league leaders without winning one.

The "Apartheid" policy followed by the Union Government of South Africa has once again come in for international criticism. Protests have been made afresh both in South Africa and in the outside world against the continuation of a policy which has been termed inhuman.

Chairmanship of the national convention committee of the Thirty-ninth National Foreign Trade Convention has been accepted by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, it was announced yesterday by Robert F. Loree, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- Wilhelm Pieck, Communist President of East Germany, said today that General Eisenhower's proposal before the American Legion for a crusade against communism was a repetition of the program devised by Adolf Hitler and would meet the same fate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The International Monetary Fund reported today that many of its member countries were "attempting to live beyond their means" and said the resulting inflation throughout the free world made it impossible to attain the objectives for which the Fund was created.

This country lacks an adequate national policy on American technical manpower, it was charged yesterday by Carey H. Brown, chairman of the Engineering Manpower Commission of the Engineers Joint Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, expressed himself today as hopeful of an "end to the unhappy dispute between two good friends of the United States," Iran and Britain, in the matter of the nationalized oil properties of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

If certain people owing more than one-third of the nation's $14,000,000,000 of consumer installment credit were to die while still in debt, the installments would be paid up by insurance companies, the Consumer Credit Insurance Association estimated yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 3 -Minister of Justice Joseph Pholien resigned tonight after a meeting of the all-Catholic Christian Social Cabinet called to consider the Storm of protest from large sections of the public against leniency toward two Belgian wartime collaborators with the Germans.

Voices squeaky and booming, fuzzy and bell-clear, questioning and explaining poured from a dozen radio loudspeakers in the octagonal-shaped control room atop the new 150-foot traffic tower at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday as engineers and technicians rushed to install and test radio and radar equipment against the dedication of the structure Wednesday.

The figures are now in and it is gratifying to note that traffic deaths over the Labor Day week-end were fewer than had been expected -- forty-eight under the prediction of the National Safety Council and twenty-nine below last year's Labor Day toll. Ironically, heavy rain over a wide area of the nation, which made driving hazardous, cut down the number of highway fatalities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Truman directed the Government today to begin putting into effect immediately his Airport Commission's recommendations for greater safety in air traffic and other improvements.

The first of a series of legal steps to establish the Democratic slate for Supreme Court Justices in the Second Judicial District (Kings and Richmond counties) was taken yesterday by the faction opposed to Francis J. Sinnott, Brooklyn Democratic leader.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- The Sir Galahad legend will be reworked by Columbia in a Technicolor adventure film the studio is calling "The Quest of the Holy Grail." Harry Kleiner is writing the script and Buddy Adler, who will be the producer, is looking for the right actors to cast as Galahad, his lady fair and the noble knights of the round table.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 27:
RENO, Nev., Sept. 3 -- A young man who quit newspaper work for politics caused a political earthquake in Nevada today.

THE striped bass fishing has been showing an improvement for a number of days now, at several Long Island, Rhode Island and Massachusetts areas, but the 62-pound fish taken off Cuttyhunk Island Sunday night is going to be a difficult mark to beat.
Fred H. Lucas has been made manager of structural and plate sales in the United States Steel Company's sales division. He succeeds A. H. Warren Jr., who is retiring after forty-three years' service.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3 -- Jersey Joe Walcott donned boxing gloves today for the first time since he retained his world title by beating Ezzard Charles last June.

SANFORD, Me., Sept. 3 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, Republican nominee for Vice President, charged tonight that, for every Administration scandal case the public knew about today, "there are ten which haven't yet been uncovered."

Mr. McCarran of Nevada, whom we have characterized with great restraint in these columns as "the worst Democratic Senator of them all," is not up for re-election this year, as his term, unhappily, runs until 1957. However, Nevada's other Senatorial seat (now held by a junior -- and Republican -- edition of Mr. McCarran) is at stake in November.

The 175th anniversary of the Battles of Saratoga should be a good time to try to clarify Benedict Arnold's part in them. His contemporary partisans did such a good job of creating the legend of Arnold as the "Hero of Saratoga" that even the Encyclopaedia Britannica repeats it.

BUFFALO, Sept. 3 -- The state Congress of Industrial Organizations, which opens its thirteenth annual convention here tomorrow, appears likely to refuse to endorse John Cashmore, the Democratic nominee for United States Senator.

Officials of the New York City Department of Hospitals declared yesterday they were "deeply disturbed" over Budget Director Abraham D. Beame's advice to Mayor Impellitteri that the municipal hospital construction program be limited.

General Eisenhower is soon to make a major address on the problems of preserving peace, and we hope that he will take advantage of this occasion to dispose of the charge, now brought forward by no less a personage than President Truman himself, that he has become the innocent victim of unscrupulous men who are "playing gutter politics" with foreign policy.

Richard Savitt, the almost forgotten man of tennis, came into the Forest Hills Stadium yesterday to demonstrate that he still wields a potent racquet in spite of all the adversity he has known since he won the Wimbledon and Australian crowns in 1951.

Discouraging prospects for United States exports, with curtailed demand in some markets extending into next year, were reported yesterday at a round-table meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Several thousand Reserve officers called involuntarily to active duty from the inactive or volunteer Reserve will be released two to three months earlier than planned, the Army announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Sam Mele smashed his thirteenth home run of the season into the left field lower deck tonight to boost the White Sox into third place in the American League with a 1-to-0 decision over the Browns.

The Monsanto Chemical Company is negotiating to acquire Detergents, Inc., and its affiliate, the Eastern Packaging Company, of Columbus, Ohio. Detergents, Inc., manufactures a detergent used in automatic washing machines and employs 152 workers.

Davega Stores Corporation will consider dividend payments on the common stock semi-annually in the future, H. M. Stein, president, announced yesterday. The company has been paying dividends quarterly since September, 1950. The last payment was 10 cents on July 1 and action on the third-quarter dividend usually is taken at this time.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 3 -- Seven political advisers of Premier Mosadegh, including the newly appointed Ambassador to the United States, Allahyar Saleh, two members of the joint oil commission, two Deputies and two Senators, met today to consider the joint Churchill-Truman offer for settlement of the Iranian oil problem.
A request for 175 additional firemen to help the Fire Department toward its quota strength of 8,574 men was sent to Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- James A. Mullally, a former Justice Department attorney, testified today that he had received $750 from a Washington law firm that he had recommended to represent the Carnation Milk Company. That company had been accused by the Federal Government in a criminal proceeding involving alleged violation of the pure food laws.

Reflecting a rise in sales, the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries increased net profit for the fiscal year ended on June 30 to $6,804,247 from $5,548,274 earned in the previous fiscal year, despite taxes that rose 142 1/2 per cent.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 3 -- Official sources here disclosed today that West Germany, which potentially is the greatest source of defense production on the Continent, was not fulfilling its promise in this respect. As a result, the Mutual Security Agency has been forced to place vital contracts in other countries.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia said today that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was "taking the South too much for granted" while Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign through Dixie "made a great many friends."

Columbia's football squad, numbering forty-one men, the smallest group in many years, arrived at Camp Columbia, Lakeside, Conn., yesterday afternoon to start preseason workouts for the Lions' sixty-first campaign. The squad, the twenty-third on Morningside Heights for Coach Lou Little, will begin practice with a drill this morning.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 -- A scandal appeared to be in the making in Argentina today as the Governors of the various provinces reported to President Juan D. Peron on the results achieved by the Peronista Government during its first six years in power.

The profile line was featured at Gimbels yesterday in its showing of eighteen original French, Italian, English and Swiss millinery designs plus their American-made copies. The copies, priced uniformly at $15, cost about one-fourth of what the originals would have been.

Overflow from the heavy rains of last winter and spring took its toll in damage to the spillway at Schoharie Reservoir in the Catskills by knocking a fifteen-foot hole through one section of the retaining wall, Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, told the City Planning Commission yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 3 -- William H. Abel, president of the Central National Bank of Mineola, told the Nassau County District Attorney today in an hour-long interview from his hospital bed that the alleged $475,000 swindle of his bank by a Roslyn business woman resulted from misplaced trust.

ROME, Sept. 3 -- Four hundred and twenty-nine of the world's leading astronomers, from thirty-five countries, will meet in Rome tomorrow for the eighth general assembly of the International Astronomical Union.

The Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, has decided not to fill his customary role this coming season as one of the speakers on the "Catholic Hour" radio program presented by the National Broadcasting Company.

DENVER, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Cincinnati rallied for three runs in the ninth inning to tie and then scored three in the eleventh to whip San Diego, 9 -- 6, today for the Ohioans' second straight triumph in the American Legion junior baseball national final.
Invigorator made his Eastern debut a successful one by taking the Babylon Handicap, the $10,000 added 2-year-old fixture that had its thirty-fifth running yesterday at the Aqueduct course.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 3 -Ignoring an impassioned plea by its leaders, the British Trades Union Congress voted by a substantial majority today to demand a reversal of all denationalization of industry proposed by the Conservative Government, as well as extensive further nationalization if and when the Labor party returns to power.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade had a choppy price course today, but in most cases fluctuations were narrow and the pit trade was of moderate volume.

Plans are being made to market $32,097,000 of school building bonds of the Georgia State School Building Authority early next week, probably on Tuesday. The obligations, which will come due serially from Oct. 1, 1953, to Oct. 1, 1971, will mark the first borrowing under a financing program expected to total $125,000,000.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- A conviction that the price of racial and religious prejudice is too much for the United States to bear was expressed today at the National, Urban League conference by leaders of labor and industry.
VANCOUVER, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) --British Columbia lumbermen today forecast little change in timber sales to the United Kingdom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The nation can expect a lower percentage of psychiatric casualties requiring continued treatment in Veterans Administration hospitals from the Korean war than in any previous conflict. The prediction was made by Dr. Harvey J. Tompkins, chief of the Psychiatry and Neurology Division of the Veterans Administration.

An indication that plastics have come of age for the home may be seen in the furnishings of a newly completed contemporary house in Scarsdale, N. Y. In the house, planned for his own family's use by the industrial designer Walter Margulies of Lippincott Margulies, almost everything is made of sturdy easy-to-clean plastics.

Residents of different parts of New York get used to certain sounds as a familiar accompaniment of daily -- and nightly -- living. In the tall buildings along the Hudson it is the river noises -- specially those that come from the shipping -- the warning blasts, running down the scale, from the great liners to the tugboats as they go about their lawful occasions.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 -- A new call on the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to play stronger roles in overcoming their members' economic and fiscal problems was made today at the opening joint session of the two organizations' annual meeting.
A 15-year-old boy was found dead last night in his lower East Side apartment with an upholsterer's tape, one end of which was tied to a bathroom pipe, knotted around his neck.

The boss has his own problems in getting an increase in pay. And he is not doing very well at it and perhaps not as well as his employes. These are among the conclusions of a study released yesterday by the American Management Association.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad is expected to oppose the application of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western for the election of two of its representatives to the Nickel Plate's board. According to reports from Cleveland yesterday, the Nickel Plate is planning to file a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking for leave to intervene and also that the I. C. C. hold a public hearing on Lackawanna's application.

A $101,112 damage suit against the state was begun in the State Court of Claims in the Bronx yesterday by the widow of one of four persons stabbed to death by a 19-year-old youth who went berserk in Brooklyn on March 5, 1950. Three other persons were wounded.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Iocal health officers throughout the state were asked by the State Health Department today to alert physicians to possible outbreaks of a polio-like illness, particularly among children of school age.

Sept. 3 is commonly regarded as the anniversary of the outbreak of the Second World War. It is not often remembered that in actual fact the war started two days earlier, when German soldiers crossed the Polish frontier and the first German bombs fell on Polish cities and villages.

Compulsory periodic physical examinations for New York City motorists 45 years of age and older, with the objective of reducing the accident rate an estimated 22 per cent was urged yesterday. Elimination of physically and mentally unfit drivers from behind the wheel was called a fundamental protective phase generally overlooked in highway safety programs.

An agreement including plans for a mutual promotion campaign between Stations WNBC and WNBT and the Organization of the Motion Picture Industry of the City of New York was signed yesterday by Fred J. Schwartz and Ted Cott, the respective heads of the organizations.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Race week at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was ushered in today under a fine northwest breeze with 189 craft competing in the twentieth annual affair.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Don Kolloway's pinch homer with the bases loaded in the sixth inning enabled the Tigers to score an 11-8 victory over the Indians tonight.

The business proptrty at 691-95 Madison Avenue, in an active section at the northeast corner of East Sixty-second Street, has been purchased by the 693 Madison Avenue Corporation through the Durand Taylor Company, brokers.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- The Canadian Government announced today it planned speedy removal of the controversial Gut Dam from the St. Lawrence River as soon as the Canadian-United States plan for hydroelectric development of the river was authorized by the International Joint Commission. The dam is located across the Channel between Galop and Adams Island.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- On occasion, the opposition still seems able to trump Casey Stengel's aces and tonight Jimmy Dykes did it with startling effect.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The Asian-Arab bloc in the United Nations is planning to demand that the General Assembly take up the race-tension problems of the Union of South Africa under the regime of Premier Daniel F. Malan as a threat to international peace.

Work was halted yesterday at nineteen small ship repair concerns as members of five American Federation of Labor unions failed to report for work after the breakdown of contract negotiations on Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- The Scottish Pot-Still Malt Distillers Association -- makers of the original pure malt whisky -- announced here today a reduction of 2 shillings sterling (28 cents) a gallon for the coming season output of Scotch malt whisky.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Ballistic experts reported today that the weapon used in the murder of John Acropolis at Yonkers eight days ago was a .38-caliber special revolver, possibly of Spanish manufacture. The analysis was made from two slugs found at the murder scene.

The Office of Price Stabilization is considering the suspension of price controls on furniture or out-right decontrol, Leo J. Heer, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, declared yesterday. His organization represents more than 9,000 furniture stores over the country.

A 27-year-old former convict who was arrested early yesterday after taking $1.40 in small change from the apron of a blind woman news dealer was castigated in Felony Court by Magistrate Benjamin Brenner as an "animal and a barbarian."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UP) -- The Senators routed Dizzy Trout in a six-run second-inning tonight and went on to defeat the Red Sox, 9 -- 2, behind Randy Gumpert's seven-hit pitching. This was the fifth straight loss for the Red Sox.
There were not enough shovels in Queens yesterday to dig up the dirt on the borough's sewer scandal.

NEW BRIGHTON, Minn., Sept. 3 (UP) -- A gigantic unmanned balloon, described as the largest without pilot in the world, built by the Navy to study cosmic rays at the threshold of outer space, was damaged by a breeze before take-off today and wobbled to a brief flight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 116,655 today, an increase of 403 since last week.

The ship was a long, white, sleek Norwegian freighter on her appointed rounds between Montreal and Rio. She cruised at sixteen knots and few waves were big enough to break over the Achilles' helmet of her bow. On the northern lap, the sea and the St. Lawrence and the Saguenay would make a fine setting for a holiday and perhaps some appropriate reading.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Pacific Coast lumbermen in Canada and the United States may increase their sales to Britain next year under a Government plan announced today raising import limits and relaxing regulations.

" America in Crisis," an anthology by Daniel Aaron, will be issued Sept. 22 by Knopf. The volume contains essays on fourteen crucial episodes that have helped shape the course of American development, beginning with Jonathan Edwards and the religious revival in the Seventeen Forties and ending with the disillusionment of the Nazi-Soviet pact in 1939.

A total of 143,630 more persons left New York City than moved in during the decade 1940 to 1950, according to population surveys made by the City Planning Commission. Results of the surveys were included in the commission's annual report for 1951, made public yesterday.

A Republican, Senator William A. Langer of North Dakota, paid tribute yesterday to President Truman as "a great statesman" who "couldn't be bribed, couldn't be bought and couldn't be bulldozed." Instead of criticism, he said, the President "deserves the praise of every true American."
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The stock markets were quiet and undecided today for the start of business for the new bookkeeping period. However, the undertone remained firm.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A 90-pound ocelot escaped from its cage at the New York State Fair midway early today, roamed the area more than four hours, killed a dog, a parrot and three chickens and finally was shot by a state policeman.
Prices of commodities for future delivery on the local exchanges yesterday were mostly mixed or a little lower. In general changes were small and trading was only moderate.

British labor is giving an interesting example of how it can be solid and patriotic on a vital issue like defense and foolishly doctrinaire on a socialistic question like the nationalization of industry. On Tuesday the annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress, which represents the entire organized labor movement of the country, voted by huge majorities to support Britain's rearmament program.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals collected four runs in the first inning tonight, added two more in the second and coasted the rest of the way behind Gerry Staley for a 6 -- 1 victory over the Cubs. The box score:

John Foster Dulles, chief foreign policy adviser of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, accused President Truman yesterday of following a policy of appeasement toward Russia while talking of liberating the nations that have come under Soviet domination since the end of World War II.

SYDNEY, Sept. 3 (AP) -- American buyers purchased some high priced lots today on the third day of Sydney's first sale of the 1952-53 Australian wool selling season. Japanese buyers were less active than during the first two days.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The foreign ministers of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty countries will meet here Dec. 15 to discuss defense plans for 1953 for an area extending from North America to the Bosporus. This decision was announced here today after a session of the permanent members of the North Atlantic Council.
Bobby Thomson, hero of the Giants' 1951 pennant drive, last night demonstrated to 15,984 Polo Grounds skeptics that he still has the winning touch.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 3 -Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois concentrated on preparations for his western trip today in the belief that his positive definition of domestic and foreign policies in the next ten days would counteract charges of corruption within the Democratic Administration made by his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference was accused by the Isbrandtsen Company yesterday of violating a Federal court order and of seeking to circumvent "rules" now being formulated by the Federal Maritime Board and destined to be applicable to the conference.

The New York State Crime Commission subpoenaed yesterday, in its investigation into waterfront crime and corruption, the bank records of 300 New York and New Jersey public officials, politicians high and low, union executives, gangsters, and men who have served as secretaries to members of the judiciary.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Harvie Ward of Tarboro, N. C., British amateur titleholder, and Bob Babbish of Detroit fired 5 under par 67's today in the first round of match play in the seventh annual Bill Waite Memorial golf tourney.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "mystery man," testified yesterday before the Special Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury for thirty-four minutes and then pleaded that his physical condition would not permit him to answer any further questions.

Young Butch, the terror of his neighborhood, was a changed character yesterday. Accustomed to yelling commands at quivering underlings, he remained strangely silent. A new humility had replaced the old-time arrogance. As he entered the big gray building, clutching his mother's hand, it was obvious to all that the inexorable forces of society had finally caught up with him.

Mrs. Marjorie Stapleton has sold her property in Roslyn Heights, L. I., to an investing customer of J. Edward Breuer, broker in the transaction. The new owner plans to construct a business building in the near future on the property which fronts 200 feet on Warner Avenue, 200 feet on St. Marks Avenue and 225 feet on Garden Street.

Two men who pranced on a plank nine stories above the street at Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street shortly before last midnight were finally persuaded by the police to climb down after their antics had collected a sizable crowd.

Plans for a "Family Rosary Crusade" here, in which persons of all faiths will be asked to join in prayer, were discussed yesterday at a luncheon in the Warwick Hotel, at which Cardinal Spellman was host to 100 persons from the press, radio, television and advertising fields.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Charles E. Dusenberry, chairman of the Orange County Republican Committee, today practically read Hamilton Fish out of the party. Mr. Fish, a former Representative, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for United States Senate on the independent ticket of the new Constitutional party.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Governor Dewey appealed tonight for "the wisest and best leadership we can call to our service in the national Government" to meet the danger of war abroad and the need for honesty, economy and security in government at home.
Four eight-week courses in investment analysis have been added to the curriculum of the New York Institute of Finance for the fall term, commencing Sept. 15.
CAMDEN, Sept. 3 -- Mayor George Brunner has urged the Navy to oppose the proposed site of a new bridge across the Delaware River which will link Philadelphia and Gloucester City, N. J.

A mortgage loan of $1,000,000 on the recently completed River House on Henry Hudson Parkway West, Netherland Avenue and West 254th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been placed with the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company by Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers, through Feist and Feist.

Three non-wage items of the original proposals by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., were withdrawn yesterday in negotiations with the New York Shipping Association, which represents employing stevedores.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland tonight revealed that he had returned testimonial dinner gifts of money presented to him recently by a group of "old friends."

HONG KONG, Sept. 3 -- Bishop Francis X. Ford, Brooklyn-born prelate of Meihsien in northern Kwangtung Province, died in a prison hospital at Canton last Feb. 21, after having been under Chinese Communist arrest for more than a year, it was announced here today.

Stock prices closed irregular yesterday in the most active market since July 31. Gains in selected issues, however, pushed THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average upward for the fifth consecutive session and to new highs for the recovery movement.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Finishing in the last foursome, Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Sea-wane Harbor posted a 79 for low gross honors today in the weekly Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament over the 1,755-yard Huntington County Club course.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 3 -- Informed British sources here foresee another winter dry season of indecisive combat between the French and Communist-led Vietminh forces in Indo-China.

The new issue of 78,734 shares of $50 par value convertible preferred stock which Carrier Corporation is about to offer to its common shareholders will carry a dividend rate of 4.8 per cent and will be priced at $53 per share, the company announced yesterday.

Can't we improve our campaign methods? In our present campaign for the Presidency we are fortunate in having two superior men who are both behaving like the gentlemen they are. They are trying to convey to the public their own ideas of good government in a calm, logical manner, without offensive recriminations.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger pitched three - hit ball tonight as the Reds blanked the Pirates, 1 -- 0.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 3 (UP) -- A fire that raged out of control for nearly two hours swept the crew's quarters of a Norwegian freighter at her dock today. All but five aboard escaped unharmed because of the heroism of a seaman who died in the flames.

Leo Durocher will manage the New York Giants again next season. The skipper of the National League champions signed a 1953 contract yesterday, then sat through a press conference with Horace C. Stoneham, president of the club, at which both made it clear that the Giants have not relinquished hopes of winning the 1952 pennant.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic candidate for Vice President, suggested today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as President would be obstructed in putting any progressive measures into effect by a reactionary Congress.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3 -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower warned white Southerners today that they were in danger of losing their own rights unless they were willing to protect with all their efforts the rights of their neighbors "whatever the color of their skin."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 3 -- Reinforcement of the Soviet group of armies in East Germany by new divisions from the Soviet Union is regarded as a probable consequence of the increased strength of the Allied forces in West Germany and West Europe.
