WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Anthracite operators and the United Mine Workers met briefly today and turned wage contract negotiations over to a subcommittee of three from each side. This group will meet tomorrow.

In a recent study conducted in Providence, R. I., it was found that the quality of a large percentage of the eggs bought at grocery stores was lower than the grade indicated on the carton. The size, too, was often labeled inaccurately.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 4--The United Nations and Communist armistice delegations met for fifty-two minutes at Panmunjom today and then adjourned again to Sept. 12, still tightly deadlocked over the question of the prisoner-of-war exchange after a cease-fire.
ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Governor Dewey today urged state department heads to trim all but the most essential programs from their 1953-54 budget requests.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Gen. Bob Neyland said today that if and when he stepped down as Tennessee football coach he planned to stay on as athletic director.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3 -- Evidence of the apparent firmness of the Soviet-Chinese alliance was provided today by a warm exchange of messages between Premier Stalin and Mao Tse-tung, and by a declaration made in identical terms by the organs of the Soviet Army and Navy that the friendship between Moscow arid Peiping secures peace in the Far East "against any and all aggressors and instigators of war."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The "embalmed beef" scandal of the Spanish-American War, referred to today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, involved charges that vast amounts of refrigerated beef, injected with harmful chemicals, were shipped to troops in the field, allegedly causing widespread sickness.

NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- A survey by the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New Jersey, Carl Holderman, state president, said today, disclosed that up to Aug. 20 sixty-seven municipalities containing about 2,376,000 of the state's 4,800,000 residents, had adopted resolutions declaring a housing shortage and requesting continued Federal rent control.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A committee of the American Federation of Labor said today that the cost of living, already at a record high, was likely to continue to rise through the rest of the year.

" George Washington: Victory with the Help of France," the fifth volume of Douglas Southall Freeman's biography of Washington, will be published by Scribners next month. Covering the years 1778-1783, the volume completes the story of the Revolution and takes General Washington back into private life.

Public officials have a way of reminding us of the existence of the philologists, for now and then they en- liven our days by resurrecting old, half-forgotten words, sayings and expressions or perhaps coining new ones that seem to ring with the ancient, authentic accent that might have come out of the Ark. And then we have no recourse but to lean on philologists for enlightenment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A labor union legally certified to represent some 65,000 workers in collective bargaining before the National Labor Relations Board was charged by a Senate investigating subcommittee today with being "under the control of agents of the Kremlin * * * dedicated to the destruction of the freedom which members of the organization now enjoy."

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- In a game marked by a last-inning dispute between Roy Campanella and Umpire Frank Secory, the Braves tonight scored an eleven-inning 6-5 victory for their first triumph of the season over the Dodgers.
Chicken pie, chicken stew, chicken cacciatore, arroz con pollo, creamed chicken, chicken a la king, chicken curry, chicken timbales, chicken hash, chicken croquettes.

The "Letters to THE TIMES" for Aug. 30 contains a letter suggesting that a fine be levied upon those persons who do not vote in elections. This expresses the feeling of a growing number of persons who wish to inaugurate some form of compulsory voting.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 4 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's recent political successes are "interesting" but are not "worrying" Democratic party headquarters, Wilson W. Wyatt, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign manager, said today. The official reaction here was as follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The stock of the American President Lines was put up for sale today to settle the seven-year legal fight between the Government and R. Stanley Dollar and associates.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Apparently the Yankees can be crowded only so far. Then something has to give, and it isn't the Bombers.

Art Linkletter's "House Party," a daytime radio fixture for the last seven years, made its television debut this week. It is presented over Channel 2 on Mondays through Fridays from 2:45 to 3:15, originating "live" in Hollywood.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- As the United States first contribution to this year's West Berlin Cultural Festival, the New York City Ballet received a warm reception both from its audience last night and from critics in tonight's newspapers.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 4 -- The Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund asserted today that the United States had raised "far too severe" barriers to the growth of exports to dollar markets, which he described as the indispensable condition for restoring a balance in international payments.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- The newspaper Pravda appeared today with a special two-page insert devoted to a discussion of the forthcoming nineteenth party congress in which sharpest emphasis was placed on the necessity of improving party discipline, the observance of Government discipline, freedom of criticism by the lower ranks, and better selection of workers.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Seventy candidates for Princeton University's varsity football squad arrived today for physical examinations before the opening of two weeks of pre-season practice at the university's training camp in Blairstown, N. J.
Parents of teen-agers may be interested in calling their attention to the following book, published recently:
The head of the American Federation of Labor's largest and most powerful union has informed his associates that he intends to quit next month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- Looking ahead to late 1953, Billy Wilder says that he then will undertake to direct and produce a film verson of "Oedipus Rex." He plans to shoot the Sophocles tragedy in actual Greek locale and is making arrangements to obtain a Technicolor commitment. Walter Reisch will write the screen adaptation of the drama, which from the point of view of motion-picture moral standards represents a considerable challenge.

HYDERABAD, India, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Hyderabad's State Cabinet held an emergency session tonight to plan how to stem Communist-inspired riots in which four persons have been killed and at least eighty injured.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower speech tonight at a Republican campaign rally in Convention Hall:
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower outlined tonight before a wildly cheering and partisan Republican audience a ten-point program for peace to avert "future Koreas."
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Will Harridge, American League president, rejected today a protest by the Indians and both Hank Greenberg and Ellis Ryan said his decision was "outrageous."

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer met the Allied High Commissioners today for about an hour, during which the latest Soviet note on German reunification was discussed. Dr. Adenauer did most of the talking, presenting the views of himself and the Cabinet, with whom he met yesterday.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 4 -- The widows and orphans of many New York City policemen killed in line of duty would get more income if they dropped their pensions and went on relief, John E. Carton president of the Police Conference of the State of New York, declared today at the annual convention here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The livestock situation in the Balkans is causing a small amount of international trouble again. Six years ago it was an ox and a mule; now it is 1,000 sheep, give or take a couple.
BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- For the first time in United States naval history, two sister aircraft carriers will exchange crews tomorrow, from seaman apprentice to commanding officer.
Reversing the seasonal expansion of the preceding four weeks, business loans from New York banks declined $5,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -Attorney General James P. McGranery declared tonight that a statement by Justice Department lawyers quoted by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, "does not mean there were Communists employed in the State Department."

Dr. John F. McNeill, superintendent of the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, testified yesterday in the State Court of Claims in the Bronx that "we were not correct" in diagnosing as "normal" William H. Jones, 19 years old, who, five days after being released from the hospital, went berserk in Brooklyn on March 5, 1950, and stabbed four persons fatally.

What should have been the biggest commodity market announcement of the day -- the Office of Price Stabilization's statement that new ceilings on soybean meals would also apply to "soybean concentrates" and other mixes -- had virtually no effect on New York Produce Exchange trading yesterday. Traders explained that guesses on the new ceilings have been so far apart that no one could be sure of his estimates of the effect on oil prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Immediate expansion of the Internal Security Section of the Department of Justice Criminal Division, in order to cope more vigorously with the Communist menace in the United States, was announced by Attorney General James P. McGranery today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is being supported editorially by five times as many daily newspapers as are supporting Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, it was reported yesterday by Editor Publisher, newspaper trade magazine.
Mayor Impellitteri reserved decision yesterday after holding a public hearing on bills to create an independent Department of Air Pollution Control and to define its powers and duties.

Not in the least bit fazed in having two of the shows he had been working on, "Devil's Hornpipe" and "Huck and Jim," shot out from under him for sundry reasons, Maxwell Anderson has virtually finished a historical play dealing With Charles II for production this season by the Playwrights Company, of which he is one of the founders.

ONE of the great unsolved mysteries of history, one that convulsed all of Scotland and much of England with partisan fury in the eighteenth century, is known as the Douglas Cause. It concerned the identity of a swarthy, solemn youth known as Archie Douglas. Was he the legitimate nephew of the Duke of Douglas and so the rightful heir of the richest nobleman in Scotland?

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4 -- If American individuals have to chisel any institution, the larger percentage would prefer to take the illegal action against a large-scale business than the government, it was reported here today. Small business would be the third choice.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 4 -- A bad spill marred the opening of tonight's harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway. The Myrtle Stable's Bob Castle, leading fifty yards from the finish, stumbled, fell and threw his driver, Frank Darish. C. R. Hurdle's Cindy's Boy, unable to pull up, crashed into Bob Castle's sulky and tossed Ben Turlington.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was cut off the air by radio and television engineers of the National Broadcasting Company last night when he failed to finish a political address on schedule in Philadelphia.

MARGATE, England, Sept, 4 -- The Trades Union Congress roundly defeated Communist-inspired efforts to overthrow its policy of moderation in the statement of British Labor's attitude toward wage claims in a series of votes here today.
Norma Holmes, pianist, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening in one of the "Interval Concerts" being presented by N. J. Seaman in the interval between summer and winter music seasons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission said today it had suspended one of its woman employes and had asked for a copy of testimony she had given to a grand jury investigating a "leak" of confidential Loyalty Review Board records to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

MANY members of the six teams that will compete next week in the ninth International Tuna Cup Matches at Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, will arrive at Yarmouth tomorrow to get in a few days of fishing at the Soldier's Rip before the opening of the matches on Wednesday.

A question on whether the same foreign goods could be twice subject to United States import duty would generally bring a definite negative reply from most foreign traders. However, under a recent Customs Court decision, they would be wrong. In what can be considered a relatively rare case, a shipment of Swiss wall clocks was imported into this country, and 1,200 of them were re-exported by airfreight C. O. D. to Mexico.

A tiny girl, clasping a doll, disrupted the schedule at City Hall yesterday when she tearfully protested being photographed with Mayor Impellitteri. Smilingly he admitted it was the first time he had received such a rebuff from a feminine visitor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it was informed an agreement has been reached for a distribution of stock holdings of the New England Public Service Company.

ROME, Sept. 4 -- Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, died in a private nursing home in Rome tonight after having suffered an attack of phlebitis in July of last year that kept him in bed for the greater part of the intervening fourteen months.
Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Aug. 30 rose 4 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Britain's hopes of selling jet airliners to the United States looked a trifle faded tonight. Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, left London for New York without having placed any orders. An official of the Pan American World Airways denied in Frankfurt, Germany, that his company had signed a contract.

VERBANIA, Italy, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Two Americans charged with the wartime "cloak-and-dagger" murder of United States Maj. William Holohan will be tried in their absence by an Italian court if the United States refuses extradition, Antonio Morando, prosecutor, said today.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 4 (UP) -- The season's second hurricane swerved northward away from the United States mainland today and aimed its 110-mile-an-hour winds at the shipping lanes between Bermuda and the Carolina coasts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Four years from now, another major political party will be in the field with a candidate campaigning actively for the Presidency, Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, predicted today.

A praying mantis refused to compete with thirty-one dogs, twelve cats, a blue-clawed crab, turtles, tropical fish and canaries at the Children's Aid Society's thirteenth annual pet show yesterday and flew out of the society's lower West Side Center before the judges could get a look at it.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 -- India returned Communist China's relief donation of 400,000 rupees ($84,000) today because it had political strings attached. The Government acted to head off a similar gift from the Soviet Union.

A Marine deserter who starred for the last four months as the monster in "Frankenstein" in a vaudeville show that toured the country was picked up yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents as just another bad actor.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 4 -- The view appears to be spreading in Teheran that the Churchill-Truman proposal to solve the Iranian oil problem will be used as a bridge to further negotiations.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Korea-assigned marine Sergeant hurriedly packed his bag for a trip to New York today, elated by the chance to see his girl friend before shipping out next Monday.

To expedite a court decision on which of the rival slates of Democratic candidates for Supreme Court Justice in the Second Judicial District is entitled to the party nominations, the Board of Elections declined yesterday to rule in favor of either group.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee, meeting in a Federal Court House protected by armed guards, today sought to trace the extent of subversive infiltration into two locals of the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., at major meat plants in Chicago.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- French residents of Tunisia threatened today to counter Arab complaints to the United Nations against continued French rule of the North African protectorate by appealing for a hearing before the world body as members of a minority menaced by Moslem nationalism.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- The Western Allies, taking note of the Bonn Government's announcement that steel and coal prices were to be "worked out" among the producers and the Government, have warned Prof. Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister, that cartel arrangements will not be tolerated.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Charlie Keller, the famed King Kong who with Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich gave the Yankees one of baseball's greatest outfields, is coming back to give the Bombers another lift.

TRENTON, Sept. 4 -- The New Jersey Eisenhower - Nixon Clubs opened headquarters here today to conduct state - wide registration and vote-getting drives for the Republican Presidential ticket and Congressional candidates.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 4 -- Greenland's status will be changed from that of a colony into an integral part of Denmark and throne succession rights will be granted to King Frederik's eldest daughter, 12-year-old Princess Margrethe, if a series of constitutional amendments, now being discussed by the Government in preparation for the autumn session of the Rigsdag (Parliament), is adopted by the legislature and approved by a popular referendum.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that he was very "tired of hearing innuendoes about improper settlement" of income tax liabilities.

The French Communist party is taking another turn, which is always an important development inside and outside of France. Maurice Thorez, the Secretary-General of the party, is coming back from Russia after two years recuperating from a serious illness -- a treatment that for some time looked more like captivity.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Sept. 5 -- United Nations infantrymen and artillery today hurled back eight columns of Chinese Reds who stormed "Bunker Hill" in a new and desperate attempt to capture the blood-soaked height on the western front.

Henry Winter has sold the two-family house at 97-30 124th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, to Anthony T. Coccia, who insured title with the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company. John J. Kennedy was the broker.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 4 -- The creation and control of life in man and the animal was the central theme of about ninety papers discussed at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science at Queens University.

Saks Thirty-fourth looked farther afield than Paris for original millinery designs to have copied line for line and sell at a fraction of what the originals would be priced. They went to Italy, England and Switzerland, and the results, plus the French designs, were highly gratifying.

A syndicate of developers represented by Irving Klein, realty broker of Lawrence, L. I., yesterday announced his purchase of 16,500 acres of land, including nine mountain lakes, in Herkimer County, where the group said it would build one of the largest summer and winter resorts in the East.
Four exhibitions of painting provide a modest overture to what everyone hopes will be a stimulating season in the art world.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 -- For economic, moral and foreign policy reasons the United States no longer can afford to tolerate a dual standard of citizenship, Winthrop Rockefeller told the National Urban League Conference at a dinner tonight.

SENOR ALFONSO RAMON LOPEZ, the hidalgo from Cleveland, has just blown another fuse. The hotter the pennant race the faster he blows fuses. Yet his wrath is both understandable and justifiable. The good senor lost an important ball game with the St. Louis Browns the other day and his formal protest reached league headquarters where nothing came of it.

Police Lieut. Francis A. O'Hara, who speaks Chinese and was a key figure in meeting the threat of tong wars in Chinatown thirty years ago, left the Ryer Avenue precinct station house in the Bronx yesterday for the last time to live in retirement.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Yale began preparations for its eightieth football campaign today, concluding the opening day of activity with a brisk workout on DeWitt Cuyler field.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 5 -- The United Nations delegation at Panmunjom tartly told the Communists yesterday that their (the Reds') "real purpose" appeared to be to prolong the war in Korea while conducting "camouflage" negotiations for an armistice.
Unionized employes on the New York Central Railroad lines east of Buffalo asked their national leaders yesterday to set a new date for a strike against the railroad.

Max Bloom, Bronx County chairman of the Liberal party, announced yesterday that M. Maldwin Fertig, the Liberal candidate for Surrogate in the Bronx, had received 20,000 signatures to a nominating petition that would make him the candidate of the independent Ideal party also. Up to the close of business yesterday, this petition had not been filed with the Board of Elections. It can be filed at any time before midnight tonight.
STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 4 -- The cold wind of scientific realism blew across the International Congress of Astronautics today.

The first of a series of twenty-six dramatic episodes in which Christian principles will be applied to family problems will be put on the air by thirty television stations over the country next week. The series is entitled "This Is the Life."
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Twenty-two years ago a little girl was kidnapped in Chicago. Today the child's mother faced a young woman and tried to recognize that child of long ago.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- Acting in response to a joint application of all groups involved, the Public Service Commission today ordered a rehearing on proposed property exchanges between the Yonkers Railroad Company and the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.
Barry Gray, radio disk jockey and commentator, suffered cuts and bruises on the left side of his face early yesterday when he was assaulted by two men at Madison Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Conflicting viewpoints on the respective merits of a Delaware River bridge or tunnel to connect this city with Camden, N. J., were expressed here today at a hearing before the United States Army Engineers.
The close relationship between the artist and the artisan will be pointed up in an exhibition by that name opening on Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum. The showing will continue through Sept. 28.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 (UP) -- A six-run burst -- all against the same pitcher in the same inning -- powered the Reds to a 7-2 conquest of the Pirates today.

BERLIN, Sept. 4 -- The scope of the Leipzig Fair, scheduled to open in that East German city Sunday, has been expanded so that it is now the chief "show window" of the Communist world. This was stated today in an article on the fair by George Handke, East German Trade Minister.

Monte Irvin's bases-loaded single in the eleventh inning yesterday brought Al Corwin home with the run that gave the Giants a second straight 4-3 overtime victory over the Phillies at the Polo Grounds. A Ladies Day crowd of 7,497 watched the 3-hour and 19-minute contest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Truman today projected a complete restudy of immigration and naturalization policies, reviving one of the most bitterly debated issues of the last session of Congress, which passed the McCarran- Walter Immigration and Naturalization Bill over the President's veto.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 4 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club and Mrs. Philip Conway of Siwanoy shot a 42, 39 -- 81 to win low gross honors in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's "Pinehurst specials" tournament over the Westchester Hills Golf Club course today.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Sept. 4 -Low net honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur team best-ball handicap event at the Leeward Golf Club today went to Mike Corcoran and Leo Coff from the Aldecress Country Club of Alpine, N. J.

Scores of New York banks put on extra help and strained their copying facilities yesterday in an attempt to produce facsimiles and transcripts of bank records subpoenaed by the New York State Crime Commission in its waterfront investigation.

Investigation of the Queens sewer scandal made headway yesterday along three fronts and was enlivened by Controller Lazarus Joseph's angry denial that his office had given premature authorization for any payments to Victor Clemente, builder of the faulty Laurelton sewer.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 4 -Former President Gen. Carlos Ibanez appeared tonight to be sweeping the country in the election for President in a remarkable comeback after having been forced out of office twenty-one years ago by popular hostility.

When the 1952-53 school year begins Monday eight new public school buildings and additions providing facilities for 7,088 boys and girls will be ready, the Board of Education said yesterday. Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the board's committee on buildings and sites, said the new units cost $11,009,749.
Bejeweled fashions for day and evening by Elfreda-Fox were presented by Jay Thorpe in the Terrace Room at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4 -- Leaders of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations executed a complete about-face here today and prepared to endorse the Democratic Senatorial candidacy of John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough president.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Dr. Alexander Brunschwig of Cornell University Medical School in New York, whose operations have been saving cancer patients given only a few months to live, reported today on the patients' survival rate before the convention of the International College of Surgeons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, Acting Director of Defense Mobilization, reported today that the delivery rate of 140 major and "problem" items on the military program had risen slightly in July and that total military hard-goods deliveries had reached the $2,000,000,000 monthly rate.

The policy committee of the Liberal party voted unanimously last evening not to endorse Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic nominee for United States Senator, but to run a candidate of its own.

with the Loft Players' successful production of "Summer and Smoke" now on vacation, Circle in the Square, the arena-style playhouse in Greenwich Village, has been taken over temporarily by Irwin Rose's production of Daniel Polis' play, "Fortress of Glass."
I read your article of several days ago which stated that the Mayor was likely to be faced soon with a choice between a 15-cent fare or additional taxes, perhaps a city income tax.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The stock markets again were quiet today but prices kept firm in most sections. British funds fell slightly in the morning but a rally restored about half of the losses. In the foreign market Japanese bonds weakened on suggestions that a debt agreement with Britain might be delayed. German stocks too fell in the afternoon but the reaction was not always sufficient to cancel earlier gains.

With a decision near on yet another "escape clause" tariff case -- this one on imports of frozen fish fillets -- import sources said here yesterday that restrictive action would hurt Canada and give new impetus to the recently-checked "high tariff protectionist" movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that -- "come White House or not" -- she was going to establish her home at her 114-year-old Gettysburg, Pa., farmhouse immediately after the election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Truman today applauded the progress being made in aiding the physically handicapped, called for expansion of programs to train more of them for productive employment and deplored as a "national disgrace" the huge casualties from highway and industrial accidents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Arguments are to be heard in United States District Court here tomorrow in the first of the attacks by major oil companies on subpoenas requiring them to testify at a grand jury investigation into an alleged world oil cartel.
The seasonal increase in shipments of medium-size and pullet eggs, which resulted last week in lower wholesale prices, is now reflected at the retail level.

TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Japan's three leading newspapers, with combined circulation of more than 16,000,000 announced today they were withdrawing their support from Kyodo, the nation's dominant news agency.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, Sept. 4 (AP) --French authorities in neighboring Togoland have arrested two more newspaper editors and charged them with spreading false information, according to advices reaching here today.

In THE TIMES Aug. 23 Benjamin Welles reports a plan offered by Sir William Slim during a conference of officers representing ten nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The plan proposed that the Western Allies revise their current policy and work toward splitting the Communist satellites from Moscow's control by "seeking a coexistence in trade and diplomatic relations" with them.

MOUNT VERNON, Ga., Sept. 4 -- A warning that Southern Democrats were seriously questioning the "political integrity" of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, was voiced today by a Georgia political figure who is the brother-in-law of Senator Richard B. Russell, foremost spokesman for Dixie adherents to the Stevenson cause.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jim Ferrier of San Francisco led the par-wreckers in the opening round of the $15,000 Empire State open golf tournament today with a blistering seven-under-par 63.

Australia's pair of 17-year-old prodigies, Kenneth Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, dealt America's waning prestige on the tennis courts a double-barreled blow yesterday to gain the quarter-finals of the national championships with two other players from Down Under.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. -- Governor Dewey urged the nation's voters today to study the critical issues in the coming election and to "give great thought" to supporting a candidate and a party that "will keep us free and strong enough so that the Soviet Union will not dare to attack us."

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept 4 -- Out in old Cow Bay modernized to Manhasset Bay, there was another northwest breeze for the second session of the race week at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. This one was a little lighter and fell apart after three-quarters of a fleet of 201 craft had gone through their paces.

The Democratic State Committee will hold a series of upstate conferences next week, beginning Monday, with county chairmen and Congressional, legislative and local candidates, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, State Chairman, announced yesterday. County chairmen and candidates from fifty-one counties have been invited to attend the conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Gen Dwight D. Eisenhower received this afternoon one of the most tumultuous welcomes ever accorded a Republican Presidential candidate in this city as he toured the midtown district.
MOONACHIE, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Eighty-one pupils who had been transferred from School 3 to School 2 here, walked to School 2 on opening day this morning but only one reported for classes.

One out of every seven New orkers will use the services of the city's voluntary hospitals in the coming year, James D. IViooney, chairman of the 1952 appeal of the United Hospital Fund, predicted yesterday at a pre-campaign meeting.

A nun just released by the Chinese Communists after imprisonment since December, 1950, has brought word to Hong Kong of the death last February of Bishop Francis X. Ford. The Bishop died in a Communist jail at the age of 60 after more than a year of maltreatment.

Recently in a group of people discussing world conditions I found several who stated frankly that they were so "tired of it all" they would like to "run away and hide somewhere" from the constant mudslinging, intolerance and hatred that today seem so prevalent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Truman set up today a clemency and parole board for war criminals, designed to advise the White House in regard to possible future lessening of punishment for Japanese nationals who have been adjudged guilty of war crimes.

Two more small shipyards engaged in negotiations with American Federation of Labor unions yielded yesterday on a disputed retroactivity point, but the remaining nineteen companies contniued to be obdurate on the issue of paying a 20-cent hourly wage increase back to March 1.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The engineer may some day take over the machinery of government from the politician, members of the American Society of Civil Engineers were told here today.

A statement that the prices of most consumer goods sold by department stores in this country will be lower for fall than a year ago and will stay low was made yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc.

optimism prevailed at the forty-first semi-annual Leather Show, sponsored by the Tanners Council of America, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The two-day event attracted more buyers than at any opening day in the past.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Scoring their fifth straight victory, the Senators handed the skidding Red Sox their sixth straight defeat tonight, 4 to 2, to jump from sixth to fourth place. Boston dropped to fifth place, just ahead of the Athletics.

Sundowner made the thirty-first running of the Bushwick a pleasant one for the favorite players among the 19,019 who attended Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old gelding owned by Rigan McKinney, whose very name is a synonym for jump racing, took the hurdle race of about two miles in easy style under a competent ride by Frank (Dooley) Adams, and paid $5.80.

The semi-annual report of the General Aniline and Film Corporation disclosed yesterday a sharp drop in net income to $886,000 in the six months ended on June 30 from $3,523,000 earned in the corresponding half of last year.
John Kostopoulos has joined the servicing department of the J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation of Jersey City, Hackensack and Newark, N. J.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 4. -- John H. Dair, Manhasset building contractor who was appointed receiver in equity for Ideal Insulators, Inc., and Ideal Aluminum Products Co., Inc., pledged his support today in the Nassau County District Attorney's investigation of the alleged $475,000 swindle of the Central National Bank of Mineola.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- A four-point program aimed at achieving Britain's "independence of aid from abroad at the earliest possible moment" was presented to the British public today by the Bevanite wing of the Labor Party. Three of the four points involved frank and outright discrimination against dollar goods.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 -- Confronted with successive subversive plots against the Government, the Peron regime is establishing a central police agency, Angel Borlenghi, Minister of the Interior disclosed today.

The Appellate Division affirmed unanimously yesterday Section 903 of the City Charter, which requires city employes to testify at department disciplinary proceedings or face loss of their jobs. The court ruling was made in upholding the action of Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol in imposing thirty-day contempt sentences on two defendants who refused to testify at the current Harry Gross police graft trial.
Dr. William F. O'Connor has been named chairman of the Chemistry Department at Fordham University, the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of the university, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The combination of Vic Wertz's homerun blasting and Duane Pillette's sharp six-hit pitching gave the Browns their first Comiskey Park triumph of the season today with an 8-0 blanking of the White Sox. Chicago, however, held third place.

The twenty-one-story building containing stores, offices and showroows on plot 50 by 100 feet at 32-34 East Fifty-seventh Street between Park and Madison Avenues has been sold by the Inch Corporation to Francis J. Kleban, president of the Kleban Realty Construction Corporation.

The country's gasoline stocks last week were increased by 847,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies amounted to 117,240,000 barrels, compared with 116,393,000 a week earlier and 124,932,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Because some of the Negro members of the American Psychological Association have been discriminated against here during the association's sixtieth annual convention this week, the association's council, its governing body, voted unanimously today against holding any further national meetings in Washington until "additional progress has been made toward democratic treatment of minority groups."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, and his wife were permitted to settle Federal tax claims of $1,384,500 for $300,000 in 1944, it was announced tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The Sadler's Wells Ballet, which twice has made successful and profitable tours of North America since the second World War, will make another tour next year, beginning at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York in September.

The American Friends of the Middle East, a voluntary, nonprofit society giving aid to Middle East countries, provided a lunch for every one of the 3,763 Moslem pilgrims airlifted last week from Beirut, Lebanon, on their way to Mecca.

The six-story apartment house accommodating 131 families at 1840 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Osinoff Brothers Sons. Lengsam Schifman were the brokers and the attorneys were Bernard Trencher for the sellers and Gainsburg, Gottlieb, Levitan Cole for the buyers.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 4 -The New York Central's new $1,500,000 railroad yards on the outskirts of this city were opened for traffic today.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 4 -- Federal Judge Harold R. Medina of New York disclosed here tonight that a Communist psychological campaign to drive him to take his own life "nearly worked."

The exhaustive nature of the State Crime Commission's inquiry into the waterfront is plainly demonstrated in the list of 300 public officials, politicians, union leaders and shadowy figures in New York and New Jersey whose bank records have been subpoenaed.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 -- A threat on the life of Joe Black was revealed tonight by Manager Charley Dressen of the Dodgers. It came in a neatly ink-printed letter addressed to the Brooklyn ace relief pitcher, purporting to come from a Giant fan but unsigned.

Dorris Clarke, chief probation officer of the Magistrates' Courts here since the post was established in 1945, said yesterday that she had submitted her resignation because the "limitations and handicaps" facing the department make it "futile any longer to attempt to do the impossible."

The Iranian crisis highlights the dangers in a lame-duck administration of foreign affairs and need of a bipartisan body to bridge the gap between party conventions in July and inauguration of a new President in January.
ROME, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Astronomers from both sides of the Iron Curtain met today to trade secrets of the stars, but started off by trading words over an earthly matter.
Twelve Massachusetts municipal housing authorities borrowed $30,818,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bond issues maturing over forty years at an interest cost of 2.433 per cent.

In a vigorous address last night in Philadelphia General Eisenhower outlined the foreign policy which he will pursue if he is elected President. As he has already done with respect to domestic policies, he proclaimed himself to be a man of the Middle Road in foreign policy as well.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- A reactionary trend featured the late trade in grain on the Board of Trade today, with longs selling on early advances, putting more weight on the market than the buyers could absorb.

If the public responds to the "get out the vote" drive in the same degree as advertising organizations, publishers and advertisers generally have supported it, there is no doubt that this year will witness a record registration.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,363, for Thursday's operations:

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Live hogs fell to new low prices for the summer today. An overnight expansion in receipts coupled with currently lower wholesale pork prices to press cash values 25 to 50 cents lower. Cattle were uneven, ranging from steady to as much as S1 lower. Sheep were steady to 25 cents off. Department of Agriculture reports of trading here today follow:
A 35-year-old policeman and a friend receiving flying lessons were killed yesterday afternoon when the patrolman's private plane crashed into a swamp on the north shore of Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will make a number of speeches before the November election and in one of the earliest of these he will "clarify some of the terms" being used in the foreign policy discussions.

Informal living, in which the out-of-doors sets the scheme for the decoration of the inside, is the motif of a model house now open to the public in East Norwich, L. I., at Northern Boulevard and Split Head Rock.

Active cotton futures closed steady yesterday, 5 to 18 points net higher, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued active before issuance of the second Government cotton crop estimate, which is scheduled to be issued on Monday.

Business spokesmen rose at a conference of 100 of the country's leading experts on "symbols and values" at Columbia University yesterday and offered a critique of the studies of the specialists which won them unexpected tributes.
Selling to the United States Government, the world's largest single customer, should be easier henceforth.
In your editorial "Strange Companions" you make some startling remarks concerning the reputation and ability of some of our elder statesmen.

" Unrealistic," "insulting," and "entirely out of proportion," were some of the expressions that marked the rejections of offers at yesterday's wage review meeting of representatives of East Coast dockworkers and their employers.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Hundreds mourned today for Charlie Davis, a Georgian, who was so crippled he could not sit or lie down for twenty-four years.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- A 46-year-old mother drowned here today after pushing her son, 11, to safety from a foundering motor boat. The woman, Mrs. Charles Dressler of 33-53 Sixty -first Street, Woodside, Queens, was trapped in the cabin of the craft. Another passenger, Avery Keever, 65, also was drowned as the boat sank.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Big Mike Garcia pitched a five-hit shutout in a tight duel today as the pennant-contending Indians defeated the Tigers, 2 -- 0. Southpaw Bill Wight also held the Tribe to five blows.
After five sessions of trading in which the averages scored modest gains, the stock market drifted easier in late dealings yesterday and closed irregularly lower on the day.

Directors of the Omnibus Corporation, a holding company which controls the Fifth Avenue Coach Corporation and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, voted yesterday to accept a bid of $16,500,000 by the Chicago Transit Authority for purchase of the Chicago Motor Coach Company.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh sent two multiple parking violators to the workhouse for fifteen days each yesterday and then announced he had issued fifty warrants for the arrest of other delinquent motorists.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, lashed out last night at Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson for his curtailment of mail service and declared that the proposed reorganization plan for the Postoffice Department would make its head "a veritable czar."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- During the week ended Sept. 3, member bank reserves decreased $37,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate asserted tonight that the two top Democratic nominees were perpetrating one of the "most cynical swindles" on record by their conflicting positions on civil rights.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Medals of Honor for three marines who died in Korea were presented to their kin at ceremonies in the Pentagon today. Secretary of the Navy Dan Kimball made the awards.

The wholesale price of rough diamonds will increase 3 to 4 per cent at the next sales offering of the Diamond Trading Company, Ltd., on Sept. 15, it was announced yesterday by the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association of America, Inc. The company, which holds its sales in London, handles the sale and distribution of uncut diamonds for the DeBeers Syndicate.

The city's oldest department store celebrated its 125th anniversary yesterday with its present head pledging up-to-the-minute service to customers. Albert Monroe Greenfield told several hundred shoppers, civic officials and employes that super market self-service operations are being made an integral part of Hearn Department Stores, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Stu Miller, rookie right-hander of the Cardinals, tonight pitched his second 1-0 shutout over the Cubs within three weeks. He hurled a four-hit game in which the Redbirds' only run off Warren Hacker was scored on three first-inning singles.
Fabrics and fashions that are important to the fall fashion picture were presented to the press yesterday by Macy's.

Daniel Starch and Staff, a marketing research organization whose present quarters are at 420 Lexington Avenue in New York, has leased the two-story former Best Co. building on Boston Post Road in Mamaroneck, N. Y., from Martin W. Lyons.

Proposals for construction of six new "unsubsidized" housing developments to cost $130,000,000 and designed to eliminate some of the worst slum conditions of the city were submitted to Mayor Impellitteri yesterday by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.

She is, this young lady, standing still for a moment, after a summer of constant motion, of goings and comings, visiting and receiving visitors -- standing still long enough to allow a ruler to be put on top of her head and a pencil mark to be made on the wall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Army and the Air Force announced today that they would hold winter maneuvers at Camp Drum, N. Y., early next year to train troops and test equipment under extreme weather conditions.

Representative Robert W. Kean of New Jersey told a special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday that top-flight Treasury and Justice Department officials had conspired to "hamstring" the tax fraud inquiry of the House Ways and Means subcommittee.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot, defending champions, tied with Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wright of Leewood for the Westchester husband and wife championship today at the Fenway Golf Club. Each team had a gross score of 79.

The Century Furniture Shop, housed in a 125-year-old building at 55 East Eighth Stret, has a new facade of California redwood, with some strips twenty-one feet long, and a new modern interior. Unveiled simultaneously are some new furniture pieces designed by Maurice Villency, shop owner.

Inspector Thomas J. Hammill Jr., an outstanding detective for the last thirty years and now head of the Brooklyn West section of the Detective Division, was promoted to Deputy Chief Inspector yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Britain can manufacture big jet airliners in greater quantity and quicker time than the public may have been led to believe, a statement from the de Havilland Aircraft Company suggested today. It remains to be seen, however, whether the production rate will meet the requirements of potential American buyers.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- The Democratic party today filed declinations with the Secretary of State for ten proposed electors for the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket, most of whom are barred by the Federal Constitution, or the New York City Charter, from serving in the posts.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 6 -- United Nations warplanes struck in force yesterday at one of the remaining industrial targets in North Korea, a mining and ore processing plant at Sinhung, sixty miles below the Manchurian frontier on the Yalu River.
Appropriately named is a new group of dinnerware at Altman's called "Interplay." The idea is to make up a service that mixes plain colored dishes with patterned ones.

BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 5 -- For the first time in United States Navy history, two 27,000-ton carriers -- the sister ships Antietam and Shangri-La -- exchanged crews today in a double ceremony aboard the two-ships at the New York Naval Shipyard Annex here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- President Truman's activity in the Democratic political campaign is to be greatly broadened from the limited and cautious in-and-out participation that he understood a few weeks ago had been assigned to him by Stevenson headquarters.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Musician showed the way from start to finish in the class A mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Stanley, Dancer guided F. J. Mollica's 5-year-old to a neck vnctory over the favored Highland Sllen in 2:05 2-5 and the black horse returned $5.90 for $2 as the second choice.

With the schools reopening on Monday it would be wise for motorists to brush up their school-time driving manners. The requirements are simple, but with the long summer vacation just past it does not hurt to remember the few safety rules designed to keep school children safe from motorists.

From now on it's Luchow's, not Luchow's, and the addition of the little umlaut over the "u" spells all the difference between an old-fashioned German restaurant and a chop suey palace. Leonard Jan Mitchell has been

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 5 -- There were fantastic finishes today in the third sailing venture of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week. Two hundred and five craft were out and in some classes the first and last to complete the courses were an hour apart.

GAINSVILLE, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP) -- A satisfactory way of using Florida's most famous product (oranges) in the manufacture of America's favorite dessert (ice cream) has been developed by two scientists of the University of Florida agricultural experiment stations.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois agreed tonight that "it's time for a change" -- a change, that is, from Truman to Stevenson and from old Republican slogans about "change" to new definitions of what kind of change the Republicans really want.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A patient granted this week to Alan M. Gordon of Madison, N. J., takes us behind the scenes with the hypnotist. Mr. Gordon has invented what he calls a hypnosis-assisting device, whose purpose is to convince a patient, who may be fresh and alert, that he's really tired and sleepy.

In your "Education Notes" of Aug. 31 I was fascinated by the item informing your readers that at the University of Vermont there had been introduced a program in remedial reading, which was intended for, among others, the assistance of "campus undergraduates who require help in reading."

Governor Stevenson spoke last night at Denver about what he described as "one of the biggest hazards" of his campaign. This is the widely held and frequently asserted belief that "It's time for a change." Mr. Stevenson, we think, is right in regarding this as one of the chief obstacles to his election.

Haspel Brothers, Inc., of New Orleans, manufacturer of men's clothing, announced yesterday that its Orlon-cotton suit for summer of 1953 will retail for $39.75, compared with $49.50 for the summer of 1952. The Sir Ultra suit, a leading number in the Haspel line, made of acetate, rayon and nylon cord will remain unchanged at $32.50.

One of the most difficult feats a newspaper man is called upon to perform is the cultivation of a wholly blank facial expression when someone to whom he is speaking or from whom he is obtaining an interview says, "I used to be a newspaper man myself."

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- East Germany's Parliament named today a five-man delegation, including one member of the Politburo and a deputy premier, to try to persuade the Bonn Government to accept the unification procedure outlined in the latest Soviet note on Germany.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5 -- Many scientists responsible for recent British achievements in the air spoke at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. The dominant theme was flight, fuel and stability problems in the airplane, the rocket and the insect.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- It is understood that the last Soviet note to the United States, Britain and France on Germany will be discussed with members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as well as with the Bonn regime. The replies to Moscow will be sent by the three powers as usual but the other members of the Western alliance will be consulted and receive an opportunity to express their views.

A request for reconsideration of the longshoremen's revised demands was denied yesterday afternoon by their employers and the next move in the current wage review negotiations put up to the union representatives.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange failed to develop a definite trend yesterday, and closing prices were 10 points lower to 6 points higher on active months than on Thursday.
Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's speech last night at Denver as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Yesterday was Michael Solomon's last day at DeWitt Clinton High School, where he has taught Latin for the last forty-four years. On Monday, he retires as chairman of the school's Latin Department.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 5 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, foe of corruption in government, resumed a campaign tour of Maine today as the Cumberland County Grand Jury was returning four indictments concerned with alleged graft in the Republican-controlled State Liquor Commission.

Your nostalgic mention of ice under the heading "Topics of The Times" on Aug. 21 calls, I feel, for a reply from this association. It is presumed that your writer refers to natural ice -- which is cut from lakes, streams and ponds.

Lumber production for the week ended Aug. 30 was 12.4 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 13.2 per cent and orders 17.2 per cent.
The Government rested yesterday in the five-month-old trial of fifteen secondary Communist leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.

A rising elevator in an alley just off East Forty-second Street near Fifth Avenue pinned a 47-year-old woman against a wall for three-quarters of an hour yesterday. While a lunch-hour crowd watched, a police emergency squad used acetylene torches to free the victim, who was taken to Bellevue Hospital in critical condition suffering from shock and a possible fracture of the skull.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5 (UP) -- A group of independent electors pledged to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees, withdrew from the Alabama general election ballot today, leaving only one set of Eisenhower-Nixon electors on the ballot, the regular Republican group.

Efforts of tax authorities in India to make foreign exporters or their agents liable for income taxes on profits derived from trading with that country were brought to light yesterday in a survey made by the Export Managers Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- James E. Alien Jr., the Acting State Education Commissioner, reserved decision today on an appeal to require school districts to provide transportation for parochial school pupils attending out - of - district schools more than eight miles from their homes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet Union's spokesman at the United Nations, attacked today the Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates, dismissing statements of their desire for peace as unbelievable, and said that United States political leaders would sign a pact with "the devil himself."
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 5 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower appealed to Maine residents today to vote in the state's election Monday, the first in the nation.

Some two weeks ago you carried a story containing information released by a "task force" of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee operating in Ohio. A part of this story singled out Antioch College as an example of the Ohio institutions which had been permeated by Communists and Communist sympathizers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- The National Urban League, avoiding endorsement of specific fair employment practice proposals, expressed regret at the closing session of its annual conference here today that civil rights "have become a political shuttlecock batted back and forth by politicians."
Net earnings of the Celotex Corporation for the nine months ended on July 31 declined to $478,024 from $2,680,988 in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, will remain the Liberal party's candidate for United States Senator. He was nominated for that office by the party's State Committee on Aug. 28.

GENEVA, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The World Federation of United Nations Associations unanimously urged the five great powers today to devise an international system of control for the limitation of armed forces and for the suppression of atomic and bacteriological weapons.

The immigration bill which Congress enacted last June over President Truman's veto should not be allowed to become permanently embedded in American law. It never should have been passed in its present form, which we described at the time as "racist, restrictionist and reactionary"; but now that it has been passed a continuing effort should be made to revise it.

Three thousand World War II veterans of the 100th Infantry Division, the first all-civilian unit to leave the United States for fighting in France, gathered yesterday at the Commodore Hotel for a three-day reunion.
Petitions nominating two Communist leaders, one of them on trial for conspiracy and the other in prison, were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

After long and careful study of the trend by newspapers toward use of narrower columns as a means of meeting increased newsprint prices and rising production costs, the American Newspaper Publishers Association came up yesterday with a number of suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Sept 5 -- Seventeen unions of nonoperating railroad employes who made a union shop agreement with Eastern carriers a week ago sent out notices to the rest of the country's railroads today requesting meetings this month on the same subject.

General of the Army George C. Marshall sailed for Europe yesterday on the superliner United States for an inspection tour of American military cemeteries in France, Belgium, Holland, Italy and possibly North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Government promised today to make every effort to speed deliveries of steel needed to help keep the nation's merchant fleet operating.

Shortly before the United States was plunged into World War II the women of this country were excited about word of a stocking made of a remarkably strong, man-made fiber called nylon. Not only would it outwear silk hose by many times, but the stocking could be washed and dried in next to no time.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Dr. Condon denied tonight that he ever had given secret scientific information to alleged Communist spies.

The Brooklyn Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York called on its ministerial membership yesterday to "alert" churchgoers to the "alarming" dearth of Protestant judges now sitting in borough courts.

Utah Power and Light Company has designated $28.75 as the price at which the company's stockholders may subscribe to 167,500 shares of new common stock at the rate of one new share for each ten held of record. Shareholders may also make secondary subscriptions to shares left unsubscribed in the primary offering.

The State Crime Commission declared yseterday that its subpoena of the personal bank records of 300 business men, union leaders, politicians, racketeers and others possibly connected with waterfront industry did not mean the commission intended to "charge any individual with any wrongdoing whatever."

Confirmation of reports that large amounts of new crop cottonseed oil have been going into Government hands under the price support program spurred trading on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Except for September, all cottonseed oil deliveries made new highs for the move and the close showed gains of 15 to 18 points.

Seven cruising - type yachts Slipped into the darkness from near Big Tom buoy at the entrance to Eastchester Bay last night to start a 140-mile race to Cornfield Lightship and back to the City Island Yacht Club, the sponsor.
Some people are inclined to think that the regulations applying ceiling prices to the charges in eating and drinking establishments are a mite difficult to follow.

William H. Jones, who stabbed four persons fatally in Brooklyn on March 5, 1950, had tried to stab an inmate while confined the previous year at the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane and had been described as "assaultive" twenty-five days before the hospital staff decided that he was ready for discharge.

An anthropological interpretation of sadism, masochism and lycanthrophy is the subject of one of two books published today. "Man into Wolf" presents a lecture by Robert Eisler that he delivered at a meeting of the Royal Society of Medicine.

America's chief hope to stem the Australian sweep in the national tennis championship was engulfed by defeat yesterday as Richard Savitt met his master in Mervyn Rose, but 38-year-old Gardnar Mulloy worked something of a miracle to snatch victory from Kenneth Rosewall, the 17-year-old boy wonder from Down Under.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- Affairs in the fluctuating fortunes of the Yankees took an exasperating turn for the worse today as Casey Stengel's Bombers frittered away the better part of a nine-hit attack and wound up dropping their series finale with the Athletics, 3 to 2.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 5 -- An attorney for Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, former deputy chief of the Chinese Nationalist Air Force Who has been accused by the Formosa Government of having embezzled $25,000,000 in procurement funds, urged First District Judge Leslie J. Eckenberg today to order the return of records seized last month at the general's Great Neck home.

YONKERS, Sept. 5 -- Although faulty with her putter, 20-year- old Barbara Bruning of Whippoorwill easily won low gross honors at the monthly best-ball tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association today. The two- time New York State titleholder, 1951 national intercollegiate champion, covered the Hudson River Country Club 6,130-yard course in 78, four under women's par.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler gave high praise today to William H. Draper, United States Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, for his semi-annual report to President Truman, published last week.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5 -- The Scottish capital's International Festival of Drama and Music, which ends here tomorrow night after the most successful season in its six-year history, announced today preliminary plans for the 1953 coronation festival that would maintain its vaunted supremacy among European festivals.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Consolidated Grocers Corporation announced today it had acquired ownership of Royal Blue Stores, Inc., and had reached an agreement to merge with the Weideman Company.

Alger B. Chapman, Republican state campaign manager, said yesterday that the Republican state organization would make an intensive television campaign for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the party's candidate for President, and Senator Richard M. Nixon, his running mate, similar to that which helped re-elect Governor Dewey in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The psychologists of the nation were called on today by Robert Ramspeck, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, to help stem the "increasing deliberate and malicious attacks" against Government employes.

A continuing study of the ways in which value symbols are used as tools of thought was approved yesterday by one hundred specialists in the study of symbols at the close of their four-day conference on the subject at Columbia University.

As the torrid heat of a New York summer begins to abate there is one place in New York City which will continue to sizzle for a while. I refer to that heavily traveled engineering antiquity, the IRT subway. It seems that this superannuated underground thermos tube was designed by engineers to whom ventilation was an undiscovered science.

Although American investors must admire the gains made by Canada, John J. Mann declared yesterday before the National Association of Securities Administrators in New Castle, N. H., they must avoid being baited by long distance telephone calls into buying "unheard-of securities from unheard-of security salesmen."

BUFFALO, Sept. 5 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations was wracked today by a bitter internal fight over the question of immediate endorsement of John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough president, as the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A routine official check-up on Federal payrolls -- in an election year that boasts nation-wide employment at a peak of around 62,000,O00 -- indicated today that one out of every twenty-four wage earners in the United States was being hired by the Government itself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Interest in the Western compromise on the Austrian State Treaty offered today to the Soviet Union centered principally on an offer to restrict Austria's defense forces to 53,000 men and seventy combat airplanes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union on the question of a treaty for Austria
WASHINGTON, Sept 5 (UP) -- Army and National Guard officials will plan the use of National Guard anti-aircraft units in home defense at a meeting here Sept. 19, it was announced today.

Engineers of the Douglas Aircraft Company are finding quicker solutions to supersonic flight problems by monitoring and directing high speed aircraft tests from the ground. This feat is accomplished by telemetry -- automatic radio transmission of technical, information -- which reports exact conditions encountered throughout the flight of an airplane.

A contract for the city's purchase of the Rockaway division of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road was signed yesterday at City Hall. Mayor Impellitteri delivered to William Wyer, Federal trustee for the railroad, the city's cheek for $850,000 as a down payment on the agreed purchase price of $8,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Averell Harriman, director of the Mutual Security Agency, expressed the hope today that the Iranian Government would accept the proposals put forward by President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill on Sept. 1 to end its dispute with the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company that has resulted in virtual economic paralysis for the country.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Stanley Calder and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair scored a six-stroke victory today over a field of sixty-seven in a Women's New Jersey Gold Association best-ball tournament at the Echo Lake Country Club.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Pierre Cot, former French Minister for Air and a leader of a fellow travelling splinter party, has received a public scolding from his Communist allies for suggesting that they should collaborate with non-Communist parties in domestic affairs.

NEW DELHI India, Sept. 5 -- India has informed the Governments of Communist China and the Soviet Union that gifts for famine relief must be divorced from "political controversies," the Ministry of External Affairs announced today.
I am in agreement with correspondent Dina Baer regarding the deplorably dirty condition of the New York streets. But I disagree completely with her suggestion as to its correction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, former Government scientist once labeled "the weakest link in our atomic security chain," objected today to what he termed "the oversimplified idea that I am opposed to security."

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, declared today that all persons living on public pensions should get special tax exemptions so that their "altogether inadequate" incomes could be raised to meet present inflationary conditions.
LAS CRUCES, N. M., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman said tonight that Republican farm policies were as arid as the semi-desert around here before water had been supplied by irrigation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Westchester County was asked today to appropriate from tax funds a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the murderer of John Acropolis, president of the Westchester County Federation of Labor and Local 456 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L. He was slain ten days ago in his Yonkers apartment.

ASPEN, Colo., Sept. 5 (UP) -- A ski instructor reported today that he had found two missing young mountain climbers on 14,126-foot Maroon Bells Peak, southwest of here, one of them dead and the other injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Disclosure of the exact strength of the United Nations forces in Korea is prohibited by security regulations, but rough estimates in Washington give the United Nations approximately 600,000 men and women, including air and naval as well as ground forces.
TRENTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The state today said it would attempt to move Moonachie school children bothered by low-flying planes to some other school.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- Broderick Crawford, returning to Columbia for his next picture, will be starred in "Posse" as the sheriff who rides herd on a gang of outlaws who terrorize a frontier settlement in New Mexico. Harry Joe Brown will produce the picture from a screen play by Connie Lee Bennett.

Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday included a new center for occupational therapy and treatment rooms for the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled. It will be erected at an estimated cost of $350,000 at 396-40 First Avenue and 401 East Twenty-third Street.

HARTFORD, Sept. 5 -- Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich, a New York banker, was nominated by Connecticut Republicans today for the four-year United States Senate term left vacant by the death of Senator Brien McMahon.

BERLIN Sept. 5 -- David E. Lilienthal has been asked to undertake an important role in a technical assistance team sponsored by the United States Mutual Security Agency to fashion a long term recovery program for West Berlin.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5 -- The free countries of Europe that are members of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development were invited today to avail themselves of the bank's facilities and to a limited extent its resources in their efforts to expand production and overcome payments problems.

Bobby Dykes of Miami registered an upset when he defeated Gil Turner of Philadelphia in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Flashing an effective left hand, Dykes gained a split decision over his favored foe. The award met with the approval of most of the 4,144 spectators, who were highly entertained by the struggle.

Members of Congress addressing the convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers, A. F. L., laid stress yesterday upon the inadequacies of wage raises for postal employes in the face of the rising cost of living. They pledged early action to try to correct them.

POCONO, Pa., Sept. 5 (UP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Federal Manpower Director, said today the Government was considering drafting fathers and more college students to keep at least 3,700,000 men under arms for the next ten to twenty years.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,364 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A National Labor Relations Board report today accused a southern paper company of resorting to virtual "chain gang" tactics by hiring armed guards to watch employes at work in an attempt to discourage union membership.

A Bronx father who caused the arrest of his 26-year-old son on charges of stealing family jewelry and clothing to buy narcotics said yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court that he wanted the young man "sent away for his own good." He said he was "begging the state to get my boy off the streets."

Clint Hartung's two-run pinch homer in the eighth inning and Sal Maglie's two-strikeout relief pitching in the ninth fanned the National League pennant race into new flame yesterday. These and Other heroics gave the Giants a third straight come-from-behind one-run victory over the Phillies, by a 5-4 score.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- President Truman today added stars to the shoulders of sixteen generals and promoted thirty-one colonels to brigadier general.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- British Actors Equity disclosed today that it had protested against a Government action permitting two actors from the United States to play leading parts in two films to be produced in this country.

DENVER, Sept. 5 -- Lady Democrats with a maternalistic feeling toward Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson may now be reassured. He had that hole in his shoe fixed. It showed up in a news picture during the Michigan trip this week -- an old-fashioned schoolboy hole right through to the sock.
BOSTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- The Rev. Leonard J. Feeney today rejected Catholic Archbishop Richard J. Cushing's plea that he cease teaching that all non-Catholics are damned.

Gatherings of Protestants are expected in 3,000 communities in the United States on Tuesday, Sept. 30, to celebrate the publication on that date of the Revised Standard Version of the Bible under the auspices of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

Six public utility districts of the State of Washington are likely to go ahead with a plan to purchase the electric properties of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company in the face of die-hard reports that the Washington Water Power Company, operating in the Eastern Washington-Northern Idaho area, has been attempting to arrange a merger with Puget on a stock exchange basis.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, rookie left-hander of the Cardinals, tonight struck out eleven batters in his tenth victory, a 4-0 shut out of the Pirates. Bill Bell, 18-year-old triple no-hit right-hander in Class D baseball, lost his major league debut for Pittsburgh.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Luke Easter's three-run homer, coupled with Early Wynn's four-hit pitching, powered the Indians to a 3-0 victory over the White Sox tonight and cut the Yankees' American League lead to two and a half games.

CAIRO, Sept. 5 -- Premier Aly Maher today reshuffled and strengthened the small Egyptian Cabinet he had hastily brought together when the army junta, headed by Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, seized power July 23.

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Seldon Mr. Druger of Newark, N. J., a graduate in international relations of Rutgers University, was re-elected chairman of the National Jewish Youth Conference at the final session today of the week- long fifth annual assembly at Camp Wel-Met.

VIENNA, Sept. 5 -- As a result of United States pressure and specific representations made in the last few days by Dr. Maurice Perlzweig of the World Jewish Congress, the Austrian Government may get around to a general settlement of the claims of the victims of nazism, such as West Germany has made.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A high source said today India would not replace her sole contribution to United Nations forces in Korea -- a 317-man parachute medical battalion, which ends its two-year hitch in November.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. James F. Cavanagh's Blackout from Glen Head, with Sara Ann Cavanagh riding, scored 14 1/2 points to win the junior championship as the nineteenth annual North Shore horse show opened on the grounds of the Old Field Club today.
Now that the oyster season is here, the Food and Drug Administration repeats a warning against the illegal practice, indulged in by some packers, of watering the shellfish.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Charles E. Dusenberry, the Orange County Republican chairman, accused the Democrats today of aiding former Republican Representative Hamilton Fish in his bid as an independent candidate for the Senate.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., chief United Nations armistice negotiator, just promoted from major general, will become deputy commander of the new United States Army Command in the Far East when its headquarters are activated, Gen. Mark W. Clark announced today.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 5 -- The singing of "Auld Lang Syne" by a thousand enthusiastic delegates brought the eighty-fourth session of the British Trades Union Congress to a harmonious close here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Grain futures showed only minor price changes today, the trade being light, with neither bulls nor bears showing much inclination to take any definite initiative. Weather conditions continued mostly favorable over the corn and soybean areas of the Midwest, but rains in northern portions of the Canadian spring wheat country may delay harvesting operations.

The Tarpon Holding Corporation has sold to Majestic Apartments, Inc., for investment the fifteen-story apartment house for 110 families on plot 100 by 85 feet at 209 West Seventy-fifth Street, corner of Broadway, for cash over a mortgage of $450,000.

As the walkout of American Federation of Labor shipyard workers in this port continued yesterday, three or four additional employers capitulated to union demands for retroactivity of a 20-cent hourly wage rise to March 1.

BOSTON, Sept 5 -- Roy Campanella, Dodger catcher, was fined $100 today and Jackie Robinson, star second baseman, was assessed $75 by Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, as a result of last night's eleventh-inning dispute with two umpires, Frank Secory and Larry Goetz.
