FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Champion Blakeen Bali Ha'i, an all-white standard poodle owned by the Puttencove Kennels of Manchester, Mass., captured best- in-show honors today in a field of 102 at the eleventh annual specialty show of the Interstate Poodle Club on the Far Hills Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today he expected to meet with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower next week to determine what part he would play in the general's Presidential campaign. Mr. Taft said in a telephone interview from his Murray Bay, Que., summer home that the meeting would "no doubt" be held next week at a place convenient to General Eisenhower.

Two of the three writers in the series of letters which you published recently on the subject of the regulation of firearms misinterpret the Second Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. One letter says that New York State's Sullivan Law is a violation of this Amendment and therefore unconstitutional.

The advertising agencies known as Geyer, Newell Ganger, Inc., and W. Earl Bothwell, Inc., have joined forces, it was announced yesterday. The combined agency will operate under the Geyer, Newell Ganger name. B. B. Geyer, president and chairman of G. N. G., continues in his present post as chief executive officer.

The Government of India has acted wisely and rightly, of course, in rejecting a "gift" from the Chinese Communists because of a string that provided that the fund -- some $84,000 -- should be administered by a Communist-created "committee." What is surprising in the episode is not the attitude of the Indians but the stupidity of the Chinese and Russian Communists.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Business continued to dwindle on the Stock Exchange today and prices again moved narrowly and irregularly.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Sept. 5 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today the United Nations troops in Korea were now so strongly entrenched and well supplied that it was unlikely the Communists would risk an all-out offensive.

Plans for the erection of a twelve-story and penthouse building containing small apartments were announced in connection with the purchase by a syndicate of the property at 411-15 East Eighty-third Street in the Yorkville section.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- Mayor Fletcher Bowron took a punch at a heckler today in another chapter of the fiery public housing controversy in this city.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Without uttering a word, two unarmed men robbed a woman proprietor of a restaurant in near-by Linden of $29,000 at 10:45 A. M. here today at Grier Avenue and Myrtle Street.

The five-story building at the southeast corner of White Plains Road and 243d Street, the Bronx, containing seven stores and forty-nine apartments, has been resold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a client of Emil Leepson, attorney.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that if elected President he would bar from appointive office in his Administration any person who took "a reactionary view about the basic tenet of our Constitution that we are created equal, regardless of race or religion or anything else."

VIENNA, Ga., Sept. 5 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, said today he might aid in the re-election campaigns of "two or three of my Senatorial friends if they need me" but would not campaign actively for the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.

BOSTQN, Sept. 5 -- Lefty Ken Lehman's major league debut here today wasn't a success, but it wasn't a complete failure either, because he got little support from his mates as the Braves beat the Dodgers, 3 --1, before 2,749 fans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- For the second time within four days, the Senators today got shutout pitching from a Cuban rookie malting his first major league start.

Completion of the Decatur Bridge at Decatur, Neb., a span left stranded by the Missouri River changing its course, will have to wait until the Corps of Army Engineers makes good on its commitment to channel the Missouri back under the main span of the bridge, W. W. Small, chairman of the Burt County Bridge Commission, said yesterday.

A new and aggressive "apparatus," controlled by a new generation and devoid of "the caution" of Lenin and Stalin, is on the way to power in the Soviet Union, according to Dr. Robert J. Kerner, director of the Institute of Slavic Studies and Sather Professor of History at the University of California, Berkeley.

Lovers of Chinese furniture who have feared the present political situation would completely cut off Oriental sources of supply will be pleasantly surprised by a collection of furnishings just arrived at the new showrooms of Charles R. Gracie Sons, 137 East Fifty-seventh Street, and available there through decorators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- State and municipal government officials and "an inert driving public" were cited today as among factors restricting the efforts of public safety leaders in the prevention of automobile accidents.

Active ordering was reported yesterday in many lines of side leathers, all types of kid leather including suedes and men's weight calf at the close of the two-day leather show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Upper Bucks County, Pa., Joint School Authority has sold $2,000,000 of revenue bonds due Oct. 1 from 1953 to 1982 to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100 for 3 1/4s, 2 3/4s and 3s, an interest cost of 2.971 per cent.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- The controversial Gut Dam in the St. Lawrence River was called an "intolerable nuisance" today as the International Joint Commission heard testimony on high water conditions in Lake Ontario.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 5 -- Science's fight against pressures imposed by government deadlines and the secrecy demanded by military security received a new and unexpected recruit today in Dr. Wernher von Braun.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- Gov. Paul A. Dever's eight-man Executive Council, of whom six are Democrats, will not act until after the Nov. 4 election on approval of pay increases for state employes and new jobs created under the $16,000,000 supplementary budget.
Selected railroad and steel issues were soft yesterday as the stock market again drifted easier and closed irregularly lower in the second dullest session of the week.

The 70,000 members of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., will be asked to vote in the next few days on whether to accept a recommendation by the union's General Electric Conference Board to terminate a contract with the General Electric Company at midnight, Sept. 15.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 5 (UP) -- A stubborn hurricane with winds of 115 miles an hour paused menacingly in the middle of shipping lanes 300 miles east-southeast of the North Carolina coast today and small craft along the Virginia and North Carolina capes were warned to hug the shore.

A spokesman for the Eastern railroads declared yesterday before an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner that the elimination of free pick-up and delivery service for less than carload shipments would cut by $17,000,000 the deficit the lines are now incurring from less than carload traffic.

The legal fight to establish the Democratic slate for Supreme Court Justices in the Second Judicial District (Kings and Richmond counties) was begun yesterday and will be continued today in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Walter R. Hart in Special Term, Part 1.
THOSE interested in getting in some pre-season training for their dogs will have an opportunity on and after the 15th, when preserve shooting will open in New York.

A former night club hat check girl and a 22-year-old Glen Ridge, N. J., woman who said she was coached in the ways of a prostitute and then cheated out of $5,000 she earned in a four-week period were held as material witnesses in $10,000 bail each as the District Attorney made new moves against an East Side vice set-up.

Dorris Clarke, chief probation officer of the city's Magistrates' Courts, changed her mind yesterday and withdrew her resignation after a meeting with Leonard Probst, State Probation Commissioner, and Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- Sand and mud are gradually destroying the thriving port of Karachi, gateway of the Indian sub-continent to Europe, port authorities disclosed today.

The Putnam Stable's Combat Boots, who finished fourth in two stakes at Saratoga, and the Cockfield Stable's Arcave, who ran twice with $12,500 claiming tags on him at the Spa, hooked up in a duel for first money in the $7,500 added handicap that headed the Aqueduct program yesterday.

James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, revealed yesterday he had received information of another contract in which Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, is charged with "improper construction methods and practices."
Six mothers appealed yesterday in Bronx Children's Court for action against a 5-year-old boy whom they described as the "bully and terror" of the neighborhood.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- New Western proposals on Austria were delivered to the Soviet Foreign Office tonight but there was little hope among Western diplomats in Moscow that they would produce a four-power agreement on the long-delayed state treaty.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 5 -- Gen. Carlos Ibanez, Nationalist Senator for Santiago and former President, has been elected again as President to serve until 1958, his rivals conceded today.

WASHIGTON, Sept. 5 -- Documentary evidence dealing with the dismissal of Theron Lamar Caudle from his post as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Tax Division was given by Mr. Caudle today to the House Judiciary subcommittee, which is investigating the Department of Justice.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 5 -- A new national bank, the American National Bank of Houston, will open here in about sixty days, spokesmen for the organizing group indicated here after announcing the bank's formation had received approval from the Controller of the Currency.

Ever since Mayor Impellitteri got behind legislation to put smoke control into a separate department a suspicion has been voiced that this was his way of "getting rid of Maxwell." While we recognized this danger we supported the legislation as right in principle. We want an independent Department of Air Pollution Control, because in the long run we believe it will be better financed and more vigorous.
Lee Shubert confirmed a London report yesterday that he had purchased an English play about a fake hero for presentation on Broadway this season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The State Department announced today that sixty-two individuals representing thirty-four countries will hold a series of meetings here, starting on Sept. 29, to explore means of increasing land ownership by individuals in underdeveloped areas, and of improving its use.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Australian -born Jim Ferrier today continued to dominate the Normanside course to lead the field midway in the $15,000 Empire State open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Aug. 30 totaled 727,344 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 106,776 cars or 12.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 102,137 cars or 12.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 124,497 cars or 14.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Apropos of the letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 30 suggesting a fine for nonvoting, I am in the curious position of wanting to vote but of being barred from voting because I recently made a change of perhaps two miles in my place of residence.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, flew into Ankara from his European headquarters today for a six-day inspection of the Turkish Army.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- A clear and precise exposition of the "strategy of the Bolshevik party" was made public today. It cited as one of the most exemplary achievements of this strategy the signing in 1939 of the non-aggression pact between the Soviet Union and Germany.

TRENTON, Sept. 5 -- Indefinite prison terms for sex offenders undergoing rehabilitation, schools for jurors and uniform sentencing procedures were recommended by study committees today at the fifth annual New Jersey Judicial Conference.

Archbishop Shokai Wada of Japan, chief abbot of the Buddhist Shingon sect, numbering 15,000,000 and second largest sect among Buddhists, who arrive here Tuesday, is scheduled to leave for Washington today. During his stay there, he plans to present to President Truman a bronze statue of the Buddha.

The United States has lost a stanch friend in the passing of Count Carlo Sforza. He was a diplomat of the good old school, a breed whose gradual disappearance is leaving the world poorer. He looked the part, acted the part and followed a line of conduct that a long tradition of European civilization had made both useful and honorable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- President Truman today appointed Henry H. (Joe) Fowler Director of Defense Mobilization, and said "there must be no letdown in our national effort to achieve these goals."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Bolivian Government has given a New York metals concern an option to negotiate tin sales with the United States Government and any other buyers.

IF, in a time of recognized peril, the description of crisis is monopolized by the prophets of doom, then courageous alertness is apt to disintegrate into cynicism and despairing fear, and these, in turn, may actually hasten disaster.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition, criticized the United States today for what he characterized as its inconsistent attitude toward free trade and a planned economy.
ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Randall Swan Jr. of Charleston, S. C., and Jerry South of Norfolk, Va., tied for the lead in the national open most boat championship today.

WE in America have been going through a period of housecleaning. Next to the words "power" or "communism," the words "gambling" and "corruption" are probably among the most often used in our press today. I have not made a statistical study of this, and therefore I may be wrong. Perhaps the words "delinquency" and "psychiatry" would vie statistically with "communism," "corruption" and "gambling."

MANY years ago, presumably in an age more innocent, the prescient Mr. Dooley remarked of men running for office: "No, 'tis no aisy job bein' a candydate, an 'twud be no aisy job if th' game iv photygraphs was th' on'y wan th' candydates had to play."

A ten-day workshop for public utility management just completed at Arden House stressed the recommendation that the executive function, besides its traditional concern with men, materials, money and machines, must devote itself more to the needs of employes and to responsibility to the community.

IT is fitting that Hollywood history -- some of it, anyhow -- should be recorded with a camera instead of a pen. And there is such an unofficial history of the last thirty years of Hollywood's span stored away in a stack of round tin cans in a vault at Columbia studio.

Leo Durocher's charged-up Giants, continuing in deed as well as in memory their sensational stretch drive to the 1951 National League pennant, sent the Dodgers reeling out of the Polo Grounds yesterday under the impact of a double defeat.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- One won't have to beg, borrow or steal to get the steel products one wants in future months even though the 1952 strike cost the nation around 19,000,000 tons of production.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- The appointment of Dr. Norman H. Topping, associate director of the National Institutes of Health at Bethesda, Md., as vice president in charge of medical affairs at the University of Pennsylvania, effective Nov. 1, was announced today by Harold E. Stassen, university president.

Many retired workers will not benefit from the higher Social Security disbursements to be made next month. Their pensions will remain the same, only the composition of the funds affecting the payments will change.

THE holder of a long, long suit is faced with a genuine dilemma. If he starts with a pre-emptive bid, he may shut out slam-going strength in his partner's hand. But if he starts with a lower bid (or with a pass) and his partner is weak the opponents will enter the auction and outbid him.

New York, long recognized as a fashion center in its own right, is today the hub of one world of fashion. It has reached a high point in the cumulative influx of inspiration. Imports contributing to its international character come from France, England, Italy, Switzerland, and Spain.

On his eighteenth attempt, Gardnar Mulloy at last achieved his goal of gaining the final of the national singles tennis championship yesterday. In so doing, the 38-year-old campaigner from Miami, Fla., became the oldest player within memory, with the possible exception of William Larned, to reach the title round.

VIENNA, Sept. 6 -- The Soviet attack last week on Austria as a reactionary country is being viewed as a ground plan of the Soviet case against Austria when the Vienna Government takes its plea for a state treaty to the United Nations.

KASSON, Minn., Sept. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a vigorous bid for the nation's vital farm vote, declared today that farmers were entitled to "full parity" prices for their products, and should be guaranteed a return at 90 per cent of parity through continuation and expansion of present price support laws for at least two more years.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Two Tiger errors in the eleventh inning gave the White Sox a 4-to-3 victory over Detroit today.

A fleet of seventeen cruising and racing yachts, delayed a half hour, because of a lack of wind, headed up Long Island Sound at 2:30 P. M. yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's nineteenth annual overnight races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Production of 386,534,118,000 kilowatt hours of power by electric utilities during the year ended on July 31 set a new record for any twelve-month period, according to the Federal Power Commission.

THE mystery story and the sonnet have much in common. Each is a literary exercise, artificial in form and highly stylized. Each is governed -- or should be governed -- by fairly inelastic rules. Each demands a special skill.

Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, ranking tennis player of the United States, yesterday was named playing captain of the United States Davis Cup team for the interzone round. In the event the United States defeats the European zone winner, he is to serve also for the challenge round with Australia in December.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 6 -- Signs of a record vote, coupled with a considerable crossover of Democrats to the Republican side, were seen here today as the state's Sept. 9 primary election neared.

The astronauts have been meeting in Stuttgart, Germany, to discuss ways of visiting other worlds. Before Samuel P. Langley flew his model airplane and the Wright Brothers soared from the sands of Kitty Hawk, inventors of airplanes were butts of ridicule. But no one laughs at the astronauts.

IT appears to me that the solutions for remedying the situation in which New York's legitimate theatres now find themselves were arrived at without any attempt to look into the reasons for this situation.

A dozen passengers on a southbound Seventh Avenue Express train watched in terror yesterday afternoon as one of two young men who had been arguing suddenly drew a pistol and shot one of the passengers for "staring," the transit police reported.

THE issuing of phonograph records falls off each summer. But, as can be judged from the disks briefly reviewed below, enough disks have been coming out through the slack period to see that the stream does not dry up entirely.

VISITORS to the Yaddo (Saratoga Springs) art colony will find an exhibition of paintings and sculpture by nearly a score of artists, most of them well known in New York, current through Sunday September 14. Six public concerts will be given on Sept. 12, 13 and 14.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,365, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 6 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins assured the North Atlantic Treaty powers today that United States atomic weapons eventually would reduce manpower needs for the defense of Europe.

IN Bali dance and music are interwoven in daily life like gold threads in a fabric. Since early times, when dancers in trance were mediums for protective ancestral gods, dance has played a major role in religious ceremony. Today no village is without its group of girls and women to perform the necessary ritual dances at the temple.

DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears roared to a 37-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today in the first major league professional football exhibition game ever played in North Carolina.

IF everything has been working out on schedule, an American company of Negro singers and actors put on "Porgy and Bess" in Vienna last evening. Under the auspices of the State Department, this troupe is to appear also in Berlin; and in other places without official sponsorship.
A report issued by the Institute of Foreign Education shows that more than 30,000 students from other lands -- a record number -- are now being trained in the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 -- The political philosophy of Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, to paraphrase the title of a recent book about the leading Indian savant in the "Library of Living Philosophers" series, was clarified tonight in a conversation with the wise famous philosopher-statesman who is now Vice President of India and who was recently New Delhi's Ambassador to Moscow.

A fiercely burning, gasoline-fed fire destroyed one automobile and damaged another last night as they stood parked at the curb in Forty-ninth Street just east of Eighth Avenue. Traffic in the block on Forty-ninth Street was shut off for half an hour while firemen fought the blaze.

VERONA, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Miss Audrey Marie Bart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stewart Barton, was married here this morning to Joseph John Healy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Healy in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Lake.

A policeman's plans to celebrate his fifth wedding anniversary last night had to be deferred when a quarrel over a small black dog called Spook resulted in a possible rib fracture and other injuries to the policeman and the filing of assault charges against two women and a man.

With the official opening tomorrow of the bulk of the nation's schools, this country will record the highest educational enrollment in its history. More than one-fifth of the total population will be attending school or college during the academic year 1952-53.

THE layman often finds it difficult to distinguish between ants and termites. Although termites are commonly called "white ants," they differ from true ants in structure and life history. A simple way to identify the two is to note the way the base of the abdomen is joined to the thorax.

THE restlessness of Hollywood's movie-makers shows no signs of abating and, at the moment, stars, directors and technicians are to be found working away in many parts of the world. This is not a happy situation as far as the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes is concerned because it means less jobs for the union's members here at home.

WAVE upon wave of now-it-can-be-told accounts have inundated Japanese bookstalls during the last seven years. First we had the anti-war billows and the memoirs of Tojo Cabinet ministers. Then followed the self-justification stories of Japanese military campaigns, task force encounters and personal exploits by colonels and admirals still young enough to have one eye on fat royalties and another on executive positions in a new Imperial Headquarters.

EARLY next month, the eyes of the world will be focused on a short, fat, black-haired, pasty-faced man of 50 as he stands at the rostrum of the Nineteenth Congress of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, delivering the report of the party's Central Committee.
The Taft-Hartley Act is proving once again that it is a more forceful instrument in politics than in labor-management relations.

Plants that are allowed to "go to seed" are rarely as unattractive as the colloquial term implies. Often, as with sweet autumn clematis and honesty, the seed heads are as handsome as the flowers that precede them. For many reasons (including future bloom on shrubs like magnolia and unwanted seedlings that do not come true to type from annuals such as alyssum) allowing cultivated garden flowers to go to seed is impractical.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A slick running and passing attack directed by Bobby Layne enabled the Detroit Lions to defeat the Cleveland Browns, 28 -- 21, in an exhibition game by the National Football League clubs before 26,000 at Archbold Stadium tonight.

The $10-billion-a-year home furnishings industry stood unabashed before the tribunal of consumer acceptance last week for the first time in seventeen months. Although no return of the unforgettable halcyon days of the period following World War II and the outbreak of the Korean War is anticipated, major segments of the trade made it clear during the week that the coming fall selling season would see manufacturers and retailers, and not consumers, at the controls.

IN the early war days, when ill stood the wind for France, the Occupied and Unoccupied parts of the country marked the boundaries of conquest and accommodation. The division was this generation's final attempt at thinking that it could live, half-slave and half-free, under a nice sort of captivity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- If Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson is going to use big words the Democrats are determined to make the most of it.

A VOYAGE by ship is a bubble on the surface of your life, self-contained and detached from the main stream. It floats gently in space, revolving airily so as to expose a placid cycle of forenoons, afternoons, evenings, all the same yet each one delicately different from its fellows.
THE news of the festival season has been, of course, the premiere of Richard Strauss' "Die Liebe der Danae."

Between 1949 and today the backlog of orders for commercial engines made by the Wright Aeronautical division of Curtiss-Wright Corporation has increased from a meager $8,000,000 to between $70,000,000 and $80,000,000. The corporation's total backlog stands at well over a $1,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Voice of America is telling Western Europe that, despite hot words on the home front, Republican and Democratic Presidential contenders actually give evidence of agreeing on the main points of American foreign policy.

FOR the fall reader, the seasonal embarrassment of riches is at hand. Between tomorrow and year's end there will be approximately 4,000 new books published in the United States. EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 6 -- On the spot near Ballachulish, Argyll, where James Stewart was hanged 200 years ago for complicity in the murder of Colin Campbell in a lonely glen at Appin, Stewart clansmen met today to protest their kinsman's innocence and pay tribute to the courage with which he faced the hangman.

THE recent return of Walt Disney from Europe brought the news that the prolific producer has placed still another project on his already weighty agenda. In addition to establishing a permanent technical unit in London to service his next three offerings, the first of which, "The Sword and the Rose," is in the final stages, Disney is busy planning the second, "Rob Roy, the Highland Rogue," another live-action work.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 -- Loy W. Henderson, the United States Ambassador, met Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today. According to a joint statement, "the meeting's purpose was to give the Premier an opportunity to explain to the Ambassador the reasons that are prompting the Iranian Government to issue in the next few days a public statement explaining its reaction to the joint [United States-British] message."

THE Englishwoman of Queen Elizabeth's day, says Carroll Camden, stood between two worlds. Medieval minded old fogies were still reminding her of her traditional inferiority, at the very moment when on the threshold of the new emancipation she was enjoying her share in the upsurge of the English Renaissance in the shape of gaudy furbelows, masculine airs, Latinate learning and the Queen's Majesty's patent to mine coal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will begin his first major campaign tour by train on Monday, Sept. 15. He will visit twelve states for at least eight principal addresses and some seventy rear-platform train appearances.
KASSON, Minn., Sept. 6 -- Fasten your seat belts, mates. The political weather is getting rough.

FOR forty years Mark Twain played with the idea of writing an account of heaven which would debunk the oriental imagery of revelations. Because in his youth the devout had still taken that imagery literally, he clung, in a notable lapse from humor, to the conviction that his commentary was shocking.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- Harry R. Bridges' conviction on charges that he conspired and swore falsely he was not a member of the Communist party in winning United States citizenship in 1945 was upheld unanimously today by a three-judge panel of the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- The Government is helping to break down the resistance of employers to hiring older workers, the Labor Department said today in a report on a special study.
MONTREAL, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation started its new Canadian television service tonight.

We speak of the wind and its voices, but most of the voices are in the trees. And even those voices vary from season to season, almost from month to month. They are speaking now, as the fall winds rise -- the winds, not the gales which have, beyond denial, voices all their own.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: September storms are hard on late summer-flowering annuals and perennials. Make certain that dahlias and delphinium are anchored firmly to their stakes, and that cosmos, perennial asters and even chrysanthemums have enough support to prevent their being beaten to the ground. After heavy rains, cut off all the bruised flowers.

BRASS, glass, mahogany and marble are the elegant materials which designer Paul McCobb has combined to create the collection of furniture pictured on these pages. The lines of the individual pieces are sparse, simple and direct. The resulting look is new, for the uncluttered line gives full play to the luxurious quality of the natural materials.

The United States program calling for cooperative action by eleven other countries in blocking shipment of strategic goods to the Soviet area drew criticism last week from an influential American business organization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Five distinguished American and foreign engineers were inducted as honorary members of the American Society of Civil Engineers at a dinner given by the society tonight. Election to honorary membership is the highest honor bestowed by the 100-year-old society.

Gertrude Lawrence, who captivated theatre audiences on two continents for more than twenty-five years, died unexpectedly at 8:30 A. M. yesterday in New York Hospital at the age of 52.
OF all the new night time television programs to be seen for the first time this fall on the four major networks nearly two-thirds will be on film. The start of the celluloid era in TV is here.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The second annual Eastern Cana Institute will be conducted at Seton Hall University here Tuesday and Wednesday under the joint sponsorship of the Roman Catholic Archdioceses of New York and Newark and the Dioceses of Trenton, Brooklyn, Hartford and Fall River.

ATLANTA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge, who publicly praised Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower here, criticized today the Republican Presidential candidate's statement that he might name a Negro to the Cabinet.

LAVALLETTE, N. J. -- Largely unadvertised and known only to a small clientele, one family here has maintained a sailboat livery for more than fourteen years. The New Jersey shore bristles with establishments that offer motorboats for rent on a you-drive-it basis and every few feet of shore line has its rowboat livery.

THE modern American Presidential campaign was born, amid much madness, in 1840. It had its roots in an era of decorum and silence in high places. It has careered through twenty-seven Presidential elections, setting precedents of every sort -- in speechmaking, zeal, propaganda, gadgetry, viciousness and noise.

CAIRO, Ill., Sept. 6 -- This Southern Illinois mining, farming and manufacturing community of more than 12,000 population has witnessed a sharp improvement in racial relations this fall, according to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6 -- Puckety Farm's Faga-La, under a slashing ride by Charles Burr, won the first running of the $15,000 added Philadelphia Turf Handicap over the Atlantic City race course today. The winner displayed a tremendous burst of speed through the final furlong to beat Sam P. Steckler's Decapolis and G. S. Smith's Handsome Teddy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Government took steps yesterday to see that gas and petroleum operators in this country, Canada and other foreign nations may get a continuous supply of finished carbon conversion steel for construction purposes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Vincent Hallinan, the Progressive party's candidate for President, said today that "the bi-partisan program of the Republicans and Democrats is leading America down the road to a bigger, a deadlier war."

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Exhibitors of soft goods items at the September Market Week being held here Sept. 6 to 12 are looking forward to business well above last year's volume. Participating in the event will be Chicago Fashion Industries, Style Exhibitors, Inc., the National Wash Apparel Show and the Chicago Wholesale District Council, Inc.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Richard R. Stokes, the former British Cabinet Minister who conducted last year's fruitless negotiations with the Teheran Government on the British-Iranian oil dispute, proposed today that private British interests try to settle the matter.

Hanson W. Baldwin's "Dissection of the 'Fortress America' Idea" (Aug. 17) starts off with a penetrating comment. "Any war," Mr. Baldwin says, "can be justified only if it results in a more durable peace or more security for our nation."

THIS work is the first of a five-volume project on the books sold by Thomas Jefferson to Congress in 1815, to replace those burned by the British the year before. In its way it is a unique memorial to our greatest philosopher-statesman and one that he would have found peculiarly gratifying.

New York's only sports event where thousands -- perhaps a million or two -- can see the excitement free of charge merely by turning their heads and looking out the window of their apartment house living room as speed boats whiz by on the North, East and Harlem Rivers pays a return visit to Manhattan this afternoon.

THE N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre will open its season on Sunday, Oct. 19, by presenting the American premiere of Benjamin Britten's opera, "Billy Budd," with a new libretto written by E. M. Forster in collaboration with Eric Crozier.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Representative Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford was nominated by acclamation today at a special state Democratic convention for the remaining four years of the Senate term of the late Senator Brien McMahon.

Substantial reorders for fall merchandise started to arrive last week, creating an optimistic feeling in the wholesale markets here and in stores, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office reported. Deliveries on fashion and staple items have slowed except in the hard goods lines.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 6 -- Robert F. Kennon, Governor of Louisiana, today endorsed Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency and broke a long-standing tradition of support for the Democratic party nominee. Bitter, blue-eyed Hagar grew up, poor but hardly honest, on the other side of the tracks from her rich cousin Connie.

THIS thoroughgoing biography of a relatively neglected but exceedingly important figure in early American history is very welcome. Morton, a distinguished orthopedist of New York, approaches the subject from the entirely new standpoint of "biomechanics," as he calls it, which means than man adapted himself structurally in the Darwinian sense to the laws of mechanics and gravity.

A two-year graduate program leading to a Master of Arts degree in teaching will be introduced this fall by Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn. The program calls for advanced study in the student's special field, plus educational theory and history, two full months of practice teaching in Connecticut's public schools and active participation in Wesleyan's academic and extracurricular program.

THE country's first national seashore recreation area is at last materializing on North Carolina's famed Outer Banks, the long stretch of barrier islands lying between the Atlantic Ocean and Pamlico Sound. Authorized by Congress fifteen years ago, the project is only now getting fully under way thanks to a gift of $618,000 from two charitable foundations established by members of the Mellon family.

LEWES, Del. -- Vacationists who want to mix a little history with travel on the Delmarva Peninsula will find some fascinating original research going on in an open field on the outskirts of this historic old town. Actual archaeological diggings are in progress here in an effort to discover the exact location and outlines of a stockade and settlement established on the site by the Dutch in 1631.

Stevenson today and, if appearances mean anything, they won't reveal their impressions until Nov. 4. Because there soon will be no more potential waterpower for development, the movement of the Federal Government into the utility field will be checked, B. L. England, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said last week at a luncheon of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

THE prestige of primitive art dates unquestionably from that famous day, now more than fifty years ago, when Picasso first saw a Negro mask hanging in Derain's studio. With his usual uncanny intuition this great illustrator realized at once that here was a whole formal language, of pure and eloquent expressiveness, whose value to the artist had never been even suspected.

WEST HARWICH, Mass. -- The answer one old Cape Codder once gave to a visitor's question probably won't hold true this year. "The Cape's a nice place, but there are a lot of queer people here, aren't there?" the visitor asked.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Grady Hatton's eighth-inning fly scored Ted Kluszewski with the winning run as the Red's edged the Cubs, 3 -- 2, before a Ladies' Day turnout of 10,966 in 64-degree weather today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Senate's "class of '46," having run its allotted span of six years, is up for re-election this year. Its term began just as weariness with World War II and the economic restrictions which accompanied it had reached a climax.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- A British supersonic fighter plane, the D.H. 110, burst into bits before the eyes of 130,000 persons at the Farnborough air display today and, as one of its jet engines hurtled into a hillside thick with humanity, killed twenty-five spectators as well as its pilot and his passenger.

DENVER, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The leaders of the Stevenson-for-President organization in Colorado took a gamble last night when they went against the advice of the Democratic national headquarters and schceduled a rally appearance for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson -- and then threw open the entire 8,000-seat Denver City Auditorium for it.

Committees of the New York County Lawyers Association for the year 1952-53, made public yesterday by Edwin Otterbourg, association president, included the following more important standing committees and their members:

RABBI AKIBA is one of the most revered figures in Jewish history. From a shepherd he rose to become one of the greatest "Tanaaim" (Talmudical sages) in ancient Judea a century after the Crucifixion. He was the inspiration of the last Jewish revolt against Roman overlordship. The uprising failed and Rabbi Akiba died a martyr's death.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP) -- If the auto industry's expectations are realized it will build five million passenger cars and one million trucks next year.

A new immigration policy should be set up by the United States Government to supplant the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, Rabbi Zev Zahavy said in his first sermon yesterday morning as spiritual leader of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Since the Liberal party was formed in New York State in 1943, it has occasionally supported Republican or independent candidates for local office -- like Newbold Morris for Mayor of New York in 1949 and Rudolph Halley for President of the City Council last year. But as a rule, the Liberals have gone along with the Democrats.

THE actors, director and cameramen in the large television studio at N. B. C. were coolly, efficiently rehearsing the latest triumph in Martin Kane's weekly war against crime. Victory over the lawless came smoothly to Kane -- just as it had every other week -- but to a quiet man from Holland named Willem Vogt, watching from a corner of the studio, the rehearsal clearly had the aura of the marvelous about it.

AS these editors point out, the science fiction short novel, while productive of so much of the best of imaginative literature, has been largely overlooked by publishers because of its unhandy length. Too long for anthology inclusion, too short for issue as a single book, this form of science fiction seldom finds a home between hard covers.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 6 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California asserted tonight that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson was unqualified to be President through his failure to recognize the threat of communism in the United States. He made the charge before 2,000 persons at a party rally ending a campaign swing through Maine.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 6 -- Sir Gerald Templer, High Commissioner General, is winning his war against Communist terrorism in Malaya, according to the Kuala Lumpur correspondent of the British-owned Sunday Times, companion to the old-established Straits Times.
I have read with great interest your recent editorial entitled "Trade Not Aid" and Ambassador Draper's report to the President on the European situation.

KASSON, Minn., Sept. 6 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois warned a multitude of Midwest farmers at the National Plowing Contest today that if they plowed under the Democrats in November they might reap a crop of divided and unreliable Republicans in Washington next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 107 casaulties of the Korean war. The new list included sixteen killed, eighty-four wounded, four injured in accidents and three missing. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

SEPTEMBER means school days again. The amateur gardener has an opportunity to widen his knowledge of plants, and the new home owner may learn how to fix up his grounds in the various courses offered here in New York City.

SNOWDROPS are of the essence of spring. Seemingly fragile, they are as able to endure the vagaries of winter as anything else in the garden. The English call them "fair maids of February," but in most American gardens they are apt to appear a little later than that.

Final acceptance of the Port of New York Authority's proposal to rebuild and rehabilitate a major section of the Hoboken, N. J., waterfront appeared assured yesterday after three of Hoboken's city commissioners, including Mayor Fred M. De Sapio, had voted approval of the project.

FOR many years David McCord has been known to readers of poetry as a distinguished craftsman, a man with a keen sense of simple vitality, a vital sense of comedy and an ear for magic. That he knows what makes good light verse has been proved by his own work and his anthology, "What Cheer?" published in 1945.
How can we get rid of corruption in the Federal Government? Honest government, like liberty, is the result of "eternal vigilance" and of constant, though often out of the limelight, labor.
A three-month-old strike by 600 armored car chauffeurs and guards against four major transport concerns was ended late yesterday afternoon when negotiators agreed on a new two-year contract.

AT 12:30 o'clock next Thursday morning the biggest commercial airline plane ever to take off from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a regular scheduled flight to the West Coast will lift off the runway and head for Los Angeles.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 -- In an abrupt reversal of his position, former Mayor James M. Curley announced tonight that he would "under no conditions" accept a $12,000-a-year pension for which he became eligible under a bill passed by the state Legislature.

THE problem of the short story comes in for perennial restatement. But not for solution. Enough of theories -- that stories should have beginnings and middles and ends, or that they should match the modern psychoanalytical mood and study the moment of a man's mind, or that they should best be poems in prose.

When the Appellate Division unanimously upheld Section 903 of the City Charter Thursday, the long fight to save their jobs waged by the remaining policemen accused of taking graft from Harry Gross, Brooklyn bookmaker, seemed to be drawing to an end.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The United States Tariff Commission late yesterday ruled against further curbs against the importation of frozen fish fillets.

Pretty soon, now, football time will be around. Pigskins will be flying and fellows will be "dying for dear old something-or-other." On college gridirons everywhere games will be played and in order that these games be played according to the rules there will have to be officials on hand.
FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, the Doberman pinscher that wears a look of greatness, became best in show today in the eighteenth event of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club.

In the debate between Chester Wilmot and Henry Steele Commager, "Was Yalta a Calamity?" (Aug. 3), it seems to me both debaters missed the main factors about Yalta: (1) that it was a deliberate rejection of the Atlantic Charter and (2) that as a result of this treaty 80 million people of nine sovereign states of Eastern Europe were yielded against their will to the Soviet Union.

" DIRTY, smelly things!" that was 10-year-old Shirley Garden's feelings about dogs. Fortunately, that was a minority point of view, for the city-bred Garden family of four youngsters and their mother had moved to the country to take over Uncle Jim's kennels when the old man went to Florida.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Representative of some forty nations completed a new international treaty here tonight to consolidate the protection of copyright throughout the Free World. The Soviet Union and its satellites were conspicuously absent.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Forty-three persons were injured early today when a Greyhound bus, en route from New York to Washington, crashed into a farm produce truck on the New Jersey Turnpike four miles north of here. The accident occurred at 1:30 A. M.

LABOR DAY is the day when business turns into the homestretch and makes the final end-of-the-year drive. And this year business is showing plenty of vitality, not only in beating last year's figures but in establishing new records for production and wholesale and retail sales.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 6 -- A general election in Maine Monday and state primaries in New Hampshire and Vermont Tuesday will give voters in those New England states their first chance to express their preferences since the 1952 Presidential campaign got under way in earnest.

THE Music Performance Trust Fund is not allowed to make grants to groups, but it has found a way of helping community symphony orchestras nevertheless. It pays the members of the orchestras to serve as barkers for their own show; for that is what it amounts to when it engages them on an individual basis to give free concerts to elicit local support.
Two of the Salvation Army's principal lodging homes for women will be moved to one building at 11 Dominick Street, Commissioner Donald McMillan, Eastern Territorial Commander, announced yesterday.

A second unprecedented event at the record-length game yesterday at the Polo Grounds was narrowly averted with the arrival of an ambulance, which took an expectant mother from the ball park to Harlem Hospital. The baby, a girl, was born there late last night.

EVER since major earthquakes and a long series of minor ones struck this area a few weeks ago, seismologists have been measuring the effects with their instruments. There is no scientific instrument to chart the shock effects on people, the changes wrought in their lives, yet the evidence is everywhere as you travel through the "quake belt" area and experience some of the tremors yourself.

WHERE are you going to hunt this fall? Each year several million hunters ask themselves this question, but, unfortunately, too many of them wait until a week before opening day to bring up the query. In these days of extremely heavy hunting pressures, a month's advance preparation often proves to be tardy.

THE fall planting list is as long as that for spring -- if not longer. Among perennials that can be set out ahead of the rush are the oriental poppies, which play such an important part in the late spring display.

THE two-thousand-year interaction between the Confucian, Taoist and Buddhist philosophies of China has long engrossed scholarly interpreters, especially among the Chinese themselves. The three main rivers of thought overflowed into each other from time to time and fertilized not only official scholarship but permeated, often in superstitious dilution, an entire civilization down to its humblest roots.

FRANKFORT, Sept. 6 -- Yet another attempt is to be made on the highest level to settle the complicated and dangerous issue of the future of the Saar Basin. Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany will meet with French Foreign Minister Schuman at Luxembourg on Monday to discuss a solution of the problem which is the focus of Franco-German difficulties.
Determination of what wholesale and retail mark-ups would be in the event of a reduction in the Federal excise tax on liquor sales is one of the most important questions being asked in the industry.

When a machine tool -- the giant machine that makes machines -- slips a cog, it does so on a grand scale. And when the tool is a special type imported from Europe, repair parts are more useful here than there.

Following is the text of the address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential candidate, at the National Plowing Contest at Kasson, Minn., yesterday afternoon, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 4 -- Elementary school studies in Israel are to be cut by two to four hours a week during the term that started today. Teachers have been asked to give two hours more a week without overtime pay.

SUNBURNED and footsore, the summer vacationists are now flooding back to the country by the boat and plane-load to resume their pedestrian, work-a-day orbits. Their memories are still fresh and ebullient, their snapshots wet from the developing bath, as their long-suffering friends now know.

ONE of the least known and, in many respects, the least inviting portions of the Americas is that short strip just above the Equator which comprises Guiana. Divided now among the British, Dutch and French, it represents the only foreign toehold on the mainland of South America.

The Department of Health has warned physicians in the city's child health stations on the possible danger of applying boric acid to an infant's skin. The current Quarterly Bulletin of the agency carries the following notice:

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 6 -- Wisconsin's Republican leaders, who have put the party organization solidly behind Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's bid for re-election, are confident that the Senator will win in next Tuesday's primary with a substantial margin. But Senator McCarthy himself has carefully refrained from making predictions about the outcome of the contest.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- Moscow's English language magazine News reported today that the "first steps" had been taken to harness the mighty power resources of the Angara River in central Siberia as projected in the new Soviet five-year plan.

Fire Department officials, headed by Commissioner Jacob Grumet and Chief Peter Loftus, were among 100 persons at a ceremony yesterday marking the unveiling of a granite plaque in the quarters of Engine Company 22, 159 East Eighty-fifth Street, in memory of Battalion Chief Michael F. Ruddy, who died June 14, 1952, at the age of 80.

RE "Give the Man Room: The Story of Gutzon Borglum": nothing definitive has been written on Borglum, and perhaps never will be. His single unique quality was a tremendous artistic megalomania, often thwarted by his inability to regard cost of any consequence in relation to his gigantic ideas.

MANY evergreen shrub plantings depend on other evergreens for contrast. A fine example of a different but handsome companion may be seen in the evergreen shrub borders at Swarthmore College. Here and there among the massed growth of rhododendrons, laurel and the like, is the slender, upward-thrusting enkianthus.

TELEVISION dance is at practically a standstill -- with a very good chance of going downhill. Perhaps the greatest tragedy associated with it is that with its enormous potentialities impossible limitations prevail.

FRANCE today is being deluged with tiny booklets titled "To Defend the Truth" and modeled on those which passed from hand to hand during the resistance to the Nazis. But these are dedicated to debunking the Communist line.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A House of Representatives subcommittee investigating global waste in military buying and storing of supplies that it estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars reported today that the Army, Navy and Air Force were "beginning to get the taxpayers' point of view."

THE Yankees never bothered to announce what they had done. But they took Billy Martin's contract out of the office safe the other day and tore it up. They gave him a new and fancier one in appreciation of the kid's uniformly excellent contributions to the team. Charles Dillon Stengel beamed in delight. He's extraordinarily fond of his little firebrand.
GOIANIA, Goias, Brazil, Aug. 26 -- Civil aviation in Brazil is facing a crisis, and a visit to an interior state capital such as Goiania brings home its seriousness.

IT starts with two photographs. One, taken in 1900, features Emily, John and Georges as children in a Bermuda garden gathered around a big balloon which is ready to float skyward in honor of the new century.

THE heroine of "The Deadweight" is a guilt-ridden innocent, meandering joylessly among a gaggle of self-centered folk for whom her guilt and innocence are qualities to be joylessly exploited. Far from overjoyed with his own handiwork, her creator vacillates between astringency and compassion.

Toys are merely playthings to most people, but to several hundred manufacturers they mean serious business. Not only is it serious, but it is big, with sales estimates for 1952 running from $370,000,000 to $400,000,000 at the producers' level.

The period following Labor Day is closely watched in financial circles as an indicator of business conditions for the remainder of the year. And the first week of September brought a confident tone to the stock market, with a reassuring effect on sentiment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Five depressing years under two totalitarian regimes in his native Europe have not dulled the optimism of Dr. Alfred Richards Jumikis, 44 years old, newly appointed head of the Joint Highway Research Project at Rutgers University.

Amendment, but not repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act to "restore" to workers "many of the gains which labor has obtained through years of struggle" was asked yesterday by delegates at the closing session of the convention of the National Association of Letter Carriers, A. F. L.

THE urge to bake a fine cake or serve a batch of piping-hot flaky biscuits is just as truly a sign of the approach of fall as turning leaves and a nip in the air. It is the season when the experienced cook, employing her new electric mixer, calls to ask why the recipe she has used successfully for years produced a close-grained heavy cake.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 6 -- Cherwell, Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's 5-year-old dark bay gelding, a recent arrival from Saratoga, took the lead at the last jump and captured the thirteenth running of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase today.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Brig. Gen. Grant B. Layng, retired, of the New York National Guard drowned here today 1,000 feet offshore from his summer house after telling a would-be rescuer to return alone to shore to seek help. The surf was extremely heavy.

EVEN in pre-war days there were rumors about a monumental piece of disk research being carried out in England by Francis F. Clough and G. J. Cuming. About two years ago, one learned, they had finished their task, a complete discography of electrical records, to which they had devoted a substantial segment of their life.

The pricing system in the petroleum industry is under attack by the United States Government. At the direction of the Department of Justice, a Federal grand jury in Washington started last week an investigation into the various practices by the oil industry in the foreign field, in which pricing operations unquestionably will receive special emphasis.

NEWARK, Sept. 6 -- Strikes and strike authorizations engulfed 10,000 employes in various industries in northern New Jersey today. The largest work stoppage involves 5,000 production, maintenance, clerical and technical employes of the Federal Telephone and Telegraph Company in Nutley.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 6 -- As new housing and industrial plants roll over farmlands without pause toward the eastern tip of Long Island, the indefatigable Mineola Fair will open its gates here Tuesday morning, "bigger and better than ever," for the 110th Annual Exhibition of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society.

Justice Walter R. Hart announced yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court that he would decide tomorrow which of two judicial slates chosen by rival Democratic factions were the official candidates of the Democratic party in the Second Judicial District, consisting of Brooklyn and Richmond.

CHARLES MORGAN'S second play, "The River Line," has provided this year's Edinburgh Festival with exactly the kind of production it needs and can so seldom find. That is to say, it is a composition which aims high artistically, gives the cast something worth acting and yet is not entirely sure in advance of its commercial prospects.

The Salvation Amy in North China has been "arbitrarily seized" by the Communists and turned over to an executive council of Chinese Salvation Army officers working under the direct supervision of the "People's Government," Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, national commander of the Army in the United States, announced yesterday.

WITH "A Cry of Children" John Horne Burns has completed what might be called an unplanned trilogy on the vagaries of human nature. It began with "The Gallery," that long look at the fleshly attachments of Americans and Italians living in wartime Naples.

Irving W. "Chief" Wilson, president of the Aluminum Company of America, occupies in the domestic aluminum business the same position that United States Steel's Benjamin F. Fairless holds in his industry -- that of leader, spokesman and statesman.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 -- Luke Easter, who had won the last two games with home runs, smacked two of them today as he powered the Indians to an 8-3 victory over the Browns. Bob Lemon pitched his eighteenth victory of the season, allowing five hits, but the homers by Easter and one by Larry Doby were the difference.

ABANDONING the usual themes of science fiction, Fletcher Pratt has attempted a detective story of the future. His effort is interesting, containing as it does some sound extrapolation of criminalistics, but the net effect is not quite believable.

AIDED, and, in a sense; edited, by young children, Ruth Kraus, always an original author, has produced a unique book. At least, I know of nothing quite like it, although it bears a certain kinship to Ethel Berkeley's "The Size of It" and "Ups and Downs."

CERTAIN operatic problems which confront the American composer, arising in considerable part from his lack of opportunity for experience of the lyric theatre, were mentioned last week in this column. A basic problem closely associated with this situation is one of particular difficulty in this country, where our poets, dramatists and musicians are so little accustomed to the demands of the music-drama. It is the problem of the libretto.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 6 (UP) -- The Dallas Texans tucked away their first professional football exhibition victory, a 27-to-14 decision over the Washington Redskins last night.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 6 -- The Todd Shipyard Corporation will begin construction here next month on a 427-foot dock barge, described as the biggest of its type in history. Todd officials said the cost of the dock barge, a major section of a 3,000-foot steel dock, would be about $500,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery has abandoned the system of special Federal grand juries across the nation established last January by the then Attorney General J. Howard McGrath. The juries were designed to sit annually to sift evidence on racketeering and organized crime.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif. -- While an earthquake is not something that chambers of commerce ordinarily list as a vacation attraction, California's recent series of tremors is certainly figuring in tourist plans in this region and throughout the southern part of the state.

Radioactive tracers, an electron microscope and other advanced techniques will be put to work on research in soap and other consumer products at the new Miami Valley Laboratories of the Procter Gamble Company scheduled to be dedicated late this week near Venice, Ohio.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- The annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences will be held on the Cornell University campus here next week -- Monday through Wednesday inclusive. More than 3,000 of the country's leading biological scientists are expected to attend.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 6 -- The Hutchinson Farm's gray gelding Peg's Pride, from Closter, N. J., ridden by Nancy Clapp, scored 16 points to win the open jumper championship as the nineteenth annual North Shore Horse Show closed on the grounds of the old Field Club today.

IF an experiment in progress at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing works out to the satisfaction of the postal authorities, the United States will issue, probably in November, the first two-color stamp ever to be made by the rotary process at Washington.

THIS week Mr. Ernest Hemingway is the news truly. Not only the literary news. Like Earl Sande booting home a Derby winner, or Johnny Vander Meer pitching two no-hitters in succession, or the Manassa Mauler battering big Jess Willard, a book by Papa is front-page news.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Sept. 6 -- Ever since it came to power four years ago South Africa's Nationalist party has been moving to complement existing segregation laws and improve its electoral chances by restricting the suffrage rights of 50,000 colored (half-caste) voters who generally oppose the Nationalists.
Following are the texts of the 1952 Democratic and Republican platform declarations on agriculture:

Dr. James G. Heller, president of the Labor Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday that the group had decided to build a labor college in Jerusalem, in honor of the organization's golden jubilee to be celebrated next year.

WHAT happened this year to August? During the four weeks that this reviewer was away on a blissfully undisturbed vacation, only twenty new pictures came to town and, of these, only one showed the mettle of an unqualifiedly top flight film.

WOODFORD, England, Sept. 6 -- Prime Minister Churchill, who represents this division in Parliament, reaffirmed today that the Government would denationalize road haulage and the iron and steel industry -- "the two principal measures to which we have pledged ourselves."

IN a Welsh play I once saw the councilor was attacked by the town's chief choirmaster for his conservatism. "Same old 'Messiah' and 'Elijah' year after year," he grumbled. "Can't you give us something new?" "Sir," replied the old man, "'Messiah' and 'Elijah' are always new."

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will reopen to the public on Tuesday. An exhibition of sculpture, paintings in oil and water-colors and drawings from the museum's permanent collection will be on view and continue through Sept. 28.

SPRING would not be nearly so breath-taking, in my opinion, without the colorful reflections which tulips make in the garden. Properly planted, their great diversity in form and season of bloom makes them indispensable to the spring landscape.

NO matter which way the political pendulum swings this Nov. 4, ere are manifestations already that a debate over the future of our two-party system is going to figure prominently in the 1952 Presidential campaign.

THERE are probably a number of record-listeners who have reached the point where they feel the madrigal is something they would like to investigate. As a starter, those in this category could hardly do better than A Treasury of Madrigals, a new disk made for Columbia by Lehman Engel and a 5-voice group known as the Renaissance Singers.

GUTHRIE WILSON, New Zealand public school English master, author of "Brave Company," the excellent documentary on infantry warfare in Italy, now offers as his second book a novel of New Zealand life in which war serves only to end irresolutely the story he tells.

AN extraordinary book, "Wisdom, Madness and Folly" was written under a pseudonym in an English insane asylum by a manic-depressive psychotic who has subsequently been discharged as sane. His release, however, has not meant his repudiation of the "overwhelming inner experiences" that have distinguished him from the rather commonplace though well-educated citizen that he was before his first straitjacket.

Ogden Phipps, the former court tennis champion who is vice chairman of the Jockey Club, had (1) a big disappointment and (2) a big thrill in the stakes races that were run at the Aqueduct track yesterday. So did those in the crowd of 32,764 winner-seekers who backed his horses.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 6 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, said today that neither the rebellion of Louisiana's Democratic Governor nor the southern tour by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee for President, would undermine the Solid South.

DUESSELDORF, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Association for German Trademarks says German exports could be increased 1,000,000,000 marks ($238,000,000) yearly if foreign concerns were prohibited from using brands which were confiscated during World War II.

Summer resort business rose substantially this season in New York and New Jersey, but declined slightly in Connecticut, according to a spot check by THE NEW YORK TIMES of fifteen recreation areas within 120 miles of New York City.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Enos Slaughter blasted his tenth home run of the season, with two on, and his 1,900th hit of his major league career to enable the Cardinals to gain a ten-inning 7-4 victory over the Pirates tonight.

EVERYONE on the stage or associated with the stage in New York knew Gilbert Gabriel, for he had a particular genius for friendship. His sudden death from a heart attack last Wednesday is widely mourned, not only by the Critics Circle, of which he was president, but by the Authors League, which he had long served as officer and committeeman, and by everyone in the theatre.

WHEN Soviet terrorism reached its peak in the so-called Yezhov era (Nikolai Yezhov was the head of the secret police in 1936-38), millions of innocent and nonpolitical people were arrested and deported and thousands were shot.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Just about everybody has seen those ships they build inside of syrup jugs up in New England. And the peaches some people grow inside of milk bottles. Well, there was a 'possum here in the same fix as those ships and peaches, only he was inside a squirrel house up in a big catalpa tree.

AS a handsome tribute to their state upon the completion of its first century, the Regents of the University of California have subsidized the preparation of these two lavishly printed volumes, the precursors of eight more that are to appear.
BERLIN, Sept. 6 -- The East German Government made a formal request to the West German Government today for permission to send a five-man delegation to Bonn to undertake negotiations on German unity.

EASTERN railroads have cast an evaluating glance at their summer experiment with low family and group fares and tentatively, at least, report that it looks like a good idea. Both fare plans, which went into operation last June 25, will run until Oct. 22.

CRABGRASS is an annual grass that turns brown with the first frost in fall. Most soils are infested with crabgrass seed, to a greater or lesser extent, and it sprouts when conditions are right. Unfortunately, they often are, and this summer has seen exceptionally strong growth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's reference to the alleged false alarm about grain storage facilities in 1948 concerned an old Republican grievance against President Truman and his Administration.
CAIRO, Sept. 6 -- Premier Aly Maher announced at the end of a long, laborious Cabinet meeting tonight that draft legislation to limit land ownership had been approved in principle.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Ferman Hanover, 5-year-old gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., turned in a fine performance tonight to capture the Canandaigua, one-mile junior free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 6 -- Top Republican strategists will be watching Maine's first-in-the-nation state election on Monday to see the result of their all-out effort to heal the serious wounds left by the Taft-Eisenhower convention battle.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6 -- The Evaluative Studies Committee of the National Community Relations Advisory Council, the coordinating body of six major national Jewish organizations and twenty - seven Jewish community councils, called here tonight for a sharply revised division of responsibilities in their community relations activities to prevent duplication of efforts.

KASSON, Minn. Sept. 6 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower hit his stride as a political campaigner this week and found out quickly that, just as in the business of making war, the biggest cheers come to the leader who is always on the attack against the enemy.

THE "Old Man" is a Cuban, without money to buy proper gear or even food, and past the days of his greatest strength, when he was "El Campeon" of the docks. He fishes for his living, far out in the Gulf Stream, in a skiff with patched sails. It is September, the month of hurricanes and of the biggest fish.

Such recondite subjects as the basic interest rate, creation of money by banks, and the Federal Reserve System itself, are becoming increasingly "popular." Concern over rising taxes, inflation and the Government debt, are at last bringing home to the average citizen the realization that these banking matters are fundamental.

THE twenty-second annual national meeting of the Biological Photographic Association, Inc., will be held Sept. 10-12 at the Hotel New Yorker. Members of this national group include medical, clinical, research and scientific photographers.
An appeal for volunteers to help raise funds for the New York United Service Defense Fund was made yesterday by Admiral Oscar C. Badger, chairman of the fund.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Jim Ferrier fired a record-breaking 8-under par 62 today to take a 9-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the $15,000 Empire State open golf tournament. The San Francisco pro's round made his 54-hole total 192, eighteen under par.

PHOTOGRAPHS of six of the designs in the series promised in honor of famous poets of India have been received from Asiatic Hobbyists in Chatkopar. The group, to be issued on Oct. 1 for the birthday of the late Mahatma Gandhi, will comprise the following:
CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Gales and high seas of an Atlantic hurricane split a Honduran tanker almost in two today and an air-sea search was begun for eleven missing crew members.
TRENTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A vivacious financier in high heels today has a firm grasp on much of the phenomenal industrial growth of this old capital city.

THE crucial test of a fantasy about animals is the credibility of the animals as personalities. This gentle, rather old-fashioned story passes that test. For some tastes it may be rather over-whimsical in the English manner but Ambrose, the Mouse, and his friend Simon, the Fieldmouse, are lively, believable creatures.

Dr. Bruno Tyson of Buffalo, N. Y., has submitted to the chairman of the National Conference on the Aging to be held in Washington, D. C., this week a project which he calls the "Garden of Eden." This calls for the provision of room and board for healthy couples, who have been compelled to retire at 65 under regulations that prevail in many industries and all universities, but who are willing and able to work.

The United States Public Health Service announced last week that there were 3,559 cases of polio reported in the country for the week ended Aug. 30. This total, according to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, set a new high mark for any week in the nation's history.

" WE need something that will lift our souls to grandeur if we are to preserve our globe for freedom," says Herbert Agar in his reasonable, yet deeply moving "Declaration of Faith." This "something," according to the book's central message, is a return to the traditional Christian - Judaic - Hellenic values: "The smallest progress in serving them might save the West from a revolution of terror and materialism.

City officials cannot afford to blind themselves to "the urgent need for construction of additional hospital facilities and new hospitals to replace obsolete and outmoded structures," Robert F. Wagner Jr. declared yesterday.

Persons active in behalf of the Manhattan School of Music have taken over the performance of "Dial 'M' for Murder," a new melodrama, with Maurice Evans in the leading role, for the evening of Oct. 27 at the Plymouth Theatre. Mrs. John Hubbard is honorary president of the beneficiary's board of trustees, and Mrs. Hayden Smith is active president.

The New York Public Library's summer series of noonday recorded concerts in Bryant Park will be concluded this week, with the final concert being held Friday noon. Since July the concerts have been presented daily from 12 noon to 2 P. M. in the Park directly behind the Library's Central building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
A bean introduced to this country from India in 1903 is beginning to make important news.

A few years ago a silver-winged DC-3 ran into a terrifying storm over Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Suddenly a bolt of lightning hit the plane amidships, burning off the paint and literally melting the radio wires.

The second annual Mardi Gras of the Rockaways ended last night after a three-hour parade of volunteer firemen from Nassau and Suffolk Counties and a day-long contest between forty teams of volunteer firemen at Rockaway Beach, Queens.
As the Presidential campaign formally got under way last week, this is how the two contenders saw it:

ROME, Sept. 6 -- High Italian state officials headed by President Luigi Einaudi and Premier Alcide De Gasperi and representatives of the Senate and Chamber and all the embassies and legations in Rome attended the solemn state funeral of former Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza in the Church of St. Roberto Bellarmino today.

BECAUSE many potential record buyers flinch at the thought of paying $17.85 for a full-length opera recording but cheerfully make purchases of children's records totaling in the long run many times that amount, children's records are an important source of revenue for the record companies.

THE once-a-week 7 P. M. curtain that Broadway's reigning entrepreneurs will launch tomorrow night is in the nature of a bouquet urged by a languishing suitor on his petulant mistress. Like the suitor, who prays his nosegay will mollify his lady's coolness and lead her into his arms, Broadway's a-wooing producers hope the early Monday starting time will lure a large group of aloof playgoers into their theatres.

IN their previous nature stories the Georges have made animals the chief characters; in this book a boy, Sycamore Will, is the central figure. Misunderstood by his father and discouraged by the hard life on a broken-down farm, Will finds a new interest in taming and caring for a baby skunk.

Not long ago the constable of a small Midwestern town dashed up to the entrance of a home where a nearly hysterical woman had a strangle hold on a cringing young man. Another "smart-aleck teenager," the officer murmured, as he yanked the youth out of the woman's arms.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- MoSt7 of the year sh9 is just one of the tninety pupils eta smart school for girls. Like the rest, she wears a white shirt, blue tunlC, a brown hat and a camel,s hair coat. But this girl iS "deS%L-ied to pray a role in"the l{fe of-the hation tlQat.wil! be far tlfferen% from' the lives of heri rclassmates.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- When Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was nominated for President, unfriendly critics described him as Europe's candidate. He was until he began making speeches on foreign policy and until Europe discovered his opponent, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson. Then the European view seemed to undergo some change.

With the call last month by the Department of Defense upon the Selective Service System for 371 physicians and 200 dentists to enter the Armed Forces in October, it has become apparent that it undoubtedly will become necessary to call Priority III physicians and dentists into the military services within the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Sam Rayburn, House Speaker, said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had quoted "completely out of context" a Rayburn statement to the House on the international situation.
