MEXICO CITY, Sept. 6 -- Consultations are being held here in an effort to remove the latest bugbear to European dollar-gap problems, a device called "retention quotas."

CENTREVILLE, Md., Sept 6 (AP) -- A brother and sister team from Oxford, Md., won the second heat in the International Comet class, regatta on the Chester River today, but a three-time champion from Edgewater Park, N. J., took the point lead.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 6 -- Gen. Carlos Ibanez, new President, will denounce Chile's military aid agreement with the United States as soon as possible after he assumes office Nov. 4. He also will repeal the act that outlawed the Communist party and will reestablish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, according to a statement by the secretary general of his campaign organization, published today.

The sales volume of major department stores in this area was estimated by trade observers to be at a level 7 per cent below that for the comparable week last year. Warm and rainy weather in the early part of the week, following the Labor Day week-end, resulted in a slowness of selling that set back merchants' expectations for a pick-up.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FOURTH DIVISION, in Germany, Sept. 6 -- Early this morning, with rain still beating on the hills and the mist still shrouding the valleys, two armored divisions, one American and the other French, plunged westward to open Exercise Rosebush, the first of the Western powers' large-scale war games in Germany this year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 6 -- The question raised by Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's abrupt rejection of the Churchill-Truman joint offer for a solution of the oil dispute with Britain is whether the Iranian Premier really wants a settlement. The answer depends on which side of the coin you are looking at.

BELGRADE, Sept. 6 -- A Yugoslav military mission will depart within the next few days for Athens, where it will explore the possibility of reaching a verbal understanding with the civil and military leaders of Greece.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Outside and inside went the sailing fleet in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week program today. The larger craft raced out in Long Island Sound to count their placings also in the Yacht Racing Association standings, while the others competed in the bay.

FIRST-CLASS reportorial skill has gone into this grimly detailed account of a small Algerian uprising against French authority in the Thirties. American students of North African politics -- and our global strategy has created quite a few of them -- will be grateful to the late French dramatist H. R. Lenormand, who has used the novel to convey a better understanding of a tragic situation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Sabaean, Glen W. Granger's 5-year-old bay gelding, strated at 25 to 1 and made his second straight victory a record performance today as he set a track mark of 1:16 in winning the six-and-a-half furlong Midwest Handicap at Hawthorne Park.

A mother's story of how her family helped combat the effects of cerebral palsy will be published on Sept. 22 by Prentice-Hall. In "Karen," Marie Killilea reveals how through courage, faith and determination her daughter learned to walk and write.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 7 -- The United States Seventh Army is nearing completion of two vital programs that increase its power and sharpen its efficiency.

A 17-year-old Queens youth who had admitted twenty assaults upon women, according to the police, was charged early this morning with the murder of Mrs. Josephine Brown, 23, of Mineola, L. I., an expectant mother, on July 25. Her body was found on a sidewalk in Kingston Place, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -- Delegates attending the second South American conference of the World Jewish Congress adopted today a series of resolutions calling for a strong counter-attack against all signs of anti-Semitism and for the enlistment of all Latin Governments in a campaign to block propaganda of race hatred from Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused a Philadelphia company today of falsely repreesnting the potency of "Fluffium," a liquid soil conditioner.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this week. The program follows:

AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 7 -- The possibility of a third successive Presidential-election bolt by conservative Texas Democrats developed, faintly but definitely, today as an eleventh-hour gambit for promoting the Presidential candidacy of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in this traditionally Democratic state.
NEWARK, Sept. 7 -- Workers in three big New Jersey factories will get a chance this week to register for the November elections without stirring outside their plants.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Lew Burdette of the Braves -- pitching in relief -- today successfully defended a 3-to-1 lead in the last inning and two-thirds of last night's suspended game with the Phillies, but the right-hander couldn't do as much for himself as a starter in the regularly scheduled game and lost, 2 to 1,

Reflecting the rise in sales, Servel, Inc., turned in net earnings of $1,062,150 in the quarter ended on July 31, in contrast to a loss of $42,066 suffered in the similar three months a year ago, W. Paul Jones, president, reported yesterday.

Two Long Island North Shore neighbors at Port Washington, Bill Leiber and Jack Kraemer, decided yesterday to make it a habit. A year ago they won the Harwood's Trophy and a $1,000 savings bond for circumnavigating Manhattan Island in their 21-year-old speed boat runabout Davy Jones at 54.2 miles an hour.
RYE, N. Y., Sept 7 -- A homebred Welsh terrier that had been tapping for recognition ever a year achieved it in a big way in the largest show of the fall dog-show season today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- The British Commonwealth Parliamentary Association will open tomorrow its third biennial conference since World War II. Although this conference can take no governmental decisions, it is expected that trends and national positions will be so strongly stressed during the debates that the future not only of the association but of the Commonwealth itself may be affected.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 7 -- The body of the last crewman to leave the crippled tanker Foundation Star was brought ashore here by the destroyer-minesweeper Fraser last night.

Americans are confronted today with the choice of either Christianity or Marxism, the Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt declared in a sermon yesterday at West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

VIENNA, Sept. 7 -- A distinguished Austro-American audience, which included President Theodore Koerner and Chancellor Leopold Figl, gave "Porgy and Bess" a rapturous reception at its European premiere in the Volksoper here tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 -- Leaders of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-defamation League and of B'nai B'rith indicated here today they would withdraw from the National Community Relations Advisory Council if a special report that proposes a division of responsibilities among Jewish groups and the community relations field was approved.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday that a civil defense central registration bureau would be set up in a new Department of Welfare building and would be activated in the city-wide air raid drill Sept. 30.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 -- The first major purge of the revolutionary Peronista party broke into the open today when a former Governor of Santa Fe Province, Hugo Caesar, and some of his close colleagues were indicted for "mismanagement, public funds fraud, criminal enrichment, violation of their public duties" and several other charges.

Voters are arguing economic matters in 1952. They are asking whether the average man (or the man earning more than $5,000 a year) has improved his standard of living since 1947, since 1942, since 1937, since 1932.
At the first press preview of "Tall Wear Fashions," presented in the salon at 13 East Forty-seventh Street, outstanding selections from fall and winter designs were shown in five categories.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California closed a six-day swing through three New England states tonight with an assertion here that foreign policy was the greatest issue of the Presidential campaign.
BOSTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Red Sox scored seven runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Athletics, 12 to 5, and sweep a three-game series.
LEWISTON, Idaho, Sept. 7 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois is going to throw the book at Republicans on the Pacific slope this week.

Richard S. Nye's Newport-to-Bermuda winner, the 46-foot yawl Carina from Greenwich, Conn., captured the perpetual Seagram Trophy yesterday by having the best corrected time for the 140-mile trip to Cornfield Lightship and back, the feature event of the City Island Yacht Club's nine-teenth annual overnight race.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The grain futures trade was in a rut so far as price changes were concerned last week, and none of the week's news developments was able to shake the market out of its lethargy. Weather conditions have been favorable outside of the Southwest drought areas, and this has tended to restrict aggressive buying.

There has been too much talk about price and not enough emphasis on quality in the sports shirt field, according to Larry S. Phillips, vice president in charge of merchandising for Phillips Jones Corporation, manufacturer of Van Heusen shirts. Companies that have prided themselves on satisfying their accounts with dress shirt lines should not consider sports shirts as having no relation to the reputation of the rest of the line, he asserted.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- San Francisco Forty - Niners downed the Pittsburgh Steelers, 29 -- 14, in a National Professional Football League exhibition game today at Forbes Field. It was San Francisco's fourth straight triumph.

SYOSSET, L. L., Sept. 7 -- The Angel, a bay gelding owned by Wee-3-Stables of New Rochelle and ridden throughout the show by Mrs. Dave Kelly, scored 23 points to win the hunter grand championships during the annual Helping Hand horse show on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. McDonald today.

The State of New York generated in 1951 a total domestic air traffic of 2,000,000 passengers, 10,000 tons of air mail and 34,000 tons of air cargo, according to a survey by the New York State Department of Commerce.

James Shannon didn't know what he was walking into when he succumbed to a moment of nostalgia yesterday. Before one could say "the Immaculate Conception Day Nursery," which is where he found himself, he was the center of much attention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Patricia Medina has signed a multiple picture contract with Sam Katzman, independent producer affiliated with Columbia Pictures. The deal calls for the actress to make three pictures a year for three years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Bob Rush, lanky 25-year-old right-handed pitcher, was just about the entire show today as he paced the Cubs to a 6-1 victory over the Reds before 12,975 to gain his fourteenth triumph -- the high of his five-season major league career.
A record school enrollment and inflationary maintenance costs have combined to cause educational headaches as the nation's 1952-53 school year gets under way this week.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 7 -- Last week's change in the Cabinet is not expected to have any marked influence on financial and economic policies although it is held that the leftist groups are more predominant than they were in the former Cabinet.

TEHERAN, Iran. Sept. 7 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh issued today a detailed rejection of the joint Churchill-Truman offer for a settlement of the Iranian oil problem. It came in the form of a written declaration released to the press that at the same time contained what amounted to a set of counter-proposals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Adequate feeding of the human liver may ultimately prove to be the key for a comfortable and useful old age, Dr. Julius Pomeranze of the New York Medical College said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, was accused today by the Republicans of permitting widespread commercial gambling to flourish in Southern Illinois "without attention or action."

Arthur Bliss Lane, former Ambassador to Poland, assailed yesterday the Administration's foreign policy, which he said was one of "containing" the Soviet Union as far as the Iron Curtain countries were concerned.
ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Randall Swan Jr. of Charleston, S. C., sailed the Blue Moon II before a sharp northeast wind into the national open moth boat championship today.

Radio advertisers who have been watching the growing popularity of television with some uncertainty can be reassured that the older medium is still alive and kicking by reading the latest A. C. Nielson Company report on radio ownership. The survey disclosed yesterday that 98 per cent of all the homes in the United States have a radio. In 1950, only 95.6 per cent had a receiver.
CHEYENNE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech delivered here last night by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate:

TEN years ago in his "A Time for Greatness" Herbert Agar wrote an eloquent appeal to his embattled countrymen to meet the challenge and the opportunities of the second World War with idealism and magnanimity. Today in his new book, "A Declaration of Faith,"* he calls upon us once again to display those same virtues during these perilous years of crisis and uncertainty. Mr. Agar is a man of impressive learning and fervent moral earnestness.

The International Monetary Fund has warned the free world that many of its member nations are living beyond their means, and that this is causing world-wide inflation, which makes the stabilization of currencies and the removal of exchange and trade controls and discriminations impossible.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 -- The first left-handed Miss America in twenty-six pageants started late today on the busy year of her reign that will find her traveling more than 100,000 miles and making 200 personal appearances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Deportations of politically suspect Czechs and Slovaks from urban Czechoslovak centers for forced labor in rural mining and industrial areas, which started on a moderate scale more than a year ago, were reported today to have risen to mass proportions in the past three months.
With three exceptions, the current Broadway shows will raise their curtains at 7 o'clock on Monday nights, beginning this evening.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 7 (UP) -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, said today he would "never concede to the Republicans" that the major source of the Democratic party's strength was anywhere but in the "enlightened Northern states."

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Prayers of thanksgiving for the fortitude of the early Christian Church and a message of hope for continued growth were solemnly blended here today in ceremonies opening the fifty-seventh Triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Fifty city firemen who are eligible for appointment as lieutenants are to receive training in the duties and responsibilities of company commanders in new courses to be given at the Fire College beginning on Thursday, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet announced yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 7 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is planning another aerial invasion of the South early in October in a bid for the sixty-three electoral votes of Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Kentucky.
MONTREAL, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Television came to Canada Saturday night as the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation officially opened CBFT, this country's first TV station.

If the past summer's weather has furrowed the farmer's brow, it has brought nothing but smiles to the soft drink vender. Hot beaches, steaming baseball parks and stifling apartments create hot and thirsty consumers of fizzing beverages, and this summer there have been heat and thirst aplenty.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Imputar, 7-year-old chestnut gelding owned by H. J. Lamude of Chappaqua, and Peg's Pride, aged gray gelding from Teddy Gussenhoven's Hutchinson Stables at Cluster, N. J., captured major honors in the sixteenth Lawrence Farms horse show at the Lawrence Farms Stable's new outdoor ring today.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- About 40 per cent of the farm families in China have been organized into various kinds of cooperative "mutual aid" groups in the Chinese Communist Government's gradual but steady march toward the collectivization of agriculture.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Astronomy has shown that man and the planet on which he lives are infinitesimally small as compared with the whole of creation but bears witness to the existence of God, the Pope today told 400 astronomers whom he received in his summer residence, Castel Gandolfo.

The old railroad swing bridge over Arthur Kill, a vital waterway between Staten Island and Elizabeth that carries 30 per cent of the commerce of the Port of New York, appears destined to remain a hazard to navigation for some time to come.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Secretary of the Army Frank Pace said today that he did not believe a military career "best qualified one for President."

JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 7 -- The Canadian Pacific liner Princess Kathleen ran aground on a reef north of here early today and sank this afternoon when she slipped off her rocky berth. The 300 pasengers and crew of 116 all were saved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A spokesman for the House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee investigating the Department of Justice held out the possibility tonight of public hearings within two weeks to receive "new facts and evidence" by Theron Lamar Caudle, dismissed last November as Assistantant Attorney General.
Funeral arrangements were completed yesterday for Gertrude Lawrence, the actress, who died here Saturday at the age of 52.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The report of yesterday's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Big Jawn Mize, 39 years of age and probably trouping around the major circuit for the last time, came to bat only once today, but it produced a home run that was something to behold.
Frank Sedgman of Australia and Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., remain enthroned for a second year as the national tennis champions of the United States.

It seems to me that THE NEW YORK TIMES has not looked thoroughly into the information it presented in its editorial of Sept. 1 on "World Champions.'' Your paper should have considered the fact that there might be another side to Little League Baseball.

NEWARK, Sept. 7 -- Nearly 1,000 persons today attended the dedication ceremonies for the $1,500,000 Mother Frances Schervier Hall, new annex of St. Michael's Hospital, which is to be used as the institution's educational center.

SANDY HOOK, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Three Brooklyn men were rescued by a passing oil tanker here today as they clung to their overturned outboard motorboat in the choppy waters of Ambrose Channel, five miles east of here in the Atlantic Ocean.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 7 -- Doris Knoeppel of Cliffside Park High, Carol La Roza of Westfield High, Dale Reis of Ridgewood High and Lorraine Lewis of Roosevelt High gained the semi-final round in the eighth annual Eastern interscholastic tennis championship for girls on the Kimberley School courts today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Washington State's first annual international Far East trade fair, displaying $500,000 worth of goods from seven nations of the Orient and the colony of Hong Kong, opened here yesterday. It will continue through Sept. 14.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 7 -- Ninety delegates arriving in Oxford tomorrow from all parts of the world for the International Union of Family Organizations' conference will find themselves living in the middle of a fair ground.
The Ford Foundation has made a grant to the Fund for Adult Education for the finding of practical methods by which to develop television as an educational medium.
Your Aug. 27 issue carried a letter over the signature of Dr. Leo Spira which made certain statements concerning fluoridation of public water supplies.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- British Aeronautical experts started an inquiry today to discover if possible the force that disintegrated the supersonic jet fighter as it flew over the heads of 130,000 spectators at the Farnborough air display yesterday, killing twenty-seven persons and injuring sixty-five.

CAIRO, Sept. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Commander in Chief of the Egyptian armed forces, brushed Premier Aly Maher and his newly reshuffled Cabinet aside today and assumed direct control of the affairs of state.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Coordinating its attack in workmanlike style, the Meadow Brook four beat Bostwick Field today 8 to 6, in the opening match in the round-robin competition leading to the national twenty-goal polo championship.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 8 -- A North Korean security officer attached to the Communist armistice delegation at Panmunjom was a prisoner of the United Nations Command today after he had strolled through the enemy lines surrounding the conference site and surrendered at an Allied guard post as a deserter.

Two independent American observers have just given a general appraisal of the situation in East Asia after extended tours. They are Associate Justice Douglas and Ambassador Bowles. They are quite different temperamentally and approach Asian problems from widely divergent points of immediate interest, but they have made reports that are closely parallel.

Cotton futures prices held in a narrow trading groove last week but the over-all trend continued upward. Net gains for the week ranged from $1 to $2.20 a bale. Weather and crop reports were again among the main bullish factors.

When the traditional 9 o'clock bells ring throughout the city this morning, it will signalize the end of the long summer vacation for 35,000 teachers and more than 900,000 boys and girls. A new academic year, with its hopes and promises, its tribulations and problems, is about to begin.

ZURICH, Sept. 7 -- Two outstanding features of stock exchange business resulting directly from the outcome of the London conference on Germany's external debts and the agreement between the Allies and Switzerland to terminate the Washington accord dominated discussions in Zurich last week because they are believed to indicate decisively the future trend of the stock market.

The possibility of a waterfront strike here increased yesterday as the 130-man wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., prepared to meet at 10 o'clock this morning to discuss the rejection by employers of their reduced demands.
This is the seventh in a series of columns on cooking in the households of consuls and other foreign officials living in New York. The eighth will appear next Monday.
DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Left-hander Ted Gray, although tagged for eight hits in the last five innings, was tough in the clutches and pitched the Tigers to a 4-2 victory over the White Sox today.

The Dodgers said it with homers at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Before 40,037 excited onlookers, they whipped the Giants, 4 to 1, snapping a five-game winning streak for Leo Durocher's crew and giving at least a temporary jolt to pennant pretensions of the champions.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 7 (UP) -- Navy Lieut. (j.g.) Harry R. Flory Jr., 26 years old, of New York, was killed when his FG-1D Corsair-type fighter plane crashed in an open field on the Clarence Rogers ranch eight miles north of here yesterday afternoon.

In statements made public yesterday by the National Conference of Christian and Jews, both major party candidates for President, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat, expressed agreement on the nation's need for understanding and cooperation among all racial and religious groups.

THERE were 13,000 witnesses to the brutal slaughter and yet the culprit escaped unapprehended. Not only did he get away with it but they gave him a trophy as a memento of man's inhumanity to man. Who said that crime doesn't pay?

For the growing number of Americans -- both professional designers and amateur consumers -- who are interested in knowing how -- and if -- Japanese traditional designs can be adapted to contemporary living there are few tangible examples to be found in this city.

" An Ambassador of Christ" whose life was devoted to building "the King's Highway in pathless China to lead the people out of the darkness" was Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly's characterization yesterday of the late Bishop Francis X. Ford. Bishop Flannelly preached the sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

The action of Gov. Robert F. Kennon of Louisiana, a Democrat, in endorsing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, is evidence that throughout the country people are revolting against "corruption and ineptitude in Washington," Walter Williams, national chairman of Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon, declared here yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Jim Ferrier won the Empire State open golf tournament today, but failed to break the Professional Golfers Association tournament record of 259 for 72 holes.

CLEVELAND Sept 7 (UP) -- Mike Carcia notched his nineteenth victory and Steve-Gromek posted his seventh today as the Indians defeated the Browns, 4 -- 0 and 3 -- 1, and cut the Yankees' first-place lead in the American League to two games.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The strength and exuberance which the stock markets have recently been displaying and which has taken many people by surprise was sooner or later bound to receive the check that came last week. It was obvious that the pace of the preceding two or three weeks could not be maintained and that a pause for consolidation was bound to come.

Edwin L. Ricker, formerly personnel division manager, has been appointed director of labor relations of the Standard Oil Development Company, Linden, N. J. Earl E. Willaur, who has been with the company fifteen years, will become personnel division manager.

Religion taught at home is more important than religion taught in school or in the church, Cardinal Spellman told 1,000 laymen and priests who gathered in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to complete plans for a "Family Rosary Crusade."

More than a score of speakers of national and international reputation will address the twenty-fourth annual Boston Conference on Distribution to be held at the Statler Hotel in Boston Oct. 20 and 21, it was announced over the week-end by Daniel Bloomfield, director of the conference.

RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 7 -- The three-legged fox was the pet of a veteran deer guide in Rapid Run, Pa. Although the guide was fond of the fox, he sold his pet to a friend from McElhattan, Pa., a town thirty miles distant. Crated, the fox was shipped by Railway Express from Lewisburg, forty miles from McElhattan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Heavy liquidation in September was the feature in lard trading last week. The liquidating movement antedated delivery day, with heavy selling starting the latter part of August. There was considerable hedge pressure which also was a weight on the market, which had been saturated by selling of long lines.

Television, having brought the Republican and Democratic conventions into our homes, has given the general public a clearer insight into the manner in which the men who are to run for the highest office in these United States are nominated.

Christians must keep their spiritual houses in order lest they be evicted from this world suddenly, Dean James A. Pike of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine declared in a sermon there yesterday morning. To illustrate, he cited the pornographic display and gambling devices found in the palace of Egypt's deposed King Farouk after his sudden departure

Evelyn Colby and John Galbraith Forrest, the latter finance and business editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, have put together a book on "Ways and Means to Successful Retirement,"* It is not a restful book. For these authors, nobody sits peacefully in the golden afterglow of life. Those who retire in the Colby-Forrest manner are going to be as busy as a man making love in a swarm of black flies.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The summer chamber music concert in semi-outdoor surroundings seems to have developed into a New England specialty, but this afternoon Mrs. Alma Morgenthau showed what Long Island could do in that direction. She presented a concert, which in musical taste, quality of performance and charm of site equaled the best New England can offer.
It was another week of listless trading in the foreign exchanges, the end result of which produced minor price changes.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,366, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Two, and possibly three, operas in English will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera Company this season in productions adapted especially for television on "Omnibus," the ninety-minute program to be started shortly by the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation.

The Rev. Dr. C. Franklin Koch, executive secretary of the Board of Social Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared yesterday that faith in God was giving strength and hope to thousands of displaced persons in Germany.

The data released by the Bureau of the Census as reported in THE TIMES of Aug. 31 on the number of new voters and the size of the voting population deserve further analysis for the benefit of those who bewail our laziness and lack of political interest.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 8 -- Communist troops lashed out with seven separate attacks on Allied positions across Korea yesterday. The Reds won key ground at three points, but savage counter-attacks by United Nations troops regained some of the positions.

Paul Deperon, a Belgian who had been associated with the League of Nations and the United Nations, was found dead at 4:25 P. M. yesterday in his room in the Beaux Arts Apartment Hotel, 310 East Forty-fourth Street. Near the body the police found a bottle partly filled with what appeared to be sleeping pills.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A report just issued by the Federal Power Commission tells the statistical story of the growing trend toward use of natural gas instead of coal in generating electricity.
Sooner or later Federal legislation will be enacted barring racial or religious discrimination in employment, Senator Irving M. Ives declared yesterday afternoon.

ABOARD U. S. S. WISCONSIN, at Sea, Sept. 7 -- The quartermaster will no longer report "two-blocked" to the officer of the deck, for naval language is being internationalized and standardized, at least by the Western Allies.

Max Liebman's ninety-minute musical, "Your Show of Shows," returned to the air Saturday evening, which for a good many viewers means the new television season has started formally. As in past years, Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca are headlining the production and on their premiere over the National Broadcasting Company network they contributed a number of thoroughly diverting moments.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Closing the twentieth annual Race Week of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, 232 sailing craft took part today in the last regatta, making 1,080 starts over the five days.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The nation's ability to defend itself is seriously affected by failure to set up a proper policy for the greatest utilization of its manpower, an engineer declared here today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1 -- A forthright attack on scientific authoritarianism in the United States and elsewhere was made tonight by Prof. Alexander MacBeath of the department of philosophy at Queens University here, who is attending the meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

It is impossible not to be alarmed by the victory of Gen. Carlos Ibanez in the Chilean Presidential elections. This has proved to be an election of great significance to the whole free world, as well as Chile. We have one more striking example of the disturbing drive of xenophobic nationalism in contemporary times.
Knitwear manufacturers will seek to reduce production difficulties brought about by delayed buying of sweaters and sportswear through an educational program among retailers, it has been learned here.

CENTREVILLE, Md., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Phil A. Somervell of Edgewater Park, N. J., piloting Triple Scotch, outsailed thirty-three other skippers to recapture the international Comet Class championship today on the rain-swept Chester River.
I read with great interest the news dispatch "Reds Building Showpiece Street in Berlin" by Walter Sullivan. What surprises me in that there is no comment to it.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- A report on one of the most unusual and successful examples of British-American cooperation since the war was published today. It was issued by the Anglo-American Council on Productivity, which for three and a half years has been promoting the exchange of industrial information between the two countries.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Enos Slaughter drove in all the St. Louis runs today as the Cardinals toppled the Pirates to their 100th defeat of the year, 4 -- 3.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern today announced the appointment of a seventeen-member special committee to study the interrelation of Federal social security programs and state and local pension systems for public employes.

We have an association covering five states and consisting of twenty-two local associations that is working toward the development of soil and water resources in the Missouri Basin and the Arkansas Basin in Kansas.

Auditions of singers for scholarships in the Opera Workshop of Hunter College will be held today through Thursday from 3 P. M. to 7 P. M. at the High School Auditorium, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. Registration for the workshop is slated for Thursday from 6 P. M. to 9 P. M. Regular students will register on Sept. 11, 15, 16 and 18 from 4. P. M. to 7 P. M. in the same auditorium.
Adaptations of French imports, a versatile coat pattern and a chic suit with dressmaker details, are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times.

Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils made known yesterday that payment of $6,020 in paving funds to Victor Clemente, contractor, in connection with a Laurelton sewer job had been approved by Queens borough officials at least two weeks before any resurfacing of the street began.

Since we cannot go to see Stalin's Russia we must learn what we can when a bit of Russia is transplanted to New York. The film critics have justly praised all the Russian artists concerned with the production of "The Grand Concert," now playing at the Stanley Theatre.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman of the Liberal party, has cabled officers of the party that he strongly endorses the nomination of Dr. George S. Counts as the Liberal nominee for United States Senator.

Funds obtained here from the Israel Bond drive are being used already in building up the country, Julian E. Venezky of Peoria, Ill., chairman of the bond drive's executive committee, said yesterday on his return from Israel.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Sept. 7 -- A station wagon carrying nine Norwegian seamen from Baltimore to a soccer game on Staten Island blew a tire on the New Jersey Turnpike four miles west of here this morning, turned a double somersault and landed in a field.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Slight rumblings of discontent similar to those which have existed often before, are being heard at Montgomery Ward Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio flew back from a seven-week Canadian vacation today to determine what role he would play in the Presidential election campaign of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Interior, Oscar L. Chapman, said today there were about 16,000,000 acres of useless trees and shrubs in the West and that positive action should be taken to put the land to constructive use.
AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 7 -- Maine voters, possibly 225,000 strong, will test Republican and Democratic strength tomorrow in their traditionally early general election.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Gen. Mohammed Naguib, who is now the civil as well as the military chief of Egypt, has come a long way in six weeks.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 7 -- The driver of the Greyhound bus that figured in a crash injuring forty-three persons on the New Jersey Turnpike early Saturday morning was still unable to talk to state police today. Joseph W. Fox, 36 years old, of 3442 Englewood Street, Philadelphia, was moved from a Burlington County hospital at Mount Holly to the Nazareth Hospital at Philadelphia.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Steelmaking operations topped 100 per cent of theoretical capacity last week for the first time since last May, just before the steel strike. If the industry can avoid serious coal labor difficulties there is reason to believe that operations will stay very close to that level for the balance of this year.

OYSTER BAY, L. L., Sept. 7 -- The annual three-day cruise of the Seawanhaka - Corinthian Yacht Club for 36-foot racing and cruising craft was complete today, with J. N. Matthews' Vim earning the top prize.

The Federal Maritime Board has affirmed the need for an operating differential subsidy on the trans-Pacific route of the American President Lines. In a decision announced over the week-end, following a lengthy review of the entire subsidy question, the board cleared the way for the signing of a formal contract covering the steamship company's operating and subsidy contract.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Federal mediator will meet tomorrow with union and company representative in an effort to settle the first industry-wide strike against pressed and blown glass manufacturers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- A commission of the American Bar Association made public today after two years of study a model anti-gambling act with the observation that existing state gambling laws were largely a "haphazard and outmoded patchwork of frequently conflicting provisions," ineffective in coping with organized crime.
On a ringing double by Don Mueller over third base to the left field corner last night at the Polo Grounds, Giant hopes of a pennant were kept alive, faint though they are.

Directors of the First National Bank in Greenwich, Conn., voted yesterday to declare a 20 per cent stock dividend, subject to approval of the Controller of the Currency. Holders of record on Sept. 8 will receive the dividend following the approval.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The Inter-American Press Association today condemned the damage to the Colombian newspapers El Tiempo and El Espectador as "an unwarranted aggression" caused by failure of the Government to take adequate precaution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The State Department retained today its optimistic view of internal developments in Egypt and gave every indication that it would cooperate closely with the new Government, headed by Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of remarks by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, and a question-and-answer period at a Republican regional meeting of representatives from Ohio, Pennsylvania and Maryland here today:

Private investment is still the most vital force in American economic life, despite encroachments made by the Federal Government, according to Ralph J. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company. Including estimated expenditures in 1952, private industry in the last seven years will have invested $150,841,000,000 in new plant and equipment, he said, contrasted with Federal Government investment of about $12,775,000,000 for similar purposes in the same period.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association took exception here tonight to Gov. Adlai Stevenson's statement terming the nation's newspapers a "one-party press in a two-party country."
A NUMBER of correspondents who keep accurate fishing diaries have written us to prove that the alleged "good old days" were no better than the present, at least so far as the bluefish are concerned.

The latest and largest addition to Trans World Airlines' fleet of transports was displayed yesterday, with a press flight from New York International Airport, Idle-wild, Queens, to Mr. Washington in New Hampshire and return in three and a half hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -A British official told American movie makers today they will have to leave a larger share of their dollar profits in Great Britain. This was disclosed by an authoritative source as British trade leaders met with United States film producers to review an Anglo-American film agreement regulating use of American films in Britain.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 8 -- A new segment in the construction of a united Western Europe was swung into place here today with the formation of a special Council of Ministers linking the supranational European Coal and Steel Community with the Governments of ifs six member states.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A White House adviser said today defense spending had just about reached a peak -- many months ahead of schedule -- and the nation might have a delicate job maintaining its present prosperity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Look Magazine reported today that Jasper County, Iowa, which has picked every Presidential winner since 1896, is for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower this year.

Carmine G. DeSapio hit back yesterday at opponents of his leadership of Tammany Hall, Without naming names he accused them of ignoring the problem of the current election "to press for party control with selfish eyes fixed on elections still ahead."

Mayor Impellitteri greeted 450 delegates yesterday at the opening of a five-day convention of the International Chemical Workers Union, A. F. L., in the New Yorker Hotel and told them recent responsibilities placed on labor warranted a "strong voice" for unions in national affairs.
Commodity futures prices on the local exchanges were mostly higher yesterday in relatively quiet trading.

On what appears to be a reasonable expectation for a gradual tapering-off in high Federal tax rates over the next three years, business executives should begin soon to consider steps for putting their companies in more favorable tax positions, members of the Printing Industry of America were advised last night.
Unionized garbage collectors offered yesterday to give the city $60,000 to help finance a five-day work week in the Sanitation Department.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The American oak, one of the country's noblest trees as well as one of its most important natural resources, is threatened with extinction by a new fungus disease known as oak wilt, it was reported here today at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences at Cornell University.

Exquisite fabrics and hand detailing marked Mme. E. Garnett's fall collection, presented last evening in her salon at 47 East Fifty-first Street. Mme. Garnett's designs are made in Rome of Italian fabrics, many woven to her specifications.

Strong support for the Crusade for Freedom, which opens on Nov. 11, will again be offered this year by the Advertising Council. Goals of the 1952 drive are $4,000,000 and the signatures of millions of Americans on "Freedom-Grams" -- leaflets to be dropped behind the Iron Curtain.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- It will cost $47,765,200 to run the United Nations next year, Secretary General Trygve Lie reported today to the world organization's sixty member governments.

Acting under authority of the President and the Congress of the United States, a high Navy officer put a gracious end yesterday to a curiously shabby bit of naval history. He presented to Electus D. Litchfield, 80-year-old retired architect and great-grandson of William S. Cox, a certificate restoring Mr. Cox posthumously to his War of 1812 rank of Third Lieutenant in the Navy.

Herman Fiedelbaum and Saul Hertzig, hotel operators and investors, have purchased the Chatham at Vanderbilt Avenue and East Forty-eighth Street from Mrs. John Dilliard, Jerrold Golding and the estate of Arthur Golding.

Omaha, Neb., sold $2,281,000 of traffic signal and auditorium bonds due from 1953 to 1957 to a banking syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank at a bid of 100.154 for interest of 1.3 per cent. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1 to 1.25 per cent.

Dodd, former member of the Communist party's national executive committee and legislative representative of the Teachers Union, asserted yesterday that there were among the nation's million school teachers about 1,500 card-carrying Communists who wielded an influence far beyond their numerical proportion.
OTTAWA, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Canada has just completed the second biggest wheat export year in her history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President Truman today voided the six-year-old but unused certificates of three airlines for air service into Mexico and directed the State Department to negotiate a new aviation agreement with that country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Gubernatorial or Congressional primary elections, or both, will be held tomorrow in eight states, at least five of which appear now to under full Republican control. The states are Arizona, Colorado, Minnesota, New Hampshire, Utah, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson reported today that the Point Four program to aid economically backward areas was operating in thirty-five countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Henry H. Fowler was sworn in today as Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization and promised to keep the vital program "rolling with the momentum that brings us closer every day to the national security we must have."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower strove today to get the still unhappy supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio back of his candidacy for the Presidency with their hearts, their, minds, their legs and their pocketbooks.

Workers in sixteen of twenty-two strikebound shipyards in Brooklyn and Staten Island returned to their jobs yesterday after ratifying an agreement with operators calling for an increase of 20 cents an hour more than the $1.90 an hour provided by a contract that expired Feb. 9.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The unexpectedly bullish September cotton estimate affected the grain futures market in early trading today. Due to the evidence that there has been greater damage to all crops in the Southwest than has been realized. Coarse grains maintained much of their gains, but in wheat a reactionary trend developed after the advances of as much as 1 cent, with most of the early upturn erased later.

Leonard Oliver Freeman, 17-year-old Queens youth who has admitted twenty assaults on women, according to the police, was arraigned yesterday morning on a homicide charge in the murder of Mrs. Josephine Brown, an expectant mother, on July 25.

A steady volume of buying orders flowed into the cotton market yesterday following the lower-than-expected crop forecast by the Department of Agriculture. Final prices on the Cotton Exchange here were 39 to 81 points, or $1.95 to $4.05 a bale net higher than on Friday.

John Foster Dulles, chief foreign policy adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, charged yesterday that the free world was falling apart and was being picek up bit by bit by Russian communism. He said that only General Eisenhower possessed the world-wide prestige and normal authority to win the peace.

At least one of the many who skipped, ran, walked, or were dragged into Public School 122 yesterday was there voluntarily as vacation came to an end. That was Marty, the cop -- or the ex-cop as he now mournfully calls himself -- who couldn't be kept away from the opening of the school at Ninth Street and First Avenue by a pack of wild billy clubs.

Pronto Don drew the No. 8 post position westerday for the $50,000 Roosevelt two-mile trot on Thursday night in a field of ten horses that will start in two other tiers at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Royal King, 4-year-old bay horse owned by M. E. and D. E. Hall of Harrisburg, Pa., took the Geneva one-mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Funds to finance labor's political action are low and disappointingly slow in coming in, union sources acknowledged today. As a result, labor's political committees are slow in paying out the funds.

Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Frank Sedgman, the brilliant Australian star, won the mixed doubles title yesterday as the seventy-first United States tennis championship tournament came to a belated end at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -Chinese and South Korean infantrymen fought a seesaw battle yesterday for "Capitol Hill," near the Pukhan River on the central front in Korea, while enemy batteries poured in a heavy barrage of mortar and artillery fire.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Leon Jouhaux, the veteran Socialist labor leader, strongly denied today reports circulated in the United States that the peace organization known as "Fighting Democracy" which he launched last July, was pro-Communist or a "front" for Communists.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 8 -- Disability and death in a the welfare state provided the subject material of many papers at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. Age, however, presents more problems, it was stated.
Petitions designed to give State Senator William J. Bianchi, American Labor party, a second line on the ballot Nov. 4 were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

WISCONSIN, At Sea, Sept. 8 -- The largest United States fleet to visit British waters since World War II will steam Wednesday and Thursday into the Firth of Clyde and Firth of Forth for a three-day rest prior to the start of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's naval maneuver Exercise Mainbrace.

" Loves of Florizel," by Philip Lindsay, British novelist and historian, will be published by Roy on Sept. 22. Henri Bendel, well-known specialty shop at 10 West Fifty-seventh Street, broke its custom yesterday afternoon of showing original designs and Paris imports at separate times. It united the two presentations in a single occasion.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8 -- After seventeen hours of debate and caucusing that ended at 2:45 A. M. today, delegates to the tenth national assembly of the National Community Relations Advisory Council today voted overwhelmingly for a redivision of responsibilities among Jewish groups and their community relations activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Department of Justice announced today that it would institute denaturalization proceedings in New York against Frank Costello, New York racketeer who is now serving a prison sentence for contempt of Congress.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Clem Miner and Louis Frattaroli, playing together for the first time in baseball competition, fashioned a 32, 31 -- 63 to capture top honors in the Westchester County Golf Association tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Confronted by increased air traffic and recent complaints by nearby Westchester and Connecticut estate owners and school officials, the Westchester County Airport ordered today strict control of flights in and out of this Class 4 airport.

Larry Jansen, fourth in line of pitchers Manager Leo Durocher of the Giants tossed into yesterday's game at the Polo Grounds, was ejected from the premises for hitting the Dodgers' Billy Cox with a pitch in a bizarre ninth-inning incident.

The Radio City Music Hall has announced the booking of two new films, "Because You're Mine" and "The Happy Time," for early fall presentation. The former, which will follow the engagement of "Ivanhoe," is a Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer musical comedy romance in Technicolor featuring Mario Lanza, Doretta Morrow and James Whitmore.

PLANDOME, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Lenny Lanzetta and Tony Marco of Oceanside triumphed among seventy-four teams in the Long Island Golfers Association one-day tournament at the Plandome G. C. today. Two local laws amending the city's fire, electrical and building codes to accommodate television production and transmission were signed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at a City Hall ceremony attended by city officials and representatives of the television industry.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Next Move and First Glance were one, two in the twenty-eighth running of the $17,700 Bay Shore Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. They were followed by Jan Burke's Squared Away, who was in front all the way except at the finish.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) --A Department of Justice spokesman said tonight a Federal grand jury in New York has begun sifting charges of job irregularities in the New York Post Office.

HONOLULU, Sept. 8 -- Thousands of members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union stayed away from their jobs on Hawaii's sugar plantations and waterfront today in a stop-work protest against the action taken Saturday by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in upholding the perjury conviction of Harry Bridges, the union's president.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Officers of five national boards of the Methodist Church were elected for four-year terms as denominational agencies opened organizational meetings here today. They were:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- A long-standing Soviet proposal for the simultaneous admission of fourteen applicants to the United Nations -- five Soviet proteges plus nine countries supported by the Western powers -- was again rejected today by the Security Council. The vote was 5 against, 2 in favor and 4 abstentions.

Acorn squash, sweet potatoes and other vegetables that are reminders of fall are beginning to appear in produce stalls here. Today Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, THE TIMES home economist, has devised a variety of recipes to show ways in which these autumnal favorites may be prepared.
" The Climate of Eden" has been selected as the title for Moss Hart's new play, scheduled to open on Nov. 13 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

In an address delivered yesterday in Portland, Ore., Governor Stevenson had some interesting things to say about the American press and its opportunities and responsibilities in the field of political action. He was, he said, "glad to pay * * * tribute to the press * * * for the impartiality and fullness" with

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony will open its 111th season on Thursday evening, Oct. 16, at Carnegie Hall. Dimitri Mitropoulos, the musical director, who will conduct for the first eight weeks of the season, yesterday announced the programs for his first fortnight with the orchestra.

Following are the texts of addresses delivered yesterday and last night in Portland, Ore., and Seattle, Wash., by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, and excerpts from a question - and - answer period in Portland, as carried by The Associated Press:

Deere Co., second largest American manufacturer and distributor of general agricultural machinery and equipment, reported yesterday record sales of $317,213,013 for the nine months ended on July 31, but earnings were lower than the similar period of the previous year.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- As the Yankees arrived today, a full day ahead of the launching of their seven-game Western trip, which comprises the first half of their final dash for a fourth straight pennant, Casey Stengel appeared in a cheerful and optimistic frame of mind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Priorities for the procurement of 80,806 tons of pipe for three new major natural gas pipeline systems in the last quarter of this year were announced today by the Petroleum Administration for Defense.

The plea of suburbanites and office workers for a generally early curtain in the Broadway theatres at 7 o'clock on Monday nights was answered last night. Of the twelve current entertainments, nine raised their curtains at 7. None sold out, but business was better in the main.

Nine officials of the nation's military establishment will participate in the city-sponsored Citizenship Day program to be held on Sunday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday.

The steel industry had thought, with some pride, that it was getting its operating rate back to the 100 per cent level last week for the first time in three strike-affected months. But it missed the mark by 1.1 points, according to actual production figures for the week released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, meets tomorrow his first test at the polls since the appearance of "McCarthyism" as a national political issue.
The American Federation of Labor reported yesterday that it was outstripping the Congress of Industrial Organizations by four to one in the unionization of production workers at atomic energy plants.

Debutantes headed by Miss Patricia Doubleday and including Miss Barbara Hoggson are assisting the Cruise Ball to be held on the night of Sept. 23 in the Persian Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society. Mrs. Kelley Keresey and Mrs. Dee Bredlin are co-chairmen of the executive committee for the event. Mrs. Carel Goldschmidt is vice chairman.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -Labor linister Sir Walter onckton capitulated tonight to pay demands from 1,500,000 workers. After a six-week fight to ge them to cut their claims he signed the last eight of twelve new wage scales for the retail distributing industries. The increases range from 6 to 10 .shillings (84 cents to $1.40) a week.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh appointed ten special representatives with exceptional powers to be assigned to each of the ten Iranian provinces to enforce his decree providing that 20 per cent of the landlord's share of the crops be divided equally between the individual peasants and the village councils for rural improvement created by the decree.

Two Democratic judicial conventions held two weeks ago in Brooklyn, one by forces opposed to the present party leadership, were "fraught with irregularities," Supreme Court Justice Walter J. Hart in Brooklyn found yesterday in directing the Democratic State Committee to call another convention.
Declaring that the Democratic party was saddled with a mess, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that it was up to independents, Democrats and Republicans alike to clean it up.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Singing Beauty, a 3-year-old homebred filly from the barn of Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio, won her third race in three starts by accounting for today's $5,000 Owls Purse at the Atlantic City race track.

Sally Milgrim always has an eye for detail. Her 1952 collection of fall custom designs, shown yesterday at the Milgrim shop, provided fresh glimpses of this in every costume. Frequently interest was Centered about the neck and shoulders, as Mrs. Milgrim believes that this is the portion of the body most often seen.
CAIRO, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Premier-Gen. Mohammed Naguib tonight promised a fair hearing to the forty-eight political leaders arrested yesterday when he took over the Government.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Frank E. Gannett of Rochester, newspaper publisher described today for New York publishers some new techniques developed for spreading more printed information to the uninformed masses of the world.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9 -Frederick G. Payne, Maine's Republican Governor, was the victor today in a three-man contest for United States Senator in the nation's first general election of the 1952 campaign. By a slightly less impressive margin, State Senate President Burton M. Cross, also a Republican, was elected Governor in a four-man race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Theron Lamar Caudle, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Tax Division, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that high Government officials, including some members of Congress, applied "more than normal" pressure on him in tax cases. The subcommittee is investigating the Department of Justice.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 8 -- A Latin-American beauty, a French glove-maker, a young New York designer and an Italian-American tailor received silver and ebony plaques "for distinguished service to the field of fashion" here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The representatives of state commissions on problems of the aged were welcomed here today with a statement by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, that the real job of aiding the aged must be done by states and communities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Food prices remained at a record level in the ten days ending Aug. 25, the Government reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Modernization of the Westchester parkways is "the most important problem" facing the county, the Board of Supervisors said this afternoon in unanimously adopting a plan for early redevelopment of the arteries.

Numerous useful aids for establishing a livable and pleasant atmosphere for the college student's room that is temporarily home are now appearing the shops. Most of these new furnishings attempt to keep at a minimum the chores of housekeeping.
New issues of first mortgage bonds, convertible debentures and common stock having an aggregate value of $76,502,000 will be offered to investors today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 8 -- Allied counter-attacks to recapture the tactical initiative would be the first task of the Western armies in event of an invasion of West Germany by the Soviet Union, Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Commander in Chief of the land forces in Central Europe, said today.

Bing Bing, Inc., and others have sold the six-story building with seventy-two apartments at 4382 Furman Avenue the Bronx, to the 4382 Furman Avenue Realty Corporation, clients of Weiss Goldwasser, attorneys. The property is assessed at $240,000 and was sold for cash above mortgages of $202,500.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- United States Judge William C. Mathes today sentenced Oleta O'Connor Yates, Communist party leader, to three years' imprisonment on each of four counts of criminal contempt of court and returned her to the county jail from which she was freed on bail last Saturday.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- After four months of futile protests and vain probings Britain and the United States have abandoned their daily attempts to patrol the Autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany.

A program of seventeen college basketball double-headers, including three nights of a holiday festival tournament during the Christmas vacation period, was made public for Madison Square Garden yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Demand for Japanese bonds on reports of an early official announcement from the debt conference was the feature of stock market trading here today. Domestic issues on balance improved on Friday's prices. Despite fairly heavy profit-taking Japanese bonds advanced as much as three points, dollar clause issues being in best demand.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, new president of City College, in his initial public address yesterday, told the students, "I am prejudiced against fascism and against communism, but I am especially prejudiced against all forms of prejudice."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Dry, hot weather during August took another 6 per cent slice from this year's already disappointing cotton crop, but left enough to cover expected needs during the marketing year ahead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8---Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, characterized today as "the numbers racket" recent reports purporting to show that the Air Force had lost ground because its plane inventory was smaller than at the start of the Korean conflict.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 8--Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, noting that the population of the United States was expected to increase by 30 or 40 million in the next twenty-five years, called today for the expansion of the Government's power and conservation policy in the interest, not only of the West, but of the entire nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The Government authorized manufacturers today to pass on recent ceiling-price increases in steel, copper and aluminum that are expected to cost consumers an estimated $900,000,000 a year.

CAIRO, Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- The new Egyptian Cabinet headed by Maj. Gem Mohammed Naguib, Commander in Chief of the armed forces, approved, in a nine-and-a-half-hour session ending early this morning, the army's land reform program and a draft law for compulsory reorganization of political parties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, announced today completion of the 1,000th project under the six-year-old Hospital Survey and Construction Act, a forty-nine-bed hospital at Lebanon, Ore.
The stock market developed an easier tone in late dealings yesterday and closed irregularly lower, with weakness most pronounced in selected copper, rail and steel issues.
Retailers expect a 5 to 7 1/2 per cent increase in sales volume for the remainder of the year, Edward J. Brown, general merchandise manager of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street, said yesterday.

Charges of bootlegging against the staff of the United Nations and of delegation personnel, made yesterday at a convention of the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association at the Astor Hotel, seemed last night to have simmered down to a tempest in a rum pot.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Wayne Millner resigned tonight as head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League because of poor health. Assistant Coach Jim Trimble was named to succeed him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Kathryn Grayson is settling down at Warner Brothers for a long stay. The soprano today signed an agreement with the studio to make "at least four" pictures, including "The Grace Moore Story," for which she had been announced previously.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 8 -With a jury waiting to be chosen from a panel of 125 talesmen, Frank Erickson today pleaded non vult (no defense) to an indictment charging conspiracy to violate the gambling statutes of New Jersey.

Americans, we believe, have ground for solid satisfaction in the parallel statements of our two Presidential candidates on the question of appeals to racial or religious prejudice. Their declarations to the National Conference of Christians and Jews were, of course, just what we would have expected from two such persons, but they are significant and gratifying nevertheless.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Republican high command offered Senator Robert A. Taft a major role in the 1952 Presidential campaign today but the Ohioan ruled out any decision until he had talked in person with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Government losses on farm produce price-support programs declined 80 per cent in the fiscal year ended June 30, the Department of Agriculture reported today. It said the drop reflected the fact that fewer products, particularly perishables, were price-supported.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Thirteen Arab and Asian members of the United Nations jointly called on the General Assembly today to take up their charges against French rule in Morocco.

THE NEW YORK TIMES and its radio station, WQXR, in cooperation with the Board of Education, will present a new free music course for teachers in fifteen weekly sessions beginning Sept. 24 and continuing until Jan. 21, except during vacation periods.
Allen Rosenthal, national sales manager of Delightform Foundations, Inc., has been elected executive vice president. He will continue to direct sales activities.

A 230-pound cab driver took matters into his own hands last night and bodily hauled two young car thieves into the Old Slip station house in lower Manhattan, where they were later booked on grand larceny, charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Will Rogers Jr. apparently got more of a kick out of acting than he was ready to admit when he was busy impersonating his father in the Warner Brothers film, "The Story of Will Rogers." At the time, he was new to grease paint and the cameras and said the performance would be his first and last.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Braves and Reds, battling for sixth place, took turns blanking each other tonight in a double-header. The Tribesmen won the twilight opener, 1-0, behind Warren Spahn's three-hit pitching and then bowed, 2-0, to Harry Perkowski's four-hit hurling.

At this time of year when fresh oranges are exceedingly expensive and often of indifferent quality, all but the rich and reckless begin breakfast with a glass of frozen or canned orange juice. The frozen, it seems to us after some weeks of using the concentrate morning after morning, is seldom as delicious as one feels it could be or as it actually is on a rare occasion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- William Green, half way between his 79th and 80th birthdays, said today he had come to no decision about accepting or refusing another term as president of the American Federation of Labor, but added that he was feeling a little better and thought his health was improving.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Department of Agriculture sent out warnings to farmers today on fall planting of next year's wheat crop. In a special wheat situations report, it painted a picture of big surpluses and low prices if farmers exceeded the department's goal of 1,080,000,000 bushels. With wheat prices averaging lower than Government support levels, the department showed concern over mounting Federal wheat stocks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Gains of fractions were registered in grain futures early today, with the market holding fairly well, but with no great enthusiasm on the part of buyers. In wheat and corn there was some stimulation in buying resulting from export sales, but there was rather free selling on the hard spots.
MONTREAL, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today ordered Joey Maxim to defend his light-heavyweight title against Archie Moore within sixty days.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 9 -- "I can hardly believe it's humanly possible."

I read with deep concern an article by C. P. Trussell in your Aug. 28 issue dealing with the charges brought by a Senatorial subcommittee against a minority group of writers in the Radio Writers Guild. One witness who testified against the group referred to them as "leftists," but the publicity-conscious counsel for the committee, knowing such an innocuous term warranted no headlines, insisted that the label be changed to "pro-Communist."

NORWALK, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- Charles P. Taft, Republican nominee for Governor, proposed here today a state constitutional amendment to authorize a $750,000,000 bond issue to finance a six-year highway program.
It is true, as you say in an editorial of Aug. 30 that "many Frenchmen -- and some in high places -- believe that the United States really has designs to supplant French power in North Africa."

IT is critically fashionable and generally popular to disparage the quality of contemporary American fiction. Since many current novels are vulnerable indeed, much of this abuse is deserved. But usually it is ill-informed and exaggerated, based upon a few books that aren't as representative as their authors and their offended readers think they are. Fine work is being produced by American novelists each year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The South African Government has decided to come before the United Nations once again to present its side in the six-year-old dispute for control of the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 -- Jersey Joe Walcott today was sullen and moody as he was forced to work indoors at Pleasantville as a result of the cool breezes sweeping ever his outdoor arena at Bader Field.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- One-third of the adult population of Britain listens to at least one religious broadcast each Sunday, the Rev. Francis House, head of the British Broadcasting Corporation's reliligous broadcasting, reported today at a conference of Modern Churchmen at Bristol.

The Garry Moore show, televised over Channel 2 on Mondays through Fridays from 1:30 to 2:30 P. M., will be discontinued Oct. 3. The first half-hour will be replaced on Oct. 6 by a new series entitled "Wheel of Fortune."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the annual rate of personal income in the country fell $2,500,000,000 in July because of the 55-day steel strike that ended July 26.

BERLIN, Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- A forceful personal protest by Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, in a meeting with Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in Germany, resulted late last night in the lifting of a day-long Soviet blockade of a short stretch of the superhighway to Berlin.

Morris Moskowitz, leather merchant and investor in lower Manhattan real estate, yesterday added to his holdings by purchasing for cash the four-story building at 194 William Street, assessed at $18,000, and the adjoining structure at 21 Frankfort Street, assessed at $14,000.

Some fresh-looking table settings, displaying new coverings and dining accoutrements, constitute the main attraction of the fashion linens show that opened yesterday at Lord Taylor. Embroidered bed linens, towels and other items also are shown.

With Jockey Ovie Scurlock keeping her up there most of the way, Boot All of the Woodvale Farm gave evidence of a return to top form by taking the Ethereal, the classified handicap that occupied the feature spot at Aqueduct yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9 -- President-elect Carlos Ibanez stated today that Chile wished "to maintain good relations and a policy of mutual collaboration with the United States, as with any other power in the world, but with a preference for the United States because of their common continental interests."

OTTAWA, Sept. 9 -- Meeting here this morning in public, the members of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association who represent parliaments in about thirty countries applauded vigorously the statement of their chairman, Harold E. Holt, who is Australian Labor and Immigration Minister, that whatever constitutional changes had occurred in recent years within the Commonwealth there never was stronger unity than now.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Bishop Charles W. Brashares of the Methodist Church, Chicago area, was elected president of the Methodist Coordinating Council at its organization meeting here today. Judge Ivan Lee Holt of St. Louis was named vice president and J. Wesley Hole of Los Angeles, secretary.
THE NEW YORK TIMES has never more appropriately followed its guiding principle, "All the news that's fit to print," than in the editorial of Sept. 6 entitled "The Mayor and Maxwell."

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, was credited yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, with taking the "most forthright" position on civil rights of any of the major party candidates for President or Vice President.

The Rockefeller Foundation made known yesterday that it had defined its policy on the special problem presented in recent years to philanthropic foundations, universities, churches and similar agencies by the conflict between academic and scientific freedom and the interests of national security.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Talking about the British Parliament's current ten-week recess, Prime Minister Churchill said in his political speech last Saturday:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Ellisi N. Slack, acting head of the Tax Division of the Department of Justice, will be removed from that post and a new Assistant Attorney General to head the division will be appointed shortly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Government announced today that a new series of atomic experiments would be held during the next few months at the remote and guarded testing grounds at Eniwetok Atoll in the western Pacific.
Selected with taste and discrimination by Andrew Goodman, sixty French and Italian imports were presented yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Construction of a $1,250,000 automatic livestock feed mill will be started at Henderson, Ky., next month, officials of Southern States Cooperative announced here today.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's bid for the Presidency was bolstered today by word from key backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio that they were going all-out to help elect him.
Your editorial of Sept. 5 "A Program for Peace" summarizes phases of General Eisenhower's Philadelphia speech, without evaluation.
The cotton futures market was moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 5 to 26 points net lower than on Monday.

Sixty parcels of land averaging one-third of an acre each in the Sleepy Hollow Manor section of North Tarrytown, N. Y., have been purchased by David S. Meister, New York real estate operator. Seymour Orlofsky was the broker. Resale of the sites to a home builder is being negotiated, Mr. Meister said.

Unsettled by broad selling pressure, the stock market closed weak yesterday, with the widest losses since mid-August and declines most pronounced in rail, oil and telephone issues. Heavy trading in the final, hour made the session the most active in more than two months.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 -- A brief glimpse of a burgeoning conflict over the future pattern of international trade in which the United States will have a major stake was revealed today in the resumed discussion of the International Monetary Fund's annual report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- William J. Bray of Bridgeport, Conn., who has been a Democratic party campaign strategist since 1928, received a recess appointment as Assistant Postmaster General from President Truman today. The appointment would require Senate confirmation Congress were in session.
SEATTLE, Wednesday, Sept 10 (AP) -- Representative Hugh B. Mitchell took an early lead in the five-man race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Washington early today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told a cheering audience of more than 16,000 Indiana voters tonight he sought the Presidency because he could not sit idly by while his country was "the prey of fear-mongers, quack doctors and bare-faced looters."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Wednesday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Representative John R. Murdock, Democrat of Arizona, took a strong lead last night in early returns on his bid for renomination to Congress from Arizona's First District.

In a move to prevent apartment house owners and superintendents from evading smoke detection by operating incinerators at night, the City Council unanimously adopted yesterday a proposed law that would limit the burning of refuse and garbage to the hours between A. M. and 9 P. M.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 9 -- The mission of the Allied troops defending West Germany against aggression from the East would involve trading terrain for time in which reserve divisions could be moved to the front, Lieut. Gen. Manton S. Eddy, Commander in Chief of the United States Army in Europe, said today.
