READING, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Fast-stepping Meadow Rice established himself as the one to beat in next week's Little Brown Jug by winning the $12,791 Reading Futurity for 3-year-old pacers in track and stake record time on the Grand Circuit today.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Allan Nunn May, the first of Britain's atomic traitors to be caught and imprisoned, will be released about the end of this year, having served his minimum term of nearly seven years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Minnesota voters got ballots the length of cross-country railroad tickets for the state's primary election today. Republicans whittled at a list of fifty-seven candidates to pick out seven nominees while Democratic-Farmer-Laborites were choosing nine nominees from twenty-seven.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Jack Dempsey watched Rocky Marciano workout today and predicted that the Jersey Joe Walcott-Marciano heavyweight title bout at Philadelphia Sept. 23 "could be another Dempsey-Firpo fight" for excitement.

Selling is a profession and there should be professional schools to train salesmen the same way doctors, lawyers and engineers are prepared for their field, Joseph Kolodny, managing director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, said last night in an address to the Professional Sales Club of New York at Freedom House.

The first annual convention of the recently reactivated Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor opened last night in the Commodore Hotel, with solid support by the assembled delegates for its demand for recognition on the federation's exexutive council.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 9 -- Before he embarked today for the United States, Dr. David R. Mace, Professor of Human Relations at Drew University, Madison, N. J., visited the conference here of the International Union of Family Organizations to speak on "The Husband-Wife Relationship."

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 9 -- The treaty committing the West German Federal Republic to the payment of $822,000,000 worth of goods to the State of Israel over the next twelve to fourteen years in reparation for Nazi persecution of Jews will be signed here tomorrow.

It is a pleasant illusion to imagine that the vacation period provides "time to think." These days the worker in every field enjoys more time off than he used to have, but it is doubtful, judging from one's own experience, that he spends his idle hours in fruitful meditation.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Utah voters gave their answer today to the bid of a former appointee of the Democratic New Deal to become the Republican nominee for United States Senator.

North Atlantic Coast longshoremen and their employers will meet this afternoon under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for the first time since the agency officially entered the wage review controversy over the week-end.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. said tonight that the Republican Presidential candidate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, had "passionately embraced the social and economic reforms" enacted under the Democratic Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Mental hospitals in most states are crowded with patients whose only difficulty is senility, the Federal Conference on Problems of the Aging heard today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The only thing that seemed certain today about the projected peace meeting between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was that it would be held sometime this week.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 9 -- One thousand eight hundred employes of the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln - Mercury assembly division went on strike today in protest over health and safety grievances. The workers are members of Local 980, United Auto Workers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- The Mutual Security Agency asked the Justice Department today to investigate a new case involving alleged overcharges for oil bought by the Government for Marshall Plan countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois praised today the Administration's policy of "defense and development" in Asia, counseled patience in the prosecution of this same policy, and predicted that the Korean war would one day be regarded as "a turning point in history."
TUNIS, Tunisia, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- The Bey of Tunis, in a polite but firm message to the President of France, has rejected the French reform plan for Tunisia, informed sources said today.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The Massachusetts Legislature convened, in special session today in response to expressions of public indignation over legislation giving generous pension benefits to retired legislators.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The death in Korea of William H. Baker, 36 years old, a Red Cross worker of Hyannis, Mass., was reported here today by the American Red Cross national headquarters.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 -- President Miguel Aleman of Mexico has submitted to the United Nations a formula designed to break the deadlock in the Korean truce negotiations over the exchange of prisoners of war.

While the trend toward bare legs is a menace to the hosiery business, it is of minor importance in the current profit showing of the industry. This is reported in the latest edition of the Hosiery News Letter of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, which states that despite the trend there has been no material reduction in consumer purchases of hosiery.

The standard procedure for the Giants this season has been to slip into a tailspin following a series with the Dodgers. They varied from this pattern yesterday by unleashing a savage early attack that enabled them to breeze to an 11-6 victory over the Pirates before a corporal's guard of 2,894 spectators at the Polo Grounds.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 -- The newest ward of the Wayne County Circuit Court happily munched oats today while perplexed judges pondered the problem of how to keep him running in the money.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,368 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

With Scotch whisky expected to continue in short supply for years and with inventories of imported spirits and wines sufficient to carry the American market for only a few months in the event of war, Harry Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Beverage Importers, urged yesterday that imports of available foreign items be increased as a means of helping the adverse balances of trade of such countries as France, Spain and Italy.

There is no factual frame of reference by which to judge the accuracy of Dr. Bella V. Dodd's statistics in her testimony that there are or have been in the recent past 1,500 card-carrying Communists among the nation's school teachers, or 600 to 750 in this city and perhaps 1,000 in the New York area.
Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech last night before a Republican party rally in Indianapolis as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 9 -- Representatives of the six European nations that have agreed to a single market for their key industries -- coal and steel -- under the supervision of a common supranational authority began today the consideration of an even bolder stride toward political federation.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, today attacked Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, as a man who had fallen "easy prey" to those he characterized as the "little moles of Wall "Street."

HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- Delegates from thirty-two countries are expected to participate in the "Asian and Pacific Peace Conference" in Peiping late this month on the eve of Red China's third anniversary, the Hsinhua News Agency announced today.

Bert Stand, a Tammany district leader in the Fourth Assembly District, South, on the lower East Side, announced yesterday that a petition calling for the ouster of Carmine G. DeSapio as leader of Tammany Hall had been placed in circulation among the members of the Tammany Executive Committee.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey said today that many of our individual liberties are being whittled away," but he lauded this country's newspapers for "sturdily and successfully" resisting any curbs. He made the statement in a proclamation designating Sept. 12-30 as "New York State Press Month."

David Quattlebaum, 24-year-old narcotics addict who walked out of a steel-barred detention pen in the Criminal Courts Building last Aug. 8, was back in a City Prison cell yesterday. He was there because several officers of the Department of Correction had worked unceasingly to bring about his recapture.

The State Congress of Industrial Organizations, which waltzed all around the mulberry bush on the issue of a Senatorial endorsement at its annual convention in Buffalo last week-end, finally decided yesterday to endorse the Democratic candidacy of John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Cliff Mapes and Joe Ginsberg hit successive home runs off right-hander Ivan Delock in the eleventh inning with one out to enable the Tigers to gain a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox today.

United States Attorney Myles J. Lane confirmed yesterday that a Federal grand jury had started an investigation into the alleged buying of promotions by Post Office employes in this area. The Department of Justice had announced in Washington Monday that it would make the inquiry.

International delegates to the fourth Hemispheric Insurance Conference, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were treated at its opening session to a forthright denunciation of United States economic policies, especially those in the field of foreign aid.

Manager Leo Durocher drew a two-day suspension and a $100 fine yesterday as a result of the bean-ball incidents that marked Monday afternoon's game between the Giants and Dodgers at the Polo Grounds. Pitcher Montia Kennedy was fined $50 and Pitcher Larry Jansen $25 but Jansen's fine was remitted because of his "excellent conduct record."

Two physicians testified yesterday before Judge George Sylvester of the State Court of Claims, sitting in the Bronx, that in their opinion William H. Jones, who ran amok and killed four persons in Brooklyn in 1950, should never have been released from Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- New York State's general hospitals have only 53,753 of the 72,941 beds they need to meet the potential peak loads that might be required for a population of more than 15,000,000, the State Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission reported today.

Paul Coirre, visiting "Mayor" of Paris, the world's eating capital, disclosed yesterday that at a Times Square cafeteria last Sunday night he had helped himself to as good a meal as he had ever eaten. Under close cross-examination he admitted that it might have been because the food was new to him.
Cocoa, coffee, wool and vegetable oils lost ground in commodity futures trading yesterday. Other commodities showed small gains or were mixed.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Government of Premier Sami By El Solh resigned today under a barrage of opposition criticism that it was riddled with corruption.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Northern Trust Life Insurance Company of Aurora and two of its officers were fined a total of $1,200 today on charges of using the mails to defraud investors.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept, 9 -- Flourishing a revolver, a well-dressed young man, who said he had been taught to kill in the Army, abducted a state motor vehicle inspector here early today and forced him to drive him in the state car to near-by Union.

Ownership of the Harold Gardens at 55 Windsor Avenue in Rockville Centre, L. I., has been conveyed through the sale of stock of the Larco Building Corporation by Ira Sollar to Martin W. Juster. Austin Hermann and Joseph H. Nassaoit, Inc., were the brokers.

The soft colorings, dainty motifs and classic designs of textiles of the Louis XVI period are on display in the new exhibit that opened yesterday at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street. Reproductions as well as antique pieces of cloth are shown in the exhibit, which will continue through the end of November.

William Raisch, who served three Democratic Borough Presidents as Queens consulting engineer, told District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens yesterday that the majority of the borough's sewer inspectors "aren't worth their salt."

FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Tighe E. Woods, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, went through a heated two-hour session here yesterday in which some 400 women gave him their views on the value of controls. The meeting was the first of several Mr. Woods plans throughout the country.

Closed circuit television demonstrations showing how to dress a woman's hair featured the National Beauty Trades Show at the Statler Hotel yesterday as part of a drive by the National Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association to obtain more trained operators.
Operations of the Kaiser Steel Corporation in the fiscal year ended in June resulted in a net income of $10,399,306, equal to $2.52 a share of common stock, the report disclosed yesterday.

Thornton Wilder's trip to Venice (he's leaving Friday aboard the America) to head the American delegation to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conference, opening there Sept. 22, will give the Pulitzer Prize author a long-sought opportunity to put the final touches on his new play, "The Emporium."

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- Fresh warning to the officers and men of the Soviet Army to heighten vigilance against foreign spies and saboteurs, and to observe with most meticulous care the laws and regulations concerning secrets, was issued by the Army newspaper Red Star today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- George W. Ball, executive director of the National Volunteers for Stevenson, today criticized Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, for endorsing Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, for reelection.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman today called "McCarthyism" the moral hole in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "so-called great crusade."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- By improving the use and distribution of physicians, the armed services in two years have made available to civilian health services about 5,000 physicians who otherwise would be in uniform, President Truman's defense health advisers reported today.

For several seasons Broadway producers have been bewailing the fact that a lot of people seem to prefer to stay at home and watch television rather than come to their shows. Now a concerted effort to counteract this trend is being made. In an unprecedented move all but two of the Rialto's current attractions are raising their curtains at 7 o'clock each Monday.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP) -- She was crazy about horses before she ever saw a tennis racket and today Maureen Connolly was given a choice of fine saddle mounts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved increased rates today to apply on commodities shipped from Sacramento, Calif., through San Francisco and the Panama Canal, to Atlantic Coast ports, because of greatly increased costs of ship operations and stevedoring.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 9 (UP) -- Governor Stevenson told a Freehold woman today that he was sorry his motorcade killed her dog.

A BASEBALL can be a terrible and lethal weapon. Never should it be forgotten that one thrown by Carl Mays of the Yankees in 1920 resulted in the death of Ray Chapman of the Indians. It was accidental, of course, but this "dusting off" of batters is a risky business. In fact, it's remarkable that only one fatality has resulted from this hazardous practice.

Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, who is running for re-election, said yesterday that repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law was "not at all necessary" but he did urge a number of amendments to the act.

The number of failures among commercial and industrial enterprises dropped again in the latest week, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. There were 110 in the week ended Sept. 4, against 132 a week before and 116 in the 1951 week.

Election of Ray Ferguson as president, and director of the Globe Knitting Works, Grand Rapids, Mich., was annonunced yesterday by Walter W. Weismann, chairman of the board of the Aetna Industrial Corporation, here.

MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- The Republican voters of Wisconsin, aided by a large number of Democrats who crossed party lines to vote the Republican ticket in the state's primary, refused today to repudiate Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address last night at Veterans Memorial Auditorium in San Francisco, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- A twelve-point program designed to win the American League pennant was presented today by Al Lopez to his Indians. It sounded good to them and they put it into practice tonight at Municipal Stadium, launching the pay-off drive with a 6-1 defeat of Bobby Shantz and the Athletics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Special lighting effects ordered for the use of newsreel camera men covering Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address here tonight were canceled to make the Democratic Presidential nominee "look good" on television screens.
TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he was considering taking the stump for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a series of speeches in other states.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Wednesday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Gov. Lee E. Emerson was virtually assured of a second term early today as he won re-nomination in a close fight with State Senator Henry D. Vail.

Mme. Pauline Soldatenko, a housewife who lives in the Soviet city of Voroshilovgrad, unburdened her troubles in a long letter to the newspaper Trud recently. Why can't Soviet housewives get reasonably priced refrigerators and washing machines? she asked.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Mutual Security Administration's program for Western Germany will be reviewed at once for a determination as to whether a contribution of $20,000,000 may be made by it to a $49,500,000 importation of American-grown tobacco into that area as an economic recovery aid measure.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Bond dealers and brokers have been asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission to continue to refrain from trading in German dollar bonds.

WITH the hunting Season approaching, a number of novice big game hunters are digging out old rifles from cellars and attics, scraping off enough of the rust to read the fine print designating the caliber, and planning a list of those they will invite to the venison dinner. Some of these hopefuls, inevitably, will contribute to the higher premiums on accident insurance.

Back in supposedly friendly home surroundings, the Dodgers last night were treated like aliens by the Cubs, one of the several teams they must beat now and then if they are to avert the catastrophe that no Flatbush fan wants to think about.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Multi-stage rockets, called the predecessors of the space vehicle, will soar to heights exceeding 1,000 miles in the next five years, two Navy scientists said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Texas-Ohio Gas Company contends it has shown that it is entitled to a Federal permit to build a 1,406-mile natural gas pipeline from the Mexican border to Ohio.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The Mexican proposal is intended to provide a way out of the present deadlock in the Panmunjom negotiations, in which the United States, which holds the unified command of United Nations forces, continues to insist that no prisoner shall be repatriated without his consent.

AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 9 -- A wave of anti-Administration sentiment, gathering momentum in Texas for more than a decade, came to a head today when the state's traditionally dominant Democratic party formally endorsed the Presidential ticket of the Republicans.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 9 -- President James P. Baxter 3d of Williams College dug today the first spadeful of earth to start construction of a $1,000,000 student union and freshman center which the college will build as part of a plan to revamp and liberalize campus life.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Strength of British funds provided the main feature of the stock markets here today. Prices rose steadily and a slight reaction near the close left general firmness of the market unimpaired. The War Loan reached is highest in months with a gain of 3/8 per cent to 79 1/8.

Contemporary glazes and motifs are used to decorate classic shapes of new Italian lamps now on view at Macy's. Comparatively inexpensive, the lamps have handmade pottery bases on which are mounted a variety of stands.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 9 -- James J. Golden, bookkeeper, for Ideal Insulators, Inc., of Roslyn, charged with uttering a forged instrument in the $475,000 swindle of the Central National Bank of Mineola, waived examination in First District Court today and was released in $5,000 bail to await grand jury action.

Detailed forward planning by commercial printing concerns, with consideration of the likelihood of a continued rise of inflation along with an expanding national economy, can assure steady and prosperous growth of the printing industry in the next five years, members of the Printing Industry of America were told yesterday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9 -- (UP) -- The Atlanta Constitution tonight announced its support of the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, calling him "a middle-of-the-roader in a day when the path is not and cannot be that of yesterday."

The ancient superstition about Maine and the nation received its deathblow with the immortal wisecrack of James A. Farley the day after the 1936 election: "As goes Maine, so goes Vermont." There never was any validity to the theory as American politicians generally understood and accepted it for generations.
Departmental trials of suspected Communists among this city's school teachers, halted since last April by order of the State Education Department, will be resumed soon, it was announced yesterday.

By April of next year, if all goes well, American depositary receipts for 5,500,000 shares of five leading Japanese corporations will have been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission and listed on the New York Curb Exchange.

When the Russians lowered their Iron Curtain, they apparently failed to take into consideration the dramatists of television. The writing boys of TV are not only penetrating the sealed-off zones with dashing aplomb but are easily keeping tabs on all the Red agents who might venture into our midst. The Communists, it seems, don't have the real secret weapon: the kiss before the middle commercial.
Mayor Impellitteri last night assailed television and motion picture writers who "nine times out of ten" depict criminals as being of Italian origin.
Federal, city and borough officials gathered yesterday for the dedication of two housing developments in outlying sections of the Bronx.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 -- The Azad, or Free, Kashmir Government warned today that if Pakistan and India failed to solve the Kashmir dispute through diplomatic means "war would be fought to the bitter end irrespective of circumstances."

Entry blanks for dog shows and field trials will not be required to include excerpts from the official rules after ninety days from now. The delegates of the American Kennel Club, meeting at the Hotel Commodore, eliminated the provision requiring such printing yesterday.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet said yesterday that the investigation into dual jobholding by city employes had shown that twenty-one officers and men of his department held outside jobs as pier guards. It has not been established that any of the men were working on department time but the practice of switching tours of duty to permit holding of second jobs was prevalent, he declared.

A new turboprop engine "expected to dwarf in power any aircraft engine yet made public" is in an advanced stage of development at the Curtiss-Wright Corporation's plant at Wood-Ridge, N. J., and the company's propeller division is working on a series of propellers that "will provide long-range military aircraft with propeller-driven controllability and fuel economy at jet speeds."

From the most charming of her daytime woolen suits to the most exquisitely colored of her formal evening gowns, one felt in reviewing Hattie Carnegie's fall and winter collection, presented yesterday afternoon, that her main purpose was understatement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A Marshall Plan for Free Asia to replace the "multiplicity of crisis projects" by which the United States has attempted to curb Communist aggression in that area was proposed in a report today by Clarence R. Decker, retiring assistant director of the Mutual Security Agency.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- Burma rejects Communist allegations of United States germ warfare in Korea, Foreign Minister Sao Hkun Hkio told Parliament today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 -- With Senator William E. Jenner of Indiana in a hot and probably close fight to retain his Senate seat against the challenge of Democratic Gov. Henry F. Schricker, the Republican State Chairman, Cale J. Holder, said today he was disappointed with what he called Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "lukewarm endorsement" of the Senator.
One-week paid vacations for 46,000 laundry workers in New York State were recommended yesterday by a nine-member board set up to revise the minimum wage order for the industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Amreican Federation of Labor chartered its 110th intrenational affiliate today. It is the International Union of Doll and Toy Workers of the United States and Canada, with headquarters at 225 Lafayette Street, New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Don Cherry, a singer from New York, deuced all three of Exmoor's short holes for a closing 69 today to share medal honor in the Western Amateur golf tournament with John Coyle of Dallas.

BENEVENTO, Italy, Sept. 9 -- Benevento's much-criticized semi-annual "child market" closed last night and a group of boys from the poorer families went off today to work for a year with the more well-to-do farmers. The families of the boys -- ranging from 12 to 16 years old -- will receive from 5,000 to 6,000 lire (about $8.50 to $10) for the year's work.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 9 -- An appeal to organized labor to stand by the Democrats as the party that re-established the responsibility of Government to the general welfare was made today at the convention of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Pinch-hitter Sam Mele's ninth - inning homer gave the White Sox a 3-2 triumph after Saul Rogovin had pitched and batted the Sox to a twelve-inning victory by the same score in a twilight-night twin bill with the Senators tonight.

INWOOD, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook produced a sparkling 79 to win the low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Inwood Country Club today.

Headaches for Headlines It would seem that the Republican and Democratic party platforms have promised something to groups of every race, creed, color or interest that consist of at least one or more persons of voting age, but there is one potent group that has not only been neglected but has even been made to suffer at the hands of both parties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- O. G. Ranch's Rusty proved best of the nine 3-year-olds in the Shoemaker purse at Atlantic City track today. The Warlock gelding finished the six furlongs a neck before Prisjoe Stable's Itsthetruth.

In what was believed to be a departmental precedent, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan accepted yesterday the resignation of Patrolman Edward P. Duffy, one of the thirty-four suspended policemen being tried on charges of accepting bookmaking graft from Harry Gross.

The first series of bonds to be issued under Georgia's new State School Building Authority was placed on the market yesterday by an underwriting syndicate headed by the Robinson-Humphrey Company of Atlanta, Ga., and by Blyth Co., Inc., here.
Martin's in Brooklyn told its fall fashion story, with emphasis on fabric, in a style show yesterday afternoon on the store's second floor.

The first series of bonds to be issued under Georgia's new State School Building Authority was placed on the market yesterday by an underwriting syndicate headed by the Robinson-Humphrey Company of Atlanta, Ga., and by Blyth Co., Inc., here.
Martin's in Brooklyn told its fall fashion story, with emphasis on fabric, in a style show yesterday afternoon on the store's second floor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Department of Justice announced today that fifty more aliens, all Canadians, had been arrested in Detroit on deportation warrants charging that they obtained immigration visas by fraud.

A second book about the late publisher, William Randolph Hearst, will be issued shortly by Dutton. It is John Tebbel's "The Life and Good Times of William Randolph Hearst," based on "hitherto untapped sources." It is scheduled for Oct. 10. Mr. Tebbel is the author of "The Marshall Fields" and the historical novels, "The Conquerors" and "Touched With Fire."

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Philip Conway won the low gross honors for the fourth time this season when she shot a 41, 40 -- 81 over the St. Andrews Golf Club course in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's weekly one-day tournament today.
Everyone knows what a shirt is and most everyone knows that a man wears a dress shirt when he wants to be dressed up and a sports shirt when he wishes to appears casual.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- Dock work on San Francisco Bay area waterfronts was scheduled to halt at 6 A. M. tomorrow with some 6,000 longshoremen leaving their jobs for twenty-four hours to protest a court decision upholding the perjury conviction of Harry Bridges, head of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican nominee for President, received 71.6 per cent of all the ballots cast in a straw poll conducted by The Houston Chronicle.
CAIRO, Sept. 9 -- A land reform bill and a bill for the reorganization of the political parties were signed by three members of the Regency Council today.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The search of world Protestantism for a "modus vivendi" by which churches of differing doctrine, ritual and background might work together in harmony for the future benefit of all, received hearty endorsement here tonight from two top-ranking church leaders.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 9 -- Experiments now taking place in Britain on the intestines of chicks, 1 to 10 days old, may have an appreciable effect on world supplies of beef, pork and poultry, according to several speakers at today's session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Looking ahead to the time when defense production slows down, the Department of Commerce is undertaking a special survey dealing with the possibilities of expanding civilian distribution, according to Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9 -- Maine Republicans rolled up their ninth consecutive sweep of the state in the nation's first general election, but apparently failed, on the basis of unofficial returns today, to revive the old' slogan that "As Maine goes, so goes the country" for the Nov. 4 national elections.

Directors of the General Reinsurance Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 10 Cents with the declaration of 40 cents a share, payable Sept. 19. The board also voted to recommend to shareholders that the authorized number of shares be increased from 500,000 to 850,000.

Following the establishment of a supranational High Authority to administer the European Coal and Steel Community two more pillars to support the structure of a united Europe are being put in place. One is the Council of Ministers, which supervises and in part directs the work of the High Authority and links the new Community to the Governments of the six nations comprising it.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept 9 -- The Swedes will try out a new secret device of their own invention in an effort to neutralize Russian radio jamming during the Swedish Navy's big autumn maneuvers in the Baltic beginning Thursday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 -- Casey Stengel, suffering from an upset stomach, did not see his Yankees open their last Western trip of the year against the Browns tonight -- and that is probably just as well.
A curious mortgage, a mortgage on a conscience, was paid off yesterday. The payment arrived twelve days after the due date, but that was the least of the irregularities in the affair.

The second floor of Saks Fifth Avenue took on a gala air last night. Following last year's successful party, Adam Gimbel, president of the specialty shop, and Mrs. Gimbel gave a ball at which Sophie's (Mrs. Adam Gimbel) fall and winter custom-designed fashions were shown.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Sollie Hemus' bases-loaded double and Red Schoendienst's booming triple were the telling blows for St. Louis tonight as the Cardinals tallied five runs in the ninth to defeat the Phillies, 7 -- 4. The batting splurge routed Curt Simmons and Karl Drews.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Fair weather paved the way for 40,000 visitors today to opening day of the 110th Mineola Fair, a well-earned beginning for its final stand at the historic fairgrounds.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German financial expert and president of the Reichsbank under the Hitler regime, arrived today in Teheran for what he described as a two-day visit.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Eliseo Velasquez, one of the leaders of opposition guerrillas in the great plains of southeastern Colombia, has been slain by Government forces, it was announced officially today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 10 -- United States Sabre jets took on more than 150 Communist MIG-15's in another blazing sky fight yesterday over North Korea, and claimed seven enemy jets destroyed and twelve damaged.
Local shipyards will be busy this month and next with the annual overhauls of five passenger liners engaged in cruise services to Bermuda, the West Indies, the Caribbean and South America.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 9 -- Mrs. Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxembourg, said, today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was a good house guest, but that she would remain a faithful Democrat in November.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The discovery that the brain and central nervous system of the giant silkworm play a vital role in the formation of the animal's muscular system was reported here today before the annual meeting today of the American Institute of Biological Sciences at Cornell University.

Events tonight: "Hairless Waif of Lodi Bog," "Seven Popular Songs," "The Long Voyage Home," "Down in the Valley," American Lyric Theatre, 133 MacDougal Street, 8:40 P. M.; guitar recital, New York Folk Guitar Club, 77 Fifth Avenue, 8:30.

OTTAWA, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Volume of Canada's exports climbed slightly during July, but lower prices trimmed the value of shipments to $375,700,000 from $378,600,000 a year ago, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. It was the first monthly value drop of the year.

CONCORD, N. H., Wednesday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Hugh Gregg, 34-year-old veteran and former Mayor of Nashua, won the Republican nomination for Governor last night on the basis of almost complete returns in the New Hampshire primary.

The ninth Yaddo Music Festival, which opens at Saratoga Springs tomorrow afternoon, will include in its three days of concerts a survey of outstanding works written by American composers during the last twenty-five years.

BERLIN, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- The Russians reimposed yesterday morning the previous day's blockade against the regular United States and British military police teams that ordinarily cross a mile of Soviet zone territory to take up their posts at a checkpoint on the Autobahn, the main route leading to West Germany.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Sir John Parkinson, chairman of the first Congress of the European Society of Cardiology, declared at its opening session here today that there should be a world-wide organization working in harmony for the progress of cardiology.

AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 10 -- Dissident Texas Democrats, in the wake of a state convention that took an aggressive stand against the Democratic national ticket, today discussed the formation of an organization to promote the campaign of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Some of Britain's colonies today asked for a greater role in the affairs of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.
I reply to Vincent Robertson's letter, which appeared in this newspaper on Aug. 18, on the subject of conditions in Angola and Mozambique.

Twelve suspended policemen were accused yesterday by Jack Gross, 25-year-old younger brother of Harry Gross, of having associated with the convicted bookmaker or frequented his betting places or abetted his gambling enterprises.

Chemicals will not be eligible for decontrol "to any important extent" under the Office of Price Stabilization program of spurring decontrol or suspension action, a group of manufacturers was told yesterday by a top official of the price agency.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The British Government intends to ask for high-level trade and financial discussions with the new United States Administration at an early date in 1953.

ATLANTA CITY, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Jack Dempsey reportedly was going to pick Rocky Marciano to beat Jersey Joe Walcott. But after watching Walcott pound the bag and skip the rope today, the former heavyweight champion refused to make a forecast.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, back in his home city for the first time since his defeat by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican nomination for President, said today that he was "delighted" with Senator Joseph McCarthy's renomination by the Republicans in Wisconsin yesterday.

Offerings of new securities totaling more than $22,000,000 and representing new-money financing by an Arkansas public utility enterprise and by two railroads, will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Committee Chairman, said today "General Eisenhower obviously is in a state of general confusion" and has set a record for conflicting statements made in the opening weeks of a Presidential campaign.

The interview which President-elect Ibanez of Chile gave to our correspondent on Tuesday was encouraging. General Ibanez expressed a desire to maintain especially good relations with the United States and he denied any present intention of repudiating the military assistance pact with the United States, nationalizing the copper and coal industries or renewing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Religious leaders who champion church mergers as the most practical vehicle for the achievement of Protestant unity received small comfort here today from the Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England.

The country's hotels are putting a good deal of time, effort and money into brightening up their guest rooms, kitchens and lobbies in an effort to get more of the traveling public's dollars. This is indicated by replies to a survey conducted by Ahrens Publishing Company, Inc., trade journal organization, of hotels throughout the country.
Nassau County, L. I., borrowed $18,574,000 in the public market yesterday on tax-exempt serial bonds maturing on Oct. 1 from 1953 to 1982 at an interest cost of about 2.46 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois rolled through the shining Central Valley of California today, extolling the irrigation accomplishments of the Democratic party and criticizing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for his political tactics and associates.
I Directors, of: Foremost Dairies, Inc:, at a meeting yesterday : in I Houston, Tex;, declared .a[stodk dividend of 5:per cent, payable to i common stockholders on Oct. 15.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- For the second straight week Great Lakes iron ore carriers have posted a record for tonnage hauled. In the week ended Monday, their total cargo was 3,384,431 tons. This exceeded by 48,448 tons the record-breaking haul of the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Southern coal operators apparently are willing to bargain with John L. Lewis on his proposal of penalty wage rates that would have the effect of shortening the work week and spreading working time more evenly.

Steel production figures for August reveal the rapid recovery staged by domestic mills after the eight-week strike in June and July. Mill output last month amounted to 8,499,000 net tons of raw steel, substantially larger than in any month since March, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue in the 1952 fiscal year, which ended June 30, audited and investigated 4,405,000 tax returns and investigated 3,855 cases of suspected fraud. It recommended prosecution of 1,284 cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 3:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that debate on Korea would be the most important question confronting the United Nations General Assembly when it meets next month.

The tugboat Liberty, the first of our powerful harbor craft being constructed for the Jersey Central Railroad as part of a $27,000,000 marine and rail modernization and replacement program, will make her first appearance here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Wage Stabilization Board approved today a wage increase of 10 cents an hour awarded by a special arbitartion panel to more than 25,000 employes of North American Aviation, Inc., in the Los Angeles and Columbus, Ohio, areas. The vote was 8 to 4, with public and labor members in the majority and industry members dissenting.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Studies providing new understanding of the basic mechanism involved in the synthesis of proteins, fundamental building blocks of the substance of life, were described here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Sciences at Cornell University.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 10 (UP) -- The tanker Foundation Star, on which nine men died when a hurricane almost split the vessel in two, sank in 9,000 feet in the Atlantic Ocean today as salvage tugs stood by helplessly.

A decline last week of 410,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 116,830,000 barrels, compared with 117,240,000 a week earlier and 124,584,000 a year ago.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The cheery open grate beloved by Britons, who for generations have toasted their coattails in front of glowing coal fires, was denounced today as a menace to the nation's economy.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- The returns from two New England primaries indicated today that Hugh Gregg, former mayor of Nashua, would be New Hampshire's next Governor and that Gov. Lee E. Emerson of Vermont would be assured a second term.

Millions of polluted sea mussels, the common small black variety, have recently invaded the twenty-four jetties of Coney Island and are presenting to the city a "potential health hazard," the Department of Health acknowledged yesterday.

Substantially larger sales and earnings were reported yesterday for the quarter and six months ended in July by the Allied Stores corporation and its subsidiaries, which operates a chain of seventy-one stores including Stern Brothers (97 per cent owned) and Gertz in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens.

Lilly Dache's new collection is truly an exciting one. She has brought a fresh importance to millinery for the fall and winter. Calculated to meet the requirements of the short and versatile hair arrangements of the present mode, her hats are soft and easily manipulated.

Many labor leaders regard the Taft-Hartley law as a symbol of all that is anti-union labor. Yet often the facts refute this sweeping charge and support the conclusion rather that the law as it stands is neither as bad nor as good as some at the ends of the spectrum believe.
The cotton futures market slowed up yesterday one the New York Cotton Exchange and closing prices for active months were 5 points lower to 1 point higher than on Tuesday.
Some friendly counsel in important traffic rules is offered for school-age children in this country, in a new Canadian film strip featuring a ,good-will neighbor from the north called Elmer.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The conservative pro-Government newspaper El Siglo reported today that thirty-six national policemen and a "considerable" number" of "bandits" had been killed in a pitched battle near Muzo, Boyaca Province.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower enrolled in the Republican party, registered her name with the Board of Elections, 400 Broome Street, and applied for an absentee ballot yesterday. On Election Day she will be away from her home at 160 Morningside Drive, she explained, and on tour with the general in his Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A record output of farm products -- but with no sign of serious surpluses -- was predicted today by the Department of Agriculture.

The Consolidated Edison Company was convicted yesterday for the third time as a violator of the city's City Smoke Ordinance. Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in Brooklyn Municipal Term Court found the utility guilty of creating a smoke nuisance at its Hudson Avenue power plant in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn. He imposed a $50 fine.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 10 -- Two Negro students have been accepted for admission to the University of Texas dental branch here, the first Negroes to qualify for admission to the school.

WILLIAM SHIRER'S "Midcentury Journey," the Literary Guild selection for October, is a challenging attempt to pin some squirming chapters of recent history to the rugged wall of time. It is based on Mr. Shirer's return, in 1950, to the Europe he had been covering off and on since 1925. The theme is the story of the profound changes that have suddenly

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10 -- A Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives reported today he was "knocked into the bushes" while passing out leaflets last night outside the Butler University Field House, where Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower made a major campaign address.
A wide open race is anticipated tonight when ten horses start in the $50,000 Roosevelt two-mile trot at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I. It will be the fifth renewal of the stake.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -Wendy Hiller, who undertakes film assignments only when she believes the role to be right for her, has signed with Twentieth Century-Fox to play the part of the mother in "Sailor of the King," to be filmed in England from a story by C. S. Forester.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A Federal judge postponed today until Oct. 1 any action on an effort by major oil companies to delay or quash a Government demand for their records.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Derek Van Dyke, a member of the Arizona Legislature, called today for commissions on aging in all states and a national association of state commissions on aging separate from the Federal Government. He spoke at the closing session today of the Conference of the State Commissions on Aging and Federal Agencies.
Placing its trust in the Biblical text: "A little child shall lead them," Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., will spend $500,000 within the next ninety days promoting its television receivers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Harvie Ward of Atlanta, the British amateur champion, Frank Stranahan, defending titleholder, and other favorites advanced through today's first round that cut the Western amateur golf field to thirty-two players.

C. H. Masland Sons will end its fourteen-year association with Alexander Smith, Inc., on Jan. 1 and set up its own sales and distribution organization, trade sources reported yesterday. Neither carpet manufacturer would comment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- For the first time in many months, representatives of the Union of South Africa sat down today to resume talks in the United Nations on the possibility of ending the six-year-old controversy over the disputed status of South-West Africa.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The White Sox held third place by toppling the Senators to their fifth straight defeat, 6 to 3, before 3,918 today.

Robert Jacobs, 37 years old, of 502 Shore Boulevard, Brooklyn, was in Traffic Court yesterday charged with ignoring twenty-one traffic summonses. Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh requested Jacobs' operator's license for inspection and the offender replied that in fifteen years of driving an automobile in this city he never obtained one.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Long Island's squad scored 31 points to win the twenty-fourth autumn interteam tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at Quaker Ridge today. New Jersey and Westchester tied for second place with 29 1/2 each in the triangular match.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The stock markets were less buoyant today and business was on a reduced scale. British funds started by drifting lower on profit taking but later recovered, in some cases more than recovered.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Two doubles and a triple, between a pair of singles and a couple of walks, scored five runs for the Phillies in the eighth inning for a 6-3 victory over the Cardinals tonight. The rally spoiled a four-hitter for Pitcher Vinegar Bend Mizell of the Cards, who suffered his seventh defeat.
PARIS, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Prince Aly Khan rode to a brilliant victory in the 2,100-meter Prix Des Lions at the Longchamps race-track today on his father's horse, Nearque II.

Does the chairman of New York City's Board of Transportation believe that the ten-cent carfare, which created a $24,773,883 operating deficit in the fiscal year just passed, should be raised? Col. Sidney H. Bingham, whose lively mind prompts him to toss off opinions on almost everything else under the sun, remains tactfully silent on the fare question while waiting for the Mayor's lead.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Results in primary elections in eight states yesterday appeared to provide a minimum of trends on how the Presidential and Congressional contests of November might work out.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Sept. 10 -- Scotland's River Clyde, one of the shipbuilding centers of the world, was crowded with men-of-war today as a large United States fleet anchored off Greenock, completing a two-week training cruise from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Hollywood movie makers and British officials reached a tentative agreement today on the amount of cash the Americans may take out of Great Britain.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 10 -- Dr. Hallowell Davis of the Central Institute for the Deaf at St. Louis, Mo., put forward a new theory about the mechanics of the human ear at the last session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here today.

A 97-year-old woman who is full-time administrator of a hospital with 146 cancer patients and sixty staff members will put on her best black lace cap today to celebrate her birthday at the House of Calvary, Featherbed Lane and Macombs Road, the Bronx.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to New York yesterday from a 6,300-mile, nine-day campaign swing through the country, cheered by the size and enthusiasm of the crowds that turned out to see him and ready, in his words, to lead the nation to "peace, sanity and solvency" if he is elected President.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Making do with little is a frequently recurring football story at Columbia. This year the sadly familiar tale reaches new heights of poignancy. Lou Little is undertaking preparations for his twenty-third season as head coach with his smallest squad in recent memory and with even fewer experienced hands than usual.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Government spokesmen said today they saw nothing strange in the Indian law which demands income tax from nonresidents who carry on business in India by means of agents or companies.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- The Yankees are still holding to the pace in the American League flag race but for a time tonight their strides appeared to be getting shorter and shorter and their breathing more laborious.
DENVER, Sept. 10 (AP) -- John W. Metzger, an orphan who became
SEATTLE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The new United States amateur golf champion, without getting into the rough, won an easy victory in his bid for a seat in Congress.

Permanent financing totaling $2,271,500 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, on the second section of Mitchell Gardens, a "213" cooperative apartment project for 1,400 families nearing completion on Union Street in Flushing, Queens. A permanent loan of $4,585,800 on the first section was placed by the same brokers last spring.

Feminine lines characterized the fall collection of the California designer, Howard Greer, which was presented for the press yesterday at Jay Thorpe. Subtle draping accented the bustlines, hips and waistlines, which followed the high Empire silhouette.

As is always the test of a really skilled designer, Tatiana of Saks Fifth Avenue made the difficult look simple in her superb collection of fall custom millinery viewed yesterday at the Savoy Plaza Hotel

Marked changes in consumer shopping habits, as well as other special factors, were cited yesterday as the principal reasons why four well - known Fifty - seventh Street specialty shops would begin a policy today of remaining open until 8 P. M. on Thursdays.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins soundly defeated Marriner S. Eccles in the race for Republican nomination as United States Senator in yesterday's primary, record returns showed today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 10 -- While the armies of the West are flexing their muscles in a series of annual war games, reports on the improving Soviet military position in East Germany continue to accumulate.

Recruited by the fathers of two young hemophilia victims, thirty members of the New Rochelle Yacht Club each will donate a pint of blood to the American Red Cross blood bank today. The Red Cross then will issue a credit of thirty pints to the Hemophilia Foundation, which has banked little more than 100 of the 500 pints it seeks.
SPLIT, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Tito recorded today his conviction that the Soviet Union would not risk attack upon Yugoslavia because that would threaten a new world war.

TORONTO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Taxes in Canada and the United States could increase 10 to 15 per cent before exceeding the economic level of taxation, Walter W. Heller, Professor of Economics at the University of Minnesota, told delegates to the second session of the National Tax Association convention today.

The first pictures ever taken on photographic film with the use of an animal eye for a camera were exhibited here yesterday at the opening of the twenty-second annual meeting of the Biological Photographic Association at the New Yorker Hotel.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Gov. C. Elmer Anderson easily won the Republication nomination in yesterday's primary election to clearly establish himself as his party's leader in the state.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- A study of the new Soviet five-year plan reveals that it contemplates the completion within little more than three years of five great new hydroelectric stations with an installed capacity of 4,016,000 kilowatts and the construction, probably by 1960, of six more enormous stations.

To the public the ideal scientist is so unemotional, so amoral an investigator that he would murder his grandmother to establish or refute a hypothesis, if the law and social convention did not arrest him. In his presidential address before the British Association for the Advancement of Science Prof. A. V. Hill dispels this illusion.

Invigorator of the Saxon Stable made it two stakes out of two New York appearances by winning the $20,000-added Cowdin at Aqueduct yesterday. A six and a half furlong test for 2-year-olds, the Cowdin had its thirtieth running, and a crowd of 19,387 saw Jockey Dave Gorman move Invigorator up in the stretch to beat Hal Price Headley's Reprimand by a head.

OXFORD, England, Sept. 10 -- Dr. Gertrude Willoughby, lecturer in social science at London University, told the International Family Conference today that the fact that so many wives went on working after marriage had brought about a new equality between husband and wife.

The current coolness in the air, encouraging to more elaborate cookery, makes this an appropriate time to discuss tomato sauce for spaghetti. The subject is controversial, at least among Italians, who originated it. Some of those who are now Americans favor quick-cooking the sauce, others cling to the old-country custom.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Longshoremen protested the perjury conviction of their union chief, Harry Bridges, with a twenty-four-hour work stoppage here today. At a mass meeting in front of Pier 18, some 3,000 dock workers crowded sidewalks on both sides of the street to hear Bridges declare:

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- South Korean troops of the crack Capitol Division, holding on fiercely to the summit of Capitol Hill on the central front, which they had seized from the Communists over Tuesday night in savage seesaw fighting, beat back Chinese Red counter-attacks twice yesterday and again early today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Representative John R. Murdock won the Democratic renomination for a ninth term in Congress by a wide margin, nearly final returns from yesterday's primary showed today. Mr. Murdock, who represents the First District, polled 22,674 votes on returns from 437 of the state's 504 precincts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense allocated 205,669 tons of line pipe today for construction of oil pipelines in the last three months of the year.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A new agreement for the purchase of crude oil and refined petroleum products was signed yesterday by the Government-sponsored Israel Fuel Corporation and a three-fold finance group: the American Palestine Trading Corporation (Ampal), the American Israel Petroleum Corporation and the Overseas Discount Corporation.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 10 -- A restless crowd at the Kansas Free Fair, apparently more interested in auto races than political candidates, broke up an address today by Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee.

Joseph R. McCarthy's victory in the Wisconsin Republican Senatorial primary is as overwhelming as it is depressing. Mr. McCarthy had made only one speech in the campaign, and yet -- in the biggest primary in Wisconsin's history -- he received 70 per cent of the vote against a vigorous and able opponent.

A slight, 105-pound 17-year-old girl managed last night to fight off a 215-pound intruder who, the police said, tried to rape her and rob the Bronx apartment in which she lived. The girl's screams attracted neighbors and they beat the man savagely until the police arrived.
Both sides in the longshoremen's wage review dispute clung to their respective positions at a meeting yesterday, the first under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

The Broadway theatregoing season, shedding its traditional mantle of summer apathy, gets going tonight with a presentation of "Seagulls Over Sorrento" at the Golden Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today reported United States battle casualties in Korea now numbered 117,237, an increase of 582 over last week.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 10 -- Iran postponed today a public parliamentary decision on the Churchill-Truman offer to settle the Iranian oil question and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, "financial wizard" of the Hitler regime went to work on the country's monetary problems in possible preparation for increasing the amount of currency circulation to ease the Iranian Government's financial problem.
BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 10 (UP) -- A temporary Superior Court injunction was issued today ordering pickets to stand at least fifteen feet apart at the strike-bound Lockheed Aircraft plant.

ARDMORE, Okla., Sept. 10 -For years 70-year-old Bob Dodson, an Oklahoma Park Service employe, had begged scientists to investigate a hard, black object sticking out of the ground in a scrub oak patch at Lake Murray State Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Now that General Eisenhower has taken some sound political advice and started swinging, with "personalities" no longer barred, the time has arrived for a survey by the candidate and his advisers of the tactical errors he and they have made and for the formulation of an operating plan for the rest of the Presidential campaign.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (UP) -The Republican party began in earnest today to build a $4,800,000 campaign fund for its Presidential nominee, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A step that could seriously impair Britain's output of goods for export and rearmament was taken today by the representatives of nearly 3,000,000 workers in key industries.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton, 150, back-pedaled to a unanimous ten-round decision over Ralph Zannelli, at 37 one of the oldest men in the ring, before a handful of fans at the Olympia Stadium tonight. Zannelli also weighed 150 pounds.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 10 -- Prof. G. Wilson Knight, of Leeds University in England, a leading Shakespearian authority, has found in South Africa what he believes is a contemporary portrait of William Shakespeare, painted from life between 1606 and 1616 by a Dutch artist, Paulus Van Somer.

DEAL, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Maurine O'Connor, Branch Brook pro, and Bert Henry Jr., amateur, forged a 6-under-par 33, 33 -- 66 over the Hollywood Golf Club course today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the New Jersey pro-amateur championship. O'Connor

I have read with shock, apprehension and hopefulness THE NEW YORK TIMES' report of Dr. Bella Dodd's testimony to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee which is investigating subversion in the American school system.

Veteran commuters hardly have batted an eyelash at the freight car that has been materializing, night by night, on the marble floor of Grand Central Terminal. Other travelers have shown curiosity, astonishment, hostility, admiration and other emotions.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (UP) -- A grand jury deliberated only six minutes today after hearing nine witnesses and returned a murder indictment against G. Edward Grammer in the so-called "perfect" slaying of his attractive wife.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Republicans in the Massachusetts Legislature suffered setbacks today in the first active skirmishing of a special session called because of public indignation over the passage of a law giving generous pension benefits to retired legislators.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 10 -- Critics of the Israeli Government are expected to organize a series of protest meetings and demonstrations throughout Israel this week in resistance to the reparations agreement with West Germany. The Communists have asked for an extraordinary meeting of the Knesset (Parliament), which is in recess. Opponents of the pact maintain that it implies a rapprochement with Hitler's heirs.

The American-Hawaiian Line has joined the list of companies under contract with the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., Capt. C. T. Atkins, president of the union, announced yesterday.

The stock market dipped to its lowest level since June during early dealings yesterday, then turned firmer and closed irregularly lower as scattered resistance to the decline developed in several key groups. It was the most active market in five months.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski's two-run double in the tenth inning tonight gave the Reds a 6-5 victory over the Braves. Homers by Walker Cooper, Sid Gordon and Jack Dittmer, accounted for four of the Boston runs. Kluszewski stroked his twelfth round-tripper of the season to give the Reds a 4-1 lead in the top of the ninth.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- Point No. 2 in Al Lopez' twelve-point program ("If we win twelve games the Yankees will have to take ten to tie us") was achieved by the Indians tonight at Municipal Stadium. Proceeding according to the Lopez Plan, the pennant-con

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 10 -- A new sports organization, the Long Island Senior Golf Association, launched its initial tournament over the seaside Seawane Harbor Club course today. Sixty entrants took part in the first half of the thirty-six-hole test that will be concluded tomorrow.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Eighty-one property owners in northern Westchester County petitioned the Public Service Commission today to halt construction of the natural gas pipeline there of the Algonquin Gas Transmission Corporation until the commission establishes rigid safety regulations. Construction began in the early summer.

Two men, who had pistol-whipped an elevator operator until he was unconscious, perpetrated a hold-up yesterday in the presence of twenty-five garment workers and escaped with a payroll of $2,300. The police of the West Thirtieth Street station began a search for the robber, who were dressed in work clothes.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 10 -- The board of directors of the Panama Canal Company recessed this evening after a day-long meeting until tomorrow, when the last session will be held. Nine members came here from the United States to attend.

Potato futures dipped in yesterday's market on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices closed 16 to 23 points lower on 628 carloads. The open position yesterday morning was 4,264 carloads, a gain of 200 cars from Tuesday morning and 469 from Aug. 11.

Eleanor Holm won her separation suit against Billy Rose in the Supreme Court yesterday after he had agreed not to offer any defense and had withdrawn all his counter-charges, expressing regret that he had made them.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The automobile industry's feast-or-famine production curve is on the upgrade, and Detroit, a labor-surplus area six months ago, today faces a manpower shortage.

The four-story building containing thirty-eight apartments at 91-47 Eighty-eighth Road in Woodhaven, Queens, has been purchased from Vincent Scuderi by an investing customer of Lane Realty, broker in the transaction. The property, on an irregular plot 107 by 94 feet, is assessed at $120,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Don Mueller kept the Giants' pennant chances alive yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Sparked by a collection of five birdies by Mrs. Alex McFadden, the Meadow Brook golfer, and Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock gained a one-stroke victory with a 32, 34 -- 66 in the Women's Long Island Golf Association best-ball tournament at the Deepdale Club today.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 (UP) -- The Tigers, with rookies in the line-up, pounded out thirteen hits today to defeat the Red Sox, 6-2, before 3,079 fans.

ALBION, Mich., Sept. 10 -- Kyle Rote, former Southern Methodist star, and Frank Gifford. 1951 All-American at Southern California, will be battling for a starting halfback berth Sunday when the New York Football Giants play the Chicago Bears in an exhibition game in Chicago.
Following is the text of the address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, at the Republican National Committee Headquarters in Washington, yesterday:

CHARLES WALTER DRESSEN, the contortionist extraordinary, has developed an uncanny knack of opening his big mouth and then always jamming his foot into it. His skills in this department became so manifest last season that few were surprised when he also became muscle-bound from patting himself on the back. And then the Dodgers blew the pennant.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 10 -- Drastic measures for dealing with a financial and economic situation that was termed "as serious and critical as can be" were revealed in a radio address to the nation here tonight by the Finance Minister, Dr. Sumitro Djojohadikusumo.

The building at 403 to 415 East Seventy-sixth Street, one of the largest modern garage properties in the city, has been subleased by the Columbia Broadcasting System to the Hoffman Motor Car Company, agent for foreign automobiles. The auto dealers have a

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Grain futures were weak today, reflecting what appeared to be overbought pit conditions, coupled with an indifferent demand. In the coarse grains and soybean futures, longs were uneasy in regard to the Government report that was due after the close, and many longs evened up their trades.
Douglas C. Lynch has been elected vice president in charge of sales of the Brush Development Company, Cleveland. This is a new post. Mr. Lynch will direct sales of all the company's products.

The men's clothing industry is in for better times, as shown by early reorders on tweeds and flannels from retailers who promoted fall clothing in late August, Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., said in a letter to the trade yesterday.
The state's part in the program observing National Home Week got off to an official start here yesterday when Governor Dewey issued a proclamation announcing Home Week of the State of New York.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- As far as Rocky Marciano's manager, Al Weill, is concerned he isn't worrying, at least for the present, about the referee for the heavyweight title bout with Jersey Joe Walcott.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today called Japan an "American colony" and again indicated that he intended to veto Tokyo's application for membership in the United Nations.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 10 -- The first major move to end the legacy of bitterness between Germany and the Jews was consummated today when agreements were signed committing the Bonn Republic to pay $822,000,000 in compensation for Nazi anti-semitic deeds and to improve the machinery for restitution to individuals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson referring today to the mistreatment of United States nationals held in custody in China, said that "these Communist crimes will be forever condemned by those who believe in simple justice and fair play for human beings." He estimated that 156 United States citizens were being held in Communist China against their will.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- Plans were made today by the New Jersey Republican leadership to raise a campaign fund of at least $600,000 and to enlist 25,000 women workers in a house-to-house canvass for Eisenhower supporters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Taft-Hartley Act did not permit a group of employers to lock out their non-striking employes in order to counteract a strike at the plant of one employer of the group. The board divided, 3 to 1.

CAIRO, Sept. 10 -- The Arab League Council convened for the second part of its sixteenth session at Zaafaran Palace this evening. The first plenary meeting was called to order by Ahmed Shoukeiry, assistant secretary general, in place of Abdul Rahman Azzam, who tendered his resignation as secretary general last night.

THE British Commonwealth team took first honors in the Ninth International Tuna Cup Matches, which began yesterday at the Soldier's Rip off Wedgeport, Nova Scotia, when Louis Mowbray of Bermuda boated the initial fish of the event, a 600-pounder.

BERLIN, Sept. 10 -- The Western Allied High Commissioners ten days ago made a formal proposal in a letter to the Soviet commander that conditions be improved in Spandau prison, where seven international war criminals are held, and that the prisoners be permitted increased liberties.

J. R. (Jack) Poppele has resigned as vice president in charge of engineering for the Mutual Broadcasting System and as director of engineering for WOR, the network's local station. He had been with WOR since 1922, becoming its chief engineer a few weeks after the station went on the air.

The new synthetics such as Orion, Dacron, Acrilan and Vicara will find their best use in apparel in blends with the older man-made fibers such as rayon and acetate, Herman E. Goodman, president of Hego Fabrics and executive vice president of Robbins Mills, said yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican nominee for re-election, declared today that the people of Wisconsin "have spoken for me."

A library grows in Brooklyn -slowly, like a tree. The familiar building on a point of land where Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue flow into Grand Army Plaza will be completed within the next fifteen months.

HONOLULU, Sept. 10 -- Federal Judge J. Frank McLaughlin issued an order today directing a San Francisco attorney, Richard W. Gladstein, to show cause why he should not be "suspended or disbarred" from practice in Hawaii's Federal District Court because of his conviction for contempt of court in the trial of eleven New York Communists.

Unless the deadlock in the Korean truce talks is broken by the middle of next month the United States, which represents the United Nations at these talks, proposes to resubmit the whole Korean issue to the General Assembly, which meets in New York on Oct. 14.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- New investigations of the death last Sunday of Willard S. Dolivet, 7 years old, son of Mrs. Beatrice Whitney Straight Cookson, an actress, were made today and the case again was listed as an accidental drowning.

Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, will open campaign headquarters on the fifth floor of the Biltmore Hotel Monday. William J. Donoghue will be in charge of publicity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, voiced satisfaction today over the agreement of the West German Government to make payments to Israel in recognition of unjust property confiscations against Jews by the Nazi regime.

To those orthodox people who measure time's flight by the calendar the new year begins on Jan. 1. Then one night of celebration, wassail and good-fellowship marks the passing of the wearying year and buoys up the wintered soul until the first robin sings.

At last the City Council has acted favorably on the much-needed local law which, if passed by the Board of Estimate and signed by Mayor Impellitteri, would restrict the burning of waste materials in the city's estimated 30,000 incinerators to the hours between 7 A. M. and 9 P. M.

Synthetic fibers are required in ever-increasing quantities to clothe the people of the world, according to Dr. Frank J. Soday, director of research and development for the Chemstrand Corporation. The manmade textile materials, he held, are not necessarily, in direct competition with cotton, wool and silk, but fill the gap caused by reduction in output of natural fibers due to increasing competition between food and fiber crops for the available arable land.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Arrested in near-by Cranford early today, several hours after a motorist was held up by a kidnap-bandit threesome here and taken for a "ride" that ended in a $200 hold-up in Newark, two young men were held by the Elizabeth police tonight as members of the gang that staged several other similar escapades since Sunday.

Seven city teachers refused yesterday to testify before the Senate subcommittee investigating communism in the nation's schools as to whether they were or ever had been members of the Communist party. Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, who is chairman of the committee, upheld them in their right to refuse to give this testimony because of possible self-incrimination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, said today that the United States Government was now preparing the position it would take when the question of a Korean armistice came before the United Nations General Assembly at its meeting starting Oct. 14.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 10 -- Delegates to the thirty-eighth annual conference of the Governmental Research Association were urged today to promote economy and efficiency in government by getting behind nonpartisan citizen groups.

SEATTLE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A "little Kefauver committee" chairman lost and a state un-American Activities investigator was ahead today in the vote count of yesterday's Washington State primary elections.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to ease the problems of builders of one and two-family houses in residence sections of the city, particularly in outlying parts of Queens where extensive construction of homes is under way, by relaxing yard space requirements.
The large amount of publicity given to the increase in crime on the city transit system is of great interest to all of the city's riders and transit workers.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Robert Marjolin, secretary general of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, declared today that the solution of Europe's dollar problem must be sought through increased dollar earnings, and not by reducing dollar imports.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 10 -- Europe's first sovereign supranational assembly, seventy-eight parliamentarians from six countries, came into being here today as an organ of the Western European Coal and Steel Community and as an instrument to work out a draft treaty establishing a European federal political community.

BOSTON, Sep. 10 (AP) -- Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr., who ruled recently "with reluctance," that Carl A. Latva, father of two war veterans, must be deported, today amended his decision to take cognizance of the possibility of its cancellation by the Attorney General.
Through a series of mysterious accidents, the title of Isabella Holt's novel was wrongly given on yesterday's book page. Miss Holt's book is titled "Rampole Place."

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens announced yesterday that he would direct Victor Clemente to open up and repair, at the contractor's own expense, a faulty two-mile $185,679 Laurelton sewer. Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils recommended that Mr. Clemente be barred from any more city contracts.

Spain has paid off eight and one-half years ahead of time the balance of its $50,000,000 of 4 per cent dollar bonds issued in 1945, the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, holder of the bonds, revealed yesterday in its semi-annual report to stockholders.
