Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils said yesterday that he had received charges that members of the Police and Correction Departments had worked for private employers on city time but that so far no evidence had been uncovered to substantiate the allegations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A more liberal Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan policy, with special emphasis on small business loans, was indicated here today by Harry A. McDonald, R. F. C. Administrator, and Clarence A. Beutel, new Deputy Administrator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- "It behooves all of us to search for a better way to settle our labor disputes," Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, told a centennial of engineering luncheon today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 10 -- Ohio laws providing censorship of moving-picture newsreels are in violation of both the Ohio and United States Constitutions, Municipal Judge Frank W. Wiley ruled today in a test case on the law.

The start of foundation work on the twenty-six story office building which the Tishman Realty and Construction Company plans at 99 Park Avenue was announced yesterday by Norman Tishman, president of the company, which is the owner and builder. The latest
PARIS, Sept. 10 -- France's North African interests in Tunisia and Morocco are causing exceptional difficulties for the Pinay Cabinet.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A Western Reserve University scientist singled out a new bacterium named "Bug 12" today as the villian in the serious kidney disease called Brights Disease. Brights Disease also known as acute nephritis, causes a breakdown of kidney function and in some instances is fatal.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,369, for the twenty -four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- Laurence F. Lee of Washington, D. C., president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, charged here today that the employe's right to negotiate with his employer has been seriously impaired by the device of industry-wide bargaining.

Application of modern electronic devices to New York's transit problems is being studied by the Board of Transportation in an effort to improve the efficiency of both subway and bus operations. This was reported yesterday by Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the board, in a speech to the Kansas City Chamber of Commerce.

Mindful of their author-manager's statement that "The Dodgers won't blow this one," and with their own pennant aspirations very much in mind, the Brooks last night trounced the Cubs twice, 4 -- 1, and 6 -- 2, before 17,480 contented Ebbets Field fans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers made $18,900,000,000 on their crops and livestock during the first eight months of this year -- 3 per cent more than their cash receipts last year.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Meyer Lansky, associate of Frank Costello, the gambler, posted $10,000 bail today after surrendering to the state's investigators of gambling and possible political payoffs in Saratoga Springs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Three Lucas County, Ohio, taxpayers have asked the United States Supreme Court to set aside an Ohio Supreme Court decision that the Ohio Turnpike Act is constitutional.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Because of declining defense demand for machine tools, the Government today began clamping down on the award of Federally- guaranteed "pool contracts."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, said today that the State Department had assured her it had no plans to require a "special" racial tag on Jewish immigrants to this country.

CLIFTON, N. J., Sept. 10 -- With many a buck and a bellow, 126 pampered, pedigreed cows and bulls from Scotland were snipped out today from the Federal "Ellis Island for Animals" here to eighteen leading breeders in the United States who had imported them to improve native herds of beef cattle.
SYDNEY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Australian miners today are producing all the coal this country needs for everything except household gas making.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The new fall styles for the Army infantry man will feature the familiar classic olive drab, but a new fashion note will appear with the use of generous powdery blue trimmings in headgear and other accessories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that a revised reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Venezuela involving an American reduction in the duty on oil imports will go into effect on Oct. 11.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today parking problems had become the biggest enemy of business.
Garcia Diaz, Inc, agent for the Spanish Line, ground floor space for passenger, freight and executive offices in the Cunard Building, 25 Broadway -- Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

Do not be misled by those sentimentalists who say that every household should have a puppy. Every household should not have a puppy. Every household should have peace, contentment, dignity, freedom of action and self-respect, and with no single one of these does a puppy agree.

Government - subsidized opera houses of Italy are outbidding the Metropolitan Opera Company for the services of outstanding singers. This was disclosed by Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan, who arrived yesterday with Mrs. Bing aboard the French liner Liberte.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Ministry of Food announced today that the price of butter, margarine, fats, cheese, sugar and bacon, all of which are still rationed, would go up next month.

Referring to your editorial "How Long Is 'Temporary'?", with regard to the Quonset huts and barrack-type buildings set up to meet a housing emergency, do you not realize that the shortage is still with us and that these buildings would be a heaven and a haven for many a doubled and tripled up family living in intolerable congestion where elbow room of any kind anywhere would prove a veritable godsend?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Bureau of Animal Industry of the Department of Agriculture, has determined to explore thoroughly the efficacy of a "cure" purportedly found in France for the hoof-and-mouth disease.

Sailing today aboard the French liner Liberte, Dr. Richard Prescott Saunders, president of the Save the Children Federation, a child welfare organization, will make a two-month survey of the organization's aid programs in Europe. He will confer with governmental health and welfare leaders and with American representatives abroad.

DEAL, N. J., Sept. 11 -- The medalists won and the defenders lost in two rounds of match play which produced the semi-finalists in the New Jersey pro-amateur championship today at the Hollywood Golf Club.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 11 -- No action was taken "one way or the other" on the question of rate of tolls for ships using the Panama Canal by the board of directors of the Panama Canal Company during their two-day meeting here, according to Karl R. Bendetsen, chairman, and Under Secretary of the Army. He is returning to Washington tomorrow.

Departmental trials of a second group of eight public school teachers who have refused to answer official questions concerning alleged Communist activities will begin Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by a special trial committee of the Board of Education.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 11 -- The relations between the new Government of Indonesia and the United States "are improving," Mukarto Notowidigdo, Foreign Minister, stated here today. He said friendlier Indonesian-American relations were developing as a result of the increased understanding by Washington of the Indonesian Government's position.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today retail sales in July were 4 per cent below those of June. However, it said the $13,200,000,000 retail sales in July this year was 7 per cent above July, 1951.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 11 (UP) -- A four-state strike of 7,500 glass workers ended at noon today when agreement was reached on a new contract providing a wage increase of 10 cents an hour, retroactive to Sept. 1.
Herbert Bayard Swope in a letter published in THE TIMES of Aug. 25 gives publicity to identical views expressed in a letter he apparently wrote simultaneously to the Atomic Energy Commission.

The State Housing Commissioner, Herman T. Stichman, announced a new departure in design policy yesterday that, if overdue, is no less welcome for what it may mean in relieving the monotony of appearance of slum-clearance low-rent housing in New York City.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Chris Spencer, Dunbar Bostwick's 10-year-old racer from Shelburne, Vt., tonight won the $50,000 Roosevelt Two-Mile Trot from eight other classy standard-breds at Roosevelt Raceway. The bay gelding by Spencer-Countess Christine, by Volomite, finished fast to beat

HAVANA, Sept. 11 -- A campaign against the United States is being conducted in Cuba by Argentines under diplomatic cover, Enrique Pizzi de Porras, former Cuban Ambassador to Chile and a well-known journalist, declared in a recent column in the paper Excelsior.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 11 -- John Robilotto, New York undertaker and chief suspect in the murder a year ago of Willie Moretti, the gambler, was released today in $25,000 bail from Bergen County Jail, where he had been held since his extradition from New York on July 21.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -Thomas F. Patton, vice president and general counsel of Republic Steel Corporation, Cleveland, predicted here today that the next session of Congress will enact legislation to "curb the power of labor." He said the American people were "frightened" by the

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 11 -- The Schuman plan Assembly, the supreme authority of the European coal and steel community, elected Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium today as its first president and prepared to consider tomorrow its new mission to draw the outlines of a European political federation.

The Communists are apparently turning the battle for Capitol Hill, on the central Korean front, into a test case for the South Korean fighters. General Van Fleet has expressed amazement at the amount of heavy fire they have poured on the United Nations position.
John H. Harris' elaborate ice spectacle, "Ice Capades of 1953," got off to a flying start, figuratively and literally, in its initial performance last night at Madison Square Garden.

The American Hard Rubber Company voted yesterday a 25-cent dividend for payment to common stockholders on Oct. 31. The action was taken, it was stated, with a view of placing the common stock on a semi-annual basis. At a board meeting last June 12 action was deferred until the September meeting on the present common stock which stems from a two-for-one split last April.

A peculiar shift in local temperatures and a sudden drop in the prevailing wind velocity early yesterday had many in the midtown area rubbing at their eyes as the city was blanketed in a thick haze of smoke and fog. Smog, the condition was termed by the experts.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- An overrun in the hog supply pitched prices 25 to 50 cents lower today to the lowest in more than four months.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, visited this morning the house where he was born. He went armed with a Hollywood script and thereby, as we say on Wiltshire Boulevard, hangs a tale.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Plans for a Pacific Coast conference of Government, industry and banking representatives to promote investment of American private capital in underdeveloped areas were announced today by Eric Johnston, chairman of the International Development Advisory Board.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- After a summer lull the Government of Premier Antoine Pinay returned to its battle against inflation today with an order establishing a ceiling on all prices at their Aug. 31 levels.

An act of national atonement unique in the annals of international relations has been consummated with the signing of an agreement between Western Germany and Israel providing a German payment of $822,000,000 in partial compensation for the Nazi savageries against the Jews.

TORONTO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Mass public transportation in large cities may be on the way out, Carl H. Chatters, executive director, American Municipal Association, told delegates today to the third session of the National Tax Association.

IT was known as the Pilgrimage of Grace, that extraordinary rising of the men of the North Country, both lords and commoners, in protest against Henry VIII's dissolution of the monasteries and his destruction of the ancient liberties of the Roman Catholic Church. Thousands of men left their accustomed ways and bound a badge upon their sleeves showing the five wounds of Christ.

A short time ago, while I was away from the city on housing business of our committee, you published an editorial entitled "How Long Is 'Temporary'?" dealing with the Quonset huts and barrack-type buildings which veterans are using in lieu of homes here in our great city.

The establishment of a transit authority to manage and operate the municipal subway and surface lines on a sound financial basis was urged yesterday by two of the city's leading business organizations. Creation of such an agency they contended, was necessary to lift the burden of huge transit deficits from the city's already overtaxed expense budget.

The Alleghany Corporation announced yesterday that if stockholders on Sept. 30 approve a plan for creation of capital indebtedness it intends to create an issue of not more than $10,000,000 of ten-year 5 per cent debentures to be exchanged for the series A preferred stock on the basis of $100 principal amount of debentures for each share of preferred.

One new film arrives at a first-run theatre this morning. "Beware, My Lovely," an R. K. O. melodrama starring Ida Lupino and Robert Ryan, opens at the Palace. Collier Young produced the Filmakers Presentation, which Harry Horner directed from Mel Dinelli's adaptation of his own Broadway play, "The Man." Featured in the cast are Taylor Holmes, Barbara Whiting, James William:, O. Z. Whitehead and Dee Pollack.

Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, predicted yesterday the election of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman, nominees for President and Vice President. Asked for the reason for his confidence, he replied:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The last New York Central steam locomotive on a passenger run in the metropolitan area left the North White Plains station at 11:55 A. M. today amid cheers from spectators, deep-throated blasts from whistles of over-age locomotives at the roundhouse and raucous trumpeting of new Diesel-electrics awaiting to supersede the old iron horses.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- A four-goal rally in the fifth chukker enabled the Meadow Brook poloists to score a 9-7 victory over Bostwick Field in a semi-final match of the sixteen-goal autumn plate tournament on Cochrane Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

CAIRO, Sept. 11 -- The Political Committee of the Arab League agreed during its opening session here today to support Lebanon as a candidate for the United Nations Security Council seat left vacant by Turkey.

A statement that the Atlantic community of the free world soon will become "impregnable" was made yesterday by Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, president of the American Electro Metal Corporation of Yonkers. He declared that technical developments had gone ahead in Europe along with economic progress, in cooperation with the United States.
Food shoppers will find that the pullet size is the most attractive buy in eggs this week-end. Large Grade A eggs advanced 2 cents this week to 87 a dozen; this figures out to 58 cents a pound.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The United Nations will set up a temporary prayer and meditation room in its new General Assembly building, but lack of funds has prevented completion of plans for a permanent chamber.

ALBION, Mich., Sept. 11 -- The extra offensive strength the football Giants have picked up this year was reflected in the starting offensive line-up Coach Steve Owen named today for Sunday's exhibition with the Chicago Bears in Chicago. Five rookies were picked for the platoon.

One in every seven of the licensed drivers re-examined by the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles in 1951 failed to pass some portion of the test and was kept off the road until corrective measures had been taken.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 11 -- Emperor Haile Selassie today signed the act federating the former Italian colony of Eritrea with the Ethiopian empire. Eritrea's new constitution automatically went into effect as he signed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Harvie Ward Jr. of Atlanta, the British amateur champion, rallied today to win by 1 up from the national collegiate champion, Jim Vickers, and advance to the quarter finals of the Western amateur golf tournament.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 -- One long wallop, a 350-foot drive into the left field seats by Bobby Avila, was all Mike Garcia needed to blank the Athletics, 1 -- 0, today at Municipal Stadium and the Indians now trail the Yankees by only half a game.

Justice Jacob Panken in Bronx Children's Court adjudged neglectful yesterday the mother of a 5-year-old boy who, according to neighbors, mistreated and abused other children in his neighborhood on East 175th Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Truman asserted today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in urging the election of a Republican Congress, was proposing an "isolationist Congress" that would not bring peace.
Pitching help is coming to Brooklyn, and the Dodgers certainly need it after yesterday's exhibition at Ebbets Field, where Manager Chuck Dressen tossed six pitchers into an 11-7 loss to the Cubs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Under the pressure of international conditions the United States has created in less than ten years not just one atomic weapon but "a family of weapons in an ever-increasing stockpile."

June Havoc, who completed an eight-week tour in "Sadie Thompson" on the straw hat trail, had taken a series of inoculations and was set to fly to England next Friday to join her sister, Gypsy Rose Lee, on a two-month European holiday. But a new play has reared its head and the trip is off.

Jack Gross, younger brother and employe of Harry Gross, former bookmaker in Brooklyn, calmly admitted yesterday that he had lied many times in testimony on Oct. 4, 1950, to the Kings County grand jury investigating police corruption.
A two-run pinch single by Bob Elliott in the fifth inning and a gift run in the seventh brought a 5-4 victory for the Giants over the Pirates yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

Sept. 10, 1952, may turn out to be a memorable date in the history books. For on that day, while the eyes of the world were turned on the election campaign in the United States and the preparations for a long-postponed Communist Congress in the Soviet Union, the nucleus for a constituent assembly of a new Europe was formed in the city of Strasbourg.
The prospects for uninterrupted work on New York's waterfront brightened considerably yesterday afternoon as arbitration of a wage review dispute was suggested by the employers' representatives.

Of the plethora of quizzes that came to life this summer on television, one at least deserves to survive. It is "Super-Ghost," which for the last several weeks has been holding down the 7 o'clock niche on Sunday evenings over the National Broadcasting Company network in anticipation of the return of Red Skelton.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church, meeting here in triennial general convention, refused today to give women the right to vote in church legislation.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Richard W. Jackson, 40 years old, Detroit civic leader and vice president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, was found dead in his automobile today. He had been shot once through the right temple and a Luger pistol lay beside him.

Reynolds Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it will head a group that will place on the market 180,000 shares of Western Union Telegraph Company stock -- a 15 per cent interest -- owned by John Fox, Boston financier.

A network of weighing stations to prevent truck weight mileage tax dodging and overloads and to aid in collections is being built on highways throughout the state by the Department of Public Works. Two will open today, one on Route 9, five miles north of Valatie, Columbia County, and on Route 9W, one mile west of Coxsackie, Greene County.

The legality of the nomination of two Democats and a Liberal for Supreme Court justice in the Second Judicial District was upheld last night by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Government's intervention in the engineering wage dispute helped the stock markets today to recover from a dull start. British Government stocks regained all their losses and many industrial shares eliminated at least part of their fails although prices remained sensitive.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,370, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's speech to the Los Angeles Town Club this afternoon and his address in the Shrine Auditorium tonight:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- When Senator Joe McCarthy's record is reviewed for the third time, as it will be from now until Nov. 4, the voters of Wisconsin might retire him from the Senate. But twice they have endorsed him over his critics in and outside the state.

A new resolution has been adopted by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, A. F. L., parent body of all performer unions, in an effort to settle a jurisdictional dispute between two of its member unions in respect to television.

A Paris street scene will be painted on Macy's Broadway windows for their fourth annual accessory bazaar that will be opened to the public Monday and continue through Sept. 27. Through the paintings on the windows the public may view accessory displays representing designs from six foreign countries.
Kempton Dunn, vice president and treasurer of the American Brake Shoe Company, has been elected to its board of directors.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 11 (UP) -- Chairman George J. Jones Jr. of the Pennsylvania Boxing Commission said today the referee for the Jersey Joe Walcott-Rocky Marciano heavyweight title fight at Philadelphia would be chosen among officials throughout the state -- not merely from the Philadelphia area.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman announced today that he had "energetically protested" to United States Ambassador James Clement Dunn against the charge alleged here to have been made by Ernest A. Gross, a United States delegate to the United Nations, that France, in her dispute with the Tunisian Government, was not negotiating with representatives of the Tunisian people.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 11 -- Britain and Iran have entered into cautious negotiations designed to give the joint Churchill-Truman proposals for the settlement of the Iranian oil question an interpretation that may make it acceptable here, according to information obtained today.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Encouraging progress in state negotiations to acquire Island Beach on the New Jersey coast for a park and wildlife preserve was reported today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- During the week ended Sept. 10 member bank reserves increased $580,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALTHOUGH we admit to the necessity of being in a duck blind by daybreak, and consider even a commuter's breakfast to be rather tardy for a deer hunter, we were rather annoyed at being routed out of bed at 5 A. M. for a chuck-hunting safari.

A syndicate of investors has purchased the ten-story and penthouse apartment building for thirty families at 125 East Seventy-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Culver, Hollyday Co., the brokers. The buyers, who were represented by Jaffin, Kimmel, Schneider Galpeer, attorneys, paid cash over a mortgage indebtedness of about $240,000. Lewis Herrick represented the seller, and tile was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- As the Yankees sat idly by today listening to the cheerless tidings that their lead had been whittled to a half game, Manager Casey Stengel occupied himself with a matter of greater importance.
The Port of New York Authority reduced its rents yesterday to airlines and other tenants at Newark Airport because of the decrease in commercial traffic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended Sept. 6 were 1 per cent below sales in the same period last year. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1951:
NEWARK, Sept. 11 -- Two blundering bandits held eighteen office employes at bay with pistols in a vain attempt this morning to obtain a $9,000 payroll which was within arm's reach of both.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11 -- An economic conference embracing all but Communist-dominated countries of the world may be held after the new United States Administration takes office next January to map a concerted drive to overcome the free world's dollar payments disbalance.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Packard Motors disclosed today it was beginning delivery to the Navy of a new type marine diesel engine, described as the lightest weight units of their type in the world.

PARIS, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe, flew back tonight from Turkey. Before leaving Ankara today General Ridgway described his inspection trip there as "one of the most impressive trips I ever had because of the burning patriotism and deep love of country which was visible among the people equally with the soldiers."

CAIRO, Sept. 11 -- The Egyptian Cabinet today approved a decree law under which any public official suspected of malfeasance in office, or flagrant inefficiency, may be dismissed or placed on pension without the right of appeal.

Stock prices fluctuated within a narrow range and closed mixed yesterday as the tempo of activity slowed perceptibly. Reversing the trend of the five preceding sessions, the market closed with gains outnumbering losses and the averages accomplishing a slight advance. American Telephone and Telegraph was the list's firmest performer, while Western Union Telegraph was its weakest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- The immediate weather outlook for Paris not being conducive to the filming of a story that is supposed to be taking place in the summertime, Milton Sperling has postponed production of "So This Is Paris" and canceled reservations to go overseas this week-end.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Claude Harmon, pro, and Homer Johnson, Winged Foot Club president, tied at 31, 33 -- 64 with the Hampshire C. C. tutor, Gus Salerno, and the Hampshire president, Irving Kuller, for the Westchester P. G. A. pro-and-president championship in best-ball competition today at Bonnie Briar C. C.

Detectives crashed a small wedding party last night in the Hamilton Hotel, 143 West Seventy-third Street, and charged the bridegroom, Willard D. Elmquist, 23 years old, of the Beacon Hotel, 2130 Broadway, with committing thirty hotel hold-ups in the last five months, the police reported.

Willard Whitney Straight Dolivet, 7 years old, whose body was found in a pond last Sunday in Bedford Village, N. Y., left an estate of $110,000. This was disclosed yesterday when his mother, Mrs. Beatrice Straight Cookson of 113 East Eighty-first Street applied to Surrogate George Frankenthaler for letters of administration.

J. J. Shubert, theatrical producer and theatre operator, filed yesterday in Federal court a civil anti-trust suit against two unions and eight theatrical equipment hauling and transfer companies charging they conspired in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Laws. He asked for a temporary injunction to restrain them from continuing the alleged conspiracy.

Those who believe that an injection of accents from the Orient may relieve the sometimes mechanistic look of a modern interior will be interested in an exhibition of arts and crafts from a part of the world heretofore almost unexplored.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Weakness in soy beans, in which long liquidation was heavy, tended to depress grains today on the Board of Trade, and the general tone was heavy. Perfect weather for maturing the corn and bean crops, however, was the paramount trade influence, discouraging bulls and making it difficult to stir up any general buying support.

Russeks culled the fashion centers of Europe for their impressive collection of import designs displayed yesterday at the store. From Florence, Paris, Rome and Spain came the approximately sixty costumes representing the houses of Balenciaga, Givenchy, Fath, Desses, Lanvin, Griffe, Battilocchi, Schuberth, Visconti, Fabiani, Capuccie, Antonelli, Vanna, La Tessetrice dell Isola, Pertegaz, Santa Eulalie, Bastida, Gres and Rodriguez.
WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Cuba took a slight edge lead over the United States as they beat the British team today in the international tuna tournament.

The one-story factory at 258 Old Country Road in Mineola, L. I., has been sold by Ernest Walter W. Pester to Stanley Babinski and Leon J. Flowers. Sigmund Moses was attorney for the buyers, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

UDINE, Italy, Sept. 11 -- The Folgore Light Infantry Division swung into action at dawn this morning, opening a ten-day maneuver by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Approximately 90,000 to 100,000 men will be engaged in simulated warfare around this eastern bastion of the western democracies.

A new political entity is taking final form in East Africa this week. By Monday Eritrea will formally become an "autonomous unit" in a confederation with Ethiopia. Last month Haile Selassie ratified the new Eritrean Constitution and yesterday he signed the act of union linking his ancient empire with Eritrea.

A sixty-one-family apartment house at 20674.71 Mapes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2067 Mapes Avenue Corporation to Bertha Lampert through Glaser Glaser, brokers. The property is assessed at $150,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $115,000. The sellers owned the parcel for eighteen years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- New cases of infantile paralysis reported last week set a third successive weekly record at 3,824 cases. This put the total for this "disease year" ahead of the similar period in the record 1949-50 year.

The split in the State C. I. O. Executive Board on the issue of a Senatorial endorsement illustrates the fact that while labor leaders may influence the rank and file they cannot "deliver the labor vote." While a majority of the C. I. O. Board voted to endorse John Cashmore, the Democratic candidate, representatives of the Utility Workers and the United Rubber Workers voted against the endorsement and the American Newspaper Guild abstained from voting.
After dipping $5,000,000 in the preceding week, New York bank loans to business resumed their upward movement last week with a gain of $112,000,000.
It is with some timidity and a good deal of hesitation that I submit to you the impressions of a woman whose sole claim to importance is that of every American citizen -- one vote.

ENFIELD, N. H., Sept. 11 (UP) -- H. Peter Pearson, who resigned on Friday as manager of a woolen mill to take a better-paying job, was back at the plant today because more than 200 employes signed a petition asking him to stay. "After all," said Mr. Pearson, "money isn't everything."

The liquor industry faces at least ten years of difficult selling conditions, during which population increases alone cannot relieve the pressure, Harry G. Serlis, president of Schenley Distributors, Inc., predicted yesterday at the company's field management conference in the Astor Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois attacked the Republican party today as the party of the past and the party of fear, and he called on all Americans to have faith in themselves and in the future of America.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 11 -- The Governmental Research Association was told today that within the next six years thousands of communities in this country would have to choose between more pupils per teacher or smaller salaries for teachers.
Mainbocher keeps alive a spirit of great elegance. In a manner quite his own, this distinguished designer unites yesterday and today in clothes that have a modern fashion idiom.

PARIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther was quoted today as saying he did not believe the people behind the Iron Curtain could be liberated without war and that there was no question of launching such a war.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- A large decrease in the mortality of patients treated by surgical means for mitral stenosis, the narrowing of the mitral, or miter-shaped valve, of the heart following rheumatic fever, was reported at the European Congress of Cardiology here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the quiet, workman-like right-hander for the Phillies, hurled his twenty-fourth victory of the season by beating the Cardinals, 3 -- 2, tonight at Shibe Park. He has won more games than any other major league pitcher.

" Rumor and Reflection," the war-time diary of Bernard Berenson, art historian and humanist, will be published by Simon Schuster on Sept. 29. The diary covers the period from Jan. 1, 1941, to Nov. 12, 1944, and records Berenson's impressions of what was happening in Italy and the world.

A green-eyed, red-haired Kentucky mountain girl, "fourteenth in a family of fourteen" who sang Elizabethan ballads, while doing dishes or working in the cornfields, will sail for England today to do some academic sleuthing into the origins of such songs.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Nassau District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta today accused officials of the Central National Bank of Mineola of obstructing his investigation of the alleged $475,000 loan swindle of the bank by a Roslyn home improvement corporation.

Additional evidence of the continuing interest in designs of the past is the new collection of wallpapers designed by Beryl S. Austrian for Sigfrid K. Lonegren, Inc. Entitled the Washington Square Group, the papers are available through decorators at the Lonegren showroom, 515 Madison Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Three hundred artists -- many of them world-renown figures in the theatre, literature, music and painting -- will meet in Venice this month to talk over their common professional problems. The meeting, which opens Sept. 22, is sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Eritrea today celebrated its birth, emerging as the world's newest state after having once been Italy's oldest colony. A public holiday was observed throughout this East African country.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 12 -- Another futile attempt to break the long deadlock on an armistice agreement for Korea was made this morning at Panmunjom by the full United Nations and Communist delegations. Their meeting lasted thirty-two minutes and produced nothing more than another week's recess, until 11 A. M., Sept. 20 [10 P. M., Sept. 19, Eastern daylight time].

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- A total of $140,000,000 in Israel bond subscriptions in the last sixteen months has been used toward building up that country's economic framework, with special emphasis on its vast network of agricultural and industrial projects, it was reported today at the opening of the second annual National Economic Conference for Israel.

CINCINNATI, Sept 11 -- The advancement of standards of living depends upon free and independent research in a competitive system, Weil McElroy, president of Procter and Gamble Company, said today at the opening of the two-day dedication of the company's multi-million dollar Miami Valley Laboratory at Venice, Ohio, near Cincinnati.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll took up the cause of newspaper representatives today to improve news contacts with state departments and officials.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 11 -- The International Fiscal Association ended a four-day congress here today with recommendations calling upon national governments
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Truman said today that more good-looking young ladies, and good-looking middle-aged ladies" were needed in the armed services.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 -- Confidence that by the end of the year the United Kingdom would be in balance with the dollar area and that, with the question of the balance of payments out of the way, there would be a big expansion in commonwealth trade, was expressed by Derick H. Amory, British Minister of Pensions, at today's meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association which is holding its biannual conference here.

With the help of their mother, two aunts and a nurse, the infant Abrams triplets attended their first party yesterday in celebration of the second anniversary of the Premature Center of St. Vincent's Hospital, Eleventh Street and Seventh Avenue.
BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Union aircraft workers prepared today for possible spread of their strike at the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation here to two plants of the Douglas Aircraft Company.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 17 to 22 points net lower than on Wednesday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson tonight called the Administration's foreign policy "the course best calculated to bridge our present dangers" and warned that liberation of Soviet-dominated territories or peoples by force was "a positive prescription for disaster."
DETROIT, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Walt Dropo clouted a pair of home runs today to lead the Tigers to a 5-to-4 victory over the Red Sox.

Dr. Thomas M. Proctor, assistant director of the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, said yesterday that William H. Jones, 19-year-old Brooklyn youth who fatally stabbed four persons on March 5, 1950, "did not show any signs or symptoms to lead me to diagnose his case as dementia praecox" when he was first admitted to the institution.

In addition to the extended export security controls to be adopted soon by the United States and eleven other countries, extra precautions are to be taken by this country on regulating shipments of automotive parts to certain Far Eastern countries, the Overseas Automotive Club heard yesterday.

Successful sales and satisfactory profits from now on will go to business organizations with up-to-the-minute management, Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Management Association, declared yesterday. He said the all-out return to a competitive economy leaves no room for top management accustomed to soft selling.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) -Three golfers shot 4-under-par scores of 68 today to tie for the lead in the opening round of the $15,000 Eastern open tournament.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Hermann Ehlers, president of the Bundestag agreed today to receive a five-man delegation from the East German Parliament, which is coming to this city with proposals for the reunification of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Truman asserted today that the nation's newspapers were "big business" and predominantly Republican and that therefore the public should read the news with a grain of salt in order to get a fair balance between Republican and Democratic political candidates.

BERLIN, Sept. 11 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Central Commission in Germany, notified United States headquarters today that Western Allied military police personnel would be permitted to traverse about one mile of the superhighway in Soviet zone territory west of Berlin to take their stations at the official checkpoint without interference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- There were reports at the Capitol today that the Export-Import Bank would announce, within a few days, a loan of about $15,000,000 to the government of Pakistan for the purpose of buying 150,000 tons of wheat in the world market.
Daniel A. Bolich, former Assistant Internal Revenue Commissioner, was indicted yesterday by the special Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges "of willfully and knowingly evading income taxes."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Acting President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez, heading the Conservative Government, and two opposition Liberal party leaders met last night to seek means of ending political violence in Colombia, it was announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Truman said today that he was unaware of any White House pressure having been applied to Theron Lamar Caudle when Mr. Caudle was Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Tax Division.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 11 -- A second-round score of 79 for an aggregate of 155 enabled the Rev. Frank Ryan, a member of Wheatley Hills, to win the first Long Island Senior Golf Association championship today at the Seawane Harbor Club course.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 11 -Army will play this football hand with most of its 1951 cards but Col. Earl H. (Red) Blaik and his coaching staff feel that by a thorough reshuffling of the deck they will be able to extract greater values from its limited strength.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's address last night to the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
The greatest buying season for spring shoes in history was predicted yesterday by spokesmen for the National Shoe Show to be held in Chicago Oct. 26 to 30.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Clifford Vail Brokaw gave a dance tonight at Westaways, his home on Centre Island, for his debutante daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gould Brokaw. Before the dance, the debutante was guest of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hutton at Hutfield, their home in the Wheatley Hills colony.

There are a great many worthy charities in this land and generous and warm-hearted people must sometimes regret that they cannot afford to contribute to every deserving appeal for funds that comes their way. But there is one drive, and it is now in progress, which practically everybody can support.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Britain's plan of buying raw materials for dollars and selling them for sterling was a complete success, the Treasury announced tonight.

On the basis of its favorable record across the seas, Hugh Hastings' comedy about the British Navy, "Seagulls Over Sorrento," has the distinction of opening the new season. It was put on at the John Golden last evening by a task force of able actors.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 11 -- New national elections, or a referendum to test Israeli opinion on the reparations agreement signed yesterday in Luxembourg with the Federal Republic of Germany, were demanded today by spokesmen for the Herut party, a nationalist group that is an outgrowth of the terrorist organization Irgun Zvai Leumi.

Department stores can capture the leadership in sales at night -- the new realm of retailing -- but they must take three basic steps, according to the latest issue of Grey Matter, published monthly by Grey Advertising Agency, Inc. No specific type of retailer, except perhaps Sears, Roebuck and some supermarkets, has as yet emerged as the leader in this field, the publication holds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The Republicans made an appeal to the worker vote today with a sixteen-page cartoon booklet depicting labor leaders as ruthless bosses and praising the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -The Duquesne Light Company, Pittsburgh, has received authorization from the Securities Commission to offer at competitional bidding 140,000 shares of preferred stock, $50 par, and $14,000,000 of thirty-year first morgage bonds.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 -Victory for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the Wisconsin Republican primary, coupled with endorsement of Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, will embarrass and defeat the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket, Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, asserted here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 -- Spokesmen for the First Naval District today acknowledged that intelligence officers had been investigating the possibility of sabotage to the machinery of the destroyer Prichett while the vessel was being overhauled at the Boston Naval Shipyard last month.
The science of silviculture, or the raising of forests as crops, is growing as slowly as the trees, but with the knowledge thus far obtained, timber can be grown as profitably as other staples.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Defense Department officials expressed puzzlement today over a statement by Robert C. Turner, a new member of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, that military expenditures had virtually reached their peak, but he stuck by his guns.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Andante, a 7-year-old brown mare from the Wee-3 Stable of New Rochelle, ridden by Dave Kelly, captured the first division of the $750 William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy event for jumpers as the forty-seventh annual Piping Rock horse show opened today.

Regional Communist party congresses in fourteen of the sixteen Soviet republics will open within the next two weeks, the Soviet newspaper, Izvestia has announced. Diplomatic observers expect these meetings to provide important clues regarding the significance of the all-union party congress scheduled to open Oct. 5.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. will place on the market today an issue of $12,000,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures of Glenmore Distilleries Company, manufacturer of bonded, straight and blended whiskeys sold under the name of Kentucky Tavern, Yellowstone, Old Thompson and Tom Hardy.

The world would be a happier place if television had never been invented, in the opinion of the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, but he admits he enjoys looking at it, and that, worst of all, his wife has become an ardent baseball fan because of it.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Sept. 11 -- The largest and most powerful naval forces to cruise the North Sea and the angry latitudes off the Norwegian coast since World War I will begin Saturday the biggest Allied naval exercise in modern history, Exercise Mainbrace.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 -Victory for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the Wisconsin Republican primary, coupled with endorsement of Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, will embarrass and defeat the Eisenhower-Nixon ticket, Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, asserted here today.

Semper Eadem, under a steady ride by Tommy Field, took the Harbor Hill, the steeplechase handicap that was the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in the colors of Isidor Bieber, Semper Eadem beat Rigan McKinney's Hot by four lengths after a sturdy exhibition over the course of about two miles.

Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor who has been ordered to open and repair a defective $185,679 sewer in Laurelton at his own expense, defied Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- David B. Fluegelman, agent for the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, New York City, was elected president of the National Association of Life Underwriters at the group's sixty-third annual convention today at Haddon Hall Hotel.

Futures traders turned their interpretations of the Government's potato crop estimate -- which came out Wednesday after the market's close -- into action yesterday and every delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange jumped the limit of 25 cents at the opening and stayed there all day.
The American Red Cross will send a bloodmobile today to the United States Court House in Foley Square to receive blood donations from 150 field workers of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Sept. 12 (UP) -- A determined Chinese soldier dashed through both Chinese and United Nations roadblocks last night near the truce talk zone of Panmunjom to give himself up to United Nations military police, the Eighth Army announced today.

New York City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that New York City has borrowed $30,000,000 on tax anticipation notes at 1 1/2 per cent interest. The notes are dated Sept. 12 and come due Oct. 30. They were sold by allotment as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan increased price support levels for next year's oats, barley, rye, and grain sorghums crops today to "assure" adequate feed grain for livestock.

Sales of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation reached a record $195,757,164 in the fiscal year ended June 30, despite sharp curtailment of all activities as a result of a strike in April, May and June. In the previous year, sales totaled $191,444,412.
CAIRO, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Egyptian authorities are refusing to pay a $1,400,000 bill that former King Farouk ran up with a New York jeweler just before his abdication, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 746,044 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,700 cars, or 2.6 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 13,275 cars, or 1.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 5,405 cars, or 0.7 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
Jewish housewives already are planning family menus for the New Year holidays that begin a week from tomorrow with the feast of Rosh ha-Shanah.

Jobless "post-Korea" veterans in New York State may file claims for unemployment insurance benefits on or after Oct. 20, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday. Those whose applications are approved will be entitled to $26 a week for not more than twenty-six weeks.
Contractual arrangements under which employers would compensate workers for wages lost daring periods of jury service were urged yesterday by United States Attorney Myles J. Lane.

A person who takes a 180-horse-power noisemaker out into New York harbor on a ferryboat may expect varying reactions. A. G. Cunnings of the Chrysler Corporation did this yesterday, for the benefit of Arthur W. Wallander, City Director of Civil Defense. The reactions were as expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The ownership of the Chicago Black Hawk hockey team today passed into control of Arthur M. Wirtz, president of the Chicago Stadium; his business associate, James D. Norris, and Norris' younger brother, Bruce, of suburban Lake Forest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's press conference statement today on the political leanings of the nation's newspapers:
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 11 (AP) -The Republican slate of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon of California was put on the Texas ballot today under a Democratic party label.

An apartment house site at 79 North Broadway in White Plains, N. Y., has been purchased from Sam Ackerman by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York on behalf of a syndicate. The site fronts 128 feet on North Broadway and extends 485 feet through the block to a frontage of 128 feet on Park View Court. Title was insured by the Security Title and Guaranty Company.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Walt Masterson set down the White Sox with four hits as the Senators snapped a five-game losing streak with a 4-to-1 victory today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, whom the General defeated for the Republican Presidential nomination, are meeting today to agree on the role that the Senator will play in the campaign.

A re-hearing on a proposed property exchange that has snagged the otherwise almost-complete transfer of lines of the Yonkers Railroad Company to the Westchester Citizens Transportation Committee was completed for the Public Service Commission yesterday by Harold M. Olmsted, examiner.

GOUROCK, Scotland Sept. 12 (AP) -- Nine tankers and fourteen other ships -- Vanguard of a 13-day mock naval war being staged by the North Atlantic Treaty powers -- moved out of the River Clyde today for the North Sea.
Bail totaling $87,500 has been forfeited for four gold smugglers who have fled the country, Assistant United State Attorney Louis I. Kaplan said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended Sept. 9 to 111.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern said today that "no bondholder has ever lost a penny through default on any bond issued by a local school district" in New York State. Mr. McGovern made the statement in a brochure, "The ABC's of local school districts in New York State."
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The stock markets were quiet today but the improved atmosphere in the engineering wage dispute contributed to firm undertone.

In an editorial of Sept. 9 entitled "Clean-up in Egypt" you said, "It is also decidedly worrying to see a member of the fanatical and nationalistic Moslem Brotherhood, Fathy Radwan, taken into the Cabinet."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission today suspended proposed wholesale natural gas rate increases sought by seven companies which would have raised their revenue $33,077,000 during the next year. The commission said it would set a date later to hear the cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- James P. McGranery, Attorney General, appointed Charles S. Lyon of New York today as head of the Tax Division of the Justice Department. Mr. Lyon succeeds Ellis N. Slack, who has been acting head of the division since Theron Lamar Caudle was dismissed by president Truman last November.
Fresh and unusual ideas for decorating within a budget are shown in a model house that will be opened to the public tomorrow in Wilshire, off Lakeville Road in Great Neck, L. I.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Greentree Stable, with favored One Hitter, and Jockey Teddy Atkinson each will be trying for a triple tomorrow in the eighteenth running of the $25,000 Narragansett Special at Narragansett Park.
The contradictions, confusions and inconsistencies of United States international trade policies are a frequent source of bafflement to foreigners and to Americans alike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The State Department said today the free world must emphasize Europe's defense more than that of Asia because its loss would give Russia a war-makin power "unequaled in history."

A burglary gang of six men, including a "master planner" who engineered more than 100 hold-ups and burglaries in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut where loot valued at upward of $1,000,000 was obtained, has been taken into custody, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 12 -- The first full dress debate in Europe's first sovereign supranational assembly demonstrated today a clear intention on the part of a majority of the seventy-eight delegates from six nations to move rapidly toward the goal of a political federation.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 12 -- The Democratic Presidential candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, ended his 6,700-mile trip of the West today by asking whom he was running against -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower or Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

UDINE, Italy, Sept. 12 -- A battalion of 230 Italian paratroopers jumped today under simulated wartime conditions on the second day of Operation Ancient Wall, the first full scale maneuvers held by North Atlantic Treaty forces in southern Europe.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Rookie Marion Fricano gained his first major league victory with a three-inning relief stint today as the Athletics defeated the Tigers, 7 to 6, before 1,828 fans, the smallest crowd of the season at Briggs Stadium.

Twelve members of the Fujiwara Opera Company of Japan will appear in two performances of Puccini's opera, "Madama Butterfly," at the City Center on Oct. 9 and 18. They will assume the Japanese roles such as Cio-Cio-San, Suzuki and Goro, while regular members of the company will take the parts of the Americans in the cast.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -- The Socialist Reich party, largest and best organized of the post-war German Neo-Fascist organizations, announced its dissolution today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic candidate for Vice President, told 3,500 cheering persons at the State Democratic Convention here tonight that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, had been able to tell the people what the Republicans were against but not what they were for.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Elizabeth Forbes-Sempill of Aberdeen who has appeared in registers of British noble families since birth in 1912 as the youngest daughter of the eighteenth Baron Sempill gave notice today of a change of sex and first name.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 -- The Austrian government told Vadim P. Sviridov, Soviet High Commissioner, today that obviously he had been made the victim of false information when he attacked Austria as a reactionary state, in the Allied Control Council a fortnight ago.

Commenting on the conference between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, declared yesterday that "General Eisenhower was able to win on the battlefield but he has completely surrendered in the political arena."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 -- The Yugoslav Government has decided that if there is to be a solution of the Trieste dispute with Italy it must be made on Yugoslav terms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A small turbine-driven aircraft that can take off straight up and then fly horizontally was patented this week by Nathan C. Price of St. Helena, Calif., who assigned his rights to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- The United Nations special commission on war prisoners announced today that it could not carry out its task of tracing hundreds of thousands of missing soldiers without Russian cooperation.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Johnny Bulla, a former airlines pilot, gained sole possession of the lead at the halfway mark in the Eastern open golf tournament today by cutting seven strokes off par with 137 for thirty-six holes.

Two men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on fifty counts of manipulating stock on the New York Stock Exchange in violation of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. It was the first action of its kind here.

Sixty-three young men and women will be welcomed tomorrow at the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, as cadets in the Salvation Army Officers' Training College, 1771 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx. They win comprise the thirty-sixth class.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- In spite of the "bludgeonings of economic change," the motion picture industry's head is "bloody but unbowed," Paul Raibourn of New York City, vice president of Paramount Pictures Corporation, said here today.

Kermit Bloomgarden has added another play to his increasing string of theatrical projects. It is tentatively called "Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang," written by Irving Ravetch. Reticent about describing it, Mr. Bloomgarden would only volunteer the following information: "It is a drama in three acts, requiring nine players.
BOSTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Braves routed Pittsburgh, 16 to 0, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Pirates took the opener, 8 -- 1, with Ralph Kiner hitting two homers.

Jack Gross, younger brother and employe of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, testified yesterday at the police trial that he had lied to a Kings County grand jury investigating his brother's dealings with policemen because he feared James E. Reardon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The price of a shave and a haircut, in the big cities at least, has risen tenfold since the good old days of the jingle about "two bits," a survey showed today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UP) -- A scheduled strike of 17,000 Douglas Aircraft Company employes, set for 12:01 A. M. tomorrow, was postponed today until Monday to coincide with an expected walkout at another Douglas plant in El Segundo, Calif.

The Beldame Handicap, the richest of the fall stakes at Aqueduct, will be even richer than originally intended by the Queens County Jockey Club when the mile-and-a-furlong fixture enjoys its fourteenth running today. So popular has the stakes for fillies and mares turned out to be that it has attracted nineteen starters, with the result that the Beldame will be run in two divisions, occupying the sixth and seventh spots on the program.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A grand jury declared today that the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane lacked sufficient attendants to guard against escapes by inmates.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- William H. Draper Jr., United States representative on the North Atlantic Council, warned today there was "no credible evidence" of the easing of the Soviet threat. The present NATO strength -- military, economic and spiritual -- still remains far from adequate," he added.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization granted a 75 cents-a-ton increase yesterday in the Ceiling price of merchant iron ore produced in the Lake Superior district of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan. The increase will not affect prices to consumers of iron and steel, the O. P. S. said.

The recent speeches of the Presidential aspirants, compared with Secretary Acheson's address at Kansas City, demonstrate how few are the points of difference among the rival candidates and the present Administration on the central issue of foreign policy.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 12 (UP) -- A Washington attorney filed suit today for $1,000,000 as his fee in the fight of the Dollar steamship interests to regain from the Government $15,000,000 in stock representing control of the Dollar lines.

Your editorial comments on Governor Stevenson's speech concerning "the one-party press in a two-party country" were most interesting. Neither your editorial nor Arthur Krock's column, however, adequately answers the Governor's perceptive remarks. There are several matters that (to paraphrase Mr. Krock) "especially THE NEW YORK TIMES should understand":

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 12 -- The City of Danbury today petitioned the Fairfield County Superior Court to dissolve a temporary injunction under which the city is restrained from interfering with the installation of natural gas pipelines across feeder mains in the north end, which carry water into the city from municipal reservoirs in that area.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Six Arab states moved today to bring before the United Nations virtually all of their disputes with Israel left unsettled after the Palestine conflict.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,371 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 12 -- The International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., endorsed the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, today, supported the Truman Administration's foreign policy, and scored "McCarthyism" in dedicating the union "to the defeat of un-American character assassins."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- The traditional ball that takes place at the Piping Rock Club on the second day of the three-day program of the Piping Rock Horse Show attracted more than 200 members and their guests tonight after several dinner parties at the club and in country homes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The hog disease, vesicular exanthema, has been stamped out in ten of twenty-three states where it broke out this summer, the Agriculture Department said today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 12 (UP) -- A Frankfort grain dealer and a Bloomington milling company were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of unlawfully taking from Government storage 49,000 bushels of corn owned by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

The cost to the United States Treasury for borrowing money is continuing to go up. Within a few weeks of the refunding of $2,000,000,000 of one-year debt at an interest rate of 2 per cent, the Treasury announced yesterday plans for refunding $10,861,027,000 of like debt at a rate of 2 1/8 per cent.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Premier Antoine Pinay backed up his government's decision yesterday forbidding any rise in the price of goods and services above their Aug. 31 levels with a radio appeal to the country to support his effort "to defend the franc."

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- United Nations warplanes carried out another heavy attack last night against the big Supung (Suiho) hydroelectric plant on the Yalu River, within 1,000 yards of the Manchurian border. The plant has been a main source of power for the Mukden-Dairen industrial complex of North China.

GONZALES, Tex., Sept. 12 (AP) -- South Texas streams, driven far from their banks by two and a half days of rain, settled back into their courses today. Seven persons were known to be dead, hundreds were homeless and property damage was high.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 12 -- The new Ambrose lightship, scheduled to replace her veteran namesake as the navigational guide at the mouth of New York harbor on or about Oct. 15, was commissioned today at the Coast Guard yard here.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12 -- Differences of opinion among the Commonwealth countries over the recognition of the Communist Government of China, a suggested new approach to the Korean peace negotiations by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, and an impassioned speech about Irish unification from John Lynch of Ireland made today's meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association more lively than harmonious.

HAMBURG, Pa., Sept. 12 -- The police mobilized Pennsylvania's biggest manhunt in years today against three shotgun-toting jail-breakers who held a family captive in its home for nineteen hours, then sped sixty-five miles to rob a roadside diner and a little later raced past a police roadblock on a main highway to New York.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Automotive production reached a new high for 1952 this week just six weeks after sinking to a post-war low during the steel strike, Ward's Reports said today.

Sales of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company in June and July, the first two months of the company's fiscal year, were about twice those of a year ago, Charles F. Adams Jr., president, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Newton, Mass.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 12 -- Former President Alfonso Lopez and Dr. Carlos Lleras Restrepo, outstanding leaders of the opposition Liberal party, have taken asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy, the Foreign Ministry announced today.
The Cardinals hit two home runs in one inning off Joe Black last night at Ebbets Field but the Dodgers hit harder and more often and came through with an 8 -- 5 victory.

In his speech in Kansas City, Secretary Acheson, who is immediately responsible for our foreign policy, took up a problem which threatens to produce a major distortion of the principal issue in the Presidential campaign to the detriment of our international relations and of peace.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The ninth Yaddo music festival of American works opened here this afternoon with the first of six concerts. The event marked the 'twenty-fifth anniversary of festival music performances given at approximately three-year intervals at Yaddo, the former Saratoga estate of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Trask.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12 -- Former Mayors Frank Hague and Frank Eggers, are scheduled to appear next Thursday before the special holdover Hudson County grand jury investigating conditions along the waterfront.

The State Court of Appeals will convene in Albany on Monday at 12:30 P. M. to hear arguments on an appeal by the insurgent forces in the Kings County Democratic party from an Appellate Division ruling affirming the party's regular slate of nominees for the State Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- Maj. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, United States commandant in Berlin, declared today that the people of the United States must realize that the situation in Berlin is just as critical now as it ever has been, even including the days of the 1948-49 Soviet blockade.
ATHENS, Sept. 12 -- The Chamber of Deputies voted tonight to adopt the majority system of elections in place of the present complex system of proportional representation.

With automobile insurance rates on the upgrade in a good many sections of the country it would seem wise for the motorist who is averse to having the rates go any higher to take heed of his driving. Even the smallest dent in another person's car costs money to repair and goes into the tabulations by which rates are figured for future policies.

Pakistan's Government is in process of negotiating loan funds to purchase wheat to meet a food crisis. There is every reason to believe that the funds will be available and that the crisis will be met. If there is any obstacle it should be speedily overcome. The need is real and urgent.
DUBLIN, Ga., Sept. 12 -- Deacons of the Ebeneezer Baptist Church swore out a warrant here today accusing a former member of the congregation of stealing the church building.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- Jersey Joe Walcott, punching hard with a left hook, knocked out Pete Nelson of Atlantic City, at Bader Field today in preparation for the defense of his title Sept. 23 against Rocky Marciano.

CHCICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Dan Topping, co-owner of the Yankees, traveled a thousand miles today only to lose the toss of a coin. As a consequence, should the American League pennant race result in a tie between the Bombers and the Indians, the play-off will be staged in Cleveland on Monday, Sept. 29, the day following the close of the regular schedule.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Tonight this busy borough at the head of navigation on the Navesink River is having its annual excitement as another National Sweeptaks gets itself in readiness for two days of speed boating, tomorrow and Sunday.
AUBURN, Calif., Sept. 12 (UP) -- A Presbyterian minister confessed today that he masqueraded as a woman in engineering a plot that swindled an elderly Loomis couple of their $23,000 life savings.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 -- Advocates of public ownership of private industry have failed to recognize the need for technological competition as a keystone of progress, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said here tonight at a dinner concluding a two-day dedication of the Miami Valley Research Laboratories of Procter Gamble Company.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12 -- The Bolivian governor of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development declared today that Bolivia "has definitely decided" to nationalize the country's three major tin-mining companies.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The battle of Crompond Road in near-by Cortlandt spread today, with more property owners parking automobiles on their private lands in the path of a natural gas pipeline to prevent its construction.
The following is a round-up of new items that may be of use to the homemaker.

The season for fresh apples has begun with juicy McIntosh, crisp red Delicious and Greenings already prominent in fruit stalls here. But the local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing puts a damper on this good news by reporting that apple prices are higher now than in 1951 and will continue to be throughout the season.

Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, political adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, told a gathering yesterday of 200 independent voters backing the Republican national ticket that the independent vote would be "indispensably important" to success in the Presidential election.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- Gerhart Eisler, East German chief of information, held a press conference today to issue an East German Government White Book attacking the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies, but he ran into a little unexpected trouble.

Complaints by parents of children attending Public School 19, Fourteenth Street, west of First Avenue, that it is "painfully overcrowded" brought yesterday from Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. an announcement that on Monday he would inspect four East Side schools.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The names of five indicted men sought across the country in the Saratoga gambling inquiry were disclosed today.

With evidence mounting that the traditional August fur promotions are not bringing in business, it might be a good idea for fur retailers to delay starting their promotions until a week or two after Labor Day, according to the Fur Trade Review, published by Vincent Edwards Co.

Joe E. Brown and Dolores Gray will be starred in a new musical comedy series with a circus background to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company network every fourth Tuesday from 8 to 9 P. M. beginning Oct. 7.

Directors of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company have decided to recommend to stockholders acceptance of the offer of six public utility districts to buy the bulk of Puget Sound's properties for $89,490,000, Frank McLaughlin, president of the utility company, said yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The successful and nontoxic effect of relatively small doses of heparin, the liver extract, on painful cases of angina pectoris was discussed by the French delegates to the European Congress of Cardiology here today. Two French researchers, Dr. Edouard Donzelot and H. Kaufmann, said they found it diminished the frequency and intensity of anginal crises in 70 per cent of the fifty cases studied and "may even suppress them altogether."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that a survey made by his department showed strong farmer backing for most existing farm aid programs and for Government support of farm prices at full parity.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 12 -- The fears of the spread of terrorism in British East Africa have been revived by the attack last night by a gange of Negroes, said to be adherents of the Mau Mau secret society, on the Roman Catholic priests residence at Kirika missions, seventy miles from Nairobi, Kenya.

Magistrate Paul Balsam reserved decision yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court after hearing argument in the case of Samuel Chapman, dress manufacturer, who was arrested on Aug. 15 on a charge of possession of pornographic pictures.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 12 -- Gov. Robert F. Kennon announced today plans for a "Democrats for Eisenhower" meeting here this month to start a Louisiana drive backing Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican, for President.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- Weekly newspapers and country correspondents received certificates for excellence in six classifications today from the New York Press Association, the state organization of weekly editors, at the group's 100th annual mid-year convention here.

Following are the texts of addresses by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson to a luncheon of Democratic party workers in Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday afternoon, and at a meeting in Albuquerque, N. M., last night, as carried by The Associated Press:

The six-story apartment house at 43-08 Fortieth Street in Long Island City, Queens, accommodating seventy families, has been sold by Mildred W. Weed to a client of Max Gellis, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by Joseph R. Paretta as broker.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- From the look of things, the Yankees will have to help themselves when they arrive here Sunday. There was no assistance from the Athletics earlier in the week, and tonight the Red Sox succumbed to Early Wynn and the Indians, 5 -- 0.

Arbitration of the wage-review dispute of 65,000 East Coast dockworkers seemed assured yesterday as the 130-man wage-scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., voted to accept this procedure subject to the approval of the membership.

Seventy-three young women who aspire to wear the severe navy blue uniform of a New York policewoman showed up in giddily eye-catching shorts and shirts yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, and went through the most strenuous sort of track meet.

Senator Francis J. Mahoney of the Nineteenth District, Manhattan, was elected yesterday as minority leader of the State Senate, succeeding the late Elmer F. Quinn, at a meeting of the Democratic Senators at the Biltmore Hotel.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Mrs. T. Arthur Menzel, who resides in Stamford, Conn., and is a member of the Innis Arden Club became the new senior champion of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today by winning the tourney at the Century Country Club.

The city's annual electricity bill for lighting its streets and public buildings, now $12,920,428, is due to increase $1,945,944, it was disclosed yesterday by Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
E. F. Gormsen has been appointed director of purchases for the Chevrolet motor division of General Motors.

Two apartment houses containing two stores and eighty-seven suites at 6920 Twentieth Avenue and 1953-1973 Seventieth Street in Brooklyn have been sold by Harry J. and Anna Sandler and Morris and Adele Mayer to Morris Stachhammer.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens reported yesterday that his engineers had found a defective half-block section in a $92,000 sewer built by G. C. (Jack) Clemente in Springfield, south of Laurelton. Mr. Clemente is a brother of Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor now under fire for defects found in a Laurelton sewer project.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- The National Federation of Federal Employes, an independent organization that says it has 100,000 members, urged all Government workers today to "reject favors, gifts, gratuities or financial benefits, in whatever guise, that are contrary to the ethical performance of their duties."

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Cuba today won the ninth international tuna tournament -- an event that will go on the records for an exciting climax and discovery of a well-stocked fishing ground.

Calling upon their cripples when the stalwarts tottered, the Giants yesterday continued their last-ditch drive to overtake the league-leading Dodgers but had to settle for a split of their twin bill with the Reds.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- Herbert E. Gaston, chairman of the export-Import Bank -- the Government agency that extends loans for the economic development of free, democratic nations -- emphasized here today that the bank's loans of $135,000,000 to Israel were a "sound and good investment." He then underscored the fact that "we expect to see the credit of Israel maintained."
