BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 12 -- Ministers of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, the Benelux nations, will meet Oct. 8 and 9 at the Belgian seaside resort of Le Zoute-Knokke to try to prevent the economic union projected between the three countries nine years ago from being stifled before birth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 -- "Democratic centralism," the ultimate establishment of total socialism and communism, and the continued monopoly of power are three of the basic principles of the revised statutes of the Yugoslav Communist party that have just been published and that will be adopted at the sixth party congress late in October.

The four-story dwelling on lot 16 by 100 feet at 154 East Sixty-fifth Street has been sold by Mrs. Richard J. Costigan to a New Yorker for occupancy in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. It was modernized last year and has a dining room on the entrance floor opening into a garden.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- Communist sources indicated yesterday that the Chinese and North Korean authorities would reject a Mexican plan to break the Korean truce deadlock. The plan would offer asylum in neutral countries to war prisoners who have refused to return to their former commands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The White House announced tonight that President Truman would roll out on his railroad train on Sept. 27 for an 8,500-mile campaign trip and make seventy-five to one hundred whistle stops between San Francisco and New York.

Restaurants around town are dusting off their signs about the oyster as a companion at the dinner table again, but over in New Jersey, according to a story in the newspapers the other day, leaders of the oyster fleet have a wary eye turned in the direction of New York City.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Harry D. Ryan's gray gelding Grey Knight from Uniontown, Pa., with Joe Green riding, took the second division of the William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy competition for jumpers at the forty-seventh annual Piping Rock horse show today.

In his final report as president of the Rockefeller Foundation Chester I. Barnard has centered attention on the problems created by the contrast between the traditional and justly honored concept of academic freedom and the security requirements created by the present perilous world situation.

The Government's suggestion that the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association (A. F. L.) arbitrate their wage-review dispute is sound. We hope that its prompt acceptance by the employers will be followed with similar union action.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- After almost five hours of procedural wrangling, the United Nations Security Council today turned down Soviet demands to send the membership applications of five countries to a committee for examination.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Air Force reported today that a Texas tornado last week had damaged 106 B-36 heavy bombers and had destroyed another at a loss of far more than $48,000,000.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores in August showed an aggregate gain of 7.2 per cent over volume for the like month of 1951, according to a compilation of forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- The rule of a six-man administrative board over Local 600, United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., which was to have ended last night, has been extended temporarily, the union announced today. The local has jurisdiction at plants of the Ford Motor Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Harvie Ward, 26-year-old British amateur champion from Atlanta, defeated the dark horse, James Frisina, Taylorville, Ill., 6 and 5, today to advance to the semi-finals of the Western amateur golf tournament.

Private placement of a substantial block of stock of the Christiana Securities Corporation, a holding company originally set up by the du Pont family, is reported to have taken place. In underwriting circles, the sale was related to the tax liabilities of the estate of Lammot du Pont, retired chairman of the board of the du Pont Company, who died recently.
The statement read by Senator Robert A. Taft and his answers to questions at a press conference here yesterday follow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- President Truman named today the United States delegation to the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly in New York beginning Oct. 14.
" Ivanhoe" has become the first film to earn $1,000,000 during the first six weeks of its release at the Radio City Music Hall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- The Ohio Republican chairman, Ray Bliss, hailed Senator Robert A. Taft's statement today supporting Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President as "a clear-cut call to Ohioans" to join in the Eisenhower campaign in this state.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 12 -- A resolution drafted by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealing to the great powers to meet on problems now threatening world peace will be placed before the All India Congress Committee, policy making body of governing Congress party, when it meets tomorrow in Indore.
Alfred M. Esberg, vice president of the American Potash and Chemical Corporation in charge of its Eston Chemicals Division, was elected yesterday a director of the company.

Lumber production for the week ended Sept. 6 was 12.7 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 19.7 per cent and orders 10.9 per cent.

Senator Robert A. Taft announced yesterday, following a two-hour breakfast conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, that they were in full agreement on fundamental campaign issues and that he would work to the limit of his ability, without qualification, to bring about the election of the man who defeated him for the Republican Presidential nomination.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12 -- The little he learned during a brief visit last Spring, when he accepted the post of back-field coach, constituted Jordan Olivar's knowledge of Yale football prior to his surprise nomination -- and he was more surprised than anyone else -- as head coach following Herman Hickman's sudden resignation on Aug. 11.

The nuns of Manhattanville handed over to a new owner yesterday the big, bronze gate key to the 105-year-old campus of the College of the Sacred Heart in a simple leave-taking ceremony on the steps of the main hall.

PHILADELPHA, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Paul Minner scattered seven hits to hurl his thirteenth triumph of the season and Bob Kelly tossed a three-hitter to score his fourth victory tonight as the Cubs defeated the Phillies, 5 -- 1 and 7 -- 0, in a double-header.

A luncheon and fashion show will be given on Oct. 14 by the women's auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. George G. Tenney and Mrs. Harold Behlke are co-chairmen of the committee for the event, the proceeds of which will be used by the auxiliary for its work among the patients.

The stock market, sagging generally, approached its low point of the downward movement during early trading yesterday but then turned a shade firmer and closed irregularly lower. Volume picked up only slightly from the slow pace set on Thursday.

Jersey City's huge $20,000,000 Claremont marine terminal, the scene of continuous labor squabbles between and among warehousemen and longshoremen of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., will have to find a new tenant after Oct. 31.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Pronounced weakness developed again today in corn and soybeans futures, long liquidation again becoming the outstanding feature after a little show of strength early in the session. Ideal weather is still the main factor, insuring early maturity of the corn crop.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 13 (AP) -- On the Korean central front last night and early today, Allied troops recaptured "Finger Ridge" and beat off a Communist battalion attack on "Capitol Hill." Troops of the Republic of Korea Capital Division have been fighting for the hill and the ridge, only a few hundred yards to the west, for the last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- John E. Horne of Alabama was nominated by President Truman today as Administrator of the Small Defense Plants Administration. Mr. Horne, Deputy Administrator since the agency's creation, follows Telford Taylor, whose resignation was simultaneously announced.

MOONACHIE, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The children of School 2 here will report to classes Monday in an abandoned schoolhouse in neighboring Wood-Ridge, which is deemed safer because it is farther away from the Port Authority's Teterboro Airport.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 12 -- With his squad reduced to thirty five men by the departure of Bill Blackburn, promising sophomore tackle, Coach Lou Little limited Columbia's football practice today to a three-hour afternoon session. The Lions began their second week of training at Camp Columbia.

Death was the loser in a close fifteen-minute contest ending on a slanted six-inch ledge ten stories above Maiden Lane yesterday. Before several thousand watchers, two painters struggled on a scaffold that hung vertically after one of them had pulled the wrong guy rope.

The Carnation Company, canners of evaporated milk and producers of condensed, powdered and malted milk, cream, butter and other farm products, achieved the highest volume of sales in the first half of this year with $154,212,006, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Four women, each representing one of the armed forces, received blocks of stamps yesterday commemorating the women who served in World War II at a ceremony on the steps of the General Post Office. The presentations were made by Postmaster George M. Bragalini.

Industry in this country was accused yesterday of having forgotten how to hunt customers. As a result, said J. E. Farr, executive vice president for sales of Schenley Distributors, Inc., salesmanship in the last ten years has become "a forgotten art."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Army issued a call today for 47,000 draftees in November as it continued to replace men who have served their two-year period of military service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, called his union policy committee today to meet here Monday as wage negotiations with northern soft coal operators entered their critical stage a little more than a week before contract termination.

All summer thirty-eight small gardeners have jealously tended their handkerchief - size garden plots at Highbridge Playground, 189th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Yesterday they met in harvest mood and within ten minutes, with locust-like thoroughness, had reduced the thriving garden to thirty-eight barren humps of ground resembling so many unkempt anthills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Marine casualties on the Korean front are continuing "very high" but the mortality rate is comparatively light, Rear Admiral Lamont Pugh, Surgeon General of the Navy, said today. The primary cause of the light mortality rate is the body armor introduced by the Marines, he added.

The fundamental issue involved in the State Department's denial of passports to certain Americans is not one of improving the method of denial (as your editorial would imply) but of depriving the department of the right to refuse a passport to any American citizen.

The New York City Housing Authority's plans to erect a large housing project in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx instead of using the area for industrial expansion is strongly opposed by Ira S. Robbins, executive vice president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.

Preston Delano, Federal Controller of the Currency, said yesterday in Washington that he had made available to Frank A. Gulotta, Nassau County District Attorney, all data "that could be of any assistance" in the swindle inquiry at the Central National Bank of Mineola, L. I.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Freddie Marsh singled to drive in Ray Coleman in the tenth inning tonight, giving the Browns a 5-4 victory in the final game against the Senators this season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Fighting with extraordinary tenacity to maintain their slender hold on first place in the American League race, the Yankees tonight turned back the White Sox, 6 -- 4, before a roaring crowd of 40,137.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Shipper groups, headed by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, today opposed further consideration by the Interstate Commerce Commission of proposals of the Railway Express Agency to double the express rate on light and bulky items of millinery, hats, and lamp shades.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Provision for the establishment of a "perpetual diaconate" within the Protestant Episcopal Church was approved here today by the House of Bishops of the church's triennial general convention.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The way London figures it Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, the Iranian Premier, has won virtually every point in his oil dispute with Britain and would do well to get down to business on the British-American offer of settlement made Aug. 30.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Robert Taylor will take on the role of Lancelot in Metro's projected filming of "King Arthur and the Round Table."
Prices of cotton futures declined 14 to 24 points yesterday in moderate business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 12 (UP) -- The South gave up its claims today to a Confederate battle flag held in the North, and a museum director said only a "hard-boiled Yankee" would accuse her of restraining Civil War bitterness in asking the flag's return.

A collection of critical articles and essays by John Lehmann, entitled "The Open Night," will be published next Friday by Harcourt, Brace. The writers whom Mr. Lehmann discusses are W. B. Yeats, James Joyce, Virginia Woolf, Edward Thomas, R. M. Rilke, Wilfred Owen, Henry James, Demetrios Capetanakis, Joseph Conrad, Alun Lewis, Marcel Proust and Rupert Brooke.

CAIRO, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Former Premier Mustafa Nahas, leader of the Wafd party, tonight announced the suspension from the party of its secretary general, Fuad Serag el-Din, and other prominent Wafdists arrested by the Army authorities last Sunday.

" YOU, the Jury,"* by Mary Borden, is the joint September selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club with Ernest Hemingway's "The Old Man and the Sea," And, like Hemingway's novel, it is the story of a man's ordeal, though in Miss Borden's modern parable the long and stoic struggle is not against the unfriendly elements of nature but against the inhumanities man shows to his fellow men.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- In a play called "Quadrille," tailored to their talents by Noel Coward, the incomparable Lunts returned to the London stage tonight, resuming their wartime love affair with the British capital.

THOSE planning a trip to the Maine woods for deer this fall will have an opportunity to qualify for membership in the "Biggest Bucks in Maine Club," an organization open to all hunters who manage to bring down a buck scaling more than 200 pounds.

Inspiration has been borrowed from the past and present and almost every possible place for the designs included in one of two new groups of furniture introduced this week by W. and J. Sloane. This large collection, manufactured by Heritage - Henredon, has been named "Circa '60."

Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan's long-awaited appearance before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury took place yesterday morning. The wife of a former plainclothes man and mother of four children, who faces possible punishment for contempt for refusing to answer the panel's earlier subpoena, was questioned for fifty minutes.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Tulyar, the Aga Khan's outstanding 3-year-old, is the favorite to win tomorrow's 176th running of the St. Leger, last British classic race of the year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12 -- Premier Mossadegh discussed with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht today for the fourth time in three days the proposed currency increase, tax and other measures for getting the Iranian Government financially afloat again.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, urged the nation's working men and women yesterday to produce "the maximum vote for the friends of labor" in November.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Is there a doctor in the house who wants to make $50,000 a year taking care of a king's harem? He and his wife will live in a palace amid waving palms, perfume baths and starlit desert nights, with the king paying the bill.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The Fenway team of Herman Barron, former Goodall champion, and Dorothy Lowenstein, 21-year-old University of North Carolina senior, gained the Westchester P. G. A pro-woman Scotch foursomes title at the Leewood Golf Club today.

SHAWNEE ON DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 12 -- Over-all Government statistics purporting to show that Americans "never had it so good" do not tell the whole story, Herbert J. Miller, executive director of the Tax Foundation, charged here tonight.

The quandary in which New York City officials find themselves on the sticky question whether to proceed with construction of the Second Avenue Subway and other transit improvements arises from increased awareness of the fact that borrowed money has to be paid back.

Potato trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange went through another sharp reversal yesterday. On Thursday more than 900 "buy" orders were unexecuted at the close, because the market had risen the 25 cents permissible for one day's fluctuation.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The French film "Jeux Interdits" tonight won the Golden Lion of St. Mark, grand prize of Venice's thirteenth International Film Festival.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared today "the American people are opposed to the proposal that we go into the Soviet satellite countries and liberate them by force of arms."

Opposition of Southern textile interests to a rise in minimum wages on Government contracts will lead to a Federal court battle, it was pointed out yesterday. Southern mills, through their counsel, have gone on record as favoring a regional or local minimum wage under the Walsh-Healy Act, rather than a national minimum.
ATHENS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Mr. Lapham, as Mutual Security Agency chief in Greece, turned thumbs down today on "any expenditures for new projects" in this country.

A flexible open market policy will not produce "automatically higher" rates of interest, bankers were told yesterday. Presiding at the third annual Investment Seminar of the New York State Bankers Association at the Commodore Hotel, Dr. Marcus Nadler, of New York University, explained that the policy "means merely a return of the initiative in creation of reserve balances to the Federal Reserve Banks."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Cherry-Oca Stable's Tio Ciro, under a magnificent ride by Sammy Boulmetis, won the $20,000 added Absecon Island Handicap over the turf at the Atlantic City race course this afternoon before 21,628 racing fans as he fought off repeated challenges by Joseph Gavegnano's Joey Boy through the stretch to win by a head.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Premier Ane Pinay this week launched an nsive to prevent the rise in costs that started during the ation lull from bringing up the ench price level to the point were it would force an automatic rease in the wage scale.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Form prevailed right down the line in the first round of men's singles play of the Pacific Southwest tournament at the Los Angeles Tennis Club today but some of the favorites had to go all out to hurdle supposedly easy opposition.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 -- The British-owned Jardine, Matheson Co., one of the largest trading concerns in the Far East, was reported today to have received permission from Chinese Communist authorities in Tientsin to liquidate its assets there.

IT seems as if Edmonton -- the northernmost city in Canada, lying' above the parallel of crucial Attu in the Aleutians -- won't ever be able to relax, take a deep breath, and hold still. It keeps on having booms. This is because Edmonton is in fact the epitome of the vast boom which, these days, is rocketing Canadian population, prestige and affluence.

Steamship and airplane passenger arrivals and departures continued at a record 'level last month but customs receipts fell below those of the previous month and of August, 1951, according to statistics made available by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

FROM Lark to Laughing Horse; from Poesy: a Magazine for the Lover of the Muses to the more accurately entitled Death; from heaven knows how many hale monosyllables like Blast, Broom, Forge, Front, Fight, Fire! to the suspect decadences of Chimaera, Tambour, Pagany, Caravel and the like -- the roster of the innumerable little magazines of the fifty years or so is as colorful as their brief lives, taken as a whole, were important.

SECOND-NOVEL trouble is notorious in the mystery-writing profession; so it's not only a delight but a surprise when an unusually good first novelist comes up with an unusually good second novel, as William Campbell Gault does in THE BLOODY BOKHARA (Dutton, $2.50).

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 -- Israel's current program of self-denial will hold little meaning unless investment dollars are made available immediately to increase its industrial and agricultural production, Dr. Joseph Burg, Israel's Minister of Health asserted here tonight.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- Only time will tell how badly the Indians were hurt today. It could be that the end of a glorious nine-game winning streak was the beginning of the end of a beautiful pennant dream, as Al Lopez' Tribe blew a 4-3 overtime decision to the Red Sox.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Frank Stranahan and Harvie Ward swept through the Western amateur golf semi-finals today to set up the same championship pairing as last June when the two rivals tangled at Prestwick, Scotland.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said yesterday that it would endorse a Presidential candidate and hinted broadly that the choice would be Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic nominee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Every service man in the United States will be handed a small buff card on Monday that will offer him the opportunity to vote on whether he wants a General for President.

ROBERT Goldsand has been industriously recording for Concert Hall, which recently issued a group of four disks played by the Austrian pianist (now a resident of America). Goldsand, never one to shy away from the more fearsome items of the repertoire, has coupled Liszt's Six Etudes after Paganini and Rachmaninoff's Variations on a Theme by Chopin on one record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The possibility of using Chinese Nationalist troops from Formosa to reinforce United Nations units in Korea bobs up from time to time, as it did this week. For more than a year, the question has aroused a rotary sort of argument that never quite reaches a conclusion.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's Presidential campaign in Louisiana has been caught in a crossfire of state politics that many observers here think may seriously hurt his chances in November.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- Corruption has come to the fore in the last two weeks as the paramount issue of the Presidential campaign so far as New England is concerned. It seems, however, to need an added spark to touch it off in favor of one national party or the other before Nov. 4, in the opinion of observers.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Soviet trade unions announced today they had agreed to an Indian Government suggestion that famine relief food and funds be sent to the Indian Red Cross rather than to a local committee to which they were initially addressed.

BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- A technical assistance team under the leadership of Richardson Wood, head of a New York engineering concern, will proceed with a four-month study of economic problems in West Berlin to provide the basis for the city's recovery, which has been lagging behind that of West Germany.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 13 -- At this stage of the campaign, when Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson has just visited Portland, and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has just patted Senator William Jenner on the head, the Northwest's political thinking is too confused to put a finger on a single "most important" issue.
PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- South Korean soldiers Friday killed one Communist prisoner and injured eight others as unrest flared again on Koje Island.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 -- Construction of Shriver Hall on the Homewood campus of Johns Hopkins University will start in a few weeks and is expected to be completed in the fall of next year.

ABILENE, Tex., Sept. 13 (UP) -- A high Government official today assailed "increasing complacency" in the United States and warned that coastal cities might soon be vulnerable to attack by guided missiles from enemy submarines.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Confronted with a tuition increase of $150 a year, undergraduates registered with Princeton University's bureau of student aid and employment have met the challenge with a record rise in summer earnings, it was learned today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 3 carried an interesting dispatch from Washington concerning the special exhibit of Bibles now opened at the Library of Congress. This is to mark the 500th anniversary of the printing of the first book, the Bible, by Johann Gutenberg at Mainz, Germany.

Prairie dogs, squirrel-like rodents of the prairies, live in densely settled "prairie dog towns." Their social behavior, which has been studied by the staff of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, Bar Harbor, Me., resembles that of clannish human communities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -John L. Lewis prepared today for a final week's bargaining battle with the coal industry as reports indicated he might not have to call a strike to win new contracts for his 475,000 miners.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Unless present indications miscarry, the American motorist will get greatly improved gasoline mileage in most of next year's automobiles.

A program has been in progress for the last two years to reorganize Bellevue Hospital's out-patient department and make it into a "model center" to be emulated by other city institutions is beginning to bear fruit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The Air Force has ordered at least eleven new models of jet fighters and bombers into production to replace present front line planes, a survey disclosed today.

Morton I. Moskowitz in his letter in your columns (Sept. 7) refers to "Russian generosity" in permitting President Roosevelt to sit in the center of the Big Three for their photograph during the Yalta conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Until the Messrs. Gallup, Roper, et al. move into Wisconsin and perform their statistical post-mortems on the "Stop McCarthy" movement which the voters of that state crushed to death last Tuesday, there will be a great deal of impassioned but fruitless argument over the how and the why of this extremely significant event.

An explanation by an expert of the qualities that make the super-liner United States the fastest in the world is expected by maritime experts when Matthew G. Forrest, principal naval architect of Gibbs Cox, Inc., speaks at a session of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers on Wednesday.
CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 13 -- The Geiger, last word in troop transports, was accepted by the Navy today from the Maritime Administration at the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

DAHLIAS come in so many different sizes, shapes and colors that an exhibition of this summer-flowering bulb alone offers plenty of diversity for the spectator. From mammoth twelve-inch blooms to the miniature pompons, the fifteen types of dahlias will be represented at the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street near Seventh Avenue, on Tuesday and Wednesday.

TO most gardeners the phrase "spring bulbs" conjures up pictures of a glamorous tulip bed, a clump of crocus, a sweep of daffodils. Yet the home owner who restricts fall bulb planting to these favorites will miss a lot.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 13 (UP) -- Even before Governor Stevenson's plane landed here, the Democratic nominee already had announced plans for a tour -- this time through the East -- to begin next Thursday in Connecticut and to include a major speech at Richmond, Va.

Started back in the era of Calvin Coolidge, the speed boat race meet on the Potomac at Washington which has always been known as the President's Cup Regatta will have top billing over the coming week-end and beyond doubt the largest number of contestants.

THE Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, in cooperation with the National Council of Churches of Christ, inaugurated last week its ambitious new television program -- a series of twenty-six films designed to convey Christian teaching within the framework of the life of the American family.
WHEN Joseph Rosenstock became the general director of the New York City Opera Company last spring, he showed his faith in Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" by making it the major effort of his first season.

SOMETIMES one comes across a book, in many respects dated, whose value nevertheless rises far above the occasions which produced it. Such is this volume of six major essays and twenty-two sermons by Rabbi Lefkowitz.

Brooklyn College is seeking one hundred citizens of the borough who are willing to sing the same tune. They are being sought for a community chorus that will be formed soon. The new group is open to men and women of the Brooklyn community regardless of previous training.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- A series of incidents in which Communist prisoners again defied Allied orders and in which some were killed by guards and others wounded has again brought to attention here the explosive subject of conditions inside the United Nations stockades in South Korea where more than 150,000 captives of the Korean war are interned.

IN television's never-ending search for ways to keep production costs to reasonable proportions, the C. B. S. scenic department claims to have made important advances. It is making a changeover from the traditional muslin on frames to masonite flats, thereby eliminating a number of problems that have plagued the set makers.
BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- The issue at stake is repeal of all legislation since 1947 that provides pensions for legislators, and revision of the travel and expense allowance schedules for them.

A footnote to Dan Jenkins' entertaining article, "Calling Names" (Aug. 31) may be in order. My pet peeve about the selection of names for telephone exchanges has always been the use of a state name whose customary abbreviation affects the dialing.

Even in September this year we're having heat waves. The temperature rose to 93 degrees at 4:50 P. M. yesterday and for most of the day was well above the record high for the date, 87.8 degrees, set in 1948. And today there will be no let-up, according to the forecast.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 13 (UP) -- "Loyal" Texas Democrats won a first-round victory today barring certification of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the nominee of the "Texas Democratic" party.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Twenty Roman amphorae, or earthen vases, dating from the first century before Christ, have been rcovered intact from the wreckage of Roman ships that sank off the island of Lavezzi, near Corsica's Cape of Bonifacio, officials have announced here.
ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP) -Business is booming in New York State and is pushing employment and production near to post-war high marks.

Under a new system of routing in effect on a progressive basis in the Bronx since last February, mail received for delivery at eleven post office stations after 8 P. M. now is sent to four terminal points for distribution in the early morning hours, an official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Republican Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who announced some time ago that he would campaign for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, indicated today he had had a change of heart and now planned to sit this one out.

HOUSTON, Sept. 13 -- The biggest issue in the Presidential campaign in Texas is the tidelands question -- that is, ownership of the offshore lands believed to be potentially rich in oil. The people of Texas feel strongly about state ownership of these lands because under the set-up in Texas the public school general fund gets the money from leases of the lands to oil companies.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 13 -- There was plenty of action during the $4,500 Oneida junior free for all pace that featured tonight's harness racing program before 24,301 persons at Roosevelt raceway. Three in the field of eight broke stride within the last two furlongs and Cleo A. Young's Ferman Hanover gained his second straight triumph in a sharp 2:03 4/5.

THE art season getting under way will, it is to be hoped, follow somewhat the pattern of the last few years during which a succession of group shows and retrospective exhibitions of work by important artists have combined to give us an ever-widening perspective over the modern movement.

SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican candidate for re-election, appealed tonight to voters under 35 years old -- "those who have never known a Republican Ad ministration" -- to vote for a "new government, new men, and a new party prepared to meet the challenges of this crucial period."

THIS slim, crimson volume which, at a safe distance and carried negligently under one arm, might very well be taken for, say, a copy of Laurence Hope's "India's Love Lyrics" or some similarly frail pastiche, is actually a book of fourteen muscular parodies on the work of eighteen authors; a number of whom work in teams, anyway, and therefore were pressed, like duck, into single chapters.

SINCE Henry Huggins made his appearance two years ago that small boy has charmed young and old alike with his deadly persistence, his spontaneity and his capacity for trouble. It is wonderful to have Henry back again, and of course Ribsy his dog -- both of them as natural as ever.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 13 -- An attitude of waiting and indecision that is like a great hush pervades the voters in two typical border states -- Kentucky and Tennessee -- whose ultimate decision may well be also the national decision as between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -Connecticut political observers are looking forward to one of the closest election races in this state's history, with the outcome considered a toss-up.

City Council President Rudolph Halley declared yesterday that scrimping on municipal hospital needs was "sheer stupidity" and asserted that the City Administration must be "blasted out of the lethargy" that permits the operation of inferior institutions.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday an agreement with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, independent, on a new contract that will provide wage increases of from 7 1/2 to 13 cents an hour.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Two hundred years ago today was Sept. 2, according to calendars throughout the realm of King George II, including the American colonies. But that night by an act of Parliament the next eleven days were dismissed from the calendar and next morning dawned Sept. 14.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- All the Japanese political parties have now virtually completed the registration of their candidates for the general election Oct. 1. The results indicate that only the conservative Liberal party, headed by Premier Shigeru Yoshida, of itself, can possibly achieve uncontested control of the Diet's (Parliament) lower house and that, short of a new Liberal victory, Japan would be governed by some form of coalition regime.
You did all right with your story about Mecca, Ind., until you got to the fantastic yarn about the name. At this point an old inhabitant, like myself, simply rolled on the floor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Selection of three advisers to travel with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower on all his train and plane trips during the Presidential campaign was announced today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- Business in this area as gauged by use of electric power is holding steady. Employment figures also bear this out. Demand for electric current by the largest producer is holding about 11 per cent above year ago. The steel rate is unchanged at 105 per cent, which equals the revised figure of the previous week.

WE have spoken of the necessity of a strong libretto for a composer of opera and of the dramatic composer's relation to the librettist, and the need of both parties to the creation of a music-drama to have a sense of theatre.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Atomic chemists searched for two stolen dimes today with the aid of a Geiger counter. The thief, however, returned the money while the scientific search was in progress.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The average new car buyer is just as likely to pay for his auto on installments as the used car buyer, it has just been revealed in a survey by the American Finance Conference.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- The Presidium of the Soviet Academy of Sciences has called to account Ivan M. Maisky, one-time Russian Ambassador to London and former Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, for his responsibility in connection with the publication of an unsatisfactory book concerning "bourgeois falsification of history."

MEXICO CITY -- Two recent developments in Mexican archaeology will be of interest to American visitors this fall. One involves new findings at a spot particularly accessible to Mexico City; the other is a discovery that adds an entirely new angle to study of the pyramids that figure so importantly in pre-Cortesian Mexican architecture.

WHEN "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" opens Wednesday night at the Rivoli, it will mark the eighth time that a movie derived from Ernest Hemingway comes before the public. This is a unique record for a modern writer who is as pure and lofty in his art as Hemingway.

ONE of the most delightful perennials I grow is the old-fashioned lily of the valley. It is also one of the least temperamental and one of the most lasting plants. While spring and fall are the accepted seasons for planting, it is possible to set out these roots or plants anytime the bed can be kept moist until established.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Led by four twelve-meters, plus a cruising yawl, the championship regatta on Long Island Sound today was held by the Frostbite Yacht Club.

EVE ARDEN, who once scorned any thought of having a television set in her Hollywood home, has become a video addict. The fact that she will be the star of a new television series, "Our Miss Brooks," which begins over the C. B. S. network on Friday, Oct. 3, at 9:30 P. M., may have influenced her decision to become a set owner.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Average and his family are slightly behind their 1951 position in terms of real income, merchants, particularly in the New York area, are confident that the weeks just ahead will add a tonic to the economic blood stream.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,372, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- Freddy Hutchinson, who took over as manager of the last-place Tigers in mid-season, will manage the American League club again next season, Walter O. Briggs Jr., president, said today.
The controversy over military aircraft production in the United States has been brought sharply into focus by recent statements of the Senate committee and the Air Force.

THE rural and suburban roads of New York State broke out last week, as any motorist could plainly see, in a rash of brightly colored school buses. Painted a designated shade of light chrome yellow and marked in black, the buses are a good example of what can be done for highway safety by conscientious application of color planning.

Back in the mid-Nineteen Twenties, when Chester Roth stepped out for himself as a hosiery mill agent, he could not have dreamed that one day he would be selling lingerie that retails for $150, in addition to heading the largest privately owned hosiery operation in the country.

EVER since some Cro-Magnon apalled his Neanderthal enemies by striking them down from afar with that dreadful new weapon, the bow, it has been one of man's dreams to produce an arm against which there is no defense and to which there is no reply.

JUST about the time everybody has made up his mind that the dance has settled down into a dependable routine season after season -- so many weeks of the New York City Ballet, so many weeks of the Ballet Theatre, and so many (or rather, so few) modern dance performances -- along comes something to upset the pattern.

SELDOM does the West, for all its tremendous anti-Stalinist literature, produce a book as sound as this. "Russia: Absent and Present" is a cultural history, and it therefore places its subject in the largest possible perspective, approaching it through an examination of the main traditions of Russian culture.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today that he believed the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, was being swayed to the left by some left-wing groups, but that he would vote for him.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 -- Only partial and fragmentary extracts of what has been said during the closed-door meetings of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association's conference, held here this week, have been publicized. The result has been, it is complained, that many opinions and points of view that would be of the greatest value for public discussion have been suppressed or misrepresented.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- To change or not to change was the big question in the minds of independent voters of this area as registration bureaus this week reported record enrollments for the November election.

TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 13 (UP) -- An official Democratic caucus of the Florida House of Representatives refused by an overwhelming voice vote here today to endorse the party's national ticket of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- Prince Wladyslaw Czartoryski, formerly of Poland but now a British subject, filed a petition in Federal District Court yesterday asking that the Boston Museum of Fine Arts be required to turn over to him two "priceless" objects of art, which, he said, were taken as loot from his castle in Guluchow by the Germans in 1939 or 1940.

A discovery making possible the building of a super-gigantic atomic machine that will fire atomic bullets with energies as high as one hundred billion electron volts, far beyond the limits of practical means available until now, has been made by a team of physicists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission at Upton, L. I.

CAIRO, Sept. 13 -- In economic circles here, the measures of social, economic and fiscal reform adopted or contemplated by the new regime in Egypt since the July 23 coup d'etat are generally conceded to leave untouched the country's fundamental problem: that of economic sclerosis and constant decline in the standard of living.

In his address earlier this month before the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped, President Truman hit the crux of the nation's rehabilitation problem when he said: "The trouble is that we are doing all kinds of fine work, but for far too few people."
DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- The Athletics pounded rookie Bud Black for five runs in the first inning today and clubbed Billy Hoeft and Dave Madison for six more in the eighth to defeat the Tigers, 11 -- 5.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- Personalities, rather than issues, dominate pre-election thinking among voters in the Central States at this stage of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The National Geographic Society announced today it would support a four-year expedition to explore the world's undersea regions -- the last stronghold of major geographical secrets.
With Messrs. Furcolo, Herter and Kennedy all occupied with other ambitions, contests have arisen for nomination to their seats in the Second, Tenth and Eleventh Congressional Districts.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Horses from Fairview Farm, belonging to Joe Del Guercio of Greenwich, Conn., took the jumper and working hunter championships today at the end of the three-day Piping Rock Horse Show.

VIENNA, Sept. 13 -- Their failure to capture the mind of youth seems to have become the chief worry of the regimes of the "peoples' democracies." It is not so immediate a problem as the collection of crops or the production of coal.

AT the annual conference of the National Council on Family Relations, which was held over Labor Day week-end at Rutgers University, representatives of a variety of professions met to discuss the special problems of family living in an era of "permanent emergency."

ATHENS, Sept. 13 -- Field Marshall Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Commander of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, arrived in Athens this afternoon for a three-day sojourn after which he will go to Ankara.

WITH over 25,000 acres of public parks in the five boroughs, and all the parkways to boot, the New York City Park Department is always short of trees and shrubs. Why couldn't they grow their own, wondered Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Chief Arboriculturist David Schweizer.

According to Edward Crankshaw's "The Question: 'Does Stalin Want War?'" (Aug. 31) we still live in dreadful fear of Moscow. Yet he quite convincingly shows, presumably to allay our fear, that Russia cannot afford a war, nor desires one.

PICKLING now while the harvest offers abundant supplies of fruits and vegetables insures appetizing and unusual relishes for winter meals. Because the fermented pickles, largely done with cucumbers, take know-how and a great deal of patience, most housewives will do well to concentrate on the easy unfermented type detailed here today.

IN a season made memorable, or at least, notorious for the palpable hits scored upon the feelings of umpires by baseball players, the temperance exhibited by Charles Francis Berry, a large, positive and talkative man of 49, who has been umpiring in the American League for exactly ten years, is chastening and very likely instructive.

A GENERATION has passed since the publication of James Joyce's "Ulysses." Perhaps no book has raised such a monument of commentary and exegesis in so short a time. And yet "Ulysses" is still a locked door.

AKRON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The San Francisco 49'ers handed the Cleveland Browns their second straight loss tonight, 35-31, in an aerial duel in a Rubber Bowl exhibition between National League teams. It was the first time in the pro football history the Browns had lost two in a row.

WHENEVER a stamp-collecting monarch is toppled from his throne philately immediately be-begins to wonder whether he took his collection with him into exile and what is to be the collection's fate if he left it behind.

Benjamin Fine's excellent appraisal, in your Sept. 7 issue, of the grim situation facing public education, reinforced the conviction of many citizens interested in their schools that we Americans are not facing our responsibilities to our youth realistically.

Activity increased in the wholesale market here last week as many buyers placed fall, winter and holiday orders, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Deliveries have slowed and stores have increased their orders in an effort to obtain more goods for early and immediate delivery. Suit orders increased, with requests for boxy styles. Fitted jacket-types in novelty worsteds, flannel and gabardine were wanted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The business outlook for Chicago is evenly divided between steady improvement for the balance of the year and little or no betterment. The view was indicated by the August report of members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., said today that General Electric Company had entered into a "collusive arrangement" with the rival left-wing electrical union, the United Electrical Workers.

Unofficial figures of the recount of the ballots cast at the primary election on Aug. 19 in the contest for the Democratic nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-first District showed that Julius A. Archibald defeated Senator Harold I. Panken, Tammany incumbent, by a majority of 207 votes.

CARTERET, N. J., Sept. 13 -- A chief test pilot brought his DC-3 plane to a safe landing in a swamp here today after one engine had fallen in flames from the craft and the other had gone dead. There were no injuries and the plane was relatively undamaged.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UP) -- A landlord's "strike," designed to take 50,000 apartments off the Chicago rental market, has been called by a Citizens Committee for Rent Decontrol.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Western Europe has 2,000,000 men under arms compared with 4,000,000 for the Soviet Union plus an unspecified number in the satellite armies, according to an esti mate made by the State Department today. These figures were contained in a booklet on the development and significance of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

" DULCIE," notes Miss Winsor, in one of the three alleged novelettes that make up the present book, "was wearing an evening gown which looked like a ballet dancer's costume, with many skirts drifted together in layers, misty tulle upon deep red.

AFTER pegging away at his autobiography for the last thirteen years, Sean O'Casey has pushed it along to the time of "Within the Gates," which was acted in New York in 1934. "Rose and Crown," he calls this, the fifth volume, published in London by Macmillan during the summer and scheduled to be published here by Macmillan next month.

THE late Eighteen Nineties and the early Nineteen Hundreds were a stodgy period, an age when everyone had so much taste and all of it bad, an era when people reposed smugly on the respectable bosom of security, a frail bosom, as it turned out, in spite of its seeming solidity; security was temporary, illusory, passing.

MONTAUK -- A trip on Montauk affords the vacationist an opportunity to visit many places at once. The rugged coast of Maine, the rolling moors of Scotland and seemingly endless acres of grazing land are all at the far tip of Long Island, less than four hours from New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The great Republican party breach is now closed at the top by the concordat of the Presidential nominee, General Eisenhower, and Senator Taft. But the great Democrat party breach remains open from top to bottom in the South.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) -- An oil company is risking more than a million dollars on a new wildcatting technique designed to tap vast petroleum pools under, the sea. Monterery Oil Company plans to drill from a man-made island in the ocean -- first of its type on the Pacific Coast.

ARTURO TOSCANINI'S recording of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, first recording of this work ever to be approved for release by the maestro, will be issued by R. C. A. Victor on Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Declarations by the State Department that it had no plans to require a racial tag for Jewish immigrants to this country appeared today not to satisfy one of the principal foes of the new law under which visas were being issued.

On Sept. 6 a great newspaper, El Tiempo of Bogota, was burned and gutted. No more flagrant violation against the freedom of the press has occurred since the confiscation of La Prensa in Buenos Aires by Peron.

The scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Deep Blue Sea," a play by Terrence Rattigan starring Margaret Sullivan, on the evening of Nov. 24 at the Morosco Theatre.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 14 -- The Schuman Plan Assembly action gives Europe the following four bodies, all aimed, more or less, at unification of the Continent.

Mayor Impellitteri, former Postmaster General James A. Farley and several church dignitaries are scheduled to be among those who will take part at 2 P. M. today at the Citizenship Day program under the sponsorship of the city on the Mall in Central Park.

Any big company which does not publish a magazine for its employes probably will do so soon, because the company magazine or "house organ" as it's commonly called is mushrooming into a thriving industry.

The advance sale of tickets indicates that the gate for the Jersey Joe Walcott-Rocky Marciano world heavyweight championship fight in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium Sept. 23 will reach the $500,000 mark.

One game that likely will have an important bearing on the Pacific Coast Conference championship and one that will be watched by televiewers from coast to coast will be played next week-end as college football sets out to prove that the game, not the talk about codes and controls, is the thing.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- Business so far this month, presents a normal seasonal appearance for the first time since before Korea. Retail sales are in their second month of increase, with average prices estimated 3 to 5 per cent above a year ago and unit volume in some lines above last year for the third consecutive month.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 13 -- Rhode Island Republicans will hold their own state primary on Monday, with all candidates unapposed except in the Second Congressional District. The Democrats will hold their primary Sept. 24, with a contest only for the nomination for Governor.

THIS is a book for lovers of dogs and horses -- for lovers of four-footed critters with spirit, courage and sticking power -- and for admirers of the two-legged sort who share the four-footed critters best qualities.

THE Alice M. Ditson Fund, established by a bequest from Mrs. Ditson to Columbia University, has since 1940 labored unremittingly on behalf of the American composer. It has spared neither effort nor expense to aid composers to secure a hearing for their work. Since 1944 the fund has sponsored an annual festival of contemporary music at Columbia.

INNSBRUCK, Austria -- These are the golden days for the rucksack tourist in the Austrian mountains. The bustling summer vacation traffic has ended, and the cows and goats coming down from Alpine pastures can cross the roads without dodging sight-seeing buses.

Republican members of the Legislature attempted to seize the initiative by circulating a petition to call the session, after Mr. Dever had refused a demand by Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican candidate for Governor, to issue a call.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 -- One of the most controversial questions to come before the current session of the triennial convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church is this: Can a non-Episcopal clergyman participate in the "laying on of hands" at an Episcopal ordination service? It has been docketed for floor debate on Monday.

The first physical step toward reconstruction of the Manhattan approach to the Queensboro Bridge is scheduled to be taken this fall with the demolition of four buildings in East Sixty-second Street at the Manhattan plaza, Acting Public Works Commissioner Albert H. Morgan announced yesterday.

TUCKED away in the platform adopted by the Democratic party in July was a modest little plank urging action to protect the harried majority of the United States Senate from domination by the minority. The proposition was not stated quite so baldly, of course, but that was the sense of the plea to "improve Congressional procedure so that majority rule prevails and decisions can be made after reasonable debate. * * *"

IN the event that Brooklyn staggers off with the National League pennant this year, Charlie (The-Dodgers-Won't-Blow-It-Again) Dressen, the distinguished author, should borrow a ritual from Bucky Harris. In the closing stages of the 1947 race Bucky would raise his glass in fervent toast "To Joe Page." Dressen can raise a cup at one of his literary teas and offer a toast "To Joe Black."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 13 (UP) -- New censorship regulations published today provided that all newspapers must submit to the Censorship Office for approval prior to publication all material dealing with a long list of subjects.

THE measure of a photographer lies in his ability to distinguish between reality and that which is meaningless and false. When this ability is brought into full play, with the photographer reacting honestly as a whole person to the truth before his camera, the results are called realistic pictures.
Some people learn from experience, others learn the "hard way" and some people never learn. Producers of boys' tailored clothing said last week that it looked as if they deal with the third group.
A British brewer is preparing a special Coronation beer to help celebrate the crowning of the new Queen. This beverage will be thrice as potent as ordinary beer.

With almost a half-million dollars in added money up for distribution, the fall season at Belmont Park will start tomorrow. For three weeks the Westchester Racing Association will conduct the turf sport, and most of the outstanding stables in the country will be represented in the competition.

A course in "Modern Celestial Navigation" will open on Wednesday the Hayden Planetarium's seventeenth annual series of popular courses in astronomy and navigation, Robert R. Coles, Planetarium chairman, announced yesterday. Seven courses of informal weekly lectures designed for the layman will be given by the Planetarium staff.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 -- A regional advisory subcommittee studying defense mobilization problems reported this week that the seasonal farm labor force in six Southern states must be stabilized if present agricultural employer needs in the area were not to become "more serious."

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Construction of the Thruway will relieve traffic congestion in most of the state's major population centers by diverting through traffic from business districts, an official of the State Thruway Authority predicted today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 13 -- The United States is ready to put $225,000,000 into Western European production of fighter aircraft, of which the Atlantic pact nations have said there is a critical shortage, if the European allies will match this with $180,000,000 worth of planes built at their own expense.

THE post-war record of the United States in the Far East has engendered more violent disagreement and bitter debate than any other phase of our national life in recent years. Yet the record itself is not well known or understood.

In Science appears a communication from Drs. Robert C. Mellors, George N. Papanicolaou and John F. Keane Jr., of the Sloan-Kettering Institute and the Pathology Laboratories, on the use of micro-spectroscopy in the study of cell specimens taken from the female sex organs and placed on slides.

WHEN the pioneer trader Jesse Chisholm passed through western Texas with a pack train in 1839 he ransomed Brit Mason, a captive white youth, from the Comanches. Though Brit was at first reluctant to leave his Indian master, Sun Eagle, he set out with the pack train for California.

IF YOU have wondered with some curiosity why nothing much has been said about new foreign-language pictures in this column for the past several months, the answer is fairly simple: nothing much has been shown to warrant a special contemplation on a peaceful Sabbath morn.

Italy has little coal and no oil -- a handicap in this industrial age. Yet the imports of coal fell from 12,000,000 tons last year to 6,000,000 this year, with an increase in industrial activity. The reason is that Italy has discovered a natural resource in volcanic energy.
THE Ballet Theatre will open a season of twenty-two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 25, with two new ballets and a revival added to the repertory.

Double stars get closer and closer together as they grow larger and larger, Dr. R. A. Lyttleton of St. John's College, Cambridge, England, stated to members of the International Astronomical Union in Rome last week. Stars are growing all the time because they pick up interstellar hydrogen as they move through space.

OF THE three women who dominated the hearts of men who at one time or another dominated portions of South America, Elisa Lynch was the most subtle, the most sophisticated and probably the most intelligent. She was most certainly the only Anglo-Saxon ever to take on the job of riding at the side of a latino liberator or dictator. (In South America it was sometimes a bit difficult to tell which was which.)

Western Europe last week pushed forward with the task of implementing the Schuman plan -- farthest advanced of its ventures toward unity. It also took an initial step toward the higher goal of a great political confederation on the Continent. But at the same time it was recognized that all such plans hinge largely on relations between France and West Germany, and in that area important problems remain to be solved.

WE were not born yesterday. Just as our hand and forebrain bear the signs of many thousands of years' purposeful development, so our adult mind is the product of thirty or forty centuries of thinking by our intellectual ancestors. If we were Chinese, those ancestors would be the men who wrote and compiled the Odes, the Histories, and the philosophical manuals; our greatest begetter would be Confucius.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called on the nation's engineers today to aid in the fight against crime, including possible sabotage not only by agents of potential enemies but by workers who just dislike their jobs.

Despite the overwhelming margin of Senator McCarthy's victory in last week's primary -- a victory in which many Democrats as well as Republicans seem clearly to have participated -- we find it difficult to believe that the voters of Wisconsin have chosen deliberately to put their stamp of approval on the type of reckless and irresponsible character-assassination that has come to be known as "McCarthyism."

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, warned tonight that "if this nation does not protect and control its water resources it will dry up and rot on the vine, as so many other rich civilizations, centuries before it, have done."

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 -- The Presidential campaign issue of most concern to the vast majority of political leaders and voters in this region is wrapped up in the same package that contained the Solid South split in 1948 -- the related questions of civil rights and states' rights.

A FORMER Air Force officer, the author will be remembered for his Congressional testimony of December, 1949, and the Washington furore it set off. His testimony alleged in substance that the late Harry L. Hopkins had sent atomic bomb materials via Lend-Lease to the Soviet Union in 1943-44. In this book he returns to the attack.

The American Press Institute at Columbia University announced yesterday its 1952-53 program of six seminars for newspaper men and women. The institute, a newspaper-supported project devoted to self-improvement of newspapers through an exchange of successful techniques, ideas and analysis of newspapers, is beginning its seventh year with a record of having served 757 newspaper men and women from forty-seven states and the District of Columbia.

DES MOINES, Sept. 13 -- Across the prairies and plains of the Midwestern farm country there is an intermingling of issues in the 1952 Presidential campaign, with some issues tied together strongly and others by rather tenuous threads.

LEON TROTSKY will hardly be remembered as the contemplative type, but while he was seeking asylum in Mexico after his break with Stalin he wrote, "Anyone desiring a quiet life has done badly to be born in the twentieth century."

BY now, Shepherd Mead, a vice president of that advertising agency which has already furnished us with a Senator and an Ambassador (Benton Bowles), must be regarded as the Tolstoy or, anyway, the Baudelaire of the special, complex world of industry, advertising and commerce.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Overgrown clumps of perennials should be dug up, divided and the sections replanted with adequate spacing. Work well-rotted manure or compost and some commercial fertilizer into the soil and water roots before soil is firmed around the transplants. Later, when the ground freezes, mulch new perennials for the first winter.

DR. RIGGS has offered a useful antidote for the type of wishful thinking that sees on Formosa a powerful, highly trained and well-equipped army of more than a half million ready to spring to the re-conquest of the Chinese mainland as soon as the United States gives the word.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower disclaimed yesterday any magic formula for insuring peace in the world but added that he was eager to work with right-minded people to help achieve that goal.

His general discussion in support of the modern type education we can applaud; but we who have taught the American progressive way have to protest most of his criticisms.

In the same airplane seats where Senators and tired business men doze through the air between here and Washington, eighty-one honor students from the Butler, N. J., high school tightened their safety belts yesterday and took off from La Guardia Airport for an aerial look at their home territory.

UP to now, no novelist has been able to skewer much more than a flickering shadow of the advertising business. We have had little pastiches of admen caught in a dreary pattern of dry Gibsons, quick seductions and eccentric clients.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 13 -- Reconstruction of an eighteenth century storehouse operated by John Holt, a merchant who became a New York publisher in pre-Revolutionary days, will be completed late next summer for use as a private residence.

BRITAIN'S debt to the United States, such as it is, has been further reduced by an English alchemist, Rowland Emett, who, working with spider webs and crochet needles, has fashioned a book of pure gold.

I KNEW Salvador de Madariaga well in the early Nineteen Thirties, when he had closed his diplomatic career and for a brief time was Minister of Education, and for some years the spokesman of Spain in the League of Nations. He had written some brilliant books that were no more sparkling than his conversation.

A momentous event took place in Western Europe last week. Meeting in Luxembourg, the foreign ministers of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg voted unanimously to begin the work of drafting a treaty for establishinig a European federal political community.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 13 -- Capt. Daniel J. Miller, 28, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Miller, of Stony Point, L. I., N. Y., who, as a helicopter pilot in Korea, made three dangerous missions in a single day to rescue six wounded United States infantrymen, received today the Cheney award, in ceremonies at Williams Air Force base near here.

FIELD sports today have lost much of the color they possessed in the less hurried past, when hunting and fishing were formal as well as formalized activities, for the modern angler and hunter pursues these sports at a pace that conforms to the tempo of his normal life, with the result that much of the ancient flavor is lost.

Many young matrons, including Mrs. John R. Fell and Mrs. Samuel R. Milbank, are aiding in the plans for the card party, fashion show and tea in behalf of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases to be held on the afternoon of Sept. 30 in the Crystal Room of the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills is honorary chairman of the benefit committee and honorary president of the Women's Auxiliary Board of the beneficiary.
IT wasn't astonishing that Raymond Fosdick was approaching his 70th birthday. That is to say, he didn't look 40 or 50; but he looked remarkably fit and alert, say a warm, dignified and enviable 60.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -The Federal Office of Education granted 857 permits for school building projects last month. Commissioner Earl J. McGrath announced today.

THE fringed gentian is one of our best loved wild flowers. Although the foliage and stiff stalks can hardly be described as peautiful, this lack of grace is readily overlooked at this time of year when the exquisite blossoms open wide on every sunny day.

UNLIKE a good many of the fantasies which come to us from England, there is nothing leisurely about "The Magic Currant Bun." The author, John Symonds, is a Londoner, but the setting of his story is Paris and his tale is filled with the electrical excitement of that city where anything might happen.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 13 -- Tulyar, the Aga Khan's compact brown 3-year-old colt, made it a clean sweep of Great Britain's flat racing classics today by speeding to victory in the 176th running of the St. Leger.

Last week, Dr. M. E. Coates rose before the British Association for the Advancement of Science at Belfast, Ireland, to report that Britain's National Institute of Dairying, with which she is connected, had discovered that cattle, swine and poultry grew with far more than normal rapidity when given such antibiotics as penicillin and aureomycin.

Although business sentiment improved following the Labor Day holiday, stock prices slumped last week to the lowest levels since June in more active trading. There was no explanation for the decline, but a less hopeful outlook in wage negotiations of the coal industry undoubtedly contributed to the more pessimistic tone of the market.

The pledge of the West German Republic to pay $822,000,000 to Israel in restitution for the persecution and massacre, of Jews under Hitler was regarded by three of the rabbis who preached here yesterday morning as a significant event in history.

New ideas in manufacturing and new machinery are to go on display this week at Hanover, Germany, and American industrialists, business men and importers of machinery will be on hand to see what is new.
WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn. -- A sparkling new terminal building at Bradley Field here will be officially dedicated tomorrow after six years of planning and construction and an expenditure of $1,800,000.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- When the British Parliament resumes its sessions this fall, battle will be joined between the two major political parties on the issue which above all others most clearly divides them -- the public ownership of essential industries.
Tropical Park at Coral Gables, Fla., yesterday announced a program of thirteen stakes ranging in value from $7,500 to $50,000.

MANY home owners have wondered what they could do to pick up their garden in the fall. Some begin to solve the problem by placing emphasis on 'mums, late-flowering annuals and even berry-bearing plants.

With power shortages in the Pacific Northwest cutting domestic production of aluminum considerably and Canada decreasing substantially exports of her metal to the United States this year, industry and Government officials have become greatly concerned over aluminum supplies for the fourth quarter.

A new combination program in public administration for graduate students will be offered at the State University of Iowa this fall. The plan will bring together a study program in public administration and political science directed by the staff of the Department of Political Science, and an in-service training program in public administration under the supervision of the Institute of Public Affairs.

MOST Americans who know Buenos Aires are likely to think of Bartolome Mitre as the name of the street on which the National City Bank and the American Club are located. Few realize that it was the name of united Argentina's first constitutional President, later the first editor of La Nacion which, since the death of La Prensa in 1951, has been the only independent newspaper in the country.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 13 -- The former Yankee baseball club owner, Larry S. MacPhail, proved he could turn out a champion in the business of horse racing today when his 4-year-old bay colt, General Staff, showed his heels to the field by galloping home first in the eighteenth running of the $25,000-added Narragansett Special.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 -- After having deliberated for six hours in a secret session late last night, the Radical party's national committee announced its decision not to withdraw from elective offices.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 13 (UP) -- The full resources of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were thrown into a four - state search today for three desperate Federal prison fugitives making a do-or-die bid for freedom.

Lights burned dimly in the lower Manhattan loft where Walter H. Simson began his lamp business in the dark days of 1929 -- but they didn't go out. Today, a leading producer of incandescent electric right bulbs and fluorescent tubes, the Duro-Test Corporation, over which he presides, flourishes, with an annual business exceeding $8,000,000.

MISS HOWARD is one writer who accepts the fact that life's big interest for most teenage girls is Romance with a capital R. Her spirited, idealistic love stories meet a need not quite filled by tales of careers and of family life.

IT is too early to say exactly which way the wind will blow this season but the weather signals so far, in the form of a few exhibitions, indicate no startling changes. Abstract and half-abstract, the advance guard will doubtless continue to occupy the front line.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Sept. 13 -- One hundred and sixty-five teen-aged girls on a cheering squad who became hysterical and fainted at a high school football game were reported "all right" today.

IT LOOKS now as if opera will have its best showing on television during the 1952-53 season. If one did not realize how complex are the problems of producing opera for television and how high the costs, one would be tempted to say, "About time."

THE chances are that the most powerful morale booster the Navy has to offer west of the International Date Line these days -- short of a Stateside leave -- is a noisy, heterogeneous and singularly well-equipped three-story building in this naval base, known officially as the Yokosuka Enlisted Men's Club and more familiarly as The Madhouse.

At the request of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of Aging, Dr. V. Korenchevsky, head of the Nuffield Gerontological Research Unit of Oxford University, England, has prepared a report which Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the committee, accepts as a succinct statement on warding off the diseases that come with advancing years.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 13 -- Gifts and bequests to Smith College in the fiscal year that ended last June 30 totaled $667,480.45, William A. Bodden, college treasurer, reported today. Of this amount, $417,597.87 was given for budget purposes and the remainder as gifts to endowment.

SINCE for a child, being different from others is one of the hardest thing to endure, Suzanne Le Duc found it hard being a French Canadian in a New England public school. Back in Fall River, at the convent, all her classmates had understood French.

PUBLISHERS, booksellers and authors who have been holding their breath awaiting developments at Ballantine Books will have some of their curiosity appeased with the announcement this week of the firm's initial list of books.
Part of Rogers Hornsby's strategy at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a gesture of contempt for Bob Elliott as a hitter, and it misfired to keep the Giants' pennant hopes alive.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The movement for some form and degree of Western European political unity, toward which the Schuman Plan is so far the most notable step, gained headway this week at a series of meetings at Luxembourg and Strasbourg.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -The Republican National Committee tonight criticized officers of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for putting Senator Richard M. Nixon of California in the same class with Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama on the issue of civil rights.

The nation's expanding network of toll express highways is now heading south, indicating a big reshuffling of passenger and truck movement in the industrial vitals of the nation, particularly in existing traffic patterns affecting the Ohio-Illinois area in the north and the Piedmont and other areas below the Mason-Dixon line.

ADONAI ECHAD: The Sabbath Service in Hebrew; Chorus of the Israeli Temple of Milan, Vasco Campagnano, tenor; J. Jacchia, soprano; Vittore Veneziani, conductor (Colosseum). Finely controlled singing that is recorded with a fidelity that catches the human quality of choral voices better than most. An organ is used in the accompaniment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -The investigation of the Justice Department will go forward next week at public hearings of a House Judiciary subcommittee.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft came home smiling today from his conference with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower but declined to pose wearing a king-sized "I Like Ike" button.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The remarkable productive capacity of this country, paired with the consumer moderation we have been witnessing, raises the question whether there will be any real need for economic controls beyond their scheduled expiration date early next year.

OVER at the Plymouth Theatre these steamy September days a large group of British actors -- and a scattering of Americans with rapidly flourishing sideburns and Cockney accents -- are working hard to recreate under the sharp directorial eye of John Burrell the exuberant cartoon-world of "The Pickwick Papers."

" The credit department is on your side." This is the theme motivating the activities of the credit planning committee of the New York Credit and Financial Management Association, which is publishing this week a booklet of model credit department letters designed to increase sales.

PERHAPS it is only in child hood that books have any influence on our lives. In later life we admire, we are entertained, we may modify some views we already hold, but we are more likely to find in books merely a confirmation of what is in our minds already: as in a love affair it is our own features that we see reflected flatteringly back.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Big Adrian Burk outmaneuvered the Los Angeles Rams and their vaunted passing duo, Bob Waterfield and Norman Van Brocklin, to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 35-14 victory today in an exhibition-game between the National Football League clubs.

" I CAN wear a hat or take it off," the redoubtable Hedda Hopper avers, "but either way it's a conversation piece." Say this for the author, who reportedly entrances more than 20,000,000 persons with each of her syndicated "Hollywood" columns, "From Under My Hat" is a conversation piece pure and simple.

Beginning tomorrow morning the provincial government on Formosa will make a detailed and comprehensive survey of all land holding on the island.
