IN South Africa in the early Thirties the name of Roy Campbell was a banner we waved in the teeth of the infidels. A whole generation of students in the South African universities grew up with his name on their lips.

AN improved model Canon IV. 35mm miniature Japanese-made camera was introduced here recently in the rapidly growing 35mm market. Equipped with the 50mm f/l.8 Serenar lens, the camera costs $295. Other Serenar lenses interchangeable on the camera are three wide-angle lenses, 28mm f/3.5, 35mm f/3.2 and f/2.8; the 35mm f/2.8; the 85mm f/2, 100mm f/4 and 135mm f/4.

In 1792 Congress passed a law providing that the states could vote for President any time within the thirty-four days preceding the first Wednesday in December of election year. The result was considerable variation in election days -- and the first states to vote had a good deal of psychological influence on the outcome of the election.

While top fiscal managers of the Western nations sought answers to complex international trade problems at the monetary conferences in Mexico City, foreign traders in this country were facing what appeared to be the start of a marked falling off in export-import volume during the balance of the year.

WHEN D. H. Lawrence first heard American Indians singing, something in his soul broke down. In one of his most wonderful essays, "Indians and an Englishman," he describes that "pungent awakening to the lost past, old darkness, new terror, new root grief, old root richness."

Textile concerns in Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee and Florida were authorized to start building projects or expansions in the first six months of this year representing a capital investment of $395,000,000, according to a survey by the Textile Information Service.

Trade observers noted that although business was better during the cooler weather in the early part of the week, the later setback put the aggregate weekly sales volume about 11 per cent below that of the corresponding 1951 week. This will be seasonally low, it was said, but merchants were confident that plus signs would appear before the weekly volume totals by the end of the month.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 -- The American Chemical Society estimated here today that close to 8,000 chemists and chemical engineers would attend technical and scientific sessions of the 122d national meeting of the society, which will open Monday morning.

Despite the expected short cotton crop this year production is expected to be sufficient to meet domestic consumption and exports. The Department of Agriculture's forecast last week placing the yield at 13,889,000 bales of 500 pounds each should meet requirements, unless there should be a greater demand abroad for the American staple than now is indicated.

WE who live in the heart of great cities or on the peaceful meadows of farms, often forget in the routine of our terrestrial existence that only a short distance from our Manhattan, Philadelphia or Boston lie miles upon miles of restless water, leagues of turbulent waves and great coursing deep-sea currents.

MORE than fifty years ago Dr. Francis Marion Pottenger, who is 82 years old, became the first tuberculosis specialist on our West Coast. His life-span covers the dramatic era in the history of tuberculosis, from the discovery of the bacillus by Robert Koch in 1882 -- the author was then 13 -- to the discovery of Rimifon and Nydracid seventy years later.

TEHERAN, Sept. 13 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh met today with the National Security Council and Army Chief of Staff as reports were received of a threatened tribal uprising in Kurdistan, of the great Kashghai tribe in the south taking to arms against the belligerent Serkhi tribe, and of a battle between two smaller tribes south of Shiraz.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The Hasty House Farm's Inseparable set a new track record for a mile over the turf in winning the $17,000 Chicago Handicap at Hawthorne today.

The first important post-McGuire Act break in the solid ranks of "fair trade" supporters occurred last week. A spokesman for 36,000 retail druggists throughout the country called on manufacturers, who fix retail prices of leading drug products, to increase retail margins and permit stores to make a reasonable operating profit.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 14 -- Warplanes from Korean bases and the decks of Navy carriers struck yesterday from coast to coast across the Korean peninsula, following up a night attack by United States Superforts on the Supung (Suiho) hydroelectric plant on the Yalu River.

BETTY E. BOX and Ralph Thomas, the British producer-director team responsible for last year's cracker-jack thriller. "The Clouded Yellow," obviously have no intention of resting on past laurels. The talented pair paused last week during the final lap of their first American visit, which, naturally, had included an inspection of West Coast studios, to relay some intelligence on their latest venture, "The Venetian Bird," and a forthcoming Canadian project.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 13 -- In a crucial test today the delegates of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg to the European Coal and Steel Community Assembly, approved by a vote of 51 to 4, with 4 abstentions, a proposal to accept the task offered them by the Schuman Plan Council of Ministers to draft measures for the political federation of Western Europe.

In a recent article George Y. Wells wrote that there are only three Meccas in the world, one in Arabia, one in Indiana and one in California. He did not need to travel across Ohio to reach Mecca, for we also have a town by that name, at the intersection of State Routes 46 and 88 in the northeastern section of Ohio on Mosquito Creek Reservoir.

ONCE again the fashion designers have come up with an exciting new conception for Fall. Their designs create a taller, slimmer look by emphasizing the dramatic sweep of the very high waist and the curved hip. Never before has a woman's figure meant so much to the clothes she wears.

LONDON. THE strongest mood in the British Labor party is one of loyalty. All the party's elder statesmen and a large number of its rank and file remember the disaster of 1931 when, under stress of economic crisis, the Labor movement split, its leaders forming a National Government with the Conservatives, the mass of the party going like sheep without a shepherd into the wilderness and remaining there for a decade.

Jacob (Jack) Wissenfeld, the "brains" of the million dollar burglary gang apprehended through the combined efforts of New York, Westchester and Nassau County authorities, has pointed out more than twenty homes in White Plains and Scarsdale that he "fingered."
THE fancier plays of bridge are a lot of fun to execute, and, in addition, a knowledge of them is of practical value to a bridge player. Sometimes such plays will work when nothing else will.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Pressure apparently being a factor that Casey Stengel and his Yankees seem always prepared to turn to good account, it perhaps was inevitable that when finally something cracked in the tense American League pennant race it wasn't the Bombers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -The Atomic Energy Commission moved further today toward its goal of making it possible for private industry to produce atomic power and fuel profitably. It has accepted a proposal by two more companies to conduct for twelve months a survey of "the feasibility of design, construction, and operation by private industry of power-producing reactors."

With more persons than ever before covered by larger Social Security and private retirement benefits, pensions will have a greater influence in stemming future economic deflationary periods, experienced observers believe.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 13 -One of the two Milwaukee men who was sentenced to prison for his part in the $1,000,000 burglary of a Reno, Nev., home may receive Wisconsin workmen's compensation payments all the time he is in the Nevada penitentiary.

IT appears almost certain now that 1952 will be the best year in the history of commercial aviation in this country. At the present time the total number of passengers carried, the number of revenue miles flown and the ton miles of freight are ahead of last year's figures for both domestic and international lines.

Stu Miller, the remarkable young right-hander of the Cardinals, whose baffling assortment of slow but sharply breaking pitches is strongly reminiscent of Eddie Lopat at his best, stopped the Dodgers, 5 -- 2, with a masterful four-hitter yesterday.

Five hundred delegates from colleges and universities throughout the world will gather in Quebec from Sept. 19 to 23 to honor Laval University, the oldest French university on this continent, which this year is celebrating the centennial of its royal charter. In honor of the Laval centennial, more than seventy national and international learned societies are holding their annual meetings in Quebec this year.

THE familiar travel book tells of places, peoples, customs, manners. This one strikes a special note; it is a guide for green-fingered folk. The purpose is to lure gardeners to the lush islands of the Greater and Lesser Antilles -- the West Indies. It does not ignore the fact that gardeners like to sample native food (especially exotic fruits), or that they are easy marks for souvenir venders.

THE biographers of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois have had a much harder time than those of his political opponent. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower. The latter had Eisenhower's own book, "Crusade in Europe," as background.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13 -- Five regimes of Chinese Government were lived under by Father Robert E. Wood, 80-year-old Episcopal missionary who spent fifty- three years in service in China. Ordered out by the fifth regime, the Communists, Father Wood returned to the United States last summer and has spent nearly a year as chaplain of St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital here.

Debutantes to be presented to society at the Deutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, their mothers and members of the committees will meet at tea tomorrow in the Palm Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. One hundred debutantes will be introduced at the Seventeenth Annual Cotillion on Dec. 22 in the hotel.

RICHMOND, Sept. 13 -- In this stronghold of conservative Southern Democrats, the civil rights issue remains a paramount concern of most voters. They also are concerned with the candidates' views on tidelands, Federal aid to education, public housing, public power and general farm policy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The third concert of the Yaddo Music Festival this afternoon featured a new work, Robert Palmer's Quintet for Wind Instruments. In addition, the concert offered Irving Fine's Partita for Woodwind Quintet (1948), Nicolai Lopatnikoff's Violin Sonata No. 2 (1948) and a group of songs by Richard Donovan, Arthur Shepherd, Theodore Chanler and Elliott Carter.

AFTER a dullish winter season, Israel is enjoying a rich musical summer. An international meeting of singers, a group of local festivals, and the visits of outstanding musical personalities have made this an interesting season.
The reports of the recent meetings of the American Psychological Association in Washington were most gratifying, especially in relation to the positive action on racial discrimination.
The Spence - Chapin Adoption Service will be the beneficary of two theatrical perfomances selected by their theatre benefit committee, of which Mrs. Robert W. Dowling is chairman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- The paramount issue of the Presidential campaign in the Central States is economic. While communism at home and abroad is a popular topic of conversation, the questions of mounting taxes, cost of government and the financial burden of aid to allies hold first rank in the considerations of business men, farmers, laborers and investor.

Russia's traditional "Time of Troubles" followed closely upon the death of Ivan the Terrible, most autocratic of the Autocrats of All Russia before Joseph Stalin. The "troubles" were of many kinds -- dynastic, political, social and foreign. Under the impact of these various "troubles" the old Russian system broke down, and after twenty-nine years (1584 to 1613) of terrible disorders the new regime of the Romanovs was established.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 13 -- The spread of a strike in the aircraft industry to involve about 25,000 production workers in two plants of the Douglas Aircraft Company in California appeared imminent today as the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., accused the Aircraft Industry Association of anti-union activities.

NOT since this port was used by the Spanish conquistatadores to embark on their invasion of the Philippine Islands in the 16th Century has Manzanillo seen so much activity. For the past three weeks, a motion picture crew has been on location here in the State of Colima recreating the saga of Daniel Defoe's immortal hero, Robinson Crusoe.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- South Korean troops seared Chinese Communist soldiers out of their bunkers and tunnels with flamethrowers this morning, but failed in their attempts to recapture Finger Ridge on Korea's central front.

UDINE, Italy, Sept. 13 -- Italy is certain that she can fulfill the goals set in April by the Lisbon conference for the North Atlantic Treaty nations provided United States materiel continues to arrive at the present rate during the rest of this year.

In the past three months Maine potatoes, traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, have been the most sensational performers on the commodity futures markets. Turnover figures have smashed old records three or four times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A shuffle in the executive committee of the Republican National Committee through which only five members of the fifteen-member group remained, was announced officially today by Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman.
They ran the Beldame Handicap in two divisions at Aqueduct yesterday, and each section provided an unexpected thrill despite the fact that the victories went to the highly regarded favorites.
BOSTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Warren Spahn nearly tied a National League strikeout record today as he breezed to his fourth consecutive shutout, 8 to 0, over the Pittsburgh Pirates before 1,957 fans.

Savings and loan associations have now "come of age" at twenty-one billion dollars of assets. Impressed with their own growth, they will insist on full recognition of their new status by the older members of the banking "family," commercial and mutual savings institutions.

ABOARD U.S.S. WISCONSIN, at Sea, Sept. 13 -- Exercise Mainbrace, the largest North Atlantic Treaty Organization naval maneuver, yet held, opened today as an Orange enemy submarine attacked the carriers of the Blue striking feet off Arran Island in the Firth of Clyde.

ROME, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A determined handful of American-led Church of Christ worshipers announced tonight that they would hold regular services here tomorrow in open defiance of an Italian police ban.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- L. S. Buckmaster president of the United Rubber Works, C. I. O., attacked the "ostrich-minded" Eighty-second Congress in a statement today as union delegates prepared for the opening of the union's seventeenth annual convention here on Monday.

CAIRO, Sept. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier and Commander in Chief of the Egyptian armed forces, has asked the Royal Egyptian Medical Association to advance proposals for a national health plan in Egypt. The request was put before the association's General Assembly yesterday by Maj. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Khalek Agrama, commandant of the Egyptian Army Medical Corps.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 13 -- Officials of the Port of Houston expressed a fear this week that increased competition from other ports on the Texas Gulf Coast, and reduced foreign aid would cut the volume of grain moving through this shipping center.

WASHINGTON -- The capital, which annually receives millions of visitors for its cherry blossoms, Presidential inaugurals and wax figures of First Ladies in the Smithsonian, will this week show what it can do in a field of entertainment for which it is less famed -- sports.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Sheffield Wednesday, promoted to the first division in English soccer, scored its first victory today, blanking Tottenham Hotspur at home, 2 -- 0.

Bertrand Russell's "As School Opens -- The Educators Examined" (Sept. 7) seemed to me a succinct summary of the spirited discussions that took place this summer in our Philosophy of Education course at Hunter College.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 -- Sam Snead turned on the steam today to leave the field in the dust at the three-quarter mark of the Eastern open golf tournament. The golf craftsman from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., birdied his way to a four-under-par 68 and a 54-hole total of 206, ten strokes better than par for that distance and three strokes in front.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 13 -- The Presidential campaign in this area has not yet brought out any one issue greatly overshadowing others. Which one is paramount appears to be a matter of individual viewpoint.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -- The southern stretch of the Pacific Coast area, with all manner of men from polished bankers to gaunt farmers and from movie actors to Indians, is too diverse to produce any consensus on what primarily is at stake in the coming election.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 13 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois returned to his home capital in Springfield today satisfied with the results of his first major political trip into the West.

The Citizens Traffic Safety Board's twenty-four point program designed to modernize the pattern of traffic control in this city was outlined yesterday by Percy C. Magnus, president of the organization. Priorities for action will be established because a program of such scope cannot be encompassed at one time, he said.

ELIZABETH, N. J. Sept. 13 -- A general-alarm fire wiped out the sprawling Heidritter Company lumberyard here tonight, causing an estimated loss of $1,000,000, and spread to seven dwellings, damaging four of them badly.

EVERYONE who read that excellent story of a California coyote, "Mojave Joe," will welcome this equally good sequel. Joe is now a father and the account of how he provides for his family is an interesting and informative chronicle of wild life.

BEVERLY HILLS. I HEARD the news of Gertrude Lawrence's death on the radio in my car, driving down to my home in California. It was a bright, hot morning. I heard the announcer say that a great stage star had died. I braced myself for the news.

AS happy as its title, "Saturday Night Is My Delight" tells of the McCaffery family, who lived in Meriden, Conn., before the turn of the century. It is particularly the story of Katy McCaffery, as warm and charming and light-hearted a girl as ever had the whole crowd over every Saturday evening.
IT seems to me that your critic is right in his estimate of the probable reception of "Porgy and Bess" in Europe.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 -- The West German Government is slowly gathering courage to explain to the Germans, the most heavily bombed people in World War II, what they will have to do to protect themselves if war and bombers come again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A prediction that the influence of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, will decline in the Eighty-third Congress, which will meet next Jan. 3, was made here today by the National Committee for an Effective Congress, of which Robert E. Sherwood is chairman.

The Impellitteri administration has once more expressed its determination to make a basic attack on the automobile parking problem by having introduced in the City Council a local law to "provide for the establishment, maintenance and operating of parking spaces." This Merli bill is written in broad terms.
HECHINGEN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- The bones of Prussia's warrior King, Frederick the Great, and of his father, Frederick William I, were reburied today in the ancient castle of the Hohenzollern family.
ALBANY, Sept 14 -- Deaths from tuberculosis in upstate New York during the current year are expected to drop below 1,000 for the first time, the State Health Department said today.

Walter P. Marshall, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, has accepted the chairmanship of the $2,500,000 development fund drive, 1952-53, of the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind. The announcement was made yesterday by Percival S. Howe Jr., president of the association, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

About a year ago the Brookings Institution brought forth a survey that indicated that 93 per cent of the American people are unbesmirched by schoolroom instruction in economics. It traced, with a somewhat wry face, the efforts that are being made by corporations -- and the small companies that prepare the material for them -- to remedy this educational lack.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Sept. 14 -- The principal stage of the first full-scale maneuvers held by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in southern Europe shifted today to the Dolomites, among whose towering mountains only a few miles from the Austrian frontier the Tridentina Alpine Brigade will conclude tomorrow a week's exercises with an attack on strongly held "enemy" positions.
Your editorial of Sept. 9 on the Wisconsin primary and Senator McCarthy interested me very much.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- One might think that the Yankees, fresh from their most important victory of the campaign, would have been whooping it up in their dressing room at Municipal Stadium today. They had every reason to celebrate the 7-1 rout of the Indians, who fell two and a half lengths behind the New Yorkers, but it was a comparatively silent band that filed into the room.
It was part of the privilege into which I was born that my home was a religious home. My father and mother believed that "the fear of God is the beginning of wisdom."

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- A substantial downturn in soybean futures prices unsettled the grain list last week, but in spite of liquidation by longs and favorable weather for maturing both beans and corn, grains generally showed unexpected resistance to selling pressure.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Representatives of ten Northeast states, including four Governors and two Lieutenant Governors, reached the grounds of the Eastern States Exposition at 8 o'clock tonight in old automobiles to participate in the colorful Governors' Day festivities at the opening of the thirty-first annual event.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz and Alex Kellner hurled the Athletics to a pair of victories over the Browns today, 10 -- 5 and 2 -- 1. The second game was called because of darkness at the end of six innings.

TOKYO, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters opened an eleven-game tour of Japan tonight with a 41-16 victory over the New York Celtics before a crowd of 25,000 which responded to the Negro basketball stars' expert ball handling with thunderous applause.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- The All-India Congress Committee, highest policy-making body of the governing party of India, appealed to the great powers today to meet in a spirit of friendliness and mutual trust to discuss questions threatening world peace.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- To Saratogians, the huge sprawling Grand Union Hotel, which finally closed its doors to the guest and wayfarer at the end of August, is a monument to a colorful past. It still is physical evidence of a gaudy, incomparable epoch, even though the structure is down-at-the-heels.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- The Chicago Yacht Club's team of four defeated the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, 20 1/4 to 15, in the final race of their series in Luders-16 sloops at Indian Harbor today to regain the Ocean-Great Lakes Challenge Trophy, three races to two.

Hermie Wehmeier pitched a six-hit shut-out against the Dodgers yesterday and the Cincinnati Reds beat the league leaders, 4 -- 0, but a man outside Ebbets Field without a radio never would have suspected such a result.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- The United Automobile Workers, largest union in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has contracted for two half-hour television periods to present its views on Presidential campaign issues to a national audience.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- It is an old story, and the script never seems to change. When the chips are down the Yankees know how to rake them in.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers turned three enemy mistakes into a pair of field goals and one touchdown to trim the Washington Redskins, 13 -- 7, in a National Football League exhibition before 6,500 fans today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Pravda published today another two-page supplement discussing the forthcoming nineteenth party congress in which some party members proposed stricter rules to strengthen internal party election rights and urged the retention of the old and deeply patriotic world" Bolshevik in the party's official title.
Mementoes of past Christmases will go on view tomorrow in conjunction with the annual opening of the Christmas card shop at Georg Jensen.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Heavy polio outbreaks existed in scattered sections of the nation today and some areas reported acute shortages of nurses.

NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Construction equipment is being assembled here for the first operation in building the three-and-one- half-mile Hudson River crossing of the New York State Thruway between South Nyack and Tarrytown, which is to start within a few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The American Junior Red Cross will mark its thirty-fifth anniversary tomorrow with 19,000,000 school-age members continuing the organization's program of relief for children in foreign countries and pushing its home activities.

VIENNA, Sept. 14 -- One hundred and fifty thousand Roman Catholics from every part of Austria crowded the Heldenplatz here today for the concluding celebration of a four-day Catholic conference to proclaim the "freedom and dignity of mankind."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- American soldiers in Korea are anxious to have more big-name movie actresses visit them and want to see newsreels of events taking place here at home, says William Holden, actor, who has returned from a three-week fact-finding mission to Japan and Korea for the Hollywood Coordinating Committee, which arranges overseas entertainment tours.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Union workers at two Douglas Aircraft Company plants reached a split decision today in separate votes on whether to go on strike tomorrow.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary Yaddo Music Festival came to an end today with concerts at 10 o'clock in the morning and 1 in the afternoon, the odd starting times being dictated by the timetable of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, left Pennsylvania Station by special train late yesterday afternoon on his first whistle-stop campaign trip, during which he will travel about 4,000 miles in two weeks and visit twelve states, all but three of which were carried by President Truman in 1948.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- One of the nation's top physicists said tonight atomic plants with "fantastic amounts of power" will be freed to drive American factories as soon as a "genuine peace" is reached.

" The Jeffersonian Heritage," which had its premier at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon over the city's station, WNYC, is an event to gladden the hearts of all those who believe the microphone and camera have a broader destiny than surveying vaudeville and commercial announcements.

Registration for all fall term classes of the Institute of Adult Studies will be held today through Thursday, Sept. 25, Mondays through Fridays from 6 P. M. to 8:30 P. M., and next Saturday from 10 A. M. to 12 noon, at the office of the institute, Language Hall, New York University, University Avenue and 181st Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A "Promotion of Women" program as part of the Americanism campaign of the General Federation of Women's Clubs was announced from national headquarters here today by Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, the organization's chairman.

CAIRO, Sept. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier and Commander in Chief of the armed forces, continuing his visit in Alexandria, Egypt's second capital, attended a race meeting at Smouha City today.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Dies made of plastic material rather than high alloy steel are being used experimentally by Chrysler Corporation in the production of major steel panels for Dodge trucks. In disclosing this today, Chrysler said it was the first time such dies have been used in the auto industry.

The state board of directors of the Americans for Democratic Ac- tion, a liberal nonpartisan organization, endorsed yesterday Dr. George S. Counts, the Liberal party candidate for the United States Senate.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- One of India's oldest land tenancy systems, under which millions of peasants lived in subjection to petty chieftains who often had the power of life and death over dwellers on private estates, will end officially tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Whizzer White paced the Chicago Bears to a 17-to-7 victory over the New York Giants in a National Football League exhibition game today before 28,158 in Wrigley Field. The game was a benefit contest for the Armed Forces.
Canon Thomas A. Sparks, pastor of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, attended his last services as minister yesterday. He will retire today.
GENEVA, Sept. 14 -- The United Nations' Economic Commission for Europe published today an unusually gloomy survey of Europe's recent economic development.

The foreign exchange market last.week continued in the pattern! .of its predecessors--rates moved narrowly on extremely dull markets. Absence of developments affecting the market was accounted the sole reason for its lethargy.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept. 15 -- The fiercest fighting in nine days raged fourteen hours on the Korean central front yesterday with South Korean infantrymen gaining possession of two-thirds of hotly contested Finger Ridge.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 14 -- The west German reparations exports to Israel under the 3,450,000,000 - Deutsche mark ($822,000,000) agreement signed last Wednesday in Luxembourg will lay the basis for large-scale Israeli economic expansion but will provide scant consolation to luxury-starved consumers.
ROME, Sept. 14 -- The police prevented the Protestant Church of Christ in Rome today from holding regular Sunday services within sight of Vatican City.

Hope that the cause and cure in one Queens sewer trouble had been found was expressed yesterday by both the city Department of Public Works and the office of Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens. The diagnosis was a blockage that caused sewage to back up into a street and cellars of homes in Malba.

Mayor Imepllitteri's administration was accused yesterday of trying, because of fear of losing political patronage, to "scuttle" the classification and pay plan for city employes as drafted by Griffenhagen Associates.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is rendering a great service by giving constant attention to education problems in general and to our city school system in particular. Your editor does well in giving due credit to Commissioner Bensley for his successful effort to secure appropriations from our Board of Estimate for many school buildings, some of which have been recently opened and others that are in course of construction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan dropped a 40-foot eagle putt on the first hole and never let Harvie Ward off the hook thereafter in their thirty-six-hole title match to win his second successive Western amateur golf championship today by 3 and 2.

This promises to be a busy week in Europe. While the United States watches the electoral campaign with an air of suspended judgment, across the Atlantic conferences, reports, military maneuvers and political building operations, both on a grand scale, fill the September air with a buzz of unusual activity. For the first time in years it looks as if we are waiting and our allies are going ahead.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Cubs scored two runs in the tenth inning to defeat the Braves, 3 to 2, in the second game of a doubleheader today after Boston's Ed Mathews had socked a ninth inning home run to win the opener, 1 to 0.

STRASBOURG, Sept. 14 -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe, grouping parliamentary delegates of fourteen nations, will open its autumn session here tomorrow with an agenda of twenty-six items but only two real issues -- that of its own future and the dispute over the Saar between France and West Germany.
Station WDRC-FM, Hartford, Conn., yesterday became the sixteenth transmitter to join the FM network of WQXR, carrying music and hourly news bulletins of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 14 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh was received by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi today for three hours. The press reported they had discussed the answer to be given to the Churchill-Truman proposal for a settlement of the oil question.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 14 (UP) -- Nearly 1,000 soldiers, policemen and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents merged forces in a vast two-state search today for three "desperate and vicious" fugitives who have terrorized the countryside since they broke out of prison Wednesday.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- In an effort to counter the Soviet-imposed slowdown on the truck traffic that delivers the bulk of the food supply to the more than 2,000,000 residents of West Berlin, the West Berlin Truckers Association today called on Berlin trucking concerns to accept no freight to or from the city.

Fourteen top-ranking persons of the Indian motion-picture industry will arrive here by plane from London this morning for a four-week, eight-city tour of America, including a ten-day visit in Hollywood.

The American Federation of Labor's Committee to oust racketeers from union ranks began yesterday an investigation into the operation of New York locals headed by ex-convicts.

Five American industrialists start for Europe on Sept. 24 to hold seminars with management officials in Austria, according to an announcement by A. M. Lederer, president of the American Management Council. The National Association of Manufacturers charged yesterday that fraud and other abuses had become so prevalent in state unemployment insurance systems that it was doubtful the systems could fulfill their basic purpose of cushioning unemployment and stabilizing jobs.

The Soviet Union is engaged in the most extensive aluminum expansion program of its history, aiming to exceed by 1955 last year's Canadian aluminum output and to reach a level equal to about 60 per cent of the United States' 1951 production, an analysis of the fifth Five Year Plan indicates.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 14 -- The stock market last week relapsed into dullness and it now appears that the preceding short-lived strength was due entirely to American demand for Royal Dutch and other international shares. With Wall Street displaying weakness and Americans refraining from purchases in foreign markets it is clear that the Amsterdam stock market is no longer isolated but closely connected with the American market.

An appeal to the nation's youth to have faith in the United Nations was voiced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States and Permanent Representative to the United Nations, who was the guest of honor on the opening television program of the New York Times Youth Forum.

ABOARD U. S. S. WISCONSIN, At Sea, Sept. 14 -- The Allied striking fleet in Exercise Mainbrace, the first large scale North Atlantic Treaty Organization naval exercise, was off the Shetland Islands tonight, moving northward through submarine infested waters.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- Steel operations were pushed up an additional point last week in an effort to satisfy urgent demand for quick delivery. The rate was 101.5 per cent of theoretical capacity. The latter is based on melting facilities installed as of Jan. 1, 1952, with allowances for repairs and maintenance.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 14 -- Governmental determination to crush the Liberal opposition was read by Liberal observers here today into a nation-wide radio broadcast made last night by acting President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez, which they had hoped might be more conciliatory.

A forthright and determined city physician has taken into her own hands the matter of reorganizing Bellevue's out-patient clinic. Although the Budget Director's office was advised two years ago that-a streamlined outpatient department would both ease the urgency of the need for more hospital beds and could save the city as much as $10 per day per patient, it has failed to make anywhere near adequate funds available to achieve this end.

L. Bamberger Co., Newark, one of the largest department stores in the East, will adopt a policy of remaining open every Monday night until 9 o'clock, beginning on Oct. 6, it was announced over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration reported today that thus far it h rough agreements with the military, about $124,000,000 in defense business has been set aside for small companies.

Twenty-two players, representing thirteen countries, will participate in the zonal tournament for the world chess championship during the next four weeks in Sweden, according to a report from Stockholm, yesterday.

Yet it still seems to be necessary to stress the obvious. The nation faces an indefinite period of partial mobilization with a shortage of manpower within the age brackets of military requirements, as well as a shortage of technical and scientific manpower.

The American opera "Porgy and Bess" has arrived in Vienna and has received a gracious and appreciative welcome there. Here is good and important news for Americans. The George Gershwin opera was sent abroad by the state Department to demonstrate to Europeans that the United States has a rich native culture of its own and that this country is not a nation of barbarians, as our enemies would have the world think.
A crowd that filled Central Park Mall yesterday heard speeches by Mayor Impellitteri, former Postmaster General James A. Farley and others at New York's celebration of Citizenship Day.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14 -- "South Pacific," the record-breaking musical play, had its Australian premiere at Her Majesty's Theatre here last night.

A long finger of cool air snaked down early yesterday morning from Canada and crossed up the Weather Bureau's prediction of continued record-breaking heat. Saturday's 93-degree high had been expected to moderate slightly, but not to the extent of a drop of fourteen degrees. For New York and New Jersey the cooling weather brought a dull overcast with possible rains tomorrow.
ELMONT, L. I., Sept. 14 -- A fire early tonight destroyed a huge stable at Belmont Park on the eve of the opening of the fall racing season and killed twenty-four horses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Two key industries in national defense -- shipbuilding and communications equipment manufacture -- are suffering from a growing shortage of skilled labor, the Government reported today.

FAIRMONT, W. Va., Sept. 13 -- Believing that coals in the Appalachian region contain germanium, the "new" magic mineral, in commercial quantities, the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Company today announced plans for making an exhaustive cooperative investigation of all mines and coal seams in the region in the hope of finding recoverable quantities of the element.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Phillies rallied in both games to defeat the last-place Pirates, 5 -- 2 and 2 -- 1, today and complete their season's series with a 16-6 record against the Buccaneers.
Gerald Tarack, violinist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. This event, marking the opening of the new music season, was presented in the Interval Concerts series.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 14 -- The United States Army has asked General Vassily I. Chuikov, the Soviet commander in Germany, to recall three members of the Soviet military liaison mission in the United States zone in reprisal for the Soviet demand that the United States withdraw three members of its mission in Potsdam in East Germany.

Dr. Chester A. Pennington said yesterday. He preached a sermon entitled "A Job Worth Doing" at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

Commissions as second lieutenants were awarded yesterday to 126 graduates of the first New York National Guard Oficer Candidate School. The graduation exercises in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue were attended by 700 friends and relatives of the new officers who comprised the school's first class.

CANBERRA, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Minister Howard Beale Supply announced the Government had reached an agreement with Zinc Corporation, Ltd., "for the rapid development of Rum Jungle radium deposits near Darwin."

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Republic of Korea police have cracked two Communist spy rings that included women typists employed in United Nations offices, officials announced today.
