TORONTO, Sept. 14 -- Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International League, upheld Toronto's protest of Montreal's 3-2 play-off victory last night and the game was completed today with Montreal winning, 4 -- 2.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 15 -- The Chinese Communist Government Peiping radio said this morning that an international scientific commission, including representatives from United Nations member countries had "confirmed" the Chinese Red charges that Allied forces conducted bacteriological warfare in Korea and dropped germ-laden bombs in Northeast China.
Increasing activity in the art world is reflected by the large number of exhibitions opening this week.

It is just 200 years since Britain and the American colonies, now called the United States, mislaid eleven days on purpose. Eleven days tossed away for all time without a flicker of misgiving. Sept. 14, 1752, was the day England and the colonies officially adopted the Gregorian calendar -- named for Pope Gregory XIII -- to replace the Julian calendar -- named for Gaius Julius Caesar of Rome.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 14 -- The earth's newest active volcano, on uninhabited San Benedicto Island, 780 miles south of San Diego, is belching clouds of boiling gray smoke and gas every twenty minutes, a geologist reported here today after flying over the erupting volcano.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Twenty-two members of the Japanese mission to the international cotton conference landed at London airport tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden left London today on a threefold foreign mission that will keep him abroad for two weeks.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Upsets of two of the world's best young tennis players highlighted second-round play today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,373 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

Dave Polansky, 33-year-old former City College track and basketball star, yesterday was named coach of the Beavers' varsity basketball team for the 1952-53 season by Prof. Raymond Purcell, chairman of the Hygiene Department. Polansky replaces Professor Nat Holman, who is on sabbatical leave from the college. Holman's leave expires in September of 1953.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Al Parsells contributed seven goals as he led the Brandywine Polo Club of Philadelphia to a 12-6 triumph over Meadow Brook in the final of the sixteen-goal Autumn Plates tournament at Bostwick Field today.

Our generation has more than its share of persons who are endeavoring to live without religion, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher declared yesterday morning in his sermon, "The Man With No Religion," at St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street.

City Council President Rudolph Halley announced yesterday the start of a campaign he hopes will result in the submission of a proposed new and "streamlined" City Charter to the city's voters at the November election in 1953.
It took the Cardinals more than two years to catch up with Lefty Dave Koslo, but when they did, they left nothing to the imagination.

Dr. Richard Link, a member of the medical staff of Long Island College Hospital, Henry and Pacific Streets, Brooklyn, was attacked in the hospital's emergency room at 3:30 A. M. yesterday by three hoodlums, who later caused considerable damage to the physician's office in the building, Dr. Link was unhurt.

ROSLYN, L. I., Sept 14 -- A spectacular $250,000 fire early today destroyed the plant of a building supplies concern owned by Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson of Roslyn Heights, now under arrest on a charge of swindling a Long Island bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Acting Secretary Edward H. Foley announced today details of the Treasury's exchange offering of nearly $11,000,000,000 worth of 1 7/8 per cent certificates of indebtedness for 2 1/8 Treasury notes.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 14 -- One of America's fastest speed-boat creations, Bobby Rowland's You-All, the shiny red 266-cubic-inch class phenomenon from South Norfolk Va., today became the National Sweepstakes champion for the year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14 -- Premier Marshal Tito suggested today that the Trieste question, which has envenomed relations between Italy and Yugoslavia, should be adjourned until such time as more favorable conditions exist for a solution.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Iranian Premier Mossadegh will be informed by the British Government this week that at this juncture it cannot make any changes in the British-American plan for a settlement of the oil dispute between Britain and Iran.

On Sept. 4 THE NEW YORK TIMES gave prominence to a letter from P. D. Saggi, styling himself Convenor and General Secretary of the All India Convention of Race Relations, in which he gave expression to his views on the South African racial problem.

The United States Coast Guard will not conduct an inquiry into the loss of the Honduras-flag tanker Foundation Star, which was lost off Cape Hatteras after she split in a storm a week ago. A spokesman for the agency's Third District Headquarters in New York said yesterday that the Coast Guard had no jurisdiction over the vessel or its crew, because of its foreign registry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The motion picture industry charged, in a letter made public today, that the American Telephone Telegraph Company was evading its request for cost data. The data were sought to help the Federal Communications Commission decide whether it should allocate channels in the upper portion of the spectrum for the use of theatre television.

The soccer season was opened at Sterling Oval yesterday with a double-header. In the first game the Hakoah and Prague teams battled to a 4-4 tie. Then the Scots-Americans of Kearny, N. J., defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 5 to 3.

" Jan Christian Smuts," a biography by the soldier-statesman's son, J. C. Smuts, has been scheduled for Oct. 22 publication by Morrow. The story of the famous South African's life and career "cuts through all the epic events of the last fifty years."
SINGAPORE, Sept. 14 -- As of tomorrow, 72 per cent of the population of the Malayan Federation will acquire citizenship under a new law that becomes effective then.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 14 -- A new record of 33,610,509 tons of cargo was transported through the Panama Canal in the fiscal year that ended on June 30, 1952. This exceeded by 2,962,741 tons the previous record set in 1929. Long tons of 2,240 pounds avoirdupois are used in all Canal traffic statistics.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A committee of the International Sugar Council will meet here on Sept. 29 to consider how to distribute the world's supply of sugar, particularly the surplus piled up in Cuba as a result of an abundant harvest.

The six-furlong Fall Highweight Handicap, with the weights on the fifteen entrants ranging as high as 140 pounds, heads today's program at Belmont Park. This is the opening of a three-week, fifteen-stake meeting that will provide the best horse racing in the land.

HONG KONG, Sept. 14 -- More than 1,500 persons attended a solemn pontifical mass celebrated here today for Bishop Francis X. Ford of Meihsien, in northern Kwangtung Province. Among those who crowded the Caine Road Roman Catholic Cathedral were representatives of various Western consulates here.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 14 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, will head into the "internationalist" Eastern Seaboard this week to continue hammering away at his theme that Republican isolationists have regained the upper hand in a party hopelessly divided on foreign policy and many other questions.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Tigers clinched the reputation of being the worst team in the club's history by taking a 6-to-2 beating today from the Senators.

The city's proposal to build "slum clearance" apartments on a vacant site in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx -- an area marked for industrial development -- was opposed yesterday by the Regional Plan Association, Inc.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 14 -- Douglas McKay, state chairman of South Carolinians for Eisenhower, announced today that the Republican Presidential nominee, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, would speak from the steps of the State Capitol here Sept. 30 and be introduced by Gov. James F. Byrnes.

Although the annual meeting of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and the International Monetary Fund ended last week in Mexico city on an optimistic note, there were rumblings from some of the members that the World Bank should look with a less jaundiced eye on many loans which come up for approval.

The Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner declared in his sermon yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle-Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street, that communism, in its opposition to religion, eventually would destroy itself.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Starting with a nine-under-par performance on the front nine, the team of Dr. Sam Anziano, William Pius, Ronnie Horne and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills finished fourteen under with a 27, 31 -- 58 to win the annual Wheatley Hills member-pro tournament by one stroke today.

ENOS SLAUGHTER was stretched out on the bed in his hotel room, hands cupped behind his head, in complete relaxation. "This is part of my conservation program," he said with a grin. "The old bones and the old muscles need rest. So I give 'em as much as I can."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- In the most hopeful pronouncement since Israel became a nation in 1948, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion reported today that his country was "well on its way" to achieve self-sufficiency in food production and balanced exports and imports "within six to ten years."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Long Island Sound's final championship regatta of the long summer season, which began in May, was held today by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- Eight thousand chemists and chemical engineers gathering here for the 122d national meeting of the American Chemical Society were confronted tonight with the news that the supply of chemists for the future was declining alarming.
Three debutantes, one from Connecticut and two from Long Island, were presented to society at receptions yesterday afternoon.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Jersey Joe Walcott, world heavyweight champion, impressed crowd of 500 in four rounds of sparring here today.

THE publication today of "The Diary of George Templeton Strong 1835-1875,"* edited by Allan Nevins and Milton Halsey Thomas, is in all probability the most important event in the world of books for 1952. This extraordinary journal, kept by a prominent New York lawyer through forty of the most interesting years of the nineteenth century, is a historical document of the first rank and a literary discovery of great general interest.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Sept. 14 -- A ribbon salesman's latent ability as a stone mason and the carpentry skill of a District Court judge are major factors in the near completion of a Sunday School and kindergarten building at the Israel Community Center of Levittown.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The stock markets had to contend with conflicting events last week but have on balance managed to show some recovery after the preceding week's setback.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 -- Dr. Anthony J. J. Rourke, president of the American Hospital Association, called on the hospitals of the nation today to combat "irresponsible stories" that have created a negative picture of the care they offer.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 -- Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to Russia and a retired naval officer, predicted here today that in the foreseeable future the Soviet Union would witness a "recrudescence and upsurge" of religious faith.
I should like to comment on O. R. Strackbein's views on foreign trade, in his letter published recently.
A variety of blouses, each a comely addition to any fall separates wardrobe, is brought to you today by Patterns of The Times in variations of three patterns, one sized for teen-agers.

Over the last fifteen years industry in the Dominican Republic has made long strides, according to a survey just released by its Secretary of Economy and Commerce. This shows that industrial establishments have risen from 1,075 to 3,412; capital investment, $62,314,340 to $119,636,855; gross sales, $16,279,129 to $120,471,745; number of workers employed from 20,301 to 48,332 and wage payments, $4,561,183 to $78,138,028.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The understanding on issues reached between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, and Senator Robert A. Taft bore its first fruit today with the announcement that the Ohioan would make a nation-wide radio address for the ticket on Wednesday night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The White Sox hit four straight singles after two were out in the seventeenth inning to beat the Red Sox, 4 to 3, in the first half of a double-header here today. The victory was credited to Luis Aloma, who yielded three of the Bosox fiftee hits after relieving Saul Rogovin at the end of the first half of the fifteenth round.
In this age, the heyday of packaging, lemons now come in toothpaste tubes. Not perhaps the most appetizing idea in the world, but certainly convenient.

Twenty-two aspirants for world championship honors started play yesterday in the zonal tournament of the International Chess Federation at the City Hall in Stockholm, according to reports from the Swedish capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, announced plans today for a soft coal strike beginning next Monday, when wage contracts covering Northern mines expire, but he exempted most mines west of Ohio.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -- A forty-three-word amendment to the Federal Constitution to meet "growing Executive usurpation" in dealings with foreign nations was proposed today by the Committee on Peace and Law of the American Bar Association.
A large section of the American public had the opportunity last night to get a close and intimate look at a Presidential candidate.

Eddie Arcaro made himself the hero of the opening day's program at Belmont Park's meeting yesterday by guiding Mrs. B. F. Whitaker's Hitex to victory in the Fall Highweight Handicap. Pegged at 130 pounds, the 3-year-old Hitex scored by a half length over the top-weighted Tea-Maker.

ROME, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Protestant Church of Christ was ordered by the Italian Government today to close its twenty-two branches in this Catholic country until it received official permission to operate. Italian officials said such permission might take years to obtain.
SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 15 -- The largest combined ground and air maneuvers that the Atlantic alliance will hold this year will start early tomorrow morning.
Light volume and uncertain price movements characterized most commodities future markets here yesterday.

TORRANCE, Calif., Sept. 15 -- A jet-propelled one-man helicopter, weighing only 300 pounds and hailed as "the answer to the infantryman's prayer," gave an impressive demonstration at its first public showing today before several hundred spectators, including the Secretary of Defense, Frank Pace Jr.

" Democracy at Bay: A Diagnosis and a Prognosis," by Felix Somary, European economist and business man, will be published by Knopf on Oct. 20. It is an analysis of Western democracy -- its evolution and its future under the extension of governmental power.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 -- West Berlin authorities prepared today an appeal to the Western Allies to find some way to help them out of a predicament in which most of the city's food imports might be cut off tomorrow midnight when trucking concerns, exasperated by Soviet-imposed delaying tactics against commercial vehicles from West Germany, have ordered a strike.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 15 -- Two of the leaders in the high fashion field of design in the local garment market are Margaret Newman and Renee Marciel.
John and Robert Burns, who recently ended four-year enlistments with the Marine Corps, don't know much about cooking, but they know what they like. They like Marine Corps cooking.

The State Public Service Commission yesterday reopened a hearing begun last October into the safety of equipment of the Children's Bus Service, Inc., and heard a report of decided improvement in the company's 237 vehicles.

Average market value of a share of stock on the New York Stock Exchange fell 61 cents in August. The figure of $41.85 on Aug. 31 compared with $42.46 on July 31, and was the lowest since the $41.14 of May 31. At the same time, borrowings by member firms of the Stock Exchange fell from $1,463,422,328 to $1,063,095,599.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Cyrus S. Ching resigned today as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service and received the nation's thanks from President Truman, who appointed David L. Cole, Paterson, N. J., lawyer, as his successor.

LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- British newspapers gave a cold reception today to the Japanese delegation to the International Cotton Textile Conference and displayed their concern over the threat of Japanese competition to British markets.

LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Some sections of the British press declared today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, by making his peace with Senator Robert A. Taft, had gravely imperiled his chances of becoming President.
LONDON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Moscow radio said that the Changchun line, the backbone of Manchuria's railway system, would be handed over to the Chinese by the end of this year "without compensation."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Mutual Security Agency announced today allotments of 1952-53 defense support funds for three European nations, totaling $139,705,000. The allotments provide $137,318,000 for Britain, $1,787,000 for West Germany and $600,000 for Iceland.

Fresh from California, the collection of the distinguished designer Irene has arrived at Jay Thorpe's. It is a large one with costumes covering many phases of social life. While it is the designer's fall and winter offering, she has included a few things that are geared to warm days at winter resorts.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 -- Future increased welfare and health needs should be met through Voluntary philanthropy rather than through government, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, told the concluding session of the National Conference of Catholic Charities today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Radio Moscow has launched a new series of bitterly anti - United States broadcasts saying, among other things, that thirteen million Americans are fully or partially unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The State Department made it clear today that the United States had no intention of mixing the question of the Panmunjom truce talks into debate in the United Nations General Assembly on the broad problems of Korean politics and economic rehabilitation.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Following are the texts, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, of two Soviet-Chinese Communist communiques, a note from Chou En-lai, Chinese Premier and Foreign Minister, and Deputy Premier Chen Yung, to Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, and the latter's reply:

In its continuation of the propaganda use of the bacterial-warfare charge the Peiping radio has named names. Supposedly eminent scientists of six nations are said to have substantiated the Communist claim. The six nations are Sweden, France, Great Britain, Italy, Brazil and the Soviet Union.

CORTINA, Italy, Sept. 15 -- Observers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were deeply impressed by what some of them described as a "truly incredible" performance of the Tridentina Alpine brigade which this morning moved swiftly over one of the most difficult terrains in the world to conquer "enemy" positions overlooked by towering peaks of the Dolomites.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- A weak corn market had a depressing effect on other grains today, and the buying demand was not vigorous enough to maintain early gains. Corn was affected directly by the favorable weather for maturing the crop, although the dry conditions which are hastening the ripening of the grain are unfavorable in other respects, as there have been further declines in pasturage and fodder crop conditions in many sections.

Designs by G. Howard Hodge were featured yesterday at the informal showings of fall millinery designs in the Rose Room of Abraham Straus. These showings will be repeated today on their third and main floor and in the restaurant from 11 A. M. to 4 P. M.

The General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., reached a deadlock last night over a contract for 71,000 members of the union in fifty-five plants in many states.

ABOARD U. S. S. WISCONSIN, at sea, Sept. 15 -- Mist, drizzle and fog intervened today in Exercise Mainbrace, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuver in which 200 ships and 81,000 men of nine nations are participating.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President, said today he would support John Cashmore, Democratic nominee for Senator from New York, in his race against Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican nominee, and Dr. George S. Counts, the nominee of the Liberal party.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 -- The peronista newspapers vigorously denounced measures that curtail transmission of news today and energetically called for freedom of the press -- in Uruguay.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The dissolution of the Spa's oldest hotel, the famed Grand Union, began in earnest today with the public auction of its furnishings. For days, enormous amounts of china, linens, furniture and carpeting from the cavernous basement and mammoth public rooms had been carted away in private sales to big buyers.

The Lighthouse signed up a new volunteer yesterday in its $2,500,000 fund-raising campaign -- a 30-year-old woman who knows what blindness means through ten years of experience and who now, with her sight restored through the aid of the Miami, Fla., Lighthouse, is studying commercial art.

There has been a decided note of sensitivity and resentment this past week over the criticisms to which the Conservative Government of Colombia has been subjected after the wanton destruction on Sept. 6 of the plants of the two big Liberal dailies and the burning and pillage of the houses of Liberal party leaders.

GENEVA, Sept. 15 -- A striking success for recently introduced tourist rates for air travel across the Atlantic Ocean was reported today at the opening meeting of the International Air Transport Association's eighth annual general conference.

John L. Lewis and the bituminous coal operators have been negotiating secretly for several weeks to modify their present agreements, which begin to expire on Saturday, and the negotiations with the Northern coal operators now appear to have broken down, with the threat of a strike being voiced.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 15 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh will present to the Iranian Chamber of Deputies tomorrow his postponed declaration on the Churchill-Truman proposals for getting the Iranian oil industry going again and enabling Iran to get out of her present financial morass.

Korean war veterans eligible for the $45-a-month additional combat pay, voted recently by Congress, may make applications immediately at the New York City Veterans Service, 500 Park Avenue. Herbert Brickman, administrator of the city agency, announced yesterday that the Veterans Service had received application blanks from the Department of Defense and would assist veterans in filing them.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Thirteen thousand workers went on strike today at the Douglas aircraft plant at El Segundo, crippling production of Navy fighter planes. The defense effort was already slowed by a strike of 25,000 workers at the Lockheed aircraft plant in Burbank.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Richard A. McDonald, San Francisco industrialist, was named today to succeed Henry H. Fowler as administrator of the National Production Authority.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the legality of the regular Democratic slate of candidates for Supreme Court Justice in the Second Judicial District. The decision was seen as a major setback to the insurgent group seeking to unseat Francis J. Sinnott, Kings County Democratic leader.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Marge Mason, the defending champion, scored a 39, 40 -- 79 today at the Essex County Country Club to lead a group of sixteen qualifiers into the first round of the New Jersey Women's amateur golf championship.

GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 15 (AP) -- The perjury indictment against James A. Leafy, Saratoga Republican leader, was dismissed today. Justice Willard L. Best of State Supreme Court said the indictment against the Saratoga Springs lawyer was not found upon sufficient legal evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- The nation's 6,832 hospitals admitted 18,750,000 patients last year, a record, Dr. Anthony J. J. Rourke, president of the American Hospital Association, reported today. He added that there were almost 3,000,000 births in hospitals in the year.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- The Massachusetts Senate concurred tonight, the eve of the state primary, in action by the House to repeal all legislative pensions bills enacted since 1947. The Senate vote was 20 to 15. It was taken shortly after 11 P. M.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 -- The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church, meeting here in triennial general convention, refused today to debate and bring to a vote the controversial question of whether a non-Episcopal clergyman can participate in an Episcopal ordination service.

Despite gloomy skies that caused the lights to be turned on at the start of the second inning and a slight drizzle that made the smallest Ebbets Field attendance of the season (2,612 paid) a bit uncomfortable, everything was bright in Brooklyn yesterday.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., will soon seek $3,000,000 worth of all kinds of merchandise to be resold to the public at prices well below usual levels. Top company officials announced yesterday imminent substantial shaving of mark-ups through gradual but thorough expansion of super market self-service for customers in all three Hearn stores.

Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Valerian A. Zorin, who will take over as permanent Soviet representative to the United Nations later this month, said on his arrival here yesterday that the Soviet Union would follow "a policy of peace and collaboration with all countries."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Government requirements of minimum down payments on new homes will be suspended tomorrow.

A protest against continuance of import quota restrictions on foreign cheeses has been filed with the Department of Agriculture by the Cheese Importers Association of America, and some favorable action is hoped for before start of a new quota period on Oct. 1, it was made known here yesterday.

A call for a "go ahead" with the city's full rapid transit construction program was issued yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri in a message to the City Planning Commission. The Mayor took his stand despite a warning last month by Controller Lazarus Joseph that the city should "consider carefully" its fiscal problems before embarking on any large-scale projects, including the Second Avenue subway.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 7 to 13 points net lower, than on last Friday after some early steadiness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Clovis D. Walker, former Director of the Cotton Branch of the Department of Agriculture's Production and Marketing Administration, and Loutfy Mansour, an Egyptian cotton importer, were indicted today for conspiracy to defraud the United States.

Five of the foremost designers of coats and suits joined forces yesterday at the Plaza Hotel for the first of Saks Fifth Avenue's series of designer showings. These included Monte Sano Pruzan, Zuckerman, Gershel, Mangone and Carmel.

The first units of a new recording camera so fast that it can be synchronized with the firing mechanism of a 500-mile-an-hour jet aircraft have been delivered to the Air Force at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, by the Bolsey Corporation of America.

Designers share the spotlight with painters and sculptors in an exhibit called "Art in Interiors," opening to the public today at Midtown Galleries, 17 East Fifty-seventh Street. Seven room settings are centered on pictures and pieces of sculpture to show how contemporary American art, in which this gallery specializes, might look when used in a home.

Another step in the march of top industrial management from New York to Westchester County was taken yesterday when the General Electric Company announced it had acquired an option on a 186-acre tract in Mount Pleasant to house the company's executive offices.

Jed Harris yesterday confirmed I the report that he had agreed to handle the direction for the new untitled Arthur Miller play, which Kermit Bloongarden is producing. No contracts have been signed yet, but the deal is set, according to the director.
A defendant in the departmental police graft trial who had submitted his resignation last Wednesday was dismissed yesterday from the force by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

ROSLYN, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Ideal Insulators, Inc., its office and all but one warehouse destroyed by a spectacular fire yesterday, resumed operation today as investigators took up this latest in a series of bizarre incidents following the alleged $475,000 swindle of a Mineola bank by a woman executive of the home improvement company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 -- Yugoslavia lost 2,000,000 tons of corn in the recent drought, according to the latest unofficial estimates. This represents 50 per cent of the 1951 crop.

The Federal Maritime Board requested yesterday that the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference hold in abeyance the effective date of its proposed new contract covering dual freight rates until such time as the board could complete action on the adoption of a procedural rule governing such systems.
Arnold Constable, Fifth Avenue department store, honored a group of young Americans yesterday by way of starting the celebration of its 127th anniversary.

SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 15 -- Total credit extended to farmers and their cooperative institutions by the Federal Farm Credit Administration System in the fiscal year ended last June 30, reached a new high of $2,389,000,000, I. W. Duggan, governor of the administration reported today.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- Nearly 40,000 clapping, shouting Eritreans here today acclaimed the birth of a new nation as they watched the British lion bow himself out after eleven years and the lion of Judah take over this former Italian colony.

The stock market dipped to new now levels of the downward movement yesterday and closed easier on the day as trading increased slightly over last Friday's volume. The losses were the widest in a week, with oil, rail and liquor issues the weakest performers.

Impressive individual pieces of furniture for the living room, and chests and a headboard for the bedroom, designed by Harold M. Schwartz for Romweber Industries, are now on display at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. Sculptured lines accent the designs.
Contemporary American ceramists are represented in three shows that opened here yesterday.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The long-hitting Pat Circelli, Ridgeway Club pro, and his partner, Charles Meaney of Hudson River, captured the chief prize in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur handicap tournament at the Briar Hall Country Club today.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 15 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, reiterated today Britain's wish to be closely associated with the six continental nations in the European Coal and Steel Community in the elaboration of their plan for a political federation without either joining the community or compromising its freedom of action.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- Agreements announced early today by the Soviet Union and Communist China provide for Soviet withdrawal from the Changchun Railroad in Manchuria by the end of the year and continuance of the joint Soviet-Chinese use of Port Arthur until China and the Soviet have signed a peace treaty with Japan.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 -- Today's newspapers tell of a large landowner and former Deputy who on Friday raided the police station at Maghasha, in the Minieh Province of Upper Egypt, at the head of a force of supporters in protest against the Government's land reform program.
Following are excerpts from whistle-stop talks by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, in his campaign tour across Indiana yesterday, as carried by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The State Department discounted today the latest Chinese Communist "germ warfare" charges as the product of "stooges" working with "lies, trumped - up evidence and forced confessions."

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Rookie Harvey Kuenn's fourth hit of the day, a booming triple in the ninth. and Fred Hatfield's single lifted the Tigers to a 5-4 victory over the Senators today before 1,239 fans, smallest crowd of the year at Briggs Stadium.

The W. T. Grant Company, which operates a chain of 485 stores of low-priced merchandise, had net earnings in the six months ended July 31 of $2,202,260, Edward Staley, president, reported to shareholders yesterday.
The long-dormant issue of labor unity came alive unexpectedly yesterday as the American Federation of Labor opened its seventy-first annual convention at the Commodore Hotel.

Several hundred buyers representing nearly all segments of business visited the Astor Hotel yesterday to attend the opening of the New York Premium Show, sponsored by the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc. There are about 10,000 items on exhibition with 200 manufacturers or their representatives occupying booths in the show, which is for the trade only.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 15 -- United States Senator Irving M. Ives in a speech here today hit out at what he called Administration confusion and incompetence. He sharply criticized Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's "polished scorn" in asking what the nation has to change to and declared that "free, competitive enterprise is a far better thing than the mismanagement of blundering theorists."

BARRING the siege of winds that often coincides with the arrival of the equinox, a lot of salty characters are convinced that the bluefish will remain in nearby waters for another two weeks, but many decided to go after the blues over the week-end and avoid the possibility of being late and sorry.

A change in the strategy of promoting the sale of sweaters this fall has become evident. The National Knitted Outerwear Association and the Wool Bureau will co-sponsor the annual "sweater girl" contest next Monday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, but the association, which follows through on the promotion, is very careful to avoid the use of the word "sweater girl."

Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which makes a business of studying business ventures, put out a detailed study yesterday to show why some businesses are successful and some are not. The study traces the growth of the country from 1900 to 1952 and analyzes the effects of the events of the day on the success or failures of businesses.

Victor Clemente, Queens sewer contractor, said yesterday he would not appear at 8 A. M. today at 133d Avenue and 223d Street, Laurelton, despite an order by Borough President James A. Lundy to start there at that time the reopening and repairing of a two-mile $185,679 sewer the contractor had built.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic Presidential nominee, will spend Thursday night in Hartford following an all-day tour of this state, according to plans announced today.

New data on four countries was released yesterday by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade to supplement its recent survey of "United States Dollar Earnings of Foreign Exporters." The additional information revealed, in part, that Denmark not permits exporters to retain per cent of dollars earned from sales to the United States market.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- The Chinese Communist Air Force threw eighty of its Russian-designed MIG jet fighters into an attempt to break up an Allied raid on the Manchurian border yesterday and lost twelve destroyed or damaged.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 15 -- Considerable attention in the Presidential campaign will be focused in the next two weeks on this area of southwestern Ohio.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Former Finance Minister Carlos Lleras Restrepo has asked permission to leave Colombia, but ex-President Alfonso Lopez has not decided whether to go or stay, Foreign Minister Juan Uribe Holguin said today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- The magazine Smena, under the title "Beizbol," explained to its readers today that baseball, the American national sport, was a "beastly battle, a bloody fight with mayhem and murder" and furthermore nothing but a Yankee perversion of an ancient Russian village sport called lapta.

Mrs. Walter J. Monaghan, wife of a former plainclothes man, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court on a contempt citation arising from her refusal to appear as a witness before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,374 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 15 -- The voters in this normally Democratic state appear at this stage of the Presidential campaign to be politically adrift.

The Government securities market exhibited a better tone yesterday with the opening of the period for exchanging $10,861,000,000 of maturing 1 7/8 per cent certificates due Oct. 1 for fourteen-month notes bearing interest of 2 1/8 per cent.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The National Hockey League will get its earliest start in history when the Montreal Canadiens meet the Chicago Black Hawks and the Detroit Red Wings play the New York Rangers on Oct. 9.

If the Fordham seismograph registered an unusual pattern yesterday, there really was no cause for alarm. It was merely a local tremor, caused by about four tons of footballers crashing onto the sod of Fordham Field.

To effect a further coordination of activities of the aircraft engine and propeller operations, the General Motors Corporation today is consolidating its Aeroproducts Division at Dayton with the Allison Division of Indianapolis, C. E. Wilson, president, announced yesterday.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Coach Lou Little concentrated on the Columbia football squad's offense today in the wind and rain, giving his first-string backfield a thorough test in an hour's scrimmage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, embarks Thursday on a campaign speaking trip that will carry him into fifteen states in five weeks.

INDIANA HARBOR, Ind., Sept. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower criticized Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign humor today and asked what was funny about the Korean fighting, the national debt, inflation, high taxes and corruption in Washington.
Robert T. Creasey, Assistant Secretary of Labor, told the United Paperworkers of America, C. I. O., yesterday that the New Deal and Fair Deal Administrations had "not been a labor government."

Sixteen high-ranking Army officials met with Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army Commander, for a closed six-hour session on Governors Island yesterday, during which they reviewed problems affecting their eight-state command area.
One-family dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas transactions reported yesterday.

GARDEN CITY PARK, L. I., Sept. 15 -- An observant dog warden and two vigilant dog catchers brought about today the reunion of a female boxer and her seven tiny puppies and added the backing of the North Hempstead Town Government in a quest for canine homes. The dog apparently was searching for food when she was caught.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- Giving off an air of satisfaction that the job thus far has been well done, but making it clear they still did not consider themselves wholly in the clear, Casey Stengel and his Yankees arrived tonight for their final pair of engagements of the season's last Western trip.
FORT LEE, N. J., Set. 15 -- Pearl Bailey, the singer and entertainer, was beaten by an unknown assailant early this morning as she was leaving the Riviera night club.

A City College engineering instructor was fined $1,200 and six other multiple traffic violators were assessed a total of $3,000 in Traffic Court yesterday as Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh continued his campaign to bring to book drivers who have failed to answer six or more summonses.
We have read with great interest the editorial "Report to Taxpayers," published in your issue of Sept. 12.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 -- Albert Fitzgerald, president of the independent United Electrical Workers Union, withdrew his personal support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency today and criticized both major political parties.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- Heavy clashes between demonstrators and policemen in Beirut, capital of Lebanon, were reported in dispatches reaching here tonight.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 15 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois bid today for the support of Republicans whose hopes for new party leadership have been dashed, he said, now that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "great crusade" has become the "great surrender" to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Israel and six Arab states separately called today on the United Nations to take up once again the Palestine dispute.

A sizable number of your readers have written me to comment upon my statement, as correctly recorded in your issue of Sept. 9, to the effect that Sweden is not a socialist country, in that 90 per cent of its trade and industry follows the pattern of private enterprise.

You state an issue, but not the whole issue, in your editorial "The Issue in Iran." While I agree that in many instances the principle of no confiscation without fair compensation should be upheld, I might question the use of this yardstick in regard to the Iranian issue.

One hundred and sixty-five years after the Constitutional Convention of Philadelphia created the United States of America another historic convention is now meeting in Strasbourg in France to start work on the momentous task of creating a United States of Europe. It is a task that poses far greater difficulties and graver problems than any faced by our own Founding Fathers.

What did an investor get for $100 invested in the assets of General Motors if he bought at the 1929 high or at the 1952 high? E. W. Axe Co., Inc., has prepared an entertaining breakdown. For $100 (using balance sheet figures for the end of 1928) he got in 1929 $18.11 in common stock equity and 1929 dividends of $4.69.

BASEBALL'S frenetic pennant races go careening along, fans hanging on the edges of their seats as they wonder who will meet whom in the world series. They are not the only ones who are wondering. The ball players themselves are doing more than wonder. They also are doing some calculating. That's when they find themselves caught in an open switch, torn in one direction by money and in another direction by glory.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a prepared statement issued by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson on the meeting last Friday between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, and a condensation of questions and answers in a Stevenson press conference today:

Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan inspected yesterday four elementary schools on the East Side reported "painfully overcrowded" by parents of children attending those schools. He declared that one of the schools was a "disgrace to the city" and that something "has to be done about the overcrowding problem."

As a long-time resident of Wisconsin may I comment on the natural but disturbing misunderstandings of the results of the recent Senate primary. Those who oppose Senator McCarthy are needlessly disturbed by the results. Close observers estimated that McCarthy would win the primary by about 400,000 votes to about 200,000 for his combined Republican opposition.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Counsel for the Meecham Corporation argued in Federal District Court here today that Chinese financing of the purchase of the surplus tanker Meacham was legal under the Ship Sales Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Republican Vice Presidential candidate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, accused Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today of "wisecracking" about such issues as the Korean war, taxes and high prices and said wit was misplaced in a political campaign.

Among life's simple pleasures there are few more heartwarming and genuine than the unexpected day off. This is not the Saturday and the Sunday respite from laborious affairs, for they can be counted upon as days off and are so set down in the regulations.

Calling Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the greatest Republican nominee of this century, Governor Dewey predicted yesterday General Eisenhower's election because, as he put it, the people were tired of the "wholesale corruption" in Washington and also wanted some assurance that there would be no third world war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, charged today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential candidate, had made an "abject surrender" to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio last Friday when they met in New York.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Making his first start since Aug. 17, Lou Kretlow stopped the Red Sox with six hits and the White Sox posted a 4-to-2 victory today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 15 -- On the basis of the present outlook, years may pass before a peace treaty is concluded and full diplomatic relations established between Indonesia and Japan.

Clyde F. Gay, vice president, administration, of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, declared yesterday that the national economy "needs more of those who are entitled to take risks to do so" and the capitalistic system "needs more than the 6,500,000 equity owners in publicly owned corporations revealed by the Brookings report."

Fur merchants extending credit to manufacturers far beyond the total capitalization of their customers' business are aiding the small percentage of "commercial scavengers and vultures" who are disrupting the fur industry, according to Nathaniel Berman, executive director of the American Fur Merchants Association.

TRENTON, Sept. 15 -- Joe Adonis, gambler serving a two-to-three-year state prison sentence, appealed to the State Supreme Court today to be relieved of five years' probation at the expiration of his term. The court reserved decision after hearing argument.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Rutgers, whose game with Princeton here on Nov. 6, 1869, launched football as an intercollegiate sport, does not expect this to be one of its better seasons.
They turned on the Polo Grounds lights in the third inning yesterday to cut the gloom of leaden skies -- and thus provided illumination for the wildest scoring splurge by the Giants this year.

The most active selling in two years was reported yesterday by exhibitors of infants', children's, boys', girls' and 'teens' wear and accessories at the New Yorker Hotel. The eight-day show, sponsored by the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart, ended yesterday.

The underlying land of the buildings occupying the west blockfront on Third Avenue between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets has been sold by the Gerry Estates, Inc., to A. Ruth Sons, real estate operators and builders. The property was acquired subject to a wholly net lease held by the S. Z. B. Corporation, of which Bernard Zimetbaum is president.

IN New York on Nov. 6, 1895, an 18-year-old girl, who had spent the entire morning of her wedding day in tears, was married to a young English Duke, who had insisted that the nuptials be postponed from the preceding day, which was Guy Fawkes Day, because "it would not be suitable for him to be married on a day that an attempt had been made to blow up the House of Lords."

Much of the emphasis of Governor Stevenson's campaign thus far has been devoted to pointing out inconsistencies in the position taken by what he calls "the two Republican parties" on various important public issues and further inconsistencies between what the Republican party promises in its platform and what its spokesmen have actually done in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- General Eisenhower and his advisers have come to the deliberate conclusion that the witty gibes and humorous anecdotes with which Governor Stevenson is wont to lighten the necessarily serious business of discussing grave issues may be turned against him.

I am sure that, editorially or in some other way, you will supplement the news report in your issue of Sept. 9 which covered the revelations of Dr. Bella Dodd concerning her experience in the Teachers Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The O. P. S. simplified the machinery today by which industries with pinched profits may obtain price ceiling increases. The change, price officials emphasized, is strictly a matter of procedure and does not relax the "earnings standard" which governs the ceiling level.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The stock markets were quiet today, business being held up by a tendency to await the outcome of wage talks between the Government and engineering trade unions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The average city family did not overspend its 1950 income by more than $400, as was announced last month by Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, the Budget Bureau asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Communist China apparently suffered a major setback in Moscow, diplomatic circles here concluded after having examined first reports on the results of Premier Chou Enlai's negotiations with the leaders of the Soviet Union.

More than three-quarters of the Jewish refugees who arrived in this country on the first displaced persons ship after World War II have become American citizens and almost all are leading happy and productive lives here, according to a report yesterday by the United Service for New Americans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- A new effort to effect a settlement of the six-week-old strike by the Screen Writers Guild-Authors League of America against the Alliance of Television Film Producers now is under way and the two groups will hold a meeting tonight.

Martin L. Scher has been appointed vice president and general manager of the International Telephone and Telegraph Distribution Corporation, New York distributor for the Capehart-Farnsworth Corporation, Fort Wayne, Ind., and the Coolerator Company, Duluth, Minn., both of which are I. T. T. associates.

Three college football bowl games to be played in Miami, New Orleans and Pasadena, Calif., are expected to be available next New Year's Day -- two of them for the first time -- to a Nation-wide television audience. The schedule will bring viewers a full five hours of gridiron coverage running from approximately 2 to 7 P. M. in the Eastern time zone.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 -- To the rest of the baseball world it may appear that the Indians, although still mathematically alive, are "dead," so far as winning the American League pennant is concerned. Al Lopez, however, refuses to go along with (a) the realists or (b) the pessimists.

The police broadcast a city-wide alarm early this morning for a war amputee's auto after he reported it had been stolen while his 18-month-old son was asleep in the rear seat. At 2:15 A. M. the car and child were still missing.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The man who controls the nation's prices kept himself under control for two hours today as he listened to criticism of high prices from Detroit housewives.
One hundred an seventy registered nurses, who have been inactive in recent years, have signed up in the Department of Hospitals' new refresher course program.

The Dow Chemical Company has a capacity of 50,000,000 pounds of Saran powder annually, according to C. B. Branch, manager of the plastics department and a director of the Saran Yarns Company. Saran is a subsidiary of Dow. Mr. Branch indicated, however, that productive capacity of the finer deniers is limited at the present time, but the spinning equipment to make such fibers can be easily expanded.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Any possibility of a rapprochement between Mario Lanza and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer over the singer's failure to report for work in "The Student Prince" appeared to be ended today with an announcement from the studio that it "had instructed its attorneys to proceed with legal action to protect the company."

In a tumultuous four-hour session, the Kings County Democratic County Committee early this morning named James M. Power to the vacancy occasioned by the retirement of William J. Heffernan from the Board of Eections. Under the Election Law, the City Council must name Mr. Power to the $12,000-a-year post unless the recommendation is upset by the courts.

Few men have a unique job, but one who might qualify for that distinction is Arthur Kleiner, piano accompanist for silent movies. Mr. Kleiner provides mood music, most of it his own composition, for the pre-talkie era films shown at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
The Pira brothers, Frank and John, six-foot-two-inch look-alikes, will not be driving their automobiles today.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- West Berlin truckers who had planned to cease at midnight tonight all efforts to pass the Soviet-imposed "little blockade" on German commercial road traffic to West Berlin agreed late in the evening to keep on trying for at least two weeks.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- The newspaper Pravda reiterated today that cure for Britain's economic plight -- which it assessed in the most dire terms -- was to develop "all-around world trade without restrictions or discriminations such as have paralyzed British trade with the Soviet Union, Red China and Eastern Europe.

" I Love Lucy" is back in fine fettle. The top program of last season returned Monday evening at 9 to the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network and once again proved a delightful slapstick romp for Lucille Ball, the erstwhile glamour girl who is now without serious rival among comediennes.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood took another step forward in defense of her New Jersey Women's Golf Association open championship by beating Mrs. A. J. Bryant of Upper Montclair, 1 up, today at the Essex County Country Club.

OTTAWA, Sept. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Partial paralysis crept into Canada's major grain-hauling business on the Prairies today as the Federal Government reacted to the threat or a grain handlers' strike at the Lakehead.

New Selective Service directives on the deferment of apprentices have materially aided the contract tool and die industry's apprenticeship training programs, it was announced yesterday in Cleveland by George S. Eaton, executive secretary of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association.

Today's new film is "Big Jim McLain," a Warner Brothers melodrama, with John Wayne and Nancy Olson, at the Paramount. The Wayne - Fellows Production was filmed on location in Hawaii. Edward Ludwig directed from a screen play by James Edward Grant.

MOMBASA, Kenya, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Headless dogs have been nailed to Government notice boards and dead goats placed on church altars by the Kikuyu tribe's secret and terrorist Mau Mau Society, a member of the Kenya Legislative Council charged here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, took emphatic issue today with a report that his department was showing a lack of "enthusiasm" for dealing with small defense plants.

John Howard Clark's Quiz Song, with Willie Lester in the saddle, registered an easy triumph in the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday. Engaging six others in the Portia, the mile race for fillies and mares, Quiz Song came through in the stretch to score by a length over Enchanted Eve of the Christiana Stable.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 16 -- Two British spokesmen in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe offered polite congratulations today to the six Continental nations moving toward a political federation and added warnings to them not to go too fast or too far without Britain and the rest of the Continent.

THE best known football player in the country on one October day last season was Fred Benners of Southern Methodist. No one could have been more adroit in picking the spot for a super-duper performance. The Mustangs were meeting Notre Dame before that great hidden (and non-paying) gathering, the television viewers.

The Wall Street Journal, in an editorial to be published today, denies an assertion by President Truman yesterday in his message to the American Federation of Labor convention that the newspaper had reported that plans were under way in Wall Street to make the Taft-Hartley Act more "oppressive and unfair."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Harry N. Rosenfield, former United States Displaced Persons Commissioner, was named today executive director of the President's new Commission on Immigration and Naturalization. The appointment was announced by Philip B. Perlman, chairman of the commission, following the organization's first meeting.

The Adriatica Navigation Company of Italy, which lost 90 percent of its fleet in the war, has neared the half-way mark in replacement of tonnage and now can offer passenger service on a three-class basis on six modern liners, Oddo Nasso, chief passenger executive, said yesterday.
I wish to refer to the events which I took place in Bogota on Sept. 6 and to the comments on these events which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China, in the opinion of Western diplomats here, have laid the basis in their current Moscow negotiations for a wide-scale extension of economic, political and defense collaboration.

Declaring that it can produce more than 700 "documented and investigated declarations of religious persecution" of Protestants and their missionaries in Colombia in the last three years, the Evangelical Confederation of Colombia has asked for conferences with the Colombian Government, the Commission on Human Rights of the United Nations and the Roman Catholic Church.

The credibility of previous testimony by Jack Gross, in which he identified twelve defendants as having had dealings with his brother, Harry, was shaken yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty-two suspended policemen charged with taking graft from the former bookmaker.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- President Truman called again today for some form of national health insurance and accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of advocating a policy that would virtually limit Government concern for the public's health to the "county poorhouse."

The New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association yesterday released their home program for the coming season. Joe Lapchick's charges have twenty-five dates, including eighteen at Madison Square Garden.

Commodity prices on the local exchanges moved generally higher yesterday. Trading volume was only moderate. Wool, sugar, vegetable oils, hides, lead and rubber were higher, while coffee, potatoes and zinc eased. Price trends in cocoa were irregular.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Radio and television spokesmen told a House of Representatives investigating subcommittee today that self-regulation was all the censorship those industries needed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Pint-size television helped run a railroad today. The tests were conducted by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the RCA Victor Division of Radio Corporation of America at the B. O.'s yard on the southwest side.

Describing existing conditions as a health menace, Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens planned yesterday to ask the Board of Estimate for funds -- whatever sum might be needed -- to open up and repair defects in the $185,679 sewer built by contractor Victor Clemente in Laurelton. Work would be done by another contractor.

New passenger ships for the route of the Moore-McCormack Lines from New York to the east coast of South America, which have been under discussion for some years, are approaching reality. Formal application for Government assistance in the construction of the vessels is expected to be made soon.

The Sherman anti-trust suit brought by the Independent Association of Women's Apparel Manufacturers against the Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., and other defendants was withdrawn yesterday before Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 220 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 19 killed, 199 wounded and 2 missing. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
Drawn games were played yesterday at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, by all three victors in Monday's opening round of the world chess championship zonal tournament, according to a report from Stockholm.

The clean-up man of the Moscow Reds has just poked a long foul down the left-field propaganda line. Swinging a big pen in the current issue of the Soviet magazine Smena, he writes that baseball as played in the United States is a "beastly battle, a bloody fight with mayhem and murder." It is also an American perversion of a traditional Russian village sport called lapta.
SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Herbert Lang, a farmer, came West the hard way -- fifteen days on a tractor -- and it was worth every minute of it, he said today.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the announcements made early today in Moscow indicated that the Chinese Communist negotiators would be returning to Peiping almost empty-handed. He expressed doubt that the Chinese could be pleased with an agreement that appeared to give them so little and failed to end Moscow's role in the Port Arthur naval base, previously due to conclude by the end of the year.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 16 -- The Twin Cities of St. Paul and Minneapolis gave Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower a reception today that he is not likely to forget for a long time.

Outsiders who are trying to understand and follow the course of the Anglo - Iranian oil negotiations have every reason to throw up their hands in bewilderment and helplessness. This is the proverbial oriental bargaining at its utmost refinement; this is the very quintessence of bargaining. Any one who wishes to study the technique will learn more from Premier Mossadegh of Iran than from all the other exponents of the art who ever lived.

Joseph Moreschi, president since 1926 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, attended the American Federation of Labor convention yesterday even though it was being held within this state.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 10 to 19 points net lower than on Monday.

No doubt the most important function of the Dancers of Bali, who opened an engagement of five weeks at the Fulton Theatre last night under the auspices of the Cultural Department of the Republic of Indonesia, is to make for better understanding between peoples.
A new maritime group known as the Industry Survey Committee announced yesterday it was conducting a survey of labor-management problems with the aim of improving future relations.

Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made on county-by-country and section-by-section estimates by newspaper editors and political writers:
BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- After a hiatus of six years, unity negotiations between the Protestant Episcopal Church and the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. are scheduled to be resumed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A two-run homer by Eddie Robinson, a pair of doubles by Rookie Rocco Krsnich and a cluster of three hits by Sherm Lollar helped the White Sox to a 7 -- 1 triumph tonight after the Athletics had won the opener 2 -- 1. The split kept Chicago in third place by a one and one-half-game margin.

Better volume in the women's apparel industry has encouraged blousemakers to continue their Parisian blouse promotion on an industry-wide basis, according to B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers.

Newspapers afford those who use premiums a perfect opportunity not only to pre-test them but, equally important, also to test their advertising presentation -- the copy, according to Douglas Taylor, vice president of J. P. McKinney Son, newspaper representatives. He spoke yesterday at a special session held in conjunction with New York Premium Show at the Astor Hotel.

Former Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson declared yesterday that he had resigned last March because Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and of the United Steel Workers of America, "exercises more control over this country than the President, the Congress we elected and the officers appointed under the Government."

First Army Headquarters announced yesterday that appreciable progress was being made in easing the military housing shortage in the First Army Area, which embraces New York, New Jersey and New England. Structures to relieve the shortage are being built by civilian contractors and financed by Federal Housing Authority mortgages.

ROSLYI, L. I., Sept. 16---A. public adjuster and adjusters representing fire insurance companies will start tomorrow to determine the total damage done by the office and warehouse fire Sunday morning at Ideal Insulators, Inc.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- In ships 100 tons and over, the United States merchant fleet lost more tonnage through various accidents last year than any other nation, Lloyds' Shipping Register reported today.

AN abundance of small game throughout the state will give New York hunters a more liberal season this fall, and even pheasant shooters will have an opportunity to spend more days afield as a result of improved populations of these birds in most areas.

Prices and volume are not the only things that have declined on the New York Stock Exchange lately. The cost of a seat on the exchange has also taken a dip. A membership was sold yesterday for $40,000, off $1,000 from the previous sale and the lowest price on a seat transaction since July 15, 1949.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Pope Pius has laid down a moral code for doctors and medical researchers that, he said, would act as a brake to confine research to areas where it would not cause damage.

President Truman's appointment of David L. Cole to succeed Cyrus S. Ching as Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service is an excellent choice. Mr. Ching, now in his seventy-sixth year, has done a conscientious job of industrial relations for the Government, after a long, honorable and notably successful career in private industry.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Five world records were set in harness racing today as the Grand Circuit opened at the Delaware County Fair. All records were for 2 and 3-year-old trotting and pacing fillies over a fast half-mile track.

Flowing lines marked the exclusive collection of ready-to-wear originals designed by Bernard Newman and presented yesterday by Bergdorf Goodman. The overall theme of simplicity was carried out with draping that gave the costumes timeless femininity

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Governor Dewey cited today "the-great contributions of the Jewish people to the material and spiritual growth of this nation" in a statement on the advent of the High Holy Days, which begin at sundown Friday, and the Jewish new year 5713.

Mortgage loans totaling $6,021,600 have been arranged by M. C. O'Brien, Inc., and David Shaw of Brooklyn, brokers, to finance the construction of two "213" cooperative apartment developments in Brooklyn, and a similar project in Queens.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Grain futures were under pressure much of the session today, with declines of fractions registered. But a brisk recovery in soybean futures brought out some support in wheat and the coarse grains, short profit taking being rather active in all pits.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 16 -- The government of Rajasthan State has been restrained by a court order from seizing feudal estates known as Jagirs under the land reform program. Repossession of six Jagirs, each having an annual income of $40,000 or more, was to have taken place today.

Those male citizens who could not find exactly the right farm this summer, or did not build or buy that new house, are in one respect quite lucky. They have been spared a disillusionment. They have been spared the decline and final loss of that one private room they were promised.

GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- The closing of doors to immigration throughout the world has forced those concerned with refugees to turn their attention almost entirely to their assimilation in Europe rather than emigration as a solution of this continuing human problem.

Gertrude Lawrence, British-born actress who died Sept. 6, left two-thirds of her estate in trust for the benefit of her daughter, Mrs. Pamela Gordon-Hawley of London, and the remainder outright to her husband, Richard Stoddard Aldrich. Her will was filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court. The petition formally valued the estate at "more than $20,000."

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 16 -- The United States will try at Eniwetok atoll this fall to detonate "an explosion greater than has ever been set off before," the acting chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee said today.

Holders of thrift and savings bank accounts who neglect to report their interest payments for tax purposes will have the chore performed for them by the banks under a new proposal by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.
ABOARD U. S. S. WISCONSIN, At Sea, Sept. 16 -- Wild seas and a roaring wind lashed the Allied fleet today as one phase of Exercise Mainbrace ended and two other phases began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Taxes levied on farm real estate in 1951, payable for the most part in 1952, were the highest on record, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The 1951 total of $774,596,000 represented the ninth consecutive year in which such taxes have increased.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania Boxing Commission today warned Al Weill, Rocky Marciano's manager, that he and Jersey Joe Walcott's manager must "get together" on a return bout contract or there will be no heavyweight title fight at Philadelphia next Tuesday night.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 16 -- Queen Juliana opened the session of the recently-elected Parliament today with a throne speech in which her newly-policy of cautiously increased public spending and private investment to combat growing unemployment, while seeking to maintain the dikes against inflation.

CAIRO, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Leaders of the Wafd (nationalist) party bowing to the demands of "Strong Man" Premier Mohammed Naguib, ordered a thorough reorganization of the party today for the first time since it was formed thirty-four years ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Milton Shubert has taken over control and operation of the Gayety Theatre and is changing its name to the Sam S. Shubert Memorial Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Ths Defense Production Administration today approved Federal tax benefits to assist eighty-one companies in undertaking plant expansion projects to cost $47,376,966.

The American Federation of Labor convention, preparing to hear Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower this morning, applauded an unbroken list of pro-Stevenson speakers and statements yesterday. Topping them was a message from President Truman warning the representatives of 8,098,302 union members that "special interests" were "grinding their axes for a fresh attack on labor" if the Republicans should win.
Irwin Keller has been named New York district manager of Chivas Brothers Import Corporation and William J. Cavanagh has been named state stores supervisor, covering Ohio, Michigan and Pennsylvania.

An 18-year-old Bronx sanitarium attendant who was discharged from the Army in 1950 because he was too young for service after seeing two months of action in Korea joined the Marines yesterday. He explained that he liked the way the Marines did things in Korea.

PORT ANGELES, Wash., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Two freighters crashed in fog off the Pacific Coast today, killing one seaman and ripping open the hulls of both ships. However, the Greek ship George D. Gratsos and the Japanese freighter Taikyu Maru steamed under their own power to near-by ports.

The first collection of millinery designs by Edward Tesche to be presented by Altman's took place Monday in the store's third floor millinery salon, where they will be carried exclusively in New York. This designer dispenses with superfluous trim for the most part, relying primarily on fabric manipulation for line and interest.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder of California, inactive in tournament play this year, upset Mervyn Rose of Australia today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

Despite improved prospects for settlement of the longshore labor dispute, importers here are taking no chances of a repetition of heavy losses suffered from the long dock tie-up last year. Precautionary measures, trade sources indicated yesterday, are being taken on the basis that a wildcat strike is still a possibility.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16 -- The Peiping People's Daily, leading organ of the Chinese Communist party, declared today that the Manchurian agreements negotiated by Premier Chou En-lai in Moscow were "vigorous proof" of the "constantly developing" and "impregnable" Chinese-Soviet alliance.

A syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of 140,000 shares of new 4.15 per cent $50 par value preferred stock of Duquesne Light Company at a price of $51.23 to yield 4.05 per cent. The stock was purchased by the banking group at public sealed bidding on Monday.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals pounded out six home runs, two of them consecutively by Solly Hemus, tonight while sweeping a twilight-night doubleheader from the Braves by 8 -- 6 and 5 -- 1. Both of Hemus' blows came in the first game as did four-baggers by Stan Musial and Larry Miggins. Dick Sisler and Hal Rice hit for the circuit in the second game.
The police will begin today a stepped-up drive against crime, particularly the muggings and rapes that have been occurring with increasing frequency in the city during the night-time hours.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Sept 16 (Reuters) -- Long files of British troops marched down the dock at Massawa to board a transport today, leaving Eritrea on its own, while in the capital the Eritrean flag waved over the new state for the first time.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh presented to Parliament today the terms under which he is prepared to settle the British-Iranian oil dispute, and announced that if Britain continued to hesitate by sending notes and continuing "economic pressure" he would feel free to sever diplomatic relations.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16 (UP) -- A state judge blocked an attempt today to place Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, on the Texas ballot as the candidate of the "Texas Democratic party."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- The political kettle boiled over in the movie colony late today when the Hollywood American Federation of Labor Film Council charged Warner Brothers Pictures with having "exacted" from studio employes financial contributions for the campaign of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Despondency over impending Army induction may have caused a New York youth to kill his fiancee and himself during a Las Vegas holiday before their marriage next week, authorities said today.

Manager Leo Durocher decided to experiment with some rookie talent just called up from Minneapolis and way stations at the Polo Grounds yesterday with results that proved discouraging to the Giants' flag hopes, to put it mildly.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 16 -- Bogota newspapers, unable for obvious reasons to comment on the Government's new move to eliminate all controversial matter from the press, have found a means to call public attention to the situation.

Traffic police coverage in New York is less than that given in a city of 8,000 inhabitants, according to statistics based on population ratio. Furthermore, in one of the most congested areas here, a single traffic policeman is on duty where five were assigned thirty-three years ago although the travel volume is many times greater.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Robin Roberts became the first National League pitcher since 1939 to win twenty-five games in one season when he hurled a five-hitter to lead the Phillies to a 4-2 victory over the Reds tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's speech today at a luncheon of the American Hospital Association:

CORNER BROOK, Nfld., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Sir Eric Bowater has announced the entire newsprint and pulp production of Bowater's Corner Brook and East Tennessee mills has been sold out for the next fifteen years.

Two swarthy, medium-sized men with more good luck than good judgment succeeded yesterday in robbing a Manufacturers Trust Company branch in the busy lower Bronx of $12,680. The hold-up, carried out at 155th Street and Third Avenue in a manner characterized by the police as "amateurish," was completed without a hitch in less than three minutes.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, returning from a European vacation yesterday, observed that the lack of Liberal party support "would undoubtedly affect" the chances of Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore in his battle for election to the United States Senate.

The tallest airport control tower in the world was formally dedicated and put into operation yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The structure, equivalent to an eleven-story building, is 150 feet high; with its ground radar antenna, 166 feet.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 16 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, in a written statement which he read today at a press conference at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, warned that atomic weapons were not sufficiently advanced to justify a slackening in the efforts to develop the ground forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

After a conference in Strasbourg night before last Premier De Gasperi of Italy and Foreign Secretary Eden of Great Britain issued a joint communication stating merely that they had talked chiefly of Mediterranean problems, with particular emphasis on Trieste.
