This was saying what goes without saying, and it is equally unnecessary to announce that the same issue will be the principal topic in the forthcoming conversations at Belgrade between Marshal Tito and Mr. Eden.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- If and when Premier Mossadegh formally presents to London the demands he proposed in his message to the Iranian Parliament today they almost certainly will be rejected.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- President Truman, in his address here today assailing those who oppose national health insurance, told the story of Mrs. Millard Fillmore and the first bathtub of the White House by way of illustrating the progress made in public health.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Bob McCullough was the offensive star for Columbia today as the 170-pound fullback broke through for several long runs on hand-offs from quarterback Mitch Price during an hour-long scrimmage at the Lions' pre-season football headquarters at Camp Columbia.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 16 -- Europe's constitution makers had before them today a preliminary report by five eminent jurists exploring the problems on the road to a European political federation and possible solutions for them.

At 8 o'clock this evening, the Playwrights Company will usher in its fifteenth season and twenty-ninth Broadway production with "Mr. Pickwick" at the Plymouth. It was there that the group began a significant career in the American theatre with the presentation of Robert E. Sherwood's Pulitzer Prize play, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois."

In a brilliantly staged and imaginative performance, the tenth annual presentation of the American Fashion Critics Awards was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel before more than 1,000 guests. The awards are sponsored by Coty and the winners are selected by more than seventy fashiong editors.

Although Governor Stevenson advises the country not to waste time in "tearful post-mortems" on what has happened in the Far East, new developments make it necessary to consider again events which are in part the consequences of a secret protocol which the United States approved at Yalta.

An extensive collection of fabrics aimed primarily at pleasing traditional tastes of all types was introduced yesterday by F. Schumacher Co. at its trade showroom, 535 Madison Avenue. Available there through decorators, the collection includes textiles from Italy, France, Western Germany, Denmark, Sweden and England, as well as fabrics woven at the company's New Jersey mill.

PARIS, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The monthly balance sheet of the European Payments Union disclosed today that Britain has all but elimininated its huge monthly deficits and that wealthy Belgium has become a debtor for the first time.

Many reservations have been made for the dinner dance next Wednesday at the Sherry-Netherland that will open the Carnaval Room for the season and also benefit the Southampton (L. I.) Hospital Association. The proceeds will be used to purchase new equipment for the hospital.

There are not many harder ways to forge a virtuoso's career than to try to be a solo 'cellist. Richard Kay, 23-year-old 'Brooklyn-born 'cellist, evidently is seeking to lick the problem by combining solo and ensemble work. Recently he has been touring with Mishel Piastro and the Longines Symphonette as first 'cellist and soloist, and last night he made his second Town Hall appearance with the help of an orchestra conducted discreetly by Mr. Piastro.

Approval of the application by the New York City Housing Authority of a state loan of $19,450,000 for clearance of a rapidly deteriorating slum area and the development of a low-rent housing development was announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

Pittsburgh, Pa., sold yesterday $4,900,000 of improvement bonds due from Oct. 1, 1953 to 1972, to a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation at a bid of 100.299 for interest of 2 1/4 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.1 per cent to 2.35 per cent. Bonds unsold at the close yesterday were estimated at $1,657,000.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Navy and Rutgers scrimmaged through a regulation game behind closed fences today. No score was kept and no statistics were released.

LONDON, Sept. 16. (AP) -- The late Walter Owen Briggs, Detroit industrialist, left an estate in England valued at $116,583.60, his executors announced today. The head of the Briggs Manufacturing Company in the United States and di/rector Of Briggs Motor Bodies Ltd., Dagenham; England, died Jan. 17i at the age of 74. He left the Frans! I-Ials painting, "The Porrait of s Man," to the Detroit Museum of LXr. t.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 16 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President, declared tonight that the greatest threat to the American Constitution was communism, but warned that constitutional freedoms also were endangered by anti-Communist "irresponsibles."

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, the defending titleholder, and 21-year-old Roslyn (Cookie) Swift from Glen Oaks, last year's runner-up, each fired an 80 to tie for the lead in the opening round of the 54-hole Long Island Women's Golf Association medal-play championship today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The political calendar at Republican National Headquarters proclaims "forty-eight days to election" and the speaking schedule for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, released today, puts him virtually on a speech-a-day basis for the duration of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Textile Workers of America, C. I. O., lost an important decision today in a fight to protect its position against the inroads of the rival United Textile Workers A. F. L.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 17 -- The dismissal from important posts in the French Communist party of two long-time leaders, Andre Marty and Charles Tillon, was announced today in the party organ L'Humanite.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today there was no present indication of a marked decline in national production or income in 1953 but that, "barring any international upsets," the need for most economic controls would have passed by the end of that year.

With the testimony of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, the holdover August Kings County grand jury started yesterday an investigation into "method of procedure" in the prosecution of cases in the Magistrates' Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP)Admiral Jonas H. Ingram was buried today while his dolleagues in war and football paid 'final !tribute. The admiral, one of l.avy's i biggest football names and World i War II commander of the South Atlantic Fleet, was laid to rest in I near-by Arlington National CemeI tery with full military honors.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol, who won the title in 1947 and 1950, took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the New Jersey Seniors Golf Association championship. Lindgrove scored a 38, 39 -- 77 over the Essex Fells Country Club course and led Robert Nash of Plainfield by a shot.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -- The creation of a high-level bipartisan council including persons of Cabinet rank, but who would be free of bureaucratic responsibilities, to plan long-range United States foreign policy was proposed here today by John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy adviser, at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

Mayor Impellitteri set aside today as Carl Schurz Day in honor of the arrival here 100 years ago of the Civil War general, statesman and diplomat. General Schurz, who also became United States Senator from Missouri, Secretary of the Interior and an editor, landed here Sept. 17, 1852, as a political refugee from Germany.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower may be losing ground with the intellectuals and the independents -- as many persons on his own campaign train think -- but he still is an immensely popular figure in the villages and cities of the Middle West.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company made known yesterday that it had arranged for the private sale of about $23,000,000 of 3 3/8 per cent, first mortgage bonds, of which it already has taken down $16,000,000.
The James Club, an after-hours drinking establishment at 38 East Sixty-fifth Street, was raided early yesterday and its owner arrested on a charge of selling liquor without a license.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16 -- The Belgrade radio broadcast tonight a statement rejecting the offer of Italian Premier Alcide De Gasperi to hold a plebiscite in the Free Territory of Trieste as a solution of the dispute between Italy and Yugoslavia.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- By a unanimous vote of the London critics today, Claire Bloom was acclaimed, "A new and enchanting Juliet" after last night's opening performance of Hugh Hunt's production of "Romeo and Juliet" at the Old Vic Theatre.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- It will be a warclub against a rapier when the former middleweight champion, Rocky Graziano, tries to end the unbeaten record of the welterweight, Chuck Davey, at Chicago Stadium tomorrow night.

The six-story building with fifty-two apartments and three stores at 1988 Newbold Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Jack Resnick, operator, from the Wyoming Realty Corporation, clients of John T. McCormick Jr., lawyer. The property was held at $175,000, according to John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker in the sale.

Sales of Montgomery Ward Co. in the six months ended July 31 declined 4.1 per cent from the same period of the previous year but earnings dropped 31 per cent, according to the semiannual statement for publication today.
OTTAWA, Sept. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian farmers may reap a 675,000,000-bushel wheat crop this year, biggest in history, the Bureau of Statistics estimated today.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept 17 -- Massachusetts' voters, stirred by the recent calling of a special session of the Legislature to wipe out increased pension benefits for its membership, dated back to 1947, turned out yesterday in close to record numbers for the state primary despite the absence of contests for top offices.

An informal account by Sir Arthur Grimble of his first years in the British Colonial Service will be published by Morrow next Wednesday under the title "We Chose the Islands: A Six Year Adventure in the Gilberts." The account, beginning in 1914, when the author arrived at Ocean Island with his young bride, presents a number of adventures the author experienced.

We stopped yesterday at the Maison E. H. Glass to find that interesting delicacy shop at 15 East Forty-seventh Street had added a few kitchenwares to its stock of good food. What caught our eye especially was a collection of receptacles from Holland in which one can both cook and serve -- and so save on dishwashing!

Despite Mayor Impellitteri's call on Monday for a prompt start on the $500,000,000 Second Avenue subway and related transit improvements, the Board of Estimate yesterday postponed action for three months pending a re-examination of costs.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The vital balance between salt and water in the working of nerves and muscles and also in the heart, lungs and brain has the central theme of the second session of the International Congress of Internal Medicine held here today.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock ruled yesterday that the Government had presented a prima facie case of conspiracy in the trial of fifteen secondary Communist party leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Deposits in federally insured banks -- the large majority of all United States banks -- increased 7 per cent in the year ended June 30.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- Bob Porterfield, who has been in and lost as many photo finishes as Jockey Conn McCreary, and who now answers to the nickname of "Hard Luck," was beaten by the Indians, 4 -- 3, tonight. This time the defeat came in the tenth inning and a scratch single and a fluke double, both after two out, were responsible.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 17 -- Six American Marine Panther jets returning from a mission in Korea crashed into the side of a mountain last week and all were lost, it became known yesterday.

The Dodgers finally increased their lead over the Giants by beating the Pirates, 4 -- 2, at Ebbets Field last night before 13,422 fans. The victory, coupled with the Giants' afternoon loss, gave the Brooks a four-game margin with only ten to play for each club.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Japan is ready to conclude a peace treaty with the Soviet Union any time so long as the terms are the same or better than the San Francisco Treaty, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Lumber dealers, piano makers and furniture manufacturers appealed to the Government today to ban the trade name "Philippine mahogany" for the Philippine lumber sold in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A State Department spokesman said today that it could be "assumed" that the Soviet Union would continue its use of the Changchun Railroad in Manchuria despite the announcement by the Soviet and Chinese Communist Governments that the line would be returned to China's control.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech at the Minnesota State Capitol today:

One car of a six-car B. M. T. subway train bound for Brooklyn jumped the tracks and struck a concrete wall at 6:47 P. M. yesterday in an underground approach to the Manhattan Bridge from the Canal Street station in Manhattan.

When the thirty-eighth annual show of the American Dahlia Society opened at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon the flowers entered in 275 competitive classes represented a triumph over weather. In spite of hot summer days that prevailed at crucial times of growth, specimens as varied and richly colored as usual lined the tables in the Colonnades Ballroom, Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street near Seventh Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Essie M. carried Meyers and Lewis' silks to an upset victory in the featured Pen and Pencil Purse at the Atlantic City race track this afternoon by beating six other 3-year-old fillies in the mile and a sixteenth event.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- The application of the new Arab state of Libya for membership in the United Nations was vetoed today by Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, who insisted that the Security Council should agree instead to his proposal for the en bloc admission of fourteen applicants, including Libya.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,375, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

The Board of Estimate has decided to stop, look and listen for three months before ordering a start of construction on the Second Avenue Subway. In a sense this may be considered a rebuff to the advice of the previous day by Mayor Impellitteri, who chose to regard a prior decision by the Board of Estimate, and ratification by the voters, as a mandate to proceed regardless of the city's financial crisis.

The stock market staged a mild and selective rally yesterday and closed irregularly higher after having registered new lows of the movement early in the session. Chrysler and du Pont joined the rail and oil issues in the recovery effort.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Tex Coulter returned to the New York Giants football camp today as the team prepared for the Polo Grounds meeting Thursday night with the Los Angeles Rams.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The stock markets were quieter today than for a long time. However, the undertone remained firm.

Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas, wife of the former Ambassador to Great Britain, received a citation yesterday for her work in improving intergroup understanding at a meeting of the Manhattan-Westchester Region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

A special Air Force team began yestherday a ninety-day survey of 10,000 local Air Force Reservists. The aim is to bring their records up to date to determine availability for service in all-out mobilization.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The International Cotton Textile Conference will open here tomorrow with British public opinion sharply divided on the policy to be adopted toward the key issue of mounting Japanese competition in Commonwealth markets.
ROME, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Church of Christ promised today that next Sunday worship services would be held, despite a police ban, in the twenty-two Italian cities where it operates.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Japan will seek American aid to help her get a bigger share in the South Asian textiles market, the Financial Times said today. In a dispatch from Osaka, Japan, the Financial Times said Japan would make her bid for bigger markets at the Textile Conference here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The three top - ranking women at Republican National Committee headquarters -- Mrs. Roy F. Priest, director of the Women's Division, Miss Bertha Adkins, its executive director, and Mrs. Donald Arth, cochairman of the Young Republicans -- will leave Thursday for the convention of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs at St. Louis.

The Parents-Teachers Association of Public School 19, Fourteenth Street and First Avenue, urged yesterday that the city acquire a site in the area for a new school and replace the over-crowded and antiquated existing structure.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Farm Credit Administration experts raised a caution signal today and called for thorough study in the face of growing pressure for long term production loans.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 -- A new chemical that promises to make possible the preservation of blood for considerably longer periods than the present limit of three weeks was described here today before the national meeting of the American Chemical Society.
LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and France today completed the draft of a note rejecting Soviet terms for a Big Four conference on Germany's future, official sources said.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Bill Miller, a fire-balling left-hander who might have been pitching for the Giants this afternoon had not the fortunes of the game altered his course early in his career, brought the Yankees a stride nearer to that fourth straight flag today by spinning another slick performance against his pet "cousins," the Tigers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- Delegates to the United Electrical Workers' convention today unanimously adopted a resolution calling for united labor action to ward off "an attack by big corporations to rob working people of all benefits achieved during the past twenty years."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A special mission recommended today that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development adopt a $59,000,000 minimum investment program for Nicaragua over the next five years to promote health and education, transportation, agriculture, industry and power facilities.
HONOLULU, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A typhoon with gusts up to 160 miles an hour hit Wake Island suddenly yesterday, driving churning seas across the whole island and smashing nearly every building there.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Red Sox pounded out fourteen hits tonight to whip the Browns, 11 -- 7, Maury McDermott gained his tenth victory of the season, though he had to have help from Ellis Kinder in the late innings when the Browns threatened.

The fine assemblage of fall and winter styles in Bloomingdale's Green Room is indeed outstanding. The press had a preview of these fashions yesterday morning. Not only were the clothes of excellent quality, but they were set off by smart ensembling, from hats that sparkled like jewels, to bags specially made for the store in Europe, and chic umbrellas, many of them imported from Paris.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 16 -- Maryland, unbeaten in fifteen games since 1950 and a decisive victor over Tennessee in the Sugar Bowl last January, has been tabbed the strongest college football team east of the Alleghanies, if not in the entire nation.

A portrait of Pope Pius XII, recently completed from life by Elmer Westley Greene Jr., Boston artist, was presented yesterday to Cardinal Spellman by Col. Robert P. Marshall, former Military Governor of Northwest Italy.

Governor Stevenson, not precisely a novice in politics, engaged in the following colloquy at a press conference on Monday when asked if he would speak with favor of a well-known fellow-Democrat, Senator McCarran of Nevada:

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had better watch his step in criticizing Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, his Democratic opponent for the Presidency because of his campaign humor, because the Governor is merely employing a technique "regularly used" by that earlier Republican leader, Abraham Lincoln.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced tonight it has asked its bondholders to approve issuance of $20,000,000 more in bonds to pay for added facilities.

POMONA, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Starting a major campaign tour, Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican candidate for Vice President, listed foreign policy, domestic communism, the high cost of living and governmental corruption tonight as the prime issues of the national election and the ones he woud stress during a ten-day swing, mainly through the Far West.

The Associated Dry Goods Association, which operates eight large department stores, including James McCreery Co. and Lord Taylor, reported yesterday increased sales for the quarter, six and twelve months ended last August 2 over the corresponding periods of the previous year.

Two distinguished visiting foreign theatrical groups, the Greek Royal Theatre of Athens and the French repertory company headed by Madeleine Renaud and Jean-Louis Barrault, have settled on their New York opening dates and show places.

ATHENS, Sept. 17 -- Seventy-nine of the children abducted into Yugoslavia before Yugoslavia broke with the Soviet Union, during a time when the Greek Communist -inspired guerrillas were at war against the Athens Government, will be returned, according to an announcement made today by the Greek Red Cross.
Exceptional measures to check the wave of muggings and rapes were undertaken by the police yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 17 -- The designing team of the Park sisters-in-law is being watched with more than a little interest by buyers as well as the fashion press.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 -- Test tube studies on the new anti-tuberculosis drugs indicate the advisability of administering them in combination with definite amounts of other chemicals known to inhibit the growth of the tuberculosis germ, according to a report presented here today at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Pravda asserted today that "Japanese militarism" now had become a real rather than a potential threat to peace in the Far East.

The Russian Government has purchased part of the former Nathan L. Miller estate, including a thirty-eight-room mansion, in Upper Brookville, L. I. It will be the residence of the chief of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Continuing its efforts to bring down prices, the Cabinet today approved plans outlined by Jean-Marie Louvel, Minister of Industry and Commerce, to bring some order into the often chaotic and cumbersome system of distribution existing in France.

In its first public financing transaction since the Federal securities laws went into effect in the Thirties, the Standard Oil Company of Indiana is offering to its shareholders today rights to subscribe for $139,647,000 of thirty-year debentures convertible into common stock.

From casuals to formals, Macy's showed imported fashions, yesterday non, at the Carnival Boom of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. It was a duet show with originals and duplicates, sometimes in exact replicas, again with the translations in colors that the stylists think more adaptable to American tastes.

Top officials of the furniture and bedding industries called on several railroads yesterday for a 10 to 20 per cent freight rate reduction in less than carload shipments of many household items. The request was made at a special hearing held at 1 Park Avenue by a joint classification committeee representing roads in different parts of the country.

Tom Fool and Teddy Atkinson, unawed by the combination of Mark-Ye-Well and Eddie Arcaro, took the Jerome Handicap at Belmont Park with little trouble yesterday. Teddy guided the son of Menow to a seven-length triumph in the one-mile fixture as Mark-Ye-Well was beaten for the place by the rank outsider, the Saxon Stable's Marcador.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the American Federation of Labor convention yesterday that he opposed repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act but favored amendments to eliminate provisions that could be used to smash unions.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Felix Bocchicchio, manager of the heavyweight champion, Jersey Joe Walcott, insisted today that he would call off the fight with Rocky Marciano at Philadelphia Tuesday if Marciano and his manager did not sign a new return-bout contract by weigh-in time.

Allan S. Haywood, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in an address to the convention of the C. I. O. United Paperworkers of America, which has endorsed the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket declared yesterday that labor support of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and the Democrats was a "necessity."

Pipe cleaners, which long have been among the relatively few items that have continued to sell for a nickel, at long last are victims of inflation. The handy items, which can serve as hair curlers or for hanging Christmas tree ornaments in a pinch, as well as to curb over-ripe pipe aroma, have had only the one price for years, 5 cents for a package of twenty-four or thereabouts.

The stock market continued the recovery effort yesterday which started on Tuesday, but again the rally was selective. The list closed irregularly higher in slower and narrower trading. The rail and chemical sections, as well as Chrysler, were the strongest features, while the steel and oil groups and General Motors lagged.

Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the finance committee of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday that a drive for $5 subscriptions to help elect Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic nominees for President and Vice President, would be started on Oct. 8 and continue for eight days

Jack Gross, younger brother of Harry Gross, yesterday named fifty-five policemen who, he said, were involved in the bookmaking operations of the convicted gambler. He made the charge at the departmental trial of thirty-two suspended plainclothes men in the Criminal Courts Building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that The Boston Post had committed an unfair labor practice in refusing to furnish the C. I. O. Newspaper Guild of Boston, Local 32, with complete payroll data during contract bargaining.

HONOLULU, Sept. 17 -- A succession of airliners from battered Wake Island landed today at International Airport and Hickam Air Force Base here bringing evacuees from the coral atoll some 2,400 miles west of the Hawaiian Islands which was lashed by a typhoon on Monday.

It appeared yesterday that the Democratic factional fight in Brooklyn, which started over nominations for the state Supreme Court in the Second Assembly District, again will result in an appeal to the courts for settlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Two fledgling thespians, one an 18-year-old actress, the other a boy of 9, today were handed roles in new pictures by Paramount and M-G-M that may well start them on the road to movie stardom.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Home runs by Stan Lopata and Willie Jones helped the Phillies gain a 7-4 victory over the Reds tonight after Cincinnati had taken an early lead on the strength of a shaky start by the winning pitcher, Karl Drews.

The city's proposed 2,400-family slum-clearance project at Hunts Point in the Bronx was defended yesterday by Construction Coordinator Robert Moses as "ideal for housing purposes." His defense, made in a letter to Mayor Impellitteri, was in reply to an attack on the project made last Sunday by Paul Windels, president of the Regional Plan Association.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- A 31-year-old test pilot shattered every known nonstop distance record for helicopters today with a flight of 1,234 miles from Fort Worth, Tex., to Niagara Falls. Elton J. Smith spun his Bell model 47D-1 to the ground at Niagara Falls airport at 6.38:30 P. M. Eastern standard time here after a flight of 12 hours, 47 minutes and 30 seconds.
Irving Brown, American Federation of Labor representative in Europe, declared yesterday that the "real danger spot in the world" was shifting from Berlin to the Middle East.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The former chief of Binghamton's vice squad and nine gamblers, accused in a grand jury's gambling inquiry, won new trials today when the Appellate Division reversed their convictions. The tribunal decided 3 -- 2, that the ten men had not received a fair trial in Broome County Court last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Tom Robbins of Winged Foot, the national seniors' golf champion, took the lead in the first round of the eighteenth annual Westchester Seniors' Championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today. Robbins, who has won the event for the last four years, tallied a 2-over-par 72.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium, president of the Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community formed to plan a common political authority for six European nations, said today there were no grounds for competition between this "little Europe" and the fourteen-nation Council of Europe or for pessimism over the future of the latter.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Allen H. Smith's Piedmont Lass defeated Mrs. E. E. Dale Shaffer's odds-on Sweet Patootie by a nose in the $10,000 added Margate Handicap at the Atlantic City race track today.

Manager Billy Meyer threw the best he had against the league-leading Dodgers yesterday, starting with Howie Pollet and relieving with Murry Dickson, and the result was disastrous for the Brooks. The Bucs beat them, 4 -- 1, and the Brooklyn lead over the Giants dropped back to three games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Truman denounced today the technique of injecting the "big lie" into politics in order to "reap personal or partisan advantage."

" So the Russian, Z. Y. Slonimsky, invented the telegraph before Morse and the Russians also invented 'beisbol,'" said Walter P. Marshall, president of Western Union, yesterday. He pointed to the new facsimile transmitter he was demonstrating and added:

Philip Marshall Brown in his Sept. 1 letter to THE TIMES leaves the impression that Southerners heatedly argue the merits of Congressional acts as measured by the divining rod of Jeffersonian democracy. I hasten to ask: Is it possible that a section of the country so bare in educational facilities has a citizenry so scholastic that they are able to navigate the mazes of Jeffersonian political thinking?

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, arrived today for a four-day visit with the Yugoslav Government during which Yugoslavia's relations with the Western powers, her position in Southeastern Europe and her dispute with Italy concerning Trieste will be reviewed.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 18 -- The number of Soviet-designed MIG fighters shot down over Korea by United States Sabre jet pilots during September rose to forty-seven yesterday. The leading jet ace of the United States, Maj. Frederick Blesse, claimed the day's single victim, raising his personal record of MIG's destroyed to eight.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's managers plan to call on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin to campaign actively for the Republican ticket on the Communist-in-Government issue.

Today's new film is "The Snows of Kilimanjaro," a Twentieth Century-Fox production based on the short story by Ernest Hemingway, which is re-opening the Rivoli Theatre. Henry King directed the Technicolor drama from a script by Casey Robinson. Darryl F. Zanuck was the producer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Out of many suggestions about the speech he should make to the convention of the American Federation of Labor today, each hotly urged and hotly opposed, General Eisenhower chose the "middle way." But because he said flatly that he is in favor of amending instead of repealing the Taft-Hartley Act the audience, composed of the leaders of one branch of organized labor, found him unsatisfactory as a candidate for President.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington mystery man in the income tax scandals uncovered by a House Ways and Means subcommittee, moved yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to halt further appearances by him before the local additional Federal grand jury investigating income tax frauds.
ABOARD EISENHOWER SPECIAL, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower -- issued aboard his train in his absence -- on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year:
Cocoa, coffee and vegetable oils provided most of the action in commodity futures trading yesterday. Most other commodities had minor volume or inconsequential price movements.
LINDEN. N. J., Sept, 17 -- The City Council here today authorized City Treasurer Charles S. Ialvano to sell $1,000,000 in improvement bonds at a public sale at 11 A. M. Oct. 30, at City Hall.
Robert M. Cornforth has joined W. M. Barnes Company, Los Angeles, as vice president in charge of sales.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines and Fred Fisher of Seattle scored the biggest upset of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today by eliminating the United States national doubles championship team of Vie Seixas and Mervyn Rose.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Acting President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez told the Inter-American Press Association last night the Government had ordered an investigation into failure of the police to act with required "promptness and energy" against a mob that partially destroyed two Liberal party newspapers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Construction work at three state institutions in Dutchess County was suspended today as the result of a protest by a laborer's union against the employment of mental patients on State Department of Public Works maintenance projects.

Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made on county-by-county and section-by-section estimates by newspaper editors and political writers:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Truman conducted ceremonies at the White House today formally exchanging documents with Mohammed Ali, Ambassador of Pakistan, that effected a $15,000,000 Export-Import Bank loan to the Parkistani Government.

The fourth of this season's Interval Concerts will be given tonight in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program, devoted to music, poetry and songs of Negro life, will offer the world premiere of "Heart of Harlem" by Langston Hughes and Duke Ellington.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- Seven corporations and nine individuals were indicted today by a Federal grand jury here on charges of exercising a monopoly in restraint of trade in the rendering industry in this area.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in his speech yesterday at the American Federation of Labor convention, revealed that he had played a hitherto undisclosed role in behind-the-scenes maneuvers to halt the railroad strike of May, 1946, which crippled the nation's economy for forty-eight hours before it was settled temporarily.

Donald C. Cook, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested yesterday that mutual funds might now participate in a limited way in providing capital for worthwhile business ventures in the early stages of development.

The rights and duties of United States citizenship were discussed and extolled yesterday by native-born, naturalized and prospective citizens. Ceremonies were conducted on the steps of the Subtreasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets, where the Sons of the American Revolution held traditional Constitution Day services; at the Hebrew Sheltering and Imgrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, and at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty- ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested eighteen more Communist party leaders today and charged them with conspiring to teach and advocate overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- House investigators of alleged immoral and other harmful influences of radio and television programs were told by an industry spokesman today that statistics of the Federal Bureau of Investigation proved that television had not contributed to the increase in crimes.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The stock markets started a new bookkeeping account on a dull note with prices lower in most sections.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 17 -- Following is the text of a statement issued here today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois on the forthcoming Jewish New Year:

NORWICH, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, called tonight for a shift from a foreign policy of containment "dictated by the Kremlin" to a policy of "liberation" that would inspire resistance to communism among freedom-loving peoples throughout the world.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 17 -- Navy approaches its 1952 football campaign with a revised offense, a reconstructed line and refreshed hopes in the face of a lightened schedule that includes only some, instead of almost all, of the nation's leading powers.

Among the outstanding fashions in the collection of Parisian imports shown yesterday at Hattie Carnegie, 42 East Forty-ninth Street, were the Balenciaga designs, with their air of casual looseness through the long bodices, and the tweed suits with their chic semi-fitted jackets.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Breaking away from a 10-10 tie at the half, the Green Bay Packers tonight pushed touchdowns across in the third and fourth periods to down the Pittsburgh Steelers, 23 -- 10.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 17 -- Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas told Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "surrender" to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had changed a rather widespread feeling in the country that it made very little difference which of the two Presidential candidates was elected in November.

WEST NEWTON, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Four high-school students were killed and thirty-nine others injured, eight of them critically, this morning when a Pittsburgh and Lake Erie freight train struck a school bus in a fog at an unguarded crossing at Collinsburg, a coalmining community about twenty-five miles southeast of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- J. Howard McGrath, whom President Truman removed last April as Attorney General, defended the Department of Justice today against charges that it had obstructed a St. Louis grand jury inquiry into tax fraud cases.

Lindy Remigino of Manhattan College and the New York Athletic Club last night won the meritorious award of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. at the annual meeting of the body at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. The award goes yearly to an athlete registered and competing in A. A. U. events and registered with the Metropolitan Association.

In celebrating its 127th anniversary, Arnold Constable presented a fall fashion show yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Illustrating the most important fashion trends, costumes were chosen from both the California and New York markets, as well as some adapted from the French couture.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 17 to 22 points net yesterday.

ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Annual operating revenues of utilities in New York State soared about $600,000,000 in the 1947-51 period -- about half from higher consumer rates and the rest from business growth.

An increase last week of 666,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 117,296,000 barrels, compared with 116,630,000 a week earlier and 124,135,000 a year ago.

MANILA, Sept. 17 -- War veterans, military leaders and diplomatic observers from eight nations of Southeast Asia gathered here today for an exchange of views on how to defeat communism. It was the first meeting of its kind in this part of the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Welterweight Chuck Davey, always a moving target, dodged the dynamite fists of Rocky Graziano for ten rounds tonight and punched out a upset unanimous decision over the aging former middleweight champion.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Col Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol posted a strong bid for his third New Jersey Golf Association seniors' championship today when he scored his second straight 77 for a 154 total at the Essex Fells Country Club.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Ray Graham of the host club and James Paul of Piping Rock shot 34, 33 -- 67 to win the low gross prize in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day best-ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Industry, more than Government, must take the initiative in attacking the threat of "creeping" materials shortages facing this and other free industrial nations if security from communism and continuing economic progress are to be realized, it was asserted yesterday by William S. Paley, former chairman of the President's Materials Policy Commission.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The Yankees brought their final tour of the season through the West to a triumphant close today. They rolled up eleven hits, touched off a five-run explosion in the fourth that routed Virgil Trucks, who only a few weeks ago had harpooned them with a no-hitter, and went on to crush the Tigers, 12 -- 3, in their farewell meeting with the last-place Bengals before 6,879.
The State of Pennsylvania yesterday designated Oct. 7 for the sale of $80,000,000 of tax anticipation notes. The notes will be dated Oct. 14, 1952 and will come due on May 29, 1953.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Christine Cromwell Hoffman, member of the Dodge motor family, disclosed in a court action today she had borrowed $1,345,000 a week ago against an anticipated $5,000,000 inheritance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Crop reports were too favorable for the bulls in grain futures today, and with prospects for a continuation of ideal conditions the rest of the week, there was little confidence on the part of buyers.

For the first time in six national elections, The Commonweal, a magazine edited by Roman Catholic laymen, announced yesterday its suuport of a Presidential candidate, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- John Foster Dulles asserted here today that this country's air superiority could be used to propagandize the Communists into ending the war in Korea.

Dipping back into the random humors of the Pickwick Papers, Stanley Young has brought us a thoroughly delightful play. He calls it "Mr. Pickwick," adding that it is "freely drawn from incidents" in the original work of Charles Dickens. Acted with extravagance and fondness by a most ingratiating company, it was put on last evening at the Plymouth before an audience that was seeing the first genuinely professional work of the season.

Plans have been virtually completed by Pressed Steel Car Company for the acquisition of the Axelson Manufacturing Company and the Umpqua Plywood Corporation within the next sixty days, according to John I. Snyder, president of Pressed Steel Car.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Two main ideas for dealing with the present world-wide recession in the cotton textile trade -- by expanding markets and avoiding wasteful competition -- were presented today at the opening session of the International Cotton Textile Conference in London.

Stockholders of the General Bronze Corporation at a special meeting yesterday at Garden City, L. I., approved amendments to the employe profit-sharing plan and trust agreement to permit the trust to invest generally in corporate securities, including those of General Bronze.

On Sept. 7 you published an article by your correspondent Harold Callender entitled "Europeans Puzzled as Campaign Develops." I should like to take issue with and comment on what your correspondent calls "Europe" and the European reaction to the Presidential campaign as it involves foreign policy issues.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,376 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday Korean time:

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Sept. 17 -- They are growing them big at Mount Hermon School these days. Of the thirty-nine boys trying out for varsity football berths, nineteen are at least six feet tall, and the head coach, Bill Rineer, the former West Chester Teachers star who later played with the Philadelphia Eagles, is wondering how this height can help him the most.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Sept. 17 -- One of the major challenges of Methodism is to provide churches in suburban areas where churches do not now exist, delegates to the annual New Jersey Methodist Conference were told tonight.

In an age when the manufacture of elaborate and costly weapons consumes large proportions of national budgets it is interesting to note with what economy people arm themselves when they are aroused to attack or defense in some violent and relatively local struggle which does not call into play tanks, bazookas, flame throwers or similar formal military equipment.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower put in yesterday a seventeen-hour work day that began with his arrival in campaign headquarters in the Commodore Hotel at 7:25 A. M. and ended after midnight (New York time) in Davenport, Iowa.

The fourth act of Shostakovich's seldom-heard opera, "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk," will be presented on Oct. 31 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as part of the Musicians Emergency Fund twentieth anniversary celebration, it was announced yesterday by Mme.

The fashion press had a preview yesterday of the import collection that Gimbels will show at the luncheon hour on Monday in the Grand Ball Room of the Plaza Hotel. This well-selected group of styles represents leading couture houses of France, Italy, Spain and England.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 17 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship loomed as a four-way battle during the final round as the four leading players were bunched within three strokes following thirty-six holes at The Glen Head Country Club today.
Local shopkeepers who illegally stuff their store rubbish into the city's wire trash baskets will be the target of 100 Sanitation Department inspectors in a new city-wide anti-litter drive.
Extensive revision of the City Charter as proposed by City Council President Rudolph Halley is unnecessary, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday at a City Hall press conference.

The E. H. Harriman Gold Medal awards for the best safety record last year among the nation's railroads were presented last night at a dinner held-here at the Hotel Ambassador. For the best record among the larger railroads, the award went to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company.
ROME, Sept. 17 -- A high temperature, due apparently to a gastric affection, obliged Pope Pius to take to his bed today and cancel all audiences until further notice.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, with 41, 42 -- 83, and Mrs. Charles Spalding of Round Hill, at 42, 41 -- 83, jointly led a field of sixty-nine players on the Winged Foot Golf Club's par 75 West Course in today's Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament for Class A members.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- The United Electrical Workers Union, independent, which claims 325,000 members, refused today to endorse either major political party, but decided to take an active part in the election of Congressional and state candidates.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 17 -- Premier Marshal Tito, Yugoslavia's 60-year-old dictator, was married last June to a 28-year-old woman major in his army, it was revealed today.

After an interval of five years, the Rodgers and Hammerstein "Allegro" does not grow in stature. St. John Terrell is restaging it this week with a revised second act in his gay Music Circus in Lambertville, N. J. You may recall that the second act was the one most seriously criticized.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Following is Governor Adlai E. Stevenson's itinerary through Oct. 4, as announced today by the Governor's campaign headquarters:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, the defending champion, and three other strong favorites gained the semi-final round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association open championship today at the Essex County Country Club.

Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils reported yesterday that he was inquiring into every contractor and contract involved in the $9,000,000 sewer network in Laurelton, Queens. Preliminary investigation already has shown "pertinent and interesting" data on construction and inspection practices, he said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 10:
LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) J. Arthur Rank, British film producer, said today he was not worried about competition from television.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft opened his nineteen-state campaign for the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, on home ground tonight before an audience of 2,000 friendly but unenthusiastic Ohio Republicans.

SENNELAGER, Germany, Sept. 17 -- The Atlantic powers have not yet attained the minimum strength necessary to defend Western Europe and civilian authorities must see that they do, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, declared today.

Mills weaving rayon, acetate and other synthetic textiles will show good recovery in the third and fourth quarters in both volume and profits, textile suppliers predicted yesterday. A fuller evaluation for the year will be ascertained by the end of October, they pointed out, but goods are now moving well in both the manufacturing and wholesale distributing levels.

New issues of $100 preferred stock and common stock of Columbus Southern Ohio Electric Company valued at more than $16,400,000 were placed on the market after the close here yesterday by an investment banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

THULE, Greenland, Sept. 17 (UP) Twelve men, including a United States captain, were stranded today atop an 8,000-foot Greenland ice cap where their British Air Force Hastings transport crashed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- This country's position in the field of atomic weapons was described before the American Bar Convention today as one of "great strength," both absolutely and in comparison with that of Russia, by Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

ROOSEVELT, L. I., Sept. 17 --Headquarters and front line operations in the defensive and offensive battle in Nassau County against the mosquito were visited here today by a group of New Jersey's top mosquito fighting officials.
Big Jim Hearn hurled his first shut-out of the campaign against the Cubs yesterday at the Polo Grounds to keep the Giants slightly better off in the pennant race than they were this time a year ago.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 17 -- Two Texas Church of Christ representatives will go to Washington Saturday to lodge protests with the State Department over the Italian Government's closing down of twenty-two branches of the church in Italy, it was announced here today.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., called on the General Motors Corporation today to implement a five-year contract because even the historic accord between the union and the company had failed to keep pace with the rise of inflation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Harvard College will provide more than $900,000 in financial aid to some 1,745 students during the academic year that opened this week, Wilbur J. Bender, dean of admissions and financial aids, said today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- James Bernard Ryan, 16-year-old junior at Iona Preparatory School on North Avenue here, died in New Rochelle Hospital this afternoon of injuries received yesterday in football scrimmage at the school.

Julio Bolbochan, one of three chess players representing Argentina in the world championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, withdrew yesterday after suffering from a hemorrhage, according to a report from Stockholm.

The first football game to be played in New York this fall will take place tonight at the Polo Grounds. It will bring together the New York Giants and the Los Angeles Rams in an exhibition game preceding the regular National Football League season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A Government survey made public today showed American business planning to spend $14,300,000,000 on plants and equipment during the second half of 1952, raising capital outlays for the year to a new high.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- No one knows how much good it will do them, but the Indians do know that they must go right on winning to keep alive their pennant chances. And that is precisely what they accomplished today as Bob Lemon pitched the Tribe to a 6-1 victory over the Senators.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday on his arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, that recent Republican criticism that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, was using too much levity in his campaign speeches indicated resentment because "the humor was largly at the expense of the two Republican parties."

ROME, Sept. 17 -- The Church of Christ, which was prevented by Italian authorities from holding a religious service in its Rome premises last Sunday, has decided to take vigorous legal action in defense of what it considers its right under the Italian Constitution to continue its religious and proselytizing activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Democratic campaign workers throughout the country were supplied today with ammunition for use in "unmasking the Republican campaign of evasion and smear." The characterization was supplied by Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a foreword to a pamphlet entitled, "How to Win in 1952."

A trial committee for the Board of Education turned down yesterday a request that it postpone for a week or ten days departmental proceedings against eight city teachers who were suspended last term for refusing to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership.

The merger of two unions representing performers in radio and television was approved yesterday by the board of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, A. F. L., parent organization for all performer unions.
Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address at the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor here yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The United Mine Workers and the anthracite operators averted a strike on Oct. 1 by making an interim agreement today raising payments to the union welfare and retirement fund 20 cents a ton, making the rate 50 cents.

BOSTON, Sept. l7 -- Twenty-five members of the Massachusetts Legislature failed to win nominations to new terms, on the basis of unofficial returns reported today from the state primary. The balloting was marked by a lack of contests for most top offices.
The annual dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York will be held on Oct. 23 at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 17 -- A runaway "Indian maid" who claimed her name was "Yalamuslankastidanamutsa" turned out today to be Yvonne Hanks of Fitchburg, Mass.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 17 (UP) -- Senator John Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, today denounced Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's criticism of the Administration's tax program.

We live in a tortured period of history when strange and primitive forces are coming into their own again. Our civilization often seems but a veneer covering dark abysses. New and then the surface is pierced and we see frightening things.

As the result of a plan put forward by a committee of first and refunding bondholders of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is interested in acquiring properties of the bankrupt railroad.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17 -- The centennial year of Yale University's School of Engineering will be celebrated Oct. 24 and 25 with lectures, special exhibits, a formal dinner and attendance at the Yale-Lafayette football game.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at a Republican political rally here tonight:

We begin to wonder how bad conditions have to get before Mayor Impellitteri can be shaken out of his imperturbable calm about the size of the Police Department. Attacks on women in subways and elsewhere startle and terrify the city; hold-ups, muggings and other crimes arrive in such numbers daily that they arouse comment everywhere.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Browns walloped sixteen hits today to rout the Red Sox, 10 -- 4, before 1,250, the Brownies' smallest crowd of the year.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 17 (UP) --The three top favorites got the worst of it while the underdogs fared well in drawings today for post positions in tomorrow's seventh Little Brown Jug harness classic for 3-year-old pacers.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Trade and finance officials of eight countries of the British Commonwealth will meet in London Monday to begin laying the groundwork for the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in November.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- A spherical shell camera capable of phographing 300 square miles at an altitude of 30,000 feet has been developed at Boston University. The photo made by the camera has no distortion and there is equal illumination and sharpness over the entire picture, university authorities said today.

Rosh ha-Shanah, which begins the Jewish New Year of 5713 and the start of the ten penitential days, will be observed, beginning at sundown tomorrow, by the Jewish people throughout the country with services in synagogues and temples.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Jacob A. Malik announced today that the Soviet Union would not permit the admission of Japan to the United Nations until Japan had ended "the American occupation," regained "full independence and sovereignty," and concluded peace treaties with the Soviet Union and Communist China.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 17 -- The Senate voted unanimously today its confidence in the Government of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh after his report on the oil dispute with Britain, the Churchill-Truman offer and the Premier's proposals for a settlement with the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- The highest budget in the history of the Protestant Episcopal Church, a yearly expenditure of $5,929,042 for the next triennium, was approved here today by the House of Deputies of the church's general convention. The House of Bishops is expected to approve it tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 117,973 today, an increase of 736 since last week.

Three months of conversion work on the Paul H. Townsend will end this morning but, paradoxically, she will look less like a completed ship than she did when she entered the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard at Hoboken, N. J.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 17 -- The New Jersey Law Enforcement Council was invited today by Municipal Public Safety Director Louis J. Messano to conduct an inquiry into waterfront conditions in this city.

Home furnishings that run the gamut from rag rugs to the richest room settings will occupy three floors of Grand Central Palace through Sept. 28. The occasion will be the fourth annual National Home Furnishings Show that will open at noon today.

Although they are aware that the number of persons over 65 years old in this country is large and increasing most manufacturers refuse to adapt their products to this mass market, according to the Standard Factors Corporation. The few producers which have taken proper action have been eminently successful, said Standard, which deals in accounts receivable financing, factoring and installment financing.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Sept. 17 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will make a major campaign trip to the Pacific Coast and back through Texas, starting front New York Sept. 30. He will start out by train, making various whistle stops on the way, but will switch to planes, probably on the Northwest sector of the journey.

A new volume will be added to the growing shelf of World War II memoirs on Oct. 2 when Doubleday will publish Gen. Maxime Weygand's "Recalled to Service." It is the general's account of how, after his recall from retirement at 72, he was entrusted with the job of defending his country.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 17 -Worsening relations between Indonesia and the Netherlands and more difficurt times for the large Dutch population and Dutch interests in Indonesia were foreseen by Dutch quarters here today. Their apprehension was the result of the indignant Indonesian reaction to the new Netherlands Cabinet's policy on New Guinea.
James Carroll, 57 years old, walked out of Kings County Court yesterday a free man after serving twenty-five years of a life sentence as a fourth felony offender.

A one-operation process for transferring multi-colored printed impressions from paper to rubber or plastics was announced yesterday in Akron by Dr. R. V. Yohe, president of American Anode, a division of the B. F. Goodrich Company.
TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- The United States Navy is using guided missiles against the Communists in Korea. They have proved deadly and accurate.

THE novice big-game hunters are exhibiting considerable interest in matters concerning their essential equipment, such as rifle, sights, clothing and footgear, but of those who write for information less than 5 per cent seem concerned with the "mental" equipment that should accompany their first sortie into the big woods.

King Faisal II of Iraq sailed for home on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth yesterday "greatly impressed" with the friendliness of the American people and the great industrial and hydroelectric power plants he saw on a five-week tour of the country.

Your editorial in the Sept. 12 issue of THE TIMES entitled "Fighting South Koreans" will be as gratifying to my embattled countrymen and the Republic of Korea Government as it was to me and all other Koreans who have thus far been privileged to read it.

An announcement by the Port of New York Authority that Eastern rail carriers had agreed to make a substantial reduction here in lighterage charges on machinery and other heavy lift freight was hailed in maritime circles yesterday as a significant victory for the port.

As the fall moves in people move out, leaving the carefree days of summer for the responsibilities of the winter which lies ahead. It is during this flight from country to city that an immediate responsibility is sometimes overlooked. Pets are too often left behind with the vague hope that an unknown somebody will take compassion on the abandoned animals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's address today to the National Conference on Citizenship:

Fashion in tidbits to accompany cocktails changes almost as capriciously as that in women's clothes. The whim this fall seems to be for vegetable hors d'oeuvre, judging from the many items of this type to be noted among new food products in delicacy shops and department stores.

The audience that viewed the Adrian collection, presented by Gunther Jaeckel yesterday morning, experienced a dual emotion, the pleasure of seeing fashions created by this great American designer and the regret at learning that for some time they would not have the same privilege again.

TORKHAM, Afghanistan, Sept. 18 (A) -- The Soviet Union has told Afghanistan "in the most threatening manner" to keep United Nations and United States technical advisers out of her northern provinces bordering Soviet Asia, reliable reports said tonight.

Subtle curved contours, molded lines and a tawny shimmering finish on walnut characterize new furniture that goes on view at B. Altman Co. today. Pieces for living, dining and bedroom are displayed in five room settings.
BERLIN, Sept 18 -- All propaganda outlets in Eastern Germany were engaged today in conveying the idea that tomorrow would be an historic day for all Germans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Back in 1947, when the United States asked the Security Council to approve the arrangements under which it is now administering the Marshall, Caroline and Marianas Islands, Andrei A. Gromyko, who was then Soviet representative, paid a generous tribute to the United States war effort in the Pacific.

The two-story business and apartment building at the southwest corner of Eighty-first Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Hugh R. Wilford of the Wilford Auto Sales, Inc., to an investing client of the Advance Realty Company, broker in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Orson Welles, stage and motion picture star, appealed today a Government ruling that he owes $24,302 in taxes for 1947.

A record-breaking performance in the feature event and a daily double of $1,469, the largest of the local season, were the chief occurrences at Belmont Park yesterday. The new time figures were set by Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Oedipus, who cut four-fifths of a second off the previous track mark in winning the Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap of about two miles in 3:39 1/5.

Net income of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on last Aug. 31 amounted to $16,025,505, equal to $1.63 a share on 9,830,603 capital shares, it was announced yesterday. This compared with $15,576,052, or $1.73 a share, on 9,000,933 shares, for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, 1951.

A year has passed since Mayor Impellitteri asked for the blueprint of a Transit Advisory Commission that would "help relieve the city from the haphazard patterns of action of the past." He hoped for machinery that would help the city government make "enduring decisions on basic transit problems," to work toward decisions on a long-term rather than a crisis-dictated basis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Joseph Hudson Short Jr., President Truman's press secretary for almost two years, died unexpectedly at 7 o'clock tonight at his home in near-by Alexandria, Va. He was 48 years of age.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 18 -- The three Allied maneuvers in Germany have demonstrated that although there has been a striking increase over the last year in men and materiel available, the defense of western Europe still rests on the concept of a fighting withdrawal to the Rhine River and the organization there of a defensive position from which a counter-offensive could be launched.

HERSEY, Pa., Sept. 18 -- Pennsylvania has the wherewithal for a good football team. With new men in the line-up, a revamped offense and Notre Dame to be faced in the season's opener a week from Saturday, the Red and Blue's virtues may not be immediately apparent.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 18 -- Currents of unknowable ultimate strength are pushing against the normally Democratic moorings of the western area of the border country.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18 A three-year plan to bring complete peace to rebel-afflicted districts in West Java was outlined in an interview here today by Sultan Hamengku Buwono, Indonesia's Minister of Defense.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission arranged yesterday for the permanent financing of the thirty-two-mile Delaware River extension to the state's toll highway system by selling to investment bankers $65,000,000 of bonds maturing over thirty years at an interest cost of about 3.03 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, said today he favored ending the excess profits tax next June 30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The number of workers in nonfarm establishments rose by almost 900,000 between mid-July and mid-August to 46,900,000, a record high for the month, as industry swung back rapidly into production after the steel strike, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

IN a recent column, in which we faintly mourned the passing of the picturesque hunting and fishing terms of yesterday, we neglected to include a few of the terms one of our readers considers important, so Sparse Grey Hackle sat down at his steam-operated Oliver and set us on the right track.

Thousands of longshoremen from Maine to Virginia are expected to cast ballots today in the first major vote held by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., since the long dock strike of 1951. The issue at stake is arbitration of the union's present wage dispute with management.

The conference of representatives of eight nations of Southeast Asia that is now in progress in Manila is strictly unofficial. It is sponsored by the Philippine veterans' organizations and they invited veterans in these other states to join with them in discussing matters of preserving the peace. The meeting is, nevertheless, just as significant as it would be if it had all the protocol of a diplomatic conference.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- September liquidation by longs featured grain trading here today. In all pits the current delivery was under pressure, and this dominated the trading, although on the setbacks there was fair general buying of wheat and the coarse grains by commission' houses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today the second perjury conviction of Harold R. Christoffel, former union official in Milwaukee, who was accused of lying to a Congressional committee about his Communist connections. He faces a prison term of two to six years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has seletced the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company of Akron as operating contractor for its new plant to be built in Pike County, Ohio, for the production of Uranium-235, a key substance for atomic energy.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 18 -- Eight years of Finland's payment of war reparations to the Soviet Union will end tomorrow with the delivery of the "golden schooner."

ABOARD NIXON CAMPAIGN TRAIN IN CALIFORNIA, Sept. 18 -- Opening his first major campaign tour today with a 400-mile trip through California's fertile Central Valley, Senator Richard M. Nixon loosed a rapid-fire series of whistle stop blasts at what he called "The Scandal-a-Day Administration" and its chosen successor.

Nine Austrian manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, guided by a girl named "Mike" and a project manager representing the Mutual Security Agency, took a look yesterday at this country's machinery for manufacturing antibiotics. One of the nine summed up the impressions of the group in these words:

Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden moved into first place yesterday in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden as a result of a draw with Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany in the third round, according to a report from Stockholm.

SAXTONS RIVER, Vt., Sept. 18 -- Vermont Academy has a headmaster and athletic director who played football against each other thirty years ago. The headmaster is Laurence Leavitt, a former Dartmouth fullback star, while the athletic chief is George Owen, who was one of Harvard's great halfbacks.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 18 -- All major Indian industries recorded substantial increase in production during the first six months of this year, according to a report from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry today.

An amiable, nostalgic long-standing disagreement between two Manhattan officials was decided yesterday in a small excavation four feet below the present surface of South Street. In that pit, just north of Clinton Street, the two men agreed that there still remained in Manhattan some old New York cobblestone paving.

Democratic objections to the independent nominating petition of M. Maldwin Fertig, a candidate for Bronx County Surrogate, were dismissed yesterday by the Board of Elections. The challenged petition named Mr. Fertig as the candidate of the Ideal party, an independent group. He received the Liberal nomination in the recent primary.

A new automobile accident prevention program was formally dedicated yesterday at the Manhattan office of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, 80 Centre Street, as hundreds of persons filed into the building to renew driver licenses expiring Sept. 30.

Joan Harris, 20 years old, who had been on trial in Special Sessions on a charge of maintaining a house of prostitution at 434 Lafayette Street last spring, was convicted yesterday. An additional charge of maintaining a public nuisance was dismissed on the motion of Miss Harris' attorney, Joseph Lombardo.

Retail prices of several cuts of meat, broiling chickens and medium-sized eggs are lower this weekend. Large Grade A eggs, however, are again higher. Vegetable and fruit prices showed only slight changes. Home cooks preparing for the Jewish holidays will find that fresh water fish are sharply higher, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

In the dismal atmosphere of the twelve-bed prison ward of Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday, a magistrate exonerated a critically wounded 34-year-old inmate, ordered the arrest on a charge of felonious assault of the patrolman who shot him, and took testimony involving a $500,000 suit against the city by the victim.

Thirty additional policewomen yesterday joined the city's campaign to halt the widespread series of assaults on women and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said he planned to use "every available resource at our command" to stop the violence.

A recent issue of your newspaper gave further circulation to a half-truth that critics of our foreign policy have repeated without substantiation for a long time. In the interest of intelligent discussion of foreign policy your readers, I feel certain, would welcome the following points, which I hope will set the record straight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Henry Williams Jr. of Kutztown, Pa., went into a trap on the first two shots he took in the National Celebrities open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Theron Lamar Caudle told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that important cases had been taken out of his hands while he was an Assistant Attorney Gen eral by the then Attorney General, Tom C. Clark, who is now a Supreme Court Justice, and by Peyton Ford, one of Mr. Clark's principal assistants in the Justice Department.

Some excellent examples of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century religious folk art of New Mexico -- called santos, or representations of saints and other holy personages -- have been lent by the Taylor Museum of the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they will go on public view beginning today.
OMAHA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a major farm speech, here tonight by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee:

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The American Cyanamid Company has purchased part of the Larry Knohl Farm in Pearl River through the Artion Realty Company, according to records filed with the Rockland County Clerk. The purchase was made July 14 and was not announced publicly.
Sharply reduced earnings were reported yesterday by Anderson, Clayton Co., merchandisers and processors of cotton and cottonseed, for the fiscal year ended with last July.

Vast undeveloped land holdings in the southeastern part of Orange County, N. Y., linked closely to the early history of this country, have just passed from the hands of the Harriman family, into ownership of the City Investing Company of New York for future development.

Warning that "the deterioration of our legitimate theatres is accelerating at an alarming rate," the New York Convention and Visitor's Bureau asked yesterday that legislation be amended to permit patrons to drink and smoke during shows, and to allow the construction of theatres as an integral part of structures with other rentable units.

Two exchange bus drivers met in the press room at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday and, as could be expected, talked shop. They were Jan van Gent, a tram operator of Amersfoort, the Netherlands, and George E. Brennan, a bus driver for the Third Avenue Transit System.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 13, 1952, totaled 881,218 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 135,174 cars, or 18.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 30,406, or 3.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 14,560, or 1.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The country's newspapers probably will use about $1,500,000 worth of advertising space in their own publications during the next twelve months in a campaign promoting the newspaper as a news and advertising medium.

Geisinger Rau, operators, bought the two five-story apartment houses at 53 to 67 Wadsworth Terrace from the Haft Assets Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $165,000. There are 103 apartments in the buildings, which occupy a plot 200 by 116 feet. The property is assessed at $270,000 and was sold through the Maxwell Brody Company, broker.

A proposed law by the city that would levy $25 fines against parents for the "wilful destruction" of city property -- especially in the parks -- by children, failed yesterday by a tie vote to receive the approval of the Board of Estimate.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active most of yesterday, and closing prices for active months were 9 to 27 points net lower than on Wednesday.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gov. James F. Byrnes' statement today in which he announced he would vote for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President:
BEIRUT, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Lebanon's new ruler, General Shehbab, has called on Parliament to meet next Tuesday to elect a new President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey announced today that the third nation-wide series of Selective Service college qualification tests would be given Dec. 4 this year and April 23, 1953.

As he left his job yesterday with his pockets bulging with 138 letters, a 34-year-old Post Office clerk was arrested and charged with embezzling $1,000 from the mails, mostly from charitable organizations.
The Mosler Safe Company is opening new Boston offices at 375 Boyleston Street on Tuesday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 18 -Israel's coalition government lost its parliamentary majority tonight with the withdrawal of two small religious parties on the question of compulsory national service for religious women.
