WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended Sept. 13 were 1 per cent below sales in the same period of last year.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- United States Ambassador George F. Kennan will leave Moscow by plane tomorrow for consultation with important United States diplomats and State Department representatives in London.
Coffee, cottonseed oil and wool managed to show gains in futures trading yesterday. Other New York commodities were lower or mixed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A Navy spokesman, in commenting today on the successful diving of remotely controlled pilotless aircraft into North Korean targets, styled the operation an "interim measure" pending the development of more effective guided missiles.

The prospect for steadily increasing dependence by the United States on importation of raw materials over the next twenty-five years offers Latin America a golden opportunity to double its volume of such exports to this country by expanding output in line with the demand, according to a hemisphere trade trend analysis released yesterday.

The ice breaker Eastwind of the United States Coast Guard is due today in Boston, her home port, after having smashed her way through deep ice fields to within 442 nautical miles of the North Pole, believed to be the northernmost point reached by a ship under its own power.

THULE, Greenland, Sept. 18 (UP) -- United States Air Force rescue specialists waited today for a dense Arctic fog to lift before starting operations to evacuate twelve fliers stranded in their crashed supply plane on the Greenland ice cap.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- Like most managers, Al Lopez of the Indians is a lobby-sitter. Lopez needs only an easy chair to be set for the day, especially if the day, like this one, happens to be an off-day and rainy, to boot.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 19 -- China's Premier Chou En-lai and Vyacheslay M. Molotov, Soviet Deputy Premier, last night exchanged cordial toasts to strengthened Soviet-Chinese friendship and mutual assistance.

The Board of Estimate at a heated session last evening rejected the application of William J. Heffernan to withdraw his application for retirement as a Commissioner of the Board of Elections and voted for his retirement next Sunday.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Six Polish men and two women accused of a murder allegedly inspired by Voice of America broadcasts went on trial in Warsaw today.
" Seagulls Over Sorrento," the first new play of the 1952-53 season, closes at the Golden tomorrow night after its twelfth performance.

ABOARD NIXON CAMPAIGN TRAIN, in California, Sept. 18 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican nominee for Vice President, today confirmed published reports that since his election to the Senate he had accepted about $16,000 in contributions from supporters.

Donald Day, editor of "Franklin D. Roosevelt's Own Story," has edited a companion volume in "Woodrow Wilson's Own Story" which Little, Brown will issue on Monday. The selections in the volume are from Wilson's private land public papers.

Jane Engel, 1025 Madison Avenue, exhibited for the press last night selections from its fall collection of casual and dressy separates. Convinced that separates are playing an increasingly important role in the fashion field, the store is endeavoring to meet this demand.

Requests for exhibit space at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America, scheduled for Nov. 30 to Dec. 4 at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels, have been received earlier than for any previous event, it was announced yesterday by Edward Atkins and Maxwell Field, co-managers.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept. 18 -- Wild seas and a gale out of the Arctic intervened again in Exercise Mainbrace today and forced the cancellation for the second straight day of a scheduled air strike against the "enemy" in the vicinity of Bodo, Norway.

Tenants of the seventeen-story building at 300 Park Avenue, at Forty-ninth Street, which formerly housed Sherry's Restaurant, scored a victory yesterday in their fight to retain their homes when Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht signed a consent injunction restraining the owners of the building from converting it into a commercial structure.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Besides their $12,500-a-year salaries and $2,500 annual tax-free expense accounts, Senators get many other benefits and privileges of financial value.

As his final contribution to the comity of nations before leaving these shores Jacob A. Malik, the first Soviet representative to become a kind of negative television celebrity, cast two more vetoes to bar two more free nations from membership in the United Nations -- Libya and Japan. He did this in a now rather stale repeat performance of his stellar role in the Month of Malik, featured by the same old line of argument.

While the Giants yesterday disclosed they were prepared to receive mail orders for the world series, the first of the three local major league clubs to get organized for the ticket sales, the Dodgers rolled out of town for Boston last night and the Yankees returned from their last swing through the West, hoping to make their two and one-half game lead over the Indians stand up.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y. Sept. 18 -- Tom Robbins of Winged Foot today won the Westchester Seniors' golf championship for the fifth consecutive year, at the Westchester Hills course.

The first made-in-America collection of fashions by Pierre Balmain, shown yesterday by De Pinna at the Pierre Hotel, made a happy combination of the French dash typical of this designer and the wearability American women want. His knack of flattering the figure, of creating a beautiful decolletage, of subtle interesting color combinations and fashioning beautiful evening clothes was evident throughout.

Cotton textile manufacturers are opposed to the proposal by the New York Cotton Exchange to make cotton packed into high density bales deliverable on futures contracts. Exporters prefer the high density bales because more poundage can be shipped in the limited spaces of ships' cargo holds.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A heavy rain turned the Delaware County Fair half-mile track into a quagmire today, forcing postponement of the final heats of the seventh annual Little Brown Jug pacing classic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Truman said today that to the best of his knowledge there was no substance in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's assertion that he, the general, had been directed in 1946 to command striking railroad workers whom the President proposed to draft into the Army.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Behind the reluctance of the United States to pledge funds for use by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees are three convictions bearing on the role this Government and others should play in easing the refugee problem.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- Prof. Joel H. Hildebrand, dean-emeritus of the College of Chemistry at the University of California and one of the country's best-known educators, declared here today at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society that the concept of freedom did not imply the granting of freedom to those who would destroy it.

GENEVA, Sept. 18 -- Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, criticized today the United States Government's program for aiding persons newly escaped from Communist countries as likely to "raise false hopes" among refugees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -The Petroleum Administration for Defense has announced that it is trying to work out arrangements to increase substantially the output of oil-country tubular goods by foreign steel mills. No specific goal was mentioned.

Following is one of a series of articles on the present political situation by The Associated Press, based on a nation-wide survey it made on county-by-county and section-by-section estimates by newspaper editors and political writers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- The increase in Government power during the last ten years has "now permeated and thoroughly poisoned our time-honored system of constitutional limitations," Clarence Manion, former dean of Notre Dame University Law School, told the National Association of Foremen today.

Events tonight: "The Old Maid and the Thief" and "Amahl and the Night Visitors," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; "L'Infant Prodigue," "Seven Popular Songs" and "The Old Maid and the Thief," American Lyric Theatre, 133 MacDougal Street, 8:40; Jazz Concert, Webster Manor, 125 East Eleventh Street, 8:30; "La Boheme," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.

THE reaction probably is wrong and inherently unsound. Yet it persists. This videot watched Rocky Graziano flounder through ten rounds against Chuck Davey the other night and found himself subconsciously drawing certain comparisons relative to the forthcoming championship fight between Rocky Marciano and Jersey Joe Walcott. The parallels are neither true nor precise. But those lines move along, side by side, for an awfully long distance.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Despite pressure from French Communist party leaders and from cells throughout the country, neither Andre Marty nor Charles Tillon, who were demoted Sept. 4 and severely criticized for their "deviationism" has as yet acknowledged his "errors" and recanted.

Custom originals from Stein Blaine, 13 West Fifty-seventh Street, opened the winter series of luncheon fashion shows which will be presented each week in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel. Accompanying designs in suits, dresses and formal gowns were luxurious furs.

Presenting an effective attack and taking advantage of every opportunity, the New York Giants whipped the Los Angeles Rams, National League champions, by 30 -- 17 at the Polo Grounds last night in the first professional football game of the season here.

The supreme council of the Scottish Rite of Freemasonry for the northern Masonic jurisdiction in the United States opened an eight-day meeting yesterday in the Statler Hotel. The first and only formal item of business was presentation of the council's highest award, the Gourgas Medal, to Dean Roscoe Pound, the veteran authority on international law, for "notably distinguished service in the cause of Freemasonry, humanity and country."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Jacob A. Malik today cast the fifty-second Soviet veto, thus blocking the admission of Japan to the United Nations until Japan complies with Soviet terms -- which include the termination of what Mr. Malik calls "the American occupation," and the conclusion of a peace treaty with the Soviet Union and with Communist China.

Aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange remained virtually unchanged in the month to Sept. 15. On that date the figure was 1,715,635 shares, against 1,728,913 shares on Aug. 15. Both totals exclude short positions in the odd lot accounts of odd lot dealers which were 82,675 shares on Sept. 15, and 79,847 shares a month earlier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The American Association of University Women announced today that inquiries to the two major Presidential candidates had brought statements of their intention, if elected, to use qualified women in responsible government posts.
Occasionally an article turns up in THE NEW YORK TIMES, and indeed many newspapers, dealing with the teacher shortage. One such article appeared in THE TIMES on Sept. 7.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,377 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, called on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today to demand the resignation of Senator Nixon as Republican candidate for Vice President.

The New York City Opera opened its tenth season last night in the City Center of Music and Drama with Puccini's "Tosca." This performance brought back to New York the distinguished Italian conductor, Tullio Serafin, who had not been heard in this city since his performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in the season of 1934-35.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Georgi N. Zarubin, new Soviet Ambassador to the United States, made what he called "just a courtesy call" on Secretary of State Dean Acheson today. Then he sat with his interpreter for a barrage of news pictures, and, as he left, said he would attend a baseball game.

Business borrowings from New York banks rose sharply last week, advancing $118,000,000 to register the biggest gain since mid-June. The seasonal increase, in which seventeen of the nineteen reporting member banks participated, brought the net decline in commercial loans since the first of this year to $83,000,000 compared with a rise of $886,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

THULE, Greenland, Sept. 18 -- The Danish and United States Governments disclosed officially today the construction here of a huge strategic air base, 930 miles from the North Pole in the high Arctic wasteland.

Additional details about the gambling business conducted by Harry Gross were provided yesterday by the former bookmaker's brother, Jack, at the departmental trial of thirty-one suspended policemen in the Criminal Courts Building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Allahyar Saleh, new Iranian Ambassador to the United States, appealed to Secretary of State Dean Acheson today to use his "good offices" to help end the bitter British-Iranian oil dispute.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois was loudly applauded tonight at the Fiftieth Ward Republican "victory dinner" when he sided with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, against General of the Army George C. Marshall, wartime Chief of Staff and former Secretary of State.

The troubles of the Protestant Church of Christ in Rome are being blown up to proportions which can do harm to all concerned and to Italo-American relations. This is one of those unhappy problems that arouse intense emotions, obscuring the basic realities and the logical, common-sense approach that would be applied to more prosaic issues.

The first commercial ultra high frequency television station, KPTV in Portland, Ore., went on the air early yesterday morning in anticipation of the start of regular programming tomorrow over Chanel-nel 26.

Now that summer is over and households with children in them are returning to that routine entailed by school, home work and the resumption of music lessons, it is about time for those autumnal domestic debates to begin over the best time to tune the piano.

In another column on this page we print a letter from Adrian S. Fisher, legal adviser to the Department of State, expressing the opinion that in a recent comment on Korea this newspaper gave "further circulation to a half-truth," which he considers to be without substantiation, and undertaking to "set the record straight."

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Sept. 18 -- No one could come even close today and Col. Martin S. Lindgrove of Baltusrol won his third New Jersey Seniors Golf Association championship at the Essex Fells Country Club.

In your editorial of Sept. 11 on the victory of Senator McCarthy in the Wisconsin Republican primary you make one unfortunate error which makes our battle against McCarthy appear far bleaker than it is.
HARTFORD, Sept, 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois said in effect tonight that he would rather be right than be President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Maybe the people of some other country where there are approximately free elections have become as obsessed with sample polls and predictions as the people of the United States. But the foreign dispatches do not reflect any comparable predilection.

Directors of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad at a meeting here yesterday authorized the redemption on Oct. 20 of the outstanding 5 per cent Series A $100 par value preferred stock at $100 a share plus unpaid dividends of $5.28 a share. The dividend accumulations consist of $1.25 a share previously declared, payable on Dec. 26, and $4.03 a share to cover the current calendar year from Jan. 1 to the redemption date.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 19 -- Powerful and sustained attack by guided missiles could he made on North Korea from United States aircraft carriers, a Navy expert here said yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Mary Pickford has changed her mind about making a screen comeback in "Circle of Fire," which the Stanley Kramer Company planned to put before the cameras on Oct. 9.

Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman overruled Immigration authorities yesterday in a decision that prevents the deportation of a 24-year-old Spanish seaman, an ardent foe of the Franco regime, to his native Spain, where he might be prosecuted as a former member of the underground Basque movement.

A committee of expert engineers was angered yesterday to learn that Mayor Impelitteri had invited it to confer with him only on prospective appointments to two minor posts on the projected Board of Air Pollution Control instead of to the two top administrative jobs in the Air Pollution Control Department.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Gen. Charles De Gaulle today consulted with the parliamentarians of his movement who have remained faithful to him with a view to future policy.

The Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday the results of a review of the operating differential subsidy of the Mississippi Shipping Company, ruling that the subsidy contract was in order and that competition in the company's route warranted Government aid.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- President Truman, at his news conference today, commended to public attention a new publication of the State Department called "Forced Labor in the Soviet Union."

Mayor Impellitteri declared war yesterday against City Council President Rudolph Halley. At an open meeting of the Board of Estimate the Mayor announced he was serving notice on all heads of city departments and agencies under his jurisdiction "not to answer the telephone when the President of the Council calls up."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 18 -- W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, an American oil refining and distribution concern, indicated in a press interview today that he might be willing to assist Iran in operating her oil industry again.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Sept. 18 -- John Cashmore, Democratic candidate for the Senate, pledged here tonight that his party would move forward with enlightened progress as the best answer to communism and despotism.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 18 -- Former Mayor Frank Hague was closeted with the Hudson County grand jury for two and one-half hours today as a witness in the jury's investigation of waterfront crime and rackets.

The first of the political programs to rely predominantly on television techniques normally associated with studio shows was presented on Wednesday evening by the New York Republican County Committee. Quite apart from partisan considerations, it was a program about which there can only be serious misgivings on several different counts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A $12,000,000 damage suit was filed today against Ronson Art Metal Works, Inc. of New York, charging it violated antitrust laws by conspiring to monopolize the automatic cigarette lighter industry.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Dutch authorities were considering an American offer to place an order of $20,000,000 with the Dutch aircraft industry for the building of British Supermarine Swifts on condition that the Dutch themselves place double that order, an authoritative spokesman confirmed today.

STRASBOURG, Germany, Sept. 18 -- Continental spokesmen today attempted to put at rest fears shown by British delegates in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe that the proposed "Little Europe" federation would be dominated and led on dangerous adventures by Germany.

A plan for a coordinated effort by all branches of the aviation industry to reduce the noise of the jet airliners of the future to a point that will be bearable by people living near big metropolitan airports will be submitted to the executive committee of the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee next week, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Approaching the end of its first year in office, the British Conservative party contended today that "swift and determined action" had been taken by the Churchill Government "to save the country from disaster" and that Britain was "back on the right road" although facing "a long uphill climb" to national economic independence.

Latin American Communists and neo-Fascists are united in an anti-United States program that is directed and supported by the Argentine Government, the American Federation of Labor convention heard yesterday.
The economic stake of the average American in this year's Presidential election was debated last night at a dinner meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association voted today to recommend to Congress a constitutional amendment aimed at putting a brake on executive agreements in international relations.

America must cling to her power and maintain her might, for American stability is a bulwark of hope for the other free nations of the world, Eikichi Araki, first post-war Ambassador of Japan to this country, declared here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Jersey Joe Walcott-Rocky Marciano world heavyweight championship bout next Tuesday night will be televised for a record number of forty-nine theatres in thirty cities, co-promoters Herman Taylor and Jim Norris announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The hospitals of the nation, like many of its people, are suffering from diseases of old age and should, in many instances, be replaced with modern facilities, Dr. Jack Masur, Assistant Surgeon General, United States Public Health Service, declared today.
Sales of homes in Bay Ridge and Park Slope featured realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday. Three of the houses in Park Slope were bought by doctors.
OMAHA, Sept. 18 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower rolled across the Missouri into Nebraska tonight quoting the Scriptures and calling for an "honest deal."

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Heavy Chinese attacks hit United Nations lines at four points along the Korean battlefront last night. One Allied position was overrun, and savage hand-to-hand fighting raged at another today.

Over the country in synagogues and temples and various Jewish institutions and overseas in military installations, observance of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year of 5713, will begin at sundown today.

SONTHOFEN, Germany, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Air Force sergeant and a Czechoslovak infantryman, deserters, joined the United States Army today to fight, if necessary, for liberation of their homelands.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18 (AP) -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden -- here to draw Yugoslavia more firmly into the Western camp -- exchanged vows with Premier Marshal Tito today that they would strive together for world peace.

The Very Rev. Paschal Ahearn, former pastor of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, Jerome Street near Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Wednesday in Our Lady of Sorrows Church friary at 213 Stanton Street. His age was 47.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 18 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes, who once served President Truman as Secretary of State, announced today he would vote for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- During the week ended Sept. 17, member banks reserves increased $727,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Commander Kurtz said as many as 1,800 World War II planes had been converted into pilotless, guided aircraft. Not all are ready for use as combat missiles. Many are target planes used for gunnery practice.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18. (AP) -- Bechara el-Khoury finally yielded to opposition pressure today and gave up the Presidency he had held since he led the fight to get the French out of Lebanon in 1943.

Dennis J. Mahon, chairman of the Tammany executive committee and a leader of the Fifth Assembly District, announced yesterday that twenty-eight of the thirty-five Assembly district leaders and thirty co-leaders, all members of the executive committee, had signed a statement reaffirming confidence in the leadership of Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, and instructing him to proceed with the organization and direction of the campaign.

At its first meeting of the new school year, the Board of Education awarded yesterday contracts totaling $1,000,000 for the partial repair and modernization of fifty-seven schools, and authorized a comprehensive survey of the health services and facilities available to public school pupils.
HARTFORD, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address at the Bushnell Auditorium tonight:

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 18 -- Mexicans have been afforded a rare look into the methods and meaning of political influence by a court battle over the granting of oil distributing rights to a new company headed by Jorge Pasquel, millionaire industrialist and close friend of President Miguel Aleman's government.

Music and Poetry of the Negro was featured at last night's "Interval Concert" presented by Norman J. Seaman at Carnegie Recital Hall. Langston Hughes was the narrator, reading selections from poetry by himself and other Negro poets.

Ohrbach's presented a collection of approximately thirty French and Italian imports and their identical American-made copies, which will sell at a fraction of the cost of the originals, to the press yesterday. There were designs from Desses, Griffe, de Rauch, Balenciaga, Lanvin, de Givenchy, Gres, Vanna, Visconti, Schuberth, Bertoli and Venziania and of two other top designers who must be nameless.

The taxpayer containing eight stores at the northwest corner of White Plains Road and East 236th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Carlo Cozzolino from the East 236 Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $60,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, told the American Federation of Labor convention here yesterday that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was now "calling the Republican signals" and was leading the party toward defeat.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Mr. Smith, a lawyer, of this city, said that between $16,000 and $17,000 has been spent to pay bills incurred by Mr. Nixon in representing California. Mr. Smith, who said he disbursed the fund, said none of the money was for personal expenses.

The advertising of the country was honored yesterday by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury for its "patriotic service" in promoting the sale of United States Savings Bonds. The Secretary presented a three-foot high statuette of the Minute Man, symbol of the defense drive, to Howard J. Morgens, chairman of the Advertising Council and vice president in charge of advertising, the Procter Gamble Company.

PANAMA, Sept. 18 -- It is unlikely that President Truman's Point Four program in Latin America will be changed if Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is elected President in November, the general administrator of the program, Stanley Andrews, said today.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Finishing with her best round of the tournament, 38, 38 -- 76, Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley retained the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Glen Head Country Club today. She had a total of 159, 76 -- 235.
The museum's influence on contemporary designs in home furnishings is demonstrated on a large scale in a number of settings and exhibits that went on view at Abraham Straus last night.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Members of the North Atlantic Council met today and spent a large share of their time discussing means by which they could develop the nonmilitary phases of action, as proposed in the Atlantic Treaty, which provides for fostering better understanding to strengthen international peace.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal Church, meeting here in triennial general convention, vociferously turned down today a resolution deploring "unsupported accusations" against respected citizens.
President Truman make his first campaign speech in New York State in Buffalo on Thursday night, Oct. 9, at a Democratic rally tentatively scheduled to be held in the Municipal Auditorium.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 18 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, attended here today a regional meeting of party leaders from midwestern states to map campaign strategy in the farm belt.

With enthusiastic buying support lacking, the stock market yesterday failed to carry through the selective rallying tendency exhibited in the two preceding sessions. Final prices were thoroughly mixed in rather dull and narrow trading.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin said yesterday that he would campaign for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in any state if the Republican nominee for President asked him to.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The stock markets remained dull and idle today reflected in small losses in almost every section. Losses in British funds were up to one-eighth per cent and leading industrials suffered a further long list of losses.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A former United States champion, Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., almost upset the applecart today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, but Frank Sedgman, Australia's No. 1 player, rallied and defeated Larsen in the quarterfinals by 8 -- 10, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern today announced the appointment of an advisory committee to study the state's water distribution problems. The group will consist of twenty-two members, with Mr. McGovern as chairman.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators met for fifty-two minutes at Panmunjon today, then took another week's recess -- their eighth in succession -- without progress toward an armistice in the Korean war.

Jack Gross, younger brother of Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, testified yesterday at the departmental trial of thirty-one policemen that he derived part of his current income from betting at local racetracks. The 25-year-old stocky witness was on the stand for the eighth day in the trial of the defendants, who are accused of helping to protect Harry Gross' $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking racket.

The one-story warehouse and factory building at 61-05 Thirty-second Avenue in Woodside, Queens, recently acquired by William and Richard Welsh has been leased to the Ascot Carpet Laying Service, Inc., through Queens Industrials, broker.

ROME, Sept. 19 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker disclosed today the United States Embassy had started discussions with the Italian Government on the new wave of closings of Protestant churches in Italy.

According to the banana people, one should never put bananas in the refrigerator. A banana, it has been heard for years now, likes the climate of the tropical equator. It is a wonder that those showing this extraordinarily solicitous attitude toward the likes and dislikes of the fruit have never raised and answered the basic question of whether the banana likes to be eaten or not.

MOORESTOWN, N. J., Sept. 19 -- A Brooklyn man, his wife and their 9-year-old daughter were killed instantly tonight when the station wagon the father was driving on the New Jersey Turnpike rammed the rear of a trailer truck. Another daughter, 8, who was thrown into the rear seat, was taken to Burlington County Hospital at Mount Holly with a fractured right arm.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 -- There must be no Asiatic retreat by the free world as a means of bolstering European defense against the possibility of a Communist attack, Dr. You Chan Yang, Korean Ambassador to the United States, said here tonight.

THULE, Greenland, Sept. 18 -- One of the Royal Air Force's most prized aircraft, a specially fitted navigational bomber, came within minutes of plunging into ice-filled Arctic waters several days ago because of the lack of standard British-United States radio and air navigation procedures in an area where airfields are few and far between.
The Port Huron Joint Building Authority of St. Clair County, Mich., will take bids Oct. 15 on $3,200,000 of revenue bonds dated Nov. 1, 1952, and due Jan. 1, 1956 to 1958.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 19 -- The final obstacle to the Port of New York Authority's plan to rehabilitate this city's Government-owned piers at a cost of $21,000,000 was removed today when the City Commission, by a vote of 3 to 2, adopted a resolution subleasing the pier property to the Authority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator Nixon came in for further attack today over his acceptance of about $16,000 in contributions from supporters since his election to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Senate records indicate that six Senators, including Richard M. Nixon of California, will receive more than $75,000 this year as personal salaries and expense money and for office help.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Admiral Cochrane's resignation raised curiosity in shipping quarters whether it meant that last summer's controversy over ship construction subsidies had been settled.
Following is the last of a series of five articles by The Associated Press on the political situation as of now, as seen by newspaper ediitors and political writers in the forty-eight states:

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat packer, today reported its net profit for the first nine months of the current fiscal year dropped to $2,075,981, compared with $13,200,927 in the same 1951 period.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, told the voters of Massachusetts, many of them of Irish descent and members of the Roman Catholic faith, that his Republican opponent, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, had chosen Oliver Cromwell "to be the model for his great crusade."

Parents will have the opportunity of sharing classroom activities with their children this season at various centers. Registration may be made now for these as well as a number of courses of special interest to parents. Fees for most are nominal.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Accused of weaving in and out of parkway traffic at a rapid speed in a manner that caused the death of five persons, a motorist was indicted by a Westchester County grand jury today on a charge of culpable, criminal negligence.

A threatened state-wide strike by construction workers on state-sponsored projects was averted yesterday after a four-hour conference between fifteen union spokesmen and three high-ranking state officials.

Two men were arrested yesterday and charged with illegally supplying narcotics to four Rikers Island inmates through the use of a scheme of double-backed envelopes. The arrests came after narcotics squad detectives had spent forty hours of investigation at the city prison.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, announced today his support of the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, and called on pro-Eisenhower Southerners to "get out of the Democratic party and show their own colors."

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- A recent Public Housing Authority announcement that Shanks Village, a project set up originally for the families of veterans attending colleges in New York City, would close next July has been set aside and the 1,400 families will be permitted to stay until July 1, 1954, an extension of one year.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent over the week ended Sept. 16 to 111.3 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A top adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today President Truman did not "check all his facts" when he contradicted a statement of the Republican Presidential nominee about the 1946 railroad strike.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Scoring two runs in the eighth inning to break a deadlock, the Dodgers today beat the Braves, 4 -- 2, in a game cut short at the end of that inning by rain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer filed a damage action today against Mario Lanza in the United States District Court in Los Angeles; seeking to recover losses said it had suffered as a result of the singer's failure to report for work in "The Student Prince."
One of the largest commercial tracts in the West Bronx has been purchased by a corporation headed by Abe and George Rosenberg.

The campaign against low-flying planes in Queens moved another steps forward yesterday when Magistrate Charles Murphy in Magistrate's Court, Long Island City, Queens, issued summonses against the Port of New York Authority and five airlines.

Dissolution of the Steam Locomotive Research Institute, Inc., and the establishment of its $40,000 in funds as a scholarship endowment at Stevens Institute of Technology for sons of railroad men were announced yesterday by R. P. Johnson, head of the locomotive institute.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Chinese Communist troops with tank support forced Allied defenders out of prefabricated bunkers atop "Old Baldy" and won control of the key crest on the western front in Korea, the Eighth Army said today.

Despite important increases in traffic the railroads of the United States showed an actual decrease in 1951 in the number of fatalities in accidents and an increase of less than 4 per cent in non-fatal injuries as compared with 1950. The gain in railroad safety has been a remarkably steady one.

Big doings -- big and brassy -- are being planned by Waterbury, Conn., to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the establishment of the brass industry in Connecticut. Three major events are planned: The first, starting Oct. 1, will be a big industrial exhibition in the Waterbury armory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said today a Senate inquiry into shortages in Government grains and farm products shows "about $10,000,000 that was stolen."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- An Interstate Commerce Commissioner today said there was nothing unlawful about tariff notes published by Northern and Southern railroads declaring that they had no through routes with Seatrain Lines, Inc., at Edgewater, N. J., or Savannah, Ga., in connection with the temporary rights to operate between those ports granted to Seatrain by the I. C. C. last fall.
OTTAWA, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian industry's great struggle for steel is slowly coming to an end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Mickey Vernon doubled with the bases filled to drive in three runs and cap a four-run rally tonight as the Senators scored their eighth straight victory over the Red Sox, 5 to 3.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society has made a mortgage loan of $1,500 000 to Albert A. Steir, Inc., on the Styertowne Shopping Center in the Allwood section of Clifton, N. J. The development comprises fourteen acres bounded by Route S-3, Bloomfield Avenue and Allwood Road.

TORONTO, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- United Asbestos Corporation, Ltd., has signed a conditional agreement with American Smelting and Refining Company, Ltd., to set up the United Asbestos property at Black Lake for a production rate of 4,000 tons daily.

The three young convicts who escaped from the Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary in Pennsylvania on Sept. 10, then terrorized a family while the fugitives took turns sleeping, were identified yesterday as the three who held up the Bronx branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company last Tuesday morning and escaped with $12,600.
In THE TIMES of Sept. 9 a letter from Curtis V. ter Kuile, concerning your recent editorial entitled "A Voyage for the Bell," stated he was opposed to such an undertaking.

Of the five Russians competing in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, only Alexander Kotov scored a victory yesterday in the fourth round, according to a report from Stockholm.
Two new collections of bedroom furnishings, adaptable to one-room living, are on view at Abraham Straus.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- American Superforts from Japan and Okinawa raided targets in Korea in force by daylight yesterday for the first time in almost a year, plastering east coast points with more than 300 tons of bombs.
A sampling survey of conditions in fifteen square blocks of slums and incipient slums in Brooklyn was begun yesterday morning for the information of a Kings County grand jury studying housing.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- An American sales promotion expert, Ed Lipscomb, told the International Cotton Textile Conference today that "from the point of view of consumption possibilities, cotton's future looks far brighter than its past."

Mayor Impellitteri dismissed yesterday as "another burst of flummery" a charge by City Council President Rudolph Halley that the Mayor was "keeping under wraps" vital reports sent to City Hall by Investigation Commissioner James H. Sheils.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- The "prime political reality" of the modern world was defined here today by the Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church as the "prodigious restlessness" of the multitudes who, counting for little in the past, "now relentlessly work and fight for a wider freedom and a greater dignity than life has ever given them."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Leon Pignon, French Governor General for Overseas Territories, defended his Government's administration of Morocco today and assured a United Nations committee that health conditions in the African protectorate compared favorably with those of other dependent territories.

More than 60,000 residents of New York State in military service or their close kin have applied for service men's ballots this year, indicating that interest in the Presidential election is running exceptionally high, William T. Simpson, chairman of the State Division for Service Men's Voting, reported yesterday.

American business will probably set a new record this year for capital investment in plant and equipment. All told, it is estimated, $27,500,000,000 will be invested this year in expanding manufacturing, mining, public utility and transportation capacity, a figure 4 per cent higher than the previous record, set last year.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Forced to beat a hasty retreat indoors when a sudden, torrential rain and windstorm interrupted his speech to 8,000 persons, here today, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois retained his sense of humor by reminding his audience that he "really wanted to save you from drowning next January."
A hundred new teachers will go to work Monday morning under orders issued yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri in an effort to relieve the critical shortage of elementary school instructors.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Southern California clashed with an aggressive Washington State football team in Memorial Coliseum tonight before more than 40,000 fans to open the Pacific Coast Conference championship race. The teams met in murky weather and the crowd was held down by occasional sprinkles just before game time.

The Radio Executives Club and the American Television Society have merged their organizations and will be known as the Radio and Television Executives Society, Inc. The new organization includes the membership of both groups.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan has ordered all patrolmen and sergeants in the uniformed force to remain in uniform while traveling to and from their posts. The order was issued yesterday in the belief that the sight of a policeman in uniform, even though he was off duty, would serve as a deterrent to crime.
BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Add still another success to the sensational reception accorded to the "Porgy and Bess" troupe in Berlin.

The 301 East Thirty-eighth Street, Inc., representing investors, has taken title to the sixteen-story apartment building on plot 110 by 100 feet at 157 East Seventy-second Street which it bought recently from Charles B. Benenson.
Price movements in commodity futures yesterday were small and well mixed. Only in wool on the New York Cotton Exchange was there a consistently strong tone.

There has been emphatic expression of disappointment in many quarters, including THE NEW YORK TIMES, because General Eisenhower has seen fit to state that he will support all regularly nominated Republican candidates for the Congress, including Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Something different in the way of a football setting was staged at Deerfield Academy this afternoon. Forced to cancel the second practice of the season because of a heavy storm, the guiding forces scheduled a blackboard drill in the spectators' gallery of the swimming room.

The stock market turned selectively firmer and very active in the final hour of trading yesterday, just prior to settlement of the New York Central Railroad's labor dispute and the statement of a coal industry official that John L. Lewis and Northern coal operators are "not far apart" in contract talks.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- Leaders of the powerful Mexican Labor Federation gave notice today that it would press the new Congress for a law providing for workers' participation in corporation profits.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Sam P. Steckler's Decapolis won the five-and-one-half furlong Alhambra Purse in the turf course here today, beating A. J. Fralinger's Irish importation, Ballinclea, by a nose. Third place went to Alan T. Clarke's King Mowlee, who finished a little less than a length behind Ballinclea in the driving finish.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The harder it rained today, the better Jerry Barber played. As a result, he led at the halfway mark in the seventy-two-hole, $15,000 national celebrities golf tournament with a six-under-par 138. Finishing the second round in a downpour, Barber shot a brilliant 68.

Discussion of an acquittal motion in the trial of fifteen secondary Communist party leaders charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government resulted yesterday in an argument between Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock and defense counsel.

Harold Hughes, 33 years old, of 67-34 Selfridge Street, Forest Hills, Queens, was arrested last night on a charge of impersonating a detectve with the intention of shaking down a guiltless 21-year-old model by implying she could be framed on a vice charge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Several of the 800 inventions patented this week are directed at the care and protection of the head. One is a vacuum cleaner attachment for the scalp, a dandruff-removing comb designed by Joshua Garner of Englewood, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Soft coal miners dug coal last week as if they expected to be on strike soon.

Being the father of a 10-year-old member of one of Stamford's Little League teams (he batted for .750 this past season), I was interested in the Sept. 8 letter in your columns from Charles A. Bucher, Associate Professor of Education, giving short shrift to Little League baseball.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 19 (UP) -- The state Franchise Tax Board disclosed today that it was investigating the state income tax of Senator Richard M. Nixon as a result of the $16,000 expense fund put up by some Californians for him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee tonight issued the following notice:

MANILA, Sept. 19 -- War veterans of Southeast Asia entering the third day of a conference here were agreed "in principle" today on establishing a permanent association of former soldiers represented by a committee instead of a general federation as first planned.
The following is a round-up of special events and displays that have been arranged in conjunction with Home Fashion Time by department stores here. Starting today, they will continue next week.

The American Federation of Labor convention, which has listened this week to conflicting views about the Presidential race, took time out yesterday to discuss a political theme on which all 800 delegates were in enthusiastic agreement -- the federation's world-wide fight against communism.

THE Northern waters seem to be providing a final flurry of salmon fishing, both of the landlocked and fresh run varieties, for word from East Grand Lake in Maine and the Miramichi in New Brunswick indicates excellent fishing.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 995 persons who successfully passed the examination for admission to the bar given on July 1 and 2. The test was taken by 1,940 applicants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- George M. Harrison, head of the Democratic National Committee's Labor Division, said today that Republicans were "insulting the intelligence of working men and women" in their campaign for labor votes.

Women are the subject of an anthology culled from Esquire Magazine which Random House will publish next Friday under the title "The Girls From Esquire." The volume contains commentaries and stories by thirty-six authors and is illustrated by thirty cartoons.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- A step toward full military cooperation among Greece, Yugoslavia and Turkey in event any of these countries is attacked was indicated in an exchange of speeches made last night at an official dinner held for a visiting Yugoslav military mission by the Greek Government.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- Afghanistan has rejected a strong Soviet note protesting against United Nations aid for Afghanistan's development program in her northern border province, an Afghan Embassy official said here today.

A three-man panel of Commissioners of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, which has been participating in negotiations between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., recessed yesterday subject to call by the service.

" AN enormous trip-hammer with an Aeolian attachment," was Emerson's memorable description of his friend Thomas Carlyle. It is also a rather less waspish judgment than some of those passed upon the author of "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution" by Lytton Strachey, that agile master of the posthumous sting.
Three large group shows, opening the season at three galleries display the works of familiar and unfamiliar artists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Roswell L. Gilpatric, Under Secretary of the Air Force, declared today that airplane production in the United States was well up to schedule, except in the eyes of critics who compared it to "the number of current models of planes sufficient to stockpile for the all-out war we are trying to prevent."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- The four-man syndicate that is expecting to get control of R. K. O. Radio Pictures still was waiting today for final word from Howard Hughes that he was ready to sign the papers to turn over his 1,050,000 shares of stock for $7,350,000.
William J. Fleming has been appointed general manager of the lighting and rectifier department of the General Electric Company.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,378 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday, Korean time:

Herbert Zelenko and Edwin Weiss have purchased the fifty-nine-family apartment house at 1622 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, from the Brooklyn Stores Corps, Arthur Malin, builder, for cash above a first mortgage of $256,200. Louis Aronson and Samuel K. Janow were the brokers.

There is heartening news from two critical sectors on the food front -- Pakistan and India. Pakistan was able to get prompt assistance in Washington in the matter of a wheat loan and Karachi can now report that the country "will get through the present food shortage without widespread suffering."

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A railroad official urged shippers today to support the railroads' efforts to get rid of money losing rail services and of subsidies to competing forms of transportation.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson here today:

Lemuel Ayers' production of "See the Jaguar," starring Arthur Kennedy, now is in the final stages of preparation. Conferences between the producer and Lee Shubert were held yesterday with the latter agreeing to provide a New York theatre for the attraction during the week of Dec. 1.

This will be a double-header stakes day at Belmont Park, where the forty-sixth running of the Matron Stakes and the thirteenth running of the New York Handicap will be among the eight little problems before the house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 162 battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported thirty-four killed, 121 wounded, four missing and three injured. The following were listed from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey):
College football games assume a major place again on the sports program as teams swing into action today throughout the nation.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 19 -- In summarizing the Miami Fashion Council's first press week for out-of-town fashion reporters, several other phases of the local fashion market should be mentioned besides the dress lines reported earlier this week.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 19 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, declared here today that his party in November "cannot lose."

Premier Oscar Torp of Norway arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon aboard a United Airlines plane from Chicago after a tour of the Midwest. Mr. Torp, accompanied by his wife Kari and an aide, said that he had found the people in the Midwest "very pleasant, friendly and aware of the world situation" and added that he had been "greatly impressed."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said in a statement today that he was "shocked" to learn that Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, favored the reelection of Senaor Joseph R. McCarthy in Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, retired, resigned today as chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and as Maritime Administrator to return to Massachusetts Institute of Technology as dean of engineering. He received high praise from President Truman and Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce. The resignation is effective Oct. 1.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, AT SEA, Sept. 19 -- The Allied striking fleet participating in Exercise Mainbrace, the Atlantic alliance naval maneuver, refueled at sea and in port today in preparation for the climactic phase next week of the twelve-day training operation.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, declared today that he and other Western diplomats resided in Moscow in an "icy-cold" atmosphere of isolation to complete that he could not talk even to his guides or servants except on simple business.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices for active months rose 7 to 28 points.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UP) -- W. G. Reynolds wore a soiled shirt, but he picked up the biggest check in 3-year-old pacing stakes when his Meadow Rice won the $60,463 Little Brown Jug today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Alabama ran into a surprisingly strong Mississippi Southern gridiron machine in the season's opener tonight, but won by a 20-6 score.

ON THE NIXON TRAIN, at Red Bluff, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, took the offensive today and drew cheers from station platform crowds by denouncing "smears" from "Communists and crooks" as he carried his first whistle-stop campaign tour through northern California and into Oregon.

LONDON, Sept 19 -- The stock markets ended a dull week with business still at a low level and prices falling. Despite an attempt at a rally, British funds weakened by up to 1/4%, while industrial leaders closed with small losses. Most other sections were dull.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A British Socialist Member of Parliament and an Italian pro-Communist who saw Premier Stalin in the Kremlin in July got into a long-range disagreement tonight over what Mr. Stalin had told the Italian.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- Yale and the University of Connecticut completed preparations today for their fourth football meeting in the bowl tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 o'clock.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Sept. 19 (UP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott belted Oakland Billy Smith out of the training ring here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Manager Eddie Stanky's bases-loaded pinch single in the ninth inning today gave the Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Cubs in the opener of a three-game series closing Chicago's National League season.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The kidnapings and concentration camps of Communist East Germany frustrated an attempt by five delegates from the East German Parliament to sell the Communist conception of unity in the West German capital today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 19 -- The possibility of any accord for a solution of the British-Iranian oil question is threatened by a wave of extremist opposition to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic candidate for President, declared here last night that "condemnation without all the evidence" of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, for use of a $16,000 political fund "would be wrong."
Shareholders of H. M. Byllesby Co. have been called to a special meeting on Nov. 6 to vote on a merger with the Byllesby Corporation, its parent, under the name of H. M. Byllesby Co.

BALDWIN, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. George Combes of the Rockville Club captured the low net prize with 94-23 -- 71. During the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Willow Brook Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A rise of 0.2 per cent in prices between mid-July and mid-August sent the new Consumers Price Index to another record high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. This was the third consecutive month the index had gone to a record high.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Sept. 19 -- At Borough Hall yesterday forty-two persons registered to be able to vote in the election Nov. 4. The day before twenty-three had registered.
National consumption of beer this year should exceed the previous peak of over 87,000,000 barrels in 1947, R. J. Schaefer, presi-

Patrolman Stanley W. Davis of the Eighty-eighth Precinct in Brooklyn was arraigned yesterday following his arrest Thursday on a charge of felonious assault in the shooting of Arthur W. Battle in the latter's home on May 25.

The "fifty to 100" private citizens who during the past two years have contributed some $16,000 to Senator Nixon to help him meet the expenses of his office showed poor judgment in making such a gift, and Senator Nixon has shown poor judgment in accepting it.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech tonight at the Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City:
TOKYO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- United Nations and Japanese Government representatives negotiating a treaty governing the status of United Nations troops in Japan hurdled a major obstacle today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Grain futures moved irregularly today with evening-up trades in the expiring September deliveries causing sharp price swings. This was especially true of September soybeans, which covered a wide range. In grains impressive buying for a time followed early declines, but a reactionary tendency recurred in late trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Jacob A. Malik used the Soviet Union's veto power three times in three minutes today to kill the applications for United Nations membership of the three Indo-Chinese states of the French union -- Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Cal Abrams' single off Murry Dickson in the ninth inning with a runner on third and two out gave the Reds a 4-3 victory over the Pirates tonight before 5,435, smallest crowd of the night season at Forbes Field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense (P. A. D.) said today it expects that by 1955 sales of gas by the nation's utilities will have risen 40 per cent above the 1951 level.

Canadian production of newsprint for August amounted to 486,496 tons and shipments to 488,575 tons, it was announced yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. Production in the United States for the month was 97,831 tons and shipments totaled 99,008 tons, making the total North American production and shipments 584,327 and 587,583 tons respectively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The seventh National Conference on Citizenship closed today with an appeal by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for free speech, including the right to differ; equality of opportunity; freedom of religion, and freedom from "the fear brought about by want."

The threat of a strike on the New York Central System east of Buffalo was erased late yesterday when the carrier and three unions announced in Cleveland the settlement of a labor dispute covering fifty-eight grievances, some dating to 1950.

A $7,800 payroll hold-up that began at 6:40 A. M. in Harrison, N. Y., yesterday ended an hour later in Harlem, where two armed robbers pushed their three victims out of a station wagon and drove off. Harrison and New York police began a search for the robbers and for the money, which was intended for workers on a school construction job in Manhasset, L. I.
Following is how editors and political writers of the forty-eight states believe their own states were leaning when Associated Press surveys were taken in late August and early September:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- Failure of "so-called labor leaders" to organize workers in the South is threatening the entire trade union movement, leaders of the independent United Electrical Workers Union charged at the concluding session of their five-day convention today.
Enforcement of Federal pollution laws in the Port of New York, a Navy function for sixty-four years, became a charge of the Army Corps of Engineers at a ceremony yesterday at Pier 26, Hudson River.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced tonight that a complete accounting would be made of the $16,000 given to his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, by some of the Senator's political supporters.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 18 -- Acting President Roberto Urdaneta Arbelaez said today that Colombia's much criticized press censorship was an essential step toward easing political tension and would be removed when circumstances allowed.

A young patrolman fatally shot his wife early yesterday in their bedroom when he was awakened by sounds that he thought were made by an intruder. Earlier in the day his wife's mother had told him of a burglar scare in the apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Industrial feeding is described as an inviting career for women interested in home economics. A career pamphlet issued yesterday by the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor, is called "The Outlook for Women as Food-Service Managers and Supervisors."

Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo reserved decision yesterday on the application of Henry W. Grunewald, Washington "mystery man," to expunge from the record his previous testimony before the special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that has been investigating tax frauds, bribery and corruption.

DES MOINES, Sept. 19 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, pursued today his demand that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, "cast away" his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California.

Soviet track and field athletes failed their country and the Communist party by failing to win supremacy at the Helsinki Olympics, an editorial attack published last Saturday in the official organ of the Young Communist League, Komsomolskaya Pravda, charges.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- War widows organizations from the United States and France today made contact here for the first time in a ceremony at the offices of the French Association of Widows and War Orphans of World War II.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- Another night, another victory and the race is far from finished. These were the sentiments of the optimistic Indians after they conquered the Tigers by 4 -- 1 tonight at Municipal Stadium and moved to within a game and a half of the Yankees.

Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland, lighter, older and far behind in the scoring, achieved an unexpected ninth-round knockout over Coley Wallace of Harlem in the scheduled ten-round heavyweight feature at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
Congratulations are due THE NEW YORK TIMES on its expert and fair reporting of the Presidential campaign.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The union on strike at the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today that it had dropped its controversial demand for a union shop. This has been the major issue at Lockheed, where 25,000 have been out since Sept. 8, and at the Douglas Aircraft Company's El Segundo plant, where nearly 15,000 went out last Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Roger Touhy testified today that American Federation of Labor unions in Chicago gave him a war chest of $125,000 to prevent the Capone gang from "muscling in" on organized labor.
The annual world-wide celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah, or the Jewish New Year, which in the Hebrew calendar is the Year 5713, was begun at sunset yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Charles Chaplin, who has made generations laugh, may be banished from the United States as a result of accusations that he has subversive tendencies.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Ken Rosewall and Lewis Hoad, making their first world-wide swing with the Australian tennis contingent, scored a major upset today by defeating Frank Sedgman and Dick Savitt in the Southwest Pacific tennis championship doubles, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 8, 8 -- 6.

While most of the West European nations are meeting at Strasbourg to work out plans for greater unification of the Continent the Atlantic Alliance forces have been holding a series of land, air and sea maneuvers, the results of which emphasize the urgent need for both speed and the broadest possible scope in this search for unification.
The resignation of W. W. Hawkins, chairman of the board, and of Roy W. Howard, president of the E. W. Scripps Company, which operates nineteen Scripps-Howard newspapers, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, SePt. 19--An autopsy performed here today at George Washington University Hospital established that a heart attack caused the death last night of Joseph Short, press secretary to President Trumam
The resignation of W. W. Hawkins, chairman of the board, and of Roy W. Howard, president of the E. W. Scripps Company, which operates nineteen Scripps-Howard newspapers, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, SePt. 19--An autopsy performed here today at George Washington University Hospital established that a heart attack caused the death last night of Joseph Short, press secretary to President Trumam
GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Before long air travel may become the poor man's way and sea travel the rich man's way to see the world.

GHENT, Belgium Sept. 19 -- Belgian cotton concerns are seeking to establish a market in cotton futures at Ghent for Dutch, French, Swiss and German as well as Belgian buyers to replace the continental futures markets at Le Havre and Bremen, neither of which has been revived since World War II.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The Algonquin Gas Transmission Corporation is losing $500 an hour because of "delaying actions" of Northern Westchester County residents who oppose construction of a natural gas pipeline across their properties, Supreme Court Justice James W. Bailey was told today.

Berkray Manufacturing Company, one of the largest producers of men's sportswear jackets, has obtained an exclusive franchise for Byrd cloth for both lined and unlined jackets, it was announced yesterday.

A morality play in modern setting will be given at 8 P. M. Sunday, Aug. 28, at St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street. It will be in two acts and will cover race relations.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, and his brother, Charles P. Taft, the Republican nominee for Governor, met with 150 Cincinnati business and professional leaders here today in an effort to establish harmony between independent and regular Republicans.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 19 -- The Indian Communist party is sending a delegation of sixty members to attend the Asian and Pacific "peace conference" in Peiping. Twenty-one of them left yesterday and today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The State Department described today the mission of a United States oil company president to help Iran sell her oil as a "purely private commercial" venture. Nevertheless, the official disavowal did little to lessen the possibility of serious friction with the British should the enterprise actually succeed.

Details of an extensive community development program for India, aimed at bringing about fundamental economic changes and a higher standard of living for at least 12,000,000 people, were announced here yesterday by the Government of India Information Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Because Clint Hartung missed an easy catch of a fly ball at Shibe Park tonight, the Giants found themselves four games behind the Dodgers in the race for the National League flag.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- The processing of special diet foods to reduce their sodium content, widely used in the treatment of high blood pressure and other diseases of the heart and the blood vessels, may also remove other essential nutrients, such as proteins, according to authorities who addressed the closing sessions of the national meeting of the American Chemical Society here today.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 -- The Royal Palace issued today a statement to the effect that King Paul had flatly refused to accept the resignation of his general secretary, George Ventiris. The resignation was tendered yesterday after Mr. Ventiris' brother, Nicholas, a journalist, had been accused of being the anonymous author of a series of anti-American editorials in the Athens daily Elleniki Imera.
Last evening the New York City Opera Company presented two operas by Gian-Carlo Menotti at the City Center, "Amahl and the Night Visitors" and "The Old Maid and the Thief."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19 -- There were indications tonight that Anthony Eden. British Foreign Secretary, had made some progress in convincing Premier Marshal Tito and his colleagues of the impartiality of the British, United States and French Governments on the question of Trieste.

Bobby Shantz, pint-sized southpaw of the Athletics, tossed his 139 pounds into the American League flag race last night and in the short space of 2 hours 35 minutes succeeded in turning everything topsy-turvy.

A controversy developed yesterday between Albert H. Morgan, acting city Commissioner of Public Works, and Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens over the flooding of streets in Malba, a residential community next to the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, with raw sewage overflowing from the $2,000,000 Whitestone interceptor sewer.

LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 19 -- A picture flashed on television screens resulted in the arrest of a butcher who had been sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for seven months on charges of defrauding the United States Government.

Banks are missing a chance for high readership of their advertising and a greater profit return by not using as copy local human interest stories from their files, Bruce Robinson, financial group supervisor of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, said yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- Man is the greatest asset of any enterprise and the most important factor in production, Antonio Ruiz Galindo, Mexican industrialist, told the 29th annual convention of the National Association of Foremen today after accepting a special award.

William J. Heffernan announced last night he would not seek a court decision to keep his position on the Board of Elections. The Board of Estimate refused on Thursday to approve Mr. Heffernan for further service on the board because he will reach his eightieth birthday on Sunday.

News that the United States, in cooperation with Denmark, has nearly completed a great strategic air base at a place called Thule, on the northwest coast of Greenland, stirs the imagination as much by the name and location as by the daring of the engineering feat. Thule means the end of the world in classic geography.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- With Dick Kazmaier and nine other regulars gone from its 1951 platoons, Princeton does not anticipate another undefeated football season. However, the Tigers, victorious in twenty-two straight games since 1949 and Eastern champions the last two years, are far from destitute despite their heavy losses.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today he saw "no reason" why a Senator or Representative should not accept gifts from his family, friends or constituents "to help pay even his personal expenses in Washington."

OTTAWA, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- For the second consecutive month, Canada's export drive, which made major gains in the first half of the year, lost ground in August, when there was a $15,000,000 reduction in exports to the United States.

Louis J. Grumbach, 78 years old, a Jewish communal leader and former banker, jumped or fell to his death yesterday from a fifth-floor window of Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, where he had been a patient.

A plastic for kitchen cabinet doors, sides and drawer fronts that is washable and also resistant to all heat, stain and wear is being introduced at the National Home Furnishings Show, now being held at Grand Central Palace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- The American Bar Association adjourned its seventy-fifth annual convention today after its House of Delegates adopted a resolution bearing directly upon the civil rights of persons convicted of minor crimes.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 20 -- The remarkable showman, Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm. Doberman pinscher owned by Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey of Cos Cob, Conn., went to the top today in the sixteenth event of the Ox Ridge Kennel Club.

The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind and the Ophthalmological Foundation, one of the oldest medical research organizations in the field of eye diseases, have affiliated, it was announced jointly here yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Thirty racing sloops of the Long Island Sound fleet were out today for the first of the post season regattas of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

HARTFORD, Sept 20 -- John M. Bailey, Democratic State Chairman, is attempting to lure Gov. John Lodge, a Republican, into a discussion of state issues during the current election campaign in Connecticut, which up to now has been based almost entirely on national affairs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 20 -- "Operation Tomato Juice," in which twelve students at Rutgers University's College of Agriculture will taste-test 3,000 cans of tomato juice, will begin at the end of this month.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 20 -- The campaign methods of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois and those of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower present a study in contrasts, but the two candidates appear to agree definitely on one thing: Each would rather run against some other person than his present opponent.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,379, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- American Sabre jets this week scored a new record for the Korean war when, at the conclusion of the first seventeen days of September, they had sent down forty-seven of the enemy's Russian-designed MIG fighters, passing the total of forty-four destroyed in April, the previous high month in more than two years of conflict.

AN extensive photographic project on an international scale on the theme, "The Family of Man," was announced last week by the Museum of Modern Art. It may prove to be the most important photographic venture ever undertaken by the museum and perhaps in the United States.

OUT of the ruins of two world wars a generation of "young" Austrian writers has grown up -- many of whom, alas, are now verging on their fiftieth year. No other generation of youths has had to bear such heavy burdens.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 -- The Central Committee of the Worker's Federation of Latin America (C. T. A. L.) ended a three-day meeting today and observers saw in its deliberations new evidence that Communist leaders were trying to take over the continent's surging nationalist movement as their own.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 -- City planners, in the next twenty-five years, will be concerned with the increasing use of helicopters, the development of power from atomic or even solar energy and "push-button" factories instead of assembly lines, it was predicted this week at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
OTTAWA, Sept. 20 -- Figures announced during the last week by Government agencies have given good indication of the extent and basis of Canada's present prosperity.
May I, as a friend of Isadora Duncan, be permitted to set down a few words about Agnes De Mille's "impartial mixture of wisdom and poppycock," to use one of her own phrases about the great artiste?

Bertrand Russell's lukewarm qualifications in favor of "progressive education" seem ill-timed and ill-directed toward Americans today, many of whom are struggling hard to substitute for "progressive education" an educational system which will better equip students to meet the rigors of adult life.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- If Premier-Foreign Minister Chou Enlai's high-powered mission to Moscow has any over-all relationship to the programs and preoccupations of Communist China, much more has been discussed there than the two somewhat anti-climactic Manchurian agreements that were announced this week.

MRS. ELEANOR JOAN PENNEY, like many another London housewife, has a special grudge against bombs. All this year she has had a team of painters and decorators tramping in and out of her house to repair the damage Hitler did to her home in 1942.

ALL over Rome today, almost everyone seems to be talking movies, making them, or helping in the process. The creative spirit flourishes, and discussions are not limited to the city's eight major studios or to the fashionable Via Veneto, that vital showcase for hasbeens and want-to-be's.

Having seen Isadora Duncan dance in Nice in the winter of 1909-10 I must say the only thing that impressed me were the children she had with her. She was very heavy of limb which in no way enhanced her grace or poses.
Fall will begin officially at 10:24 P. M. tomorrow, according to the calculation of the Hayden Planetarium.

Arthur Daley in "Wait 'Til -- This Year" (Sept. 7) describes an incident in which Babe Herman of the Dodgers pulled a lighted cigar from his pocket and writer Frank Graham was "aghast." According to Mr. Graham, in his book "The Brooklyn Dodgers," the person involved was Joe Gordon.
