THE federation of the former Italian colony of Eritrea with the Ethiopian empire has been commemorated by Ethiopia with a series reaching J. H. Stolow. "The way which leads to the sea is free" is inscribed on 15-centimes red-violet and 30c yellow picturing an opened gate with water in the background to indicate that Haile Selassie's kingdom now has access to the Red Sea through Eritrea's port of Massawa.

Success of the armored vests which combat soldiers have been wearing in Korea opens a big field for that portion of the textile industry specializing in synthetic fibers. While thus far the quantity of cloth going into the vest can be measured only in hundreds of thousands of yards, the product, if adopted as standard equipment, eventually will require many millions of yards.

At Belmont Park yesterday Jockey Conn McCreary made the acquaintance of a 2-year-old filly named Is Proud, a Brookfield Farms' thoroughbred. McCreary hopes for a long and happy friendship. Is Proud, who had been handled by other riders in her four previous starts, whisked McCreary down the Widener chute to a three-length victory in the $52,920 Matron Stakes.

BELGRADE, Sept. 20 -- Premier Josip Broz Tito's speech last Sunday at Dolenska Toplice, Slovenia, and certain Yugoslav statements which preceded the arrival of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden last Thursday, emphasized the almost unbridgable chasm between the present position of the Yugoslav and Italian Governments on the question of Trieste.

MUSIC, like the theatre, is born again each fall. September is tune-up month for musicians. October is the month when actual music making gets under way. The orchestras launch their subscription series, the round of recitals begins, the opera singers start rehearsing in earnest, and live symphonic programs may be heard on the air again.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 20 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois got a roaring ovation tonight from a Southern audience whom he had told that he would support the pledges in the Democratic party platform and work for enactment of a Federal law to guarantee equal employment rights to whites and Negroes alike.

Samuel A. Markel began with a jitney twenty-five years ago. Today he heads an insurance company with $24,000,000 in assets, controls others of equal importance, and with his four sons -- two sets of twins -- operates one of the country's most successful safety engineering services.
The nation's private power producers are spending an estimated $2,500,000,000 this year to keep ahead of an unprecedented demand for electricity.

IS the double-breasted suit obsolescent, moribund, dead as the celluloid collar and high button shoes? Is the single-breasted suit due to become the only possible packaging for homo Americanus? And -- to get at the fundamentals -- are American men becoming a prey to the whimsies that seasonally sweep the world of women's fashions, requiring a change in style just for the sake of change?

AMONG the score or so musical festivals which have sprung up in Central Europe since the war, the Internationale Musikfestwochen in Lucerne have come closest to attaining equality in prestige with the older festivals at Bayreuth, Salzburg and Munich.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- A 7-year-old boy was killed and at least twelve other persons were injured today as a sports car participating in the fifth annual running of the Grand Prix race veered into spectators on Franklin Street, the main street of this village.

Messages from the American people to those of the Iron Curtain countries will be sent via a new Freedomgram program to be begun today at 4 P. M. by the Crusade for Freedom under the direction of Henry Ford 2d, chairman. Messages will be tape-recorded in the Park Sheraton Hotel and typical messages will be selected by Radio Free Europe and Radio

Ever since the Communists came to power in China, the West has sought clues to the question: How firm are the ties between Moscow and Peiping? The entire strategic picture in the Far East hangs on the answer. In Korea, for example, United Nations military strategy has been deeply influenced by the question of what Russia might do if the U. N. extended the war and attacked Communist China itself.

Bertrand Russell's penetrating article is so valuable that one hesitates to take issue with any of it. But I should like to know his evidence for the generalization: "* * * progressive schools, however unintentionally, tend to sacrifice citizenship.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman of Australia, the defending champion, dominating play all the way, defeated Dick Savitt of East Orange, N. J., 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, today to gain the final of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, came to the defense today of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, whose acceptance of $18,235 expense money from private contributors since coming to the Senate has aroused a political storm.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 256 battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported twenty-six killed, 225 wounded, three missing and two injured.

IT seems a long time since William Saroyan checked in his messenger's cap and coat in Fresno, Calif., and gave up his nickname of Speed (fastest messenger boy in town) and became a short story writer, novelist, scenarist, traveler, husband and father.

THERE is an old superstition that if you stand long enough at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, sooner or later everybody you have ever heard of will pass by. Since the Fulton Theatre is not too far from that strategic intersection, it is perhaps not surprising to discover that the entire gamelan of a Balinese village, together with its best dancers, have somehow inexplicably arrived there for a brief run.
The City Mission Society will be the beneficiary of a preview of "The Seven-Year Itch" on the evening of Nov. 19 at the Fulton Theatre. The play opens the next night.

Brilliant as was Jay Monaghan's article * * * may I protest the way he described Nicholas Biddle? According to Mr. Monaghan, Biddle was "director of the Bank of the United States which Jackson ruined," the implication being that Jackson should not have ruined it.

FEW gardeners, no matter how new at the game, remember how blissfully ignorant they were when first introduced to it. Imagine then the plight of the cliff dweller transplanted to the suburbs who doesn't know topsoil from subsoil, peat moss from petunias, or. as in the classic case presented here, an annual from a perennial.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- The Dodgers' ship moved a little closer to pennant harbor today under the skillful piloting of Carl Erskine and the timely aid of Jackie Robinson and Billy Cox, two outstanding crew members.

A ROCK amid the tides of fickle twentieth century taste, Fernand Leger has not yielded an inch to other painting fashions in the ever rolling stream since he first built his own sturdy art out of Cubism before 1914.

In an effort to reduce the amount of smoke being added to the atmosphere by the stacks of city hospitals, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame is studying plans for modernizing the incinerators of five hospitals at a cost of $35,000.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Texas, playing its first night game in fifteen years, employed the running and passing talents of Quarterback T. Jones to gain a 35-to-14 victory over Louisiana State University tonight in a driving rain.

All necessary arrangements for three forms of stand-by war risk insurance were completed last week by the Maritime Administration, ruling out any recurrence of the confusion that existed on coverage when this country's steamships were suddenly thrust into World War II.
Ties, the traditional Christmas gift for a man, an item he is sure to use unless the style and pattern are not to taste, are being neglected by retailers, producers said last week.

BEFORE the first snowfall, Touring Players, Inc., a repertory group of restless young actors who have traveled over 40,000 miles in seven seasons on the road, plan to settle clown off-Broadway for a few months to give the first New York presentation of "Three Plays With Music," by their own playwright, Ellen Violett.

CAIRO, Sept. 20 -- Egyptian policy in the Sudan is expected to come under review when the Egyptian Cabinet meets Monday. It was predicted in political circles here that the Egyptian Government would seek to reach an understanding with London concerning the Sudan before general elections are held in the area this autumn.

THE Maxwell Grant country -- "Satan's Paradise," a preacher once called it -- lies along and out from the Cimarron River in northern New Mexico. There is evidence that when the grant was issued, shortly before New Mexico became a part of the United States, it called for only 32,000 acres.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Greek Ship did it again today as he won the $25,000 added All American handicap by defeating Joey Boy by a half length in the thrilling mile and a quarter race before a crowd of 24,242 fans. High Dive was third, three-quarters of a length farther back.

As a Vietnamese nationalist and patriot I protest indignantly against the false charges made on Vietnam, its Government and its people, and especially against the inadmissible interference of the Soviet Union in the internal affairs of Vietnam.

The Yankees defeated the Athletics by 2 -- 0 at the Stadium yesterday and retained their game and a half lead over the Indians, who won at night from the Tigers, 11 -- 3. With a 1 -- 0 victory over the Braves, the Dodgers lifted their lead to five games over the Giants, who lost to the Phils, 3 -- 2.

REEDSBURG, Wis., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy launched another attack on Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson today, charging that the Democratic Presidential candidate once "was recommended by Alger Hiss for a top job."

Sixty-seven arrests were made by detectives throughout the city in the twenty-four-hour period ended Friday midnight, Police Headquarters reported yesterday. The total included four cases of rape and fifteen of felonious assault. Figures were not available for arrests by the uniformed force.

The three convicts who escaped from the Federal Penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pa., and later robbed a bank in the Bronx were cornered by detectives early this morning in upper Manhattan. In the fierce gun battle that followed two of the convicts and one detective were killed.

Profit prospects of the nation's industrial manufacturers for the remainder of the year are not promising. Despite the pick-up in production and business generally, the cross current of rising price trends and labor troubles may influence sales.

WASHINGTON Sept., 20 -- If Georgi N. Zarubin, the new Soviet Ambassador to the United States, wants to lead a gay, sociable life in Washington, he will have to ignore the examples set by his predecessors of the past few years.

Representatives of Colombian coffee interests hastened last week to assure United States customers that the recent burning of newspaper plants and of the homes of Liberal leaders in Bogota will no interfere with supplies of the aromatic bean to this market.

WHEN New York City's high schools opened for the new term early this month, each one of them -- if previously made plans went through as scheduled -- was equipped with a Geiger counter and a mimeographed outline for conducting sixteen experiments involving radioactivity designed to make at least some facets of the Atomic Age less mysterious to the rising generation than they are to most adults today.

The American freighter Dorothy and the Swedish motorship Paranagua collided at 9:39 P. M. Friday in narrow Grove Channel at the western entrance to the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. Damage to both ships was slight, and no casualties were reported.

The third act of Shaw's "Man and Superman," a civilized entertainment known for theatre purposes as Don Juan in Hell, was outstanding among last season's theatre offerings, and Columbia Records at once took steps to make the work available on disks.

Joseph Nyatt, 39 years old, of 43-30 Forty-second Street, Sunnyside, Queens, a cook, punched a patrolman from the rear on Lexington Avenue near Fifty-third Street at 7:10 P. M. yesterday, struck him until he fell, and was preparing to jump on him when passers-by interfered, the police of the East Fifty-first Street station reported.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 -- Although the Georgia political kettle is bubbling over with intraparty controversy and with widespread talk of Democratic defection, all signs point to an election victory for the Democratic national ticket on the basis of traditional loyalty to the party label.

The old familiar story in the soft coal industry -- threats of another strike -- had little effect on financial markets last week. Traders have become somewhat immune to labor disturbances since the last steel strike and the action of stock prices last week, after dipping to a new low since June, revealed their attitude.

As president of the Show of the Month Club, I have had occasion to see quite a number of summer tryouts. Although the plays and the "barns" were different there was one factor that was, unfortunately, the same. I refer to a group of "critical experts" attendant upon each production who might perhaps better be referred to as summer-theatre pallbearers.

General Eisenhower at the A. F. L. convention last week and Governor Stevenson in his Labor Day speech have now outlined their labor programs. To what extent is there agreement and wherein do the two candidates disagree?

Long ago the French called him Charlot, the Spanish Carlitos, the Italians Carlino. He seemed to express much of the pathos, the puzzlement and the comedy of our day. He came into this position, in spite of great native gifts, almost by accident. His arrival in Hollywood some forty years ago was strategically timed.

THE most recent novella by Paul Gallico has the sunny charm and rich pigmentation of an Italian primitive painting, translated into words. It recalls an earlier novella, also about a miracle in the Umbrian countryside, Maurice Hewlett's wistful, enchanting "Madonna of the Peach Tree," still fresh and apropos, still memorable, thirty years after publication; for the novella need not die as soon the novel.

RIGHT now, while grass is still growing, is the time to renovate the lawn. Many sods took a terrific beating early this summer, when intense and prolonged heat burned up the good grasses and left ugly brown patches where crabgrass and other weeds were only too happy to take over.

The story of the reentombment of the ashes of Frederick II of Prussia, published in THE TIMES last week, was in keeping with his strange life. His coffin was spirited away from Potsdam to keep it out of the hands of the Russians.

MOSCOW'S theatrical season traditionally opens Sept. 1, and this year it has gotten under way in an atmosphere of considerable expectancy -- expectancy over the fruits of a great debate, the like of which has seldom been seen in recent years in the Russian theatre.

MEN are getting brighter, gayer, more colorful, at least on the surface. The peacock in them, long muted, is breaking out all over, and the garb they affect, particularly when loose in the bracken and the gorse on vacation or while coddling the maniac Martini, outrages the spectrum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The sleek, dark mahogany speed boat Miss Pepsi and her driver, Chuck Thompson of Detroit, who has made it a habit of winning the President's Cup regatta here on the sometimes rough Potomac River, tonight seemed headed in the same direction once more.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Woodrow Wilson Sayre, grandson of President Woodrow Wilson, today has the Democratic nomination for Congress from the Twenty-fifth California District through a recount.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Continue maintenance to counteract the shabby, end-of-the-season look. Cut off not only spent bloom but also the straggly foliage of perennials; pull up annual plants that are brown and exhausted.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Senator Richard M. Nixon's special expense fund:

HERE, for all those who knew and loved (or loved without knowing) the old Greenwich Village, is the story of Gonfarone's Restaurant and Family Hotel. This village institution, although gone now from West Eighth and Macdougal, must still be a landmark in the hearts of many who shared the food, drink, advice, philosophy and good cheer dispensed there by Papa Sermolino, host and co-owner of the famous establishment.

IN your critic's article about the suitability " of "Porgy and Bess for European audiences I think he draws an unconvincing analogy when he maintains that "'Porgy and Bess' is not a flattering portrait of American life, as 'Electra' and 'Lysistrata' are not flattering portraits of Greek life."

FOR the third time in the last four years, top honors at the Venice Film Festival, which last week ended its three-week run in the city on the lagoon, have gone to a French production. The symbol of filmic supremacy -- a gold statue of the Lion of St. Mark -- this year went to Rene Clement's "Jeux Interdits," after a fight to the finish with John Ford's "The Quiet Man," its closest rival.

WHILE he was tramping the lovely, lonely mountain tracks near the Soviet periphery in Central Asia, and recording his vivid impressions of the life there, from lizards to kings, Associate Justice William O. Douglas also found time to evaluate our Asian policy.

RAINY it may have been the day the eleven Fripseys moved into the big house next door, but for lonesome Marcy the advent of that family of individualists -- and their assorted pets -- promised a future full of bright days.

DELTA, Utah -- Just west of this lively livestock-raising center (1,750 pop.) on the edge of the dusty Sevier Desert, folks from neighboring ranches and officials from Salt Lake City and Ely, Nev., are planning a sizable two-day celebration next Friday and Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- The history of written laws has been rolled back another century to 2500 B. C. through the translation of a clay tablet excavated fifty years ago in the ruins of the ancient Sumerian city of Nippur by a University of Pennsylvania expedition to southern Mesopotamia.

UNEVEN as this book is in style and technique it is considerably more interesting than the average junior novel of contemporary life. Its main theme -- that of a young girl's emergence from awkward diffidence into self-confidence -- is valid and ever-popular with girls.

Millions of Americans laughed last week when they read that a Russian magazine had told its readers that the American national sport of "beizbol" was a "beastly battle, a bloody fight with mayhem and murder," and, basically, a steal from the old Russian game called lapta.

The Republicans have pegged their campaign largely on one theme -- that it's time for a change because of the "top to bottom mess in Washington." In developing this theme they have pounded relentlessly on two charges -- that the Administration has been "riddled" with corruption, and that it has been "slow" in weeding Communists out of Government.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- The most attractive heavyweight championship battle here in twenty-six years is slated for Tuesday night at Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Representative Herman P. Eberharter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, demanded tonight that Senator Nixon "explain all the circumstances" of the home he had purchased in the fashionable Spring Valley section of Washington.

Organized labor was up to its union button in national politics last week. For the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the button already had "Stevenson" written on it. The American Federation of Labor, with a tradition of neutrality in Presidential contests to worry about, took longer to make up its mind.

ROTTERDAM, Sept. 20 -- The outcome of the London conference on German external debts has at last made feasible the realization of many projects sponsored by the "Union of the Chambers of Commerce of the Rhine Region."

General Eisenhower's pledge to include the principle of liberation of the subjugated nations behind the Iron Curtain as an explicit objective of American foreign policy, was assailed as irresponsible playing with the risk of war for the sake of votes. This accusation was made by President Truman, followed by similar charges on the part of Governor Stevenson and Secretary Acheson.

The new voice behind the Voice of America is a gruff, very American one that spoke out publicly yesterday for the first time thus: "We want to tell the truth and though this sounds platitudinous as hell, there must be something to it."

WITH all the recent hoopla over synthetic fibers -- Dacron, Orlon and other "miracle" weaves which, when put in a man's suit, may do everything but carry the suit to the cleaner -- it has become all too easy for everyone to overlook the virtues of natural fibers.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 20 -- Following is the text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at the Mosque Auditorium here tonight:
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 20 -- Gene Filipski and Ben Addiego, two fleet runners, found gaping holes in Kentucky's defense tonight and helped Villanova win an intersectional football game, 25 -- 6.
Planning for the future of the nation's economy, with emphasis on expanding foreign trade as a key source of strength, is gaining wider attention from business and Government leaders.

WITH the publication of "Blood Royal," Robert Payne, prolific writer on Asiatic and Oriental subjects, makes good on a promise he gave when his "The Young Emperor" was brought out two years ago. In a note on the earlier work, he wrote: "This is the first of two novels concerning the Emperor Shah Jehan, in whose lifetime the Taj Mahal was built and the Empire of Hindustan knew its greatest extent."

BONN, Germany, Sept. 20 -- Three damaging admissions by members of the East German parliamentary delegation that came to the Federal Republic to talk about unity and make propaganda doomed their mission to apparent failure today.
RIDING along almost any road from Maine to Maryland during the next few weeks, the motorist will see on all sides a display of flaming foliage.

FOOD is stored wisely and well for reasons of economy, flavor and health. With food costs at an all-time high, economy is of present interest, while flavor and health are, of course, of perennial interest.

Mandy, a two-year-old Scottish terrier-Pomeranian, will board a plane at midnight tonight at the New York International airport, Idlewild, Queens, for a vacation in Houston, Tex., having finally, by dint of strict dieting, managed to lose enough weight to squeeze herself into her ventilated suitcase.
The nation's press was divided yesterday in its editorial comments on the disclosure that Senator Richard M. Nixon had received an $18,235 "expense fund" from a group of his California supporters.
TRENTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Public Utility Commission rejected today a telephone company request for a rehearing on a two-year application for higher rates.

WITH China now closed to Western correspondents (except for representatives of the European Communist press), British Hong Kong has become a key "listening post" for news of what is happening in the sealed domain of its sprawling and dynamic neighbor on the Asiatic mainland.

AMERICAN - born duchesses have never been as plentiful as dandelions, and most of us have never worried about this, but there was a time, not so long ago, when more than one American mother was eager to have her daughter meet a duke at the altar.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Kansas used a strong defensive line to halt Texas Christian's highly advertised spread formation today and Quarterback Gil Reich, former Army star, sparked the offense that gave the Jay Hawks a 13-to-0 victory before the nation's millions of television viewers.

The first new market supply of federally backed public housing bonds in more than eight months is slated to reach the market next week under circumstances that underscore the difficulties that have stalked the permanent financing of the large-scale low-rent program authorized by the 1949 amendments to the Housing Act.

The fire boat Fire Fighter, flagship of the Fire Department's fleet and probably the most powerful fire fighting unit in the world, ran through a few of her paces last week for the fifty firemen who will fill the next lieutenancies in the department.

ACROSS-SECTION view of Israel's growing automotive industry and the strides it has made in the last four years is one of the outstanding features of the Israel Exposition, currently being conducted at 22 West Forty-eighth Street under sponsorship of the State of Israel Bond Organization.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 20 -- A recovery in Bolivian tin exports following the April revolution is indicated in statistics published today by the International Tin Study group.

FOR its first few pages Mary Borden's novel "You, the Jury" appears to be one of those old-fashioned, amiable English novels with its big house and quaint village, Nanny and Vicar, cook and groom, poachers and postmistresses.

UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS BASE, Quantico, Va., Sept. 20 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, who may have to make peace or war decisions if he is elected President, today presented a commission as a second lieutenant in the Marine to his 22-year-old son and namesake, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, who might have to help enforce his father's decisions.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The machine tool industry, backbone of the nation's production might, is pouring out goods at its fastest rate since World War II.

The big press program is really under way. The engineering problems of applying pressures up to 35,000 tons to form complicated aircraft parts at one blow have been solved. The giants are a-borning and by next year great batteries of them will be doing simply what it took unending riveting and welding with bits and pieces to do during World War II.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, attacked today what he described as the "stench of crime and corruption in Washington" and declared it to be "a grave handicap to our international relations."

" WHAT I need most in the world is a back yard," was the unhesitating decision of a 5-year-old boy on his return to a New York apartment from a summer weekend. In a few weeks he will have one. For, like many other parents with growing families, his mother and father are buying a home in the suburbs.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the only way to get an incorruptible Government was to axe out the present Administration, root and branch, and replace it with "incorruptible men and women."

It must come as a complete surprise to those experiencing late summer heat that it is almost time to think of sending Christmas parcels to members of our armed forces overseas. Surprising as the thought may be, the Defense Department has made its early notification based on past experience.

THIS might be called a superescapist novel. When it has run its course, William Burnett, its protagonist, has escaped from the pseudo-intellectual half-world of the London quarterlies into the frenetic half-city that is Venice; from Venice (and a frustrated love affair) to Pescano, a fisherman's island then populated only by the wives of the fishermen; from Pescano back to Venice (and a happy termination of the above-mentioned affair).

The traditionally inflationary blas or the Soviet Union's index of industrial production has been made a permanent feature of Soviet economic calculation, the latest available issue of the official statistical journal Vestnik Statistiki reveals.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 20 -- The perennial cry of famine is being heard again from crowded and poverty stricken South India, where life-giving monsoon rains have failed over a widespread area for the seventh successive year.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Britain, her Government and her people, had occasion this week to think very hard again about her relations with the Continent of Europe and the new federal institutions taking shape there.
A diverse summer program was assembled yesterday by Richard Korn for his first seasonal appearance with the N. B. C. Symphony.

A NEW kind of nation-wide radio network put together with magnetic recording tape is being nurtured by the National Association of Educational. Broadcasters. Seventy stations participate in the network, all non-commercial, the vast majority operated by schools, universities and boards of education.

THE first returns on trans-Atlantic tourist-class flights were read off last week by the International Air Transport Association at its meeting in Geneva and there can be no doubt that the three-month trial period was a great success.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 21 -- United Nations infantrymen, in a two-pronged converging attack, drove Chinese Communist troops from the crest of "Old Baldy" yesterday. The hotly contested outpost hill is west of Chorwon, on the central front in Korea.

We have again seen the Soviet Union run true to form in the use of the veto to bar membership in the United Nations. It has just been used in five cases, the applications of Libya, Japan and the Associated States of Indo-China, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos.

Any chance that the American Federation of Labor would take a neutral stand on the Presidential race appeared yesterday to have been killed by the disclosure that Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, accepted $18,000 from political supporters.

IT WAS an old Italian custom for the girl to set a pot of sweet basil on her window to call her suitor. Nowadays it is the boy (if he remembers custom) who carries a sprig of sweet basil on his person when he goes courting.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 20 -- A determined Temple squad threw a scare into favored Penn State today by taking a third period lead, but the home team scored two touchdowns in the final period for a 20-13 victory in the season's opener for the intrastate rivals before 14,000 spectators at Beaver Field.

There was a heavy demand for holiday and fall goods in the wholesale market here last week and substantial reorders indicated fall activity was good, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Deliveries have slowed and stores are revising their plans. Buying increased on suit lines with fill-ins requested on gabardines, novelty worsteds and boxy jacket types. Coat business was better than last year with fitted types gaining in importance.

THULE, Greenland, Sept. 16 -- The largest group of persons to fly over the North Pole -- thirty-six, including eighteen American and Danish news correspondents -- landed here today upon completing a ten-hour daylight flight to the wastes of the top of the world.

The United States again is being threatened with an unwieldy wheat surplus. With the support price of the cereal at 90 per cent of parity for the next two years, the chances are that the bulk of any surplus will be held by the United States Government.
WHAT is claimed to be "a new experiment in concerts" will be offered this season by the Cooper Union Forum as part of its Sunday evening programs of "Dance, Opera, Orchestra and Folk Song."

A BIRTHDAY party in any language is a cause for rejoicing. Two new books give us variations on that theme, each with a Chinese accent. In "Dee Dee's Birthday" Yen Liang, Peking-born and now with the United Nations Headquarters Planning Office, presents a vivid account of a traditional celebration in China, as experienced by a very small boy.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's speech in St. Louis tonight before the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs:

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- France's negotiations with the rulers of Tunisia and Morocco have reached an apparent deadlock so that there is little probability that the situation will be changed before the United Nations General Assembly is asked to take up both questions by a group of Arab and Asian countries next month.

WHY this masochism men practice upon themselves of wearing clothes they can't stand? From the way they so frequently seem to suffer from their garments, the simple feminine mind is hard put to it not to believe that a sort of self-flagellation is involved, that the shirts so widely and flamboyantly advertised are not of hair.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Seventy-six men, composing chiefly an abbreviated "who's who" of wealthy and influential Southern California business figures, were disclosed today as the contributors to the "supplementary expenditures" fund of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Two Negro women said they were refused admittance today at the University of Alabama.
KONXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman said today that his wife had been on his Congressional office staff since 1942 because he had been unable to find anyone else for the job.

GERTRUDE STEIN'S reputation has undergone a remarkable change. For years she was regarded as the personification of the literary avant garde, and of everything willful and unrestrained in the experimentation of the Twenties and Thirties.

VISITING town last week for the opening of "The Snows of Killimanjaro," Ave Gardner interrupted a late brunch in her hotel suite for a career appraisal of candor not unbecoming to a Hemingway heroine. A surprisingly slender young woman with large green eyes and, apparently, no delusions of grandeur, the actress credited her Hollywood status entirely to luck and photogenic features.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 20 (UP) -- A sharp passing attack and a strong ground game, sparked by the line plunges of Fullback Bob Mathias, gave Stanford University's football team a 28-13 victory over Santa Clara.

THE author of this compelling first novel has lived in both Peru and Argentina on a level of intimacy with the people seldom attained by norte-americanos. The great truth which he presents with exciting and shaming clarity is one that is overlooked in nine-tenths of what is written, spoken or even thought about Latin America -- certainly in "official" or diplomatic circles.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 20 (AP) -- It's still possible to get rich overnight in the oil business without a penny to start on.

By winning his postponed game from the third round and drawing in the fourth, Laszlo Szabo of Hungary advanced to third place in the world championship chess zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden yesterday, according to a report from Stockholm.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 20 -- The Danbury Fair, Connecticut's largest fall agricultural exposition, will open next Saturday and continue daily through Sunday, Oct. 5. The hours each day will be 8:30 A. M. to 6 P. M.

THE American Broadcasting Company television network and the Columbia University School of General Studies, in a cooperative effort, will enable video viewers to participate in an actual seminar in American Civilization given by the school.

In the early morning hours of yesterday a gangland bullet put an end to the crime-ridden career of Eugene (Gene) Giannini, 45 years old, whose twenty-five-year police record included convictions for armed robbery and narcotics smuggling and a murder indictment, later dismissed, in the slaying of a policeman.

THE biggest celebrity in the life of a clothing salesman is a customer, an ambivalent creature with money in his pocket or a charge account in the store, who is always right by rote and sometimes in fact. Seventy-five per cent of all customers may be classified as "good," if not downright docile. The remaining 25 per cent are not bad.

The range of aerial search and the limited movement of ice into the heavily traveled North Atlantic shipping lanes this year made it possible for the Coast Guard's International Ice Patrol to maintain its 1952 safety mission with the aid of a single airplane.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Committee for Economic Development proposed today that this nation notify the Soviet Union and its minions "that the United States will fight, if necessary, to defend strategically vital areas." Where such areas are outside the Atlantic community, it urged that the United States "give clear-cut guarantees" to that effect.

A plan for the temporary outdoor care of thousands of homeless persons following an enemy attack has been formulated by the State Civil Defense Commission as a result of recent civil defense exercises.

THE venerable Jersey Joe Walcott will place his heavyweight championship on the line in Philadelphia's huge Municipal Stadium on Tuesday and defy the rock-fisted Rocky Marciano to take it away from him. There's something peculiarly significant about both the place and the date. In that identical site twenty-six years ago to the day, Gene Tunney achieved one of boxing's monumental upsets.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- In a speech he delivered last Tuesday to 300 surgeons attending the First International Congress of Histopathology (pathology of tissues), Pope Pius laid down a moral code for doctors and medical researchers and severely censured "the pansexual method of a certain school of psychoanalysis."

SOMETIMES great pieces of writing are recognized at once for what they are; sometimes they wait for full discovery. The most obvious example of the delayed reaction, I suppose; is the Gettysburg Address. There seems to be no doubt that Ernest Hemingway's new story belongs in the larger group of immediate reception.

BECAUSE of new methods in handling the bulbs, it is now possible to have lilies that will flower the year after planting. In the past, one of the worst barriers to growing lilies was the fact that bulbs of most kinds could be had only after the ground was frozen for winter.

THIS old port is the one place in the United States which continues the occupation for which it was settled more than three centuries ago: fishing. And at long last it is doing something about commemorating what was its romantic, golden age: the era of the Gloucester schooner, one of the speediest and most graceful of all sailing craft.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Wright Morrow of Houston resigned today as Democratic National Committeeman from Texas because of the views held by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and the "unequivocal" action taken by the State Democratic Convention held recently at Amarillo.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Sept. 20 -- A 245-acre tract on which a former owner had planned a major development of small-lot homes has been purchased by this municipality for $60,000 to prevent the character of the community from changing.

FOR many years Augustus John has been the artist-image among his countrymen. Academic? Not exactly. Profound? That is never a public question to be asked or answered about an artist. But Augustus John, whether he wished it or no, was hauled early into that niche on the social wall which has to be occupied by licensed bravura and bohemianism.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The richest 2-year-old race in the world, a futurity with a purse of $100,000 added at one mile and a sixteenth, will be inaugurated at Garden State Park during the 1953 fall meeting, Eugene Mori, president of the New Jersey course, announced today.

IN a world full of changing relationships, a shift in the attitude of foreign singers toward an American institution like the Metropolitan is a small change, indeed. But a change has taken place that reverses a trend of decades, and it is worth some examination.

THE few to whom so many owed so much, as Mr. Churchill once reminded us, were a gallant, magnificently reckless group, quite unprepared to accept subjection, capture or any discipline except that imposed by the limitations of their aircraft.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Wild Bill Schindler, 43-year-old daredevil of the Indianapolis Speedway and other auto races, was killed today in a big-car event at the Allentown Fair.

AS part of its "Plant America" program, the American Association of Nurserymen recently presented a model back-yard fruit garden -- complete with trees -- to the school children of Detroit for study purposes. Home owners with less than 50 by 70 feet of space to devote to fruit might do well to consider this model planting (see plan), with a view toward having one just like it or developing only a part of it.

THE Sangamon River, which cuts off from the Illinois to the north central part of the state of Illinois, is not an impressive stream. In fact, it is reported that in summer long rows of catfish can be seen standing on their heads in midstream trying to keep their gills moist.

JACK LEVINE is one of the most puzzling of modern American painters. He is puzzling because there seem to be curious contradictions and unresolved conflicts in his work which make him somehow miss achieving the full importance of which he keeps giving shining promise.
Business executives representing twenty-six newspapers in seventeen states will begin tomorrow a one-week seminar conducted by the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

Last week, as hospital experts from all parts of the country convened in Philadelphia at the annual meeting of the American Hospital Association, final plans were being made in the small city of Lebanon, Ore., for the formal opening on Oct. 12 of the 1,000th hospital to be completed under the Hospital Construction and Survey Act.

THE New York City Opera Company elected to open its 1952-53 season last Thursday night with good old "Tosca." The company could not have chosen a work more exemplary of the masterly application of the principles of operatic construction to a dramatic subject than this one, or one better illustrative of the essential differences between opera (Puccini's "Tosca") and drama (Sardou's "La Tosca"), which have been discussed of late in this place.

Over the years the college man has been constantly ready to tread new paths in fashion. Some collegiate fads -- like the raccoon coat -- never took with the general male population. But other enthusiasms -- like the Norwegian loafer or the button-down shirt -- are now as proper in Wall Street as they are in the Harvard Yard.

IN view of the reading public's passion for the works of Ernest Hemingway (whose stock is once more in the ascendant with his current "The Old Man and the Sea"), it is not in the least surprising that Hollywood has made many tries at capturing the substance of their magic -- and their consequent success -- on the screen.

The tercentenary of the incorporation of New Amsterdam will be observed next May in a series of events under the auspices of the Staten Island Historical Society, Dr. Vernon B. Hampton, president, announced yesterday.

JOAN HENRY spent eight months in two of England's prisons -- Halloway, one of the grimmest, and York, the most progressive, the country's only prison-without-bars for women. Whatever her crime (never revealed), society can feel that the score has been evened, for she has given us a warm, entertaining yet serious book.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Cubs eliminated the Cardinals from the National League pennant race today when Warren Hacker pitched the Cubs to a 4-1 victory in a stormy game before a crowd of 14,081 at Wrigley Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau made more than $90,000 worth of bad guess back in 1937 that Ethel Barrymore was finished as an actress.

POLITICAL storm warnings fluttered in the Hollywood breeze last week as the American Federation of Labor Film Council, officially neutral at the moment, but admittedly pro-Democratic party, and Warner Brothers, solidly linked with the Republican Presidential nominee, if not the party itself, became involved in a controversy over the collection of campaign funds for General Eisenhower and his running mate, Senator Richard Nixon.

The equivalent of the income from nearly a quarter of a billion dollars was contributed by graduates and former students of American colleges to their annual alumni funds last year, according to a survey by the American Alumni Council.

Better deposits, loans, investments and rates are combining to push estimates of the 1952 earnings of New York banks to higher levels than were anticipated earlier this year. Third quarter condition statements to be published at the end of this month, it is expected, will indicate a major improvement.

Greatly increased school enrollments everywhere in the country are beginning to have serious repercussions. Reports from various sections of the United States indicate severe overcrowding, lack of adequate teaching facilities, and an increase in part-time or double sessions for the elementary grades.

AT the age of 47, Arthur Koestler has a crowded life to look back on, fuller than that of most octogenarians. This, the first volume of his autobiography, breaking off with the day when he entered the Communist party, deals only with what Bernard Shaw would call his "nonage."
The evening performance on Nov. 6 of "The Millionairess," starring Katharine Hepburn at the Shubert Theatre, has been taken over by the Professional Children's School for its annual benefit.

Arthur Tarshis, former trade paper reporter and promotion man, has become a showman and he "makes no bones" about letting the world know it. To a natural voice and mannerisms that strongly remind one of Ed Wynn he has added props such as woolen hats and ties that defy description. One of his more than 100 chapeaus has a band made of pheasant feathers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 20 -- With Jordan Olivar at the helm for the first time, Yale opened its eightieth season of football today and rewarded its recently named head coach with a 34-to-13 triumph over the University of Connecticut. The contest failed to reveal much about the Elis, as Olivar, perhaps with a thought to tougher games to come, used forty-six players.

* * * It is indeed sad to think of the many deserving Americans of the past who lack biographies when we realize that "Billy the Kid" has had several biographies written about him. He was, of course, nothing but a cheap "punk" who was brave when he had a loaded gun in his hand.

AFTER more than two months of bodily rest and spiritual contemplation, the new Broadway Season opened on Sept. 11 with the sort of drama that begs an old question: Is a second-rate play good enough? Or specifically, is it good enough if it happens to come from another country?

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- Despite some expansion of river and truck transport, the new Five Year Plan specifies that the railroads will continue to be the Soviet Union's prime transport media carrying at the end of 1955 approximately double the freight volume of 1940 and a little more than 82 per cent of all Soviet transport loads.
CONSIDERING his prolific output, it is surprising that there are only two Erroll Garner disks among the recent releases.

THE war in Korea these days is described in short newspaper accounts of air raids, hills captured and lost, naval bombardments and routine patrol activities. Behind all those impersonal communique terms are airmen, soldiers and sailors who fight and die in anonymity now that the spotlight is on the truce negotiations.

WHEN Shirley Booth appears at the Empire Theatre, beginning on Oct. 15, as the star of Arthur Laurents' play, "The Time of the Cuckoo," she will be undertaking her twenty-fifth assignment on the Broadway stage. Her first role, after stock apprenticeship, was in "Hell's Bells," a comedy at Wallack's Theatre in 1925, in which she was the ingenue lead.

Several rabbis of the three branches of Judaism condemned threats to freedom in the United States in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons here yesterday morning. All Jews celebrated yesterday their New Year 5713. Conservative and Orthodox Jews will continue the observance until sunset today.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN it comes to filming Shakespeare, the British have a record of artistic and financial success (vide "Henry V" and "Hamlet") that leaves our movie people green with envy. Now Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has set out to prove that Hollywood, too, can handle the Bard.

Agriculturists are agreed that fall is the most favorable time for replenishing and improving the structure of soils. Six authorities on the subject tell why they think this is so, and give their views as to how the home gardener can best approach the matter of soil improvement:
HAVING been brought up in England, and having three brothers, I was keenly aware at an early age of the importance of the masculine wardrobe in English eyes.

ABOARD THE EISENHOWER SPECIAL, Jefferson City, Mo., Sept. 20 -- This was a gloomy day in Missouri, but it was no gloomier than the Republican gentlemen in the rear of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's campaign train.

IN the dark the old man could feel the morning coming and as he rowed he heard the trembling sound as flying fish left the water and the hissing that their stiff set wings made as they soared away in the darkness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Jerry Barber clung tenaciously to first place today in the national celebrities golf tournament, with a fifty-four-hole total of 209, but Byron Nelson zoomed into second place at 210 with the best golf of the tournament, a 67.

HORSE chestnuts and hickory nuts plummeting from their trees, ripening apples and haws, goldenrod in fields and along roadsides and chrysanthemums in gardens are vivid reminders that tomorrow brings a change of season.

It is hard to imagine what bird watching can be done at night -- except for watchers who specialize in owls. This fall, though, volunteer bird watchers at 200 stations in the forty-eight states, Canada, Mexico and Puerto Rico will be especially busy on moonlit nights, working on the first nationwide study of night bird migration.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 20 -- A struggle was taking place today in the ranks of the Iranian Parliament's Mixed Oil Commission and the National Front politicians to determine whether the prospective Iranian note to Britain and the United States containing Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's counter-proposals to the Churchill-Truman offer for settlement of the Iranian oil problem, should be a grand final gesture in the form of an ultimatum to Britain.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 20 -- President Truman today urged the 541 cadets of the United States Coast Guard Academy here to learn the lesson of leadership if the United States was to retain the foremost position among the nations of the world.

TEL AVIV. RARELY have a people been so conscious of an expressive past as the Israelis. Biblical history and prophecy explain and give meaning to their presence today as an independent nation in Palestine. From Biblical accounts, historical annals and archaeological research the Israelis derive not only spiritual inspiration but physical guidance for charting the future of their fledgling country.

* * * Particularly noteworthy was Mr. Monaghan's reference to William McKendrie Gwin, whose Plan for the Colonization of Sonora "was a subject of much interest and concern to the United States Government and people during the last two years of the Civil War (1864-65)."

WAX begonias and African violets are house plant staples in winter. But a little bouquet of fresh cut garden flowers is a joyful thing indeed on a dark January day. If there is a small greenhouse or conservatory, or oven a south window that provides approximately greenhouse conditions, the indoor gardener can have flowers to pick in midwinter.

Several branches of the New York Public Library will hold during coming weeks film forums and discussions on the power of the ballot in a series of "Register and Vote" meetings arranged by the library and the American Heritage Foundation.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Liverpool scored a 4-1 victory over Middlesbrough today and topped the first division in English soccer with 14 points, one point ahead of Burnley and Blackpool.
For the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club, a theatre party has been arranged by the board of trustees of the club for "Dial 'M' for Murder" at the Plymouth Theatre on the night of Nov. 20.

ATLANTA, Sept. 20 -- Home builders and real estate brokers predicted a "limited" spurt in sales of new housing as a result of the suspension of Regulation X. They emphasized that many lending agencies will continue to require sizeable down payments and that "there is no shortage of mortgage money but a considerable shortage of down payment money."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Bureau of Reclamation announced today that President Truman, during his visit to Hungry Horse Dam in Montana on Oct. 1, will give the signal to start power flowing from the project.

ADMIRAL MAHAN'S "The Influence of Sea Power on History" has long been required reading for naval officers of all nations. The present reader couldn't help feeling that Commander Max Miller's "Always the Mediterranean" might be called "The Influence of Sea Power on Navy Personnel."

THERE is probably no more forlorn creature than an Easter bunny a couple of days after Easter. So Winthrop, a rather plain department store rabbit, was overfed and well petted on Sunday and on Tuesday was almost pulled apart by fractious children.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The "corruption" issue which Republicans had counted on as one of the main points in their campaign took on a wholly new aspect this week as a result of the "Nixon affair."

The world's waters yield annually some twenty million tons of fish, or about a million tons of protein. The Committee on Oceanography of the National Research Council points out that this amounts to only about one-fiftieth of the total consumption of protein and suggests that a world population -- which does not consume enough protein -- may well turn to the sea to feed itself.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- The Fordham football squad that went through a long practice scrimmage against Princeton today had the look of a very capable outfit and afterward Ed Danowski said that this might turn out to be the best of the seven teams he has coached at Rose Hill.

STRASBOURG, Sept. 20 -- Early this week in Strasbourg Paul Reynaud, the aging sphinx-faced Frenchman who presided at the fall of France as the last Premier of the Third Republic before Petain, spoke of "our unhappy Europe * * * Europe parceled out * * * this broken mirror."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 20 -- Changes in the Colombian Constitution, asked by the titular President, Laureano Gomez, in a message to Congress at the opening of its session last October, have aroused heated discussion and charges by the Liberal Opposition that the proposals are a disguised effort by the Conservative Government to get dictatorial powers for the President.

DUBLIN, Sept. 16 -- The town of Athlone, on the banks of the Shannon River, has at last bestirred itself to perpetuate and honor the memory of John Count McCormack, its most distinguished son. A memorial committee has been formed, with Frederick J. Bond as chairman, and plans are in hand to erect a monument to the famous tenor there in his birthplace in the center of Ireland.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The International Court of Justice may be asked to rule whether the United Nations has the legal right to debate the Union of South Africa's racial segregation policies.

Dr. Allen O. Whipple, former Valentine Mott Professor of Surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, will be the guest of honor at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel tomorrow evening. At the dinner a portrait of Dr. Whipple by Elmer Greene of Boston will be unveiled and presented to the Presbyterian Hospital.
Jay Monaghan limits his gallery of American history's neglected characters to explorers, statesmen and writers. * * * What about the unsung heroes of music?

EACH fall, in recent years, has found hunting pressure on the increase and open hunting areas decreasing, and although most states have expanded their game stocking programs, only a very few have developed practical landowner-sportsman programs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A strike Monday by about 170,000 soft coal miners was averted today when John L. Lewis won a steep wage increase for members of the United Mine Workers from northern bituminous operators.
IT was evening. We were on the hill. Below us was the valley, back of the ridge the old mountains, and the sky was full of stars and scudding clouds.

RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 20 -- Construction is scheduled to be completed this year on an atomic reactor on the campus of North Carolina State College here that the college describes as the first to be privately owned and operated.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept. 20 -- An amphibious task force with a reinforced battalion of more than 1,500 United States Marines sailed from the Firth of Forth today for Denmark as the final phases of Exercise Mainbrace opened.

TATIANA Riabouchinska and David Lichine will be guest artists with the Ballet Theatre in the first performance of Lichine's revival of his "Graduation Ballet" on the opening night of the company's season at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday.

ONE of the happiest periods in Handel's life was the three years he spent in Italy as a young man in his beginning twenties. One of the most miserable were those years of the late 1730's when, as he approached the age of 50, he was still struggling with failing operas and had not yet fully developed the oratorio form which was to lead to his ultimate triumph.

They gave Phil Rizzuto an automobile at the Stadium yesterday for having won a popularity contest. A couple of hours later it can be taken for a certainty a roaring crowd of 34,828 would have voted Lil' Phil another one, with special privileges for Hank Bauer and Yogi Berra to ride in the front seat with him.

MOST gardens are gay with color during spring and early summer, when many different kinds of flowers are in bloom. But by August too many borders have settled down to the monotony of phlox, and in September even that may have petered out.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 20 -- Ferman Hanover, a 5-year-old gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., was the winner of the junior free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Driven by Robert Walker, Ferman Hanover held second position most of the mile, moving into the lead at the final stride.

MEN wear too many clothes. They waste too much time getting out of them, too much time getting into them. My solution? A colorful variation of the burnoose, that flowing one-piece garment which has made Moorish and Arabian cavaliers so irresistible to touring blondes throughout the ages.

The report on intra-European trade which has just been issued by the European Payments Union is, on the whole, a heartening document. The British trade deficit in August, in relation to E. P. U. nations was nearly wiped out, almost ending the former substantial gold drain required to meet these deficits.

My interested attention has been drawn to the letter in your issue of Sept. 2 from O. R. Strackbein on the subject of world trade problems and particularly those of Great Britain and the United States.

THE American capitalist comes in for an amazing lot of attention in most of the world outside the United States. His chief publicity agents are the Soviet and Communist propaganda services. Not being hampered by facts, they give a spectacular picture of him.

WASHINGTON, Sept 20 -- The revelation that Senator Nixon, the Republican candidate for Vice President, is endowed by private persons out of a continuing fund, unreported to the income tax authorities either by the contributors or the Senator, is a bombshell and a boomerang.

VERGENNES, Vt. -- Some years ago one of the best-known and canniest natives in this area, his Vermont initiative long piqued by the unhurryable miracle of the autumn leaves, tried a little experiment. On the popular theory that a good frost was needed to start the color, he lopped off a green branch of sugar maple and stuffed it in the freezer.
WACO, Tex., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Cosimo Brocato's field goal from the 11-yard line with 14 seconds to go gave Baylor a dramatic 17-to-14 victory over Wake Forest before 16,000 spectators today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The United Fresh Fruit arid Vegetable[ Association, with headquarters I here, has announced that the PortI of New York Authority would join] next week with others in the filing of a complaint with the Interstate Commee Commission seeking toI void unloading charges levied byl tile raih'oads on fruit and vegetables at New York.

AT this time of year many gardeners are harvesting their late vegetable crops and are about ready to quit for the year. If there is a coldframe on the place, the period of harvest might be extended to Thanksgiving, or even to Christmas.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 -- For just about one hour tonight the Indians were in trouble. The Tigers, with Ted Gray on the hill, enjoyed a 2-0 lead over Mike Garcia and it was so quiet at Municipal Stadium one could almost hear a flag -- an American League flag -- drop. The Yankees had won their matinee game at New York and the Tribe was hardly in position to afford a defeat here.

THE new home owner with a limited amount of space and capital to invest in bulbs will do well to consider which ones will last longest and give the most enjoyment. Those dazzling tulips of brilliant hues and the stately hyacinths are beautiful in the bulb catalogues. But will they be as satisfactory in the long run as, perhaps, daffodils and grape hyacinths?

SHRUBS properly placed and spaced add a beauty to the home grounds that would be difficult to achieve in any other way. Evergreen kinds, with their year-around foliage, certainly merit a spot in any landscape scheme. Many of them also have attractive flowers as well as fruits.

A world-wide slump in cargo offerings has forced the lay-up of scores of ships in major maritime countries, and shipping companies here say there is little prospect that the situation will improve greatly in the immediate future.

About 10,000 surgeons, physicians and technical experts are expected to attend the thirty-eighth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The week-long meeting begins tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- New foreign aid figures revealed today that United States arms shipments to Europe jumped more than 100 per cent during the first six months of 1952. Govern ment officials admit they are elated. They had feared that the whole free world rearmament program would slump badly if the lag in deliveries continued much longer.

AS Lenore Glen Offord has recently pointed out, a mystery reviewer spends much of his time tilting at windmills. Mrs. Offord and James Sandoe and I, to name only three, have consistently leveled our sturdiest lances against the (for lack of a better word) heart of Mickey Spillane; and every time we unanimously assault him as unpublishable and unreadable, his sales go up another million.

ADD The Atlantic Monthly to the list of go-getters in the flourishing field of book clubs. Beginning next month, with James Norman Hall's "My Island Home" as the initial selection, the Atlantic Monthly Book Club will be a going enterprise, with original appeals for membership directed at the magazine's readers.
ON NIXON CAMPAIGN TRAIN, at Eugene, Ore., Sept. 20 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon of California indicated today he had no intention of withdrawing as the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee.

Te Carnegie Institute of Technology is offering a "pay-as-you-go" plan to take care of financing Korean veterans. The veterans will receive their funds from the Government in monthly installments; those without dependencies will get $110 monthly, those with two or more $160.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 12 -- Now that the German-Israeli reparations agreement has been signed, it is possible to lift the curtain on the efforts of Israeli extremists to disrupt the negotiations by violence.

LONDON, Sept 20 -- John Strachey, former Laborite War Minister, who was an ardent admirer of the Soviet Union and a critic of the United States twenty years ago, explained today why he favored friendly cooperation with the United States in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

JAY MONAGHAN'S article, "Forgotten Faces of Our History," was a much needed boost for some of those neglected great * * *.

TITLES of books are often whimsical and so misleading. In this case the name is simple and completely justified. Partly an autobiography, Sir Roderick Jones' book is also, in greater measure, the chronicle of a famous professional house.

UNABLE to get over the death of his 17-year-old son, Dave Barton takes to drink. It helps for a time, but the grief-born dreams return. Dave then tries psychiatry in vain. Finally, he decides to seek the healing solitude of the Adirondacks.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- The Giants were bludgeoned into defeat by the Phillies, 3 to 2, before 21,712 fans tonight, and skidded five games behind the Dodgers in the National League flag chase.

The Brooklyn Dodgers disclosed yesterday that there would be no sale of world series tickets through the mails. Business Manager Harold Parrott said that the club had outlined a completely new and radical plan of ticket distribution "aimed at the satisfaction of the fan in the street."

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON made available last week a photograph of the design of the promised International Red Cross commemorative 3-cent stamp. Depicted is the globe, with the Western Hemisphere featured, illuminated by light radiating from a cross at right. Within a frame of dark background surrounding the vignette, the inscription, "Honoring the International Red Cross Founded -- 1864," appears in white face modified Gothic capital letters at left, top and right.
Florida's black peat muck produced $127,000,000 worth of winter vegetables for the Northern markets last year, according to a report last week by the City of Miami, where the trade centers.

" SUMMER over?" called my neighbor, as she leaned out the top-floor window to find me pulling battle-scarred plants from the boxes on my third-story terrace. It was, indeed. With more than a hint of fall in the cold grayness that clung to Manhattan last Sunday, city gardeners like myself settled down to repair the ravages of summer and get set for the months ahead.
