With more than a hint of fall in the cold grayness that clung to Manhattan last Sunday, city gardeners like myself settled down to repair the ravages of summer and get set for the months ahead.

I doubt very much if Gregory Zilboorg would ever permit any opponent of his to roll the dice illustrating his article, "What Makes People Gamble?" (Sept. 7), depicted on Page 39. Nor do I think he would shoot them himself.

AWARD winners in the Eighth Print-of-the-Year Contest sponsored by The Camera Magazine are announced and their pictures reproduced in the October issue of the magazine. Six of the thirty winners are by camera club members in this area.

Representatives of the Navy, the shipping industry and marine labor joined last week in paying tribute to the achievements of the United Seamen's Service. A luncheon marking the tenth anniversary of the war-born organization was held in the Whitehall Club.

The U. S. coal industry employs a total of 450,000 miners. About 75,000 of them work in the anthracite mines of Pennsylvania. The rest are employed in the bituminous coal fields -- about 65,000 in pits west of the Appalachians, another 200,000 in the northeast, and 100,000 in the southeast.

Two Americans who stowed away on ships bound for Europe so they could renounce their United States citizenship were taken into custody here yesterday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. They were brought back to this country on the Italian liner Vulcania.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 -- In size, atmosphere and crowd reaction the Eisenhower and Stevenson Presidential campaigns are not only different but they seem to differ more as the campaign proceeds.

Perhaps nature thought of everything. At any rate, new studies at the University of California indicate that the animal body may already have an age-old "built-in" safety factor protecting against the hazards of radio-active dust, a peril to life heretofore believed to be unique to the Atomic Age. Research on rabbits by Dr. George V. Taplin suggests that secretions from the respiratory membranes and the action of scavenger cells expels inhaled insoluble radioactive dust.

RETAILERS of both high and low degree took a new lease on life last week. The owner of the corner hardware store joined hands with his much more dignified department store confrere in rejoicing at the suspension of Regulation X.

I suppose you get asked all sorts of questions, so perhaps this one won't stump you. In a photograph of a medal designed for Queen Elizabeth's coronation, in your issue of Sept. 7, why is the Z in Elizabeth backward?

HAVE you ever noticed how one well-grown perennial set out in an odd corner will attract more attention from visitors than a whole group grown conventionally in a border? It's like the fern or violet in the woodland -- the one that has strayed far from its tight little family group to settle in a rock crevice or hollow stump.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 20 -- Colombia caught world attention momentarily when a mob burned two of her leading newspapers and the homes of her two leading Liberal (Opposition) politicians two weeks ago. But that outbreak was only a symptom of a state of chronic crisis that is making Colombia one of the unhappiest countries of South America.

WESTON, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Prominent members of the American theatre met here today to formulate plans for the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy Connecticut, under a bill signed by Gov. John Davis Lodge on July 9, 1951, setting up the project as a nonprofit foundation.

SPRING - FLOWERING bulbs are included on almost every gardener's fall order list. Whether it be for a few pots in the apartment window, a brand-new garden or well-established home grounds, planting a few bulbs for early bloom seems to be almost irresistible.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 -- Despite the increasingly sharp line that divides this city as well as the two halves of Germany, the United States Army still provides a service in Berlin known to some as "Uncle Sam's Guided Tour Behind the Iron Curtain."

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Traveling incognito as "Mrs. Pahlevi," the queen mother of Iran, Esmat Molouk Pahlevi, was injured today when she fell on a staircase of the Holland America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam shortly after the vessel docked at the Fifth Street pier here.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 20 -- The University of Maryland's twelve-game winning streak and national reputation rode the pitching and passing arm of Jack Scarbath and the churning legs of Ralph Felton to a 13-10 victory today over the University of Missouri's Tigers.

RESUMPTION of passenger service between Italian ports and the Near East, disrupted during the war, is announced by the Adriatica Navigation Company of Italy. Six passenger ships are now operating through the Mediterranean, among them the 10,000-ton Esperia, with a capacity of 500 passengers, and five smaller vessels accommodating 300 each.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 16 -- The Copei party, one of the two chief parties in opposition to the present Government, decided this week to take part in the coming general elections Nov. 30.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- One hundred and seventy-five years ago next Oct. 6 this popular scenic and recreation area was a bloody battleground. The year was 1777, the Revolution was barely two years old and the day brought the defeat of the colonial troops and the loss of their twin forts, Clinton and Montgomery, which stood on either side of Popolopen Brook on the banks of the Hudson.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 -- The State Fair, climax of the New Jersey farm exposition season, will open tomorrow, offering a wide variety of entertainment, competition and educational exhibits for adults and children. There will be everything from pink cotton candy and hot dogs to free tuberculosis tests and symphony concerts.

BULBS are almost foolproof, for within the dull outer coating the flowers are already formed and neatly folded into a compact sphere. They await only the warmth and rains of spring to unfold. New varieties for fall planting crowd nursery lists in ever increasing numbers.

Albert H. Morgan, Acting Public Works Commissioner, planned yesterday to confer with his chief engineers tomorrow to decide what to do about installing a regulating mechanism to end sewage overflows in residential Malba, Queens.

LAST week's return of Milton Berle to television was an extraordinary experience in theatre-going. Out in full view before an audience of millions a major star tried to make over his entire personality and adopt a new style of performing.

PALISADES PARK, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Forty New York and New Jersey boys between the ages of 14 and 18 were seized by the police in a school yard here last night, shortly before the scheduled start of an interstate juvenile gang battle.
Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri strolled through Mulberry Street yesterday visiting booths set up for the feast of San Gennaro to raise funds for a Boys Town in Naples, Italy.

For the last forty-two years, except for a brief eight-month stint with a steel company early in his business career, Harold Sines Vance, chairman and president of the Studebaker Corporation, has had one hobby: Studebaker.

OKINAWA. ON war maps in Peiping's moated Imperial Palace and Moscow's white-arched Building of the Red Army some special warning symbols certainly have been crayoned around Okinawa, this spot of Pacific coral where the last battle of World War II was fought -- and from which the Western powers may well make their first major counterstrike if the Communists set off world war III.

TIGHTLY packed dramatic accounts of fourteen American criminal trials make up this book. With one exception, Richard Morris has skillfully laid each courtroom scene in an authentic setting of the relevant political, religious or social climate of its day.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- Statements that Marshal Tito, the Yugoslav Premier, made prior to the arrival in Belgrade of British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden are considered in Rome to be a bad omen for the success of the effort that is about to be made to solve the Trieste question by direct negotiation between Italy and Yugoslavia.

THAT the oak trees of New York State include a European species was first called to my attention by an article in The Conservationist last year. This oak was introduced from Germany in 1882 in the woods on the east shore of Schroon Lake, north of the present hamlet of Adirondack, N. Y.

The weather was warm and wet in the latter part of the week, and as a result stores continued to turn in disappointing sales results. Trade observers estimated the decline from the 1951 week at about 4 per cent. Still merchants were optimistic for the near future and predicted that cooler weather would bring a definite pick-up in sales.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20 -- The conversations between Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Premier Marshal Tito will be resumed Monday at Brdo Castle in Slovenia. The Premier will give Mr. Eden his final views on the dispute with Italy over the question of the free territory of Trieste.
Agnes DeMille in "The Revolution of Isadora's" (Sept. 14) has contrived a splendid summation of the achievement and influence of Isadora Dun can.

AMERICAN TRAGIC BALLADS: The Unquiet Grave, Searching for Lambs, Pretty Sally and others; Andrew Rowan Summers, tenor, accompanying himself on the dulcimer (Folkways). Though his manner is sympathetic, Mr. Summers does not bring enough variety of characterization to these ballads to avoid monotony.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 20 -- Wisconsin political leaders and interested citizens this week have been sorting out the possible explanations for the startlingly wide margin of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's victory in the state's primary on Sept. 9.
A READER complains that all the good plays reported in this column are made with high cards and good hands. As such, he says, they have no instructive value to him.

THE summer is over and now I can throw away the travel brochures and the resort hotel pamphlets that accumulated during that crucial period last spring when I was trying to decide where to spend my first vacation.

IN this autobiography Benjamin L. Gordon tells of his life in Lithuania, his emigration to America and career as a physician, his work as a founder of the Zionist movement in America, his travels in the Near East and Europe, his constant interest in books and things of antiquity.

COOL nights of autumn seem to give roses a depth of color that is not seen in their traditional month of June. A trip to the nearest display garden at this time of year means a chance to look over the latest varieties for fall planting. And there are some good ones, too.

THIS fourth in a series of stories about that hardy Maine lad, Jeff White, takes him into the tall timber to cut pulpwood in the remote, lawless Big Ten section. Even before he and his partner. Skipper Dogget, get to camp they hear rumors that the district is haunted by the ghost of Big Mose, a local Paul Bunyan, dead for twenty years.

Chemists have catholic interests. This is always apparent at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society. Last week in Atlantic City 8,000 chemists and chemical engineers feasted on a great scientific smorgasbord: 1,046 papers were read; they covered subjects ranging from the proper fermentation of Kentucky bourbon to the chemical treatment of tuberculosis.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Henry Campagna streaked 101 yards with a punt today to give Georgia the jump on Vanderbilt and his fellow sophomore, Bob Clemens, scored twice in the fourth period to pace a 19-to-7 victory for the Bulldogs.

CRISSY'S father sold carriages, but he wanted to sell automobiles. The year being 1902, there were few to sympathize with his ambition, except for Crissy. This story, which covers the months during which Crissy helped here father to sell twenty cars and get his agency, is neatly placed in time and setting.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Aided by $5,028,849 in gifts and legacies in the last year, and with seven distinguished faculty members elevated to endowed chairs, Princeton University will open its 207th academic year tomorrow with an undergraduate enrollment of 2,923 students.

Traffic was diverted for an hour late last night on Ninth Avenue at Fifty-third Street when a hand grenade, which turned out to be a harmless war souvenir, was thrown at a restaurant by two youths who escaped on foot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, charged tonight that "political rather than moral considerations" were guiding the Republican leadership in deciding whether to keep or drop Senator Richard M. Nixon as the party's Vice Presidential candidate.
Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate, spent a little more than an hour at luncheon yesterday with Cardinal Spellman at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A Congressman from the Michigan copper country has urged that the price ceiling on domestic copper be raised to 36 1/2 cents or taken off.

Chugging and puffing, twenty-eight venerable automobiles driven by optimistic owners left here yesterday for Washington. The scheduled trip is a revival of the Glidden tour founded in 1905 to persuade a skeptical public that the motor car had come to stay.

TRENTON, Sept. 21 -- Attendance at the New Jersey State Fair exceeded all opening day records today, with 75,000 visitors at the exposition. The crowd came mainly from central Jersey and nearby Pennsylvania. The largest groups arrived about sundown and remained for the evening ice revue.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia upset Australia's Frank Sedgman with an amazing straight set triumph, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 - 4, for the men's singles title in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

Football is a chief topic of conversation at most prep schools these days, and visits to the athletic fields will find boys of varying ages and sizes trying for positions on teams. At most institutions, sports are conducted on so vast a scale that virtually every member of the student body participates.

A plot of land containing 38,000 square feet bounded by the block-front on the west side of Washington Street and fronting 256 feet on Bank Street and 132 feet on West Eleventh Street has been sold by the American Weekly, Inc., to the Bawael Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Price discrimination based on volume of purchases by their customers were charged to four big manufacturers of rubber heels, soles and other shoe repair products today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Eugene Giannini, the racketeer whose body was found in an East Harlem gutter at dawn Saturday, was revealed yesterday as having informed Federal agents of some details of narcotic drugs and counterfeit money deals here and in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret, who didn't play a single practice round in getting ready for the national celebrities tournament, won it today with a 71 for a four-under-par 282.
College football fans enjoyed a fine concoction of thrills and surprises on Saturday, the first day of the season, and the second course next Saturday promises to be even better.
The American Federation of Labor convention, which has been cheering Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson for a week, will get a chance to cheer him in person this morning.

Once every three hours a fire occurs in a school somewhere in the United States and once every six hours in a hospital. Yet many schools and hospitals over the nation are not protected by fire-alarm systems which connect directly with the municipal fire department.
The letter signed R. Mark published in THE TIMES on Sept. 6 reveals such a vast, though all too prevalent, lack of information that it must not pass unanswered.
The Yankees, in disclosing they were ready to accept world series ticket orders, revealed plans yesterday to divide their public distribution into mail and window sales.

BONN, Sept. 21 -- With the ending of autumnal war games from the North Cape to the Alps, the Atlantic alliance will enter a period of review and re-examination of military planning, not only in Europe, but throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Healy Ross, specialist in psychiatric social work, has been named to the new position of Deputy Chief of the Children's Bureau, Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, announced today.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" as given by the New York City Opera Company Saturday night at the City Center was the organization's familiar production of the masterpiece. Extra interest was provided by the presence of three newcomers -- Carl Bamberger on the podium, Laurel Hurley as Zerlina and Randolph Symonette as the Commandant.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Two Michigan Republican leaders are defending in campaign speeches the acceptance of $18,235 by Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, from private sources since his election to the Senate.

Now that the young girl has begun her fall activities, she should have the time to give a second thought to her winter clothes. Has she got a good top coat? Does she need a serviceable dress that can be useful in the daytime and attractive in the evening?
Reports from correspondents of THE TIMES in the forty-eight states indicate a close contest for the Presidency between Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A spokesman for Cuba's sugar industry said today, "We very sincerely hope to lay the groundwork for an international sugar agreement at the London conference starting on Sept. 29."

In times of turmoil, such as the present, men become aware increasingly of their need for certainty, the Right Rev. Gerald A. Ellison, Lord Bishop Suffragan of Willesden, England, declared at the morning service yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, At Sea, Sept. 21 -- An Allied fleet of 200 ships cruised in and near the waters of the North Sea today preparing for the "Battle of Denmark," the climactic phase of Exercise Mainbrace.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Marta Toren packed her bags in a hurry on Friday and started for Rome by plane after having been asked to co-star in "The Life of Puccini."

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- Governor Dewey will launch an intensive campaign for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and the entire Republican national and state tickets with a state-wide telecast from New York Wednesday night.

A House Armed Services subcommittee has just returned from a frontline inspection of our defense positions in the Pacific. Its formal report has not been made, but its acting chairman, Representative Fisher of Texas, has given considerable insight into the consensus of the ten-man group.
BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 21 -- In the wake of a two-car accident, eleven children from 10 months to 21 years of age are without parents today.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon talked for twenty minutes late tonight with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Republican Presidential nominee, presumably on the question of whether the Senator, under fire for using contributions from supporters to help pay his expenses in office, should withdraw as the general's running mate.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UP) -- A committee of six medical experts reported today that the controversial drug krebiozen would not cure cancer.

It is essential to the survival of Western culture and ethics that every Christian ask himself the very question that Jesus asked of common men and kings, "Do men gather grapes from thorns?" the Rev. Dr. Edwin McNeill Poteat, minister of the Pullen Memorial Baptist Church, Raleigh, N. C., declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Riverside Church.

HONG KONG, Sept. 21 -- Every factory in the machine industries in China has been ordered to make an inventory of its productive capacity for the Ministry of First Machine Industries in Peiping by Oct. 10.

The new Italian liner Andrea Doria will make her first seventeen -day cruise to the West Indies from New York on Jan. 30, 1953. William H. McConnell, vice president in charge of passenger traffic for the American Export Lines, agents for the Italian Line, announced yesterday.

The normal traquillity that settles over New York Harbor from sundown Saturday until daybreak Monday -- a period during which maritime activity is at a minimum -- was disrupted briefly yesterday morning as the port welcomed the new $20,000,000 luxury troopship Geiger.

New York State is preparing for the largest emergency collection of fresh blood in history to care for the thousands of persons who may be injured in an atomic bomb attack in the state, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, suggested today that a Congressional committee should investigate Senator Richard M. Nixon's expense fund.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -The Red Sox, who had lost nine straight games to the Senators, rallied with five runs in the ninth inning today to end the string with a 7-to-3 triumph at Griffith Stadium.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 21 -- A nuclear reactor capable of expanding many phases of atomic research, but costing only $50,000, is to be installed in an empty motion picture theatre on the campus of the University of Utah, officials of the Atomic Energy Commission and the university announced yesterday.
The American Lyric Theatre will extend its season through Oct. 18 at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Shooting great, spraying rooster tails astern that rose high into the afternoon sun, four of America's best super-powered speed boats were able to stay in one piece and finish the forty-five miles of the traditional early autumn fixture known as the President's Cup Regatta.

Plans for converting an apartment building into a cooperative for the tenants, if not in conflict with other laws, cannot be construed as a violation of rent control regulations, according to a court decision reported by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.
Falling freight rates have a resulted in scores of privately owned dry cargo vessels being laid up along the United Stages Atlantic seaboard.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 21 -- Italian Premier Alcide De Gasperi arrived here today for a three-day visit during which Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is expected to ask Italy's cooperation in speeding ratification of the European Defense Community treaty by the six member nations.

After moving steadily downward for most of last week, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly firmer on Friday. Active months were down 37 to 53 points from the close of the previous week.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 21 -- The bitter Spanish-Mexican bullfight feud has turned from the general to the particular -- in this case a sizzling clash involving the two men who are possibly the greatest matadors in the ring today, the Spaniard Luis Miguel Dominguin and the Mexican Carlos Ariuza.

Mrs. Bert V. Marien, 28 years old, mother of two boys, observed that "American people drink very much juice but no soup." To a Belgian housewife who, even when transplanted from Louvain to Great Neck, makes soup every second or third day and serves it nightly, this was something as strange as drinking, as Americans said they did, orange juice for breakfast.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 21 -- Thirty-five paratroopers, sparetime soldiers of a Scottish-battalion returning home from the exercise Holdfast maneuvers in Western Germany, made an emergency night jump 800 feet above Renfrew Airport tonight when the undercarriage of their aircraft, a United States C-82 Flying Boxcar, jammed as the plane was approaching to land.

Reports from Paris, headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, confirm estimates from Washington that in recent months deliveries of arms to Western Europe have been speeded up to a point where the defense effort is stimulated all along the line. In the past fortnight several of the member countries have announced that they believe now they can fulfill the NATO schedule for this year.

MAIDENHEAD, England, Sept. 21 -- The spectators were so unruly that an eighteen-hole charity golf match in which Bob Hope and Bing Crosby represented the United States had to be cut to nine holes today at the Temple Golf Club.

President Truman will deliver a major address on civil rights in Harlem on Oct. 11, it was announced here yesterday by the Rev. C. Asapansa-Johnson, president of the Interdenominational Ministers Alliance of Greater New York and Vicinity.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 21 (UP) -- Federal agents arrested an Idaho newspaper executive on a charge of bank robbery today as he gambled in an all-night dice game at a Lake Tahoe casino.

A record net income of $3,086,843 was cleared by Family Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries for the year ended June 30, according to the report issued for release today. Earnings for the period were equal to $1.69 a share on 1,699,703 common shares. This compares with $2,920,671, or $1.78 each on 1,568,891 shares in the previous fiscal year.

The City Planning Commission's annual report covering the year 1951, under the chairmanship of John J. Bennett, gives a glimpse of what real planning could be if this function were adequately staffed and adequately financed. True, things are better than they were, but they aren't what they might be.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Paul Titus, Auburn appliance dealer convicted of misapplication of some $319,000 in Syracuse Trust Company Funds in a retrial will be sentenced Oct 7.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 -- A five-man East German delegation that had been in Bonn to deliver a proposal on German unity to the West German Bundestag returned here this morning. The five were received by Wilhelm Pieck, East German President, who declared their mission a success.

Questioning of contractors who have had any part in building the $8,000,000 sewer network in Laurelton, Queens, will be started this week by Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils, after a preliminary study of contracts and statistics.

For those who were not watching Jimmy Durante and Margaret Truman on the National Broadcasting Company's video network a pleasant surprise was provided by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The new Jackie Gleason TV show, running from 8 to 9 o'clock on Saturday night, wasn't half bad at all.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 21 -- Government sources privately welcomed today the statement by the East German Minister of Agriculture that his Government had no basic objections to discussions with the Israeli Government on compensation for German war crimes and that nothing had been done because Israel had not made any concrete requests.
Casey Stengel still seems to be holding trumps and yesterday he played the most powerful card in his hand, the redoubtable Allie Reynolds.

The sun is swinging lower in the heavens as the days wear on, and pretty soon we shall pass that day -- Sept. 26 -- when the hours of daylight again equal the hours of darkness. Sunset this month occurs two minutes earlier each evening, and before long working people will be arriving home in the dark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Legislation providing Federal supervision and control of bank holding companies and requiring approval of all bank mergers however accomplished was recommended today in a staff report to a judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives.

Your article on the Soviet discovery that baseball was really invented in Russia and that its American form is barbarous and dangerous is indeed news, for the baseball article in volume 4 of the new Large Soviet Encyclopedia, which was officially approved for publication on Aug. 31, 1950, is factual and dispassionate in tone.
The number of day-session undergraduate matriculated students at the four municipal colleges is about 26,000, the same as last year, it was announced yesterday.

The purpose of the Christian Church "is to get people to see what life is for," the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker declared yesterday in his first sermon as pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street.

For the third successive season, Station WQXR, which is operated by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will broadcast this winter its "Musical Talent in Our Schools" concerts, featuring talented high school pianists, violinists and 'cellists, it was announced yesterday by Abram Chasins, music director of the station.

A solemn mass of thanksgiving, at which Cardinal Spellman presided, was offered yesterday in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, 329 West Forty-second Street, the first of three religious ceremonies marking the centennial of the parish. There was a capacity congregation of 1,100.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski and Rookie Jim Greengrass hit a home run each to score all of Cincinnati's runs as the Reds edged the Pirates, 4 -- 3, today at Forbes Field.

Prints of five successful Hollywood films that were seized several years ago in Eastern Germany by agents of the Soviet Union will not be relinquished by that country, despite protests transmitted through the State Department at the request of Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Export Association, it was revealed yesterday by that organization.

ZURICH, Sept. 21 -- Zurich bankers were surprised last week at receiving cable queries from New York asking whether any justification existed for the prediction of various radio commentators in the United States that a business depression might be expected in Germany in the near future.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The Phillies lowered the curtain on the National League baseball season at Shibe Park today and dropped the boom on the Giants' pennant hopes.

" ALL my life I have had emotional measles," says Arthur Koestler in has autobiography, "Arrow in the Blue."* By this he means that he has been emotionally unstable, haunted by a variety of neuroses which he has cherished dearly. They made him interesting to himself, a worthy subject for introspection and self-analysis.

The new signal light pattern to provide two-way progressive traffic flow on West End and Eleventh Avenues between Fortieth and 106th Streets will go into operation Thursday. However, since last Thursday night travel along the upper section of that main thoroughfare has been an irritating experience for all motorists because cable failures have disrupted the signal light system north of Seventy-second Street.

The extension of shopping hours for more night openings by department and specialty stores, while on the increase, should not be merely "copied" by merchants, but examined carefully from the standpoint of profit and local needs, members of a leading retail organization were advised over the week-end.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower talked to his running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, by telephone just before midnight tonight after spending most of the day meditating about whether to recommend the Senator's withdrawal from the Republican ticket.

Mrs. Alieda van Wesep, the only woman among the five vice presidents of Lord Taylor, has been named vice chairman of the Manhattan Women's Committee of the Greater New York Council of Girl Scouts. Seventeen campaign committees in the five boroughs will open a drive on Oct. 8 to raise $650,000 to permit the council to carry on its program for more than 46,000 Girl Scouts.
SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 21 -- R. Dean Messner's My Folly, a consistent show-ring winner, triumphed at the annual Watchung hunter fixture today.

There have been books this year by public relations men who wanted to prove how smart they had been in the past. There have been books full of excruciating detail on the best ways to get around that whimsical, unpredictable clothhead, the editor.

Detective Nicholas J. Cotter, who was wounded in the pistol battle with three escaped convicts in the Bronx, has had an exceptional police record. He has been cited six times for heroism and meritorious duty.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon's asserted political opportunism in breaking away from the delegation of Gov. Earl Warren at the Republican National Convention to accept the Vice Presidential nomination is believed partly responsible for the current publicity about his $18,235 "supplementary expenditures" fund.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Bill Serena hit a two-run homer off Joe Presko in the seventh inning today to enable the Cubs to score a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Since July when the two major parties in the United States nominated their candidates for President, there has been a noticeable increase of sentiment in this country for the Democratic nominee, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois.
For the homemaker interested in antiques or making useful objects several courses are starting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation in an estimate issued today said that the nation's crime toll would exceed 2,000,000 major offenses this year. The agency reported a 6.4 per cent increase in crime for the first half of 1952 against the corresponding period last year.
Except for a modest show of strength in spot sterling late on Tuesday and carried into Wednesday's session, interest in the other foreign exchanges last week was extremely light.
SUDBURY, Ont., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Three mining men here have reported discovery of large deposits of kyanite, a mineral which has become valuable recently in construction of jet aircraft.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- The comprehensive program drafted by Soviet engineers for the harnessing of the energy resources of Siberia's fabulous Angara River would provide power sufficient for installations with a capacity of 9,000,000 kilowatts -- several times greater than projected plans for Niagara Falls.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Sept. 21 -- The best-in-show spot went to a bloodhound, Ch. Fancy Bombardier, owned by Tom and Pearl Sheahan of Torrington in the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club's fixture today. Bombardier was named for his first show victory by Anna Katherine Nicholas. Tom Sheahan handled the winner.

The New York Americans of the American Soccer League, minus some of their regulars, were defeated, 3 to 1, by a picked team of the National League in the first game of a double-header at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, who prides himself on being in "the liberal school" of the Republican party, said today he thought Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, had made "a mistake in judgment" and followed an "unwise policy" in accepting funds from private sources to meet the supplementary expenses of his office.

In the great days of polar exploration the would-be discoverers established bases, from which, with infinite labor and hardship, they pushed slowly northward. The late Admiral Robert E. Peary got to the North Pole only after more than a quarter of a century of struggle, and his exploit made resounding news when word of it reached this country forty-three years ago this month.

The variety of art events this week includes an exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by Rembrandt opening at the Metropolitan on Friday, a showing of paintings and graphic work by Picasso from the period 1920-25 at Curt Valentin's tomorrow and an exhibit of paintings by Pascin at the Perls Gallery today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who is seeking re-election in Wisconsin, issued this statement today on behalf of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate:

A city detective was dead and another was fighting for his life last night because three prison breakers had taken the wrong road. The desperate men arrived here by mistake, it was learned yesterday, after spreading terror through the countryside for a week after their escape from the Federal Penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pa., on Sept. 10.

The largest decrease in public assistance cases recorded in the last two years occurred last month, Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, noted yesterday in his report to Mayor Impellitteri for August. The number receiving assistance dropped to 280,846 from 285,782 in July.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 21 -- Shouts from the galleries in the Municipal Council (board of aldermen) resulted in suspending the session three times yesterday during a discussion of a bill offered by Mayor Joao Carlos Vital to increase taxes on merchants almost 100 per cent.

THULE AIR BASE, Greenland, Sept. 19 -- Eighteen months ago Thule, named for classical-mythological references to the outermost habitable part of the world, consisted of a small Eskimo village, a rough air strip built in 1946, and a 90,000-acre area, unusually flat for this section of the Arctic lands.
Possessing the means to satisfy physical wants is not a short cut to spiritual contentedness, it was maintained in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons here yesterday morning.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 21 -- John Muhlfeld with Ajax in the Quincy Adams-17 class and Russ Hall with Loon III among the Lightnings were named season champions at the Riverside Yacht Club today following the final regatta of the campaign.

The East German parliamentary delegation appears to have made a mess of its unity and propaganda mission to Bonn. What came out of it was that the Russians would levy reparations on a united Germany and that they control the security police. In any event, the East Germans met a popular hostility in Bonn which was impressive, and unity is certainly as far off as ever.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Forty Bulgarian Roman Catholics, including twenty-eight priests, have been accused by the Communist Government in Sofia of planning a coup d'etat and spying for the Vatican and France, the Moscow radio said early today.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The stock markets last week developed a somewhat deflated appearance. This downward movement in security values has been described by market men as a technical reaction after the prolonged rise.

The city has been warned by bankers and investment experts that the status of its outstanding bonds as prime investments may be impaired unless the Second Avenue subway project and related transit improvements are postponed, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today private and public debt rose $33,000,000,000 during 1951.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- The executive manager of the American Transit Association held here today that "the American motoring public is on the verge of mass apoplexy from traffic frustration."

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Restricting the opposition to three third-period goals, Pete Bostwick's Bostwick Field four rode to a 9-3, triumph over the Milwaukee Shamrocks today as play in the National 20-goal polo championship tournament was resumed at Bostwick Field.

I would appreciate the opportunity to comment briefly on the purely practical financial aspects of the agreement signed on Sept. 10 in Luxembourg City Hall by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer for West Germany, Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett for Israel and Dr. Nahum Goldman for the Jewish Claims Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, today complained that the drinking public was paying too much for legitimate liquor and said that there were too few revenue agents to combat the bootlegging of moonshine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Defense Production Administration (D. P. A.) announced today that steel allocations to civilian industries in the first quarter 1953 will be about 25 per cent below the quotas for the last quarter of this year.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Rene Pleven, France's Minister of National Defense today reminded Frenchmen that their country was saved by the "miracle of the Marne" thirty-eight years ago partly because French conscripts then served twice as long in the armed forces as they do today.

A four-story building containing thirty-eight apartments and six stores and occupying a plot 120 by 100 feet at 126 East Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Penrose Real Estate Company to Harry Molberger for investment in a deal negotiated by David B. Applebaum and Morris I. Tucker, brokers.

Motifs inspired by such divergent sources as rustic Americana and Chinese antiquity keynote a new group of drapery fabrics available through decorators from Morton Sundour, 40 East Fifty-third Street.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 22 -- American Sabre jets patrolling the Manchurian frontier downed four more of the enemy's Russian-designed MIG fighters yesterday in an air battle that produced the Fifth Air Force's twentieth jet ace of the Korean war.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- One thousand persons crowded the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church here today for a service marking the 100th anniversary of the dedication of the building. Many came in costumes of the Eighteen Fifties.

Rocket ships and interplanetary travel were discussed for an hour yesterday before 700 high school students, with the questions including: "When will man travel to the moon?" and "How soon could a space ship be built?"
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Dean Chenoweth of Xenia, Ohio, won three of nine races on Lake Merritt today to outshine his elders in the national stock outboard championships.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Billy Pierce and the White Sox defeated the Browns, 4 to 1, in the season's final 1952 American League game in Sportsman's Park today.

Tullio Serafin conducted his first "Traviata" last night at the City Center, with Frances Yeend, David Poleri and Walter Cassel in the principal roles. The courtly, aristocratic Prelude that Mr. Serafin directed supplied the key to the rest of the opera.
BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Joe Black made his first major league start today, hurled a three-hitter and gave no earned runs as the Dodgers beat the Braves, 8 -- 2, for a sweep of the three-game series.

Even though there is good reason to suspect a publicity stunt in a letter sent earlier this month by Frederic R. Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Inc., to Harry Sheresky, president of Hutton's Restaurant, it is still worthy of mention in this type of column.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Noting that familiarity with the safgueards of popular government and free elections places Americans in increasing danger of considering these rights "as natural as the sunrise," Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, called today for a searching personal examination of the citizen's function in a republic.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- If Charles Chaplin, now on his way to Britain, should be barred from reentering the United States, he would be welcome to stay here in his native country and make motion pictures, several prominent persons stated today.

At least four different breaks in a 48-inch water main under Fifth Avenue at Seventeenth Street sent water flooding nearby basements up to more than a foot in depth, and coursing an inch or so deep across sidewalks for several blocks yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 21 (UP) -- Four car passengers were killed tonight when the landing gear of an Army C-47 transport plane coming in for a landing ripped off the auto's top. The plane later made a "belly" landing at near-by Truax Field, but none of its twelve passengers, all Air Force personnel, or the pilot were injured.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 21 -- The City Zoning Board will meet with the Planning Commission on Wednesday night to review and establish procedural requirements for a "designed" area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- John L. Lewis, who negotiated a wage increase of $1.90 a day for his Northern soft coal miners, still has to overcome the obstacle of Government controls, and there was some question today as to whether, or how, he could do it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The Army said today it would offer new indefinite-term appointments soon to the 250,000 Reserve officers and warrant officers not on active duty now. A similar plan was announced last month for those on active duty.

ROME, Sept. 21 - - For the second Sunday in succession the police prevented the Church of Christ, a United States sect that is carrying on missionary activities in Italy, from holding religious services in its Rome premises. Three United States missionaries and about twenty-five Italian members of the congregation later drove in five taxis to San Cesareo where they attended Sunday services in an authorized Church of Christ house of worship.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 -- The Indians battered the Tigers, 7 -- 1, behind Bob Lemon's 4-hit pitching for his twenty-first victory of the season today. But the greatest excitement developed after, not during the game at Municipal Stadium.
TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,380, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korea time:

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Joseph Pois, Illinois' state director of finance, declared tonight that there was no "analogy" between his position as an appointed state official in the administration of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President, and that of public officials charged with accepting money for furthering their political fortunes.

Inequality of wages received by Soviet industrial workers probably is substantially greater than wage inequality among such workers in the United States, a report to be issued this week by the Department of Labor indicates.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- Chiefs of police from all parts of the country joined with others from foreign lands at the fifty-ninth annual conference of the International Association of Chiefs of Police today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 -- Dr. Fenn E. Poole, physician and surgeon and an authority on industrial and aero medicine, was killed instantly early today in a two-car crash. His age was 46.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Interest in the grain market last week centered largely on developments in the September deliveries, which have been influenced by the usual evening-up tactics of both shorts and longs. The trade in September wheat was orderly with no conspicuous change in prices. In September corn there was a sharp decline on liquidation, while the reaction in oats was moderate.

David O. Selznick, who produced the motion picture "Gone With the Wind," has taken steps to bring a musical version of that work to the stage within the next two years under the title "Scarlett O'Hara."
