STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The ruling coalition of Social Democrats and Agrarians won Sweden's parliamentary elections today, but by a smaller margin than previously.

THE Beau Ideal of the fight mob is what its most articulate spokesman, Francis Albertanti, blissfully describes as "a gutter fighter." It isn't a nice-sounding term and isn't meant to be one. But, it graphically characterizes the pugilist as to type.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Dick Sheehan, who raced for years in the handicap class and last winter purchased the International sloop Myyen, won his first race with her today.
Seven new films, including one from Italy and one from England, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. They are:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Senator Richard M. Nixon bought a $41,000 home here eight months after his election, to the Senate, public records in the Office of Recorder of Deeds for the District of Columbia indicated today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- A cheering crowd of several hundred persons greeted Senator Richard M. Nixon this afternoon on his arrival here in his home district from Portland, Ore., to make a nationwide talk, over television and radio, about the controversial $18,235 special-expense fund given to him over a two-year period by a group of wealthy Southern California supporters.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Joe Tavernelli, new head football coach at Peekskill Military Academy, is confronted with a hard task this season. The former Boston University lineman, who hails from Plymouth, Mass., inherited a green squad when he was named to take over the job handled last year by Lieut. James Riter.

On next Monday trading hours of the New York Cotton Exchange will be extended by a half hour daily. The Exchange will open at 10:30 A. M. and close at 3:30 P. M. The extension was voted by the members yesterday, 227 to 14.

The trend to the use of photographs instead of art work by retail stores is bound to increase but it is important that the stores be taught their proper use, according to Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Dow Chemical Company's board of directors authorized and offering of 625,000 shares of common stock today to its employes and common stockholders.

The British Foreign Office has announced that a further protest has been made to the Chinese Communists on the subject of the imprisonment or house arrest of Western nationals. In this case the United Kingdom was acting on behalf of Canada, Australia and the United States as well as itself.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation, after refusing for three years to accept crime figures supplied by the New York City Police Department on the ground of "incomplete data," has again accepted these figures and included them in its current Uniform Crime Reports for the country, issued Sunday. The bulletin covers the first six months of 1952.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- About 4,000 green-uniformed members of West Germany's Frontier Police (Bundesgrenzschutz) began today an armed field exercise.

PROVIDENCE, R. I, Sept 22 -- "Everything is going as well as could be expected" with Brown's football team, to quote Alva Kelley, the energetic 33-year-old Cornell graduate who is starting his second season as coach of the Bruins.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- Five men and a woman, identified as leaders of the Communist party in Michigan, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The official Chinese Communist radio said today that the release of South Korean war prisoners by the United Nations made the basis of the armistice negotiations "null and void."

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson spent a busy day here yesterday, speaking to the American Federation of Labor in the morning, attending a campaign fund-raising luncheon afterward and then devoting the rest of the afternoon to a round of conferences in his Biltmore Hotel suite.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower blamed tonight the "incompetence" of the Democratic Administration leaders for the Soviet blockade of Berlin, the Korean war and the loss of China and declared that they had condemned the American people "to live in a purgatory of improvisation."

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 22 -- Military advisers of the United States, Australia and New Zealand opened a three-day conference on Pacific defense planning here today with an announcement that there would not be enough unclassified material discussed to warrant a daily conference communique. A spokesman said that any information released would be contained in a single communique at its conclusion.

It is disheartening to read in a statement given out by Director J. Edgar Hoover of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that crime in this country is increasing. The indications are that there will be over two million major offenses this year, or one for approximately each seventy-five of the population.

The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee that is investigating communism in schools examined in private yesterday most of the officers of the Teachers Union, preparatory to calling them to the stand in the second phase of its public hearings, starting at 9 A. M. today in the Federal Court House on Foley Square.

Rumors that the Bahia cocoa crop would be smaller than expected boosted Cocoa Exchange prices 75 to 66 points in trading yesterday, and touched off a chain of denials and explanations. A spokesman for the Bahia Cocoa Trade Commission told THE NEW YORK TIMES that, so far as he knew, the report had no official basis.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Doctors at the University of Minnesota announced today that they had performed a delicate heart operation successfully on a 5-year-old girl by "deep freezing" her to 79 degrees and temporarily stopping the flow of her blood.

A Queens field inspector asserted yesterday that where violations occurred on the $185,679 Victor Clemente sewer project in Laurelton, "such violations were with the consent and approval, expressed or implied, of the engineer in charge, Gerard Brinkman."

The question whether the socialization of medicine in Great Britain will deprive St. Dunstan's, a charitable organization in London caring for men and women blinded in war service, of a legacy of $200,000 was posed yesterday in a construction proceeding before Surrogate George Frankenthaler.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today issued a press statement about the pink bollworm -- a cotton crop insect pest -- that later caused embarrassment to some officials.

ACCORDING to records, the Puritan Fathers opposed bull and bear baiting, not because these activities were rather rough on the bull and the bear, but because they gave the people worldly pleasure, and it now appears that some modern hunters are opposed to the shooting preserves for a similar reason.

BERLIN, Sept. 22 -- Paul P. Roudakoff, chief protocol officer for United States authorities in Berlin, met Soviet officials today and discussed with them the initiation of a joint investgation into the case of Dr. Walter Linse, anti-Communist German jurist widely believed to have been kidnapped by Soviet order last July 8.

MADRID, Sept. 22 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs today informed the Rev. Paul E. Freed of Greensboro, N. C., a Baptist minister, that "foreign intervention" on behalf of Spanish Protestants would do more harm than good because it was viewed by the Roman Catholic population with the "greatest distaste."

Describing himself as "one of the old fashioned coaches," Charlie Caldwell, Princeton mentor, expressed the belief that rushing rather than passing is the basic attack in football, as he addressed the Football Writers Association refresher clinic held yesterday at Toots Shor's.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- When Sancho Panza repeated to Don Quixote the saying that the pot called the kettle black and told it to "get away," he did not relate whether the kettle obeyed the order; or replied in kind, stayed where it was and let the public decide which was the blacker.

While Jack Gross was testifying for the ninth day in the Criminal Courts Building at the departmental trial of thirty-one suspended plainclothes men, four former bookmaking employes of his brother. Harry, were freed yesterday in Brooklyn Special Session Court for cooperating in the police graft trials.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 22 -- Gen. Isaias Medina Angarita, former President of Venezuela, returned today after an exile of almost seven years. He had been imprisoned by the Accion Democratica Government in November, 1945, and expelled the following January.

The retreat from the left that has been a feature of most recent developments in Europe has manifested itself again in the latest parliamentary elections in Sweden. The Social Democrats have lost their non-Communist plurality, the Communist vote has been virtually slashed in two, and the only parties to register gains have been the Conservatives and Liberals.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 22 -- In the initial race of the team match for the Skoal Trophy between international class yachts of Norway and this country the American skippers won a long drawn out contest that finished in semi-darkness this evening.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- The conversations between Marshal Tito and Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, ended tonight in the hope of an easing in Yugoslav-Italian relations that would enable the two governments to resume normal relations and to cooperate on problems not related to the Trieste dispute.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Prices continued to fall in all parts of the Stock Exchange today. The reaction was started by weakness of British Government securities which, under light but persistent selling, lost as much as five-eighths of 1 per cent. They carried industrials lower, although losses here were generally limited to a few pence.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. Sept. 22 (AP) -- An increase of 10,000,000 tons of coke for 1953 was called for today by Charles W. Connor, Defense Solid Fuels Administrator. In a speech prepared for delivery at the annual meeting of the American Coke and Coal Chemicals Institute, Mr. Connor said united efforts are required in the coke and coal chemical industry to prevent what he called "a grave shortage" of coke.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The opening of a drive to enlist medical, dental, legal, engineering and other professional men and women in support of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates, was announced here today.

Three men were held in a total of $60,000 bail last night in Kings County Court as material witnesses in a waterfront racket involving the resale of "sweepings" of coffee, cocoa and tea from Brooklyn docks.

CAIRO, Sept. 22 -- There were strong indications today that the Administration was seeking to unseat former Premier Mustafa Nahas as leader of the Wafd, Egypt's largest political party and long the symbol of Egyptian nationalism.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- New England industry received a blueprint of new opportunities for future growth today as part of a continuing study of the regional economy by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. Reports on the outlook for textile and leather products deliberately were omitted, it was explained, as both of those basic industries had been thoroughly investigated in the past.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The King Ranch of Robert J. Kleberg gained its initial victory of the meeting when Armagh beat four other 3-year-olds in the Jericho Purse before 11,000 race-goers today.

John Notte, first-string end on the New York University football team, will be out of action for more than a month because of torn ligaments in his left knee. Notte was injured during a light passing scrimmage last week.

The Binsky Parcel Service has leased the one-story garage-type building on a plot 43 by 100 feet at 218-33 Ninety-eighth Street in Queens Village, Queens, from Robert S. Greenfield and will use it for a trucking terminal and warehouse. Colony Realty was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The political furor over the private expense fund of Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, may take a grave turn. Tonight it was learned that Attorney General James P. McGranery was awaiting Senator Nixon's explanation with more than casual interest.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 22 -- A guarantee of harmonious labor relations in the future may help continue the operation of the Claremont Terminal here, even after the Army moves out on Oct. 31, George C. Dade, president of Dade Brothers, Inc., the stevedoring concern that holds the lease on the pier, indicated today.

Our City Hall reporter has revealed that it was a warning from bankers and investment experts that was largely responsible for a Board of Estimate decision last week to delay for three months any steps to proceed with construction of the Second Avenue subway.

The two-story garden-type apartment house accommodating sixteen families at 2566-76 East Sixth Street, Brooklyn, has been resold by a syndicate represented by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York to a client of Milton J. Goell, attorney.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The new contract between the United Mine Workers and the northern soft coal operators contains language discouraging lawsuits but, in the operators' opinion, does not bar them from suing for violation of contract.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 22 -- In another step toward insuring peaceful elections, President Otilio Ulate Blanco has prohibited the importation or carrying of firearms, La Hora, his newspaper, announced today. The penalty for violations of this decree will be imprisonment for six months to two years, the announcement said.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Harvard University announced tonight the election of Gen. Lucius D. Clay of New York as one of five new members of the council of the Harvard Foundation for Advanced Study and Research.

As had been expected, Governor Stevenson reaffirmed his stand in favor of repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act in his speech yesterday before the American Federation of Labor. In this connection he stood pat on his Labor Day speech, in which he outlined five principles he would follow in writing a new labor relations law.

Of the many myths which circulate about the Soviet Union and the Stalinist doctrine on which that country is based one of the most persistent and most false is the notion that in some way Russia has worked or is working toward equality of human beings, economically and otherwise.

BUXTON, England, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- Japenese delegates to the international cotton conference here today showed a movie on working conditions in Japan to quash London press reports that their supremacy over Britain in world markets was gained through "sweated labor."

Military reserve officer training in America's colleges is essential to the nation's security, New York University R. O. T. C. students were told yesterday by Frank L. Howley, N. Y. U. vice chancellor and a retired brigadier general. General Howley, American commandant of Berlin during the 1948-49 Russian blockade, addressed an opening ceremony of the Air Force R. O. T. C. unit as the university's Washington Square Center.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 209 battle casualties in Korea in a new list that retported 40 killed, 161 wounded, 6 missing and 2 injured. The following were listed from New York (none from New Jersey or Connecticut):
OTTAWA, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Canada rolled up her biggest monthly world trading credit of the year in July and put herself $197,000,000 in the black for the first seven months of 1952.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 22 -- The crisis has now come in the struggle for Texas.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Americans were cautioned today to stand firm for local law enforcement and not to hand over such responsibilities to the states or the Federal government.
CHERBOURG, France, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin, in a jovial, holiday mood, said today threats to bar him from the United States had not altered his plans to return there in about six months.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The Georgian Communist party has been placed on warning that Georgia's exposed geographic position adjacent to the Turkish frontier requires special vigilance because of hostile activities of the United States directed from Turkey and efforts of the Turkish intelligence service.
SALEM, N. H., Sept. 22 (UP) -- Anthony (Tony) DeSpirito, the nation's leading rider, increased his 1952 victory total to 243 today when he handled five straight winners at Rockingham Park.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,381, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

Improvement of city street-cleaning and housing-inspection services and new means to discourage "speculation in human misery" were urged yesterday by City Council President Rudolph Halley and City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs to end "ghettoes" here.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Lou Perini, president of the seventh-place Braves, plans to keep the National League baseball club in Boston, but says "I'm not going to be stubborn about it."

Thirteen local ship-repair concerns have been found guilty by the enforcement commission of the regional Wage Stabilization Board of paying over-the-ceiling wages and making false statements to the board.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Col. Harley L. Swift, president of the American Transit Association, said here today that there is a definite note of optimism in the nation's transit industry this year after a steady decline in transit riding since the end of World War II.

Three more projects to increase the domestic production of sulphur have been put in operation in recent weeks, bringing to almost 600,000 long tons annually the amount of productive capacity added in North America this year.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Sir Miles Thomas, chairman of the British Overseas Airways Corporation, said today that wind strengths at 40,000 feet over the North Atlantic must be explored before anyone could tell whether the Comet II, improved version of the first commercial jetliner, could operate regular service between London and New York.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 -- Delegates in the annual convention of the National Council of Catholic Women were told here today that women of the world have been singled out as leaders in the task of restoring peace.

The strained capital investment of the aircraft industry can be protected by a Government procurement policy that will permit attainment of high efficiency in production of military airplanes, the National Credit Office asserted yesterday.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company was not the plaintiff in a recent suit before the Supreme Court to clarify rent control laws in regard to the right of an owner to convert an apartment house into a tenant-owned cooperative building. It was incorrectly stated in these columns yesterday that the Tishman company, in conjunction with others, brought suit.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Chou Enlai, Chinese Premier and Foreign Minister, said in a speech on his departure from Moscow this morning that Soviet-Chinese relations had been strengthened by his talks with Premier Stalin and high Soviet leaders. He warned that any effort to disrupt Chinese-Russian friendship was doomed to failure.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, the Democratic Presidential nominee, was challenged today to "acknowledge publicly" that he had approved financial assistance to appointed members of his administration in Springfield during the last four years.
The bust of a Sicilian-born Civil War general was presented to the city yesterday by the Italo-American Association of Sicily, and accepted by New York's Sicilian-born Mayor.

Carrie Munn's collection of fall custom and wholesale designs, viewed yesterday at the salon at 640 Madison Avenue, had the same saucy gaiety and full-skirted charm of a Dresden shepherdess. One had the feeling that the designer had great fun creating these fashions, never taking them seriously.

WENTWORTH-BY-THE-SEA, N. H., Sept. 22 -- "Savings banking today faces the greatest challenges of its long career of service in the cause of thrift. Only organized savings banking can find the answers to these challenges," declared Raymond Rodgers,

TORONTO, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The partnership agreement between Sears, Roebuck Co. of Chicago and Simpsons, Ltd,. of Toronto provides that the big United States mail-order house and the Toronto company will form a new firm to purchase the mail order agency and order office business of Simpsons, the purchase to be made as of Jan. 7, 1953.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Structural changes in the Communist party proposed for approval by the nineteenth party congress in October are directly related to the principle of "democratic centralism," in the opinion of the editor of the Communist Central Committee's chief theoretical and political organ, the magazine Bolshevik.

Two large new blast furnaces, with a combined capacity of 1,000,000 tons of pig iron a year, were placed in operation yesterday at steel-making divisions of the National Steel Corporation, according to an announcement by Ernest T. Weir, chairman.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- Only one length separated the Indians and the idle Yankees following the Tribe's 6 -- 3 defeat of the Tigers today at Municipal Stadium. A glance at the standings reveals the top two teams deadlocked in the games won column, each with 90.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Early strength in grain futures and in soybeans was deceptive this morning, as there was little buying following the early upturns. Selling increased and the tone was weak in all pits before the close of the session.
DUMONT, N. J., Sept. 22 -- A boy just turned 13 became today what is probably the youngest Community Chest trustee in the country.
ABOARD THE EISENHOWER SPECIAL, Sept. 22 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is still adopting a "wait and see" attitude on the Nixon case.

THE art of being a perfect courtier is an ancient one and will probably endure as long as those in positions of power and influence like to have other less important people flatter them, wait upon them, smooth away the little inconveniences of life and do everything possible to make an agreeable existence even more agreeable.

Production of raw steel by domestic mills this week is scheduled to be the third largest weekly output thus far in 1952. With operations slated at 102.3 per cent of theoretical capacity, the industry's furnaces are expected to pour 2,125,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- Charges that Ohioans in the low-income groups "can't afford to be sick" and that hospitals are "getting all the traffic will bear," were made here today before the President's Commission on Health Needs of the Nation at a regional meeting.
The Department of Sanitation opened a city-wide anti-litter drive yesterday against shopkeepers who illegally stuff their rubbish into the city's sidewalk wire trash baskets.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich is writing a new opera. The Moscow radio says he got his inspiration after reading the draft for the forthcoming congress of the Soviet Communist party to be held Oct. 5.
A Brooklyn ambulance driver gave the police an assist yesterday in the apprehension of four youths who allegedly attacked a laundry worker and stole $27.

TORONTO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Sears Roebuck Co. of Chicago and Simpsons, Ltd., one of Canada's largest mercantile concerns, have signed an official agreement for a partnership, it was announced by E. G. Burton, Simpsons president.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Jersey Joe Walcott, world heavyweight champion, and Rocky Marciano, Brockton, Mass., undefeated challenger with a paralyzing punch, tonight were poised and ready on the eve of their title fight tomorrow night in Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Republican Governors launched their "Choosing the Right President" radio series tonight with an attack upon the record and associations of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee, while he was in the State Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Prime Minister Oscar Torp of Norway today unveiled a massive mural painting that complete his Government's gift to the United Nations of decorations for the Security Council chamber.

Elmer Schuer, sole survivor of three escaped convicts who engaged in a fatal pistol battle early Sunday in which one detective was killed and another critically wounded, sought yesterday in Felony Court to shift the blame to his two dead partners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The White House looks beautiful, Mrs. Ernest L. Ives, who will be hostess for her brother, Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois, if he is elected President, said today after a teatime visit with Mrs. Harry S. Truman.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 22 -- Senator Nixon left Portland in the midst of a controversy without disclosing whether he was staying or quitting as the running mate of General Eisenhower, the party's Presidential standard bearer.
BALDWIN, L. I., Sept. 22 -- Fred Amsterdam and Bob Stuhler of the Bayside Golf Club swept the honors in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at Willow Brook tday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Truman was telling some glamorous actresses from India today about his anxiety for world peace when--bang!--the peace of the White House Rose Garden was shattered.

Ireene Wicker, whose "Singing Lady" television program went off the air two years ago, will return in a new program entitled "Little Lady Party" over Channel 5 on Sunday from 12 noon to 12:30 P. M. Miss Wicker will be featured as a hostess at a weekly children's party, at which she introduces young performers and tells classic children's stories.

BUXTON, England, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Reports from the ten-nation Cotton Conference here today indicated United States delegates are at loggerheads with British representatives over Japan's future role in the world textile market.

The Timken-Detroit Axle Company had the highest sales in its forty-three year history in the fiscal year ended on June 30, the total of $233,338,334 exceeding the previous year by 61 per cent. About 53 per cent of sales was for Government purposes compared with 24 per cent in the year ended June 30, 1951.

Continuing argument on an acquittal motion in the trial of fifteen secondary Communist party leaders, defense counsel denied yesterday the charge that the defendants conspired for the violent overthrow of the Government. They said prosecution testimony showed only that they sought scientific socialism.
The appointment of Giuseppe Ali as general representative .of the Italian Line in the United States and Canada was announced yesterday by the American Export Lines, agent here for the Ilian Line.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 22 -- Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, said today he had never heard of any other Senator's having a political fund such as that set up for Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential choice.
The New York Giants football team will leave by train tonight for Dallas where they will open their National Football League season against the Dallas Texans on Sunday.

SKAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 22 (AP) -- United States Marines who swarmed ashore on Skagen's sandy beach in a mock amphibious landing today were showered with Communist propaganda leaflets. An uninvited Russian merchant ship also figured in the day's happenings.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The furor set off by the Nixon incident prompted fresh suggestions today that United States Senators get more money from the Government.

A photograph of some banana bread for teatime, appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine a couple of Sundays ago as an example of a well-made product, apparently quickened the appetites of several readers, who have asked us for a recipe for it.

Buying interest in the television and railroad sections provided a lift for the stock market yesterday land moved the averages to the best levels in two weeks during early trading. However, prices subsequently drifted easier in less active dealings and the market closed irregularly higher.
A new season is here, and with it as usual a need for additional hospital volunteers.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- A three-month concentrated campaign to collect $1,000,000 to complete a $4,200,000 fund for development of the projected Phelps Memorial Hospital on the Albany Post Road south of here opened tonight with gifts of $111,000 from sixty physicians who would use the hospital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission charged today in a complaint that !Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, practices unfair methods of competition.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- The attempt of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations to set up a new teachers union was denounced by the State Federation of Labor, A. F. L., today as "divisive, unprincipled and directly opposed to the best interests of the school staffs."

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey urged upstate Republicans today to give "an overwhelming vote of confidence" to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower "to offset the captive vote controlled by tottering and desperate New York City Democrat bosses."
Andre Marty and Charles Tillon, the temporarily disgraced French Communist leaders, refuse to confess their sins.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 -- Capital of the republic during the Indonesian war of independence against the Dutch, this pleasant provincial city in South Central Java has become the center of higher education for the new Indonesian state, although the capital now is Jakarta.

GENEVA, Sept. 22 -- There is a strong feeling among European, United States and international officials responsible for charting the road ahead of the Western community in economic matters that the financial discussions opening in London today among British Commonwealth officials, and those that will follow during the autumn, are truly "fateful."

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- A request by Britain that she send observers to the defense committee of the Pacific Council now meeting in Honolulu has been rejected for the second time, it was indicated here today. Members of the defense organization are the United States, Australia and New Zealand.

The outcome of competitive bidding yesterday for two new issues of corporate public utility bonds totaling $21,500,000 suggested that the new issue market for corporate debt may now be on the way to stabilization after a fortnight of nervous price retreat.

The rank and file of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., casting ballots in ports from Maine to Virginia for the first time since the long dock strike of 1951, have voted by an overwhelming majority to accept arbitration of their present wage dispute with management.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The United States and Britain have rejected the Soviet Union's protest that they are trying to bring the controversial Trieste area into the Atlantic bloc, and make it a "permanent military and naval base."
With the American League pennant pot still boiling and the National League barely simmering the future status of Manager Chuck Dressen of the Dodgers came to the fore yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania, long an advocate of live telecasts of college football games, today asked permission from the National Collegiate Athletic Association to televise its game with the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame at Franklin Field on Saturday.

Four newcomers will join the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra when it opens its new season under Dimitri Mitropoulos at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 16. They will be Walter Botti, double-bass player; Edward Herman Jr., trombonist; Paige Brook, flutist, and Bernardo Altmann, 'cellist.

The Textile Finishing Employers Association at a mediation session yesterday offered a wage rise to two locals of cloth finishers and drivers of the American Federation of Labor. The schedule is to be submitted to the union membership tonight.
Of all the editorial comments printed in the metropolitan press on the so-called "Nixon fund," the views of THE TIMES are the most impartial as well as fairest to the California Senator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A split within the House Ways and Means subcommittee that has been investigating tax scandals will halt the preparation and release of a final report before the election.

A serious shortage in all types of television receivers is developing rapidly and will grow worse as the active fall selling season goes into the Christmas rush period, manufacturers and dealers declared yesterday. Retailers said "leader" or lowest-price sets in most manufacturers' lines already are in critically short supply and probably will be virtually unobtainable by late November.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 23 -- Allied infantry, backed by tanks, planes and heavy artillery fire, recaptured yesterday a hill northeast of the "Punchbowl" in the eastern Korean mountains after fifteen hours of sharp local fighting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Highway perils created by teen agers driving "hot rod" cars were reported today as increasing rapidly in New York State. Youths speeding ninety miles an hour were called "common sights on the roads."

More evidence that there is a slow but continuing trend away from the "gadgety" toy for children and toward simple, solidly built playthings that lend themselves to many different play uses is seen at the newly organized Creative Playthings University Shop, just opened at 5 University Place.

Statements regarding captive Eastern Europe made by the Presidential candidates have raised the issue of the liberation of that area before the indispensable first phase -- the containment policy -- has produced its full effects.
Your editorial against Senator Nixon seems to me to be a case of unfair denunciation before reviewing the facts.
The following pamphlets, of interest to parents and children, have just been published by Science Research Associates, 57 West Grand Avenue, Chicago 10, Ill (40 cents each):

An encouraging aspect of the fourth annual National Home Furnishing Show at Grand Central Palace is the appearance of well-designed furnishings at encouragingly prices. Stores once overloaded with florid furnishings, overblown upholstery and flashy fabrics are displaying at the show an outstanding number of pieces of simple, direct, uncluttered modern design.
A field of 148, comprising forty-one amateurs and 107 professionals, will start play in the thirty-seventh metropolitan open golf championship today at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Stanley Kramer has his sights set on Marlon Brando to star in "Frenzy," which is a new title for the projected film originally called "The Cyclist Raid." Initial talks have been held with the actor, who is preoccupied with playing the role of Marc Antony in Metro's "Julius Ceasar."

" The Mafia," by Ed Reid, an account of the activities of the organization popularly known as the "Black Hand," will be published Oct. 17 by Random House. The account begins with the Mafia's birth in medieval Sicily and traces its spread to this country and its expansion to its present-day role in organized crime

More than 500 Brooklyn business and civic leaders gathered at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, yesterday at a luncheon marking the beginning of a drive to raise $500,000 for a new Brooklyn Red Cross Chapter House.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic national chairman, met with New Jersey Democratic leaders at the Kingsley Arms Hotel here today for a discussion of campaign policies aimed to put New Jersey into the party's victory column in November.

Scheduled price increases on newsprint were announced yesterday by two producers in this country. They were Great Northern Paper Company, a major United States producer with mills in Maine, and Coosa River Newsprint Company, Coosa Pines, Ala.

A new attack on mental illness was started yesterday with the announcement by the League for Mental Health of a plan to make low-cost psychoanalytic psychotherapy available in the offices of psychiatrists instead of in clinics or hospitals.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary, Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia and E. Geller of Russia scored yesterday in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, according to a report from Stockholm.

Governor Stevenson said here last night that there had never been any secret about the fact a number of appointive officials of his state administration had received extra financial assistance with funds left over from his 1948 campaign for Governor and "subsequent general contributions."

Joe W. Brown's Parading Lady, neglected by the fans and by her opposition, won the Vosburgh Handicap, the $20,000 added race that held the feature spot at Belmont Park yesterday. With Jim Hardinbrook in the saddle, Parading Lady came from nowhere to beat Tea-Maker by a length and a half.

It seems to this humble Republican that regardless of the good intentions of all parties to the celebrated gift to Senator Nixon he did his cause a great disservice when he accepted the nomination for Vice President with this incident in his background.

The Gerry Estates, Inc., has sold the underlying land of the twelve- story loft building at 102 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of East Twenty-ninth Street, to A. Ruth Sons, real estate operators and builders. Sale was subject to a wholly net lease to the Brunswick Realty Company to 1970.
An American business man returning with his family from a vacation cruise to South America related yesterday how two toy cameras led to their arrest by the Argentine police.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Walter M. Bush, 73 years old, believed to be the country's first woman licensed driver, fulfilled a childhood dream today and reported that it made her "just breathless."

MANILA, Sept. 22 -- The Conference of Southeast Asia Veterans closed today with a nucleus of a permanent organization assured and in general agreement that some of the world's newest republics have found common ground for promoting peace without Government initiative or interference.

Dr. Donald C. Balfour of the Mayo Clinic, one of the world's best-known stomach surgeons, told a distinguished gathering of surgeons from all parts of the United States and from foreign lands last night that the chance of a patient dying from an operation on the stomach has been reduced from more than 25 per cent about forty years to less than 5 per cent today in the hands of competent surgeons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The White House issued today the detailed itinerary tof the 8,500-mile whistle-stop political campaign on which President Truman will embark next Saturday night.
Take following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's address yesterday before the convention of the American Federation of Labor here as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Sept. 22 -- Recent victories won by South Korean troops have convinced many authorities in the United Nations Command that South Korea rapidly is reaching the stage where its own army could take over the bulk of the country's defense in the event the Chinese "volunteers" are withdrawn across the Yalu River.
ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept. 22 -- The climax of Exercise Mainbrace, the Battle for Denmark, opened today with the shallow waters of the North Sea lashed by a thirty to forty-five knot wind.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Jersey Joe Walcott is a man with years of experience. But that, unfortunately, is the trouble with him. He has far too many years of experience. The ancient heavyweight champion of the world will put his crown up for grabs with Rocky Marciano and the Brockton Block Buster rules as the favorite.
Witco Chemical Co, in 260 Madison Ave through Pease Elliman, Inc. -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

" The Magic Box," which arrives at the Normandie, is today's lone film newcomer. Robert Donat is starred as William Friese-Greene, English photographer and motion-picture pioneer, in the British biography made for the Festival of Britain last year.
In a surprise action, the police have suddenly banned bingo throughout the city.

" Buttrio Square," which has had more than the usual share of production difficulties, involving postponements and financial trouble, is now faced with the necessity of undergoing radical book changes.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices for active months were 25 to 48 points net higher than on last Friday.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 22 -- An international conference devoted exclusively to artists, sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization, opened this morning in the assembly room of the Doges Palace. The delegates are guests of the Italian Government.
ABOARD EISENHOWER SPECIAL, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's train overshot the railroad station at Carmi, Ill., today.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic nominee for President, won the unanimous endorsement of the American Federation of Labor executive council yesterday after he had made a triumphal appearance before 2,000 cheering, foot-stomping, table - thumping union leaders at the federation's seventy-first annual convention here.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 (AP) -Following is the text of a foreign policy address delivered by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower at a Republican rally here tonight:

TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- The State Department of Law ruled today that the State Highway Authority has sufficient legal power to extend Garden State Parkway from its proposed terminus at Paramus in Bergen County to the New York State boundary.

Puerto Rico pushed its industrial development program to a new high in progress last month with completion of eight new factories, it was announced here yesterday by Hugo Storer, director of the Department of Industrial Promotion for the island Government's Economic Development Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The five-month-old rent dispute involving United Nations personnel living at Parkway Village, Queens, moved one step closer to a settlement tonight after the banker-owners of the community project agreed to lower their request for rent increases from an average of 24 per cent to an average of 16 per cent.

The Public Service Commission, reversing a ruling on Aug. 12, acted yesterday to expedite the sale of the Yonkers Railroad Company to the Westchester Citizens Transportation Committee but insisted that $8,000,000 owed by the company to the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation be canceled.
HARTFORD, Sept. 23 -- The oldest structure in the city, the famous Wadsworth barn where George Washington's horse spent a night in 1781, has been saved from destruction by action of the City Council.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Lansing P. Shield, president of the Grand Union Company, said today American business must adopt a platform that will give the American people what they want out of life or "face continual harassment from politicians."

Public utility companies raised about $3,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of new issues of mortgage bonds, serial notes and preferred stock at competitive bidding. Eighteen banking syndicates competed for the business and awards were as follows:

The phrase "magic number" is important when it is used in connection with the closing stages of a baseball pennant race. Yesterday the Giants, after calling off their Polo Grounds double-header with the Braves because of rain and wet grounds, were toying with the number "four."
Following is the text of the address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in Cleveland last night, rebroadcast nationally over the American Broadcasting Company network, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Chain stores can achieve a substantial increase in over-all sales and extra traffic by specialized promotion and display of fragrance products, J. S. Wiedhopf, president of Parfums Ciro, Inc., told the annual meeting of Associated Chain Drug Stores yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.

In the first action of its kind since the Government began prosecuting Communist party leaders under the Smith Act, two of fifteen defendants were freed yesterday, when Judge Edward J. Dimock directed a verdict of acquittal in Federal Court here.

The new police order requiring members of 'the force to travel to and from duty in uniform as a crime deterrent, paid its first dividend yesterday. Two women, who said they were followed in a Brooklyn subway train, called to Patrolman Joseph Lanzetta for help.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- At least one-fourth of the nation's police officers are emotionally unfit for their jobs, a noted psychiatrist and professor of criminology at the University of California declared today at a meeting of the nation's police chiefs attending the fifty-ninth annual conference of International Association of Chiefs of Police here.

City Council President Rudolph Halley was accused of a "labored effort to achieve a cheap notoriety at the expense of, and detriment to the taxpayers of New York City" yesterday by Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley.

Nearly 700 parents from 300 city public schools met at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, on Monday night as citywide parent activity guided by the United Parents Associations got under way for the new school year.

The New York Times Youth Forum, which as a radio feature of WQXR won a Peabody Prize last spring, has joined the procession to television this year. The students who weigh the issues of the day under the guidance of Mrs. Dorothy Gordon now can be seen at 5 o'clock Sunday afternoons over the Du Mont network (Channel 5).

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The names of the players who will bolster the first and second all-star teams when they meet at Detroit Oct. 5 in the sixth annual All-Star game, were revealed today by the National Hockey League office.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept 23 -- Martin B. Dunphy, 50 years old, of White Plains, N. Y., was sentenced to state's prison by Superior Court Judge James E. Murphy today after he pleaded guilty to two counts of manslaughter in connection with a Merritt Parkway accident on Aug. 16 in Greenwich in which two persons were killed.

East Germany differs from other Soviet-controlled territories in that it cannot be cut off from the outer world. Germany is the one country in which the people on both sides of the dividing line can compare the reports published in the Eastern zone with what really happened. Berlin was originally set up as a meeting place for the four Powers that defeated Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Truman was quoted in testimony before a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee today as saying that he had done Theron Lamar Caudle "a great injustice" when he dismissed him as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Tax Division of the department.

A California sherry was not quite what he thought of as sherry, Richard Bett remarked yesterday. We had asked the director of the British company of Williams Humbert, which owns a large sherry winery in Jerez, Spain, what had discouraged the consumption of imported sherry in this country, and he had said it was the price.
TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 189 for Tuesday:
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Stan Musial's third hit, a double that drove in Red Schoendienst with one out in the tenth inning, enabled the Cardinals to score a 4-3 victory over the Reds tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- "Hanging Judge," a play by Raymond Massey, the actor, based on a novel by Bruce Hamilton, went over well at the New Theatre here tonight. The audience was impressed both by the dramatic and exciting qualities of the work and by the acting of Sir Godfrey Tearle in the leading part.
Fred J. Kidde has joined Goodall Fabrics, Inc., and will be in charge of styling of its woolen division.

There are many difficulties in advertsiing in Central and South America, according to the Standard Of Company of California. Since the war the concern has penetrated into twenty-three markets in fourteen countries below the Rio Grande.

GENEVA, Sept. 23 -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions named eleven groups of products today, all vital to Western defense industries, that are now subject to control by private international cartels.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Prices fell again on stock markets today under the lead of British Government securities. Although a rally reduced losses, gilt edges closed as much as seven-eighths per cent down.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Government eased up today on its restrictions on imports of some types of farm-made cheese.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Control of R. K. O. Radio Pictures today passed into the hands of a five-man syndicate which purchased for $7,345,940 the majority stock blocks held by Howard Hughes since May, 1948.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Jack Kramer and Don Budge of the United States advanced to the semi-final round of the international professional tennis tournament today. Kramer won from Kalle Schroeder of Sweden, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, while Budge downed Bobby Riggs by 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

Equity's attitude toward alien performers working here finally will be resolved through a mail poll, soon to be taken, of the entire membership. Several suggestions for settling the problem were made by the union's alien committee after a second conference with the League of New York Theatres.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Sept. 23 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, said tonight that "I have always been in favor of members of Congress and high policy-makers in the Federal Government putting their financial position before the American people every year."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 -- Almost every political campaign is a process of giving up, of starting with high ideals and noble themes and of gradually whittling them away under pressure.

An important portrait by Velazquez, newly acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be on exhibition today in the museum's Great Hall, where it will remain until Oct. 31. The picture, the first-equestrian portrait by the Spanish seventeenth-century master to come to this country, portrays Don Gaspar de Guzman, Count of Olivares and Duke of San Lucar (1587-1645), on a rearing white charger against a battlefield background.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The International Materials Conference has dissolved its pulp- paper committee, a move reflecting improved supplies of newsprint and wood pulp.

The A. F. L. displayed its customary caution yesterday in the way it went about adopting a convention resolution in support of Governor Stevenson. In committee a proposal to "endorse" the Governor's candidacy was set aside as too strong and instead it was decided to "advise and urge" every member to vote for him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A crop grown on an acre of ground will furnish enough fuel to run a car for three years, Charles F. Kettering, a director for the General Motors Corporation, told the fiftieth annual convention of the American Automobile Association here today.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 23 (UP) -- Federal Judge William J. Lindberg today held two agents of the Central Intelligence Agency in contempt for refusing to testify in the Lattimore false tip trial of Harry A. Jarvinen, 32.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Republican leaders in Illinois continued today to hammer away at Governor Stevenson, demanding that he give full accounting of his acceptance of private funds for payment to his state administration appointees.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- Following is the text of the Nixon financial statement issued tonight: Price Waterhouse Co., Los Angeles, Sept. 23, 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- The Soviet Union has badly ruffled India's sensitive Asian feelings by vetoing the admission of Japan to the United Nations. The view is strongly held in official and diplomatic circles here that, by her action on Japan, Russia damaged her own case for letting Communist China into the world organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee blamed lax administration and poor enforcement policies today for the Federal grain storage scandals brought to light in public hearings earlier this year.

The vital and complex operation carried out by the Military Sea Transportation Service in transporting the tremendous quantities of materials and equipment and much of the manpower required to build the huge new airbase at Thule, Greenland, was made public here yesterday by Rear Admiral John M. Will.

The permanent financing of the Federally backed public housing program was extended beyond the $600,000,000 mark yesterday as seventy-three local housing authorities in twenty-three states sold new issues of bonds totaling $170,719,000 and maturing over forty years at an average interest cost of 2.57 per cent.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Tigers squeezed into baseball's record books tonight by becoming the first cellar team in the history of the American League to draw more than a million fans at home. The 7,888 fans who pushed the Tigers over the 1,000,000 mark saw the Browns win, 3 -- 1, behind Bob Cain's eight-hit pitching.

Harry Gross is scheduled to take the stand today in the twenty-seventh court day of the departmental graft trial of thirty-one suspended policemen that began two months ago. Expectations are that his testimony will take several weeks.

Daniel A. Bolich, former assistant commissioner of Internal Revenue, pleaded not guilty yesterday when arraigned before Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court on an indictment charging him with income tax evasion. Judge Byers held the defendent in $1,500 bail and scheduled trial for Oct. 6.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The old gentleman stepped out of character tonight and made a truly wonderful fight of it. That prince of caution, Jersey Joe Walcott, abandoned his careful tactics and did some slugging with Rocky Marciano.

In view of the decided views taken by THE NEW YORK TIMES on the question of courts-martial reform, as indicated in your editorial of July 13, 1947, which views were controverted in part by the writer in a letter published in your columns on Aug. 28, 1947, I am sure you and your readers would be interested in the first annual report of the United States Court of Military. Appeals just released.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- A suit filed here in Supreme Court by humane societies and pet owners to invalidate the state's recently enacted Metcalf-Hatch Law, which permits the use of stray dogs and other animals for experimental research in medical laboratories, was held to be "insufficient" today by Justice Samuel W. Eager.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- Rocky Marciano, undefeated Brockton, Mass., fighter, knocked out Jersey Joe Walcott, 38-year-old ring warrior from Camden, N. J., tonight to become the world heavyweight champion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Truman took a brief recess from the affairs of state and the political turmoil this afternoon for a bit of a esthetic shopping.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Leaders of the United States and British delegations to the International Cotton Textile Conference in Buxton unexpectedly made public statements today, both indicating that the main accomplishment of the conference had been to exchange views and information.

A 29-year-old man alleged to be connected with the "top echelon in narcotics throughout the country" and a "contact man for the nation's biggest distributors" was held in $50,000 bail yesterday in Bronx County Court on an indictment charging possession of narcotics with intent to sell.

Roderick Stephens, an industrial consultant representing eighty property owners in the area around Peekskill, N.Y., announced yesterday that he had demanded more Public Service Commission hearings on a proposed safety code for natural-gas pipelines.
GENOA, Italy, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Nearly 100,000 tons of shipping has already been laid up in Genoa, Italy's principal port, because of falling world freight rates, according to shipowners here.

The special patrols watching the Brooklyn Bridge in search of Flatbushites seeking to emulate Steve Brody have been withdrawn. Owners of hardware stores have ceased hoping to sell those revolvers with which followers of that team from across the river were supposed to do away with themselves.

ABOARD U. S. S. MIDWAY, at Sea, Sept. 23 -- The best-laid plans of exercise Mainbrace were again disrupted by nature today as typical North Sea weather -- a brisk wind and a choppy sea, low-lying scud and poor visibility -- intervened in the "Battle of Denmark."
Average market price of a bond on the New York Stock Exchange fell in August from $98.43 to $98.14, a loss of 29 cents. The Aug. 31 figure was the lowest since the $97.83 reported for Feb. 29 last.

Following the formal establishment of the ANZUS Council as a nucleus of a collective security system in the Pacific the Military Committee of the Council is now meeting at Pearl Harbor to consider practical defense measures for that region on the basis of mutual cooperation among its members -- the United States, Australia and New Zealand.
Coffee, lead and cocoa drifted lower in futures markets here yesterday but potatoes, zinc, hides and vegetable oils advanced. Sugar closed irregularly.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon, in a nation-wide television and radio broadcast tonight, defended his $18,235 "supplementary expenditures" fund as legally and morally beyond reproach.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Tito tentatively has accepted Prime Minister Winston Churchill's invitation to visit Britain, it was disclosed today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at a brief news conference concluding the Briton's five-day visit to Yugoslavia, where he has held a busy round of talks with the leaders of the West's Communist ally.

SEATTLE, Sept. 23 -- Resolutions urging the continuance of price controls on items in short supply and supporting the efforts of the United Nations to achieve peace in Korea were adopted here today by the national convention of the National Council of Catholic Women.

KIRKLAND LAKE, Ont., Sept. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Detroit Red Wings played to a 1-1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League exhibition game in which Gordie Howe, Detroit star, was injured.

Two officers of the Teachers Union testified under oath yesterday that they were not and never had been members of the Communist party, but they joined eight other witnesses who refused to tell a Senate Internal Security subcommittee whether they were Communists in denouncing the current investigation into communism in the schools as an attack upon the concept of the open mind in education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Joseph Short, widow of President Truman's press secretary, who died last Thursday, was appointed correspondence secretary to the President today. She is the first woman in the history of the United States to hold such a position, as far as White House staff members could determine.
BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP) -- For the first time in her life the mother of Rocky Marciano prayed tonight that he would be victorious in a boxing bout.

The first of five weekly bird watching excursions under the sponsorship of the American Museum of Natural History was held early yesterday morning in Central Park. Despite the rain and murk at that time several hundred birds of at least twenty-five species were identified.
Following is the text of an address by Governor Adlai E. Stevenson at the Fifth Regiment Armory in Baltimore last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Favorites today took second and third round matches of the sixty-third annual pacific Coast tennis championships.

Congressional review of the new tax requirements on mutual savings banks in order to assure adequate surplus and reserves to match rapid deposit gains, was urged yesterday by August Ihlefeld, president, Savings Bank Trust Company.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Outside it rained, causing a postponement of the opener of the three-game series between the Yankees and Red Sox today. A little later the sun popped out, but for the Bombers the world never appeared quite so bright as it became indoors while they listened to the radio broadcast of developments in the Indian-White Sox game.

The world's biggest aircraft carrier, U. S. S. Forrestal, now being built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's plant on Hampton Roads, Va., will whisk its big airplanes between hangar and flight decks on newly designed Westinghouse elevators capable of handling more planes per minute than ever before without interfering with flight operations.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies were asked today by an organ of the Council of Europe to make regular reports to the council and give clear-cut assurance that all nations of the alliance would be fully defended in case of Soviet aggression.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Falling freight rates with their grim consequences, dwindling of the profit margin, are causing concern but not yet seriously affecting Belgian shipping interests.
David Nutt got back to New York the other day from his fourth expedition to Labrador and he has been choking and spluttering with hay fever ever since.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs and immediate past president of the North Atlantic Council, said today that the Council's first objective for 1953 would be "to complete 100 per cent the 1952 program.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is scheduled to appear on the platform with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, at a rally in Milwaukee during the first week of October.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Long liquidation by holders of grain futures was again of substantial volume, and lower prices were registered for all grain early in the session. Short profit taking caused a firmer tendency in the late trade, however, and on the extreme declines general commission buying broadened and helped steady the markets.

Senator Richard M. Nixon's radio and television appeal for voters to wire the Republican National Committee has met with wide and apparently favorable response -- at least from those on the Republican side of the fence.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Six operators of a Saratoga Springs gambling casino admitted today they had conspired to bribe politicians and public officials for "protection" purposes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The United States, Britain and France rejected today a proposal by the Soviet Union for a Big Four conference on a German peace treaty and insisted again that such a meeting be limited to making plans for free, all-German elections.

Wool manufacturers can minimize their inventory risk and gain time in styling and promoting their product by greater utilization of "on basis" buying of wool and tops, according to Morton H. Darman, of Arthur I. Darman Company, Inc., wool top makers of Woonsocket, R. I.

A former displaced person who came to this country in 1947 with six dollars in his pocket awarded $5,000 in fellowships yesterday for study at Teachers College, Columbia University, to two young women students, themselves refugees.

Among the truly worth-while noises of the average working day, there can be counted two whistles, so spaced as to get the utmost in value from them both. One is the noon whistle, whose sound indicates that half of the long working day is over, is gone beyond any possibility of recall by the foreman.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz suffered a broken bone in his pitching wrist today, ending prematurely the Philadelphia southpaw's best major league season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A plan to permit key officials and commanders of the North Atlantic Treaty common defense force access to certain United States atomic secrets may soon be revived here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Defense Production Administration today announced that it had certified 120 new or expanded facilities as eligible for accelerated tax amortization in the period from Sept. 11 through Sept. 17. In addition, the agency rejected thirty-one applications for certificates on some $20,200,000 worth of expansion projects.

How a century-old United States postal cover enters upon its destiny as a rarity that should bring increasingly higher prices as it changes hands was demonstrated at a public auction yesterday. An 1845 envelope bearing twelve copies of the classic 10-cent bluish-paper "postmaster's provisional" used in New York before the Government printed regular stamps realized $3,750 when sold through Gordon Harmer of Harmer, Rooke Co. at 560 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Seven representatives of the Protestant Pentecostal and Evangelical denominations appealed to the State Department today to protest officially the "discrimination and persecution" by the Italian Government against the Pentecostal churches in Italy.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican of the Twenty-seventh District of Westchester and Putnam Counties, said tonight he and at least 100 other members of Congress had used privately donated funds in the manner of Senator Richard M. Nixon to "fight the powers of the devil in Washington."

Your recent editorial that the transit fares should be raised to provide sufficient funds for operation (and debt retirement) is understandable in the light of the present financial situation of the city. But did it go far enough?
Mandingo, with David Gorman in the saddle, won yesterday's top race at Belmont Park -- and Mrs. Kay Erik Jensen got another big return on a $1 investment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a plan for dissolution filed by the United Public Service Corporation, Wilmington, Del., a holding company. The plan calls for the liquidation of the company and the distribution to its stockholders of all of its assets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Government officials said today they believe the automobile industry would get enough steel to build 1,250,000 cars in the first three months of 1953.

Games usually found aboard ship were among the divertissements last night at the "Cruise Ball" given under the auspices of the Holland-American Lines in the Persian Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Jess Willard, the Hun School's football coach, has only three letter men back from last year's varsity eleven, but he isn't crying the blues. "We should do better than last year," Willard said today.

In line with its long-term program of expansion and product diversification, directors of the New York Air Brake Company have made five appointments to top management positions, Bernard Peyton, president, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 -- Bus and streetcar operators attending the seventy-first annual meeting of the American Transit Association here today assailed obsolete taxes imposed upon transit companies as a "luxury" which the riding public cannot afford.
Columbia stressed passing in its daily football workout yesterday at Baker Field as Coach Lou Little began grooming his offense for the Lions' opening game on Saturday against Princeton.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak Company met a Federal Trade Commission complaint of unfair dealing with retail stores with a statement today that its contracts are "within the law" and "can be supported."

Lower sales and earnings were reported by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the six and twelve months ended on July 31. In the unaudited mid-year statement issued to stockholders yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, sales were listed at $129,425,312 for the six months, a drop of 3.4 per cent from the $134,003,391 volume transacted in the corresponding period last year.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Sir James Turner of the National Farmers' Union said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was not justified in inferring recently that British farmers operate under severe bureaucratic control.

Two newly arrived immigrants visited City Hall yesterday and gave Mayor Impellitteri the first invitation to a $100 a plate dinner to be held Oct. 30 at the Commodore Hotel in honor of St. Frances X. Cabrini. The dinner is being sponsored by the American Committee on Italian Migration.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower listened to Senator Richard M. Nixon's explanation of his defense fund tonight and immediately indicated that he would retain the Senator as his Vice Presidential running mate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A Point Four official, back from a tour of ten Near Eastern, Asian and African countries, reported today that the United States technical aid program was making headway in that area but that progress is combating communism by improving living standards would be faster if more money were available.

Six Representatives in Congress came here yesterday to investigate immoral and offensive material in radio and television and heard from a network executive that both media were agencies of culture and enlightenment as well as entertainment.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The television camera eye will be put to use this fall at Cornell University in the freshman and sophomore physics courses, Dr. Lloyd P. Smith, chairman of the Department of Physics, said today.

Consummation of the reorganization plan of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, under which its theatre business will be separated from its picture-producing and distributing business, becomes effective on Saturday.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Boston College's football fortunes hit bottom with a resounding thump in 1950, when the once-mighty Eagles failed to win a game. Last year, in his freshman season as head coach at his alma mater, Mike Holovak made encouraging progress. His first team finished strong to win three of nine games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made two slight modifications in the plan of reorganization for the Wisconsin Central Railway Company, which it approved last March.

Extensive rehabilitation and modernization of public schools throughout the city at a cost of $9,118,000 was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. The work is to be rushed to completion this year by the Board of Education.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh will present to George Middleton, the British Charge d'Affaires, tomorrow the Iranian reply to the Churchill-Truman joint proposal for a settlement of the British-Iranian oil dispute.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Arbitrator Herman A. Gray, Professor of Labor Law at New York University, ruled today that members of Marine Warehousemen's Local 1478, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., who took part in a series of wildcat strikes at the Army pier at Claremont Terminal over the last six months, could not be deprived of seniority rights by union officials.
Ground was broken yesterday for the Sound View Houses, a $13,500,000 state-aided, low-rent housing project to provide 1,259 apartments in the Bronx.
The stock market achieved new peaks of the recovery movement during late dealings yesterday and closed with its best gains in three months as trading accelerated in the session's final hour.

A BIG clock can't tell any more time than a small clock. Neither can a big novel tell any more about the elementals of man's on this planet than a small novel -- as Hemingway is once more demonstrating in "The Old Man and the Sea" and as Isabel Bolton shows in her new novel, "Many Mansions,"* the story of a lady's turbulent private past told against the background of a singularly untidy modern world.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Assemblyman Sharon J. Mauhs of Cobleskill contends the United States Secretary of Agriculture's rejecttion of his appeal for a Federal milk price hearing was an "irresponsive, unfounded and wrong decision."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The government today suspended price controls on shoes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Prisjoe Stable's Lone Shadow won the featured $5,000 Chari-Teers Purse over the turf course today before a Ladies' Day crowd of 11,237. The 3-year-old filly charged to the line a length before the favored Villager from the River Divide Farm.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 23 -- The need for the absolute freedom of the playwright was emphasized today by Marc Connelly, United States playwright, to the delegates of thirty-five countries attending the International Conference of Artists sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Cecil B. DeMille and Walt Disney today were singled out for honors by the Southern California Motion Picture Council, an affiliate of the American Federation of Women's Clubs. This was the first time that the group paid tribute to individuals in the movie industry, though it occasionally commends the production of certain pictures.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Former Foreign Minister Camille Chamoun, pledged to a program of sweeping government reform, was elected as the new President of Lebanon today and given a 21-gun salute.

A pennant finally grew in Brooklyn. With Duke Snider doubling in the two runs that made the difference, the long-struggling Dodgers beat the Phils, 5 -- 4, in the twilight opener of a double-header at Ebbets Field last night, to clinch the flag that has eluded them for the last two years.
A five-for-one split of the common tock of the Pocahontas Fuel Company, Inc., was approved by stockholders yesterday. It is expected that the stock exchange will take place in December.

CAIRO, Sept. 23 -- The first efforts of the Administration to get former Premier Mustafa Nahas out as leader of the Wafd, Egypt's largest political party, appeared tonight to have misfired, but the threat remained.
Following is the text of the nationwide broadcast from Los Angeles last night by Senator Richard M. Nixon in explanation of his $18,235 trust fund, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARIS, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The 2,500,000-ton French merchant fleet is fully operative today and the lowering of world freight rates, although a threat to its well-being, is not expected to lead to any very serious consequences.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Charlie Chaplin, facing an inquiry into his fitness to re-enter the United Stares, received from his native city today a welcome that brought tears to his eyes and a look of wonderment to his young wife's face.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the attraction is "The Merry Widow," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Technicolor adaptation of the Franz Lehar operetta, starring Lana Turner in the title role, and Fernando Lamas.
A concise and complete report on the Paris collections was offered by Mrs. Carmel Snow, editor of Harper's Bazaar, at yesterday's meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., at the Astor Hotel.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- Though Communist China's Premier Chou En-lai today was en route by air back to Peiping, the Soviet-Chinese negotiations on important political, economic and defense questions have by no means come to an end.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- British diplomatic officials were annoyed today by the United States rejection of a British request to sit in on the current meetings of the Pacific Council in Honolulu.

Profiting from an unsound sacrifice by Lodewijk Prins of the Netherlands in yesterday's sixth round, Alexander Kotov, one of the five Russian experts competing, gained his fourth victory in the world championship zonal chess tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, according to a Stockholm report.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley's plan to eliminate the bottleneck on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at East Ninety-sixth Street by altering the left-turn pattern of northbound travel off the highway will go into effect at 4 P. M. today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- What politics put asunder, art has brought together -- Trygve Lie and Jacob A. Malik.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- By the luck of the draw, the Soviet Union will get the first seat in the first row in the United Nations General Assembly Hall when the session opens on Oct. 14.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Sept. 23 -- New York City's Equitable Life Assurance Company turned back Sumner, Iowa, 4 -- 1 today for a sweep of the amateur world series of the American Baseball Congress. The New Yorkers had won the previous two games of the best-of-five series. 4 -- 1 and 10 -- 1.

HONG KONG, Sept. 23 -- Gen. Yeh Chien Ying, Governor of Kwangtung Province in Southeast China and a former chief of staff of the Chinese Communist Army, has been appointed acting commander of the Fourth Field Army, according to information reaching Hong Kong from the mainland.

The American Federation of Labor, scrapping its long tradition of neutrality in Presidential contests, urged its 8,098,302 members yesterday to vote for Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., while awaiting the formal response of the General Motors Corporation to its proposal last week for liberalization of the five-year escalator agreement covering 300,000 of the company's employes, said today that it would ask other manufacturers to grant the same improvements.

A suspended Queens sewer engineer and his attorney formally walked out of a departmental hearing on charges of incompetency and misconduct yesterday, only to walk back in within three minutes as observers when the proceeding continued.

A posthumous selection of F. G. 1Nfatthiessen's essays and reviews, assembled by John Rackliffe, will be published Oct. 16 by Oxford University Press,' entitled "The Respensibilities of the Critic." The title is derived from the opening piece, a lecture given by ProfessorI Matthiessen at the University of Michigan, shortly before his death.
