Amateur radio operators, whose services have been invaluable in numerous emergencies, will have active parts in the city-wide disaster rehearsal set for next Tuesday evening. Fifty of the city's 1,200 "hams" will operate mobile units, maintaining constant communication among civil defense workers at each of twenty-five simulated "incidents" and control points.

Brazil's continuation of strict import controls is reflected in its rise of $3,700,000 in its draft indebtedness last month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The rise, the bank explained, brought the total to a new high of $199,000,000, but it was the smallest monthly increase this year.

DESPITE flood tides that are only normal, the railbird shooters on the Maurice River marshes in southern New Jersey are getting their twenty-five-bird limits without much difficulty, and reports indicate that a large flight of birds has arrived there with more coming in every day.

WENTWORTH BY THE SEA, N. H., Sept. 23 -- Members of the Maine Savings Bank Association, at their concluding business session today, were told by Alfred C. Averell Harriman, Director of Mutual Security, yesterday accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of a "glaring omission and misrepresentation" in the foreign policy speech that the Republican Presidential candidate gave on Monday night in Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The White House at first confirmed and later denied today that President Truman had directed James P. McGranery, Attorney General, to study the possibility of criminal prosecution of Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, and the seventy-six Californians who contributed $18,235 to his expense fund.

William Saroyan, playwright and author, has entered the field of television writing and will be represented on the forthcoming "Omnibus" series with six plays running one-half hour each. He also will appear on the program to introduce each play and serve as narrator.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 24 -- United Nations troops struck back today at the Communists on the western front in Korea after the enemy, probing all along the 100-mile Allied line yesterday from Panmunjom in the west to the "Punchbowl" in the eastern Korean mountains, sought but failed to find weak spots.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- The Government of India appointed an eleven-man commission today to examine the workings of the newspaper industry in India. The group, headed by Justice G. J. Rajadhyaksha of the Bombay stare high court, is to report its findings and recommendations by March 1, 1953.

The homemaker, whether she is her own decorator or enlists the help of a professional one, should depend upon her own likes as a guide to furnishing her home, according to several speakers who appeared yesterday at two panel meetings concerned with decoration.

AVERILL PARK, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Senator Irving M. Ives tonight backed up Senator Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, in his fight to stay on the party's ballot as the running mate of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

The temporary transplantation of the heart and lungs of a monkey into a child born with a defective heart, in whom the animal's organs would take over long enough to permit surgery to correct the defects, may soon become possible as a result of experiments on animals.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased yesterday and closed 3 to 34 points net lower than on Monday.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Two golfers among the 154 in the Metropolitan open championship at the Winged Foot Club's west course today were able to break par. They are Jim Turnesa of Briar Hall, National P. G. A. champion, and Herman Barron of Fenway.

Rocky Marciano had almost as tough a fight getting into his dressing room afterward as he did in the ring. After all, he had only one man to confront in Joe Walcott, while his opposition in the battle of the dressing room was a fair segment of the population of his home town plus a sizable gathering of Philadelphia fans.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 24 -- Today's football practice at Phillips Andover Academy was delayed by a scholastic aptitude test in which the entire student body participated. The examinations were held in the Case Memorial Building and, although it was a short walk to Brothers Field, it was late afternoon before members of the gridiron squad were able to start their workout.
Except for potatoes, in which trading aggregated 743 car lots, and hides, of which sixty-five contracts changed hands in unusual activity, most commodity futures markets were qiuet yesterday.

Neutral colors, with special emphasis on black and white combinations, were favored in the collection of fashions presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Rosette Pennington of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street. Among the designers represented were Dior, Desses, Traina-Norell, Ben Zuckerman, Adele Simpson and Lawrence Gaines.

All of the long and short maturities of the new $170,719,000 issue of Federally backed housing bonds have been sold and orders can now be filled only from the intermediate maturities, according to the marketing syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Phelps, Fenn Co., and Lehman Brothers.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., Sept. 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, H. Republican of Ohio, tonight accused Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, Democratic nominee for President, of concealing his true position on the Taft-Hartley law in a bid for political support from the leaders of organized labor.

The United States Customs Inspectors Association of the Port of New York will meet at 7 P. M. tomorrow in the Georgian Room of the Statler Hotel to nominate officers and members of its executive committee for biennial elections to be held Nov. 28.

Election of Abraham L. Bienstock, Gardner Cowles and Robert Montgomery as directors of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president. They fill two existing vacancies and the vacancy created by the resignation of Edward K. Straus, who moved to San Francisco to become the executive vice president of Macy's San Francisco.

In their latest note to Moscow the United States, Britain and France again reject the Soviet demand for a new four-Power conference to draft a German peace treaty before Germany has been unified under an all-German Government which is able to join in the peace negotiations and to accept the treaty.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- Too many children in need of medical care are being hospitalized today "for the convenience of the physician," without sufficient consideration of the emotional effect upon a child of separation from his home and parents, a New York pediatrician declared today.
WORTHINGTON, Minn., Sept. 24 The main streets and rural byways of mid-America are alive today with talk of the "Nixon business."
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,383, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Highway construction and maintenance throughout the country were estimated today as lagging about 100,000 miles behind basic schedules for this year.

WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 24 -- Senator Richard M. Nixon broke off his Western campaign tour today for a 2,400-mile cross-country trip in his chartered airliner to meet his running-mate, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, and receive from him formal word of the Republican party's full acceptance of his public defense of his integrity.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Edward P. Taylor's Navy Page, an $18,000 yearling buy for his Canadian owner, won the first major race of his career when he captured the seventh running of the $20,000 added World's Playground Stakes today.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Arturo Toscanini arrived in London today to conduct two orchestra concerts for which there has been such an overwhelming public demand that a drawing has had to be held to choose the members of the two audiences.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The British Conservatives, it seems, are reasonably content with the policy of their party, but are distressed that more of their fellow citizens cannot be persuaded to take the same view.

With a whoop and a yippee the twenty-seventh World's Championship Rodeo roared into Madison Square Garden last night. Thirteen thousand persons attended the opening performance. The rodeo will close Oct. 19. Between now and then 100 performers will compete for $100,800 in prize money.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Tigers dissipated a four-run first-inning lead today as they bowed to Tommy Byrne and the Browns, 7 -- 4, for their eighth straight setback, matching their string of eight losses at the start of the campaign.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Dr. Stevan Durovic, discoverer of the controversial drug krebiozen, hit back today at a committee of six doctors, which reported the substance has no curative value in cancer cases.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Walter W. Weller, president of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board, said today, "We are heading into another freight car shortage, partially due to the steel strike which delayed the repairing of damaged cars."

Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines declared last night that, just as there could be no peace without Asia, so there could be no economic stability without Asia. He was one of several speakers at The Asia House, 7 East Eighty-fourth Street, where the first of several conferences on Asian problems was held.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, today called his 200-man Wage Policy Committee into special session here next Monday, two days before a strike deadline in Southern soft coal mines.

I read in THE TIMES of Sept. 16 a report about Borough President of Manhattan Wagner discovering the shocking conditions at two schools in his borough. One of the schools is so outmoded that it can be considered a hazard, and the other is overcrowded by two thousand students.
The Wool Bureau has declined to accept the resignation of Michael Daroff as chairman of its men's wear advisory committee, according to F. Eugene Ackerman, president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Ambassador of Iran, Allahyar Saleh, told President Truman today that economic conditions in his country were becoming "very dangerous" and urged this country to use its influence to end the "British blockade" that was preventing Iran from exporting oil.

A barrage of home runs disturbed the peace and calm of the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants captured a double-header from the Braves and took a step in the direction of clinching second place in the National League.

" THIS morning, as for some days past," Abraham Lincoln wrote for his own eyes alone in the summer of 1864, "it seems exceedingly probable that this Administration will not be re-elected. Then it will be my duty to so cooperate with the President-elect, as to save the Union between the election and the inauguration; as he will have secured his election on such ground that he cannot possibly save it afterward."

The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., yesterday unanimously endorsed the Democratic national candidates, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator John J. Sparkman, and urged the election of "a forward-looking Congress.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Treasury today offered to taxpayers an opportunity to pay two and one-half billion dollars of this year's taxes in advance, at a slight discount.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Barbara Stanwyck will step into the starring role vacated by Mary Pickford in the Stanley Kramer production, "Circle of Fire." Miss Pickford, who has been absent from pictures for twenty years, announced last week that she had changed her mind about attempting a comeback at this time because Mr. Kramer could not obtain facilities to make the film in Technicolor.

MCKINLEY PARK, Alaska, Sept. 24 -- Gov. Ernest Gruening set the stage for the third annual Alaskan Science Conference yesterday with a speech in which he called for a new Alaska on a "cosmic scale in keeping with its great size, possibilities, and potentialities."

It is customary, not unusual, for a national legislator to augment his finances from independent sources. Although reliance upon the individual's own professional or business establishment remains the most usual, there are actually a limitless variety of such sources.

The extent to which insurgent forces were routed in the balloting last Friday by 15,099 rank and file members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., was disclosed yesterday with the release of complete returns by Joseph P. Ryan, union president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- New York and four other labor market areas have been dropped from the "substantial labor surplus" category as a result of improvements in employment conditions.

Eddie Arcaro's riding and Mark-Ye-Well's 'running were of the summa cum laude variety at Belmont Park yesterday. Astride the Calumet Farm's 3-year-old son of Bull Lea, Arcaro gained the winner's circle in the Lawrence Realization, the mile-and-five-furlong fixture that occupied the top spot on the program.

Advice for manufacturers and their advertising agencies with products to sell in Europe was given here yesterday by Paul O. Althaus, president of the International Union of Advertising, head of his own agency in Zurich, Switzerland, and former advertising manager of the Omega Watch Company.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 -- The Indians did everything right today. Bob Lemon blanked the White Sox, 6 -- 0, with three hits and Ai Rosen and Bobby Avila slammed homers, but the Tribe did not gain an inch. In fact, the Indians lost ground even while winning because at Boston the Yankees matched and then doubled Cleveland's success.
Following is the text of an address by Governor Dewey last night from the studios here of the National Broadcasting Company, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 24 -DeOrmond (Tuss) McLaughry, who retains a neophyte's enthusiasm for football in his thirty-third season as a college head coach, rates his tenth Dartmouth squad as "at least as good as last year." In 1951 the Big Green won four and lost five of nine major games, giving a good account of itself in every contest.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -- A concerted attack in Parliament yesterday and today on the policies of subordinates of Sultan Hamengku Buwono of Jogjakarta, Minister of Defense, is threatening the existence of the five-month-old Wilopo Cabinet.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Regional Advisory Board forecast today a 7.1 per cent increase in railroad freight car-loadings in the fourth quarter of this year.

The nation's supplies of gasoline, light fuel oil and heavy fuel oil showed sharp increases last week, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end gasoline stocks totaled 118,315,000 barrels, an increase of 1,019,000 barrels over the previous week's 117,296,000, but below the 123,120,000 barrels of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- General Eisenhower tonight will make known his decision whether Senator Nixon "is the kind of man America would like for its Vice President." If he follows the decision of the vast majority of the thousands who expressed themselves to the Republican National Committee on the matter, and the members of the committee itself, he will vote in the affirmative.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., and Westinghouse Electric Corporation reached agreement today on a one-year contract extension, giving pay rises of 7 1/2 to 13 per cent an hour to 45,000 production workers.
There is a way to make $100 by giving away $10,000, which is as easy as falling off a log if conditions are right. There are no tricks in the method and the $100 is an outright gain.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis posted 43, 38 -- 81 over the soggy fairways of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today to win low gross honors in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament.
In a sharply worded protest to the Government of Israel, 4,000 Jaws demanded last night an immediate end to "systematic attacks on the fundamentals of the Jewish religion" in that nation.

Thanks to the American Museum of Natural History you now may add to your fund of fascinating and little-known facts the information that the average body temperature of the Gila monster is 84.2 degrees Fahrenheit.

The two bills creating an independent city Department of Air Pollution Control, replacing the present Bureau of Smoke Control within the Department of Housing and Buildings, were signed late yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman's shimmery gown of silver-gray brocade, in which she took her bows with her husband and daughter at the Jan. 20, 1949, inaugural reception, has gone to the National Museum to join the famous costume collection of First Ladies' dresses. This gown is by a New York designer, Pola.
STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 24 (AP) The European Consultative Assembly today called for a new world-wide monetary conference to write a substitute for the Bretton Woods agreement.

Those who advise investors must not fall complacently into Wall Street's bullish trend, Marshall, Dunn, new president of the Association of Customers' Brokers, told its members following his election at the annual meeting yesterday.
The ethereal problem of beer drinking was examined yesterday by a Congressional committee investigating immoral and otherwise offensive material on radio and television.

" Because You're Mine," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical in Technicolor, starring Mario Lanza, will have its local premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Alexander Hall directed and Joe Pasternak produced from a script by Karl Tunberg and Leonard Spigelgass and a story by Ruth Brooks Flippen and Sy Gomberg.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- The Blue Ribbon Trophy for the fastest Atlantic crossing, which gathered dust in a Hanley, England, jeweler's shop for fourteen years, will be presented to the American liner United States in November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson chided the Soviet Union today for making up its own, unique definitions of some fine old words.

The distinguished gentleman in the homburg reading his paper across the way might very well have started his career as a soda dispenser. Quite a few such men, with and without homburgs, joined yesterday at a gathering in Chicago in forming the Ancient and Honorable Guild of Former Soda Dispensers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- John M. Allison, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, is leaving Washington Friday for an extended official visit that will symbolize the continued interest of the United States in the Pacific nations on both sides of the equator.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, announced today that he would submit the treaty on the European Defense Community with a request for urgent ratification as soon as the National Assembly reconvened Oct. 7. He expressed the hope that France's Parliament would take action on it soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A Senate investigating subcommittee cited the case histories of four prominent figures in the entertainment world today to charge that communism was using the prestige of those providing comedy, drama and music for the American people to give strength to its own subversive programs.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 25 -- Hard-fighting Chinese Red infantry threw United Nations forces back yesterday from "Kelly Hill" on the Western Korean front. But Allied troops scored in an eastern sector, smashing two enemy attacks on ridges south of Kosong near the Japan Sea.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Two more races were held today on Long Island Sound in the international class match race for the Skoal Trophy between teams of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club and the Manhasset Bay Club.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 24 -- The primary election victory of Republican Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in Wisconsin on Sept. 9 unleashed "a hurricane that swept the state and is now sweeping the country" and in his fight for reelection the Senator was in the forefront of the effort to save the nation, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling declared in a speech here tonight.

Senator Nixon has now given to the American people his accounting. We see no reason to doubt the accuracy of the figures he has presented regarding his personal financial status; nor do we see any reason from the evidence now at hand --especially in view of the Price, Waterhouse Co. audit -- to question his statement regarding the receipt and disbursement of the $18,000 fund that has caused the uproar.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Culminating a thirty-five-year fight with the Federal Government over the old North German Lloyd and Hamburg - American Line piers here the municipal administration, in a colorful public ceremony, today leased the piers for fifty years at $1 a year and then promptly subleased them to the Port of New York Authority.

With "Top Banana" all set for a nation-wide tour starting in Philadelphia on Oct. 6, Paula Stone and Mike Sloane, producers of the current hit musical, are focusing their attention on their next Broadway project, "Carnival in Flanders." This is the musical adaptation of the French motion picture success, "La Kermesse Heroique."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 24 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois declared today that he had no intention of making public any details of the fund from which he gave secret extra compensation to some appointive Illinois state officials.

The homemaker often buys upholstery or drapery fabrics that would be more suitable for a dress than for use on a chair or at a window, Boris Kroll, fabric designer, told the audience at the second in a series of morning meetings held in Grand Central Palace.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 24 -- As a funeral service was being held today for John J. Conger, 47 years old, and his wife, Loretta, 39, who were killed in an automobile crash late Saturday, funds began pouring in for their eleven orphaned children.

The Chase National Bank raised its quarterly dividend to 50 cents and declared an extra payment of 30 cents yesterday. Previously the bank had been on a 40 cents quarterly basis, and in 1950 and 1951, the extra payment amounted to 20 cents.
Many dinner parties were given last night in connection with the dinner dance in the Carnival Room of the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of the Southampton Hospital Association.

Nearly 100 tons of the beef being offered in local stores this week comes, for the first time, not from the West and Midwest, our usual source of this meat, but from cattle ranges that have been developed along Philadelphia's Main Line.

The good-sized sampling of what has become of the graduates of the 1941 and 1947 classes of the four municipal colleges of New York City shows the fine contribution that these colleges make to government and to education, and also provides the groundwork for improvement of the colleges.

Before the announcement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower last night that the Republican National Committee had voted 107 to 0 to retain Senator Robert M. Nixon on the ticket, a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES showed the committee overwhelmingly in favor of the Senator.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 24 -- The Iranian reply to the Churchill-Truman proposals for a settlement of the British-Iranian oil dispute was presented tonight to George Middleton, British Charge d'Affaires, and Loy W. Henderson, United States Ambassador, by Premier Mohammed Mossadegh. The text will be published here tomorrow.
Work clothing manufacturers have sold up their fourth-quarter production of denim overalls, jackets and dungarees, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Bob Hope's representatives today announced what they called the biggest single-season deal in radio's history -- a $2,000,000 contract under which the comedian will do six shows a week.

The Federal investigation into communism in the nation's schools reached yesterday into colleges in this area as faculty members of Columbia and Rutgers Universities and Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges testified at an open hearing of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee in the Federal Court House on Foley Square.

WASHINGTON, Sept 24 -- A flood of telegrams, pouring in on the Republican National Committee at the rate of 4,000 an hour, appeared tonight to have assured Senator Richard M. Nixon's retention on the Republican national ticket even before he met with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in West Virginia.

The City Investing Company had a net income of $2,693,744 in the quarter ended on July 31, equal to $2.79 a common share, Robert W. Dowling, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger, the Reds' left-hander, scored his sixteenth victory tonight, defeating the Cardinals, 6 -- 1. He missed his seventh shutout only because Stan Musian hit his twentieth home run in the third inning.

The new plan to eliminate the traffic bottleneck on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at East Ninety-sixth Street by altering the left-turn pattern of northbound travel off the highway was only partly successful yesterday, its first day of operation. Motorists, failing to alter ingrained driving habits, were responsible for countless little jams.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that 800 new policemen would be appointed next Wednesday. He announced also that the Board of Estimate would be asked at its meeting on Oct. 9 to provide funds for 200 civilian clerks to be assigned to the Police Department to make available for patrol duty an equal number of policemen now doing clerical work.
A total of 592 pints of blood was collected Tuesday at permanent Red Cross centers in New York and by mobile units in the city and its environs.
The University of Pennsylvania yesterday received permission to televise its football game Saturday with Notre Dame at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

ABOARD U.S.S. MIDWAY, in the Skagerrak, Sept. 24 -- The most powerful fleet to cruise the turbulent waters of the North Sea since World War I began to disperse today as exercise Mainbrace ended in the Skagerrak entrance to the Baltic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Truman today requested Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, to take an economic survey group to Europe and plan for mutual efforts to assure the "economic stability of our allies."

The elegance of restrained good taste was evident throughout the Revillon fur showing, presented yesterday morning in the store's 11 West Fifty-seventh Street establishment. In it one felt the flavor of Paris.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- For the third day in succession British funds were weak today. Indeed, the declines considerably exceeded those on either Monday or yesterday. The war loan fell 1 1/2 per cent to 76.

Harry Gross, sallow-faced and hollow-eyed, walked through a courtroom in the Criminal Courts Building yesterday and picked out twenty - eight suspended plainclothes men whom he said he knew. Of the remaining three defendants in the departmental graft trial, two were absent and the third was excluded from identification because his lawyer was not present.

Mitch Price and Bob Mercier were tabbed as Columbia's offensive stars for the coming season by Lou Little yesterday as the Lion coach named his starting line-up for Saturday's opening game against Princeton at Baker Field.
The melodies of Stephen Foster, among the most beloved of American composers, floated yesterday through the hall of Bellevue Hospital where he died a pauper in 1864.

The Port of New York Authority will break ground today, in a ceremony attended by New Jersey, New York and municipal officials, for the $90,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel. We take the building of these great underwater crossings in stride as a commonplace nowadays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Theron Lamar Caudle testified today at a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee hearing that J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, had told him that a "clique in the White House" was "after him" and that the same "clique" was after Mr. McGrath.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott "unretired" from a thirteen-hour retirement today to set up a return bout with Rocky Marciano, who knocked him off the heavyweight throne last night.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The McCarthy Club of Wisconsin said Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Republican of Wisconsin, challenged President Truman today to disclose the nature of a meeting with the defense attorney for Alger Hiss.

BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Joseph P. Molony, district director of the C. I. O. United Steelworkers, said today that a charge of unfair labor practices had been filed with the National Labor Relations Board in Cleveland against the Pittsburgh Steamship Division of the United States Steel Corporation.

The body of Detective Philip La Monica, killed in an exchange of shots with three escaped convicts last Sunday morning in an apartment house at 500 West 140th Street, was taken last night from an undertaking establishment to Bellevue Hospital for an autopsy, the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.
WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the addresses here tonight by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon:

Superb artistry in the creating of fur designs was demonstrated last night, in the roof ballroom of the Pierre Hotel, when Maximilian presented his winter collection. It was, in the main, the same one shown by him a few weeks ago in the Palazzo Grassi, in Venice.
The stock market extended the recovery movement through its fourth session yesterday and closed irregularly higher on the most active dealings since July 1.

Discovery that a new form of highly purified trypsin, a powerful digestive agent derived from an animal gland, can dissolve dangerous blood clots in veins and possibly also in arteries, was reported yesterday at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told state banking supervisors today the nation has a "real prosperity" derived from more permanent factors than defense spending.
John Bell has sold his home on Pound Ridge Road in Bedford, N. Y., to John Hurdman through the Thomas C. Grimes Company, broker. A lake and brook are on the property.
Mandy, a fat little Scotch terrier-Pomeranian which lost ten pounds so she could fly to Texas, has apparently disappeared between here and Houston.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $42,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include first mortgage bonds, serial notes and preferred and common stock. The issuing companies will use the money to pay off bank loans incurred for capital purposes and to finance further expansion.

A major revision of its personnel and program schedule is underway at WOR-TV in an effort to put the station on a profitable footing. The indications are that the operating policy of the outlet, purchased earlier this year by the General Tire and Rubber Company, will undergo many changes within the next few weeks.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 24 -- The Social Democratic party and the German Trade Union Federation, two of the most powerful political forces in Germany, accepted today the West German Government's "declaration of war" and formed an alliance to fight for the political leadership of West Germany.
A dramatic drop in the number of tuberculosis deaths in this city has taken place since the beginning of the year, a study of Department of Health records showed yesterday.

Robin Roberts, the "winningest" pitcher in the major leagues, yesterday achieved his twenty-seventh triumph at Ebbets Field, but it was scored over the second-string Dodgers and wasn't a very tidy victory.

Vincent Hallinan, Progressive part candidate for President, reopened the American Labor party campaign last night by charging that the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees wanted to prolong the Korean war indefinitely.

The policy committee of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany ratified yesterday the settlement of $107,000,000 reached by the West German Government and the Conference Sept. 10 to aid in the rehabilitation of Jewish victims of the Nazi regime now living outside Israel.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Britain has decided to renew her invitation to Egypt to join in setting up an international body that would help the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan settle its own future, informed officials said tonight.

When a small business man goes after a defense contract he sometimes has a mite of difficulty. Although he is an important cog in the country's production might, there have been instances when he has had to make a little noise to get himself heard.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- The dream of Mother Eleanor M. O'Byrne became a reality today. Friends had called it fantastic and builders had considered it impossible. But on D-Day for the shift of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart from New York to the country, the school's new campus here began functioning -- just sixteen months after the first shovel of earth had been turned.

WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 24 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said tonight that his Vice Presidential running mate, Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, had been "completely vindicated" of charges in connection with a privately raised expense fund.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 24 -- The death sentence of Willy P. F. Lages, wartime head of the German security police in Amsterdam, who was officially branded as one of the nation's arch-war criminals, was commuted to life imprisonment by royal decree today.
TRENTON, Sept. 24 -- The State Department of Law and Public Safety announced today a two-year study of reasons why some automobile drivers are habitual violators of traffic rules.

THE Brigantine National Wildlife refuge, controlled by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, will be opened to "managed" waterfowl hunting this fall, a move which will be of real value to the New Jersey duck hunters, whose open hunting grounds have been reduced considerably in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Federal grand juries in Seattle, Washington and St. Louis, Mo., today indicted twelve more Communist party leaders on charges that they conspired to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the United States Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- President Truman's San Francisco speech on Oct. 4 will be devoted to health, education, welfare, housing and civil rights, his hosts for the occasion announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 -- A significant new step in the general rapprochement between church and state was taken today by the Mexican Supreme Court in a decision recognizing the validity of church marriage for the purpose of legal indemnity.

TRENTON, Sept. 24 -- New Jersey court magistrates, conferring today on changes in procedure, were urged by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to impose jail sentences to check the growing "holocaust" of highway accidents and fatalities.

Gerard J. Brinkman, suspended section engineer in charge of South Queens sewer construction, testified yesterday that he had been away sick with pneumonia during final inspection and approval of the faulty $185,679 Victor Clemente sewer in Laurelton.

Six rounds of the world chess championship zonal tournament were completed, yesterday, in Saltsjobaden, Sweden, when ten adjourned games from the fifth and sixth rounds were played off, according to a report from Stockholm.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The executive council of the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions decided tonight to instruct the thirty-eight member unions to support the confederation's bid for higher wages by refusing to work overtime and by cutting down on piecework, starting Oct. 20.

Charging that the United States is in a Korean war because the Democratic National Administration invited the war by two acts of "supreme folly," Governor Dewey declared last night that the election of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican nominee for President, was essential to the survival of this country.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 24 -- The Labor party in saddle more or less constantly since World War I received such a setback in Sunday's general election for the Riksdag or lower house of Parliament that political observers here think its position will become untenable after the new Riksdag meets in January.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The wheat futures market dragged today but corn and other grains had a more buoyant tone. Light country offerings of new-crop corn and soybeans tended to switch sentiment in those commodities and there was active covering of shorts, with considerable straight commission buying on the little setbacks in evidence early in the session.

Christian citizens have a responsibility to vote in the coming general election and to "apply Christian principles in their voting," the General Board of the National Council of the Churches Christ in the U. S. A. declared in a resolution adopted here yesterday afternoon.
LOCK HAVEN, Pa., Sept. 24 (UP) -- "Fickle Fanny," a natural gas well which caught fire twice before it was capped, now is the center of a legal battle involving more than $1,000,000 in royalties.
A material witness in the Brooklyn waterfront investigation was revealed yesterday as the owner of a "quarter of a million dollars in stocks, bonds and cash."

TOULON, France, Sept. 24 -- The French submarine La Sibylle vanished off this naval base today and ships and planes were sweeping the Mediterranean Sea near here tonight for traces of the missing craft and her forty-eight-man crew.

The hand applying a match to the pipe's tobacco shook perceptibly. The match went out and the smoker struck another with his thumbnail; this time smoke rose from the pipe bowl and was expelled from around the stem in nervous puffs.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The French Government decided today to invite other European states to declare common war on disease by joining a European health community established on the same supranational basis as the Schuman plan for coal and steel industries and the European army.

I agree with your recent editorial statement on the school system that an "unregenerate Communist member need not expect, nor does he deserve, to be permitted to promote his conspiratorial philosophy in the classroom."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Charges of concealed collections and uses of Republican party funds in Nassau County, a Republican stronghold, were made here today by James E. Boboras, Mineola attorney and Democratic candidate for the State Senate from the Third Senatorial District.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers across the country on the address Tuesday night by Senator Richard M. Nixon, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

New hope for parents of mentally retarded children is inherent in the growing realization that even if a youngster's low I. Q. cannot be raised, his useful and contented adjustment to life is largely dependent on healthy personality traits, which parents can help to foster at home, Edgar A. Doll declared last night.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, an American oil concern, said here today, after a month's visit to Iran at the invitation of Premier Mossadegh, that the Abadan oil refinery was in good condition and could resume operations in a short time.

The Clent, a garden apartment development for 150 families at 5-15 and 10-20 Clent Road, Great Neck, L. I., has been sold by the Doglen Realty Corporation and the Glendar Realty Corporation to a syndicate headed by Benjamin Duhl. It consists of two three-story buildings with garage space for ninety cars and was sold in a deal negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 -- An 18-year-old University of California student today scored the tennis upset of the year by downing the nation's No. 1 player, Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today accused Senator Herman Welker, Republican of Idaho, of resorting to distortion of testimony in Congressional committee records in an effort to divert attention from the case of the $18,235 "supplementary expenditures" fund of Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee.

The American Federation of Labor decided yesterday to hold its 1953 convention in St. Louis, but made its decision contingent on assurance that Negro delegates would not find themselves discriminated against in St. Louis hotels and restaurants.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 -- The Wafd, Egypt's largest political party, held up today its application to the Interior Ministry for approval under the new Political Parties Act pending clarification of the intentions of the Naguib regime toward former Premier Mustafa Nahas, the party's veteran leader.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 17:

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- The No. 1 job of public utility commissions in dealing with bus and street car companies is "to provide service for passengers" and to do this fare questions must be given quicker consideration, Ray O. Martin of Columbus, member of the Public Utility Commission of Ohio, said here today.

Starting next Wednesday, the 14,000 persons receiving supplementary funds for old-age assistance from the City Welfare Department will get $5 more from the Federal Government, but $5 less from the city.

A new process for coating metal surfaces with tungsten carbide or other hard metals to protect them from excessive wear was announced yesterday by the Linde Air Products Company, a division of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- By scoring 3-under-par 69's in the second round of the Metropolitan open golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today, amateur Jimmy McHale, a Walker Cup star, and Dick Mayer, 28-year-old professional, shared the lead with totals of 143 for thirty-six holes.

As part of the admission fee, everyone attending the luncheon and fashion show in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre on Tuesday has been asked to donate a doll, which will be sold later for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Private United States investment abroad in the first half of this year set a new record and nearly equaled the total for 1951, the Department of Commerce said today.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- Paced by the extraordinary Mickey Mantle, who exploded four extra-base hits, and further aided by two superb relief jobs by Johnny Sain, the Yankees today swept two strides nearer to their fourth straight pennant as they brought down Lou Boudreau's Red Sox in both ends of the afternoon's double-header before 17,651 fans.

One hundred stenographers and typists are wanted by the Federal Government, but they must be "under 35 years of age." The jobs are for Washington and abroad, a spokesman at the New York State Employment Office, where the notice is posted, said yesterday.

Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey have accepted invitations to serve as sponsors of the 1952 "Friends' Fund" campaign of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, David M. Keiser, general chairman of the drive, announced yesterday.

India is displeased by the Soviet veto on the admission of Japan to the United Nations. Although the Indian Government refused to join the other Powers in signing the Japanese peace treaty at San Francisco, preferring to make a separate settlement, it believes that the United Nations should be a universal body, open to all nations.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The late Philip Barry's last play, "Second Threshold," which was completed by Robert E. Sherwood, made a poor impression on representative newspaper critics here tonight. Their main complaint was that the writing was verbose, thereby burying the play's significance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -- The brand-new king of the boxing business didn't look particularly regal. He wore no ermine robe and carried no scepter. Rocky Marciano was just a very tired young man in undershirt and striped shorts as he sprawled on the bed in his hotel suite early this morning, just a few hours after he had dethroned that magnificent ancient, Jersey Joe Walcott.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- An owner of common stock in the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad today objected vigorously to any measure of control over that line by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 24 -- A mass demonstration of at least 10,000 South Koreans against Japan was held today as a dispute over fishing rights brought the historic bitterness between the two countries into the open again.
Price of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 5 points higher to 10 points lower yesterday.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, 20-year-old Glen Oaks ace, overcame the difficult conditions of the newly sodded fairways of the North Shore Country Club today to lead a field of forty-eight in the opening round of the Women's Cross-County Golf Association's annual fifty-four-hole medal play championship.

BUEDINGEN, Germany, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- Four thousand West German frontier guards in a three-day exercise here failed in their allotted task to round up 400 "terrorists" in a wooded mountain hide-out, guard headquarters here said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Price increases ranging from 1 to 8 cents a pound on retail cuts of pork that have been prepared in consumer portions by a wholesaler, on specialty pork products and on dried pork products other than aged or cured, were authorized by the Office of Price Stabilization today.

John L. Lewis has negotiated a substantial wage increase for the bituminous coal miners employed by the Northern operators, and the Southern operators have no alternative but to follow suit if they are to avoid a strike.

Miles (Lucky) Leslie, 43-year-old alleged vice operator whose activity on the midtown East Side had become so lucrative that it could have attracted the attention of gangster overlords, was indicted yesterday on charges of compulsory prostitution and other felonies, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.

A 15-year-old Bronx high school boy accused of attempting three times to shoot his father with a home-made "zip" gun capable of firing .22 caliber bullets was sent yesterday to Bellevue Hospital for observation. The boy's name was withheld because of his age.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Amendments intended to "clarify and enlarge" reporting requirements and exemptions under the Securities Exchange Act's provisions governing activities of "insiders" in companies with securities listed upon exchanges were voted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The jury in the conspiracy trial of thirteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with teaching and advocating the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, was recalled to the courtroom in Federal Court yesterday for the first time since it was excused on Sept. 5.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's speech today at a breakfast meeting of his supporters:

We have long been arguing, with all the facts and vehemence at our command, that New York City's police force should be enlarged. The recent series of particularly brazen crimes emphasized the need, but it was clear long since that the city's parks, subways and streets were underpoliced.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 24 -- Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth College, called upon political campaigners today to "mind their manners." Speaking at the fall convocation before 2,000 students and faculty members, Dr. Dickey said there were "limits on utterances beyond which candidates should not press or be pressed."
Cheese importers expressed satisfaction yesterday over the further lifting of quota controls on their trade, announced by the Department of Agriculture on Monday.

Sales of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the first half of this year rose 92 per cent to $188,628,640 from the $98,053,883 volume in the 1951 period, but earnings declined under high operating costs, Robert E. Gross, president, informed shareholders in the mid-year report yesterday.
DENVER, Sept. 24 -- The American Mining Congress adopted today a resolution calling for the United States return to the gold standard after a battery of speakers blasted the American fiscal policies.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Southpaw Bobby Shantz disclosed today that the bone break that ended his pitching for 1952, apparently will not affect his hurling next season.

Events tonight: "La Boheme," City Center, 8:15 P. M.; "The Marriage of Figaro," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Almo Russ concert, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; "L'Enfant Prologue," "Claudia's Blues," "California," "The Long Voyage Home," American Lyric Theatre, 133 Macapugal Street, 8:40.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Republicans here today who claimed knowledge of the details of the week-long controversy over Senator Richard M. Nixon's future as the Republican party's candidate for Vice President gave the following account:

ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it had authorized the Western Union Telegraph Company to increase rates within New York State on Oct. 3 to raise revenues by about $365,250 a year.

The United States equestrian team that will compete in the international jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden will be made up of Arthur McCashin of Pluckemin, N. J., the captain; Mrs. Carol Durand of Kansas City, Mo., and William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn. Norman Brinker of Roswell, N. M., will be an alternate.

The National Distillers Products Corporation plans to reduce its fourth quarter dividend from the customary 50-cent payment to 25 cents, Seton Porter, chairman and John E. Bierwirth, president, announced yesterday following the regular monthly board meeting.

Harry J. Anslinger, Commissioner of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Narcotics, estimated yesterday that the number of arrests of narcotics smugglers, sellers and users in this city was 30 per cent less in the first six months of this year than in the first half of 1951.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- The Communists in Estonia have been warned that the special geographical position of that Baltic state, makes necessary a "higher and higher vigilance" against the intrigues of "American and British warmongers."

The 163d anniversary of the Bill of Rights was observed yesterday with ceremonies conducted by members of the Bill of Rights Commemorative Society and other organizations on the steps of the Subtreasury Building, Nassau and Wall Streets.

A new nation-wide organization known as the National Cargo Bureau, Inc. has been formed by shipping men, insurance underwriters and government agencies to inspect loading of dangerous cargoes and develop loading regulations.

WENTWORTH-BY-THE-SEA, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Both management and labor must get behind modernization in New England's textile mills to pull the Northern segment of the textile industry out of its rut, Leonard Carmichael, president of Tufts College and chairman of the Committee of New England, asserted here tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today at the end of a six - week European tour that the Continent's mutual security efforts were "hopeful and promising" but still short of the level required for safety.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 25 -- A masterpiece of late fifteenth century art, purchased by a Westport resident in Germany in 1928 for only $2,500, is now hanging in the Boston Museum of Fine Art as one of the lost works of Bartholomaeus Zeitblom.

Young people today have three times as much taste as their parents and one third the money, according to Sam Black, vice president and general manager of the Lightolier Company. Mr. Black spoke on "Lighting for Our Time" at a meeting yesterday morning in Grand Central Palace in conjunction with the National Home Furnishings Show.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican National Chairman, went through the formality today of telegraphing Senator Richard M. Nixon of California to tell him that "the combined decision" of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and the Republican National Committee assured his continuance on the ticket.
An American working girl reached through the Iron Curtain yesterday and did for a troubled Soviet housewife what the immense Russian Government could not do.

Three modifications of regulations announced yesterday by the Office of Price Stabilization here marked the softening of meat prices, along with the shortages of grain for feed and a surplus of distillers' feed residue.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Billy Johnson's double and Solly Hemus' single accounted for the winning tally in the last of the ninth inning tonight with one out as the Cardinals scored their thirty-third one-run victory, beating the Reds by 4 to 3.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Kip Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan and Mrs. Chauncey Mayers of Fairview both finished at minus 2, or 2 down to par, at Sunningdale Country Club today to tie for the Joseph J. Windle Challenge Trophy and will play off for the prize over an additional eighteen holes here next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A dismaying picture of the congestion in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York was painted in an annual report today by Henry P. Chandler, director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.

The opening meeting of the board of directors of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, Inc., was held yesterday in the association headquarters at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. deLeslie Allen of Buffalo, the president, is presiding over the sessions, which will continue through Oct. 2.

Only one film will open at a first-run theatre this morning "Night Without Sleep," a Twentieth Century - Fox melodrama starring Linda Darnell, Gary Merrill and Hildegarde Neff, is the newcomer at the Palace. Featured in the supporting cast are Joyce MacKenzie, June Vincent and Donald Randolf.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway assured the Netherlands today that the aim of his North Atlantic Treaty Organization command was the defense of all of Western Europe. He qualified this by saying that the measure in which it could be done would depend on the forces available.

As he had done early in his administration, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday, at the groundbreaking for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, put traffic congestion relief among his foremost aims. To those who heard him, and who have listened to his other statements on the subject -- such as at the dedication of the Port Authority Union Bus Terminal -- there is no questioning his sincerity.
MASON CITY, Iowa, Sept. 25 -- Prosperity will determine the Presidential election of 1952, Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A University law professor whom Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson appointed to the Illinois Supreme Court said today that Mr. Stevenson had given a $500 Christmas check to him in 1950 while he was serving as non-salaried chairman of the State "Little Hoover" Committee.

Those who like to get an early start on Christmas shopping may be interested in some new offerings at the Associated American Artists. Included in the seasonal suggestions introduced yesterday are Christmas cards, tiles sold alone or inserted into trays and tables, ceramics in odd shapes, enamels and an assortment of framed reproductions of paintings and posters.
BUXTON, England, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Japan served notice today of her determination to recapture her pre-war position in the world exports of cotton textiles.

Three men, two of them supervisory employes of the New York Post Office, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of promising the use of influence to obtain promotion for postal employes in exchange for sums ranging from $200 to $1,300.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Truman Administration's chief Congressional spokesmen on health insurance today accused Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of issuing a "Taft-dictated statement" on the issue. They called it "a complete fabrication of misstatements."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- During the week ended Sept. 24 member bank reserves decreased $486,000,00O, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The automobile has knit the United States -- "the most heterogenous and geographically varied nation in the world" -- into a giant, unified nation, Paul G. Hoffman, former head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, told the closing session of the fiftieth anniversary convention of the American Automobile Association at the Mayflower Hotel today.
Following is the text of an address by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower last might at a Republican rally in Baltimore as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Net income of the New York Central Railroad and all leased lines for the first eight months of 1952 totaled $2,375,071, it was announced yesterday. This compares with a loss of $1,540,339 for the eight months ended Aug. 31, 1951.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 25 -- The basic Mexican laws on marriage have not been changed by the Supreme Court decision upholding the validity of a church marriage for the purpose of legal indemnification, it was made clear today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 25 -- Launching an intensified campaign offensive in the wake of his own ethical "vindication," Senator Richard M. Nixon of California tonight labeled Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois "the chlorophyll candidate," picked to cover up "malodorous aspects" of the Truman Administration.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, with evening up continuing in the October position. Final prices were 10 to 18 points net lower than on Wednesday.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman issued a statement yesterday, charging Governor Dewey with "deliberate distortion of history" in his television and radio speech Wednesday night. Senator Lehman objected particularly to Governor Dewey's reference to the national administration "abandoning" China and declared that China could only have been saved from communism, if at all, by military intervention on our part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 20, 1952 were 873,559 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 7,659 cars, or 0.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 9,869 cars, or 1.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 3,030 cars, or 0.3 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The National Collegiate A. A. television committee last night refused to change the terms of its approval of the televising of the Pennsylvania-Notre Dame football game in the Philadelphia area tomorrow.
Rocky Marciano, newly crowned heavyweight boxing champion, said last night he would like to make the first defense of his title in New York City.

Mistaking bluster for statesmanship, Premier Mossadegh has now replied to the Truman-Churchill proposal for settlement of the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute by serving on Britain a virtual ultimatum calling for acceptance of his counter-proposals within ten days -- "or else." What the "or else" might imply he made plain in his statement to the Iranian Parliament threatening to break off diplomatic relations with Britain unless he gets his way.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 25 -- A score of ships from seven Allied nations were anchored in the Oslo fjord near the entrance to the Baltic tonight after the conclusion of Exercise Mainbrace, the first Atlantic pact maneuver of its kind.

The problem of what to do with their spare time has been solved by many persons in varied occupations who have become rock hounds, one of the popular new hobbies in the United States. Rock hounds are the men and women who prospect for gem material on field trips.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered special elections today to determine which union should bargain for stewards with members of the Shipowners Association of the Pacific Coast and with the Pacific Maritime Association.

In the collection of Harvey Berin fashions presented yesterday by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof the trim, pencil-slim dandy look was apparent in town dresses. Tightly fitted skirts, bodices and long sleeves were accented by high standing collars with small black ties or large black silk bows.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavian, Sept. 25 -- Yugoslav sources reported today that the Italian Government had blocked almost all exports to Yugoslavia since the beginning of July in what was described as an effort to force the Belgrade Government to surrender Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste to Italy.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,384 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

The news of anti-Japanese demonstrations in Korea over the matter of fishing rights is understandable but disturbing. The Koreans have some old scores against the Japanese and they would be something more than human if they could do a complete job of forgiving and forgetting.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A $15,000,000 anti-trust suit by the Dean Milk Company of Chicago against seven other dairies and the National Tea Company was settled today for $1,225,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican Presidential nominee, will embark Oct. 1 on a train-airplane campaign tour of twenty-six states, the Republican National Committee announced today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 -- To understand clearly the tragedy that befell the Indians today, one must be familiar with the architecture of the "Wigwam" here at Municipal Stadium. It is a combination press room and dining hall, where club executives and newspaper men gather before and after a ball game.

New York bank loans to business rose moderately last week, advancing $23,000,000 under seasonal influences. The gain brought the decline in such borrowings since the start of this year to $60,000,000, compared with an increase of $943,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

The Department of Sanitation's office of engineering has completed an extensive cost study indicating that the introduction of the alternate-side-of-the-street parking plan in two Manhattan areas has not only brought about a decided improvement in litter conditions but has resulted in tremendous budgetary savings.

WASHINGTON, Sept 26 -- The National Production Authority today moved against the Leviton Manufacturing Co., Inc., of 236 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, which it described as one of the nation's largest manufacturers of electrical wiring devices.

One hundred elevator operators, chambermaids, waiters and bell men walked out without warning yesterday at the Lincoln Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. One thousand guests in the twenty-seven-story structure were deprived of all service during the two-hour stoppage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Through an official, spokesman the State Department has now joined Averell Harriman and others who accused General Eisenhower of "glaring omissions and misrepresentations" in his discussion of the speech on Far East policy made to the National Press Club by Secretary of State Acheson, Jan. 12, 1950.

DETROIT, Sept 25 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, in the twilight of his fourteen-year career with the Tigers, today won his 200th major league game -- a feat that only fifty-four other pitchers ever achieved. He held the Browns to six hits in the 3-2 victory.

ROGER DONOGHUE is a handsome youngster with curly hair and twinkling eyes. He was a top-flight middleweight in his day and made enough money to tide his family over its most dire emergency. Once the nest egg was established, this intelligent youth retired from the ring. Roger Donoghue now is 21 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Sept. 20 were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Rochester Red Wings beat the Montreal Royals, 3 to 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Jackie Collum tonight to win the final round of the International League play-off, four games to two.

EXETER, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Walter O. Pennell, Class of 1893, occupied his usual vantage point on the sideline this afternoon as Coach Bill Clark sent the Phillips Exeter Academy football squad through its first lengthy scrimmage of the season.

In the recent dispatch describing the fire in the Belmont Race Track it is noted that you failed to mention the presence of members of the Franklin Square Fire Department who assisted the Elmont and Floral Park Fire Departments in bringing the fire under control.
Optimism about the city's traffic future was voiced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as he joined with New York and New Jersey officials in breaking ground for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

The stock market coasted yesterday, fluctuating irregularly and closing thoroughly mixed, after a four-day advance. Further extension of the recovery effort was checked by some liquidation and some disappointing dividend action.
James M. Power, new Commissioner of the Board of Elections, drew his own name out of a cardboard box yesterday and thereby became president of the board.

BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Details of a 25-hour fight by a Navy diver and a Navy doctor to save a civilian diver, stricken with a critical attack of the "bends," were revealed today as the civilian diver was recovering in his home.

Those interested in promoting brand name products in wearing apparel must recognize that retailers of textiles are not just distributors but merchants, according to Bert Goldsmith, executive vice president of Albert J. Silberstein, Bert Goldsmith, Inc. He spoke at a convention of salesmen of "Botany" Brand 500, Tailored by Daroff, in the Philadelphia offices.
LONDON, Sept, 25 -- British Government securities rallied strongly on the stock markets here today ofter opening weakly as they have done all this week.

Gross operating revenues and net income of the American Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, increased 10 per cent and 5 per cent, respectively, compared with previous period.

" Life With Luigi" looks as if it's going to be quite a trial on television. The premiere of the video version of the story of the Italian immigrant in America as a pointless and witless charade without taste or credibility.

ALTHOUGH the upland game and waterfowl hunters are inclined to took with some scorn on the lowly rabbit, the ammunition manufacturers would rather see any two of the popular game birds disappear from the sporting scene than have the cottontail wiped out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman dipped into the Bible today to reply to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's criticism of the witticisms that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois has been employing in the Presidential campaign.
Three pieces of jewelry valued at $18,000 were stolen Wednesday from the apartment of Mrs. Brenda Frazier Kelly at 563 Park Avenue, her lawyer told the police yesterday.

I wonder what THE NEW YORK TIMES would say if Italy had a law requiring newspapers to obtain approval of Government authorities before they could be published or distributed. I dare say THE TIMES would be up in arms against such an abridgment of freedom.

A comprehensive collection of fall and winter fashions was presented yesterday on Wanamaker's recently redecorated third floor. Represented in the fifty-eight selections were the season's important trends in silhouette, fabric and color. Size and price-wise the choices also were varied, including day into evening designs for the misses, woman and junior.

The New York City Opera Company offered last evening at the City Center an "Aida" which could boast a new tenor, Roberto Turrini; a new Aida, Anne McKnight; a new Ramphis, Randolph Symonette, and a new conductor, Tullio Serafin, who was conducting the work with the company for the first time.

The Sidney Hillman Foundation awarded yesterday prizes of $500 each for newspaper and magazine reporting and for a work of nonfiction. The presentations were made at a luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel by Jacob S. Potofsky, who succeeded Mr. Hillman as president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., after the latter's death in 1946.
Retirement applications by a deputy inspector and a former deputy inspector, now serving as a captain, were released yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Eighty members and associates of the executive committee of the Defense Production Administration made a brief inspection tour of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday to study ship-building, repair and conversation operations.

Dr. Grayson S. Kirk, acting president of Columbia University, emphasized yesterday in an address at the opening convocation of Barnard College that "the fullest freedom of inquiry is still the strongest shield of a free and democratic people."

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 26 -- Rain swept the Korean front yesterday, bogging down the enemy's recent exploratory attacks against Allied outpost positions and grounding the fast-flying United States Sabre jets, which have already made September a record month for victories against the Chinese Communists' Russian-designed MIG's.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Arnold Reuben Jr. of New York, president of the 52 Association of the United States, will receive an Award Certificate here tomorrow from Maj. Gen. Carl R. Gray Jr., the Administrator of Veterans Affairs.

Graft payments to nine more, policemen were charged yesterday by Harry Gross at the departmental trial of thirty-one suspended plainclothes men. This brought to twelve the number of defendants he has linked directly to his late bookmaking empire in two days of testimony.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, and Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, have notified United Nations officials that they do not expect to attend the 1952 session of the General Assembly until after the United States Presidential elections.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 25 -- German socialism demanded today a four-power conference on Germany now instead of a fruitless exchange of notes between the East and West and rejected the "little Europe" conception of unity fostered by the European Coal and Steel Community.

The United States yesterday indicated its interest in the financial affairs of John Mammano, a material witness in the Brooklyn waterfront investigation, who, on Wednesday, was disclosed as the owner of a "quarter of a million dollars in stocks, bonds and cash."

The Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be given on Oct. 9 in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza. Miss Barbara Gile Lord is chairman of the junior committee for the event and Miss Mary Hicks Edson is one of her aides.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Metro has moved on to its 1953 production schedule the old David Belasco play, "The Girl of the Golden West," and says it will be the most ambitious musical undertaking of next season. Arthur Freed has drawn the producer assignment and Alan Jay Lerner is due in from New York this week to begin story conferences with Mr. Freed preliminary to writing the screen adaptation.

Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden, president of the Institute of World Affairs, Inc., is co-chairman of its benefit committee that has taken over the performance of "The Millionairess," starring Katharine Hepburn, on the evening of Nov. 18 at the Shubert Theatre. The date was changed from Nov. 5 because of the delayed opening of the play.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- The American Mining Congress formally closed its deliberative portion of its 1952 convention here today after adopting resolutions assailing United States tax schedules.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- In a note to Prime Minister Churchill, the Iranian Premier, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, consented today to submit the claims and counter-claims arising from the nationalization of the British-owned oil industry in Iran to arbitration by the International Court of Justice.
The ideal sweet for children, and adults, too, for that matter, is one that gives the body something other than calories.

ONE HUNDRED years ago one of the most admired living English poets was a learned, brilliant and neurotic invalid, Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Today she is little read, although the heartfelt love poems she wrote during her secret engagement to Robert Browning, the "Sonnets From the Portuguese," still retain much of their beauty. But the reason Elizabeth Barrett Browning is a familiar name to many of us is fortuitous.
DALLAS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Southern Methodist opens its football season tomorrow night against Duke.

James F. McHugh's Jam proved his dependability as a field campaigner by capturing the Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Impound came along strongly near the end of the distance of about two miles and a half to register over Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Oedipus.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- A new shake-up in the management of Montgomery Ward Co., the country's second largest mail order house and retail store chain, was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman today repeatedly declined to answer questions about the Nixon and Stevenson funds, but asserted that his proposal to require officials to report outside sources of income was now more pertinent than when he urged it on Congress a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Truman asserted today he had never been sorry that he discharged Theron Lamar Caudle as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Tax Division of the Justice Department.

Iran is "ripe for a Communist coup" if the British-Iranian oil dispute is not settled, in the opinion of W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Oil Company, who returned by air yesterday with four of his top aides from a one-month stay in Iran.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, marking its thirteenth anniversary with a dinner at the Astor Hotel last night, announced that it had raised more than $300,000,000 in the metropolitan area since 1939 for Jewish needs here and throughout the world, with special emphasis on Israel.
A detailed account of outside activities and income of United States Attorneys and their assistants is being sought by Attorney General James P. McGranery, it was learned yesterday.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Two hundred and sixty-nine veterans of the Colombian battalion in Korea, the only Latin-American army unit in history to fight overseas, arrived here tonight on their way home after more than a year in action.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is the one American who can do the most to bring peace to the world, and restore decency to government, Senator Irving M. Ives told 200 women who filled the assembly hall of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday.

Action on twenty petitions by Queens taxpayers for sewers and other improvements was balked at a meeting of the borough's Local Improvement Board at Lost Battalion Hall in Elmhurst last night when City Councilman Hugh Quinn, Democrat of Queens, walked out.

Robin Maugham, nephew of Somerset Maugham, is determined to follow in his celebrated uncle's footsteps. Having Written a number of books, he tried his hand with two plays, "The Barrier" and "The Servant" neither of which has reached the local stage yet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A spokesman for the New York Better Business Bureau said today it had received 438 written complaints in eighteen months on the operations of nonscheduled air carriers or of ticket agencies.

By all odds the most important issue on the nation's domestic front today is the issue of inflation -- in the popular sense of rising living costs. Indeed, it is so transcendentally important that it is impossible to discuss any other major economic problem except with this one as a frame of reference.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Approaching the annual conference of the British Labor party, at which the policies of Aneurin Bevan's left wing will oppose those of the party's leadership, Mr. Bevan directed attention today to the tradition of unity in the party, thus discounting the possibility of a split.

An alleged member of the Communist party's disciplinary commission was plucked from his seat yesterday among spectators at a Senate subcommittee hearing and put on the stand, where he denied that he had gone to the Federal Court House to intimidate an ex-Communist witness who had just finished a recital of Communist machinations within the Brooklyn College faculty.

Retailers will enjoy a greater volume of business this Christmas season than last year, but they can't expect too much help from Santa Claus, members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association were told last night.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said in a speech here tonight that the nation could have both "security and solvency" and he laid down a three-point program to achieve that objective.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept 25 -- Two rock-ribbed Democratic states of the deep South -- Alabama and Arkansas -- are approaching this year's Presidential election with a political vigilance seldom exercised in behalf of the national ticket.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 25 -- In accordance with a new "national front" policy adopted early this year, Communists in Indonesia are seeking to spread their influence through a broader association with non-Communist groups and individuals.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that Senator Richard Nixon of California, the Republican nominee for Vice President, was "morally wrong" in accepting the $18,000 fund for political expenses. She commented that she believed the reaction of many Americans to the Senator's address Tuesday night was "one of sorrow."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 25 -- Seven scientists and professors from American universities and colleges are joining the faculty of the Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa for the new term opening next month, it was announced today by Maj. Gen. Yaakov Dori, president of the institute.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- For the third straight month refugees have been pouring out of Communist controlled East Germany at the rate of 500 a day into West Berlin. Seeking political asylum they bring evidence that the Sovietization of East Germany is being carried out speedily and ruthlessly without any consideration of the possible eventual reunification of the country.

An anthology of world nature writing, edited by Edwin Way Teale, naturalist-author, has been scheduled for late October publication by Dodd, Mead, entitled "Green Treasury."
