The volume includes works by more than eighty-seven writers from all countries and times, ranging from Aristotle and Pliny to Hudson and Peattie.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company is offering to its stockholders today a new issue of the company's common stock valued at about $98,500,000 and representing the first major broadening of the company's equity base in more than twenty years.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- Two days after Senator Nixon made his personal appeal to the people for endorsement, Western Union here reported its circuits to Washington still overloaded with telegrams to the Republican National Committee.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 25 -- Heeding mounting political criticism, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois changed his mind today and decided to speak out in greater detail about the funds he used to supplement salaries of key state employes and for his own political expenditures.

A slim silhouette, a chic covered-up look and a definite preference for black were fashionable characteristics of the Anna Miller collection, shown yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at the Plaza Hotel. Being tiny herself, this designer realizes the flattery of sleek willowy lines and shapes her daytime designs accordingly, reserving always the fillip of a low back pleat for the slender skirts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Georgi N. Zarubin, the new Soviet Ambassador to the United States, denied today, both formally and spontaneously, that Russia was carrying on a "Hate America" campaign. Both forms of the denial were made in the course of the Ambassador's call at the White House to present his credentials as the new Soviet envoy to this country.

If last night's performance by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House is any indication, we are in for a bang-up three weeks of ballet. The company is in fine shape, the stars are resplendent, and there is a general air of ease and effortlessness under the surface brilliance.

With retailers now committed to a policy of keeping merchandise stocks and new ordering to low pre-war levels, there is need for stores and manufacturers to join in solving the problem of providing extra supplies to meet unexpected peaks of consumer demand, members of the Textile Distributors. Institute were told at their annual meeting yesterday.

Columbia's first Thursday football press conference turned from a routine discussion of tomorrow's game between the Lions and Princeton at Baker Field into a reiteration of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's policy on television yesterday.

Theodore F. Otten, 46 years old, a third-rail maintenance man on the Staten Island Rapid Transit, sought the Government's support yesterday in his stand against joining a labor union because of religious scruples.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda attacked United States Ambassador George F. Kennan today as a "slanderer disguised as a diplomat."

Directors of the Heyden Chemical Corporation yesterday elected John P. Remensnyder to the new office of chairman of the board and Simon Askin as president. Barrett Brown, partner of R. W. Pressprich Co. was elected a director to succeed Dr. Donald B. Keyes who resigned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The American Civil Liberties Union, through a staff counsel, Herbert Monte Levy, argued before a House investigating subcommittee today that there already was sufficient law and regulation to keep radio and television programs clean and in good taste.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- New England's sixteen major electric power companies announced today a $3,000,000,000 thirty-year expansion program geared to quadrupling the region's output and sale of electricity.
The next market borrowing by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will consist of an issue of $60,000,000 of bonds due in nineteen years.

Showmanship and a newly installed collection of unusual or rare antique furniture and room accessories in the Gift Shop of Bergdorf Goodman combined yesterday to make shopping there an adventure for the treasure-hunter.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has sent shareholders a letter detailing the company's position in respect to the Federal Grand Jury investigation of "possible violation" of the anti-trust laws in connection with "world arrangements" of oil companies and in respect to the Mutual Security Agency's suit against the company to recover alleged overcharges on oil supplied to Western European countries.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- A husky New Jersey amateur golfer, Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair, achieved special distinction today by winning the metropolitan open championship at the Winged Foot Club with a 72-hole total of 289.

Only second place depended upon the game and there weren't many fans on hand to see it, but it was in dramatic fashion that the Giants clinched the runner-up position to the pennant-winning Dodgers at the Polo Grounds.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Argentina's low wheat production is causing a serious drain on Brazil's dollar exchange.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 25 -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe approved tonight a plan for its members to pool their resources for the development of the colonies and dominions of European nations and to share in the rewards.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Gov. Dennis J. Roberts was renominated by a 10-to-1 margin over Arthur E. Marley yesterday in the only state-wide contest of the Rhode Island Democratic primary.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 25 -- A three over par performance of 39, 38 -- 77 enabled Miss Roslyn (Cookie) Swift, Glen Oaks, to gain an eight-shot lead in the first annual Women's Cross-County Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship during the second round at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.

CAIRO, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former top financial adviser to Adolf Hitler, said today the British-Iranian oil dispute could be settled only by direct negotiations between Iran and the United States.

RACINE, Wis., Sept. 25 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio assured a gathering of 400 Racine County Republican workers tonight that he had "no doubt" that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, if elected President, would not try to usurp for the office powers outside the Constitution and would adhere to the principles of sound democratic government.

Sixty home sites of about one-third of an acre each in the Sleepy Hollow Manor section of North Tarrytown, N. Y., bought earlier this month by David S. Meister, New York realty operator, have been resold to the Crane Bridge Land Corporation.
The Metropolitan Museum held a members' preview last evening and will open to the public today an exhibition of paintings, etchings and drawings by Rembrandt.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Next year, for the first time since she began receiving United States aid, France will abandon the practice of laying down a budget based on hopes and expectations of unspecified United States assistance. Only the aid amounts that have been actually promised will be figured in the military estimates.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Sept. 25 (UP) -Silver Creek Ranch's Patronage hustled to anose Victory over Black Zida today in the $3,250 Chips Serenade purse at Bay Meadows. The 4-year-old son of Alibhai paid $13.50 and was clocked in 1:10 2-5 for the six furlongs.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 25 -- The International Class team of yachts from the Manhasset Bay Club took the fourth race of the match with the Royal Norwegian Club and tied the score today at 2-all.
CAIRO, Sept. 25 -- The Egyptian Cabinet, at its meeting today, retired 450 Army officers of all ranks and dismissed a number of high Government officials.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- History virtually repeated itself today as Allie Reynolds, strong-armed clutch pitcher of the Yankees, hurled and batted the Bombers to a 3-2 victory over the Red Sox and placed Casey Stengel's champions in a position where they need only one more victory to clinch that coveted fourth straight pennant.

Saying that the foremost object of our foreign policy must be to halt and eventually roll back the thrust of Communist aggression, Dr. George S. Counts, Liberal candidate for United States Senator, called last night for return of a nonpartisan approach to international problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Six major steel companies charged today that the "unnecessary intervention of the Administration into the collective bargaining process" was the chief cause of the recent steel strike.

Both leaders in the world chess championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, won their scheduled games yesterday. Alexander Kotov of Russia defeated Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany, and Gideon Stahlberg of Sweden won from R. G. Wade of New Zealand in seventh round matches, according to a report from Stockholm.

As the new public school registration figures released yesterday showed the city's classes to be virtually bursting at the seams, Mayor Impellitteri ordered the immediate appointment of 145 more elementary teachers to relieve "an unusually overcrowded condition."

Heavy fall marketing of cattle and calves has increased sharply the supply of beef and veal. Current receipts are substantially above those of a year ago at this time, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

Pressure on September coffee highlighted trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The delivery, which closed on Tuesday at 54 cents, sold as low as 53.01 cents a pound before it went out yesterday. Twenty-eight transferable notices were tendered.
TORONTO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Gold valued at $300,000, vanished last night from an air cargo shed at near-by Malton airport while awaiting shipment by plane to Montreal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Grain futures prices followed an irregular course on the Board of Trade today. Deferred futures of wheat as well as corn and soybeans moved up sharply at times but receded sharply when profit-taking developed.

In its continuing work of reclassifying various items of imports for tariff duty purposes, the Bureau of Customs is also enlightening trade members on little-known items of this country's foreign commerce. Among some of the articles now up for reclassification are Chinese chopping blocks and cork parts of artificial bait.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25 -- With only eight two-platoon first-stringers back, twenty-seven players missing from last year's squad for assorted reasons and no new material added, Holy Cross cannot reasonably expect to improve on, or even duplicate, its splendid 1951 record of eight victories and two defeats.

The first city-owned building designed and constructed as a welfare center was dedicated yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at 1951 Park Avenue in Harlem. The $1,600,000 structure begins carrying out a long-term plan to house all welfare units in city buildings.

The Firestone Tire Rubber Company showed a moderate increase in sales for the nine months ended July 31, but earnings declined $4,373,241 from the similar period of the prior year, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri's campaign to oust Carmine G. DeSapio as Tammany leader and strengthen his own position as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor has shifted into high gear. Dismissal notices have been sent, it was learned yesterday, to sixteen city jobholders owing political allegiance to Manhattan Democratic district leaders considered loyal to Mr. DeSapio.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- United States business men concluded tonight after a two-day study of problems involved in investing dollars abroad that "national sentiments" must be recognized and investments must be made in the spirit of partnership, not economic imperialism.

Your editorial of Sept. 23 "Crime Takes Its Toll" rightfully concludes that "if crime cannot be abolished, at least some lives may be rescued and some crimes prevented." Few will take issue with the preventive remedies you propose, all of which seem to be aimed at the child in his early years.

Sixty well-behaved, well-scrubbed, well-trained and well-born dogs were paraded in the sunken plaza in Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon in honor of National Dog Week. The show was presented for the ninth successive year by the National Dog Welfare Guild, a non-profit society of breeders, owners and dealers.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- The East German Government announced tonight two measures that Western observers immediately related to preparations in the Soviet zone for the building up of an East German Army. Such an army has not been formally announced yet, but Wilhelm Pieck, East German President, and other high officials of the Communist-controlled regime have disclosed their plans to do so.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- Two Royal Navy warships engaged a Chinese Communist shore battery in a five-minute gun duel this morning after the Communists had intercepted a British-registered ship, the Takshing, on the high seas, diverted her to Lafsami Island and removed two of her Chinese passengers.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Direct Rhythm, a son of Billy Direct, shattered two world records today to win the Tattersalls pace.

The American College of Surgeons, holding its annual clinical congress here this week, announced yesterday an intensified campaign to stamp out fee-splitting, "ghost surgery and similar "dishonest and unethical" practices.

MADRID, Sept. 26 -- After five months of talks with United States representatives here members of the Spanish Government have reached the conclusion that there are two distinct and contrasting policies on Spain emanating from Washington and that the resultant disagreement within the United States Government has been responsible to a large extent for the lack of any substantial progress in current United States-Spanish negotiations for military and economic agreements.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- A tense, dramatic battle for more than two and a half hours, a sudden rush of three runs across the plate in the eleventh inning and in a few more minutes another brilliant chapter was written tonight by baseball's perennial champions.

Nine fine old houses in Litchfield, Conn., and near-by Milton, some of which have not been open to the public before, will welcome next Saturday members of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut and others who wish to join the society by paying a S3 membership fee.

The National Collegiate A. A. television committee said "no" last night to the University of Pennsylvania's proposal that both the Penn-Notre Dame game at Franklin Field and the Princeton-Columbia contest in New York be televised in the Philadelphia area today.
In line with the popular practice of decorating the kitchen, as well as equipping it, are the accessories displayed in the Gourmet Gift Shop at Bloomingdale's.

Mrs. Eileen Griffin, 25-year-old Queens waitress, who told the police that she and her estranged husband, Willis, were held up at 1 A. M. last Tuesday, was ordered held yesterday together with three men accused of robbing the couple. Charged with robbery, conspiracy and violation of the Sullivan Law, each was held in $11,000 bail. Hearing was set for Oct. 3.
Mayor Impellitteri has been ordered by his physician to stay in bed for the next four or five days and cancel all appointments for that period, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.
Following are texts of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's talks in Charlotte, N. C., and Richmond, Va., as carried by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Steps were taken by the Federal Government today to deport William G. (Big Bill) Lias, the "millionaire sportsman" of Wheeling, W. Va., from whom the Government is seeking to recover a tax claim of $3,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Rudy Bukich, a converted T-formation quarterback, ran and passed for two touchdowns tonight to start a scoring spree that led Southern California to a 31--0 victory over Northwestern before 59,756 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Mrs. E. P. Alker had the winner today in the fall specialty of the Welsh Terrier Club of America in the imported 3-year-old dog, Ch. Topflight Template of Twin Ponds. The event drew forty-two dogs, was held on the Alker estate and was judged by Robert Gorman.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The United Kingdom has agreed to buy 115,000,000 bushels of wheat from Canada during the 1952-53 crop year under the International Wheat Agreement, it was announced today. The figure includes wheat sold in the form of flour.

NEWARK, Sept. 26 -- A record increase in voting registration in New Jersey was reflected today in reports by officials in most of the state's twenty-one counties. The number of eligible voters, it was indicated, would be at least 2,650,000 This will be an increase of 270,000 over 1948, a record Presidential year registration.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Despite a decision by the French Government not to count upon additional United States aid until it has been definitely allotted, France is preparing a memorandum to be sent to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that increases the outlays to be made for defense next year above the amount spent in 1952.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,385, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korea time:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26 -- In a lecture today at the Belgrade Technical High School, Prof. Gunnar Randers, director of the Norwegian-Dutch Research Center for Nuclear Physics in Norway, said that small nations would have to concentrate on atomic research if they wished to preserve their standard of living and maintain their cultural level in the future.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- Party lines are now tightly drawn for the first Japanese general election in more than a decade in which the voters will cast ballots unsupervised either by the pre-war military regime or the Allied occupation after the surrender.
DALLAS, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Duke's Blue Devils ripped 80 yards against the clock tonight to write a dramatic 14-to-7 victorious finish to a thrilling battle with Southern Methodist.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The median income of all earners went up 10 per cent in 1951 to $2,200, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

The seventeenth season of Town Hall concerts by the New Friends of Music, opening Nov. 2. will feature composers participating in their own works, performances of seldom-heard operas and the first American appearance of Britain's Boyd Neel Orchestra.

A junior committee has been formed under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Charles T. Mattmann and Mrs. Charles A. Von Elm to aid with the plans for the luncheon and fashion show to be given on Oct. 21 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the welfare services of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were barely steady yesterday and closing prices were 22 points lower to 18 points higher than on Thursday.

Matthew T. Ryan, a vice president of the Colonial Trust Company, 90 Wall Street. was arrested last night by Federal authorities on charges of having made false entries in the bank records in an attempt to perpetrate a fraud.

Three pieces of jewelry valued at $18,000 that had been stolen last Wednesday afternoon from the seventeen-room apartment of Mrs. Brenda. Frazier Kelly at 563 Park Avenue were turned over to the police of the East Fifty-first Street station yesterday by a jeweler who had bought them from a woman as part of an estate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed an unfit airplane and "questionable" pilot technique for the Pan American World Airways crash in which fifty-two persons died April 11 near San Juan, Puerto Rico.
Their position as runners up for the National League pennant assured, the Giants yesterday did some free swinging and submerged the Phillies, 8 to 0, at the Polo Grounds.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 26 -- The amazing progress of the international defense organization that was only a dream two or three years ago was demonstrated by Exercise Mainbrace, first North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuver of its kind.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Truman charged today that "the old isolationists" were engaged in a "growing attempt to undermine" the United Nations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark's headquarters in Tokyo reported to the United Nations today that extensive anti-epidemic measures in South Korea had resulted in drastic reductions in deaths from typhoid, smallpox and typhus.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- A group of Protestant clergymen, headed by Bishop Otto Dibelius, head of the Evangelical Church in Germany, will accept an invitation to visit Moscow in November, church sources reported.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Snowballing political charges growing from Governor Stevenson's special expense fund drew a promise from the Democratic Presidential nominee today to name contributors.

AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 26 -Senator Richard M. Nixon, carrying into the not-so-solid South an appeal for bipartisan support of the Republican ticket, told a whooping, rebel-yelling crowd at the Tri-State Fair tonight that "the Democrats in Washington have so conducted the affairs of this country that they have lost the right to the support of decent Democrats."

H. Golombek, former British chess champion, was pitted against Alexander Kotov of Russia in the eighth round of the world championship zonal tournament at Saltsjobaden, Sweden, yesterday, but failed to stop the Soviet grandmaster in his determined bid for the first prize, according to a report from Stockholm.
Department store executives have become increasingly worried in recent weeks over the continued slowness of business in the older shopping centers, the so-called "downtown sections."
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Following are the texts of speeches by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson at Evansville, Ind., today, and at Indianapolis, tonight.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 26 -- The plenary session of the International Conference of Artists today adopted resolutions of its committees on motion pictures and music.

The section engineer in charge of sewer construction in South Queens has been dismissed and the field inspector on the faulty $185,679 Victor Clemente sewer project in Laurelton has been suspended for two more months without pay.

STRASBOURG, France, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe gave its almost unanimous endorsement tonight to a plan for the coordination of Western Europe's rail, highway and canal networks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- President Truman said today that "if the Soviet Republic would act to its neighbors as we act to ours, I don't think there would be any chance for a third world war."

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 27 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets in two air battles over North Korea close to the Manchurian border yesterday shot down four of Communist China's Russian-designed MIG jet fighters and damaged three others. Damage to a fourth MIG was claimed but unconfirmed.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 26 (UP) -Louise Suggs of Carrollton, Ga., took a two-stroke lead today in the first Betty Jameson women's golf open with a 3-under-par 69.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -The Army said today that Herman W. Miaski, 23-year-old Army vetteran with overseas service; originally was arrested as a deserter because he failed to report when called to active duty as a reservist,

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Francis W. Carpenter of the Associated Press has been elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association, which is composed of accredited correspondents from more than twenty countries.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Cardinals clinched third place in the National League tonight as they knocked out Warren. Hacker and went on to whip the Cubs, 10 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Navy unveiled today a powerful radiation device and said it would help speed research toward finding better defenses against atomic bomb rays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today seventy battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported four killed, sixty-four wounded, one missing and one injured. The following were listed from New York (none from Connecticut or New Jersey):

Shareholders of the General Public Utilities Corporation were told this week that the company will help them adjust their holdings of its stock without tax fee or brokerage commission. Those who wish to bring their holdings up to a block divisible by ten may do so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Tighe E. Woods, Director of the Office of Price Stabilization, today rejected a request by a committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to suspend price control regulations governing the goods they sell.

With the script in his possession for almost a year, Herman Levin may get around to producing this season the comedy by James V. McGee called "The Temptation of Maggie Haggarty," the principal role of which is described as "a wild, funny and savage woman who runs a New York rooming house on East Fifteenth Street."

SHRUB OAK, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Ground will be broken on a 336-acre site tomorrow afternoon for the new $5,000,000 Loyola Seminary, the first major Jesuit seminary in the state. The site, on Stoney Street, .a mile south of Shrub Oak, is seven miles east of Peekskill and a half mile west of the Taconic State Parkway.

When the next Administration takes over it will have to take account of a new trend in the thought and policy of our European allies. This trend developed rapidly during the summer; if the attention of our political observers were not otherwise engaged it would be recognized as the forecast of an important turn in trans-Atlantic relations.

The nation's longest football winning streak will be placed on the line today when Princeton, undefeated in twenty-two games over a three-year period, meets Columbia at Baker Field. The contest, which will be televised nationally over N. B. C. as the National Collegiate A. A. "game of the week," will open the 1952 campaign for both teams.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Edgar F. Kaiser, president of Kaiser-Frazer, said today the auto concern plans to introduce on an "experimental" basis a plastic-body sports car in about nine months.

PONCA CITY, Okla., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Senator Sparkman said today he was "sorry" for Senator Richard M. Nixon, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, and wondered "how far the public can go in requiring candidates for public office to divulge everything about their private and financial affairs."

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois campaigned today for Indiana's thirteen electoral votes with pledges of strict, but wise, governmental economy and warnings that a Republican victory in November might mean that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio would conduct the Nation's foreign policy and write its labor laws.

The Maternity Center Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of "My Darlin' Aida," starring Dorothy Sarnoff, on the evening of Oct. 30 at the Winter Garden Theatre Co-chairmen of the committee for the event are Mrs. Virgil G. Damon, Mrs. S. Maitland Goldsmith, Mrs. Edward F. Hutton and Mrs. Edmund P. Rogers. Mrs. Walter N. Rothschild is president of the association.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- The Board of Regents recommended today for the state's public high schools a new American history syllabus putting additional stress on the early development of the nation and the heritage of the Constitution.
Cottonseed oil and potatoes were active in commodity futures trading yesterday, one losing and the other gaining ground.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- A report containing concrete recommendations on admission practices at state medical schools will be available next spring, Dr. Howard E. Wilson, director of a study into admission policies, told the Board of Regents today.

Two American citizens who tried recently to reach Italy as ship stowaways so they could renounce their citizenship have been released from Ellis Island, it was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the Immigration Service.
PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Breaking with tradition, Mme. Marcel Rochas retarded her winter showing this year until the middle of September when the private clientele had returned to town.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Karl R. Bendetsen resigned today as Under Secretary of the Army. President Truman named as his successor Earl D. Johnson, an Assistant Secretary of the Army.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A mechanical golf stance positioner that leaves very little to guess-work was patented (2,611,610) by James Rikuo Hara of Honolulu. Mr. Hara says that previous devices to teach the proper swing have indicated the positions of the head and feet, but he has added a belt with hip pads and a shoulder blade brace.

The first part of a two-volume biography of Benjamin Harrison, the twenty-third President of the United States, will be published Monday by Henry Regnery. Entitled "Benjamin Harrison: Hoosier Warrior," the volume covers his first years in Indiana and Ohio through his Civil War days.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- A group of Iroquois braves became hopelessly tied up today -- eagle feathers and all -- in a tangle of United Nations red tape.

Homer Folks, 85-year-old pioneer in mental health and former executive director of the State Charities Aid Association, received the newly created Hermann Mr. Biggs Memorial Award yesterday for his "distinguished service" in public health.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- The University of Notre Dame football team will make its first appearance in Philadelphia since 1931 tomorrow when it clashes with the University of Pennsylvania at Franklin Field. A capacity crowd of 74,711 will watch the season opener between the two squads, which are expected to rate with the nation's best.
With negotiations on its cargo ship contracts virtually complete, the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., has opened talks with tanker operators for a similar agreement.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- State Education Commissioner Lewis A. Wilson ruled today that the New York City Board of Education had the legal right to ask teachers whether they were members of the Communist party and to dismiss those who refuse to answer.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 26 -- An impressive sight at St. Paul's School today was the calisthenics drill engaged in by 440 students on Brinley Field. Togged out in football and soccer uniforms, the students went through the exercises under the direction of E. Leonard (Bunny) Barker, athletic director.
Tankers have a new heavyweight champion, the 32,500-ton World Enterprise which is now undergoing finishing work at Newcastle-on-Tyne, England.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Green but willing Boston College stumbled to a 14-7 victory over the University of Richmond eleven tonight on a rain-soaked gridiron that made passing hazardous and fumbles frequent.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- Japanese textile spokesmen today forecast an all-out "textile war" between Britain and Japan as a result of the two-week International Cotton Conference at Buxton, England, which ended yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Syracuse University's powerful football team broke through a gallant but reeling Boston University eleven for two quick fourth-period touchdowns tonight to register a 34-21 triumph at Archbold Stadium before 15,000 fans.
The new art season warms up this week with a selection of one-man and group exhibitions of paintings and sculpture of diverse interest.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 26 -- The Rutgers University faculty member who refused on Wednesday to answer questions about alleged membership in the Communist party before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in New York said today that he was not and never had been a party member.

The primary interest of last night's "La Boheme" at the City Center was centered on young Thomas Schippers, who up to now has been mainly concerned with Menotti operas. This "Boheme" marked his entry as a conductor of a standard repertory item.

The year's top race for 2-year-olds, the Futurity, will be up for decision at Belmont Park today. It will be the sixty-third running of a six-and-a-half-furlong sprint that never has been won by a gray horse. Perhaps there'll be a change in the color scheme on this occasion, for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's gray Native Dancer heads the ten-colt line-up.

BERN, Switzerland, Sept. 26 -- Developments in the new European Coal and Steel Community during its critical first period are being watched almost as closely outside as inside the group of the six participating countries.

Ten additional assistant corporation counsels are slated for dismissal as part of Mayor Impellitteri's campaign to bring pressure on Tammany district leaders to oust Carmine G. DeSapio as leader of Tammany Hall, it was reported yesterday.
Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, will be observed by Jews over the world from sundown tomorrow until sundown on Monday.

One totally nonpartisan observation on the present stage of the Presidential campaign is that it is not apathetic. The Nixon issue has stirred up strong emotions, and these are likely to get stronger before the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. It would be pleasant to think that a major election might go through without any personal name-calling.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who was defeated in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, said today that, while he and the nominee "may have some differences about foreign policy and what we ought to do," they were in complete accord on all other issues.

A dividend of 8 1/2 cents a share was declared yesterday on the common stock of Foster Kleiser Company, payable Oct. 31. This is the amount due in dividends on the common up to Oct. 17 when the option of W. R. Grace Co. to purchase Foster Kleiser common stock will expire or be exercised.

BRIDGEPORT, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Two ferryboats of the Chester- Bridgeport Ferry Company went aground here this morning, stranding 177 passengers on-mud flats outside the ferry slips for seven and eight hours. A heavy fog that rolled in unexpectedly across the Delaware River was blamed for the mishaps.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Breaking the 2-all tie by winning the fifth race, the quintet of International Class skippers from the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today won the Skoal Trophy put up last year by the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club.
New York University will face Lehigh today in the opening game of its sixty-sixth football season at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The kickoff time is 2 P. M.
Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks retained the title in the Women's Cross County Golf Association's annual 54-hole medal play tourney with 157, 80 -- 237 at North ills in Douglaston yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 -- Since the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System temporarily suspended its controls on consumer credit, installment finance is again demonstrating its ability to keep its house in order, the Association of Bank Women were told today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 -- John Foster Dulles accused the Truman Administration tonight of showing a "diminishing interest" in the United Nations.

The Yankees last night clinched the American League championship with an eleven-inning 5-2 victory over the Athletics at Philadelphia. It was the fourth consecutive title for the New Yorkers under Manager Casey Stengel and the nineteenth for the club since 1921.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 26 -- President Otilio Ulate resigned tonight after having addressed Congress, as the climax to a Governmental crisis brought about when five of the nation's six top-ranking military and police leaders resigned in a body.

The sixteen-story-apartment hotel containing sixty-one suites and six stores at 25 East Sixty-seventh Street has been sold by the Knott Hotels Corporation to Nathan Wilson, operator, it was announced yesterday. It fronts 100 feet on Madison Avenue and thirty feet on Sixty-seventh Street, at the northwest corner, and was bought subject to a mortgage of about $315,000.

SEATTLE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A top United States Air Force official said today targets in Russia were within reach of jet bombers that could fly from American-operated airdromes abroad and refuel in the air en route.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Northern soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers still do not have a contract, despite their announced agreement on terms almost a week ago.

LONDON, Sept 26 -- Stock jobbers in foreign markets suspended dealings in Japanese bonds after official working hours following a flood of small selling orders of Japanese bonds. Profit taking was inspired by reports that announcement of a debt settlement was imminent.

The United Nations in its role as acting landlord of the Parkway Village housing development in Queens, notified the aroused residents yesterday, that they must agree to pay an average of 16 per cent higher rent or move out next Tuesday.

On Thursday evening in Baltimore General Eisenhower made what is perhaps the most important address of the political campaign, on either side, that has been heard thus far. It is doubtful that any future utterances will surpass it in coming to grips with what is actually uppermost in all our minds.

A new industrial building at 100 Taft Avenue and 99 Madison Avenue in Hempstead, L. I., has been leased by the Remington Aluminum Window Corporation from David Cohen, builder. Albert M. Greenfield Co. were the brokers.

This is the day, Sept. 27, when the dramatization of a notable, best-selling American novel is to have its first performance in an upstate New York theatre. In the year of publication the book on which it is based has sold over 300,000 copies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended Sept. 23 to 111.1 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products declined 0.8 per cent from the previous week, reflecting sizable decreases in the price of steers and lambs, corn and oats, eggs in New York, and some fresh fruits and vegetables.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Japanese authorities said tonight either a tidal wave or suction from an underwater volcano must have sunk a Japanese observation ship that vanished Tuesday with thirty-one aboard.

The high rate of shoe production in August and September may create excessive inventories in the shoe industry this year, the Tanners' Council warned yesterday in a bulletin to its members. Unless retail shoe volume expands more than has been the case so far, stocks will be increased to a point requiring a cutback, the Council said.

Mr. Webster defines class as "quality, distinguishing one as of superior grade." For the past four years in the American League seven teams have encountered that class in the persons of men with the name "New York Yankees" written across their chests. Now, for the fourth straight time, the Yankees have won the junior circuit's pennant, and are about to embark on a try for their fourth straight world's championship in the world series.

Last night we had Alicia Mark-over back again in "Giselle" after an absence of far too many seasons, for this is one of the supreme performances of our time. It is true that she has returned only as guest artist with the Ballet Theatre in its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, and that inevitably imposes elements of imperfection.

NOW that humor, including the he-who-laughs-last gambit, has become a rambunctious issue in the Presidential campaign, it behooves us to find out all we can about it. What masters shall we study ? Why not Bernard-Shaw and Oscar Wilde and Richard Brinsley Sheridan and John Millington Synge and perhaps a couple of other Irishmen?

The city's much-put-upon Department of Sanitation thinks it has tracked down a group of major offenders responsible for causing unsightly street litter. Periodic checking, the department claims, has revealed that shopkeepers fill sidewalk wire baskets with bulk trade waste, crowding out the passing pedestrian with his empty candy wrapper or cigarette package.

Although rice is the main course at meals in many countries, it is used here merely as a dessert or "vegetable" with meat dishes. Nevertheless, it is an important commodity in the agricultural economy of this country, it was pointed out yesterday by the National Rice Council, Beaumont, Tex.
Crime, its prevention and correction, has been a frequent topic among your news items and letters to THE TIMES.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- Although many United States officials have striven to portray the German people as eager recruits to the cause of Atlantic alliance, the results of polls take by a responsible German agency indicate no overwhelming German enthusiasm for this policy.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Two industrial spokesmen today praised New York State's revised Unemployment Insurance Law but called for further changes.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 26 -- Nurses should not be expected to subsidize the cost of health care by foregoing their right to reasonable economic gains, it was decided today at an American Nurses Association workshop on economic conditions of registered nurses.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 (UP) -Mexican Air Force cargo planes flew food and medicine today to 200,000 half-starved victims of floods spreading across one-third of Mexico.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson made a thirteen-word unscheduled talk tonight -- and touched off a howl of laughter.

Tentative, preliminary results of a survey intended eventually to provide a picture of the non-industrial illness experiences of 400,000 working Americans were outlined yesterday by the Research Council for Economic Security. The Chicago group was host at luncheon in the Cammodore Hotel to representatives of fifty business and industrial organizations, many of whose employes are to be included in the survey.

The word "slump" gained more acceptance this week as the appropriate term for the continuing poor sales showing of New York's large department stores. There continued to be support, however, for the belief that a marked pick-up in sales usual at this time of the year had simply been delayed, mostly by unseasonable weather.

Title to the Yonkers Railroad Company, operator of nine trolley lines in lower Westchester County, was transferred yesterday to the Westchester Citizens Transportation Committee. The sale became effective last midnight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 -- Harvard is quietly confident that tomorrow's opener with Springfield will launch the Crimson on its most successful football campaign since 1948, when a 20-7 victory over Yale embellished a 4-4 won-and-lost record.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa. Sept. 26 -- The six-story office building of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company was sold here today to King's College despite a controversy which led to the resignation of Benjamin Henderson as vice president and general manager of the coal company in protest at the sale price of $450,000.
The President, in accepting the resignation of Mr. Ching as director of the Conciliation Service, issued a well-deserved tribute of the nation's appreciation and gratitude.

The New York Shipping Association and the international Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., have completed their formal arbitration agreement for settlement of a wage re-opening dispute and are submitting the pact to Federal mediators.
With selected oil and copper issues softest, the stock market displayed a sagging tendency in late dealings yesterday and closed irregularly lower.

The Second International Art Film Festival will be held at the Hunter College Auditorium, Nov. 28 through 30, it was announced by the American Federation of Arts, the Film Advisory Center and the Woodstock (N. Y.) Artists Association, the sponsors.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Dan A. Kimball, United States Secretary of the Navy, said today that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Republican candidate for President, was mistaken when he declared in Baltimore last night that the Navy had laid in "a fifty-year supply of anchors."
SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A state of siege was established today throughout El Salvador as a result of an alleged Communist plot to overthrow the Government of President Oscar Osorio.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 26 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, said today he thought "another Democratic Administration can work out" a civil rights program in Congress.

Kelly Gruzen, architects and engineers, have been appointed design consultants for the Raritan Valley Shopping Center to be erected on the former estate of Joseph S. Frelinghuysen in Raritan, N. J. The firm will work in association with Wolf Glucksman of Newark, architects and engineers.

Some commissions charged with regulating the natural gas industry "seem to ignore" the future needs of natural gas consumers, Stuart M. Crocker, chairman of The Columbia Gas System, Inc., told members of the Society of Security Analysts yesterday in Richmond, Va.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 -- An old friend returned to the Berlin newsstands today. The old Ullstein publication, Berliner Morgenpost, which was founded Sept. 28, 1898, was on the streets for the first time since April 19, 1945, and in the hands of the Ullstein family for the first time since the Nazis took it over in 1934.

A new method to help detect cancer of the stomach in its early, and possibly still curable, stages was outlined yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -An industry spokesman acknowledged today that he sometimes got so bored with beer commercials on radio and television he turned them off.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Board of Regents ruled today that a Spanish-language film, "Slaves of the Underworld," could not be shown publicly in this state because of its portrayal of drug addiction.
The American Bankers Association announced a series of organizational changes at the top executive level yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, charged today that the Armed Forces Reserve Act "fails to establish a real ready reserve in being * * * prepared for combat service with minimum delay."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The suggestion that the salaries of members of Congress be increased from $12,500 to $24,000 a year to assure the same "take-home" pay as in 1939 was advanced tonight by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, in a radio appearance.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation had a consolidated net income of $6,647,079 in the nine months ended last Aug. 31, equal to 72 cents a share on 8,889,400 common shares outstanding, the report disclosed yesterday. In the corresponding period of the prior year the net was $7,660,372, or 84 cents each on 8,755,353 common shares then outstanding.

A group of defendants in the departmental trial of thirty-one suspended policemen accused of taking graft from Harry Gross offered unofficially yesterday to submit to a lie detector test if the convict bookmaker would take one with them.

Twenty-four firemen strapped on new gas masks yesterday and plunged into the fume-filled basement of Firehouse Rescue Company No. 4 at 64-18 Queens Boulevard, Winfield, Queens, where they splintered railroad ties, with axes. After ten minutes of a strenuous workout they trotted up to the third floor of the firehouse, exchanged equipment and went through the performance a second time.
The college football season will hit full stride today, in virtually every sector of the nation.

Senator Irving M. Ives, campaigning in the city between upstate tours, last night attacked concentration of power in the Federal Government. The Administration, he declared, appeared to have "lost all faith in the ability of Americans to govern themselves at the local and state levels."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Scandinavian Airlines System tonight announced plans for the first California-to-Europe air service over the top of the world via Thule, Greenland, Air Base.
C. Walter Buhler has been named executive vice president of A. S. Harrison Company, South Norwalk, Conn., and G. Gardner Pitts has been named secretary. The company makes various house-hold products.

Lovers of the ironical will have much to relish in the tale of two envoys that has been unfolded these past two days. On Thursday Georgi M. Zarubin, the new Soviet Ambassador to this country, told reporters in Washington that there is no "Hate America" campaign in his country.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The auto industry is planning to hire women again in the plants, Ward's automotive report said today.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Sept. 26 -America's top military planning is not in good working order, Dr. Vannevar Bush, one of the nation's top scientists, declared here tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Robert Schuman, the French Foreign Minister, said today that France would not accept direct United Nations intervention in her relations with the French protectorates of Morocco and Tunisia.
E. R. Zane has been elected a director of Burlington Mills Corporation and Walter E. Greer Jr., vice president, has been named executive vice president.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Additional information concerning the manner in which the United States acted to meet the Korean crisis in the United Nations in June, 1950, came to light today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Heavy liquidating pressure continued on the nearby wheat deliveries today, with December setting a new crop low. But there was fair support in the coarse grains and soybeans futures showed a strong undertone much of the session.

DORTMUND, Germany, Sept. 26 -- A Communist proposal for a popular front with the Socialists against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government and the treaty system linking West Germany with the Atlantic alliance was summarily rejected today by the annual convention of the Social Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, announced today his resignation as chairman and member of the storm-tossed Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, appealed last night for "friendly cooperation between Asia and America" as a key to world peace. General Romulo, who also is chief delegate from his country to the United Nations, spoke at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel given by the Asia Institute as a part of its International Conference on Asian Problems.

His wife's $2,000 mink coat, purchased while ha was earning a salary of $3,800 a year, led to the indictment yesterday of a suspended Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue, charged with making a false statement to the Treasury Department in connection with its purchase.
Is Governor Stevenson going to do a "Nixon"?

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa !Fee Railway System announced a net income of $43,352,630, yester{day, equal to $8.08 a common !share, for the eight months ended i Aug. 31., This represents an increase of 48 per cent over the $29,195,654 or $5.16 a share cleared {in the first eight months of 1951,
Parents with youngsters in senior high school may find the following 1952-53 catalogue edition, published recently, of special interest:

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 26 -- A radiologist on the faculty of Iowa State University College of Medicine told the American Roentgen Ray Society here today that radio-active gold offered hope for men suffering with cancer of the prostate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The struggles of two white mice in a rocket thirty-eight miles above earth have nearly convinced the Air Force that future space travelers will not mind being weightless if they hang on to their seats.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Robert Menzies announced today the Australian Government has sold its controlling interest in the Commonwealth Oil Refineries, Ltd., to the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, which thus becomes sole stock-holder in the distributing and refining enterprise.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 26 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower escaped unhurt tonight when temporary stands on the steps of the Virginia State Capitol collapsed under the weight of spectators as he was walking off the rostrum after making a major address.

It's sweet potato time. The sugary-flavored tubers with yellow or deep orange flesh are arriving from Virginia, North Carolina and Maryland; the price is down to 12 1/2 cents a pound. But there will be no abundance this year. The crop is only slightly better than in 1951 when the harvest was the smallest since 1881.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized the United Gas Corporation at Shreveport, La., today to sell at competitive bidding $60,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due in 1972.

Among the many projects for the unification of Europe the most ambitious and potentially most helpful is the "Greater Europe" plan adopted without opposition by the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe at Strasbourg. It is still just a plan in which many things must be spelled out.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Dr. Donald F. Gibson of Danbury and West Redding won a technical point in Fairfield County Superior Court today in his fight to retain his license to practice medicine and surgery in Connecticut. It came when Judge Howard W. Alcorn denied a motion by the State Health Department and the Connecticut Medical Examining Board to strike from the record a portion of the physician's appeal.
Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter reserved decision yesterday in a suit to declare unconstitutional the city's $5 and $10 tax on trucks engaged in inter-state commerce.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement by Secretary Acheson today in reply to General Eisenhower:

The 500th anniversary of the printing of the Gutenberg Bible in Europe will be widely celebrated among Roman Catholics and Protestants this coming week, starting tomorrow. It will be the second Roman Catholic Bible Week in the history of the American hierarchy.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Maurrie O'Connor, Branch Brook pro, and Charlotte De Cozen of Montclair combined for a brilliant 35,36 -- 71 on a selected drive, alternate shot round to win the qualifying medal today in the Frank J. Cloran pro-woman tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club.

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 27 -- L'Humanite, official organ of the French Communist party, published two statements today from Andre Marty and Charles Tillon accepting sanctions taken against them early this month and promising to make the detailed self-criticism the party has been demanding of them.

Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the New York State Assembly, of which he was Speaker in 1935, died yesterday afternoon, at the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, of a heart attack at the age of 58. He had been in the hospital for two weeks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- "The Valley of the Kings" is the title affixed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to a story being written by Robert Pirosh about an archeological expedition and its adventures in Egypt.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Two of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson's state appointees said today they had received "Christmas gifts" from the Governor, but declined to disclose the amount.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Although Secretary General Trygve Lie's present term of office will not expire until Feb. 1, 1954, there is already considerable discussion as to whether he will accept another extension of his term, and if not who his successor will be.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 26 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower stood on the lovely south portico of Thomas Jefferson's Virginia capitol tonight and said in effect that he would be mighty proud to have Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia support the Republican ticket on Election Day.

IRVINGTON, N. J., Sept. 26 -- A 16-year-old boy has confessed the theft of $8,400 from his recently widowed mother to finance the purchase of automobiles, the police reported today. The youth was arrested yesterday after a report to the police that he was riding around town in a new convertible without a driver's license.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- India's principal leftist opposition parties have merged into two politcal units, one headed by Socialists, the other by Communists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Truman received today the first copy of the new revised standard version of the Old and New Testaments from the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S .A.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 26 -- Indonesian and American embassy officials are optimistic that a new agreement for United States aid to Indonesia can be concluded soon.

Lebanon is the latest -- but not the last -- of the Middle Eastern states to throw out its old Government and install a regime pledged to drastic reform. The overturn in Beirut differs from others in that it was not accompanied by violence or accomplished by coup d'etat.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Dr. Joseph Needham, fellow of the Royal Society and Cambridge University biochemist, who was the sole British representative on the Communist-sponsored "International Scientific Commission for the Investigation of the facts concerning bacteriological warfare in Korea and China," said today he was convinced that the United States was guilty of waging germ warfare.
DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 26 -- An unheralded shakeup in the high command of Dan River Mills, Virginia's second largest industrial corporation, was announced today.

Manager Chuck Dressen's preparations for the world series continued at Ebbets Field yesterday before the smallest attendance of the season as the second-string Dodgers beat the Braves, 8 -- 4, in a rather loosely played game.

Daylight Saving Time will end at 2 A. M. tomorrow in more than twenty-two states, mostly along the Eastern Seaboard, and in the District of Columbia. Sixty million persons, their clocks and watches adjusted back one hour, will accordingly lol1 in the annual luxury of an extra hour's Sunday morning sleep.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- Following is the text of Pravda's statement on United States Ambassador George F. Kennan:
As one who plans to vote for Eisenhower this November I feel that the letter of Peter Gay, as published in your issue of Sept. 13, cannot be allowed to go unanswered.
RAPID CITY, S. D., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Farmers were urged today to do a better public relations job for themselves by J. R. Isleib, Washington, D. C., land bank commissioner.

THE scoter, that miscalled and misunderstood diver of our coastal waters, will be legal game at noon tomorrow, and although the real migration of big sea ducks is not yet under way, there are enough of them here to justify an excursion to a point outside the "outer harbor lines."

The New York Public Library's copy of the Gutenberg Bible, which was brought here in 1847 by James Lenox, one of the library's early benefactors and founders, will be on exhibition, beginning tomorrow, until Oct. 15, in the main lobby of the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
FORT DIX, N. J., Sept, 28 -- A 23-year-old Rensselaer, N. Y., plasterer left today for home, a civilian again after he had been held fourteen days as a deserter.

Conscious but unable to move because of a severely injured -- perhaps broken -- back, a laborer lay for six hours yesterday alone in the damp, stone-cold blackness of a pit beneath one of the arches under the Brooklyn Bridge. The police of the Old Slip Station said last night he was in a serious condition at Beekman Hospital, where he was being treated for shock, exposure and a possible spine fracture.

Your recent article on the anniversary of the English calendar treats a subject in which historians have long been interested -- struggling, as they have to, with the change of dates and the passing of the old-style calendar.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- An attack today in Pravda, Communist party newspaper, against George F. Kennan, United States Ambassador, branding him as an "enemy of the Soviet Union," a "slanderer under the mask of a diplomat" and a violator of the "elementary rules obligatory for a diplomat, marked a substantial disturbance in diplomatic norms between the Soviet Union and the United States.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Rochester University scored a 20-7 victory over the United States Merchant Marine Academy today at Fauver Stadium before 4,500 fans. Scores were made in the first and second periods by the Yellowjackets while Kings Point tallied in the closing minutes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The chilling realization that North American survival may rest upon the North Pole's ice cap has been driven home in recent days with the relentless force of a billion-ton iceberg's first plunge into the Arctic seas.

ALTHOUGH Lord Raglan in his learned volume "The Hero" concluded that Leif the Lucky's voyages to the New World did not take place but were ritual drama comparable to "the other-world voyages of Irish mythology," there are few historical facts better established than that the son of Eric the Red did indeed land at various points in North America.

THIS interesting analysis of English comedies is based upon lectures delivered in the graduate school of Columbia and at Brandeis University. Mr. Kronenberger disclaims both completeness and philosophical system but he has a point of view and something specific to say about a very considerable number of plays which have retained their power to amuse.

WITHIN the nearly five centuries that have elapsed since Columbus sailed from Spain on his first voyage of discovery we have seen the complete development of scientific investigation as we know it today. Each new generation has re-examined and assessed the findings of the previous one, corrected and reinterpreted those findings, and enlarged our knowledge.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- In another sail-cloth spread of post-season racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club forty-one craft competed on Long Island Sound today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27 -- In baseball terms, the Democrats felt this week that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower settled for a base on balls to advance his campaign when he had a chance to hit a home run and win the Presidency with a single blow.
Brooklyn Prep upset the Erasmus Hall eleven, 7 -- 6, at Boys High Field yesterday in the first meeting of the teams since 1935.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Following is the text of an address by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois here tonight:

ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Frank (Pepper) Rodgers, using the identical script that made him an Orange Bowl hero last Jan. 1, kicked a fourth-quarter field goal today to give Georgia Tech's jittery Engineers a 17-to-14 victory over underrated Florida.
TULSA, Okla., Sept. 27 (AP) -- America's oil industry will usher in "Oil Progress Week" on Oct. 12 with the perennial theme, "Your Progress and Oil Progress Go Hand in Hand."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. -- With this city of 80,000 people gradually replacing Washington, D. C., as the citadel of the democratic party, tourists are being made conscious these days of the sight-seeing and recreational opportunities in the nation's forty-eight state capitals.

WHEN defense spending begins to level off, what sort of a situation will the country's business men face? The amount that is being spent to make the country ready to fight for survival is $50,000,000,000 a year.

THE 9-year-old in the family is on a class committee for bringing in the news -- "news of the nation and the world." In the midst of the breakfast rush, he pops into the kitchen, morning paper in hand, and points to the full text of a candidate's speech. "

CAIRO, Sept. 27 -- The Wafd party, standard-bearer of Egyptian nationalism for the last thirty-four years, defied the new Government today by refusing to dismiss its veteran leader, former Premier Mustafa Nahas, or to comply with the provisions of the Government's Political Parties Law.

COLUMBIA, which has shown an alert, progressive attitude toward its responsibilities to modern music, has come out with one of the most significant scores of the twentieth century -- Alban Berg's opera Lulu. Recorded on three disk, the set features Ilona Steingruber in the title role.

I have read your editorial "Two Funds" and it leaves me not quite half satisfied, as did Senator Nixon's TV broadcast. You condemn the use of private funds to meet expenses which a conscientious Government servant feels are essential to the welfare of his country.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 27 -- Members of the eighth congress of the International Institute of Public Finances ended their annual meeting here today having agreed on six major points concerning techniques for financing national armaments, which was the theme of the discussions.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27 -- In his sharpest attack of the campaign on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower personally, Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois charged tonight that the general was laying down "a barrage of ugly, twisted, demagogic distortion" in an effort to make a vote-getting issue out of "our ugly, miserable, bloody ordeal" in Korea.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The second Veterans Administration hospital in this state will be opened here Tuesday morning. Officially designated as the East Orange Hospital, the $22,000,000 thirteen-story structure will serve a maximum of 950 bed patients after next April.

AMATEUR gardeners and ardent iris growers hail the slender Siberian iris for its ease of culture and lavish flower production. They know, too, that it is unsurpassed among garden iris for its beauty in cut flower arrangements. Light, airy and graceful, Siberian iris flower in late June from sturdy plants set out in fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, announced today that he had accepted an unspecified amount of contributions from unnamed Republicans to help pay for reprints of speeches on proposed organizational reforms in the Government.

TEN years ago the Metropolitan's show of some of its own Rembrandt paintings, drawings and etchings drew 140,000 people. Now, after a decade, it has opened another exhibition nearly double in size, many of the paintings having been recently cleaned with spectacular results discussed in other columns on this page, and with a few impressive loans from the Morgan Library and two private collections.

THERE are pitfalls in the path of those writers of Westerns who date their books. Mention of Wyoming as a territory automatically places the yarn as pre-1890 and there's a resounding anachronism if the hero is equipped with a .30-30 rifle or if McKinley is mentioned as President.

My attention has just been called to a letter which appeared in your columns last June 8 criticizing my assertion, in an earlier letter, that D. W. Griffith's great film, "The Birth of a Nation," grossed the sum of $48,000,000 in the thirty years between 1915 and 1946.

The effects of the Korean war and the draft on the attitudes and study programs of American college students were indicated last week in a report on a study of 5,000 representative undergraduate men at eleven colleges and universities.

THE greatest single expansion of passenger service in the history of the New Haven Railroad will take place today with the placing in service of fifty additional trains. Communities from Boston to New York will be benefited by the new set-up but most of the new trains will operate within Massachusetts, many of them in the Old Colony area.

TANGIER, Sept. 20 -- Morocco's only daily newspaper in English, the Atlantic Courier, published in Casablanca, has been closed down by order of the French residency at Rabat. About 10,000 Americans in the Air Force and Navy and construction companies, few of whom read French, are left without a paper.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (UP) -- One woman was drowned and two other persons were missing today after a Swedish motor vessel rammed and sank a small fishing craft off Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay.

A hint of what may be expected of surgery in the future was offered here last week during the Thirty-eighth Annual Clinical Congress of the American Congress of Surgeons. Transplantation of heart, lung and other vital organs, impossible now, is being seriously studied in an increasing number of surgical tests.

BULBS that flower in summer must be lifted and stored indoors for winter. The place: any frost-free part of the house (cellar or enclosed porch, for example). The time: either before or after frost, depending on the kind of bulb. Storage temperature is another factor and varies with the plant.
PARIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Defects in three new runways at French-built airbases in France, to which United States taxpayers contributed funds, have prevented their use by American jet planes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Truman, in a happy mood but avoiding political predictions, started out at 11:35 o'clock tonight in his sixteen-car special train for his 8,500-mile, fifteen-day whistle-stop tour across the country in which he will make seventy-eight rear-platform talks and eleven major addresses in twenty-four states.

WHEN autumn with its opportunity for so many kinds of planting comes, gardens fall into two distinct classes. There is the one which has so little bloom that it is a pleasure to wade in and clean up to make room for setting out spring bulbs and other plants that will make a better display next year.

THE career of Mahatma Gandhi is continuing to intrigue the moviemakers. Plans for filming a Gandhi biography or various aspects of his life have come from at least three creditable sources during the past two years and now, it became known the other day, a feature-length documentary on the late spiritual leader is being prepared by the American Academy of Asian Studies of San Francisco.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 27 -- The Johannesburg Nationalist newspaper Die Vaderland said today that Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, a Nationalist, might withdraw South African forces from Korea if the United Nations acceded to the request by Arab and Asian countries to debate South Africa's racial policy.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Colgate's football team gave its new coach, Harold Lahar, a choice present on Schoellkopf Field today, the Maroon's first victory over Cornell since 1944. The score was 14 -- 7.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- T. Lamar Caudle, and a lobbyist who assaulted the columnist, Drew Pearson, were today dropped from the Washington Social Register.

IN the beginning of "Hemlock and After" one character says of another: "Doing doesn't last, even if one knows what one's doing, which one usually doesn't. But Bernard was something to people * * * and that has its effect in the end, I think."

JASPER, Alberta -- With an occasional curious bear or deer from the surrounding woodlands acting as sidewalk superintendent, work is now proceeding on a round-the-clock basis on construction of Jasper Park Lodge's new central building.

THE airlines had a good year last year and will have an even better one in 1952. This has been predicted by Sir William P. Hildred, director general of the International Air Transport Association. He anticipates that 45,000,000 passengers will have been carried when the year ends in another fourteen weeks.

FIRST of all, let us reaffirm that the Robert Breen-Blevins Davis production of "Porgy and Bess" was both an artistic and popular success in Vienna, where the European premiere was held two weeks ago, and in this city.

With an echo-sounder on a forty-foot Navy launch, Arthur D. Hasler, James R. Villemonte, Lester V. Whitney and Richard Dugdale of the University of Wisconsin traced the movements of schools of perch in Lake Mendota in Wisconsin and made the remarkable discovery that the fish spend the night sleeping on the bottom near the shore. The echo sounder's revelations were confirmed by divers.

JUST as some people are accident-prone, or trouble-prone, so Sir Alexander Korda appears to be news-prone. Without seeming consciously to do anything except his job, he attracts the headlines. Now it seems likely that in the immediate future, for a variety of concurrent reasons, Sir Alex will be, not for the first time, the figure to watch in the British film world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- One of the paradoxes of our times is the fact that although the Korean War is being fought to uphold the United Nations Charter and its pledges against aggression, the Korean question has not been formally discussed in any United Nations organ for more than a year and a half.

THE near-by villages of Tetecala and Tepoztlan, two quaint little settlements steeped in ancient legend and, until recently, drowsing contentedly in an almost unbroken siesta, have been playing hosts for some time now to the first Hollywood motion picture troupe either has seen.

KONISHIROKU Photo Ind. Co., Ltd., the "little Eastman Kodak of Japan," that country's largest manufacturer of miscellaneous photographic products including cameras, color and black-and-white film, papers, chemicals, photographic plates and sheet film, has established an American agency, the Konica Camera Company, 76 West Chelten Avenue, Philadelphia.

In addition to its substantial, though somewhat curtailed, expansion in steelmaking facilities this year, the nation's iron and steel industry is achieving notable increases in two other phases of its operations -- blast furnace capacity and boron steel production.
BOULDER, Col., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Oklahoma drove 78 yards in the closing minutes today to earn a 21-21 tie with Colorado.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Two fourth-quarter touchdown passes from Jim Skidmore to George Mills brought Muhlenberg from behind twice and gained for the Mules a 19-19 deadlock with Rutgers in the season's opener for both elevens today.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Officials of the City Volunteer Firemen's Association here have opened a fight to win approval of a bill to be presented to the next session of the General Assembly calling for modification of statutes pertaining to operation of lotteries and carnivals.

EVEN the voluble, volatile Desi Arnaz is somewhat awestruck when he discusses the ratings of "I Love Lucy," the weekly TV romp starring Desi and his wife, Lucille Ball, seen Monday nights at 9 o'clock on the C. B. S. network.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Jack Scarbath pulled Maryland from behind in the fourth period today as the Sugar Bowl champions barely brushed aside Auburn, 13 to 7.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Seventeen Britons who studied newspaper production methods in the United States recommended tonight that this country adopt the American "little merchant" newsboy system.

A complete administrative reorganization of the New York University School of Education was announced yesterday by Dean Ernest O. Melby. The plan will integrate the school's twenty-eighth separate departments into three general divisions, a change designed to free members of the faculty for creative effort.

ONE of the most rewarding points about landscaping is that most plants appreciate rather than depreciate in value. Furniture may get shabby and house paint peel. Permanent plantings grow more valuable with the years if they are well chosen and cared for.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, candidate for re-election on the Republican ticket, told the Nassau County Women's Republican Club today that the real feeling of the Democratic candidates toward Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower could be found '''in comments made prior to the pressure of campaign oratory."

" GOOD HUMOR" is an asset in politics, as elsewhere in life. But a sense of humor may be something else again. The former usuually belongs to men who live from without; the latter characterizes men who live from within. The intellectual, introspective type is generally suspected by politicians, who prefer humor that is more earthy than worldly.

Billy Rose summoned the police yesterday to the home at 33 Beekman Place he once shared with his wife, Eleanor Holm, and asked them to watch his "private detectives" jimmy a basement door. After a brief inspection of the five-story residence, he announced that 90 per cent of its "treasures" had been "looted."

HERE we have not only the fullest biography of a Soviet artist that has yet appeared but also the most vivid account of the effect of Soviet cultural policies on the underlying artist. It is an important book and a fascinating one and yet in many ways it is a poor performance.

In "An Indictment of the Fourth B" (Sept. 21) Aaron Copland notes the vast popular interest in new books, contrasting that fact with America's attitude in regard to new music. That such a situation exists is evident and can even be defended.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Loud rumblings within the Communist party structure in France during the last two weeks have once more brought the attention of political observers here and throughout the free world to bear on two questions -- the future of the party itself and the next moves in its fight to tear away a key member nation from the Western defense system.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- After a renewed study of the situations in France and Britain the European Payments Union Council issued today a statement saying that suspension of trade liberalization measures in both countries was still justified.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- This week's dramatic disclosures surrounding the private expense fund of Senator Richard M. Nixon of California, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, have raised anew the question of whether members of Congress are adequately paid.

Back in New York for a brief rest between campaign tours, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and his political advisers were reported yesterday to be reading portents of a Republican victory in the size and manifest good will of the crowds that have greeted him wherever he has appeared.

THIS week will find the television and radio schedules taking what will be pretty much their final form as the first week of October brings a spate of returning shows and a number of new ones.

Columbia University is offering nine new areas of study on both the graduate and undergraduate levels during the 1952-53 academic year. The university will initiate this year four four-year courses of undergraduate study leading to the degree of Bachelor of Fine Arts.

A program for making the Republic of Indonesia self-sufficient in its basic food of rice within the next five years has been disclosed here by the Indonesian Government's New York information office following an announcement by Gen. Gunung Iskandar, Secretary of the Agricultural Ministry.
