Food kitchens and clinics providing hot meals and medical treatment for children of impoverished Jews in French Morocco are achieving "spectacular results" in combating malnutrition, trachoma and other diseases, Jack D. Weiler reported yesterday.

SPECIES crocus are undiscovered treasure for many gardens where the better-known Dutch varieties are well established. There are both autumn and spring-blooming species and, in fact, autumnal varieties planted in previous years should be flowering now.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP) -- John Cashmore, long an outspoken foe of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway, promised tonight to "re-appraise" his position on that controversial issue if elected to the United States Senate.

VINELAND, N. J., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith called tonight for the strengthening of the United Nations. Mr. Smith, a candidate for re-election, said the Truman Administration had acted on its own and outside the United Nations.

Less than three hours after the public sale of tickets for the Yankee Stadium games in the world series had been opened yesterday, it closed -- a complete sell-out of boxes and reserved seats. Several thousand person lined up around the four-block area at the Stadium. The windows opened for business at 9 A. M. and shortly before noon every ticket had been bought.

THE New England preacher whose famous Baltimore sermon, in 1819, opened the floodgates of revolt against religious dogmatism and made him leader of the Unitarian movement, has been widely revered, not only as preacher and prophet but for his powerful impact on the social issues of his time.

SIR FREDERICK PONSONBY was a courtier for all of forty years, professional in his approach and businesslike in his methods. He served Queen Victoria and two Kings -- Edward VII and George V. At one time or another he was equerry, assistant private secretary, keeper of the privy purse.

Public school teachers have an obligation to take up controversial subjects in the classroom, but they should present those topics in such a way as to enable young people to think through the issues and to form "rational judgments," the Board of Education said last week.
CLEMSON, S. C., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Villanova, using an ex-Army halfback who transferred from West Point after the cribbing scandal, crushed Clemson today, 14 -- 7, before 28,000 fans.

THE magnetism of Paris never radiated more alluringly than during the first decades of this century. Irresistible to hinterland artists were the siren songs emanating from Montmartre and Montparnasse. And in droves they came: Chagall from Russia; Soutine from Lithuania; Modigliani from Italy and Alfred Maurer from New York.

WASHINGTON -- An abundance of material from the first official attempt to create a comprehensive and continuing survey of world travel and tourist trends is stacking up in a Government office here, badly in need of an author and publisher.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 27 -- The five day work week has been slowly but steadily gaining popularity in offices, stores and factories in Atlanta, according to a survey completed by the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce. About sixty offices and stores and sixty-nine factories are on a five day work week, the study showed.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- The Radical party disclosed today that Peronista officials had initiated a campaign designed to wipe out all vestiges of opposition in every city and town of the Province of Buenos Aires. Long questionnaires have been sent by the Ministry of the Interior to all Mayors, calling for detailed information on all associations including sporting clubs and cultural groups that might have an anti-Peronista bias.

BERTIL A. RENBORG of Sweden announced last week that he will retire on Tuesday as Chief of the Postal Administration of the United Nations. He will be succeeded by Reidar Tvedt of Norway, a career man with the Norwegian Government and the U. N. before becoming Mr. Renborg's assistant about four months ago.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Tommy O'Connell passed for one touchdown and set up two others today as Big Ten champion and Rose Bowl winner Illinois swamped Iowa State, 33 to 7, before 47,338 fans.

Dollar sales volume of the major New York City department stores ran an estimated 11 per cent behind the corresponding 1951 week, according to trade observers. It was the twenty-fourth consecutive week in which the combined volume of the large stores failed to equal or exceed the 1951 weeks. Merchants were becoming more concerned over the trend, but optimism for a good fall and holiday season persisted.

IN the flush of victory Bucky Harris forgot all about protocol. Custom calls for the losing manager to make the painful trip to the dressing quarters of the winning manager and offer him congratulations on capturing the world series. But Bucky was the new boy on the block then.

Retail sales of home freezers seem destined to exceed the half-billion dollar mark this year for the first time as manufacturers report an unexpected spurt in sales from May 1 through Aug. 30. Last week appliance producers estimated that freezer dollar volume now stands at better than one-third of that for refrigerators, although the latter still outsell freezers better than four to one.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- The "Nixon case" would never have arisen if Congress had courage enough to enact proposed laws aimed at publicizing the financial status of Federal officials, Archibald S. Alexander, Democratic candidate for Senator from New Jersey, said here today.

TRENTON, Sept. 27 -- A higher tilt to headlight beams on automobiles and trucks registered in New Jersey will become a regulation Wednesday.
AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 27 (AP) -- American International College defeated Amherst today, 21 to 0, before 4,500 fans.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (UP) -- A high school football player was shot dead today by an angry fan whom he had punched in the nose for making fun of his gridiron ability, the police reported.

RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 27 -- Gov. W. Kerr Scott and the State Budget Bureau removed this week salary discriminations against the staff of the mental hospital for Negroes in Goldsboro. They also increased the pay of psychiatrists and hospital officials at all state hospitals.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Americans who are accustomed to, and are now absorbed in, the tooth-and-nail tactics of United States politics will see an interesting contrast to the Presidential campaign if they can spare the time to look this way next week.

ATHENS, Sept. 27 -- Today's issue of the Athens newspaper Allaghi, usually regarded as an organ of Premier Nicholas Plastiras' Progressive party, astonished its readers with an editorial written on the eleventh anniversary of the formation of the EAM and Elas, wartime civil and military Resistance organizations, respectively, commending them for their struggle, and adding: "Long may they live."

The New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will open its winter series of concerts in Room 213 on Wednesday at noon with the first performance of the latest recording of Beethoven's Ninth symphony, conducted by Arturo Toscanini.

TAKING a spoonful of facts recorded in the Gospels and a full measure of her own fancy, Miss Malvern has concocted a romantic tale of a Jewish girl and a Roman boy during the early days of the Christian era. The girl is Tamar, Jairus' daughter whom Jesus raises from the dead.

CALCUTTA, Sept. 27 -- Representatives of the Indian jute industry are leaving on Tuesday for the United States to establish "personal contacts" with the principal American importers of jute products and to organize a publicity campaign.
It was a week packed with more drama than many whole campaigns in American history could show. These things happened:

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Bobby Luna, a 180-pound sophomore halfback, scored two touchdowns and kicked three extra points to lead the Alabama Crimson Tide to a 21-20 victory over Louisiana State University tonight.

Business is good, and is expected to remain so through mid-December, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its September survey, issued for publication today.

The facts are that Nixon was the willing beneficiary of a secret fund contributed by donors whose identity was concealed until dug out and sensationally disclosed. The fund was used as Nixon directed and entirely for his benefit.

The gas appliance industry is facing some materials shortages, the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. The association said sharply increased demand for domestic and industrial gas equipment is causing the difficulty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has told President Truman that the fourteen-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization has entered upon its "realistic phase" and that the base for building a true defense force for Western Europe now exists.

Some 60,000,000 persons in twenty-two states and the District of Columbia could have an extra hour of sleep this morning -- if they wanted to. Daylight Saving Time ended today, at 2 A. M., with clocks and watches set back one hour to standard time.

WHEN the North Korean Communist forces slashed across the Thirty-eighth Parallel an era ended for a small band of American advisers to the fledgling Republic of Korea. The author of this book had been a member of that band, serving in the United States Information Service, until his dismissal.

SUCH was the beauty of Antonio Magnano, that his mere appearance on a street or in a cafe was enough to engender an eruption of passion in the entire female population of Catania -- barely nubile signorinas, portly signoras and shelved spinsters alike.

ONE day last March, that eminent monologist, Charles Dillon Stengel, was babbling away in one of his bewildering dissertations, identifying no person and no team by name and frequently not even bothering to use subject or predicate along with his dangling participles. Finally he said something that didn't have to be translated.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 -- Billy Meyer resigned today as manager of the last-place Pittsburgh Pirates "for a healthier" job.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Texas' powerhouse gave North Carolina, which is just learning the T-formation, a rude lesson in that style of play today by piling up a 28-7 victory before 40,000 fans.

STARTING with Aloha Week, Oct. 12 to 18, the Hawaiian Islands will hold a series of festivals during the weeks of late fall. Plays and pageants will recall the early conquest of the islands and the days of King Kamehameha.
Any occurrence affecting the life of the nation is a historical event, and as such is a battlefield in the cold war. This is true of the Presidential election and therefore of the Nixon affair.

Two of the country's leading hospital authorities turned away in despair from the registration desk of the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Philadelphia last week. Harried clerks had just informed them that not another delegate to the American Hospital Association Convention, even those with reservations, could possibly be jammed into the hotel.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- The Senators took sole possession of fifth place in the American League today with a 3-2 victory over the Red Sox before 5,168 fans.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Ten famous old houses of Westchester will be opened to the public from 10:30 A. M. to 5 P. M. next Saturday for the first general pilgrimage of its kind ever arranged by the County Historical Society. Maps at each house will guide visitors to the other places, in any order of preference.

SPEAKING at this year's annual Festival of Contemporary Arts of the University of Illinois, Howard Mumford Jones attempted to provide a new shield of Perseus in which his university audience might safely gaze at the beauty of Medusa, the dread impersonation of inspired art whose beauty turns the unwary to stone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Truman tonight opened the 1952 Community Chest campaigns and called on Americans to support the annual drive as "one of the finest and most important things that ever happens in America."

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 27 -- A better conditioned Holy Cross football team bounced back from a sluggish opening period today and routed Dartmouth, 27 -- 9, in the opening game for both teams. A crowd of 14,327 watched the Memorial Field contest in beautiful fall weather.

TO Henry Steele Commager's revealing review of "Henry Adams: Scientific Historian," one word might be added that would clear a connection. The title of Adams' essay, "The Rule of Phase Applied to History," names a source which was not "out-of-date" then or now, a source which provided him with much more than the "scientific tags" to which Mr. Commager so justly objects.

If Manager Charlie Dressen was looking merely at the scoreboard yesterday at Ebbets Field he might have felt some dismay about the pre-world series performance of his ace relief pitcher, Joe Black -- who will become a starting pitcher in the big battle starting next Wednesday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Ohio State, with Howard (Hop-a-Long) Cassady running wild for three touchdowns, came from behind to beat Indiana, 33 -- 13, with three last-period touchdowns before 70,206 fans today in the first Big Ten game of the season here.
Almost all categories of clothing and accessories showed firm demand last week with heavy reorders and fill-ins both for current and Christmas retailing, according to resident buying offices here.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Sophomore Quarterback Rudy Mattioli passed for two touchdowns and scored one himself to spark the University of Pittsburgh to a 26-14 victory over Iowa today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept 27 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh has decided to slash the budget of the Iranian Army, possibly by half, if he does not get soon substantial funds, such as advances on future oil deliveries or the 49,000,000 ($137,000,000) he has demanded from the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.

IT'S unusual enough for a mystery novelist to display a marked individuality which sets him apart from his fellows. It's almost unheard of for him to display a book-by-book individuality which makes each novel not only unlike the work of the other men, but even unlike its own predecessors.

The autumnal equinox usually brings a change in the weather; last week it also had a beneficial effect on stock market sentiment, as prices advanced in active trading to the best levels since early in September. Settlement of a potential strike in the Northern soft coal fields removed one dark cloud from the business horizon, but a few hurdles remain before peace is assured in the coal fields generally.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 27 (UP) -- The University of Nebraska, sparked by Bobby Reynolds and Quarterback John Bordogna, powered its way to a 28-13 intersectional victory over the University of Oregon tonight before 24,061 in the first clash in history between the two schools.

The Artists Equity Association, which began a few years ago as a young, struggling organization of painters and sculptors determined to advance the cause of art and artists in this country, is about to embark on a project that has been clear to the heart and ideals of its members from the beginning -- the opening of a workshop.

McKINLEY PARK, Alaska, Sept. 27 -- Experiments on a great fifty-mile-square floating ice island, which has been the ocean-going laboratory of American Air Force scientists since early this summer, prove that man can now occupy and not merely explore the Arctic Basin, an Air Force officer reported this week at the Alaska Science Conference here.

RALPH VAUGHAN WILLIAMS will be 80 on Oct. 12, and in Great Britain there will be extensive observance of the anniversary. It is likely that there will be a good deal in this country when our musical leaders become aware of the occasion.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- The Communist party of Armenia has been told that the Middle Eastern countries adjacent to the Soviet Union steadily are sinking deeper into poverty, starvation and economic stagnation under "American-British oppression" and that resistance in all these countries to American policy is growing steadily.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Jack Culver, fullback from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, scored three touchdowns today as Harvard opened its seventy-ninth football season with a 27-7 victory over Springfield before 9,000 fans.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 28 -- Intense local fighting flared up again along the Korean front yesterday, with both sides probing sharply at their opponents' outposts, but without a gain in ground for either.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communiqu 1,386, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korea time:

Assistant Secretary General Byron Price, chief personnel administrator of the United Nations, said yesterday that its employes living in the Parkway Village Housing development in Queens had been notified in June that their leases would expire on Sept. 30.

THE ban on the importation of Canadian big game, resulting from the outbreak of hoof and mouth disease in Canada, will have no effect on American sportsmen who hunt in the Dominion primarily for trophies which, when properly cured, may be brought into this country.

AUTUMN is officially here. Established gardeners are showing off the final fruits of the year's labor at local shows, while inexperienced home owners are going back to school to learn the ABC's of growing plants to fix up their grounds.

AFTER Senator Richard N. Nixon's defense of his personal trust fund of $18,000 last Tuesday evening, there can be no further doubt about television's influence on the political scene. On all major counts his was a remarkable performance peculiar to the video age.

An optimistic picture of Portuguese overseas trade, particularly that with the United States, was presented here yesterday by Jose Bensaude, president of the Flomarcy Company, local agent for the Portuguese Line (Companhia de Navegacao Carregadores Acoreanos).

ABOARD NIXON CAMPAIGN PLANE, Sept. 2 -- Impressive turnouts at every stop as Senator Richard M. Nixon neared the end of a flying tour of the West and South evoked from the Californian today public predictions of major Republican inroads on traditionally Democratic territory in the November election.

NEXT Thursday night the New York City Opera gives the first of its novelties of the present season. These will be Bela Bartok's one-act "Bluebeard's Castle," which, conducted by Joseph Rosenstock, will then receive its first stage performance in America, with Ravel's "L'Heure Espagnole," presented for the first time by this company, as the second part of a double bill.

A JOURNEY is such an important event to a youngster that I am often puzzled as to why there are so few really good stories for children based on that motif. This is a good one. Writing with a gusto seldom found in the more pretentious travel stories, Ruth Simon describes one family's excursions into the mountains.

The regional director of the American Meteor Society, at Geneva, N. Y., recently announced that the organization will pay a dollar a pound for meteorites brought to it. And, in addition, there will be a five-dollar bonus for those found in New York State soil.

Victor Clemente, the contractor whose work touched off the Queens sewer investigations, was disclosed yesterday to have a long pending claim of $38,298 against the city for a Laurelton sewer project in 1949. The bid on that job had been only $35,367, and Mr. Clemente had been penalized $1,629 of that sum because of excessive water leakage into the pipes.

EACH year, more people must be considering the attractions of the Provencal festival circuit -- Aix - en - Provence and Menton, which can easily be taken in on the way to Italy. Munich or Salzburg, and are timed for late July and early August, so as not to overlap with the German celebrations.

ANYONE who thinks that stories for teen-agers must necessarily be confined to romance or sports would do well to investigate these two collections. With one exception, all the stories in "Nineteen From Seventeen," selected by Bryna Ivens from the magazine Seventeen are contemporary in setting and all of them deal with teen-agers, either directly or obliquely.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Truman today named Harold Shantz, a career diplomat, to be Minister to Rumania, a post that has been purposely left vacant for more than eighteen months.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Sept. 26 -- Allied military commanders at Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's supreme headquarters are now showing cautious satisfaction over the steady build-up in North Atlantic Treaty defenses throughout Western Europe.

SEIN, a ledge of rock and bitter soil off the coast of Brittany, is the setting of "Island Priest" -- which is really the story of an island that has no priest. The men of Sein are like their island, stubborn. All tenderness has been eroded from them.

SINCE Charles Dickens was a singularly uncomplicated young man in 1836, the characters in "The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club" are singularly uncomplicated people. Stanley Young has now brought some of them together in a jovial comedy, dubbed "Mr. Pickwick," which is mighty pleasant theatre.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 27 (UP) -- The University of California's rampaging backfield aces, ripping off touchdown runs of 66, 49 and 21 yards, smashed a stubborn Missouri defense today as they rolled to a 28-14 victory before 45,000 fans in Memorial Stadium.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Refrigerated warehouse space in the Chicago area is reaching its peak occupancy as frozen foods continue to pour from producers and the area's surplus products go into coolers. Chicago has about 40,000,000 cubic feet of space for refrigerated products.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -Pennsylvania and Notre Dame battled to a 7-to-7 tie in their season's opener today. A capacity crowd of almost 75,000 fans saw the contest, which provided a supply of thrills large enough to satisfy the most demanding partisan.

SINISTER in appearance, ferocious in battle, the praying mantis is about as appealing at first glimpse as a Gila monster, which may be just why it holds a peculiar fascination for most youngsters. According to Captain Leyson, this insect makes an interesting, if not precisely affectionate, pet.

RALPH STOLKIN, head of the syndicate which has obtained control of R. K. O. Radio Pictures by purchasing the stock block owned by Howard Hughes, is a stocky, dark-haired, deep-voiced young man who was born in Chicago thirty-five years ago last Sept. 3.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Ch. Giraldas Kriss, a 3-year-old bloodhound owned by the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, Madison, N. J., became best in show today in the fourteenth event of the Suffolk County Kennel Club.

IF you haven't read Edna Ferber's name on any new novel lately, it isn't (as you might have suspected) because she was relaxing on the royalties from "Show Boat," "Cimarron," "Saratoga Trunk" and other movie masterpieces made from her books.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- President Truman appealed tonight to the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., to call off strikes against the Douglas Aircraft Company and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in California "in the interest of national defense."
LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Blackpool took the lead in the first division of English soccer today with an 8-4 victory over Charlton.

THE American composer making the biggest noise in Europe at the moment is George Gershwin. Fifteen years after his death his memory is still verdant and his music continues to enjoy enormous popularity not only in his native land but in far-flung countries on several continents.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 27 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois announced today that he and his running mate, Senator John J. Sparkman, would make public their personal income tax returns for the last ten years and, in effect, challenged Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Richard M. Nixon, to follow suit.

It seems to me that the outcome of the McCarthy struggle in Wisconsin and the Nixon affair in the whole country should prove to most of the American people that these two men are liked and supported by a large number of us.

MANY people have the impression that a coldframe is an elaborate piece of equipment. It need be neither elaborate nor costly. A few odds and ends of lumber and almost any piece of sash for a cover are all that is needed in the way of material. Cheaper than buying a new sash is a frame covered with a transparent cellulose material.

IN the annals of oil production, Spindletop is one of the major landmarks, and this book tells the Spindletop story. The Spindletop field is at Beaumont. Tex. It was brought in with the first American gusher in 1901.

The Department of Health is planning an intensive crack-down on scavengers who gather spoiled fish discarded by dealers in the Fulton Fish Market and then peddle their ill-gotten goods to unsuspecting restaurants, stores and housewives.

MANY books have been written of the Western railroad expansion that followed the Civil War. It partook of all the characteristics of that high and wide, if scarcely handsome, epoch. Here are seen the savage force of the westward movement, the daring and drive of American engineering, the financial manipulations of "robber barons," and the venality of a subservient Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The disclosure today by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of the names of persons who contributed to his 1948 Gubernatorial campaign fund and the identities of eight state officials who received gifts to augment their state salaries, and his announcement that he would make public his income tax record for the last ten years startled political leaders and voters alike in this area.

I was delighted to read your critic's column on "Widowers Houses" at the Greenwich Mews Theatre. Both my husband and I are avid theatregoers and we enjoyed this production more than anything we've seen on or off Broadway in a good long time.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -The University of Pennsylvania's proposal to televise the PennNotre Dame football game today smashed up against the wall of controls erected by the National Collegiate Athletic Association around telecasts of college sports.

Tomorrow the five-day week for Wall Street becomes the standard, rather than a summertime exception. And tomorrow almost all security, cotton and grain exchanges throughout the United States and Canada will extend daily trading hours by thirty minutes.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 -- For all the grave talk by both Presidential candidates of foreign policy and war and peace as the capital question, it seems that this election may well turn on homely and shopworn issues almost as old as politics in the United States.

DUBLIN, Sept. 27 -- Sweden won the European contract bridge championship here tonight after an exciting last-minute finish with Italy, the previous winner. With one to go at the end of ninety-five boards in the final, Italy was leading by one international match point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Fear of higher prices in the near future appears universal among housewives of the nation, but there is a wide divergence of opinion among them as to how an upswing in living costs can be prevented, according to Tighe E. Woods, director of the Office of Price Stabilization.

In Agnes deMille's article, "The Revolution of Isadora" (Sept. 7), I was mentioned as having "disappeared into Russia.'' I would like to correct this statement because it is not true and also because of the sinister connotation a remark like that carries.

Four of the five Russians competing in the world chess championship tournament at Saltsjobaden in Sweden give promise of qualifying for places in the challengers' competition to be staged next year. According to a report from Stockholm, yesterday, when six adjourned games were played off, two of these Soviet representatives were among the winners.

MRS. LOTHROP has turned a compassionate eye on the plight of lonely women, those whose hold on their men is tenuous, for psychological or social reasons. All of her heroines have suffered the failure of at least one marriage.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 27 -- With a Presidential campaign under way and interest rates continuing to show a rising tendency, bankers gathering here for their annual convention which starts tomorrow appear to have adopted a "waiit and see" attitude.

M. Delannoy is the director of "Savage Triangle," the French drama known in France as "Le Garcon Sauvage," which was originally rejected by the New York censors and then approved by them. It is slated to open at the Paris tomorrow.

Pension problems that have been created by inflation are in some degree no less difficult for the managers of pension funds than they are for employers and employes. While not directly a part of retirement programs, except in a fiduciary capacity, trustees of the funds are concerned with the investment of the funds to benefit employer and employe participating in the programs.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The Soviet notes declared a "readiness" today to take part in a new Four-Power meeting on the stalemated Austrian treaty question, but hedged by asking whether the West was ready to withdraw its previous proposal for the abbreviated Austrian compact.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The four-time champion Yankees, with three of their regulars riding the sidelines, brought added misery to 10,212 Philadelphia fans tonight by defeating the Athletics, 3 to 0, as Ray Scarborough and Bob Kuzava blanked the Mackmen on five hits.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Stan Musial had one hit and Frankie Baumholtz went hitless in their battle for the National League batting crown tonight as Big Bob Rush scored his seventeenth victory for the Cubs, beating the Cardinals, 4 -- 1.

NAMES make news and, in the opinion of R. C. A. Victor, also sell phonograph records. Victor ought to know. For years it dominated the field in this country and carried more prestige than any other label.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 27 -- Mighty Michigan State, famous last season for rallying to victories, spotted Michigan a two-touchdown lead today and then stormed back for its sixteenth straight football triumph, 27 to 13, before a sellout crowd of 97,239 in Michigan Stadium.

Charles C. Green, managing director of the advertising Club of New York never has belonged to a chamber of commerce! This is also true of a lot of other people, but in his case it seems almost incongruous, because he is the personification of what a good chamber of commerce executive should be.

FOR its second week at the Metropolitan Opera House, Ballet Theatre has two novelties scheduled, both world premieres. One is Agnes de Mille's "The Harvest According" on Wednesday and the other is Edward Caton's "Triptych" on Thursday.

Adolf A. Berle Jr.'s "Our Capitalists -- Soviet View and the Reality" (Sept. 21) succeeded in blasting the Soviet myth of the bloated cigar-smoking billionaire American capitalist but failed in the effort to justify the distribution of wealth in the United States.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 28 -- The United Nations proposed to Communist representatives at Panmunjom today to conclude an armistice in Korea immediately, leaving until later the question of the return of prisoners of war who oppose repatriation.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 27 -- From noon to twilight today, speed boat daredevils had one of their season's gala events, shooting for new one-mile stragiht-away records as a curtain-raiser for tomorrow's inboard race meet on the Ohio River in front of the Magnolia Yacht Club.
A FAITHLESS Penelope and an unvengeful Odysseus are the protagonists in this exceedingly well-wrought and perceptive novel of life on Long Island.

THE first complete interpretive statement on how modern photojournalism works will be published on Wednesday in Wilson Hicks' "Words and Pictures, an Introduction to Photojournalism" (New York: Harper Brothers. $5).

A RUSSIAN-speaking theatre in the Stanislavsky tradition now exists in New York City. The new Russian Theatre, a professional company composed of Soviet DP's who have arrived in the United States within the last three years, opens its second season on Oct. 3 at the Master Institute Theatre with "Vasilisa Menletyeva," by the Russian nineteenth century playwright, Ostrovsky.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 28 -- The Soviet Union has rejected the latest Western bid for a Big Four Power meeting to draw up a treaty to restore independence to occupied Austria, the Moscow radio announced early today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner hit his thirty-seventh homer and tied Hank Sauer for the major league leadership today as the Pirates battled back from a five-run deficit to beat the Reds, 9 -- 6.

The American people have themselves primarily to blame for the conditions that led the Vice-Presidential candidate of one party and the Presidential candidate of the other to accept financial contributions from private individuals to be used for public purposes.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- George Santayana, famed poet and philosopher, died in his sleep last night of cancer of the stomach. His age was 88. He succumbed in the nursing home of the Little Company of Mary, an English order of Roman Catholic nuns, where he had resided for many years.

The Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe has adopted a report from its Economic Affairs Committee calling for a world-wide monetary conference to write a substitute for the Bretton Woods agreement. That agreement was based on the assumption that the world would soon return to normal.

One hundred Iroquois, whose ancestors put down their tomahawks centuries ago, picked up one of the white man's weapons yesterday and marched in single file down Fifth Avenue, half in pageantry and half in protest, wearing ceremonial regalia and carrying placards protesting treatment of the Indians.

The world-wide ocean transportation network of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, dubbed by its thousands of civilian and blue-jacketed sailors as the biggest and busiest shipping line in the world, will celebrate its third birthday this week.

THOMAS SCHERMAN and the Little Orchestra Society, who heretofore have confined their activities in Manhattan to Town Hall and Hunter College Auditorium, will make their first appearance at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 15 to offer a performance of Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ."

IT IS the pleasant function of this department to report this morning that the summer drought is just about over and that a dozen Broadway playhouses should be showing signs of renewed vitality before the coming month is over.

In 1902 the automobile was still a relatively strange vehicle, with only some 23,000 of them using the dirt tracks that passed for roads in those days. Today there are some 50,000,000 motor vehicles registered in the United States and the road system in the United States is one of the finest in the world.

There will be hundreds of tributes today throughout the whole of the civilized world to the contribution of a gentle philosopher who was born in Spain, lived at Harvard, in Oxford and in Rome, and was at home wherever there was sweet reason and high poetry.

BONN, Germany, Sept 27 -- Time is running out for the Russians in West Germany. They are a stubborn people and recently they have been unaccustomed to political failure. But even the most sanguine comrade must have been able to glimpse defeat in the fiasco that attended the reception here of five delegates from the East German People's Chamber.

OLD STURBRIDGE VILLAGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower urged in a letter read here today the development of "every psychological weapon" to rally men everywhere to the cause of freedom. He also called for support of "our friends behind the Iron Curtain."

The Metropolitan has just placed its new accession, Velasquez' nearly half-life-size equestrian portrait of Don Gaspar de Guzman, Count- Duke of Olivares, on view in the Great Hall (whose Cyclopean scale does not provide the most sympathetic of settings).

With this veristic novel of adolescent sexuality in the school cellar, Andre Brincourt adds one more title to the growing list of books which bear out Freud -- and, lately, Kinsey. But "The Paradise Below the Stairs" is more than a case history.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 27 Army's football legions opened their season on a spectacular note today as they swept to a 28-to-7 triumph over South Carolina. The quality of the victors' play proved a revelation to many who believed the Black Knights' rebuilding program was still in the incubation stage.

PITTSTOWN, N. J. -- People who like to investigate out-of-the-way historic spots in the course of a Sunday afternoon's driving can make a note of the annual fall pilgrimage to the old St. Thomas' Church on a country road about a mile from here.

FROM January to April, 1952, Bill Mauldin was in Korea. This book is a report in the form of letters written from Joe, temporarily a war correspondent, to Willie, his old cartoon sidekick. The device is an attractive one and at the same time allows the author to take "cover and concealment" (as they say in the infantry) behind two of the most likable characters ever devised.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS rescue the garden from the doldrums during September and October, when many annuals are looking shabby and most early perennials have finished bloom. From now until hard frost the chrysanthemum is the one perennial- that can give masses of color and dependable bloom.
